Chullin



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Everyone slaughters</b> an animal, i.e., can perform halakhically valid slaughter, <b>and their slaughter is valid, except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, lest they ruin their slaughter</b> because they lack competence. <b>And</b> for <b>all of them, when they slaughtered</b> an animal <b>and others see</b> and supervise <b>them, their slaughter is valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> There is an apparent contradiction between the first two phrases of the mishna. The <i>tanna</i> begins: <b>Everyone slaughters</b> an animal, indicating that their performing slaughter is permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>,</b> and then teaches: <b>And their slaughter is valid,</b> indicating that their slaughter is valid only <b>after the fact.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: And</b> does <b>every</b> use of the term: <b>Everyone,</b> indicate that the action in question is permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>? If that is so,</b> in the mishna (<i>Temura</i> 2a), where it says: <b>Everyone substitutes</b> a non-sacred animal for a sacrificial animal, <b>both men and women, is</b> that <b>also</b> an expression indicating <b>that</b> it is permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>? But isn’t it written: “He shall neither exchange it, nor substitute it, good for bad, or bad for good”</b> (Leviticus 27:10)?
Rav Ashi answers: <b>There, the reason</b> the mishna uses the word everyone is <b>that it</b> immediately <b>teaches:</b> That is <b>not</b> to say <b>that it is permitted for a person to substitute; rather,</b> it means <b>that if one did substitute</b> a non-sacred animal for a sacrificial animal, <b>substitution takes effect, and</b> the one who substituted the non-sacred animal <b>incurs [<i>vesofeg</i>] the forty</b> lashes that are the punishment for violating the prohibition “Nor substitute it.” But here, since the mishna does not similarly qualify its statement, it indicates that everyone may perform the slaughter <i>ab initio</i>.
Rav Aḥa challenges: <b>But</b> a mishna teaches (<i>Arakhin</i> 2a): <b>Everyone takes</b> vows of <b>valuation</b> and is thereby obligated to donate to the Temple treasury the value fixed by the Torah based on the age and gender of the person valuated; <b>and</b> everyone <b>is valuated,</b> and therefore one who vowed to donate his fixed value is obligated to pay; everyone <b>vows</b> to donate the market value of a person as a slave to the Temple treasury and is thereby obligated to pay; <b>and</b> everyone is the object of <b>a vow</b> if others vowed to donate his market value. Is that <b>also</b> an expression indicating <b>that</b> it is permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>? But it is written: “And if you shall cease to vow, there shall be no sin in you”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:23), indicating that it is preferable not to vow.
<b>And it is written: “It is better that you should not vow, than that you should vow and not pay”</b> (Ecclesiastes 5:4); <b>and it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to that verse: <b>Better than</b> both <b>this</b> one, who vows and does not pay, <b>and that</b> one, who vows and pays, is <b>one who does not take a vow at all;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: Better than</b> both <b>this</b> one, who vows and does not pay, <b>and that</b> one, who does not vow at all, is <b>one who vows and pays</b> in fulfillment of that vow. Rav Aḥa comments: <b>And even Rabbi Yehuda states</b> his opinion <b>only in</b> a case where one vows and <b>says: This</b> animal <b>is</b> designated for sacrifice, as in that case there is no concern that he will fail to fulfill his commitment, since even if the animal is stolen or lost, he is not required to bring another in its place.

Daf 2b

<b>But</b> in the case of one who vows and <b>says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring an offering, even Rabbi Yehuda concedes that <b>no,</b> it is best not to vow at all. Likewise, it is preferable not to vow to donate a certain monetary value to the Temple treasury. Apparently, then, the statements in that mishna: Everyone takes vows of valuation, and: Everyone vows to donate the assessment of a person to the Temple treasury, do not indicate that it is permitted to do so <i>ab initio</i>.
Rav Ashi responded: <b>And</b> is that to say that <b>every</b> use of the term: <b>Everyone,</b> is an indication that the action in question <b>is not</b> permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>? Rather,</b> is the term: Everyone, in the <i>baraita</i> that states: <b>Everyone is obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b><i>sukka</i>,</b> and in the <i>baraita</i> that states: <b>Everyone is obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>ritual fringes, also</b> an indication <b>that</b> they are <b>not</b> permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>?</b>
Rav Aḥa answered: <b>I am not speaking</b> about cases where it is stated: Everyone is <b>obligated,</b> as it goes without saying that fulfilling any obligation is permitted <i>ab initio</i>. Rav Ashi asked: <b>If that is so,</b> that which was stated: <b>Everyone</b> who brings an offering <b>places hands</b> on the animal, <b>both men and women</b> (see <i>Menaḥot</i> 93a), is that <b>also</b> an expression indicating <b>that</b> it is <b>not</b> permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>? But isn’t it written: “And he shall place his hand</b> upon the head of the burnt offering, <b>and it shall be accepted</b> for him to effect atonement for him” (Leviticus 1:4)?
Rav Aḥa answered: <b>Indeed, there are</b> instances where the word: <b>Everyone,</b> indicates <b><i>ab initio</i>, and there are</b> instances where the word: <b>Everyone,</b> indicates <b>after the fact. Rather,</b> concerning the term: <b>Everyone, that</b> appears <b>here</b> in the mishna, <b>from where</b> can it be determined <b>that it is</b> an expression indicating that it is permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>,</b> creating an apparent contradiction in the mishna <b>that will be difficult for you? Perhaps</b> it is an expression indicating that everyone’s slaughter is valid <b>after the fact, and</b> there will <b>not</b> be a contradiction in the mishna that <b>will be difficult for you.</b>
Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Rav Aḥa: <b>I</b> find the phrase: <b>And their slaughter is valid,</b> to be <b>difficult for me. From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches: And their slaughter is valid,</b> which is an expression indicating that it is valid <b>after the fact,</b> conclude <b>by inference that</b> the initial phrase in the mishna: <b>Everyone</b> slaughters, <b>is</b> an expression indicating that it is permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>. As, if</b> it indicated that it is valid <b>after the fact, why do I</b> need <b>two</b> phrases teaching that it is valid <b>after the fact?</b>
<b>Rabba bar Ulla said,</b> in resolution of the conflict in the mishna, that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is teaching: Everyone slaughters, and even a ritually impure</b> person may slaughter <b>a non-sacred</b> animal <i>ab initio</i>. The Gemara interjects: <b>What</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> that <b>a ritually impure</b> person may slaughter <b>a non-sacred</b> animal <i>ab initio</i>? There is no prohibition against rendering non-sacred meat impure. The Gemara answers that the reference is <b>to non-sacred</b> animals <b>that were</b> being <b>prepared according to</b> the strictures of <b>sacrificial</b> food, <b>and</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that the halakhic status of <b>non-sacred</b> foods <b>that were prepared according to</b> the strictures of <b>sacrificial</b> food is <b>like</b> that of <b>sacrificial</b> food insofar as it is prohibited to render such food impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>How does</b> an impure person <b>act</b> in order to ensure that he will not render the flesh of the slaughtered animal impure? The Gemara answers: <b>He brings a long knife and slaughters</b> the animal <b>with it, so that he will not come into contact with the flesh</b> of the slaughtered animal.
Rabba bar Ulla continues his interpretation of the mishna: <b>And</b> the reason the mishna also indicates that he may not slaughter <i>ab initio</i> is that <b>with regard to sacrificial</b> animals, <b>he may not slaughter</b> them <i>ab initio</i> even with a long knife, <b>lest he come into contact with the flesh. But if he slaughtered</b> the sacrificial animal <b>and says:</b> It is <b>clear to me that I did not come into contact</b> with the flesh, <b>his slaughter is valid</b> after the fact.
And it teaches: This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all people <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, who, even</b> if they slaughtered <b>only non-sacred</b> animals, their slaughter is <b>not</b> valid <b>even after the fact.</b> The reason the Sages deemed such slaughter not valid is <b>lest</b> people in these categories <b>interrupt</b> the slaughter, <b>lest they press</b> the knife in the course of slaughter, <b>and lest they conceal</b> the knife beneath the windpipe or the gullet in the course of an inverted slaughter.
The Gemara asks: If so, with regard to the clause that follows in the mishna: <b>And any of them who slaughtered</b> an animal and others see and supervise them, their slaughter is valid, <b>to which</b> case in the mishna is it referring? <b>If we say</b> that the reference is to the case <b>of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor,</b> why was it formulated: And any of them who slaughtered? Since <b>it stands adjacent</b> to that <i>halakha</i>, the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> formulated the phrase: <b>And if they slaughtered. Rather,</b> perhaps the reference is to the case <b>of a ritually impure</b> person who slaughtered <b>a non-sacred</b> animal. The Gemara rejects that possibility as well. <b>But didn’t you say</b> in that case: <b>He slaughters</b> the animal <b>even <i>ab initio</i>?</b>
<b>And rather,</b> perhaps the reference is to the case <b>of a ritually impure</b> person who slaughtered <b>a sacrificial</b> animal. The Gemara rejects that possibility, as <b>in</b> that case, if the ritually impure person says: It is <b>clear to me</b> that I did not come into contact with the flesh, it is <b>sufficient,</b> and there is no need for supervision. The Gemara answers: Supervision is necessary in the case of a ritually impure person who slaughtered a sacrificial animal, to account for a case <b>where</b> the ritually impure person <b>is not before us</b> so <b>that we</b> can <b>ask him</b> whether he came into contact with the flesh.
The Gemara asks: Is <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>a ritually impure</b> person who slaughtered <b>a sacrificial</b> animal <b>learned from</b> an analysis of the mishna <b>here?</b> It is <b>learned</b> explicitly <b>from</b> the mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 31b): With regard to <b>all</b> those <b>who are unfit</b> for Temple service <b>who slaughtered</b> an offering, <b>their slaughter is valid, as the slaughter</b> of an offering <b>is valid</b> <i>ab initio</i> when performed even <b>by non-priests, by women, by</b> Canaanite <b>slaves, and by ritually impure</b> individuals. <b>And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even with</b> regard to <b>offerings of the most sacred order, provided that the ritually impure will not touch the flesh</b> of the slaughtered animal, thereby rendering it impure.
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>here</b> is the <b>primary</b> source. <b>There, since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught the rest of</b> those <b>disqualified</b> for Temple service, <b>he taught</b> the case of <b>a ritually impure</b> person who slaughtered <b>a sacrificial</b> animal <b>as well. And if you wish, say</b> instead that the mishna <b>there</b> is the <b>primary</b> source, as it <b>is standing</b> in tractate <i>Zevaḥim</i>, <b>which</b> deals <b>with sacrificial</b> animals. <b>Here, since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> the case of <b>a ritually impure</b> person who slaughtered <b>a non-sacred</b> animal, <b>he also teaches</b> the case of <b>a ritually impure</b> person who slaughtered <b>a sacrificial</b> animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>This ritually impure</b> person mentioned in the mishna is one <b>who became impure with what</b> form of impurity? <b>If we say that he became impure with</b> impurity imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> this is difficult, as <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “And whosoever in the open field touches <b>one slain with a sword”</b> (Numbers 19:16).

Daf 3a

It is derived from the juxtaposition of “slain” to “sword” that the halakhic status of <b>a sword</b> or any other metal vessel that comes into contact with a corpse <b>is like</b> that of <b>a corpse</b> itself. Similarly, if a metal utensil comes in contact with a person impure with impurity imparted by a corpse, it assumes his status. Therefore, since the impure person <b>is a primary source of ritual impurity, let him render the knife impure,</b> rendering it as well a primary source of impurity, <b>and the knife</b> then <b>goes and renders the flesh impure.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the person <b>became impure with</b> impurity imparted by <b>a creeping animal;</b> as he assumes first-degree ritual impurity status and does not render vessels impure, the knife remains ritually pure. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that actually he became impure with</b> impurity imparted by <b>a corpse, and</b> it is a case <b>where one examined the stalk of a reed,</b> which is a flat wooden vessel that does not become ritually impure, to ensure that it is perfectly smooth with no nicks, <b>and slaughtered with it, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may slaughter</b> an animal <b>with any</b> sharp object, <b>whether with a flint, or with glass</b> shards, <b>or with the stalk of a reed.</b>
§ <b>Abaye said</b> in resolution of the apparent contradiction in the mishna <b>that this</b> is what the mishna <b>is teaching: Everyone slaughters, and even a Samaritan. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where a Jew is standing over him</b> and ensuring that he slaughters properly; <b>but</b> if the Jew merely <b>exits and enters</b> and does not have a constant presence, the Samaritan <b>may not slaughter</b> the animal.
<b>And if</b> the Samaritan <b>slaughtered</b> the animal without supervision, the Jew <b>cuts an olive-bulk of meat</b> from the slaughtered animal <b>and gives it to</b> the Samaritan to eat. If the Samaritan <b>ate it,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for the Jew <b>to eat</b> meat <b>from</b> what the Samaritan <b>slaughtered.</b> Since Samaritans are meticulous with regard to the meat that they eat and eat meat only from an animal that was slaughtered properly, the Jew may partake of the meat. But if the Samaritan <b>did not eat</b> the meat, there is concern that the animal was not slaughtered properly, and it is <b>prohibited to eat from</b> what the Samaritan <b>slaughtered.</b>
And it teaches: This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all people <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, who,</b> even if they slaughtered only non-sacred animals, their slaughter is <b>not</b> valid <b>even after the fact.</b> The reason the Sages deemed such slaughter not valid is <b>lest</b> people in these categories <b>interrupt</b> the slaughter, <b>lest they press</b> the knife in the course of slaughter, <b>and lest they conceal</b> the knife beneath the windpipe or the gullet in the course of an inverted slaughter.
The Gemara asks: If so, with regard to the clause in the mishna that follows: <b>And any of them who slaughtered</b> an animal and others see and supervise them, their slaughter is valid, <b>to which</b> case in the mishna is it referring? <b>If we say</b> that the reference is to the case <b>of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor,</b> since that is the <i>halakha</i> to which <b>it stands adjacent,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> formulated the phrase: <b>And if they slaughtered,</b> instead of: And any of them who slaughtered.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps the reference is to the case <b>of a Samaritan</b> who slaughters. The Gemara rejects that possibility. <b>But didn’t you say</b> in that case: <b>When a Jew is standing over him,</b> a Samaritan may <b>slaughter even <i>ab initio</i>?</b> The Gemara concedes that the formulation of the mishna: And any of them who slaughtered, is <b>difficult</b> according to this explanation of the mishna.
<b>Rava said: And</b> in a case where a Jew <b>exits and enters,</b> is it <b>not</b> permitted for the Samaritan to slaughter the animal <b><i>ab initio</i>? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Avoda Zara</i> 69a): In the case of <b>one who leaves a gentile in his store</b> in which there is wine, <b>and a Jew exits and enters,</b> the wine is <b>permitted?</b> Just as there, the sporadic presence of the Jew is sufficient to ensure that the gentile will refrain from touching the wine, it should be sufficient in the case of a Samaritan who slaughters an animal as well. The Gemara rejects that proof. <b>There,</b> in the case of the store, <b>does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach: One leaves</b> a gentile <i>ab initio</i>? The <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches: One who leaves, after the fact.</b> Consequently, there is no proof from there that the Jew’s sporadic presence is sufficient to permit slaughter by a Samaritan <i>ab initio</i>.
<b>Rather,</b> proof can be cited <b>from</b> the mishna <b>here</b> (<i>Avoda Zara</i> 61a): In a case where barrels of wine belonging to a Jew are in the possession of a gentile, and a Jew was tasked with supervising those barrels, <b>the supervisor need not be</b> continuously <b>sitting and supervising</b> to ensure that the gentile does not touch the wine; <b>rather, even if</b> the supervisor <b>exits and enters,</b> the wine is <b>permitted.</b> This mishna clearly indicates that exiting and entering is sufficient even <i>ab initio</i>.
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> in resolution of the apparent contradiction similar to the resolution proposed by Abaye, that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is teaching: Everyone slaughters, and even a Samaritan. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where a Jew exits and enters; but</b> if the Jew does not exit and enter and instead <b>came and found that</b> the Samaritan <b>slaughtered</b> the animal, the Jew <b>cuts an olive-bulk of meat</b> from the slaughtered animal <b>and gives it to</b> the Samaritan to eat. If the Samaritan <b>ate it,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for the Jew <b>to eat</b> meat <b>from</b> what the Samaritan <b>slaughtered.</b> But if the Samaritan <b>did not eat</b> the meat, it is <b>prohibited to eat from</b> what the Samaritan <b>slaughtered.</b>
And it teaches: This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all people <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, whose</b> slaughter is <b>not</b> valid <b>even after the fact.</b> The reason the Sages deemed such slaughter not valid is <b>lest</b> people in these categories <b>interrupt</b> the slaughter, <b>lest they press</b> the knife in the course of slaughter, <b>and lest they conceal</b> the knife beneath the windpipe or the gullet in the course of an inverted slaughter. The Gemara asks: If so, with regard to the clause in the mishna that follows: <b>And any of them who slaughtered</b> an animal and others see and supervise them, their slaughter is valid, <b>to which</b> case in the mishna is this referring? <b>If we say</b> that the reference is to the case <b>of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor,</b> since that is the <i>halakha</i> to which <b>it stands adjacent,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> formulated the phrase: <b>And if they slaughtered,</b> instead of: And any of them who slaughtered.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps the reference is to the case <b>of a Samaritan</b> who slaughters. The Gemara rejects that possibility. <b>But didn’t you say</b> that if a Jew is present, then <b>even</b> if he <b>exits and enters</b> and does not have a constant presence, a Samaritan may <b>slaughter even <i>ab initio</i>?</b> The Gemara concedes that the formulation of the mishna: And any of them who slaughtered, is <b>difficult</b> according to this explanation of the mishna.
§ <b>Rav Ashi said</b> in resolution of the apparent contradiction in the mishna that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is teaching: Everyone slaughters, and even a Jewish transgressor [<i>meshummad</i>].</b> The Gemara asks: <b>A transgressor of what</b> sort? The Gemara answers: It is one whose transgression is <b>to eat</b> unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses to</b> satisfy his <b>appetite,</b> i.e., for his convenience. <b>And</b> the ruling of the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rava, as Rava says:</b> In the case of <b>a Jewish transgressor</b> whose transgression is that he <b>eats</b> unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses to</b> satisfy his <b>appetite,</b> if he seeks to slaughter an animal,

Daf 3b

<b>one examines a knife</b> to ensure that it is perfectly smooth with no nicks <b>and gives it to</b> the transgressor, <b>and</b> it is <b>permitted to eat from</b> what <b>he slaughtered. But if one did not examine</b> the knife <b>and give it to</b> the transgressor, the transgressor <b>may not slaughter</b> an animal <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And if</b> the transgressor <b>slaughtered</b> an animal, <b>one examines his knife after his</b> slaughter. If <b>his knife is found</b> to be <b>perfectly</b> smooth, it is <b>permitted to eat</b> meat <b>from</b> what <b>he slaughtered, and if not,</b> it is <b>prohibited to eat from</b> what <b>he slaughtered.</b>
And it teaches: This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all people <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, whose</b> slaughter is <b>not</b> valid <b>even after the fact.</b> The reason the Sages deemed such slaughter not valid is <b>lest</b> people in these categories <b>interrupt</b> the slaughter, <b>lest they press</b> the knife in the course of slaughter, <b>and lest they conceal</b> the knife beneath the windpipe or the gullet in the course of an inverted slaughter. The Gemara asks: If so, with regard to the clause in the mishna that follows: <b>And any of them who slaughtered</b> an animal and others see and supervise them, their slaughter is valid, <b>to which</b> case in the mishna is it referring? <b>If we say</b> that the reference is to the case <b>of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor,</b> since that is the <i>halakha</i> to which <b>it stands adjacent,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> formulated the phrase: <b>And if they slaughtered,</b> instead of: And any of them who slaughtered.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps the reference is to the case <b>of a Jewish transgressor</b> who slaughters. The Gemara asks: In what case? <b>If</b> it is a case <b>where one examined a knife and gave it to</b> the transgressor, <b>didn’t you say</b> in that case that the transgressor <b>may slaughter <i>ab initio</i>? Rather,</b> perhaps the reference is to a case <b>where one did not examine</b> the knife. <b>If</b> it is a case <b>where the knife is</b> available, <b>let him examine</b> the knife <b>now</b> to make sure that there are no nicks. <b>And if</b> it is a case <b>where the knife is not</b> available, then <b>when others see him</b> slaughter, <b>what of it?</b> How can one eat from what he slaughtered? <b>Perhaps he slaughtered the animal with a notched knife.</b> The Gemara concedes that the formulation of the mishna: And any of them who slaughtered, is <b>difficult</b> according to this explanation of the mishna.
§ <b>Ravina said</b> in resolution of the apparent contradiction in the mishna <b>that this</b> is what the mishna <b>is teaching: Everyone slaughters,</b> i.e., <b>everyone</b> who is <b>an expert</b> in the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual slaughter <b>slaughters;</b> all <b>experts</b> are qualified to slaughter, <b>and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even if they are not established</b> as accustomed to slaughter with a steady hand and without fainting.
<b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where</b> people <b>know about him that he knows</b> and is able <b>to recite the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual slaughter. But if</b> people <b>do not know about him that he knows</b> and is able <b>to recite the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual slaughter, he may not slaughter</b> an animal <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And if he slaughtered</b> an animal, <b>one examines him; if he knows</b> and is able <b>to recite the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual slaughter</b> it is <b>permitted to eat</b> meat <b>from</b> what <b>he slaughtered, and if not,</b> it is <b>prohibited to eat from</b> what <b>he slaughtered.</b>
And it teaches: This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all people <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, whose</b> slaughter is <b>not</b> valid <b>even after the fact.</b> The reason the Sages deemed such slaughter not valid is <b>lest</b> people in these categories <b>interrupt</b> the slaughter, <b>lest they press</b> the knife in the course of slaughter, <b>and lest they conceal</b> the knife beneath the windpipe or the gullet in the course of an inverted slaughter. The Gemara asks: If so, with regard to the clause in the mishna that follows: <b>And any of them who slaughtered</b> an animal and others see and supervise them, their slaughter is valid, <b>to which</b> case in the mishna is this referring? <b>If we say</b> that the reference is to the case <b>of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor,</b> since that is the <i>halakha</i> to which <b>it stands adjacent,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> formulated the phrase: <b>And if they slaughtered,</b> instead of: And any of them who slaughtered.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps the reference is <b>to</b> a case <b>where they are not experts.</b> The Gemara rejects the possibility that they are not experts, as in that case, if <b>one examines him</b> after the slaughter to determine his expertise in the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual slaughter, it is <b>sufficient.</b> The Gemara answers: Supervision is necessary in the case where the one who slaughtered the animal <b>is not before us</b> so <b>that we</b> can <b>examine him.</b>
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Ravina said</b> that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is teaching: Everyone slaughters,</b> i.e., <b>everyone</b> who is <b>established</b> as accustomed to slaughter with a steady hand and without fainting <b>slaughters;</b> all those <b>established</b> concerning this are qualified to slaughter, <b>even</b> if it is <b>not</b> known if <b>they are experts. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where they slaughtered before us two or three times and did not faint. But if he did not slaughter before us two or three times he may not slaughter</b> an animal <i>ab initio</i>, <b>lest he faint. And if he slaughtered</b> an animal <b>and said: It is clear to me that I did not faint, his slaughter is valid.</b>
And it teaches: This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all people <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, whose</b> slaughter is <b>not valid even after the fact.</b> The reason the Sages deemed such slaughter not valid is <b>lest</b> people in these categories <b>interrupt</b> the slaughter, <b>lest they press</b> the knife in the course of slaughter, <b>and lest they conceal</b> the knife beneath the windpipe or the gullet in the course of an inverted slaughter. The Gemara asks: If so, with regard to the clause in the mishna that follows: <b>And any of them who slaughtered</b> an animal and others see and supervise them, their slaughter is valid, <b>to which</b> case in the mishna is this referring? <b>If we say</b> that the reference is to the case <b>of a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor,</b> since that is the <i>halakha</i> to which <b>it stands adjacent,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> formulated the phrase: <b>And if they slaughtered,</b> instead of: And any of them who slaughtered.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps the reference is <b>to</b> a case <b>where they are not established</b> as accustomed to slaughter with a steady hand and without fainting. The Gemara rejects that possibility, as in that case, <b>didn’t you say</b> that if one said after the slaughter: <b>It is clear to me</b> that I did not faint, it is <b>sufficient?</b> The Gemara answers: Supervision is necessary in the case <b>where</b> the one who slaughtered the animal <b>is not before us</b> so <b>that we</b> can <b>ask him</b> whether he fainted.
The Gemara summarizes: <b>Ravina and Rabba bar Ulla did not say</b> a resolution to the apparent contradiction in the mishna <b>like</b> that of <b>Abaye, Rava, and Rav Ashi due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the phrase in the mishna: <b>And any of them who slaughtered,</b> is <b>difficult for them.</b>
<b>All of</b> the other <i>amora’im</i> <b>did not say</b> a resolution to the apparent contradiction in the mishna <b>like</b> that of <b>Rabba bar Ulla,</b> who interprets the mishna as referring to the case of a ritually impure person; <b>according to that version that you said:</b> The mishna <b>here</b> is the <b>primary</b> source for the <i>halakha</i> of a ritually impure person who slaughtered a sacrificial animal, the other <i>amora’im</i> reject this interpretation because, <b>on the contrary,</b> the mishna <b>there</b> is the <b>primary</b> source, <b>as it is standing in</b> tractate <i>Zevaḥim</i>, which deals with <b>sacrificial</b> animals.
The <i>amora’im</i> also reject the interpretation <b>according to that</b> other <b>version that you said:</b> The mishna <b>there</b> is the <b>primary</b> source, <b>and here, since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> the case of <b>a ritually impure</b> person who slaughtered <b>non-sacred</b> animals, <b>he teaches</b> the case of <b>a ritually impure</b> person who slaughtered <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>as well.</b> The reason is that it <b>was not necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to teach the case <b>itself</b> of <b>a ritually impure</b> person who slaughtered <b>a non-sacred</b> animal, as in the opinion of the other <i>amora’im</i>, the halakhic status of <b>non-sacred</b> foods <b>that were prepared according to</b> the strictures of <b>sacrificial</b> food is <b>not like</b> that of <b>sacrificial</b> food, and it is permitted to render such food impure.
<b>All of</b> the other <i>amora’im</i> <b>did not say</b> a resolution to the apparent contradiction in the mishna <b>like</b> that of <b>Ravina; according to that version that he said: Experts, yes,</b> may slaughter <i>ab initio</i>, but those <b>that</b> it is <b>not</b> known that they are <b>experts, no,</b> they may not slaughter <i>ab initio</i>, the other <i>amora’im</i> disagree because they hold that <b>the majority</b> of those <b>associated with slaughter are experts.</b> Therefore, even if it is not known whether they are experts, their slaughter is valid.
<b>According to that version that</b> Ravina <b>said:</b> People who are <b>established</b> as accustomed to slaughter without fainting, <b>yes,</b> they may slaughter <i>ab initio</i>, but people who are <b>not established</b> as accustomed to slaughter without fainting, <b>no,</b> they may not slaughter <i>ab initio</i>, the other <i>amora’im</i> disagree because they hold that <b>we are not concerned for</b> the possibility of <b>fainting.</b>
<b>Rava did not say</b> a resolution <b>like</b> that of <b>Abaye,</b> that the mishna is referring to a Samaritan, <b>in accordance with</b> the <b>difficulty</b> that <b>he</b> raised from the <i>halakha</i> of wine belonging to a Jew to which a gentile has access. <b>Abaye did not say</b> a resolution <b>like</b> that of <b>Rava,</b> that a Samaritan may slaughter <i>ab initio</i> if a Jew enters and exits, because <b>there,</b> in the case of wine, the gentile <b>does not touch</b> the wine; therefore, it is sufficient if the Jew enters and exits. <b>Here,</b> in the case of slaughter, the Samaritan <b>touches</b> the animal in the course of slaughter, and he can disqualify the slaughter in an instant. Therefore, Abaye holds that it is insufficient for a Jew to enter and exit.
<b>Rav Ashi did not say</b> a resolution <b>like</b> that of <b>both of them,</b> Abaye and Rava, because <b>he holds: Samaritans are converts</b> who converted under duress due to the threat posed by <b>lions,</b> and their conversion is void; therefore, their halakhic status is that of a gentile, whose slaughter is not valid.
<b>Abaye did not say</b> a resolution <b>like</b> that of <b>Rav Ashi,</b> who interprets the mishna as referring to a Jewish transgressor whose transgression is that he eats unslaughtered animal carcasses to satisfy his appetite, because <b>he does not hold that which Rava</b> said, that such a transgressor may slaughter <i>ab initio</i> if his knife is examined beforehand by someone reliable. <b>But</b> as for <b>Rava, what is the reason</b> that <b>he did not say</b> a resolution <b>in accordance with his</b> own statement of <b><i>halakha</i></b> with regard to the slaughter of a transgressor and explain the mishna in the manner that Rav Ashi did?
The Gemara answers: When Rava explained that the <i>tanna</i> in the mishna is referring to the slaughter of a Samaritan, <b>he stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with the statement of Abaye</b> in order to resolve the difficulty that Abaye raised; <b>but he himself does not hold accordingly.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The slaughter</b> performed by <b>a Samaritan is permitted</b> <i>ab initio</i>. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where</b> there is <b>a Jew standing over him</b> and supervising to ensure that the slaughter was performed properly. <b>But</b> if the Jew <b>came and found that</b> the Samaritan already <b>slaughtered</b> the animal, the Jew <b>cuts an olive-bulk</b> of meat from the slaughtered animal <b>and gives it to</b> the Samaritan to eat. If the Samaritan <b>ate it,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for the Jew <b>to eat</b> meat <b>from</b> what the Samaritan <b>slaughtered. But if</b> the Samaritan <b>did not</b> eat the meat, it is <b>prohibited to eat from</b> what the Samaritan <b>slaughtered.</b>
<b>Similarly,</b> if the Jew <b>found in the possession of</b> a Samaritan

Daf 4a

<b>a string [<i>dekurya</i>] of birds,</b> and the Jew does not know whether they were properly slaughtered, <b>he severs the head of one of them and gives it to</b> the Samaritan to eat. If the Samaritan <b>ate it,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for the Jew <b>to eat</b> the meat <b>from</b> what the Samaritan <b>slaughtered. But if</b> the Samaritan did <b>not</b> eat the meat, it is <b>prohibited to eat from</b> what the Samaritan <b>slaughtered.</b>
In arriving at their respective interpretations of the mishna, <b>Abaye inferred from the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> and <b>Rava inferred from the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Abaye inferred from the first clause:</b> The slaughter performed by a Samaritan is permitted in a case where there is a Jew actively supervising to ensure that the slaughter was performed properly, that <b>the reason</b> it is permitted is <b>that the Jew is standing over him. But</b> if the Jew <b>exits and enters,</b> then <b>no,</b> it is prohibited to eat from what the Samaritan slaughtered.
<b>Rava inferred from the latter clause:</b> If the Jew came and found that the Samaritan already slaughtered the animal, the Jew cuts an olive-bulk of meat from the slaughtered animal and gives it to the Samaritan to eat. <b>The reason</b> that it is necessary to administer this test is due only to the fact <b>that</b> the Jew <b>came and found that</b> the Samaritan already <b>slaughtered</b> the animal. <b>But</b> in a case where the Jew <b>exits and enters,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> to eat from what the Samaritan slaughtered <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>And according to Abaye, the latter clause</b> is <b>difficult.</b> The Gemara answers that Abaye could have <b>said to you:</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>also characterizes</b> the case where a Jew <b>exits and enters</b> as a case of: If the Jew <b>came and found</b> the Samaritan. The Gemara raises an objection: <b>And according to Rava, the first clause</b> is <b>difficult.</b> The Gemara answers that Rava could have <b>said to you:</b> The case where a Jew <b>exits and enters</b> is <b>also</b> considered <b>like</b> a case where the Jew <b>is standing over him,</b> and it is included in that <i>halakha</i>.
§ The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Similarly,</b> if the Jew <b>found a string of birds in the possession of</b> a Samaritan, and the Jew does not know whether they were properly slaughtered, <b>he severs the head of</b> one of them and gives it to the Samaritan to eat. If the Samaritan ate it, it is permitted for the Jew to eat from what the Samaritan slaughtered. But if the Samaritan did not eat the meat, it is prohibited to eat from what the Samaritan slaughtered. The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> is that a reliable indication? <b>Let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> it <b>is this</b> bird alone, whose head the Jew severed, <b>that</b> the Samaritan <b>slaughtered properly,</b> and the rest are unslaughtered carcasses.
<b>Rav Menashe said</b> an answer to this question. Before presenting his answer, the Gemara cites <b>a mnemonic</b> for the three statements of Rav Menashe cited in this tractate, this one and two others: <b>Inserts, a scalpel</b> (see 31a), <b>into rams</b> (see 51a). Rav Menashe’s answer is as follows: The case in the <i>baraita</i> is one <b>where</b> the Jew <b>inserts</b> the string of birds <b>under the corners of his garment</b> and hands the Samaritan the head of one of the birds. In that way, the Samaritan has no way of knowing from which bird the head was taken. If he ate it, apparently all the birds were slaughtered properly.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And perhaps</b> the Samaritan <b>placed a distinguishing mark in</b> that bird, indicating to him that it is the kosher one. <b>Rav Mesharshiyya said:</b> The case in the <i>baraita</i> is one <b>where</b> the Jew <b>crushed</b> the head that he gave the Samaritan, thereby rendering it indistinguishable from the others.
The Gemara challenges this answer: <b>And perhaps the Samaritans hold there is no</b> source for the <b>slaughter of a bird in the Torah.</b> Therefore, the fact that the Samaritan ate the bird’s head is no proof that the bird was properly slaughtered.
The Gemara rejects that possibility: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> those actions that disqualify the slaughter of an animal: <b>Interrupting</b> the slaughter, <b>pressing</b> the knife, <b>concealing</b> the knife in the course of an inverted slaughter, <b>diverting [<i>hagrama</i>]</b> the knife from the place of slaughter, <b>and ripping</b> the <i>simanim</i> from their place before cutting them, <b>are they written</b> in the Torah?
<b>Rather,</b> even though the details are not all written in the Torah, <b>once</b> the Samaritans <b>embraced</b> those disqualifications, <b>they embraced them,</b> and a Jew may rely on their slaughter; when they eat from the meat, it is permitted for a Jew to eat the meat as well. <b>Here too,</b> although the requirement of ritual slaughter for a bird is not written in the Torah, <b>once</b> the Samaritans <b>embraced</b> the mitzva of ritual slaughter, <b>they embraced</b> it in the same manner that it is performed by Jews.
<b>And with regard to</b> mitzvot <b>that are not written</b> explicitly in the Torah that Samaritans embraced, the question of whether they are <b>presumed</b> to fulfill them in the manner that Jews fulfill them <b>or</b> they are <b>not presumed</b> to do so <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is <b>permitted</b> to eat <b>the <i>matza</i> of a Samaritan</b> on Passover, <b>and a person fulfills his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on</b> the first night of <b>Passover with it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar prohibits</b> the consumption of the <i>matza</i> of a Samaritan on Passover, <b>because</b> the Samaritans <b>are not experts in the details of mitzvot like Jews</b> and do not know the precise nature of leaven prohibited by the Torah.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> On the contrary, with regard to <b>any mitzva that the Samaritans embraced</b> and accepted upon themselves, <b>they are more exacting in its</b> observance <b>than</b> are <b>Jews.</b> Therefore, one may assume that they prepared the <i>matza</i> properly.
The Gemara proceeds to analyze that <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said:</b> It is <b>permitted</b> to eat <b>the <i>matza</i> of a Samaritan</b> on Passover, <b>and a person fulfills his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on</b> the first night of <b>Passover with it.</b> The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that if the <i>matza</i> is permitted one fulfills his obligation with it on Passover? The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that Samaritans <b>are not expert in</b> the mitzva of <b>guarding</b> the <i>matza</i> for the sake of the mitzva, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that they are expert. <b>Rabbi Elazar deems it prohibited</b> to eat the <i>matza</i> of Samaritans on Passover, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the Samaritans <b>are not experts in the details of mitzvot. He holds</b> that Samaritans <b>are not expert in</b> the mitzva of <b>guarding</b> the <i>matza</i> for the sake of the mitzva.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> With regard to <b>any mitzva that Samaritans embraced</b> and accepted upon themselves, <b>they are</b> more <b>exacting in its</b> observance <b>than</b> are <b>Jews.</b> The Gemara raises an objection: <b>That is</b> identical to the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between</b> their opinions with regard to a mitzva <b>that is written but</b> with regard to which the Samaritans <b>did not embrace it. The first <i>tanna</i> holds: Once</b> the mitzva <b>is written</b> in the Torah, <b>even if</b> there is <b>no</b> knowledge <b>that they embraced it,</b> Samaritans can be relied upon to perform it properly. <b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds:</b> Even with regard to a mitzva written in the Torah, <b>if they embraced</b> its observance, <b>yes,</b> one may rely on the Samaritans, but <b>if they did not embrace</b> its observance, <b>no,</b> one may not rely on them.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If</b> it is <b>so</b> that this is the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, the formulation of his statement is imprecise. He said: With regard to <b>any mitzva that Samaritans embraced</b> and accepted upon themselves, they are more exacting in its observance than are Jews; this indicates that one may rely upon Samaritans to observe those mitzvot even if they are not written in the Torah. Therefore, <b>he should have</b> said: <b>If they embraced,</b> which addresses the statement of the first <i>tanna</i>. Contrary to the first <i>tanna</i>, who said that one may rely upon Samaritans with regard to any mitzva that is written, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says that one may rely upon them only if they embraced the mitzva.
<b>Rather, there is</b> a practical difference <b>between</b> their opinions with regard to a mitzva <b>that is not written and</b> with regard to which the Samaritans <b>embraced its</b> observance. <b>The first <i>tanna</i> holds: Since it is not written, even though they embraced its</b> observance one may <b>also not</b> rely upon them. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds: Once</b> it is known <b>that they embraced</b> observance of a mitzva, <b>they embraced</b> the mitzva and one may rely upon them.
§ With regard to the statement of Rava cited earlier (3a), the Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rava says:</b> In the case of <b>a Jewish transgressor</b> whose transgression is that he <b>eats</b> unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses to</b> satisfy his <b>appetite,</b> if he seeks to slaughter an animal, <b>one examines a knife</b> to ensure that it is perfectly smooth with no nicks <b>and gives</b> it <b>to</b> the transgressor, <b>and it is permitted to eat from</b> what <b>he slaughtered.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason? Since</b> in this case <b>there is</b> the option to slaughter the animal in <b>a permitted</b> manner <b>or</b> to slaughter the animal in <b>a prohibited</b> manner, such a transgressor <b>would not</b> intentionally <b>forsake the permitted</b> manner <b>and eat</b> food slaughtered in a <b>prohibited</b> manner. Since he has a knife that was examined and the majority of those associated with slaughter are experts, the food is presumed to be permitted, and there is no concern that perhaps he intentionally sabotaged the slaughter.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> then <b>even</b> in a case <b>where</b> the Jew <b>did not examine</b> the knife, it should be permitted to eat from the animal slaughtered by the transgressor. The Gemara answers: It is prohibited because if the transgressor discovers that the knife is flawed, <b>he does not exert</b> himself to replace it with a knife with a smooth blade.
<b>The Sages said to Rava:</b> A <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught that supports your</b> opinion: With regard to <b>the leavened bread of transgressors,</b> who do not eradicate their leavened bread before Passover, <b>after Passover</b>

Daf 4b

it is <b>permitted immediately, due to</b> the fact <b>that they exchange</b> the forbidden leavened bread in their possession with permitted leavened bread belonging to gentiles immediately after Passover.
The Sages who cited this proof <b>assumed</b> that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion? They assumed it <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says: Leavened bread</b> that was not eradicated before Passover is forbidden <b>after Passover by Torah law.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> nevertheless <b>it is taught</b> that it is permitted <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the transgressors <b>exchange</b> their leavened bread with that of gentiles. <b>Apparently,</b> even one who performs transgressions <b>does not</b> intentionally <b>forsake the permitted and eat forbidden</b> food, where the permitted food is easily accessible.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> in the <i>baraita</i> can this be proven? <b>Perhaps</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says: Leavened bread</b> that was not eradicated before Passover is prohibited <b>after Passover by rabbinic law. And</b> accordingly, <b>when we are lenient it is with regard to</b> prohibitions <b>by rabbinic law,</b> whereas <b>with regard to</b> prohibitions <b>by Torah law,</b> e.g., the prohibition of an unslaughtered carcass, <b>we are not lenient.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>And let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>be even</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. Does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach: As I say</b> that <b>they exchanged</b> their leavened bread for the leavened bread of a gentile, which would indicate that it is an assumption? <b>He teaches: Due to</b> the fact <b>that they exchange,</b> as a statement of fact, <b>as they certainly exchange. And if in</b> cases involving prohibitions <b>by rabbinic law</b> the transgressor <b>does not</b> intentionally <b>forsake the permitted and eat forbidden</b> food, then <b>in</b> prohibitions <b>by Torah law</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> reasonable that he would not forsake the permitted in favor of the forbidden?
<b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the opinion of Rava: <b>Everyone slaughters, and even a Samaritan, and even an uncircumcised</b> man, <b>and even a Jewish transgressor.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>This uncircumcised</b> man, <b>what are the circumstances? If we say</b> that he is an uncircumcised man <b>whose brothers died due to circumcision</b> and the concern is that he might suffer a similar fate, clearly he may slaughter, as <b>he is a full-fledged Jew</b> and not a transgressor at all. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that he is <b>a transgressor with regard to</b> remaining <b>uncircumcised,</b> as he refuses to be circumcised, <b>and</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that he may nevertheless slaughter an animal since <b>a transgressor concerning one matter is not a transgressor concerning the entire Torah.</b>
<b>Say the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And even a Jewish transgressor. This transgressor, what are the circumstances? If he is a transgressor concerning another matter</b> besides eating unslaughtered animal carcasses, <b>that is</b> identical to the case of <b>a transgressor with regard to</b> remaining <b>uncircumcised. Rather, is it not</b> that he is <b>a transgressor concerning the same matter</b> of eating unslaughtered carcasses, <b>and</b> the <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava,</b> who said that one may even rely on the slaughter of a Jewish transgressor whose transgression is that he eats unslaughtered animal carcasses to satisfy his appetite, <i>ab initio</i>?
The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>No, actually I will say to you:</b> The slaughter of <b>a transgressor concerning the same matter</b> is <b>not</b> valid. <b>What is the reason?</b> It is that <b>since he has become accustomed to</b> performance of that transgression, it is <b>like a permitted</b> act <b>for him,</b> and the concern is that he is not at all careful to slaughter the animal properly. <b>Rather,</b> the transgressor mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> is <b>a transgressor with regard to idol worship, and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Anan, as Rav Anan says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>a Jew</b> who is <b>a transgressor with regard to idol worship, it is permitted to eat from</b> what <b>he slaughters.</b>
§ The Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav Anan says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>a Jew</b> who is <b>a transgressor with regard to idol worship, it is permitted to eat from</b> what <b>he slaughters, as we found with regard to Jehoshaphat, king of Judea, who partook of the feast</b> prepared by <b>Ahab,</b> king of Israel, who was a transgressor with regard to idol worship, <b>as it is stated: “And Ahab slaughtered sheep and cattle for him in abundance, and for the people that were with him, and incited him to go up with him to Ramoth Gilead”</b> (II Chronicles 18:2).
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>And perhaps</b> Ahab <b>slaughtered</b> the animals, but Jehoshaphat <b>did not eat</b> the meat of those animals. The Gemara explains: <b>It is written: “And incited him,”</b> indicating that there was an element of persuasion that presumably involved food. The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>And perhaps</b> Ahab incited him <b>with</b> his <b>words.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There is no incitement with words.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is there <b>not</b> incitement with words? <b>But isn’t it written: “If your brother…entices you</b> secretly, saying: Let us go and serve other gods” (Deuteronomy 13:7)? The Gemara answers: There too the incitement is <b>with eating and with drinking.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written</b> that God said to Satan, who denounced Job: <b>“And you incited Me against him, to destroy him gratuitously”</b> (Job 2:3)? Clearly Satan did not incite God with food and drink. The Gemara answers: Incitement against the One <b>on High is different,</b> as the term is used metaphorically. By contrast, incitement with regard to people involves food and drink.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And perhaps</b> Jehoshaphat <b>drank</b> at the feast but <b>did not eat.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>What is different</b> about <b>drinking</b> wine with Ahab that it would be permitted? It would be permitted because <b>we say: A transgressor with regard to idol worship is not</b> considered <b>a transgressor with regard to the entire Torah</b> and therefore his wine is not forbidden. With regard to <b>eating</b> a transgressor’s food <b>too, a transgressor with regard to idol worship is not</b> considered <b>a transgressor with regard to the entire Torah.</b> Therefore, the meat of an animal that he slaughters is not forbidden.
The Gemara asks: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared?</b> With regard to <b>drinking,</b> Ahab’s wine <b>is</b> considered <b>ordinary wine</b> of gentiles, <b>and the ordinary wine of gentiles was not yet prohibited,</b> as the Sages issued that decree only several generations later. Therefore, it was permitted for Jehoshaphat to drink Ahab’s wine. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>eating, I will say to you: A transgressor with regard to idol worship is</b> considered <b>a transgressor with regard to the entire Torah.</b> Therefore, it was prohibited for Jehoshaphat to eat the meat from the animals slaughtered by Ahab.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say:</b> It is clear that Jehoshaphat ate at the feast, as it is <b>not typical conduct of a king to drink</b> wine <b>without eating. And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>“And</b> Ahab <b>slaughtered</b> sheep and cattle for him in abundance, and for the people that were with him, <b>and incited him,” is written,</b> indicating: <b>With what did</b> Ahab <b>incite</b> Jehoshaphat? It was <b>with slaughter</b> of an animal. Apparently, it is permitted to eat from an animal slaughtered by a transgressor with regard to idol worship.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And perhaps Obadiah,</b> who was the majordomo of Ahab’s household and a righteous man, <b>slaughtered</b> the animals. The Gemara rejects that suggestion: <b>“In abundance” is written,</b> and <b>Obadiah would not have managed</b> to slaughter all the animals himself.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And perhaps</b> the <b>seven thousand</b> righteous people <b>slaughtered</b> the animals, <b>as it is written: “And I will leave seven thousand in Israel, all the knees that have not bowed to Baal,</b> and every mouth that has not kissed it” (I Kings 19:18). The Gemara rejects that suggestion: <b>They were hiding from Jezebel,</b> Ahab’s wife, and would not have gone to the palace to slaughter animals for the feast.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And perhaps,</b> although Ahab was an idolater, <b>the men</b> in the employ <b>of Ahab were upstanding</b> people, not idolaters, and they slaughtered the animals. The Gemara rejects that suggestion: That possibility should <b>not enter your mind, as it is written: “If a ruler hearkens to matters of falsehood, all his servants are wicked”</b> (Proverbs 29:12).
The Gemara suggests: <b>And perhaps the men</b> in the employ <b>of Jehoshaphat were also not upstanding,</b> and the animals that <b>the men</b> in the employ <b>of Ahab slaughtered, the men</b> in the employ <b>of Jehoshaphat ate,</b> and the animals that <b>Obadiah slaughtered, Jehoshaphat ate.</b>
The Gemara rejects that suggestion: That possibility should <b>not enter your mind; from</b> the fact <b>that</b> it is written: <b>“If a ruler hearkens to matters of falsehood, all his servants are wicked,”</b> it may be inferred that if a ruler hearkens <b>to matters of truth, all his servants are righteous.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>And perhaps</b> the animals that <b>the men</b> in the employ <b>of Ahab slaughtered, Ahab and his men ate,</b> and the animals that <b>the men</b> in the employ <b>of Jehoshaphat slaughtered, Jehoshaphat and his men ate.</b>

Daf 5a

The Gemara rejects that suggestion: Jehoshaphat <b>would not have separated himself from</b> Ahab to eat and drink by himself, as he relied on him completely. <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>If we say</b> that it is derived <b>from</b> that <b>which is written</b> that Jehoshaphat said to Ahab: <b>“I am as you are, my people as your people”</b> (I Kings 22:4), i.e., I am equally reliable, this is difficult, as, <b>if that is so,</b> then when Jehoshaphat said at the conclusion of that verse: <b>“My horses as your horses,”</b> can this <b>also</b> be referring to reliability? <b>Rather,</b> Jehoshaphat’s intention was: <b>That which will befall your horses will befall my horses; so too, that which will befall you and your people will befall me and my people.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it is derived that Jehoshaphat relied upon Ahab <b>from here: “And the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat, king of Judea, sat each on his throne, arrayed in their robes, in a threshing floor, at the entrance of the gate of Samaria”</b> (I Kings 22:10). The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term <b>threshing floor</b> in this context? <b>If we say</b> that it was <b>an actual threshing floor; is that to say</b> that <b>the gate of Samaria was a threshing floor?</b> Typically, the gate of a city was the place of assembly for the city’s judges and elders, not a threshing floor. <b>Rather,</b> they were sitting in a configuration <b>like</b> that of a circular <b>threshing floor,</b> i.e., facing each other in a display of amity, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Sanhedrin</i> 36b): <b>A Sanhedrin was</b> arranged in the same layout <b>as half of a circular threshing floor, so that</b> the judges <b>would see each other.</b> This verse demonstrates that Jehoshaphat deliberated with Ahab and relied on his judgment.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the verse written with regard to Elijah <b>supports</b> the opinion of Rav Anan. The verse states: <b>“And the ravens [<i>orevim</i>] brought him bread and meat in the morning, and bread and meat in the evening”</b> (I Kings 17:6); <b>and Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> They would bring the meat <b>from the slaughterhouse of Ahab.</b> Clearly, Elijah would not have eaten the meat if Ahab’s slaughter was not valid. The Gemara responds: Since he ate the meat <b>according to the word</b> of God, the case of Elijah <b>is different,</b> and no proof may be cited from there.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b><i>orevim</i></b> in this context? <b>Ravina said:</b> They were <b>actual ravens. Rav Adda bar Minyumi said to him: And perhaps</b> they were <b>two men whose names were Oreb? Isn’t it written: “And they slew Oreb at the Rock of Oreb, and Zeeb</b> they slew at the winepress of Zeeb” (Judges 7:25), indicating that Oreb is a person’s name? Ravina <b>said to him:</b> Did <b>the matter</b> just so <b>happen that the names of both of</b> the people supplying Elijah with food <b>were Oreb?</b> The improbability of this occurrence indicates that they were actual ravens.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And perhaps</b> they are called <i>orevim</i> <b>after the name of their place</b> of origin. <b>Isn’t it written: “And the Arameans had gone out in bands, and had brought away captive out of the land of Israel a minor young woman [<i>na’ara ketana</i>]”</b> (II Kings 5:2)? <b>And</b> it is <b>difficult for us</b> to understand why the verse <b>calls her a young woman and</b> also <b>calls her a minor,</b> which are two different stages in a girl’s development. <b>And Rabbi Pedat said:</b> She was <b>a minor girl who was from</b> a place called <b>Naaran.</b> Perhaps in the case of Elijah they were two people from a place called Oreb. The Gemara rejects that suggestion: <b>If so, Orebites [<i>oreviyyim</i>] should have</b> been written in the verse.
§ <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the opinion of Rav Anan, who says that it is permitted to eat from the slaughter of a Jew who is a transgressor with regard to idol worship: <b>Everyone slaughters, and even a Samaritan, and even an uncircumcised</b> man, <b>and even a Jewish transgressor.</b> The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>This uncircumcised</b> man, <b>what are the circumstances? If we say</b> that he is an uncircumcised man <b>whose brothers died due to circumcision</b> and the concern is that he might suffer a similar fate, clearly one may eat from what he slaughters, as <b>he is a full-fledged Jew</b> and not a transgressor at all. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that he is <b>a transgressor with regard to</b> remaining <b>uncircumcised,</b> as he refuses to be circumcised.
<b>Say the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And even a Jewish transgressor. What are the circumstances? If he is a transgressor with regard to one matter, that is</b> identical to the case of <b>a transgressor with regard to</b> remaining <b>uncircumcised. Rather, is it not</b> that he is <b>a transgressor with regard to idol worship, and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Anan?</b>
The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>No, actually I will say to you</b> that <b>a transgressor with regard to idol worship</b> may <b>not</b> slaughter, <b>as the Master said: Idol worship is a severe</b> transgression, <b>as</b> with regard to <b>anyone who denies it,</b> it is <b>as</b> though <b>he acknowledges</b> his acceptance of <b>the entire Torah.</b> Conversely, with regard to one who accepts idolatry, it is as though he denies the entire Torah. Therefore, his halakhic status is that of a transgressor with regard to the entire Torah, and his slaughter is not valid.
<b>Rather,</b> the transgressor in the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>a transgressor concerning the same matter</b> of eating unslaughtered carcasses, <b>and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava,</b> who said that one may rely on the slaughter of a transgressor with regard to eating unslaughtered animal carcasses to satisfy his appetite even <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rav Anan from that which is taught in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “When any man of you brings an offering unto the Lord, from the animal” (Leviticus 1:2). The <i>tanna</i> infers: <b>“Of you,”</b> indicating: <b>But not all of you.</b> This serves <b>to exclude the transgressor,</b> from whom an offering is not accepted. The <i>tanna</i> continues: The term <b>“of you”</b> is also interpreted to mean that <b>I distinguished among you and not among the nations.</b> Therefore, a gentile may bring an offering even if he is an idol worshipper. The expression <b>“from the animal”</b> serves <b>to include people who are similar to an animal</b> in that they do not recognize God. <b>From here,</b> the Sages <b>stated: One accepts offerings from Jewish transgressors so that they will consequently repent, except for the transgressor, one who pours wine as a libation</b> to idolatry, <b>and one who desecrates Shabbat in public [<i>befarhesya</i>].</b>
<b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>itself</b> is <b>difficult.</b> Initially, <b>you said: “Of you,”</b> indicating: <b>But not all of you.</b> This serves <b>to exclude the transgressor,</b> from whom an offering is not accepted. <b>And then</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches: One accepts offerings from Jewish transgressors.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult. The first clause</b> states that an offering is not accepted from <b>a transgressor with regard to the entire Torah. The middle clause</b> states that one accepts an offering from <b>a transgressor with regard to one matter.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>Say the last clause: Except for the transgressor, and one who pours wine as a libation</b> to idolatry, <b>and one who desecrates Shabbat in public.</b> With regard to <b>this transgressor</b> in the last clause, <b>what are the circumstances? If</b> the reference is to <b>a transgressor with regard to the entire Torah, that is</b> identical to <b>the first clause:</b> Of you, and not all of you, to exclude the transgressor. <b>And if</b> the reference is to <b>a transgressor with regard to one matter, the middle clause</b> is <b>difficult,</b> as it is stated there that one accepts an offering from a transgressor with regard to one matter.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying</b> in the last clause: <b>Except for the transgressor to pour wine as a libation</b> to idolatry <b>or to desecrate Shabbat in public? Apparently, a transgressor with regard to idol worship is a transgressor with regard to the entire Torah, and</b> this <i>baraita</i> is <b>a refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Anan.</b> The Gemara concludes: It is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And is this</b> <i>halakha</i> that one does not accept an offering from a transgressor <b>derived from</b> the verse cited <b>here? It is derived from</b> the verse written <b>there</b> with regard to a sin offering:

Daf 5b

“And if any one <b>of the common people</b> sins unwittingly…and he shall bring his offering” (Leviticus 4:27–28), from which it is inferred in a <i>baraita</i>: “Of the common people,” indicating: But not all of the common people. This serves <b>to exclude a transgressor,</b> from whom a sin offering is not accepted.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yosei says in the name of Rabbi Shimon</b> that the verse states: “And does <b>unwittingly</b> one of the things…<b>that may not be done, and he becomes guilty,</b> or if his sin that he sinned became known to him” (Leviticus 4:22–23). From the words “become known to him” it is inferred: <b>One who repents due to his awareness</b> that he performed a transgression, as had he known that the action is prohibited he would not have performed it, <b>brings an offering for his unwitting</b> transgression in order to achieve atonement. But one who <b>does not repent due to his awareness</b> that he sinned, e.g., a transgressor who would have sinned even had he been aware that the act is prohibited, <b>does not bring an offering for his unwitting</b> action.
<b>And we say: What</b> is the difference <b>between their</b> two opinions? <b>And Rav Hamnuna said:</b> The difference is in the case of <b>a transgressor with regard to eating</b> the forbidden <b>fat</b> of a domesticated animal <b>and he brought an offering for</b> unwittingly consuming <b>blood is</b> the difference <b>between them.</b> According to the first <i>tanna</i> he may not bring an offering, as he is a transgressor. According to Rabbi Shimon, since he repented for unwittingly consuming blood, due to his awareness that he sinned, he brings a sin offering for that unwitting sin. In any event, this <i>baraita</i> apparently contradicts the previously cited <i>baraita</i> with regard to the source for the <i>halakha</i> that one does not accept an offering from a transgressor.
The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> source teaches <b>with regard to</b> the <b>sin offering</b> of a transgressor that it is not accepted, <b>and one</b> source teaches <b>with regard to</b> the <b>burnt offering</b> of a transgressor that it is not accepted. <b>And</b> both sources <b>are necessary, as, if</b> the Torah had <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> one might have thought that it is not accepted <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is for atonement,</b> and as a transgressor he is undeserving of atonement, <b>but</b> with regard to <b>a burnt offering, which is</b> merely <b>a gift [<i>dedoron</i>], say</b> that one ought <b>to accept</b> it <b>from him. And if</b> the Torah had <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>a burnt offering,</b> one might have thought that it is not accepted <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is not an obligation, but</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering, which is an obligation, say</b> that one ought <b>to accept</b> it <b>from him.</b> Therefore, both sources are <b>necessary.</b>
§ In the previous <i>baraita</i> the Sages derived from the phrase “from the animal” that people who are similar to an animal are included among those from whom offerings are accepted. The Gemara seeks to understand the meaning of the phrase: Similar to an animal, and asks: <b>And everywhere that</b> the word <b>animal is written</b> and interpreted as referring to a person, does it indicate <b>a deficiency? But isn’t it written: “Man and animal You preserve, Lord”</b> (Psalms 36:7), <b>and Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: These are people who are clever in</b> terms of their <b>intellect,</b> like people, <b>and</b> despite their intelligence they <b>comport themselves</b> humbly and self-effacingly, <b>like an animal.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There it is written “man and animal.” Here,</b> the word <b>“animal” alone is written.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And everywhere that</b> the terms <b>“man” and “animal” are written</b> together, does it indicate <b>a virtue? But isn’t it written: “And I will sow the house of Israel and the house of Judah with the seed of man and with the seed of animal”</b> (Jeremiah 31:26), and the Sages interpreted the phrase “seed of animal” as a reference to ignorant, inferior people. The Gemara answers: <b>There, doesn’t the verse separate</b> man and animal? <b>The seed of man</b> is <b>discrete and the seed of animal</b> is <b>discrete.</b>
§ The Gemara revisits the matter of slaughter by a Samaritan and cites <b>a mnemonic</b> for the names of the Sages that follow: <b><i>Nun</i>,</b> for Ḥanan; <b><i>kuf</i>,</b> for Ya’akov; <b><i>lamed</i>,</b> for ben Levi; and <b><i>peh</i>,</b> for bar Kappara.
§ <b>Rabbi Ḥanan says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says in the name of bar Kappara:</b> The opinions of <b>Rabban Gamliel and his court were counted with regard to</b> the status of <b>the slaughter of a Samaritan, and they prohibited it. Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi: Perhaps my teacher heard</b> that <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where a Jew is not standing over him.</b> Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: <b>This</b> one <b>of the Sages seems like</b> one of <b>the people who have not studied <i>halakha</i>. When a Jew is not standing over</b> the Samaritan <b>is it necessary to say</b> that it is prohibited to eat from what he slaughters?
The Gemara asks: <b>Did</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>accept</b> that response <b>from</b> Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi <b>or did he not accept it from him? Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof to resolve that dilemma from that <b>which Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi says: I saw that Rabbi Yoḥanan ate from the slaughter of a Samaritan.</b> And <b>Rabbi Asi too ate from the slaughter of a Samaritan. And Rabbi Zeira wondered about it,</b> whether perhaps <b>they did not hear</b> the <i>halakha</i> that it is prohibited to eat from the slaughter of a Samaritan <b>but had they heard</b> it <b>they would have accepted it, or perhaps they heard</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>but did not accept it.</b>
Rabbi Zeira <b>then resolved</b> the matter <b>for himself. It stands to reason that they heard it and did not accept it. As, if it enters your mind</b> that <b>they did not hear it, but</b> that <b>had they heard it they would have accepted it, how did the matter eventuate,</b> leading these Sages <b>to eat forbidden</b> food? <b>Now</b> consider: If even <b>through the animals of the righteous, the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not generate mishaps,</b> then is it <b>not all the more so</b> true that <b>the righteous themselves</b> would not experience mishaps?

Daf 6a

<b>And if it enters your mind</b> that Rabbi Zeira <b>did not accept</b> from Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi that Rabban Gamliel prohibited eating from the slaughter of a Samaritan even when a Jew was standing over him, <b>let</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>resolve</b> the matter <b>for himself</b> in a different manner: <b>Here,</b> where Rabbi Yoḥanan ate from the slaughter of a Samaritan, it was <b>when a Jew</b> was <b>standing over him; there,</b> where Rabban Gamliel prohibited eating from the slaughter of a Samaritan, it was <b>when a Jew was not standing over him. Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Zeira <b>accepted</b> the response <b>from</b> Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi. The Gemara affirms: Indeed, <b>learn</b> this <b>from it.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>the Sages,</b> Rabban Gamliel and his court, <b>issued a decree</b> rendering it prohibited to eat from the slaughter of Samaritans? The Gemara answers: It is <b>like that</b> case <b>involving Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar,</b> in which <b>Rabbi Meir dispatched him to bring wine from the area of the Samaritans. A certain elder found him</b> and <b>said to him: “And put a knife to your throat, if you are a man given to appetite”</b> (Proverbs 23:2),as a warning to distance himself from them and not to drink their wine, because they were not reliable. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar went and related</b> those <b>matters before Rabbi Meir, and</b> Rabbi Meir <b>issued a decree against them.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> that the Samaritans are deemed unreliable? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: At the peak of Mount Gerizim they found the image of a dove, which</b> the Samaritan residents of Mount Gerizim <b>would worship; and Rabbi Meir</b> issued the decree <b>according to his</b> line of <b>reasoning that he takes the minority into consideration, and</b> therefore, despite the fact that the majority of Samaritans did not live on Mount Gerizim, <b>he issued a decree</b> rendering meat slaughtered by <b>the majority</b> forbidden <b>due to the minority</b> that worshipped that idol. <b>And Rabban Gamliel and his court also hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b>
The Gemara asks: As to <b>the plain</b> meaning <b>of</b> that <b>verse:</b> “And put a knife to your throat, if you are a man given to appetite,” <b>with regard to what</b> matter is <b>it written?</b> The Gemara answers: It is written <b>with regard to a student who is sitting before his teacher,</b> as he must consider his words carefully. <b>As Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches</b> a <i>baraita</i> interpreting the verses: <b>“When you sit to eat with a ruler, consider well [<i>bin tavin</i>] him that is before you; and put a knife to your throat, if you are a man given to appetite”</b> (Proverbs 23:1–2).
The <i>tanna</i> explains the verse: <b>If a student knows about his teacher that he knows to respond to him</b> with <b>a reasoned</b> answer, <b>seek wisdom [<i>bin</i>]</b> from him. <b>And if</b> the student believes that the teacher is <b>not</b> capable of doing so, <b>understand [<i>tavin</i>] who is sitting before you, and put a knife to your throat</b> and refrain from embarrassing him with questions that he cannot answer. And <b>if you are a man given to appetite</b> and you seek an answer to your question, <b>distance yourself from him.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu dispatched Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Yosef to bring wine from the area of the Samaritans. A certain elder found him</b> and <b>said to him:</b> The people <b>here</b> are <b>not keepers of the Torah. Rabbi Yitzḥak went and related the matters before Rabbi Abbahu, and Rabbi Abbahu went and related the matters before Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi, and they did not move from there until they rendered</b> the Samaritans <b>full-fledged gentiles.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> matters did those Sages render them full-fledged gentiles? <b>If it was to</b> prohibit eating from their <b>slaughter and</b> to render their wine as <b>wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> in idol worship, these prohibitions were issued previously. <b>From there,</b> from the generations of Rabbi Meir and Rabban Gamliel, <b>the Sages issued a decree</b> prohibiting <b>them.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They issued a decree, and</b> the people <b>did not accept</b> it <b>from them. Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi came</b> and <b>issued a decree, and</b> the people <b>accepted</b> it <b>from them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>full-fledged gentiles? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> It means that the halakhic status of a Samaritan is like that of a gentile with regard <b>to renouncing</b> his <b>domain</b> in a jointly-owned courtyard on Shabbat <b>and to transferring</b> his <b>domain</b> in the courtyard to residents of that courtyard.
<b>And</b> this is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a Jewish transgressor</b> who nevertheless <b>observes his Shabbat in the marketplace,</b> i.e., in public, if he failed to establish a joining of houses in a courtyard before Shabbat, his halakhic status is that of an observant Jew, and he may <b>renounce</b> his <b>domain</b> in the courtyard <b>and transfer</b> his <b>domain</b> in the courtyard. <b>But</b> a transgressor <b>who does not observe his Shabbat in the marketplace</b> may <b>neither renounce</b> his <b>domain</b> in the courtyard <b>nor transfer</b> his <b>domain</b> in the courtyard.
This is <b>because</b> the Sages <b>said:</b> Only <b>a Jew</b> may verbally <b>transfer</b> rights in his <b>domain or renounce</b> his rights in his <b>domain,</b> but <b>with regard to a gentile,</b> the other residents cannot establish a joining of courtyards <b>unless</b> the residents of the courtyard <b>lease</b> his domain from him. The halakhic status of one who publicly desecrates Shabbat is that of a gentile.
<b>How</b> does a Jew transfer or renounce his domain? If a Jew <b>says to</b> his neighbor: <b>My domain is transferred to you</b> or <b>my domain is renounced to you,</b> his neighbor <b>has acquired</b> his domain, <b>and it is not necessary</b> for him <b>to grant</b> it to his neighbor by means of one of the standard modes of acquisition.
§ The Gemara revisits the statement that the righteous would not experience mishaps. <b>Rabbi Zeira and Rav Asi happened</b> to come <b>to the inn of</b> the town of <b>Ya’ei.</b> In the inn, <b>they brought before</b> these Sages <b>eggs that shriveled</b> after being cooked <b>in wine. Rabbi Zeira did not eat</b> the eggs, <b>and Rav Asi ate</b> them. <b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rav Asi: And is the Master not concerned about</b> the possibility that the dish is <b>a mixture</b> containing wine that is <b>doubtfully tithed produce [<i>demai</i>]?</b> Rav Asi <b>said to him:</b> It did <b>not</b> enter <b>my mind.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> to himself: Is it <b>possible</b> that the Sages <b>issued a decree on a mixture</b> containing <b><i>demai</i> and the matter eventuated that Rav Asi ate forbidden</b> food? <b>Now,</b> since <b>even</b> with regard to <b>the animals of the righteous, the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not generate mishaps through them,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> true that <b>the righteous themselves</b> would not experience mishaps?
<b>Rabbi Zeira emerged, analyzed, and found</b> that no mishap was generated through Rav Asi, <b>as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Demai</i> 1:24): In the case of <b>one who purchases wine to place into fish gravy [<i>hamorayes</i>] or into <i>aluntit</i>,</b> a beverage in which wine is mixed, or one who purchases <b>vetch to prepare grist from it,</b> or <b>lentils to prepare groats from it,</b> if it is uncertain whether what he purchased is tithed, e.g., he bought it from one who is unreliable with regard to tithes [<i>am ha’aretz</i>], <b>one is obligated</b> to tithe it, <b>due to</b> the fact that it is <b><i>demai</i>. And needless to say,</b> if it is certain that what he purchased is not tithed, he is obligated to tithe it <b>due to</b> the fact that it is <b>certain</b> that it is untithed produce.
