<b>And they themselves,</b> the gravy, <i>aluntit</i>, grist, and groats that one purchased from an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, <b>are permitted, because they are a mixture.</b> Since only one element of the mixture must be tithed, the food is permitted.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it so that the Sages <b>did not issue a decree on a mixture</b> containing <b><i>demai</i>? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who gives his neighbor,</b> who is an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, <b>dough to bake</b> and gives her leaven for the dough to rise, <b>or</b> gives her <b>a pot</b> of food and the spices <b>to cook</b> in it, he need <b>not be concerned about the leaven and the spices that are in</b> the dough and the pot respectively, that perhaps she replaced them with her own, <b>neither with regard to</b> the possibility that they are <b>Sabbatical</b> Year produce <b>nor with regard to</b> the possibility that <b>tithe</b> was not separated.
<b>And if he says to her: Prepare</b> the dough or the food <b>for me with your own</b> leaven and spices, <b>he</b> must be <b>concerned about the leaven and the spices that are in</b> the dough and the pot respectively, <b>with regard to</b> the possibility that they are <b>Sabbatical</b> Year produce <b>and with regard to</b> the possibility that <b>tithe</b> was not separated, even though it is a mixture containing <i>demai</i>.
The Gemara answers: It is <b>different there, as, since he said to her: Prepare</b> the dough or the food <b>for me from your own,</b> it is <b>like one who mixed it by</b> direct <b>action. Rafram said: Leaven and spices are different, as</b> each of them <b>is made for</b> the purpose of adding <b>taste</b> to the mixture, <b>and taste is not nullified</b> in a mixture.
The Gemara asks: <b>And are we not concerned about replacement</b> of the ingredients that he gave his neighbor with her own? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 3:6): <b>One who gives</b> dough <b>to his mother-in-law,</b> who is suspect with regard to tithing, so that she will prepare it for him, must <b>tithe</b> everything <b>that he gives her and</b> everything <b>that he takes</b> back <b>from her.</b> This is <b>because she is suspected</b> of <b>replacing</b> an ingredient <b>that spoils.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There, the reason</b> is <b>like it is taught</b> explicitly in that mishna, that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> The mother-in-law <b>desires her daughter’s well-being</b> and wants to ensure that she eats quality food, <b>and is reticent</b> to tell <b>her son-in-law</b> that she replaced the ingredients that spoiled.

Daf 6b

The Gemara asks: <b>And in general,</b> in a case not involving one’s mother-in-law, <b>are we not concerned</b> about the possibility of replacement? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 3:5): <b>One who gives</b> dough or a pot of food <b>to his innkeeper [<i>pundakit</i>]</b> who is an <i>am ha’aretz</i> to bake or cook, <b>tithes what he gives her and</b> tithes <b>what he takes</b> back <b>from her, due to</b> the fact <b>that she is suspected</b> of <b>replacing</b> the ingredients? The Gemara answers: <b>There too,</b> her intentions are good, as the innkeeper <b>rationalizes</b> her deception <b>and says:</b> Let the <b>student</b> of Torah <b>eat</b> my <b>hot</b> food <b>and I will eat</b> his <b>cold</b> food.
The Gemara asks: <b>And are we not concerned about replacement</b> of the ingredients? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The wife of a <i>ḥaver</i>,</b> one devoted to the meticulous observance of mitzvot, especially the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity, <i>teruma</i>, and tithes,<b>grinds</b> grain <b>with the wife of an <i>am ha’aretz</i> when</b> the wife of the <i>ḥaver</i> <b>is ritually impure</b> with the impurity of a menstruating woman. In that case, there is no concern that she will eat her counterpart’s untithed produce, as, since she is impure she will refrain from touching the grain so that she will not render it impure. <b>But</b> she may <b>not</b> do so <b>when she is ritually pure,</b> due to the concern that she will eat the untithed produce.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Even when she is impure,</b> the wife of the <i>ḥaver</i> <b>may not grind</b> grain together with the wife of the <i>am ha’aretz</i>, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that her counterpart gives her</b> grain <b>and she eats</b> it without touching the rest of the grain.
The Gemara infers: <b>Now</b> that there is suspicion that the wife of the <i>am ha’aretz</i> <b>steals</b> from her husband’s grain and gives it to her counterparts, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that she is suspect with regard to <b>replacing</b> ingredients? <b>Rav Yosef said: There too</b> there are special circumstances, as the wife of the <i>am ha’aretz</i> <b>rationalizes</b> her behavior <b>and says</b> metaphorically: <b>The ox eats from its threshing,</b> and believes that the wife of the <i>ḥaver</i> is entitled to some of the grain that she is grinding.
§ The Gemara resumes its discussion of the statement that the righteous would not experience mishaps. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Zeruz, son of the father-in-law of Rabbi Meir, testified before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>about Rabbi Meir that he ate the leaf of a vegetable in Beit She’an</b> without tithing or separating <i>teruma</i>, as he holds that Beit She’an is not part of Eretz Yisrael and therefore is not sacred with its sanctity. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permitted all</b> the produce of <b>Beit She’an on</b> the basis of <b>his</b> testimony.
<b>His brothers and his father’s household united against him</b> and <b>said to him:</b> In <b>a place where your fathers and the fathers of your fathers treated</b> untithed produce as <b>forbidden, will you treat</b> it as <b>permitted?</b>
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>interpreted this verse to them: “And he broke in pieces the copper serpent that Moses had made; for until those days the children of Israel burned incense to it; and it was called Nehushtan”</b> (II Kings 18:4). Is it <b>possible</b> that they burned incense to it and <b>Asa,</b> a righteous king, <b>came and did not eradicate it,</b> and <b>Jehoshaphat,</b> a righteous king, <b>came and did not eradicate it,</b> and it remained until the time of Hezekiah? <b>But didn’t Asa and Jehoshaphat eradicate all</b> objects of <b>idol worship in the world?</b>

Daf 7a

<b>Rather,</b> it must be that in not eradicating the serpent, <b>his ancestors left</b> Hezekiah <b>room through which to achieve prominence [<i>lehitgader</i>]. I too</b> can say that <b>my ancestors left me room through which to achieve prominence</b> by permitting untithed produce from Beit She’an.
The Gemara adds: <b>From here</b> one learns with regard to <b>a Torah scholar who states</b> a new <b>matter of <i>halakha</i> that one does not move [<i>meziḥin</i>] him</b> from his position; <b>and some say: One does not disregard [<i>mazniḥin</i>] him; and some say: One does not attribute</b> his innovative statement <b>to his conceit [<i>mazḥiḥin</i>].</b>
The Gemara explains: With regard to <b>the one who says <i>meziḥin</i>,</b> it is <b>as that which is written: “And the breastplate shall not be loosed [<i>yizaḥ</i>] from the ephod”</b> (Exodus 28:28). <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the one who says: One does not disregard [<i>mazniḥin</i>],</b> it is <b>as it is written: “For the Lord will not abandon [<i>yizaḥ</i>] forever”</b> (Lamentations 3:31). <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the one who says <i>mazḥiḥin</i>,</b> it is <b>as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Sota</i> 14:9): <b>From</b> the time <b>that those with conceited [<i>zeḥuḥei</i>] hearts proliferated, dispute proliferated among the Jewish people.</b>
<b>Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, objects to</b> the basic <i>halakha</i>: <b>And is there anyone who says that Beit She’an is not</b> part <b>of Eretz Yisrael? But isn’t it written: “And Manasseh did not drive out the inhabitants of Beth She’an and its towns, nor of Taanach and its towns”</b> (Judges 1:27).
The Gemara answers: <b>That which Rabbi Shimon ben Elyakim says in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Pedat, who says in the name of Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua, escaped</b> the attention of Yehuda: <b>Many cities were conquered by those who ascended from Egypt</b> to Eretz Yisrael, led by Joshua, son of Nun, <b>and were not conquered by those who ascended from Babylonia</b> to Eretz Yisrael in the return to Zion led by Ezra. Among those cities was Beit She’an.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds: The initial consecration</b> with which Eretz Yisrael was sanctified during the era of Joshua, son of Nun, in terms of the obligation to fulfill land-based mitzvot, <b>sanctified</b> Eretz Yisrael <b>for its time but did not sanctify</b> it <b>forever.</b> Rather, the obligation lapsed with the exile to Babylonia. When those who ascended from Babylonia returned to Eretz Yisrael <b>and</b> sanctified the land, <b>they left</b> certain places unsanctified, <b>so that the poor would rely upon them</b> for sustenance <b>during the Sabbatical</b> Year, when produce is not plentiful. Since these areas were not sanctified, it is permitted to sow crops there during the Sabbatical Year, and the poor will not go hungry. Once Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi discovered that Beit She’an was one of those cities, he exempted it from land-based mitzvot.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira:</b> How did Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi rely on the testimony of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Zeruz to exempt from <i>terumot</i> and tithes produce that grows in Beit She’an? <b>But wasn’t it merely a leaf that Rabbi Meir ate?</b> It is permitted to eat untithed produce incidentally, not in the framework of a meal. Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: He ate</b> the leaf <b>from a bundle, and we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’asrot</i> 1:5): With regard to <b>a vegetable that is</b> typically <b>bound</b> in a bundle, one is obligated to separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes <b>from</b> the moment <b>that it is bound.</b> From that point, one may not eat from it even incidentally before tithing.
Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira: <b>And perhaps</b> it was <b>not on</b> Rabbi Meir’s <b>mind,</b> and his attention was diverted when he ate the leaf. Rabbi Zeira answered: <b>Now,</b> since even with regard to <b>the animals of the righteous, the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not generate mishaps through them,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> true that <b>the righteous themselves</b> would not experience mishaps?
Rabbi Yirmeya asked: <b>And perhaps</b> Rabbi Meir <b>tithed those</b> leaves <b>from</b> produce in <b>another place.</b> Rabbi Zeira answered: <b><i>Ḥaverim</i> are not suspected of separating <i>teruma</i> from</b> produce <b>that is not proximate</b> to the produce for which it is being separated. Rabbi Yirmeya asked: <b>And perhaps</b> Rabbi Meir <b>set his sight on this side</b> of the vegetable with the intent of separating <i>teruma</i> and tithes, <b>and ate</b> a leaf <b>on the other side.</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: See who the great man</b> is <b>who is testifying about</b> Rabbi Meir. Certainly a man of the stature of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Zeruz accurately observed and reported Rabbi Meir’s actions.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the reference to <b>animals of the righteous,</b> about whom it is stated that God does not generate mishaps through them? It is based on the incident <b>where Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir was going to</b> engage in <b>the redemption of captives,</b> and <b>he encountered the Ginai River.</b>
<b>He said to</b> the river: <b>Ginai, part your water for me and I will pass through you.</b> The river <b>said to him: You are going to perform the will of your Maker and I am going to perform the will of my Maker,</b> to flow in my path. With regard to <b>you,</b> it is <b>uncertain</b> whether you will <b>perform</b> His will successfully, <b>and</b> it is <b>uncertain</b> whether <b>you</b> will <b>not perform</b> His will successfully. <b>I</b> will <b>certainly perform</b> His will successfully. Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>said to</b> the river: <b>If you do not part, I</b> will <b>decree upon you that water will never flow through you.</b> The river <b>parted for him.</b>
There <b>was a certain man who was carrying wheat</b> for the preparation of <i>matza</i> <b>for Passover.</b> Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>said to</b> the river: <b>Part</b> your waters <b>for that</b> person <b>too, as he is engaged in</b> the performance of <b>a mitzva.</b> The river <b>parted for him.</b> There <b>was a certain Arab [<i>taya’a</i>] who was accompanying them.</b> Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>said to</b> the river: <b>Part</b> your waters <b>for that</b> person <b>too, so that he will not say: Is that</b> what <b>one does to a person who accompanies</b> him? The river <b>parted for him.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: How great is this man,</b> Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir, greater <b>than Moses and</b> the <b>six hundred thousand</b> who left Egypt, <b>as there,</b> at the Red Sea, the waters parted <b>one time, and here</b> the waters parted <b>three times.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps here too,</b> the waters parted <b>one time,</b> and the river began to flow again only after all three of them passed. <b>Rather,</b> this man was as great <b>as Moses and</b> the <b>six hundred thousand</b> children of Israel.
After crossing the river, Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>happened</b> to come <b>to a certain inn [<i>ushpiza</i>].</b> His hosts <b>cast barley before his donkey</b> for him to eat. The donkey <b>did not eat</b> it.

Daf 7b

The hosts <b>sifted</b> the barley with a utensil, but the donkey <b>did not eat</b> it. <b>They separated</b> the chaff from the barley by hand, but the donkey <b>did not eat</b> it. They wondered why the donkey would not eat the barley. Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>said to</b> his hosts: <b>Perhaps</b> the barley <b>is not tithed.</b> They <b>tithed it and</b> the donkey <b>ate</b> it. Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>said: This poor</b> animal <b>is going to perform the will of its Maker, and you are feeding it untithed produce?</b> Rabbi Zeira was referring to this donkey when it spoke of God preventing mishaps from occurring through animals of the righteous.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is one</b> who purchases grain that is <i>demai</i> in order to feed his animal <b>obligated</b> to tithe it? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 1:3): <b>One who purchases</b> grain in the market <b>for sowing or for</b> feeding <b>an animal, or flour to</b> process animal <b>hides, or oil to</b> kindle <b>a lamp, or oil to smear on vessels is exempt from the</b> obligation of tithing <b><i>demai</i>?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There, it was stated</b> with regard to that mishna that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> in a case <b>where one purchased</b> those items <b>initially for the animal</b> or for the other purposes enumerated in the mishna, <b>but</b> if <b>he purchased them initially for a person and reconsidered</b> his plans <b>for them</b> and decided to use them <b>for an animal, he is obligated to tithe</b> the <i>demai</i>. <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in support of that understanding: In the case of <b>one who purchases produce from the market for</b> human <b>consumption, and</b> he <b>reconsidered</b> his plans <b>for it</b> and decided to use it <b>for an animal, that</b> person <b>may neither place</b> it <b>before his animal nor before the animal of another unless he tithed</b> the produce.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>heard</b> that Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir arrived, and he <b>emerged to greet him.</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him:</b> Is it <b>your desire</b> to <b>dine with me?</b> Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>said to him: Yes. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi’s <b>face beamed [<i>tzahavu</i>],</b> as it was well known that Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir did not accept invitations to dine with others.
Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>Are you under the impression that deriving benefit from the Jewish people is forbidden to me by vow?</b> On the contrary, <b>the Jewish people are holy.</b> I avoid accepting invitations, as <b>there is one who wants</b> to invite guests to dine with him <b>but he does not have</b> the means, and I do not want to enjoy a meal that my host cannot afford. <b>And there is one who has</b> the means <b>but does not want</b> to host guests, <b>and</b> with regard to those people <b>it is written: “Eat not the bread of him that has an evil eye, neither desire his delicacies. For as one that has reckoned within himself, so is he: Eat and drink, says he to you; but his heart is not with you”</b> (Proverbs 23:6–7). <b>But you want</b> to invite guests to dine with you, <b>and you have</b> the means.
<b>But now I am rushing [<i>mesarheivna</i>], as I am engaged in</b> the performance of <b>a matter involving a mitzva. When I come back I will enter to</b> dine with <b>you.</b>
<b>When</b> Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>came</b> back, <b>he happened to enter through that entrance in which white mules were standing. He said: The Angel of Death</b> is <b>in this</b> person’s <b>house, and I will eat with him?</b> White mules were known to be dangerous animals.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>heard</b> the comment of Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir and <b>emerged to greet him. He said to him: I will sell</b> the mules. Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir <b>said to him:</b> You will thereby violate the prohibition: <b>“Nor place a stumbling block before the blind”</b> (Leviticus 19:14), as it is prohibited for any Jew to keep a destructive animal in his possession.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to him: <b>I will declare</b> the mules <b>ownerless.</b> Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir said to him: <b>You</b> will thereby <b>increase the damage,</b> as there will be no owner to restrain it. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to him: <b>I</b> will <b>remove their</b> hooves so that they will be unable to kick and cause damage. Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir said to him: <b>There is</b> the requirement to prevent <b>suffering to animals,</b> and you will be violating it. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said to him: <b>I</b> will <b>kill them.</b> Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir said to him: <b>There is</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not destroy</b> items of value.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>was greatly imploring him</b> to enter his home until <b>a mountain rose between them</b> and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi could no longer speak with him. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>wept and said: If during their lifetimes</b> it is <b>so</b> that the righteous are great, <b>after their death</b> it is <b>all the more so</b> true. The Gemara comments: This is <b>as Rabbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina says: The righteous are greater after their death, more so than during their lifetimes, as it is stated: “And it came to pass, as they were burying a man, that they spied a raiding party; and they cast the man into the tomb of Elisha; and as soon as the man touched the bones of Elisha, he revived, and stood up on his feet”</b> (II Kings 13:21).
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye:</b> This proof from the case of Elisha that the righteous are greater after death is not valid. <b>And perhaps</b> this transpired <b>to fulfill with regard to</b> Elisha <b>the blessing of Elijah, as it is written: “Please, let a double portion of your spirit be upon me”</b> (II Kings 2:9). Elijah revived one dead person and this one is the second revived by Elisha. Abaye <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa: <b>If so, is this</b> consistent with that <b>which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The dead person <b>arose on his feet but he did not go to his home,</b> indicating that he had not truly been revived?
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if that is the case, <b>in what</b> manner <b>was</b> Elijah’s blessing <b>fulfilled?</b> It is <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The blessing was fulfilled <b>when he cured the leprosy of Naaman, since</b> a leper <b>is equivalent to a dead person, as it is stated</b> with regard to Miriam when she was afflicted with leprosy: <b>“Please, let her not be as one dead”</b> (Numbers 12:12).
Apropos white mules, which were likened to the Angel of Death, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: Why are</b> the mules <b>called <i>yemim</i></b> (see Genesis 36:24)? It is <b>because their terror [<i>eimatam</i>] is cast over</b> all <b>creatures, as Rabbi Ḥanina says: In</b> all <b>my days, no man has asked me about a wound</b> caused him <b>by a white mule and survived,</b> indicating that they are extremely dangerous. The Gemara asks: <b>But haven’t we seen that</b> some people <b>survive</b> after being wounded by a white mule? The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> instead, no man has asked me about a wound caused him by a mule <b>and</b> the wound <b>healed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But haven’t we seen that</b> such wounds <b>heal?</b> The Gemara answers: The wound that <b>we say</b> does not heal is one caused by a mule <b>the top of whose legs are white.</b>
The Gemara relates other statements of Rabbi Ḥanina: With regard to the verse: <b>“There is none else beside Him”</b> (Deuteronomy 4:35), <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: And even sorcery</b> is ineffective against the will of God. The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain woman who would try to take dust from beneath the feet of Rabbi Ḥanina</b> in order to perform sorcery on him and harm him. Rabbi Ḥanina <b>said to her: Take</b> the dust, but <b>the matter will be ineffective for you,</b> as it <b>is written: “There is none other beside Him.”</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: Why</b> is sorcery <b>called <i>keshafim</i>?</b> It is an acronym for <b><i>makhḥishin pamalya shel mala</i>,</b> meaning: <b>That they diminish the heavenly entourage [<i>pamalya</i>],</b> indicating that they function contrary to the will of God. The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Ḥanina is different, as,</b> because <b>his merit is great,</b> sorcery has no effect on him.
<b>And Rabbi Ḥanina says: A person injures his finger below,</b> on earth, <b>only if they declare about him on high</b> that he should be injured, <b>as it is stated: It is of the Lord that a man’s goings are established; and a man, what does he understand of his way</b> (see Psalms 37:23 and Proverbs 20:24). <b>Rabbi Elazar says: The blood of a wound effects atonement like the blood of a burnt offering. Rava said:</b> This is stated <b>with regard to</b> a wound on his <b>right thumb,</b> as one applies force with that thumb and the wound is consequently more severe; <b>and</b> it is also stated <b>with regard to a second wound</b> in the same place before the first has healed, <b>and it is</b> provided <b>that</b> he is wounded while <b>going to</b> perform <b>a matter</b> involving <b>a mitzva.</b>
Apropos Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir, the Gemara notes that <b>they said about Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir: In</b> all <b>his days he never broke</b> bread and recited a blessing <b>on a piece of bread that was not his, and from the day that he achieved cognition he did not benefit</b> even <b>from the meal of his father,</b> because he eschewed benefit from everyone.

Daf 8a

§ <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> If <b>one heated a knife until</b> it became <b>white hot [<i>libben</i>] and slaughtered</b> an animal <b>with it, his slaughter is valid,</b> as cutting the relevant <i>simanim</i> with the knife’s <b>sharp</b> blade <b>preceded</b> the effect of <b>its white heat.</b> Had the effect of the heat preceded the cutting, the animal would have been rendered a <i>tereifa</i>, an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months, before the slaughter was completed, by searing the windpipe and the gullet. The Gemara asks: <b>But aren’t there the sides</b> of the knife, which burn the throat and render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>The area of the slaughter</b> in the throat <b>parts</b> immediately after the incision, and the tissue on either side of the incision is not seared by the white-hot blade.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If <b>one heated a skewer [<i>shappud</i>] until</b> it became <b>white hot and struck</b> a person <b>with it,</b> and after the wound healed a leprous mark developed, is that mark <b>adjudged as</b> a leprous <b>boil or is it adjudged as</b> a leprous <b>burn?</b>
<b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> whether it is adjudged a boil or a burn? The difference is <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Both a leprous <b>boil and</b> a leprous <b>burn become impure during one week</b> of quarantine <b>with two symptoms: With white hair</b> that grows in the leprous mark <b>and with spreading</b> of the leprous mark. <b>And why did the verse divide them</b> into two separate passages even though their halakhic status is the same? The verse divided them <b>to say that they do not join together</b> to constitute the requisite measure of impure leprous marks. Rather, there is impurity only if the boil or the burn constitutes that measure individually.
<b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Which</b> wound <b>is a boil and which is a burn?</b> If <b>one was struck with wood, with a stone, with pomace, with the hot springs of Tiberias, or with any item that is not heated by fire,</b> a phrase that serves <b>to include lead</b> that was mined <b>from its source</b> in the ground, which is occasionally hot enough to burn a person, <b>this</b> impression left on the skin <b>is a boil. And which</b> wound <b>is a burn?</b> If <b>one was burned with a coal, with hot ashes, with boiling limestone, with boiling gypsum [<i>begippesit</i>], or with any item that is heated by fire,</b> a phrase that serves <b>to include</b> water <b>heated by fire, this</b> impression left on the skin <b>is a burn.</b>
<b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If there is <b>a boil and a burn</b> on the same place on the skin and a leprous mark developed, the later wound determines the nature of the leprosy. Therefore, <b>if the boil preceded the burn, the burn nullifies the boil</b> and the mark is a leprous burn. <b>And if the burn preceded the boil, the boil nullifies the burn</b> and the mark is a leprous boil.
<b>And here,</b> where the dilemma was raised whether the mark that develops from being struck with a hot skewer is a boil or a burn, <b>what are the circumstances?</b> It is a case <b>where initially there was a boil half</b> the size of <b>a split bean on</b> the person’s skin, <b>and one heated a skewer until</b> it became <b>white hot and struck</b> him <b>with it, and another</b> mark <b>half</b> the size of <b>a split bean emerged</b> on the skin there.
The Gemara clarifies the dilemma: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Does</b> the effect of <b>the blow come first and</b> then the effect of <b>the heat comes and nullifies</b> the effect of <b>the blow, and it is</b> a half-measure <b>boil and</b> a half-measure <b>burn and they do not join together</b> to constitute a full measure? <b>Or perhaps</b> the effect of <b>the heat comes first and</b> then the effect of <b>the blow comes and nullifies</b> the effect of <b>the heat, and it is</b> a half-measure <b>boil and</b> a half-measure <b>boil and they join together.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to the dilemma from that <b>which Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> If <b>one heated a knife until</b> it became <b>white hot and slaughtered</b> an animal <b>with it, his slaughter is valid,</b> as cutting the relevant <i>simanim</i> with the knife’s <b>sharp</b> blade <b>preceded</b> the effect of <b>its white heat. Apparently,</b> the effect of <b>the blow comes first.</b> The Gemara rejects that proof: Cutting with <b>a sharp</b> blade <b>is different</b> from striking with a blunt object, and only in the case of a blade does the cut precede the effect of the heat.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to the dilemma from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one heated a skewer until</b> it became <b>white hot and struck</b> a person <b>with it</b> and after the wound healed a leprous mark developed, that mark <b>is adjudged as</b> a leprous <b>burn</b> caused <b>by fire. Apparently,</b> the effect of <b>the blow precedes</b> the effect of the burn. The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>There too,</b> the reference is to a case <b>where he stabbed</b> the skin with the skewer, <b>which is</b> the same as cutting with <b>a sharp</b> blade.
§ <b>Rav Naḥman says that Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> With regard to <b>a knife</b> used <b>for idol worship,</b> it is <b>permitted to slaughter</b> an animal <b>with it, but</b> it is <b>prohibited to cut meat with it.</b> It is <b>permitted to slaughter</b> an animal <b>with it</b> because slaughtering it <b>is a destructive</b> action vis-à-vis the animal, which is worth more when it is alive. <b>But</b> it is <b>prohibited to cut meat with it,</b> because once the animal is slaughtered, cutting it <b>is a constructive</b> action that renders the meat manageable.
<b>Rava said:</b> There are <b>times when</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal to use a knife used for idol worship, e.g., <b>in</b> the case of an animal that is in <b>danger,</b> meaning that it is about to die. If he does not slaughter the animal it would become an unslaughtered carcass and depreciate in value. <b>And</b> there are times when it is <b>permitted</b> for <b>one who cuts</b> meat to use a knife of idol worship, e.g., <b>in</b> the case of an animal whose <b>thighs are intended to</b> be sent as <b>a gift</b> to a person of stature. Cutting it into pieces would render it unfit for this purpose, thereby diminishing its value.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And derive</b> that <b>it</b> is prohibited to use a knife used for idol worship, not because benefit from it is prohibited, but <b>due to</b> the residue of <b>fat of forbidden</b> carcasses on the knife.

Daf 8b

The Gemara rejects that possibility: Rav Naḥman is referring <b>to</b> the case of <b>a new</b> knife on which there is no residue.
The Gemara challenges: If it is <b>a new</b> knife, <b>both</b> according <b>to Rabbi Yishmael and</b> according <b>to Rabbi Akiva,</b> who disagreed about whether an idol is forbidden from the moment that one crafts it or from the moment that one worships it, a knife is merely in the category of <b>accessories of idol worship, and accessories of idol worship are forbidden only after they are</b> used for idol <b>worship.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the reference is to a case <b>where he cut a branch [<i>gevaza</i>] for idol worship with</b> the knife, which leaves no residue. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that Rav Naḥman is referring <b>to</b> the case of <b>an old</b> knife <b>that he burned until</b> it became <b>white hot in the fire,</b> and therefore, there is no residue on the knife.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal <b>with the knife of gentiles, Rav says: He peels</b> off a layer of the flesh from the place on the animal where the knife touched the flesh and the forbidden residue on the knife was absorbed. <b>And Rabba bar bar Ḥana says: He rinses</b> the place where the knife touched the flesh. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>they disagree about this, that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabba bar bar Ḥana, <b>holds: The area of the slaughter</b> on the throat <b>is cold</b> and does not absorb the forbidden residue, and therefore rinsing is sufficient. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds: The area of the slaughter</b> on the throat <b>is hot</b> and therefore it absorbs the forbidden residue.
The Gemara rejects that suggestion: <b>No,</b> it is possible <b>that everyone</b> holds that <b>the area of the slaughter</b> on the throat <b>is hot.</b> For <b>the one who says</b> that <b>he peels</b> off a layer, it works out <b>well, and the one who says</b> that <b>he rinses</b> the place where the knife touched the flesh holds that <b>since the two organs that must be severed in ritual slaughter [<i>simanim</i>],</b> i.e., the windpipe and the gullet, <b>are occupied</b> with <b>discharging blood, they do not absorb</b> the residue.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say that everyone</b> holds that <b>the area of the slaughter</b> on the throat <b>is cold.</b> For <b>the one who says</b> that <b>he rinses</b> the place where the knife touched the flesh, it works out <b>well, and the one who says</b> that <b>he peels</b> off a layer holds that although that area is cold, <b>due to the pressure of the knife</b> on the throat, the flesh <b>absorbs</b> the residue.
§ <b>With regard to a knife</b> with which an animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> was slaughtered, <b>Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree. One says:</b> One purges it <b>in hot</b> water to remove the absorptions from the <i>tereifa</i>, <b>and one says:</b> One rinses it <b>in cold</b> water, and that is sufficient. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is: One may rinse it <b>even in cold</b> water. <b>And if there is a tattered</b> piece <b>of a curtain</b> with which <b>to wipe</b> the knife, <b>one need not</b> rinse it.
<b>And according to the one who says</b> that one purges it <b>in hot</b> water, <b>what is the reason</b> that he must do so; is it <b>due to</b> the premise <b>that</b> the knife <b>absorbed forbidden</b> residue? That reasoning should not be limited to a case where he slaughtered a <i>tereifa</i>. A knife with <b>which</b> he slaughtered an animal that is <b>permitted</b> should <b>also</b> require purging, because <b>it absorbed</b> residue from <b>the limb from a living</b> animal before the slaughter was completed. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> is there concern that the knife <b>absorbed</b> the residue? It is <b>when</b> the throat <b>grows warm. When does it grow warm?</b> It is <b>at</b> the point <b>when the slaughter is complete.</b> At <b>that moment, it is</b> already <b>permitted.</b>
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: The slaughterer requires three knives, one with which he slaughters</b> the animal, <b>and one with which he cuts meat, and one with which he cuts</b> forbidden <b>fats.</b> One may not use the same knife for cutting the meat and the forbidden fats due to the residue on the knife after cutting the forbidden fats.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And let him designate one</b> knife for cutting both the meat and forbidden fats <b>and cut meat with it and then cut</b> forbidden <b>fats with it.</b> In this manner the forbidden residue on the knife will not affect the meat. The Gemara explains: The Sages issued a rabbinic <b>decree</b> prohibiting the use of one knife to cut meat and then forbidden fats <b>lest he</b> also <b>cut</b> forbidden <b>fats and cut meat thereafter.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>Now too,</b> after the decree mandating separate knives there is a concern that <b>they will be confused for him</b> and he will use the knife that cut the forbidden fats to cut the meat. The Gemara explains: <b>Since</b> the Sages <b>required him</b> to have <b>two</b> knives, <b>he has a conspicuous marker</b> on one of the knives that will prevent confusion.
<b>And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: The slaughterer requires two vessels of water, one with which he rinses meat and one with which he rinses</b> forbidden <b>fats.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>And let him designate one</b> vessel <b>and rinse meat with</b> the water in the vessel <b>and then rinse</b> forbidden <b>fats with</b> the water in the same vessel. The Gemara explains: The Sages issued a rabbinic <b>decree</b> to prohibit doing so <b>lest he rinse</b> fats <b>and rinse meat thereafter.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>Now too,</b> after the decree mandating separate vessels there is a concern that <b>they will be confused for him</b> and he will rinse meat in the vessel in which he rinsed fats. The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the Sages <b>required him</b> to have <b>two</b> vessels, <b>he has a conspicuous marker</b> on one of the vessels that will prevent confusion.
§ <b>Ameimar says in the name of Rav Pappa: A person should not place [<i>lisḥof</i>] the flanks</b> of an animal <b>atop</b> other <b>meat</b> so that the forbidden fats that are attached to the flanks are in contact with the other meat, due to the fact <b>that the</b> forbidden <b>fat</b> liquefies and <b>flows and the meat absorbs</b> it.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>If so,</b> and that is a concern, <b>when</b> the flanks are <b>placed</b> in their <b>typical</b> manner <b>[<i>teritzi</i>] as well,</b> with the forbidden fat above the meat of the flanks, <b>the</b> forbidden <b>fat flows and the meat</b> of the flanks <b>absorbs</b> it. The Gemara explains: <b>The membrane</b> between the forbidden fat and the meat of the flanks <b>interposes from below</b> and prevents absorption of the forbidden fat. The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b>

Daf 9a

<b>from above too there is a membrane</b> that should prevent the forbidden fat from flowing onto the piece of meat even if the forbidden fat is placed directly upon it. The Gemara explains: <b>Since the hand of the slaughterer touches</b> the upper membrane, that membrane <b>disintegrates</b> and the forbidden fat flows onto the meat.
§ <b>And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: A Torah scholar is required to learn</b> the requisite skills to perform <b>three matters: Writing,</b> so that he will be able to write texts on various occasions, <b>ritual slaughter, and circumcision. And Rav Ḥananya bar Shelamya says in the name of Rav:</b> He must <b>also</b> learn to tie <b>the knot of the phylacteries, and</b> to recite <b>the blessing of the grooms</b> by heart and with the traditional intonation, <b>and</b> to tie <b>ritual fringes</b> to the corners of a garment. The Gemara notes: <b>And the other</b> <i>amora</i>, Rav Yehuda, holds that <b>those</b> skills <b>are commonplace</b> and do not require special training.
§ <b>And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>any slaughterer who does not know the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual slaughter,</b> it is <b>prohibited to eat from his slaughter. And these are the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual slaughter: Interrupting</b> the slaughter, <b>pressing</b> the knife, <b>concealing</b> the knife under the windpipe or the gullet in the course of an inverted slaughter, <b>diverting</b> the knife from the place of slaughter, <b>and ripping</b> the <i>simanim</i> from their place before cutting them.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the novelty in what Rav is <b>teaching us? We learned all of them</b> in the <i>mishnayot</i> in the second chapter of this tractate, and therefore it is obvious that a slaughterer who does not know these <i>halakhot</i> is not qualified. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> in a case <b>where</b> the slaughterer <b>slaughtered before us twice or three times and slaughtered well. Lest you say: From</b> the fact <b>that he slaughtered the other</b> animals <b>well, this</b> animal <b>he also slaughtered well;</b> therefore, Rav <b>teaches us: Since he did not learn</b> the <i>halakhot</i>, <b>sometimes</b> it happens <b>that he interrupts</b> the slaughter <b>or presses</b> the knife, <b>and he does not know</b> that he invalidated the slaughter.
§ <b>And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: The slaughterer must examine the <i>simanim</i>,</b> the windpipe and the gullet, <b>after</b> completing the <b>slaughter. Rav Yosef said: We learn</b> in a mishna (32a) <b>as well: Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The slaughter is not valid <b>if he interrupted</b> the slaughter for an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of <b>an examination. What, is it not</b> an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of <b>an examination of the <i>simanim</i>?</b> Apparently, one is obligated to examine the <i>simanim</i>.
<b>Abaye said to him: No, this</b> is what <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of <b>an examination</b> of the knife, as the Sages instituted that one must take the knife to be examined by a Torah <b>scholar</b> prior to slaughtering the animal. Rav Yosef said to him: <b>If so, you have rendered your statement</b> subject <b>to circumstances,</b> as sometimes the Torah scholar is near and sometimes the Torah scholar is far, and the time required for examination varies accordingly. <b>Rather,</b> it is an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of <b>an examination</b> performed by <b>a slaughterer</b> who is a Torah <b>scholar.</b> In that case, the travel time is not factored, just the time of the examination, which does not vary.
The Gemara asks: If the slaughterer <b>did not examine</b> the <i>simanim</i> after completing slaughter of the animal, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Antigonus says in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yannai:</b> The halakhic status of the slaughtered animal is that of <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, and it is forbidden for consumption,</b> but it does not impart impurity. <b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>:</b> Its halakhic status is that of <b>an unslaughtered carcass, and it imparts impurity by means of carrying</b> it.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: They disagree <b>with regard to</b> the application of the <i>halakha</i> stated by <b>Rav Huna, who says: An animal during its lifetime exists with the presumptive status of prohibition,</b> as it is prohibited to eat a living animal, and it continues to have this status even after its death <b>until it will become known to you in what</b> manner <b>it was slaughtered,</b> i.e., whether it was properly slaughtered. Once the animal <b>was slaughtered,</b> it exists <b>with the presumptive status of permissibility until it will become known to you in what</b> manner <b>it was rendered a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
It is with regard to the application of this <i>halakha</i> that Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yannai, and the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> disagree in a case where the slaughterer did not examine the <i>simanim</i> after completing the slaughter. One <b>Sage holds:</b> Since it has not been verified that the animal was slaughtered properly, the animal <b>exists with the presumptive status of prohibition, and</b> since <b>now it is dead,</b> it assumes the status of an unslaughtered carcass and imparts impurity. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage holds: With</b> regard to <b>the presumptive status of prohibition, we say</b> that the animal is forbidden until it is verified that it was slaughtered properly; <b>with regard to the presumptive status of ritual impurity we do not say</b> that the animal is impure, as a living animal is not ritually impure.
§ The Gemara proceeds to analyze <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav Huna says: An animal during its lifetime exists with the presumptive status of prohibition until it will become known to you in what</b> manner <b>it was slaughtered.</b> Once the animal <b>was slaughtered, it exists with the presumptive status of permissibility until it will become known to you in what</b> manner <b>it was rendered a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> The Gemara challenges this: <b>And let us say</b> that once the animal <b>was slaughtered, it became permitted,</b> instead of saying that it exists with the presumptive status of permissibility. The Gemara explains: <b>This teaches us that even if a flaw developed in</b> the animal that raises uncertainty with regard to its permitted status, it retains its presumptive status of permissibility.
<b>As Rabbi Abba raised a dilemma before Rav Huna:</b> If <b>a wolf came and took</b> the <b>innards</b> of a slaughtered animal, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara asks: <b>Took?</b> In that case the innards <b>are not</b> there, and therefore there is no way of seeing an indication of a flaw. <b>Rather,</b> the dilemma is: In a case where a wolf <b>perforated the innards</b> of a slaughtered animal, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara challenges: <b>Perforated? We see that</b> the wolf <b>perforated them</b> and in that case too there is no indication of a flaw. <b>Rather,</b> the dilemma is: In a case where a wolf <b>took</b> the innards <b>and returned them when they are perforated, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Are we concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the wolf <b>perforated</b> the innards <b>in the place of</b> a preexisting <b>perforation</b> and the animal was a <i>tereifa</i> from the outset, <b>or</b> is that possibility <b>not</b> a concern?
Rav Huna <b>said to</b> Rabbi Abba: <b>One is not concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the wolf <b>perforated</b> the innards <b>in the place of</b> a preexisting <b>perforation,</b> because one relies on the presumptive status of permissibility.
Rabbi Abba <b>raised an objection to</b> the opinion of Rav Huna: If <b>one saw a bird pecking at a fig or a mouse gnawing at melons,</b>

Daf 9b

<b>one is concerned that perhaps</b> the bird or the mouse <b>perforated</b> it <b>in the place of</b> the preexisting <b>perforation</b> caused by a snake, and it is prohibited to eat the fig or the melon, due to the danger that the snake might have left its venom.
Rav Huna <b>said to</b> Rabbi Abba: <b>Are you comparing danger to prohibition? Danger is different,</b> and one rules stringently in cases involving danger. <b>Rava said to him: What is different</b> about the fact that the ruling in cases of <b>uncertainty</b> involving <b>danger</b> is <b>stringent,</b> given that in cases of <b>uncertainty</b> involving <b>prohibition</b> the ruling is <b>also stringent?</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>And is there no difference between prohibition and danger? But isn’t</b> it the <i>halakha</i> that in a case of <b>uncertainty</b> involving <b>ritual impurity in the public domain, its uncertain</b> impurity leaves it <b>pure, while</b> in a case of <b>uncertainty</b> involving <b>water</b> that is <b>exposed</b> and therefore susceptible to a snake leaving venom in it, the water is <b>forbidden.</b>
Rava <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>There,</b> in the case of ritual impurity in the public domain, the Sages <b>learned this <i>halakha</i> through tradition from</b> the case of <b>a <i>sota</i>,</b> a woman who enters into seclusion with a particular man after her husband warns her not to. She is forbidden to her husband even though there is uncertainty whether or not she committed adultery. <b>Just as a <i>sota</i> is</b> forbidden only in a case of uncertainty <b>in the private domain,</b> as there is no seclusion in the public domain; <b>so too</b> with regard to <b>ritual impurity,</b> one becomes ritually impure in a case of uncertainty only <b>in the private domain.</b>
<b>Rav Shimi raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rava from a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 4:2): If the carcass of <b>a creeping animal</b> was <b>in the mouth of a weasel, and</b> that <b>weasel</b> was <b>walking on loaves of <i>teruma</i>,</b> and there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether the creeping animal <b>touched</b> the loaves and <b>uncertainty</b> whether it <b>did not touch</b> the loaves, <b>its uncertain</b> impurity leaves it <b>pure, while</b> in a case of <b>uncertainty</b> involving <b>water</b> that is <b>exposed</b> and therefore susceptible to a snake leaving venom in it, the water is <b>forbidden.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>There too, the <i>halakha</i> is derived from</b> the case of <b>a <i>sota</i>. Just as</b> the uncertainty in the case of <b><i>sota</i></b> involves <b>an entity that has consciousness</b> in order for her <b>to be asked</b> whether she was unfaithful and is forbidden to her husband, <b>so too here,</b> only uncertainty involving <b>an entity that has consciousness</b> in order for it <b>to be asked</b> whether the loaves were rendered impure would become impure. The weasel does not have that consciousness.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> additional proof that danger is more severe than prohibition (see mishna <i>Para</i> 11:1): In the case of <b>a flask</b> of purification water <b>that one left exposed and he came</b> back <b>and found it covered,</b> it is <b>ritually impure, as I say: An impure man entered into there and covered</b> it, and in the course of doing so he rendered the vessel and its contents impure.
In a case where <b>one left</b> the vessel <b>covered and came</b> back <b>and found it exposed, if</b> it is in a place where <b>a weasel could drink from it, or a snake according to the statement of Rabban Gamliel, or</b> if there is concern <b>that dew fell into it at night,</b> the purification waters are <b>disqualified</b> for sprinkling in the process of purification of a person impure with impurity imparted by a corpse, due to the concern that the saliva of the weasel or the dew, which are unfit for sprinkling, intermingled with it. Nevertheless, the water is not impure.
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: What is the reason</b> that there is no concern that a ritually impure person exposed the waters and rendered them impure?

Daf 10a

It is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is</b> the typical <b>manner of creeping animals to expose</b> the contents of a vessel so that they may drink. Therefore, the exposure of the water is attributed to a creeping animal or to a ritually pure person. By contrast, in a case where he left the vessel exposed and found it covered, the concern is that it was an impure man who covered it, since <b>it is not</b> the typical <b>manner of</b> creeping animals <b>to cover</b> exposed vessels. Evidently, with regard to prohibition or ritual impurity, there are circumstances of uncertainty when the ruling is lenient.
<b>Alternatively,</b> it can be inferred from the <i>baraita</i> that <b>the reason</b> the contents of the vessel are impure or disqualified, respectively, is <b>that he left it exposed and came</b> back <b>and found it covered</b> or that he left it <b>covered and came</b> back <b>and found it exposed. But</b> if <b>he found</b> the vessel just <b>as he left it, there is neither impurity nor disqualification.</b>
<b>But</b> in a situation of <b>uncertainty</b> where he left <b>exposed water</b> and then came and found the vessel exposed, the water is <b>forbidden</b> under all circumstances. <b>Learn from it</b> that <b>danger is more severe than prohibition.</b> The Gemara affirms: Indeed, <b>learn from it.</b>
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Terumot</i> 8:4): <b>Three liquids are forbidden due to exposure: Water, wine, and milk. How long shall they remain</b> exposed <b>and</b> their contents <b>will be forbidden?</b> It is a period <b>equivalent</b> to the time necessary so <b>that a snake could emerge from a proximate place and drink. And how</b> far away is considered <b>a proximate place? Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Yehuda, said:</b> Even a period <b>equivalent</b> to the time necessary <b>so that</b> a snake <b>could emerge from beneath the handle of the vessel and drink.</b>
The Gemara asks: If it is only the time necessary for the snake to emerge and <b>drink, doesn’t one see</b> the snake drink, in which case there is no uncertainty? <b>Rather,</b> it is a period equivalent to the time necessary for a snake to emerge from a proximate place, <b>drink, and return to its hole.</b> If one left exposed liquid unattended for that interval, it is possible that the snake drank the liquid unseen by the owner of the liquid.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal <b>with a knife that was</b> afterward <b>found</b> to be <b>notched, Rav Huna says: Even</b> if, after the slaughter and before the knife was examined, <b>he broke bones with</b> the knife <b>all day,</b> the slaughter is <b>not valid,</b> as <b>we are concerned that perhaps</b> the knife <b>became notched on the hide</b> of the neck. <b>And Rav Ḥisda says:</b> The slaughter is <b>valid,</b> as <b>perhaps</b> it was <b>on the bone</b> that he broke with the knife after the slaughter that <b>it became notched.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, Rav Huna</b> stated his opinion <b>in accordance with his <i>halakha</i></b> cited earlier (9a): An animal during its lifetime exists with the presumptive status of prohibition until it becomes known in what manner it was slaughtered. <b>But</b> as for <b>Rav Ḥisda, what is the reason</b> for his ruling that the slaughter is valid? The Gemara answers that Rav Ḥisda could have <b>said to you: A bone certainly notches</b> the knife, but with regard to <b>hide,</b> it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it <b>notches</b> the knife and <b>uncertain</b> whether it <b>does not notch</b> it. This <b>is</b> a case of <b>certainty and uncertainty, and</b> the principle is that <b>an uncertainty does not override a certainty.</b>
<b>Rava raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rav Ḥisda <b>to support</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna,</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one immersed and emerged</b> from the ritual bath <b>and an interposing item was</b> later <b>found on him,</b> then <b>even if he had been engaged in</b> handling <b>that same type</b> of item for <b>the entire day</b> after his immersion, <b>the immersion does not fulfill his</b> obligation. This is so <b>until he will say:</b> It is <b>clear to me that</b> this interposition <b>was not on me beforehand. And here</b> it is a case <b>where he certainly immersed,</b> and it is <b>uncertain</b> whether the interposition <b>was on him</b> at that time and <b>uncertain</b> whether it <b>was not on him, and</b> nevertheless, contrary to the opinion of Rav Ḥisda, the <b>uncertainty overrides</b> the <b>certainty.</b>
The Gemara rejects that proof: It <b>is different there, as it can be said: Establish</b> the status of <b>the impure</b> person <b>on</b> the basis of <b>his presumptive status</b> of impurity, <b>and say</b> that <b>he did not immerse</b> properly.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Here too, establish</b> the status of <b>the animal on</b> the basis of <b>its presumptive status</b> of prohibition <b>and say</b> that <b>it was not slaughtered</b> properly. Why does Rav Ḥisda rule that it is permitted? The Gemara explains: That status has been undermined, as the <b>slaughtered</b> animal <b>is before you.</b> There is no indication that the slaughter was not valid, and most slaughtered animals are slaughtered properly.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Here too,</b> in the case of immersion, the status of impurity is undermined, as the person who <b>has immersed</b> is <b>before you.</b> The Gemara explains: The case of immersion is different, as <b>a flaw developed in</b> the presumptive validity of the immersion, since there is an interposition.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Here too, a flaw developed in</b> the presumptive validity of slaughter, as the knife is notched. The Gemara explains: In the case of slaughter, <b>the knife became flawed,</b> but <b>the animal did not become flawed.</b> Therefore, the animal assumes the presumptive status of permissibility. By contrast, in the case of immersion, the interposition was found on the person, thereby nullifying his presumptive status of purity.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rav Ḥisda from a <i>baraita</i>: The slaughter of a bird is valid with the cutting of one <i>siman</i>, the windpipe or the gullet. Therefore, if <b>one cut the gullet, and the windpipe was displaced thereafter,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid.</b> If <b>the windpipe was displaced and one cut the gullet thereafter,</b> the slaughter is <b>not valid.</b>
If <b>one cut the gullet, and the windpipe was found displaced, and he does not know whether</b> the windpipe <b>was displaced before the slaughter</b> or <b>whether</b> it <b>was displaced after the slaughter; that was</b> the <b>incident</b> that came before the Sages, <b>and they said:</b> In <b>any</b> case of <b>uncertainty with regard to slaughter,</b> the slaughter is <b>not valid.</b>
The Gemara asks: With regard to the expansive formulation: With regard to <b>any</b> case of <b>uncertainty with regard to slaughter, what</b> does it serve <b>to add?</b> Does it <b>not</b> serve <b>to add a case like this</b> one where there is uncertainty whether the knife was notched before or after the slaughter? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it serves <b>to add</b> a case of <b>uncertainty</b> whether <b>he interrupted</b> the slaughter in the middle, or <b>uncertainty</b> whether <b>he pressed</b> the knife on the <i>simanim</i>. If he did either, it invalidates the slaughter.

Daf 10b

The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way is uncertainty whether he interrupted the slaughter or pressed the knife <b>different</b> from uncertainty whether the knife became notched before or after the slaughter? The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of uncertainty with regard to interruption or pressing, <b>the flaw developed in the animal,</b> and the slaughter is not valid. <b>Here,</b> in the case of uncertainty whether the knife became notched before or after the slaughter, <b>a flaw developed in the knife</b> but <b>a flaw did not develop in the animal,</b> and the slaughter is valid.
<b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Huna</b> that the slaughter is not valid in a case <b>where he did not break a bone with</b> the knife. <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda</b> that the slaughter is valid in a case <b>where he broke a bone with</b> the knife. Learn <b>by inference that Rav Ḥisda</b> rules that the slaughter is valid <b>even if he did not break a bone with</b> the knife. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if he did not break bones, <b>on what was</b> the knife <b>notched?</b> It must have been on the hide. Why, then, is the slaughter valid? The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that <b>it was notched on the neck bone</b> after he competed slaughtering the animal.
The Gemara relates: <b>There was an incident, and Rav Yosef deemed as many as thirteen animals <i>tereifot</i></b> when he discovered the knife was notched after slaughtering the final animal. The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Rav Yosef issue his ruling? Is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna,</b> who holds that the concern is that the knife was notched by the animal’s hide, <b>and</b> he ruled that <b>even the first</b> animal is forbidden? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> perhaps it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda,</b> who holds that the notch is attributed to the neck bone, <b>and</b> they are all forbidden <b>except for the first</b> animal.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Actually,</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, as, if</b> it were <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda, since we attribute</b> the notch to the neck bone as a leniency, <b>from where</b> is it ascertained <b>that</b> it is <b>on the neck bone of the first</b> animal that <b>it was notched? Perhaps</b> it is <b>on the neck bone of the last</b> animal that <b>it was notched,</b> and all of the animals are permitted.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: Rav Kahana requires an examination</b> of the knife <b>between each and every</b> act of slaughter. The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Rav Kahana issue his ruling? Is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, and</b> he stated the <i>halakha</i> <b>to invalidate</b> the slaughter of <b>the first</b> animal that he slaughtered if he discovers a notch in the knife? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> perhaps it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda,</b> according to the first of the two explanations of the ruling of Rav Yosef, who holds that if a notch is found it is attributed to the neck bone, <b>and</b> examination of the knife is required <b>to validate</b> the slaughter of <b>the next</b> animal.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>If so,</b> and the reference is to the examination before slaughter, the knife <b>should require the examination of a</b> Torah <b>scholar</b> that was required by the Sages. The Gemara explains: There is no need for a Sage to examine the knife, based on the principle: The testimony of <b>one witness,</b> in this case the slaughterer, <b>is deemed credible with regard to ritual matters.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>If so, even from the outset,</b> examination of the knife by a Torah scholar should <b>also not</b> be required. The Gemara explains: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that the Sages <b>said to show</b> the <b>knife to a</b> Torah <b>scholar only due to</b> the requirement to show <b>deference to the Sage?</b> Once deference was shown before the initial slaughter, it is no longer necessary to do so.
§ Apropos the statement of Rav Huna that an animal during its lifetime exists with the presumptive status of prohibition, and therefore in cases of uncertainty whether the animal was properly slaughtered, one rules stringently and it is prohibited to eat its flesh, the Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter that the Sages said: Establish</b> the status of <b>the matter on</b> the basis of <b>its presumptive status,</b> derived?
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said</b> that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to leprosy of houses that after a priest views a leprous mark: <b>“And the priest shall emerge from the house to the entrance of the house, and quarantine the house seven days”</b> (Leviticus 14:38). The Gemara asks: How can the priest quarantine the house based on his viewing the leprous mark? <b>Perhaps as he was emerging and coming</b> out of the house, the size of the leprous mark diminished and <b>it lacks</b> the requisite <b>measure</b> for leprosy. <b>Rather, is it not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Establish</b> the status of <b>the matter on</b> the basis of <b>its presumptive status?</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov objects to</b> that proof: <b>And perhaps</b> the verse is referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>emerged backward, as</b> in that case, the priest <b>sees</b> the leprous mark <b>as he emerges.</b>
<b>Abaye said to him</b> that there are <b>two refutations of</b> that <b>statement. One</b> is <b>that emerging backward is not called emerging,</b> and the priest would not fulfill the verse “And the priest shall emerge from the house” by doing so. <b>And furthermore,</b> in a case where the leprous mark is <b>behind the door, what is there to say?</b> Even walking backward would not enable the priest to see it. <b>And if you would say that</b> the priest can <b>open a window in</b> the wall to enable him to see the leprous mark, <b>but didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 2:3): <b>In a dark house one may not open windows</b> to enable him <b>to see his leprous mark?</b>
<b>Rava said to</b> Abaye: With regard to <b>that which you say: Emerging backward is not called emerging,</b> the case of the <b>High Priest on Yom Kippur will prove</b> that this is not so, <b>as emerging is written in his</b> regard (see Leviticus 16:18), <b>and we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Yoma</i> 52b): The High Priest <b>emerged and came</b> out backward in the <b>manner of his entry,</b> facing the Ark in the Holy of Holies. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which you say: In a dark house, one may not open windows</b> to enable him <b>to see his leprous mark, this statement</b> applies only in a case <b>where</b> the existence of a leprous mark in the house <b>was not</b> yet <b>established;</b> but in a case <b>where</b> the existence of a leprous mark in the house <b>was</b> already <b>established, it was established,</b> and the priest may open a window to view it.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov,</b> who suggested that the verse is referring to a case where the priest emerged from the house backward and therefore there is no proof that one lets the matter remain in its presumptive status. It is written: <b>“And the priest shall emerge from the house</b> to the entrance of the house and quarantine the house.” One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>he may go into his</b> own <b>house and quarantine</b> the house from there; therefore, <b>the verse states: “To the entrance of the house,”</b> referring to the house that is being quarantined.
<b>If</b> he must emerge to <b>the entrance of the house,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>he may stand beneath the lintel and quarantine</b> the house; therefore, <b>the verse states: “From the house,”</b> indicating that he does not quarantine the house <b>until he emerges from the house in its entirety. How so? He stands alongside the lintel and quarantines</b> the house.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that if he went inside his</b> own <b>house and quarantined</b> the leprous house, <b>or that</b> if <b>he stood inside the</b> leprous <b>house and quarantined</b> it, <b>that his quarantine is</b> a valid <b>quarantine?</b> It is derived from that which <b>the verse states: “And quarantine the house,”</b> meaning <b>in any case.</b> Apparently, the quarantine is valid even if he is unable to see the leprous mark, as the mark remains in its previous presumptive status.
<b>And Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov</b> interprets the <i>baraita</i> in accordance with his opinion

Daf 11a

in a case <b>where</b> there is <b>a row of standing men,</b> from the house to be quarantined to the priest’s house, <b>and they</b> each <b>say</b> to the one standing next to him that the leprous mark <b>remains standing</b> unaltered.
§ After discussing the role of presumptive status in determining <i>halakha</i>, the Gemara discusses the role of the majority. <b>From where is this matter that the Sages stated: Follow the majority,</b> derived? The Gemara is surprised at the question: <b>From where do we</b> derive it? Obviously, it is derived from a verse, <b>as it is written</b> explicitly: <b>“After the majority to incline”</b> (Exodus 23:2).
The Gemara explains: With regard to <b>a majority that is</b> quantifiable <b>before us, for example,</b> in the case of a piece of meat that was found on the street before ten shops, <b>nine shops</b> selling kosher meat and one shop selling non-kosher meat, one follows the majority and deems that piece kosher. <b>Or</b> when the <b>Sanhedrin</b> adjudicates a case, one follows a majority of the judges in determining the ruling. In these cases, <b>we do not raise the dilemma.</b>
<b>When the dilemma is raised to us</b> it is in the case of <b>a majority that is not</b> quantifiable <b>before us, for example,</b> the case of <b>a minor boy and a minor girl.</b> If the boy entered into levirate marriage with the girl, it is permitted for them to remain married, and there is no concern that when they grow older it will be discovered that the boy or the girl never develop sexually. Rather, one follows the majority, that minors develop sexually at puberty. It is with regard to that non-quantifiable majority that the Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive it?
<b>Rabbi Elazar said</b> an answer to this question. Before presenting his answer, the Gemara cites <b>a mnemonic</b> for the names of the Sages who address this question: <b><i>Zayin</i>,</b> Rabbi Elazar; <b><i>mem</i>,</b> Mar, son of Ravina; <b><i>nun</i>,</b> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak; <b><i>shin</i>,</b> Rav Sheshet; <b><i>beit</i>,</b> Rabba bar Rav Sheila; <b><i>ḥet</i>,</b> Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov; <b><i>mem</i>,</b> Rav Mari; <b><i>kaf</i>,</b> Rav Kahana; <b><i>nun</i>,</b> Ravina; <b><i>shin</i>,</b> Rav Ashi.
Rabbi Elazar’s answer was as follows: It is <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>the head of a burnt offering,</b> that one severs it from the animal’s body but does not cut it into smaller pieces, <b>as the verse states:</b> “And he shall flay the burnt offering <b>and cut it into its pieces”</b> (Leviticus 1:6), and it is inferred: The animal is cut <b>into its pieces, but its pieces,</b> including its head, are <b>not</b> cut <b>into pieces.</b> Rabbi Elazar suggested: <b>And</b> since the head is not cut and cannot be examined, <b>let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps the brain membrane was perforated,</b> which would render the animal a <i>tereifa</i> and unfit for sacrifice. <b>Rather,</b> is the reason we are not concerned for this <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Follow the majority</b> of animals, which are not <i>tereifot</i>?
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is that conclusion drawn? <b>Perhaps</b> the reference is to a case <b>where one splits</b> the head open <b>and examines</b> the brain membrane. <b>And if</b> that could not be <b>due to</b> the inference: The animal is cut <b>into its pieces, but its pieces</b> are <b>not</b> cut <b>into pieces, that statement</b> applies in a case <b>where one cuts</b> the head <b>completely</b> in half. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where</b> the sides of the head remain <b>joined, we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b> Therefore, no proof can be cited from here.
<b>Mar, son of Ravina, said:</b> The fact that we follow a non-quantifiable majority is <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the breaking of a bone in the Paschal offering, as the Merciful One states: “Nor shall you break a bone thereof”</b> (Exodus 12:46). Mar, son of Ravina, suggested: <b>And let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps the brain membrane was perforated</b> and the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, as it is impossible to examine its brain membrane since one may not break its bones. <b>Rather, is</b> the reason we are not concerned for this <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Follow the majority</b> of animals, which are not <i>tereifot</i>?
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is that conclusion drawn? <b>Perhaps</b> the reference is to a case <b>where one places a coal on the head and burns</b> through the head, exposing the brain membrane, <b>and</b> then <b>examines it, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who cuts the sinews or burns the bones</b> of the Paschal offering <b>is not subject to</b> lashes <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b>breaking bones.</b> Therefore, no proof can be cited from here either.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> It is <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>tail</b> of a lamb brought as a peace offering, with regard to <b>which the Merciful One states:</b> “And he shall sacrifice of the peace offering…<b>the fat tail whole,</b> which he shall remove opposite the rump bone” (Leviticus 3:9), meaning that the tail must remain intact and may not be cut. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak suggested: <b>And let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the segment of <b>the spinal column</b> in the tail <b>was severed</b> prior to slaughter, rendering the animal a <i>tereifa</i> and unfit for sacrifice. <b>Rather, is</b> the reason we are not concerned for this <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Follow the majority</b> of animals, which are not <i>tereifot</i>?
<b>And if you would say</b> in rejection of that proof <b>that one severs</b> the tail <b>from below</b> the spine, in a place that would not render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>the Merciful One states: “Opposite the rump bone [<i>he’atze</i>],” the place where the kidneys advise [<i>yo’atzot</i>],</b> This is a location where severing the spinal column renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. Consequently, the proof that the majority is followed remains intact.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is that conclusion drawn? <b>Perhaps</b> the reference is to a case <b>where one splits</b> the tail <b>and examines</b> the spinal column. <b>And if</b> that could not be, <b>due to</b> the requirement that the fat tail remain <b>“whole,” that statement</b> applies in a case <b>where one cuts</b> the tail <b>completely</b> in half. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where</b> the sides of the tail remain <b>joined, we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b> Therefore, no proof can be cited from here.
<b>Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> The principle of following a non-quantifiable majority is <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>heifer whose neck is broken</b> when a person is found killed in an area that is between two cities and the murderer is unknown (Deuteronomy 21:1–9). <b>As the Merciful One states:</b> “And all the elders of that city…shall wash their hands over the heifer <b>whose neck was broken,</b> in the valley” (Deuteronomy 21:6), from which it is inferred: Other than its neck being broken, the heifer <b>should remain</b> in a state <b>where it is whole. And</b> if one does not follow the majority, <b>let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the animal <b>is a <i>tereifa</i>. Rather, is</b> the reason we are not concerned for this <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Follow the majority</b> of animals, which are not <i>tereifot</i>?
<b>And if you would say</b> in rejection of that proof that there is no need for an examination, as <b>what difference is</b> there whether it is a <i>tereifa</i>, since it is neither eaten nor sacrificed, <b>didn’t they say</b> in <b>the school of Rabbi Yannai:</b> A term of <b>atonement is written in its</b> regard (see Deuteronomy 21:8), indicating that the halakhic status of the heifer whose neck is broken is <b>like</b> that of <b>sacrificial</b> animals, and a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for use in that ritual?
<b>Rabba bar Rav Sheila said:</b> The principle of following an unquantifiable majority is <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>red heifer,</b> with regard to <b>which the Merciful One states: “And he shall slaughter…and he shall burn”</b> (Numbers 19:3, 5), from which it is derived: <b>Just as its slaughter</b> is performed <b>when it is whole, so too its burning</b> is performed <b>when it is whole. And</b> if the majority is not followed, <b>let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the animal <b>is a <i>tereifa</i>. Rather, is</b> the reason we are not concerned for this <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Follow the majority</b> of animals, which are not <i>tereifot</i>?
<b>And if you would say</b> in rejection of that proof that there is no need for an examination, as <b>what difference is</b> there whether it is a <i>tereifa</i>, since it is neither eaten nor sacrificed, <b>the Merciful One called it <i>ḥatat</i>,</b> meaning purification, just as a sin offering is called <i>ḥatat</i>, indicating that in both cases a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said:</b> The fact that one follows a non-quantifiable majority is <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>scapegoat,</b> with regard to <b>which the Merciful One says: “And he shall take the two goats…</b>one lot for the Lord and one lot for Azazel” (Leviticus 16:7–8). From the fact that the verse mentions the two goats together, the Sages inferred <b>that the two</b> goats <b>should be equal. But</b> how can it be ascertained that they are equal; <b>let us be concerned</b>

Daf 11b

that <b>perhaps one of</b> the animals, the scapegoat, <b>is a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> Since it is not slaughtered, but is rather cast from a cliff while alive, there is no way to ascertain that it is not a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rather, is</b> the reason we are not concerned for this <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Follow the majority</b> of animals, which are not <i>tereifot</i>?
<b>And if you would</b> seek to reject that proof and <b>say</b> that there is no need for an examination, as <b>what</b> practical <b>difference is there to us</b> whether it is a <i>tereifa</i>, since it is neither eaten nor sacrificed, and the two goats are fit after the fact even if they are not equal (see <i>Yoma</i> 62a); <b>doesn’t the lot determine</b> the goat <b>for Azazel only with regard to an item,</b> a goat, <b>that is fit</b> for sacrifice <b>to the Lord? And if you would say that we examine</b> the goat after it is cast from the cliff and do not rely on a majority, <b>but didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Yoma</i> 67a): The goat <b>did not reach halfway</b> down <b>the mountain until it was</b> torn <b>limb</b> from <b>limb.</b>
<b>Rav Mari said:</b> The fact that one follows a non-quantifiable majority is <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>one who strikes his father or his mother,</b> with regard to <b>whom the Merciful One states: Kill him</b> (see Exodus 21:15). Rav Mari clarifies: <b>But let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the man that he struck <b>is not</b> actually <b>his father. Rather, is</b> the reason we are not concerned for this <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Follow the majority, and the majority of</b> acts of <b>intercourse</b> performed by a married woman <b>are attributable to the husband.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is that conclusion drawn? <b>Perhaps</b> the reference is to a case <b>where</b> at the time he was conceived <b>his mother and father were incarcerated</b> together <b>in prison.</b> Therefore, the fact that it was his father that he struck is based on certainty, not a majority. The Gemara answers: <b>Even so, there is no steward [<i>apotropos</i>] for</b> restraining <b>sexual immorality,</b> and the identity of his father is not based on certainty.
<b>Rav Kahana said:</b> It is <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>one who kills</b> another <b>person,</b> with regard to <b>whom the Merciful One states: Kill him</b> (see Exodus 21:12). Rav Kahana clarifies: <b>And let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the person that he killed <b>was a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> one who has a wound or condition that will lead to his death within twelve months. One who kills a <i>tereifa</i> is exempt from capital punishment because in that sense, the halakhic status of a <i>tereifa</i> is that of a dead person. <b>Rather, is</b> the reason we are not concerned for this <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Follow the majority</b> of people, who are not <i>tereifot</i>?
<b>And if you would</b> seek to reject that proof and <b>say that we examine</b> the corpse to determine whether he was a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>wouldn’t</b> the corpse be <b>mutilated</b> through that examination? <b>And if you would say</b> that <b>due to</b> concern for the possibility of an unjustified <b>loss of life of that</b> murderer, <b>we will mutilate</b> the corpse to determine whether the victim was a <i>tereifa</i>, it would remain necessary to rely on the majority, as <b>let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps there was a perforation in the place</b> that he stabbed the victim with the <b>sword.</b>
<b>Ravina said:</b> It is <b>derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>conspiring witnesses,</b> with regard to <b>whom the Merciful One states: “And you shall do unto him as he had conspired</b> to do unto his brother” (Deuteronomy 19:19). If the witnesses testified falsely that a person is guilty of a capital offense, they are liable to receive the death penalty. <b>And let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps that</b> person <b>against whom they testified was a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> and they should not be executed for conspiring to have a <i>tereifa</i> executed. <b>Rather, is</b> the reason we are not concerned for this <b>not due to</b> the fact <b>that we say: Follow the majority</b> of people, who are not <i>tereifot</i>?
