When they entered into Eretz</b> Yisrael, the <b>meat of stabbing was forbidden to them,</b> and it was permitted to eat the meat of an animal only after valid slaughter.
Rav Yosef added: <b>And now that</b> the Jewish people <b>were exiled, might</b> one have thought that stabbed animals <b>are restored to their initial permitted</b> state? <b>Therefore, we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One</b> must <b>always slaughter</b> the animal to eat its meat.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Akiva holds:</b> The <b>meat of desire was not forbidden at all, and Rabbi Yishmael holds:</b> The <b>meat of stabbing was not permitted at all.</b>
The Gemara asks a series of questions: <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Yishmael,</b> who holds that the meat of stabbing was forbidden in the wilderness, <b>that is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written</b> with regard to the burnt offerings sacrificed in the Tabernacle: <b>“And he shall slaughter the young bull”</b> (Leviticus 1:5). <b>But according to Rabbi Akiva, what</b> is the meaning of: <b>“And he shall slaughter”?</b> Why would he slaughter it if stabbing is permitted? The Gemara answers: <b>Sacrificial</b> animals <b>are different,</b> as slaughter is required in that case. By contrast, there was no obligation to slaughter non-sacrificial animals to eat their meat.
<b>Granted, according to Rabbi Yishmael,</b> who holds that the meat of stabbing was forbidden in the wilderness, <b>that is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “Will flocks and herds be slaughtered for them”</b> (Numbers 11:22), indicating that they slaughtered the animals in the wilderness. <b>But according to Rabbi Akiva, what</b> is the meaning of: <b>“Will flocks and herds be slaughtered for them”?</b> Ostensibly, the words: <b>Be stabbed for them, should have</b> been written. The Gemara answers: In the wilderness, <b>their stabbing is their slaughter.</b>
<b>Granted, according to Rabbi Yishmael, that is</b> the meaning of that <b>which we learned</b> in a mishna (85a) with regard to the mitzva of covering the blood of an undomesticated animal or a bird: <b>One who slaughters</b> an undomesticated animal and the slaughter is not valid <b>and it became an unslaughtered carcass by his hand, and one who stabs</b> an animal, <b>and one who rips</b> the <i>simanim</i> from their place before cutting them, invalidating the slaughter, is <b>exempt from covering</b> the blood. One must cover the blood of only an animal whose slaughter was valid. <b>But according to Rabbi Akiva, why is one exempt from covering</b> the blood of an animal that was stabbed, since in his opinion when they were commanded to cover blood, animals that were stabbed were permitted?
The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the meat of stabbing <b>was forbidden, it was forbidden,</b> and the halakhic status of stabbing is no longer that of slaughtering.
<b>Granted, according to Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that the <b>meat of desire was not forbidden at all, that is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written</b> before they entered Eretz Yisrael: <b>“However, as the gazelle and as the deer is eaten, so shall you eat of it,</b> the pure and the impure may eat of it alike” (Deuteronomy 12:22). This means that just as it is permitted to eat the meat of a gazelle and a deer in the wilderness in a state of ritual impurity, so may you eat them when you enter Eretz Yisrael, although at that point it will be prohibited to stab them and eat their meat, as their meat will be permitted only through slaughter. <b>But according to Rabbi Yishmael,</b> who holds that the meat of desire was forbidden in the wilderness, <b>were the gazelle and the deer themselves permitted</b> in the wilderness? They are not brought as offerings.
The Gemara answers: <b>When the Merciful One rendered</b> the meat of desire <b>forbidden,</b> that was specifically the meat of <b>a domesticated animal that is fit for sacrifice. But the Merciful One did not render forbidden undomesticated animals that are not fit for sacrifice.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma</b> according to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, who says that the meat of stabbing was permitted in the wilderness: With regard to <b>the limbs of</b> the <b>meat of stabbing that the Jewish people took with them into Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>what is</b> their halakhic status?
The Gemara asks: <b>When?</b> With regard to what period does Rabbi Yirmeya raise his dilemma? <b>If we say</b> that the dilemma is <b>with regard to</b> the <b>seven</b> years during <b>which they conquered</b> the land, <b>now, non-kosher items were permitted for them</b> during that period, <b>as it is written:</b> “And it shall be, when the Lord your God shall bring you into the land that He swore to your fathers, <b>and houses full of all good things…</b>and you shall eat and be satisfied” (Deuteronomy 6:10–11), <b>and Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rav says: Cuts of pig</b> meat <b>[<i>kotlei daḥazirei</i>]</b> that they found in the houses were permitted for them; is it <b>necessary</b> to say that the <b>meat</b> from the <b>stabbing</b> of a kosher animal was permitted?
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yirmeya’s dilemma is with regard to the period <b>thereafter. And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Actually,</b> his dilemma is <b>with regard to</b> the <b>seven</b> years during <b>which they conquered</b> the land, as perhaps <b>when</b> the forbidden food <b>was permitted for them,</b> it was specifically food from <b>the spoils of gentiles,</b> but <b>their own</b> forbidden food <b>was not permitted.</b> The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>Rabba says: You explained</b> the phrases in the mishna: <b>All slaughter, and: One may always slaughter.</b> In <b>what</b> way <b>do you explain</b> the phrase: <b>One may slaughter with any</b> item that cuts?
<b>And if you would say</b> that it means: <b>Whether with a flint, or with glass</b> shards, <b>or with the stalk of a reed, but isn’t</b> this phrase <b>taught</b> in a manner <b>similar to those</b> other phrases in the mishna? <b>If these</b> phrases: All slaughter, and: One may always slaughter, are referring <b>to those that slaughter, this</b> phrase <b>too</b> is referring <b>to those that slaughter; and if those</b> phrases are referring <b>to those that are slaughtered, this</b> phrase <b>too</b> is referring <b>to those that are slaughtered.</b> The first two phrases in the mishna were explained as referring to the animals that are slaughtered. The first phrase was interpreted to include birds, and the second phrase was interpreted as referring to the <i>halakha</i> that meat may be eaten only through slaughter of the animal.
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that the entire mishna is referring to those that slaughter. The initial phrase means <b>everyone [<i>hakkol</i>] slaughters.</b> Although an identical phrase was used in the first mishna (2a), both are necessary: <b>One is to include a Samaritan and one is to include a Jewish transgressor.</b> The second phrase: <b>One may always slaughter,</b> means <b>both during the day and at night, both on a rooftop and atop a ship,</b> and there is no concern that it will appear that he is slaughtering in an idolatrous manner to the hosts of heaven or to the god of the sea. The phrase: <b>One may slaughter with any</b> item that cuts, means: <b>Whether with a flint, or with glass</b> shards, <b>or with the stalk of a reed.</b>
The mishna states: <b>Except for</b> the serrated side of <b>the harvest sickle, and the saw. Shmuel’s father</b> would <b>notch</b> a knife <b>and send</b> it to Eretz Yisrael to ask if it is fit for slaughter, and would <b>notch</b> a knife in a different manner <b>and send</b> it to Eretz Yisrael in order to determine the type of notch that invalidates slaughter. <b>They sent to him</b> from Eretz Yisrael that the principle is: <b>We learned</b> that the notch that invalidates slaughter is <b>like a saw,</b> whose teeth point upward, as it rips the <i>simanim</i> with every draw of the knife back and forth.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 17b

The status of <b>a knife in which there are several notches is considered like</b> that of <b>a saw; and</b> with regard to a knife <b>in which there is only one notch,</b> if it <b>catches,</b> the slaughter is <b>unfit,</b> but if it <b>entangles [<i>mesukhsekhet</i>],</b> the slaughter is <b>fit. What are the circumstances</b> of a notch that <b>catches,</b> and <b>what are the circumstances</b> of a notch that <b>entangles? Rabbi Eliezer said:</b> A notch that <b>catches</b> is one that has a sharp edge <b>on two sides,</b> while a notch that <b>entangles</b> is one that has a sharp edge <b>on one side.</b>
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>What is different</b> about a notch with a sharp edge <b>on two sides, where the first edge [<i>moresha</i>] compromises</b> the neck by removing the hide and the flesh, <b>and the latter edge rips</b> the <i>simanim</i>; in the case of a notch with a sharp edge <b>on one side too, the sharp</b> tip <b>of the knife compromises</b> the neck and <b>the edge</b> of the notch <b>rips</b> the <i>simanim</i>. The Gemara explains: The reference is to a notch <b>that stands at the top of the knife,</b> which begins the slaughter. The Gemara objects: <b>Ultimately, when</b> the knife <b>goes</b> in one direction <b>it compromises</b> the neck and <b>when it comes</b> back in the other direction <b>it rips</b> the <i>simanim</i>. The Gemara explains: The reference is to a case <b>where he drew the knife backward and did not draw it forward.</b>
<b>Rava says:</b> There are <b>three types</b> of notches <b>in a knife.</b> If the notch <b>catches, one may not slaughter</b> with it, <b>and if he slaughtered, his slaughter is not valid.</b> If the notch <b>entangles, one may not slaughter with it <i>ab initio</i>; and if he slaughtered</b> with it, <b>his slaughter is valid</b> after the fact. If the notch <b>rises and falls in</b> the <b>knife</b> and has no sharp edges, <b>one may slaughter with it <i>ab initio</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Neḥemya, said to Rav Ashi: You said to us in the name of Rava</b> that if the notch <b>entangles,</b> the slaughter is <b>not valid. But doesn’t Rava say:</b> If the notch <b>entangles,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid?</b> Rav Ashi answers: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where Rava says that the slaughter is not valid, is in a case <b>where he drew the knife back and forth. There,</b> where Rava says that the slaughter is valid, is in a case <b>where he drew the knife backward and did not draw it forward.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Ashi:</b> If the knife was <b>similar to an awn</b> of grain <b>[<i>sasa</i>],</b> which is not perfectly smooth but does not have actual notches, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Who will give us from the meat of</b> an animal slaughtered with that knife, <b>and we will eat</b> it.
§ <b>Rav Ḥisda says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that examination of a knife</b> is an obligation <b>by Torah law?</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to Saul’s instructions to the people: <b>“And slaughter with this and eat”</b> (I Samuel 14:34), indicating that Saul gave them the knife only after ensuring that it was fit to slaughter their animals.
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that a knife must be examined before slaughter? <b>Since were one to create a perforation</b> in the gullet, the animal would be a <b><i>tereifa</i>,</b> therefore the knife <b>requires examination</b> to prevent that situation. The Gemara answers: <b>We are saying</b> that a source for the <i>halakha</i> that one must show the knife <b>to</b> a Torah <b>scholar</b> for examination is needed. The Gemara asks: Is that an obligation by Torah law? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that the Sages <b>said to show</b> the <b>knife to</b> a Torah <b>scholar only due to</b> the requirement to show <b>deference to</b> the Torah <b>scholar?</b> The Gemara answers: Indeed, it is a requirement <b>by rabbinic law, and the verse is</b> cited as <b>a mere support</b> for that practice, not as a source.
The Gemara notes: <b>In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they examine</b> the knife <b>in the sun</b> to determine whether there is a notch. <b>In Neharde’a they examine</b> the knife <b>with water.</b> They would place the blade on the surface of the water, and if there was a notch, it would noticeably alter the surface of the water. <b>Rav Sheshet would examine it with the tip of his tongue. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov would examine it with a strand of hair.</b> He would pass the strand over the blade of the knife and if there was a notch, it would be caught in that notch.
<b>In Sura they say:</b> The knife <b>consumes the flesh; let the flesh examine</b> the knife. Since the concern is that the knife will rip the flesh during the slaughter, it should be examined by passing it on the tongue or the fingertip. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The knife <b>requires examination on the flesh, and on the fingernail, and on the three sides</b> of the knife, i.e., the blade and the two sides of the knife.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Rav Sama, son of Rav Mesharshiyya, said to us in your name that</b> which <b>you said to him in the name of Rava:</b> The knife <b>requires examination on the flesh, and on the fingernail, and on the three sides.</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Ravina: <b>On the flesh and on the fingernail I said, and on the three sides I did not say. There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Rav Ashi said to him: <b>On the flesh and on the fingernail and on the three sides I said,</b> and <b>in the name of Rava I did not say.</b>
<b>Ravina and Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, were sitting before Rav Ashi.</b> People <b>brought a knife before Rav Ashi to examine it.</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to Rav Aḥa, son of Rava: Examine it. He examined it on the fingernail, and on the flesh, and on the three sides.</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Well done, and Rav Kahana likewise said</b> that this is the way to examine a knife.
<b>Rav Yeimar said:</b> Examination <b>on the fingernail and on the flesh is necessary,</b> and examination <b>on the three sides is not necessary. Doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> If <b>one heated a knife until</b> it became <b>white hot and slaughtered</b> an animal <b>with it, his slaughter is valid, as its sharp</b> blade <b>preceded</b> the effect of <b>its white heat; and</b> it is <b>difficult for us: But aren’t there</b> the <b>sides</b> of the knife, which burn the throat and render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>? <b>And we say: The area of the slaughter</b> in the throat <b>separates</b> quickly after the incision, and the tissue on either side of the incision is not seared by the white hot blade. <b>Here too, the area of slaughter separates</b> quickly, and notches on the side of the knife do not come in contact with the <i>simanim</i>.
§ <b>Rav Huna bar Rav Ketina says</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says</b> that <b>there are three deficiencies</b> with the same measure, as follows: <b>The deficiency of a bone in the Paschal offering,</b> with regard to which it is written: “Neither shall you break a bone therein” (Exodus 12:46); <b>the deficiency of an ear in a firstborn</b> animal that renders it blemished and unfit for sacrifice, in which case a priest may slaughter it anywhere and eat it; and <b>the deficiency</b> that constitutes <b>a blemish in</b> other forms of <b>sacrificial</b> animals.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda says:</b> There is <b>the deficiency of a knife as well.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>amora</i>, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, why does he not include the knife? The Gemara answers: He does not include it because <b>he is not speaking with regard to non-sacred</b> animals.
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish continues: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of</b> these deficiencies, <b>the measure of their deficiency</b> is <b>equivalent to</b> the measure of <b>deficiency</b> that renders <b>the altar</b> unfit.

Daf 18a

<b>And how much</b> is <b>the deficiency</b> that renders <b>the altar</b> unfit? It is a deficiency that is <b>sufficient for a fingernail to be impeded on it.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How much</b> is <b>the deficiency</b> that renders <b>the altar</b> unfit? <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says:</b> One <b>handbreadth. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> One <b>olive-bulk.</b> The Gemara answers: This apparent contradiction is <b>not difficult. This</b> measure of one handbreadth or one olive-bulk is referring to a deficiency <b>in the limestone</b> coating of the altar; <b>that</b> smaller measure of a fingernail being caught is referring to a deficiency <b>in the stone</b> of the altar.
§ Apropos the obligation to show the knife to a Torah scholar, <b>Rav Huna says: This slaughterer who did not present [<i>sar</i>] the knife before</b> a Torah <b>scholar, we ostracize him. And Rava says: We remove him</b> from his position <b>and we proclaim about meat</b> from an animal <b>that he</b> slaughtered <b>that it is <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And they do not disagree. Here,</b> where Rav Huna says that he is ostracized, it is <b>in</b> a case <b>where his knife was discovered intact,</b> and he is ostracized for treating the scholar with contempt. <b>There,</b> where Rava says that his slaughter is proclaimed <i>tereifa</i>, it is <b>in</b> a case <b>where his knife was discovered not intact,</b> as in that case the meat from all animals that he slaughtered is suspect. <b>Ravina said:</b> In a case <b>where his knife was discovered not</b> to be <b>intact, one spreads excrement on</b> the flesh so <b>that even to a gentile it</b> will <b>not be sold.</b>
There was <b>a certain slaughterer who did not present his knife before Rava bar Ḥinnana.</b> Rava bar Ḥinnana <b>ostracized him, and removed him</b> from his position, <b>and proclaimed about meat</b> from an animal <b>that he</b> slaughtered <b>that it is <i>tereifa</i>. Mar Zutra and Rav Ashi happened before</b> Rava bar Ḥinnana in his place of residence. Rava bar Ḥinnana <b>said to them: Let the Sages examine the matter of</b> the slaughterer, <b>as small children are dependent upon him.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi examined his knife and it was discovered intact, and he deemed</b> his meat <b>fit</b> for consumption. <b>Mar Zutra said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>And shouldn’t the Master be concerned for</b> the honor of <b>the elder,</b> Rava bar Ḥinnana, who removed him from his position and you restored him? Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Mar Zutra: <b>We are carrying out his agency,</b> as he requested that we examine the matter of the slaughterer.
§ <b>Rabba bar Huna says: With a detached tooth and a detached fingernail, it is permitted to slaughter <i>ab initio</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna (15b): <b>Except for the harvest sickle, and the saw, and the teeth, and the fingernail, because they strangle?</b>
The Gemara answers that the contradiction between this statement with regard to <b>a tooth and</b> that statement with regard to <b>a tooth</b> is <b>not difficult: This</b> statement of Rava bar Huna that one may slaughter with a tooth is referring to slaughter <b>with one</b> tooth. <b>That</b> mishna that prohibits slaughter with teeth is referring to slaughter <b>with two</b> teeth, as due to the gap between them they rip the <i>simanim</i>. The contradiction between the statement with regard to <b>a fingernail and</b> the statement with regard to <b>a fingernail</b> is <b>not difficult: This</b> statement of Rava bar Huna that one may slaughter with a fingernail is referring to slaughter <b>with a detached</b> fingernail. <b>That</b> mishna that prohibits slaughter with a fingernail is referring to slaughter <b>with an attached</b> fingernail, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi (15b), who invalidates slaughter performed with an item attached to the ground or a living animal.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal <b>with a harvest sickle,</b> which is serrated with its teeth inclined considerably in one direction, <b>in a forward direction,</b> where the serrations do not tear the flesh, <b>Beit Shammai deem</b> the slaughter <b>not valid and Beit Hillel deem</b> it <b>valid. And</b> they both agree that <b>if they smoothed its serrations</b> so that they do not tear the flesh, its halakhic status <b>is like</b> that of <b>a knife</b> and one may slaughter with it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even when Beit Hillel deemed</b> the slaughter <b>valid, they deemed</b> it <b>valid only to purify it from</b> the ritual impurity of <b>an unslaughtered carcass; but its consumption is prohibited. Rav Ashi said:</b> The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches: Beit Shammai deem</b> the slaughter <b>not valid and Beit Hillel deem</b> it <b>valid, and he does not teach: Beit Shammai prohibit and Beit Hillel permit</b> its consumption. The Gemara objects: <b>But according to your reasoning, let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach: Beit Shammai deem</b> the carcass <b>ritually impure and Beit Hillel deem</b> it <b>ritually pure. Rather,</b> the terms <b>deem</b> it <b>not valid and deem</b> it <b>valid and</b> the terms <b>prohibit and permit are</b> all <b>one matter,</b> and no inferences may be drawn from that phrasing.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal <b>from within the</b> cricoid cartilage that forms a complete <b>ring</b> at the top of the windpipe <b>and left a thread breadth over the surface of</b> the ring in <b>its entirety</b> intact, as the knife did not go beyond the ring toward the head of the animal, <b>his slaughter is valid. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> It is valid even if he left <b>a thread breadth over the majority of the surface of</b> the ring.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> It is <b>Rav and Shmuel who both say:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. And even Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says</b> his statement <b>only with regard to the large</b> upper <b>ring, since it encircles the entire windpipe, but with regard to the rest of the rings,</b> which are incomplete and where a strip of flesh connects their edges, he did <b>not</b> state his <i>halakha</i>. Therefore, his slaughter is not valid, as he is required to slaughter in the space between those rings and not in the rings themselves.
The Gemara objects: <b>And with regard to the rest of the rings,</b> Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, did <b>not</b> state his <i>halakha</i>; <b>but isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b>

Daf 18b

With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> from <b>within the rest of the rings, even though they do not encircle the entire windpipe, since they encircle the majority of the windpipe his slaughter is valid.</b> The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And</b> in a case where the knife <b>is diverted</b> from the place of slaughter above the ring, the slaughter is <b>not valid. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus testified about</b> a case where the knife <b>is diverted</b> from the area of slaughter above the ring <b>that</b> in such a case the slaughter is <b>valid.</b> Contrary to that which Rav and Shmuel said with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, he holds that slaughter from within the other rings is valid.
<b>Rav Yosef said: Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda is saying two</b> statements; <b>Rav and Shmuel hold in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>with regard to one</b> matter, that if one cuts a majority of the windpipe within the large ring the slaughter is valid, <b>and disagree with him with regard to one</b> matter, as in their opinion if one cuts the windpipe within the other rings, the slaughter is not valid.
The Gemara objects: <b>But didn’t</b> Rav and Shmuel <b>say:</b> And even Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>said</b> his statement <b>only</b> with regard to the large upper ring and not with regard to the other rings, indicating that in their opinion, this is the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda? The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what Rav and Shmuel are <b>saying:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>with regard to</b> cutting the majority of the windpipe within <b>the large ring, and</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>with regard to</b> the <b>other rings</b> that since they encircle a majority of the windpipe, one may slaughter within them as well.
<b>When Rabbi Zeira ascended</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he ate</b> meat from an animal during whose slaughter the knife was <b>diverted</b> from the place of slaughter, with regard to <b>which Rav and Shmuel</b> ruled that the slaughter is not valid, and in Eretz Yisrael the ruling was that the slaughter is valid. The Torah scholars in Eretz Yisrael <b>said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: <b>Aren’t you from</b> Babylonia, <b>the place where Rav and Shmuel</b> are the halakhic authorities? You should follow their ruling. Rabbi Zeira <b>said to them: Who said</b> this <i>halakha</i> citing Rav and Shmuel? It was <b>Yosef bar Ḥiyya,</b> referring to Rav Yosef. <b>Yosef bar Ḥiyya learns from everyone,</b> even from students of Rav and Shmuel who misquote their statements.
<b>Rav Yosef heard</b> the comment of Rabbi Zeira and <b>was angry. He said:</b> Do <b>I learn from everyone? I learn from Rav Yehuda,</b> who is so meticulous in citing the statements of Rav and Shmuel <b>that he cites even uncertainties</b> with regard to attribution of statements <b>to the men</b> who said them. <b>As Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says,</b> and it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it is <b>in the name of Rav</b> and <b>uncertain</b> whether it is <b>in the name of Shmuel:</b> A tribunal of <b>three permits</b> slaughter of a blemished <b>firstborn</b> animal outside of the Temple <b>in a place where there is no expert</b> Sage to consult.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Zeira not accept</b> the principle that when a person travels from place to place, the Sages <b>impose upon him the stringencies of the place from which he emerged and the stringencies of the place to which he went?</b>
<b>Abaye said: That statement</b> applies when one travels <b>from</b> one place in <b>Babylonia to</b> another place in <b>Babylonia, or from</b> one place in <b>Eretz Yisrael to</b> another place in <b>Eretz Yisrael,</b> or <b>alternatively,</b> when one descends <b>from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia. But</b> when one ascends <b>from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael,</b> this principle does not apply. <b>Since we,</b> the residents of Babylonia, <b>are subordinate to them</b> in terms of <i>halakha</i>, <b>we act in accordance with their</b> custom.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that when one travels <b>from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael,</b> he is required to act stringently in accordance with the custom of the place from which he emerged, <b>that statement</b> applies only in a case <b>where his intent is to return. Rabbi Zeira was not</b> one <b>whose intent was to return.</b> Therefore, he was not obligated to observe the Babylonian stringencies.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: But didn’t the Sages who came from Meḥoza say</b> that <b>Rabbi Zeira says in the name of Rav Naḥman:</b> In a case where the knife <b>is diverted</b> from the place of slaughter above the ring, the slaughter is <b>valid?</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to him: Each river and its</b> unique <b>course,</b> i.e., each place follows its custom, and in Meḥoza the custom was not in accordance with the opinion of Rav and Shmuel.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish deemed</b> the slaughter <b>valid</b> in a case where one cut the windpipe <b>at the tip of the thyroid cartilage</b> that is above the large ring. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan proclaimed about</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: He <b>greatly exaggerated</b> the limits of valid slaughter. <b>Rav Pappi said in the name of Rava:</b> If one cut the windpipe and <b>encountered the arytenoid cartilage</b> that is adjacent to the upper ring in the direction of the jaw and covered by the tip of the thyroid cartilage, the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> i.e., forbidden. Since the arytenoid cartilage is outside the area of slaughter, the slaughter is invalid.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Does encountered mean <b>encountered and touched it, as it is written: “And he encountered him and he died”</b> (I Kings 2:25); <b>or perhaps</b> it means <b>encountered but did not touch, like that which is written: “And the angels of God encountered him”</b> (Genesis 32:2)?
<b>It was stated</b> that <b>Rav Pappa said in the name of Rava:</b> If <b>one left</b> part <b>of the arytenoid cartilage,</b> i.e., if he cut it in the middle, the slaughter is <b>valid. Rav Ameimar bar Mar Yenuka said: I was standing before Rabbi Ḥiyya, son of Rav Avya, and he said to me:</b> If <b>one left</b> part <b>of the arytenoid cartilage,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid. Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Rav Shemen of Suvara said to me</b> that <b>Mar Zutra happened</b> to come <b>to our place and taught:</b> If <b>one left</b> part <b>of the arytenoid cartilage,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid. Mar bar Rav Ashi said:</b> If <b>one encountered the arytenoid cartilage,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid.</b> If <b>one left</b> part <b>of the arytenoid cartilage,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>

Daf 19a

The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is: If one slaughters <b>from the incline of the thyroid cartilage and below</b> in the direction of the windpipe, the slaughter is <b>valid, and that is in</b> accordance with the opinion <b>that one who left</b> part <b>of the arytenoid cartilage</b> has still performed a valid slaughter, as the arytenoids cartilage extends beyond this point.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Naḥman deemed</b> the slaughter <b>valid</b> in a case where one slaughtered <b>from the incline of the thyroid cartilage and below. Rav Ḥanan bar Rav Ketina said to Rav Naḥman: In accordance with whose</b> opinion is that ruling? It is <b>neither in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis nor in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who both hold that if one cuts the windpipe above the large upper ring, the cricoid cartilage, the slaughter is not valid.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: Neither do I know Ḥillek nor do I know Billek,</b> i.e., I know the reason neither for this one’s opinion nor for that one’s opinion. <b>I know the <i>halakha</i>, as Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba bar Zavda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: From the incline of the thyroid cartilage and below,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to analyzing the <i>baraita</i> (18b): In a case where the knife is diverted from the place of slaughter above the ring, the slaughter is not valid. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus testified about a case where the knife is diverted from the place of slaughter above the ring that the slaughter is valid. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> With regard to a case where the knife was <b>diverted</b> according to the opinion <b>of the Rabbis</b> cited in the mishna, the slaughter is <b>valid</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who ruled that the slaughter is valid when the majority of the windpipe was cut within the large, upper ring.
<b>And</b> with regard to a case where the knife was <b>diverted</b> according to the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> it is <b>valid</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus,</b> who ruled that even if a majority of the windpipe was cut outside the large upper ring, the slaughter is valid.
The Gemara objects: That is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Lest you say</b> that the statement of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus,</b> who ruled that in a case where the knife is diverted from the place of slaughter above the ring it is valid, <b>addresses</b> the statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> and he agrees with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, that the slaughter is not valid when the majority of the windpipe was cut above the large upper ring, therefore, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
The Gemara objects: <b>And say it is indeed so</b> that Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus agrees with Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. The Gemara responds: <b>If so,</b> the formulation of the <i>baraita</i> <b>should have</b> been: Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus <b>testified about it.</b> Since the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus was introduced merely with the term: Testified, apparently he disagrees with all of the other opinions. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus, as Rav Naḥman holds in accordance with his</b> opinion.
§ The mishna cited a dispute between the Rabbis, who hold that in a case where one slaughtered within the large upper ring and did not leave a thread breadth over the entire surface of the ring, the slaughter is not valid, and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who hold that even if one left a thread breadth over a majority of the surface of the ring, the slaughter is valid. Apropos to that, <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav Asi says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> is only <b>in</b> a case <b>where one cut two-thirds</b> of the windpipe within the ring <b>and</b> then <b>diverted</b> the knife upward toward the head of the animal and cut the remaining <b>one-third, as the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we require the entire slaughter</b> to be performed <b>within the large ring, and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds:</b> The halakhic status of <b>its majority is like</b> that of <b>its entirety.</b>
<b>But</b> if <b>one diverted</b> the knife upward toward the head of the animal, cut <b>one-third</b> of the windpipe, <b>and</b> then <b>cut two-thirds</b> within the ring, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the slaughter is <b>not valid, as when the life left</b> the animal, i.e., when the majority of the windpipe was cut, <b>we require</b> that the entire <b>majority</b> be cut <b>by means of slaughter, and that is not</b> so in this case.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said to</b> Rav Huna: <b>On the contrary, let the Master say the opposite.</b> The <b>dispute</b> is only <b>in</b> a case <b>when one diverted</b> the knife upward toward the head of the animal, cut <b>one-third</b> of the windpipe, <b>and</b> then <b>cut two-thirds</b> within the ring, <b>as Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds</b> that the slaughter is valid <b>just as it is</b> in the case <b>where half the windpipe is deficient.</b> In that case, once the slaughterer cuts any additional part of the windpipe, the slaughter is valid because the cut that rendered a majority of the windpipe slaughtered was performed properly. So too in this case, since the cut of the second third was performed properly, the slaughter is valid.
<b>And the Rabbis</b> hold that <b>there,</b> in the case of the deficient windpipe, the deficiency was in <b>the place of</b> proper <b>slaughter,</b> and therefore most of the life of the animal left in the proper place. <b>Here,</b> the first third was cut while the knife was diverted, and therefore most of the life of the animal did <b>not</b> leave in <b>the place of</b> proper <b>slaughter.</b>
<b>But</b> in a case where <b>one cut two-thirds</b> of the windpipe within the ring <b>and</b> then <b>diverted</b> the knife and cut the remaining <b>one-third, everyone agrees</b> that the slaughter is <b>valid, as didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (27a): The halakhic status of the slaughter of the <b>majority of one</b> <i>siman</i>, the windpipe or the gullet, <b>is like</b> that of the slaughter of the entire <i>siman</i> <b>itself?</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>Who will say to us that</b> with regard to the mishna <b>there</b> concerning <b>the majority of</b> one <i>siman</i>, <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, did not teach it? Perhaps Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, taught it,</b> and the Rabbis disagree.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Is that to say</b> that with regard to <b>all</b> principles that address <b>majorities in general, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, taught them?</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to him: I am speaking of the</b> principle of <b>majority with regard to slaughter, as we heard that</b> the Rabbis <b>disagree</b> with him.
<b>Some say</b> that there is <b>an alternative version</b> of this discussion: <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav Asi says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> is only in a case <b>where one diverted</b> the knife upward toward the head of the animal, cut <b>one-third</b> of the windpipe, <b>and</b> then <b>cut two-thirds</b> within the ring, <b>as Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, holds</b> that the slaughter is valid <b>just as it is</b> in the case <b>where half the windpipe is deficient, and the Rabbis</b> hold that <b>there,</b> in the case of the deficient windpipe, the deficiency was in <b>the place of</b> proper <b>slaughter,</b> but <b>here,</b> most of the life of the animal did <b>not</b> leave in <b>the place of</b> proper <b>slaughter.</b>
<b>But</b> in a case where <b>one cut two-thirds</b> of the windpipe within the ring <b>and</b> then <b>diverted</b> the knife and cut the remaining <b>one-third, everyone agrees</b> that the slaughter is <b>valid, as didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (27a): The halakhic status of the slaughter of the <b>majority of one</b> <i>siman</i>, the windpipe or the gullet, <b>is like</b> that of the slaughter of the entire <i>siman</i> <b>itself?</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda objects to this: Who will say to us that</b> with regard to the mishna <b>there</b> concerning <b>the majority of</b> one <i>siman</i>, <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, did not teach it? Perhaps Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, taught it,</b> and the Rabbis disagree. <b>Rav Yosef said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>Is that to say</b> that with regard to <b>all</b> principles that address <b>majorities in general, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, taught them?</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: I am speaking of the</b> principle of <b>majority with regard to slaughter, as we heard that</b> the Rabbis <b>disagree</b> with him.
§ If <b>one diverted</b> the knife and cut <b>one-third</b> of the windpipe, <b>and</b> then <b>cut one-third</b> properly, <b>and</b> then <b>diverted</b> and cut the final <b>one-third, Rav Huna</b> says that <b>Rav says:</b> The slaughter is <b>valid. Rav Yehuda</b> says that <b>Rav says:</b> The animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> i.e., forbidden. <b>Rav Huna</b> says that <b>Rav says:</b> The slaughter is <b>valid,</b> as <b>when the life left</b> the animal, it was <b>in</b> the course of a valid <b>slaughter</b> that <b>it left. Rav Yehuda</b> says that <b>Rav says:</b> The animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, as we require a majority</b> of the windpipe to be cut <b>with</b> valid <b>slaughter,and</b> that <b>is not</b> the case.
If <b>one cut one-third</b> of the windpipe properly, <b>and</b> then <b>diverted</b> the knife and cut <b>one-third, and</b> then <b>cut</b> the final <b>one-third</b> of the windpipe properly, <b>Rav Yehuda</b> says that <b>Rav said:</b> The slaughter is <b>valid.</b> When the Sages <b>came and asked Rav Huna, he said to them:</b> It is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. Rav Yehuda heard</b> the ruling of Rav Huna, and <b>he was angry. He said: I deem</b> it <b>a <i>tereifa</i> and he deems</b> the slaughter <b>valid, and I deem</b> the slaughter <b>valid</b> and <b>he deems</b> it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. Rav Huna said:</b> It is <b>proper</b> that <b>he was angry. One</b> reason is that <b>he heard</b> it <b>from Rav and I did not hear</b> it from Rav; <b>and furthermore, isn’t there the majority</b> of the <i>siman</i> that was cut <b>with</b> valid <b>slaughter?</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said to</b> Rav Huna: <b>Do not retract</b> your statement,

Daf 19b

<b>as, if</b> you retract your statement, <b>you repudiate the first</b> ruling that you stated with regard to a case where one diverted the knife and cut one-third of the windpipe, and then cut one-third properly, and then diverted and cut the final one-third. <b>There, what is the reason</b> that <b>you deemed</b> the slaughter <b>valid?</b> The reason is <b>that when life left</b> the animal with the cutting of the second third of the windpipe, <b>it left</b> the animal <b>in</b> the course of <b>valid</b> slaughter. Based on that reasoning, <b>here too, when life left</b> the animal with the cutting of the second third of the windpipe, <b>it left</b> the animal <b>in</b> the course of <b>diverting</b> the knife, and the slaughter is invalid.
<b>Rav Naḥman happened</b> to come <b>to Sura,</b> where <b>they asked him:</b> If <b>one cut one-third</b> of the windpipe properly, <b>and</b> then <b>diverted</b> the knife and cut <b>one-third, and</b> then <b>cut</b> the final <b>one-third</b> of the windpipe properly, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>He said to them: Isn’t that</b> the <i>halakha</i> stated by <b>Rabbi Elazar bar Minyumi, as Rabbi Elazar bar Minyumi says: Slaughter that is performed like</b> the teeth of <b>a comb,</b> which are jagged, is <b>valid.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>And perhaps</b> Rabbi Elazar bar Minyumi stated his <i>halakha</i> only when the slaughter goes up and down <b>within</b> the proper <b>place of slaughter.</b> The Gemara asks in response: <b>Within</b> the proper <b>place of slaughter, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> it? Clearly the slaughter is valid in that case. The Gemara explains: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>we require slaughter</b> that is <b>clear</b> and straight, <b>and</b> slaughter that is jagged <b>is not</b> straight, therefore, Rabbi Elazar bar Minyumi <b>teaches us</b> that nevertheless, the slaughter is valid.
The Gemara cites <b>a mnemonic</b> for the order of the Sages in the following discussion: <b><i>Beit</i></b> for Rabbi Abba; <b><i>kaf</i></b> for Rav Kahana; <b><i>dalet</i></b> for Rav Yehuda.
<b>Rabbi Abba sat behind Rav Kahana and Rav Kahana sat before Rav Yehuda, and he sat and said</b> to Rav Yehuda: If <b>one cut one-third</b> of the windpipe properly, <b>and</b> then <b>diverted</b> the knife and cut <b>one-third, and</b> then <b>cut</b> the final <b>one-third</b> of the windpipe properly, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav Yehuda <b>said to</b> Rav Kahana: <b>His slaughter is valid.</b>
Rav Kahana then asked: If <b>one diverted</b> the knife and cut <b>one-third</b> of the windpipe, <b>and</b> then <b>cut one-third</b> properly, <b>and</b> then <b>diverted</b> and cut the final <b>one-third, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav Yehuda <b>said to</b> him: <b>His slaughter is not valid.</b>
Rav Kahana then asked: If <b>one cut in a place</b> where there was <b>a perforation</b> in the front of the windpipe and continued cutting, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav Yehuda <b>said to</b> him: <b>His slaughter is valid.</b>
Rav Kahana further asked: If <b>one cut</b> the windpipe <b>and</b> after cutting half the windpipe <b>encountered a perforation,</b> after which point a majority of the windpipe had been cut, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav Yehuda <b>said to</b> him: <b>His slaughter is not valid.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba went</b> to Eretz Yisrael and <b>stated</b> these <i>halakhot</i> <b>in the presence of Rabbi Elazar,</b> and <b>Rabbi Elazar went</b> and <b>stated</b> these <i>halakhot</i> <b>in the presence of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: What is different</b> about a case where one cut in a place where there was a perforation relative to a case where he encountered a perforation in the middle of the slaughter?
Rabbi Elazar <b>said to him:</b> In a case where <b>one cut in a place</b> where there was <b>a perforation, it becomes like</b> an animal <b>that a gentile</b> began to <b>slaughter and a Jew completed</b> its slaughter, in which case the slaughter is valid. In a case where <b>one cut</b> the windpipe <b>and encountered a perforation, it becomes like</b> an animal <b>that a Jew</b> began to <b>slaughter and a gentile completed</b> its slaughter, in which case the slaughter is not valid. Rabbi Yoḥanan mockingly <b>proclaimed about him: Gentile, gentile,</b> i.e., you merely repeat something about gentiles. Rabbi Yoḥanan did not accept the distinction.
<b>Rava said:</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan did <b>well</b> when he <b>proclaimed about him: Gentile, gentile. Granted, there,</b> in the case where the gentile completed the slaughter, <b>since a Jew was</b> supposed <b>to cut a majority</b> of the windpipe <b>and he did not cut</b> it, <b>when life left</b> the animal <b>it left by the hand of a gentile. But here, after all, he</b> was the one who <b>slaughtered</b> the entire animal, and the animal was not a <i>tereifa</i> until this point, and so <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if one began to cut <b>in a place</b> where there was <b>a perforation</b> and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if he <b>encountered a perforation?</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who slaughters from the sides</b> of the throat, <b>his slaughter is valid. One who pinches</b> the neck of a bird offering <b>from the sides, his pinching is not valid.One who slaughters from the nape [<i>oref</i>]</b> of the neck, <b>his slaughter is not valid. One who pinches</b> a bird offering <b>from the nape</b> of the neck, <b>his pinching is valid. One who slaughters from the throat, his slaughter is valid. One who pinches</b> a bird offering <b>from the throat, his pinching is not valid, as the entire nape is valid for pinching and the entire throat is valid for slaughter. It is found that</b> that which is <b>valid for slaughter</b> is <b>not valid for pinching</b> and that which is <b>valid for pinching</b> is <b>not valid for slaughter.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the statement in the mishna: One who slaughters an animal from the <i>oref</i>, its slaughter is not valid, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b><i>oref</i>? If we say</b> that the reference is to the <b>actual occipital bone</b> at the rear of the skull, <b>why</b> does this <i>halakha</i> apply <b>specifically</b> to one who <b>slaughters</b> from the <i>oref</i>? <b>Even</b> if one <b>pinches</b> a bird offering from the <i>oref</i> it would <b>also</b> not be valid, as <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “Pinch off its head <b>adjacent to its <i>oref</i>”</b> (Leviticus 5:8), at the nape beneath the occipital bone, <b>and not its <i>oref</i>. Rather, what</b> is the <b><i>oref</i></b> mentioned in the mishna? It is <b>adjacent to the <i>oref</i>,</b> the back of the neck below the occipital bone, <b>as it is taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>The entire nape is valid for pinching.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? They are derived <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the phrase <b>“adjacent to [<i>mimmul</i>] its <i>oref</i>,” adjacent</b> means a place <b>that sees the <i>oref</i></b>  and not the <i>oref</i> itself. <b>And likewise,</b> the verse <b>states: “And they reside adjacent to me [<i>mimmuli</i>]”</b> (Numbers 22:5); <b>and</b> the verse <b>states: “For they have turned their <i>oref</i> unto Me, and not their face”</b> (Jeremiah 2:27). The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is added by the latter proof, introduced with the term: <b>And</b> the verse <b>states?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>And if you would say, we do not know where the <i>oref</i> itself</b> is, so <b>that we will know where adjacent to it is, come</b> and <b>hear: “For they have turned their <i>oref</i> unto Me, and not their face,”</b> from which it may be ascertained <b>by inference that the <i>oref</i> is opposite the face,</b> at the rear of the head.
§ <b>The sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya say:</b> How is <b>the mitzva of pinching</b> of a bird offering performed? <b>One moves</b> the two <b><i>simanim</i></b> that must be severed in ritual slaughter, i.e., the windpipe and the gullet, <b>behind the nape and pinches.</b> There is a dispute among the Sages with regard to the meaning of the statement. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say:</b> The mitzva <i>ab initio</i> is to pinch through the spinal column first and then pinch the windpipe and the gullet, and one may <b>even move</b> the <i>simanim</i> to behind the nape and pinch. <b>And there are</b> those <b>who say:</b> The mitzva is <b>specifically</b> to <b>move</b> the <i>simanim</i> behind the nape and pinch.
The Gemara notes: <b>And it is reasonable according to the one who says: One may even move</b> the <i>simanim</i> behind the nape. <b>From where</b> does one draw that conclusion? It is <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches: One who slaughters from the nape</b> of the neck, <b>his slaughter is not valid. One who pinches from the nape</b> of the neck, <b>his pinching is valid.</b>

Daf 20a

<b>And if it enters your mind that</b> the mitzva is <b>specifically</b> to <b>move</b> the <i>simanim</i> behind the nape and pinch them, <b>why</b> did the <i>tanna</i> say <b>specifically</b> that if one <b>pinches</b> in this manner it is valid? <b>Even</b> if <b>one slaughters</b> from the nape in this manner the slaughter would be valid. <b>Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from it</b> that the proper understanding is: One may <b>even move</b> the <i>simanim</i> behind the nape and pinch, <b>and the mishna is</b> referring to a case <b>where one did not move</b> the <i>simanim</i> behind the nape.
<b>Rabbi Yannai says: The young ones [<i>rovin</i>],</b> the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya, <b>shall receive their response</b> that rejects their statement from <b>that</b> which <b>is taught</b> in the mishna: <b>It is found that</b> that which is <b>valid for slaughter</b> is <b>not valid for pinching and</b> that which is <b>valid for pinching</b> is <b>not valid for slaughter. What</b> does this statement serve <b>to exclude?</b> Does it <b>not</b> serve <b>to exclude</b> the case where <b>one moves the <i>simanim</i> behind the nape,</b> teaching <b>that</b> it is valid only for slaughter and <b>not</b> for pinching?
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: No,</b> perhaps it serves <b>to exclude</b> one who uses <b>a tooth or a fingernail</b> that is not detached, which are valid for pinching and not valid for slaughter. The Gemara objects: That could not be, as the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches explicitly</b> the case of <b>a tooth and a fingernail</b> in a mishna (15b), and there was no need to repeat it.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> The statement of the mishna: That which is valid for slaughter is not valid for pinching, serves <b>to exclude drawing back and forth.</b> One who pinches may not cut the <i>simanim</i> by drawing his fingernail back and forth. Rather, he must press and cut them in one motion. The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says: Drawing back and forth for pinching is not valid, but according to the one who says:</b> It is <b>valid, what is there to say?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya hold in accordance with the one who says: Drawing back and forth for pinching is not valid.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana says: The mitzva of pinching</b> is that <b>one cuts</b> with his fingernail from the nape <b>and continues downward, and that is its mitzva. Rabbi Avin thought to say: Cuts and continues downward, yes; draws back and forth, no. Rabbi Yirmeya said to him: All the more so that drawing back and forth for pinching is valid.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>That is its mitzva,</b> which indicates that it is specifically in that manner? The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that it means: <b>That too is its mitzva.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Any</b> place <b>that is valid for slaughter</b> on the throat <b>is correspondingly valid for pinching</b> on the nape. By inference, any place on the throat that <b>is not valid for slaughter is not valid for pinching.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does this statement serve <b>to exclude? If we say</b> that it serves <b>to exclude ripping</b> the <b><i>simanim</i></b> from their place before cutting them, which is invalid with regard to pinching just as with regard to slaughter, <b>but didn’t Rami bar Yeḥezkel teach:</b> There is <b>no</b> disqualification of <b>ripping</b> the <b><i>simanim</i> in</b> the case of <b>a bird?</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It serves <b>to exclude</b> pinching the occipital bone at the back of <b>its head;</b> just as it is not the place of slaughter, it is not the place of pinching. The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that pinching at the back of <b>its head</b> is not valid? <b>The Merciful One states: “Adjacent to its nape,” and not at its head.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>What</b> is <b>its head</b> that is not the place for pinching? It is <b>the incline of its head,</b> e.g., in a case <b>where one began at the incline of its head and diverted and continued until he reached below</b> to the place of the <i>simanim</i>, where he completed the pinching. Since he began the process in the incorrect location, it is invalid, similar to slaughter. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>that Rav Huna</b> says that <b>Rav Asi says, as Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav Asi says:</b> If <b>one diverted</b> the knife upward and cut <b>one-third</b> of the windpipe <b>and</b> then <b>cut two-thirds</b> within the ring, the slaughter is <b>not valid.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> With regard to <b>that which Rami bar Yeḥezkel teaches:</b> There is <b>no</b> disqualification for <b>ripping <i>simanim</i> in a bird, we say</b> it <b>only according to the one who says: There is no</b> source for the <b>slaughter of a bird in the Torah.</b>

Daf 20b

<b>But according to the one who says: There is</b> a source for the <b>slaughter of a bird in the Torah, there is</b> disqualification for <b>ripping</b> <i>simanim</i> in a bird as well.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: On the contrary, the opposite is reasonable. According to the one who says: There is</b> a source for the <b>slaughter of a bird in the Torah,</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter are not explicit and were transmitted to Moses orally, and <b>it can be said that this is what</b> God <b>taught him, that there is no</b> disqualification for <b>ripping</b> <i>simanim</i>. <b>And even according to the one who says</b> that the halakhic status of a bird is <b>like</b> that of <b>an animal,</b> as the <i>halakhot</i> of the slaughter of a bird are derived from the <i>halakhot</i> of the slaughter of an animal, perhaps God taught Moses that with regard <b>to the matter of ripping</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>it will not be like an animal.</b>
<b>But according to the one who says: There is no</b> source for the <b>slaughter of a bird in the Torah,</b> but <b>rather</b> it is <b>by rabbinic law, from where are</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of the slaughter of a bird <b>learned?</b> They are learned <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of the slaughter of <b>an animal;</b> consequently, <b>the entire matter</b> of the slaughter of a bird is <b>like</b> that of <b>an animal.</b>
<b>Ravina said: Ravin bar Kisi said to me:</b> With regard to <b>that which Rami bar Yeḥezkel teaches,</b> i.e., that <b>there is no</b> disqualification for <b>ripping <i>simanim</i> in a bird, we say</b> it <b>only with regard to pinching, but with regard to slaughter, there is</b> disqualification for <b>ripping</b> <i>simanim</i>. The Gemara objects: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yirmeya say</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Any</b> place <b>that is valid for slaughter</b> on the throat <b>is correspondingly valid for pinching on the nape, but</b> that which is <b>not valid</b> for slaughter is <b>not valid</b> for pinching. The Gemara explains: <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>disagrees</b> with this statement of Shmuel.
§ <b>Ze’eiri says:</b> If <b>the neck bone</b> of an animal or a bird <b>was broken and most of the</b> surrounding <b>flesh</b> was cut <b>with it,</b> the status of the animal or the bird is that of <b>an unslaughtered carcass.</b> It is dead and can no longer be rendered fit by slaughter.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>we learn</b> this in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 68a) as well: If <b>one pinched</b> a bird offering <b>with a knife</b> and not with his thumbnail, the bird <b>renders the garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat,</b> which is the <i>halakha</i> in the case of an unslaughtered carcass of a kosher bird. <b>And if you would say</b> that if the neck bone of an animal or a bird was broken and most of the surrounding flesh was cut with it, the bird is not an unslaughtered carcass but <b>it is a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> then since with regard to a bird offering <b>its pinching is its slaughter, let</b> pinching with <b>a knife be effective to purify</b> the bird <b>from</b> the impurity of <b>an unslaughtered carcass,</b> as a <i>tereifa</i> does not transmit impurity when slaughtered properly. From the <i>halakha</i> that pinching with a knife does not render the bird pure it is evident that when its neck bone is broken the bird is rendered an unslaughtered carcass.
The Sages <b>say</b> in response: <b>There,</b> pinching with a knife is ineffective in rendering it pure not because the breaking of the neck bone renders the bird an unslaughtered carcass. Rather, it is <b>because it is not slaughter at all.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason? Rav Huna says:</b> It is <b>because he conceals</b> the knife and performs an inverted slaughter, which invalidates the slaughter. <b>Rava says:</b> It is <b>because he presses</b> the knife.
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>the one who says: Because he conceals</b> the knife and performs an inverted slaughter, <b>what is the reason</b> that <b>he does not say: Because he presses</b> the knife? The Gemara answers: It is because <b>he holds</b> that <b>drawing back and forth in pinching is valid.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And the one who says: Because he presses</b> the knife, <b>what is the reason</b> that <b>he does not say: Because he conceals [<i>maḥlid</i>]</b> the knife? The Gemara answers that <b>he</b> could have <b>said to you: What are the circumstances of concealing</b> the knife? It is <b>like a rat [<i>ḥulda</i>] that resides in the foundations of houses that are concealed. Here,</b> when he begins cutting from the nape of the neck, <b>that</b> knife <b>is exposed.</b>
<b>Rava said: If</b> that which Ze’eiri said: If the neck bone of an animal or a bird was broken and most of the surrounding flesh was cut with it, the status of the animal or the bird is that of an unslaughtered carcass, is <b>difficult for me, this</b> is <b>difficult for me:</b> How does pinching a bird offering prepare it for sacrifice? Since pinching involves breaking the neck bone and cutting most of the surrounding flesh with it before cutting the <i>simanim</i>, what significance is there to pinching the <i>simanim</i>? <b>And does he stand and pinch a dead</b> bird? If it is dead, of what use is the pinching?
<b>Abaye said to him: And</b> even without the statement of Ze’eiri, <b>let</b> the case of <b>a bird burnt offering be difficult for you, as</b> it <b>requires</b> cutting of <b>two <i>simanim</i>.</b> Since slaughter of a non-sacred bird requires cutting of one <i>siman</i>, once one <i>siman</i> is cut the bird is considered dead for all intents and purposes, <b>and does he stand and pinch a dead</b> bird? Rava <b>said to him: There,</b> he continues pinching <b>in order to fulfill through it the mitzva of separation</b> between the head and the body in the bird burnt offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> there should be an obligation to cut the <b>skin</b> of the bird <b>as well</b> in order to fulfill the mitzva of separation. Abaye answers: <b>Any</b> element <b>that invalidates slaughter invalidates separation, and any</b> element <b>that does not invalidate slaughter does not invalidate separation.</b> Failure to cut the skin does not invalidate slaughter.
The Gemara objects: <b>But isn’t</b> there <b>the minority of the <i>simanim</i> according to the Rabbis, which do not invalidate slaughter,</b> as, if one slaughtered a majority of the <i>simanim</i> and a minority remained uncut, the slaughter is valid, <b>and</b> they hold that <b>they invalidate separation?</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>Rather, say: Any</b> element <b>that is</b> in effect <b>with regard to slaughter is</b> in effect <b>with regard to separation, and any</b> element <b>that is not</b> in effect <b>with regard to slaughter is not</b> in effect <b>with regard to separation.</b> The two <i>simanim</i>, although they do not invalidate slaughter, are part of the mitzva of slaughter, while the skin is not part of the mitzva of slaughter.

Daf 21a

<b>In any case,</b> the statement of Ze’eiri remains <b>difficult.</b> What is the significance of pinching a dead bird? <b>Rava said: Say</b> in explanation: <b>And likewise he does</b> when he pinches, <b>he cuts</b> the spinal <b>column and</b> the <b>neck bone without a majority of</b> the surrounding <b>flesh</b> and then he pinches the <i>simanim</i>.
The Gemara relates: <b>When Rabbi Zeira ascended</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found Rabbi Ami sitting and saying this <i>halakha</i></b> that Ze’eiri said, and Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: And does one stand and pinch a dead</b> bird? Rabbi Ami <b>was astonished [<i>eshtomam</i>] for a moment</b> (see Daniel 4:16), and thought about it and <b>said to</b> Rabbi Ami: <b>Say</b> that <b>this is what he does: He cuts</b> the spinal <b>column and</b> the <b>neck bone without a majority of</b> the surrounding <b>flesh.</b>
<b>That is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How does one pinch</b> the nape of <b>a bird sin offering? He cuts</b> the spinal <b>column and</b> the <b>neck bone without a majority of</b> the surrounding <b>flesh until he reaches the gullet or the windpipe.</b> Once <b>he has reached the gullet or the windpipe, he cuts one <i>siman</i> or its majority and a majority of</b> the surrounding <b>flesh with it; and in a burnt offering</b> he cuts <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>or the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> whose opinion is cited in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>If</b> you say it is <b>the Rabbis, don’t they say</b> that one must cut <b>specifically two</b> <i>simanim</i> and not their majority? <b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, doesn’t he say</b> that one must cut only <b>a majority of</b> the <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i> and no more, in which case why does the <i>baraita</i> specify two <i>simanim</i> or the majority of two <i>simanim</i>?
The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that when the <i>baraita</i> says <b>two,</b> it is according <b>to the Rabbis;</b> when it says <b>a majority of two,</b> it is according <b>to Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon. And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Both this,</b> two, <b>and that,</b> a majority of two, are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, and what</b> is the meaning of <b>two?</b> It does not mean two <i>simanim</i> in their entirety; rather, it means that one must cut a significant majority of the <i>simanim</i> <b>that is similar to two</b> entire <i>simanim</i>.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> If the <b>neck bone</b> of a person <b>was broken and a majority of</b> the surrounding <b>flesh with it</b> was cut, that person <b>imparts impurity in a tent,</b> i.e., if one is beneath the same roof with him he becomes impure, as his halakhic status is that of a corpse even though he is still twitching.
<b>And if you say that</b> the <b>incident</b> of the death <b>of Eli,</b> the High Priest, whose death is described: “And his neck bone broke, and he died” (I Samuel 4:18), <b>was</b> one where the <b>neck bone</b> broke <b>without the majority of</b> the surrounding <b>flesh</b> being cut, and nevertheless he died immediately, the Gemara responds: <b>Old age is different, as it is written: “And it came to pass, when he made mention of the Ark of God, that he fell from off his seat backward by the side of the gate, and his neck broke, and he died; for he was an old man, and heavy;</b> and he had judged Israel forty years” (I Samuel 4:18).
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If <b>one ripped</b> a person <b>like</b> one cuts <b>a fish,</b> lengthwise, the halakhic status of the ripped person is that of a corpse even though he is still convulsing, and he <b>imparts impurity in a tent. Rabbi Shmuel bar Yitzḥak says: And</b> that is specifically if he was ripped <b>from his back.</b>
§ The Gemara resumes discussions of the <i>halakhot</i> of an animal. <b>Shmuel says:</b> If <b>one rendered</b> the animal like <b>a shard [<i>gistera</i>]</b> by cutting it in two widthwise, its halakhic status is that of <b>an unslaughtered carcass</b> even though it is still convulsing. <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> If <b>the thigh,</b> the hind leg of the animal, <b>was removed and its recess is obvious,</b> it is <b>an unslaughtered carcass</b> and it imparts impurity even if it remains alive. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances of its recess</b> being <b>obvious? Rava said:</b> It is <b>any</b> situation <b>where</b> the animal <b>is collapsed and</b> even so its hind leg <b>is visibly lacking.</b>
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Oholot</i> 1:6) with regard to creeping animals whose carcasses are ritually impure: <b>If their heads were removed, even if they are convulsing, they are impure like the tail of a lizard</b> that was severed <b>that convulses</b> even though it is not alive.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>Were removed? Reish Lakish said:</b> They were <b>actually removed. Rabbi Asi</b> said that <b>Rabbi Mani said:</b> It is <b>like the separation of</b> the head of <b>the bird burnt offering.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Asi:</b> Do you mean <b>like the separation of</b> the head of <b>the bird burnt offering</b> according <b>to the Rabbis,</b> who hold that in addition to the neck bone and the surrounding flesh, one also completely severs the <i>simanim</i>, <b>and</b> then <b>you</b> and Reish Lakish <b>do not disagree,</b> as it is just like breaking the neck of the animal, since nothing remains other than the skin? <b>Or perhaps</b> you mean <b>like the separation of</b> the head of <b>the bird burnt offering</b> according <b>to Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> who says that one cuts the majority of two <i>simanim</i>, <b>and you</b> and Reish Lakish <b>disagree,</b> as Reish Lakish holds that the animal imparts impurity only when it is completely beheaded.
Rabbi Asi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: I mean <b>like the separation of</b> the head of <b>the bird burnt offering</b> according <b>to Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> who says that one cuts the majority of two <i>simanim</i>, <b>and we disagree.</b>
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said:</b> They were <b>actually removed. Rabbi Asi</b> said that <b>Rabbi Mani said:</b> It is <b>like the separation of</b> the head of <b>the bird burnt offering</b> according <b>to Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that one suffices <b>with</b> cutting <b>a majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i>.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and what</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon?</b> The dispute is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a sliding-scale offering, in which a poor person who cannot afford an animal sin offering brings two doves or two pigeons, one as a sin offering and one as a burnt offering, it is written: <b>“And he shall prepare the second as a burnt offering, according to the ordinance”</b> (Leviticus 5:10), which means <b>according to the ordinance of an animal sin offering</b> in whose stead the offering was brought.
<b>Do you say</b> that it is <b>according to the ordinance of an animal sin offering, or</b> perhaps <b>it is only according to the ordinance of a bird sin offering?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When it says</b> with regard to the bird burnt offering brought as a gift offering: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall bring it</b> to the altar” (Leviticus 1:15), meaning that it shall be sacrificed in a unique manner, <b>the verse distinguished between a bird sin offering and a bird burnt offering. And</b> if so, <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of the term <b>“according to the ordinance”?</b> It means <b>according to the ordinance of an animal sin offering; just as an animal sin offering comes only</b>

Daf 21b

<b>from non-sacred</b> animals and not from an animal purchased with second-tithe money, <b>and</b> it is sacrificed only <b>during the day, and with the right hand of</b> the priest, <b>so too, a bird burnt offering comes only from non-sacred</b> animals, <b>and</b> it is sacrificed only <b>during the day, and with the right hand of</b> the priest.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>If</b> so, perhaps <b>just as there,</b> with regard to an animal sin offering, slaughter is valid <b>with</b> the cutting of <b>the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i>, the windpipe and the gullet, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to a bird burnt offering, the pinching is valid <b>with</b> the cutting of <b>the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i>. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And pinched off</b> its head…<b>and burned</b> it on the altar” (Leviticus 1:15). This indicates that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>burning, the head</b> is burned <b>by itself and the body</b> is burned <b>by itself, so too</b> with regard to <b>pinching, the head</b> remains <b>by itself and the body</b> remains <b>by itself.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael says: “According to the ordinance”</b> (Leviticus 5:10), which is written with regard to the sliding-scale bird sin offering, means <b>according to the ordinance of the bird sin offering</b> mentioned in the previous verse. <b>Just as a bird sin offering</b> is pinched <b>adjacent to its nape</b> (Leviticus 5:8), beneath the occipital bone, <b>so too a bird burnt offering</b> is pinched <b>adjacent to its nape,</b> beneath the occipital bone.
<b>If</b> so, perhaps <b>just as there,</b> with regard to the bird sin offering, <b>he pinches and does not separate</b> between the head and the body and leaves <b>one <i>siman</i></b> uncut, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the burnt offering, <b>he pinches and does not separate</b> between the head and the body and leaves <b>one <i>siman</i></b> uncut. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And</b> the priest <b>shall bring it,”</b> meaning that a bird burnt offering shall be sacrificed in a unique manner, not like the sin offering.
<b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: “According to the ordinance”</b> means <b>according to the ordinance</b> that is written with regard to <b>a bird sin offering. Just as there,</b>

Daf 22a

after the pinching, the priest <b>holds [<i>oḥez</i>] the head and the body</b> of the bird <b>and sprinkles</b> the blood on the altar, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the bird burnt offering, <b>he holds the head and the body and sprinkles</b> the blood on the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is he saying?</b> There is no requirement with regard to a bird sin offering that the priest hold both the head and the body while sprinkling the blood. The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> is what <b>he is saying: Just as there,</b> with regard to the bird sin offering, <b>when the head is attached [<i>aḥuz</i>] to the body,</b> the priest <b>sprinkles</b> the blood on the altar, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the bird burnt offering, <b>when the head is attached to the body,</b> the priest <b>sprinkles</b> the blood on the altar. This is what was cited above in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, that one cuts a majority of two <i>simanim</i> in a burnt offering and not the two <i>simanim</i> in their entirety.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If</b> so, perhaps <b>just as there,</b> in the sin offering, the pinching is performed <b>with</b> the cutting of <b>one <i>siman</i>, so too here,</b> in the burnt offering, the pinching is performed <b>with</b> the cutting of <b>one <i>siman</i>.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states: “And</b> the priest <b>shall bring it,”</b> meaning that the burnt offering is sacrificed in a manner different from that of the sin offering, by cutting two <i>simanim</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the first <i>tanna</i>, once we derive</b> that both <i>simanim</i> of a bird burnt offering must be cut in their entirety <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“And pinch off</b> its head…<b>and burn</b> it on the altar,” <b>why do I</b> need the phrase: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall bring it?”</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>If not</b> for the verse that states: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall bring it,” I would say: What</b> is the meaning of <b>“according to the ordinance”</b> that is stated with regard to the bird burnt offering? It means <b>according to the ordinance of the bird sin offering</b> mentioned in that same passage, in the sense that even in the burnt offering, the priest cuts only one <i>siman</i>.
<b>And if you would say</b> that one cannot suggest this interpretation <b>due to</b> the verse: <b>“And pinch</b> off its head…<b>and burn</b> it on the altar,” <b>I would say</b> that perhaps another <i>halakha</i> would be derived from that verse: <b>Just as burning</b> the offering is <b>atop the altar, so too pinching</b> is performed <b>atop the altar.</b>
<b>Now that the Merciful One writes: “And</b> the priest <b>shall bring it,”</b> indicating the distinction between the pinching of a bird burnt offering and the pinching of a bird sin offering, <b>derive this also from</b> the verse: “And pinch off its head…and burn it on the altar,” i.e., that the body and the head of a bird burnt offering must be completely separated.
§ The first <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> derives from the analogy between the bird burnt offering and the animal sin offering that a bird burnt offering is brought only from non-sacred animals and not from an animal purchased with second-tithe money, that it is sacrificed only during the day, and that the priest sacrificing it must do so with his right hand. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> <b>that an animal sin offering comes only from non-sacred</b> animals? <b>Rav Ḥisda said that the verse states: “And Aaron shall sacrifice the bull of the sin offering that is his”</b> (Leviticus 16:6, 11), from which it is derived: The animal must come <b>from his</b> cattle, <b>but not from communal</b> property, from his cattle, <b>but not from</b> second-<b>tithe</b> property.
The Gemara objects: The <i>halakha</i> that the bird burnt offering is sacrificed only <b>during the day is derived from</b> the verse: <b>“In the day that he commanded</b> the children of Israel to present their offerings” (Leviticus 7:38), not from the <i>halakha</i> of the animal sin offering. The Gemara explains: The requirement of sacrificing the bird burnt offering during the day is not derived from the <i>halakha</i> of the animal sin offering, and it was <b>cited</b> in that list incidentally, <b>for no reason [<i>kedi</i>].</b>
The Gemara objects: The <i>halakha</i> that the priest performs the service with <b>his right hand is derived from</b> the statement <b>of Rabba bar bar Ḥana, as Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: Any place where</b> the terms <b>finger or priesthood</b> are <b>stated</b> with regard to offerings, the sacrificial rites of that offering <b>are</b> performed <b>only</b> with the <b>right</b> hand, and in the context of the bird burnt offering the term “priest” is employed. It is therefore unnecessary to derive this <i>halakha</i> from the analogy to the animal sin offering.
The Gemara responds: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, the first <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i>, who derived that the right hand is used from the analogy to the animal sin offering based on the term “according to the ordinance,” did not derive it from the statement of Rabba bar bar Ḥana because in his opinion, in order to derive that the right hand must be used, if the verse mentions only the <b>priesthood,</b> it <b>requires</b> mention of <b>finger</b> for the limitation to apply. If the verse mentions only the term <b>finger,</b> then it <b>does not require</b> a mention of the <b>priesthood</b> as well. With regard to the bird burnt offering, the priesthood is mentioned, but the word finger is not. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> must be derived from the animal sin offering.
It is taught in the <i>baraita</i> that Rabbi Yishmael derived from the term “according to the ordinance” that is written with regard to the bird burnt offering that the pinching of the bird burnt offering is performed at the nape of the neck, as it is in a bird sin offering. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> who derive other matters from that term, <b>from where do they derive</b> that pinching of the bird burnt offering is performed at the nape of the neck? The Gemara answers: <b>They derive pinching</b> that is written with regard to the burnt offering: “And pinch off its head” (Leviticus 1:15), <b>from pinching</b> that is written with regard to the sin offering: “And pinch off its head adjacent to its neck” (Leviticus 5:8).
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> It is written with regard to bird offerings: “He shall bring his offering of doves, or of young pigeons” (Leviticus 1:14). The age that is <b>fit</b> for sacrifice <b>in doves,</b> mature birds, is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice <b>in pigeons,</b> immature birds;the age that is <b>fit</b> for sacrifice <b>in pigeons</b> is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice <b>in doves.</b> At the intermediate stage of <b>the beginning of the yellowing</b> of its plumage (see 22b), a bird <b>is unfit</b> both <b>as this,</b> a pigeon, <b>and as that,</b> a dove, since it is no longer a fledgling but is not yet a mature bird.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> in explaining the mishna: <b>Doves,</b> when they are <b>older,</b> are <b>fit</b> for sacrifice; when they are <b>younger,</b> they are <b>unfit. Pigeons,</b> when they are <b>younger,</b> are <b>fit</b> for sacrifice; when they are <b>older,</b> they are <b>unfit. It is found</b> that that which is <b>fit</b> for sacrifice <b>in doves</b> is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice <b>in pigeons;</b> that which is <b>fit</b> for sacrifice <b>in pigeons</b> is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice <b>in doves.</b>
