<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And he shall bring his offering of doves, or of young pigeons” (Leviticus 1:14), that <b>doves</b> are <b>older and not younger. As</b> one <b>might</b> have thought: <b>And couldn’t this</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference:</b>

Daf 22b

<b>If pigeons, which were not deemed fit when older, were deemed fit when younger,</b> as the term “young pigeons” indicates that they are young, then with regard to <b>doves, which were deemed fit when older, isn’t it logical that they were deemed fit when younger?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Doves,”</b> meaning <b>older and not younger.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Young pigeons</b> must be <b>younger and not older, as</b> one <b>might</b> have thought: <b>And couldn’t this</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: If doves, which were not deemed fit when younger, were deemed fit when older,</b> then with regard to <b>pigeons, which were deemed fit when younger, isn’t it logical that they were deemed fit when older?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Young pigeons,”</b> meaning <b>younger and not older.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation</b> of these matters? <b>Rava said:</b> It is derived from the fact that it is <b>not</b> found that <b>the verse</b> would <b>deviate</b> from the norm <b>and write: Of young doves, or of pigeons;</b> rather, the wording in the Torah is always “of doves” or “of young pigeons.” Evidently, doves must be older and pigeons must be younger.
The Gemara objects: <b>Say</b> instead that with regard to <b>pigeons, since the Merciful One writes: “Young,”</b> this means <b>younger</b> birds, <b>yes, older</b> birds, <b>no;</b> but with regard to <b>doves, if one wishes, let him bring older</b> birds, and <b>if he wishes, let him bring younger</b> birds. The Gemara responds: Since doves and pigeons are always juxtaposed to one another in the Torah, it is derived that the <i>halakha</i> of doves is <b>similar to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>pigeons: Just as</b> with regard to <b>pigeons</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>younger</b> birds, <b>yes, older</b> birds, <b>no, so too</b> with regard to <b>doves,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>older</b> birds, <b>yes, younger</b> birds, <b>no.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that all the</b> older <b>doves or all the</b> younger <b>pigeons would be fit</b> for sacrifice; therefore, <b>the verse states: “Of doves,” and not all doves; “of young pigeons,” and not all young pigeons.</b> This serves to <b>exclude</b> birds at <b>the beginning of the yellowing</b> of their neck plumage, <b>which are unfit as this,</b> doves, <b>and as that,</b> pigeons. They are unfit as doves because they are not sufficiently old and as pigeons because they are no longer young. The <i>tanna</i> elaborates: <b>From when are the doves fit?</b> It is <b>from when</b> the color of their feathers <b>turns a glistening gold. From when are the pigeons unfit?</b> It is <b>from when</b> their feathers <b>turn yellow.</b>
<b>Ya’akov Korḥa taught</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From when are pigeons fit?</b> It is <b>from when <i>ye’alu</i>. He teaches</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>and he states its</b> explanation: The reference is to that which is stated: <b>“Its fledglings will suck up [<i>ye’alu</i>] blood”</b> (Job 39:30). <b>When</b> is that? <b>Abaye said:</b> It is <b>from</b> the stage <b>when one plucks a feather from it and blood emerges.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering of doves or of pigeons, and he brought</b> birds at <b>the beginning of the yellowing</b> of their neck plumage <b>of this,</b> doves, <b>and of that,</b> pigeons, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Is</b> it a case of <b>uncertainty</b> whether it is considered older or younger, <b>and</b> therefore when he brings both <b>he fulfills</b> his obligation, as one of the birds was fit for sacrifice; <b>or perhaps</b> a bird at the beginning of the yellowing <b>is an entity</b> in and of itself and is neither older nor younger, <b>and he does not fulfill</b> his obligation?
<b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from the <i>baraita</i> where it is taught that the verse: “Of doves or of young pigeons,” serves to <b>exclude</b> birds at <b>the beginning of the yellowing</b> of their neck plumage <b>that are unfit as this,</b> doves, <b>and as that,</b> pigeons. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that a bird at that stage <b>is an entity</b> in and of itself, that works out <b>well,</b> as the verse serves to ensure that a bird at that stage of development will never be sacrificed. <b>But if you say</b> that it <b>is</b> a case of <b>uncertainty, was</b> it <b>necessary</b> for <b>the verse to exclude</b> a case of <b>uncertainty?</b>

Daf 23a

The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>When</b> the phrase in <b>the verse</b> “of doves or of young pigeons” <b>was necessary,</b> it was <b>to exclude</b> a bird <b>that was the object of bestiality or</b> a bird that <b>was worshipped</b> as a deity.
As it could <b>enter your mind to say: Since it is written</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of disqualified offerings: <b>“Because their corruption [<i>moshḥatam</i>] is in them, there is a blemish in them”</b> (Leviticus 22:25), referring to two types of disqualifications: Corruption and blemish, <b>and the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Anywhere that</b> the term <b>corruption [<i>hashḥata</i>] is stated, it is</b> referring to <b>nothing other than a matter of licentiousness and idol worship.</b> The Gemara cites proofs for this claim: Corruption is referring to <b>matters of licentiousness, as it is written: “For all flesh had corrupted [<i>hishḥit</i>] their way upon the earth”</b> (Genesis 6:12); the word “way” alludes to sexual intercourse.
Corruption is also referring to <b>idol worship, as it is written: “Lest you deal corruptly [<i>tashḥitun</i>], and make you a graven image”</b> (Deuteronomy 4:16); one might have thought: <b>Any</b> type of offering <b>that a blemish disqualifies, matters of licentiousness and idol worship disqualify it, and any</b> type of offering <b>that a blemish does not disqualify, matters of licentiousness and idol worship do not disqualify it. And</b> with regard to <b>these birds, since blemishes do not disqualify them, as the Master says:</b> There is a requirement of <b>an unblemished state and male gender in</b> a sacrificial <b>animal and there is no</b> requirement of <b>an unblemished state and male gender in</b> sacrificial <b>birds, say</b> that <b>matters of licentiousness and idol worship</b> should <b>also not disqualify</b> the birds. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> from the phrase in the verse “of doves or of young pigeons” that a bird that was the object of bestiality and a bird that was worshipped as a deity are disqualified.
§ Apropos the discussion of the beginning of the yellowing of the neck plumage, the Gemara cites another matter where there is uncertainty as to whether an animal of a particular age is of uncertain status or an entity in and of itself. <b>Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>an animal burnt offering of a ram,</b> which is a sheep that is at least thirteen months old, <b>or of a lamb,</b> which is up to one year old, <b>and he brought a <i>palges</i>,</b> which is between one year and thirteen months old, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara elaborates: <b>According to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan, do not raise a dilemma, as he says</b> that a <i>palges</i> <b>is an entity in and of itself, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Para</i> 1:3): If one was obligated to bring a ram or lamb as an offering, and he <b>sacrificed</b> a <i>palges</i>, <b>he brings with it</b> the meal offering and <b>the libations of a ram</b> offering, namely, a meal offering of two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mingled with four <i>log</i> of oil, and a libation of four <i>log</i> of wine, <b>but it does not fulfill his</b> obligation to bring <b>his offering.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that the requirement to bring the meal offering and libations of a ram offering is derived from the verse in the portion of the libations: <b>“Or for a ram,</b> you shall prepare for a meal offering two-tenths of an ephah of fine flour mixed with one-third of a <i>hin</i> of oil” (Numbers 15:6); that serves <b>to include the <i>palges</i>,</b> whose meal offering and libations are like that of a ram. Based on that derivation, there is no uncertainty with regard to the status of the <i>palges</i>.
<b>When you raise a dilemma,</b> it is <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of bar Padda,</b> who holds that it is a case of uncertainty,

Daf 23b

<b>as he says</b> that one who sacrifices a <i>palges</i> <b>brings</b> the meal offering and the libation of a ram <b>and stipulates:</b> If it is a ram, this is its meal offering and libation, and if it is a lamb, whose meal offering and libation are less than that of the ram, then the remainder will be a gift offering.
The dilemma is: <b>Do we say</b> that he <b>stipulates</b> only if it is <b>a ram or</b> if it is <b>a lamb,</b> but <b>he does not stipulate</b> the possibility that it is <b>an entity</b> in and of itself, as bar Padda does not accept such a possibility? If so, bar Padda holds that one who vowed to bring a ram or a lamb can fulfill his obligation by bringing a <i>palges</i> and stipulating accordingly. <b>Or perhaps</b> bar Padda holds that <b>he also stipulates</b> the possibility that it is <b>an entity</b> in and of itself, and in <b>that</b> case <b>he says: If</b> it <b>is an entity, let the entire</b> libation <b>be a gift</b> offering. According to that possibility, even according to bar Padda, if one vowed to bring a ram or a lamb and brought a <i>palges</i>, due to the uncertainty he does not fulfill his obligation. The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The concept of an entity in and of itself is mentioned with regard to a thanks offering, with which one must bring twenty tenths of an ephah for the accompanying loaves: Ten tenths of an ephah for <i>matza</i> and ten for leavened bread. <b>Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>loaves of a thanks offering of leavened bread or of <i>matza</i>, and he brought leavening</b> dough [<b><i>siur</i></b>], <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara asks: <b><i>Siur</i></b> according <b>to whose</b> opinion? <b>If</b> the reference is to the <b><i>siur</i> of Rabbi Meir,</b> who says that it is dough at the stage when its surface pales, according <b>to Rabbi Yehuda</b> it is not leavened bread at all; <b>it is full-fledged <i>matza</i></b> and one fulfills his vow to bring <i>matza</i>.
<b>If</b> the reference is to the <i>siur</i> <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who says that it is dough at the stage when it has cracks that look like the antennae of locusts and is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> Rabbi Meir holds that <b>it is</b> full-fledged <b>leavened bread,</b> and one fulfills his vow to bring leavened bread.
<b>And if</b> the reference is to the <i>siur</i> <b>of Rabbi Meir</b> and is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> although one is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating it on Passover, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>that one is flogged for</b> eating <b>it</b> on Passover it <b>is</b> clearly <b>leavened bread,</b> with which one fulfills his vow to bring leavened bread.
<b>Rather,</b> the dilemma is with regard to the <i>siur</i> <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that although one is obligated to destroy it before Passover, one is not liable to receive lashes for eating it on Passover. It is unclear whether this is due to uncertainty or due to <i>siur</i> having a unique status. Therefore, Rabbi Zeira raises the dilemma: <b>What</b> is its status? <b>Is</b> it a case of <b>uncertainty, and</b> consequently one who vowed to bring loaves of <i>matza</i> or leavened bread and brings <i>siur</i> <b>fulfills</b> his obligation <b>whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, because if it is <i>matza</i>, he fulfills his vow to bring <i>matza</i>, and if it is leavened bread, he fulfills his vow to bring leavened bread? <b>Or perhaps</b> <i>siur</i> <b>is an entity</b> in and of itself, neither <i>matza</i> nor leavened bread, <b>and he does not fulfill</b> his obligation at all.
The Gemara asks: Even if it is a case of uncertainty, how can a person fulfill his vow with that <i>siur</i>? <b>But doesn’t Rav Huna say</b> that <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>loaves of a thanks offering,</b> is obligated to <b>bring a thanks offering and</b> all <b>its loaves,</b> twenty tenths of an ephah, ten for matza and ten for leavened bread? <b>And since he is obligated to</b> bring <b>a thanks offering and</b> all <b>its loaves, but this man does not know whether</b> the <i>siur</i> that he brought <b>is leavened bread so that he will bring <i>matza</i>,</b> or <b>whether</b> the <i>siur</i> that he brought <b>is <i>matza</i> so that he will bring leavened bread,</b> so how can he fulfill his vow? In any case, the only way that he could fulfill his vow would be to bring an additional twenty tenths of an ephah.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the dilemma of Rabbi Zeira is <b>necessary</b> only in a case <b>where one said: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring the <b>loaf</b> element of the thanks offering <b>to exempt the thanks offering of so-and-so</b> from the obligation to bring loaves, as in that case he can fulfill his vow because he did not obligate himself to bring a thanks offering.
The Gemara objects: <b>Ultimately, this man</b> who brings the thanks offering <b>does not know whether</b> the <i>siur</i> that the other contributed <b>is leavened bread so that he will bring <i>matza</i>,</b> or <b>whether</b> the <i>siur</i> that the other contributed <b>is <i>matza</i> so that he will bring leavened bread.</b> Therefore, the man bringing the thanks offering must bring both matza and unleavened bread in addition to the <i>siur</i>, and the one who vowed has then not exempted him from any obligation by contributing the <i>siur</i>. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the dilemma of Rabbi Zeira is <b>necessary</b> only in a case <b>where</b> he said: It is incumbent upon me to bring loaves of leavened bread or <i>matza</i> for the thanks offering of so-and-so, but <b>did not say: To exempt</b> his thanks offering. In that case, he is not obligated to fulfill the other’s obligation, and the dilemma is: <b>Does the man fulfill his vow</b> by bringing the loaves of <i>siur</i> <b>or does he not fulfill</b> his vow? The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> That which is <b>fit in</b> a red <b>heifer</b> is <b>unfit in a heifer</b> whose neck is broken; that which is <b>fit in a heifer</b> whose neck is broken is <b>unfit in</b> a red <b>heifer.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in explanation of the mishna: With regard to the red <b>heifer, with slaughter</b> it is <b>fit; with breaking the neck</b> it is <b>unfit.</b> With regard to the <b>heifer</b> whose neck is broken, <b>with breaking the neck</b> it is <b>fit; with slaughter</b> it is <b>unfit. Consequently,</b> that which is <b>fit in</b> a red <b>heifer</b> is <b>unfit in a heifer</b> whose neck is broken; that which is <b>fit in a heifer</b> whose neck is broken is <b>unfit in</b> a red <b>heifer.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> it be derived that the red <b>heifer</b> is <b>fit with breaking the neck by means of an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If a heifer</b> whose neck is broken, <b>which is not rendered fit with slaughter, is rendered fit with breaking the neck,</b> then with regard to a red <b>heifer, which is rendered fit with slaughter, isn’t it logical that it is rendered fit with breaking the neck?</b>

Daf 24a

The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the red heifer: <b>“And he shall slaughter</b> it” (Numbers 19:3), <b>and</b> it mentions the term <b>statute:</b> “This is the statute of the Torah” (Numbers 19:2), indicating that <b>with slaughter, yes,</b> the red heifer is rendered fit; <b>with breaking the neck,</b> the red heifer is <b>not</b> rendered fit.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it so that <b>anywhere that statute is written with regard to</b> a certain matter, <b>we do not learn an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference? <b>But</b> what <b>about Yom Kippur, with regard to which statute is written:</b> “And this shall be an everlasting statute unto you” (Leviticus 16:34), <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “And Aaron shall bring forward the goat upon which the lot came up for the Lord, <b>and he shall offer it for a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 16:9). The verse indicates that <b>the lottery renders</b> the goat <b>a sin offering, but a verbal designation</b> of the goat with the status of a sin offering <b>does not render</b> it <b>a sin offering.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: A verse is necessary to teach this <i>halakha</i>, <b>as</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the opposite conclusion is correct: <b>Could this not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: If in a case where the lottery does not sanctify</b> the animal with a specific designation, such as in the case of two birds brought by a woman after childbirth, and nevertheless <b>a verbal designation</b> of that offering <b>sanctifies</b> it, in <b>a case where the lottery sanctifies</b> the animal on Yom Kippur, <b>isn’t it logical that a verbal designation</b> as a sin offering <b>sanctifies it?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And render it a sin offering;” the lottery renders</b> the goat <b>a sin offering, but a verbal designation</b> of a sin offering <b>does not render</b> the goat <b>a sin offering.</b>
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that the <i>a fortiori</i> inference is not learned is <b>that the Merciful One writes: “And he shall offer it for a sin offering.” But otherwise we</b> would <b>learn an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, despite the fact that statute is written with regard to the Yom Kippur service.
The Gemara explains: Actually, one may learn an <i>a fortiori</i> inference even in a case where statute is written. Nevertheless, <b>with regard to</b> the <b>heifer</b> whose neck is broken, <b>the Merciful One restricts</b> the use of breaking the neck: “And all the Elders of that city…shall wash their hands over the heifer <b>whose neck is broken”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:6). From the relative pronoun “whose” it is derived: <b>This</b> heifer <b>is</b> killed <b>by breaking the neck, but no other,</b> i.e., the red heifer, is killed <b>by breaking the neck.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let it be</b> derived that the heifer whose neck is broken is rendered <b>fit with slaughter by means of an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If</b> a red <b>heifer, which is not rendered fit with breaking the neck,</b> is rendered <b>fit with slaughter,</b> then with regard to <b>a heifer</b> whose neck is broken, <b>which</b> is rendered <b>fit with breaking the neck, isn’t it logical that it is rendered fit with slaughter?</b> The Gemara responds that <b>the verse states: “And shall break the neck of the heifer</b> there in the valley” (Deuteronomy 21:4). The doubled reference to breaking the neck in the two verses indicates that <b>by breaking the neck, yes,</b> the heifer may be killed; <b>by slaughter,</b> the heifer may <b>not</b> be killed.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There is an element with which <b>priests</b> remain <b>fit</b> and <b>Levites are unfit,</b> and there is also an element with which <b>Levites</b> remain <b>fit</b> and <b>priests are unfit.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in explanation of the mishna: <b>Priests are</b> rendered <b>unfit</b> for Temple service <b>with</b> the <b>blemishes</b> enumerated in the Torah (see Leviticus 21:16–23), but remain <b>fit with</b> the passage of <b>years,</b> as from the moment that they reach majority they are fit for service for the rest of their lives. <b>Levites</b> remain <b>fit</b> for Temple service <b>with</b> the <b>blemishes</b> enumerated in the Torah but <b>are unfit with</b> the passage of <b>years,</b> as they are fit for service only between the ages of thirty and fifty (see Numbers 4:47). <b>It is found</b> that there is an element with which <b>priests</b> remain <b>fit</b> and <b>Levites are unfit,</b> and there is an element with which <b>Levites</b> remain <b>fit</b> and <b>priests are unfit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? The Gemara answers: It is <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“This is that which pertains to the Levites”</b> (Numbers 8:24); <b>why</b> must <b>the verse state</b> this? <b>Since it is stated: “And from the age of fifty years he shall return</b> from the service” (Numbers 8:25), <b>we learned with regard to the Levites that</b> the passage of <b>years disqualifies them.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>blemishes disqualify them</b> too. <b>And</b> ostensibly, it could be learned through <b>logical inference: If priests,</b> with regard to <b>whom</b> the passage of <b>years does not disqualify them, blemishes disqualify them,</b> then in the case of <b>Levites,</b> with regard to <b>whom</b> the passage of <b>years disqualifies them, isn’t it logical that blemishes disqualify them?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “This is that which pertains to the Levites,”</b> from which it is derived: <b>“This,”</b> the passage of years, is a disqualification that pertains <b>to the Levites, and there is no other</b> disqualification that pertains <b>to the Levites.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>priests would be disqualified with</b> the passage of <b>years. And</b> ostensibly, <b>could this not</b> be derived through the following <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference: If Levites,</b> with regard to <b>whom blemishes do not disqualify them,</b> the passage of <b>years disqualifies them,</b> then in the case of <b>priests,</b> with regard to <b>whom blemishes disqualify them, isn’t it logical</b> that the passage of <b>years disqualifies them?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Which pertains to the Levites,” and not which pertains to the priests.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that the Levites were disqualified with the passage of years <b>even in Shiloh,</b> the permanent place of the Tabernacle, <b>and in the eternal Temple.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “To perform the work of service, and the work of bearing burdens”</b> (Numbers 4:47), juxtaposing the two forms of Levite service to teach: <b>I stated</b> the disqualification of the passage of years <b>only at a time when</b> there is Levite <b>service</b> involving carrying the Tabernacle <b>on</b> their <b>shoulders.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> notes that <b>one verse states: “From twenty-five years old and upward”</b> (Numbers 8:24), <b>and one verse states: “From thirty years old</b> and upward” (Numbers 4:47). It is <b>impossible to say thirty, as twenty-five is already stated, and</b> it is <b>impossible to say twenty-five, as thirty is already stated. How</b> can these verses be reconciled? <b>Twenty-five</b> years old is the time <b>for apprenticeship and thirty for service.</b>
<b>From here</b> it is derived that <b>a student who did not see a positive indication in his studies</b> after <b>five years will no longer see</b> a productive result from those studies. <b>Rabbi Yosei says</b> that the period is <b>three years, as it is stated</b> with regard to Daniel and his cohort who instructed the king of Babylonia: <b>“And they should be raised three years”</b> (Daniel 1:5), <b>“and he should teach them the books and the language of the Chaldeans”</b> (Daniel 1:4).
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> <i>tanna</i> explain the verses in Daniel? The Gemara answers: He holds that the verses in Daniel cannot be cited as a source for this principle because <b>the language of the Chaldeans is different, as</b> it is <b>easy</b> and can be learned in a shorter period. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yosei, explain the verses with regard to the Levites? The Gemara answers: He holds that <b>the <i>halakhot</i> of</b> Temple <b>service are different, as they are difficult</b> and require a longer period of study.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A priest, from</b> the time he reaches puberty and <b>grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs until he ages, is fit for</b> Temple <b>service, and blemishes disqualify him. A Levite from the age of thirty until the age of fifty is fit for</b> Temple <b>service, and</b> the passage of <b>years disqualifies him. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to the Tent of Meeting</b> of the Tabernacle <b>in the wilderness. But with regard to Shiloh and in the eternal Temple,</b> Levites <b>are disqualified only</b> due to a change <b>in voice</b> that renders them unable to recite the songs in the Temple with their brethren. <b>Rabbi Yosei said: What is the verse</b> from which this is derived?

Daf 24b

<b>“It came to pass, when the trumpeters and singers were as one, to make one sound to be heard”</b> (II Chronicles 5:13). This indicates that the Levites must be capable of singing in one voice, and one who is unable to do so is unfit for service.
The <i>baraita</i> teaches that the priest is eligible for service <b>until he ages.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Until when,</b> i.e., what is the definition of aging in this context? <b>Rabbi Ela says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: Until</b> his hands and feet begin to <b>tremble.</b>
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Mikvaot</i> 8:4): With regard to <b>one who experienced a seminal emission who</b> then <b>immersed</b> in a ritual bath <b>and did not urinate</b> before immersing, <b>when he urinates he is ritually impure,</b> because residue of the semen remain in his body and was discharged with the urine, rendering him impure. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: In</b> the case of <b>an ill</b> person <b>and an elderly</b> person, he is <b>ritually impure; in</b> the case of <b>a young</b> person <b>and a healthy</b> person, he is <b>ritually pure,</b> as the semen was presumably discharged in its entirety at the outset.
<b>Until when</b> is one considered <b>a young</b> person? <b>Rabbi Ela says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: Anyone who</b> is able to <b>stand on one of his legs and remove his shoe or put on his shoe</b> is considered young. <b>They said about Rabbi Ḥanina that he was eighty years old and would stand on one of his legs and remove his shoe or put on his shoe. Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> The <b>hot water and oil that my mother smeared on me in my youth benefited me in my old age.</b>
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>one’s beard</b> is <b>fully</b> grown, <b>he is fit to be appointed an emissary of the community</b> for various matters, <b>and to descend before the ark</b> as a prayer leader, <b>and to lift his hands</b> for the Priestly Benediction. <b>From when</b> is a priest <b>fit for</b> Temple <b>service?</b> It is <b>from</b> the time he reaches puberty and <b>grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: I say</b> that he is not fit for Temple service <b>until he is twenty</b> years of <b>age.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? The reason is <b>as it is written: “And appointed the Levites, from twenty years old and upward, to oversee of the work of the House of the Lord”</b> (Ezra 3:8). <b>And</b> what does <b>the other</b> <i>tanna</i> hold? He holds that <b>to oversee is different</b> and requires an older priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> what proof can be cited from this verse with regard to priests; <b>isn’t that verse written with regard to Levites?</b> The Gemara answers: It is understood <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: In twenty-four places</b> in the Bible the <b>priests are called Levites. And this is one of those</b> verses: <b>“And the priests the Levites, the sons of Zadok”</b> (Ezekiel 44:15). The verse in Ezra is another one of the verses.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“Any man of your descendants throughout their generations</b> that has a blemish shall not approach to offer the bread of his God” (Leviticus 21:17); <b>from here Rabbi Elazar says: A minor</b> priest is <b>unfit for</b> Temple <b>service, even</b> if he is <b>unblemished,</b> as he is not a man. <b>From when</b> is <b>he fit for service? From</b> the time he reaches puberty and <b>grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs. But his brethren the priests do not allow him to perform the service until he is twenty</b> years of <b>age.</b>
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say: This is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and he is</b> of the opinion that there is <b>no disqualification</b> for one between puberty and twenty years of age <b>even by rabbinic law.</b> The other priests simply do not allow priests of that age to perform the Temple service <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And there are</b> those <b>who say: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>is of</b> the opinion that there is <b>disqualification by rabbinic law</b> in that case, <b>and this</b> statement in the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and</b> they hold that <b>it is <i>ab initio</i> that</b> one may <b>not</b> perform the service, <b>but after the fact, his service is valid.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> That which is <b>ritually pure in an earthenware vessel</b> is <b>ritually impure in all the</b> other types of <b>vessels;</b> that which is <b>ritually pure in all the</b> other types of <b>vessels</b> is <b>ritually impure in an earthenware vessel.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> explaining the mishna: If a primary source of ritual impurity fell into the <b>airspace of an earthenware vessel</b> the vessel is <b>ritually impure, and</b> if it fell on <b>its outer side,</b> the vessel is <b>ritually pure.</b> If a primary source of ritual impurity fell into the <b>airspace of all the</b> other types of <b>vessels,</b> the vessels are <b>ritually pure, and</b> if it fell on <b>their outer side,</b> they are <b>ritually impure. It is found</b> that that which is <b>ritually pure in an earthenware vessel</b> is <b>ritually impure in all the</b> other <b>vessels,</b> and that which is <b>ritually pure in all the</b> other <b>vessels</b> is <b>ritually impure in an earthenware vessel.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? It is <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> based on the verse: “And every earthenware vessel into which [<i>tokho</i>] any of them falls, whatever is in it [<i>tokho</i>] shall be impure, and it you shall break” (Leviticus 11:33); if an impure item fell <b>“in it [<i>tokho</i>],” and even</b> in a case <b>where</b> the impure item <b>did not come into contact</b> with the vessel, the vessel becomes impure.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Do you say</b> that it is impure <b>even if</b> the impure item <b>did not come into contact</b> with the vessel, <b>or</b> perhaps <b>it is</b> impure <b>only if it did come into contact</b> with the vessel? <b>Rabbi Yonatan ben Avtolemos says: <i>Tokho</i> is stated</b> with regard <b>to transmitting impurity</b> to food in its airspace, as it is stated: “Whatever is in it [<i>tokho</i>] shall be impure,” <b>and <i>tokho</i> is stated</b> with regard <b>to becoming impure,</b> as it is stated: “Into which [<i>tokho</i>] any of them falls”; <b>just as</b> in the case of <b><i>tokho</i> that is stated</b> with regard <b>to transmitting impurity</b> to food in its airspace, the food is impure <b>even if</b> the impure item <b>did not come into contact</b> with the vessel, <b>so too,</b> in the case of <b><i>tokho</i> that is stated</b> with regard <b>to</b> the vessel <b>becoming impure,</b> the vessel is impure <b>even if</b> the impure item <b>did not come into contact</b> with it.
The Gemara asks: <b>And there,</b> with regard to rendering food impure in its airspace, <b>from where do we</b> derive that the food becomes impure even if it did not come into contact with the impure vessel? <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: The Torah testified about an earthenware vessel</b>

Daf 25a

that it renders impure everything within it, <b>and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if it is <b>full of mustard</b> seeds, in which case most of the seeds do not come in contact with the sides of the vessel, and nevertheless all the mustard seeds become impure.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said to Rava: And let</b> it be derived that <b>an earthenware vessel becomes impure from</b> contact of an impure item with <b>its outer side by means of an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If all the</b> other types of <b>vessels, which do not become impure from</b> the presence of an impure item in <b>their airspace, become impure from</b> contact of an impure item with <b>their outer side,</b> then with regard to <b>an earthenware vessel, which becomes impure from</b> the presence of an impure item in <b>its airspace, isn’t it logical that it will become ritually impure from</b> contact of an impure item with <b>its outer side?</b>
The Gemara answers: Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And every open vessel that has no sealed cover upon it</b> is impure” (Numbers 19:15), indicating that its impurity is dependent upon the mouth of the vessel. <b>Which is the vessel whose impurity hastily</b> takes effect just after the impure item enters <b>into its mouth? You must say</b> that is <b>an earthenware vessel. And</b> it is <b>when there is no sealed cover on it that</b> the vessel becomes <b>impure. But</b> when <b>there is a sealed cover on it,</b> the vessel is <b>pure,</b> as the earthenware vessel does not become impure from contact of an impure item with its outer side.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And let</b> it be derived that <b>all the</b> other <b>vessels become impure from</b> the presence of an impure item in <b>their airspace by means of an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If an earthenware vessel, which does not become impure from</b> contact of an impure item with <b>its outer side, becomes impure from</b> the presence of an impure item in <b>its airspace,</b> then with regard to <b>all the</b> other <b>vessels, which become impure from</b> contact of an impure item with <b>their outer side, isn’t it logical that they will become ritually impure from</b> the presence of an impure item in <b>their airspace?</b>
The Gemara answers: Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the carcasses of creeping animals: “And every earthenware vessel <b>into which [<i>tokho</i>]</b> any of them falls” (Leviticus 11:33), from which it is inferred: <b><i>Tokho</i>,</b> i.e., the airspace, <b>of this</b> earthenware vessel renders the vessel impure, <b>and not <i>tokho</i>,</b> the airspace, <b>of</b> any <b>other</b> kind of vessel.
The Gemara objects: How can the <i>halakha</i> be derived from the term <i>tokho</i> in that verse? <b>But didn’t</b> the Sages <b>interpret these</b> instances of <b><i>tokho</i></b> that appear in that verse and derive: Just as in the case of <i>tokho</i> that is stated with regard to transmitting impurity, the food is impure even though it did not come into contact with the vessel, so too, in the case of <i>tokho</i> that is stated with regard to the vessel becoming impure, the vessel is impure even though the impure item did not come into contact with it.
The Gemara explains: <b>Four</b> instances of the term <b><i>tokho</i></b> from which <i>halakhot</i> can be derived <b>are written: “<i>Tokho</i>”</b> is written, and <b><i>tokh</i></b> could have been written; those are two instances. Then, later in that verse, once again <b>“<i>tokho</i>”</b> is written, and <b><i>tokh</i></b> could have been written.
<b>One</b> instance is <b>to</b> teach the <i>halakha</i> <b>itself,</b> that the vessel renders the food in its airspace ritually impure, <b>and one</b> instance is <b>to</b> teach the <b>verbal analogy</b> from which it is derived that the vessel becomes impure without contact with the impure item; <b>and one</b> source is to teach that <b><i>tokho</i>,</b> the airspace, <b>of this</b> earthenware vessel renders the vessel impure, <b>and not <i>tokho</i> of</b> any <b>other</b> kind of vessel; <b>and one</b> source is to teach <b><i>tokho</i>,</b> food in the airspace of an impure earthenware vessel becomes impure, <b>but not <i>tokh tokho</i>,</b> not food that is in the airspace of a vessel that is within an earthenware vessel, <b>and even</b> if that inner vessel is one of the other types of <b>vessel</b> purified through <b>rinsing</b> in the water of a ritual bath.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> it be derived that <b>all the</b> other <b>vessels</b> do <b>not become impure from</b> contact of an impure item with <b>their outer sides, but</b> rather <b>from</b> the presence of an impure item <b>inside them and with contact</b> with their inner sides <b>by means of an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If an earthenware vessel, which becomes impure from</b> the presence of an impure item in <b>its airspace, does not become impure from</b> contact of an impure item with <b>its outer side,</b> then with regard to <b>all the</b> other <b>vessels, which do not become impure from</b> the presence of an impure item in <b>their airspace, isn’t it logical that they do not become impure from</b> contact of an impure item with <b>their outer side?</b>
The Gemara answers: Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And every open vessel that has no sealed cover upon it is impure”</b> (Numbers 19:15), from which it is derived: <b>This</b> earthenware vessel (see Leviticus 11:33) <b>is</b> the one <b>that when there is not a sealed cover upon it,</b> it is <b>impure, but</b> when <b>there is a sealed cover upon it,</b> it is <b>pure. But</b> with regard to <b>all the</b> other <b>vessels, whether there is a sealed cover upon them or whether there is not a sealed cover upon them, they become impure.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> That which is <b>ritually pure in wooden vessels</b> is <b>ritually impure in metal vessels;</b> that which is <b>ritually pure in metal vessels</b> is <b>ritually impure in wooden vessels.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in explanation of the mishna: <b>Unfinished [<i>golmei</i>] wooden vessels</b> that are receptacles and are fit for use but work remains to complete their crafting are susceptible to becoming <b>impure. Flat</b> wooden utensils are <b>not susceptible to impurity. Unfinished metal vessels</b> are <b>not susceptible to impurity. Flat</b> metal utensils are susceptible to becoming <b>impure. It is found</b> that that which is <b>ritually pure in wooden vessels</b> is <b>ritually impure in metal vessels;</b> that which is <b>ritually pure in metal vessels</b> is <b>ritually impure in wooden vessels.</b>
<b>And these are</b> the <b>unfinished wooden vessels: Any</b> vessel <b>that</b> one plans in the <b>future to smooth, to set</b> gems or ornaments in it, <b>to plane</b> it, <b>to adorn</b> it with grooves and protuberances, <b>to rub</b> it and smooth it <b>with</b> the skin of <b>a tuna [<i>tunas</i>],</b> or if it is <b>lacking a base or a rim or a handle,</b> the vessel is susceptible to becoming <b>impure.</b> If the vessel is <b>lacking</b> the <b>hollowing</b> necessary to render it a receptacle, it is <b>not susceptible to impurity.</b>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that if the vessel is <b>lacking hollowing,</b> it is not susceptible to becoming impure, as it is clearly not a vessel? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> only in a case <b>where one hollowed three <i>log</i> [<i>kefiza</i>] in</b> a receptacle that he intends to hold <b>one <i>kav</i>,</b> which contains six <i>log</i>. Even though it is a receptacle, since the receptacle is incomplete it is not susceptible to impurity.
<b>And these are</b> the <b>unfinished metal vessels: Any</b> vessel <b>that</b> one plans in the <b>future</b>

Daf 25b

<b>to smooth, to set</b> gems or ornaments in it, <b>to plane</b> it, <b>to adorn</b> it, <b>to strike</b> it <b>with a hammer,</b> or if it is <b>lacking a base or a rim or a handle,</b> the vessel is <b>not susceptible to impurity.</b> If the vessel was complete and was <b>lacking a cover,</b> the vessel is susceptible to becoming <b>impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>these</b> unfinished wooden vessels, with regard to which the <i>halakha</i> is that provided they are fit for use they are susceptible to impurity, <b>and what is different</b> about <b>those</b> unfinished metal vessels, with regard to which the <i>halakha</i> is that even if they are fit for use they are not susceptible to impurity until their crafting is complete? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The difference is that <b>since</b> metal vessels <b>are crafted for</b> uses of <b>honor,</b> they are not considered vessels until their completion. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The difference is that <b>since the worth of</b> metal vessels <b>is expensive,</b> they cannot be sold at that price unless they are complete.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between their</b> opinions? The Gemara answers: The difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to <b>bone vessels</b> crafted from horns, which are expensive but are not crafted for uses of honor. <b>And Rav Naḥman follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as Rav Naḥman says:</b> The halakhic status of <b>bone vessels</b> with regard to impurity is <b>like</b> that of <b>metal vessels.</b>
The Gemara asks: Is that to say <b>by inference that bone vessels are susceptible to ritual impurity?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “And all work of goats…you shall purify”</b> (Numbers 31:20)? It is <b>to include</b> vessels <b>that come from the goats, from the horns and from the hooves,</b> and indicate that they are susceptible to impurity. And <b>from where</b> is it derived that vessels that come from the horns and the hooves of <b>other domesticated animals and undomesticated animals</b> are susceptible to impurity? It is derived from the verse, as <b>the verse states: “And all work,”</b> where the term “all” is an amplification. <b>If so, why</b> must <b>the verse state: “Goats?”</b> It serves <b>to exclude birds,</b> as vessels crafted from the bones of birds are not susceptible to impurity.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to the obligation of separating <i>teruma</i> and tithes, the stage of development <b>that</b> is <b>obligated in bitter almonds</b> is <b>exempt in sweet</b> almonds; and the stage in development <b>that</b> is <b>obligated in sweet</b> almonds is <b>exempt in bitter</b> almonds.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in explanation of the mishna: In the case of <b>bitter almonds,</b> when they are <b>small</b> one is <b>obligated</b> to separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes, as they are not yet bitter and are fit for consumption; when they are <b>large</b> one is <b>exempt</b> from separating <i>teruma</i> and tithes, because they are bitter and unfit for consumption. In the case of <b>sweet</b> almonds, when they are <b>large</b> one is <b>obligated</b> to separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes, because the almonds are ripe and fit for consumption; when they are <b>small</b> one is <b>exempt</b> from separating <i>teruma</i> and tithes, because they are not fit for consumption.
With regard to bitter almonds, <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, says in the name of his father to exempt</b> both <b>this</b> small almond <b>and that</b> large almond. <b>And some say to obligate</b> both <b>this</b> small almond <b>and that</b> large almond. <b>Rabbi Ela said: Rabbi Ḥanina issued a ruling in Tzippori in accordance with the statement of the one who says to exempt</b> both <b>this</b> small almond <b>and that</b> large almond.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to the one who says to obligate</b> both <b>this</b> small almond <b>and that</b> large almond, <b>for what</b> use <b>are</b> the <b>large</b> almonds <b>fit?</b> They are bitter and unfit for consumption. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Since one can sweeten them by means of</b> roasting them on <b>the fire,</b> this renders them fit for consumption.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b><i>Temed</i>,</b> a beverage produced from grape residue soaked in water, <b>until it fermented, may not be purchased with</b> second-<b>tithe money</b> to be drunk in Jerusalem, because it is not wine. <b>And</b> if three <i>log</i> of it fall into a ritual bath, its halakhic status is that of drawn water and <b>it invalidates the ritual bath. Once it fermented, it</b> is wine, and therefore it <b>may be purchased with</b> second-<b>tithe money and it does not invalidate the ritual bath.</b>
With regard to <b>brothers who are partners</b> in the inheritance of their father, <b>when they are obligated to</b> add <b>the premium [<i>kalbon</i>]</b> to their annual half-shekel payment to the Temple, <b>they are exempt from animal tithe; when they are obligated to</b> separate <b>animal tithe, they are exempt from</b> adding <b>the premium.</b> Partners who pay the half-shekel are required to add the premium and are exempt from animal tithe. If they are not true partners, but their inheritance remains the property of the father, the sons are exempt from paying the premium, and they are obligated to separate animal tithe.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to <i>temed</i>, the Gemara asks: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in <b>the mishna?</b> Ostensibly, it is <b>neither</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda nor</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as it is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Ma’asrot</i> 5:6): With regard to <b>one who prepares <i>temed</i></b> by placing water over grape byproducts, <b>and he placed</b> a certain <b>measure of water, and</b> when measuring the finished product <b>he found</b> its measure <b>equivalent to</b> the <b>measure</b> of water that he placed, he is <b>exempt</b> from the obligation of tithing it, as although it tastes like wine, there is nothing in it but water. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda obligates</b> him to tithe it because the taste determines that it is wine.
<b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in the mishna? <b>If</b> it is the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> then if there is no more than the initial measure of water that he placed, he should be exempt <b>even if it fermented. If</b> it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> he holds that one is obligated <b>even if it did not ferment,</b> as taste is his sole criterion. <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b>

Daf 26a

It is <b>in</b> a case <b>where</b> the <i>temed</i> <b>fermented</b> that there is <b>a dispute</b> between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis. It is only then that Rabbi Yehuda deems him obligated to tithe the <i>temed</i> if it tastes like wine, <b>and the mishna</b> that treats fermented <i>temed</i> like wine is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. And likewise, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> It is <b>in</b> a case <b>where</b> the <i>temed</i> <b>fermented</b> that there is <b>a dispute.</b>
§ <b>And Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says:</b> In a case of unfermented <b><i>temed</i> that one purchased with</b> second-<b>tithe money and</b> that <b>ultimately fermented,</b> the <i>temed</i> <b>he purchased</b> assumes the sanctity of second-<b>tithe</b> produce, and the money is desacralized. <b>What is the reason</b> that the <i>temed</i> assumes the sanctity of second-tithe produce? The reason is that <b>the matter was revealed retroactively,</b> such <b>that</b> when the <i>temed</i> was purchased it <b>was produce</b> fit to be purchased with second-tithe money and was not merely water.
<b>But</b> in that case, <b>the mishna that teaches</b> that if the <i>temed</i> <b>fermented, yes,</b> one may purchase it with second-tithe money, but if it <b>did not ferment,</b> it may <b>not,</b> and the money remains sacred, why does the mishna state it unequivocally? <b>Perhaps, if he</b> would have <b>left</b> the <i>temed</i> long enough, it would <b>have fermented. Rabba said</b> in explanation: The mishna is referring to a case <b>where one left</b> some <b>of</b> the <i>temed</i> <b>in a cup</b> to monitor its status <b>and it did not ferment.</b> Therefore, one may be certain that it was not produce when he purchased it with second-tithe money, and the money remains sacred.
<b>Rava said:</b> It is not necessary to understand the mishna specifically in that manner; rather, in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 7:5): In a case where there are <b>three <i>log</i></b> of drawn <b>water less one sixty-fourth of a <i>log</i> [<i>kortov</i>],</b> or any small measure of water, <b>into which a <i>kortov</i> of wine fell,</b> increasing the measure of liquid to a total of three <i>log</i>, <b>and the appearance of</b> those three <i>log</i> is <b>like the appearance of wine, and</b> then those three <i>log</i> <b>fell into a ritual bath,</b> completing its requisite forty <i>se’a</i>, <b>it has not invalidated</b> the ritual bath. The reason is that three <i>log</i> of drawn water invalidate the ritual bath, and less than that measure of water fell into the ritual bath.
Furthermore, in a case where there are <b>three <i>log</i></b> of drawn <b>water less one <i>kortov</i>, into which a <i>kortov</i> of milk fell, and the appearance of</b> those three <i>log</i> is <b>like the appearance of water, and</b> those three <i>log</i> <b>fell into a ritual bath, it has not invalidated</b> the ritual bath, because in this case too, less than three <i>log</i> of drawn water fell into the ritual bath.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says: Everything follows the appearance</b> of those three <i>log</i>. Therefore, in the case of a <i>kortov</i> of milk completing the three <i>log</i>, the ritual bath is invalidated because the mixture still has the appearance of water.
Rava reasoned: <b>Doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> ben Nuri <b>say</b> that <b>we follow the appearance</b> in determining the halakhic status of the liquid? <b>Here too,</b> in the mishna, <b>follow the appearance</b> in determining the halakhic status of the liquid, <b>and</b> in the case of the <i>temed</i>, as long as it has not yet fermented, <b>the taste and the appearance of that</b> liquid <b>is</b> that of <b>water.</b> By contrast, Rav Naḥman holds in accordance with the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i> in the mishna in tractate <i>Mikvaot</i> that the status of the liquid is not determined by its appearance. Rather, since it ultimately fermented, it became clear retroactively that when the <i>temed</i> was purchased it was produce fit to be purchased with second-tithe money, and was not merely water.
The Gemara resumes its discussion of the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis with regard to which Rav Naḥman said: It is in a case where the <i>temed</i> fermented that there is a dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis, and it is only then that Rabbi Yehuda deems one obligated to tithe the <i>temed</i> if it tastes like wine. If it did not yet ferment, even Rabbi Yehuda concedes that one is not obligated to tithe it. The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> Rav Naḥman <b>disagrees</b> with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar, as Rabbi Elazar says: Everyone,</b> even Rabbi Yehuda, <b>agrees that one may not separate</b> tithes <b>for</b> this <i>temed</i> <b>from</b> <i>temed</i> in <b>another place, unless it fermented.</b>
Apparently, Rabbi Elazar <b>holds</b> that it is <b>in</b> a case where the <i>temed</i> <b>did not ferment</b> that there is <b>a dispute</b> between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis, <b>and Rabbi Yehuda obligates</b> one to tithe the <i>temed</i> that did not ferment <b>only from</b> that <i>temed</i> <b>itself,</b> because if it ferments it is tithe and if not, he has done nothing. <b>But</b> concerning <i>temed</i> that comes <b>from elsewhere,</b> one may <b>not</b> separate it for this <i>temed</i>, as <b>perhaps</b> he will <b>come to separate</b> tithe <b>from the</b> produce of <b>obligation,</b> i.e., fermented <i>temed</i>, <b>for the</b> produce of <b>exemption,</b> i.e., <i>temed</i> that will not ferment, <b>and from the</b> produce of <b>exemption for the</b> produce of <b>obligation.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to <b><i>temed</i></b> that became ritually impure, <b>until it ferments,</b>

Daf 26b

<b>one brings</b> the <i>temed</i> <b>into contact with water</b> of a ritual bath by immersing the vessel holding the <i>temed</i> in a ritual bath, thereby purifying the <i>temed</i>. <b>Once it ferments, he does not bring it into contact with water,</b> as that is effective only in purifying water and not in purifying other liquids. <b>Rava said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <b>only</b> with regard to a case <b>where one prepared <i>temed</i> with ritually pure water and</b> it later <b>became impure, but</b> if the water was <b>impure from the outset,</b> the contact with the ritual bath would <b>not</b> purify it.
<b>Rav Geviha from Bei Katil went</b> and <b>stated this <i>halakha</i> before Rav Ashi</b> and asked: <b>What is different</b> in the case of water that is <b>impure from the outset</b> such <b>that</b> bringing the <i>temed</i> into contact with the ritual bath would <b>not</b> purify it, <b>as we say: Since the water is heavy it settles</b> at the <b>bottom</b> of the vessel, <b>and the fruit,</b> the grape residue, <b>floats above, and</b> therefore, <b>contact</b> with the water of the ritual bath <b>would not be effective for the water</b> of the <i>temed</i>? <b>If so,</b> the same would apply in the case of water that was <b>ritually pure and ultimately became impure</b> as <i>temed</i> <b>also.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the reason contact is effective in the case of ritually pure water that later became impure as <i>temed</i> is that the water and the residue <b>are intermingled. Here too,</b> in the case of water that was impure from the outset, the water and the residue <b>are intermingled,</b> and contact with the water of a ritual bath would be effective.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any situation where there is sale</b> of one’s daughter as a Hebrew maidservant, i.e., when she is a minor, <b>there is no fine</b> of fifty <i>sela</i> paid to her father if she is raped or seduced, as that fine is paid to her father only when she is a young woman. <b>And any situation where there is a fine</b> paid to the father <b>there is no sale.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: This is the statement of Rabbi Meir, but the Rabbis said: There is</b> the possibility of payment of <b>a fine in a situation</b> where there is <b>sale, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A minor girl from</b> the age of <b>one day old until she</b> reaches puberty and <b>grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs is subject to sale, but is not entitled to</b> receive payment of <b>a fine. Once she</b> reaches puberty and <b>grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs,</b> from that point <b>until she matures</b> into a grown woman <b>she is entitled to</b> receive payment of <b>a fine, but is not subject to sale.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir, as Rabbi Meir would state</b> a principle: <b>Any situation where there is a sale, there is no fine; and any situation where there is a fine, there is no sale.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: A minor girl from the age of three years and one day until she matures</b> into a grown woman <b>is entitled to</b> receive payment of <b>a fine.</b>
The Gemara asks: Is that to say that <b>yes,</b> she is entitled to payment of <b>a fine,</b> but she is <b>not</b> subject to <b>sale?</b> Isn’t her father permitted to sell her during most of that period? The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that the Rabbis said: She is <b>also</b> entitled to receive payment of <b>a fine</b> during that period <b>in a situation</b> where she is subject to <b>sale.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any situation where there is</b> the right of <b>refusal</b> for a minor girl married by her mother or brothers, enabling her to opt out of the marriage, <b>there is no <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> as a minor girl whose husband died without children cannot perform <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>And any situation where there is <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> once she has reached majority, <b>there is no</b> right of <b>refusal.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: This is the statement of Rabbi Meir, but the Rabbis say: There is</b> the right of <b>refusal in a situation</b> where there is <b><i>ḥalitza</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Until when may a girl refuse?</b> She may do so as long as she is a minor, <b>until she grows two</b> pubic <b>hairs,</b> which are signs of puberty rendering her a young woman; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> She may refuse <b>until the black</b> hairs in the pubic area appear to cover an area <b>greater than the white</b> skin of the area uncovered by hair. At that stage, she is already eligible to perform the rite of <i>ḥalitza</i>. That is the opinion of the Rabbis.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Any situation where there is a shofar blast</b> sounded on the eve of Shabbat or a Festival to stop the people from performing labor and to demarcate between the sacred and the profane, <b>there is no <i>havdala</i></b> recited at the conclusion of the Shabbat or Festival in prayer and over a cup of wine. <b>And any situation where there is <i>havdala</i></b> recited, <b>there is no shofar blast</b> sounded.
How so? On <b>a Festival that occurs on Shabbat eve, one sounds</b> the shofar to stop the people from performing labor that is permitted on the Festival and prohibited on Shabbat and to demarcate between one sacred day and another; <b>and one does not recite <i>havdala</i>,</b> as that is recited only when the transition is from a sacred day to a profane day or from a day of greater sanctity to a day of lesser sanctity. The sanctity of Shabbat is greater than the sanctity of the Festival, and therefore <i>havdala</i> is not recited in this case. On a Festival that occurs <b>at the conclusion of Shabbat, one recites <i>havdala</i>, but one does not sound</b> the shofar.
<b>How does one recite <i>havdala</i></b> in that case; i.e., what is the formula of the blessing? It concludes: <b>Who distinguishes between sacred and sacred,</b> as opposed to the standard blessing at the conclusion of Shabbat: Who distinguishes between sacred and profane. <b>Rabbi Dosa says</b> that the formula is: Who distinguishes <b>between greater sanctity and lesser sanctity.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>How does one sound a <i>tekia</i></b> on a Festival that occurs on Shabbat eve, when the difference between the sanctity of the preceding day and the sanctity of the coming day is not as pronounced as it is on a standard Shabbat eve? <b>Rav Yehuda said: One sounds a <i>tekia</i>,</b> i.e., a long continuous shofar blast, <b>and sounds a <i>terua</i>,</b> i.e., a staccato series of shofar blasts, <b>from the midst of the <i>tekia</i>. And Rav Asi said:</b> One does not sound a continuous blast; rather, <b>he sounds a <i>tekia</i> and</b> then <b>sounds a <i>terua</i> in one breath. Rav Asi instituted</b> the practice <b>in</b> the city of <b>Huzal in accordance with his <i>halakha</i>.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statements of Rav Yehuda and Rav Asi from a <i>baraita</i>: On <b>a Festival that occurs on Shabbat eve, one sounds a <i>tekia</i> but does not sound a <i>terua</i>. What, is it not</b> that <b>one does not sound a <i>terua</i> at all?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> rather, <b>Rav Yehuda explains</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>according to his</b> line of <b>reasoning and Rav Asi explains</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>according to his</b> line of <b>reasoning. Rav Yehuda explains</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>according to his</b> line of <b>reasoning: One does not sound a distinct <i>terua</i>; rather,</b> he sounds the <i>terua</i> that emerges <b>from the midst of</b> the <b><i>tekia</i>. And Rav Asi explains</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>according to his</b> line of <b>reasoning: One does not sound</b> the <i>tekia</i> and <b>the <i>terua</i> in two breaths; rather,</b> he sounds them <b>in one breath.</b>
§ The mishna states that on a Festival that occurs <b>at the conclusion of Shabbat</b> one recites <i>havdala</i>, and that the Sages disagreed as to the formula of that blessing. The Gemara asks: <b>Where does one recite</b> the formula in question? <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> He recites the formula <b>at the conclusion of</b> the blessing. But in the body of the blessing one recites the same formula as in every conclusion of Shabbat: Who distinguishes between sacred and profane, between light and darkness, etc. <b>And likewise, Rav Naḥman said:</b> He recites the formula <b>at the conclusion of</b> the blessing.
<b>And Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> One recites that formula <b>even at the beginning,</b> in the body of the blessing, instead of the formula: Who distinguishes between sacred and profane. The Gemara comments: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his</b> opinion.
The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Dosa says</b> that the formula is: Who distinguishes <b>between greater sanctity and lesser sanctity.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his</b> opinion.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> At the conclusion of <b>a Festival that occurs in the middle of the week, one recites: Who distinguishes between sacred and profane, and between light and darkness, and between Israel and the nations, and between the seventh day and the six days of labor,</b> even though it is not Shabbat. <b>What is the reason</b> for that practice? <b>He is enumerating the series of distinctions</b> that the Sages instituted and not specifically the distinction unique to that particular day.

Daf 27a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slaughters</b> by cutting <b>one</b> <i>siman</i>, i.e., the windpipe or the gullet, <b>in a bird, and two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>in an animal, his slaughter is valid, and</b> the halakhic status of <b>the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>is like</b> that of the entire <i>siman</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The slaughter is not valid <b>until he cuts the veins [<i>haveridin</i>],</b> i.e., the major blood vessels in the neck. If one cut <b>half of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird or one and a half</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>in an animal, his slaughter is not valid.</b> If one cut <b>the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird or the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>in an animal, his slaughter is valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers from the term: <b>One who slaughters,</b> that if one slaughtered, then <b>after the fact, yes,</b> the slaughter is valid; but <b><i>ab initio</i>, no,</b> it is prohibited. The Gemara asks: Is the ruling with regard to the cutting of <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>in an animal</b> that <b><i>ab initio</i>, no,</b> it is prohibited? If so, <b>how much</b> is one expected <b>to continue and cut</b> the <i>simanim</i>, <i>ab initio</i>? There are only two relevant <i>simanim</i> to be cut. The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the reference is <b>to</b> the cutting of <b>one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird,</b> as one is required to cut both <i>simanim</i> in a bird <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the reference is <b>to</b> the passage in the mishna that states that the halakhic status of <b>the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>is like</b> that of the entire <i>siman</i>, as one is required to cut the entire <i>siman ab initio</i>.
§ <b><i>Kaf</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>shin</i></b> is <b>a mnemonic</b> for the sources of the statements cited in the discussion that follows: Rav Kahana, Rav Yeimar, and the school of Rabbi Yishmael.
<b>Rav Kahana says: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to slaughter that it is</b> performed <b>from the neck?</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated: “And he shall slaughter [<i>veshaḥat</i>] the young bull</b> before the Lord” (Leviticus 1:5), which is interpreted homiletically: <b>From the place where</b> the animal <b>bends [<i>shaḥ</i>], purify it [<i>ḥattehu</i>]</b> through slaughter. The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> does one ascertain <b>that this</b> term, <b><i>ḥattehu</i>, is an expression of purification?</b> The Gemara answers: It is ascertained from a verse, <b>as it is written: “And he shall purify [<i>veḥitte</i>] the house”</b> (Leviticus 14:52). <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that it is ascertained <b>from here: “Purge me [<i>teḥatte’eni</i>] with hyssop and I will be pure”</b> (Psalms 51:9).
The Gemara challenges: <b>And say</b> that slaughter is <b>from its tail,</b> which is also a place in the animal’s body that is bent. The Gemara responds: From the term: <b>Bends [<i>shaḥ</i>],</b> one can conclude <b>by inference that we require</b> a part of the animal’s body that can stand <b>erect</b> and that bends; <b>and this,</b> the tail, <b>is bent perpetually</b> and is never erect. The Gemara challenges: <b>And say</b> that slaughter is <b>from its ear,</b> which is erect and bends. The Gemara explains: <b>We require</b> that slaughter be performed on a part of the animal’s body from which <b>blood of the soul</b> is spilled, <b>and</b> when one cuts the ear <b>there is no</b> blood of the soul spilled.
The Gemara asks: <b>And say that one rends</b> the animal starting from the ear <b>and continues until the blood of the soul</b> is spilled. <b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to those actions that invalidate slaughter, i.e., <b>interrupting</b> the slaughter, <b>pressing</b> the knife, <b>concealing</b> the knife in the course of an inverted slaughter, <b>diverting</b> the knife from the place of slaughter, <b>and ripping</b> the <i>simanim</i> from their place before cutting them, <b>from where do we</b> derive them? <b>Rather,</b> these disqualifications are learned through <b>tradition,</b> i.e., a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai. The requirement of <b>slaughter from the neck is also</b> learned through <b>tradition,</b> and has no biblical source.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if the <i>halakha</i> is derived through tradition, <b>what</b> <i>halakha</i> does <b>the verse:</b> “And you shall slaughter,” <b>come to</b> teach? The Gemara answers: The verse serves to teach <b>that</b> one should <b>not</b> sever the head completely from the animal’s body and <b>render it a broken</b> animal. He cuts only the windpipe and the gullet, which are adjacent to the major blood vessels.
<b>Rav Yeimar says:</b> From where is it derived that slaughter is performed from the neck? It is derived from a verse, as <b>the verse states: “And you shall slaughter [<i>vezavaḥta</i>]</b> of your herd and of your flock” (Deuteronomy 12:21), which is interpreted homiletically: <b>From the place where</b> the blood <b>flows [<i>shezav</i>], break it [<i>ḥattehu</i>],</b> i.e., cut it. The Gemara asks: <b>From where may</b> it <b>be inferred that this</b> term, <b><i>ḥattehu</i>, is an expression of breaking?</b> The Gemara answers: It is inferred from a verse, <b>as it is written: “Neither fear nor be dismayed [<i>teḥat</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 1:21); ensure that your spirit will not be broken.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And say</b> that an animal is slaughtered <b>from its nose,</b> from which mucus flows, as the verse did not mention blood. The Gemara responds: <b>We require</b> a fluid that <b>flows by means of breaking, and this</b> mucus <b>flows on its own.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>And say</b> that an animal is slaughtered <b>from its heart</b> by means of stabbing. <b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to those actions that invalidate slaughter, i.e., <b>interrupting, pressing</b> the knife during slaughter, <b>concealing</b> the knife in the course of an inverted slaughter, <b>diverting</b> the knife from the place of slaughter, <b>and ripping, from where do we</b> derive them? <b>Rather,</b> these disqualifications are learned through <b>tradition.</b> The requirement of <b>slaughter from the neck is also</b> learned through <b>tradition.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if the <i>halakha</i> is derived through tradition, <b>what</b> <i>halakha</i> does the phrase in <b>the verse:</b> “And you shall slaughter” <b>come to</b> teach? The Gemara answers: The phrase serves to teach <b>that</b> one should <b>not</b> sever the head completely from the animal’s body and <b>render it a broken</b> animal. He cuts only the windpipe and the gullet.
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> From where is it derived that slaughter is performed from the neck? It is derived from a verse, as it is stated: <b>“And he shall slaughter [<i>veshaḥat</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 1:5). <b>Do not read</b> it as: <b><i>Veshaḥat</i>; rather,</b> read it as: <b><i>Vesaḥat</i>,</b> which literally means: And he shall squeeze, which is interpreted homiletically: <b>From the place where</b> the animal <b>speaks [<i>saḥ</i>], purify it [<i>ḥattehu</i>].</b> The animal’s voice emanates from its throat; therefore, it is slaughtered from the neck.
The Gemara objects: <b>And say</b> that slaughter is <b>from its tongue.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>We require</b> that slaughter be performed on a part of the animal’s body from which <b>blood of the soul</b> is spilled, <b>and</b> when one cuts the tongue <b>there is no</b> blood of the soul spilled. The Gemara objects: <b>And say that one rends</b> the animal starting from the tongue <b>and continues until the blood of the soul</b> is spilled. <b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to those actions that invalidate slaughter, i.e., <b>interrupting, pressing</b> the knife, <b>concealing</b> the knife, <b>diverting</b> the knife, <b>and ripping, from where do we</b> derive them? <b>Rather,</b> these disqualifications are learned through <b>tradition.</b> The requirement of <b>slaughter from the neck is also</b> learned through <b>tradition.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if the <i>halakha</i> is derived through tradition, <b>what</b> <i>halakha</i> does the phrase in <b>the verse:</b> “And you shall slaughter,” <b>come to</b> teach? The Gemara answers: The phrase serves to teach <b>that</b> one should <b>not</b> sever the head completely from the animal’s body and <b>render it a broken</b> animal. He cuts only the windpipe and the gullet.
<b>And a <i>tanna</i></b> who recited <i>mishnayot</i> and <i>baraitot</i> in the study hall <b>cites</b> the source for the <i>halakha</i> that slaughter is performed from the neck <b>from here: As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya says: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to slaughter that it is</b> performed <b>from the neck?</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated: “And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall arrange the pieces,</b> the head, and the fat…upon the altar” (Leviticus 1:8).
Rabbi Ḥiyya explains: <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “The head, and the fat.” What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “The head, and the fat”? Weren’t the head and the fat</b> included <b>in</b> the <b>category of all the pieces,</b> mentioned earlier in the verse? <b>For what</b> purpose did <b>they emerge</b> from the category and warrant individual mention? This is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is stated: “And he shall flay the burnt offering, and cut it</b> into its pieces” (Leviticus 1:6). One might have thought that <b>I have</b> derived that <b>only the pieces that are</b> included <b>in the category of flaying</b> must be arranged on the altar. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include the head, which was already</b> partially <b>severed</b> when the animal was slaughtered, and is not flayed? It is derived from a verse, as <b>the verse states: “With its head and its fat, and</b> the priest <b>shall arrange</b> them” (Leviticus 1:12).
The <i>tanna</i> concludes: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>says: The head, which was already</b> partially <b>severed,</b> one learns <b>by inference that slaughter is from the neck,</b> as the neck connects the head to the body.
The Gemara questions the formulation of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>And the <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>opened with</b> a question about the extraneous phrase written with regard to a bull burnt offering: <b>“The head, and the fat”</b> (Leviticus 1:8), <b>and concludes with</b> an explanation of the phrase written with regard to a sheep burnt offering: <b>“Its head and its fat”</b> (Leviticus 1:12). The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> is what the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying: From where</b> is it derived <b>to include the head, which was already</b> partially <b>severed?</b> It is derived from a verse, as <b>the verse states: “The head, and the fat”</b> (Leviticus 1:8).
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the verse cited at the end of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>“Its head and its fat”?</b> The Gemara answers: The verse <b>is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that the head and the fat precede all the</b> other <b>pieces</b>when the sacrificial portions are sacrificed on the altar? <b>The verse states: “With its head and its fat, and</b> the priest <b>shall arrange</b> them” (Leviticus 1:12).

Daf 27b

The Gemara asks: <b>And why do I</b> need <b>the first</b> mention of <b>fat that the Merciful One writes:</b> “The pieces, the head, and the fat” (Leviticus 1:8)? Wasn’t the derivation from that verse restricted to the head? The Gemara answers that it is <b>necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How does</b> the priest who elevates the sacrificial portions of the animal to the altar <b>perform</b> that task? <b>He</b> uses <b>the fat</b> to <b>cover the place of slaughter,</b> i.e., to conceal the bloody neck, <b>and elevates</b> the head to the top of the altar, <b>and that is a deferential manner</b> toward <b>the Most High.</b>
<b>And this <i>tanna</i> cites</b> proof that slaughter is from the neck <b>from here: As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the Torah writes with regard to the impurity of carcasses: <b>“This is the law of the animal, and of the bird”</b> (Leviticus 11:46), indicating that the two are somehow equated. <b>But with regard to what law is an animal equal to a bird and a bird to an animal?</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity governing animals and birds are not comparable; <b>an animal imparts impurity by contact and by carrying,</b> whereas <b>a bird does not impart impurity by contact or by carrying.</b> Furthermore, <b>a bird renders</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat; an animal does not render</b> one’s <b>garments impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>With regard to what law is an animal equal to a bird and a bird to an animal?</b> The verse comes <b>to say to you: Just as an animal</b> avoids the impurity of being an unslaughtered carcass <b>through slaughter, so too, a bird</b> avoids the impurity of being an unslaughtered carcass <b>through slaughter.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>If</b> so, say, based on the same juxtaposition: <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of an animal, it avoids the impurity <b>through</b> the cutting of <b>the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i>, i.e., the windpipe and the gullet, <b>so too here,</b> in the case of a bird, it avoids the impurity <b>through</b> the cutting of <b>the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i>. The Gemara explains that <b>the verse states: “This</b> is the law,” to restrict the scope of the juxtaposition in the sense that not all of the <i>halakhot</i> of birds and animals are equal.
The <i>baraita</i> continues. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: With regard to what law is an animal equal to a bird and a bird to an animal?</b> The verse comes <b>to say to you: Just as</b> in the case of <b>a bird, its fitness</b> for sacrifice and for consumption is accomplished through pinching and slaughter <b>from the neck,</b> as the Torah states with regard to bird offerings that one pinches off its head from the neck, <b>so too,</b> in the case of <b>an animal, its fitness</b> for sacrifice and for consumption is accomplished through slaughter <b>from the neck.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>If</b> so, say, based on the same juxtaposition: <b>Just as there,</b> in the case of a bird, the pinching is performed <b>adjacent to</b> the <b>nape</b> of the neck, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to an animal, the slaughter is performed <b>adjacent to</b> the <b>nape</b> of the neck and not from the throat. The Gemara explains that therefore, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to a bird: <b>“And pinch off its head adjacent to its nape, but shall not divide it asunder”</b> (Leviticus 5:8), from which it is derived: <b>Its head,</b> i.e., the bird’s head, is pinched <b>adjacent</b> to the <b>nape, but the head of another,</b> the animal, <b>is not</b> cut <b>adjacent</b> to the <b>nape.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Eliezer, what does he do with this</b> term: <b>“This</b> is the law,” from which the first <i>tanna</i> restricted the scope of the juxtaposition between animals and birds? The Gemara answers: <b>If not</b> for the derivation from the term <b>“This</b> is the law,” <b>I would say: Just as</b> the fitness of <b>a bird</b> is accomplished <b>by</b> cutting <b>one of the <i>simanim</i> that must be severed in ritual slaughter,</b> i.e., either the windpipe or the gullet, <b>so too,</b> the fitness of <b>an animal</b> is accomplished <b>by</b> cutting <b>one <i>siman</i>.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “This</b> is the law,” to restrict the juxtaposition.
§ The Gemara proceeds to discuss the source for the slaughter of non-sacred birds. <b>Bar Kappara teaches</b> that the verse states: <b>“This is the law of the animal, and of the bird,</b> and of every living creature that moves in the waters, and of every creature that swarms upon the earth” (Leviticus 11:46). <b>The verse situated the bird between</b> the <b>animal and</b> the <b>fish.
