To require</b> the cutting of the <b>two <i>simanim</i></b> that must be severed in ritual slaughter, i.e., the windpipe and the gullet, for the slaughter of a bird, <b>is impossible, as it was already juxtaposed to fish,</b> which do not require slaughter at all. <b>To exempt it with nothing,</b> i.e., to exempt the bird from slaughter altogether, <b>is impossible, as it was already juxtaposed to</b> the <b>animal. How,</b> then, <b>is fitness</b> of a bird for consumption accomplished? It is rendered fit <b>with</b> the cutting of <b>one <i>siman</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>fish are not subject to slaughter? If we say</b> that it is <b>because it is written: “If flocks and herds be slaughtered for them…or if all the fish of the sea be gathered together for them,</b> will they suffice them” (Numbers 11:22), which indicates that <b>mere gathering suffices for them,</b> that is not a proof.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>But if that is so, with regard to quail</b> as well, concerning <b>which it is written:</b> “And the people rose up…<b>and gathered the quail”</b> (Numbers 11:32), <b>so too,</b> would one say with regard to birds <b>that,</b> like fish, their fitness is <b>not</b> accomplished <b>with slaughter?</b> The Gemara responds with a question. <b>But didn’t you say: To exempt</b> birds from slaughter altogether <b>with nothing is impossible, as it was already juxtaposed to</b> the <b>animal?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There, gathering</b> of quail <b>is not written in</b> the <b>context</b> of the <b>slaughter of others;</b> therefore, gathering is not to be understood as an alternative to slaughtering the birds. <b>Here, gathering</b> of fish <b>is written in</b> the <b>context</b> of the <b>slaughter of others,</b> i.e., the flocks and herds, which indicates that gathering is an alternative to slaughter.
The Gemara relates that <b>a passerby from the Galilee taught: Fitness</b> for consumption of <b>animals, which were created from the</b> dry <b>land,</b> is accomplished <b>through</b> cutting <b>two <i>simanim</i>,</b> the gullet and the windpipe. <b>Fitness</b> for consumption of <b>fish, which were created from the water,</b> is accomplished <b>with nothing,</b> as no slaughter is required. <b>Fitness</b> for consumption of <b>birds, which were created from mud [<i>harekak</i>],</b> a combination of dry land and water, is accomplished <b>through</b> cutting <b>one <i>siman</i>. Rav Shmuel of Cappadocia says: Know</b> that <b>birds</b> were created from a combination of dry land and water, <b>as they have scales on their feet like fish.</b>
The Gemara relates an excerpt of an exchange between a Roman government official and Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai. <b>And furthermore,</b> the official <b>asked</b> Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai: <b>One verse states: “And God said: Let the waters swarm with swarms of living creeping animals, and birds will fly”</b> (Genesis 1:20); <b>apparently</b> birds <b>were created from the water. And it is written: “And from the ground the Lord God formed every beast of the field, and every bird of the air</b> and brought them unto the man to see what he would call them” (Genesis 2:19); <b>apparently</b> birds <b>were created from the land.</b>
Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai <b>said to him: They were created from the mud. He saw his students looking at each other,</b> wondering. <b>He said to them: Does it trouble you that I dismissed my enemy with a flimsy</b> pretext? Actually, it is <b>from water</b> that birds <b>were created. And why</b> does the verse state that they were formed from the ground and that God <b>brought them to Adam?</b> In other words, why are they mentioned in the second verse? It is not because they were actually formed from the ground, but only because they were brought to Adam so that <b>he would call them names.</b>
<b>And some say</b> that Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai spoke <b>to that officer with a different formulation,</b> i.e., he said to him that the birds were created from the water. <b>And he stated the first formulation,</b> that the birds were created from the mud, <b>to his students, because it is written: “And</b> from the ground the Lord God <b>formed</b> every beast of the field, and every bird of the air” (Genesis 2:19). According to this explanation, the birds are mentioned there not only because Adam called them names, but also because they too were created from the ground.
On the matter of slaughtering birds, <b>Rav Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Pineḥas: Slaughter of a bird is not</b> obligatory <b>by Torah law, as it is stated:</b> “And whatever man there be of the children of Israel…who traps any undomesticated animal or bird that may be eaten, <b>he shall spill its blood,</b> and cover it in earth” (Leviticus 17:13). This indicates that <b>mere spilling</b> of its blood <b>is sufficient.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> with regard to <b>an undomesticated animal,</b> which is mentioned in the same verse, spilling should be sufficient <b>also.</b> The Gemara explains: An undomesticated animal <b>is juxtaposed to disqualified consecrated</b> animals, for which slaughter is required, as explained later in the Gemara (28a). The Gemara asks: <b>Birds too are juxtaposed to animals,</b> and therefore slaughter should be required, <b>as it is written: “This is the law of the animal, and of the bird”</b> (Leviticus 11:46). The Gemara answers: <b>But isn’t it written: “He shall spill its blood,”</b> indicating that slaughter is not required?
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> concerning the derivation that slaughter is not required, based on the phrase in the verse “He shall spill,” <b>what did you see that</b> led you to <b>cast it upon,</b> i.e., apply it to, the case of <b>a bird?</b> Why not <b>cast it upon</b> the case of <b>an undomesticated animal?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> to cast the derivation upon the case of a bird <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the verse <b>concluded with</b> the bird, i.e., the bird is mentioned just prior to the directive to spill and cover the blood, as it is written: “Who traps any undomesticated animal or bird that may be eaten, he shall spill its blood.”
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the proofs cited in the Gemara with regard to the slaughter of birds: <b>Became a carcass, blood, through pinching.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Pineḥas from a mishna (85a): <b>One who slaughters</b> an undomesticated animal <b>and it became</b> an unslaughtered <b>carcass by his hand</b> because the slaughter was not valid, or <b>one who stabbed</b> the animal by slicing the length of the <i>simanim</i>, <b>or one who ripped</b> the gullet or windpipe of the animal, rendering the slaughter not valid, <b>is exempt from covering</b> the blood because his slaughter was ineffective in permitting consumption of the animal, and it is written that the requirement of covering the blood applies only to “any undomesticated animal or bird that may be eaten.” <b>And if you say</b> that <b>slaughter of a bird is not</b> obligatory <b>by Torah law,</b> the halakhic status of <b>its stabbing is</b> like that of <b>its slaughter; let</b> its blood <b>require covering.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Do you maintain</b> that this mishna is referring <b>to a bird? No,</b> it is referring exclusively <b>to an undomesticated animal.</b>
The Gemara cites another challenge: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who slaughters</b> an undomesticated animal or a bird <b>and requires the blood</b> and not the animal <b>is obligated to cover</b> the blood. Rather, <b>how does he act</b> if he seeks to make use of the blood rather than cover it? He <b>either stabs</b> the animal <b>or rips</b> the <i>simanim</i>, and then he is exempt from covering the blood.

Daf 28a

<b>What, is it not</b> referring <b>to a bird, as he requires its blood to</b> remove <b>a moth</b> from his garments? If so, apparently birds require slaughter by Torah law, as, if that were not the case, then even if a bird were stabbed, covering of the blood would be required. The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to an undomesticated animal, as he requires its blood to</b> use as a red <b>dye [<i>lelakka</i>]</b> Therefore, no proof may be cited from this <i>baraita</i> that birds require slaughter by Torah law.
The Gemara cites proof from a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 68a): <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> If <b>one cut</b> the nape of the neck of a sacrificial bird <b>with a knife</b> instead of pinching it with his fingernail, this bird carcass <b>renders</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who eats the bird <b>ritually impure</b> when the meat is <b>in</b> his <b>throat.</b> The Gemara explains the proof: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>slaughter of a bird is not</b> obligatory <b>by Torah law,</b> then <b>although when</b> cutting the bird from the nape, <b>he breaks the spine and the neck bone</b> with the knife before severing the gullet and windpipe, and <b>it indeed becomes a <i>tereifa</i></b> and may not be eaten, cutting the <i>simanim</i> with the <b>knife should be effective to purify it,</b> i.e., to prevent it <b>from</b> assuming the status of <b>an unslaughtered carcass.</b> The fact that the garments of one who swallows the meat of the bird become ritually impure indicates that slaughter is the only method effective in permitting the consumption of a bird and for preventing it from assuming the status of an unslaughtered carcass.
The Gemara rejects that proof: Although it is clear from that mishna that slaughter of birds is obligatory by Torah law, Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Pineḥas <b>states</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>that <i>tanna</i></b> who holds that it is not obligatory by Torah law, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Elazar HaKappar, the distinguished Sage, says: What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “However, as the gazelle</b> and as the deer <b>is eaten,</b> so shall you eat of it” (Deuteronomy 12:22)? <b>And what now have we derived from the gazelle and the deer</b> with regard to disqualified consecrated animals?
These two undomesticated animals <b>come</b> in the verse <b>to teach</b> a <i>halakha</i> with regard to disqualified consecrated animals, <b>and</b> it is <b>found</b> that a <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived</b> from the case of disqualified consecrated animals in their regard. The Torah <b>juxtaposes a gazelle and a deer to disqualified consecrated animals</b> to teach: <b>Just as disqualified consecrated animals</b> are rendered fit for consumption <b>through slaughter, so too, a gazelle and a deer</b> are rendered fit for consumption only <b>through slaughter. But</b> for <b>a bird, slaughter is not</b> obligatory <b>by Torah law; rather,</b> the obligation is <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabbi Elazar HaKappar</b> and holds that the slaughter of a bird is obligatory by Torah law? <b>It is Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The Torah states: <b>“And you shall slaughter</b> of your herd and of your flock, which the Lord has given you, <b>as I have commanded you”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:21). <b>This</b> verse <b>teaches that Moses was</b> previously <b>commanded</b> about the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter, even though they are not written explicitly in the Torah. He was commanded <b>about</b> cutting <b>the gullet and about</b> cutting <b>the windpipe, and about the</b> requirement to cut the <b>majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>for a bird, and the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>for an animal.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that in the case of one who cuts <b>one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird,</b> his slaughter is valid. <b>It was stated</b> that there is an amoraic dispute with regard to this matter. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> One may cut <b>either the gullet or the windpipe. Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> One must cut the <b>gullet</b> for the slaughter to be valid, <b>but</b> cutting <b>the windpipe</b> is <b>not</b> sufficient. The Gemara explains the formulation of the mishna according to the opinion of each <i>amora</i>. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> One may cut <b>either the gullet or the windpipe. One</b> <i>siman</i> <b>is taught</b> in the mishna, meaning that the slaughter is valid if he severs <b>one,</b> indicating that <b>either</b> <i>siman</i> is valid. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> One must cut the <b>gullet</b> for the slaughter to be valid, <b>but</b> cutting <b>the windpipe</b> is <b>not</b> sufficient. <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>One,</b> in the mishna? It means the <b>special</b> one, the gullet.
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the proofs to be cited by the Gemara: <b>Slaughter, halves, windpipe, deficiency, of a bird sin offering.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rav Naḥman from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one cut the</b> bird’s <b>gullet and thereafter the windpipe was displaced,</b> the slaughter <b>is valid.</b> If <b>the windpipe was displaced and thereafter he cut the gullet,</b> the slaughter <b>is not valid.</b> With regard to a case where <b>one cut the gullet and the windpipe was found displaced and he does not know if it was displaced prior to the slaughter or if it was displaced after the slaughter, that was an incident</b> that transpired, <b>and</b> the Sages <b>said:</b> In <b>any</b> case of <b>uncertainty with regard to slaughter,</b> the slaughter <b>is not valid.</b> The <i>baraita</i> mentions only the case of cutting the gullet, <b>while cutting the windpipe is not taught.</b> The <i>baraita</i> supports the opinion of Rav Adda bar Ahava and is contrary to the opinion of Rav Naḥman.
The Gemara rejects that proof: The <i>baraita</i> mentions only the cutting of the gullet and displacement of the windpipe not because slaughter may be performed only by cutting the gullet. Rather, those scenarios were mentioned <b>because the windpipe,</b> unlike the gullet, <b>is likely to be displaced.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof contrary to the opinion of Rav Naḥman from a <i>baraita</i>. If one <b>cut two halves,</b> one half of each <b>of the <i>simanim</i>, in a bird,</b> the slaughter is <b>not valid,</b> as the requirement is that a majority of one <i>siman</i> is cut; <b>and needless to say</b> the slaughter performed in that manner is not valid <b>in</b> the case of <b>an animal,</b> where the requirement is that a majority of both <i>simanim</i> are cut. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: In a bird</b> the slaughter is not valid <b>until he cuts the gullet and the veins;</b> the veins must be cut so that the blood will drain from the body. The fact that Rabbi Yehuda mentions cutting only the gullet and not the windpipe indicates that slaughter is valid only when the gullet is cut. The Gemara rejects that proof: Rabbi Yehuda mentions only the gullet <b>because</b> the <b>gullet is adjacent to the veins.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof in support of the opinion of Rav Naḥman from a <i>baraita</i>. If one <b>cut half</b> the <b>windpipe and interrupted</b> the slaughter for an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of the <b>slaughter</b> of <b>another</b> animal, <b>and</b> then <b>completed his slaughter,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid</b> and it is not invalidated due to an interrupted slaughter. <b>What, is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>not</b> referring to the slaughter <b>of a bird? And what</b> does the term: <b>Completed it,</b> mean in the <i>baraita</i>? Doesn’t it mean that he <b>completed</b> cutting <b>the windpipe,</b> which he had started cutting, indicating that with the cutting of the windpipe the slaughter is valid, in accordance with the opinion of Rav Naḥman as opposed to the opinion of Rav Adda bar Ahava? The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to slaughter <b>of an animal,</b> for which both <i>simanim</i> must be cut. <b>And what</b> does the term: <b>Completed it,</b> mean in the <i>baraita</i>? It means that he <b>completed the entire slaughter.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof in support of the opinion of Rav Naḥman from a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>half of the windpipe was deficient,</b> i.e., somewhat cut, prior to the slaughter <b>and</b> the slaughterer <b>added to</b> that deficiency an incision of <b>any size, and completed it, his slaughter is valid. What, is it not</b> referring to the slaughter of <b>a bird? And what</b> does the term: <b>Completed it,</b> mean in the <i>baraita</i>? Doesn’t it mean that he <b>completed</b> cutting the majority of the <b>windpipe,</b> indicating that cutting the windpipe renders the bird fit for consumption? The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to slaughter <b>of an animal,</b> for which both <i>simanim</i> must be cut. <b>And what</b> does the term: <b>Completed it,</b> mean in the <i>baraita</i>? It means that he <b>completed</b> the entire slaughter by cutting <b>the gullet.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof in support of the opinion of Rav Naḥman from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How does one pinch</b> the nape of the neck of <b>a bird sin offering?</b> Using his thumbnail, the priest <b>cuts the spine and the neck bone, without</b> cutting through <b>the majority of</b> the surrounding <b>flesh until he reaches</b> either <b>the gullet or the windpipe. Once he reaches the gullet or the windpipe, he cuts one <i>siman</i></b> with his nail <b>and a majority of</b> the surrounding <b>flesh with it. And in</b> the case of a bird <b>burnt offering,</b> he cuts the <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>or the majority of the two</b> <i>simanim</i>. The Gemara concludes: <b>The refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> from this <i>baraita</i> is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> halakhic conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about the matter?</b> The Gemara asks in response: <b>What</b> halakhic conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about the matter?</b> It is <b>as you said,</b> that the opinion of Rav Adda bar Ahava was conclusively refuted. The Gemara says that there is not absolute proof from the <i>baraita</i>, as <b>perhaps it is different there</b> with regard to pinching, <b>as</b> in that case <b>there is</b> the <b>spine and</b> the <b>neck bone</b> that are cut initially, and therefore cutting the windpipe is sufficient. But in the case of slaughter of a non-sacred bird, perhaps only if one cuts the gullet the slaughter is valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> then is the <i>halakha</i> in the case of slaughter? The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from the following incident, <b>that</b> there was <b>a certain duck that was in the house of Rava,</b> which <b>came</b> for slaughter <b>with its neck filthy with blood</b> and they did not know whether the blood was the result of its windpipe having been severed or its gullet having been perforated, in which cases the duck is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rava said: What should we do</b> with regard to this duck?

Daf 28b

If one suggests: <b>Let</b> us <b>slaughter it and then we will examine it</b> to determine whether its windpipe was severed or its gullet was perforated, that is difficult, because <b>perhaps</b> the slaughterer <b>will slaughter</b> the duck precisely <b>in the place of the perforation</b> and it will be impossible to determine whether the gullet was perforated before the slaughter. If one suggests: <b>Let</b> us slice open the hide and <b>examine</b> the <i>simanim</i> <b>and then we will slaughter it,</b> that is difficult, because <b>didn’t Rabba say: The gullet has no</b> possible <b>examination from without,</b> as its outer side is red, and a small perforation would be indiscernible, <b>but</b> only <b>from within,</b> as its inner side is white, and blood at the site of the perforation would be discerned?
<b>Rav Yosef, son</b> of Rava, <b>said to him: Let us examine the windpipe,</b> as it is possible to discern from without whether the majority of the windpipe was severed, <b>and</b> then <b>cut the</b> duck’s <b>windpipe and</b> thereby <b>render it permitted,</b> as cutting either of the two <i>simanim</i> suffices in a bird. <b>And then let us turn the gullet inside out and examine its</b> inner side to determine whether it was perforated and the duck is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rava said: My son Yosef is as wise in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>tereifot</i> as Rabbi Yoḥanan. Apparently, one</b> <i>siman</i>, <b>which is taught</b> in the mishna as being sufficient in the slaughter of a bird, means <b>either this</b> <i>siman</i>, the gullet, <b>or that</b> <i>siman</i>, the windpipe.
§ The mishna states: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The slaughter is not valid <b>until he cuts</b> the veins in the neck. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Rav Yehuda said</b> that one must cut the veins <b>only</b> in the slaughter of <b>a bird, as</b> one typically <b>roasts it in its entirety as one</b> whole entity; therefore, one must cut the veins to ensure that the blood drains. <b>But</b> with regard to the slaughter of <b>an animal, since it is</b> typically <b>quartered</b> into <b>limbs,</b> resulting in the blood draining more readily, one <b>need not</b> cut the veins.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that the reason that Rabbi Yehuda</b> requires cutting of the veins <b>is due to</b> the need to drain the <b>blood? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The slaughter is not valid <b>until he cuts [<i>sheyishḥot</i>] the veins,</b> indicating that the cutting of the veins is a component of the slaughter [<i>sheḥita</i>]?
The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda’s statement is <b>until he punctures the veins. And what</b> is the meaning of: <b>Until he cuts? Until he punctures</b> the veins <b>at the moment of slaughter,</b> when the blood flows.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof rejecting this interpretation of Rabbi Yehuda’s statement from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The veins through slaughter,</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> which indicates that the cutting of the veins is a component of slaughter. The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>Say</b> that the correct reading of the <i>baraita</i> is: <b>He must puncture the veins at the moment of slaughter;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof from a <i>baraita</i>: The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Yehuda: Since veins were mentioned only to drain blood from them, what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> whether one cuts them as a component <b>of slaughter,</b> and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> whether one cuts them <b>not</b> as a component <b>of slaughter?</b> One can learn <b>by inference</b> from this <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that one cuts the veins as a component <b>of slaughter.</b>
The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>This is</b> what the Rabbis <b>are saying</b> to Rabbi Yehuda: <b>What</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> whether one <b>punctures them at the moment of slaughter,</b> and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> whether one <b>punctures them not at the moment of slaughter?</b> One can puncture the veins after the slaughter. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>holds</b> that <b>at the time of slaughter the blood emerges</b> from the body quickly <b>because</b> the blood <b>is warm;</b> when it is <b>not at the time of slaughter, the blood does not emerge</b> from the body quickly <b>because it is cool.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> In cutting the <b>veins according to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> if one <b>interrupted</b> the act in the midst of cutting <b>them,</b> or if <b>he pressed</b> the knife and cut <b>them</b> instead of drawing the knife back and forth, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do these actions, which invalidate slaughter when cutting the <i>simanim</i>, also invalidate slaughter when performed in the cutting of the veins?
<b>A certain elder said to him: This is</b> what <b>Rabbi Elazar said; and some say</b> that <b>a certain elder said to Rabbi Elazar</b> that <b>this is what Rabbi Yoḥanan said: He punctures</b> the veins <b>with a thorn and their</b> cutting is <b>valid.</b> Cutting the veins is not a component of the slaughter.
The Gemara notes that it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda</b> that Rabbi Yehuda requires cutting of the veins only in the slaughter of birds, and not in the slaughter of animals. If one <b>cut two halves,</b> one half of each <b>of the <i>simanim</i>, in a bird,</b> the slaughter is <b>not valid, and needless to say</b> the slaughter performed in that manner is not valid <b>in</b> the case of <b>an animal. Rabbi Yehuda says: In a bird</b> the slaughter is not valid <b>until he cuts the gullet and the veins.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: If one cut <b>half of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird</b> or one and a half <i>simanim</i> in an animal, his slaughter is not valid. <b>It was stated</b> that there is an amoraic dispute. <b>Rav said:</b> The halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is like</b> that of a <i>siman</i> of which the <b>majority</b> was cut. <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> The halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is not like</b> that of a <i>siman</i> of which the <b>majority</b> was cut.
The Gemara elaborates. <b>Rav said:</b> The halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is like</b> that of a <i>siman</i> of which the <b>majority</b> was cut, and <b>this is what the Merciful One said to Moses: Do not leave the majority</b> uncut. When cutting precisely half, the majority does not remain uncut. <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> The halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is not like</b> that of a <i>siman</i> of which the <b>majority</b> was cut, and <b>this is what the Merciful One said to Moses: Cut the majority</b> of the <i>siman</i>. Therefore, cutting precisely half is insufficient.
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the proofs that it cites with regard to this dispute: <b>Half, Ketina, windpipe, deficiency.</b>
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If one cut <b>half of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird or one and a half</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>in an animal, his slaughter is not valid.</b> The Gemara questions the opinion of Rav: <b>If you say</b> that the halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is like</b> that of a <i>siman</i> of which the <b>majority</b> was cut, <b>why is</b> his slaughter <b>not valid?</b> By cutting half, <b>didn’t he perform</b> the cutting of <b>a majority</b> of the <i>siman</i>? The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>By rabbinic law,</b> the slaughter is not valid, due to the concern that <b>perhaps he will not come to perform</b> cutting on even <b>half</b> of the <i>siman</i>.
<b>Rav Ketina said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof contrary to Rav’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i> with regard to an impure earthenware vessel that is purified through being broken. If it is broken in two, the larger portion remains impure and the smaller portion is purified. If <b>he divided it into two and they are</b> seemingly <b>equal</b> halves, <b>both are impure, because it is impossible to measure precisely</b> in breaking an earthenware vessel and render both halves equal. Since it is impossible to determine which half is larger, both remain impure due to uncertainty.
The Gemara infers: <b>But were it possible to measure precisely</b> and divide it into equal halves, both would be <b>pure.</b> If, as Rav states, the halakhic status of half is like that of a majority, <b>why are they pure? Go here,</b> to one half of the vessel, and you will see that <b>there is a majority</b> and it should remain impure, and <b>go there,</b> to the other half, and you will see that <b>there is a majority</b> and it should remain impure.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> in rejecting that proof: <b>There are not two majorities in one vessel.</b> Therefore, one cannot consider the halakhic status of half like that of a majority. By contrast, with regard to cutting the windpipe or gullet, the halakhic status of precisely half can be like that of a majority, as there is no other majority contradicting that status.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof contrary to Rav’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>cut half</b> the <b>windpipe and interrupted</b> the slaughter

Daf 29a

for an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of the <b>slaughter</b> of <b>another</b> animal, <b>and</b> then <b>completed</b> his slaughter, <b>his slaughter</b> is <b>valid. But if you say</b> the halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is like</b> that of the <b>majority,</b> then by cutting half the windpipe <b>he rendered it a <i>tereifa</i></b> because it is as though the majority of the windpipe is severed.
The Gemara answers: <b>Do you hold</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is referring to the slaughter <b>of an animal? No,</b> it is referring to the slaughter <b>of a bird,</b> which requires the cutting of only one <i>siman</i>. <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, the slaughter should be valid. <b>If</b> the halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is like</b> that of the <b>majority, he has performed</b> the cutting of <b>the majority</b> and the slaughter is valid. And <b>if</b> the halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is not like</b> that of the <b>majority,</b> then in cutting half the <i>siman</i> <b>he did not perform any</b> action that would render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof contrary to Rav’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>half of the windpipe was deficient</b> prior to the slaughter <b>and</b> the slaughterer <b>added to</b> that deficiency an incision of <b>any size, and completed it, his slaughter is valid. And if you say that</b> the halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is like</b> that of the <b>majority,</b> the animal <b>is a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> as half its windpipe was deficient before the slaughter.
<b>Rava said: The matter of <i>tereifa</i> is different, as we require a majority that is clearly visible.</b> If precisely half the windpipe is deficient it does not appear to be a majority. By contrast, with regard to slaughter, the status of half is like that of the majority.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>And is it not</b> derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference that <b>all the more so,</b> a conspicuous majority is required for slaughter? <b>And just as</b> with regard to <b><i>tereifa</i>, where</b> the animal <b>is rendered a <i>tereifa</i></b> by a deficiency <b>of any size,</b> e.g., by a minuscule perforation of the gullet, in cases <b>where we require a majority, we require a majority that is clearly visible,</b> with regard to <b>slaughter, where until there is a majority</b> of the <i>simanim</i> cut, the slaughter <b>is not valid, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear <b>that we require a majority that is clearly visible?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara revises its understanding of the dispute between Rav and Rav Kahana. <b>Everyone</b> agrees that the halakhic status of a <i>siman</i> of which precisely <b>half</b> was cut and <b>half</b> remained uncut <b>is not like</b> that of a <i>siman</i> of which the <b>majority</b> was cut. <b>And when</b> the dispute <b>of Rav and Rav Kahana was stated, it was stated with regard to</b> the <b>matter of the Paschal offering.</b> If a majority of the Jewish people were ritually impure on the fourteenth of Nisan, the Paschal offering is sacrificed that day and eaten in a state of impurity. If only a minority of the Jewish people were impure, the ritually pure majority brings the Paschal offering on the fourteenth of Nisan, and the impure minority brings the Paschal offering on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> one month later.
In a case where <b>the Jewish people were</b> equally divided on the fourteenth of Nisan, with <b>half</b> of them <b>pure and half</b> of them <b>impure, Rav said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> in the case where <b>half</b> the people were impure and <b>half</b> were pure <b>is like</b> that of a case where the <b>majority</b> was impure, and the entire people brings the Paschal offering in Nisan. <b>And Rav Kahana said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> in the case where <b>half</b> the people were impure and <b>half</b> were pure is <b>not like</b> that of a case where the <b>majority</b> was impure. Therefore, those who are pure bring the Paschal offering on the fourteenth of Nisan, and those who are impure bring the Paschal offering on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And there,</b> with regard to the Paschal offering, <b>what is the reason that Rav</b> accords half the people the status of a majority? It is <b>as it is written: “Any man who shall be impure by reason of a corpse…</b>shall observe the Passover to the Lord. On the fourteenth day of the second month at evening they shall observe it” (Numbers 9:10–11), from which it is derived: A ritually impure <b>person</b> is <b>deferred</b> to observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, <b>but</b> a ritually impure <b>congregation is not deferred</b> to observe the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. The status of half the people is that of a congregation, not that of a collection of individuals.
§ The mishna teaches: If one cut <b>the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird</b> or the majority of two <i>simanim</i> in an animal,his slaughter is valid. The Gemara asks: <b>We</b> already <b>learn</b> this on <b>another occasion,</b> in the first clause of the mishna: The halakhic status of <b>the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>is like</b> that of the entire <i>siman</i>. Why is the redundancy necessary?
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the names of the <i>amora’im</i> who participate in the discussion that ensues: <b><i>Heh</i>,</b> Rav Hoshaya; <b><i>kaf</i>,</b> Rabbi Kahana; <b><i>shin</i>,</b> Rabbi Shimi; <b><i>peh</i>,</b> Rav Pappa; <b><i>shin</i>,</b> Rav Ashi; <b><i>ḥet</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Hoshaya said: One</b> mention of the equivalence between majority and whole is referring to slaughter <b>of non-sacred</b> birds and animals <b>and one</b> is referring to slaughter <b>of sacrificial</b> birds and animals. <b>And</b> it <b>is necessary</b> for the <i>tanna</i> to teach both cases, <b>as, if</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only the case of slaughter of <b>non-sacred</b> birds and animals, one might think that it <b>is there that one suffices with the majority</b> of the <i>siman</i>, <b>because he does not require the blood;</b> he seeks merely to slaughter the animal. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>sacrificial</b> birds and animals, <b>where he requires the blood</b> for sprinkling on the altar, <b>say</b> that <b>it will not suffice for him</b> to cut <b>the majority,</b> and the slaughter is not valid <b>until there is</b> a cutting of <b>the entire</b> windpipe or gullet.
<b>And if</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> only the case of slaughter of <b>sacrificial</b> birds and animals, one might think that one must cut a majority of the <i>siman</i> <b>because he requires the blood</b> for sprinkling on the altar; but with regard to the slaughter of <b>non-sacred</b> birds and animals, <b>where he does not require the blood, say that</b> cutting <b>half</b> the <i>siman</i> <b>is sufficient,</b> and there is no need to cut a majority. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> the principle twice, once to teach that a majority suffices in the case of sacrificial animals, and once to teach that a majority is required in the case of non-sacred animals.
The Gemara asks <b>which</b> clause of the mishna is referring to cutting a majority of the <i>simanim</i> <b>in non-sacred</b> birds and animals, <b>and which</b> is referring to cutting a majority of the <i>simanim</i> <b>in sacrificial</b> birds and animals?
<b>Rav Kahana said: It stands to reason</b> that <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna is referring to the slaughter <b>of non-sacred</b> birds and animals <b>and the latter clause</b> is referring to the slaughter <b>of sacrificial</b> birds and animals. The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> does Rav Kahana arrive at that conclusion? The Gemara answers: It is <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the first clause of the mishna <b>teaches: One who slaughters</b> by cutting one <i>siman</i> in a bird and two <i>simanim</i> in an animal. <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that the <b>first clause</b> is referring to the case <b>of sacrificial</b> birds and animals, the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> formulated it as: <b>One who pinches</b> the nape of the neck of a bird, as sacrificial birds are not slaughtered with a knife, but pinched with a fingernail.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what</b> do you say? That the <b>latter clause</b> is referring to slaughter <b>of sacrificial</b> birds and animals? But the <i>tanna</i> teaches in the latter clause: If one cut the majority of one <i>siman</i> in a bird or the majority of two <i>simanim</i> in an animal, <b>his slaughter is valid.</b> If the reference is to sacrificial birds and animals, the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> formulated it: <b>His pinching is valid.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> is <b>not difficult; since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>concluded</b> with mention of the slaughter <b>of an animal, he also taught: His slaughter is valid,</b> which is referring to the sacrificial animal. <b>But</b> in <b>the first clause, since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>stands to</b> begin with the case of <b>a bird, if it enters your mind</b> that the reference is <b>to sacrificial</b> birds, the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have</b> formulated it: <b>One who pinches</b> the nape of the neck of the bird.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said</b> that one arrives at the conclusion that <b>the first clause</b> is referring to slaughter <b>of non-sacred</b> birds and animals <b>from here: As</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches:</b> One who slaughters by cutting <b>one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird. And if it enters your mind</b> that the reference is to the slaughter <b>of sacrificial</b> birds, <b>isn’t there the bird burnt offering, which requires</b> that <b>two <i>simanim</i></b> be cut?
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what</b> do you say? That the <b>latter clause</b> is referring to slaughter <b>of sacrificial</b> birds and animals? But the <i>tanna</i> teaches in the latter clause: If one cut <b>the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird</b> or the majority of two <i>simanim</i> in an animal, his slaughter is valid. If the reference is to sacrificial birds, <b>isn’t there the bird burnt offering, which requires</b> the pinching of <b>two <i>simanim</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>The majority of one</b> <i>siman</i>? It means <b>the majority of each and every one</b> of the two. <b>And by right</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>should have taught: The majority of two.</b> But <b>since there is the</b> bird <b>sin offering, which suffices with</b> the cutting of <b>one <i>siman</i>, due to that</b> reason the matter is <b>not clear-cut for him.</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> formulated the <i>halakha</i> in a manner that could apply to one <i>siman</i>, i.e., in the case of a sin offering, and to two <i>simanim</i>, i.e., in the case of a burnt offering and of animal offerings.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> that one arrives at the conclusion that <b>the first clause</b> is referring to slaughter <b>of non-sacred</b> birds and animals <b>from here: As</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The slaughter is not valid <b>until he cuts the veins</b> in the neck. <b>And the Rabbis disagree with him,</b> and do not require that one cut the veins in the neck. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the reference is to the slaughter of <b>non-sacred</b> birds, it works out <b>well. But if you say</b> that the reference is to the slaughter of <b>sacrificial</b> birds, <b>why do the Rabbis disagree with him? He himself,</b> i.e., the one slaughtering, <b>requires the blood</b> in order to sprinkle it on the altar, which would warrant cutting the veins.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that one arrives at the conclusion that <b>the latter clause</b> is referring to slaughter <b>of sacrificial</b> birds and animals <b>from here: As</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> in the mishna (30b): <b>One who slaughters</b> by cutting <b>two</b> animals’ <b>heads simultaneously, his slaughter is valid.</b> The Gemara infers from the precise language of the mishna: <b>One who slaughters,</b> indicating that <b>after the fact, yes,</b> his slaughter is valid; but one may <b>not</b> slaughter two animals simultaneously <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>
<b>Granted, if you say</b> that the reference is to <b>sacrificial</b> birds or animals, <b>this is</b> the reason that one may <b>not</b> slaughter two animals simultaneously <b><i>ab initio</i>:</b> It is <b>due to that which Rav Yosef teaches</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “And when you sacrifice a peace offering to the Lord, you shall sacrifice it [<i>tizbaḥuhu</i>] that you may be accepted” (Leviticus 19:5). The term “<i>tizbaḥuhu</i>” can be divided into two terms: You shall sacrifice [<i>tizbaḥ</i>] and it [<i>hu</i>]. From the term <b>“You shall sacrifice [<i>tizbaḥ</i>],”</b> it is derived <b>that there will not be two</b> people <b>slaughtering one offering.</b> From the full term <b>“You shall sacrifice it [<i>tizbaḥuhu</i>]”</b> it is derived <b>that one</b> person <b>may not slaughter two offerings</b> simultaneously.
<b>And Rav Kahana said,</b> to explain the derivation of the first <i>halakha</i> in the <i>baraita</i>: Although the term “<i>tizbaḥuhu</i>” is vocalized in the plural, leading to the conclusion that two people may slaughter an animal together, nevertheless, because the word is written without a <i>vav</i>, the term <b><i>tizbaḥehu</i> is written,</b> in the singular, indicating that two individuals may not slaughter the offering. <b>But if you say</b> that the reference is to the slaughter of <b>non-sacred</b> birds, it should be permitted <b>even <i>ab initio</i>.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, too, holds</b> that the <b>first clause</b> of the mishna is referring to the slaughter <b>of non-sacred</b> birds and animals <b>and</b> the <b>latter clause</b> is referring to the slaughter <b>of sacrificial</b> birds and animals, <b>as Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: Since we learned</b> in the mishna that the halakhic status of <b>the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>is like</b> that of the entire <i>siman</i>, <b>why did we</b> also need to <b>learn</b> later in the mishna: <b>The majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird or the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>in an animal?</b> The latter clause is obvious based on the principle articulated in the first clause.
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish explains: <b>Since we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Yoma</i> 31b): <b>They brought him</b> the sheep for <b>the daily</b> morning <b>offering,</b> and <b>he slaughtered it [<i>keratzo</i>]</b> by cutting most of the way through the gullet and the windpipe, <b>and a different</b> priest <b>completed</b> the <b>slaughter on his behalf</b> so that the High Priest could receive the blood in a vessel and proceed with the order of the Yom Kippur service, one <b>might</b> have thought that if the other priest <b>did not complete</b> the cutting of the two <i>simanim</i>, the slaughter <b>would not be valid. Therefore, we learned</b> in the mishna: If one cut <b>the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird or the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>in an animal,</b> his slaughter is valid.
The Gemara analyzes the statement of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish. <b>The Master said:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that if the other priest <b>did not complete</b> the cutting of the two <i>simanim</i>, the slaughter <b>would not be valid.</b>

Daf 29b

How could that possibility enter one’s mind? <b>If</b> that is <b>so,</b> the completion of that slaughter <b>is</b> a Temple <b>service</b> performed <b>by another</b> on Yom Kippur. <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The entire Yom Kippur</b> Temple <b>service is valid only</b> if performed <b>by</b> the High Priest.
The Gemara answers that <b>this</b> is what Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>is saying:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that if the slaughter was not completed by the other priest it <b>would be not valid by rabbinic law, as it</b> might <b>enter your mind to say that there is an invalidation by rabbinic law. Therefore, we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>The majority of one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>in a bird or the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>in an animal.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And since there is not even an invalidation by rabbinic law, why do I</b> need the other priest <b>to complete</b> the cutting of the <i>simanim</i>? The Gemara answers: There is a <b>mitzva to complete</b> the slaughter <i>ab initio</i> to facilitate the free flow of the blood.
§ <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says in the name of Levi the Elder:</b> Halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>only at</b> its <b>conclusion. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>from the beginning to the end</b> of the act.
<b>Rava said</b> in establishing the parameters of the dispute between Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish and Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>Everyone concedes</b> in a case <b>where a gentile slaughtered,</b> i.e., cut, <b>one <i>siman</i> and a Jew</b> slaughtered <b>one <i>siman</i>, that</b> the slaughter <b>is not valid</b> even if slaughter is accomplished only at its conclusion, as <b>an action</b> rendering the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i> was performed at the hand of a gentile.</b> Since slaughter by a gentile is not valid, the gentile renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>In</b> the case <b>of a bird burnt offering as well, where one <i>siman</i> was pinched</b> by a priest <b>below</b> the red line marking half the height of the altar, in accordance with the procedure of the sin offering, <b>and one <i>siman</i></b> was pinched <b>above</b> the red line, in accordance with the procedure of the burnt offering, the pinching is <b>not valid, as</b> the priest <b>performed an action</b> appropriate for <b>a bird sin offering below</b> the red line, disqualifying it from being sacrificed as a burnt offering.
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish and Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>disagree only</b> in a case <b>where</b> an individual <b>cut one <i>siman</i> outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and one <i>siman</i> inside</b> the Temple courtyard. <b>According to the one who says:</b> Halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>from the beginning to the end</b> of the act, i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan, one who begins the slaughter outside the Temple courtyard <b>is liable</b> for slaughter of a sacrificial animal outside the courtyard. <b>According to the one who says:</b> Halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>only at</b> its <b>conclusion,</b> i.e., Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, one who does so <b>is not liable,</b> as the conclusion of the slaughter, which is the determining factor, is performed inside the Temple courtyard.
<b>Rabba bar Shimi said to</b> Rava: <b>The Master did not say</b> that <b>this</b> was the crux of the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish. <b>And who is</b> the Master? It is <b>Rav Yosef,</b> who says that in a case <b>where one cut one <i>siman</i> outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and one <i>siman</i> inside</b> the Temple courtyard, all agree that the slaughter is <b>not valid</b> and the priest is liable to receive punishment, <b>because</b> he <b>performed an action</b> appropriate for <b>a bird sin offering outside</b> the Temple courtyard.
<b>They disagree only</b> in a case <b>where one slaughtered the minority</b> of each <b>of the <i>simanim</i> outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and completed</b> the slaughter <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard. <b>According to the one who says:</b> Halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>from the beginning to the end</b> of the act, i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan, one who begins the slaughter outside the Temple courtyard <b>is liable</b> for slaughter of a sacrificial animal outside the courtyard. <b>According to the one who says:</b> Halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>only at</b> its <b>conclusion,</b> i.e., Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, one who does so <b>is not liable,</b> as he concludes the slaughter in an appropriate place.
<b>Rabbi Zeira raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Para</i> 4:4): <b>Anyone who is engaged in</b> any part of the rite of the red <b>heifer</b> continuously <b>from beginning to end transmits</b> ritual <b>impurity to</b> the <b>garments</b> that he is wearing. <b>And they disqualify</b> the red heifer for use in the rite if they perform any <b>other labor</b> while engaged in any part of the rite of the red heifer.
If <b>a disqualification befell</b> the heifer <b>during its slaughter,</b> with regard to all those engaged in the rite of the red heifer, <b>whether</b> they engaged in the rite <b>before</b> the heifer <b>was disqualified or after</b> the heifer <b>was disqualified,</b> the heifer <b>does not render garments</b> that they are wearing <b>impure.</b> Since its slaughter was not valid it is disqualified from being used as a red heifer and therefore does not impart impurity. If it became disqualified at the time <b>of sprinkling</b> the blood of the heifer toward the opening of the Temple, with regard to those who engaged in the rite of the red heifer <b>before it was disqualified,</b> the heifer <b>renders the garments</b> that they are wearing <b>impure.</b> By contrast, with regard to those who handled the animal <b>after it was disqualified,</b> the heifer <b>does not render</b> the <b>garments</b> that they are wearing <b>impure.</b>
Rabbi Zeira elaborates: <b>And if you say</b> that halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>from the beginning to the end</b> of the act, <b>let</b> the mishna <b>also distinguish</b> between disqualification at the beginning and at the end <b>of the slaughter:</b> If it <b>became disqualified during slaughter,</b> with regard to one who engaged in any part of the rite <b>before it became disqualified,</b> the heifer <b>renders garments</b> that he is wearing <b>impure,</b> and with regard to one who engaged in any part of the rite <b>after it became disqualified,</b> the heifer <b>does not render</b> the <b>garments</b> that he is wearing <b>impure.</b>
<b>Rava said: Are you saying</b> that the discussion concerns a case where the <b>slaughter was invalidated? There it is different, because the matter was revealed retroactively,</b> i.e., it was revealed <b>that it was not</b> a valid <b>slaughter at all.</b> Since at no stage of the slaughter was it valid, the heifer does not render the garments impure at all.
<b>Rava said: If</b> any aspect of that mishna is <b>difficult for me</b> it is <b>this</b> that is <b>difficult for me: According to the one who says:</b> Halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>only at</b> its <b>conclusion, let</b> the mishna <b>distinguish</b> between two individuals <b>in</b> the preparation <b>of a fit</b> red <b>heifer,</b> even when the heifer was not disqualified. Let the mishna teach a case <b>where they slaughtered it with two men, as the</b> heifer <b>does not render the first man</b> who slaughters <b>impure,</b> as the slaughter did not yet begin, <b>and the</b> heifer <b>renders the latter man impure.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: Are you saying</b> that the discussion concerns a case of <b>two men</b> slaughtering <b>one offering?</b> Raise difficulties <b>except for that, as we learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And when you sacrifice a peace offering to the Lord, you shall sacrifice it [<i>tizbaḥuhu</i>] that you may be accepted” (Leviticus 19:5), that the term “<i>tizbaḥuhu</i>” can be divided into two terms: You shall sacrifice [<i>tizbaḥ</i>] and it [<i>hu</i>]. From the term <b>“You shall sacrifice [<i>tizbaḥ</i>],”</b> it is derived <b>that there will not be two</b> people <b>slaughtering one offering.</b> From the full term <b>“You shall offer it [<i>tizbaḥuhu</i>],”</b> it is derived <b>that one</b> person <b>may not slaughter two offerings</b> simultaneously.
<b>And Rav Kahana said,</b> to explain the derivation of the first <i>halakha</i> in the <i>baraita</i>: Although the term “<i>tizbaḥuhu</i>” is vocalized in the plural, leading to the conclusion that two people may slaughter an animal together, nevertheless, because the word is written without a <i>vav</i>, it emerges that the phrase <b>“You shall sacrifice it [<i>tizbaḥehu</i>],”</b> in the singular, <b>is written,</b> indicating that two individuals may not slaughter the offering.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Wasn’t it stated with regard to this</b> <i>halakha</i> that <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This is the statement of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b>

Daf 30a

which is cited <b>unattributed,</b> i.e., it is one of his many opinions that are cited in the Mishna and <i>baraitot</i> without attribution. <b>But the Rabbis say: Two</b> people <b>may slaughter one offering.</b> According to the Rabbis, Rava’s difficulty remains: Let the mishna teach a case where they slaughtered it with two men, as the heifer does not render the first man who slaughters impure, as the slaughter did not yet begin, and the heifer renders the latter man impure.
<b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that two people may not slaughter one offering, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>also distinguish</b> and teach a case <b>where one man slaughtered with two cloths</b> on his head, starting the slaughter with one and replacing it with the other midway through the slaughter, <b>as</b> in that case, since halakhic slaughter is accomplished only at its conclusion, the <b>first cloth is not rendered impure but the latter cloth is rendered impure. Rather,</b> one must say that the <i>tanna</i> <b>is speaking</b> only <b>in</b> reference to cases involving the <b>disqualification of the</b> red <b>heifer</b> itself, but he <b>is not speaking in</b> reference to cases involving <b>a fit</b> red heifer, and no proof may be cited from here.
<b>Rav Idi bar Avin raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 63a) to the opinion that halakhic slaughter is accomplished only at its conclusion. If one slaughters an animal for the sake of the Paschal offering on the fourteenth of Nisan after noon while he has leaven in his possession, he is flogged for violating the prohibition: “You shall not slaughter the blood of My sacrifice with leavened bread” (Exodus 23:18). If he slaughtered the animal not for the sake of the Paschal offering, he is exempt from receiving lashes. <b>And</b> if he slaughtered the animal <b>during the festival</b> of Passover <b>for</b> the <b>sake</b> of the Paschal offering with leaven in his possession, <b>he is exempt,</b> because it is a disqualified Paschal offering, as it was slaughtered beyond its appointed time. But if he slaughtered the animal during the Festival <b>not for</b> the <b>sake</b> of the Paschal offering, but rather as a peace offering, <b>he is liable</b> for slaughtering the animal with leaven in his possession.
<b>And we discussed</b> this matter: <b>The reason</b> he is liable is due to the fact <b>that</b> his intent was to slaughter it <b>not for the sake of</b> the Paschal offering, <b>but</b> had he slaughtered it with <b>unspecified</b> intent he would be <b>exempt,</b> because the offering would be disqualified. Unless he specifically intends otherwise, the animal retains its status as a Paschal offering and is disqualified when sacrificed beyond its appointed time.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why is he exempt?</b> Doesn’t <b>a Paschal offering</b> sacrificed <b>during the rest of the days of the year</b> assume the status of <b>a peace offering,</b> and doesn’t one who slaughters a peace offering during the time when it is prohibited to possess leaven with leaven in his possession also violate the prohibition? <b>Conclude from it</b> that <b>a Paschal offering</b> sacrificed <b>during the rest of the days of the year requires</b> explicit <b>revocation</b> of its status; otherwise, it does not assume the status of a peace offering and it remains a disqualified Paschal offering.
<b>And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Gamda said:</b> A response <b>emerged from the group</b> of scholars that discussed this matter, <b>and they said: What are we dealing with here?</b> It is <b>with</b> a case <b>where the owners</b> of the Paschal offering <b>were ritually impure</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan with impurity imparted <b>by a corpse</b>. In that case, the Torah commands (Numbers 9:10–11) <b>that</b> since they were unable to sacrifice the Paschal offering at the appointed time, the fourteenth of Nisan, they <b>were deferred to the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>,</b> the fourteenth of Iyyar. Since presumably the owner plans to use his Paschal offering on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, its <b>unspecified</b> slaughter in the interim <b>stands</b> to be offered <b>for the sake of</b> the Paschal offering, <b>and it is that</b> Paschal offering <b>that requires revocation</b> of its status. <b>But other</b> situations of a Paschal offering that is slaughtered beyond its designated time <b>do not require revocation</b> of the animal’s status, and it assumes the status of a peace offering.
Returning to the matter at hand, if a Paschal offering that is designated for use on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i> is slaughtered on Passover while one has leaven in his possession, he is exempt from receiving lashes because it is a disqualified Paschal offering. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>from the beginning to the end</b> of the act, the offering is <b>disqualified from the beginning of the slaughter</b> as a Paschal offering slaughtered beyond its appointed time. Therefore, one is exempt from receiving lashes. <b>But if you say</b> that halakhic <b>slaughter is</b> accomplished <b>only at</b> its <b>conclusion,</b> why is one exempt if he slaughtered the animal with leaven in his possession? <b>Once he</b> began and <b>cut a bit</b> of the <i>siman</i>, <b>it is rejected from</b> its status as <b>a Paschal offering</b> and can no longer be offered on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>. Therefore, <b>when he slaughters the other,</b> remaining, portion of the <i>simanim</i> without specification, <b>it is a peace offering that he is slaughtering.</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Idi bar Avin: Even if you say that halakhic slaughter is accomplished only at its conclusion, <b>although it was rejected from</b> the possibility of being sacrificed on the second <b><i>Pesaḥ</i>, was it rejected from</b> the possibility of being redeemed and from the possibility of <b>the monetary value of a Paschal offering</b> being used to purchase an animal to be sacrificed on the second <i>Pesaḥ</i>? As long as the slaughter is not yet complete, redemption of the animal remains possible. Therefore, unspecified slaughter at that time is for the sake of a Paschal offering and one should be exempt from receiving lashes.
<b>And if you would say that</b> in order to redeem a consecrated item <b>one requires</b> that the animal be placed <b>standing</b> before the priest <b>and</b> it requires <b>valuation</b> (see Leviticus 27:11–12), and once it is slaughtered it is unable to stand, <b>but didn’t we learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>slaughtered,</b> i.e., cut, <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>in</b> the animal <b>or a majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i>, <b>and</b> the animal <b>is still convulsing,</b> its halakhic status <b>is like a living</b> animal <b>in every respect,</b> and it may be redeemed until the convulsing ceases?
§ <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who cuts</b> a <i>siman</i> <b>in two or three places</b> on the neck, and together the cuts constitute the requisite measure of slaughter, <b>his slaughter is valid.</b> Rav Yehuda adds: <b>When I stated this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>before Shmuel he said to me: We require a clear</b> and obvious <b>slaughter and</b> in the case of cuts in two or three places <b>there is no</b> obvious slaughter.
<b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish also holds</b> that <b>we require a clear</b> and obvious <b>slaughter, as Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that slaughter must be clear</b> and obvious? <b>As it is stated: “Their tongue is a sharpened [<i>shaḥut</i>] arrow, it speaks deceit;</b> one speaks peaceably to his neighbor with his mouth, but in his heart he lays wait for him” (Jeremiah 9:7). Just as an arrow clearly enters one part of the body, so too, the slaughter [<i>sheḥita</i>] must be clear and obvious.
<b>Rabbi Elazar raises an objection</b> from a mishna (30b): If <b>two</b> people <b>are grasping a knife and slaughtering</b> one animal, <b>even</b> if each is holding a knife and slaughtering <b>one above and one below,</b> with each one slaughtering at a different point in the neck, their <b>slaughter is valid. But why</b> is the slaughter valid according to the opinions of Shmuel and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish? <b>There is no clear</b> and obvious <b>slaughter,</b> as each is cutting a different part of the neck.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to</b> Rabbi Elazar: <b>The mishna</b> is referring to a case <b>with one knife and two people,</b> each holding one end of the knife, resulting in a single diagonal incision from above to below.
<b>Rabbi Abba said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>If so, is this</b> what <b>is taught in that regard</b> in a <i>baraita</i> commenting <b>on</b> that mishna: One need <b>not be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps each</b> will <b>render</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> due <b>to the other? Granted, if you say</b> that the mishna is referring to a case <b>of two knives and two people</b> it works out <b>well, lest you say: Let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps each will rely on the other</b> that he will perform the slaughter properly, <b>and neither will this</b> one <b>come to execute</b> the cut on <b>the majority</b> of the <i>simanim</i>, <b>nor will that</b> one <b>come to execute</b> the cut on <b>the majority</b> of the <i>simanim</i>. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us that</b> one need <b>not be concerned.</b>
<b>But if you say</b> that the mishna is referring to a case <b>of one knife and two people, that</b> statement in the <i>baraita</i> should not have said: One need <b>not be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps each</b> will <b>render</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> due <b>to the other;</b> it <b>should have</b> said: One need not be concerned that because one is pulling in one direction and one is pulling in the other, <b>perhaps each will</b> cause <b>the other</b> to <b>press</b> the knife and thereby invalidate the slaughter.
<b>Rabbi Avin said to him: Teach:</b> One need <b>not be concerned</b>

Daf 30b

that <b>perhaps each will</b> cause <b>the other</b> to <b>press</b> the knife.
<b>Rabbi Avin raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one slaughtered,</b> i.e., cut, <b>the gullet below</b> on the neck <b>and the windpipe above</b> on the neck, <b>or</b> cut <b>the gullet above</b> on the neck <b>and the windpipe below</b> on the neck, <b>his slaughter is valid.</b> Based on this, Rabbi Avin asks: <b>Why</b> is the slaughter valid? <b>But</b> in that case <b>there is no clear</b> and obvious <b>slaughter.</b>
<b>He raises the objection and he resolves it.</b> This <i>baraita</i> is not referring to cuts on two places on the neck; rather, it is referring <b>to slaughter performed</b> on a diagonal, <b>like</b> the point <b>of a reed [<i>kekulmos</i>]</b> fashioned into a writing utensil. The slaughterer begins cutting from the top of one <i>siman</i> and cuts diagonally downward so that when he reaches the second <i>siman</i>, the knife is lower down.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain bull that was slaughtered</b> with cuts <b>in two or three places</b> in the <i>simanim</i> on its neck. <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta entered</b> the store <b>and took</b> a cut of meat <b>from the highest quality</b> parts of the animal, thereby demonstrating that the slaughter was valid. <b>Rabbi Zeira said to him: Our rabbi, you have taught us</b> through your actions that <b>the mishna:</b> If two people are grasping a knife and slaughtering one animal, even one above and one below, is referring even to a case <b>of two knives and two people</b> who are each cutting the <i>simanim</i> at a different part of the neck with their knives.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If <b>one concealed the knife</b> in the neck <b>between</b> one <b><i>siman</i> and</b> the other <b><i>siman</i>,</b> i.e., he inserted the knife between the windpipe and the gullet, <b>and he severed</b> the gullet first and then removed the knife and cut the windpipe, the slaughter is <b>not valid.</b> If one concealed the knife <b>beneath the hide</b> of the neck and then he cut both <i>simanim</i>, the slaughter is <b>valid.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rav <b>teaching us? We</b> already <b>learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> explicitly in a mishna (32a): <b>Or</b> if one cut one <i>siman</i> and <b>concealed the knife beneath the second</b> <i>siman</i> <b>and severed it, Rabbi Yeshevav says:</b> The animal is <b>an unslaughtered carcass</b> and imparts ritual impurity through contact with it and carrying it. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> and although eating it is prohibited, it does not transmit ritual impurity. Both agree that the slaughter is not valid in the sense that it does not permit the consumption of the meat of the animal.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> this <i>halakha</i> is learned <b>from the mishna</b> alone, <b>I would say</b> that <b>this statement</b> applies only in a case where one conceals the knife beneath the gullet and cuts it <b>from below to above,</b> i.e., from the nape to the front of the neck, <b>because he did not perform</b> the slaughter <b>in the</b> standard <b>manner of slaughter. But</b> if he cut the gullet <b>from above to below,</b> i.e., from the front of the neck to the nape, <b>since he performed</b> the slaughter <b>in the</b> standard <b>manner of slaughter, say</b> that the slaughter is <b>valid.</b> Therefore, Rav <b>teaches us</b> that with regard to any case where one conceals the knife during slaughter, his slaughter is not valid.
The Gemara proceeds to analyze the second part of that which Rav Yehuda says that Rav says: If one concealed the knife <b>beneath the hide</b> of the neck and then he cut both <i>simanim</i> in the standard manner the slaughter is <b>valid. The school of Rav say</b> that Rav says that in a case where one conceals the knife <b>beneath the hide</b> and cuts the <i>simanim</i> of the animal, <b>I do not know</b> whether the slaughter is valid, or whether it is not valid because he concealed the knife during the slaughter.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>the school of Rav, who say: Beneath the hide, I do not know,</b> if one concealed the knife <b>beneath a cloth</b> that is around the animal’s neck, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If one concealed the knife <b>beneath tangled wool</b> on the neck of a sheep, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara concludes: These dilemmas <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>concealed</b> the knife <b>in</b> cutting <b>the minority of the <i>simanim</i></b> and cut the majority of the <i>simanim</i> in the standard manner, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> by cutting <b>two</b> animals’ <b>heads simultaneously, his slaughter is valid.</b> If <b>two</b> people <b>are grasping a knife and slaughtering</b> one animal, <b>even</b> if each is holding a knife and slaughtering <b>one above and one below,</b> with each one slaughtering at a different point in the neck, their <b>slaughter is valid.</b> If <b>one decapitated</b> the animal <b>in one</b> motion and did not slaughter the animal in the standard manner of drawing the knife back and forth, the slaughter is <b>not valid.</b> In a case where <b>one was</b> in the process of <b>slaughtering</b> the animal in the standard manner <b>and he decapitated</b> the animal <b>in one</b> motion, <b>if</b> the length <b>of the knife</b> is equivalent to <b>the</b> breadth of the animal’s <b>entire neck,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid.</b>
If <b>one was</b> in the process of <b>slaughtering</b> two animals simultaneously, <b>and he decapitated two heads in one</b> motion, <b>if</b> the length <b>of the knife</b> is equivalent to <b>the breadth of an entire neck</b> of <b>one</b> of the animals, the slaughter is <b>valid. In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that one must be concerned about the length of the knife, <b>said?</b> It is <b>when one drew</b> the knife <b>back and did not draw</b> it <b>forth, or drew it forth and did not draw it back; but</b> if <b>he drew it back and forth, even</b> if the knife was of <b>any length, even</b> if he slaughtered <b>with a scalpel [<i>be’izemel</i>],</b> the slaughter is <b>valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna stated: If one decapitated the animal in one motion, the slaughter is not valid. The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>Shmuel said:</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as the verse states: “Their tongue is a sharpened [<i>shaḥut</i>] arrow, it speaks deceit”</b> (Jeremiah 9:7). Just as an arrow is propelled by drawing back the bowstring, so too, slaughter [<i>sheḥita</i>] must be performed by drawing the knife across the animal’s neck and not by pressing the knife or striking the neck with the knife.
Likewise, <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The verse states: <b>“And he shall slaughter [<i>veshaḥat</i>]</b> the young bull before the Lord” (Leviticus 1:5). The term <b>“<i>veshaḥat</i>”</b> means <b>nothing other than: And he shall draw</b> the knife across the neck of the animal. <b>And similarly,</b> the verse <b>states:</b> “And King Solomon made two hundred targets <b>of drawn [<i>shaḥut</i>] gold”</b> (I Kings 10:16), meaning gold that is smoothed in the manner of goldsmiths. <b>And</b> the verse <b>states: “Their tongue is a sharpened arrow, it speaks deceit”</b> (Jeremiah 9:7).
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the purpose of citing the additional verse introduced with the term: <b>And</b> the verse <b>states?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>And if you would say</b> that the term <b>“drawn [<i>shaḥut</i>] gold”</b> means that the gold <b>was spun like</b> soft <b>thread [<i>keḥut</i>], come</b> and <b>hear: “Their tongue is a sharpened [<i>shaḥut</i>] arrow.”</b> In this verse, <i>shaḥut</i> means drawn like the bowstring that propels an arrow, and is not a reference to thread.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rava would examine the arrow for Rabbi Yona bar Taḥlifa</b> to ensure that there were no notches in it. <b>And</b> Rava shot the arrow and <b>slaughtered a bird with it as it was flying.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>And perhaps</b> when the arrow cut the bird’s neck <b>it performed</b> an inverted slaughter, with the arrow <b>concealed</b> in the neck, and cut the <i>simanim</i> from back to front. The Gemara responds: <b>We see</b>

Daf 31a

<b>that the feathers</b> at the front of the neck were <b>unraveled</b> by the arrow, a clear indication that slaughter was performed from the front of the neck.
The Gemara notes another difficulty encountered in the slaughter of a flying bird with an arrow. <b>But doesn’t</b> the bird’s blood <b>require covering</b> with earth? <b>And if you would say that</b> Rabbi Yona bar Taḥlifa <b>covers</b> the blood, <b>but doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> In fulfilling the mitzva of covering the blood, <b>one who slaughters</b> an undomesticated animal or bird <b>must place earth beneath</b> the blood <b>and earth above</b> it, <b>as it is stated:</b> “He shall spill its blood, <b>and cover it in earth”</b> (Leviticus 17:13). <b>It is not stated:</b> Cover it with <b>earth, but rather “in earth</b>.” This <b>teaches that one who slaughters must place earth beneath</b> the blood <b>and earth above</b> the blood, so that the blood will be within the earth.
The Gemara answers <b>that</b> Rabbi Yona bar Taḥlifa would <b>designate for himself</b> the <b>earth of the entire valley [<i>patka</i>]</b> before shooting the arrow. That earth would serve as the layer of earth beneath the blood and he would proceed to cover the blood with another layer of earth.
§ The mishna teaches: In a case where <b>one was</b> in the process of <b>slaughtering</b> the animal in the standard manner <b>and he decapitated</b> the animal in one motion, if the length of the knife is equivalent to the breadth of the animal’s entire neck, the slaughter is valid. <b>Rabbi Zeira says:</b> The knife must be equivalent to <b>the</b> breadth of the animal’s <b>entire neck and</b> extend <b>beyond the neck.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Did Rabbi Zeira mean: Equivalent to the breadth of the animal’s <b>entire neck and</b> extend <b>beyond the neck</b> by an amount equivalent to the breadth of the <b>entire neck,</b> in which case the length of the knife <b>would</b> equal the breadth of <b>two necks? Or perhaps</b> he meant: Equivalent to the breadth of the <b>entire neck and beyond the neck</b> by <b>any amount?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof to resolve the dilemma from the continuation of the mishna: If <b>one was</b> in the process of <b>slaughtering</b> two animals simultaneously, <b>and he decapitated two heads in one</b> motion, <b>if</b> the length <b>of the knife</b> is equivalent to the breadth of <b>an entire neck</b> of <b>one</b> of the animals the slaughter is <b>valid.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: The breadth of <b>an entire neck</b> of <b>one</b> of the animals? <b>If we say</b> that it means the breadth of <b>one entire neck and nothing more,</b> that is difficult. <b>Now,</b> for the slaughter <b>of one animal, we require</b> that the knife be equivalent to the breadth of the animal’s <b>entire neck and</b> extend <b>beyond the neck;</b> for the slaughter <b>of two animals,</b> is it possible that a knife whose length is equivalent to the breadth of <b>one</b> animal’s <b>entire neck would be sufficient? Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that it means that the length of the knife must be equivalent to the breadth of <b>one entire neck beyond the</b> breadth of <b>two necks.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Learn from</b> the mishna that Rabbi Zeira means that the length of the knife must be equivalent to the breadth of the animal’s entire neck and extend <b>beyond the neck</b> by the breadth of the <b>entire neck.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that this was Rabbi Zeira’s intent.
§ The mishna continues: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>when one drew</b> the knife <b>back and did not draw</b> it <b>forth,</b> or drew it forth and did not draw it back. But if he drew it back and forth, even if the knife was of any length, even if he slaughtered with a scalpel, the slaughter is valid. <b>Rav Menashe said:</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>in</b> the case of <b>a scalpel that does not have protrusions</b> from the sides. If there are protrusions, since the scalpel is short, there is concern that the corners may perforate the <i>simanim</i> or enter between the <i>simanim</i> and invalidate the slaughter.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya, said to Rav Menashe: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to slaughter with <b>a needle?</b> Rav Menashe <b>said to him: A needle pierces</b> the <i>simanim</i>, as it perforates the neck instead of cutting it.
Rav Aḥa then asked Rav Menashe: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to slaughtering with <b>a cobbler’s needle,</b> which is flat and has sharp sides? Rav Menashe <b>said to him: We</b> already <b>learn</b> in the mishna: <b>Even</b> if the knife was of <b>any length,</b> the slaughter is valid. <b>What, is it not</b> referring to slaughter with <b>a cobbler’s needle?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>No.</b> The reference is to slaughtering with <b>a scalpel,</b> which is larger than a cobbler’s needle. The Gemara objects: The <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> the case of <b>a scalpel explicitly</b> in the mishna. Therefore, the phrase in the mishna: A knife of any length, must be referring to an item smaller than a scalpel. The Gemara explains: The subsequent mention of the scalpel <b>is explaining</b> the phrase: Even if the knife was of any length. <b>What is</b> the knife of <b>any length</b> with which slaughter is valid? It is <b>a scalpel.</b>
<b>This too stands to reason, as, if it enters your mind</b> that the phrase: A knife of any length, is referring to <b>a cobbler’s needle, now</b> that it is <b>permitted</b> to slaughter with <b>a cobbler’s needle, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> for the <i>tanna</i> to teach that it is permitted to slaughter with <b>a scalpel,</b> which is larger than a cobbler’s needle? The Gemara rejects that reasoning: It <b>is necessary</b> for the mishna to teach both the case of a cobbler’s needle and the case of <b>a scalpel,</b> as it could <b>enter your mind to say</b> that it is prohibited to slaughter with a scalpel even though it is permitted to slaughter with a cobbler’s needle. The reasoning for this distinction would be: <b>Let</b> the Sages <b>issue a decree</b> prohibiting the use of <b>a scalpel with no protrusions due to</b> the prohibition against using <b>a scalpel with protrusions.</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us</b> that there is no decree and it is permitted to slaughter with a scalpel that has no protrusions.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a knife fell and slaughtered</b> an animal, <b>although</b> the knife <b>slaughtered</b> the animal <b>in the standard manner,</b> the slaughter is <b>not valid, as it is stated: “And you shall slaughter…and you shall eat”</b> (Deuteronomy 27:7), from which it is derived: <b>That which you slaughter you may eat,</b> and that which was slaughtered on its own, you may not eat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if a knife fell and slaughtered an animal the slaughter is not valid. The Gemara notes: <b>The reason</b> the slaughter is not valid is <b>that</b> the knife <b>fell.
