But</b> by inference, if <b>one dropped</b> the knife the slaughter is <b>valid, and</b> that is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though</b> when dropping the knife he <b>did not intend</b> to slaughter the animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds <b>that we do not require intent for slaughter? Rava said:</b> It <b>is Rabbi Natan, as Oshaya, the youngest of the company</b> of Sages, <b>taught</b> a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one threw a knife to embed it in the wall and</b> in the course of its flight the knife <b>went and slaughtered</b> an animal <b>in its</b> proper <b>manner, Rabbi Natan deems</b> the slaughter <b>valid and the Rabbis deem</b> the slaughter <b>not valid.</b> Oshaya <b>teaches</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>and he says</b> about <b>it:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan</b> that there is no need for intent to perform a valid act of slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rava</b> already <b>say it one time</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Natan? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (2a): <b>And</b> with regard to <b>any of them,</b> a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor, <b>who slaughtered</b> an animal <b>and others see</b> and supervise <b>them, their slaughter is valid</b> even though they are incapable of intent. <b>And we said: Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds <b>that we do not require intent for slaughter? And Rava said:</b> It <b>is Rabbi Natan.</b>
The Gemara answers: Both statements <b>are necessary. As had</b> Rava <b>taught us</b> his statement <b>there</b> with regard to a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, one would have thought that the slaughter is valid <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> although the individual lacks intent to slaughter the animal, <b>he intends</b> his action <b>for the sake of cutting in general. But here,</b> with regard to throwing a knife at the wall, <b>where he does not intend</b> to cut at all, <b>say no,</b> the slaughter is not valid.
<b>And had</b> Rava <b>taught us</b> his statement <b>here</b> with regard to throwing the knife, one would have thought that the slaughter is valid is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> it <b>comes due to</b> the action <b>of a mentally competent person. But there,</b> with regard to slaughter by a deaf-mute, an imbecile, or a minor, <b>where</b> the slaughter <b>does not come due to</b> the action <b>of a mentally competent person, say</b> that the slaughter is <b>not</b> valid. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for Rava to teach both cases.
§ The mishna is now cited as proof in an amoraic dispute. <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to <b>a menstruating woman who,</b> after the menstrual flow ended, <b>was compelled</b> against her will <b>and immersed</b> in a ritual bath, <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: She is ritually pure vis-à-vis her house,</b> i.e., it is permitted for her to engage in intercourse with her husband, <b>but it is prohibited for her to partake of <i>teruma</i></b> because the immersion is not considered valid for that purpose. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: She was not purified even vis-à-vis her house.</b>
<b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, who says</b> that <b>she is ritually pure vis-à-vis her house but it is prohibited for her to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> it is difficult. With regard to <b>a transgression</b> punishable <b>by <i>karet</i>,</b> i.e., intercourse with a menstruating woman, <b>she was rendered permitted</b> by immersion against her will; with regard to partaking of <i>teruma</i>, <b>a prohibition</b> punishable by <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven, which is a lesser punishment, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that it is permitted for her through immersion against her will? Why then does Rav deem it prohibited for her to partake of <i>teruma</i>?
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him:</b> The halakhic status of <b>her husband is non-sacred, and non-sacred</b> items <b>do not require intent</b> for purification. <b>And from where do you say</b> so? It is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 5:6): In the case of <b>a wave that was detached</b> from the sea, <b>and in it</b> were <b>forty <i>se’a</i></b> of water, <b>and</b> that wave <b>fell on</b> an impure <b>person or on</b> impure <b>vessels, they are ritually pure. What, is it not</b> that <b>a person</b> is <b>similar to vessels? Just as vessels do not intend</b> to be purified and they are purified by the wave, <b>so too, a person does not require intent</b> in order to be purified.
The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>From where</b> is there proof that this is the meaning of the mishna? <b>Perhaps we are dealing with</b> the case of one who <b>sits</b> near the water <b>and waits</b> to determine <b>when the wave will be detached,</b> which is tantamount to having intent to immerse,

Daf 31b

<b>and vessels</b> are <b>similar to a person: Just as</b> for <b>a person, we require</b> his <b>intent</b> for purification, <b>so too</b> for <b>vessels,</b> they are purified only in a case <b>where a person intends for them</b> to be purified.
<b>And if you would say:</b> If the mishna is referring <b>to</b> the case of one who <b>sits and waits</b> to determine when the wave will be detached, <b>what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> this <i>halakha</i>? It is obvious and introduces no novel element.
The Gemara responds that there is a novel element in this <i>halakha</i>. <b>Lest you say: Let us issue a decree</b> that a detached wave does not effect purification <b>due to</b> the concern that otherwise, one would receive the mistaken impression that one is purified in <b>a cascade [<i>ḥardalit</i>] of rainwater</b> containing forty <i>se’a</i>. The <i>halakha</i> is that rainwater purifies only when pooled in one place. <b>Alternatively, let us issue a decree</b> that <b>the edges</b> of the waves, which are in contact with the ground, are ineffective in purifying people and vessels standing on the ground <b>due to</b> the concern that otherwise one would receive the mistaken impression that vessels are purified even if one pushes them upward into the <b>arc</b> of the waves while the water remains airborne. Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us that we do not issue</b> either of those <b>decrees.</b>
<b>And from where do you say that we do not immerse in the arcs</b> of waves? <b>As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may immerse in the edges</b> of waves, <b>but one may not immerse in</b> their <b>arcs, as one may not immerse in air.</b> Immersion may be performed only on the ground.
The Gemara again asks: <b>But in any event, from where do we</b> derive <b>that non-sacred</b> items <b>do not require intent?</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Makhshirin</i> 4:7): Produce becomes susceptible to ritual impurity only if it is dampened by one of seven liquids and its owner was amenable to its dampening. This is derived from the verse: “But when water is placed on the seed, and some of their carcass shall fall on it, it is impure to you” (Leviticus 11:38). If <b>produce fell into a stream, and one whose hands were ritually impure extended</b> his hands <b>and took</b> the produce from the water channel, <b>his hands are ritually pure</b> through immersion in the stream, <b>and</b> this <b>produce is not in</b> the category of: “But <b>when</b> water <b>is placed.”</b> The produce is not susceptible to ritual impurity because the owner did not intend that his hands become wet.
<b>But if</b> he placed his hands into the stream <b>so that</b> his hands <b>would be rinsed</b> and purified, <b>his hands are ritually pure, and the produce is in</b> the category of: “But <b>when</b> water <b>is placed.”</b> Since he was amenable to the dampening of his hands, the water on his hands renders the produce susceptible to ritual impurity. From the first case in the mishna it is clear that his hands are purified even though his intent was not to immerse them in the water.
<b>Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman</b> from a mishna (<i>Ḥagiga</i> 18b): If <b>one immersed for</b> the purpose of eating <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>and assumed the presumptive status</b> of ritual purity <b>for non-sacred</b> food, it <b>is prohibited</b> for him to partake of second-<b>tithe</b> produce. The Gemara infers: If <b>one assumed the presumptive status</b> of ritual purity with regard to non-sacred food, <b>yes,</b> it is permitted for him to eat non-sacred food; <b>if he did not assume the presumptive status,</b> he may <b>not</b> eat non-sacred food. This indicates that even when immersing in order to partake of non-sacred food, one must intend to assume the presumptive status of ritual purity.
Rav Naḥman rejects the proof from the mishna and says that no intent is required to assume the presumptive status of ritual purity in order to eat non-sacred food. Rather, <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying: Although he assumes the presumptive status</b> of ritual purity <b>for non-sacred</b> food, it <b>is prohibited</b> for him to partake of second-<b>tithe</b> produce.
Rava <b>raised an objection to</b> Rav Naḥman from that same mishna: If <b>one immersed without</b> intent to <b>assume the presumptive status</b> of ritual purity, it is <b>as though he did not immerse. What, is</b> the meaning of the mishna <b>not</b> that it is <b>as though he did not immerse at all?</b>
Rav Naḥman rejects that proof as well. <b>No,</b> it means that if he immersed without intent it is <b>as though he did not immerse to</b> partake of second-<b>tithe</b> produce, <b>but</b> in that case, <b>he immersed for non-sacred</b> food, for which no intent is necessary. The Gemara comments: Rava <b>believed</b> that Rav Naḥman <b>was</b> merely <b>putting him off</b> with his claim that the formulation of the mishna does not conclusively support his objection; he believed that Rav Naḥman was not stating the real meaning of the mishna. Rava then <b>went out, examined</b> the sources, <b>and discovered that it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> explicitly in accordance with the opinion of Rav Naḥman: If one <b>immersed and</b> had <b>no</b> intent to <b>assume the presumptive status</b> of ritual purity, it <b>is permitted</b> for him <b>to</b> eat <b>non-sacred</b> food, <b>but</b> it <b>is prohibited</b> for him <b>to</b> partake of second-<b>tithe</b> produce.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: Let us say that</b> there <b>will be a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan from this</b> <i>baraita</i>. This <i>baraita</i> states that immersion without intent is effective for non-sacred items, while Rabbi Yoḥanan said (31a) that if a woman who is impure due to menstruation immerses without intent she is forbidden to her husband, who is non-sacred.
Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> Indeed, the <i>baraita</i> is contrary to his opinion, but <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan is saying</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yonatan ben Yosef.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse dealing with the purification of a leprous garment, which must be laundered, quarantined for a week, and then immersed in a ritual bath: “And the garment…that you shall wash and the leprosy departed from them, and it shall be washed a second time and shall be pure” (Leviticus 13:58). <b>Rabbi Yonatan ben Yosef says:</b> It would have been sufficient for the verse to simply state: <b>And it shall be washed</b> and shall be pure. For <b>what</b> purpose does <b>the verse state: “A second time”?</b> The Torah <b>juxtaposes the second washing,</b> the immersion, <b>with the first washing,</b> the laundering. <b>Just as the first washing is</b> performed <b>with intent,</b> as it is written: “And the priest shall command that they wash the garment that has the leprous mark, and he shall quarantine it seven days more” (Leviticus 13:54), <b>so too, the second washing,</b> the immersion in a ritual bath, must be performed <b>with intent.</b>
<b>If</b> so, based on the same juxtaposition, perhaps derive: <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the first washing, <b>we require the intent of a priest,</b> who commands to wash the garment, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the second washing, <b>we require the intent of a priest.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And shall be pure”</b> (Leviticus 13:58), indicating that there is purity <b>in any case</b> where there is intent, even without a command from a priest. In the opinion of Rabbi Yonatan ben Yosef, even the immersion of the non-sacred garment must be performed with intent. Rav Yosef states that Rabbi Yoḥanan bases his statement on Rabbi Yonatan ben Yosef’s opinion.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi objects to</b> the association of the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan with the opinion of Rabbi Yonatan ben Yosef: <b>Did Rabbi Yoḥanan say that</b> immersion of a non-sacred garment requires intent? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with an unattributed mishna?</b>
<b>And we learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>a knife fell and slaughtered</b> an animal, <b>although</b> the knife <b>slaughtered</b> the animal <b>in the standard manner,</b> the slaughter is <b>not valid. And we discussed it: The reason</b> the slaughter is not valid is <b>that</b> the knife <b>fell. But</b> by inference, if <b>one dropped</b> the knife the slaughter is <b>valid, and</b> that is the ruling <b>even though</b> when dropping the knife he <b>did not intend</b> to slaughter the animal. <b>And we say: Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds <b>that we do not require intent for slaughter? Rava said:</b> It <b>is Rabbi Natan.</b> Based on his principle that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with an unattributed mishna, Rabbi Yoḥanan should rule in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Natan cited in the unattributed mishna, and not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yonatan ben Yosef.
The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to slaughter, even Rabbi Yonatan ben Yosef</b> concedes that intent is not necessary. He learns this <b>from the fact that the Merciful One revealed</b> that if <b>one acts unawares</b> in performing the slaughter <b>of sacrificial</b> animals, with no intent to slaughter, the offering <b>is disqualified.</b> This is derived (13a) from the verse: “You shall slaughter it to your will” (Leviticus 19:5). <b>By inference,</b> conclude that with regard to the slaughter <b>of non-sacred</b> animals <b>we do not require intent.</b>
While on this subject the Gemara clarifies: <b>And the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Rabbi Natan and hold that slaughter of non-sacred animals requires intent would say: <b>Although we do not require intent to slaughter</b> non-sacred animals, <b>we require</b> intent <b>to cut</b> the neck of the animal. Throwing the knife down is not sufficient.
<b>Rava said</b> that it was <b>with this</b> contention that <b>Rabbi Natan overcame the Rabbis:</b> He said: <b>Is it written</b> with regard to the slaughter of non-sacred animals: <b>And you shall cut?</b> It <b>is written: “And you shall slaughter”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:21). The Torah does not distinguish between cutting and slaughtering; <b>if we require intent for cutting, we</b> should <b>require</b> intent <b>even for slaughtering.</b> Conversely, <b>if we do not require intent for slaughtering, we should also not require</b> intent <b>for cutting.</b>
The Gemara revisits the matter of immersion without intent. <b>What are the circumstances of a menstruating woman who,</b> after the menstrual flow ended, <b>was compelled</b> against her will <b>and immersed</b> in a ritual bath? <b>If we say that another</b> woman <b>compelled her and immersed her</b> in a ritual bath, the immersion should be valid even according to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, as <b>the intent of another</b> woman <b>is full-fledged intent.</b>
<b>And furthermore,</b> in that case the immersion enables her to <b>partake of <i>teruma</i> as well, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nidda</i> 13b): In the case of a woman who is <b>a deaf-mute, or an imbecile, or blind, or who went insane,</b> and is therefore unable to examine herself reliably, <b>if</b> one of these women <b>has a competent</b> friend, that friend <b>prepares her</b> by examining her and immersing them in a ritual bath. And on that basis the incompetent woman <b>may partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said: According to Rabbi Natan,</b> who does not require intent for the slaughter of non-sacred animals, immersion against her will that renders it permitted for a woman to engage in intercourse with her husband is in a case <b>where she fell from a bridge</b> into a river, with no intent at all. <b>According to the Rabbis,</b> who require intent to cut for slaughter to be valid and intent to enter the water for immersion to be valid, it is referring to a case <b>where she descended</b> into the water <b>to cool</b> herself, with no thought of purification.
The Gemara continues its discussion of the dispute between Rabbi Natan and the Rabbis. <b>Rava said:</b> If one <b>slaughtered</b> a red <b>heifer and</b> in the same action <b>slaughtered another animal</b> together <b>with it, everyone agrees</b> that the red heifer is <b>disqualified.</b>

Daf 32a

But if <b>another animal was</b> inadvertently <b>slaughtered</b> together <b>with</b> the red heifer in the same action, <b>according to Rabbi Natan,</b> who holds that the slaughter of non-sacred animals without intent is valid, the red <b>heifer is disqualified,</b> because an additional labor was performed with its slaughter, and the other <b>animal is fit</b> for consumption, as its slaughter was valid. <b>According to the Rabbis,</b> who hold that slaughter of non-sacred animals without intent is not considered slaughter, the red <b>heifer is fit</b> for use in the purification rite because no other labor was performed with its slaughter, and <b>the</b> other <b>animal is unfit</b> for consumption.
The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious;</b> why did Rava have to teach that? The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary for</b> Rava to teach the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan</b> in the case where <b>another animal was</b> inadvertently <b>slaughtered</b> in the same action with the red heifer. It may <b>enter your mind to say: The Merciful One states</b> with regard to the slaughter of the red heifer: “And you shall give it to Elazar the priest…<b>and he shall slaughter it</b> before him” (Numbers 19:3), from which it is inferred: One may slaughter it, <b>but not it and another</b> animal simultaneously. <b>And what are the circumstances</b> of that prohibition? It is a case <b>where one slaughtered two</b> red <b>heifers at the same time. But</b> in a case where one slaughtered a red heifer together with <b>a non-sacred animal, say no,</b> that it does <b>not</b> disqualify the red heifer. Therefore, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that even slaughter with a non-sacred animal disqualifies the red heifer.
Rava adds: If one slaughtered a red heifer and in the same action <b>cut a gourd</b> together <b>with it, everyone agrees</b> that the red heifer <b>is disqualified.</b> If one slaughtered a red heifer and <b>a gourd was</b> inadvertently <b>cut</b> together <b>with it</b> in the same action, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the red heifer is <b>fit</b> for use in the purification rite, as that is not labor that disqualifies a red heifer and it is also not excluded by the derivation from the verse “And he shall slaughter it.”
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If, when one was in the middle of slaughtering an animal, <b>the knife fell and he lifted it</b> and then completed the slaughter, or if <b>his garments fell and he lifted them</b> and then completed the slaughter, or if <b>he had honed the knife and grew weary</b> before completing the slaughter and <b>another came and slaughtered</b> the animal, <b>if he interrupted</b> the slaughter in one of these ways or in a different way for an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of an act of <b>slaughter,</b> the slaughter is <b>not valid. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The slaughter is not valid <b>if he interrupted</b> the slaughter for an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of <b>an examination.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of an act of <b>slaughter? Rav said:</b> It means an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of an act of <b>slaughter of another animal,</b> not the duration required to complete the act of slaughter that was interrupted.
<b>Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav:</b> Is the interruption that invalidates the slaughter an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of an act of <b>slaughter of</b> another <b>animal for an animal,</b> i.e., in a case where an animal was being slaughtered, <b>and</b> an interval equivalent to the duration of an act of slaughter <b>of</b> another <b>bird for a bird? Or perhaps</b> it is an interval equivalent to the duration of an act of slaughter <b>of an animal even for a bird,</b> and if the interruption is any shorter it does not invalidate the slaughter?
Rav <b>said to them:</b> When we studied this topic <b>I</b> did <b>not</b> feel sufficiently <b>intimate with my beloved</b> uncle, Rabbi Ḥiyya, such <b>that I</b> could <b>ask him</b> that question. Rav was able only to transmit that which he heard from Rabbi Ḥiyya, but was unable to resolve their dilemma.
<b>It was stated</b> that there is an amoraic dispute with regard to this matter. <b>Rav said:</b> An interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of an act of <b>slaughter of</b> another <b>animal for an animal, and</b> an interval equivalent to the duration of an act of slaughter <b>of</b> another <b>bird for a bird. And Shmuel said:</b> An interval equivalent to the duration of an act of slaughter <b>of an animal even for a bird. And likewise, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> An interval equivalent to the duration of an act of slaughter <b>of an animal even for a bird.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥananya said:</b> An interval <b>equivalent</b> to the period in <b>which one can bring another animal and slaughter</b> it. The Gemara asks: Does that mean the time in which <b>one can bring</b> an animal <b>even from anywhere else,</b> regardless of the distance? Occasionally, there is no animal available in close proximity. If so, <b>you have rendered your statement</b> subject <b>to circumstances;</b> it does not apply uniformly to all cases.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The practical difference <b>between</b> the opinion of Rabbi Ḥananya and that of the other Sages is in a case where there is an animal <b>standing</b> before the slaughterer and it is necessary <b>to cast</b> it to the ground in order to slaughter it. Even Rabbi Ḥananya disregards the time required to bring the animal from elsewhere. But Rabbi Ḥananya holds that the slaughter is invalidated only if the interruption lasts an interval equivalent to the duration of the act of casting the animal to the ground and slaughtering it. The Rabbis invalidate the slaughter even if an interval has elapsed that is equivalent to the duration of the act of slaughtering the animal, without casting it to the ground.
The Gemara cites an additional opinion with regard to the duration of the interruption that invalidates slaughter. <b>They said in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina:</b> The duration of the interruption that invalidates slaughter is <b>equivalent</b> to the period in <b>which he can lift</b> the animal from the ground <b>and</b> then <b>lay it</b> back on the ground <b>and slaughter</b> it. The interval is calculated based on the size of the animal in question. The duration of the interruption that invalidates slaughter of <b>a small</b> animal is equivalent to the period necessary <b>to</b> lift, lay down, and slaughter <b>a small</b> animal. <b>And</b> the duration of the interruption that invalidates slaughter of <b>a large</b> animal is equivalent to the period necessary <b>to</b> lift, lay down, and slaughter <b>a large</b> animal.
§ <b>Rava said:</b> In the case of <b>one who slaughters with a blunt knife, even</b> if the completion of the slaughter lasts <b>the entire day,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid</b> provided there is no interruption in the midst of the slaughter.
<b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> If there were several short <b>interruptions</b> during a single act of slaughter, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in terms of whether <b>they join</b> together to invalidate the slaughter if the sum of the durations of all the interruptions is greater than the maximum permitted interruption?
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let</b> Rava <b>resolve</b> the dilemma <b>from his own</b> statement, as he permitted an act of slaughter that lasts the entire day, during which there were presumably brief interruptions throughout. Apparently, the interruptions do not join together. The Gemara responds: <b>There,</b> Rava was referring to a case <b>where there was no interruption,</b> as the slaughterer drew the knife back and forth throughout.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, raises a dilemma:</b> If one cut the majority of the <i>simanim</i> and then <b>interrupted</b> the slaughter before proceeding to cut the <b>minority of the <i>simanim</i>, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The slaughter is not valid <b>if he interrupted</b> the slaughter for an interval equivalent to the duration of an examination. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of <b>an examination? Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of <b>an examination</b> of the knife <b>by a Sage</b> prior to the slaughter of the animal. The Gemara objects: <b>If so, you have rendered your statement</b> subject <b>to circumstances,</b> as sometimes the Sage is near and sometimes the Sage is far, and the time required for examination varies accordingly. The Gemara responds: <b>Rather,</b> the reference is to an interval <b>equivalent</b> to the duration of <b>an examination</b> performed by <b>a slaughterer</b> who is <b>a Sage.</b> In that case, travel time is not factored in; only the time of the examination itself is considered, and this does not vary.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one cut the gullet</b> in the standard manner of slaughter with a back-and-forth movement, <b>and he severed the windpipe</b> not in the standard manner, <b>or</b> if <b>one severed the windpipe and thereafter cut the gullet, or</b> if <b>one cut one of</b> the <i>simanim</i> <b>and waited until</b> the animal <b>died, or</b> if one cut one <i>siman</i> and <b>concealed the knife beneath the second</b> <i>siman</i> <b>and severed it</b> from below, <b>Rabbi Yeshevav says:</b> The animal is <b>an unslaughtered carcass</b> and imparts ritual impurity through contact with it and carrying it. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> and although eating it is prohibited, it does not transmit ritual impurity.
<b>Rabbi Yeshevav stated a principle in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua: Any</b> animal <b>that was rendered unfit during its slaughter</b> because the slaughter was not performed properly <b>is an unslaughtered carcass; any</b> animal <b>whose slaughter was</b> performed <b>properly and another matter caused it to become unfit is a <i>tereifa</i>. And Rabbi Akiva conceded to his</b> opinion.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: If <b>one cut the gullet…and Rabbi Akiva conceded to his</b> opinion. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna at the beginning of the next chapter (42a): <b>These</b> wounds constitute <b><i>tereifot</i> in an animal:</b>

Daf 32b

An animal that has <b>a perforated gullet,</b> where the perforation goes through the wall of the gullet, <b>or</b> one with <b>a severed windpipe.</b> According to this mishna, the severed windpipe renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> and not an unslaughtered carcass. If Rabbi Akiva reconsidered his opinion and conceded to Rabbi Yeshevav, in accordance with the opinion of which <i>tanna</i> is that mishna?
<b>Rava said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where one cut</b> the gullet <b>and ultimately severed</b> the windpipe not in the standard manner. <b>There,</b> the mishna in the next chapter is referring to a case <b>where he severed</b> the windpipe not in the standard manner, <b>and ultimately cut</b> the gullet. If he <b>cut</b> the gullet <b>and ultimately severed</b> the windpipe, the animal <b>was rendered unfit during its slaughter;</b> therefore, it assumes the status of an unslaughtered carcass, according to the principle of Rabbi Yeshevav. But if <b>he severed</b> the windpipe <b>and ultimately cut</b> the gullet, it is <b>as</b> though <b>another matter caused</b> the animal <b>to become unfit;</b> therefore, it assumes the status of a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Huna raised an objection to Rava</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>cut the gullet and</b> then <b>severed the windpipe,</b> or if one <b>severed the windpipe and cut the gullet thereafter,</b> the animal is <b>an unslaughtered carcass.</b> Apparently, contrary to Rava’s statement, the order is irrelevant, and even if the windpipe is severed first, the animal assumes the status of an unslaughtered carcass.
Rava said: <b>Say</b> that the latter case in the <i>baraita</i> means not that he cut the gullet thereafter; rather, it is a case where one severed the windpipe <b>and had already cut the gullet at the outset.</b>
Rav Aḥa bar Huna <b>said to him:</b> There are <b>two refutations of the statement,</b> i.e., of your attempt to answer the difficulty from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>One</b> is that if the second case in the <i>baraita</i> is one where he initially cut the gullet, then <b>that is</b> identical to <b>the first</b> case in the <i>baraita</i>. <b>And furthermore, didn’t we learn</b> explicitly in the <i>baraita</i>: Or if one severed the windpipe and cut the gullet <b>thereafter,</b> the animal is an unslaughtered carcass?
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The use of the term: <i>Tereifot</i>, in the mishna in the next chapter is not to the exclusion of unslaughtered carcasses; rather, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> that term in a general sense, meaning: <b>These</b> wounds serve to render an animal <b>forbidden; and there are</b> some <b>of them</b> that are <b>unslaughtered carcasses,</b> e.g., an animal with a severed windpipe, <b>and there are</b> some <b>of them</b> that are <b><i>tereifot</i>.</b>
The Gemara objects to that interpretation: If the mishna is listing those circumstances that render the animal an unslaughtered carcass, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>consider</b> the circumstance <b>of Ḥizkiyya as well, as Ḥizkiyya says:</b> If <b>one rendered</b> the animal like <b>a shard</b> by cutting it into two widthwise, its halakhic status is that of <b>an unslaughtered carcass</b> even while it is convulsing before its death. <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>consider</b> the circumstance <b>of Rabbi Elazar as well, as Rabbi Elazar said:</b> If <b>the thigh,</b> the hind leg of the animal, <b>was removed and its recess</b> is obvious (see 21a), it is <b>an unslaughtered carcass.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>When</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> the case of <b>an unslaughtered carcass,</b> it is a case where the animal <b>does not</b> assume that status and <b>impart impurity while alive. But</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>does not teach</b> the case of <b>an unslaughtered carcass</b> where the animal assumes that status and <b>imparts impurity while alive,</b> e.g., the cases of Ḥizkiyya and Rabbi Elazar.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> resolved the apparent contradiction between the mishna here and the mishna on 42a, and <b>said: Here,</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring to a case <b>where one cut</b> the gullet <b>in</b> the same <b>place</b> as the initial <b>cut</b> in the windpipe. <b>There,</b> on 42a, the <i>tanna</i> is referring to a case <b>where he cut</b> the gullet <b>not in</b> the same <b>place</b> as the initial <b>cut</b> in the windpipe. The reason for the distinction is that if <b>one cut</b> the gullet <b>in</b> the same <b>place</b> as the initial <b>cut</b> in the windpipe, it is an animal that <b>was rendered unfit during its slaughter</b> and it assumes the status of an unslaughtered carcass. By contrast, if he cut the gullet <b>not in</b> the same <b>place</b> as the initial <b>cut</b> in the windpipe it is <b>like</b> a case where <b>another matter caused</b> the animal <b>to become unfit.</b> Therefore, cutting the gullet renders it a <i>tereifa</i> and prevents it from imparting ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish say this,</b> that slaughter can be effective to prevent impurity after the windpipe was severed? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish say:</b> If one <b>cut the windpipe and the lung was perforated thereafter</b> before he cut the gullet, the animal is <b>fit</b> for consumption? <b>Apparently,</b> after cutting the windpipe, the status of the lungs, whose existence is dependent upon the windpipe, <b>is like</b> that of an item <b>that is placed in a basket;</b> they are irrelevant to the determination of the animal’s status. <b>Here too,</b> when the windpipe is severed at the beginning of the slaughter the windpipe should be considered <b>like</b> an item <b>that is placed in a basket</b> in the sense that the animal is considered to have only one <i>siman</i>, the gullet, and cutting of one <i>siman</i> does not affect the animal’s status.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The apparent contradiction is <b>not difficult. There</b> (42a), where it is stated that an animal with a severed windpipe is a <i>tereifa</i>, the mishna presents the opinion of Rabbi Akiva <b>before retraction</b> of his opinion. <b>Here,</b> the mishna presents the opinion of Rabbi Akiva <b>after retraction</b> of his opinion. <b>And</b> even though Rabbi Akiva retracted his opinion, <b>a mishna does not move from its place.</b> Once this version of the mishna was learned in the study hall, it remained valuable, even though it is no longer current.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> that was cited previously. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says:</b> If one <b>cut the windpipe and the lung was perforated thereafter</b> before he cut the gullet, the animal is <b>fit</b> for consumption. <b>Rava said: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish states</b> this principle <b>only with regard to a lung, since the function of the lung is dependent upon the windpipe.</b> Once the windpipe is severed it is as though the lungs were removed from the animal. <b>But with regard to innards</b> that were perforated after the windpipe was cut but before the slaughter was completed, <b>no,</b> the animal becomes a <i>tereifa</i>, because the function of the innards is not dependent on the windpipe.
<b>Rabbi Zeira objects to</b> Rava’s distinction. <b>Since</b> when <b>signs of being a <i>tereifa</i> developed</b> in the animal after the slaughter began, <b>you permitted</b> the animal and deemed the slaughter valid, <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if the perforation was <b>in</b> the <b>lung,</b> and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if the perforation was <b>in</b> the <b>innards?</b> In either case, the animal should not be deemed a <i>tereifa</i> if the signs developed once the slaughter began.
<b>But Rabbi Zeira retracted</b> his objection, <b>as Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma:</b> If the <b>innards were perforated between</b> the cutting of the first <b><i>siman</i> and</b> the second <b><i>siman</i> what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Does the first <i>siman</i> join</b> together <b>with the second <i>siman</i> to purify</b> the animal <b>from</b> the impurity of <b>an unslaughtered carcass or not?</b>
<b>And we say: Isn’t this</b> the <b>dilemma that Ilfa raises: If a fetus extended its foreleg</b> outside the womb while the mother was being slaughtered, <b>between</b> the cutting of the first <b><i>siman</i>,</b> the windpipe, and the second <b><i>siman</i>,</b> the gullet, thereby causing the foreleg to have the status of a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?

Daf 33a

The Gemara clarifies this dilemma: <b>Does the first <i>siman</i> join</b> together <b>with the second <i>siman</i> to purify the animal from</b> the impurity of <b>an unslaughtered carcass or not?</b> In both cases the dilemma is: Does the cutting of the first <i>siman</i>, which serves the dual purpose of being a component of permitting consumption and preventing impurity of the animal, join together with the cutting of the second <i>siman</i>, which serves only the purpose of preventing impurity, in order to constitute a single act of slaughter and thereby prevent the animal from assuming the impurity of an unslaughtered carcass? Or perhaps because the cutting of each <i>siman</i> is performed for a different purpose they do not join together?
In any event, <b>we raise the dilemma only</b> in order <b>to purify</b> the foreleg <b>from</b> the impurity of <b>an unslaughtered carcass. But with regard to eating</b> the slaughtered animal, all agree that it is <b>forbidden,</b> as even Rabbi Zeira concedes that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> and retracts his objection to the distinction that Rava proposed between the lungs and the innards.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav said to Ravina: Perhaps</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>actually did not retract</b> his opinion, as even initially he held that there is no distinction between lungs and innards. If either is perforated after one <i>siman</i> was cut, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And Rabbi Zeira stated</b> his objection to the distinction of Rava <b>in accordance with the statement of Rava, but</b> he <b>himself does not hold accordingly.</b>
The Gemara continues its analysis of the statement of Reish Lakish, who said that after the windpipe is cut, the lung is considered as though it was placed in a basket, and if it is perforated before the slaughter is completed, the animal does not become a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov said: Learn from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> that <b>one may invite Jews</b> to eat the <b>innards</b> of an animal that was slaughtered, <b>but one may not invite gentiles</b> to eat the <b>innards</b> of an animal that was slaughtered, because they are forbidden to gentiles.
<b>What is the reason?</b> For <b>Jews the matter</b> of rendering the meat of the animal fit for consumption <b>is dependent upon</b> the performance of a valid act of <b>slaughter. Once there is full-fledged slaughter</b> and both <i>simanim</i> are cut, the innards <b>are permitted to them</b> even if the animal is convulsing. But with regard to <b>gentiles, for whom stabbing is sufficient</b> and slaughter is not required, the innards are permitted only after the animal is completely dead, since <b>the matter</b> of rendering the meat of the animal fit for consumption <b>is dependent upon</b> its <b>death.</b> Therefore, if the animal is still convulsing, <b>these</b> innards, which are considered to be outside the body after the cutting of the two <i>simanim</i>, are <b>considered like a limb from a living</b> animal and it is forbidden for gentiles to eat them.
<b>Rav Pappa said: I was sitting before Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov and I sought to say to him</b> that his statement is difficult: <b>Is there anything that is permitted for a Jew but prohibited for a gentile? But I did not say</b> that <b>to him, as I said</b> to myself: <b>Didn’t he say a reason</b> for his ruling? Therefore, there is no reason to ask the question.
The Gemara notes: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov: One who seeks to eat from</b> the meat of <b>an animal before its soul departs may cut an olive-bulk of meat from the area of the slaughter,</b> the neck, <b>and salt it very well,</b> i.e., more than is normally required, <b>and rinse it very well</b> in water to remove the salt and the blood, <b>and wait until the</b> animal’s <b>soul departs, and eat it.</b> It is <b>permitted</b> for <b>both a gentile and a Jew to</b> eat <b>it.</b> Contrary to the statement of Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov, there is no distinction between Jew and gentile.
This <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the statement of <b>Rav Idi bar Avin, as Rav Idi bar Avin says</b> that <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashyan says: One who seeks to recuperate</b> from an illness should <b>cut an olive-bulk of meat from the area of slaughter,</b> i.e., the neck, <b>of an animal, and salt it very well, and rinse it very well, and wait until the</b> animal’s <b>soul departs,</b> and eat it. It is <b>permitted</b> for <b>both a gentile and a Jew to</b> eat <b>it.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slaughters a domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, or a bird, and blood did not emerge from them</b> during the slaughter, all of these are <b>permitted</b> for consumption <b>and</b> do not require the ritual washing of the hands as <b>they may be eaten with ritually impure [<i>mesoavot</i>] hands, because they were not rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity through contact <b>with blood,</b> which is one of the seven liquids that render food susceptible to impurity. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: They were rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>by means of</b> the <b>slaughter</b> itself.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The <b>reason</b> that they may be eaten with ritually impure hands is <b>that blood did not emerge from</b> the animals or birds during the slaughter; <b>but</b> if <b>blood emerged from them</b> during slaughter, <b>they</b> may <b>not be eaten with ritually impure hands.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> not? Ordinary <b>hands are</b> impure with <b>second-degree</b> ritual impurity <b>and</b> an item of <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>cannot impart third-degree</b> impurity to <b>non-sacred</b> items with which it comes into contact.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>From where</b> is it ascertained <b>that we are dealing</b> in the mishna <b>with non-sacred</b> food, and not with the slaughter of an offering? That is clear, <b>as</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> in the list of those slaughtered: <b>An undomesticated animal. As, if</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring to the slaughter of <b>sacrificial</b> animals and birds, <b>is there</b> any <b>undomesticated animal</b> included <b>in</b> the framework of <b>sacrificial</b> animals? <b>And furthermore, if</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring <b>to sacrificial</b> animals, <b>when no blood emerges from them are</b> the offerings <b>valid?</b> The offering <b>itself requires blood,</b> as it is only through the presenting of the blood upon the altar that the offering is accepted.
<b>And furthermore, if</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring to <b>sacrificial</b> animals, <b>when blood emerges from them, does it render</b> them <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the blood of sacrificial</b> animals <b>does not render</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated:</b> “You shall not eat it; <b>you shall pour it upon the earth like water”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:24). <b>Blood</b> of a non-sacred animal, <b>which is poured like water</b> when it is slaughtered, <b>renders</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. By contrast, blood of a sacrificial animal, <b>which is not poured like water</b> but is presented on the altar, <b>does not render</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity.
<b>And furthermore, if</b> the <i>tanna</i> is referring to <b>sacrificial</b> animals, <b>when blood does not emerge from them</b> are they <b>not</b> nevertheless rendered <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? <b>Let them be</b> rendered <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>by means of regard for sanctity, as we maintain</b> that <b>regard for sanctity renders</b> food <b>suceptible</b> to ritual impurity even in the absence of contact with any of the seven liquids.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: Here we are dealing with non-sacred</b> food <b>that one purchased</b> in Jerusalem <b>with</b> second-<b>tithe money,</b> which assumes the status of the second-tithe produce. This produce, in turn, assumes third-degree impurity through contact with hands that have second-degree impurity. <b>And</b> this mishna is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Para</i> 11:5):

Daf 33b

With regard to <b>anything that by rabbinic law requires entry</b> into <b>water,</b> i.e., either immersion or ritual washing of the hands, although it is pure by Torah law, it is accorded second-degree impurity. Therefore, such an item <b>renders sacrificial</b> food <b>impure,</b> meaning that the sacrificial food becomes impure and transmits impurity to other sacrificial food, <b>and disqualifies <i>teruma</i>,</b> meaning that it renders the <i>teruma</i> itself impure, but not to the extent that the <i>teruma</i> can render other <i>teruma</i> impure. <b>And</b> it <b>is permitted for non-sacred</b> food <b>and for</b> second-<b>tithe</b> produce to come in contact with such an item, and no impurity is thereby transmitted. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis prohibit</b> items that require entry into water from coming in contact <b>with</b> second-<b>tithe</b> produce, as they hold that the produce is thereby rendered impure. According to the Rabbis, the status of second-tithe produce is more stringent than that of non-sacred food, and second-tithe produce assumes third-degree impurity upon contact with an item of second-degree impurity, which is in accordance with the opinion of the mishna.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi objects to</b> this interpretation of that mishna. <b>From where</b> is it clear that it is contact that the Rabbis prohibit? <b>Perhaps the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Meir only with regard to</b> a person with second-degree impurity <b>partaking of</b> second-<b>tithe</b> produce. <b>But with regard to contact</b> of an individual with second-degree impurity with second-<b>tithe</b> produce <b>or</b> his <b>eating non-sacred</b> food, <b>they do not disagree.</b>
<b>And this</b> case in the mishna <b>is</b> a case involving <b>contact</b> with the flesh of the slaughtered animal, <b>from</b> the fact <b>that it teaches: They may be eaten with ritually impure hands,</b> in the passive form, and not: One may eat them with impure hands. <b>Are we not dealing</b> with a case where <b>another</b> with impure hands <b>fed him,</b> but the one eating it was ritually pure and did not touch it? Therefore, the case in the mishna here, which indicates that it is forbidden for one with impure hands to touch the flesh if it has come in contact with the blood, cannot be referring to an animal purchased in Jerusalem with second-tithe money. The reason is that in that case, the Rabbis concede that contact with second-tithe produce, even produce rendered susceptible to ritual impurity by the blood, is permitted for one whose hands are impure with second-degree ritual impurity.
<b>Rather Rav Pappa said: Here,</b> in the mishna, <b>we are dealing with hands</b> that are impure with <b>first-degree</b> ritual impurity, which render even non-sacred food impure. <b>And</b> the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In those cases where <b>hands</b> have <b>first-degree</b> impurity, it is <b>not</b> that they render <b>non-sacred</b> food impure; rather, it means that they impart to <i>teruma</i> and sacrificial food second-degree impurity rather than third-degree impurity. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Meir:</b> In those cases where <b>hands</b> have <b>first-degree</b> impurity, it means that they render <b>non-sacred</b> food impure. <b>And</b> in those cases where hands have <b>second-degree</b> impurity it means that they invalidate <b><i>teruma</i></b> and impart to it third-degree impurity.
The Gemara asks: Did Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar say that in those cases where hands have <b>first-degree</b> impurity, with regard <b>to non-sacred</b> food, <b>yes,</b> they render it impure, but with regard <b>to <i>teruma</i>,</b> hands do <b>not</b> render it impure? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is what Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar <b>is saying:</b> In those cases where hands have <b>first-degree</b> impurity, it means that they render <b>even non-sacred</b> food impure, and all the more so they render <i>teruma</i> impure. But in those cases where hands have <b>second-degree</b> impurity, it means that with regard <b>to <i>teruma</i>, yes, the hands</b> invalidate <b><i>teruma</i></b> and impart third-degree impurity, but with regard <b>to non-sacred</b> food, hands do <b>not</b> render it impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>And are there</b> cases where <b>hands</b> assume <b>first-degree</b> impurity? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, as it is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Yadayim</i> 3:1): If <b>one inserts his hands into a leprous house</b> (see Leviticus 14:33–53) <b>his hands</b> assume <b>first-degree</b> impurity as though his entire body entered the house; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. And the Rabbis say: His hands</b> assume <b>second-degree</b> impurity.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Everyone</b> agrees <b>that</b> in principle, <b>partial entry</b> into a leprous house <b>is not characterized</b> as <b>entry</b> in terms of rendering one who enters impure. Therefore, one who inserted his hands into the house is not impure by Torah law. <b>And here,</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> a rabbinic <b>decree</b> that renders his hands impure that <b>they disagree:</b> The Sages issued a decree that if one inserted his hands into a leprous house, <b>his hands</b> are impure <b>due to</b> the impurity by Torah law that one assumes when he enters the house with his entire <b>body.</b> The objective of the decree is to prevent him from entering the leprous house.
One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds</b> that when <b>the Sages</b> issued the decree they determined that the status of <b>his hands</b> inserted into the house is <b>like</b> the status of <b>his body</b> that enters the house, first-degree impurity. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>the Sages rendered</b> the status of <b>hands</b> inserted into the house <b>like</b> the status of <b>hands in general,</b> with regard to which they issued a decree of second-degree impurity, even if they had been washed.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> why did Rav Pappa interpret the mishna in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar? <b>Let</b> Rav Pappa <b>interpret</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says:</b> If one inserts his hands into a leprous house, <b>his hands</b> assume <b>first-degree</b> impurity. The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps when Rabbi Akiva says</b> that one’s hands assume first-degree impurity, <b>that statement</b> applies only <b>in</b> cases of <b><i>teruma</i> and sacrificial</b> food, <b>which are stringent. But</b> with regard <b>to non-sacred</b> food, perhaps hands <b>are</b> impure only with <b>second-degree</b> impurity.
The Gemara objects: <b>And let</b> hands <b>also be</b> impure only with <b>second-degree</b> impurity and the mishna could still be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Akiva. <b>As we heard that Rabbi Akiva says:</b> An item of <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>imparts third-degree</b> impurity to <b>non-sacred</b> items.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Sota</i> 27b): <b>On that day,</b> when Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya was appointed <i>Nasi</i> in Yavne, <b>Rabbi Akiva taught: “And every earthenware vessel</b> into which any of them falls, whatever is in <b>it shall be impure,</b> and you shall break it” (Leviticus 11:33). With regard to the item rendered impure in the vessel, <b>it is not stated:</b> It <b>is impure [<i>tameh</i>]; rather,</b> the term <b>“it shall be impure [<i>yitma</i>]”</b> is stated, indicating that the item has the capacity <b>to transmit impurity to other</b> items. <b>This</b> verse <b>teaches about a loaf</b> with <b>second-degree</b> impurity that had been rendered impure in the airspace of an earthenware vessel in which there was a creeping animal, <b>that</b> through contact <b>it renders non-sacred</b> food impure with <b>third-degree</b> ritual impurity.
The Gemara explains: <b>Perhaps this statement,</b> that non-sacred food becomes impure with third-degree ritual impurity, applies only <b>with regard to impurity by Torah law,</b> e.g., a creeping animal; <b>but with regard to</b> impurity by <b>rabbinic law,</b> e.g., impurity of hands, that is <b>not</b> the <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said</b> that <b>Rabbi Hoshaya said</b> a third explanation of the mishna: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case of <b>non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food. <b>And</b> the mishna is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, as it is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 2:2): <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: One who eats food</b> with <b>first-degree</b> ritual impurity assumes <b>first-degree</b> impurity. One who eats food with <b>second-degree</b> ritual impurity assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity. One who eats food with <b>third-degree</b> impurity assumes <b>third-degree</b> impurity.
The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: One who eats food</b> with <b>first-degree or second-degree</b> impurity assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity. One with second-degree impurity who comes into contact with <i>teruma</i> disqualifies it, but does not render it impure. One who eats food with <b>third-degree</b> impurity assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis sacrificial</b> food, i.e., his contact with sacrificial food renders it impure with the capacity to transmit impurity to other sacrificial food, <b>but</b> does <b>not</b> assume <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis <i>teruma</i>,</b> and his contact with <i>teruma</i> does not disqualify it.
Eating an item that has third-degree impurity is feasible only in the case of non-sacred food, as partaking of impure <i>teruma</i> or sacrificial food is prohibited. Generic non-sacred food cannot contract third-degree impurity at all. Therefore, the case of one who eats food that has third-degree impurity is referring specifically <b>to non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i>.</b>
The Gemara infers from Rabbi Yehoshua’s statement that if one prepares items as if their level of purity were <b>on the</b> level of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i>,</b> then <b>yes,</b> they have the status like <i>teruma</i>, but if one prepares items as if their level of purity were <b>on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food, they do <b>not</b> have the status like sacrificial food, and such items would not contract third-degree impurity. This indicates that Rabbi Yehoshua <b>holds</b> that <b>non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food <b>do not</b> assume <b>third-degree</b> impurity.
The Gemara objects: <b>Let us interpret</b> the mishna

Daf 34a

<b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i> and</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>It</b> should <b>not enter your mind</b> that the mishna is referring to a case of the level of purity of <i>teruma</i>, <b>as</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> a case of the slaughter of animals and birds and consumption of their <b>meat.</b> And <b>if</b> the mishna is taught <b>with regard to</b> non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of <b><i>teruma</i>, is there meat</b> eaten with the level of purity of <i>teruma</i>? The practice of preparing non-sacred food items on the level of purity of <i>teruma</i> is done only so that one will not treat actual <i>teruma</i> in the correct manner, and <i>teruma</i> is separated only from produce that grows in the ground.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what</b> is the case in the mishna? Is it a case of non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of <b>sacrificial</b> food? <b>Is there an undomesticated animal</b> that can be sacrificed as an offering and its meat is <b>sacrificial</b> food? The Gemara answers: Although undomesticated animals cannot be sacrificed as an offering, there are those who would undertake to eat their meat only when prepared on the level of purity of sacrificial food because <b>meat</b> of an undomesticated animal is sometimes <b>interchanged with meat</b> of a domesticated animal. No one would undertake to eat meat only when prepared on the level of purity of <i>teruma</i>, because <b>meat</b> would <b>not</b> be <b>interchanged with produce.</b>
<b>Ulla said:</b> My <b>colleagues say</b> that the mishna is referring to the case <b>of non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food, <b>and</b> the mishna is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who says: Non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of <i>teruma</i> assume third-degree impurity, but non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of sacrificial food do not assume third-degree impurity.
Ulla continues: <b>And I say</b> that the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> and when he said that non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of <i>teruma</i> assume third-degree impurity, he <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary. It is not necessary</b> to say that in the case of <b>non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food, <b>which is stringent, that they have</b> the capacity of assuming <b>third-degree</b> impurity. <b>Rather, even non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i> also have</b> the capacity of assuming <b>third-degree</b> impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who are the colleagues</b> to whom Ulla referred? <b>It is Rabba bar bar Ḥana, as Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: What did Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua reply to each other?</b> The differences between their opinions are twofold. First, Rabbi Eliezer holds that one who eats food with first-degree impurity assumes first-degree impurity, while according to Rabbi Yehoshua he assumes second-degree impurity. Second, Rabbi Eliezer holds that one who eats food with third-degree impurity assumes third-degree impurity, while according to Rabbi Yehoshua he assumes second-degree impurity vis-à-vis sacrificial food but not vis-à-vis <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to Rabbi Yehoshua:</b> The basis for my opinion that one assumes the level of impurity of that which he ate is that <b>we found</b> a case where the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the one who eats</b> a food item <b>is more stringent than</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the food</b> itself. <b>As, the carcass of a kosher bird</b> on <b>the outside,</b> i.e., when one comes into contact with it, <b>does not impart ritual impurity, while</b> one who <b>eats</b> the carcass of the kosher bird <b>renders</b> his <b>garments impure</b> when the food is <b>in</b> his <b>throat. And we,</b> in light of that, <b>how will we not deem one who eats</b> the impure item to be on a level of impurity at least <b>like</b> that of <b>the food</b> that he ate?
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua</b> responded that <b>we do not derive</b> other cases <b>from the</b> case of the <b>carcass of a kosher bird, because it is a novel</b> ruling that cannot serve as a paradigm. <b>Rather, we found that</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>food is more stringent than</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the one who eats</b> it, <b>as food</b> becomes impure if its measure is <b>that</b> of <b>an egg-bulk, and</b> one who <b>eats</b> impure food does not become impure <b>until he eats half of a half-loaf. And we,</b> in light of that, <b>how will we deem one who eats</b> the impure item to be on a level of impurity <b>like</b> that of <b>the food</b> that he ate?
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer</b> responded: <b>We do not derive</b> the relative stringency of ritual <b>impurity from</b> the relative size of halakhic <b>measures,</b> as measures are not indicative of stringency or leniency. <b>And furthermore, according to your statement, that</b> which <b>you say with regard to one who eats food</b> with <b>first-degree</b> ritual impurity, that he assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity, what <b>you say</b> is <b>well.</b> But <b>that</b> which <b>you say</b> with regard to one who eats food with <b>second-degree</b> impurity, that he assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity, <b>why</b> is that the case? It contradicts your reasoning.
Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to</b> Rabbi Eliezer: <b>We found that</b> food with <b>second</b>-<b>degree</b> impurity <b>renders</b> other food impure with <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>by means of liquids.</b> Liquids that come into contact with food with second-degree impurity render other food with which they come into contact impure with second-degree impurity.
Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to him: But aren’t</b> those <b>liquids also</b> impure with <b>first-degree</b> ritual impurity through contact with an item impure with second-degree impurity? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Para</i> 8:7): <b>Any</b> item with second-degree ritual impurity that <b>disqualifies <i>teruma</i> renders liquids impure</b> with <b>first-degree</b> ritual impurity. These liquids assume a degree of impurity greater than that of the item that rendered them impure. This rabbinic decree applies to all people and items with second-degree impurity <b>except</b> for <b>one</b> who was ritually impure <b>who immersed that day</b> and is waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed. Liquids with which he comes into contact follow the standard course of transmitted impurity and assume third-degree impurity, one level below his own impurity.
Rabbi Eliezer questioned the next segment in the ruling of Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>And furthermore,</b> that which you say with regard to one who eats food with <b>third-degree</b> impurity, that he assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity vis-à-vis sacrificial food, <b>why</b> is that the <i>halakha</i>? It contradicts your reasoning.
Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to</b> Rabbi Eliezer: <b>I too stated</b> that one who eats food with third-degree impurity assumes second-degree impurity vis-à-vis sacrificial food <b>only with regard to</b> one who eats non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of <b><i>teruma</i>, as its</b> state of <b>purity</b>

Daf 34b

<b>is impurity vis-à-vis sacrificial</b> food. The Sages issued a decree that even one who is vigilant to partake of his <i>teruma</i> in a state of ritual purity is considered impure vis-à-vis one partaking of sacrificial food. Therefore, one who ate a food item that was prepared on the level of purity of <i>teruma</i> that had become impure with third-degree impurity assumes second-degree impurity, and he renders sacrificial food impure.
<b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai says:</b> With regard to <b>one who eats non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food, and these items had become impure with <b>third-degree</b> impurity, <b>his body becomes</b> impure with <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis sacrificial</b> food. He renders sacrificial food with which he comes into contact impure with third-degree impurity, and that food in turn disqualifies sacrificial food with which it comes into contact.
<b>Rabbi Zeira raised an objection to</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Asi</b> from the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua: One who eats food with <b>third-degree</b> impurity assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis sacrificial</b> food <b>but</b> does <b>not</b> assume <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis <i>teruma</i>.</b> This is stated <b>in</b> the case of <b>non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>Yes,</b> one is able to prepare items <b>on the</b> level of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i>,</b> but one is <b>not</b> able to prepare items <b>on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food, as in the latter case the non-sacred food does not become impure at all.
Rabbi Asi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: That inference is incorrect, as Rabbi Yehoshua <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary.</b> It is not necessary to say that in the case of non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of sacrificial food, which is stringent, they have the capacity of assuming third-degree impurity. Rabbi Yehoshua teaches that non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of <i>teruma</i> also have the capacity of assuming third-degree impurity.
The Gemara objects: <b>But didn’t</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>say</b> to Rabbi Eliezer according to the explanation that Rabba bar bar Ḥana said that Rabbi Yoḥanan said: <b>I too stated</b> this <b>only with regard to</b> non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> indicating that he was not referring to non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of sacrificial food. The Gemara explains: Rabba bar bar Ḥana and Rabbi Asi <b>are <i>amora’im</i>, and</b> disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> and they disagree about whether the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua was stated specifically with regard to non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of <i>teruma</i>, or whether it includes even those prepared on the level of purity of sacrificial food.
§ <b>Ulla says: One who eats non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i></b> and that are impure with <b>third-degree</b> impurity, <b>his body is disqualified from</b> the right <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Ulla <b>teaching us? We</b> already <b>learn</b> in the mishna cited earlier (33b) from tractate <i>Teharot</i>: One who eats food with <b>third-degree</b> impurity assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis sacrificial</b> food, <b>but</b> does <b>not</b> assume <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis <i>teruma</i>.</b> This is stated <b>in</b> the case of <b>non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara infers: It is <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>that he does not assume, but third-degree</b> impurity <b>he assumes,</b> and he is therefore disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara answers: It was necessary for Ulla to teach this <i>halakha</i>, <b>as if</b> it was learned <b>from that</b> mishna, <b>I would say</b> that vis-à-vis <i>teruma</i> <b>he assumes neither second-degree nor third-degree</b> impurity, as there is no reason to deem the status of one who eats like that of the food that he ate. <b>And</b> perhaps it was only <b>since</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said</b> that he assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis sacrificial</b> food that he <b>also said</b> that he does <b>not</b> assume <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis <i>teruma</i>.</b> Therefore, Ulla <b>teaches us</b> that he assumes third-degree impurity and is disqualified from partaking of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rav Hamnuna raised an objection to</b> the statement of <b>Ulla</b> from a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 2:3): <b>Non-sacred</b> food that is impure with <b>first-degree</b> impurity is <b>impure and renders</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>impure</b> in the sense that this <i>teruma</i> disqualifies other <i>teruma</i> with which it comes into contact. Non-sacred food that is impure with <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>disqualifies</b> <i>teruma</i>, <b>but</b> it does <b>not</b> render <i>teruma</i> <b>impure,</b> meaning that it renders the <i>teruma</i> itself impure, but not to the extent that the <i>teruma</i> can render other <i>teruma</i> impure. <b>And</b> food that is impure with <b>third-degree</b> impurity may be <b>eaten</b> by a priest <b>in a stew</b> that is <b>a mixture</b> containing spices of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And if you say</b> that by partaking of food that is impure with third-degree impurity <b>his body is disqualified from</b> the right <b>to partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> do <b>we feed him a matter that invalidates his body</b> from the right to partake of <i>teruma</i>? According to this, when eating the stew that contains food that is impure with third-degree impurity, he is disqualified from partaking of the spices of <i>teruma</i> that the mishna permits him to add to the stew. Ulla <b>said to him: Leave</b> the matter of <b>stew</b> that is <b>a mixture</b> containing spices of <i>teruma</i>,

Daf 35a

<b>as there is not an olive-bulk</b> of <i>teruma</i> in the amount of stew that he eats <b>in</b> the time it takes <b>to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread. Therefore, one need not treat the mixture with the level of purity required of <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rabbi Yonatan says</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> For <b>one who partakes of actual <i>teruma</i> that</b> is impure with <b>third-degree</b> impurity, it is <b>prohibited to partake</b> of other <i>teruma</i>, <b>but</b> it is <b>permitted to come into contact</b> with <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara notes that the statement <b>of Ulla was necessary and</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yonatan was necessary. As, if</b> the <i>halakha</i> were learned exclusively <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Ulla, I would say: This statement</b> applies <b>with regard to non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of <i>teruma</i>, but</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> itself perhaps <b>contact is also prohibited.</b> Therefore, the statement <b>of Rabbi Yonatan was necessary. And if</b> the <i>halakha</i> were learned exclusively <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yonatan, I would say: This statement</b> applies with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>, but</b> with regard to <b>non-sacred</b> food that was prepared with purity of <i>teruma</i>, perhaps <b>eating</b> it is <b>also permitted.</b> Therefore, both statements <b>are necessary.</b>
§ <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta was sitting before Rav Naḥman, and he was sitting and saying:</b> With regard to <b>one who eats non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food, and these items had become impure with <b>third-degree</b> impurity, he <b>is ritually pure</b> in terms of the right <b>to partake of sacrificial</b> food, <b>as you have nothing that confers fourth-degree</b> impurity <b>in sacrificial</b> food <b>other than consecrated sacrificial</b> food <b>alone,</b> but non-sacred food prepared with the purity of sacrificial food does not.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raises an objection</b> from the mishna cited earlier (33b): One who eats food with <b>third-degree</b> impurity assumes <b>second</b>-<b>degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis sacrificial</b> food, <b>and</b> he does <b>not</b> assume <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>vis-à-vis <i>teruma</i>.</b> Eating an item with third-degree impurity is feasible only in the case of non-sacred items, as partaking of impure <i>teruma</i> is prohibited. It is only possible <b>in</b> the case of <b>non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared</b> as if their level of purity were <b>on the</b> level of the <b>purity of <i>teruma</i>.</b> According to the statement of Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta, <b>why</b> does this food assume second-degree impurity? <b>It is not sacrificial</b> food, which is <b>sanctified.</b>
Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta <b>said to him: Leave <i>teruma</i></b> alone; <b>its</b> state of <b>purity is impurity vis-à-vis sacrificial</b> food. Therefore, non-sacred food that was prepared with the purity of <i>teruma</i> renders sacrificial food impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do you say</b> that the purity of <i>teruma</i> is impurity vis-à-vis sacrificial food? It is from a mishna (<i>Ḥagiga</i> 18b), <b>as we learned:</b> The halakhic status of <b>the garments of an <i>am ha’aretz</i>,</b> who does not scrupulously observe the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity, is like that of items rendered impure by <b>treading,</b> e.g., items designated for sitting or lying upon which a <i>zav</i> or a menstruating woman sits or lies, which are rendered a primary source of ritual impurity <b>for individuals who scrupulously observe</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>ritual purity [<i>perushin</i>]</b> and eat their non-sacred food in a state of purity. In other words, it is considered a primary level of impurity for them. The halakhic status of <b>the garments of <i>perushin</i></b> is like that of items rendered impure by <b>treading for</b> priests <b>who partake of <i>teruma</i>.</b> In addition, the halakhic status of <b>the garments of</b> priests <b>who partake of <i>teruma</i></b> is like that of items rendered impure by <b>treading for</b> those who eat <b>sacrificial</b> food.
<b>Rava said: Are you saying</b> that one can cite proof from the <i>halakha</i> of items rendered impure by <b>treading</b> that the state of purity of <i>teruma</i> is impurity vis-à-vis sacrificial food? No proof may be cited from there, as the decree that the halakhic status of the garments of priests who partake of <i>teruma</i> is like that of items rendered impure by <b>treading</b> for those who eat sacrificial food <b>is different,</b>

Daf 35b

as with regard to garments there is concern <b>lest his wife sit upon them</b> when she is impure with the impurity of <b>a menstruating woman. But with regard to produce, we do not say</b> that if it was prepared with the purity of <i>teruma</i> it renders sacrificial food impure, <b>and Rabbi Yitzḥak states</b> his <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to produce as well.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya of Difti raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Yitzḥak: <b>And do we say with regard to produce</b> that if it was prepared with the purity of <i>teruma</i> it renders sacrificial food impure? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥagiga</i> 24b): It is not permitted for a priest to accept <i>teruma</i> wine from an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, but <b>if</b> an <i>am ha’aretz</i> <b>says</b> to the priest: <b>I separated</b> and placed <b>into</b> this barrel of <i>teruma</i> wine <b>a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> <b>of sacrificial</b> wine, <b>he is deemed credible? And</b> this indicates that <b><i>teruma</i> does not render the sacrificial</b> food <b>impure. And if you say</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i> that <b>its</b> state of <b>purity is impurity vis-à-vis sacrificial</b> food, <b>let the <i>teruma</i> render</b> the <b>sacrificial</b> food <b>impure.</b>
Rabbi Yitzḥak <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya of Difti: <b>Are you are saying</b> that there is an objection to my opinion based on the case of <b>impurity in</b> a case of food items, the <i>teruma</i> wine and the sacrificial wine, that are <b>attached</b> in one barrel? <b>Impurity in</b> a case of food items that are <b>attached is different, as, since</b> the <i>am ha’aretz</i> <b>is deemed credible with regard to the sacrificial</b> food, <b>he is deemed credible with regard to the <i>teruma</i> as well.</b>
<b>Rav Huna bar Natan raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> to the opinion of Rabbi Yitzḥak with regard to rendering sacrificial food impure with fourth-degree ritual impurity: <b>Non-sacred</b> food that is impure with <b>second-degree</b> impurity <b>renders impure</b> through contact <b>a non-sacred liquid,</b> which assumes first-degree impurity, <b>and disqualifies <i>teruma</i> foods,</b> in the sense that those foods are impure but do not transmit impurity to other food. <b>And</b> non-sacred food that is impure with <b>third-degree</b> impurity <b>renders impure</b> through contact <b>a sacrificial liquid and disqualifies sacrificial foods, in</b> the case of <b>non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food. This contradicts the opinion of Rabbi Yitzḥak, who said that there is nothing that confers fourth-degree impurity in sacrificial food other than consecrated sacrificial food alone, but not non-sacred food prepared with the purity of sacrificial food.
The Gemara answers that this matter <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The halakhic status of <b>non-sacred</b> food items <b>that were prepared on the</b> level of <b>purity of sacrificial</b> food <b>is like</b> that of <b>non-sacred</b> foods, and they are incapable of assuming third-degree impurity.
<b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says:</b> The halakhic status of non-sacred food items that were prepared on the level of purity of sacrificial food <b>is like</b> that of <b><i>teruma</i>.</b> Accordingly, a primary source of ritual impurity is able <b>to render two</b> items <b>impure:</b> The food item with which it comes into contact assumes first-degree impurity, and the food item with which that came into contact assumes second-degree impurity. <b>And</b> that item is able <b>to disqualify one</b> further item, which assumes third-degree impurity but will not render sacrificial food impure with fourth-degree impurity. According to both opinions in this <i>baraita</i>, non-sacred food prepared with the purity of sacrificial food does not disqualify sacrificial food. According to the mishna in <i>Teharot</i>, it does disqualify sacrificial food.
§ The mishna states (33a): In the case of one who slaughters a domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, or a bird, and blood did not emerge from them, <b>Rabbi Shimon says: They were rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>by means of</b> the <b>slaughter</b> itself. <b>Rav Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon would say:</b> It is <b>its slaughter</b> that <b>renders it susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, <b>and not</b> the <b>blood</b> that emerges during the slaughter.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the mishna <b>supports</b> the opinion of Rav Asi. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: They were rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>by means of</b> the <b>slaughter</b> itself. The Gemara asks: <b>What, is it not</b> that Rabbi Shimon is saying: <b>By means of</b> the <b>slaughter and not by means of</b> the <b>blood</b> from the slaughter?
