The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> perhaps Rabbi Shimon is saying: The animal can be rendered susceptible to ritual impurity by means of blood and <b>also by means of slaughter.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> is support of Rav Asi’s statement. <b>Rabbi Shimon said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>Is it blood that renders</b> the animal <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? <b>But isn’t it slaughter</b> that <b>renders</b> it <b>susceptible?</b> This indicates that Rabbi Shimon holds that it is specifically the slaughter and not the blood that renders the flesh susceptible to impurity. The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>This</b> is what Rabbi Shimon <b>is saying to</b> the Rabbis: <b>Is it blood alone that renders</b> the animal <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? <b>Slaughter too renders</b> it <b>susceptible.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i> contrary to Rav Asi’s statement. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Blood of the</b> animal that is <b>dead</b> of natural causes <b>does not render</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. <b>What, is it not</b> that one may infer that <b>blood of slaughter renders</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>No,</b> infer that <b>blood of</b> animals that <b>are killed renders</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>blood of slaughter, what</b> then is the <i>halakha</i>; that <b>it does not render</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity?
If so, <b>let</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>teach us</b> that <b>blood of slaughter</b> does not render the animal susceptible to ritual impurity, <b>and</b> we will conclude that <b>all the more so</b> that is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>blood of the</b> animal that is <b>dead</b> as a result of natural causes. The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary for</b> Rabbi Shimon to teach the <i>halakha</i> of <b>blood of the</b> animal that is <b>dead</b> as a result of natural causes, as it could <b>enter your mind to say: What</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if <b>one killed</b> the animal <b>himself,</b> and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if the animal was <b>killed</b> by <b>the angel of death?</b> In both cases the blood should render the animal susceptible to ritual impurity. Therefore, Rabbi Shimon <b>teaches us</b> that unlike blood of an animal that was killed, blood of an animal that is dead as a result of natural causes does not render food items susceptible to ritual impurity, and no inference may be drawn with regard to blood of slaughter.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another <i>baraita</i> contrary to Rav Asi’s statement. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Blood of</b> the <b>wound</b> of an animal <b>does not render</b> other items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. <b>What, is it not</b> that one may infer that <b>blood of slaughter renders</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>No,</b> infer that <b>blood of</b> animals that <b>are killed renders</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>blood of slaughter, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>; that <b>it does not render</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity?
If so, <b>let</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>teach us</b> that <b>blood of slaughter</b> does not render the animal susceptible to ritual impurity, <b>and</b> we will conclude that <b>all the more so</b> that is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>blood of its wound.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary for</b> Rabbi Shimon to teach <b>blood of its wound,</b> as it could <b>enter your mind to say: What</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if <b>one killed</b> the <b>entire</b> animal, and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if <b>one killed half</b> of the animal, i.e., wounded it? In both cases the blood should render the animal susceptible to ritual impurity. Therefore, Rabbi Shimon teaches that unlike the blood of an animal that was killed, the blood from an animal’s wound does not render food items susceptible to ritual impurity, and no inference may be drawn with regard to blood of slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> with regard to <b>blood of</b> animals that <b>are killed that they render</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? It is due to the fact <b>that it is written:</b> “Behold, they are a people that rises up as a lioness, and as a lion he lifts himself up; he shall not lie down until he eats of the prey <b>and drinks blood of carcasses”</b> (Numbers 23:24). The fact that the blood of a carcass, which in the context of the verse is referring to an animal that was killed, is mentioned in the context of drinking, indicates that it is a liquid that renders food items susceptible to ritual impurity.
With regard to <b>blood of slaughter it is also written:</b> “Only, you shall not eat the blood; <b>you shall pour it upon the earth as water”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:16). The parallel to water ostensibly indicates that the blood of slaughter should also render food items susceptible to ritual impurity. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse is not written with regard to susceptibility to impurity. The purpose for <b>which</b> it <b>comes</b> is <b>to permit benefit</b> from the <b>blood of disqualified consecrated</b> animals.

Daf 36a

It could <b>enter your mind to say: Since</b> benefit from disqualified consecrated animals <b>is forbidden with regard to</b> their <b>fleece and labor,</b> perhaps benefit from <b>their blood</b> is also forbidden, and <b>let</b> it <b>require burial.</b> Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that benefit from their blood is permitted.
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> that the verse: <b>“And drinks the blood of carcasses,”</b> from which it is derived that the blood of an animal that was killed renders food items susceptible to ritual impurity, serves to <b>exclude blood</b> that emerges in <b>a surge</b> due to arterial pressure at the moment of slaughter while the animal is still alive <b>that does not render seeds susceptible to</b> ritual impurity.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to one who <b>slaughters</b> an animal <b>and splashed blood</b> of the slaughter <b>on a gourd</b> of <i>teruma</i>, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The gourd is <b>rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya says:</b> If the gourd came into contact with a source of impurity, <b>one places</b> the matter <b>in abeyance,</b> as there is uncertainty whether the blood rendered it susceptible to impurity.
<b>Rabbi Oshaya said: Since Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that the gourd is <b>rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>and Rabbi Ḥiyya says</b> that <b>one places</b> the matter <b>in abeyance, on whom shall we rely? Come and let us rely on the statement of Rabbi Shimon, as Rabbi Shimon would say:</b> It is <b>slaughter</b> that <b>renders</b> the animal <b>susceptible, and not blood.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> in explanation: <b>Everyone,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabbi Ḥiyya, <b>agrees</b> that <b>where there is blood</b> on the gourd throughout the slaughter continuously <b>from beginning to end, everyone,</b> both Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, who says: Slaughter is defined only as the conclusion of its performance, and Rabbi Yoḥanan, who says: Slaughter is defined from the beginning to the end of its performance, <b>agrees that</b> the blood <b>renders</b> the gourd <b>susceptible</b> to impurity, in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, who disagree with Rabbi Shimon. <b>When they disagree</b> is in a case <b>where the blood is wiped</b> off the gourd <b>between</b> the cutting of one <b><i>siman</i> and</b> the other <b><i>siman</i>. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>slaughter is</b> defined <b>from</b> the <b>beginning to</b> the <b>end</b> of its performance, <b>and this blood</b> that splashed on the gourd <b>is blood of slaughter.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya holds</b> that <b>slaughter is</b> defined <b>only</b> as <b>the conclusion</b> of its performance, <b>and this is blood of a wound,</b> which does not render food items susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the ruling of Rabbi Ḥiyya that <b>one places</b> the matter <b>in abeyance?</b> It means that <b>one places</b> the matter <b>in abeyance until</b> the <b>conclusion of</b> the <b>slaughter. If there is blood</b> remaining on the gourd <b>at the conclusion of the slaughter</b> the blood <b>renders</b> the gourd <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, <b>and if not,</b> the blood <b>does not render</b> the gourd <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the statement of Rabbi Oshaya: <b>Come and let us rely on the statement of Rabbi Shimon?</b> According <b>to Rabbi Shimon</b> the blood of slaughter <b>does not render</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, while according <b>to Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> the blood of slaughter <b>renders</b> the gourd <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity.
The Gemara answers that in a case <b>where</b> the blood <b>is wiped</b> off the gourd prior to the conclusion of slaughter, <b>in any event,</b> the opinions of Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>correspond to each other:</b> One <b>Sage</b> holds that the blood of slaughter <b>does not render</b> the gourd <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>and</b> the other <b>Sage</b> holds that the blood of slaughter <b>does not render</b> the gourd <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. The result is that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that the blood of slaughter renders the gourd susceptible to ritual impurity, <b>is one</b> Sage stating an individual opinion, <b>and the statement of one</b> Sage <b>has no</b> standing <b>in a place</b> where it is disputed by <b>two</b> Sages.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that the term: <b>One places</b> the matter <b>in abeyance, indicates</b> that it remains in abeyance <b>forever.</b> It is a fundamental halakhic uncertainty for which there is no resolution. <b>And</b> in the case where the blood is <b>wiped</b> off the gourd prior to the conclusion of the slaughter, the <i>halakha</i> is unclear. This is because <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya is uncertain whether slaughter is</b> defined <b>from</b> the <b>beginning to</b> the <b>end</b> of its performance <b>or whether slaughter is</b> defined <b>only</b> as the <b>conclusion</b> of its performance. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of his ruling that <b>one places</b> the matter <b>in abeyance?</b> It means that if a source of impurity comes into contact with the gourd after the blood was wiped off the gourd, <b>one may neither eat</b> the gourd, as perhaps it is impure <i>teruma</i>, <b>nor may one burn</b> it, as perhaps it is pure.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to this explanation, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the statement of Rabbi Oshaya: <b>Come and let us rely on the statement of Rabbi Shimon?</b> According <b>to Rabbi Shimon</b> the blood of slaughter <b>does not render</b> food items <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, while according <b>to Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> there is <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to the status of the gourd. The Gemara answers that with regard <b>to the matter of burning, in any event,</b> the opinions of Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>correspond to each other:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>does not burn</b> the gourd, because it was not rendered susceptible to impurity, <b>and</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya, <b>does not burn</b> the gourd, due to the uncertainty.
The result is that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that one burns the gourd since the blood of slaughter renders the gourd susceptible to ritual impurity and contact with a source of impurity renders it impure, <b>is one</b> Sage stating an individual opinion, <b>and the statement of one</b> Sage <b>has no</b> standing <b>in a place</b> where it is disputed by <b>two</b> Sages. <b>And this</b> is what Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>is saying:</b> In a case <b>such as this, one places</b> the matter <b>in abeyance; one may neither eat</b> the gourd <b>nor burn</b> it.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to a dry <b>portion</b> of consecrated flour that was not mixed with the oil <b>of meal offerings,</b> does <b>one count</b> the descending levels of impurity characteristic of other foods that come into contact with a primary source of impurity, i.e., that food assumes <b>first-degree</b> impurity, <b>and</b> food that comes into contact with that food assumes <b>second-degree</b> impurity; <b>or</b> does one <b>not count</b> the descending levels of <b>first-degree</b> impurity <b>and second-degree</b> impurity? The Gemara elaborates: <b>When regard for sanctity is effective</b> in rendering an item susceptible to impurity, is it effective only <b>to disqualify</b> that item <b>itself, but to count</b> the descending levels of <b>first-degree and second-degree</b> impurity it is <b>not</b> effective? <b>Or perhaps</b> once it is rendered susceptible to impurity there <b>is no difference</b> whether it is rendered susceptible by means of regard for sanctity or by means of contact with liquids.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from a <i>baraita</i>. It is written: <b>“Of all food that may be eaten,</b> on which water comes, it shall be impure; and all drink that may be drunk it shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:34). From that verse it is derived: <b>Food that comes into</b> contact with <b>water is rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity and to count the descending levels of impurity, but <b>food that does not come into</b> contact with <b>water is not rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. Apparently, for the dry portion of flour that did not come into contact with a liquid but was rendered susceptible by regard for sanctity, one does not count the descending levels of impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish does not have</b> knowledge of the <i>halakha</i> that only <b>food that comes into</b> contact with <b>water</b> is susceptible to ritual impurity? The Gemara answers: <b>This is the dilemma</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish is raising:</b> Is the halakhic status of consecrated food that is subject to <b>regard for sanctity like</b> that of <b>food that comes into</b> contact with <b>water,</b> and one does not count the descending levels of impurity for items that come into contact with it, <b>or no,</b> its halakhic status is unique?
The Gemara explains that <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> who cited the verse to resolve the dilemma of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, is not merely citing a verse that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish knows. Rather, he <b>too is stating</b> his proof <b>from the extraneous</b> formulation <b>of the verses. Since it is written: “But when water is placed upon the seed,</b> and any of their carcass falls upon it, it is impure for you” (Leviticus 11:38), <b>why do I</b> need the verse: <b>“Of all food which may be eaten,</b> on which water comes, shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:34)?

Daf 36b

Is it <b>not to exclude</b> items rendered susceptible to impurity due to <b>regard for sanctity?</b> The Gemara rejects that proof: <b>No,</b> both verses teach that food becomes impure only after it is rendered susceptible to impurity by one of the seven liquids. <b>One</b> verse is referring to <b>impurity</b> imparted by a <b>corpse, and one</b> verse is referring to <b>impurity</b> imparted by the carcass of <b>a creeping animal.</b>
<b>And</b> both verses <b>are necessary, as had</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> the requirement of being rendered susceptible to impurity only with regard to <b>impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse,</b> one would have concluded that <b>it is there</b> that food <b>requires</b> being <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity by one of the seven liquids in order to become impure, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the impurity imparted by a corpse is less stringent, as a portion of a corpse the size of <b>a lentil-bulk does not render</b> people or vessels <b>impure. But</b> in the case of impurity imparted by the carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> which is more stringent, <b>as</b> the creeping animal <b>renders</b> people or vessels <b>impure</b> with a portion of it the size of <b>a lentil-bulk, say</b> that food <b>does not require</b> to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> by one of the seven liquids in order to become impure.
<b>And had</b> the Torah <b>taught us</b> the requirement of being rendered susceptible to impurity only with regard to impurity imparted by the carcass of <b>a creeping animal,</b> one would have concluded that it is there that food must be rendered susceptible to impurity, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the impurity imparted by a creeping animal is less stringent, as a creeping animal <b>does not render</b> people or vessels <b>impure</b> with <b>impurity</b> that lasts <b>seven</b> days. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a corpse, which renders</b> people or vessels <b>impure</b> with <b>impurity</b> that lasts <b>seven</b> days, <b>say</b> that food <b>does not require</b> to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> by one of the seven liquids in order to become impure from it. Therefore, <b>it is necessary</b> for the Torah to teach both verses.
<b>Rav Yosef raises an objection</b> from the mishna (33a) to Rabbi Elazar’s opinion that only with regard to food rendered susceptible by one of the seven liquids does one count the descending levels of impurity, i.e., first-degree impurity and second-degree impurity: <b>Rabbi Shimon says: They were rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>by means of</b> the <b>slaughter</b> itself. Rabbi Shimon is saying <b>they were rendered susceptible</b> in every sense, <b>and even to count</b> the descending levels of impurity, <b>first-degree</b> impurity <b>and second-degree</b> impurity.
<b>Why</b> is the animal rendered susceptible to impurity in every sense; <b>but</b> the slaughtered animal is <b>not food that comes into</b> contact with <b>water?</b> Apparently, even items that did not come into contact with water are susceptible to impurity in every sense. <b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: Rabbi Shimon holds that it is not susceptible by Torah law. Rather, the Sages <b>accorded</b> susceptibility via slaughter of the animal a status <b>like</b> that <b>of susceptibility rendered</b> by means of <b>water, by rabbinic law.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an objection to Rabbi Elazar’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who harvests</b> grapes in order to take them <b>to the winepress, Shammai says:</b> The grapes are <b>rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity by the liquid that seeps from them, and <b>Hillel says:</b> They are <b>not rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity; <b>and ultimately, Hillel was silent</b> and did not respond <b>to Shammai,</b> accepting his opinion. <b>Why</b> does that liquid render the grapes susceptible to impurity; <b>but</b> the grapes <b>are not food that comes into</b> contact with <b>water?</b> Contact with liquid renders food susceptible to impurity only if the contact was with the intent of the owner, and here, the liquid did not seep out of the grapes of one’s own volition. <b>Abaye said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: Hillel does not hold that the grapes are susceptible by Torah law; rather, the Sages <b>accorded</b> susceptibility via the liquid a status <b>like</b> that <b>of susceptibility rendered</b> by means of <b>water, by rabbinic law,</b> to count the descending levels of impurity, i.e., first-degree impurity, second-degree impurity.
<b>Rav Yosef said to</b> Abaye: <b>I said to you</b> an objection from the statement of Rabbi Shimon: <b>They were rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>by means of</b> the <b>slaughter</b> itself, <b>and you said to me:</b> It was the Sages who <b>accorded</b> susceptibility via slaughter of the animal a status <b>like</b> that <b>of susceptibility rendered</b> by means of <b>water. And Rabbi Zeira said to you</b> an objection from the case of one who harvests grapes, <b>and you said to him:</b> It is the Sages who <b>accorded</b> susceptibility via the liquid from the grapes a status <b>like</b> that <b>of susceptibility rendered</b> by means of <b>water.</b> If so, will you <b>also</b> say in response to the dilemma of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> with regard to a dry portion of consecrated flour that was not mixed with the oil of meal offerings that it is the Sages who <b>accorded</b> susceptibility via the regard for sanctity of the flour a status <b>like</b> that <b>of susceptibility rendered</b> by means of <b>water,</b> by rabbinic law, to count the descending levels of impurity, i.e., first-degree impurity, second-degree impurity?
Abaye <b>said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish was raising a dilemma</b> with regard to <b>placing</b> the matter <b>in abeyance,</b> and one may neither eat the consecrated flour nor may one burn it, which would be the case for impurity by rabbinic law? <b>When</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>raises the dilemma</b> it is with regard to whether <b>to burn</b> the gourd, which is the case when the impurity is by Torah law.
The Gemara notes that it may be learned <b>by inference</b> that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish holds <b>that regard for sanctity</b> renders sacred items subject to ritual impurity <b>by Torah law,</b> as his dilemma was limited to whether one counts the descending levels of impurity from those susceptible items, i.e., first-degree impurity, second-degree impurity, not the impurity of the sacred item itself. <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? <b>If we say</b> that it is derived <b>from</b> that <b>which is written: “And the flesh that touches any impure</b> item shall not be eaten; it shall be burned with fire” (Leviticus 7:19), then it must be ascertained: <b>This flesh that was rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, <b>by what means</b> was it rendered susceptible?
<b>If we say that it was rendered susceptible</b> to impurity <b>by means of</b> the <b>blood</b> of the animal, this is difficult. <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to blood of sacrificial</b> animals <b>that it does not render</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity? It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated: “You shall not eat it; you shall pour it upon the earth like water”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:24). <b>Blood</b> of a non-sacred animal, <b>which is poured like water</b> when it is slaughtered, <b>renders</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. By contrast, blood of a sacrificial animal, <b>which is not poured like water</b> but is presented on the altar, <b>does not render</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps say <b>that</b> the flesh <b>was rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>by means of the liquids of the</b> Temple <b>abattoir. But didn’t Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, say:</b> With regard to <b>the liquids of the</b> Temple <b>abattoir, not only are they ritually pure, but they do not</b> even <b>render</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity. <b>And if you would say</b> that one should <b>explain</b> the statement of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, as referring exclusively <b>to blood,</b> and the other liquids render food susceptible, <b>but doesn’t he say: Liquids,</b> in the plural? <b>Rather,</b> is it <b>not that</b> the flesh <b>was rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>via regard for sanctity?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>And perhaps</b> the verse can be explained <b>in accordance with</b> the statement that <b>Rav Yehuda</b> says that <b>Shmuel says, as Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The verse is referring to a case <b>where one had a cow</b> that was to be sacrificed as <b>a peace offering, and</b> since the owner is entitled to the meat and the hide of the animal, in order to improve their quality <b>he conveyed it through the river</b> and <b>slaughtered</b> the animal <b>while</b> the <b>liquid was still upon it</b> and the animal was <b>damp.</b> That liquid rendered the meat susceptible to impurity.
<b>Rather</b> the proof is <b>from the latter</b> portion of that verse: “And the flesh that touches any impure item shall not be eaten; it shall be burned with fire. <b>And the flesh,</b> every pure person may eat flesh” (Leviticus 7:19). The Gemara explains: The second mention of the term “and the flesh” in the verse is superfluous and serves <b>to include</b> the <i>halakha</i> that with regard to sacred <b>wood and frankincense,</b> impurity disqualifies them from being burned on the altar. Are <b>wood and frankincense edible</b> and therefore included in the verse: “Of all food that may be eaten, on which water comes, shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:34)? <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish derived from this that <b>regard for sanctity renders</b> them <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>and renders their</b> status like that of <b>food. Here too,</b> in the case of a dry portion of flour that was not mixed with the oil of meal offerings, <b>regard for sanctity renders</b> it <b>susceptible</b> to ritual impurity.

Daf 37a

The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the resolution of the dilemma raised by Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: <b>When regard for sanctity is effective</b> in rendering an item susceptible to impurity, is it only <b>to disqualify</b> that item <b>itself, but to count</b> the descending levels of <b>first-degree</b> impurity <b>and second-degree</b> impurity, it is <b>not</b> effective; <b>or perhaps</b> once it is rendered susceptible to impurity there <b>is no difference</b> whether it is rendered susceptible by means of regard for sanctity or by means of contact with liquids? The Gemara answers: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal <b>that is in danger</b> of imminent death, <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> The slaughter is valid <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> after the slaughter <b>it convulses with its foreleg and with its hind leg. Rabbi Eliezer says: It is sufficient if</b> blood <b>spurted</b> from the neck. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In the case of <b>one who slaughters at night and the next day he awoke and found walls full of blood,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid,</b> as it is clear <b>that</b> the blood <b>spurted, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with the rule of Rabbi Eliezer. And the Rabbis say:</b> It is valid <b>only</b> in a case <b>where it convulses with its foreleg or with its hind leg, or</b> in a case <b>where it wags its tail.</b>
This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>both a small animal,</b> e.g., a sheep, <b>and a large animal,</b> e.g., a cow, that is in danger of imminent death. The slaughter of <b>a small animal that</b> when being slaughtered <b>extended its foreleg</b> that was bent <b>and did not restore</b> it to the bent position <b>is not valid, as</b> extending the foreleg <b>is only</b> part of the natural course of <b>removal</b> of the animal’s <b>soul</b> from its body and not a convulsion indicating life. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is in a case <b>where the presumptive status</b> of the animal <b>was</b> that it was <b>in danger</b> of imminent death. <b>But if its presumptive status was</b> that it was <b>healthy,</b> then <b>even if there were none of these indicators,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is it known <b>that</b> the flesh of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death <b>is permitted</b> by means of slaughter? The Gemara responds with a question: <b>And from where would it enter your mind that it is prohibited?</b> The Gemara explains that one may have thought it is prohibited, <b>as it is written: “These are the living beings [<i>haḥayya</i>] that you may eat</b> among all the animals that are on the earth” (Leviticus 11:2). One might have thought that the verse is saying: <b>Eat</b> an animal that is fit to <b>live [<i>ḥayya</i>], but do not eat</b> an animal <b>that is not</b> fit to <b>live. And this</b> animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death <b>is not</b> fit to <b>live.</b>
The fact that its meat is permitted is derived <b>from the fact that the Merciful One states that you shall not eat an unslaughtered animal carcass,</b> as it is written: “You shall not eat any unslaughtered carcass” (Deuteronomy 14:21); one learns <b>by inference</b> that eating the meat of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death <b>is permitted. As, if it enters your mind</b> that eating the meat of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death <b>is prohibited, now</b> if an animal is <b>prohibited while alive,</b> is it <b>necessary</b> to state that it is prohibited <b>after death?</b>
The Gemara rejects that proof. <b>And</b> that is not a legitimate inference, as <b>perhaps</b> the halakhic status of <b>an unslaughtered carcass is</b> the same as <b>that of</b> an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death, and the prohibition: “You shall not eat any unslaughtered carcass,” includes both. The Gemara answers: <b>It would not enter your mind</b> to say so, <b>as it is written: “And if any animal of which you may eat dies, one who touches its carcass</b> shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39). This indicates that <b>it is after death that the Merciful One calls</b> the animal <b>a carcass; while alive,</b> the animal <b>is not called a carcass.</b>
The Gemara questions that understanding. <b>And perhaps, actually I will say to you:</b> The halakhic status of <b>an unslaughtered carcass is</b> the same as <b>that of</b> an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death, but if one slaughters the animal in danger of imminent death <b>while alive,</b> he would be <b>in</b> violation of <b>a positive</b> mitzva: “These are the living beings that you may eat” (Leviticus 11:2), whereas <b>after</b> its <b>death,</b> he would be <b>in</b> violation of <b>a prohibition:</b> “You shall not eat any unslaughtered carcass” (Deuteronomy 14:21).
<b>Rather,</b> the fact that its meat is permitted is derived <b>from the fact that the Merciful One states you shall not eat that an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>],</b> as it is written: “And you shall not eat any animal that was mauled in the field [<i>tereifa</i>]” (Exodus 22:30). From here, one learns <b>by inference</b> that eating the meat of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death <b>is permitted. As, if it enters your mind</b> that eating the meat of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death <b>is prohibited, now</b> that an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death <b>that is not lacking</b> any limb <b>is prohibited,</b> is it <b>necessary</b> to state that <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> an animal that was mauled and lacking body parts, is prohibited?
The Gemara rejects that proof. <b>And</b> that is not a legitimate inference, as <b>perhaps</b> the halakhic status of <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> that is lacking body parts <b>is</b> the same as that of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death that is not lacking body parts, and both are included in the category of <i>tereifa</i>. This would render one who slaughters either <b>to</b> be <b>in violation</b> of both <b>a positive</b> mitzva: “These are the living beings that you may eat,” <b>and a prohibition:</b> “And you shall not eat any animal that was mauled in the field [<i>tereifa</i>].” The Gemara questions that understanding: <b>If so, why do I</b> need the prohibition <b>that the Merciful One writes</b> with regard to <b>an unslaughtered carcass? If while</b> an animal is <b>alive one stands in</b> violation of <b>a prohibition and a positive</b> mitzva, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that it is prohibited <b>after death?</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>And</b> that is not a legitimate question, as <b>perhaps</b> the halakhic status of <b>an unslaughtered carcass is</b> the same as <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> that is lacking body parts, and <b>is</b> the same as <b>that of</b> an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death that is not lacking body parts. Therefore, when the Torah writes the word “carcass,” it is the same as though it had written <i>tereifa</i> and the same as though it had written an animal in danger of imminent death. The Torah prohibits each, <b>and the result will be that he will violate two prohibitions and a positive</b> mitzva.
<b>Rather,</b> the fact that the meat of an animal in danger of imminent death is permitted is derived <b>from here: “And the fat of a carcass and the fat of a <i>tereifa</i> may be used for any purpose; but you shall not eat it”</b> (Leviticus 7:24). <b>And the Master says:</b> In order <b>to</b> derive <b>what <i>halakha</i></b> is this verse written? Would one imagine that because it is an unslaughtered carcass or a <i>tereifa</i> its fat would be permitted for consumption? <b>The Torah states: Let the prohibition against</b> eating <b>an unslaughtered carcass come and take effect upon the prohibition against</b> eating forbidden <b>fat,</b> which already exists. One who eats the forbidden fat of an unslaughtered carcass is liable for violation of both prohibitions. Likewise, the word “<i>tereifa</i>” in the verse teaches: <b>Let the prohibition against</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i> come and take effect upon the prohibition against</b> eating forbidden <b>fat,</b> which already exists, so that one who eats the forbidden fat of a <i>tereifa</i> is liable for transgressing both prohibitions.

Daf 37b

<b>And if it enters your mind</b> to say that the halakhic status of <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> lacking body parts <b>is</b> the same as that of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death, <b>let the Merciful One write:</b> And <b>the fat of a carcass may be used for any purpose, and the fat of a <i>tereifa</i> you shall not eat.</b> The prohibition against eating the forbidden fat should have been written exclusively with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>and I would say: If while</b> an animal is <b>alive</b> and in danger of imminent death <b>the prohibition against</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i> takes effect upon the prohibition against</b> eating forbidden <b>fat, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that <b>after</b> its <b>death</b> the prohibition against eating an unslaughtered carcass takes effect upon the prohibition against eating forbidden fat?
The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather, from the fact that the Merciful One writes</b> that the prohibition against eating <b>an unslaughtered carcass</b> takes effect upon the prohibition against eating forbidden fat, one learns <b>by inference that</b> the <b><i>tereifa</i></b> in the verse <b>is not the same as</b> an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death. Rather, the <i>tereifa</i> in the verse is an animal that was mauled and is lacking body parts, and it is only that animal that is prohibited after slaughter. Eating an animal in danger of imminent death after slaughter is permitted.
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi objects to this: And perhaps, actually I will say to you</b> that the halakhic status of <b>a <i>tereifa</i> is</b> the same as that of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death, <b>and</b> with regard to <b>that which you said: Why do I</b> need the prohibition with regard to <b>an unslaughtered carcass that the Merciful One writes,</b> one can explain that it is necessary <b>for that unslaughtered carcass that does not come as a result of danger</b> of imminent death. <b>And what are the circumstances</b> of that unslaughtered carcass? It is in a case <b>where one rendered</b> the animal like <b>a shard,</b> by cutting it into two widthwise. The Gemara rejects that distinction: <b>There too,</b> in the case where one rendered the animal like a shard, it is <b>impossible that</b> the animal <b>was not</b> at least <b>somewhat in danger</b> of imminent death <b>before he cut the majority</b> of the animal.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that there is a different source for the fact that the meat of an animal in danger of imminent death is permitted. <b>If</b> it is <b>so</b> that an animal in danger of imminent death is included in the category of <i>tereifa</i>, <b>let</b> the verse <b>say: The fat of an unslaughtered carcass and a <i>tereifa</i>. Why do I</b> need it to be written: <b>“Fat</b> of a carcass and the <b>fat</b> of a <i>tereifa</i>”? The term “fat” is repeated to teach that <b>it is this</b> case <b>where</b> the status of <b>its fat is not distinct from</b> the status of <b>its meat,</b> and both are prohibited; <b>but you have another</b> case <b>where</b> the status of <b>its fat,</b> which is forbidden, <b>is distinct from</b> the status of <b>its meat,</b> which is permitted. <b>And which</b> case is that? <b>That is</b> the case of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that it is derived <b>from here: “Then I said: Ah, Lord God, my soul has not become impure; and from my youth until now I have not eaten an unslaughtered carcass or a <i>tereifa</i>, and no <i>piggul</i> flesh came into my mouth”</b> (Ezekiel 4:14).
The Gemara explains: <b>“My soul has not become impure”</b> means <b>that I did not consider</b> any sinful thoughts <b>during the day</b> that would cause me <b>to come to impurity</b> due to a seminal emission <b>at night. “And from my youth until now I have not eaten an unslaughtered carcass or a <i>tereifa</i>”</b> means <b>that I never ate</b> the <b>flesh of</b> an animal that was in danger of imminent death, leading one to say: <b>Slaughter</b> it, <b>slaughter</b> it quickly, before it dies. <b>“And no <i>piggul</i> flesh came into my mouth”</b> means <b>that I never ate from an animal</b> with regard to which there was uncertainty whether it is forbidden and <b>a Sage issued a ruling</b> to permit it. <b>They said in the name of Rabbi Natan</b> that the last portion of the verse means: <b>That I never ate from an animal whose gifts</b> to which members of the priesthood are entitled, i.e., the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw, <b>were not</b> already <b>separated.</b>
The proof is: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>it is permitted</b> to slaughter and eat an animal in imminent danger of death, then <b>that is the greatness of Ezekiel,</b> as, although eating it is permitted, he refrained from doing so. <b>But if you say</b> that <b>it is forbidden</b> to slaughter and eat that animal, <b>what</b> in that action attests to <b>the greatness of Ezekiel?</b> Apparently, it is permitted to slaughter and eat an animal in danger of imminent death.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It is <b>any</b> animal with regard to <b>which one stands it</b> on its feet <b>but it does not stand</b> unaided. <b>Rav Ḥanina bar Shelamya in the name of Rav said:</b> That indicator is so clear that <b>even</b> if that animal maintains sufficient strength in its jaw and <b>eats pieces of wood,</b> if it is unable to stand, its status is that of an animal in danger of imminent death. <b>Rami bar Yeḥezkel said:</b> That is the case <b>even</b> if that animal <b>eats beams.</b>
<b>In Sura, they</b> would <b>teach</b> the exchange in <b>that</b> manner. <b>In Pumbedita, they</b> would <b>teach</b> the exchange in <b>this</b> manner: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It is <b>any</b> animal with regard to <b>which one stands it</b> on its feet <b>but it does not stand</b> unaided, <b>even</b> if that animal maintains sufficient strength in its jaw and <b>eats pieces of wood. Rami bar Yeḥezkel said:</b> That indicator is so clear that <b>even</b> if that animal maintains sufficient strength in its jaw <b>and eats beams,</b> if it is unable to stand its status is that of an animal in danger of imminent death.
<b>Shmuel found students of Rav</b> after Rav’s death. <b>He said to them: What did Rav say with regard to</b> an animal <b>in danger</b> of imminent death? <b>They said to him: This</b> is what <b>Rav said:</b>

Daf 38a

If the animal <b>lows, or excreted excrement, or wiggled its ear</b> during the slaughter, <b>that is a convulsion,</b> and the slaughter renders eating the flesh of the animal permitted. Shmuel <b>said to them: Is it necessary</b> according <b>to Abba,</b> i.e., Rav, for the animal <b>to move its ears</b> during the slaughter, which requires a considerable life force? <b>As I say: Any</b> movements of the animal <b>that are not matters that the death</b> of the animal <b>engenders</b> are convulsions sufficient to render the slaughter valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are matters that the death</b> of the animal <b>engenders? Rav Anan said:</b> This <b>was explained to me from Master Shmuel</b> himself: If the animal’s <b>foreleg was bent, and</b> the animal <b>straightened it,</b> that is <b>a matter that the death</b> of the animal <b>engenders.</b> But if its foreleg was <b>straight and</b> the animal <b>bent</b> it, that is among the <b>matters that the death</b> of the animal <b>does not engender</b> and is a convulsion sufficient to render the slaughter valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Shmuel <b>teaching us</b> with that statement? <b>We</b> already <b>learn</b> in the mishna: The slaughter of <b>a small animal that</b> during its slaughter <b>extended its foreleg</b> that was bent <b>and did not restore</b> it to the bent position <b>is not valid, as</b> extending the foreleg <b>is nothing other than</b> part of the natural course of <b>removal</b> of the animal’s <b>soul</b> from its body and not a convulsion indicating life. <b>But</b> one may infer that if the animal does <b>restore</b> its foreleg to the bent position, that indicates life and the slaughter is <b>valid.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> is learned <b>from the mishna</b> alone, <b>I would say</b> that it is <b>specifically</b> in a case <b>where</b> the animal’s foreleg had been <b>bent, and</b> the animal now <b>straightens</b> it <b>and then bends it,</b> that the slaughter is valid. <b>But</b> if the foreleg had been <b>straight and</b> the animal <b>bent it,</b> the slaughter is <b>not</b> valid. Therefore, Shmuel <b>teaches us</b> that if its foreleg was straight and the animal bent it; that is a convulsion sufficient to render the slaughter valid.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> to Rav’s statement cited earlier. <b>Rabbi Yosei says</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say:</b> If an animal <b>lows during its slaughter, that is not</b> a <b>convulsion</b> sufficient to render the slaughter valid. <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, says in</b> the <b>name</b> of Rabbi Yosei: <b>Even</b> if the animal <b>excreted excrement or wagged its tail, that is not</b> a <b>convulsion</b> sufficient to render the slaughter valid. The Gemara now clarifies: Rabbi Yosei’s statement in the <i>baraita</i> that if an animal <b>lows</b> it is not a convulsion sufficient to render the slaughter valid is <b>difficult,</b> as it contradicts the statement of Rav that if an animal <b>lows</b> it is a convulsion. And Rabbi Elazar’s statement in the <i>baraita</i> that if an animal excreted <b>excrement</b> it is not a convulsion sufficient to render the slaughter valid <b>is difficult,</b> as it contradicts the statement of Rav that if an animal excreted <b>excrement</b> it is a convulsion.
The Gemara answers: The apparent contradiction between the opinion that when an animal <b>lows</b> it is a convulsion and the opinion that when an animal <b>lows</b> it is not a convulsion is <b>not difficult. This</b> opinion, that it is a convulsion, is referring to a case <b>where</b> the animal’s <b>voice</b> is <b>rich</b> and powerful, a clear indication of life; <b>that</b> opinion, that it is not a convulsion, is referring to a case <b>where</b> the animal’s <b>voice</b> is <b>muted,</b> which is not an indication of life. The apparent contradiction between the opinion that when an animal excreted <b>excrement</b> it is a convulsion and the opinion that when an animal excreted <b>excrement</b> it is not a convulsion is also <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the opinion that it is not a convulsion is referring to a case where the animal <b>expels</b> the excrement <b>in a trickle.</b> That is not an indication of life. <b>There,</b> the opinion that it is a convulsion is referring to a case where the animal <b>expels</b> the excrement <b>with force.</b> That is an indication of life.
§ The Gemara continues its definition of convulsion that indicates life. <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> I was taught that <b>the convulsion that</b> the Sages <b>said</b> is an indication of life is a convulsion <b>at the conclusion of</b> the act of <b>slaughter.</b> Rav Ḥisda elaborates: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>At the conclusion of</b> the act of <b>slaughter?</b> It means even <b>in the midst of the slaughter.</b> The Sages said that it must be at the conclusion of the slaughter only <b>to exclude</b> convulsions at <b>the beginning of</b> the act of <b>slaughter, which</b> are <b>not</b> an indication of life.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: From where do I say</b> that a convulsion in the midst of the act of slaughter is an indication of life? It is from the mishna, <b>as we learned:</b> The slaughter of <b>a small animal that</b> when being slaughtered <b>extended its foreleg</b> that was bent <b>and did not restore</b> it to the bent position <b>is not valid,</b> as extending the foreleg is only part of the natural course of removal of the animal’s soul from its body and not a convulsion indicating life. Rav Ḥisda elaborates: <b>When</b> did the animal extend its foreleg but not restore it? <b>If we say</b> that it occurred <b>at the conclusion of</b> the <b>slaughter, must</b> the animal <b>continue living</b> for <b>so extended</b> a period that it restores its leg to its bent position after the slaughter is complete? Is the slaughter truly not valid otherwise? <b>Rather, is it not</b> that the mishna is referring to a case where the animal extends its foreleg <b>in the middle of</b> the <b>slaughter?</b> If so, then when it restores its leg as well, it is considered a convulsion that indicates life.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: That is no proof. <b>Actually,</b> one could explain that the mishna is referring to a case where the animal extends its foreleg but did not restore it to the bent position at <b>the conclusion of</b> the <b>slaughter, as I say</b> with regard to <b>any</b> animal <b>that does not do so at the conclusion of</b> the <b>slaughter, it is known that its soul was taken from it before that</b> moment, and it was not alive.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: The convulsion that</b> the Sages <b>said</b> is an indication of life is a convulsion even <b>at the beginning of</b> the act of <b>slaughter.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</b> explained further and <b>said: From where do I say</b> that this is so? It is from the mishna, <b>as we learned</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In the case of <b>one who slaughters at night and the next day</b> he awoke <b>and found walls full of blood,</b> the slaughter is <b>valid,</b> as it is clear <b>that</b> the blood <b>spurted, and</b> this is <b>in accordance with the rule of Rabbi Eliezer. And Shmuel said</b> with regard to the walls mentioned in the statement of Rabbi Shimon: It is <b>the walls of the place of the slaughter,</b> i.e., the walls of the neck, not the walls of the house, that <b>we learned. Granted, if you say</b> that a convulsion even <b>at the beginning of</b> the act of <b>slaughter</b> is an indication of life, this works out <b>well. But if you say</b> that a convulsion is an indication of life only <b>at the conclusion of</b> the act of <b>slaughter, let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the blood <b>spurted</b> onto the walls of the neck <b>at the beginning of</b> the act of <b>slaughter,</b> and there was no indication of life.
The Gemara rejects that proof. <b>But perhaps spurting is different, as</b> it is <b>superior</b> as an indication of life to extending or bending a foreleg, and therefore, although extending or bending a foreleg is a sufficient indicator of life only at the conclusion of the act of slaughter, spurting is a sufficient indicator even at the beginning of the act of slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> spurting <b>superior? But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says it is sufficient if</b> blood <b>spurted</b> from the neck, indicating that spurting of blood is a less substantive indication of life than those indications mentioned in the statement of Rabban Gamliel, who requires that the animal convulse with its foreleg and with its hind leg? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Eliezer’s requirement of spurting is <b>less</b> substantive <b>than</b> the requirements <b>of Rabban Gamliel</b> as an indication of life, <b>but superior to</b> the requirement of <b>the Rabbis</b> as an indication of life, where the Rabbis require that the animal convulse either with its foreleg or with its hind leg.
<b>Ravina said: Samma bar Ḥilkai said to me</b> that <b>the father of bar Abuveram, and some say</b> that it was <b>the brother of bar Abuveram, raises a difficulty: And is</b> blood spurting <b>superior to</b> the requirement of <b>the Rabbis</b> as an indication of life? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> It is permitted <b>only</b> in a case <b>where it convulses with its foreleg or with its hind leg,</b> or in a case where it wags its tail?
Ravina elaborates: <b>To which</b> statement of the <i>tanna’im</i> in the mishna <b>do the Rabbis stand</b> and respond? <b>If we say</b> that they are responding to the statement <b>of Rabban Gamliel,</b> who requires that the animal convulse with its foreleg and with its hind leg, the Rabbis <b>should</b> have said: <b>Once</b> the animal <b>convulsed</b> with its foreleg or with its hind leg or it wagged its tail, indicating that this is sufficient.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the Rabbis are responding to the statement <b>of Rabbi Eliezer. And if</b> Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion is <b>superior</b> to that of the Rabbis as an indication of life, <b>what</b> is the meaning of: It is permitted <b>only</b> in a case where it convulses with its foreleg or with its hind leg or it wags its tail? In that case too, the Rabbis should have said: Once the animal convulses with its foreleg or with its hind leg or it wags its tail. Apparently, blood spurting is a less substantive indication of life, and the proof of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak remains valid: If spurting at the beginning of the act of slaughter is a sufficient indication of life to render the slaughter valid, then all the more so, extending and bending a limb are also sufficient indications of life.
<b>Rava said: The convulsion that</b> the Rabbis <b>said</b> is an indication of life is a convulsion <b>at the conclusion of</b> the act of <b>slaughter. Rava said: From where do I say</b> that this is the case? It is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “When a bull or a sheep or a goat is born, it shall be seven days under its mother; and from the eighth day and onward it may be accepted for an offering to the Lord” (Leviticus 22:27). The phrase <b>“a bull</b>

Daf 38b

<b>or a sheep”</b> is <b>to the exclusion of</b> an animal born to parents of <b>diverse kinds,</b> which may not be brought as an offering. The phrase <b>“or a goat”</b> is <b>to the exclusion of</b> an animal <b>that resembles</b> another species of animal. <b>“When it is born”;</b> this is <b>to the exclusion of</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section.</b> “It shall be <b>seven days”;</b> this is <b>to the exclusion of</b> an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived. <b>“Under its mother”;</b> this is <b>to the exclusion of</b> an animal that is <b>an orphan.</b>
Rava elaborates: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>this orphan? If we say that its mother gave birth to it and then died,</b> this is unreasonable. Will the mother <b>continue living forever? Rather,</b> perhaps the reference is to a case <b>where</b> the mother <b>died and then gave birth to it.</b> The Gemara rejects that possibility, as the fact that this animal is disqualified from sacrifice <b>is derived from</b> the phrase: <b>“When it is born,”</b> since after the mother’s death the newborn animal can emerge from the womb only by means of caesarean section.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the reference is to a case where the mother died at the conclusion of the birth, at which point <b>this</b> mother <b>withdrew for death and that</b> newborn <b>withdrew for life. Granted, if you say</b> that <b>we require life at the conclusion of</b> the <b>birth, that is why a verse was necessary to exclude</b> the orphan. <b>But if you say</b> that <b>we do not require life at the conclusion of the birth,</b> and the verse is excluding only an animal that was born after its mother’s death, <b>why is</b> this verse necessary to exclude it? It can <b>be derived from</b> the phrase: <b>“When it is born.”</b> It may be derived from here that in any situation where the animal must be alive, it must remain alive until the end of the process. That is the case with regard to the slaughter of an animal in danger of imminent death as well. The slaughter is valid only if there is an indication of life at the end of the act of slaughter.
§ The mishna teaches: The slaughter of a small animal in danger of imminent death that during the slaughter extended its foreleg that was bent and did not restore it to the bent position is not valid, as extending the foreleg is only part of the natural course of removal of the animal’s soul from its body and not a convulsion indicating life. <b>Rava says</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion expressed in <b>this <i>baraita</i>:</b> The slaughter of <b>a small animal that extended its foreleg</b> that was bent <b>and did not restore it</b> to the bent position <b>is not valid.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>with regard to the foreleg. But with regard to the hind leg, whether</b> the animal <b>extended it and did not restore</b> it to the bent position <b>or</b> the animal <b>bent it but did not extend it,</b> the slaughter <b>is valid. In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> about extending the foreleg, <b>said?</b> It is <b>with regard to a small</b> animal. <b>But with regard to a large</b> animal, <b>whether</b> the convulsion involves its <b>foreleg or its hind leg,</b> and <b>whether</b> the animal <b>extended it and did not restore</b> it to the bent position <b>or</b> the animal <b>bent it but did not extend it,</b> the slaughter <b>is valid. And</b> with regard to <b>a bird, even</b> if it <b>fluttered [<i>rifref</i>] only its wing or wagged only its tail, that is a convulsion</b> and an indication of life.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rava <b>teaching us</b> in ruling in accordance with the <i>baraita</i>? He is teaching us <b>all of</b> those <i>halakhot</i> <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: The slaughter of <b>a small animal that</b> when being slaughtered <b>extended its foreleg</b> that was bent <b>and did not restore</b> it to the bent position <b>is not valid, as</b> extending the foreleg <b>is only</b> part of the natural course of <b>removal</b> of the animal’s <b>soul</b> from its body and not a convulsion indicating life. It may be inferred from the mishna that with regard to movement of <b>a foreleg</b> alone, <b>yes,</b> it is not an indication of life, but movement of <b>a hind leg, no,</b> it is an indication of life. With regard to <b>a small</b> animal, <b>yes,</b> this is the <i>halakha</i>; with regard to <b>a large</b> animal, <b>no,</b> this is not the <i>halakha</i>, and extending a hind leg does indicate life. The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary for</b> Rava to teach the <i>halakha</i> in the <i>baraita</i> with regard to <b>a bird, as we did not learn</b> it in the mishna.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a Jew <b>who slaughters</b> the animal of a gentile <b>for a gentile, his slaughter is valid, and Rabbi Eliezer deems it not valid. Rabbi Eliezer says: Even if</b> the Jew <b>slaughtered</b> the animal with the intent <b>to feed the gentile from its diaphragm [<i>meḥatzar kaved</i>],</b> its slaughter is <b>not valid, as the unspecified intent of a gentile is</b> to slaughter the animal <b>for idol worship,</b> and it is prohibited to derive benefit from it.
<b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The <b>matter</b> of the intent of the gentile is irrelevant in this case, as can be derived by means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. <b>If in a place where intent</b> while slaughtering the animal <b>invalidates</b> the slaughter, i.e., <b>in sacrificial</b> animals, such as when slaughtering an offering with the intent to sacrifice it beyond its designated time, <b>everything follows only</b> the intent of the priest <b>performing the service</b> and not the intent of the owner, then <b>in a place where intent does not invalidate</b> the slaughter, i.e., <b>in non-sacred</b> animals, <b>is it not right that everything should follow only</b> the intent of <b>the one who slaughters</b> the animal?
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> In explanation of the dispute between the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Eliezer, the Gemara explains: <b>These <i>tanna’im</i> hold</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei, says: I heard that the owners,</b> and not only the priest, <b>render</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> by means of improper intent. The same is true with regard to non-sacred slaughter, where the owners’ intent for idol worship invalidates the slaughter, even if the slaughterer has no intent for idol worship.
<b>But the first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>if we heard</b> the gentile say <b>that he intends</b> the animal for idol worship, <b>yes,</b> his intent invalidates the slaughter, and <b>if</b> the gentile did <b>not</b> voice his intent before us, his intent does <b>not</b> invalidate the slaughter, as <b>we do not say</b> that the <b>unspecified intent of a gentile is for idol worship. Rabbi Eliezer holds: Although we did not hear</b> the gentile say <b>that he intends</b> the animal for idol worship, the slaughter is not valid, as <b>we say</b> the <b>unspecified intent of a gentile is for idol worship. And Rabbi Yosei comes to say</b> that <b>even though we heard</b> the gentile say <b>that he intends</b> the animal for idol worship, in a case where <b>this</b> owner <b>has intent</b> for idol worship <b>and that</b> other person is <b>performing</b> the slaughter, <b>we do not say</b> that the intent of the owner invalidates the slaughter.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> an alternative explanation of the mishna. It is <b>with regard to</b> a case <b>where we heard</b> the gentile say <b>that he intends</b> the animal for idol worship that the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree. The first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>when we say</b> in a case where <b>this</b> owner <b>has</b> improper <b>intent and that</b> other person is <b>performing</b> the slaughter that the intent of the owner invalidates the slaughter, <b>this statement</b> applies only <b>inside</b> the Temple, in the slaughter of offerings. <b>But</b> with regard to non-sacred slaughter <b>outside</b> the Temple, the intent of the owner does <b>not</b> invalidate the slaughter, as with regard to deriving the <i>halakhot</i> of non-sacred slaughter <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter of sacrificial animals <b>inside</b> the Temple,

Daf 39a

<b>we do not derive</b> in this manner. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer comes to say</b> that <b>we derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of non-sacred slaughter <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter of sacrificial animals <b>inside</b> the Temple, and therefore the intent of the gentile invalidates non-sacred slaughter. <b>And Rabbi Yosei comes to say</b> that <b>even inside</b> the Temple, in a case where <b>this</b> owner <b>has</b> improper <b>intent and that</b> other person is <b>performing</b> the slaughter, <b>we do not say</b> that the intent of the owner invalidates the slaughter.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that there is an amoraic dispute with regard to <b>one who slaughtered an animal</b> in order <b>to sprinkle its blood for idol worship, or to burn its fat for idol worship. Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The slaughter is <b>not valid,</b> and benefit from the animal is forbidden. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says:</b> The slaughter is valid and deriving benefit from the animal is <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara elaborates. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The slaughter is <b>not valid</b> and benefit from the animal is forbidden. He holds that <b>one transfers intent from</b> one sacrificial <b>rite to</b> another sacrificial <b>rite.</b> If, while slaughtering a sacrificial animal, one intends to perform one of the other sacrificial rites in an improper manner the offering is invalidated. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that <b>we derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of non-sacred slaughter <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter of sacrificial animals <b>inside</b> the Temple. Since that intent invalidates the slaughter of sacrificial animals inside the Temple, it invalidates the slaughter of non-sacred animals outside the Temple as well.
<b>Reish Lakish says:</b> The slaughter is valid, and deriving benefit from the animal is <b>permitted.</b> He holds that <b>one does not transfer intent from</b> one sacrificial <b>rite to</b> another sacrificial <b>rite.</b> Therefore, while slaughtering the animal, only intent to perform the slaughter improperly invalidates the offering, but intent to perform another sacrificial rite improperly does not invalidate the offering. <b>And</b> Reish Lakish holds that <b>we do not derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of non-sacred slaughter <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter of sacrificial animals <b>inside</b> the Temple.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish <b>follow their</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as it was stated:</b> If one <b>slaughtered</b> a sin offering <b>for its own sake,</b> but with intent <b>to sprinkle its blood not for its own sake</b> but for the sake of another type of offering, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that the offering is <b>unfit,</b> and <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says</b> that the offering is <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that the offering is <b>unfit.</b> He holds that <b>one transfers intent from</b> one sacrificial <b>rite to</b> another sacrificial <b>rite, and</b> the reason is that <b>we derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of slaughter of a sin offering not for its sake <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>intent for <i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., performance of one of the sacrificial rites with the intent to sprinkle the blood of the offering beyond its appointed time. And <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says</b> that the offering is <b>fit</b> because he holds that <b>one does not transfer intent from</b> one sacrificial <b>rite to</b> another sacrificial <b>rite, and</b> the reason is that <b>we do not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of any other improper intent <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>intent for <i>piggul</i>.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish in both cases. <b>As, if</b> it <b>were stated</b> only <b>with regard to that</b> case of one who slaughters an animal in order to sprinkle its blood for idol worship, perhaps one would conclude that it is specifically <b>in that</b> case that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish states</b> his opinion that the slaughter is valid, <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that we do not derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of non-sacred slaughter <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter of sacrificial animals <b>inside</b> the Temple. <b>But</b> in the case of one who slaughters an offering for the sake of another offering, where we would be deriving the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter of sacrificial animals <b>inside</b> the Temple <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of another case of slaughter of sacrificial animals <b>inside</b> the Temple, <b>say</b> that Reish Lakish <b>concedes to Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that the offering is unfit.
<b>And if</b> their dispute <b>was stated with regard to this</b> case of one who slaughters an offering for the sake of another offering, perhaps one would conclude that it is specifically <b>in this</b> case that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that the offering is unfit, because he holds that one derives the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter of sacrificial animals inside the Temple from the <i>halakhot</i> of another case of slaughter of sacrificial animals inside the Temple. <b>But in that</b> case of one who slaughters an animal in order to sprinkle its blood for idol worship, <b>say that</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>concedes to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> that the offering is fit due to the fact that the <i>halakhot</i> of non-sacred slaughter outside the Temple are not derived from the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughter of sacrificial animals inside the Temple. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish in both cases.
<b>Rav Sheshet raises an objection</b> to both Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish from the statement in the mishna with regard to one who slaughters for a gentile when the intent of the gentile is for idol worship. <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The <b>matter</b> of the intent of the gentile is irrelevant in this case as can be derived by means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference. <b>If in a place where intent</b> while slaughtering the animal <b>invalidates</b> the slaughter, i.e., <b>in sacrificial</b> animals, such as when slaughtering an offering with the intent to sacrifice it beyond its designated time, <b>everything follows only</b> the intent of the priest <b>performing the service</b> and not the intent of the owner, then <b>in a place where intent does not invalidate</b> the slaughter, i.e., <b>in non-sacred</b> animals, <b>is it not right that everything should follow only</b> the intent of <b>the one who slaughters</b> the animal?
Rav Sheshet elaborates: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>Intent does not invalidate</b> the slaughter <b>in non-sacred</b> animals? <b>If we say</b> that it means <b>that</b> intent <b>does not invalidate</b> the slaughter of non-sacred animals <b>at all, but</b> then <b>how can you find</b> a case of <b>slaughter</b> with intent <b>for idol worship where</b> the animal <b>is forbidden?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the meaning of that phrase in the statement of Rabbi Yosei is that one does not transfer intent <b>from</b> one sacrificial <b>rite to</b> another sacrificial <b>rite, and this</b> is what Rabbi Yosei <b>is saying: If in a place where intent invalidates,</b> i.e., <b>in sacrificial</b> animals, <b>from</b> one sacrificial <b>rite to</b> another sacrificial <b>rite, everything follows only</b> the intent of the one <b>performing</b> the slaughter, and the intent of the owners is irrelevant, in a <b>place where intent does not invalidate,</b> i.e., <b>in non-sacred</b> animals, <b>from</b> one <b>rite to</b> another <b>rite</b> but it does so <b>only within the same rite, is it not right that everything should follow only</b> the intent of <b>the one who slaughters</b> the animal?
According to this understanding of the contention of Rabbi Yosei in the mishna, the case of the slaughter of a sacrificial animal <b>inside</b> the Temple is <b>difficult for Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> as contrary to his opinion, Rabbi Yosei says that in that case one transfers intent from one sacrificial rite to another sacrificial rite. The case of slaughter of a non-sacred animal <b>outside</b> the Temple is <b>difficult for Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> as contrary to his opinion, Rabbi Yosei says that in that case one does not transfer intent from one rite to another rite.
Rav Sheshet continues: <b>Granted,</b> the case of <b>inside</b> the Temple is <b>not difficult for Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> because one can explain that he stated <b>this</b> statement that one does not transfer intent from one sacrificial rite to another sacrificial rite before <b>he heard</b> the mishna <b>from Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> his teacher, and he stated <b>that</b> one transfers intent from one sacrificial rite to another sacrificial rite <b>after he heard</b> the mishna <b>from Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> His dispute with Rabbi Yoḥanan is limited to transfer of intent for idol worship from rite to rite. <b>But</b> the case of slaughter of a non-sacred animal <b>outside</b> the Temple <b>is difficult for Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b>
Rav Sheshet <b>raises the objection, and he resolves it.</b> That which Rabbi Yosei said, that intent inside the Temple disqualifies the slaughter of a sacrificial animal but intent outside the Temple does not disqualify the slaughter of a non-sacred animal, is unrelated to transfer of intent from one rite to another. Rather, Rabbi Yosei is referring to a case where one performed any <b>of the four</b> sacrificial <b>rites</b> with improper intent, e.g., to eat the offering beyond its appointed time. <b>And this</b> is what Rabbi Yosei <b>is saying: If in a place where intent</b> while slaughtering the animal <b>invalidates</b> the slaughter <b>in sacrificial</b> animals, if that intent was <b>during</b> performance of any of the <b>four</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> i.e., slaughter, receiving the blood, conveying the blood to the altar, and sprinkling the blood on the altar, <b>everything follows only</b> the intent of the priest <b>performing the service</b> and not the intent of the owner,

Daf 39b

then <b>in a place where intent invalidates</b> the slaughter <b>in non-sacred</b> animals slaughtered with intent for idol worship <b>during</b> performance of <b>only two</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> slaughter and sprinkling the blood, <b>is it not right that everything should follow only</b> the intent of <b>the one who slaughters</b> the animal?
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> With regard to <b>one who slaughters an animal</b> in order <b>to sprinkle its blood for idol worship</b> or <b>to burn its fat for idol worship,</b> the status of <b>these</b> animals <b>is</b> that of <b>offerings to the dead,</b> i.e., to idols, and the slaughter is not valid. <b>If one slaughtered</b> the animal <b>and thereafter intended in its</b> regard to sprinkle its blood or burn its fats for idol worship, <b>that was</b> the <b>incident in Caesarea, and</b> the Sages <b>did not say</b> anything <b>with regard to</b> the animal, <b>neither prohibition nor permission.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> in explanation of the conduct of the Sages that <b>they did not say prohibition, due to the honor of the Rabbis</b> in the mishna, who hold that the unspecified intent of a gentile, and presumably likewise of a Jew who worships idols, is not presumed to be directed to idol worship, and therefore his slaughter is valid. <b>Nor</b> did the Sages say <b>permission, due to the honor of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who holds that the unspecified intent of a gentile, and presumably likewise of a Jew who worships idols, is presumed to be directed to idol worship.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> is that conclusion drawn? <b>Perhaps the Rabbis say</b> that the slaughter is permitted <b>only there</b> in the mishna, <b>because we did not hear</b> explicitly <b>that</b> the gentile <b>intends</b> the slaughter for idol worship. <b>But here</b> in the case in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>where we hear</b> thereafter <b>that he intends</b> to sprinkle the blood or burn the fats for idol worship, perhaps <b>his ultimate</b> statement <b>proves</b> the nature of <b>his original</b> intent while performing the slaughter.
<b>Alternatively,</b> perhaps when <b>Rabbi Eliezer states there</b> in the mishna that slaughter performed on behalf of a gentile is not valid, this applies <b>only with regard to</b> an animal that is owned by <b>a gentile, as the unspecified intent of a gentile is directed to idol worship. But</b> in the case in the <i>baraita</i> where the animal belongs to <b>a Jew, we do not say</b> that <b>his ultimate</b> statement <b>proves</b> the nature of <b>his original</b> intent.
<b>Rather, Rav Sheizevi said</b> that the Sages <b>did not state permission with regard to</b> the animal in the <i>baraita</i> <b>due to the honor of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> who holds that one’s ultimate actions prove the nature of his original intent. The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> statement of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> indicates that this is his opinion?
<b>If we say</b> that the reference is to the statement of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel with regard to bills of divorce,</b> this is difficult. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 66a) that if a dying man said to the people present: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, those people should write and deliver the bill of divorce to his wife. Although the delivery was not included in his command, that is clearly his intent. But <b>a healthy</b> man <b>who says: Write a bill of divorce for my wife,</b> but did not say: Deliver it to her, presumably <b>sought to mock her</b> and not to designate his listeners as agents of delivery.
The mishna continues: <b>And</b> there was <b>an incident involving a healthy</b> man <b>who said: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, and</b> then <b>ascended to the roof and fell, and died. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: If he fell at his own</b> initiative, taking his own life, <b>it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> as it is clear that he anticipated his death, thereby rendering his halakhic status like that of a dying man. But <b>if the wind forced him</b> to fall and he died, <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> as there was no clear intent to give her the bill of divorce.
<b>And we discussed</b> the mishna: Did the <i>tanna</i> cite <b>an incident to contradict</b> that which was stated previously in the mishna? The <i>tanna</i> states unequivocally that when a healthy man says: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, the bill of divorce is not valid. The <i>tanna</i> then cites an incident indicating that under certain circumstances, when a healthy man says: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, the bill of divorce is valid.
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>is incomplete and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching:</b> The healthy man who says: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, but did not say: Deliver it to her, presumably sought to mock her. But <b>if his ultimate</b> actions <b>prove</b> the nature of <b>his initial</b> intent, that he seeks to give the bill of divorce because he is about to die, <b>it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce. And</b> there was <b>an incident involving a healthy</b> man <b>who said: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, and</b> then <b>ascended to the roof and fell, and died. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: If he fell at his own</b> initiative, <b>it is</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce,</b> but <b>if the wind forced him</b> to fall, <b>it is not</b> a valid <b>bill of divorce.</b>
The Gemara explains why this is not a proof: <b>But perhaps</b> the case cited <b>there is different, as</b> the husband initially <b>says: Write</b> a bill of divorce for my wife, indicating that he originally intended to fall from the roof. By contrast, in the case of slaughter, there is no indication of his original intent.
<b>Rather, Ravina said</b> that the Sages did not state permission in the incident in Caesarea with regard to the animal <b>due to the honor of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> to avoid contradicting the opinion <b>that</b> is cited <b>here, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case of a person on his deathbed <b>who wrote</b> a document transferring <b>his property to others, and there were slaves among</b> his property, <b>and that</b> intended recipient <b>says: I do not want</b> to assume ownership of the slaves, <b>if their second master,</b> the intended recipient, <b>was a priest, these</b> slaves <b>may partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> and his protest is ignored. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Once that</b> intended recipient <b>says: I do not want</b> to assume ownership of the slaves, <b>heirs</b> of the original owner <b>already acquired them.</b>
<b>And we discussed</b> the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> according <b>to the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> does the intended recipient acquire the slaves <b>even</b> if <b>he stands and shouts</b> in protest that he does not want to assume ownership of the slaves? That is not reasonable.
<b>Rabba said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> who said: <b>In</b> a case where <b>he shouts</b> in protest <b>at the outset,</b> while the owner is giving him the gift, <b>everyone agrees that he did not acquire</b> the slaves. In a case where <b>he was silent</b> at that moment <b>and ultimately shouted</b> his protest at a later opportunity, <b>everyone agrees that he acquired</b> the slaves.
<b>When they disagree</b> it is in a case <b>where</b> the owner <b>transferred ownership</b> of the slaves <b>to him through another</b> person, <b>and</b> at that point the recipient <b>was silent, and ultimately,</b> when he actually received the slaves, <b>he shouted</b> in protest. <b>The first <i>tanna</i> holds: Since he was</b> initially <b>silent, he acquired</b> the slaves, <b>and</b> the fact <b>that he is</b> ultimately <b>shouting</b> indicates that <b>he is retracting</b> his initial acceptance of the gift. That retraction is ineffective, as acquisitions cannot be nullified in that manner.
<b>And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds: His ultimate</b> actions <b>prove</b> the nature of <b>his original</b> intent. He never wanted the slaves and always intended to avoid assuming ownership of them. <b>And</b> the fact <b>that he did not shout initially</b> is because <b>he thought:</b> As the situation is <b>that they did not</b> yet <b>enter my possession, why would I shout?</b>
§ The Gemara resumes discussion of the dispute in the mishna where Rabbi Yosei says that when a Jew slaughters an animal on behalf of a gentile, even if it is known that the intent of the gentile is for idol worship, the slaughter is valid, as it is only the intent of the slaughterer that is relevant. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b>
