Consequently, the very bottom of the neck is not a location fit for slaughter.
<b>Rav Ḥanina, and some say Rav Ḥananya, raises a dilemma:</b> If the animal <b>forced itself</b> and extended its neck, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the additional area? The Gemara responds: The question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved. The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish sat</b> together, and <b>a matter emerged from between them:</b> If the slaughterer <b>forced</b> the animal to extend <b>the <i>simanim</i></b> by stretching the neck <b>and slaughtered</b> the animal at the lower end of the neck, the slaughter is <b>not valid.</b> And if <b>the windpipe was perforated below the breast, it is considered</b> to be <b>like</b> a perforated <b>lung,</b> which renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> no matter the size of the perforation. A perforation in the upper windpipe must be the size of an <i>issar</i> to render the animal a <i>tereifa</i> (see 54a).
The Gemara elaborates: <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Which is the breast</b> that must be given to the priests as a gift from every peace offering (see Leviticus 7:31)? <b>This</b> is the section <b>that faces the ground,</b> not the ribbed area on the sides. And lengthwise it extends <b>below,</b> when the animal is hung from the legs, <b>until the neck,</b> and <b>above until the rumen.</b> One <b>cuts the two ribs</b> nearest the head <b>from the two sides</b> of the animal <b>from both directions, and this is the breast that is given to the priests.</b>
§ The mishna states: If <b>the membrane of the brain was perforated,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara cites <b>Rav and Shmuel, who both say:</b> The brain is covered by two membranes, a thick outer membrane adjacent to the skull and a thin inner membrane adjacent to the brain. The animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if <b>the outer membrane</b> was perforated, <b>even if the inner</b> membrane <b>was not perforated. And some say</b> that the animal is not a <i>tereifa</i> <b>unless the inner</b> membrane <b>was perforated</b> as well. <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says: And</b> this is <b>your mnemonic</b> to remember the <i>halakha</i>: The <b>bag in which the brain rests,</b> i.e., the inner membrane.
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> Even though the inner membrane of the brain is very thin and not easily visible, <b>its equivalent in the testicles,</b> which are also enclosed in a thin membrane, <b>is conspicuous,</b> as it has an appearance different from the testicles themselves. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says in the name of bar Kappara:</b> With regard to the <b>brain, everything inside the skull is considered</b> part of <b>the brain.</b> From the point where it <b>begins to extend</b> like a cord out of the base of the skull, it <b>is considered the spinal cord. And from where does it begin to be extended? Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Naḥmani said: It was explained to me</b> personally <b>by Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> himself: Protrusions <b>similar</b> to <b>two</b>

Daf 45b

<b>beans lie at the opening of the skull,</b> where the spinal cord exits. <b>From the beans inward,</b> the nerve tissue is considered <b>like the inside,</b> i.e., the brain. Therefore, if its membrane is perforated, even minimally, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>From the beans outward,</b> the nerve tissue is considered <b>like the outside,</b> i.e., the spinal cord. A perforation of the membrane in this area renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> only if the spinal cord is mostly cut. <b>And</b> with regard to the area of <b>the beans themselves, I do not know</b> what the <i>halakha</i> is; <b>but it stands to reason</b> that it is considered <b>like the inside.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya inspected a bird and found</b> protrusions <b>similar</b> to <b>two beans lying on the opening of the skull.</b>
§ The mishna states: If <b>the heart was perforated to its chamber,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma:</b> Is the mishna referring <b>to</b> the <b>small chamber</b> within the heart <b>or to</b> the <b>large chamber? Abaye said to him: What is your dilemma? Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna with regard to the lung: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> It is not a <i>tereifa</i> <b>unless it is perforated</b> through <b>to the bronchi? And Rabba bar Taḥlifa says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> Rabbi Shimon means that it is not a <i>tereifa</i> <b>unless it is perforated</b> through <b>to the large bronchus.</b> If so, it may be presumed that the mishna is referring to the large chamber of the heart as well.
The Gemara responds: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> the mishna <b>teaches: To the bronchi [<i>simponot</i>],</b> in the plural form, i.e., the one bronchus <b>into which all the bronchi [<i>simponot</i>] empty</b> out. <b>But here,</b> with regard to the heart, it <b>teaches: To the chamber. What</b> is it <b>to me</b> if this is <b>a large chamber</b> and <b>what</b> is it <b>to me</b> if it is <b>a small chamber?</b> The language does not indicate one or the other.
§ With regard to the <b>aorta,</b> the chief artery exiting the heart, <b>Rav says:</b> Like the heart itself, if it is perforated <b>in any amount</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> The animal is a <i>tereifa</i> only if the aorta is perforated <b>in its majority.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> blood vessel <b>is the aorta? Rabba bar Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> This is the artery found in the <b>fat on the sides.</b> The Gemara asks: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> to say that this is referring to the <b>sides</b> of the animal, i.e., the ribs, which are not adjacent to the heart? <b>Rather,</b> this is referring to the artery covered in fat <b>that</b> exits the heart and passes <b>on the sides of the lung.</b>
<b>Ameimar says in the name of Rav Naḥman: There are three ducts</b> adjacent to one another in an animal’s chest. <b>One separates to the heart, and one separates to the lung, and one separates to the liver.</b> The duct <b>of the lung</b> is treated <b>like the lung,</b> and renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> if perforated in any amount. The duct <b>of the liver</b> is treated <b>like the liver,</b> and only if it is completely missing does it render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, in accordance with the mishna. As for the duct <b>of the heart,</b> the aorta, Rav and Shmuel <b>disagree</b> as to the measure of its perforation, as mentioned above.
<b>Mar bar Ḥiyya teaches the opposite:</b> The duct <b>of the lung</b> is treated <b>like the liver</b> and renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> only if it is completely missing. The duct <b>of the liver</b> is treated <b>like the lung,</b> and a perforation of any amount renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. And with regard to the duct <b>of the heart,</b> Rav and Shmuel <b>disagree.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef went and stated the <i>halakha</i> of Rav,</b> that an aorta perforated in any amount renders an animal a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>before Shmuel.</b> Shmuel <b>said to him: If Abba,</b> i.e., Rav, actually <b>said so, he knows nothing at all about <i>tereifot</i>.</b>
§ The mishna states: If <b>the spinal</b> column <b>was broken</b> and its cord was cut, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. With regard to this <b>the Sages taught:</b> If <b>the spinal cord was cut in its majority,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Ya’akov says:</b> It is a <i>tereifa</i> <b>even</b> if the spinal cord was only <b>perforated.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>ruled in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov</b> that even a small perforation of the spinal cord renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rav Huna says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And how much is</b> considered <b>a majority of</b> the spinal cord to render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>? <b>Rav says: A majority of</b> the circumference of <b>its</b> surrounding membranes, the <b>meninges. And some say a majority of the nerve tissue of</b> the spinal cord itself. In other words, even if the meninges are intact, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if a majority of the nerve tissue is cut.
The Gemara notes: According to <b>the one who says</b> that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if <b>a majority of the nerve tissue</b> is severed, <b>all the more so</b> if <b>a majority of the meninges</b> is cut, since if the meninges, the protective membranes, are damaged, the nerve tissue itself will certainly be damaged soon thereafter. But <b>according to the one who says</b> that a tear in <b>a majority of the meninges</b> renders it a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in a case where only <b>a majority of the nerve tissue</b> was cut? Perhaps the intact membranes will keep the damage from spreading.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof: <b>As Nayyoli says</b> that <b>Rav Huna says: The majority of</b> the spinal cord, <b>which they said</b> renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> if cut, is <b>the majority of</b> the <b>meninges.</b> But <b>this nerve tissue makes no difference.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Natan bar Avin was sitting before Rav.</b> Rav Natan first <b>checked</b> the spinal cord to make sure that <b>a majority of</b> the <b>meninges</b> was intact, <b>and</b> then <b>was checking</b> to see that <b>a majority of its nerve tissue</b> was intact. Rav <b>said to him: If a majority of</b> the <b>meninges is intact, this nerve tissue makes no difference.</b>
§ <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> If the spinal cord <b>was liquefied [<i>nitmareikh</i>],</b> the animal is <b>unfit</b> for consumption. Even if it <b>softened [<i>nitmasmeis</i>],</b> the animal is <b>unfit,</b> i.e., a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>What is liquefaction, and what is softening? Liquefaction</b> is <b>any</b> case in <b>which</b> the nerve tissue becomes liquid, and if the membrane is punctured it can be <b>poured</b> out <b>like</b> water from <b>a jug. Softening</b> is <b>any</b> case in <b>which</b> the nerve tissue <b>cannot stand</b> upright on its own and sags when it is not being supported.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> In a case where the spinal cord became unusually heavy such that it <b>cannot stand</b> upright <b>due to its weight,</b> but not due to softening or melting, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara responds: The question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved. <b>In the study hall they say:</b> If the spinal cord <b>softened</b> due to disease, the animal is <b>unfit</b> for consumption. But if some of its tissue softened and <b>was emptied</b> from the spinal cord, the animal remains <b>kosher.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: An animal whose nerve tissue was emptied [<i>nitmazmez</i>]</b> from the spinal cord <b>is a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> version of the <i>baraita</i> is incorrect. In fact, the word <b>softened [<i>nitmasmes</i>] was stated,</b> not the word emptied.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so,</b> that an animal whose nerve tissue has dissolved is kosher? <b>But didn’t</b> it happen that <b>Levi was sitting in the bathhouse,</b> where <b>he saw a certain man who banged his head</b> severely, whereupon <b>he said: This</b> man’s <b>nerve tissue has</b> softened and <b>been emptied?</b> Is it <b>not</b> that Levi meant <b>that</b> the man <b>cannot live?</b> If so, the softening and emptying of the nerve tissue should render an animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Abaye said: No,</b> he intended <b>to say that</b> the man <b>cannot reproduce,</b> since head trauma might lead to infertility.
§ The Gemara asks: <b>Until where</b> does the <b>spinal cord</b> extend downward, such that if it is cut above that point the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>? <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Until</b> the point <b>between the branches</b> of the spinal cord that split off behind the thighs.
The Gemara recounts: <b>Rav Dimi bar Yitzḥak wanted to go to Bei Ḥozai. He came before Rabbi Yehuda</b> and <b>said to him: Master, show me, where</b> is the area <b>between the branches</b> to which Shmuel referred? Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to him: Go bring me a kid and I will show you.</b> Rav Dimi bar Yitzḥak <b>brought him</b> a choice <b>kid</b> with much <b>fat.</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to him:</b> The location <b>is buried very</b> deep in the fat <b>and</b> is <b>not recognizable. He brought</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>a lean</b> kid. Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to him:</b> The bones <b>jut out very</b> far, <b>and</b> the location is <b>not recognizable.</b>
Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to him: Come, I will teach you a tradition</b> without showing you: <b>This</b> is what <b>Shmuel said:</b> There are three successive points around the same bone behind the pelvis at which branches diverge from the spinal cord. If the spinal cord is cut anywhere <b>until the first</b> gap between these branches, the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> If it is severed anywhere after <b>the third</b> gap, i.e., after the third branch, the animal is <b>kosher.</b> If it was severed within the <b>second</b> gap, i.e., between these areas, <b>I do not know</b> the <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raises a dilemma:</b>

Daf 46a

When Shmuel says that the animal is certainly a <i>tereifa</i> if the spinal cord is cut anywhere <b>until</b> the first gap, does he mean <b>until and including</b> the first gap, in which case if it is cut within the first gap the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>? <b>Or perhaps</b> he means <b>until and not including</b> the length of the gap itself?
<b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: If you say</b> that Shmuel means <b>until and not including</b> the length of the first gap, and if the spinal cord is cut in the first gap the <i>halakha</i> is unknown, then if the spinal cord was cut in <b>the mouth of</b> the first <b>branch,</b> exactly where it branches off, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is it considered to be within the first gap, in which case the <i>halakha</i> is unknown? Or is it considered before the gap, in which case a tear in the mouth renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma: If you say</b> that Shmuel means <b>until and including the measure</b> of the first gap, and if the spinal cord is cut in the first gap the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, then if the first <b>branch itself,</b> i.e., the first pair of branching nerves, was cut from the spinal cord, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The branch</b> of the spine that was cut <b>shall be considered as</b> normal <b>flesh,</b> not as the spine. Therefore, it does not render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, unlike the spinal cord itself. <b>What, is it not</b> referring even to the <b>first or second branch?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring only to the <b>third</b> branch. But if either of the first two pairs of nerves that branch off from the spinal cord are cut, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>With regard to a bird,</b> the Sages disagreed as to the lower boundary of the spinal cord, above which if it is cut, the bird will be rendered a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rabbi Yannai says:</b> The spinal cord extends until <b>below the</b> level of the <b>wings. And Reish Lakish says: Until</b> the point <b>between the wings,</b> not below them.
<b>Ulla says: I was standing before</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>ben Pazi, and they brought before him a bird</b> whose spine had been injured, <b>and he checked until</b> the point <b>between the wings. And</b> at that point a messenger <b>of the house of the <i>Nasi</i> sent for him, and he got up and went, and I do not know if</b> he left <b>because one does not need to check beyond</b> that point, <b>or</b> if <b>due to the honor of the <i>Nasi</i></b> he left without completing the inspection.
§ The mishna states: If <b>the liver was removed</b> and nothing remained of it, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara asks: It follows, <b>therefore,</b> that if <b>anything remained of it,</b> the animal is <b>kosher, even if</b> the remaining piece <b>does not constitute an olive-bulk. But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna on 54a: If <b>the liver was removed and an olive-bulk of it remained,</b> it is <b>kosher?</b> One can infer that if less remained, it is a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. This</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> while <b>that</b> mishna later in the chapter is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. This is <b>like that</b> incident in which an amount smaller than an olive-bulk remained of the liver, and <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya discarded it,</b> as he holds that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>but Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>dipped it</b> in a seasoning and ate it. <b>And your mnemonic</b> to remember which Sage maintained which opinion is: <b>The rich are stingy.</b> Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, was wealthy, but he nevertheless did not allow the meat to go to waste.
The Gemara relates that <b>a certain</b> royal <b>army came to Pumbedita,</b> and <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef fled</b> the city, whereupon <b>Rabbi Zeira met them.</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to them: Refugees,</b> hear this <i>halakha</i>: The <b>olive-bulk that</b> the Sages <b>said</b> must remain of the liver so the animal will remain kosher must be <b>in the place</b> where the liver connects to the <b>gallbladder. Rav Adda bar Ahava says:</b> The olive-bulk must be <b>in the place that</b> the liver <b>lives,</b> i.e., is connected to the other organs, under the right kidney. <b>Rav Pappa said: Therefore,</b> in order to satisfy both opinions, <b>we require an olive-bulk in the place of the gallbladder, and we</b> also <b>require an olive-bulk in the place that it lives.</b> Otherwise, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> If the olive-bulk that remained was not all in one piece, but rather small pieces that could be <b>gathered</b> together to form the requisite measure, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Alternatively, if it was long and thin <b>like a strip, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Ashi raises a dilemma:</b> If the <b>olive-bulk</b> was <b>flat,</b> broad but thinner than an olive, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? To all these questions the Gemara responds: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rabbi Zerika asked Rabbi Ami:</b> If the <b>liver was detached</b> from the other organs in numerous places <b>and</b> was <b>attached</b> only <b>to its membranes [<i>betarpasheha</i>],</b> but the liver itself remained intact, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Ami <b>said to him:</b> With regard to the <i>halakha</i>, <b>I do not know what</b> the significance is of <b>this detachment</b> that you mentioned. <b>If</b> you rule <b>according to the one who says</b> that an olive-bulk must remain <b>in the place of the gallbladder, that is</b> the case here. And <b>if</b> you rule <b>according to the one who says</b> that it must be <b>in the place that it lives, that is</b> the case here as well. Consequently, there is no doubt that the animal is kosher.
§ The mishna states: <b>The lung that was perforated</b> renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara quotes <b>Rav and Shmuel and Rav Asi, who</b> all <b>say:</b> The mishna is referring specifically to the <b>outer membrane. And some say</b> that they said that the mishna is referring specifically to the <b>inner membrane. Rav Yosef bar Minyumi said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said: And your mnemonic</b> should be: The <b>red robe in which the lung rests.</b> The inner membrane is red, while the outer membrane is white, and according to Rav Naḥman, the mishna is referring to the inner membrane.
The Gemara comments: It is <b>obvious</b> that <b>if the outer</b> membrane <b>is perforated but the inner</b> membrane <b>is not perforated, the inner</b> membrane <b>protects</b> the lung, and the animal is kosher. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rabba, as Rabba says: This</b> animal with <b>a lung whose</b> outer membrane <b>was removed,</b>

Daf 46b

so that it looks <b>like a red date,</b> is <b>kosher;</b> all the more so is that the case if it was only perforated. But if <b>the inner</b> membrane <b>was perforated but the outer</b> membrane <b>was not perforated,</b> does the outer membrane <b>protect</b> the lung? <b>Or</b> does it <b>not protect</b> it, in which case the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>?
<b>Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree with regard to</b> this question. <b>One says:</b> It <b>does not protect</b> the lung; <b>and one says:</b> It <b>protects</b> the lung. <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that it <b>protects</b> the lung, <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rav Yosef. As Rav Yosef says:</b> With regard to <b>this lung that emits a sound</b> when inflated, <b>if we know</b> from <b>where it emits a sound, we set a feather, or saliva, or straw on</b> that point. <b>If</b> the saliva <b>bubbles</b> when the lung is inflated, the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> since this proves that the lung is perforated through both membranes. <b>And if not,</b> the animal is <b>kosher. And if we do not know</b> from <b>where it emits a sound, we bring a basin of tepid water and set</b> the lung <b>inside it.</b>
One <b>cannot</b> place it <b>in hot water, as it causes</b> the lung <b>to contract,</b> closing the perforation. And one <b>cannot</b> place it <b>in cold water, as it hardens</b> the lung and may cause it to crack. <b>Rather, we set it in tepid water and inflate it. If</b> the water <b>bubbles,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And if not,</b> the animal is <b>kosher,</b> since it is apparent that only <b>the inner</b> membrane <b>is perforated</b> and <b>the outer</b> membrane <b>is not perforated, and the</b> fact <b>that it emits a sound is</b> due to <b>the air</b> moving in the space <b>between</b> the two membranes. Evidently, Rav Yosef holds that if only the inner membrane is perforated, the animal is kosher.
§ The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> to remember the following statements of Rava with regard to the lung: <b>Dates, red, that dried, scabbed.</b>
The Gemara turns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> mentioned above: <b>Rava says: This</b> animal with <b>a lung whose</b> outer <b>membrane was removed</b> so that it looks <b>like a red date</b> is <b>kosher. And Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>a lung</b> whose outer membrane <b>reddened</b> due to bleeding of the lung, if only <b>part of it</b> turned red, then the animal is <b>kosher,</b> but if <b>all of it</b> turned red, the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
<b>Ravina said to Rava: What is the reason</b> that the animal is kosher if only <b>part of</b> the outer membrane reddened? Presumably, it is <b>because</b> the animal eventually <b>recovers</b> from the wound. But even if <b>all of it</b> turned red <b>as well,</b> the animal <b>recovers. Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one injures one of the eight impure creeping creatures mentioned in the Torah, one is liable for desecrating Shabbat; <b>but</b> if one injures <b>other repugnant creatures and creeping animals,</b> one is not liable <b>until blood leaves their</b> body as a result of the injury, even if their skin reddens as a result of internal bleeding?
<b>And if you would say: We compare</b> the lung <b>to</b> one of the <b>eight creeping creatures, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>the blood collected</b> under the skin of one of the eight creeping creatures, <b>even if it did not leave</b> the body, one is liable for desecrating Shabbat, because the blood will not be reabsorbed into the body and the wound is permanent; that is difficult: <b>If so,</b> then there is still no reason to distinguish between part of the lung and all of it, and <b>even</b> if only <b>part of</b> the lung turned red, the animal should be rendered a <i>tereifa</i> <b>as well,</b> because the blood will not be reabsorbed into the body. <b>Rather, there is no difference</b> between the reddening of part or all of the lung.
<b>And Rava says:</b> If <b>part of the lung was dried,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And how much</b> must the lung be dried so as to render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>? <b>Rav Pappi says in the name of Rava:</b> It must be <b>so</b> dry <b>that it can be crumbled with a fingernail.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this statement? Is it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei ben HaMeshullam? As it is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Bekhorot</i> 37a): If a kosher firstborn animal has a blemish, such as a dried ear, it may be slaughtered outside the Temple. <b>What is a dried</b> ear? It is any ear <b>that if perforated does not bleed a drop. Rabbi Yosei ben HaMeshullam says:</b> It must be <b>so dry that it can be crumbled with a fingernail.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the statement is in accordance with the opinion of the <b>Rabbis. With regard to the ear of a firstborn, which is exposed to the wind,</b> the Rabbis hold that the animal <b>would not recover</b> if it is so dry that it does not bleed. <b>But</b> with regard to the <b>lung, which is not exposed to the wind,</b> the animal <b>would recover</b> unless it is so dry that it can be crumbled with a fingernail. <b>And Rava says: This lung that stands</b> before us <b>covered</b> in <b>scabs,</b> or covered in <b>black</b> marks, or covered in sores with different <b>appearances,</b> is nevertheless <b>kosher.</b>
§ <b>Ameimar says in the name of Rava: One may not compare cysts</b> of the lungs. If one finds a perforated cyst on the lung, but does not know whether it was perforated before or after slaughter, he may not perform a test by perforating another cyst in order to compare their appearances.
<b>And Rava says: These two lobes</b> of the lung <b>that adhere to one another</b> by thin strands <b>have no</b> need for <b>inspection,</b> since it is certain that these adhesions arose due to a perforation of the lung, rendering the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara adds: <b>And we said</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to adhesions <b>that are out of order,</b> where a lobe adhered to a non-adjacent lobe. <b>But</b> with regard to adhesions that are <b>in order, that is their</b> normal manner of <b>growth,</b> and the animal is kosher.

Daf 47a

<b>And Rava says: These two cysts that are adjacent to one another</b> on the lung <b>have no</b> need for <b>inspection.</b> The animal is definitely a <i>tereifa</i>, since it is presumed that the cysts formed around a perforation in the lung. But if there is only <b>one</b> cyst that <b>looks like two,</b> due to a depression in the middle, <b>we bring a thorn and pierce it</b> to remove the fluid inside. <b>If</b> the fluids from either side <b>empty into one another,</b> this indicates that <b>it is one</b> cyst, <b>and</b> the animal is <b>kosher. And if not, they are two</b> separate cysts, <b>and</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
§ <b>And Rava says: The lung has five lobes [<i>unnei</i>].</b> When the animal hangs by its legs with <b>its face toward the person</b> checking it, he sees <b>three</b> lobes <b>on</b> his <b>right and two on</b> his <b>left.</b> If the animal is <b>missing</b> a lobe <b>or</b> has <b>an extra</b> lobe, <b>or</b> if the lobes were <b>switched,</b> with two on the right and three on the left, the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>a certain</b> lung that <b>had an extra</b> lobe <b>was brought before Mareimar. Rav Aḥa was sitting at the door</b> of Mareimar’s house. When the animal’s owner was leaving, Rav Aḥa <b>said to him: What did</b> Mareimar <b>say to you?</b> The man <b>said to him:</b> Mareimar <b>deemed it kosher.</b> Rav Aḥa was surprised by this, because it contradicts Rava’s statement, so <b>he said to him: Turn around</b> and <b>bring</b> the animal <b>before him.</b> The owner did so. Mareimar realized why he was being asked twice, and <b>said to him: Go tell whomever is sitting at the door: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava in</b> the case of an animal that has <b>an extra</b> lobe.
The Gemara adds: <b>And this statement</b> applies only <b>when</b> the extra lobe <b>stands in line with the</b> other <b>lobes,</b> on the left or right. <b>But</b> if it is <b>in between</b> the two sides, the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>a certain</b> animal with an extra lobe <b>in between</b> the two sides <b>was brought before Rav Ashi. Rav Ashi thought to deem it a <i>tereifa</i>. Rav Huna Mar bar Avya said to him: All those animals</b> that graze <b>outside</b> in the fields <b>have</b> extra lobes like <b>this, and butchers call it the little rose lobe.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>And this statement</b> applies only when the extra lobe is on the <b>inside</b> face of the lung, facing the heart.

Daf 47b

<b>But</b> if it is <b>on the back</b> of the lung, <b>even</b> if it is as small <b>as a myrtle leaf,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
§ <b>Rafram says: This lung that is similar to a chip</b> of wood renders the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that the similarity lies <b>in</b> its <b>appearance,</b> i.e., if it is pale like wood. <b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that it lies <b>in</b> its <b>feeling,</b> i.e., if it is hard like wood. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say that it is swollen. And there are</b> those <b>who say that it is light. And there are</b> those <b>who say that it is</b> completely <b>smooth, that it has no sectioning of lobes.</b>
§ <b>Rava says:</b> If the lung assumed a dark color <b>like eye shadow,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b> If its color is black <b>like ink,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. As Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> Menstrual blood that appears <b>black is</b> actually <b>red, except that it decayed.</b> Black color is therefore a sign of decay, and the lung is assumed to be defective.
The Gemara continues: If the lung was <b>green,</b> the animal is <b>kosher,</b> as can be derived <b>from</b> the episode <b>of Rabbi Natan.</b> And if it was <b>red,</b> it is <b>kosher,</b> as can be derived <b>from</b> the episode <b>of Rabbi Natan. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Natan says: Once I went to the cities overseas,</b> where <b>one woman came before me who circumcised her first son and he died,</b> and she circumcised her <b>second</b> son <b>and he died,</b> and out of concern that circumcising her <b>third</b> son might cause him to die as well, <b>she brought him before me. I saw that he was red,</b> so <b>I said to her: My daughter, wait for him until his blood is absorbed into him. She waited for him until</b> his blood was absorbed into him <b>and</b> then <b>circumcised him, and he survived. And they would call him Natan the Babylonian after my name.</b> This incident indicates that a red lung can heal.
Rabbi Natan further related: <b>And on another occasion I went to the state of Cappadocia,</b> and <b>a woman came before me who circumcised her first son and he died,</b> and she circumcised her <b>second</b> son <b>and he died.</b> Out of concern that circumcising her <b>third</b> son might cause him to die as well, <b>she brought him before me. I saw that he was green,</b> i.e., pale. <b>I looked at him and</b> saw that <b>he did not have the blood of circumcision in him,</b> i.e., he had a deficiency of blood such that no blood would emerge from the circumcision. <b>I said to her: My daughter, wait until his blood enters him. She waited for his</b> blood to increase <b>and</b> then <b>circumcised him, and he survived. And they would call his name Natan the Babylonian after my name.</b> This incident indicates that a green lung can heal as well.
<b>Rav Kahana says:</b> If the lung has an appearance <b>like the liver,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b> If it has an appearance <b>like flesh,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And your mnemonic</b> to remember that the latter is a <i>tereifa</i> is the verse: “You shall not eat any <b>flesh that is torn of animals [<i>tereifa</i>] in the field”</b> (Exodus 22:30).
<b>Rav Sama, son of Rava, says: This lung</b> whose appearance <b>resembles dodder, or saffron, or</b> has a yellow color <b>such as</b> that of <b>an egg</b> yolk, renders the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> Since all of these appearances are various shades of green, the Gemara asks: <b>But the green</b> lung <b>that is kosher, what is it like?</b> The Gemara responds: It is <b>like a leek.</b>
§ <b>Ravina says:</b> If there was <b>a sealed</b> area <b>in the lung</b> that does not inflate, <b>we bring a knife and tear it open. If there is pus in</b> the sealed area, then <b>it</b> was <b>definitely</b> sealed <b>due to the pus, and</b> the animal is <b>kosher. But if</b> we do <b>not</b> find pus there, <b>we lay a feather or saliva on</b> the opening and inflate the lung. <b>If</b> the saliva <b>bubbles</b> or the feather moves, the animal is <b>kosher,</b> since some air does reach the area, <b>and if not,</b> there is some defect in the lung, and the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef says: A membrane that appeared due to a wound in the lung,</b> i.e., a scab that covered a perforation through the lung, <b>is not</b> considered a true <b>membrane,</b> since it does not last. <b>And Rav Yosef says:</b> With regard to <b>this lung that emits a sound</b> when inflated, <b>if we know</b> from <b>where it emits a sound, we set a feather, or straw, or saliva on</b> that point. <b>If</b> the saliva <b>bubbles</b> when the lung is inflated, the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> since this proves that the lung is perforated through both membranes. <b>And if not,</b> the animal is <b>kosher. And if we do not know</b> from where <b>it</b> emits a sound, <b>we bring a basin of tepid water and set</b> the lung <b>inside it.</b>
One <b>cannot</b> place it <b>in hot water, as it</b> causes the lung to <b>contract,</b> closing the perforation. And one <b>cannot</b> place it <b>in cold water, as it hardens</b> the lung and may cause it to crack. <b>Rather, we check it in tepid water. If</b> the water <b>bubbles,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And if not,</b> the animal is <b>kosher,</b> since it is apparent that only <b>the inner</b> membrane <b>is perforated</b> and <b>the outer</b> membrane <b>is not perforated, and the</b> fact <b>that it emits a sound is</b> due to <b>the air</b> moving in the space <b>between</b> the two membranes.
§ <b>Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> An animal with <b>a lung that</b> liquefied and can be <b>poured</b> out <b>like</b> water from <b>a jug</b> is <b>kosher.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>Evidently,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>holds</b> that <b>a deficiency on the inside</b> of an organ <b>is not considered a deficiency.</b> Only a deficiency in the wall or membrane of an organ renders an animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rabbi Abba raised an objection to Ulla</b> from the mishna, which states: <b>The lung that was perforated or that was missing</b> a piece renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>What</b> is the case of a lung that was <b>missing</b> a piece? <b>If we say</b> that it was missing a piece <b>on the outside, this is</b> the same as if it <b>was perforated,</b> since any missing piece of the lung wall would constitute a perforation. <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a missing piece <b>on the inside?</b> If so, <b>learn from</b> the mishna that <b>a deficiency on the inside</b> of an organ <b>is considered a deficiency</b> to render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the mishna <b>actually</b> is referring to a missing piece <b>on the outside. And</b> with regard to <b>that which you said: This is</b> the same as if it <b>was perforated,</b> one may respond that <b>no,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to mention both cases to account <b>for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> in the mishna, <b>who says:</b> It is not a <i>tereifa</i> <b>until</b> the lung <b>is perforated</b> through <b>to the bronchi.</b> By mentioning both cases, the mishna teaches that <b>this statement</b> of Rabbi Shimon applies only to a small <b>perforation that does not constitute a deficiency. But</b> in the case of <b>a perforation</b> so large <b>that</b> it <b>constitutes a deficiency, even Rabbi Shimon concedes</b> that it renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> even if the perforation does not reach the bronchi.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Ḥananya became sick. Rabbi Natan and all the eminent</b> scholars <b>of the generation entered before him</b> to visit. <b>They brought before him a lung that</b> could be <b>poured</b> out <b>like</b> water from <b>a jug, and he deemed</b> the animal <b>kosher.</b>
<b>Rava said: This</b> is the <i>halakha</i> only if the <b>bronchi</b> still <b>exist</b> and only the flesh of the lung has liquefied. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: From where do we know</b> whether the bronchi still exist? Rav Ashi <b>said to him: We bring</b> a glazed <b>earthenware vessel</b> with no cracks, so the contents can be observed, <b>and we pour</b> the lung <b>into it. If there are white streaks in it,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> as the white streaks are remains of the liquefied bronchi. <b>And if not,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman says: If the lung</b> was partially <b>atrophied</b> and only part of the flesh remains, <b>but its membrane</b> still <b>exists,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If the lung was atrophied, but its membrane</b> still <b>exists, even</b> if the space vacated by the atrophied lung can <b>hold a quarter-</b><i>log</i> of fluid, the animal is <b>kosher.</b>

Daf 48a

If <b>its womb was removed,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b> If <b>its liver became infested by worms,</b> with regard to <b>this</b> there <b>was an incident, and the residents of Asia</b> Minor <b>went up</b> on <b>three occasions to</b> the great Sanhedrin in <b>Yavne</b> to inquire with regard to the <i>halakha</i>. On the first two occasions they did not receive an answer; on <b>the third occasion,</b> after the Sanhedrin had deliberated, <b>they permitted</b> the animal <b>to them.</b>
§ <b>Rav Yosef bar Minyumi says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> With regard to <b>a lung that is adjacent,</b> i.e., attached, <b>to the</b> ribs in the chest <b>wall, one</b> need <b>not be concerned about</b> the possibility that <b>it</b> became attached as a result of a perforation in the lung as opposed to some injury to the chest wall. But if <b>cysts</b> full of pus <b>sprouted</b> on the lung itself in the area of its attachment to the chest wall, <b>one</b> must be <b>concerned about</b> the possibility that <b>it</b> was perforated, and that this gave rise to the cysts. <b>Mar Yehuda says in the name of Avimi:</b> In <b>both this</b> case <b>and that</b> case, whether or not there are cysts on the lung, <b>one</b> must be <b>concerned about</b> the possibility that the lung was perforated.
The Gemara asks: <b>How do we perform</b> an examination to determine whether the injury is in the chest wall or the lung? <b>Rava said: Ravin bar Sheva explained</b> the procedure <b>to me: We bring a knife whose edge is</b> sharp and <b>thin, and we separate</b> the lung from the chest wall. <b>If there is a defect,</b> a wound or disease, <b>in the</b> chest <b>wall, we attribute</b> the attachment <b>to</b> the defect in the chest <b>wall. And if not,</b> we presume that the attachment is <b>due to</b> a defect in <b>the lung, and</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though</b> the lung <b>does not expel air</b> when inflated, since it is assumed that a scab covered the perforation, and a scab does not prevent the animal from being rendered a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Neḥemya, son of Rav Yosef, examined</b> such a lung by inflating it <b>in tepid</b> water to see if bubbles would appear. <b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Huna, son of Rav Pappi, said to Ravina:</b> Concerning <b>this</b> episode <b>of Rav Neḥemya, son of Rav Yosef, you teach it</b> as being <b>about this</b> case of a lung attached to the chest wall. But <b>we teach it</b> as being <b>about</b> the case <b>of Rava, as Rava says: These two lobes</b> of the lung <b>that adhere to one another have no</b> means of <b>inspection to deem them kosher.</b> Still, <b>Rav Neḥemya, son of Rav Yosef, examined</b> such a lung by inflating it <b>in tepid water.</b> If no bubbles appeared he would deem the lung kosher.
<b>Rav Ashi objects to this: What is this?</b> How can an animal with a lung whose lobes adhered to one another be permitted by means of such an inspection? <b>Granted, here,</b> in the case of a lung attached to the chest wall, <b>we attribute</b> the attachment to an injury <b>in the</b> chest <b>wall</b> rather than the lung, <b>and</b> the animal is <b>kosher. But there,</b> in the case of an adhesion between two lobes, what can be said? <b>If this</b> lobe <b>was perforated</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, and if that</b> lobe <b>was perforated</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> Even if a scab covers the perforation and prevents bubbles from appearing, the animal is still a <i>tereifa</i>.
Rav Naḥman stated that if there are cysts on the lung in the area of its attachment to the chest wall, one must be concerned about the possibility that the lung was perforated. Evidently, if the lung was perforated, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rav Naḥman</b> really <b>say this? But doesn’t Rav Yosef bar Minyumi say</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> If the <b>lung was perforated but the</b> chest <b>wall seals</b> the perforation, the animal is <b>kosher?</b> The Gemara responds: This is <b>not difficult. There,</b> Rav Naḥman is referring to a lung attached to the chest wall <b>in the place that it grows [<i>revita</i>]</b> naturally. In that case, if the chest wall seals the perforation it will remain sealed, and the animal can live. But <b>here,</b> Rav Naḥman is referring to a lung attached to the chest wall <b>not in the place that it grows.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>And where is the place that it grows?</b> It is the area of <b>the sectioning of the lobes,</b> i.e., the front of the lung where the lobes are adjacent to the chest wall on all sides.
§ Since the Gemara cited the statement of Rav Naḥman, the Gemara turns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav Yosef bar Minyumi says</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> If the <b>lung was perforated but the</b> chest <b>wall sealed</b> the perforation, the animal is <b>kosher.</b> With regard to this statement, <b>Ravina said: And this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when</b> the lung <b>is tangled in the flesh</b> of the chest wall, between the ribs. <b>Rav Yosef said to Ravina: And if</b> it is <b>not tangled, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. Evidently, we say</b> that the lung <b>is perforated.</b> But <b>if so, when it is tangled as well,</b> it should be deemed a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>As isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a man’s penis was <b>perforated,</b> he is <b>unfit</b> to marry a Jewish woman of fit lineage, <b>because</b> his semen <b>is discharged gently</b> and he cannot procreate, in accordance with the verse: “He that is crushed or maimed in his private parts shall not enter into the assembly of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:2). But if the perforation <b>was</b> later <b>sealed</b> with flesh, he is <b>fit, because</b> now <b>he can procreate. And this is</b> an instance of someone who is <b>unfit who returns to his</b> previous state of <b>fitness.</b> Rav Yosef continues: When the <i>baraita</i> states: <b>And this is, what does it</b> serve <b>to exclude?</b> Does it <b>not</b> serve <b>to exclude a case like this,</b> where the lung was perforated and then sealed by the chest wall, in which case the animal would not become kosher again?
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the phrase serves <b>to exclude a membrane that appeared due to a wound in the lung, which is not</b> considered <b>a membrane</b> that can seal a perforation, because it is temporary. By contrast, the flesh of the chest wall is considered a permanent seal on the lungs and renders the animal kosher.
<b>Rav Ukva bar Ḥama objects to</b> the ruling of Rav Naḥman that if a lung was perforated but the chest wall sealed the perforation, the animal is kosher: <b>If</b> flesh <b>in the</b> chest <b>wall was perforated against</b> the perforation in the lung, <b>what</b> would the <i>halakha</i> be? The animal would be <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> since air can now escape from the lung. Evidently, the question of whether the animal is permitted is dependent on the state of the chest wall. If so, <b>let</b> the mishna <b>teach,</b> in addition to the given list of <i>tereifot</i>: An animal <b>whose</b> chest <b>wall was perforated.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> one can also ask: The mishna states that if the gallbladder was perforated, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>That which Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> with regard to this, that if the <b>gallbladder was perforated but the liver sealed</b> the perforation the animal is <b>kosher,</b> is difficult. <b>If the liver were perforated against</b> the perforation in the gallbladder, <b>what</b> would the <i>halakha</i> be? The animal would be <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> If so, <b>let</b> the mishna also <b>teach:</b> An animal <b>whose liver was perforated.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> one must say that the mishna <b>does not teach</b> cases <b>where</b> the <b>perforated</b> organ is <b>not</b> the one <b>by which</b> the animal <b>is rendered a <i>tereifa</i>. Here, too,</b> in the case of a lung sealed by the chest wall, <b>since</b> the perforated organ, i.e., the chest wall, is <b>not</b> the one <b>by which</b> the animal <b>is rendered a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> the mishna <b>does not teach</b> it.
§ <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana asked Shmuel:</b> If the lung <b>grew cysts</b> full of pus, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Shmuel <b>said to him:</b> The animal is <b>kosher.</b> Rabba bar bar Ḥana <b>said to him</b> in reply: <b>I also say so,</b> that the animal is kosher, <b>except that the students doubt the matter, as Rav Mattana says:</b> If the cyst was <b>full of pus,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>;</b> if it was full of <b>clear fluid,</b> it is <b>kosher.</b> Shmuel <b>said to him: That</b> <i>halakha</i> of Rav Mattana <b>was stated</b> with regard to a cyst <b>on the kidney,</b> not on the lung.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosef was walking after Rabbi Yirmeya in the butchers’ market. He saw these</b> lungs <b>that were full of cysts,</b> and he wished to determine the <i>halakha</i> with regard to them. <b>He said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>Doesn’t</b> the <b>Master desire a piece of meat?</b> If so, meat from those animals is for sale. Rabbi Yirmeya, not wanting to issue a ruling with regard to the meat, <b>said to him: I have no money.</b> Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosef <b>said to him: I will</b> buy them for you on <b>credit.</b> Rabbi Yirmeya realized that he could not avoid issuing a ruling, so <b>he said to him: What can I do for you? As when</b> people <b>came before Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> with such lungs, <b>he</b> would <b>send them before Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon, who</b> would <b>instruct</b> them <b>in</b> such cases <b>in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, to permit</b> the meat for consumption. <b>But</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>himself does not hold accordingly,</b> and does not permit the meat. I practice stringency in accordance with his opinion.
<b>Rava said: When we would walk after Rav Naḥman in the market</b>

Daf 48b

<b>of the skinners, and some say in the market of the Sages, he would see</b> these lungs <b>that were full of jugs,</b> i.e., they were covered in large cysts full of liquid, <b>and he</b> would <b>not say anything to</b> the butchers. Evidently, he held that the animals were kosher.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi were passing through the market of Tiberias. They saw these</b> lungs <b>that were full of rocks,</b> i.e., large, hard growths, <b>and they did not say anything to</b> the butchers. Evidently, they held that the animals were kosher.
§ It <b>was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagree with regard to <b>a needle that was found in the lung</b> of a slaughtered animal: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Ḥanina deem</b> the animal <b>kosher,</b> while <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish and Rabbi Mani bar Pattish and Rabbi Shimon ben Elyakim deem</b> it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>they disagree about this: That</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., those who deem it a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>a deficiency on the inside</b> of the lung, created by the needle, <b>is considered a deficiency,</b> rendering the animal a <i>tereifa</i>; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., those who deem it kosher, <b>holds</b> that <b>it is not considered a deficiency.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>No, everyone</b> holds that <b>a deficiency on the inside is not considered a deficiency. And here,</b> in the case of a needle, the Sages <b>disagree with regard to this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> i.e., those who deem it kosher, <b>holds</b> that the needle <b>took the respiratory route and came</b> into the lung without perforating the membrane; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., those who deem it a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>it perforated</b> its way out of the digestive system <b>and came</b> through to the lung by perforating its membrane.
The Gemara relates that <b>a certain needle was found in a piece of lung</b> after it had been cut into pieces. People there <b>brought it before Rabbi Ami,</b> and <b>he thought to deem it kosher. Rabbi Yirmeya, and some say Rabbi Zerika, raised an objection to</b> this possible ruling from the mishna: <b>The lung that was perforated or that was missing</b> a piece renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. Now, <b>what</b> is the case of a lung that was <b>missing</b> a piece? <b>If we say</b> that it was missing a piece <b>on the outside, this is</b> the same as if it <b>was perforated,</b> since any missing piece of the lung wall constitutes a perforation. <b>Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> referring to a missing piece <b>on the inside?</b> If so, <b>learn from</b> the mishna that <b>a deficiency on the inside</b> of an organ <b>is considered a deficiency,</b> and the needle certainly caused a deficiency inside the lung.
Rabbi Ami did not decide the matter, so <b>they then sent</b> the lung <b>before Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa. He,</b> too, <b>thought to deem it kosher. Rabbi Yirmeya, and some say Rabbi Zerika, raised an objection to this</b> from the mishna: <b>The lung that was perforated or that was missing</b> a piece renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. Now, <b>what</b> is the case of a lung that was <b>missing</b> a piece? <b>If we say</b> that it was missing a piece <b>on the outside, this is</b> the same as if it <b>was perforated. Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> referring to a missing piece <b>on the inside?</b> If so, <b>learn from</b> the mishna that <b>a deficiency on the inside</b> of an organ <b>is considered a deficiency.</b>
<b>They then sent</b> the lung <b>back before Rabbi Ami, and he deemed</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. They said to him: But don’t the Rabbis,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan, Rabbi Elazar, and Rabbi Ḥanina, <b>deem it kosher?</b> Rabbi Ami <b>said to them: They deemed it kosher since they knew for which reason they deemed it kosher.</b> They were confronted with a whole lung and could see that it had no perforation. But <b>we, for which reason shall we deem it kosher?</b> We see only part of the lung. <b>Perhaps if the</b> whole <b>lung was before us</b> we would see that its membrane <b>was perforated.</b>
The Gemara asks: One can infer that the <b>reason</b> he deemed it a <i>tereifa</i> is <b>that</b> the entire lung <b>was not</b> before him, <b>but</b> if it <b>had been</b> before him <b>and</b> the membrane <b>had not been perforated,</b> then he would have deemed the animal <b>kosher. But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say: This bronchus of the lung that was perforated</b> renders the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>?</b> Accordingly, even if the needle entered the lung through a bronchus the animal ought to be a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> statement of Rav Naḥman <b>was stated</b> in reference <b>to</b> a case where a needle pierced from one bronchus into <b>another.</b> Since the bronchi are hard, one bronchus cannot seal a perforation in another. By contrast, when a needle perforates the bronchi and continues into the flesh of the lung, soft tissue left behind can seal the perforation.
The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rav Naḥman say:</b> If <b>this spiral colon was perforated against another</b> coil of the intestine, the other coil <b>protects it</b> by sealing the perforation? If so, why does a bronchus not seal a perforation in another bronchus? <b>Rav Ashi said: Are</b> you <b>comparing <i>tereifot</i> to one another? One cannot say with regard to <i>tereifot</i>: This is similar to that, as one cuts</b> an animal <b>from here,</b> in one place, <b>and it dies,</b> while <b>one cuts it from there,</b> in another place, <b>and it lives.</b>
The Gemara recounts the case of <b>a certain needle that was found in the large,</b> i.e., main, <b>bronchus of the lung. They brought it before the Rabbis who deem</b> an animal <b><i>tereifa</i></b> if a needle is found in the lungs, i.e., Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, Rabbi Mani bar Pattish, and Rabbi Shimon ben Elyakim. <b>They did not say</b> that <b>it</b> was <b>prohibited, nor</b> that it was <b>permitted. They did not say it</b> was <b>permitted, in accordance with their ruling,</b> but <b>they also did not say it</b> was <b>prohibited since</b> the needle <b>was found in the large bronchus,</b> and one can therefore <b>say</b> that it likely <b>took the respiratory route and came</b> into the lung rather than perforating through from the digestive system.
§ The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain needle that was found in a piece of liver. Mar, son of Rav Yosef, thought to deem</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. Rav Ashi said to him: If</b> a needle <b>had been found in the flesh, like this case</b> where it was found in the liver, <b>would</b> the <b>Master have deemed it a <i>tereifa</i>?</b> A perforated liver, like perforated flesh, does not in itself render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, as is evident from the mishna (42a). <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said</b> that <b>we see: If the eye</b> of the needle faces <b>outward,</b> toward the stomach cavity, one must presume that <b>it perforated</b> its way out of the gullet, rendering the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>and</b> thereby <b>came</b> to the liver. <b>If the eye</b> of the needle faces <b>inward,</b> buried in the liver, and the sharp end of the needle is facing outward, one may presume that <b>it took hold of</b> a blood <b>vessel and came</b> to the liver through it, rather than through the gullet, and the animal is kosher.
The Gemara adds: <b>And this statement</b> applies only <b>to a thick</b> needle, the eye of which is not sharp enough to cause a perforation by itself. <b>But</b> if the needle is <b>thin,</b> it <b>is no different if the eye</b> faces <b>inward</b> and it <b>is no different if the eye</b> faces <b>outward,</b> and one must presume that <b>it perforated</b> its way out of the gullet <b>and</b> thereby <b>came</b> to the liver.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> that of <b>a needle that is found</b>

Daf 49a

embedded <b>in the thickness of</b> the wall of <b>the reticulum,</b> where the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: If the needle protrudes <b>from one side,</b> i.e., the inner side of the stomach wall, the animal is <b>kosher,</b> but if it protrudes <b>from both sides,</b> it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>; and</b> if it protrudes only on the inside <b>we do not say: See if the eye</b> of the needle is facing <b>outward or if the eye</b> of the needle is facing <b>inward?</b> Rather, the animal is deemed kosher even if the eye is facing outward, and that is not considered evidence that the needle perforated through the gullet into the chest cavity and then perforated the thickness of the reticulum.
The Sages <b>say</b> in response: <b>There,</b> in the case of the reticulum, <b>since there are food and liquid</b> present, one may <b>say that the food and liquid pushed</b> the eye of the needle through the stomach wall. Therefore, even if the eye points outward, one may still presume that the needle came from the inside, and the animal is kosher.
The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain needle that was found in the large duct of a liver. Huna Mar, son of Rav Idi, deemed</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> while <b>Rav Adda bar Minyumi deemed it kosher. They came</b> and <b>asked Ravina</b> about the issue, and <b>he said to them: Take the robe of those who deemed it a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> They must pay restitution to the owner of the animal, who was wrongfully forced to discard his kosher meat.
The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain</b> date <b>pit that was found in a gallbladder. Rav Ashi said: When we were in the house of Rav Kahana</b> as students, <b>he would say</b> with regard to such a case: <b>This</b> date pit <b>certainly took</b> the route <b>of</b> the <b>duct</b> connecting the liver and gallbladder <b>and came</b> through it to the gallbladder, as it is not sharp enough to have perforated the gallbladder from without. <b>Even though it</b> is large enough that it <b>does not exit</b> the gallbladder if one tries to squeeze it into the duct, one may still assume that the movements of the animal’s body gradually <b>cause it to slip</b> through the duct. The Gemara adds: <b>And this statement</b> applies only to the pit <b>of a palm,</b> i.e., of a date, <b>but</b> the pit <b>of an olive</b> is pointed. Therefore, one must be concerned that it <b>has pierced</b> the wall of the gallbladder, rendering the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ The Gemara returns to its discussion of the lung: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Why is</b> the lung <b>called <i>rei’a</i></b> in Hebrew? <b>Because it lights up [<i>me’ira</i>] the eyes</b> of one who eats it. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Is Rabbi Yoḥanan referring <b>to</b> a lung <b>eaten</b> as is, <b>or</b> is he referring to a lung eaten only <b>through</b> its treatment with certain <b>substances?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from that <b>which Rav Huna bar Yehuda says: A goose</b> may be purchased <b>for a dinar, but its lung</b> may be purchased <b>for four</b> dinars. <b>And if</b> it should <b>enter your mind</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan is referring <b>to eating</b> the lung without treating it, one has no incentive to buy a lung separately for more money. <b>Let him buy</b> the whole goose <b>for a dinar and eat</b> the lung that comes included. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that the lung gains special properties only <b>through</b> treatment with certain <b>substances,</b> and this treatment is the reason for the higher price.
§ The Gemara asks: If <b>the lung is perforated where the hand of the butcher handles</b> it after slaughter, <b>do we attribute</b> the perforation to the butcher’s handling, <b>or do we not attribute</b> the perforation to the handling, in which case the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>? <b>Rav Adda bar Natan says: We attribute</b> it to the butcher’s handling, while <b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, says: We do not attribute</b> it to the handling. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>we attribute</b> it to the handling.
<b>Rav Shmuel, son of Rabbi Abbahu, said:</b> My <b>father was</b> one <b>of the heads of the <i>kalla</i></b> lectures of <b>Rafram, and he said: We attribute</b> it to the handling. <b>They said this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>of Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari,</b> who held the opposite, <b>before</b> Rav Shmuel, <b>and he did not accept it.</b>
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya said: It stands to reason</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Grandfather,</b> i.e., Rav Adda bar Natan, <b>as we attribute</b> perforations <b>to a wolf.</b> If slaughtered meat is recovered from a wolf and found to have a perforation that would have rendered the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, one may attribute the perforation to the wolf and presume that it did not exist beforehand.
Furthermore, if a perforation was caused by <b>a worm [<i>murana</i>], Rav Yosef bar Dosai and the Rabbis disagree. One says</b> that the worm <b>emerged</b> from the lung and perforated it <b>before</b> the <b>slaughter,</b> and the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>and one says</b> that <b>it emerged after</b> the <b>slaughter,</b> and the animal is kosher. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that one presumes that <b>it emerged after</b> the <b>slaughter.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> An animal with a perforated lung is not a <i>tereifa</i> <b>until it is perforated</b> through to the bronchi. With regard to this, <b>Rabba bar Taḥlifa says</b> that <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says:</b> Rabbi Shimon meant specifically that it is not a <i>tereifa</i> <b>unless it is perforated</b> through <b>to the large bronchus,</b> from which the smaller bronchi branch out.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Aḥa bar Abba sat before Rav Huna, and he was sitting and saying: Rabbi Malokh says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> Rav Huna <b>said to him: Are you saying</b> this in the name of <b>Malokh the Arab? He says</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with Rabbi Shimon.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>When Rabbi Zeira went up</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found Rav Beivai, who was sitting and saying: Rabbi Malokh says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him:</b> On the <b>Master’s life, I and Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba and Rav Asi visited the place</b> of residence <b>of Rabbi Malokh, and we said to him: Did</b> the <b>Master say that</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon? And he said to us: I said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> Rav Beivai asked Rabbi Zeira: <b>And you, what</b> more do you have <b>in your possession</b> on this matter? Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: This</b> is what <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Ami says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
The Gemara rules: <b>And</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> Any perforation of the membranes of the lung renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ The mishna states: If <b>the abomasum was perforated,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. Concerning this, <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Naḥmani says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says:</b> With regard to <b>fat that is on the abomasum,</b> the <b>priests accustomed</b> themselves to consider <b>it permitted,</b> and they would eat it along with the rest of the abomasum, which was given to them from non-sacred animals as one of the gifts of the priesthood. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael that he says in the name of his forefathers. And</b> since there is a disagreement between the Sages with regard to this issue, <b>your mnemonic</b> to remember the lenient opinion is the idiom: <b>Yishmael the priest</b> generally <b>helps the priests.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is</b> this, i.e., where does Rabbi Yishmael help the priests? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the priestly benediction: <b>“So you shall bless the children of Israel”</b> (Numbers 6:23). <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: We learn</b> from this verse about <b>a blessing for Israel from the mouth of the priests,</b> but <b>we have not learned</b> about a blessing <b>for the priests themselves. When it says</b> afterward with regard to the priests: “And they shall put My name upon the children of Israel, <b>and I will bless them”</b> (Numbers 6:27), <b>you must say:</b> The <b>priests bless Israel, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, blesses the priests.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> a different interpretation: <b>We learned</b> from the verse about <b>a blessing for Israel from the mouth of the priests,</b> but <b>we have not learned</b> about a blessing for Israel <b>from the mouth of the Almighty. When it says</b> afterward: “And they shall put My name upon the children of Israel, <b>and I will bless them,” you must say: The priests bless Israel, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, affirms their</b> blessing. The word “them” is referring to Israel.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> then <b>from where does Rabbi Akiva</b> learn about <b>a blessing for the priests? Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> He learns it <b>from</b> God’s promise to Abraham: <b>“And I will bless them that bless you”</b> (Genesis 12:3). All who bless the Jewish people are blessed themselves.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> sense does only Rabbi Yishmael <b>help the priests,</b> given that Rabbi Akiva concedes that the priests are also blessed? The Gemara responds: He helps the priests in the sense <b>that he establishes the blessing for the priests in the</b> same <b>place,</b> the same verse, that one finds <b>the blessing of Israel,</b> indicating that they receive the same blessing.
It was stated that the priests accustomed themselves to permit the fat on the abomasum, in accordance with the statement of <b>Rabbi Yishmael that he says in the name of his forefathers.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is</b> this statement? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that when the verse states with regard to forbidden fats mentioned in the Torah: <b>“All the fat that is upon the innards”</b> (Leviticus 3:3),

Daf 49b

the word “all” serves <b>to include</b> the <b>fat that is on the small intestines;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The word “all” serves <b>to include</b> the <b>fat that is on the abomasum.</b> According to Rabbi Yishmael, the fat of the abomasum is permitted.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “The fat that covers the innards, and all <b>the fat that is upon the innards”</b> (Leviticus 3:3). <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yishmael, <b>says: Just as the fat that covers the innards</b> possesses <b>a membrane, and</b> that membrane is easily <b>peeled</b> off, <b>so too, all</b> fat possessing <b>a membrane and</b> whose membrane is easily <b>peeled</b> is forbidden, including the fat on the abomasum. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: Just as the fat that covers the innards is spread out</b> loosely over them, and it possesses <b>a membrane, and</b> the membrane is easily <b>peeled</b> off, <b>so too, all</b> fat that is <b>spread out</b> loosely, and possesses <b>a membrane, and</b> whose membrane is easily <b>peeled,</b> e.g., the fat on the intestines, is forbidden. The fat on the abomasum is fixed tightly and is therefore permitted. It would seem from this <i>baraita</i> that Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yishmael contradict themselves.
<b>Ravin sent</b> an answer <b>in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Such is the</b> proper <b>layout of the mishna,</b> i.e., the <i>baraita</i>. The latter attribution of the opinions is correct, <b>and</b> one must <b>reverse</b> the attribution of opinions in <b>the first</b> <i>baraita</i>. Accordingly, Rabbi Akiva deems the fat on the intestines prohibited, while Rabbi Yishmael deems the fat on the abomasum prohibited as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>What did you see that</b> led <b>you</b> to <b>reverse the first</b> <i>baraita</i>? Why not <b>reverse the second</b> <i>baraita</i> instead? The Gemara responds: The second <i>baraita</i> <b>here is different, since it teaches</b> using the formula: <b>Just as.</b> Because it takes care to <b>specifically</b> provide the textual justifications for the opinions, it is presumably accurate about the attributions as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> how can Rabbi Oshaya claim above that the priests acted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael? It</b> was actually <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> Rabbi Oshaya meant only <b>that</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>says</b> the lenient opinion <b>in the name of his forefathers, but</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>himself does not hold accordingly,</b> and he considers the fat of the abomasum forbidden.
§ The Gemara discusses a connection between the issue of fats and that of <i>tereifot</i>: <b>Rav says: Kosher fat</b> effectively <b>seals</b> a perforation that it covers, and the animal is not rendered a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Non-kosher</b> fat <b>does not</b> effectively <b>seal</b> a perforation, and the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And Rav Sheshet says: Both this and that</b> fat effectively <b>seal</b> a perforation.
<b>Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to the <b>fat of an undomesticated animal,</b> all of which is permitted for consumption, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Shall one say that Rav <b>specifically said</b> that <b>kosher fat seals</b> a perforation, <b>and</b> since <b>this too,</b> i.e., all the fat of an undomesticated animal, <b>is kosher,</b> it is all considered an effective seal? <b>Or perhaps</b> Rav specified that permitted fat of a domesticated animal seals a perforation only <b>because it is</b> firmly <b>attached. But this,</b> the fat on the innards of an undomesticated animal, <b>is not</b> firmly <b>attached,</b> and it is not an effective seal, even though it is permitted for consumption.
<b>Abaye said: Why</b> does Rabbi Zeira <b>raise this dilemma? Granted that</b> the fat of the innards is <b>permitted for consumption,</b> but still, <b>it is not</b> firmly <b>attached</b> and clearly does not form an effective seal.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain perforation that was sealed by non-kosher fat that came before Rava. Rava said: With regard to what</b> need <b>we be concerned? First, doesn’t Rav Sheshet say: Non-kosher fat also</b> effectively <b>seals</b> a perforation? <b>And furthermore,</b> in general, <b>the Torah spares the money of the Jewish people,</b> and it is appropriate to rule leniently in this regard. <b>Rav Pappa said to Rava:</b> But there is also the opinion of <b>Rav</b> that non-kosher fat does not seal a perforation, <b>and</b> this dispute concerns <b>a prohibition by Torah law, and</b> yet <b>you say</b> that <b>the Torah spares the money of the Jewish people?</b> One cannot rely on this principle to rule in accordance with the lenient opinion with regard to such matters.
The Gemara relates a similar episode: <b>Manyumin the jug maker</b> had <b>a jug [<i>bisteka</i>]</b> full <b>of honey</b> that <b>was</b> left <b>uncovered,</b> and he was concerned it might have been contaminated by snake venom. <b>He came before Rava</b> to inquire as to the <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rava said: With regard to what</b> need <b>we be concerned? First, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 8:4): <b>Three liquids are prohibited due to exposure: Wine, water, and milk; and all other liquids are permitted.</b> Honey, therefore, is permitted. <b>And furthermore, the Torah spares the money of the Jewish people. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rava:</b> But there is also the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> that exposed honey is prohibited, <b>and</b> this dispute concerns a matter of <b>mortal danger, and</b> yet <b>you say</b> that <b>the Torah spares the money of the Jewish people?</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is</b> this opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Five</b> liquids <b>are not</b> subject to the prohibition of <b>exposure,</b> since snakes do not drink from them: <b>Fish brine, vinegar, oil, honey, and fish gravy [<i>morayes</i>]</b> made from fish brine mixed with oil and salt. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Even they are</b> subject to prohibition <b>due to exposure. And Rabbi Shimon said: I</b> once <b>saw a snake that drank fish brine in Tzaidan.</b> The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> That snake <b>was strange,</b> i.e., it behaved differently than other snakes, <b>and one does not bring a proof from strange</b> creatures.
Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak: <b>Concede to me, at least, with regard to fish brine</b> that it is not prohibited by exposure, <b>as when Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rabbi Yehoshua, and the Sages would have</b> a case of <b>exposure</b> of some liquid, <b>they would cast it into fish brine.</b> The sharpness of the brine neutralizes the snake venom. Accordingly, just as the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon with regard to fish brine, so too it is not in accordance with his opinion with regard to honey. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <b>said to him: Concede to me, at least, with regard to honey</b> that it is prohibited by exposure, <b>as Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar held in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And likewise, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar would deem</b> exposed <b>honey prohibited.</b>
The Gemara returns to the initial discussion with regard to fats and perforations: <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> Permitted <b>fat that is made like a hat does not</b> effectively <b>seal</b> a perforation, even though it is permitted for consumption. The Gemara clarifies: <b>Where</b> is this fat? <b>Some say</b> it is the <b>grains</b> of fat found <b>on the rectum,</b> which, if perforated, renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And some say</b> that it is <b>the membrane</b> surrounding <b>the heart,</b> which, if perforated to the chambers, renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ <b>Rava said: I heard from Rav Naḥman</b> about <b>two</b> fats found on the abomasum, in different places. One is called the <b><i>ḥimtza</i> and</b> one the <b><i>bar ḥimtza</i>,</b> meaning: Son of <i>ḥimtza</i>. <b>One</b> effectively <b>seals</b> a perforation of the abomasum, <b>and one does not</b> effectively <b>seal</b> a perforation of the abomasum. <b>But I do not know which of them</b> is which. <b>Rav Huna bar Ḥinnana and Rav Huna, son of Rav Naḥman, said:</b> The <b><i>bar ḥimtza</i> seals;</b> the <b><i>ḥimtza</i> does not seal. Rav Tavot said: And your mnemonic</b> is: <b>The power of the son is greater than the power of the father.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Which is the <i>ḥimtza</i> and which is the <i>bar ḥimtza</i>?</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from that <b>which Rav Naḥman says</b> with regard to one of the fats on the abomasum. Can it be that <b>they,</b> the residents of Eretz Yisrael, <b>eat</b> it, considering it permitted for consumption,

Daf 50a

<b>and to us,</b> the residents of Babylonia, not only is it forbidden but <b>it also does not seal</b> a perforation? It cannot be that this fat is forbidden by Torah law if they permit it for consumption. Even though we are stringent with regard to its consumption, we may still maintain that it effectively seals a perforation.
The Gemara explains: The abomasum is shaped like a bow. The side facing outward is curved like the bow itself, while the side facing inward is flat and straight like the bowstring. With regard to the fat <b>that is on the bow, everyone agrees,</b> even the residents of Eretz Yisrael, <b>that it is forbidden</b> for consumption. This fat, then, is the <i>ḥimtza</i>, which does not seal a perforation according to Rav Naḥman. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is with regard to the fat <b>that is on the bowstring.</b> The residents of Eretz Yisrael permit it for consumption, while those of Babylonia prohibit it. According to Rav Naḥman, the residents of Babylonia should concede that it is nevertheless an effective seal. This, then, is the <i>bar ḥimtza</i>.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that with regard to the fat <b>that is on the bowstring, everyone agrees that it is permitted.</b> This, then, is the <i>bar ḥimtza</i>. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is with regard to the fat <b>that is on the bow.</b> The residents of Eretz Yisrael permit it, but the residents of Babylonia prohibit it. This, then, is the <i>ḥimtza</i>.
The Gemara adds: When it was stated that only the residents of Eretz Yisrael permit the fat on the bowstring for consumption, this means that they would eat it in a manner <b>like that which Rav Avya says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami says:</b> One <b>takes a handful</b> of the fat that lies above the fat on the bowstring, since this is the fat prohibited by the verse: “And all the fat that is upon the innards” (Leviticus 3:3), and the rest is permitted for consumption. <b>And so says Rabbi Yannai,</b> also a resident of Eretz Yisrael, <b>in the name of a certain elder:</b> One <b>takes a handful. Rav Avya said: I was standing before Rabbi Ami.</b> The people there <b>took a handful</b> of the fat on the bowstring <b>and gave him</b> the remaining fat, <b>and he ate</b> from it.
The Gemara relates: <b>The attendant of Rabbi Ḥanina was standing before Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> a resident of Eretz Yisrael. Rabbi Ḥanina <b>said to him: Take</b> off <b>a handful</b> from that fat on the bowstring and <b>give me</b> the rest so <b>that I will eat</b> from it. Rabbi Ḥanina <b>saw that</b> the attendant <b>was hesitating,</b> so <b>he said to him: You are a Babylonian</b> and usually consider all of this fat forbidden. If so, <b>cut</b> off all the fat and <b>throw it</b> away.
§ The mishna states that if the small intestines are perforated, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. With regard to this, <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> If the <b>intestines were perforated but mucus seals</b> the perforated intestines, the animal is <b>kosher.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is this <b>mucus? Rav Kahana said:</b> It is the <b>mucus of the intestines that comes out under pressure,</b> when one scrapes with a knife.
The Gemara relates: <b>The colleagues of Rabbi Abba learned</b> a tradition <b>from Rabbi Abba. And who are they?</b> The phrase: Colleagues of Rabbi Abba, is referring to <b>Rabbi Zeira. And some say the colleagues of Rabbi Zeira</b> learned it <b>from Rabbi Zeira. And who are they?
