Rabbi Abba.</b> This is the tradition: <b>Rabbi Abba, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, said</b> that <b>this</b> is what <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, and</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>mourning.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>; this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>that we stated</b> above, that mucus forms an effective seal in the intestines. The <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon with regard to mourning; what is</b> this <i>halakha</i>? <b>As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one learns of the death of an immediate relative after other relatives have already begun their period of mourning, the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: During <b>the entire first three days</b> of mourning, if a mourner <b>comes</b> to the house of mourning <b>from a nearby place, he counts</b> his days of mourning <b>with</b> the other mourners and completes his mourning with them.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If he came <b>from a distant place, he counts</b> seven days <b>on his own</b> from the time that he was informed of the death. <b>From this</b> point <b>forward,</b> i.e., after the first three days, <b>even if he comes from a nearby place, he counts</b> seven days <b>on his own. Rabbi Shimon says: Even on the seventh day,</b> if <b>he comes from a nearby place, he counts</b> and completes his mourning <b>with</b> the other mourners.
<b>Someone</b> whose name was not given <b>said: May I merit to go up</b> to Eretz Yisrael <b>and learn this <i>halakha</i> from the mouth of its Master. When he went up</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found Rabbi Abba, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba,</b> and <b>said to him:</b> Is it true that <b>the Master said</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>?</b> Rabbi Abba <b>said to him: This</b> is not true. Rather, <b>I said</b> just the opposite, that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not</b> in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, and even if mucus seals the perforation of the intestine, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>.
The anonymous man asked Rabbi Abba again: <b>What</b> about the other ruling reported in your name, that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon with regard to mourning;</b> is this accurate? Rabbi Abba <b>said to him: There are conflicting</b> opinions with regard to this matter, <b>as it was stated</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, <b>and so says Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> That is the <b><i>halakha</i>. But Rav Naḥman says:</b> That is <b>not</b> the <b><i>halakha</i>.</b>
The Gemara concludes: <b>And</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, and</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon with regard to mourning, in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Shmuel,</b> who <b>says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with the statement of the</b> more <b>lenient</b> authority <b>in</b> matters relating to <b>mourning.</b>
§ <b>Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya says: One may compare</b> perforations <b>in the intestines.</b> If one is unsure whether a perforation occurred before or after slaughter, one may make an additional perforation and compare the two. If their appearance is similar, one may conclude that the perforation occurred after slaughter, and the animal is kosher.
The Gemara relates: There were <b>certain</b> perforated <b>intestines that came before Rava.</b> Rava made other perforations and <b>compared them, but they were not similar. Rav Mesharshiyya, his son, came</b> and <b>rubbed</b> the new perforations, <b>and they were similar.</b> Rav Mesharshiyya therefore deemed the animal kosher. Rava <b>said to him: From where</b> did <b>you</b> know to do <b>this?</b> Rav Mesharshiyya <b>said to him:</b> I reasoned: <b>How many hands rubbed these</b> earlier perforations <b>before they came before</b> the <b>Master?</b> Therefore, I thought that if I handled the new ones, perhaps they would look similar. Rava <b>said to him: My son is as wise in</b> matters of <b><i>tereifot</i> as Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b>
Similarly, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar both say: One may compare</b> perforations <b>in the lung</b> to determine whether they occurred after slaughter. <b>Rava said: We said</b> this <b>only</b> when the two perforations are <b>on the same side</b> of the lungs. <b>But</b> one may <b>not</b> compare perforations <b>from</b> one <b>side to the</b> other <b>side.</b> The Gemara rules: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is: One may compare <b>even from</b> one <b>side to the</b> other <b>side,</b> and even <b>from a small</b> animal <b>to</b> another <b>small</b> animal, <b>or from a large</b> animal <b>to</b> another <b>large</b> animal, <b>but not from a large</b> animal <b>to a small</b> animal, <b>and not from a small</b> animal <b>to a large</b> animal.
Similarly, <b>Abaye and Rava both say: One may compare</b> severed or perforated areas <b>in the windpipe. Rav Pappa said: We said</b> this <b>only</b> when the two areas are <b>in the same segment</b> of the windpipe. <b>But</b> one may <b>not</b> compare <b>from</b> one <b>segment to</b> another <b>segment.</b> The Gemara rules: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is: One may <b>even</b> compare <b>from</b> one <b>segment to</b> another <b>segment, and from</b> one <b>subsegment,</b> i.e., a thin segment between the main segments, <b>to</b> another <b>subsegment, but not from a segment to a subsegment, and not from a subsegment to a segment.</b>
§ <b>Ze’eiri says:</b> If <b>the rectum was perforated,</b> the animal is <b>kosher, since the hips hold it up</b> and seal the perforation. <b>And</b> to <b>how much</b> of the rectum does this apply? <b>Rabbi Ilai says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If the rectum was perforated in <b>the place where</b> it <b>is attached</b> to the hips, even if it was perforated <b>in its majority,</b> the animal is kosher. If the perforation was <b>not in the place where</b> it <b>is attached</b> to the hips, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if it was perforated <b>in any amount.</b>
<b>The Sages said this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>before Rava in the name of Rav Naḥman.</b> Rava <b>said</b> to them: <b>Have I not told you not to hang on</b> Rav Naḥman

Daf 50b

<b>empty bottles,</b> i.e., not to falsely attribute statements to him? <b>So said Rav Naḥman:</b> With regard to <b>the place that</b> the rectum <b>is attached</b> to the hips, <b>even</b> if <b>all of it was removed,</b> the animal is <b>kosher. And this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> only <b>where sufficient</b> space <b>remains of it</b> for a hand to <b>grip.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> is considered sufficient to grip? <b>Abaye said: The width of a finger.</b> This measure is sufficient even <b>in</b> the case of a large <b>bull.</b>
§ The mishna states that if <b>the internal rumen</b> was perforated or most of the external rumen was torn, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. With regard to this, <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: Natan bar Sheila, chief butcher of Tzippori, testified before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>in the name of Rabbi Natan: Which is the internal rumen?</b> It is <b>the cecum. And so said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa:</b> It is <b>the cecum. Rabbi Yishmael said:</b> It is the <b>opening [<i>istumka</i>] of the rumen.</b>
<b>Rav Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> says: <b>There is a narrow place in the rumen,</b> and this is the internal rumen; all the rest is the external rumen. <b>But I do not know which</b> area <b>is</b> this narrow place. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: The rumen has fallen in a pit,</b> i.e., since it is unknown which area is considered the narrow place, a perforation in any part of the rumen renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav Ava says</b> that <b>Rav Asi says:</b> The inner rumen extends <b>from the narrow place,</b> where the rumen begins to narrow as it approaches the gullet, <b>and downward</b> toward the gullet when the animal is suspended by its legs.
<b>Rabbi Ya’akov bar Naḥmani says</b> in the name of <b>Shmuel:</b> The internal rumen is the <b>place</b> in the rumen <b>that has no wool,</b> i.e., downy projections on the inside of the rumen. <b>Rabbi Avina says</b> in the name of <b>Geneiva,</b> who said <b>in the name of Rav:</b> The <b>handbreadth in the gullet adjacent to the rumen, this is the internal rumen.</b>
<b>In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they said in the name of Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina: The entire rumen is the internal rumen. And</b> if so, <b>which is the external rumen?</b> It is the <b>flesh that envelops the majority of the rumen</b> on the underside of the animal. <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna says:</b> The internal rumen is the <b><i>mafrata</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the <i>mafrata</i>? Rav Avya said:</b> It is <b>the place that the butcher exposes</b> when he opens up the animal, i.e., the underside of the stomach.
The Gemara recounts: <b>In Neharde’a, they practiced in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna. Rav Ashi said to Ameimar,</b> one of the Sages of Neharde’a: <b>What</b> about <b>all these</b> other <b>statements,</b> that the internal rumen is another part of the rumen? Ameimar <b>said to him: They are all included in</b> the definition <b>of</b> the rumen according to <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna.</b> The cecum, the opening of the stomach, and the place with no wool all face the underside of the stomach, i.e., the <i>mafrata</i>.
Rav Ashi replied: <b>And what</b> about the opinion <b>that Rav Asi says</b> in the name of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> that the internal rumen is an unknown narrow area? Shouldn’t the entire rumen be treated as the internal rumen? Ameimar <b>said to him: Rav Aḥa bar Ava already explained</b> that <b>it</b> is the area extending from the narrow place until the gullet. This area is also included in the <i>mafrata</i>. Rav Ashi asked further: <b>And what</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Avina,</b> that the internal rumen is the handbreadth near the gullet, <b>and of the residents of the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, that it is the entire rumen? Ameimar <b>said to him: These</b> opinions <b>certainly disagree</b> with that of Rabba bar Rav Huna, but we do not follow them.
§ The mishna states: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to a tear in the external rumen, for <b>a large</b> animal, a tear of one handbreadth renders it a <i>tereifa</i>, while for a small animal, it is a <i>tereifa</i> only if most of it was torn. <b>Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The word: <b>Large,</b> is <b>not</b> referring <b>literally</b> to <b>a large</b> animal, and the word: <b>Small,</b> is <b>not</b> referring <b>literally</b> to <b>a small</b> animal. <b>Rather,</b> concerning <b>any</b> animal large enough that <b>its</b> external rumen can be <b>torn one handbreadth and</b> this <b>does not constitute most</b> of it, <b>this is what we learned:</b> For <b>a large</b> animal, a tear of <b>one handbreadth</b> renders it a <i>tereifa</i>. And concerning any animal small enough that <b>most</b> of its external rumen can be torn <b>and</b> this does <b>not constitute one handbreadth, this is what we learned: For a small</b> animal, it is a <i>tereifa</i> only if <b>most</b> of it was torn. In other words, any external rumen torn either one handbreadth or in its majority renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara asks: If <b>most</b> of the external rumen is torn <b>but</b> it does <b>not constitute a handbreadth,</b> isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that the animal is rendered a <i>tereifa</i>? There is a principle that the majority of an entity is considered like all of it. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this for a case <b>where</b> the tear would <b>constitute a handbreadth with any amount</b> more than a majority, i.e., the external rumen is slightly smaller than two handbreadths. <b>Lest you say</b> that in such a case, the animal <b>is not a <i>tereifa</i> until a handbreadth of it is torn,</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so. Rather, if the majority of the rumen is torn, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, even if this constitutes less than a handbreadth.
<b>Geneiva says</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi says:</b> If a round hole was <b>bored</b> through the external rumen <b>as</b> large as <b>a <i>sela</i></b> coin, the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, since if</b> a hole of such size <b>will be stretched, it will reach the</b> length of a <b>handbreadth. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said:</b> This matter <b>was explained to me</b> personally <b>by Geneiva</b> himself, when we were <b>on the ferry of Neharde’a:</b> If the hole is exactly as large <b>as a <i>sela</i>,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b> If the size of the hole is <b>greater than a <i>sela</i>,</b> it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> is considered <b>greater than a <i>sela</i>? Rav Yosef said: For example,</b> if <b>three</b> date <b>pits covered</b> in remains of the date can fit through the hole <b>with difficulty,</b> or if, <b>without</b> being <b>covered</b> in any remains, they can fit <b>comfortably,</b> this is considered a hole larger than a <i>sela</i>.
§ The mishna states: An animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if the <b>omasum or the reticulum</b> was perforated to the outside, i.e., to the abdominal cavity. With regard to this, <b>the Sages taught:</b> In the case of <b>a needle that is found in the thickness of the reticulum,</b> if it pierced the wall <b>from</b> only <b>one side,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b> If it pierced the wall <b>from both sides,</b> i.e., the needle completely pierced the wall of the stomach, it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> But even if it protrudes from both sides, it is not always a <i>tereifa</i>, and it may be inspected further: If <b>a drop of</b> congealed <b>blood is found on top of</b> the needle,

Daf 51a

<b>it is certain that</b> the perforation was created <b>before</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of the animal, and it is therefore a <i>tereifa</i>. If <b>a drop of blood is not found on it, it is certain that it</b> occurred <b>after</b> the <b>slaughter,</b> when the blood of the animal had stopped flowing. The animal is therefore kosher.
If <b>a scab covered the opening of the wound,</b> i.e., the perforation, <b>it is certain that</b> the perforation occurred <b>three days before</b> the <b>slaughter.</b> Consequently, if the animal was sold less than three days before the slaughter, the buyer can claim that the transaction was performed in error, as he did not intend to purchase a <i>tereifa</i> animal, and the seller must refund the buyer. If <b>a scab did not cover the opening of the wound,</b> and it is uncertain whether the perforation occurred before or after the animal was purchased, <b>the burden of proof rests upon the claimant.</b> Accordingly, the buyer must furnish proof that the perforation occurred before the purchase in order to demand a refund.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from all other perforations, where even though there is no blood</b> on the wound the <b>Master deems</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>There,</b> in all other cases, <b>there is nothing to</b> which the blood can <b>attach.</b> Even if the wound had bled, the blood would be reabsorbed into the flesh. <b>Here, since there is a needle,</b> it follows that <b>if it is</b> the case that the perforation occurred <b>before slaughter,</b> blood from the wound <b>would have attached</b> to the needle. Accordingly, if there is no blood on the needle, it is certain that the perforation occurred after slaughter.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Safra said to Abaye:</b> Did <b>the Master see a Torah scholar who came from the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>and said: My name is Rav Avira? He said</b> that there was <b>an incident that came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi involving <b>a needle that was found in the thickness of the reticulum</b> protruding <b>from</b> only <b>one side, and he deemed</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> Abaye <b>sent</b> a message <b>to</b> Rav Avira calling for him to come and explain the matter, since this contradicts the <i>baraita</i> that states that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> only if the needle protrudes from both sides. Rav Avira <b>did not come before him,</b> so Abaye <b>went before</b> Rav Avira. Rav Avira <b>was standing on the roof.</b> Abaye <b>said to him: Let Master descend and come,</b> but Rav Avira <b>did not descend.</b> Abaye <b>ascended to him</b> and <b>said to him: Say to me, what were the circumstances of the incident itself?</b>
Rav Avira <b>said to him: I am a director of assemblies</b> in the study hall. I was standing <b>above the Great Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and Rav Huna of Tzippori and Rabbi Yosei of Medea were sitting before him, and a needle came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>that was found in the thickness of the reticulum</b> protruding <b>from one side,</b> i.e., the inside, <b>and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>turned</b> the reticulum <b>over and found a drop of blood on</b> the outside, parallel to the wound on the inside, <b>and he deemed</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And he said: If there is no wound</b> on the outside <b>there</b> as well, <b>from where</b> is this <b>drop of blood?</b> Abaye <b>said to</b> Rav Avira: <b>He caused that man trouble</b> needlessly, i.e., you troubled me for no reason. <b>This is</b> nothing more than <b>the mishna,</b> which states that an animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if the <b>omasum or the reticulum was perforated to the outside.</b>
§ The mishna states: An animal that <b>fell from the roof</b> is a <i>tereifa</i>, since its limbs may have been shattered. <b>Rav Huna says:</b> If one <b>left an animal above,</b> on the roof, <b>and he came</b> back <b>and found it below,</b> but did not see it fall, <b>one</b> need <b>not be concerned with regard to the shattering of limbs.</b> One may presume that it jumped intentionally and was not injured.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain kid belonging to Ravina that saw barley groats through</b> an open <b>skylight. It jumped</b> down through the skylight and <b>fell from the roof to the ground.</b> The case <b>came before Rav Ashi,</b> and Ravina <b>said to him:</b> What is the rationale for <b>this</b> statement <b>that Rav Huna says,</b> that if one <b>left an animal above and he came</b> back <b>and found it below, one</b> need <b>not be concerned about the</b> possible <b>shattering of limbs?</b> Is it <b>because</b> the animal usually <b>has something to grab hold of?</b> If so, since <b>this</b> kid jumped through a skylight, it <b>did not have something to grab hold of,</b> and one must be concerned. <b>Or perhaps</b> it is <b>because</b> the animal <b>evaluates itself</b> and determines that it can jump without injury. If so, <b>this</b> kid <b>also evaluated itself</b> before jumping, and one need not be concerned.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>because</b> the animal <b>evaluates itself</b> before jumping, <b>and this</b> kid <b>also evaluated itself</b> before jumping. Therefore, one need not be concerned about the possible shattering of limbs.
The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain ewe that was</b> in <b>the house of Rav Ḥaviva, whose hind legs would drag. Rav Yeimar said: This</b> ewe <b>suffers from rheumatism</b> [<b><i>shigrona</i></b>], and this is why she drags her legs. <b>Ravina objects to this: But perhaps the spinal cord was cut,</b> and this is why the ewe dragged her legs, and the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>They inspected her and found</b> that the spinal cord was cut, <b>as Ravina</b> said. The Gemara notes: <b>And even so, the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yeimar,</b> since <b>rheumatism is common,</b> but a cut <b>spinal cord is not common.</b> Accordingly, one need not be concerned about the possibility of a cut spinal cord.
<b>Rav Huna</b> also <b>says:</b> With regard to <b>rams that butt one another, one</b> need <b>not be concerned with regard to shattering of limbs. Even though they are in pain and stand</b> still, it is <b>only a fever that afflicts them;</b> one need not be concerned about the possibility of severe injuries. But <b>if they fall to the ground</b> due to the impact, <b>we certainly must be concerned</b> that their limbs may have been shattered.
<b>Rav Menashei says:</b> With regard to <b>these rams that thieves steal</b> and throw over the fence, <b>one</b> need <b>not be concerned with regard to the shattering of limbs. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>When</b> the thieves <b>throw them</b> over the fence, <b>they throw them</b> so that they land <b>on their hips,</b> where they will not be injured, <b>so that they will</b> be able to <b>run before them.</b> But if the thieves <b>returned them</b> to the owner, <b>we certainly must be concerned</b> that their limbs may have been shattered, since thieves do not throw them carefully when returning them. <b>And this statement</b> applies only <b>when they return them due to fear</b> of being caught, or are otherwise forced to return them. <b>But</b> if they return them <b>due to repentance, they have performed full-fledged repentance</b> and will take care to return them without injury.
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If <b>one hit</b> an animal <b>on its head</b> with a stick, <b>and</b> the length of the stick <b>continued toward its back;</b> or if one hit the animal <b>on its tail and</b> the length of the stick <b>continued toward its head,</b> such that in either case the blow extended <b>along the entire spine, one</b> need <b>not be concerned with regard to the shattering of limbs. But if the</b> length of the <b>stick concluded at the middle of the back, we</b> must be <b>concerned</b> that the strike caused an injury to the spine. <b>And if there are knots,</b> i.e., protrusions, <b>on</b> the stick, <b>we</b> must be <b>concerned</b> that it injured the spine, even if the stick fell across the entire back. <b>And if he struck it like a slash</b> across the width of the back, <b>we</b> must <b>be concerned</b> that it injured the spine.
§ <b>Rav Naḥman says: The womb is not subject to</b> concern about possible <b>shattered limbs.</b> In other words, one need not be concerned that the limbs of a newborn calf may have been shattered by the narrow birth canal. <b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman:</b> That which <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>supports your</b> opinion: <b>A one-day-old infant</b>

Daf 51b

<b>becomes</b> ritually <b>impure</b> if he experiences a gonorrhea-like <b>discharge [<i>ziva</i>]. And if it should enter your mind</b> that a newborn <b>is subject to</b> concern about possible <b>shattered limbs, read here</b> the ruling stated with regard to <i>ziva</i>, that one’s discharge renders one impure only when it issues <b>“out of his flesh”</b> (Leviticus 15:2), <b>but not</b> when it issues <b>due to circumstances beyond his control,</b> e.g., due to illness. Therefore, if one must be concerned that a newborn’s limbs may have shattered during birth, his discharge would not render him impure.
The Gemara responds: One cannot bring a proof from this <i>baraita</i>, since <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the infant <b>left</b> the womb <b>by caesarean section</b> and did not exit through the narrow birth canal. By contrast, after normal births, a newborn’s discharge does not render it impure, since one is concerned about the possibility of shattered limbs.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a calf was born on a Festival, one may slaughter it</b> and eat it <b>on</b> the <b>Festival.</b> One need not wait twenty-four hours before deeming the animal kosher, as one does for an animal that fell from a roof. Apparently, one need not be concerned that its limbs were shattered during the birth. The Gemara responds: <b>Here, too,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the calf <b>left</b> the womb <b>by caesarean section.</b> But after normal births, one must wait twenty-four hours before slaughtering the calf.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from another <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> all <b>agree that if</b> a firstborn animal <b>was born</b> on a Festival <b>and its blemish</b> was born <b>with it,</b> i.e., if it was born with a blemish that removes its sanctity and renders it permitted for consumption, <b>it is</b> considered to be <b>prepared</b> for the Festival and may be eaten. Evidently, one need not wait twenty-four hours before deeming it kosher. <b>And if you would say</b> that <b>here too,</b> the <i>baraita</i> deals with a case <b>where</b> the animal <b>left</b> the womb <b>by caesarean section,</b> one might respond: <b>Is</b> a firstborn animal born <b>by caesarean section sanctified? But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: Rabbi Shimon would concede with regard to sacrificial</b> animals, e.g., a firstborn, <b>that</b> an animal born by caesarean section <b>is not sanctified?</b> Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> must be referring to an animal born naturally.
The Gemara responds: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a firstborn <b>that spread out</b> its legs <b>on the ground</b> and stood up immediately after birth. In such a case the animal is certainly not a <i>tereifa</i> on account of shattered limbs.
§ <b>And Rav Naḥman says:</b> If an animal was thrown to the ground in <b>the slaughterhouse</b> in preparation for slaughter, it <b>is not subject to</b> concern for <b>shattered limbs.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>A certain bull fell</b> in the slaughterhouse, <b>and its bellowing was audible</b> due to the blow. Still, <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta entered</b> and <b>took from the very best</b> portions of the bull and was not concerned that it may have been a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>The Sages said to him: From where</b> did you learn <b>this?</b> Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta <b>said to them: This is what Rav said:</b> When falling, the bull <b>digs in its hooves until it reaches the earth.</b> Therefore, one need not be concerned that it fell roughly.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If an animal fell and <b>stood</b> up again, <b>it does not require</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> mentioned in the mishna (56b) to determine if it may be slaughtered. Nevertheless, <b>it certainly requires inspection</b> after slaughter to determine whether it was injured by the fall and rendered a <i>tereifa</i>. But if it both stood up and <b>walked</b> after the fall, <b>it does not</b> even <b>require inspection</b> after slaughter. <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi says: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case, i.e., even if it walked after the fall, <b>it requires inspection.</b>
<b>Rav Yirmeya bar Aḥa says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If the animal <b>stretched out its foreleg to stand, even if it did not</b> actually <b>stand,</b> it is considered to have stood and does not require a twenty-four-hour waiting period. If <b>it raised its leg to walk, even if it did not</b> actually <b>walk,</b> it is considered to have walked and does not require inspection according to Rav. <b>And Rav Ḥisda says:</b> Even if it did not stretch out its foreleg, but simply <b>struggled to stand, even if it did not stand,</b> it is considered to have stood and may be slaughtered that day.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is: In any case <b>where</b> an animal <b>fell from the roof unawares,</b> i.e., unintentionally, <b>and stood but did not walk,</b> it <b>requires inspection</b> after slaughter <b>but does not require</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period</b> before slaughter. <b>And if it walked, it does not even require an inspection.</b>
§ <b>Ameimar said in the name of Rav Dimi of Neharde’a: A fallen</b> animal <b>that</b> the Sages <b>said requires inspection</b> must be inspected <b>around the intestines</b> to see whether the organs there have been perforated or torn, rendering the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Mar Zutra said to him: This</b> is what <b>we say in the name of Rav Pappa:</b> Such an animal <b>requires inspection around the entire</b> space of the body <b>cavity,</b> in case the ribs or spine have been damaged.
<b>Huna Mar, grandson of Rav Neḥemya, said to Rav Ashi: What</b> about the <b>two organs that must be severed in ritual slaughter [<i>simanim</i>],</b> i.e., the windpipe and the gullet? Do they require inspection as well? Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> The <b><i>simanim</i> are hard</b> and resistant to damage <b>in falling.</b> Therefore, one need not inspect them.
§ With regard to birds that have fallen, <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: If a bird</b> fell and <b>hit the surface of the water, once it swims the full length of its</b> body, this <b>is sufficient</b> to indicate that its limbs have not been shattered, similar to an animal that walks after falling. <b>And we said</b> this <b>only</b> in cases where it swam <b>from below to above,</b> i.e., upstream. <b>But</b> if it swam <b>from above to below,</b> i.e., downstream, <b>it is</b> only <b>the water that carried it down,</b> and it must be inspected. <b>And if the water is standing,</b> e.g., in a pond, <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it,</b> as it is clear that the bird is swimming on its own strength, and it need not be inspected. <b>And</b> even if the bird swims downstream, <b>if straw was scattered</b> in front of it <b>and</b> the bird <b>overtook it</b> with its swimming, <b>then</b> the bird <b>overtook it</b> on its own strength and need not be inspected.
If the bird fell on <b>a garment</b> spread out <b>taut</b> over poles, <b>we must be concerned</b> that its limbs may have been shattered from the impact. If it fell on a garment <b>that was not taut, we</b> need <b>not be concerned.</b> In any event, if the garment was <b>folded, we</b> need <b>not be concerned,</b> since it presumably was not taut enough to injure the bird. If the bird fell on <b>a net whose knots were</b> woven <b>closely</b> together, <b>we must be concerned</b> that its limbs may have been shattered from the impact. If the <b>knots were not close</b> together, <b>we</b> need <b>not be concerned.</b>
If the bird fell directly on to <b>flax arranged into bundles, we must be concerned</b> that its limbs may have been shattered from the impact, because the bundles are hard. If it fell on <b>this side or that side</b> of the bundles, <b>we</b> need <b>not be concerned,</b> because it did not fall directly onto the bundles and the impact was dampened. If it fell on <b>bundles of reeds, we must be concerned.</b> If it fell on <b>beaten and combed flax,</b> with the impurities removed, <b>we</b> need <b>not be concerned,</b> since it is soft. If it fell on flax that was <b>beaten but not combed, we must be concerned</b> due to the residue of flax stalks in the bundles. If it fell on flax <b>that was bundled</b> after it was beaten and combed, <b>since it has knots</b> in it <b>we must be concerned.</b> If the bird fell on flax <b>tow,</b> a coarse bundle of unspun fiber, <b>we must be concerned.</b> If it fell on <b>fine tow, we</b> need <b>not be concerned,</b> because it is soft.
If the bird fell on <b><i>nevara</i>,</b> the fibers that grow around a palm tree, <b>we must be concerned</b> that its limbs may have been shattered. If it fell on <b><i>timaḥta</i>,</b> palm bark cut into strips, <b>we</b> need <b>not be concerned.</b> If it fell on <b>sifted ashes, we must be concerned,</b> because the ashes harden. If it fell on <b>unsifted</b> ashes, <b>we</b> need <b>not be concerned,</b> because they are soft and scatter on impact.

Daf 52a

If the bird fell on <b>fine sand, we</b> need <b>not be concerned,</b> because the sand slides on impact, cushioning the fall. If it fell on <b>coarse sand, we must be concerned,</b> because there are large stones mixed into it. If it fell on <b>dust of the road, we must be concerned,</b> because the dust is compact and hard. If the bird fell on <b>bundled straw, we must be concerned,</b> because it is compact and hard. If the straw <b>was not bundled, we</b> need <b>not be concerned.</b>
If the bird fell on <b>wheat and all</b> similar <b>types of</b> grain, such as spelt or rye, whose kernels are hard, <b>we must be concerned.</b> If it fell on <b>barley and all</b> similar <b>types of</b> grain, such as oats, <b>we must be concerned.</b> With regard to <b>all types of beans, there is no</b> concern <b>due to</b> possible <b>shattered limbs</b> if a bird fell <b>on them,</b> since their round shape causes the bird to slide when it hits them, <b>except for fenugreek.</b> With regard to <b>peas, there is no</b> concern <b>due to</b> possible <b>shattered limbs,</b> but <b>with regard to chickpeas, there is</b> a concern <b>due to</b> possible <b>shattered limbs. The principle of the matter</b> is: <b>With regard to anything that slips</b> to the sides on impact, <b>there is no</b> concern <b>due to</b> possible <b>shattered limbs.</b> And with regard to anything that <b>does not slip, there is</b> a concern <b>due to</b> possible <b>shattered limbs.</b>
If the bird’s wings became stuck to <b>a <i>davuk</i>,</b> a board covered with glue set as a trap, and in trying to escape it fell to the ground while stuck to the board, <b>Rav Ashi deemed</b> the bird <b>permitted,</b> while <b>Ameimar deemed</b> it <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>In</b> a case where only <b>one wing</b> was stuck to the board, <b>everyone agrees that it is permitted,</b> because the bird flaps with the other wing, lessening the impact of the fall. <b>They disagree when both wings</b> are stuck to the board. The one <b>who deemed</b> it <b>prohibited</b> could have <b>said to you: How will it stand</b> itself up so that it might dampen the impact? <b>And</b> the one <b>who deemed</b> it <b>permitted</b> could have <b>said to you: It is possible for</b> it to <b>stand</b> itself up <b>by</b> using <b>the tips of</b> its <b>wings.</b>
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say: In</b> a case where <b>two wings</b> were stuck to the board, <b>everyone agrees that it is prohibited,</b> because it cannot dampen the impact. <b>They disagree when</b> only <b>one wing</b> is stuck to the board. <b>The one who deemed</b> it <b>permitted</b> could have <b>said to you: It is possible for</b> it to <b>fly with one wing</b> and dampen the fall. <b>And the one who deemed</b> it <b>prohibited</b> could say: <b>Since it cannot fly with this</b> wing that is stuck to the <i>davuk</i>, <b>it also cannot fly with that</b> untrapped wing. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is: <b>In</b> a case where <b>two wings</b> were stuck, it is <b>prohibited. In</b> a case where only <b>one wing</b> was stuck, it is <b>permitted.</b>
§ The mishna states that if <b>most of</b> an animal’s <b>ribs were fractured,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>The Sages taught: These are most of the ribs: Six from here and six from there,</b> i.e., six on each side, <b>or eleven from here and one from there.</b> Twenty-two ribs are significant for matters of <i>tereifot</i>, eleven on each side. Twelve fractured ribs constitutes a majority.
<b>Ze’eiri says: And</b> this applies only when the ribs were fractured <b>from the half of</b> the rib <b>toward the spine,</b> but not if they were fractured on the other half. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And</b> this applies only to fractures occurring <b>in large ribs that contain marrow;</b> fractures in small ribs do not render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ <b>Ulla said</b> that <b>ben Zakkai says:</b> If the ribs were <b>dislocated</b> from the spine, even <b>a majority of one side,</b> i.e., six dislocated ribs, is enough to render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. Only if the ribs were <b>broken</b> is <b>a majority of both sides</b> necessary. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Whether they were dislocated or broken,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> only <b>with a majority of both sides.</b>
<b>Rav says:</b> If <b>a rib was dislocated and</b> the attached <b>vertebra</b> was torn out <b>with it,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> even if the spinal cord remains intact. <b>Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav:</b> If <b>a rib was dislocated from here and</b> another <b>rib from there,</b> i.e., both ribs connected to a single vertebra were dislocated, <b>but</b> the <b>vertebra</b> itself remains <b>intact, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav <b>said to them: Are you saying</b> that an animal that was <b>sliced</b> in half is a <i>tereifa</i>? This animal is considered to have been sliced and already has the status of a carcass, as it is already considered dead (see 21a).
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav also say</b> that <b>a sliced</b> animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, since he said that if a rib was dislocated along with the attached vertebra, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>? In such a case, the opposite rib is inevitably detached. If so, the animal should be considered a carcass. The Gemara responds: <b>When Rav said</b> that such an animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, he was referring to a case where the <b>rib</b> was dislocated <b>without the vertebra.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t</b> Rav explicitly <b>say</b> his statement with regard to <b>a rib and vertebra</b> that were dislocated? The Gemara responds: Rav meant that if <b>a rib and half</b> its attached <b>vertebra</b> were dislocated, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. The opposite rib, however, is intact and connected to the remainder of the vertebra.
The Gemara challenges: <b>By inference,</b> one may conclude <b>that Rav Kahana and Rav Asi stated</b> their question with regard to a less serious case, i.e., where <b>a rib</b> from each side was torn out <b>without</b> the <b>vertebra</b> being damaged at all. <b>And</b> yet, Rav <b>said to them: Are you saying</b> that an animal that was <b>sliced</b> in half is a <i>tereifa</i>? Rather, this animal is a carcass and is certainly prohibited. <b>And</b> how could Rav say this? <b>But didn’t Ulla say</b> that <b>ben Zakkai says:</b> If the ribs were <b>dislocated,</b> even <b>a majority of one side</b> is enough to render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, while if the ribs were <b>broken, a majority of both sides</b> is necessary? If so, any animal with fewer than six dislocated ribs should be kosher, as long as the spine is undamaged.
The Gemara responds: Rav could have <b>said to you: There,</b> where ben Zakkai says that six dislocated ribs on one side render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, this is referring only to ribs <b>not</b> dislocated <b>one opposite the other. Here,</b> where Rav says that two dislocated ribs render the animal a carcass, this is referring to ribs dislocated <b>one opposite the other.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> only if <b>a majority of both sides</b> was dislocated, <b>and in a majority of both sides, it is impossible that one of them is not situated opposite another?</b> Still, Rabbi Yoḥanan says that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> and not a carcass.
The Gemara responds: <b>There,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan is referring to a case where <b>the pestle,</b> i.e., the end of the rib, was torn out <b>without the mortar,</b> the socket of the vertebra in which it sits, leaving the spine completely intact. In such a case, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> only if twelve ribs were dislocated, even though this necessarily includes one rib opposite another. <b>Here,</b> where Rav says that two dislocated ribs opposite one another render the animal a carcass, that is referring to a case where the <b>pestle and mortar</b> were torn out together, damaging the spine.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> why did Rav Kahana and Rav Asi ask anything of Rav? Their case in question <b>is</b> identical to the statement of <b>Rav.</b> If Rav says that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if a rib and part of its vertebra were dislocated, that should be the <i>halakha</i> all the more so if ribs opposite one another were dislocated in addition to part of the attached vertebra. The Gemara responds: Rav Kahana and Rav Asi <b>did not hear</b> that statement <b>of Rav.</b>
The Gemara persists: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let them ask</b> about the simpler case of one dislocated rib, <b>like that</b> which <b>Rav</b> himself discussed. Why ask specifically about two ribs opposite one another? The Gemara responds: <b>They reasoned: Let us ask him one</b> question through <b>which he</b> will <b>explain to us two</b> different cases. <b>As, if we ask him</b> about only <b>one</b> dislocated rib, <b>this works out well if he says to us</b> that the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> because we can infer that <b>all the more so</b> if <b>two</b> ribs opposite one another are dislocated, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. But <b>if he says to us</b> that it is <b>kosher, we</b> must <b>still ask</b> with regard to a case of <b>two</b> dislocated ribs.
The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so,</b> then <b>now, too, when they ask him</b> about <b>two</b> ribs, they may not receive an answer with regard to both cases. Granted, <b>this works out well if he says to them</b> that an animal with two dislocated ribs opposite one another is <b>kosher,</b> since they can infer that <b>all the more so</b> it is kosher if only <b>one</b> rib is dislocated. <b>But if he says to them</b> that it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, they</b> must <b>still ask</b> with regard to a case of only <b>one</b> dislocated rib.
The Gemara responds: <b>They reasoned</b> that it is better to ask about a case where two ribs opposite one another were dislocated, because <b>if</b> it is <b>so</b> that Rav holds that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if even one rib is dislocated, then <b>he would become angry</b> and respond: If an animal with even <b>one</b> dislocated rib is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to ask about an animal with <b>two</b> dislocated ribs?
The Gemara objects: <b>But they did say</b> this question <b>to him and he did not become angry,</b> despite the fact that he holds that even one dislocated rib renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara responds: <b>When he said to them: Are you saying</b> that an animal that was <b>sliced</b> in half is a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>this is his anger.</b> Rav Kahana and Rav Asi understood from this response that an animal with two dislocated ribs opposite one another is a carcass, but an animal with one dislocated rib is a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ <b>Rabba bar Rav Sheila says</b> that <b>Rav Mattana says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> If <b>a rib was ripped from its root, or</b> if the <b>skull was crushed in its majority, or</b> if <b>the flesh that envelops the majority of the rumen</b> was damaged <b>in its majority,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: Did Shmuel really say that if <b>a rib was ripped from its root,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>? But raise a contradiction</b> from a mishna (<i>Oholot</i> 2:3):

Daf 52b

<b>How much</b> is considered <b>a deficiency in the spine</b> of a corpse so that it will not be considered a full corpse that would render one impure in a tent? <b>Beit Shammai say: Two</b> missing <b>vertebrae, and Beit Hillel say: One vertebra. And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: And</b> just as Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagree with regard to ritual impurity, <b>so too</b> they disagree with regard <b>to a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> i.e., according to Beit Hillel an animal missing only one vertebra is a <i>tereifa</i>. Evidently, Shmuel holds that a missing vertebra renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, but a dislocated rib does not.
The Gemara responds: This is not difficult. <b>Here,</b> where Shmuel says that a rib ripped from its root renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, he is referring to a case where the <b>rib</b> was torn out <b>without the vertebra. There,</b> where he says that a missing vertebra renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> according to Beit Hillel, he is referring to a case where the <b>vertebra</b> was missing <b>without</b> the <b>rib</b> being dislocated. But if the rib itself was ripped from its root, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> with regard to a case where <b>a rib</b> was dislocated <b>without the vertebra, you find this</b> commonly. <b>But how can you find</b> a case of a missing <b>vertebra without</b> a dislocated <b>rib?</b> The Gemara responds: This can occur <b>at the ends of the flanks,</b> where there are vertebrae with no ribs attached to them.
Shmuel said that just as Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel disagree with regard to ritual impurity, so too they disagree with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rav Oshaya objects to this</b> statement: <b>But</b> if that is so, then the opinion of Beit Hillel is the more stringent one, as they hold that even one missing vertebra renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. Accordingly, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> this dispute <b>along with</b> the list of <b>leniencies of Beit Shammai and stringencies of Beit Hillel</b> in tractate <i>Eduyyot</i>. <b>Rav said to him: When</b> the question <b>was asked, it was asked with regard to</b> the <b>ritual impurity</b> of a corpse. That is the source of the dispute between Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai, and on that matter, <b>Beit Shammai constitute</b> the <b>stringent</b> opinion. The parallel disagreement with regard to <i>tereifot</i> is not mentioned explicitly in any mishna or <i>baraita</i>, and it was therefore omitted from the list in tractate <i>Eduyyot</i>.
The Gemara returns to Shmuel’s statement: <b>Or</b> if the <b>skull was crushed in its majority,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> Is this referring to <b>the majority of its height or the majority of its circumference?</b> The Gemara responds: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
Shmuel also said: <b>Or</b> if <b>the flesh that envelops the majority of the rumen</b> was damaged <b>in its majority,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rav Ashi raises a dilemma:</b> Is this referring even to a case <b>where</b> the <b>majority</b> of the length of the flesh was <b>torn? Or</b> is it referring only to a case <b>where</b> the <b>majority</b> of the flesh was <b>removed,</b> but if it was torn along the majority of its length the animal remains kosher?
The Gemara responds: <b>Resolve</b> the dilemma <b>from that which we learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>the internal rumen was perforated or most of the external rumen was torn,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they said in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: The entire rumen is the internal rumen. And</b> if so, <b>which is the external rumen?</b> It is the <b>flesh that envelops the majority of the rumen.</b> Apparently, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> even if the flesh is torn in its majority.
The Gemara rejects the proof: <b>This explanation is</b> meant <b>only to</b> clarify the statement of <b>Shmuel,</b> and Shmuel does not agree with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, as <b>this</b> is what <b>Rabbi Ya’akov bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The case of: Most of the external rumen was torn, mentioned in the mishna, where the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, is not referring to where the flesh enveloping the majority of the rumen was torn, but rather where the majority of the rumen itself was torn. The internal rumen is the <b>place</b> in the rumen <b>that has no wool,</b> i.e., downy projections on the inside of the rumen. Accordingly, one cannot prove anything about the statement of Shmuel based on an explanation of the mishna offered by Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina.
§ The mishna states: <b>And</b> an animal that was <b>clawed by a wolf</b>  is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: In</b> the case of <b>an animal,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i> if it was clawed by any predator <b>from the</b> size of a <b>wolf and upward. And with regard to birds,</b> they are <i>tereifot</i> if they were clawed by any predator <b>from the</b> size of <b>a hawk and upward.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What does</b> this statement of Rav, that an animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if it was clawed by a predator at least as large as a wolf, <b>serve to exclude? If we say</b> it serves <b>to exclude a cat</b> that clawed an animal, since it is smaller than a wolf, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> in the mishna: <b>And</b> an animal <b>clawed by a wolf</b> is a <i>tereifa</i>. One can infer from this that cats do not render an animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And if you would say: This</b> mishna <b>teaches us that a wolf</b> can <b>also</b> effectively <b>claw a large</b> animal, e.g., cattle, but it may still be that a cat can render a small animal a <i>tereifa</i>, this cannot be; <b>didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If it was <b>clawed by a wolf in</b> the case of <b>a small</b> animal, <b>or clawed by a lion in</b> the case of <b>a large</b> animal, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda disagrees</b> with the Rabbis, and they hold that a wolf can also render large livestock <i>tereifa</i> by clawing, this too is impossible, as <b>doesn’t Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ela says:</b> The statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> in the mishna <b>comes only to explain the statement of the Rabbis?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Are you setting</b> the statement of one <b>man against</b> the statement of another <b>man?</b> Even if Rabbi Ela holds that Rabbi Yehuda comes only to explain the statement of the Rabbis, Rav may still hold that Rabbi Yehuda disagrees with the Rabbis. Or, <b>if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Actually,</b> everyone agrees that a wolf can render only a small animal a <i>tereifa</i> through clawing. Nevertheless, the statement of Rav serves <b>to exclude a cat</b> from the ability to render even a small animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Lest you say</b> that the mishna <b>taught</b> about a wolf only because this is <b>the manner</b> in which <b>the matter</b> typically occurs, but a cat may in fact render a small animal a <i>tereifa</i>, Rav <b>teaches us</b> that it is referring specifically to a wolf.
§ <b>Rav Amram says</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> If an animal was <b>clawed by a cat or a mongoose, in</b> the case of <b>kids or lambs,</b> which are very small, it is a <i>tereifa</i>. If it was <b>clawed by a weasel in</b> the case of <b>birds,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: An animal <b>clawed by a cat, hawk, or mongoose</b> is not rendered a <i>tereifa</i> <b>until</b> one of its internal organs <b>is perforated to</b> its <b>recesses.</b> One may infer: <b>But they,</b> i.e., a cat, hawk, and mongoose, <b>do not have</b> the ability to render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through the <b>clawing</b> itself.
The Gemara questions the inference: <b>And can you understand</b> that <b>a hawk does not</b> effectively <b>claw</b> an animal? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>And</b> a small bird <b>clawed by a hawk</b> is rendered a <i>tereifa</i>? The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where the mishna states that a hawk can effectively claw, it is <b>with regard to birds,</b> while <b>there,</b> where the <i>baraita</i> states that a hawk does not effectively claw, it is <b>with regard to kids and lambs.</b>
The Gemara returns to its initial objection: <b>In any case,</b> the <i>baraita</i> poses <b>a difficulty for Rav Ḥisda,</b> who says that a cat may render kids and lambs <i>tereifot</i> through clawing. The Gemara responds: Rav Ḥisda <b>states</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>that <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Distinguished One says: They said</b> that a kid is <b>not</b> effectively <b>clawed</b> by a cat <b>only in a place where there are none</b> present to <b>save</b> it. <b>But in a place where there are</b> bystanders trying to <b>save</b> the kid, it <b>is</b> effectively <b>clawed,</b> since the cat is angered and injects venom into the wound. Rav Ḥisda is referring specifically to the latter case.
The Gemara asks: <b>And in a place where there are none</b> to <b>save</b> the kid, is it <b>not</b> effectively <b>clawed? But</b> there was <b>a certain hen that was</b> in <b>the house of Rav Kahana, which a cat pursued, and</b> the cat <b>entered</b> after it into <b>a small room, and the door shut in</b> the cat’s <b>face, and it struck the door with its paws</b> in anger. <b>And</b> afterward, <b>five drops of blood,</b> i.e., venom, <b>were found on</b> the door. Apparently a cat is venomous even if no one is present to save its prey.
The Gemara responds: For a cat, <b>saving itself is also considered like saving others.</b> Since the cat felt threatened, it acted as it would if there had been someone present to defend the hen. The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> who state in the <i>baraita</i> that a cat can never effectively claw a small animal, even when there are bystanders attempting to save its prey, how do they explain this incident? The Gemara responds: According to the Rabbis, a cat does <b>have venom, but its venom does not burn</b> enough to render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who state</b> the details of this exchange differently: After raising an objection to the statement of Rav Ḥisda from the <i>baraita</i> that states that a cat cannot effectively claw kids and lambs, the Gemara responds: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Distinguished One, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Distinguished One says: They said</b> that a kid <b>is</b> effectively <b>clawed</b> by a cat <b>only in a place where there are</b> bystanders present to <b>save</b> it. <b>But in a place where there are none</b> present to <b>save</b> the kid, it is <b>not</b> effectively <b>clawed.</b> The <i>baraita</i>, then, discusses a case where there are none present to save it. Rav Ḥisda agrees with the Rabbis that a cat can effectively claw an animal even when there are none present to save it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But in a place where there are none</b> present to <b>save</b> the kid, is it <b>not</b> effectively <b>clawed? But</b> there was <b>a certain hen that was</b> in <b>the house of Rav Kahana, which a cat pursued, and</b> the cat <b>entered</b> after it into <b>a small room, and the door shut in</b> the cat’s <b>face, and it struck the door with its paws</b> in anger. <b>And</b> afterward, <b>five drops of blood,</b> i.e., venom, <b>were found on</b> the door. The Gemara responds: For a cat, <b>saving itself is also considered like saving others.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Kahana asked Rav:</b>

Daf 53a

<b>Does a cat</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing, or does a cat not</b> render it a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing?</b> Rav <b>said to him: Even a weasel,</b> which is smaller than a cat, <b>does</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing.</b> Rav Kahana also asked him: <b>Does a weasel</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing, or does a weasel not</b> render it a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing?</b> Rav <b>said to him: Even a cat does not</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing.</b>
Rav Kahana also asked him: With regard <b>to a cat and a weasel, do they</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing, or do they not</b> render it a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing?</b> Rav <b>said to him: A cat does</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing,</b> but <b>a weasel does not</b> render it a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>And</b> the apparent contradiction between these responses is <b>not difficult. That which</b> Rav <b>said to him: Even a weasel does</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing,</b> was stated <b>about</b> a case of clawed <b>birds. That which he said to him: Even a cat does not</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing,</b> was stated <b>about</b> a case of <b>adult sheep. That which</b> Rav <b>said to him: A cat does</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing,</b> but <b>a weasel does not</b> render it a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing,</b> was stated <b>about</b> a case of <b>kids and lambs.</b>
§ The mishna states that a small bird clawed by a hawk is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rav Ashi raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>other non-kosher birds</b> beside a hawk, <b>do they</b> render a bird a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing, or do they not</b> render it a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing? Rav Hillel said to Rav Ashi: When we were in the study hall of Rav Kahana, he said: Other non-kosher birds do</b> render a bird a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>Or</b> if it was <b>clawed by a hawk in</b> the case of <b>a small bird,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i>? Apparently, only a hawk renders a small bird a <i>tereifa</i> through clawing. The Gemara responds: The mishna means that a small bird <b>clawed by a hawk</b> is rendered a <i>tereifa</i> even <b>in</b> a case <b>where</b> it is as large <b>as</b> the hawk. <b>But these</b> other non-kosher birds can render a small bird a <i>tereifa</i> only <b>in</b> a case <b>where</b> it is <b>smaller than them. And there are</b> those <b>who say:</b> A small bird <b>clawed by a hawk</b> is rendered a <i>tereifa</i> even <b>in</b> a case <b>where</b> it is <b>larger than</b> the hawk. <b>But these</b> other non-kosher birds can render a small bird a <i>tereifa</i> only <b>in</b> a case <b>where</b> it is, at most, as large <b>as them.</b>
§ <b>Rav Kahana said in the name of Rav Shimi bar Ashi: A fox does not</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said:</b> There was <b>an incident</b> in which <b>a fox clawed a ewe in the bathhouse of Beit Hini, and the incident came before the Sages, and they said:</b> This <b>is</b> a case of <b>clawing. Rav Safra said</b> in response: In <b>that</b> case the predator <b>was a cat,</b> not a fox.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> the above exchange differently: <b>Rav Kahana said in the name of Rav Shimi bar Ashi: A fox does</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said:</b> There was <b>an incident</b> in which <b>a fox clawed a ewe in the bathhouse of Beit Hini, and the incident came before the Sages, and they said:</b> This is <b>not</b> a case of <b>clawing. Rav Safra said</b> in response: In <b>that</b> case the predator <b>was a dog,</b> not a fox. And <b>Rav Yosef said: We have a tradition</b> that <b>a dog does not</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through <b>clawing.</b>
§ With regard to the definition of clawing that renders an animal a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>Abaye said: We have a tradition: Clawing is only with the foreleg, to the exclusion of</b> clawing with the <b>hind leg, which does not</b> render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. Additionally, <b>clawing is only with the claw, to the exclusion of</b> savaging with the <b>tooth, which does not</b> render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, because the teeth contain no venom. And <b>clawing is only through an intentional</b> act, <b>to the exclusion of an unintentional</b> act, <b>which does not</b> render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, e.g., if the predator accidentally fell on the prey with its claws outstretched. And <b>clawing is only while</b> the predator is <b>alive, to the exclusion of</b> a case where it clawed an animal <b>after death, which does not</b> render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Sages <b>say: Now</b> that <b>you said</b> that <b>an unintentional</b> act of clawing does <b>not</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to say that clawing <b>after death</b> is ineffective? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> for a case <b>where</b> the predator <b>clawed</b> while still alive, <b>and they cut off its hand</b> with its claws still inside the prey’s flesh. <b>Lest you say: It injects its venom while it claws,</b> Abaye <b>teaches us</b> that <b>it injects its venom while it withdraws</b> its claws. Accordingly, where the venom has yet to be injected before its death, i.e., before its hand is severed, the animal is kosher.
§ <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If <b>a lion entered among the oxen, and</b> afterward <b>a claw was found</b> stuck <b>in the back of one of</b> the oxen, <b>one</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> the <b>lion clawed it. What is the reason</b> for this? Even though <b>a majority of lions claw</b> their prey <b>and</b> only <b>a minority of them do not claw,</b> still, it is known with regard to <b>any</b> lion <b>that claws</b> that <b>its claw is not ripped out</b> in the process. <b>And</b> therefore, with regard to <b>this</b> ox, <b>since a claw sits in its back, say</b> that <b>it rubbed against a wall</b> that had a claw embedded in it.
The Gemara objects: <b>On the contrary,</b> say that even though <b>a majority of oxen rub</b> against the wall <b>and</b> only <b>a minority do not rub,</b> still, it is known with regard to <b>any</b> ox <b>that rubs</b> that <b>a claw does not sit in its back. And</b> therefore, with regard to <b>this</b> ox, <b>since a claw sits in its back, say</b> that the <b>lion clawed it.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>One can say this, and one can say that.</b> Therefore, <b>establish the matter</b> according to <b>its presumptive status,</b> in which case the ox is not a <i>tereifa</i>. Accordingly, the ox is permitted because <b>this</b> case <b>is</b> one of <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether the animal was <b>clawed, and Rav</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says: One</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> in a case of <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether an animal was <b>clawed.</b>
<b>Abaye said: We said</b> that one need not be concerned that the lion clawed the ox <b>only</b> when the <b>claw</b> was found in its back, since it is known that a claw is not ripped out during clawing. <b>But</b> if only <b>the spot of a claw</b> was found, i.e., a perforation, <b>one must be concerned. And even</b> if the <b>claw</b> was found in its back, <b>we said</b> that one need not be concerned <b>only</b> when it was <b>moist,</b> since this indicates it was well connected to the flesh. Accordingly, if the lion had clawed the ox, this claw would not have been ripped out. <b>But</b> if the claw was <b>dry,</b> one must be concerned, because <b>it happens that</b> such a claw <b>is ripped out</b> during clawing.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>a moist</b> claw <b>as well, we said</b> that one need not be concerned <b>only</b> when <b>one</b> claw was found in its back. <b>But</b> if there were <b>two or three</b> claws embedded in its back, <b>we must be concerned,</b> because multiple claws were not likely to be embedded in the wall. <b>And this is</b> the <i>halakha</i> only <b>where they are situated in a row as</b> they are in the <b>paw of</b> a lion.
§ It <b>was stated: Rav says: One</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> in a case of <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether an animal was <b>clawed. And Shmuel says: One must be concerned</b> in a case of <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether an animal was <b>clawed,</b> and the animal must be inspected.
The Gemara explains: <b>Everyone</b> agrees that in a case where it is <b>uncertain</b> whether a predator <b>entered</b> the pen or coop and <b>uncertain</b> whether it <b>did not enter, I will say</b> that <b>it did not enter.</b> Furthermore, if it is known that an animal entered but it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it was <b>a dog</b> and <b>uncertain</b> whether it was <b>a cat, I will say</b> that it was <b>a dog,</b> which cannot render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> through clawing. And even if a predator <b>entered,</b> but it <b>was quiet and sat among</b> the animals, <b>I will say it made peace</b> with them, as though it were tame, and did not claw them. And if it <b>decapitated one of them,</b> I will say that its <b>anger subsided</b> afterward, and it did not claw other animals. And if <b>it was roaring and they were clucking,</b> I will say that <b>they are</b> only <b>frightening</b>

Daf 53b

<b>each other,</b> and one need not be concerned. <b>They disagree when</b> the lion <b>is quiet and</b> the birds <b>are clucking.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Shmuel, <b>holds:</b> They are clucking because <b>it is acting upon them,</b> i.e., clawing them, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> that <b>they are doing this out of fear of</b> the predator, but it is not necessarily clawing them.
<b>Ameimar said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>one must be concerned</b> in a case of <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether an animal was <b>clawed. Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: What</b> about <b>this</b> statement <b>of Rav</b> that one need not be concerned? Ameimar <b>said to him: I did not hear</b> that statement; <b>that is to say, I do not hold</b> in accordance with it.
<b>Or if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>Rav retracted</b> his statement and conceded <b>to Shmuel</b> that one must be concerned in a case of uncertainty. <b>As</b> there was <b>a certain basket of</b> birds concerning which there was <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether they had been <b>clawed</b> by a hawk that entered among them, <b>which came before Rav.</b> Rav <b>sent them before Shmuel</b> to issue a ruling, and Shmuel <b>strangled them and threw them in the river. And if it enters your mind that</b> Rav <b>did not retract</b> his statement, then <b>let him permit them</b> for consumption. Why did he send them to Shmuel?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Rather, what</b> will you say, that Rav really did <b>retract?</b> If so, <b>let him prohibit them</b> for consumption without sending them to Shmuel. <b>Rather,</b> he sent the birds to Shmuel because <b>it was Shmuel’s place,</b> and although Rav disagreed with Shmuel, it would be improper to issue a contradictory ruling.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need Shmuel <b>to strangle</b> the birds? <b>Let him</b> simply <b>throw them into the river as is.</b> The Gemara responds: Shmuel was concerned lest <b>they fly and leave</b> the river and eventually end up in the possession of an unwitting Jew.
The Gemara objects: <b>But let him delay</b> killing <b>them</b> for <b>twelve months.</b> If they survive it will prove that they are not <i>tereifot</i>, and they will be permitted. The Gemara responds: Shmuel was concerned lest people <b>encounter a stumbling block,</b> as they might forget that these birds are prohibited and eat them before twelve months have passed. The Gemara asks: <b>But let him sell them to gentiles</b> so that they will not be a stumbling block. The Gemara responds: Shmuel was concerned that perhaps the gentiles <b>will come to sell them</b> back <b>to Jews.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But let him strangle them and throw them into the garbage.</b> Why did Shmuel throw them into the river? The Gemara responds: <b>And according to your reasoning, we should throw them to the dogs,</b> as at least then they will come to some use. <b>Rather,</b> Shmuel threw them into the river, a public place, in order <b>to publicize the matter of the prohibition.</b>
The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain duck that was in the house of Rav Ashi.</b> The duck <b>entered between the reeds,</b> and it <b>came out with its throat stained with blood. Rav Ashi said: Do we not say:</b> If it is <b>uncertain</b> whether the predator was <b>a dog</b> and <b>uncertain</b> whether it was <b>a cat, I will say</b> that it was <b>a dog,</b> which cannot claw an animal effectively? <b>Here, too,</b> since it is <b>uncertain</b> whether the duck was injured by <b>a reed</b> and <b>uncertain</b> whether it was injured by <b>a cat, I will say</b> that <b>a reed struck it,</b> and the duck is not a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ <b>The sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> Yehuda and Ḥizkiyya, <b>said: A clawed</b> animal, about <b>which</b> the Sages <b>said</b> one must be concerned, <b>requires inspection</b> of the flesh <b>adjacent to the intestines.</b> If the flesh surrounding the intestines reddened, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, because the venom will eventually penetrate the body cavity and perforate the intestines themselves.
<b>Rav Yosef said: This</b> statement <b>of the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> was <b>already explained</b> by <b>Shmuel, as Shmuel says in the name of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus: A clawed animal,</b> about <b>which they said</b> one must be concerned, <b>requires inspection adjacent to the intestines.</b>
<b>Ilfa raises a dilemma: Is there clawing with regard to the <i>simanim</i>, or is there no clawing with regard to the <i>simanim</i>?</b> Does the venom penetrate the <i>simanim</i> as it does the intestines? <b>Rabbi Zeira said: This dilemma that Ilfa raises</b> was <b>already explained</b> by <b>Rav Ḥanan bar Rava, as Rav Ḥanan bar Rava says</b> that <b>Rav says: A clawed animal,</b> about <b>which they said</b> one must be concerned, <b>requires inspection</b> of the flesh <b>adjacent to the entire</b> body <b>cavity, and even in</b> the area of <b>the <i>simanim</i>.</b>
<b>Ilfa raises</b> another <b>dilemma:</b> With regard to <b><i>simanim</i> that were detached, how much</b> detachment renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>? <b>Rabbi Zeira said: This dilemma that Ilfa raises</b> was <b>already explained</b> by <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana, as Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b><i>simanim</i> that were detached,</b> if they were detached <b>in their majority</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rav Ami raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an animal that was clawed in an area not surrounding the body cavity, such as the legs, and <b>rot</b> was found in the flesh of that area? <b>Rabbi Zeira said: This dilemma that Rav Ami raises</b> was <b>already explained</b> by <b>Rav Yehuda, as Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: With regard to a clawed</b> animal, the injury does not render it a <i>tereifa</i> <b>unless the flesh adjacent to the intestine reddens;</b> but if <b>the flesh rotted, one views</b> the rotten area <b>as if it does not exist.</b> If the animal would be a <i>tereifa</i> when missing this flesh, it is also a <i>tereifa</i> if the flesh rotted.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is considered rotten</b> flesh? <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> It is <b>any</b> flesh in such a state that <b>the doctor scrapes it off and leaves</b> the animal <b>with</b> its <b>raw flesh</b> exposed so that it will heal. <b>Rav Ashi said: When we were in the study hall of Rav Kahana they brought before us a certain lung that, when they would set it down, would sit well, but when they would pick it up it would disintegrate and fall into pieces. And we deemed it a <i>tereifa</i> based on</b> the statement <b>of Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua,</b> that one views rotten flesh as if it does not exist. Since the animal would be a <i>tereifa</i> if missing the lung (see 42a), it is also a <i>tereifa</i> if the lung is rotten.
<b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> If an animal was pierced <b>by a thorn,</b> it is not a <i>tereifa</i> <b>until it is perforated to the cavity</b> of the body. But <b>in</b> the case of <b>a clawed</b> animal, <b>once the flesh adjacent to</b> the <b>intestines reddens,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rav Zevid</b> would <b>teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> in <b>this</b> manner: <b>In</b> the case of <b>a clawed</b> animal, <b>once the flesh adjacent to</b> the <b>intestines reddens</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i>; but if it was clawed <b>in the <i>simanim</i>,</b> it is not a <i>tereifa</i> <b>unless the <i>simanim</i> themselves redden.</b> If only the flesh around them reddens, the animal is kosher, since the venom may not penetrate to the <i>simanim</i> themselves.
<b>Rav Pappi said: Rav Beivai bar Abaye raises a dilemma:</b>

Daf 54a

If the <b>gullet</b> is <b>perforated in any amount,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, as taught in the mishna (42a). Therefore, if the gullet is <b>clawed</b> and <b>any amount</b> of its flesh reddens, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> as well. But <b>a perforation</b> of the <b>windpipe</b> renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> only <b>where</b> it is the size of <b>an <i>issar</i>.</b> If <b>clawed, what amount</b> of its flesh must redden in order to render it a <i>tereifa</i>? <b>After he raised the dilemma he then resolved it: Both this and that</b> render the animal a <i>tereifa</i> if <b>any amount</b> of its flesh reddened. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is because <b>its venom burns continuously</b> around the circumference of the hole and widens it.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta sat before Rav Naḥman, and he was sitting and saying: A clawed animal,</b> about <b>which</b> the Sages <b>said</b> one must be concerned, <b>requires inspection adjacent to the intestines</b> to see that the flesh has not reddened. <b>Rav Naḥman said to him: By God! Rav would teach</b> that <b>it</b> must be inspected over its entire body, <b>from</b> the flesh around <b>the hollow to</b> that of <b>the thigh.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the hollow? If we say</b> that it is <b>the hollow of the foreleg,</b> i.e., its shoulder, then the area between it and the thigh <b>is</b> the same as the area <b>adjacent to the intestines,</b> and Rav Naḥman has said nothing new. <b>Rather,</b> Rav Naḥman referred to the area <b>from the hollow of the brain,</b> i.e., the skull, <b>to the thigh.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>when Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef went up</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found that Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish were sitting and saying: A clawed animal,</b> about <b>which they said</b> one must be concerned, <b>requires inspection adjacent to the intestines.</b> Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef <b>said to them: By God! Rav would teach</b> that <b>it</b> must be inspected <b>from</b> the flesh around <b>the hollow to</b> that of <b>the thigh. Reish Lakish said to him: Who is</b> this <b>Rav, and who is</b> this <b>Rav? I do not know</b> who <b>he</b> is.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> to him: <b>But don’t</b> you <b>remember that student who served the great Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> and studied under them? <b>But by God! All those years that this student served in the yeshiva,</b> he was held to be one of the most important students and was allowed to sit during study, while <b>I</b> held a lower status and <b>served while standing up. And who was greater? He was greater in all</b> things, in Torah and piety.
<b>Immediately, Reish Lakish began</b> to speak <b>and said: Indeed [<i>beram</i>], that man,</b> Rav, <b>is remembered for the good, as they said this <i>halakha</i> in his name:</b> If an animal’s windpipe is <b>dislocated</b> from the throat, <b>and</b> it has already been <b>slaughtered,</b> and it is uncertain whether it was dislocated before or after slaughter, the animal is <b>kosher, as it is impossible for</b> an animal with <b>a dislocated windpipe to be slaughtered.</b> A dislocated windpipe would have slipped away from the knife, and therefore the animal must have been slaughtered while it was still attached.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> This is not certain; rather, one <b>should bring</b> the windpipe, make a new slit in it, <b>and compare</b> the two slits. If they are similar, then the first slit by the slaughtering knife was also made after the windpipe was dislocated, and the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. If they are different, then the slaughter preceded the dislocation of the windpipe and the animal is kosher.
<b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that it is impossible to slaughter a dislocated windpipe <b>only</b> in cases <b>where he did not grip the <i>simanim</i></b> during slaughter. <b>But</b> if <b>he gripped the <i>simanim</i> and slaughtered</b> the animal, then it is <b>possible for</b> an animal with <b>a dislocated windpipe to be slaughtered,</b> since it will not slip away from the knife.
§ The mishna states: <b>This is the principle:</b> Any animal that was injured such that an animal in a similar condition could not live for an extended period is a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> case does this principle <b>add</b> that was not previously mentioned? The Gemara responds: It was stated <b>to add seven <i>halakhot</i></b> of <i>tereifot</i> taught by <i>amora’im</i> and not listed in the mishna. These cases are enumerated on 42b.
The Gemara recounts: The men <b>of the house of Yosef the hunter</b> would <b>strike the sciatic nerve</b> of an animal with an arrow <b>and kill</b> it that way. In other words, the animal would die from that wound. <b>They came before Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira</b> to ask if an animal with an injured sciatic nerve is a <i>tereifa</i>, which is relevant if the animal was slaughtered before it died. Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira <b>said to them: And is</b> it possible <b>to add to the</b> list of <b><i>tereifot</i>? You have only what the Sages counted,</b> and the Sages mentioned no such <i>tereifa</i>.
Likewise, the men of <b>Rav Pappa bar Abba the hunter</b> would <b>strike</b> an animal <b>in the kidney</b> with an arrow <b>and kill</b> it that way. <b>They came before Rabbi Abba</b> to ask if such an animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. Rabbi Abba <b>said to them: And is</b> it possible <b>to add to the</b> list of <b><i>tereifot</i>? You have only what the Sages counted.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But we see that they die.</b> Isn’t this an indication that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>? The Gemara responds: It <b>is learned</b> as a tradition <b>that</b> in all these cases, <b>if one</b> were to <b>scatter medicine</b> on the wound, the animal would <b>live.</b> An animal is not considered a <i>tereifa</i> unless it cannot be healed.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these,</b> despite their condition, <b>are kosher in an animal:</b> If its <b>windpipe was perforated or cracked</b> lengthwise. <b>How much can</b> the windpipe <b>be missing</b> and still be kosher? <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Until</b> the perforation is the same size <b>as the Italian <i>issar</i>.</b> If <b>the skull was fractured but the membrane of the brain was not perforated,</b> it is kosher.
