If <b>the heart was perforated and</b> the perforation <b>did not</b> reach <b>its chamber,</b> or if <b>the spinal</b> column <b>was broken but its cord was not cut,</b> or if <b>the liver was removed and an olive-bulk of it remained,</b> it is kosher.
Additionally, it is kosher if the <b>omasum or the reticulum was perforated one into the other.</b> If <b>the spleen was removed,</b> or <b>the kidneys were removed,</b> or if <b>its lower jaw was removed,</b> or if <b>its womb was removed, or</b> if its lung <b>shriveled by the hand of Heaven,</b> the animal is kosher. In the case of an animal <b>whose hide was removed, Rabbi Meir deems it kosher, and the Rabbis deem it</b> a <i>tereifa</i> and <b>unfit</b> for consumption.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna begins: And these are kosher, while the previous mishna begins: These are <i>tereifot</i>. With regard to this, it <b>was stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <i>tanna</i> intended the phrase: <b>These are <i>tereifot</i>, specifically,</b> teaching that an animal is kosher in another case. The list of kosher cases here is therefore not exhaustive. <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says</b> that the <i>tanna</i> intended the phrase: <b>These are kosher, specifically,</b> teaching that an animal is a <i>tereifa</i> in another case. The list of <i>tereifot</i> at the beginning of the chapter is therefore not exhaustive.
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what</b> case <b>do they disagree?</b> They disagree <b>with regard to</b> the statement <b>of Rav Mattana, as Rav Mattana says: This head of the femur that was</b> completely <b>dislocated</b> renders the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> According to <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who <b>says</b> that the phrase: <b>These are <i>tereifot</i>,</b> is meant <b>specifically,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> the list of <b><i>tereifot</i> and taught</b> afterward: <b>This is the principle,</b> to add cases that were not stated explicitly;

Daf 54b

<b>and</b> the <i>tanna</i> then <b>saw</b> that the case <b>of Rav Mattana,</b> where the end of the thigh is dislocated, ostensibly <b>comes</b> under the heading of: <b>This is the principle,</b> and one might assume that it renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i> as well. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because</b> a dislocated thigh is <b>similar to</b> the cases of <b>removed</b> organs that render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. Therefore, <b>he taught</b> the phrase: <b>These are <i>tereifot</i>,</b> at the beginning of the mishna, to emphasize that <b>it is</b> only <b>these that</b> render an animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, but</b> in the case <b>of Rav Mattana,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b>
<b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> who <b>says</b> that the phrase: <b>These are kosher,</b> is meant <b>specifically,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> the list of <b><i>tereifot</i>, and taught</b> afterward that <b>this is the principle. And</b> the <i>tanna</i> then <b>saw</b> that the case <b>of Rav Mattana</b> ostensibly <b>does not come</b> under the heading of: <b>This is the principle,</b> and one might assume that it does not render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is because a dislocated thigh <b>is not similar to</b> cases of <b>perforated</b> organs, <b>and it is not similar to</b> cases of <b>cut</b> organs, such as the windpipe, <b>and</b> it <b>is not similar to</b> cases of <b>removed</b> organs. Therefore, <b>he taught</b> the phrase: <b>These are kosher,</b> to emphasize that <b>it is</b> only <b>these that are kosher, but</b> in the case <b>of Rav Mattana,</b> the animal <b>is a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara addresses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav Mattana says: This head of the femur that was</b> completely <b>dislocated</b> renders the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And Rava said:</b> The animal is <b>kosher, but if its sinew</b> holding the bone in place <b>is cut,</b> it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is: Even if the sinew is <b>cut,</b> the animal is <b>still kosher, unless</b> the sinew <b>decomposed,</b> in which case the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ The mishna states: <b>How much can</b> the windpipe <b>be missing</b> and still be kosher? Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Until the perforation is the same size as an Italian <i>issar</i>. <b>Ze’eiri,</b> who came from Eretz Yisrael, <b>said</b> with regard to this: <b>You, who are not familiar with the measure</b> of an Italian <i>issar</i>, because it is not used in Babylonia, should estimate <b>its measure as a Kurdish dinar. And it is like a small <i>peruta</i></b> coin <b>and can be found among the <i>perutot</i> of Pumbedita.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥana the money changer said: Bar Nappaḥa,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>was standing over me, and he requested of me a Kurdish dinar with</b> which <b>to measure <i>tereifot</i>,</b> in accordance with the statement of Ze’eiri. <b>And I wanted to rise before him</b> out of respect, <b>but he did not let me.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to me: Sit, my son, sit. Tradesmen are not permitted to stand before Torah scholars when they are engaged in their work.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> are tradesmen <b>not</b> permitted to stand before Torah scholars? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Bikkurim</i> 3:3): When the pilgrims bring their first fruits to Jerusalem, <b>all the tradesmen stand before them, and greet them, and say to them: Our brothers from such and such place, welcome?</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Yes, <b>they stand before</b> those bringing first fruits, but <b>they do not stand before Torah scholars. Rabbi Yosei bar Avin says: Come and see how beloved is a mitzva</b> performed <b>in its</b> proper <b>time, as</b> the tradesmen <b>stand before those</b> who brought first fruits, while <b>they do not stand before Torah scholars.</b>
The Gemara rejects the statement of Rabbi Yosei bar Avin: <b>From where</b> does one know that they rise out of respect? <b>Perhaps</b> the tradesmen stand only <b>in order not to cause</b> those bringing first fruits to <b>fail</b> and sin <b>in the future.</b> That is, if the tradesmen do not treat those bringing the first fruits with great respect, they may not make the effort to travel to Jerusalem in a subsequent year.
§ The mishna states: How much can the windpipe be missing and still be kosher? Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Until the perforation is the same size as an Italian <i>issar</i>. With regard to this, <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> Whenever the Sages specify the measure <b>as</b> that of <b>a <i>sela</i>,</b> e.g., with regard to a damaged skull for purposes of <i>tereifot</i>, they mean that even an area exactly the size of a <i>sela</i> is treated <b>as more than a <i>sela</i>.</b> Likewise, when they specify the measure <b>as</b> that of <b>an <i>issar</i>,</b> they mean that an area exactly the size of an <i>issar</i> is treated <b>as</b> though it were <b>more than an <i>issar</i>.</b>
Since Rav Naḥman holds that a perforation exactly the size of an <i>issar</i> is treated as though it were larger than an <i>issar</i>, he must hold that such a perforation in the windpipe renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara therefore infers: <b>Apparently, Rav Naḥman holds</b> that whenever the Sages use the word: Until, it means <b>until and not including the measure,</b> as the mishna states that an animal with a perforated windpipe is kosher until the perforation reaches the size of an <i>issar</i>.
<b>Rava raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman</b> from a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 19:2): The end of <b>a rope that extends from</b> a rope <b>bed is not susceptible to ritual impurity until</b> it is <b>five handbreadths</b> long. If the bed becomes impure, the rope remains pure, because it has no use and is therefore not considered part of the bed. <b>What, is it not</b> teaching that a rope exactly <b>five</b> handbreadths long is treated <b>as</b> though its length were <b>below</b> that amount? If so, the word: Until, means until and including the exact measure. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> a rope exactly <b>five</b> handbreadths long is <b>like</b> a rope whose length is <b>above</b> that amount.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the continuation of the mishna: If the end of the rope was of any length <b>from five</b> handbreadths <b>until ten, it is susceptible to impurity. What, is it not</b> teaching that a rope exactly <b>ten</b> handbreadths long is treated <b>as</b> though its length were <b>below</b> that? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> a rope exactly <b>ten</b> handbreadths long is treated <b>like</b> a rope whose length is <b>above</b> that, and it is not susceptible to impurity.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from another mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 2:2): With regard to <b>the smallest of earthenware vessels,</b> if <b>they, or</b> even <b>their</b> broken-off <b>bases or sides,</b> can <b>sit,</b> i.e., remain upright, <b>without being supported,</b>

Daf 55a

<b>their measure</b> in order to be susceptible to ritual impurity is that they can hold <b>enough</b> oil with which <b>to anoint a small child.</b> If they cannot hold this amount, they are considered useless and are not susceptible to impurity. <b>And</b> this measure applies only to vessels that held <b>up to a <i>log</i></b> when they were whole; if they had originally held more, they must hold more when broken in order to be susceptible to impurity. <b>What, is it not</b> teaching that if it originally held exactly one <b><i>log</i></b> it is treated <b>as</b> though it had held <b>below</b> that amount? If so, the term: Up to, means up to and including. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> if it held exactly one <b><i>log</i></b> it is treated <b>as</b> though it held <b>above</b> that amount, and if broken it must be capable of holding a greater measure in order to be susceptible to impurity.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from the continuation of the same mishna: If the vessel originally held <b>from a <i>log</i> up to a <i>se’a</i>,</b> its broken-off base or sides must hold <b>a quarter-<i>log</i></b> in order to be susceptible to impurity. <b>What, is it not</b> teaching that if it originally held exactly <b>a <i>se’a</i></b> it is treated <b>as</b> though it had held <b>below</b> that amount? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> if it held exactly <b>a <i>se’a</i></b> it is treated <b>as</b> though it had held <b>above</b> that amount, and its base or sides must hold a greater measure in order to be susceptible to impurity.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from the continuation of the same mishna: If the vessel had originally held <b>from a <i>se’a</i>up to two <i>se’a</i>,</b> its broken-off base or sides must hold <b>half a <i>log</i></b> to be susceptible to impurity. <b>What, is it not</b> teaching that if it had originally held exactly <b>two <i>se’a</i></b> it is treated <b>as</b> if though it had held <b>below</b> that amount? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> if it had held exactly <b>two <i>se’a</i></b> it is treated <b>as</b> though it had held <b>above</b> that amount.
The Gemara asks: How can one explain the mishna in this manner? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: If the vessel had originally held exactly <b>a <i>log</i></b> it is treated <b>as</b> though it had held <b>below</b> that amount; if it had held exactly <b>a <i>se’a</i></b> it is treated <b>as</b> though it had held <b>below</b> that amount; if it had held exactly <b>two <i>se’a</i></b> it is treated <b>as</b> though it had held <b>below</b> that amount? Evidently, the term: Up to, means up to and including the given measure, in contradiction to Rav Naḥman’s opinion that it means up to and not including the measure.
The Gemara responds: The term: Up to, is always interpreted in the more stringent manner. Accordingly, <b>there,</b> with regard to the impurity of vessels, the term: Up to, is interpreted as up to and including in order to rule <b>stringently,</b> since the vessel is then more easily susceptible to impurity. <b>As Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: All measures of the Sages</b> must be interpreted <b>stringently, except for</b> the measure of <b>a groat</b> as a standard <b>for stains</b> of blood found on a woman’s clothing, which is interpreted <b>leniently.</b> Even if the stain is exactly the size of a groat, the woman remains pure. Here, it is more stringent to interpret the phrase: Up to, as up to and including, because an animal is then more susceptible to being rendered a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara notes: The language <b>is also precise,</b> i.e., it is evident that the phrase: Up to, is always interpreted stringently, as the mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 19:2) states that if a rope extending from a rope bed is of any length up to five handbreadths, it is not susceptible to ritual impurity, but if it is of any length from five up to ten handbreadths, it is susceptible. And a <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches with regard to that</b> mishna: If the rope was exactly <b>five</b> handbreadths long, it is treated <b>as</b> though its length were <b>above</b> that; if the rope was exactly <b>ten</b> handbreadths long, it is treated <b>as</b> though its length were <b>below</b> that. In both cases, the measure is interpreted stringently.
§ The mishna states: If <b>the spleen was removed</b> the animal remains kosher. <b>Rav Avira says in the name of Rava:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that it is kosher <b>only</b> when the spleen was <b>removed, but</b> if it was <b>perforated,</b> it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei bar Avin, and some say Rabbi Yosei bar Zevida, raises an objection</b> from a mishna in the next chapter (68a): If, prior to slaughtering an animal, one <b>severs</b> pieces <b>from a fetus that is in</b> the <b>womb</b> and leaves those pieces in the womb, their <b>consumption</b> is <b>permitted</b> by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal (see 69a). By contrast, if one severs pieces <b>of the spleen or of the kidneys</b> of an animal and then slaughters it, then even if those pieces are left inside the animal their <b>consumption</b> is <b>prohibited,</b> because an organ severed from a living being is not permitted by the subsequent slaughter of the animal. One can infer from the mishna <b>that the animal itself is permitted</b> even when part of the spleen was severed. Evidently, such an animal is not a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>The same is true</b> of the animal, and <b>even the animal is prohibited.</b> But <b>since</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> in <b>the first clause,</b> with regard to the parts of the fetus: Their <b>consumption is permitted, it taught</b> in <b>the last clause</b> with regard to the parts of the spleen: Their <b>consumption is prohibited,</b> to contrast between them. <b>Or, if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>a perforated</b> spleen is <b>a discrete</b> case, in which the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>and a cut</b> spleen is <b>a discrete</b> case, in which the animal is not.
§ The mishna states: If <b>the kidneys were removed</b> the animal remains kosher. <b>Rakhish bar Pappa said in the name of Rav:</b> If an animal was <b>diseased in</b> even <b>one kidney,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they say: And this</b> applies only in a case <b>where the disease reached</b>

Daf 55b

<b>the location of the crevice. And where is the location of the crevice?</b> This is a reference <b>to the white</b> matter <b>under the loins. Rav Neḥunya said: I asked all the authorities on <i>tereifot</i> of the West, and they said to me: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rakhish bar Pappa</b> in the name of Rav that a diseased kidney renders an animal a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>but the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Avira</b> that a perforated spleen renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara adds: And <b>even</b> with regard to the opinion <b>of Rav Avira, we said</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his opinion <b>only</b> if the spleen was perforated <b>in its narrow,</b> lower <b>end, but</b> if it was perforated <b>in its thick,</b> upper <b>end,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And</b> even if it was perforated in its thick end, <b>if</b> it was not perforated completely and a layer of the spleen <b>as thick as a gold dinar remains</b> intact, the animal is <b>kosher.</b>
§ <b>They say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael: <b>Any</b> injury <b>that renders</b> an animal <b>unfit</b> for consumption when occurring <b>in the lung is kosher</b> when occurring <b>in the kidney.</b> For example, <b>a perforation</b> renders an animal <b>unfit</b> when occurring <b>in the lung</b> (see 42a), <b>but</b> the animal <b>is kosher</b> if it occurs <b>in the kidney. And</b> it follows that <b>all the more so, where</b> an animal <b>is kosher</b> despite an injury <b>in the lung,</b> it will remain <b>kosher</b> despite a similar injury <b>in the kidney.</b>
<b>Rabbi Tanḥuma objects to this: And is this</b> an established <b>principle? But</b> what about a case of <b>pus, where</b> the animal is <b>kosher</b> if it occurs <b>in the lung and unfit</b> for consumption if it occurs <b>in the kidney? And</b> what about <b>clear fluid, which is kosher</b> both <b>here and there,</b> i.e., whether occurring in the lungs or the kidney? <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: Are</b> you <b>comparing <i>tereifot</i> to one another? One cannot say with regard to <i>tereifot</i>: This is similar to that, as one cuts</b> an animal <b>from here,</b> in one place, <b>and it dies,</b> while <b>one cuts it from there,</b> in another place, <b>and it lives.</b> Certain injuries may compromise the kidney but not the lung, or vice versa.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>clear fluid</b> found in the lungs or kidney, which is <b>kosher, we said</b> so <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the fluid was <b>unclouded, but</b> if it was <b>clouded,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And even when</b> the fluid was <b>unclouded, we said</b> the animal is kosher <b>only</b> if the fluid <b>is not fetid, but if it is fetid,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara continues to discuss cases of <i>tereifot</i> due to the kidneys: With regard to <b>a kidney that shrank, in small</b> animals, such as sheep, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if it shrank <b>until</b> the size <b>of a bean; in large</b> animals, such as cattle, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if it shrank <b>until</b> the size <b>of an intermediate-</b>sized <b>grape.</b>
§ The mishna states: If the animal’s <b>lower jaw was removed,</b> it remains kosher. With regard to this, <b>Rabbi Zeira says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <b>only when</b> the animal <b>is able to live by placing</b> food in its mouth <b>or stuffing</b> it down its throat. <b>But</b> if <b>it cannot live by placing or stuffing</b> food into it, it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
§ The mishna states: If <b>its womb [<i>em</i>] was removed,</b> the animal remains kosher. A Sage <b>taught: The <i>em</i> is</b> synonymous with the <b><i>tarpaḥat</i>, and it is</b> synonymous with the <b><i>shalpuḥit</i>.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>Or</b> if its lung <b>shriveled [<i>ḥaruta</i>] by the hand of Heaven,</b> the animal is <b>kosher. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Which is a <i>ḥaruta</i>?</b> It is <b>any</b> animal <b>whose lung shriveled.</b> If this occurred <b>by the hand of Heaven,</b> e.g., if the lung shriveled from fright of thunder and lightning, the animal is <b>kosher.</b> But if it happened <b>by the hands of a person</b> who frightened it, e.g., if it witnessed another animal being slaughtered, it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Even</b> if the lung shriveled <b>by the hands of any creature,</b> e.g., if it was frightened by a lion’s roar.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Is</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar referring to the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, in which case the statement is <b>a leniency,</b> and even the roar of a lion is considered by the hand of Heaven? <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is referring to the latter clause, and</b> the statement is <b>a stringency,</b> and a lung shriveled by the hand of any creature renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof, <b>as it is taught</b> in the above <i>baraita</i>: A lung that was <b>shriveled by the hands of a person</b> renders the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Even by the hands of any creature.</b> Evidently, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar is referring to the latter clause.
The Gemara recounts: <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana was walking in the desert,</b> and <b>he found certain rams whose lungs were shriveled. He came and asked</b> in <b>the study hall</b> how one can determine the cause of the shriveling. The Sages <b>said to him: In the summer, bring white vessels and fill them with cold water and set</b> the lungs in them <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period. If they go back</b> to appearing <b>healthy,</b> i.e., if they expand, one knows that <b>it was by the hand of Heaven and</b> the animals are <b>kosher; but if</b> they do <b>not</b> expand, the animals are <b><i>tereifa</i>. In the winter, bring dark vessels and fill them with tepid water, and set</b> the lungs in them <b>for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period. If</b> they <b>go back</b> to appearing <b>healthy,</b> they are <b>kosher; but if not,</b> they are <b><i>tereifa</i>.</b>
§ The mishna states: In the case of an animal <b>whose hide was removed,</b> Rabbi Meir deems it kosher, and the Rabbis deem it a <i>tereifa</i>. With regard to this, <b>the Sages taught:</b> In the case of an animal <b>whose hide was removed, Rabbi Meir deems it kosher, and the Rabbis deem it</b> a <i>tereifa</i> and <b>unfit</b> for consumption. <b>And Elazar the scribe and Yoḥanan ben Gudgeda already testified</b> before the Sages <b>with regard to</b> an animal <b>whose hide was removed that</b> it is <b>unfit</b> for consumption. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Rabbi Meir retracted</b> his statement.
The Gemara objects: <b>By inference,</b> one may conclude that <b>according to Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, Rabbi Meir</b> initially <b>disagreed with regard to</b> an animal <b>whose hide was removed. But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Rabbi Meir and the Sages did not disagree with regard to</b> an animal <b>whose hide was removed,</b> and all agree <b>that it is unfit</b> for consumption. <b>And Rabbi Oshaya, son of Rabbi Yehuda the spice merchant, already testified before Rabbi Akiva in the name of Rabbi Tarfon with regard to</b> an animal <b>whose hide was removed that it is unfit</b> for consumption. <b>And if</b> a piece of hide the same size <b>as a <i>sela</i> remained</b> intact, the animal is <b>kosher.</b> The Gemara explains the objection: The phrase: Did not disagree, indicates that Rabbi Meir never disagreed with the Sages. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>Did not disagree?</b> It means that <b>Rabbi Meir did not stand</b> firm <b>in his disagreement</b> and retracted.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said: If</b> a piece of hide the same size <b>as a <i>sela</i> remained</b> intact <b>in</b> the animal, it is <b>kosher.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Where</b> must this piece of hide be? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The piece of hide must be <b>along the entire spine.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Does Shmuel mean <b>that</b> it is kosher if <b>a long and thin</b> strip of hide remains along the spine, such <b>that when</b> one <b>combines its</b> area, it will <b>constitute</b> the same size <b>as a <i>sela</i>? Or perhaps</b> it is kosher only if the remaining hide is <b>the width of a <i>sela</i> along the entire spine?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from that <b>which Rabbi Nehorai explained in the name of Shmuel:</b> It must be <b>the width of a <i>sela</i> along the entire spine.</b>
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says:</b> There must be a piece of hide the size of a <i>sela</i> on <b>the tips of</b> all <b>segments</b> of the spine and on the tips of the femur and tibia. <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Antigonus says in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yannai:</b> The piece of hide must be the width of a <i>sela</i> at <b>the place of its navel.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yannai, son of Rabbi Yishmael, raises a dilemma:</b> If all the hide covering <b>the place of the spine was removed, but all of</b> the remaining hide <b>was intact,</b> or if the hide covering <b>the place of its navel was removed but all of</b> the remaining hide <b>was intact,</b> or if the hide covering all the <b>tips of the segments were removed but all of</b> the remaining hide <b>was intact, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara responds: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav says: Any</b> portion of <b>the hide</b> that is the size of a <i>sela</i> <b>saves</b> an animal <b>whose hide was removed</b> from becoming a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>except for the hide of the hooves,</b> which is not considered hide. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Even the hide of the hooves saves</b> it.
The Gemara recounts: <b>Rabbi Asi asked Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> With regard to the <b>hide of the hooves, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does it <b>save</b> an animal <b>whose hide was removed</b> if a piece of it the size of a <i>sela</i> remains? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: It saves</b> the animal. Rabbi Asi <b>said to him:</b> But didn’t <b>you teach us, our teacher,</b> the following mishna (122a): <b>These</b> are the entities <b>whose hide is like their flesh</b> in terms of halakhic status, in that it transmits ritual impurity…the skin of a head of a young calf, and <b>the hide of the hooves?</b> Evidently, the hide of the hooves is considered like flesh and not true skin. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: Do not trouble me</b> by invoking that mishna, <b>as I teach it in the singular.</b> Only according to one Sage, Rabbi Shimon, is the hide of the hooves not true skin; according to the Rabbis, it is considered true skin.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who slaughters a burnt offering</b> with intent <b>to burn an olive-bulk of the hide beneath the tail outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> i.e., outside the Temple courtyard, renders the offering <b>unfit, but there is no</b> liability for <b>excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>]</b> for one who partakes of the offering. If he had intent to burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> then it is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> partaking of <b>it.</b> This <i>halakha</i> usually applies to an offering’s flesh but not its hide. Since the hide beneath the tail is soft, it is treated like part of the flesh. This is the opinion of the Rabbis.
<b>Eliezer ben Yehuda of Evlayim said in the name of Rabbi Ya’akov, and so says Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda of Ikos in the name of Rabbi Shimon: Whether the hide of the hooves, or the hide of the head of a young calf, or the hide beneath the tail, or any</b> hide <b>that the Sages listed with regard to ritual impurity</b> under the heading: <b>These</b> are the entities <b>whose hide is like their flesh</b> in terms of halakhic status,

Daf 56a

<b>including the hide of the vulva,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is the same: If one performs the sacrificial rites with intent to burn one of them <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> the offering is <b>unfit, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i></b> for one who partakes of the offering. If he had intent to burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> this renders it <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating <b>it.</b> This <i>baraita</i> indicates that only Rabbi Shimon holds that the hide of the hooves is treated like its flesh, and that the Sages disagree, as Rabbi Yoḥanan stated.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these are <i>tereifot</i> in a bird:</b> One with <b>a perforated gullet, or</b> with <b>a cut windpipe</b> that was cut across its width; or if <b>a weasel struck</b> the bird <b>on its head</b> in <b>a place that renders it a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> as one must be concerned that the membrane of the brain was perforated; or if <b>the gizzard was perforated;</b> or if <b>the small intestines were perforated.</b> In a case where a bird <b>fell into the fire and its innards were singed [<i>neḥmeru</i>], if</b> they turned <b>green</b> they are <b>unfit,</b> and the bird is a <i>tereifa</i>, but <b>if</b> they are <b>red</b> the bird is <b>kosher.</b> If a person <b>trampled</b> the bird, <b>or slammed it against a wall, or if an animal crushed it and it is twitching,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i> because its limbs were shattered. <b>But</b> if the bird <b>lasted for</b> a twenty-four-hour <b>period, and</b> then <b>one slaughtered it,</b> it is <b>kosher.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states: If a weasel struck the bird on its head in a place that renders it a <i>tereifa</i>, one must be concerned that the membrane of the brain was perforated. <b>Rav and Shmuel and Levi say:</b> How does one inspect the membrane? After slaughter, one <b>inserts his hand into</b> the mouth of the bird and pushes the nerve tissue with his finger <b>and inspects</b> it. <b>If</b> the nerve tissue <b>emerges and rises</b> out through the hole in the skull, the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> because this proves that the membrane has been perforated, allowing the nerve tissue through. <b>And if not,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> (45a) that an animal is not a <i>tereifa</i> <b>unless the inner membrane is perforated</b> as well. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that the animal is rendered a <i>tereifa</i> if <b>the outer</b> membrane <b>was perforated, even if the inner</b> membrane <b>was not perforated,</b> how can one rely on this inspection? <b>Let us be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps the outer</b> membrane <b>was perforated</b> but <b>the inner</b> membrane <b>was not perforated,</b> in which case the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> even if the nerve tissue does not emerge through the hole. The Gemara responds: <b>If it is</b> the case <b>that the outer</b> membrane <b>was perforated, the inner membrane will</b> inevitably <b>burst due to its fragility,</b> allowing the nerve tissue to emerge. If it does not emerge, it is certain that the outer membrane is intact as well.
<b>Ze’eiri says: There is no</b> effective <b>inspection for</b> a bird bitten on the head by <b>a weasel, because</b> the weasel’s <b>teeth are</b> so <b>thin</b> that even if they perforate the membrane, the nerve tissue will not emerge through the perforations. The Gemara asks: <b>And if its teeth are thin, what of it?</b> Certainly a small amount will emerge through the perforation. <b>Rav Oshaya said:</b> There is no inspection <b>because its teeth are fine and crooked.</b> The hole in the skull does not overlap the perforation in the membrane, and nothing will be able to escape.
The Gemara recounts: <b>When</b> Ze’eiri <b>went up to Neharde’a, he sent</b> a message <b>to</b> the Sages: <b>The matters that I stated before you are an error on my part. In fact, they said this in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: One inspects</b> a bird bitten on the head by <b>a weasel with</b> one’s <b>hand,</b> pressing against the nerve tissue to see if it emerges through the hole, <b>but not with a nail.</b> One may not inspect it by dragging the tip of a nail over the surface of the membrane to see if it catches on a perforation, since the nail itself may perforate the membrane. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> One may <b>even</b> inspect it <b>with a nail.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> this disagreement is also reflected <b>in the dispute of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> wherein <b>one inspected</b> the bird <b>by hand, and one inspected</b> it <b>with a needle. The one who inspected</b> it <b>by hand said to the one who inspected</b> it <b>with a needle: Until when will you waste the money of the Jewish people</b> by causing them to discard kosher meat? Sometimes the needle itself will perforate a membrane that was initially whole. <b>The one who inspected</b> it <b>with a needle said to the one who inspected</b> it <b>by hand: Until when will you feed carcasses to the Jewish people,</b> as you permit for consumption a bird that might well be forbidden?
The Gemara asks: <b>Carcasses? But</b> this is a <b>slaughtered</b> animal; even if it is forbidden, it is a <i>tereifa</i>, not a carcass. <b>Rather,</b> he must have said: Until when will you feed <b><i>tereifot</i></b> to the Jewish people; <b>perhaps the membrane of the brain was perforated.</b> Inspection by hand is not reliable, since the teeth of the weasel are thin and crooked and the nerve tissue may not escape even if the membrane is perforated.
The Gemara notes: <b>It may be concluded that it is Rabbi Yehuda who inspected</b> it <b>by hand, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Yehuda</b> that <b>one may inspect</b> a bird bitten on the head by <b>a weasel with</b> one’s <b>hand, but not with a nail.</b> The <i>baraita</i> continues: If <b>the bone</b> of the skull <b>was broken, even if the membrane of the brain was not perforated,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara affirms: Indeed, <b>it may be concluded</b> that Rabbi Yehuda permits inspection only by hand.
The Gemara objects: <b>This itself</b> is <b>difficult. You said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may inspect</b> a bird injured by <b>a weasel with</b> one’s <b>hand, but not with a nail; apparently, it has</b> an option of <b>inspection. But you then teach:</b> If <b>the bone</b> of the skull <b>was broken, even if the membrane of the brain was not perforated,</b> the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>; <b>apparently it has no inspection,</b> because inspecting for a perforation would be pointless. The Gemara responds: In <b>the latter clause, we come to</b> discuss <b>a water bird,</b> which cannot be inspected, <b>since it has no membrane.</b> The Gemara clarifies: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> that it <b>has no membrane?</b> One can see that it does. <b>Rather,</b> the response is: <b>Since its membrane is fragile,</b> it must have ruptured when the skull was broken.
Similarly, the Gemara relates that <b>Rav Naḥman said to Rav Anan: The Master says</b> that <b>Shmuel inspects</b> a bird bitten on the head by a weasel <b>with</b> his <b>hand and deems it kosher</b> if the membrane is not perforated, <b>and our colleague</b> Rav <b>Huna</b> also <b>says that Rav inspects</b> it <b>by hand and deems it kosher. But doesn’t Levi teach:</b> Those <b><i>tereifot</i> that the Sages enumerated in an animal</b> apply <b>likewise in a bird,</b> and <b>in addition to those, a bird</b> is a <i>tereifa</i> if <b>the bone</b> of the skull <b>was broken, even if the membrane of the brain was not perforated?</b> If so, how can a bird be permitted through inspection? Rav Anan <b>said to him: That</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a water bird,</b> which cannot be inspected <b>since it has no membrane.</b> The Gemara clarifies: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> that it <b>has no membrane? Rather,</b> the response is: <b>Since its membrane is fragile.</b>
Similarly, the Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain hen that was in the house of Rav Ḥana</b> whose skull was injured. <b>He sent it before Rav Mattana,</b> who inspected it and found that <b>the bone</b> of the skull <b>was broken but the membrane of the brain was not perforated, and he deemed it kosher.</b> Rav Ḥana <b>said to</b> Rav Mattana: <b>But doesn’t Levi teach:</b> Those <b><i>tereifot</i> that the Sages enumerated in an animal</b> hold <b>likewise in a bird,</b> and <b>in addition to those, a bird</b> is a <i>tereifa</i> if <b>the bone</b> of the skull <b>was broken, even if the membrane of the brain was not perforated?</b> Rav Mattana <b>said to him: That</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a water bird,</b> which cannot be inspected <b>since it has no membrane.</b> The Gemara clarifies: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> that it <b>has no membrane? Rather, say</b> that his response was: <b>Since its membrane is fragile.</b>
The Gemara notes that <b>Rav Sheizvi would inspect</b> the membrane of the brain <b>by</b> the light of <b>the sun. Rav Yeimar would inspect</b> it <b>by</b> pouring <b>water</b> into the skull through the hole, to see if it emerges mixed with nerve tissue. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov would inspect</b> it

Daf 56b

<b>by</b> dragging <b>a wheat straw</b> over the membrane to see if it would catch on a perforation.
<b>Rav Sheizvi said: Our geese are considered like water birds.</b> If the skull of a goose is broken, even if the membrane is not perforated, it is a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ The mishna states: In a case where a bird <b>fell into the fire</b> and its innards were singed, if they turned green the bird is a <i>tereifa</i>; if they are red the bird is kosher. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yosei ben Yehoshua: The measure of their</b> turning <b>green is like the measure of their perforation. Just as their perforation in any amount</b> renders them a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>so too their turning green in any amount</b> renders them a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rav Yosef, son of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, asked Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: If a liver turned green</b> on the side <b>facing the intestines, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>said to him:</b> The bird is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to him: But</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>should be no more</b> stringent than that of a case where the liver was <b>removed</b> and an olive-bulk remained (see 54a), in which case the bird is kosher. Therefore, as long as an olive-bulk remains red, the bird should be kosher. <b>Rava said: Since the liver turned green facing the intestines, it is certain that</b> the bird <b>fell into the fire and the intestines</b> themselves <b>were singed, and</b> this is why the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> not because of the liver per se.
The Gemara recounts: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi had a certain hen</b> that fell into the fire. After it was slaughtered, <b>he sent it before the distinguished Rabbi Elazar HaKappar and said to him:</b> Its innards <b>were green, and</b> Rabbi Elazar HaKappar <b>deemed it kosher.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi asked: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: If they turned <b>green</b> they are <b>unfit?</b> Rabbi Elazar HaKappar said to him: The Sages <b>said</b> that if they turned <b>green</b> they are <b>unfit only with regard to the gizzard, the heart, and the liver,</b> which are naturally red. Other innards of a hen, such as the intestines, are naturally green, and a green appearance in them does not render the hen a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara notes: <b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Concerning which innards did they say</b> that a green appearance renders the bird a <i>tereifa</i>? Only <b>concerning the gizzard, the heart, and the liver.</b>
The Gemara recounts: <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosef had a certain hen</b> that fell into the fire. After it was slaughtered, <b>he sent it before Rabbi Abbahu and said to him:</b> Its innards <b>were red, and</b> Rabbi Elazar HaKappar <b>deemed it a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosef asked: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: If they are <b>red,</b> the bird is <b>kosher?</b> Rabbi Elazar HaKappar <b>said to him: Red</b> innards <b>that turned green and green</b> innards <b>that turned red</b> render the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> The Sages <b>said</b> in the mishna that <b>red</b> innards <b>are kosher only with regard to the heart, the gizzard, and the liver,</b> because these organs are naturally red. Organs that are naturally green, however, render the bird a <i>tereifa</i> if they have turned red.
<b>Rav Shmuel bar Ḥiyya says</b> that <b>Rabbi Mani says:</b> If <b>red</b> organs <b>turned green, and one boiled them and they turned red again, they are kosher. What is the reason?</b> This proves that they were not burned; rather, <b>smoke entered them</b> and changed their color temporarily. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: We, too, will say:</b> If <b>red</b> organs <b>did not turn green, and one boiled them and they</b> then <b>turned green,</b> the animal is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. What is the reason? Their shame was revealed,</b> i.e., it is evident that they were in fact burned. <b>Rav Ashi said: Therefore,</b> even if a bird’s innards remain red after it fell in a fire, <b>a person may eat it only</b> if it is <b>boiled,</b> to be certain that the innards will not turn green. The Gemara rejects this: <b>But</b> that <b>is not so,</b> since <b>we do not presume</b> the existence of <b>a flaw</b> without evidence.
§ The mishna states: If a person <b>trampled</b> the bird, <b>or slammed it against a wall,</b> or if an animal crushed it, and it lasted twenty-four hours, and then one slaughtered it, it is kosher. <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Antigonus says in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yannai: Both this and that,</b> i.e., all of the above cases, <b>require inspection</b> after slaughter, to ascertain that there is no injury that would itself render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these are kosher among birds:</b> If a bird’s <b>windpipe was perforated or cracked</b> lengthwise; or if <b>a weasel struck</b> the bird <b>on its head</b> in <b>a place that does not render it a <i>tereifa</i>;</b> or if <b>the crop was perforated. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> It is kosher <b>even</b> if the crop <b>was removed.</b> If the bird’s <b>intestines emerged</b> from the abdominal wall <b>but were not perforated,</b> or if <b>its wings were broken,</b> or if <b>its legs were broken,</b> or if the feathers on <b>its wings were plucked,</b> the bird is kosher. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If the down</b> covering its body <b>was removed,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i> and <b>unfit</b> for consumption.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving Rabbi Simai and Rabbi Tzadok, who went to intercalate the year in Lod, and they spent Shabbat in</b> the town of <b>Ono. And they ruled with regard to</b> an animal whose <b>womb</b> was removed, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi in the mishna <b>with regard to the crop.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: What is the meaning of the <i>baraita</i>? Is it referring to two different rulings, i.e., that <b>they ruled with regard to the womb to prohibit</b> it, and they also ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>with regard to the crop to permit</b> it? <b>Or perhaps</b> it is referring to only one ruling, and it means that <b>they ruled with regard to the womb to permit</b> it, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>with regard to the crop, but they do not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>with regard to the crop</b> itself. The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rabba says, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> who says: <b>The roof the crop is treated like the gullet,</b> i.e., it renders the bird a <i>tereifa</i> if perforated in any amount. The Gemara asks: <b>Where</b> is the roof of the crop? <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said:</b> It is <b>any</b> part of the crop <b>that stretches with</b> the gullet.
§ The mishna states: If the bird’s <b>intestines emerged</b> from the stomach wall but were not perforated, the bird is kosher. <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where one did not jumble them,</b> but returned them to the stomach in their proper order. <b>But</b> if <b>he jumbled them,</b> the bird is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, as it is written: “Has He not made you, and established you?”</b> (Deuteronomy 32:6). The verse <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created established</b> locations for each organ <b>in a person,</b> so <b>that if one of them is switched he cannot live.</b> The same applies to other creatures.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir would say</b> that the verse: <b>“Has He not made you, and established you?”</b> teaches that the Jewish people is <b>a city with everything in it. Out of it</b> come <b>its priests, out of it</b> come <b>its prophets, out of it</b> come <b>its chiefs, out of it</b> come <b>its kings, as it is stated: “Out of them shall come forth the cornerstone, out of them the stake,</b> out of them the battle bow, out of them every master together” (Zechariah 10:4).
The Gemara recounts an incident involving <b>a certain Roman who saw a certain man fall from the roof to the ground,</b> and <b>his stomach ruptured and his intestines emerged.</b> The Roman <b>brought</b> the man’s <b>son and slaughtered him before</b> his father’s eyes

Daf 57a

<b>deceptively,</b> i.e., he only pretended to kill the son. The father <b>fainted and went limp.</b> By this movement, <b>his intestines entered</b> his stomach, and the Roman <b>sewed up his stomach,</b> and he recovered.
§ The mishna states: If <b>its legs were broken,</b> the bird remains kosher. The Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain basket of birds</b> with broken legs <b>that came before Rava. Rava inspected</b> each bird <b>at the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh, <b>and</b> when he found that all its sinews were intact, <b>he deemed it kosher.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: A dislocated foreleg in an animal is kosher. A dislocated femur in an animal</b> renders it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. A dislocated femur in a bird</b> renders it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. A dislocated wing in a bird</b> renders it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> because <b>we</b> must be <b>concerned</b> that <b>perhaps the lung was perforated.</b> The lung is located near the wing’s attachment to the body, and part of the lung may have been torn out with the wing. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> The lung <b>should be inspected,</b> and if no damage is found, the bird is kosher. <b>And so says Rabbi Yoḥanan: It should be inspected.</b>
<b>Ḥizkiyya,</b> son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, <b>says: A bird has no lungs. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> A bird <b>does have</b> lungs, <b>and they are like a rose petal</b> in appearance, thin and red, <b>between the wings.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does Ḥizkiyya mean when he says that <b>a bird has no lungs? If we say that it has no</b> lungs <b>at all,</b> that is problematic, as <b>don’t we see that it does have</b> lungs? <b>Rather,</b> say that he means <b>that</b> the bird <b>is not rendered a <i>tereifa</i> by them</b> if they are perforated. But this, too, is problematic, as <b>doesn’t Levi teach:</b> Those <b><i>tereifot</i> that the Sages enumerated in an animal</b> hold <b>likewise in a bird,</b> and <b>in addition to those, a bird</b> is a <i>tereifa</i> if <b>the bone</b> of the skull <b>was broken, even if the membrane of the brain was not perforated?</b> If so, a perforated lung in a bird, as in an animal, renders it a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rather,</b> say that Ḥizkiyya means that a bird’s lung <b>has no</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>falling and no</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>singeing.</b> If a bird falls, one need not inspect the lungs for damage as he must other organs (see 51b), and if it falls in a fire, one need not inspect the lungs for a change in color as he must other organs (see 56b). <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Rav Ḥana said: Since a majority of</b> the bird’s <b>ribs protect</b> the lungs, one need not be concerned that the lung was damaged.
The Gemara asks: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> in response: A bird <b>does have</b> lungs, <b>and they are like a rose petal between the wings, by inference</b> one must conclude <b>that Ḥizkiyya maintains that it has no</b> lungs at all. <b>Rather,</b> one must say as <b>they say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: From the statement of the Distinguished,</b> i.e., Ḥizkiyya, <b>it is apparent that he is unfamiliar with chickens.</b>
§ <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: A dislocated femur in a bird is kosher. Rabba bar Rav Huna said to Rav Huna: But the Rabbis that came from Pumbedita said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda says in the name of Rav: A dislocated femur in a bird</b> renders it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> Rav Huna <b>said to him: My son, each river and its course,</b> i.e., different communities observe different customs. Although Rav himself held that such a bird is kosher, he ruled for those living in Pumbedita that such a bird is a <i>tereifa</i>, in accordance with their own custom.
The Gemara recounts: <b>Rabbi Abba went</b> and <b>found Rav Yirmeya bar Abba inspecting</b> birds <b>at the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh. Rabbi Abba <b>said to him: Why</b> must <b>Master</b> do <b>all this? But doesn’t Rav Huna say</b> that <b>Rav</b> says: <b>A dislocated femur in a bird is kosher?</b> If a bird is kosher even when the whole thigh has been removed, all the more so it should be kosher when only the convergence of sinews has been removed. Rav Yirmeya bar Abba <b>said to him: I know the mishna</b> (76a): With regard to <b>an animal whose hind legs were severed,</b> if they were severed <b>from the leg joint and below,</b> it is <b>kosher; from the leg joint and above,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i> and <b>unfit</b> for consumption. <b>And likewise</b> an animal whose <b>convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh <b>was removed</b> is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And Rav said about this: And likewise with regard to a bird.</b>
Rabbi Abba responded: <b>If so,</b> this statement <b>of Rav,</b> that a bird whose convergence of sinews was removed is a <i>tereifa</i>, poses <b>a difficulty for</b> that statement <b>of Rav,</b> that a bird with a dislocated femur is kosher. Rav Yirmeya bar Abba <b>was silent</b> and did not respond. Rabbi Abba <b>said to him: Perhaps there is a difference for</b> Rav <b>between a dislocated</b> femur <b>and a severed</b> femur, and while the former does not render a bird a <i>tereifa</i>, the latter does. Rav Yirmeya bar Abba <b>said to him: And are you interpreting Rav’s <i>halakhot</i></b> based on your own reasoning? <b>Rav said explicitly: A dislocated</b> femur <b>is kosher,</b> while <b>a severed</b> femur renders the animal <b>unfit</b> for consumption. <b>And do not be confounded</b> by this distinction, <b>as</b> one <b>cuts</b> an animal <b>from here,</b> in one place, <b>and it dies,</b> but one <b>cuts it from there,</b> in another place, <b>and it lives.</b>
The Gemara recounts: <b>When Rabbi Abba went up</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found Rabbi Zeira sitting and saying: Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> that <b>a dislocated femur in a bird</b> renders it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> Rabbi Abba <b>said to him:</b> By <b>Master’s life, since the day that Master came up to here,</b> Eretz Yisrael,

Daf 57b

<b>we had the opportunity to speak with Rav Huna, and we asked him</b> about this matter, <b>and he said to us: A dislocated femur in a bird is kosher.</b>
<b>And I also found Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba sitting and inspecting</b> birds <b>at the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh. <b>And I</b> posed <b>a difficulty to him: Doesn’t Master maintain</b> in accordance with <b>this</b> statement <b>that Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says: A dislocated femur in a bird is kosher?</b> Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba <b>said to me: I know the mishna</b> (76a): With regard to <b>an animal whose hind legs were severed,</b> if they were severed <b>from the leg joint and below,</b> it is <b>kosher; from the leg joint and above,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i> and <b>unfit</b> for consumption. <b>And likewise</b> an animal whose <b>convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh <b>was removed</b> is a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And Rav said about this: And likewise with regard to a bird.</b>
<b>And I said to him: If so,</b> this statement <b>of Rav</b> poses <b>a difficulty for</b> that statement <b>of Rav.</b> Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba <b>was silent. And I challenged him: But perhaps there is a difference for Rav between a dislocated</b> femur <b>and a severed</b> one. <b>And he said to me: And are you interpreting Rav’s <i>halakha</i></b> based on your own reasoning? <b>Rav said explicitly: A dislocated</b> femur <b>is kosher,</b> while <b>a severed</b> femur renders the animal <b>unfit</b> for consumption.
Rabbi Abba then asked Rabbi Zeira: <b>And</b> as for <b>you, what is in your hand?</b> What have you heard with regard to this <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: This</b> is what <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi says</b> that <b>Rav says: A dislocated femur in a bird</b> renders it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And so said Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A dislocated femur in a bird</b> renders it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
<b>And</b> with regard to this, <b>Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi said: If Rabbi Yoḥanan had been in the place where the assembly ruled to permit</b> such a bird, he would <b>not</b> have <b>stirred.</b> In other words, he would not have contested their ruling, because they were the greatest Sages of the previous generation. <b>As Rabbi Ḥanina says</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: A dislocated femur in a bird is kosher. And Rabbi Ḥanina had a hen whose femur was dislocated, and he brought it before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>permitted it to him, and Rabbi Ḥanina salted</b> the hen to preserve it. <b>And he would teach the students the <i>halakha</i> with it,</b> as he would show them the preserved body of the hen and say: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permitted this to me, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permitted this to me.</b>
The Gemara concludes: <b>But the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with any of these statements. Rather,</b> it is <b>in accordance with that which Rabbi Yosei ben Nehorai asked Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: In what amount</b> must <b>a windpipe</b> be <b>punctured</b> to render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>? Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>said to him: We learned a full mishna</b> (54a): <b>Until</b> the perforation is the same size <b>as the Italian <i>issar</i>.</b> Rabbi Yosei ben Nehorai <b>said to him: But wasn’t there a certain ewe in our neighborhood whose windpipe was punctured</b> in a greater amount, <b>and they made</b> a seal <b>for</b> the windpipe out of <b>the shell of a reed and it lived?</b>
Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>said to him: And do you rely on this</b> incident as evidence? <b>But isn’t it a widespread <i>halakha</i> among the Jewish people</b> that <b>a dislocated femur in a bird</b> renders it <b>a <i>tereifa</i>? And</b> still, <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Ḥalafta had a hen whose femur was dislocated, and they made it</b> a support out of the <b>tube of a reed and it lived. Rather, what have you to say</b> about this case? It must have <b>occurred within twelve months</b> of the dislocation, and afterward the hen died, since no <i>tereifa</i> can live more than twelve months. <b>Here, too,</b> in the case of the punctured windpipe, the episode <b>occurred within twelve months</b> of the injury and the ewe later died.
§ <b>They said about Rabbi Shimon ben Ḥalafta that he was a researcher of</b> various <b>matters, and he would act to counter the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, as Rabbi Yehuda would say: If the down</b> covering a bird’s body <b>was removed,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i> and <b>unfit</b> for consumption, as stated in the mishna. <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Ḥalafta had a hen whose down was removed, and he placed it in an oven,</b> a warm place, <b>and he covered it with a Coppersmiths’ [<i>tarsiyyim</i>] apron, and its new,</b> i.e., rehabilitated, <b>wings grew</b> even <b>more</b> feathers <b>than the original</b> wings.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how does this counter Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion? <b>Perhaps Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> can live and that its health can even <b>improve</b> beyond its previous state. The Gemara responds: Even <b>if</b> this is <b>so,</b> would Rabbi Yehuda say so <b>with regard to the</b> very <b>thing</b> with <b>which it was rendered a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> as is the case here, where <b>it grew new wings</b> with <b>more</b> feathers <b>than the original</b> wings?
The Gemara asks: From <b>what</b> episode did Rabbi Shimon ben Ḥalafta earn the title: <b>Researcher of matters? Rav Mesharshiyya said:</b> He saw <b>that it is written: “Go to the ant, you sluggard; consider her ways, and be wise; which having no chief, overseer, or ruler, provides her bread in the summer”</b> (Proverbs 6:6–8). Rabbi Shimon ben Ḥalafta <b>said: I will go and see if it is correct that they have no king.</b>
<b>He went in the season of Tammuz,</b> i.e., summer. Knowing that ants avoid intense heat, <b>he spread his cloak over an ant hole</b> to provide shade. <b>One of</b> the ants <b>came out</b> and saw the shade. Rabbi Shimon <b>placed a distinguishing mark on</b> the ant. <b>It went into</b> the hole and <b>said to</b> the other ants: <b>Shade has fallen. They</b> all <b>came out</b> to work. Rabbi Shimon <b>lifted up his cloak,</b> and <b>the sun fell</b> on them. They all <b>fell upon</b> the first ant <b>and killed it. He said:</b> One may <b>learn from</b> their actions that <b>they have no king; as, if they had a king, would they not need the king’s edict [<i>harmana</i>]</b> to execute their fellow ant?
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: But perhaps the king was with them</b> at the time and gave them permission. <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>they</b> already <b>possessed the king’s edict</b> giving them license to kill the ant. <b>Or</b> perhaps it <b>was</b> an interregnum <b>between kings, as it is written: “In those days there was no king in Israel; every man did that which was right in his own eyes”</b> (Judges 17:6). <b>Rather, rely on the credibility of Solomon,</b> the author of Proverbs, that ants have no king.
§ <b>Rav Huna says: The sign of a <i>tereifa</i></b> is <b>twelve months.</b> If it is uncertain whether an animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, one may wait twelve months; if the animal survives, it is kosher. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The sign of a <i>tereifa</i></b> is <b>any</b> animal <b>that cannot give birth. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> If its health <b>improves continuously, it is certainly kosher;</b> if its health <b>deteriorates continuously, it is certainly a <i>tereifa</i>. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: The sign of a <i>tereifa</i></b> is any animal that does not survive <b>thirty days.</b> The Sages <b>said to him: But don’t many</b> animals that are certainly <i>tereifot</i> <b>survive two</b> or <b>three years?</b> None of the opinions cited in the <i>baraita</i> accord with Rav Huna’s statement.
The Gemara responds: The matter <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And in a skull that contains one long hole,</b> or <b>even</b> if it has <b>many holes,</b> the areas of the holes <b>join together to</b> constitute the <b>size of a drill hole,</b> and they render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rabbi Yosei ben HaMeshullam said:</b> There was <b>an incident in</b> a place called <b>Inbul involving one whose skull was missing</b> a piece, <b>and they made for him</b> a patch out of <b>the shell of a gourd, and he survived.</b> Therefore, an animal with a missing piece of skull cannot be a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said to him:</b> Can you bring <b>proof from there? It was summer</b> then, <b>and once winter came upon him he died immediately.</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar holds that an animal is a <i>tereifa</i> if it does not survive through summer and winter, i.e., one year. Rav Huna’s statement accords with this opinion.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> can give birth and</b> its health can even <b>improve.</b> If the animal appears to recover or gives birth, this does not prove it is not a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Ameimar says:</b> With regard to <b>these eggs of a <i>tereifa</i></b> bird,

Daf 58a

<b>the first clutch [<i>shiḥala</i>]</b> of eggs that were in its body at the time it was rendered a <i>tereifa</i> <b>is prohibited</b> for consumption, because these eggs are considered part of the bird and were therefore rendered <i>tereifa</i> along with it. But as for any egg fertilized <b>from this</b> point <b>forward, it is</b> a case where both <b>this and that cause</b> it, i.e., a <i>tereifa</i> female and a kosher male, <b>and</b> as a rule, when permitted and prohibited causes operate together, the joint result is <b>permitted.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi raised an objection to Ameimar</b> from a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 5:1): <b>And</b> all <b>agree with regard to the egg of a <i>tereifa</i></b> bird <b>that it is prohibited</b> for consumption, <b>because it grew in</b> a state of <b>prohibition.</b> Evidently, even eggs created after the bird was rendered a <i>tereifa</i> are prohibited. Ameimar said to him: <b>There,</b> the mishna is dealing <b>with</b> a bird <b>that is heated by the earth,</b> i.e., that was not fertilized by a male, and the female <i>tereifa</i> is therefore the sole source of the egg.
The Gemara objects: <b>And let</b> Ameimar <b>answer</b> differently, that the mishna is dealing <b>with the first clutch</b> of eggs, which were part of the mother’s body when it became a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara responds: <b>If</b> this was <b>so,</b> why does the mishna state: Because <b>it grew</b> in a state of prohibition? The mishna <b>should have</b> stated: Because it <b>was finished</b> in a state of prohibition.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> if the offspring in the womb of an animal becomes a <i>tereifa</i> along with it, then <b>that which we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> is difficult: With regard to the <b>offspring of a <i>tereifa</i>, Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that <b>it shall not be sacrificed on the altar, and Rabbi Yehoshua says</b> that <b>it may be sacrificed. With regard to what</b> case do they <b>disagree?</b> It must be <b>with regard to</b> a case <b>where</b> the mother animal <b>was rendered a <i>tereifa</i> and afterward became pregnant</b> from a kosher male, and <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds:</b> In a case where <b>this and that cause</b> it, it is <b>prohibited, and Rabbi Yehoshua holds:</b> In a case where <b>this and that cause</b> it, it is <b>permitted.</b> But <b>if so, rather than disputing</b> whether it is permitted to sacrifice such offspring <b>to the Most High, let them disagree</b> concerning the more basic issue of whether the offspring is permitted <b>to an ordinary</b> person for consumption.
The Gemara responds: The dispute addresses the question of whether it is permitted to sacrifice the animal as an offering in order <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature of</b> the lenient opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua, that</b> such an animal is <b>permitted even</b> as an offering <b>to the Most High.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let them disagree</b> concerning whether the animal is permitted <b>to an ordinary</b> person in order <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature</b> of the stringent opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer, that</b> such an animal <b>is prohibited even to an ordinary</b> person. The Gemara responds: It is <b>preferable for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to emphasize <b>the power of leniency.</b>
The Gemara concludes: Since Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua disagree with regard to an offspring brought about by two causes, it follows that when the mishna states: <b>And</b> they <b>concede with regard to the egg of a <i>tereifa</i></b> bird <b>that it is prohibited</b> for consumption, this is <b>referring to</b> a bird <b>that is heated by the earth</b> and was not fertilized by a male, so <b>that there is</b> only <b>one cause,</b> the <i>tereifa</i> mother bird.
The Gemara notes: <b>Rav Aḥa holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov,</b> who said at the end of the previous <i>amud</i> that a <i>tereifa</i> animal can be capable of giving birth, and similarly a <i>tereifa</i> bird can be capable of laying eggs as well, <b>and he</b> therefore <b>teaches</b> the statement <b>of Ameimar as we have said,</b> that any egg fertilized after the bird became a <i>tereifa</i> is permitted.
But <b>Ravina does not hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov.</b> Rather, he holds that a <i>tereifa</i> cannot produce eggs or give birth. <b>And he</b> therefore <b>teaches</b> the statement <b>of Ameimar in this formulation: Ameimar said</b> that with regard to <b>these eggs of</b> a bird concerning which it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: <b>We leave</b> aside <b>the first clutch</b> of eggs. <b>If</b> the bird <b>produces</b> eggs <b>again,</b> the first eggs <b>are permitted</b> for consumption, because the bird is certainly not a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>And if not, they are prohibited,</b> because they were considered part of the bird when it was rendered a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rav Ashi raised an objection to Ameimar</b> from a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 5:1): <b>And they concede with regard to the egg of a <i>tereifa</i></b> bird <b>that it is prohibited</b> for consumption, <b>because it grew in</b> a state of <b>prohibition.</b> Evidently, a <i>tereifa</i> bird can produce eggs. Ameimar <b>said to him:</b> The mishna <b>there</b> deals <b>with the first clutch</b> of eggs, which existed before the bird became a <i>tereifa</i>. Rav Ashi asks: <b>If so,</b> why does the mishna state: Because <b>it grew</b> in a state of prohibition? The mishna <b>should have</b> stated: Because it <b>was finished</b> in a state of prohibition. Ameimar responded: <b>Teach</b> an emended version of the mishna: Because it <b>was finished</b> in a state of prohibition.
Rav Ashi asks: <b>But</b> if a <i>tereifa</i> cannot become pregnant, <b>that which we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> is difficult: With regard to <b>the offspring of a <i>tereifa</i>, Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that <b>it shall not be sacrificed on the altar,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says</b> that <b>it may be sacrificed. With regard to what</b> case do they <b>disagree?</b> It must be <b>with regard to</b> a case <b>where</b> the mother animal <b>became pregnant and</b> only <b>afterward was rendered a <i>tereifa</i>. Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that <b>a fetus is</b> considered like <b>the thigh of its mother</b> and is rendered a <i>tereifa</i> as part of its body, <b>and Rabbi Yehoshua holds</b> that <b>a fetus is not</b> considered like <b>the thigh of its mother.</b> The Gemara objects: But <b>if so, rather than disputing</b> whether it is permitted to sacrifice such offspring <b>to the Most High, let them dispute</b> the more basic issue of whether the offspring is permitted <b>to an ordinary</b> person for consumption.
The Gemara responds: The mishna discusses the question of whether it is permitted to sacrifice the animal as an offering in order <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature</b> of the lenient opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua</b> that such an animal is permitted even as an offering to the Most High. The Gemara suggests: <b>But let them dispute</b> whether the animal is permitted <b>to an ordinary</b> person, in order <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature</b> of the stringent opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer</b> that such an animal is prohibited even to an ordinary person. The Gemara responds: It is <b>preferable for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to emphasize <b>the power of leniency.</b>
The Gemara concludes: According to this explanation, when the mishna states: <b>And they certainly concede with regard to the egg of a <i>tereifa</i></b> bird <b>that it is prohibited</b> for consumption, it is dealing <b>with the first clutch</b> of eggs in the bird’s oviduct at the time it becomes a <i>tereifa</i>. Even Rabbi Yehoshua, who holds that the fetus of an animal is not considered like the thigh of its mother, concedes that a bird’s egg is rendered a <i>tereifa</i> along with it. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Rabbi Yehoshua holds that an egg <b>is</b> a true part of <b>its body.</b>
The Gemara rules: <b>And</b> with regard to an animal concerning which it is uncertain whether it is a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is: <b>In</b> the case of <b>a male,</b> it is prohibited for <b>an entire twelve-month</b> period. After that point, the animal is certainly kosher. <b>In</b> the case of <b>a female, any</b> animal <b>that does not give birth</b> is prohibited. Once it has, it is certainly kosher.
§ <b>Rav Huna says: Any creature that has no bones cannot last twelve months. Rav Pappa said:</b> One may <b>learn from Rav Huna’s</b> statement about <b>that which Shmuel says: If a serpent melon became infested by worms while attached to the ground</b> [<b><i>be’ibbeha</i></b>], the worm <b>is prohibited</b> for consumption, in accordance with the verse: “And every swarming thing that swarms upon the earth is a detestable thing; it shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 11:41).

Daf 58b

<b>These dates</b> stored in <b>a jar are permitted after</b> remaining there for <b>twelve months</b> of <b>the year.</b> Since worms have no bones, they cannot last twelve months. Consequently, any worms found in the dates must have hatched after they were picked and are therefore permitted.
<b>Rav says: There is no one-day-old mosquito,</b> since all mosquitoes die before they have lived a day. <b>And there is no one-year-old fly.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: But isn’t</b> there the adage that <b>people say</b> that <b>the female mosquito revolted against the male mosquito seven years, since she said to him: I saw a townsman swimming in the water, and he came out and wrapped himself in sheets, and you sat on him and sucked</b> blood <b>from him, and you did not inform me?</b> Apparently, some boneless creatures can survive at least seven years. Abaye <b>said to him: And according to your reasoning,</b> what about <b>that</b> adage <b>that people say: Six thousand iron dinars hang in a mosquito’s mallet,</b> i.e., its bite is powerful? <b>Is there</b> really such a thing? <b>How much does</b> the mosquito <b>itself</b> weigh? <b>Rather,</b> the saying must be referring <b>to hundreds of their own dinars,</b> i.e., the mosquitoes’ coins. <b>Here, too,</b> the adage is referring <b>to their own years,</b> not human years.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Bekhorot</i> 40a): <b>With regard to an animal with five legs, or</b> one <b>that has only three, this is a blemish,</b> and the animal may not be brought as an offering. <b>Rav Huna said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the animal <b>was missing or had an additional foreleg. But</b> if it <b>was missing or had an additional hind leg, it is also a <i>tereifa</i>. What is the reason?</b> It is that <b>any extra</b> limb <b>is considered like a removed</b> limb. An animal whose foreleg was removed is kosher, but if its hind leg was removed it is a <i>tereifa</i>; the same applies if it had an extra leg.
The Gemara recounts the case of <b>a certain animal that had two ceca. They brought it to Ravina, and he deemed it a <i>tereifa</i> based on</b> the statement <b>of Rav Huna</b> that an extra limb is like a missing limb. Since an animal missing a cecum is a <i>tereifa</i>, an animal with an extra cecum is likewise a <i>tereifa</i>. The Gemara adds: <b>But if they empty into each other,</b> such that food can move freely between them, the animal is <b>kosher,</b> because they are considered one organ.
The Gemara recounts the case of <b>a certain tube that exited from the reticulum into the omasum. Rav Ashi thought to deem</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. Rav Huna Mar bar Ḥiyya said to Rav Ashi: All animals</b> that dwell <b>outside have</b> tubes like <b>this,</b> and one need not be concerned.
The Gemara recounts the case of <b>a certain tube that passed from the reticulum to the rumen. Mar bar Rav Ashi thought to deem</b> the animal <b>kosher,</b> as in the above case. <b>Rav Oshaya said to him: Is that to say all</b> such cases <b>are woven in one weave? Where it was stated</b> that such an organ is normal, <b>it was stated; where it was not stated, it was not stated.</b> This animal is a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Natan bar Sheila, head of the butchers of Tzippori, testified before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>about two intestines that exit</b> the abomasum of <b>the animal as one, that this</b> renders the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. But</b> if this phenomenon occurs <b>likewise in a bird,</b> it is <b>kosher,</b> because it is common in birds. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said,</b> i.e., that two intestines render an animal a <i>tereifa</i>? It is said in a case <b>where they exit at two different points. But</b> if <b>they exit at one point,</b> adjacent to each other, <b>and they end,</b> i.e., they merge into one intestine, <b>within a fingerbreadth,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b>
<b>Rav Ami and Rav Asi disagree with regard to</b> this <i>halakha</i>. <b>One says: It</b> is kosher when the two intestines exit at one point only in a case <b>where they subsequently merge</b> into one intestine; <b>and one says:</b> It is kosher <b>even if they do not subsequently merge.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that <b>it</b> is kosher only in a case <b>where they subsequently merge, this</b> explanation is consistent with <b>that which</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Within a fingerbreadth.</b> That is, the two intestines must merge within a fingerbreadth for the animal to be kosher. <b>But according to the one who says:</b> It is kosher <b>even if they do not subsequently merge, what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: And they end <b>within a fingerbreadth?</b> The Gemara responds: It means <b>within a fingerbreadth below.</b> As long as the intestines merge before the final fingerbreadth near the anus, the animal is kosher.
§ The mishna states: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If the down</b> covering its body <b>was removed,</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i> and <b>unfit</b> for consumption, like an animal whose hide was removed. With regard to this, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yishmael said the same thing. Rabbi Yehuda</b> said <b>that which we said</b> here, that the removal of the feathers is like removal of the hide. <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> agrees, <b>as we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: The down joins</b> the flesh to constitute an olive-bulk for purposes of <i>piggul</i>. If a priest pinches the nape of the neck of a bird with intent to consume a combined olive-bulk of its meat and its down beyond the permitted time, the offering is rendered <i>piggul</i>. Evidently, both Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yishmael agree that the down of a bird is considered like the hide of an animal.
<b>Rava said: Perhaps it is not so,</b> and they disagree. Perhaps <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that the down is like the hide of an animal <b>here only with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, since</b> when the down is removed, <b>there is nothing that protects</b> the bird, and its life is in danger; <b>but with regard to <i>piggul</i>, he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> that the down is not treated like the hide of an animal, because <i>piggul</i> applies only if one had intent to consume an item that is normally consumed. <b>And</b> perhaps <b>Rabbi Yishmael says</b> so <b>there only with regard to <i>piggul</i>,</b> since he holds that the down is in fact fit for consumption; <b>but with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> he holds that the down <b>does not protect</b> the bird, and its removal does not endanger it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to an animal that is <b>congested with</b> excess <b>blood, or that</b> was <b>smoked,</b> i.e., that suffered from smoke inhalation, <b>or that</b> was <b>chilled</b> and subsequently became sick, <b>or that ate oleander,</b> which is poisonous, <b>or that ate the excrement of chickens, or that drank foul water,</b> although in all these cases the animal is in danger, it is <b>kosher.</b> By contrast, if the animal <b>ate deadly poison, or</b> if <b>a snake bit</b> the animal, <b>with regard to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>tereifa</i>,</b> consumption of the animal would be <b>permitted, but</b> it is <b>prohibited due to the threat to</b> one’s <b>life</b> if he eats it.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Shmuel says:</b> If one <b>fed</b> an animal <b>asafoetida,</b> a very sharp plant, it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. What is the reason? Since it perforates its intestines.</b>
<b>Rav Sheizvi raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: An animal that is <b>congested with</b> excess <b>blood, or that</b> suffered from <b>smoke</b> inhalation, <b>or that ate</b> poisonous <b>oleander, or that ate the excrement of roosters, or that drank foul water,</b> or if <b>one fed it <i>tia</i>, asafoetida, or peppers,</b> or if it <b>ate deadly poison,</b> it is <b>kosher.</b> But if <b>a snake bit</b> the animal, <b>or if a mad dog bit it, with regard to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>tereifa</i></b> its consumption is <b>permitted, but</b> it is nevertheless <b>prohibited due to the threat to</b> one’s <b>life.</b> The statement of the <i>baraita</i> concerning an animal that was fed <b>asafoetida</b> poses <b>a difficulty to</b> Shmuel’s statement that <b>asafoetida</b> renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, and the statement concerning <b>deadly poison</b> poses <b>a difficulty to</b> the mishna’s statement that <b>deadly poison</b> renders the animal prohibited due to the threat to one’s life.
The Gemara responds: The apparent contradiction between one statement about <b>asafoetida</b> and the other statement about <b>asafoetida</b> is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a case where the animal ate asafoetida <b>leaves,</b> which are less dangerous. <b>There,</b> Shmuel is referring <b>to</b> a case where the animal ate <b>slivers</b> of asafoetida, which are very sharp. Likewise, the apparent contradiction between one statement about <b>deadly poison</b> and the other statement about <b>deadly poison</b> is <b>not difficult. This</b> statement of the <i>baraita</i> that it is permitted is referring to a case where the animal consumed poison that is deadly only <b>to itself. That</b> statement of the mishna that it is prohibited is referring to a case where it consumed poison deadly <b>to a person.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Poison deadly to an animal is</b> the same as <b>oleander;</b> why should the <i>baraita</i> mention both? The Gemara responds: The <i>tanna</i> is referring to <b>two types of deadly poison.</b>
