The above <i>baraita</i> teaches that if an animal was fed <i>tia</i>, it is kosher. The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>tia</i>? Rav Yehuda said:</b>

Daf 59a

It is <b>the root of a bitter</b> vegetable.
<b>Rav Yehuda says: This</b> individual <b>who eats</b> the weight of <b>three shekel of asafoetida on an empty heart,</b> i.e., stomach, <b>his skin sheds</b> due to the fever he contracts. <b>Rabbi Abbahu said: There was an incident in which I</b> was involved, wherein <b>I ate</b> the weight of <b>one shekel of asafoetida, and had I not</b> immediately <b>sat in water</b> to cool off, <b>my skin would have shed. And I</b> thereby <b>fulfilled with regard to myself</b> that which the verse states: <b>“Wisdom preserves the life of him that has it”</b> (Ecclesiastes 7:12).
<b>Rav Yosef says: This</b> individual <b>who eats sixteen eggs and forty nuts and seven fruits of the caper bush, and he drinks a quarter-<i>log</i> of honey in the season of Tammuz,</b> i.e., summer, all <b>on an empty heart,</b> i.e., stomach, <b>his heartstrings are uprooted.</b>
§ The mishna states that if an animal is bitten by a poisonous snake, it is not a <i>tereifa</i>, but it is nevertheless prohibited for consumption due to the hazard it poses. The Gemara recounts the case of <b>a certain young deer that was brought to the house of the Exilarch</b> after slaughter <b>whose hind legs had been cut. Rav inspected it at the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh and found them intact, <b>and he deemed it kosher. He thought to eat it rare,</b> i.e., lightly roasted. <b>Shmuel said to him: Is the Master not concerned for</b> the possibility that it may have <b>a snakebite?</b>
Rav <b>said to him: What is the rectification</b> for such an uncertainty? Shmuel said to him: <b>We shall set it in a</b> hot <b>oven, as it will</b> then <b>inspect itself.</b> Shmuel <b>set it</b> in the oven on a spit, and the meat <b>fell</b> off the bone <b>bit by bit,</b> a sign that a snake had bitten the young deer. <b>Shmuel recited about Rav</b> the verse: <b>“There shall no mischief befall the righteous”</b> (Proverbs 12:21), since he was saved due to his righteousness. <b>Rav recited about Shmuel</b> the verse: “And <b>no secret causes you trouble”</b> (Daniel 4:6), since he was learned even with regard to such matters.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The signs</b> that indicate that <b>a domesticated animal and an undomesticated animal</b> are kosher <b>were stated in the Torah, and the signs of</b> a kosher <b>bird were not</b> explicitly <b>stated. But the Sages stated</b> certain signs in a bird: <b>Any bird that claws</b> its prey and eats it is <b>non-kosher. Any</b> bird <b>that has an extra digit</b> behind the leg slightly elevated above the other digits, <b>and a crop,</b> which is a sack alongside the gullet in which food is stored prior to digestion, <b>and</b> for which the yellowish membrane inside <b>its gizzard can be peeled,</b> is <b>kosher. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: Any bird that splits</b> the digits of <b>its feet</b> when standing on a string, placing two digits on one side of the string and two on the other, is <b>non-kosher.</b>
<b>And with regard to grasshoppers,</b> whose signs were also not stated in the Torah, the Sages stated: <b>Any</b> grasshopper <b>that has four legs, and four wings, and</b> two additional <b>jumping legs, and whose wings cover most of its</b> body, is kosher. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: And</b> this applies only if the <b>name</b> of <b>its</b> species is <b>grasshopper. And with regard to fish,</b> the signs are explicitly stated in the Torah: <b>Any</b> fish <b>that has a fin and a scale</b> is kosher; <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Two scales and one fin. And these are scales:</b> Those <b>that</b> are <b>fixed to its</b> body; <b>and fins</b> are those <b>with which</b> the fish <b>swims.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that the signs of a kosher domesticated animal are stated in the Torah. With regard to this, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>These are the signs of a</b> kosher <b>domesticated animal: “Whatsoever parts the hoof,</b> and is wholly cloven-footed, and chews the cud, among the animals, that may you eat” (Leviticus 11:3). <b>Any animal that chews the cud certainly has no upper</b> front <b>teeth,</b> i.e., incisors, <b>and is kosher.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> this an established <b>principle? But</b> isn’t there <b>a camel, which chews the cud, and has no upper</b> front <b>teeth, and</b> it is still <b>non-kosher</b> (see Leviticus 11:4)? The Gemara responds: <b>A camel has cuspid</b>-like upper incisors, one on each side.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> isn’t there <b>a young camel, which does not even have cuspid</b>-like upper incisors and is still non-kosher? <b>And furthermore,</b> aren’t there the <b>hyrax and</b> the <b>hare, which chew the cud, and</b> yet <b>they have upper</b> front <b>teeth, and are non-kosher? And furthermore,</b> one might ask: <b>Are teeth written in the Torah</b> with regard to the kosher status of an animal? <b>Rather, this</b> is what the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying: Any animal that does not have upper</b> front <b>teeth certainly chews the cud and parts the hoof and is kosher.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why should one inspect the teeth? <b>Let him</b> simply <b>inspect</b> whether <b>the hooves</b> are cloven. The Gemara responds: One inspects the teeth in a case <b>where its hooves were cut</b> and one cannot tell whether they are cloven. <b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rav Ḥisda, as Rav Ḥisda says:</b> If one <b>was walking in the wilderness, and he found an animal whose hooves were cut, he may inspect its mouth. If it has no upper</b> front <b>teeth, it is certainly kosher; if</b> that is <b>not</b> the case, <b>it is certainly non-kosher, provided that he recognizes</b> that this animal is not <b>a camel,</b> which is non-kosher even though it has no upper incisors. The Gemara asks: Why must one recognize that this is not <b>a camel?</b> A camel <b>has cuspid</b>-like upper incisors. <b>Rather,</b> say: <b>Provided that one recognizes</b> that it is not <b>a young camel,</b> which has no cuspid-like upper incisors.
The Gemara asks: How can one rely only on an inspection of the mouth? <b>Did you not say that there is a young camel,</b> which has no upper incisors but is still non-kosher? If so, perhaps <b>there is also another species that is similar to a young camel</b> and is non-kosher despite having no upper incisors. The Gemara responds that this possibility should <b>not enter your mind, as the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The verse states: <b>“The camel, because it chews the cud</b> but parts not the hoof, it is unclean” (Leviticus 11:4). <b>The Ruler of His world knows that nothing other than</b> the <b>camel chews the cud and is</b> still <b>non-kosher. Therefore, the verse singles it out</b> with the word <b>“it,”</b> i.e., it and no other.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda says:</b> If one <b>was walking on the road, and he found an animal whose mouth was mutilated, he may inspect its hooves. If its hooves are cloven, it is certainly kosher. If not, it is certainly non-kosher.</b> This applies <b>provided that he recognizes</b> that it is not <b>a pig,</b> which is non-kosher even though it has cloven hooves.
The Gemara asks: But <b>didn’t you say that there is a pig,</b> which has cloven hooves but is still non-kosher? If so, perhaps <b>there is also another species that is similar to a pig.</b> The Gemara responds that this possibility should <b>not enter your mind, as the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The verse states: <b>“And the pig, because it parts the hoof,</b> and is cloven-footed, but chews not the cud, it is unclean” (Leviticus 11:7). <b>The Ruler of His world knows that nothing other than</b> the <b>pig parts the hoof and is</b> still <b>non-kosher. Therefore, the verse singles it out</b> with the word <b>“it.”</b>
<b>And Rav Ḥisda says:</b> If one <b>was walking in the wilderness, and he found an animal whose mouth was mutilated and whose hooves were cut, he may inspect its flesh. If it runs</b> like <b>warp and woof,</b> i.e., part of it stretches vertically and part of it horizontally, <b>it is certainly kosher; and if not, it is certainly non-kosher, provided that one recognizes</b> that this animal is not <b>a wild donkey,</b> which is non-kosher even though its flesh runs like warp and woof.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t you say that there is a wild donkey,</b> whose flesh runs like warp and woof but who is still non-kosher? If so, perhaps <b>there is also another species that is similar to a wild donkey.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>It is learned</b> as a tradition <b>that there are no</b> similar species. The Gemara asks: <b>And where does one inspect</b> the flesh? <b>Abaye said, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> said: <b>At the edges of the tailbone,</b> on the upper thighs.
§ The mishna states: <b>The signs of an undomesticated animal</b> were stated in the Torah. With regard to this, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>These are the signs of an undomesticated animal.</b> The Gemara interjects: Why does one need signs for an undomesticated animal? <b>An undomesticated animal [<i>ḥayya</i>] is included</b> in the category of <b>a domesticated animal [<i>behema</i>] with regard to signs,</b> as the verse states: “These are the living things [<i>ḥayya</i>] which you may eat among all the animals [<i>behema</i>] that are on the earth. Whatsoever parts the hoof” (Leviticus 11:2–3). <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b>

Daf 59b

The signs are given <b>to permit its</b> forbidden <b>fat,</b> i.e., to deem the animal undomesticated. Fat that is forbidden for consumption in domesticated animals is permitted in undomesticated animals. <b>And this</b> is what the <i>tanna</i> <b>is saying: These are the signs of a</b> kosher <b>undomesticated animal,</b> so that one will know <b>that its fat is permitted: Any</b> animal <b>that has horns and</b> cloven <b>hooves</b> is an undomesticated animal.
<b>Rabbi Dosa says:</b> If <b>it has horns,</b> it is certainly a kosher undomesticated animal, and <b>you need not search for</b> cloven <b>hooves.</b> But if <b>it has</b> cloven <b>hooves, you must</b> still <b>search for horns. And</b> with regard to the animal called <b>a <i>keresh</i>, even though it has only one horn,</b> its fat <b>is permitted</b> for consumption.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is</b> this an established <b>principle? But</b> isn’t there <b>a goat, which has horns and</b> cloven <b>hooves, and</b> still <b>its fat is forbidden,</b> as it is a domesticated animal? The Gemara responds: <b>We require</b> horns that are <b>layered</b> to designate a kosher animal as undomesticated; a goat’s horns are not layered. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> isn’t there <b>a bull, which</b> has <b>layered</b> horns, <b>and</b> still <b>its fat is forbidden</b> since it is domesticated? The Gemara responds: <b>We require horns</b> that are <b>grooved;</b> a bull’s horns are not grooved.
The Gemara persists: <b>But</b> isn’t there <b>a goat, which</b> has <b>grooved</b> horns, <b>and</b> still <b>its fat is forbidden?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>We require</b> horns that are <b>branched;</b> a goat’s horns are not branched. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> isn’t there <b>a gazelle [<i>tzevi</i>],</b> whose horns <b>are not branched, and</b> still <b>its fat is permitted?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>We require</b> horns that are <b>rounded</b> and not broad like those of a sheep.
The Gemara concludes: <b>Therefore, where</b> an animal’s horns are <b>branched, there is neither judgment nor judge,</b> and the animal is without a doubt undomesticated. <b>Where</b> they are <b>not branched, we require</b> that they be <b>layered, rounded, and grooved. And it</b> must be grooved in a pattern such <b>that its grooves are absorbed</b> into one another.
<b>And this is the uncertainty</b> that arose concerning the <b><i>karkoz</i> goat,</b> i.e., whether it is considered a domesticated animal. As there was <b>a certain <i>karkoz</i> goat that was in the house of the Exilarch, from which</b> they <b>removed a full basket of fat</b> after slaughtering it. <b>Rav Aḥai deemed</b> the fat <b>forbidden,</b> because he considered it a domesticated animal. But <b>Rav Shmuel, son of Rabbi Abbahu, ate of it. He read</b> the verse <b>about himself: “A man’s belly shall be filled with the fruit of his mouth”</b> (Proverbs 18:20). In other words, due to his learning, he knew it was permitted to eat the fat of the <i>karkoz</i> goat.
The Sages <b>sent</b> a message <b>from there,</b> Eretz Yisrael: <b>The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of</b> Rav <b>Shmuel, son of Rabbi Abbahu,</b> that a <i>karkoz</i> goat is an undomesticated animal and its fat is permitted; <b>but</b> nevertheless, <b>be mindful of</b> the honor of <b>our teacher Aḥai</b> who deems it forbidden, and do not partake of the fat in his presence, <b>as he enlightens the eyes of the exile.</b>
§ The <i>baraita</i> states: <b>And</b> with regard to the animal called <b>a <i>keresh</i>, even though it has only one horn,</b> its fat <b>is permitted</b> for consumption. <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> The <b><i>keresh</i></b> is the <b>gazelle</b> that is native to the area <b>of Bei Ila’ei.</b> The <b><i>tagras</i></b> mentioned by the Sages is the <b>lion of Bei Ila’ei. Rav Kahana says: There are nine cubits between the ears of the lion of Bei Ila’ei. Rav Yosef says: The length of the gazelle of Bei Ila’ei is sixteen cubits.</b>
The Gemara recounts: The Roman <b>emperor said to Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya: Your God is compared to a lion, as it is written: “The lion has roared, who will not fear”</b> (Amos 3:8). But if so, <b>what is His greatness? A cavalryman</b> can <b>kill a lion.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him:</b> God <b>is not compared to that lion</b> which a cavalryman can kill. Rather, God is <b>compared to the lion of Bei Ila’ei.</b> The emperor <b>said to him: I ask that you show it to me.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him: You cannot see it.</b> The emperor <b>said to him: Truly, I</b> wish to <b>see it.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>prayed for mercy,</b> and the lion of Bei Ila’ei <b>set off from its place</b> of origin toward Rome.
<b>When it was four hundred parasangs away</b> from Rome, <b>it roared once,</b> and <b>all the pregnant women miscarried, and the wall of Rome fell. When it was three hundred parasangs away, it roared another</b> time, and all <b>the men’s front and back teeth fell out</b> from fear. <b>And even he,</b> the emperor, <b>fell from his throne to the ground.</b> The emperor <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>I beg you, pray for mercy with regard to it, that it should go back to the place</b> from which <b>it</b> came. Rabbi Yehoshua <b>prayed for mercy with regard to it, and it returned to the place</b> from which <b>it</b> came.
§ The Gemara recounts: <b>The emperor said to Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya: I wish to see your God.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him: You cannot see Him.</b> The emperor <b>said to him: Truly,</b>

Daf 60a

<b>I</b> wish to <b>see Him.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>went and stood</b> the emperor <b>facing the sun in the season of Tammuz,</b> i.e., summer. Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him: Look at it.</b> The emperor <b>said to him: I cannot.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him:</b> Now, if with regard to <b>the sun, which is</b> only <b>one of the servants that stand before the Holy One, Blessed be He, you say: I cannot look at it,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> with regard to <b>the Divine Presence?</b>
§ The Gemara recounts: <b>The</b> Roman <b>emperor said to Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya: I desire to arrange bread,</b> i.e., a meal, <b>for your God.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him: You cannot.</b> The emperor asked him: <b>Why?</b> Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: <b>His hosts are too great.</b> The emperor <b>said to him: Truly,</b> I wish to do it. Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him: Go out and arrange</b> a meal <b>on the shore of the great</b> sea <b>[<i>dirvita</i>], where there is a wide</b> open <b>space.</b> The emperor <b>worked</b> all <b>the six months of summer</b> to accomplish this. <b>A wind came and swept it</b> all <b>into the sea.</b>
The emperor <b>worked</b> to arrange another meal all <b>the six months of winter. Rain came and sank it</b> all <b>in the sea.</b> The emperor <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehoshua: <b>What is this?</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him: These are</b> only the <b>sweepers</b> and floor <b>washers that wait on Him,</b> and they alone have eaten everything. The emperor <b>said to him: If so, I cannot</b> arrange a meal before Him.
§ The Gemara recounts: <b>The daughter of the</b> Roman <b>emperor said to Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya: Your God is a carpenter, as it is written: “Who lays the beams of His upper chambers in the waters”</b> (Psalms 104:3). <b>Tell Him to make for me a distaff,</b> a simple tool used in spinning. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya <b>said: Very well. He prayed for mercy for her and she was stricken</b> with leprosy. <b>She sat in the Roman market, and they gave her a distaff, since it was their custom</b> to <b>give a distaff to anyone stricken</b> with leprosy <b>in Rome, and</b> the leper would <b>sit in the market and untangle bunches</b> of wool, <b>so that people would see and pray for mercy on him.</b>
<b>One day</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya <b>was passing there,</b> and he saw that <b>she was sitting and untangling bunches</b> of wool <b>in the Roman market.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya <b>said to her: Is the distaff my God gave you pleasing? She said to him: Tell your God to take</b> back <b>what He has given me.</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya <b>said to her: Our God gives,</b> but <b>does not take.</b>
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says: A bull</b> has a large <b>paunch and</b> large <b>hooves. Its head is large, and its tail is large. And the opposite</b> is true <b>for a donkey.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> that results from such a statement? It is relevant <b>for</b> purposes of <b>buying and selling.</b> One who agrees to sell a bull must provide the buyer with one that fits this description, and the opposite for a donkey.
<b>And Rav Yehuda says:</b> The <b>bull that Adam, the first</b> man, <b>sacrificed</b> as a thanks offering for his life being spared <b>had a single horn on its forehead, as it is stated: “And it shall please the Lord better than a bullock that has horns [<i>makrin</i>] and hoofs”</b> (Psalms 69:32). The Gemara comments: On the contrary, the word <b><i>makrin</i> indicates two</b> horns. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> Although it is vocalized in the plural, <b><i>makran</i> is written</b> in the verse, without the letter <i>yod</i>, to indicate that it had only a single horn.
<b>And Rav Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>the bull that Adam, the first</b> man, <b>sacrificed, its horns preceded its hooves.</b> It was not born of a cow, but rose fully formed out of the earth such that its head emerged first, <b>as it is stated: “And it shall please the Lord better than a bullock that has horns and hoofs.”</b> The phrase <b>“has horns”</b> comes <b>first, and</b> only <b>afterward</b> the word <b>“hoofs.”</b>
And this <b>supports</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: All</b> items created during the <b>acts of Creation were created with their</b> full <b>stature,</b> immediately fit to bear fruit; <b>they were created with their</b> full mental <b>capacities; they were created with their</b> full <b>form. As it is stated: “And the heaven and the earth were finished, and all the host of them”</b> (Genesis 2:1). <b>Do not read</b> it as: <b>“The host of them [<i>tzeva’am</i>]”; rather,</b> read it as: <b>Their form [<i>tzivyonam</i>].</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa taught: “May the glory of the Lord endure forever; let the Lord rejoice in His works”</b> (Psalms 104:31). <b>This verse was stated by the minister of the world,</b> i.e., the angel charged with overseeing the world. <b>When the Holy One, Blessed be He, said:</b> “Let the earth put forth grass, herb yielding seed, and fruit tree bearing fruit <b>after its kind”</b> (Genesis 1:11), <b>the grasses drew an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>with regard to themselves.</b>
They reasoned: <b>If the Holy One, Blessed be He, wishes</b> the <b>mixing</b> of species, <b>why did he say: After its kind, with regard to the trees? And furthermore,</b> let us draw <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If</b> with regard to <b>trees, which do not naturally grow mixed,</b> as they are large and distinct from one another, <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: “After its kind,” all the more so</b> with regard to <b>us,</b> since grass naturally grows mixed.
<b>Immediately, every</b> kind of grass <b>emerged after its kind,</b> as it is stated: “And the earth brought forth grass, herb yielding seed after its kind” (Genesis 1:12). <b>The minister of the world began</b> to speak <b>and said: “May the glory of the Lord endure forever; let the Lord rejoice in His works,”</b> who do His will even when not explicitly instructed.
With regard to the above description, <b>Ravina raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>grafted two</b> species of <b>grass onto one another,</b> as is done with trees,

Daf 60b

<b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa?</b> Shall one say that <b>since</b> the phrase <b>“after its kind” is not written</b> as a mitzva <b>with regard to them,</b> one is <b>not liable</b> for transgressing the prohibition against mixing diverse kinds? <b>Or perhaps, since</b> God <b>agreed with them</b> after the fact, as the verse states: “Let the Lord rejoice in His works,” <b>it is as if</b> the mitzva <b>“after its kind” is written with regard to them.</b> The Gemara responds: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi raises a contradiction</b> between two verses. It <b>is written: “And God made the two great lights”</b> (Genesis 1:16), <b>and</b> it <b>is</b> also <b>written</b> in the same verse: <b>“The greater light</b> to rule the day, <b>and the lesser light</b> to rule the night,” indicating that only one was great. Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi explains: When God first created the sun and the moon, they were equally bright. Then, <b>the moon said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe,</b> is it <b>possible for two kings to serve with one crown?</b> One of us must be subservient to the other. God therefore <b>said to her,</b> i.e., the moon: If so, <b>go and diminish yourself.</b>
<b>She said before Him: Master of the Universe, since I said a correct</b> observation <b>before You,</b> must <b>I diminish myself?</b> God <b>said to her:</b> As compensation, <b>go and rule</b> both <b>during the day</b> along with the sun <b>and during the night. She said to Him: What is the greatness of</b> shining alongside the sun? <b>What use is a candle in the middle of the day?</b> God <b>said to her: Go; let the Jewish people count the days and years with you,</b> and this will be your greatness. <b>She said to Him: But</b> the Jewish people will count with <b>the sun as well,</b> as <b>it is impossible that they will not count seasons with it, as it is written: “And let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days and years”</b> (Genesis 1:14). God said to her: <b>Go; let righteous men be named after you.</b> Just as you are called the lesser [<i>hakatan</i>] light, there will be <b>Ya’akov HaKatan,</b> i.e., Jacob our forefather (see Amos 7:2), <b>Shmuel HaKatan</b> the <i>tanna</i>, and <b>David HaKatan,</b> i.e., King David (see I Samuel 17:14).
God <b>saw that</b> the moon <b>was not comforted. The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: Bring atonement for me, since I diminished the moon.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>And this is what Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: What is different</b> about the <b>goat</b> offering <b>of</b> the <b>New Moon, that</b> it <b>is stated with regard to it: “For the Lord”</b> (Numbers 28:15)? <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said: This goat shall be an atonement</b> for Me <b>for having diminished</b> the size of <b>the moon.</b>
§ <b>Rav Asi raises a contradiction</b> between two verses. It <b>is written: “And the earth brought forth grass”</b> (Genesis 1:12), <b>on the third day of the week</b> of Creation. <b>And</b> it <b>is</b> also <b>written: “No shrub of the field was yet in the earth”</b> (Genesis 2:5), <b>on Shabbat eve,</b> the sixth day of Creation, immediately before Adam was created. Rav Asi explains: This <b>teaches that the grasses emerged</b> on the third day <b>and stood at the opening of the ground,</b> but they did not grow <b>until Adam, the first</b> man, <b>came and prayed for mercy upon them, and rain came, and they sprouted.</b> And this is meant <b>to teach you that the Holy One, Blessed be He, desires the prayers of the righteous.</b>
The Gemara recounts: <b>Rav Naḥman bar Pappa had a certain garden. He planted seeds but they did not sprout. He prayed for mercy,</b> and <b>rain came, and</b> they <b>sprouted. He said: This is</b> what is meant by the statement <b>of Rav Asi,</b> that the Holy One, Blessed be He, desires the prayers of the righteous.
§ In one of the passages discussing kosher and non-kosher animals, the Torah states: “Nevertheless, these you shall not eat of them that only chew the cud, or of them that have split hooves that are cloven [<i>hashesua</i>]: The camel, and the hare, and the hyrax” (Deuteronomy 14:7). <b>Rav Ḥanan bar Rava said: “<i>Hashesua</i>”</b> is not a redundant description of the split hooves but <b>a distinct creature, which has two backs and two spines</b> and therefore looks like an entirely cloven animal. One might ask: <b>But was Moses our teacher a hunter, or was he an archer,</b> who was familiar with the most exotic animals? Rather, <b>from here</b> there is <b>a refutation to those who say that the Torah is not from Heaven,</b> since Moses could not have known of the existence of such an animal save by divine revelation.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Taḥlifa bar Avina: Go write</b> this statement about the <b>hunter [<i>kinnigi</i>] and</b> the <b>archer [<i>ballisteri</i>] in your</b> book of <b><i>aggada</i>, and explain</b> those two words, since some are unfamiliar with them.
The Gemara relates another statement. The verse states: <b>“The five lords of the Philistines: The Gazite, and the Ashdodite, the Ashkelonite, the Gittite, and the Ekronite; also the Avvim”</b> (Joshua 13:3). The verse is difficult, since it first <b>said</b> there are <b>five</b> lords of the Philistines, <b>but it</b> then <b>lists six. Rabbi Yonatan said:</b> There were in fact six lords, but <b>the greatest of them</b> were only <b>five. Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Taḥlifa bar Avina: Write</b> this statement about <b>the greatest [<i>arunekei</i>] in your</b> book of <b><i>aggada</i>, and explain</b> that word. The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> this statement <b>disagrees</b> with the opinion <b>of Rav, as Rav says:</b> The <b>Avvim</b> were not Philistines; rather, they <b>came from Teiman.</b>
<b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>Avvim came from Teiman. And why were they called Avvim</b> and not Teimanim? <b>Because they corrupted [<i>ivvetu</i>]</b> and destroyed <b>their place</b> of origin when they left. <b>Alternatively,</b> they were called <b>Avvim since they desired [<i>ivvu</i>] many deities. Alternatively,</b> they were called <b>Avvim since</b> they were so fearsome that <b>all who saw them were seized by convulsions [<i>avit</i>]. Rav Yosef said: And each one of them has sixteen rows of teeth.</b>
The Gemara cites another statement related to the Avvim: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says:</b> There are <b>many verses that</b> are seemingly <b>fit to be burned as books of the heretics,</b> since they appear redundant or frivolous, <b>and</b> yet <b>they are themselves the essence of Torah.</b> For example, the verse states: <b>“And the Avvim, that dwelt in villages as far as Gaza,</b> the Caphtorim, that came forth out of Caphtor, destroyed them, and dwelt in their stead” (Deuteronomy 2:23). <b>What</b> practical <b>difference</b> does this make <b>for us?</b>
The verse teaches the following: <b>Since Abimelech,</b> king of the Philistines, <b>administered an oath to Abraham: “That you will not deal falsely with me, nor with my son, nor with my grandson”</b> (Genesis 21:23), the Jewish people were prohibited from conquering the land of the Philistines until four generations had passed. Therefore, <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: Let</b> the <b>Caphtorim come</b> and <b>remove</b> the land <b>from</b> the <b>Avvim, who are</b> the same as the <b>Philistines, and let Israel come</b> and <b>remove</b> it <b>from the Caphtorim,</b> circumventing the prohibition.
<b>Similarly, you say</b> with regard to another apparently unnecessary verse, describing a city that the Israelites conquered: <b>“For Heshbon was the city of Sihon, the king of the Amorites, who had fought against the</b> former <b>king of Moab,</b> and taken all his land out of his hand” (Numbers 21:26). <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> in knowing this information? It teaches <b>that</b> since <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Israel: “Be not at enmity with Moab”</b> (Deuteronomy 2:9), the Jewish people were prohibited from conquering the land of Moab. Therefore, <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: Let Sihon come</b> and <b>remove</b> the land <b>from Moab, and let Israel come</b> and <b>remove</b> it <b>from Sihon.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>And this is what Rav Pappa says:</b> The lands of <b>Ammon and Moab were purified by Sihon,</b> i.e., rendered permitted for conquest.
The Gemara cites another seemingly superfluous verse, describing Mount Hermon: <b>“Which Hermon the Sidonians call Sirion,</b> and the Amorites call it Senir” (Deuteronomy 3:9). A Sage <b>taught: Senir and Sirion are mountains of Eretz Yisrael.</b> The verse <b>teaches that every one of the nations of the world went and built itself a great city</b> on Mount Hermon, <b>and named it after</b> one of <b>the mountains of Eretz Yisrael, teaching you that even the mountains of Eretz Yisrael are beloved by the nations of the world.</b>
<b>Similarly,</b> a difficult verse describes Joseph’s treatment of the Egyptians: <b>“And as for the people, he removed them city by city”</b> (Genesis 47:21). <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference</b> of this information? It teaches Joseph’s love for his brothers, as he transferred the entire Egyptian population <b>so that they would not call his brothers exiles.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>The signs of the</b> kosher <b>bird were not</b> explicitly <b>stated</b> in the Torah. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it true that they were <b>not</b> stated in the Torah? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“The <i>nesher</i>”</b> (Leviticus 11:13) is a non-kosher bird.

Daf 61a

<b>Just as a <i>nesher</i></b> is <b>unique</b> in <b>that it has no extra digit or crop, and its gizzard cannot be peeled, and it claws</b> its prey <b>and eats</b> it, and it is <b>non-kosher, so too, all like</b> birds with these four signs are <b>non-kosher.</b> And just as <b>doves</b> and pigeons, <b>which have an extra digit and a crop, and whose gizzard can be peeled, and do not claw</b> their food <b>and eat</b> it, are <b>kosher,</b> as they are fit for sacrifice on the altar (see Leviticus 1:14), <b>so too, all like</b> birds with these four signs are <b>kosher.</b> If so, why does the mishna state that the signs were not stated in the Torah? <b>Abaye said:</b> The mishna means that <b>the explanation of</b> the signs of a kosher bird <b>was not stated in the Torah. Rather,</b> one learns it <b>from the statements of the Sages,</b> i.e., the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches: A bird that comes</b> before a person <b>with one sign</b> of a kosher bird, and which is not listed in the Torah as non-kosher, <b>is kosher, since it is unlike a <i>nesher</i>.</b> The verse did not need to state that the <i>nesher</i> is non-kosher, since one could have inferred this from the list of other non-kosher birds. Rather, the verse mentions the <i>nesher</i> specifically to indicate that <b>it is</b> only a bird like <b>a <i>nesher</i>, which has none</b> of the signs of a kosher bird, <b>that you shall not eat. But</b> if <b>there is</b> a bird <b>that has</b> even <b>one</b> of the signs, <b>you may eat</b> it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why learn specifically from the case of a <i>nesher</i>? <b>Let one derive</b> the opposite <b>from</b> the case of <b>doves: Just as doves, which</b> the Torah mentions explicitly as kosher, <b>have all four</b> signs, <b>so too here,</b> no other bird is kosher <b>unless it has all four</b> signs.
The Gemara responds: <b>If</b> it is <b>so</b> that one learns from the case of a dove, <b>why do I</b> need <b>the rest of the non-kosher birds that the Merciful One wrote?</b> Since none of them has all four signs of a kosher bird, their non-kosher status could simply be inferred from the case of a dove. Rather, since the Torah states explicitly that they are non-kosher, it follows that one does not learn from the case of a dove.
The Gemara objects: <b>But let us derive</b> instead <b>from them,</b> i.e., the rest of the non-kosher birds, which each have only three signs, the following: <b>Just as there,</b> those birds have <b>three</b> of the signs of a kosher bird mentioned in the mishna, <b>and we</b> still <b>do not eat</b> them, <b>so too, all</b> other birds that have <b>three signs</b> should have the same halakhic status, <b>and we will not eat</b> them. <b>And all the more so</b> should this apply to a bird that has only <b>two</b> signs <b>or one.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>If so, why do I</b> need <b>the crow that the Merciful One wrote</b> among the non-kosher birds? <b>Now</b> that it is established <b>that we do not eat</b> any bird <b>that has three</b> signs, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to mention the crow, <b>which has</b> only <b>two?</b> Rather, those birds explicitly listed as non-kosher are prohibited, and all other birds with any number of signs are kosher.

Daf 61b

The Gemara objects: <b>But one should derive</b> instead <b>from a crow: Just as there,</b> a bird with <b>two</b> signs is <b>not</b> kosher, <b>so too any</b> other bird that has only <b>two</b> signs is <b>not</b> kosher. The Gemara responds: <b>If so, why do I</b> need the <b><i>peres</i> and</b> the <b><i>ozniyya</i> that the Merciful One wrote</b> among the non-kosher birds? <b>Now</b> that it is established <b>that we do not eat</b> any bird <b>that has two</b> signs, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to mention these birds, <b>which have</b> only <b>one?</b> Rather, even birds that have only one sign are kosher, save those mentioned explicitly in the Torah as non-kosher.
The Gemara objects: <b>But let us learn</b> instead <b>from</b> the <b><i>peres</i> and <i>ozniyya</i></b> themselves that all other birds with only one sign are non-kosher. The Gemara responds: <b>If so, why do I</b> need the <b><i>nesher</i> that the Merciful One wrote? Now</b> that it is established <b>that we do not eat</b> any bird <b>that has one</b> sign, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to mention the <i>nesher</i>, <b>which has none? Rather,</b> the Torah mentions the <i>nesher</i> to indicate that <b>it is a <i>nesher</i>, which has none</b> of the signs of a kosher bird, <b>that you shall not eat. But</b> if you find any bird <b>that has</b> even <b>one</b> of the signs, you may <b>eat</b> it.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> if so, <b>the reason</b> for eating birds with even one sign is only <b>that the Merciful One wrote: “<i>Nesher</i>.”</b> One can infer, <b>then,</b> that if <b>not</b> for <b>this, I would say: Derive from</b> the <b><i>peres</i> and <i>ozniyya</i></b> that any bird with one sign is non-kosher. But that cannot be, since the <b><i>peres</i> and <i>ozniyya</i> are two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., that teach the same matter, <b>and</b> as a rule, <b>two verses that come as one do not teach</b> a principle.
The Gemara responds: <b>It is learned</b> as a tradition <b>that</b> the sign <b>present in this,</b> the <i>peres</i>, <b>is absent in that,</b> the <i>ozniyya</i>, <b>and that</b> which is <b>present in that is absent in this.</b> Accordingly, this is not a case of two verses that come as one, since each case would teach only that any other bird with only its respective sign is non-kosher. Consequently, it would have been possible to derive from them that any bird with only one sign is non-kosher. The verse therefore states: “<i>Nesher</i>,” to indicate otherwise.
The Gemara persists: <b>Now, there are twenty-four non-kosher birds</b> mentioned in the verses. <b>It is impossible that</b> the <b>one</b> sign <b>present in these,</b> the <i>peres</i> and <i>ozniyya</i>, respectively, <b>is absent in</b> all <b>those</b> other birds. Consequently, the mentioning of the <i>peres</i>, <i>ozniyya</i>, and the other birds <b>constitutes two verses that come as one.</b> If so, one could not have derived from the cases of the <i>peres</i> and <i>ozniyya</i> that a bird with one sign is not kosher, and the inclusion of the <i>nesher</i> is unnecessary.
The Gemara responds: <b>It is learned</b> as a tradition that <b>there are twenty-four non-kosher birds, and four signs</b> of a kosher bird. The same <b>three</b> signs <b>can be found in all of them,</b> with the exception of either the <i>peres</i> or the <i>ozniyya</i>. <b>Twenty of them</b> have all <b>three</b> signs, <b>and two</b> of those signs can be found <b>in a crow. One</b> sign is found <b>in a <i>peres</i> and one in an <i>ozniyya</i>,</b> and the sign <b>present in this is absent in that,</b> i.e., one of them has the fourth sign, which is absent from the other twenty-three non-kosher birds. <b>Lest you say: Derive from it</b> that any other bird with only that sign is non-kosher, <b>the Merciful One wrote</b> about the <b><i>nesher</i></b> to indicate: <b>It is a <i>nesher</i>, which has none</b> of the signs of a kosher bird, <b>that you shall not eat. But</b> if <b>there is</b> any bird <b>that has</b> even <b>one</b> of the signs, you may <b>eat</b> it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if one learns from <i>nesher</i> that a bird with even one sign is kosher, <b>why do I</b> need the <b>doves that the Merciful One wrote</b> are kosher, which have all four? <b>Rav Ukva bar Ḥama said:</b> The dove was not mentioned to teach that it is kosher, but rather <b>to</b> teach that it is the only bird fit to be sacrificed as <b>an offering. Rav Naḥman says:</b>

Daf 62a

If <b>one is familiar with</b> the non-kosher birds <b>and their names,</b> any <b>bird that comes</b> before him <b>with</b> only <b>one sign is kosher,</b> since he can be sure that it is not the <i>peres</i> or <i>ozniyya</i>, which have only one sign. If <b>he is not familiar with them and their names,</b> any bird that he finds <b>with one sign is non-kosher,</b> since it may be the <i>peres</i> or <i>ozniyya</i>. But if he finds a bird <b>with</b> exactly <b>two signs,</b> it is <b>kosher, provided that he</b> can <b>recognize a crow,</b> since the crow is the only non-kosher bird with exactly two signs.
The Gemara asks: Must he recognize only the <b>crow and nothing more? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “Every <i>orev</i> after its kinds” (Leviticus 11:15). With regard to the <b><i>orev</i>, this is the</b> well-known <b>crow;</b> as for the phrase <b>“after its kinds,” Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> It is written <b>to include the <i>zarzir</i>,</b> another type of crow, to teach that it is non-kosher. The Sages <b>said to Rabbi Eliezer: But wouldn’t the people of Kefar Temarta in Judea eat</b> the <i>zarzir</i>, <b>because it has a crop?</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to them: They too will be judged in the future</b> for their transgression.
<b>Alternatively,</b> the phrase <b>“after its kinds”</b> is written <b>to include</b> the <b>white <i>senunit</i></b> and teach that it is non-kosher; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> The Rabbis <b>said to him: But don’t the people of the upper Galilee eat it, because its gizzard can be peeled?</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to them: They too will be judged in the future</b> for their transgression. In any event, the <i>baraita</i> indicates that other non-kosher birds exist that have two signs, like the crow. The Gemara responds: <b>Rather,</b> Rav Naḥman must have meant that one must be able to recognize the well-known <b>crow and all</b> other <b>species of crow.</b>
<b>Ameimar said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is: Any <b>bird that comes</b> before a person <b>with one sign is kosher, provided that it does not claw</b> its food. <b>Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: What</b> about <b>that which Rav Naḥman</b> said, that if one finds a bird with exactly one sign, he may eat it only if he can identify all the non-kosher birds in the Torah, to be sure that it is not one of them? Ameimar <b>said to him: I did not hear</b> this statement; <b>that is to say: I do not hold</b> accordingly. <b>What</b> concern <b>is there?</b> Is one concerned <b>because</b> of <b>the <i>peres</i> and <i>ozniyya</i>,</b> which have only one sign? <b>They are not</b> found <b>in settled areas,</b> and one need not be concerned about them.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> The bird known as <b>the scratching bird is fit for</b> use in <b>the purification of a leper,</b> i.e., it is kosher. Only kosher birds are fit for this rite, as the verse states: “Then shall the priest command to take for him that is to be purified two living pure birds” (Leviticus 14:4). <b>And this is the white <i>senunit</i> about which Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis disagreed</b> in the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>Ameimar said:</b> There are two kinds of white <i>senunit</i>. <b>With regard to</b> the <i>senunit</i> <b>with a white belly, everyone agrees that it is permitted</b> for consumption. <b>They disagree when</b> discussing the kind <b>with a yellow belly. Rabbi Eliezer prohibits it, and the Rabbis permit it. And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
<b>Mar Zutra teaches</b> the statement of Ameimar in <b>this</b> manner: <b>With regard to</b> the <i>senunit</i> <b>with a yellow belly, everyone agrees that it is prohibited. They disagree when</b> discussing the kind <b>with a white belly. Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> it <b>prohibited, and the Rabbis deem</b> it <b>permitted. And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who deem</b> it <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that <b>they disagree with regard to</b> the kind <b>with a white belly, this</b> explanation is consistent with <b>that which</b> Rav Yehuda <b>teaches: This is the white <i>senunit</i></b> about which Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis disagreed. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>they disagree with regard to</b> the kind <b>with a yellow</b> belly, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>This is the white <i>senunit</i>?</b> The Gemara responds: The phrase: White <i>senunit</i>, is used only <b>to exclude</b> the <b>house</b> <i>senunit</i>, <b>which is black.</b>
§ <b>Raḥava says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> A young <b><i>tasil</i>,</b> which is similar to a dove, is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice <b>as a dove,</b> which is fit only when mature, <b>but</b> it is <b>fit</b> for sacrifice <b>as a pigeon,</b> which is fit only when immature. In other words, the <i>tasil</i> is considered a type of pigeon, not a dove. A mature <b><i>datzifi</i></b> bird, <b>and</b> mature <b>doves of Reḥava, are fit as doves, but are unfit as pigeons,</b> since they are types of doves. <b>Rav Daniel bar Rav Ketina raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Para</i> 9:3): <b>All birds</b>

Daf 62b

<b>disqualify</b> the <b>water of purification,</b> i.e., water in which ashes of the red heifer have been placed, by drinking from it. The water that entered the bird’s mouth is disqualified, and some of it drips back into the container, disqualifying the rest. This applies to all birds <b>except for the pigeon, because it sips</b> the water from the container and none falls back in from its mouth. <b>But if it is so</b> that the <i>tasil</i> is a type of pigeon, <b>let</b> the mishna <b>teach: Except for</b> the <b>pigeon and</b> the <b><i>tasil</i>. Rabbi Zeira said:</b> Although the <i>tasil</i> is a type of pigeon and sips the water as well, <b>this,</b> the <i>tasil</i>, <b>sips</b> the water <b>and spits</b> part of it back, and therefore disqualifies the water of purification, <b>and that,</b> the pigeon, <b>sips but does not spit.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda says: The <i>tzutzeyanei</i> doves are fit for</b> sacrifice <b>on the altar, and they are the doves of Reḥava</b> mentioned earlier. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 14:6): The Torah requires hyssop for the purification of a leper. It must be standard <b>hyssop, and neither a hyssop of Greece, nor stibium hyssop, nor Roman hyssop, nor desert</b> hyssop, <b>nor any</b> other kind of <b>hyssop whose</b> name is accompanied by <b>a modifier.</b> Likewise, <i>tzutzeyanei</i> doves should be unfit for sacrifice, because they have a modifier in their name.
<b>Abaye said: Any</b> item <b>whose name was modified before the giving of the Torah, and</b> concerning which <b>the Torah was particular</b> when naming <b>it, is unfit</b> if <b>its</b> name is accompanied by <b>a modifier,</b> since the language of the Torah was formulated to exclude it. <b>But the name of these</b> <i>tzutzeyanei</i> doves <b>was not modified,</b> i.e., the modifier <i>tzutzeyanei</i> was not applied to them, <b>before the giving of the Torah.</b> Even though it was applied to them later, they are still fit for sacrifice. Alternatively, <b>Rava said: The <i>tzutzeyanei</i> doves are called simply</b> doves <b>in their place</b> of habitation.
Similarly, <b>Rav Yehuda says: These grasshoppers</b> found <b>among the shrubs</b> are kosher and <b>permitted</b> for consumption. <b>And</b> those found <b>among the cabbages are forbidden. Ravina said: And we flog</b> those who eat them <b>on their account, due to</b> the prohibition: “And all <b>winged swarming things</b> are impure unto you” (Deuteronomy 14:19). <b>And Rav Yehuda says:</b> The bird called <b><i>tzarda</i> is permitted</b> for consumption, <b>and</b> the <b><i>barda</i> is prohibited. And your mnemonic</b> to remember which is which is this: Eat any bird <b>except [<i>bar</i>] for it.</b> As for <b>the <i>marda</i>, it is uncertain</b> whether it is kosher.
<b>Rav Asi says: There are eight uncertain</b> cases: The <b><i>ḥuva</i>, <i>ḥuga</i>, <i>suga</i>, and <i>harnuga</i>, <i>tushelemi</i>, and <i>marda</i>, <i>kuḥilna</i>, and <i>bar nappaḥa</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What is their uncertainty? The gizzard of kosher birds can be peeled,</b> as mentioned in the mishna, <b>and the gizzard of non-kosher</b> birds <b>cannot be peeled, but the gizzard of these</b> birds <b>can be peeled</b> only <b>with a knife.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why should these not be kosher? Wasn’t there <b>a certain duck in the house of Mar Shmuel whose gizzard could not be peeled, and they set</b> the gizzard <b>in the sun, and once it softened it could be peeled?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>There, when it softened it could be peeled by hand. Here,</b> in these eight cases, <b>even when it softened it could be peeled only with a knife.</b>
<b>Abaye says: The swamp rooster is one of the eight uncertain</b> cases, <b>and this is</b> the <b><i>mardu</i>,</b> i.e., the <i>marda</i> mentioned earlier. <b>Rav Pappa says: The swamp rooster is forbidden, but the swamphen is permitted. And your mnemonic</b> to remember this is the statement of the Sages with regard to the verse: “An Ammonite or a Moabite shall not enter into the assembly of the Lord” (Deuteronomy 23:4), that <b>an Ammonite man</b> is unfit to enter the assembly, <b>but not an Ammonite woman. Mareimar taught: The swamphen is forbidden,</b> because the Sages <b>saw that it claws</b> its prey <b>and eats</b> it. <b>And this is</b> the <b><i>giruta</i>,</b> a non-kosher bird (see 109b).
<b>Rav says:</b> The bird called the <b><i>shavor anderafta</i> is permitted,</b> but the <b><i>piruz anderafta</i> is forbidden. And your mnemonic</b> to remember this is the known personality <b>Piruz the Evil. Rav Huna says:</b> The bird called the <b><i>bunya</i> is permitted.</b> The <b><i>parva</i> is forbidden. And your mnemonic</b> to remember this is the known personality <b>Parva’a the Sorcerer.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The bird known as the <b>reclining and eating <i>mardu</i> is permitted,</b> while the <b>bowing and eating</b> <i>mardu</i> <b>is forbidden. And your mnemonic</b> to remember this is the verse: <b>“You shall bow down to no other god”</b> (Exodus 34:14). <b>Shmuel says:</b> The bird called the <b>wine drinker is forbidden. And your mnemonic</b> to remember this is the <i>halakha</i>: <b>Those who drank wine are unfit for service</b> in the Temple. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> The bird called the <b>wine pourer is forbidden.</b>

Daf 63a

But the bird called the <b>little wine pourer is permitted. And your mnemonic</b> to remember this is the idiom of the Sages: <b>The power of the son is greater than the power of the father,</b> i.e., the larger is forbidden while the smaller is permitted.
<b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> There are several types of <b><i>shekitena</i>.</b> The <b>long-shanked red</b> ones are <b>permitted. And your mnemonic</b> to remember this is the <b><i>murzema</i></b> bird, which is similar in appearance and known to be kosher. The <b>little red</b> ones are <b>forbidden, and your mnemonic</b> for this is the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a dwarf</b> priest is <b>unfit</b> for Temple service. The <b>long-shanked green,</b> i.e., yellow, ones are <b>forbidden, and your mnemonic</b> for this is the mishna (56a): Innards that have turned <b>green</b> render an animal a <i>tereifa</i> and <b>unfit</b> for consumption.
<b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> As for the <b><i>shalakh</i>,</b> listed as a non-kosher bird (see Leviticus 11:17), <b>this is</b> the bird <b>that scoops [<i>sholeh</i>] fish out of the sea.</b> The <b><i>dukhifat</i></b> (see Leviticus 11:19) is the bird <b>whose comb</b> seems <b>bent [<i>hodo kafut</i>]</b> due to its thickness. The Gemara notes: <b>This is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b><i>dukhifat</i></b> is the bird <b>whose comb</b> seems <b>bent, and this is</b> the bird <b>that brought the <i>shamir</i> to the Temple.</b> As recounted in tractate <i>Gittin</i> (68b), King Solomon required a unique worm called the <i>shamir</i> to carve stones of the Temple, as the verse states: “There was neither hammer nor ax nor any tool of iron heard in the house, while it was in building” (I Kings 6:7).
The Gemara recounts: <b>When Rabbi Yoḥanan would see a <i>shalakh</i>, he</b> would <b>say: “Your judgments are like the great deep”</b> (Psalms 36:7), as God exacts retribution even upon the fish in the sea. <b>When he would see an ant, he</b> would <b>say</b> the first half of the same verse: <b>“Your righteousness is like the mighty mountains,”</b> as God provides sustenance for the tiny ant just as He does for the largest creatures.
<b>Ameimar says:</b> The <b><i>laknei</i> and <i>batnei</i></b> birds are <b>permitted.</b> As for the <b><i>sakna’ei</i> and <i>batna’ei</i></b> birds, in any <b>place that it is customary to eat</b> them, <b>one may eat</b> them; in any <b>place that it is customary not to eat</b> them, <b>one may not eat</b> them. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that the matter</b> of whether it is permitted <b>depends on custom?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Yes, but</b> it is <b>not difficult: This</b> place where they are forbidden is <b>a place where the <i>peres</i> and <i>ozniyya</i> are found.</b> Since they are similar to these birds, one must be concerned that people will confuse them, even though the <i>sakna’ei</i> and <i>batna’ei</i> are themselves kosher. <b>That</b> place where they are permitted is <b>a place where the <i>peres</i> and <i>ozniyya</i> are not found.</b>
<b>Abaye says:</b> The birds called <b><i>kevai</i> and <i>kakvai</i> are forbidden,</b> but the <b><i>kakvata</i> is permitted.</b> Still, <b>in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they flog</b> one who eats it <b>on its</b> account, <b>and they call it <i>taḥveta</i>.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b><i>tinshemet</i>,</b> listed in the Torah as non-kosher (see Leviticus 11:18), is the <b><i>ba’ut</i> among birds.</b> One might ask: <b>Do you say</b> that it is <b>the <i>ba’ut</i> among birds, or is it only the <i>ba’ut</i> among creeping animals?</b> The <i>tinshemet</i> is also listed among the creeping animals (see Leviticus 11:30). <b>Say: Go out and learn from the thirteen hermeneutical principles,</b> of which one is: <b>A matter derived from its context. What are the</b> adjacent <b>verses speaking about?</b> They are speaking <b>about birds. So too here,</b> the word <i>tinshemet</i> is referring <b>to birds.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>It is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in this way with regard to</b> the <i>tinshemet</i> listed among the <b>creeping animals:</b> The <b><i>tinshemet</i></b> here is the <b><i>ba’ut</i> among creeping animals.</b> One might ask: <b>Do you say</b> that it is the <b><i>ba’ut</i> among creeping animals, or it is only</b> the <b><i>ba’ut</i> among birds? Say: Go out and learn from the thirteen hermeneutical principles,</b> of which one is: <b>A matter derived from its context. What are the</b> adjacent <b>verses speaking about?</b> They are speaking <b>about creeping animals. So too here,</b> the word <i>tinshemet</i> is referring <b>to creeping animals.</b>
<b>Abaye says:</b> The <b><i>ba’ut</i> among birds</b> is commonly called the <b><i>kifof</i>.</b> The <b><i>ba’ut</i> among creeping animals</b> is commonly called the <b><i>kurpedai</i>. Rav Yehuda says:</b> As for the <b><i>ka’at</i></b> listed in the Torah as non-kosher (see Leviticus 11:18), <b>this is the</b> bird called <b>a <i>kuk</i>.</b> As for the <b><i>raḥam</i>, this is</b> the <b><i>sherakrak</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Why is it called the <i>raḥam</i>?</b> Because <b>when the <i>raḥam</i> comes</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>mercy [<i>raḥamim</i>] comes to the world,</b> as it appears at the beginning of the rainy season. <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: And it is</b> a sign of rain only <b>when it sits on something and makes a <i>sherakrak</i></b> sound. And it <b>is learned</b> as a tradition <b>that if it sits on the ground and hisses [<i>veshareik</i>],</b> this is a sign that <b>the Messiah is coming, as it is stated: “I will hiss [<i>eshreka</i>] for them, and gather them”</b> (Zechariah 10:8).
<b>Rav Adda bar Shimi said to Mar bar Rav Idai: But</b> wasn’t there <b>a certain</b> <i>raḥam</i> <b>that sat on a plowed field and hissed, and a stone came and broke its head?</b> Mar bar Rav Idai <b>said to him: That</b> <i>raḥam</i> <b>was a liar</b> and was punished for prophesying falsely.
With regard to the verse: “Every <i>orev</i> after its kinds” (Leviticus 11:15), <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: As for the <b><i>orev</i>, this is the crow.</b> When the verse states: <b>“Every <i>orev</i>,”</b> this serves <b>to include the valley crow</b> as non-kosher. And the verse states: <b>“After its kinds,” to include the crow that comes at the heads of pigeons.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>The Master said:</b> As for the <b><i>orev</i>, this is the crow. Is that to say</b> that the particular crow <b>stands before us,</b> such that one immediately knows which one it is? <b>Rather, say:</b> As for the <b><i>orev</i>, this is the black crow, and so</b> the verse <b>states: “His locks are curled, and black as a crow”</b> (Song of Songs 5:11). The Gemara continues to explain the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The valley</b> crow <b>[<i>ha’amaki</i>]</b> is the <b>white</b> crow. <b>And so</b> the verse <b>states</b> with regard to leprosy: <b>“If the appearance thereof be deeper [<i>amok</i>] than the skin”</b> (Leviticus 13:30), and the Sages explained: <b>As the appearance of</b> an area lit by the <b>sun, which</b> seems <b>deeper than the shade,</b> which appears to cover it. There is therefore an association between a valley and the color white.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>the crow that comes at the heads of pigeons, Rav Pappa said: Do not say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means <b>that it comes at the head of pigeons,</b> i.e., it dwells with them; <b>rather,</b> it means that this crow’s <b>head resembles that of a pigeon.</b>
With regard to the verse: “And the <i>netz</i> after its kinds” (Leviticus 11:16), <b>the Sages taught:</b> As for <b>the <i>netz</i>, this is the hawk.</b> The verse states: <b>“After its kinds,” to include</b> the bird called <b><i>bar ḥireya</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the <i>bar ḥireya</i>? Abaye said:</b> It is the bird commonly called the <b><i>shurineka</i>.</b>
With regard to the verse: “And the <i>ḥasida</i>, and the <i>anafa</i> after its kinds” (Leviticus 11:19), <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> As for <b>the <i>ḥasida</i>, this is the white <i>dayya</i>. And why is it called <i>ḥasida</i>? Since it performs charity [<i>ḥasidut</i>] for its fellows,</b> giving them from its own food. As for <b>the <i>anafa</i>, this is the irritable <i>dayya</i>. And why is it called <i>anafa</i>? Since it quarrels [<i>mena’efet</i>] with its fellows.</b>
§ <b>Rav Ḥanan bar Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Rav Ḥanan, son of Rava, says</b> that <b>Rav says: There are twenty-four non-kosher birds. Rav Ḥanan bar Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Ḥisda,</b> his father: <b>From where</b> in the Torah is this number obtained? <b>If</b> you are referring to the list <b>of Leviticus</b> (11:13–19), <b>there are</b> only <b>twenty</b> birds listed there. <b>If</b> you are referring to the list <b>of Deuteronomy</b> (14:12–18), <b>there are</b> only <b>twenty-one</b> there. <b>And if you would say: Add</b> the <b><i>da’a</i>, which is written in Leviticus but is not written in Deuteronomy, to</b> the others in Deuteronomy, <b>still there are</b> only <b>twenty-two.</b>
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: This</b> is what <b>your mother’s father,</b> Rav Ḥanan, son of Rava, <b>said in the name of Rav:</b> The phrases <b>“after its kinds,” “after its kinds,” “after its kinds,”</b> and <b>“after its kinds,”</b> that appear in each list indicate additional cases. <b>Here,</b> then, <b>are four</b> more. The Gemara objects: <b>If so, there are twenty-six,</b> not twenty-four. <b>Abaye said:</b> The <b><i>da’a</i></b> mentioned in Leviticus <b>and</b> the <b><i>ra’a</i></b> mentioned in Deuteronomy <b>are one</b> bird. <b>As, if it enters your mind that they are two</b> different birds,

Daf 63b

one might ask: <b>Since</b> it is assumed that the list in <b>Deuteronomy comes to add</b> to the list in Leviticus, <b>what is different here,</b> in Leviticus, <b>that it is written: “<i>Da’a</i>,”</b> and <b>what is different here,</b> in Deuteronomy, <b>that it is written: “<i>Ra’a</i>,” and <i>da’a</i> is not written? Rather, conclude from</b> the presence of each on only one list that the <b><i>ra’a</i> and <i>da’a</i> are one species.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But still, there are twenty-five</b> birds, not twenty-four. <b>Abaye said: Just as</b> the <b><i>ra’a</i> and <i>da’a</i> are one</b> species, <b>so</b> too, the <b><i>ayya</i> and</b> the <b><i>dayya</i>,</b> the latter of which is mentioned only in Deuteronomy, <b>are one</b> species. <b>As, if it enters your mind that they are two</b> different species, one might ask: <b>Since</b> it is assumed that the list in <b>Deuteronomy comes to add</b> to the list in Leviticus, <b>what is different here,</b> in Leviticus, <b>that it is written: “After its kinds,” about</b> the <b><i>ayya</i>,</b> prohibiting some other kind of <i>ayya</i>, <b>and what is different there,</b> in Deuteronomy, <b>that it is written: “After its kinds,” about</b> the <b><i>dayya</i>?</b> Why is the <i>ayya</i> not mentioned? <b>Rather, learn from</b> the use of the same phrase with regard to the <b><i>ayya</i> and <i>dayya</i></b> that they <b>are one</b> species.
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that</b> the <b><i>ayya</i> and <i>dayya</i> are one</b> species, <b>why did</b> the Torah need <b>to write</b> both <b><i>ayya</i> and <i>dayya</i></b> in Deuteronomy? The Gemara responds: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> Given that the two are one species, <b>I will read <i>ayya</i></b> and know that it is forbidden. <b>Why is <i>dayya</i> stated?</b> It is <b>so as not to give a claim to a litigant to disagree,</b> and <b>it should not occur</b> that <b>you call</b> it <b>an <i>ayya</i> and he calls</b> it <b>a <i>dayya</i></b> and eats it. Likewise, the Torah did not write only <i>dayya</i> so that it will not occur that <b>you call</b> it <b>a <i>dayya</i> and he calls</b> it <b>an <i>ayya</i></b> and eats it. <b>Therefore,</b> the Torah <b>writes in Deuteronomy: “And the <i>ra’a</i>, and the <i>ayya</i>, and the <i>dayya</i> after its kinds”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:13). Consequently, both the list in Leviticus and that in Deuteronomy enumerate twenty-four birds, in accordance with the statement attributed to Rav.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Why</b> is the list <b>of</b> non-kosher <b>animals</b> in Leviticus <b>repeated?</b> It is <b>due to</b> the necessity of adding <b>the <i>shesua</i></b> (Deuteronomy 14:7), which was not listed in Leviticus. <b>And</b> the list <b>of</b> non-kosher <b>birds</b> is repeated <b>due to the <i>ra’a</i>. What, is it not</b> understood <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the extra list of <b>animals there,</b> in Deuteronomy, is <b>to add</b> animals, that the list of <b>birds</b> is <b>also</b> repeated <b>to add</b> birds? The Gemara responds: <b>No, there,</b> i.e., with regard to animals, the list is repeated <b>to add,</b> but <b>here,</b> with regard to birds, it is repeated only <b>to explain.</b>
<b>And</b> the opinion that the <i>da’a</i> and <i>ra’a</i> are one species, and that the <i>ayya</i> and <i>dayya</i> are another species, <b>differs from</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu says:</b> The <b><i>ra’a</i> is</b> the <b><i>ayya</i>. And why is it called</b> the <b><i>ra’a</i>? Since it sees [<i>ro’ah</i>] most</b> vividly. <b>And so</b> the verse <b>states: “That path no bird of prey knows, neither has the eye of the <i>ayya</i> seen it”</b> (Job 28:7). And a Sage <b>taught:</b> The <i>ra’a</i> can <b>stand in Babylonia and see a carcass in Eretz Yisrael.</b>
The Gemara discusses Rabbi Abbahu’s statement: <b>Since</b> the <b><i>ra’a</i> is</b> the same as the <b><i>ayya</i>, by inference,</b> one may conclude <b>that</b> the <b><i>da’a</i> is not the</b> same as the <b><i>ra’a</i>;</b> otherwise, there are not twenty-four non-kosher birds. But <b>since</b> it is assumed that the list in <b>Deuteronomy comes to add</b> to the list in Leviticus, <b>what is different here,</b> in Leviticus, <b>that it is written: “<i>Da’a</i>,”</b> and <b>what is different there,</b> in Deuteronomy, <b>that <i>da’a</i> is not written? Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from</b> the discrepancy that the two are the same? If so, one must conclude that according to Rabbi Abbahu, the <b><i>da’a</i> and <i>ra’a</i> and <i>ayya</i> are</b> all <b>one</b> species.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>from</b> the fact that Rabbi Abbahu holds that the <b><i>ra’a</i> is</b> the same as the <b><i>ayya</i>, by inference,</b> one may conclude that the <b><i>dayya</i> is not</b> the same as the <b><i>ayya</i>.</b> But if so, one may ask again: <b>What is different there,</b> in Leviticus, <b>that it is written: “After its kinds,” about</b> the <b><i>ayya</i>, and what is different here,</b> in Deuteronomy, <b>that it is not written: “After its kinds,” about</b> the <b><i>ayya</i> but about</b> the <b><i>dayya</i>? Rather,</b> the <i>ayya</i> and <i>dayya</i> must be one species. And one may <b>learn from</b> the combination of the two disputes that according to Rabbi Abbahu, the <b><i>da’a</i> and <i>ra’a</i>, <i>dayya</i> and <i>ayya</i> are</b> all <b>one</b> species. Consequently, according to Rabbi Abbahu, there are only twenty-three non-kosher species.
§ With regard to the phrase: “The <i>ayya</i> after its kinds” (Leviticus 11:14), <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Isi ben Yehuda says: There are one hundred non-kosher birds in the East, and they are all species of <i>ayya</i>. Avimi, son of Rabbi Abbahu, taught: There are seven hundred types of</b> non-kosher <b>fish, and eight hundred types of</b> non-kosher <b>grasshopper, and there are countless birds.</b> The Gemara protests: Are there countless non-kosher <b>birds?</b> But <b>there are</b> only <b>twenty-four</b> non-kosher birds mentioned in the Torah. <b>Rather,</b> Avimi must have meant: <b>And there are countless kosher birds.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: It is revealed and known before the One Who spoke and the world came into being that</b> the species of <b>non-kosher animals are more numerous than the kosher</b> ones. <b>Therefore, the Torah lists the kosher</b> animals, teaching that all the rest are non-kosher. On the other hand, <b>it is revealed and known before the One Who spoke and the world came into being that</b> the species of <b>kosher birds are more numerous than the non-kosher</b> ones. <b>Therefore, the Torah lists the non-kosher</b> birds.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>teaching us?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>As Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav</b> says, <b>and some say</b> that <b>Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says in the name of Rabbi Meir: A person should always teach his student in a concise manner,</b> just as the Torah is concise in its language.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says: A kosher bird may be eaten on</b> the strength of <b>a tradition</b> that it is kosher, without inspecting for the signs listed in the mishna. And <b>the hunter is deemed credible to say: My teacher conveyed to me</b> that <b>this bird is kosher. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when</b> the teacher <b>is familiar with</b> the non-kosher birds <b>and with their names.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma:</b> Was Rabbi Yoḥanan referring to the hunter’s <b>teacher the Sage, or</b> to <b>his teacher the hunter,</b> i.e., the one who taught him how to hunt? The Gemara responds: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from that <b>which Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And this</b> applies only <b>when</b> the teacher <b>is familiar with them and with their names. Granted, if you say</b> this is referring to <b>his teacher the hunter,</b> this works out <b>well. But if you say</b> it is referring to <b>his teacher the Sage, granted,</b> a Sage will know <b>their names,</b> since <b>he has learned them, but does he recognize</b> the birds <b>themselves? Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan referred to <b>his teacher the hunter?</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is so.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may buy eggs from the gentiles anywhere, and one</b> need <b>not</b> be <b>concerned, neither with regard to carcasses,</b> i.e., that the egg may have been removed from a carcass of a bird and therefore forbidden, <b>nor with regard to</b> eggs from <b><i>tereifot</i>,</b> because neither of these possibilities is likely.
The Gemara objects: <b>But perhaps they</b> are from <b>a non-kosher bird. Shmuel’s father said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a case where the gentile <b>says</b> they are <b>of such and such bird,</b> which is known to be <b>kosher.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> if the gentile is deemed credible, <b>let him say</b> only that they are <b>of a kosher bird.</b> Why does he need to name the species? The Gemara responds: <b>If so,</b> if he does not name the species, <b>he has</b> the opportunity to <b>deflect</b> scrutiny if he is dishonest; but if he names the species, one can bring other eggs of the same species to compare and validate the claim.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why must one rely on the gentile? <b>Let him inspect</b> the eggs <b>for signs, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Like the signs of</b> kosher <b>eggs, so</b> too are <b>the signs of fish.</b> The Gemara interjects: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>the signs of fish? The Merciful One states</b> them explicitly in the Torah: <b>“Fins and scales”</b> (Leviticus 11:9). <b>Rather, say: So</b> too are <b>the signs of</b>

Daf 64a

<b>fish embryos,</b> i.e., fish eggs found in the fish’s innards.
The Gemara continues: <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>about eggs</b> that <b>these are the signs of</b> bird <b>eggs: Any</b> egg <b>that narrows</b> at the top <b>and is rounded,</b> so that <b>one of its ends is rounded and</b> the other <b>one of its ends is pointed, is kosher.</b> If <b>both of its ends are rounded or both of its ends are pointed,</b> they are <b>non-kosher.</b> If the <b>albumen</b> is <b>on the outside and</b> the <b>yolk on the inside,</b> it is <b>kosher.</b> If the <b>yolk</b> is <b>on the outside and</b> the <b>albumen on the inside,</b> it is <b>non-kosher.</b> If the <b>yolk and albumen are mixed with each other, it is certainly the egg of a creeping animal.</b> Therefore, if it is possible to recognize a kosher egg by these signs, there is no need to rely on the gentile.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> if the eggs have already been <b>cut</b> and one cannot know their original shape. The Gemara challenges: <b>But let him inspect the yolk and the albumen,</b> to see which is inside and which is outside. The Gemara responds: The <i>baraita</i> deals <b>with</b> a case where the eggs are <b>mixed in a bowl,</b> and it is impossible to discern this.
The Gemara counters: <b>But in a case like this,</b> where the eggs are mixed, <b>may we buy</b> eggs <b>from them? Isn’t it taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may sell the egg of a <i>tereifa</i></b> bird <b>to a gentile only if it is mixed in a bowl; therefore, one may not buy eggs mixed in a bowl from them,</b> because they may be from <i>tereifot</i>? If so, it cannot be that the <i>baraita</i> deals with a case where they are mixed, and one should be able to inspect the yolk and albumen.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The <b>signs</b> of a kosher egg <b>are not</b> valid <b>by Torah law. As, if you do not say so,</b> one encounters difficulty with <b>that which Rav Asi says: There are eight</b> birds whose kosher status is <b>uncertain.</b> Why is there uncertainty? <b>Let one inspect their eggs</b> for the signs listed in the <i>baraita</i> to determine whether they are kosher. <b>Rather, learn from it</b> that the <b>signs are not</b> valid <b>by Torah law</b> and one may not rely on them.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if one may not rely on these signs, <b>with regard to what <i>halakha</i> is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaching</b> them? The Gemara responds: <b>This</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> If <b>both of its ends are rounded, or both its ends are pointed, or</b> the <b>yolk</b> is <b>on the outside and</b> the <b>albumen</b> is <b>on the inside,</b> it is <b>certainly non-kosher.</b> But if <b>one of its ends is pointed</b> and <b>one of its ends is rounded, and</b> the <b>albumen</b> is <b>on the outside and</b> the <b>yolk on the inside, and</b> the gentile <b>says to you</b> that it is <b>from such and such bird, and</b> that bird <b>is kosher, rely on</b> the signs. But if he offers <b>no specification</b> of the type of bird, or if one simply finds eggs with these signs, <b>do not rely on them, since there are crow’s</b> eggs <b>that resemble those of a pigeon.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said:</b> If the <b>albumen and yolk are mixed with each other, it is certainly the egg of a creeping animal</b> and not of a non-kosher bird. The Gemara asks: <b>For what <i>halakha</i></b> is this information necessary? Either way, the egg is forbidden. <b>Rav Ukva bar Ḥama said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> means <b>to say that if tissue</b> of an embryo <b>developed [<i>rikema</i>]</b> inside it <b>and it was perforated,</b> and one touched it, <b>it transmits ritual impurity</b> provided <b>that</b> the embryo is at least the size <b>of a lentil-bulk,</b> because the carcass of a creeping animal of this size is a source of ritual impurity.
<b>Ravina objects to this: But perhaps it is</b> the egg <b>of a snake,</b> whose carcass does not transmit ritual impurity, even though the albumen and yolk of its eggs are mixed together. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> does not teach about ritual impurity, but rather <b>that if tissue</b> of an embryo <b>developed</b> inside the egg <b>and one ate it, he is flogged on its account, due to</b> the prohibition: “And every <b>swarming thing that swarms upon the earth</b> is a detestable thing; it shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 11:41).
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, why specifically</b> mention the egg <b>of a non-kosher</b> creeping animal? The same would apply <b>even</b> for one who eats the embryo <b>of a kosher</b> bird <b>as well.</b> In either case, one is flogged, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse: <b>“Every swarming thing that swarms upon the earth,”</b>

Daf 64b

serves <b>to include chicks</b> of pigeons <b>whose eyes have not</b> yet <b>opened</b> in the prohibition against consuming swarming things. The Gemara responds: This prohibition is <b>by rabbinic</b> law, <b>and the verse</b> cited is <b>a mere support</b> for it. One who eats the embryo of a kosher bird is not liable to receive lashes.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Kosher <b>eggs</b> that have been <b>boiled</b> with non-kosher eggs are <b>permitted. Unfertilized eggs</b> are permitted, and one of <b>strong constitution may eat them,</b> even if the hen has sat on them for a long period of time. If <b>a drop [<i>koret</i>] of blood is found on it,</b> one <b>discards the blood,</b> which is the first stage of an embryo’s development, <b>and eats the rest.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said: And this</b> applies <b>when</b> the blood <b>is found on its knot,</b> i.e., the place in the albumen where the embryo begins to develop, since this proves that tissue has not developed elsewhere in the egg. And so <b>taught Dostai, father of Rabbi Aptoriki:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that one may eat the rest of the egg <b>only when</b> the blood <b>is found on its albumen,</b> i.e., the knot; <b>but</b> if <b>it is found on its yolk, even</b> the rest of <b>the egg is forbidden. What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>that the decay has spread through all of it. Rav Geviha from Bei Ketil said to Rav Ashi: A <i>tanna</i> taught the opposite before Abaye,</b> that one may eat the rest of the egg only when the blood is found on its yolk, <b>and it is Abaye that corrected it</b> in <b>this</b> manner.
§ <b>Ḥizkiyya says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the egg of a non-kosher</b> bird <b>is prohibited by Torah</b> law? <b>As it is stated: “And the daughter [<i>bat</i>] of the <i>ya’ana</i>”</b> (Leviticus 11:16). <b>But does the <i>ya’ana</i> have a daughter</b> whose forbidden status would be different from that of its mother? Both daughter and mother should be included in the same prohibition. <b>Rather, which</b> is this? <b>This is a non-kosher egg.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>But perhaps this is their name,</b> i.e., the bird is called <i>bat ya’ana</i>. The Gemara responds: This <b>should not enter your mind, as it is written: “The daughter of my people has become cruel, like the <i>ye’enim</i> in the wilderness”</b> (Lamentations 4:3).
The Gemara persists: <b>And</b> is <i>bat ya’ana</i> <b>not</b> its name? <b>But isn’t it written: “I will make a wailing like the jackals, and a mourning like the daughters [<i>benot</i>] of the <i>ya’ana</i>”</b> (Micah 1:8)? The Gemara responds: The verse means: I will make mourning <b>like this <i>ya’ana</i> that mourns for its children.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written: “And <i>benot ya’ana</i> shall dwell there”</b> (Isaiah 13:21)? The Gemara responds: Here too, the verse means: And they shall dwell there <b>like this <i>ya’ana</i> that dwells with its children.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written: “The animals of the field shall honor Me, the jackals and the <i>benot ya’ana</i>”</b> (Isaiah 43:20)? <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that the term <i>bat ya’ana</i> is referring to <b>an egg, can an egg sing a song</b> of praise to God? <b>Rather,</b> one must say: <b>The <i>ya’ana</i> is written, and the <i>bat ya’ana</i> is</b> also <b>written,</b> and both are acceptable names for this bird.
<b>And</b> still, the name <b>here is different</b> from those of other animals, in <b>that the scribe splits</b> it <b>into two words:</b> <i>Bat ya’ana</i>, even though it is one species. <b>And from</b> the fact <b>that the scribe splits it</b>

Daf 65a

<b>into two words, conclude from it</b> that <b>they are two names,</b> prohibiting the egg as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> what about the name: <b>“Chedorlaomer”</b> (Genesis 14:4), <b>which the scribe splits in two</b> so that it appears as: Chedor Laomer? Is it <b>also</b> true there <b>that they are two names?</b> The verse is clearly referring to only one person. <b>They say</b> in response: <b>There,</b> with regard to Chedor Laomer, the scribe <b>splits</b> the name <b>into two words,</b> but he <b>may not split it into two lines</b> if the first half nears the end of one line. <b>But here, he may split</b> the name <i>bat ya’ana</i> <b>even into two lines,</b> indicating that they are completely separate.
§ The mishna states: <b>But the Sages stated</b> that <b>any bird</b> that claws its prey and eats it is non-kosher. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabban Gamliel says:</b> A bird that <b>claws</b> its prey <b>and eats</b> it <b>is certainly non-kosher.</b> If <b>it has an extra digit and a crop, and its gizzard can be peeled, it is certainly kosher. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: One stretches a line,</b> and the bird perches on it. <b>If it splits its feet</b> on the line, with <b>two</b> digits <b>here and two there,</b> it is <b>non-kosher.</b> If it places <b>three</b> digits <b>here and one there,</b> it is possibly <b>kosher. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Any bird that catches</b> food <b>out of the air is non-kosher.</b>
The Gemara interjects: But the <b><i>tziparta</i> also catches</b> food out of the air, and it is kosher. <b>Abaye said: We say</b> this only for a bird that both <b>catches and eats</b> its food in the air. The <i>tziparta</i> lands before eating what it has caught.
