The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>Others say:</b> If a bird <b>dwells with non-kosher</b> birds, it is <b>non-kosher;</b> if it dwells <b>with kosher</b> birds, it is <b>kosher.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this last statement? Perhaps it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> It was <b>not for naught</b> that the <b><i>zarzir</i> went</b> to dwell <b>with the crow, but because it is</b> of the same <b>species.</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the opinion introduced with the words: Others say, is like that of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Eliezer and deem the <i>zarzir</i> kosher. The statement introduced with the words: Others say, is understood as follows: <b>We say</b> that a bird is non-kosher whenever it both <b>dwells</b> with a non-kosher bird <b>and resembles</b> it. The <i>zarzir</i>, though, does not resemble the crow.
§ The mishna states: <b>And with regard to grasshoppers, any</b> grasshopper <b>that has</b> four legs, and four wings, and two additional jumping legs, and whose wings cover most of its body, is kosher. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is considered <b>most of its</b> body? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Most of its length. And some say</b> that he said: <b>Most of its circumference. Rav Pappa said: Therefore,</b> one must satisfy both versions of the statement. <b>We require</b> that the wings cover <b>most of its length, and we</b> also <b>require</b> that they cover <b>most of its circumference.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A grasshopper that <b>has no</b> wings <b>now but will grow</b> them <b>after a time, e.g., the <i>zaḥal</i>, is permitted. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, says:</b> The verse states: “Yet these may you eat of all winged swarming things that go upon all fours, <b>which have [<i>lo</i>] jointed legs</b> above their feet, wherewith to leap upon the earth” (Leviticus 11:21). The word <i>lo</i> is written with the letter <i>alef</i>, meaning not, so that it can be understood as: Do not have jointed legs. This teaches that <b>even though it has no</b> jointed legs <b>now but will grow</b> them <b>after a time,</b> it is still kosher. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <b><i>zaḥal</i>? Abaye said:</b> It is called <b><i>askarin</i></b> in Aramaic.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse states: <b>“These of them you may eat: The <i>arbeh</i></b> after its kinds, and the <i>solam</i> after its kinds, and the <i>ḥargol</i> after its kinds, and the <i>ḥagav</i> after its kinds” (Leviticus 11:22). The <b><i>arbeh</i> is</b> the insect known as the <b><i>govai</i>.</b> The <b><i>solam</i> is</b> the <b><i>rashon</i>.</b> The <b><i>ḥargol</i> is</b> the <b><i>nippul</i>.</b> The <b><i>ḥagav</i> is</b> the <b><i>gadyan</i>. Why</b> must <b>the verse state: “After its kinds,” “after its kinds,” “after its kinds,”</b> and <b>“after its kinds,” four times? It is to include</b> four similar species: The <b>vineyard bird, and</b> the <b>Jerusalem <i>yoḥana</i>, and the <i>artzuveya</i>, and the <i>razbanit</i>,</b> which are also kosher.
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: These</b> appearances of the phrase “after its kinds” in the verse <b>are generalizations, and these</b> species mentioned explicitly <b>are details.</b> The verse must be understood in light of the previous verse, which offers general signs of a kosher grasshopper. The two verses together are a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization, in the following manner: The first verse is a generalization, <b><i>arbeh</i> is</b> a detail referring to the species <b><i>govai</i>,</b> and the phrase <b>“after its kinds”</b> is another generalization. According to Rabbi Yishmael’s hermeneutical principles, the second generalization serves to include a case similar to the detail. In this case, the phrase “after its kinds” serves <b>to include</b>

Daf 65b

the <b>vineyard bird,</b> which is similar to the <i>arbeh</i> in that its forehead is not smooth but has small hairs.
<b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a species <b>that comes</b> before a person <b>and does not have a smooth forehead</b> is kosher. <b>From where</b> is it derived that even one <b>that comes</b> before a person <b>and has a smooth forehead</b> is kosher? <b>The verse states: “<i>Solam</i>,”</b> and <b>this is</b> the <b><i>nippul</i>,</b> which has a smooth forehead. The phrase <b>“after its kinds”</b> that follows <i>solam</i> is another generalization, which serves <b>to include</b> a case similar to the detail, i.e., <b>the <i>ushkaf</i>,</b> which has a smooth forehead like the <i>solam</i>.
<b>And I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a species <b>that comes</b> before a person <b>and does not have a smooth forehead,</b> like the <i>arbeh</i>, or one <b>that comes</b> before a person <b>and has a smooth forehead,</b> like the <i>solam</i>, or one that <b>comes</b> before a person <b>and has no tail,</b> is kosher, since none of the previously mentioned grasshoppers have a tail. <b>From where</b> is it derived that even one <b>that comes</b> before a person <b>and has a tail</b> is kosher? <b>The verse states: “<i>Ḥargol</i>,”</b> and <b>this is</b> the <b><i>rashon</i>,</b> which has a tail. The phrase <b>“after its kinds”</b> that follows <i>ḥargol</i> is another generalization, and it serves <b>to include the <i>karsefet</i> and the <i>shaḥlanit</i>,</b> which also have tails.
<b>And I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a species <b>that comes</b> before a person <b>and does not have a smooth forehead,</b> or <b>that comes</b> before a person <b>and has a smooth forehead,</b> or <b>that comes and has no tail,</b> or <b>that comes and has a tail,</b> or <b>that comes and its head is not long,</b> is kosher, since every grasshopper mentioned until this point does not have a long head. <b>From where</b> is it derived that even one <b>that comes and its head is long</b> is kosher?
<b>You</b> will <b>say: You derive a paradigm from the three of them,</b> as follows: <b>The aspect [<i>re’i</i>] of</b> the <b><i>arbeh</i>,</b> which has neither smooth forehead nor tail, <b>is not similar to the aspect of</b> the <b><i>ḥargol</i>,</b> which has both; <b>and the aspect of</b> the <b><i>ḥargol</i> is not similar to the aspect of</b> the <b><i>arbeh</i>. And the aspect of neither of them is similar to the aspect of</b> the <b><i>solam</i>,</b> which has a smooth forehead but no tail, <b>and the aspect of</b> the <b><i>solam</i> is similar to neither of their aspects.</b> The characteristic that renders them all kosher can only be an aspect common to all of them. <b>Their common denominator is that</b> each <b>has four legs, and four wings, and jumping legs, and its wings cover most of its</b> body. <b>So too, any</b> other species <b>that has four legs, and four wings, and jumping legs, and its wings cover most of its</b> body is kosher, even if its head is long.
One might ask: <b>But doesn’t this <i>tzartzur</i> have four legs, and four wings, and jumping legs, and its wings cover most of its</b> body? Consequently, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>it should be permitted.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “<i>Ḥagav</i>,”</b> to indicate <b>that its name</b> must be <b><i>ḥagav</i>.</b> This includes all of the species previously mentioned, but not the <i>tzartzur</i>.
But <b>if its name</b> must be <b><i>ḥagav</i>,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that any <i>ḥagav</i> is kosher, even if <b>it does not have all these signs.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “After its kinds,”</b> indicating that even if it is called a <i>ḥagav</i> it is not kosher <b>unless it has all these signs.</b> This concludes the <i>baraita</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael.
<b>Rav Aḥai refutes</b> the <i>baraita</i>: The four signs listed are not the sole common denominators between the <i>arbeh</i>, <i>ḥargol</i>, and <i>solam</i>. <b>What</b> is also unique <b>about these</b> grasshoppers in addition to these signs? They are unique <b>in that their heads are not long.</b> If so, grasshoppers with long heads might not be kosher. <b>And if you would say: Since they share</b> these <b>four signs, we include</b> all others with these four signs <b>and we do not refute</b> them, since the included species need not be identical in all their aspects, <b>if so,</b> the Torah <b>should not even write</b> the <b><i>ḥargol</i>, which shares</b> these four signs <b>with</b> the <i>arbeh</i> and the <i>solam</i>, <b>and let it be derived</b> that the <i>ḥargol</i> is kosher by inference <b>from the</b> common denominators between the <b><i>arbeh</i> and <i>solam</i>.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it was necessary for the verse to write <i>ḥargol</i> because if it were omitted, its inclusion <b>could be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about these,</b> the <i>arbeh</i> and <i>solam</i>? They are unique <b>in that they</b> both <b>have no tail.</b> Since the <i>ḥargol</i> has a tail, its kosher status cannot be inferred from theirs. <b>So too,</b> the inclusion of grasshoppers with long heads <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about these,</b> the <i>arbeh</i>, <i>ḥargol</i>, and <i>solam</i>? They are unique <b>in that their heads are not long.</b> If so, grasshoppers with long heads might not be kosher.
<b>Rather, Rav Aḥai said:</b> One can derive that grasshoppers with long heads are kosher as follows: The <b><i>solam</i></b> mentioned in the verse <b>is redundant.</b> How so? <b>Let the Merciful One not write <i>solam</i>, and</b> instead <b>let it be derived</b> by inference <b>from</b> the common denominators between the <b><i>arbeh</i> and <i>ḥargol</i>,</b> that they have four legs, four wings, jumping legs, and that their wings cover most of their body. <b>As what can you</b> say to <b>refute</b> this? If you say: <b>What</b> can be derived <b>from</b> the <b><i>arbeh</i>, which,</b> unlike the <i>solam</i>, <b>does not have a smooth forehead;</b> one can respond: <b>But</b> there is the <b><i>ḥargol</i>, which has a smooth forehead.</b> And if you say: <b>What</b> can be derived <b>from</b> the <b><i>ḥargol</i>, which,</b> unlike the <i>solam</i>, <b>has a tail,</b> one can respond: <b>But</b> there is the <b><i>arbeh</i>, which has no tail.</b> If so, <b>why do I</b> need the <b><i>solam</i> that the Merciful One wrote?</b> Rather, <b>if</b> the <i>solam</i> <b>is not</b> necessary <b>for the matter itself, apply it</b> to the <b>matter of a long-headed</b> grasshopper, to teach that it is kosher.

Daf 66a

The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do the <i>tanna</i> of the study hall,</b> who taught the first <i>baraita</i> above, <b>and the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael disagree? They disagree with regard to</b> a grasshopper <b>whose head is long.</b> According to the <i>tanna</i> of the study hall it is prohibited, and according to the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael it is permitted.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>The <i>tanna</i> of the study hall holds</b> that the previous verse, permitting all species <b>“which have jointed legs”</b> (Leviticus 11:21), is <b>a generalization.</b> The species <b><i>arbeh</i>, <i>solam</i>, <i>ḥargol</i>,</b> and <b><i>ḥagav</i>,</b> and the phrase <b>“after its kinds,”</b> that appears after each, are <b>a detail.</b> As a rule, in any instance of <b>a generalization and a detail, the generalization includes only that which is</b> spelled out <b>in the detail.</b> Therefore, only grasshoppers <b>of the</b> same <b>species as</b> those detailed in the verse <b>are</b> kosher. Grasshoppers <b>that are not of the</b> same <b>species as</b> them are <b>not</b> kosher. <b>And</b> the phrase “after its kinds” <b>amplifies</b> the <i>halakha</i> to include grasshoppers <b>that are similar to</b> the named species <b>in two aspects,</b> i.e., that are very similar to them. Since all the named species have short heads, grasshoppers with long heads are forbidden.
By contrast, <b>the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael holds</b> that the phrase <b>“which have jointed legs”</b> is <b>a generalization.</b> The species <b><i>arbeh</i>, <i>solam</i>, <i>ḥargol</i>,</b> and <b><i>ḥagav</i></b> are a <b>detail.</b> And by the phrase <b>“after its kinds”</b> after each species, <b>it then generalized</b> again. In any instance of <b>a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization, you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail. And</b> the verse therefore <b>amplifies</b> the <i>halakha</i> to include <b>any</b> grasshopper <b>that is similar to</b> the named species <b>in</b> even <b>one aspect,</b> i.e., that has the four signs listed in the mishna, even if its head is long.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how can this be considered a generalization, a detail, and a generalization? <b>The first generalization is not similar to the latter generalization.</b> In <b>the first generalization, the Merciful One states: “Which have jointed legs,”</b> indicating that you may <b>eat</b> a grasshopper <b>that has</b> jointed legs, but <b>you may not eat</b> one <b>that does not have</b> jointed legs, irrespective of any other sign. However, <b>the latter generalization:</b> “After its kinds,” indicates that no grasshopper is kosher <b>unless it shares</b> all <b>four signs</b> with the named species.
The Gemara responds: <b>The <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael deduces</b> from <b>generalizations and details like this case,</b> even if the generalizations are not similar to one another. The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> that <b>which we also say generally, that the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael deduces</b> from <b>generalizations and details like this case,</b> is derived <b>from here.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael: <b>The Master said: If its name</b> must be <b><i>ḥagav</i>,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that any <i>ḥagav</i> is kosher, even if <b>it does not have all these</b> four <b>signs.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “After its kinds,”</b> indicating that it is not kosher <b>unless it has all these signs.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where would this be derived,</b> that a grasshopper is kosher even if <b>it does not have all these signs?</b> How could one entertain this possibility? <b><i>Arbeh</i> and <i>ḥargol</i> are written</b> beforehand, indicating that all kosher grasshoppers must share the signs they both possess.
The Gemara responds: <b>If <i>solam</i> had not been written</b> as well, it would be <b>as you said.</b> But <b>now that it is written: “<i>Solam</i>,” to include long-headed</b> grasshoppers even though none of the named species have long heads, <b>I will say: Let us also include any</b> grasshopper that is called <i>ḥagav</i>. Therefore, the phrase “after its kinds” <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different there,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> of the study hall, <b>that you say</b> that the <b><i>solam</i> is</b> the <b><i>rashon</i>,</b> and the <b><i>ḥargol</i> is</b> the <b><i>nippul</i>, and what is different here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, <b>that you say:</b> The <b><i>solam</i> is</b> the <b><i>nippul</i>,</b> and the <b><i>ḥargol</i> is</b> the <b><i>rashon</i>?</b> The Gemara responds: This <b>Sage</b> refers to them <b>in accordance with</b> the custom of <b>his locale and</b> that <b>Sage</b> refers to them <b>in accordance with</b> the custom of <b>his locale.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>And with regard to fish, any</b> fish <b>that has a fin and a scale</b> is kosher. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a fish <b>does not have</b> scales <b>now but will grow</b> them <b>after</b> a period of <b>time, such as the <i>sultanit</i> and <i>afyan</i></b> fish, <b>it is permitted.</b> Likewise, if <b>it has</b> scales <b>now but will shed them when it</b> is caught and <b>rises from the water, such as</b>

Daf 66b

the <b><i>akunas</i>, and</b> the <b><i>afunas</i>,</b> and the <b><i>kesaftiyas</i>, and</b> the <b><i>akhsaftiyas</i>, and</b> the <b><i>atunas</i>, it is permitted.</b>
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Nidda</i> 51b): <b>Any</b> fish <b>that has scales</b> certainly <b>has fins, but there are</b> fish <b>that have fins and do not have scales.</b> Any fish that <b>has scales and fins</b> is <b>a kosher fish.</b> If <b>it has fins but no scales,</b> it is <b>a non-kosher fish.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Now,</b> since <b>we rely</b> only <b>on scales</b> to deem a fish kosher, presuming that if it has scales it must have fins as well, <b>let the Merciful One write</b> only <b>“scales”</b> as the sign of a kosher fish <b>and let</b> Him <b>not write “fins”</b> at all. The Gemara responds: <b>If the Merciful One had written: Scales [<i>kaskeset</i>], and had not written: Fins [<i>senappir</i>], I would say: What</b> is <b><i>kaskeset</i>?</b> It is <b>fins. And</b> I would thereby come to permit <b>even non-kosher fish.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One stated: “<i>Senappir</i> and <i>kaskeset</i>,”</b> to leave no room for error.
The Gemara asks: <b>But now that the Merciful One has written: “<i>Senappir</i> and <i>kaskeset</i>,” from where</b> is it derived that <b><i>kaskeset</i></b> denotes <b>clothing,</b> i.e., scales, rather than fins? <b>As it is written: “And he was clad with a coat of scale armor [<i>kaskasim</i>]”</b> (I Samuel 17:5). And if it is certain that <i>kaskeset</i> refers to scales, the question resurfaces: <b>Let the Merciful One write</b> only <b>“<i>kaskeset</i>,” and let</b> Him <b>not write “<i>senappir</i>.”</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu said, and so the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael</b> taught: The Holy One, Blessed be He, wished to bestow good upon the Jewish people. Therefore, He made their Torah abundant, as it is written: “The Lord was pleased, for His righteousness’ sake, <b>to make Torah great and glorious”</b> (Isaiah 42:21). He consequently expanded some aspects of the Torah more than strictly necessary.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah states the prohibition of non-kosher fish both positively and negatively: “These may you eat of all that are in the waters: Whatever has fins and scales…them you may eat. And all that have not fins and scales…they are a detestable thing unto you” (Leviticus 11:9–10). <b>From the implication</b> of <b>that</b> which <b>is stated: Eat</b> fish <b>that have</b> these signs, <b>I</b> would <b>derive</b> the inverse: <b>Do not eat</b> fish <b>that do not have</b> them. <b>And from the implication</b> of <b>that</b> which <b>is stated: Do not eat</b> fish <b>that do not have</b> them, <b>I</b> would <b>derive</b> the inverse: <b>Eat</b> fish <b>that have</b> them. If so, <b>why</b> did the Torah <b>teach</b> both of <b>them?</b> It is in order <b>to</b> indicate that one who eats non-kosher fish <b>transgresses, on its account,</b> both <b>a positive mitzva and a prohibition.</b>
Given that the verse states: “Whatever has fins and scales…them may you eat,” <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states:</b> “These <b>may you eat of all that are in the waters?”</b> Why is this necessary? It is necessary, <b>as</b> without this verse one <b>might</b> have thought: <b>Since</b> the Torah <b>permitted</b> creeping creatures of the water without fins and scales <b>explicitly and</b> also <b>permitted</b> them <b>implicitly,</b> one can infer: <b>Just as when</b> the Torah <b>permitted</b> such creatures <b>explicitly, it permitted</b> them <b>only</b> when <b>in vessels, so too, when it permitted</b> them <b>implicitly, it permitted</b> them <b>only in vessels. From where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> as kosher even those in <b>pits, ditches, and caves, that</b> one may <b>dig</b> them <b>and drink from them and</b> need <b>not refrain</b> from drinking the creeping creatures in them? <b>The verse states:</b> “These <b>may you eat of all that are in the waters,”</b> to indicate that this is permitted.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Where did</b> the Torah <b>permit</b> them <b>in vessels?</b> It did so in the following verse, <b>as it is written: “These may you eat of all that are in the waters:</b> Whatever has fins and scales in the waters, in the seas, and in the rivers, them may you eat.” It would have been sufficient to write simply: “In the waters.” The addition of “in the seas and in the rivers” indicates that <b>it is</b> only <b>in the seas and in the rivers that when it has</b> fins and scales you may <b>eat</b> it, and that <b>you</b> may <b>not eat</b> one <b>that does not have</b> them. <b>But</b> with regard to a creeping creature found <b>in vessels, even if it does not have</b> fins and scales you may <b>eat</b> it.
The Gemara objects: One could just as easily <b>say</b> the opposite: You may eat a fish that has these signs only when it is found in seas and rivers, but <b>in vessels, even if it has</b> fins and scales, <b>you</b> may <b>not eat</b> it. The Gemara responds: This should <b>not enter your mind, as it is written: “And all that have not fins and scales in the seas, and in the rivers, of all that swarm in the waters, and of all the living creatures that are in the waters,</b> they are a detestable thing to you.” The verse indicates that it is only <b>in the seas and in the rivers that you</b> may <b>not eat</b> a fish <b>that does not have</b> fins and scales. <b>But</b> you may <b>eat</b> a creeping creature found <b>in vessels, even if it does not have</b> fins and scales.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> one can prove whether it is permitted to drink from pits, ditches, and caves differently. <b>Say</b> instead that the phrase “whatever has fins and scales <b>in the waters”</b> is <b>a generalization,</b> and the phrase <b>“in the seas and in the rivers”</b> is <b>a detail.</b> In any instance of <b>a generalization and a detail, the generalization only includes that which is</b> spelled out <b>in the detail.</b> Therefore, in the <b>seas and rivers, yes,</b> one may eat only fish with fins and scales, but in <b>water channels and trenches,</b> as well as pits, ditches, and caves, this restriction does <b>not</b> apply. Consequently, the clause “These may you eat of all that are in the waters” is unnecessary.
The Gemara responds: This deduction is not sound. The term <b>“in the waters”</b> appears twice in the verse. When the verse repeated it, <b>it then generalized</b> again. Consequently, there are two generalizations and one detail in the verse, making it an instance of a generalization, a detail, and a generalization, which includes all cases similar to the detail, including pits, ditches, and caves, indicating that the restriction applies to them as well. Therefore, the clause “These may you eat of all that are in the waters” is necessary to teach that all fish in pits, ditches, and caves are permitted.
The Gemara asks: How can this verse be an instance of a generalization, a detail, and a generalization? <b>These are two generalizations that are adjacent to each other.</b> Both instances of the term “in the waters” precede the detail, such that the verse is actually a generalization, a generalization, and a detail. <b>Ravina said: As they say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael: <b>Wherever you find two generalizations juxtaposed one with the other,</b> followed by a specific detail,

Daf 67a

<b>place</b> the <b>detail between</b> the two generalizations <b>and</b> then <b>expound them as a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization.</b> Therefore, the first instance of the phrase <b>“in the waters”</b> is <b>a generalization.</b> The phrase <b>“in the seas and in the rivers”</b> is <b>a detail.</b> And by the second instance of the phrase <b>“in the waters,” it then generalized</b> again.
Therefore, as in any instance of <b>a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization, you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail. Just as the detail,</b> seas and rivers, is referring <b>explicitly</b> to <b>flowing water, so too,</b> fish without fins and scales found in <b>all flowing water</b> are forbidden. <b>What</b> does this <b>include?</b> It includes <b>trenches and water channels, to prohibit</b> fish without fins and scales found in them. <b>And what</b> does it <b>exclude?</b> It excludes <b>pits, ditches, and caves,</b> which are collections of still water, <b>to permit</b> all fish found in them.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say: Just as the detail</b> refers <b>explicitly</b> to <b>water that grows,</b> i.e., is found, <b>on the ground, so too,</b> it includes <b>all water that grows on the ground? And what</b> would this <b>include?</b> It would include <b>even pits, ditches, and caves, to prohibit</b> fish found in them that do not have fins and scales. <b>And what</b> would it <b>exclude?</b> It would <b>exclude</b> only those found in <b>vessels.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>If so, what use is</b> the phrase “These <b>may you eat</b> of all that are in the waters”? Even without it, vessels would be excluded, since they are not at all similar to seas and rivers. Rather, the phrase “These may you eat of all that are in the waters” serves to indicate that only trenches and water channels are considered similar to the detail, but all fish found in pits, ditches, and caves are permitted.
§ The <i>tanna</i> of the school of <b>Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The verse’s use of the phrase <b>“in the waters,” “in the waters” twice is not</b> to be interpreted as <b>a generalization and a detail,</b> but <b>rather</b> as an instance of <b>amplification and restriction.</b> By the first phrase <b>“in the waters,”</b> the verse <b>amplifies,</b> by the phrase <b>“in the seas and in the rivers” it restricts,</b> and by the second instance of <b>“in the waters” it then amplifies again.</b> According to a hermeneutical principle, when a verse <b>amplified, and</b> then <b>restricted, and</b> then <b>amplified, it amplified</b> the relevant category to include <b>everything</b> except for the specific matter excluded by the restriction, i.e., in the seas and in the rivers. <b>What,</b> then, <b>does it include?</b> It includes <b>trenches and water channels, to prohibit</b> fish without fins and scales found in them. <b>And what does it exclude?</b> It excludes fish found in <b>pits, ditches, and caves, to permit</b> them.
The Gemara objects: Why not <b>say: What does it include?</b> It includes fish found in <b>pits, ditches, and caves, to prohibit</b> them if they do not have fins and scales. <b>And what does it exclude?</b> It excludes only fish found in <b>vessels.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>If so, what use is</b> the phrase “These <b>may you eat</b> of all that are in the waters”? Even without it, vessels would be excluded. Rather, it indicates that pits, ditches and caves are excluded by the restriction, and all fish found in them are permitted.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> perhaps <b>l should reverse</b> the statement and claim that fish without fins and scales in pits, ditches, and caves are prohibited, and those in trenches and water channels are permitted. The Gemara responds: One must say <b>as Mattitya taught, as Mattitya bar Yehuda taught: What did you see</b> that caused you <b>to include pits, ditches, and caves, to permit</b> them, <b>and to exclude trenches and water channels, to prohibit</b> them? <b>I include pits, ditches, and caves, which</b> contain <b>still</b> water <b>like vessels, and I exclude trenches and water channels, which are not still like vessels,</b> as water flows through them.
§ The <i>baraita</i> on the previous <i>amud</i> states that the Torah permits all fish without fins and scales in vessels both explicitly and implicitly. The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> verse is the <b>implicit</b> source <b>and which</b> is the <b>explicit</b> source? <b>Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree with regard to it. One says:</b> The verse permitting “whatever <b>has</b> fins and scales in the waters, in the seas, and in the rivers,” is the <b>explicit</b> source, <b>and</b> the verse prohibiting “all that <b>have not</b> fins and scales in the seas, and in the rivers,” is the <b>implicit</b> source. <b>And one says</b> the opposite, i.e., that the verse prohibiting “all that <b>have not</b> fins and scales” is the <b>explicit</b> source <b>and</b> the verse that permits “whatever <b>has</b> fins and scales” is the <b>implicit</b> source.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of the one who says</b> that “whatever <b>has</b> fins and scales” is the <b>explicit</b> source? The Gemara responds: That Sage could have <b>said to you: It is from</b> this verse <b>that</b> the Gemara derives on the previous <i>amud</i> that fish without fins and scales found in <b>vessels are permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of the one who says</b> that “all that <b>have not</b> fins and scales” is the <b>explicit</b> source? The Gemara responds: The reasoning is <b>that it is this</b> verse <b>that proves that the other</b> verse permits all fish in vessels. <b>As, if</b> one attempted to derive whether fish in vessels are permitted <b>from the other</b> verse alone, <b>I would say</b> the opposite: The verse indicates that a fish with fins and scales is permitted only in the seas and rivers; but <b>in vessels, even if it has</b> fins and scales, <b>you</b> may <b>still not eat</b> it. The phrase in the verse “and all that have not fins and scales” indicates that these restrictions apply only to fish in the seas and rivers.
§ <b>Rav Huna says: A person should not pour beer</b> into a vessel <b>through straw</b> to filter it <b>at night, lest</b> a creeping animal <b>emerge</b> from the beer <b>above the straw and then fall into the cup.</b> Since the drinker poured the beer through a filter, he will assume that all creatures found in the vessel originated there and are permitted despite lacking fins and scales. He will therefore drink the beer along with the creature, <b>and</b> in doing so, he <b>violates</b> the prohibition: “Every <b>swarming thing that swarms upon the earth</b> is a detestable thing; it shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 11:41).
The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> that one must be concerned that a creeping animal may have fallen from the straw into the cup, one should <b>also</b> be concerned about any beer found <b>in a vessel,</b> as <b>perhaps</b> some creature <b>emerged</b> from the beer <b>onto the side of the vessel,</b> thereby becoming forbidden, <b>and then fell</b> back <b>into the vessel.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>There, that is</b> the creature’s normal manner of <b>growth,</b> to attach itself to the sides of the vessel, and it is not considered to have emerged from the liquid.
<b>And from where do you say</b> that emerging in its normal manner of growth does not render it forbidden? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include pits, ditches, and caves, that</b> one may <b>dig</b> them <b>and drink from them and</b> need <b>not refrain</b> from drinking the creeping creatures inside them? <b>The verse states:</b> “These <b>may you eat of all that are in the waters,”</b> indicating that all fish in pits, ditches, and caves are permitted. <b>And</b> one might ask: <b>Let</b> one <b>be concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> a creature <b>emerged</b> from the water <b>onto the side</b> of the pit or cave, thereby becoming forbidden, <b>and then fell</b> back into it. <b>Rather,</b> one must say that since <b>that is</b> the creature’s normal manner of <b>growth,</b> it does not render it forbidden. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to beer in a vessel, <b>that is</b> the creature’s normal manner of <b>growth</b> and does not render it forbidden.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Huna:</b> A <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught that supports your</b> statement that one need be concerned only about filtered beer: The verse: <b>“Every swarming thing that swarms upon the earth</b> is a detestable thing” (Leviticus 11:41), serves <b>to include gnats</b> found in liquid <b>that one filtered.</b> One may infer: <b>The reason</b> they are prohibited is <b>because one filtered</b> the liquids, <b>but</b> if one <b>did not filter them,</b> the gnats <b>are permitted.</b> Evidently, one need not be concerned that they emerged from the water onto the side of the vessel.
§ With regard to the prohibition against consuming creeping animals, <b>Shmuel says: A cucumber that became infested with worms</b>

Daf 67b

<b>while attached to the ground is prohibited, due to</b> the prohibition of: “Every <b>swarming thing that swarms upon the earth,”</b> because the cucumber was considered part of the earth when the worms infested it.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that a comparison of the following two <i>baraitot</i> <b>supports</b> Shmuel’s opinion. <b>As it is taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: “Every swarming thing that swarms <b>upon the earth”</b> serves <b>to exclude <i>zizin</i>,</b> a type of insect <b>that</b> is found <b>in lentils, and mosquitoes that are in <i>kelisim</i>,</b> a type of bean, <b>and worms that are in dates and in dried figs.</b> All of these are permitted for consumption because they do not swarm on the earth itself. <b>And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that when the verse states: <b>“Every swarming thing that swarms upon the earth,”</b> the word “every” serves <b>to include</b> as non-kosher <b>worms that are in the roots of olive trees and that are in the roots of vines.</b>
<b>What, is it not</b> that both <b>this and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are referring to insects that are found <b>in the fruit, and this,</b> the latter <i>baraita</i>, deems forbidden fruit that is <b>attached to the ground, and that,</b> the former <i>baraita</i>, deems permitted fruit <b>that is not attached to the ground?</b> This would support Shmuel’s statement that worms in a cucumber attached to the ground are forbidden.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is possible that both <b>this and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are referring to insects found in vegetation <b>attached to the ground; and</b> the apparent contradiction between the two is <b>not difficult. This,</b> the former <i>baraita</i>, deems permitted insects found <b>in the fruit,</b> and <b>that,</b> the latter <i>baraita</i>, deems forbidden insects found <b>in the tree itself.</b> This interpretation contradicts Shmuel’s statement.
The Gemara notes: The language of the latter <i>baraita</i> <b>is also precise, as it teaches: Worms that are in the roots of olive trees and in the roots of vines,</b> clearly referring to the tree itself rather than the fruit. The Gemara concludes: <b>Learn from it</b> that the second interpretation is correct.
§ From the above discussion, it is clear that worms that grow in produce not attached to the ground, and have never emerged from the produce, do not fall under the prohibition of: “Every swarming thing that swarms upon the earth,” because they have never swarmed on the earth. <b>Rav Yosef raises a dilemma:</b> If a worm <b>emerged</b> from the produce <b>but died</b> before it reached the earth, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is it considered to have swarmed on the earth simply by having emerged? If only <b>part of it</b> emerged, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If it emerged <b>into the air of the world</b> and flew away without landing, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara responds to all of the above: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Ashi raises a dilemma:</b> If a worm was spawned in a date, and it emerges and climbs <b>onto the roof of</b> the <b>date,</b> i.e., its upper part, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is this considered the normal manner of growth for the worm, in which case this does not render it forbidden, or is the roof of the date considered a separate entity such that crawling there constitutes swarming on the earth? And if it is considered a separate entity, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if the worm climbed <b>onto the roof of</b> the date’s <b>pit?</b> Is this considered the normal manner of growth for the worm? If the worm emerged <b>from a date</b> and entered <b>a date</b> that was attached to it, without being exposed to the air, <b>what</b> then <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara responds to all of the above: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, says: <i>Kukeyanei</i>,</b> worms found in the internal organs of animals, e.g., in the lung and liver, are <b>forbidden. What is the reason</b> for this? It is that <b>they came from</b> the outside <b>world,</b> i.e., the animal must have swallowed them along with vegetation, in which case these worms were already included in the prohibition: “Every swarming thing that swarms on the earth is a detestable thing; it shall not be eaten.”
<b>Rav Ashi objects to this: If they came from</b> the outside <b>world, they should be found in the digestive tract</b> as well. Since they are found only in non-digestive organs, they must have originated in the animal and should not be considered creeping animals that swarm on the earth.
<b>Some state</b> the exchange differently: <b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, says: <i>Kukeyanei</i> are permitted. What is the reason</b> for this? It is that <b>they originate from</b> inside the animal. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> This is <b>obvious, as if they came from</b> the outside <b>world, they should be found in the digestive tract.</b>
The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is: <b><i>Kukeyanei</i> are forbidden. What is the reason</b> for this? It is that the animal <b>sleeps, and worms enter it through its snout.</b> From there they travel to the internal organs without passing through the digestive tract. <b>Worms</b> found in <b>meat</b> between the skin and the flesh <b>are forbidden;</b> those found in <b>fish are permitted.</b>
The Gemara recounts: <b>Ravina said to his mother: Conceal</b> the fish’s worms inside it so I cannot see them, <b>and I will eat</b> the fish. <b>Rav Mesharshiyya, son of Rav Aḥa, said to Ravina: What is different</b> in this case <b>from that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, that the verse: <b>“Their carcasses you shall have in detestation”</b> (Leviticus 11:11), serves <b>to include worms that are in animals</b> as forbidden? Why are worms in fish permitted?
Ravina <b>said to him: How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? An animal is rendered permitted</b> for consumption only <b>by slaughter.</b> Before it is slaughtered, it and all its contents are considered part of a living animal and prohibited by the Torah. <b>And since</b> the animal’s <b>slaughter is not effective for these</b> worms, <b>they retain their forbidden</b> status. <b>But fish are rendered permitted by merely gathering</b> them; they are not included in the prohibition against eating a limb from a living animal. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>when these</b> worms <b>originate</b> inside the fish, <b>they originate in a permitted</b> state.
§ The verse states: “Whatever goes upon the belly, and whatever goes upon all fours, or whatever has many feet, even all swarming things that swarm upon the earth, them you shall not eat” (Leviticus 11:42). <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the phrase <b>“goes upon the belly”</b> is referring to the <b>snake.</b> The preceding word <b>“whatever”</b> serves <b>to include</b> the <b>earthworm and</b> animals <b>similar to an earthworm.</b> The phrase <b>“upon all fours”</b> is referring to the <b>scorpion.</b> The preceding phrase <b>“whatever goes”</b> serves <b>to include the beetle and</b> animals <b>similar to a beetle.</b> The phrase <b>“has many feet”</b> is referring to the <b>centipede.</b> The preceding phrase <b>“or whatever”</b> serves <b>to include</b> animals <b>similar</b> to a centipede <b>and</b> animals <b>similar to those similar to</b> it.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei ben Durmaskit says:</b> The <b>leviathan</b> mentioned in the Bible <b>is a kosher fish, as it is stated: “His armor is his pride”</b> (Job 41:7), and: <b>“Sharpest potsherds are under him”</b> (Job 41:22). The phrase <b>“his armor”</b> is referring to <b>his scales,</b> which protect him like armor. The phrase <b>“sharpest potsherds are under him”</b> is referring to <b>fins with which he swims,</b> which are sharp and project from his underside.

Daf 68a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> When a pregnant kosher animal is slaughtered, the slaughter also renders the consumption of its fetus permitted. Even if <b>an animal was encountering difficulty giving birth and</b> meanwhile <b>the fetus extended its foreleg</b> outside the mother animal’s womb <b>and</b> then <b>brought it back</b> inside, and then the mother animal was slaughtered, the <b>consumption</b> of the fetus is <b>permitted</b> by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal. But if the fetus <b>extended its head</b> outside the womb, <b>even if it</b> then <b>brought it back</b> inside, the halakhic status of <b>that</b> fetus is <b>like</b> that of <b>a newborn,</b> and the slaughter of the mother animal does not permit the consumption of the fetus. Rather, it requires its own slaughter.
If, prior to slaughtering an animal, one <b>severs</b> pieces <b>from a fetus that is in</b> the <b>womb</b> and leaves those pieces in the womb, their <b>consumption</b> is <b>permitted</b> by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal. By contrast, if one severs pieces <b>of the spleen or of the kidneys</b> of an animal and then slaughters it, then even if those pieces are left inside the animal their <b>consumption</b> is <b>prohibited,</b> because an organ severed from a living being is not permitted by the subsequent slaughter of the animal. <b>This is the principle: An item that is</b> part of an animal’s <b>body</b> that was severed prior to its slaughter is <b>prohibited</b> even after slaughter, <b>and</b> an item <b>that is not</b> part of <b>its body,</b> i.e., its fetus, is <b>permitted</b> by virtue of its slaughter.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara qualifies the first ruling of the mishna: <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: But</b> as for <b>the limb itself,</b> i.e., the foreleg, its consumption is <b>prohibited,</b> even though the fetus brought it back inside prior to the slaughter.
<b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>as the verse states: “And flesh, in the field, a <i>tereifa</i>, you shall not eat”</b> (Exodus 22:30). A <i>tereifa</i> is an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months; its consumption is prohibited even if it is ritually slaughtered. The Gemara interprets the verse as teaching a principle: <b>Once flesh</b> whose permitted status is dependent on being within a certain area, e.g., sacrificial meat within the Temple courtyard, <b>has gone outside of its boundary,</b> i.e., the area in which it is permitted, which the verse describes as being “in the field,” <b>it becomes</b> permanently <b>prohibited,</b> like a <i>tereifa</i>. Likewise, the permitted status of a fetus is dependent on its being within the womb when the mother animal is slaughtered. Accordingly, if any part of the fetus leaves the womb before the slaughter, it is rendered permanently prohibited.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>an animal was encountering difficulty giving birth and</b> as a result <b>the fetus extended its foreleg</b> outside the mother animal’s body <b>but</b> then <b>brought it back,</b> and then the animal was slaughtered, the <b>consumption</b> of the fetus is <b>permitted</b> by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal. The Gemara assumes: <b>What,</b> is the mishna <b>not referring to</b> the entire fetus, including <b>the limb,</b> i.e., the foreleg, when it states that its consumption is permitted by the slaughter? This would contradict Rav’s ruling. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the mishna is <b>referring to</b> the rest of the <b>fetus,</b> apart from the foreleg.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the mishna is <b>referring to</b> the rest of the <b>fetus, why</b> state <b>specifically</b> that the fetus <b>brought back</b> its foreleg? <b>Even</b> if it did <b>not bring it back</b> the rest of the fetus would still be permitted. The Gemara answers: <b>The same is true,</b> that the rest of the fetus is permitted, <b>even if</b> it <b>did not bring back</b> its foreleg. <b>But since</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>wants to teach</b> in <b>the latter clause:</b> If the fetus <b>extended its head, even though it brought it back,</b> the halakhic status of <b>that</b> fetus is <b>like</b> that of <b>a newborn</b> and is permitted only through its own slaughter, therefore <b>he also taught</b> in <b>the first clause</b> that the fetus <b>brought back</b> its foreleg, for stylistic reasons, despite the fact that the ruling is not limited to that case.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> concerning this <b>latter clause</b> itself, <b>what does it teach us?</b> Does it teach <b>that once</b> the fetus <b>extended its head, that is</b> considered <b>a birth?</b> But <b>we</b> have already <b>learned</b> this in a mishna (<i>Bekhorot</i> 46a): <b>Who is</b> considered <b>a firstborn with regard to inheritance but is not</b> considered <b>a firstborn with regard to</b> the requirement to be redeemed by giving five shekels to <b>the priests?</b> It is a son <b>who came after</b> the <b>miscarriage</b> of an underdeveloped fetus. The mishna adds that the category of stillbirth includes the case of a child who did not reach full term, <b>even if its head emerged alive, or</b> a fully developed, <b>nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus <b>whose head emerged dead.</b>
The Gemara infers from the final clause of the mishna: <b>The reason</b> a son born following the miscarriage is considered a firstborn with regard to inheritance is <b>that</b> the <b>head</b> of the miscarriage emerged only after it was already <b>dead. But</b> if <b>its head</b> had initially emerged <b>alive,</b> even if it then died before being fully delivered, the son <b>born after him would not be</b> considered <b>a firstborn even with regard to inheritance.</b> Apparently, this is because the emergence of the head alive is considered a birth, and therefore any subsequent child cannot be considered the firstborn. Evidently, it is unnecessary for the mishna here to teach this definition of a birth.
<b>And if you would say</b> that the mishna there <b>teaches us</b> the definition of birth <b>with regard to a person, and</b> the mishna here <b>teaches us</b> that the same definition applies <b>to an animal,</b> another problem remains, as the Gemara will presently explain.
Before explaining the problem with this suggestion, the Gemara explains why it is necessary to teach the definition with regard to both people and animals: <b>Because</b> the definition of birth with regard to <b>a person cannot be derived from</b> that <b>of an animal, as an animal does not have a concealed opening [<i>prozdor</i>]</b> to the womb, unlike women, whose thighs conceal the opening to their womb. Consequently, even if the definition were stated with regard to an animal, one might limit it to animals, as that stage is immediately visible; whereas in women it is not. <b>And</b> conversely, the definition of birth with regard to <b>an animal cannot be derived from</b> that of <b>a person, as the form of</b> a person’s <b>face is significant</b> because people are created in the image of God, and their faces bear the mark of their intelligence, which is not true of animals. Consequently, perhaps the emergence of the head alone is considered a birth only with regard to a person.
The Gemara proceeds to explain why the above suggestion is not a solution: With regard to <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>also,</b> that the emergence of the head of an animal is considered a birth, <b>we</b> have already <b>learned</b> it in a mishna (77a): If <b>part of a placenta emerged</b> from the womb of an animal before it was slaughtered, its <b>consumption</b> is <b>prohibited</b> even after the mother animal is slaughtered. The reason for this is just <b>as</b> the placenta is <b>an indication of</b> the presence of <b>a fetus in a woman, so too,</b> it is <b>an indication of</b> the presence of <b>a fetus in an animal.</b> Consequently, it is possible that the part of the placenta that emerged contained the head of the fetus, and accordingly it would be considered to have been born. The slaughter of the mother animal would therefore not permit it for consumption. Evidently, it is unnecessary for the mishna here to teach the definition of a birth even with regard to an animal.
The Gemara has established that the latter clause does not teach any novelty. Accordingly, it returns to challenging Rav’s ruling: <b>Granted,</b> the mishna is understood <b>if you say</b> that the statement that the fetus <b>brought</b> its foreleg <b>back</b> inside the mother animal, which is mentioned <b>in the first clause</b> of the mishna, is written <b>specifically</b> in order to teach the novelty that the foreleg is permitted if it was brought back before the slaughter, in contrast to Rav’s ruling. If so, then one can claim the mishna <b>taught</b> it in <b>the latter clause due to the first clause,</b> so that they would be parallel stylistically, and no novelty is necessary in the latter clause.
<b>But if you say the first clause</b> is <b>not</b> written <b>specifically</b> and does not teach a novelty, but rather the mishna is referring to the permitted status of the rest of the fetus, which is permitted even if it does not bring back its foreleg, <b>and</b> you also say <b>the latter clause is not</b> written <b>specifically</b> to teach a novelty, since the definition of birth is already taught in a mishna elsewhere, then <b>why does it</b> need <b>to teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the foreleg or head were brought back <b>at all?</b> Perforce, the first clause must be referring to the permitted status of the foreleg and limiting it specifically to the case where it was brought back inside. This contradicts Rav’s ruling.
The Gemara responds: <b>No; actually,</b> the mishna is <b>referring to</b> the permitted status of the rest of the <b>fetus, but</b> nevertheless, the statement that the fetus brought back its foreleg does teach a novelty. This is <b>similar to that which Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said,</b> in explanation of a ruling in a <i>baraita</i> cited below, that it is <b>necessary only with regard to the location of a cut</b> limb on the fetus’s body. If the foreleg were to be severed at precisely the point that lay on the boundary between the inside and the outside of the womb, then the location of the cut on the fetus’s body would also be prohibited. <b>Here too,</b> one can explain that the ruling is <b>necessary only with regard to the location of the cut,</b> and it teaches that if the fetus did not bring back its foreleg, then not only is the foreleg prohibited but the location of the cut is also prohibited.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a challenge to Rav’s ruling from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>an animal was encountering difficulty giving birth,</b> and as a result <b>the fetus extended its foreleg</b> outside the mother animal’s body <b>and then brought it back</b> inside <b>and</b> then <b>afterward one slaughtered its mother,</b> its <b>consumption</b> is <b>permitted</b> by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal. But if <b>one</b> first <b>slaughtered its mother, and</b> only <b>afterward</b> did the fetus <b>return its</b> foreleg back inside, its <b>consumption</b> is <b>prohibited.</b>
If the fetus <b>extended its foreleg</b> outside <b>and</b> one <b>cut it</b> off, <b>and</b> then <b>afterward one slaughtered its mother,</b> then the part of the foreleg <b>that was outside</b> and was cut off is <b>ritually impure and</b> its consumption is <b>prohibited,</b> as it has the status of a limb cut from a living animal, which is forbidden. <b>And</b> the rest of the fetus <b>that was inside</b> is <b>ritually pure and</b> its consumption is <b>permitted</b> by virtue the slaughter of the mother animal.
If <b>one slaughtered its mother and</b> only <b>afterward cut off</b> the foreleg that had been extended outside,

Daf 68b

then <b>the flesh</b> of both the mother animal and the fetus, excluding the foreleg, is impure due to <b>contact with a carcass.</b> Since the foreleg of the now dead fetus was not permitted through an act of slaughtering, it is regarded as a carcass. It therefore imparts impurity to the rest of the flesh, which was in contact with it. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> Although the slaughter of the mother animal does not permit the consumption of the foreleg, it does serve to prevent the foreleg from imparting the ritual impurity of a carcass. Accordingly, the flesh has the status of having been in <b>contact with a slaughtered <i>tereifa</i>.</b> By Torah law, consumption of the animal is prohibited but it does not impart ritual impurity. The Sages decreed it to be impure in that it disqualifies sacrificial flesh with which it comes in contact.
The Gemara explains the challenge to Rav’s ruling: <b>In any event, the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches:</b> If <b>the fetus extended its foreleg</b> outside the mother animal’s body <b>and then brought it back</b> inside <b>and</b> then <b>afterward one slaughtered its mother,</b> its <b>consumption</b> is <b>permitted. What, is it not</b> referring <b>to the limb,</b> i.e., the foreleg, and the <i>baraita</i> rules that it is permitted, in contradiction to Rav’s ruling? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it <b>is referring to</b> the rest of <b>the fetus.</b>
The Gemara questions this: <b>If</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is referring to</b> the <b>fetus, say the latter clause:</b> If <b>one</b> first <b>slaughtered its mother, and</b> only <b>afterward</b> the fetus <b>returned its</b> foreleg inside, its <b>consumption</b> is <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara explains the question: <b>And if</b> it is referring to the <b>fetus, why</b> should it be <b>prohibited</b> in this case?
The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to the fetus, and should be explained in a manner <b>similar to that which Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said,</b> in explanation of a ruling in a <i>baraita</i> cited below, that it is <b>necessary only with regard to the location of the cut</b> limb on the fetus’s body. If the foreleg was severed at precisely the point that lay on the boundary between the inside and outside when it was extended outside the womb, the location of the cut on the fetus’s body is also prohibited. <b>Here too,</b> one can explain that this ruling is <b>necessary only with regard to the location of the cut,</b> and it teaches that if the fetus did not return its foreleg, then not only is the foreleg prohibited but the location of the cut is prohibited as well. The foreleg itself, though, is prohibited even if it was brought back inside before the slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But when Avimi came from Bei Ḥozai he came and brought a <i>baraita</i> with him:</b> One of the sources (see 69a) that the slaughter of a pregnant animal also serves to permit the consumption of the fetus is the verse: “And every animal that has a split hoof and is cloven into two hooves, chews the cud, of the animals, it you may eat” (Deuteronomy 14:6). The verse mentions both “hoof” in the singular and “hooves” in the plural to teach that sometimes one may eat two hooves and sometimes only one, as follows: If the fetus extended two of its hooves outside the womb, if it <b>returned</b> one <b>hoof one may eat,</b> if it brought back both <b>hooves one may eat. What, is it not</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means that if it <b>brought back</b> one <b>hoof one may eat</b> that <b>hoof,</b> and likewise if it brought back both <b>hooves one may eat</b> both of them, in contradiction to Rav’s ruling?
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it means that if it <b>brought back</b> one <b>hoof</b> or even both, <b>one may eat</b> the rest of the <b>fetus</b> but not the hooves. The Gemara objects: <b>If</b> it is referring to the permitted status of the <b>fetus, why does it specifically</b> state that it <b>brought back</b> the hoof? <b>Even</b> if it did <b>not bring</b> it <b>back</b> the fetus would be permitted. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>necessary only with regard to the location of the cut</b> limb on the body of the fetus. If the limb were to be severed at precisely the point that lay on the boundary between the inside and the outside when it was extended outside the womb, then the location of the cut on the fetus’s body would also be prohibited, but only if the fetus had not brought back that limb before the mother animal was slaughtered.
The Gemara persists: <b>But</b> even given Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak’s claim the <i>baraita</i> <b>adduces two verses,</b> i.e., the mention of hoof and hooves. <b>What, is it not</b> that <b>one</b> serves <b>to</b> permit the <b>limb,</b> in contradiction to Rav’s ruling, <b>and</b> the other <b>one</b> serves <b>to</b> permit the <b>location of the cut,</b> in accordance with Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak’s ruling? The Gemara responds: <b>No; one</b> mention does serve <b>to</b> permit the <b>location of the cut, but</b> the other <b>one</b> serves <b>to</b> permit a fetus with <b>non-cloven hooves [<i>kalut</i>]</b> found <b>inside the womb of a cow</b> that was slaughtered. Although the fetus does not bear the distinguishing characteristics of a kosher species, it is nevertheless permitted by virtue of the slaughter of its mother.
<b>And</b> it is necessary to have a specific source to permit this <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon, as Rabbi Shimon says:</b> A calf with <b>non-cloven hooves born from a</b> kosher <b>cow</b> is <b>forbidden,</b> as the calf does not bear the distinguishing characteristics of a kosher species. The verse teaches that <b>this matter</b> applies only <b>where</b> the fetus <b>emerged into the airspace of the world,</b> i.e., it was born before the mother animal was slaughtered. <b>But</b> if it was still <b>inside its mother’s womb</b> when the mother was slaughtered, it is permitted.
§ The Gemara attempted to challenge Rav’s ruling that once a limb of a fetus is extended outside the mother animal’s body it becomes prohibited even if it was then brought back, but did not find a conclusive refutation. It now presents a dissenting opinion: <b>Ulla</b> says that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And</b> even the <b>limb itself is permitted</b> by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal.
<b>Rav Yehuda said to Ulla: But Rav and Shmuel both say</b> the <b>limb itself is prohibited;</b> how can you say otherwise? Ulla <b>said to him: Who will give us</b> some <b>of the dust of</b> the graves of <b>Rav and Shmuel and we will fill our eyes</b> with it; such is the greatness of those Sages. <b>But</b> I follow the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, and <b>this</b> is what <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Initially one would assume <b>all</b> flesh that is permitted due to being within a certain boundary, e.g., a fetus inside its mother’s womb, the flesh of offerings of the most sacred order within the Temple courtyard, and the flesh of offerings of lesser sanctity within Jerusalem, <b>was included</b> in the verse: <b>“And flesh, in the field, a <i>tereifa</i>, you shall not eat”</b> (Exodus 22:30). The verse is interpreted to teach that if such flesh leaves its boundaries it is rendered forbidden, even should it subsequently return.
<b>Once</b> another <b>verse applies</b> the concept <b>for you specifically with regard to a sin offering,</b> teaching <b>that</b> if it <b>went outside of its boundary and returned</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> (see Leviticus 10:18), then it is apparent <b>that the Merciful One specifically applied</b> the concept <b>to a sin offering. But</b> with regard to <b>all</b> other <b>items</b> that left their boundary, <b>once</b> they are <b>brought back</b> they are <b>permitted,</b> including the limb of a fetus that was extended outside the womb and then was brought back.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Ulla and Rabbi Yoḥanan from a <i>baraita</i>: It is derived from the verse: <b>“And flesh, in the field, a <i>tereifa</i>, you shall not eat,”</b> that flesh that leaves the boundary in which it is permitted is thereby rendered forbidden like a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state</b> that it is like a <i>tereifa</i>? The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>Since we find with regard to second tithe and first fruits that even though they went outside of their boundary,</b> which is the city of Jerusalem and the only place where it is permitted to eat them, nevertheless if they <b>are brought back</b> to there <b>they are</b> once again <b>permitted,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought <b>that also</b> with regard to <b>this</b> prohibition, that of flesh that leaves its boundary, <b>it is so,</b> i.e., if it is brought back it once again becomes permitted for consumption. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “A <i>tereifa</i>.”</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation</b> from the term “a <i>tereifa</i>”? <b>Rabba said:</b> The verse indicates that the prohibition of flesh that left its boundary is <b>like</b> the prohibition of <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. Just as</b> with regard to <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, once</b> an animal <b>is mortally wounded,</b> rendering it a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>it can no longer regain a permitted status, so too</b> with regard to <b>flesh</b> referred to in the verse: <b>Once it has gone outside of its boundary it can no longer regain permitted</b> status. Accordingly, if the limb of a fetus was extended outside the womb it would thereby become permanently prohibited, contradicting the opinion of Ulla and Rabbi Yoḥanan. The Gemara concludes: <b>The refutation of</b> the statement of <b>Ulla</b> is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>, which states: <b>The Master said: Since we find with regard to second tithe and first fruits</b> that although they left their boundary, if they are brought back there they are again permitted. The Gemara asks: <b>Where did we find</b> this, i.e., what is the source for this <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara explains <b>that it is written: “You may not eat within your gates the tithe of your grain,</b> or of your wine, or of your oil, or the firstborn of your herd or of your flock, nor any of your vows that you have vowed, nor your voluntary offerings, nor the offering of your hand. But you shall eat them before the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:17–18). The phrase “the tithe of your grain, or of your wine, or of your oil” is referring to second tithe, and the phrase “the offering of your hand” is referring to first fruits. The verse states that all the items listed may be eaten only “before the Lord your God,” i.e., within the city of Jerusalem. The prohibition stated in the verse is that <b>within your gates,</b> i.e., outside of Jerusalem, <b>you may not eat</b> these items. <b>But</b> by inference, if these items <b>went outside of their boundary,</b> i.e., outside of Jerusalem, <b>and</b> then <b>were brought back, they are permitted.</b>
§ The Gemara explained the dispute between Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan in the way in which it was taught in Babylonia. The Gemara notes that <b>in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>they taught</b> the dispute <b>like this: Rav says there is</b> a concept of <b>birth with regard to limbs.</b> When a limb is extended outside the womb, it is considered born and is independent of the mother animal. Consequently, it can never be permitted by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>there is no</b> concept of <b>birth with regard to limbs.</b> Since the limb is never considered to have been born, as long as it is inside the mother animal when the mother animal is slaughtered it will be permitted by virtue of that slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> these two versions which explain why Rav deemed the limb forbidden? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between</b> them is in a case in which only the majority of a limb was extended outside the womb. In that case, the issue is whether or not <b>to prohibit the minority of</b> the <b>limb that</b> remained <b>inside.</b> If the limb is forbidden because it is considered to have been born, the entire limb would be forbidden and not just the part that was extended. If the limb is forbidden because it left its boundary, then only the part that extended outside the womb would be forbidden.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>According to the statement of the one who says there is no</b> concept of <b>birth with regard to limbs,</b> if <b>the fetus extended its foreleg</b> outside the womb <b>and brought it back, and again it extended its</b> other <b>foreleg</b> outside <b>and brought it back,</b> and continued to extend parts of its body outside <b>until</b> the total amount that had been outside the womb <b>constituted the majority of</b> the fetus, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that ultimately the <b>majority</b> of the fetus <b>has left</b> the womb and the entire fetus should be regarded as having been born, and consequently the slaughter of its mother can no longer permit its being consumed? <b>Or perhaps, since it brought</b> each limb <b>back,</b> the limbs are considered to have been <b>brought back;</b> therefore, the majority of the fetus is not considered to have left the womb and it is not regarded as having been born. In that case, the slaughter of its mother would still permit its being consumed.
The Gemara asks: <b>If you want to say</b> that <b>since it brought back</b> each limb, they are considered to have been <b>brought back</b> and the majority of the fetus is not considered to have left the womb, the following dilemma still arises: If the <b>fetus extended its foreleg</b> outside <b>and</b> someone <b>severed it, and again it extended its</b> other <b>foreleg</b> outside <b>and</b> someone <b>severed it,</b> and this continued with its other limbs <b>until</b> the total amount outside the womb <b>constituted the majority of</b> the fetus, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that since the <b>majority</b> of the fetus <b>has left</b> the womb, the entire fetus should be regarded as having been born and therefore the slaughter of its mother can no longer permit it? <b>Or perhaps,</b> in order for the fetus to be regarded as having been born <b>we require a majority</b> of the fetus to leave <b>simultaneously,</b> which does not exist in this case.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna:

Daf 69a

<b>This is the principle: An item that is</b> part of an animal’s <b>body</b> that was severed prior to the slaughter is <b>prohibited</b> to be consumed even after slaughter, <b>and</b> an item <b>that is not</b> part of <b>its body,</b> i.e., its fetus, is <b>permitted</b> by virtue of its slaughter. The Gemara asks: Just prior to stating the principle, the mishna states the <i>halakha</i> that even if parts of a fetus are cut from it the slaughter of the mother permits it. If so, when the mishna presents the principle and states that an item <b>that is not</b> part of <b>its body</b> is permitted, <b>what is added?</b> Is it <b>not to include a case like this,</b> where the majority of the fetus has already left the womb, and nevertheless the principle clarifies that the rest of the fetus that remains inside the womb is permitted?
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No, it comes to include</b> a fetus with <b>non-cloven hooves</b> found <b>inside the womb of a cow</b> that was slaughtered. Although the fetus does not bear the hallmarks of a kosher animal, which has split hooves and chews its cud, it is nevertheless permitted to be consumed by virtue of the slaughter of its mother. <b>And</b> a specific clause in the mishna permitting this is necessary <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon, as Rabbi Shimon says:</b> A calf with <b>non-cloven hooves born from a</b> kosher <b>cow</b> is <b>forbidden,</b> as the calf does not bear the hallmarks of a kosher animal. The mishna teaches that <b>this matter</b> applies only <b>where</b> the fetus <b>emerged into the airspace of the world,</b> i.e., it was born before the mother animal was slaughtered. <b>But</b> if it is still <b>inside its mother’s womb</b> when the mother is slaughtered, it is permitted to be consumed.
§ The Gemara taught that the reason to deem a limb of a fetus that was extended outside the womb forbidden for consumption is because it went outside of its boundary. Based on this, <b>Rav Ḥananya raises a dilemma:</b> If the <b>fetus</b> of a sacrificial animal of the most sacred order <b>extended its foreleg</b> outside the womb while <b>in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard</b> and then brought it back, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Will the slaughter of the mother permit that limb? Do we say that <b>since</b> the courtyard <b>is</b> regarded as the <b>boundary for</b> such <b>sacrificial</b> animals, as they are permitted only when in the courtyard, therefore <b>it is also</b> regarded as the boundary <b>for this</b> fetus, and even if it extended its limb outside of the womb, it is irrelevant since it ultimately remained within its boundary? <b>Or perhaps, for this</b> fetus, the courtyard <b>is not</b> considered its <b>boundary, as the boundary of a fetus is its mother,</b> and so the limb would become prohibited.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Ḥananya: <b>But</b> why don’t <b>you raise</b> the same <b>dilemma</b> with regard to the fetuses of <b>offerings of lesser sanctity,</b> which are permitted only <b>within Jerusalem?</b> Abaye continues: It would appear that concerning <b>offerings of lesser sanctity within Jerusalem, what is the reason</b> that <b>you did not raise</b> this <b>dilemma?</b> It is because it is clear to you <b>that the boundary of a fetus is its mother.</b> But <b>here too,</b> concerning a fetus of an offering of the most sacred order, one must say that <b>the boundary of a fetus is its mother,</b> and not the Temple courtyard.
§ The <i>baraita</i> cited on 68b discusses the case of a fetus that extended a limb outside the womb. It cites the opinion of the Rabbis that although the slaughter of the mother does not permit the consumption of the limb, it does prevent it from being defined as a carcass with the associated ritual impurity. Based on this, <b>Ilfa raises a dilemma: If</b> the <b>fetus extended its foreleg</b> outside the womb <b>between</b> the severing of its mother’s windpipe, which is <b>one of the organs that must be severed in ritual slaughter [<i>siman</i>],</b> and the severing of the other <b><i>siman</i>,</b> the gullet, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Does</b> the cutting of the <b>first <i>siman</i> combine with</b> that of <b>the second <i>siman</i> to render</b> that limb <b>pure from</b> the impurity of <b>a carcass or not?</b> The cutting of the first <i>siman</i> could potentially permit the consumption of the limb, as the limb was still inside the womb, whereas the cutting of the second <i>siman</i> could not permit consumption, as the limb had already been extended outside the womb. Since they have different effects, can they combine to render the limb pure? <b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If</b> the cutting of the <b>first <i>siman</i> was effective to</b> the extent that it can combine with the cutting of the <b>second <i>siman</i> to permit</b> the rest of the fetus <b>for consumption, will it not be effective</b> with regard to the limb <b>to render it pure from</b> the impurity of <b>a carcass?</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> If a fetus extended a limb outside the womb, thereby rendering the limb forbidden, and then, after the mother animal was slaughtered, the fetus emerged alive, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>concerning</b> whether there is a need <b>to be concerned with regard to</b> any <b>offspring of</b> that fetus, i.e., that the prohibition pertaining to its limb will pass on to its offspring?
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If we say</b> the dilemma applies to the offspring in a case <b>where</b> the fetus matured and <b>mated with a full-fledged,</b> normal <b>animal,</b> which would be fully permitted if slaughtered, then <b>why</b> raise this dilemma <b>specifically</b> with regard to <b>this</b> fetus, <b>which has a prohibition</b> attached to it caused <b>by leaving</b> its boundary?
<b>Even</b> in the case of <b>a regular fetus that emerged alive from its mother’s womb after the mother was slaughtered [<i>ben pekua</i>],</b> which is permitted without the need for any slaughter, the dilemma could <b>also</b> be raised, <b>as Rav Mesharshiyya says: According to the statement of the one who says</b> that when defining the status of an animal <b>one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity</b> and not only its maternity, if <b>a <i>ben pekua</i> mated with a full-fledged animal, the offspring has no rectification.</b> The offspring of two <i>ben pekua</i> animals is permitted without ritual slaughter. But if the father is a <i>ben pekua</i> but not the mother, then it is simultaneously defined as requiring slaughter, based on the mother, and being excluded from the possibility of being permitted through slaughter, based on the father. Therefore, no act of slaughter can permit it.
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the dilemma does not concern that case. Rather, it is <b>necessary</b> in a case in <b>which</b> the fetus later <b>mated with a <i>ben pekua</i> like it</b> and had offspring. Since neither of the parents require slaughter, the offspring does not require it either. In such a case, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? To what extent does the prohibition pertaining to the limb of the father pass to the offspring? Do we say that each <b>limb</b> of the father <b>produces</b> the corresponding <b>limb</b> in the offspring, <b>and</b> so only the parallel limb in the offspring is prohibited, <b>and</b> therefore <b>one</b> could <b>sever</b> that limb <b>and</b> the rest of the offspring will be <b>permitted? Or perhaps</b> the father’s <b>seed is intermingled</b> through the entire offspring, and so the entire offspring is prohibited.
After raising this dilemma, Rabbi Yirmeya <b>then said:</b> It is <b>obvious that the seed of</b> the father <b>is intermingled</b> through the entire offspring, <b>as if</b> it were <b>so</b> that each limb produces the corresponding limb, every <b>blind</b> father would <b>bear blind</b> offspring, <b>and an amputee</b> father would <b>bear</b> offspring that is <b>an amputee.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious that the seed of</b> the father <b>is intermingled, and this is</b> the <b>dilemma we are raising:</b> Even with regard to <b>a regular animal,</b> is it <b>not produced from the influence of</b> the forbidden <b>fat and blood</b> of its father and mother, <b>and</b> yet it <b>is permitted</b> to be consumed? <b>Here too,</b> it <b>is no different,</b> and although the forbidden limb of the father was an influence in the offspring’s formation, the offspring should nevertheless be permitted. <b>Or perhaps we say</b> that the Torah permitted these <b>two prohibitions,</b> the consumption of forbidden fat and the consumption of blood, but <b>we do not say</b> that it permitted <b>three</b> prohibitions, i.e., also the prohibition of a limb that left its boundary.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to whom</b> is it possible to speak of three prohibitions in order to raise this dilemma? <b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> that is difficult, because he holds that a fetus that has completed its gestational term is regarded as being independent of its mother and is no longer permitted by virtue of its mother’s slaughter. Consequently, <b>there is a prohibition of</b> forbidden <b>fat and blood,</b> just like any other animal, <b>but there is no prohibition of</b> a limb that <b>leaves</b> its boundary, as its permitted status is no longer dependent on being within its mother’s womb.
And <b>if</b> you say it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> that is also difficult, because he holds that since ultimately the offspring was inside its mother’s womb when the mother was slaughtered, the fetus is permitted in its entirety by virtue of that slaughter. Consequently, <b>there is a prohibition of</b> a limb that <b>leaves</b> its boundary, <b>but there is no prohibition of</b> forbidden <b>fat and blood.</b>
The Gemara cites the source of the opinions of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda: <b>As we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The prohibition of the <b>sciatic nerve applies to the fetus</b> that had already completed its gestational term when its mother was slaughtered, <b>and</b> likewise <b>its fat is forbidden;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that the prohibition of the <b>sciatic nerve does not apply to the fetus, and its fat is permitted.</b> Evidently, according to all opinions, both the prohibitions of forbidden fat and blood and the prohibition of a limb that leaves its boundary cannot apply to the same animal.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>we do not say</b> that <b>any</b> item that is produced <b>from the influence of</b> a forbidden entity is itself forbidden, <b>as</b> in fact <b>it is permitted.</b> Therefore, it would certainly be permitted to consume the offspring of a fetus whose limb had been forbidden, and the dilemma does not concern such an animal.
<b>And this is</b> the <b>dilemma</b> that <b>we are raising: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to drinking</b> the <b>milk</b> of a fetus whose limb is forbidden? <b>Isn’t regular milk</b> of a normal animal <b>comparable to a limb from a living</b> animal, given that it is taken from a live animal, <b>and</b> yet it <b>is permitted?</b> If so, <b>this</b> milk <b>too</b> should be <b>no different,</b> and although the milk comes from an animal whose limb is forbidden as a limb from a living animal, as it was not permitted through the slaughter of its mother, nevertheless, the milk should be permitted.
<b>Or perhaps there,</b> with regard to regular milk, the Torah waives the prohibition of a limb from a living animal, <b>as there is a rectification for its prohibition through slaughter.</b> But <b>here,</b> with regard to a fetus whose limb is forbidden as a limb from a living animal, <b>there is no rectification for its prohibition through slaughter.</b> The Gemara accepts that this was the dilemma, but concludes that no resolution for it was found, and so the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
