§ The mishna states: If, prior to slaughtering an animal, one <b>severed</b> pieces <b>from a fetus</b> that is in its womb, leaving those pieces in the womb, their consumption is permitted by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is written: “And every animal that has a split hoof</b> and is cloven into two hooves, chews the cud, of the animals, it you may eat” (Deuteronomy 14:6). The term “of the animals [<i>babehema</i>]” is translated literally as: In the animal, and is referring to the term “every animal” mentioned at the beginning of the verse. Accordingly, the verse may be read as saying: Every <b>animal in the animal</b> you may eat, and is referring to a fetus inside its mother. It therefore serves <b>to include the offspring,</b> i.e., the fetus, as being permitted by its mother’s slaughter, even if parts of the fetus had been severed.
The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so,</b> that the phrase: Every animal of the animals, is referring to a fetus, then one should be able to <b>substitute</b> a non-sacred animal <b>for</b> the sanctified fetus of a pregnant offering, i.e., the non-sacred animal should become consecrated through the attempt to do so. This is because the verse referring to substitution also uses that phrase: “And if he shall substitute an animal for an animal [<i>behema bivhema</i>], it and its substitute shall be consecrated” (Leviticus 27:10). There too, the phrase “an animal for an animal” translates literally as: An animal in an animal.
<b>Why,</b> then, <b>did we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Temura</i> 10a): <b>One cannot substitute limbs</b> of a non-sacred animal <b>for fetuses</b> of pregnant offerings, i.e., those limbs will not thereby be consecrated; <b>and</b> one <b>cannot</b> substitute <b>fetuses</b> of non-sacred animals <b>for limbs</b> of an offering, <b>and</b> one <b>cannot</b> substitute <b>limbs and fetuses</b> of non-sacred animals <b>for whole</b> offerings, <b>and</b> one <b>cannot</b> substitute <b>whole,</b> non-sacred animals <b>for them,</b> i.e., limbs and fetuses of offerings?
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a fetus and its severed pieces are permitted to be consumed by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal is derived from that which <b>the verse states: “And every animal.”</b> The term “and every” serves <b>to include the offspring,</b> i.e., the fetus, as being permitted, even if parts of it had been severed.
The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> then <b>even</b> if <b>one severs</b> pieces <b>of the spleen or of the kidneys</b> of an animal, those pieces should be permitted <b>as well. Why,</b> then, <b>did we learn</b> in the mishna: If one <b>severed</b> pieces <b>from a fetus that was in</b> its <b>womb,</b> leaving those pieces in the womb, their <b>consumption</b> is <b>permitted</b> by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal, but if one severed pieces <b>of the spleen or of the kidneys</b> of an animal and then slaughtered it their <b>consumption</b> is <b>prohibited?</b> The Gemara explains: That <b>verse states:</b> “Of the animal, <b>it</b> you may eat,” which indicates that slaughter permits consumption of only the <b>whole</b> animal, <b>but not</b> of the parts of the animal that it is <b>lacking,</b> i.e., the parts that were severed.
The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so,</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is derived from the term “and every animal,” then even in the case of <b>one who slaughters an animal and finds a dove-shaped</b> fetus <b>in it, it should be permitted. Why,</b> then, <b>does Rabbi Yoḥanan say: One who slaughters an animal and finds a dove-shaped</b> fetus <b>in it,</b> that fetus is <b>prohibited for consumption?</b>

Daf 69b

The Gemara explains: In order for the fetus to be permitted, <b>I require</b> that it have <b>hooves,</b> and a dove-shaped fetus <b>does not have</b> hooves.
The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so,</b> that the fetus is permitted only if it fulfills the conditions mentioned in that verse, then a fetus with <b>non-cloven</b> hooves found <b>inside a cow’s womb should be forbidden,</b> whereas the <i>baraita</i> cited on 68b states that it is permitted. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is as <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai:</b> Each phrase in the verse is taken as a sufficient condition. Furthermore, the term “hoof” can be understood independently of the phrase “cloven into two hooves,” and is referring to a non-cloven hoof. Accordingly, the verse can be interpreted as teaching: An animal that has <b>a hoof, in the animal,</b> it <b>you may eat,</b> and teaches that even a fetus with a non-cloven hoof is permitted.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: Actually,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the fetus and its severed pieces are permitted <b>should be</b> derived <b>as you</b> previously <b>said,</b> i.e., from the phrase: An animal in the animal. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which posed a difficulty for you,</b> i.e., the mishna in <i>Temura</i> that states <b>one cannot substitute</b> a non-sacred animal for the fetus of a pregnant offering, that difficulty can be resolved by saying: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who compares substitution to</b> the animal <b>tithe: Just as the</b> animal <b>tithe does not apply to limbs and fetuses</b> but only to live animals that can walk, as it is stated: “Whatever passes under the rod” (Leviticus 27:32), <b>so too, substitution does not apply to limbs and fetuses.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do you say</b> that this mishna expresses the opinion of Rabbi Shimon? The Gemara explains: <b>As we learned</b> in the same mishna (<i>Temura</i> 10a) that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: But with regard to consecrated</b> offerings, if <b>one says the leg of this</b> animal <b>is a burnt offering,</b> then <b>all of</b> the animal <b>is</b> consecrated as <b>a burnt offering.</b> Accordingly, <b>even</b> with regard to substitution, if one says: <b>The leg of this</b> non-sacred animal should be substituted <b>instead of that</b> offering, <b>the entire</b> animal <b>should be a substitute in its stead.</b>
Rabbi Yosei clearly disagrees with the opinion that substituting a limb is not possible. But Rabbi Yosei’s formulation indicates that even according to that opinion, if a single limb is consecrated then the entire animal becomes consecrated. The Gemara clarifies: <b>To whom is</b> Rabbi Yosei <b>responding? If we say</b> he is responding <b>to Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda, do they accept this reasoning? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that in the case of <b>one who says: The leg of this</b> animal <b>is a burnt offering, all of it will be a burnt offering.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And if it is an animal of those that they bring as an offering to the Lord, <b>anything of it that one gives to the Lord, it shall be sacred”</b> (Leviticus 27:9). The verse indicates that the part <b>of it</b> that one gives will be <b>sacred, but all of it</b> will <b>not</b> be <b>sacred.</b>
A non-sacred animal with a consecrated limb may not be sacrificed. Accordingly, one <b>might</b> have thought the consecrated limb may be redeemed and thereby <b>transferred to non-sacred</b> status. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “It shall be</b> sacred,” indicating that <b>it shall</b> remain <b>as it is. How</b> is <b>this</b> possible? The animal <b>should be sold for the needs of burnt offerings,</b> i.e., to an individual who will sacrifice the entire animal as a burnt offering, <b>and the payment</b> received <b>for</b> the animal will be <b>non-sacred, except for the payment</b> received in exchange <b>for</b> that one <b>limb</b> that is consecrated. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon say: From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> in the case of <b>one who says: The leg of this</b> animal <b>is a burnt offering, all of it becomes a burnt offering? The verse states: “It shall be</b> sacred.” This serves <b>to include all of</b> the animal, indicating that it all becomes sacred.
The Gemara reiterates its question: <b>To whom is</b> Rabbi Yosei responding? Rabbi Yosei clearly disagrees with the opinion that if a single limb is consecrated then the entire animal becomes consecrated. <b>If we say</b> he is responding <b>to Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda, do they accept this reasoning? Rather, isn’t</b> Rabbi Yosei responding <b>to Rabbi Shimon,</b> as the Gemara suggests above in resolution of the difficulty from the mishna in <i>Temura</i>?
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is possible that Rabbi Yosei is not responding directly to any other opinion; rather, <b>he stated his own reasoning,</b> without reference to that of another Sage. Consequently, his statement affords no proof that the mishna in <i>Temura</i> expresses the opinion of Rabbi Shimon.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Upon its birth, the firstborn male offspring of a domesticated animal is automatically consecrated with firstborn status, and it is prohibited to derive benefit from it. Furthermore, if it dies, it may not be discarded, but must be buried. If <b>an animal that was giving birth to a firstborn male was encountering difficulty giving birth,</b> and in order to alleviate the difficulty one wishes to terminate the birth, <b>he may cut up</b> the fetus <b>limb by limb and cast it to the dogs.</b> Since the fetus was not born, it is non-sacred and does not require burial. If <b>a majority of</b> the fetus <b>had</b> already <b>emerged,</b> it is considered to have been born and is therefore consecrated; consequently, if one cut it up <b>it must be buried, and</b> the mother animal is <b>exempted from</b> having <b>firstborn</b> status conferred on any future offspring.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> An amoraic dispute <b>was stated</b> with regard to a case in which <b>one-third</b> of a firstborn fetus <b>emerged</b> from the womb <b>and</b> then <b>one sold it to a gentile, and then another one-third</b> of the fetus <b>emerged.</b> Once a majority of the fetus emerges it is considered born. The <i>halakha</i> is that a fetus partly owned by a gentile is not consecrated as a firstborn. In this case, the firstborn was sold to a gentile only after it had already partially emerged from the womb. <b>Rav Huna says</b> it is <b>consecrated,</b> while <b>Rabba says</b> it is <b>not consecrated.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rav Huna says</b> it is <b>consecrated,</b> as <b>he maintains</b> a firstborn is <b>consecrated retroactively</b> from the moment the first part of its body emerges from the womb. <b>And</b> therefore in this case, <b>once most of it had emerged,</b> it <b>became clarified retroactively that it had</b> already <b>been consecrated from the outset, and</b> so with regard to <b>that which he had sold</b> to a gentile, it arises that <b>he did not</b> actually <b>sell anything</b> at all. Since it had already been consecrated, he did not have full ownership of it to be able to sell it.
<b>Rabba says</b> it is <b>not consecrated,</b> as he <b>maintains</b> a firstborn is consecrated <b>from that point forward,</b> i.e., only at the moment the majority of it emerges. <b>And</b> so with regard to <b>that which he had sold</b> to a gentile, it arises that <b>he had sold</b> it <b>properly,</b> i.e., the sale was valid because at the time of the sale it had not been consecrated. Accordingly, by the time the majority of its body emerged it was already partly owned by a gentile, and that prevented it from being consecrated.
The Gemara notes: Rav Huna and Rabba <b>follow their</b> lines of <b>reasoning, as</b> another dispute between them <b>was stated</b> with regard to a case in which <b>one-third</b> of a firstborn fetus <b>emerged through</b> the <b>wall</b> of the womb, i.e., via caesarean section, <b>and</b> then the other <b>two-thirds</b> emerged <b>through</b> the opening of the <b>womb.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that a fetus is consecrated only if it emerged through the opening of the womb. In this case a majority did emerge through the opening, but the first majority to emerge was not through the opening. <b>Rav Huna says</b> it is <b>not consecrated</b> and <b>Rabba says</b> it is <b>consecrated.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: When <b>Rav Huna says</b> it is <b>not consecrated Rav Huna</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says</b> a firstborn is <b>consecrated retroactively,</b> since the birth consecrates it. <b>And</b> in this case, <b>the first majority</b> that emerged, which defined its birth, was <b>not through</b> the opening of <b>the womb.</b> Therefore, it was not consecrated. Conversely, when <b>Rabba says</b> it is <b>consecrated Rabba</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he says</b> a firstborn is <b>consecrated from that point forward,</b> i.e., only once a majority of the fetus has emerged from the opening of the womb. This is because the emergence of a majority of the fetus through the opening of the womb consecrates it, even if that is not the first majority, <b>and</b> in this case <b>the majority</b> of the animal <b>emerged through</b> the opening of the <b>womb.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to convey Rav Huna and Rabba’s dispute in both of these cases. <b>As, had</b> the Sages <b>taught us</b> only their dispute <b>with regard to this</b> case, where after one-third emerged it was sold to a gentile, one might have thought that it is only <b>with regard to this</b> case that <b>Rav Huna says</b> the animal is consecrated retroactively. This is <b>because</b> to rule it is consecrated from that point forward <b>would be a leniency,</b> as then the fetus would be exempt from being subject to firstborn status. <b>But with regard to that</b> case, when one-third emerged through the wall of the womb, <b>where</b> Rabba’s opinion would lead to <b>a stringency,</b> one might <b>say</b> that Rav Huna <b>concedes to Rabba.</b>

Daf 70a

<b>And</b> if their dispute <b>was stated</b> only <b>with regard to that</b> case, when one-third emerged through the wall of the womb, one might have thought it is only <b>in that</b> case that <b>Rabba says</b> the animal is consecrated from that point forward, as that results in a stringency, i.e., the fetus is subject to firstborn status. <b>But in this</b> case, when after one-third emerged it was sold to a gentile, and where ruling that the animal is consecrated from that point forward results in a leniency, one might <b>say</b> that Rabba <b>concedes to Rav Huna.</b> Therefore, it was <b>necessary</b> for the dispute to be stated in both cases.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with the opinion of Rav Huna. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>an animal that was giving birth to a firstborn male was encountering difficulty giving birth,</b> and in order to alleviate the difficulty one wishes to terminate the birth, <b>he may cut up</b> the fetus <b>limb by limb and cast it to the dogs. What, is it not</b> teaching that <b>one cuts</b> each limb <b>and leaves</b> it outside the body, casting the limbs to the dogs only after he has already extracted a majority of its body? <b>And if you say</b> a firstborn is <b>consecrated retroactively,</b> then once the majority of the fetus emerges from the womb all of the limbs would be consecrated retroactively according to Rav Huna. Accordingly, the mishna <b>should have</b> said the limbs <b>must be buried.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>No, here we are dealing with one who cuts</b> each limb <b>and</b> immediately <b>casts</b> it to the dogs, before any consecration takes effect.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to this, if <b>one cuts</b> the limbs <b>and leaves</b> them, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Each one <b>must be buried.</b> If that is so, <b>rather than teaching in the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If <b>a majority of</b> the fetus <b>had</b> already <b>emerged</b> it is considered to have been born and duly consecrated, and so if one cut it up <b>it must be buried, and</b> any future offspring from that animal <b>is exempted from firstborn</b> status; <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> instead <b>distinguish and teach</b> a case in which the limbs are consecrated <b>within the</b> context of the first case <b>itself,</b> in the following manner: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that the limbs may be cast to the dogs, <b>said?</b> It is <b>with regard to one who cuts</b> pieces of the fetus <b>and</b> immediately <b>casts</b> them to the dogs <b>limb by limb,</b> before a majority has emerged. <b>But</b> if <b>one cuts and leaves</b> the limbs until a majority has emerged, each one of them <b>must be buried.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>That is indeed what</b> the latter clause of the mishna <b>is saying: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is <b>with regard to one who cuts and casts</b> the limbs to the dogs before a majority emerges. <b>But</b> if <b>one cuts and leaves</b> the limbs until a majority emerges it is <b>regarded as though a majority of it emerged</b> at one time, <b>and</b> so <b>it must be buried.</b>
§ <b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> Does <b>one follow the majority with regard to limbs or</b> does <b>one not follow the majority with regard to limbs?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this dilemma; what exactly is Rava’s question?
<b>If we say</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the <b>majority</b> of the fetus <b>emerged,</b> but that majority <b>includes</b> the emergence of the <b>minority</b> part <b>of</b> one of its <b>limbs,</b> then Rava is <b>raising the</b> following <b>dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>this minority</b> part of a limb <b>that is outside</b> the womb, do <b>we cast it,</b> i.e., count it, together <b>with</b> the <b>majority of</b> that <b>limb,</b> which is still inside the womb, as if the entire limb was still inside the womb? If so, it would be regarded as though a majority of the fetus has not yet emerged. <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>we cast it</b> and count it together <b>with the majority of the fetus</b> that has already emerged, and so it is regarded as though a majority of the fetus has emerged and it is duly consecrated.
The Gemara rejects this possibility: In that case it is <b>obvious that we do not disregard the majority of</b> the <b>fetus and go after the majority of</b> the <b>limb.</b> Consequently, Rava would not have raised a dilemma about this.
<b>Rather,</b> the dilemma is referring to a case <b>where half of</b> the fetus <b>emerged,</b> but that half <b>includes the majority of</b> a certain <b>limb, and</b> Rava <b>raises the</b> following <b>dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>this minority</b> part of a limb <b>that is inside</b> the womb, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as <b>to</b> whether <b>one casts it</b> and counts it together <b>with the majority of</b> that <b>limb</b> and considers it as if that entire limb has emerged? If it is counted, it would be regarded as though a majority of the fetus has emerged, and it is duly consecrated.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from a statement of the mishna: If <b>a majority of</b> the fetus <b>had</b> already <b>emerged,</b> it is considered to have been born and duly consecrated, and so if one cut it up <b>it must be buried.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> is meant by <b>a majority of</b> the fetus? <b>If we say</b> it means <b>literally the majority of</b> the fetus, then the following difficulty arises: <b>Until now had we not learned</b> the principle that <b>the majority</b> of an item is considered <b>like all</b> of <b>it?</b> This is a well-established principle and it is not necessary to teach it again in this context.
<b>Rather, is</b> the mishna <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where half of</b> the fetus <b>emerged,</b> but that half <b>includes the majority of a limb?</b> If so, the mishna directly resolves Rava’s dilemma and teaches that the minority part of the limb inside the womb is regarded as though it had emerged.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the mishna could be referring to a case <b>where</b> the <b>majority of</b> the fetus <b>emerged,</b> but that majority <b>includes</b> the emergence of the <b>minority of a limb, and it teaches us that we do not disregard the majority of</b> the <b>fetus and go after the majority of</b> the <b>limb.</b>
§ A firstborn animal is consecrated by virtue of the fact that its birth is the first in which the womb of the mother opens, as indicated by the verse: “Consecrate to Me every firstborn, that which opens the womb” (Exodus 13:2). Concerning this condition, <b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> If <b>one wrapped</b> the fetus <b>in</b> the <b>bast</b> of a palm tree while it was still in the womb, and it therefore did not come in contact with the opening of the womb directly when it emerged, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to whether it is consecrated? Likewise, if one wrapped it <b>in his robe</b> when it emerged, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Rava adds: If it emerged wrapped <b>in its afterbirth, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara interjects: How could one suggest that being wrapped <b>in its afterbirth</b> would pose a problem? <b>That is its</b> natural <b>manner</b> of birth, and the afterbirth is consequently not considered an interposition. Accordingly, it is considered as though it was in direct contact with the opening of the womb. <b>Rather,</b> Rava’s dilemma must be as follows: If it emerged wrapped <b>in</b> the <b>afterbirth</b> of <b>a different</b> animal, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Another dilemma: If one <b>wrapped it</b> in one’s hands <b>and held it and brought it out</b> in that fashion, such that the fetus did not come in direct contact with the opening of the womb, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? With regard to all these dilemmas the Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> the fetus <b>had</b> already partially <b>emerged headfirst</b> and then one wrapped up the body, which was still inside the womb, the <i>halakha</i> in such a case is clear: Since its head emerged, it is already considered to have been born and to have <b>opened up</b> the womb, and it is duly consecrated. <b>Rather,</b> the dilemma is in a case <b>where it</b> partially <b>emerged hind legs first,</b> and the majority of the body, which was still in the womb, was wrapped before it emerged.
Rava raises additional dilemmas: If <b>a weasel</b> entered the womb and <b>swallowed</b> the fetus there, <b>and</b> then exited the womb, <b>bringing</b> the fetus <b>out</b> in its stomach, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara interjects: Is there any doubt about a case where the weasel <b>brought</b> the fetus <b>out</b> in its stomach? In such a case it is the weasel that <b>brought it out,</b> and it is certainly not regarded as though the fetus opened the womb. <b>Rather,</b> the dilemma concerns a case where the weasel <b>swallowed</b> the fetus <b>and brought it out, and</b> then <b>brought it</b> back <b>into</b> the womb <b>and vomited it</b> out while inside the womb, <b>and</b> the fetus subsequently <b>emerged of its own accord. What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this case?
Another dilemma: If <b>one pressed together</b> the openings of <b>two wombs</b> of two animals giving birth to firstborns, <b>and</b> a fetus <b>exited from</b> the womb of <b>this</b> animal <b>and entered</b> the womb of <b>that</b> animal, and then emerged from the womb of the second animal, after which the second animal gave birth to its fetus, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to whether the fetus of the second animal is consecrated as a firstborn? Is the womb considered to have <b>opened</b> only when <b>its own</b> fetus emerges from inside, but a fetus <b>that is not its own</b> is <b>not</b> halakhically considered to have <b>opened</b> the womb? <b>Or perhaps</b> even a fetus <b>that is not its own</b> is <b>also</b> considered to have <b>opened</b> the womb? The Gemara does not provide a resolution for these dilemmas and concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Aḥa raises a dilemma:</b> If <b>the walls of the</b> opening of the <b>womb opened</b> and widened to such an extent that when the fetus emerged it did not touch them, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does the <b>airspace</b> of the opening of the <b>womb consecrate</b> the fetus as it is born, <b>and</b> this situation <b>exists</b> here in this case; <b>or perhaps</b> it is the <b>contact with</b> the opening of the <b>womb</b> that <b>consecrates it, and</b> this situation <b>does not exist</b> here in this case?
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi raises a dilemma:</b> If <b>the walls of the</b> opening of the <b>womb were removed, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara interjects: The <i>halakha</i> in this case is clear, since if <b>they were removed they are not</b> there to consecrate the fetus. <b>Rather,</b> the dilemma is in a case where <b>they were removed</b> from their original place, recessed inside the womb, <b>and</b> as the fetus emerged, the walls <b>lay on its neck.</b> In such a case, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do the walls of the opening of the womb <b>consecrate</b> a fetus only <b>when they are in their</b> natural <b>place,</b> but <b>when they are not in their</b> natural <b>place they cannot consecrate</b> a fetus? <b>Or perhaps when they are not in their</b> natural <b>place they also consecrate</b> the fetus.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma before Rabbi Zeira:</b> If <b>the walls of the opening of the womb were thinned [<i>nigmemu</i>]</b> by removing the inner layer, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If the fetus then emerges through them is it consecrated? Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: You have touched upon a dilemma that was</b> already <b>raised before us,</b> and that discussion provides the answer to your dilemma. <b>As Rabbi Zeira raised a dilemma, and some say Rabbi Zeira raised</b> that <b>dilemma before Rabbi Asi:</b> If a section of the opening of the womb was cut away, but the <b>standing</b> section, i.e., the part remaining, <b>is greater</b> in size <b>than the breached,</b> removed, section, <b>and</b> the offspring <b>emerged through the breached</b> section; or if the <b>breached</b> section <b>is greater</b> in size <b>than the standing</b> section <b>and</b> the offspring <b>emerged through</b> the <b>standing</b> section, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Rabbi Zeira explains how this dilemma can resolve Rabbi Yirmeya’s dilemma: That <b>dilemma was raised only with regard to</b> a case where the <b>breached</b> section <b>is greater than the standing</b> section, <b>as there is</b> at least some part of the womb still <b>standing</b> and therefore one can consider the possibility that it could consecrate the fetus. <b>But a dilemma was not raised with regard to</b> case where the walls <b>were thinned,</b> because in that case it is obvious that the fetus is not consecrated, as there is nothing left to consecrate it.

Daf 70b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>an animal whose fetus died in its womb and the shepherd reached his hand</b> into the womb <b>and touched</b> the fetus, <b>both in</b> the case of <b>a non-kosher animal and in</b> the case of <b>a kosher animal</b> the fetus does not have the status of an animal carcass that imparts ritual impurity, and the shepherd remains <b>ritually pure. Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: In</b> the case of <b>a non-kosher</b> animal it is <b>impure, and in</b> the case of <b>a kosher</b> animal it is <b>pure.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the ruling <b>of the first <i>tanna</i>? Rav Ḥisda said:</b> It is apparent through <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If</b> being inside <b>its mother is effective to permit it for consumption</b> through the slaughter of its mother even if the fetus was found dead inside the womb, then <b>should</b> being inside its mother <b>not</b> also <b>be effective to render it pure from</b> the impurity of <b>an animal carcass?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a rationale for this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a kosher animal; from where do we</b> derive that the same applies to <b>a non-kosher animal?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states:</b> “And when a domesticated animal dies, of those that you eat, one who touches its carcass shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39). The Gemara interprets the verse as follows: <b>“And when a domesticated animal dies,” this</b> is referring to <b>a non-kosher animal; “of those that you eat,” this</b> is referring to <b>a kosher animal.</b> The verse thereby <b>juxtaposes a non-kosher animal to a kosher animal</b> with regard to imparting impurity of a carcass, and teaches that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>a kosher animal, its fetus</b> that died in its womb is <b>pure,</b> as derived above through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>a non-kosher animal, its</b> dead <b>fetus</b> is <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, what is the reason</b> for his ruling? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said that the verse states</b> with regard to non-kosher animals that do not have cloven hooves: <b>“And whatever walks on its paws, among any [<i>bekhol</i>] undomesticated animal [<i>ḥayya</i>] that walks</b> on all fours, they are impure for you; whoever touches their carcass shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:27). Rabbi Yosei HaGelili expounds this verse as follows: Those animals <b>that walk on</b> their <b>paws,</b> i.e., that do not have cloven hooves, which are <b>inside</b> the body of <b>an animal, I rendered impure for you.</b> Rabbi Yitzḥak interprets the term <i>bekhol</i> as meaning: Inside the body of, and the word <i>ḥayya</i> as meaning: A live animal. Accordingly, he understands the verse to be referring to a dead fetus found inside a living animal.
The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so,</b> then a dead fetus with <b>non-cloven</b> hooves found <b>inside a cow should be impure,</b> despite the fact that it is from a kosher species, <b>as it is</b> an animal that <b>walks on</b> its <b>paws</b> that is <b>inside</b> the body of a kosher <b>animal.</b> The Gemara explains: The verse renders impure an animal that <b>walks upon</b> its four <b>paws</b> that is <b>inside</b> an animal <b>that walks</b> on <b>four</b> paws. <b>But this is</b> a case of an animal that <b>walks</b> on <b>four inside</b> an animal that <b>walks on eight.</b> Since the mother cow’s hooves are entirely split into two parts, it actually walks on eight parts and is not the animal referred to by the verse.
The Gemara raises another objection: If that is so, then a dead fetus in the form of <b>a cow,</b> which has eight parts to its legs, <b>inside the womb of a camel,</b> a non-kosher animal with non-cloven hooves, <b>should not be impure, as it is</b> an animal that <b>walks on eight inside</b> an animal that <b>walks on four,</b> and the verse is not referring to it. The Gemara responds that the verse could have stated: <b>Walks upon,</b> but instead states: <b>“And whatever walks upon,”</b> i.e., the addition of the word “whatever” serves <b>to include</b> a dead <b>cow</b> fetus <b>in the womb of a camel,</b> teaching that it is impure.
The Gemara objects: If that is so, then a dead fetus with <b>non-cloven</b> hooves <b>inside the womb of</b> a cow with <b>non-cloven</b> hooves should <b>be impure, as it is</b> an animal that <b>walks on four inside</b> an animal that <b>walks on four,</b> but the <i>halakha</i> is that since the mother is a kosher species, it is pure. The Gemara explains: It is <b>to that</b> end that the <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference of <b>Rav Ḥisda is effective,</b> as it renders pure the fetuses of all kosher animals, even if their hooves are not fully cloven.
<b>Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami objects to this</b> explanation that the verse renders impure only animals that walk on four inside animals that walk on four: If that is so, a dead <b>pig</b> fetus <b>inside the womb of a female pig should not be impure, as</b> a pig has cloven hooves, and so <b>it is</b> an animal that <b>walks on eight inside</b> an animal that <b>walks on eight,</b> and so the verse is not referring to it.
<b>Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that Rabbi Yosei HaGelili’s opinion is derived <b>from here:</b> The verse states with regard to the sliding-scale offering brought by one who was unaware that he was impure when he ate consecrated food or entered the Temple: <b>“A person who touched anything impure, or the carcass of a non-kosher undomesticated animal, or the carcass of a non-kosher domesticated animal, or the carcass of an impure creeping animal,</b> and is guilty, it having being hidden from him that he is impure” (Leviticus 5:2).
The verse presents a difficulty: <b>Does</b> only <b>a carcass of a non-kosher animal impart impurity, and</b> that <b>of a kosher</b> animal <b>not impart impurity?</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that both do. <b>Rather, what is this</b> animal to which the verse is referring? <b>This is a fetus, which</b> if <b>inside a non-kosher</b> animal is <b>impure, and</b> if <b>inside a kosher</b> animal is <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And since</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from</b> the statement of <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak, why do I</b> need the proof <b>of Rabbi Yitzḥak</b> from the verse: “And whatever walks on its paws, among any undomesticated animal that walks on all fours” (Leviticus 11:27)? The Gemara explains: <b>Were it not</b> for the derivation of <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak, I would say</b> that <b>the entire</b> verse expounded by Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <b>comes to</b> teach only <b>that which Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi derived from it, as cited by the Gemara later on. Rabbi Yitzḥak’s statement <b>teaches us</b> that the verse is also to be expounded as Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak explained.
§ It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan,</b> a student of Rabbi Yishmael, <b>says: I said [<i>namti</i>] to ben Azzai: We learned that a carcass of a kosher domesticated animal imparts impurity</b> from the verse: “And when a domesticated animal dies, of those that you eat, one who touches its carcass shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39). <b>And</b> we learned that <b>a carcass of a non-kosher domesticated animal imparts impurity,</b> and <b>that a carcass of a non-kosher undomesticated animal imparts impurity,</b> from the verse: “A person who touched anything impure, or the carcass of a non-kosher undomesticated animal, or the carcass of a non-kosher domesticated animal” (Leviticus 5:2).
But <b>we did not</b> yet <b>learn</b> about <b>a carcass of a kosher undomesticated animal. From where</b> is it derived that it imparts impurity? Ben Azzai <b>said to me</b> that this is derived from the verse: “And <b>whatever walks on its paws, among any undomesticated animal that walks</b> on all fours” (Leviticus 11:27). The inclusive term “among any” serves to include even a carcass of a kosher undomesticated animal among those that impart impurity.
Rabbi Yonatan continues. <b>I said to</b> ben Azzai: <b>But does it state: And any undomesticated animal? Isn’t it stated only: “Among any undomesticated animal”?</b> And as explained earlier, this <b>comes to</b> teach <b>that</b> a dead fetus in the form of any of the animals that <b>walk on</b> their <b>paws inside an undomesticated animal imparts impurity. He said to me: And what does</b> Rabbi <b>Yishmael,</b> your teacher, <b>say about this matter?</b>
<b>I said to him</b> that Rabbi Yishmael derives all these <i>halakhot</i> from the verse: “And when a domesticated animal dies, of those that you eat, one who touches its carcass shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39), as follows: <b>“And when a domesticated animal [<i>habehema</i>] dies,” this</b> is referring to <b>a non-kosher animal; “of those that you eat,” this</b> is referring to <b>a kosher animal.</b> And <b>we learned</b> that <b>a <i>ḥayya</i> is included</b> in the category of <b>a <i>behema</i>,</b> i.e., the term <i>behema</i> can also refer collectively to both domesticated and undomesticated animals. <b>And</b> likewise, <b>a <i>behema</i> is included</b> in the category of <b>a <i>ḥayya</i>.</b>
Furthermore, <b>a kosher <i>ḥayya</i> is included</b> when the Torah makes reference to <b>a kosher <i>behema</i>,</b> and <b>a non-kosher <i>ḥayya</i> is included</b> when the Torah makes reference to <b>a non-kosher <i>behema</i>.</b>

Daf 71a

And likewise, <b>a non-kosher <i>behema</i> is included</b> in the category of <b>a non-kosher <i>ḥayya</i>,</b> and <b>a kosher <i>behema</i> is included</b> in the category of <b>a kosher <i>ḥayya</i>.</b> Accordingly, although the verse here is referring to a <i>behema</i>, it is understood to be referring collectively to both a <i>behema</i> and a <i>ḥayya</i>, and teaches that the carcasses of both types impart impurity. <b>And</b> upon hearing this, ben Azzai <b>said to me in these words: Woe [<i>ḥaval</i>] unto ben Azzai, who did not serve Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
The Gemara analyzes Rabbi Yishmael’s statement: <b>From where do we</b> derive that according to the Torah, <b>a <i>ḥayya</i> is included</b> in the category of <b>a <i>behema</i>? As it is written: “These are the <i>behema</i> that you may eat: An ox, a sheep,</b> and a goat, <b>a deer, and a gazelle, and a fallow deer,</b> and a wild goat, and an oryx, and an aurochs, and a wild sheep” (Deuteronomy 14:4–5). Despite employing the term “<i>behema</i>,” the verse also lists the deer and the gazelle, which are undomesticated animals. <b>How</b> is <b>this</b> possible? From here it is evident that <b>a <i>ḥayya</i> is included</b> by the Torah in the category of <b>a <i>behema</i>.</b>
<b>From where do we</b> derive that according to the Torah, <b>a <i>behema</i> is included</b> in the category of <b>a <i>ḥayya</i>? As it is written: “These are the <i>ḥayya</i> that you may eat, among all the <i>behema</i> that are on the earth. Whatever parts the hoof”</b> (Leviticus 11:2–3). <b>How</b> is <b>this</b> possible, that the verse mentions a <i>ḥayya</i> and then refers to a <i>behema</i>? This indicates that <b>a domesticated animal is included</b> in the category of <b>a <i>ḥayya</i></b> by the Torah.
The Gemara further clarifies: The principle that <b>a kosher <i>ḥayya</i> is included</b> by the Torah in the category of <b>a kosher <i>behema</i></b> is relevant <b>with regard to</b> the <b>distinguishing characteristics</b> of kosher animals. The Torah states with regard to a domesticated animal that only a species that chews its cud and has cloven hooves is kosher. Nevertheless, this requirement is understood as a reference to both domesticated and undomesticated animals.
The principle that <b>a non-kosher <i>ḥayya</i> is included</b> by the Torah in the category of <b>a non-kosher <i>behema</i></b> is relevant <b>with regard to</b> the prohibition against <b>mating</b> one species with another. The Torah states the prohibition with regard to a <i>behema</i>: “You shall not let your animal [<i>behema</i>] mate with a diverse kind” (Leviticus 19:19). Nevertheless, this is understood as referring to both a <i>behema</i> and a <i>ḥayya</i>.
The principle that <b>a non-kosher <i>behema</i> is included</b> by the Torah in the category of <b>a non-kosher <i>ḥayya</i></b> is relevant <b>with regard to that which Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi taught, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse delineates a case in which one is obligated to bring a sliding-scale offering as an atonement: “A person who touched anything impure, or the carcass of a non-kosher undomesticated animal [<i>ḥayya</i>], or the carcass of a non-kosher domesticated animal [<i>behema</i>], or the carcass of an impure creeping animal, and is guilty, it having being hidden from him that he is impure” (Leviticus 5:2). But the nature of the transgression for which the person requires atonement is not apparent from the verse.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> Since a domesticated animal is also referred to as a <i>ḥayya</i>, it would be sufficient if <b>I would read,</b> i.e., the verse would write, only the clause about <b>a <i>ḥayya</i>,</b> and I would have known that one who touches a carcass of any non-kosher animal is impure. <b>Why,</b> then, <b>is</b> an explicit clause about <b>a <i>behema</i> stated?</b> It serves as the basis for a verbal analogy.
<b>It is stated here,</b> with regard to one who is unaware that he touched an impure item: <b>“Non-kosher <i>behema</i>,” and it is</b> likewise <b>stated below,</b> with regard to one who was aware that he touched an impure item: <b>“Non-kosher <i>behema</i>,”</b> in the following verse: “And when any one shall touch any impure thing, whether it is the impurity of man, or a non-kosher <i>behema</i>, and then eats of the flesh of a peace offering to the Lord, that soul shall be cut off from its people” (Leviticus 7:21). <b>Just as below,</b> the verse is referring to the <b>defiling of sacrificial</b> foods, <b>so too here,</b> the reference is to the <b>defiling of sacrificial</b> foods, and therefore one must bring a sliding-scale offering as an atonement.
The Gemara clarifies the final statement: The principle that <b>a kosher <i>behema</i> is included</b> by the Torah in the category of <b>a kosher <i>ḥayya</i></b> is relevant <b>with regard to</b> the <b>formation</b> of children. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nidda</i> 21a): With regard to a woman <b>who miscarries</b> a fetus that appears to be in the form of <b>a type of <i>behema</i>, <i>ḥayya</i>, or bird, whether</b> it had the form of <b>a non-kosher</b> species <b>or a kosher</b> species, <b>if</b> the fetus is <b>a male,</b> then <b>she observes</b> the periods of impurity and purity required <b>for</b> giving birth to <b>a male.</b>
The mishna continues: And <b>if</b> the fetus is <b>a female,</b> then <b>she observes</b> the periods required <b>for</b> giving birth to <b>a female.</b> After giving birth to a male, a woman is impure for seven days, during which it is prohibited for her to engage in intercourse. During the next thirty-three days she may immerse in a ritual bath at any time, after which she is permitted to engage in intercourse even should she then experience a discharge of uterine blood. Nevertheless, during the entire forty-day period she may not enter the Temple or be in contact with consecrated foods. After giving birth to a girl, the length of each of these periods is doubled to fourteen days and sixty-six days, respectively (see Leviticus 12:2–5).
If the sex of the fetus is <b>unknown, she observes</b> the strictures of a woman who gave birth both <b>to a male and to a female.</b> Accordingly, it is prohibited for her to engage in intercourse for the fourteen days after birth, after which she immerses in a ritual bath. After that she is permitted to engage in intercourse despite any discharge of uterine blood until the fortieth day after birth, i.e., for thirty-three days following the seven days she would have been prohibited from engaging in intercourse if the fetus was male. The prohibition against entering the Temple, however, continues until eighty days have passed from the birth.
This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> The Gemara elsewhere (<i>Nidda</i> 22b) explains that Rabbi Meir derives his opinion from the fact that the term “formation” is used to describe both the formation of man: “Then the Lord God formed man” (Genesis 2:7), and the formation of animals and birds: “The Lord God formed every animal [<i>ḥayya</i>] of the field, and every bird of the air” (Genesis 2:19). Furthermore, he holds that the term “<i>ḥayya</i>” is referring to both domesticated and undomesticated animals, and concludes that a woman observes these periods of purity and impurity if the fetus has the form of any of these types of animals.
<b>And the Rabbis say: Any</b> fetus <b>that is not of human form is not</b> regarded as <b>an offspring</b> with regard to observance of these periods of purity and impurity, and she is permitted to engage in intercourse provided she does not experience a discharge of uterine blood.
§ The Gemara returns to explaining the opinion of the Rabbis, cited in the mishna, who hold that a dead fetus found inside its mother’s womb does not impart impurity, irrespective of whether it is of a kosher or a non-kosher animal. Rabbi Yosei HaGelili disagrees and holds that a dead fetus inside a non-kosher animal imparts impurity. He derives this from the verse: “A person who touched anything impure, or the carcass of a non-kosher <i>ḥayya</i>, or the carcass of a non-kosher <i>behema</i>, or the carcass of an impure creeping animal, and is guilty” (Leviticus 5:2), which is referring only to non-kosher animals. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to the Rabbis, why do I</b> need <b>this verse?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>The entire</b> verse <b>comes to</b> teach <b>that which Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi taught in the <i>baraita</i> cited earlier, that the verse obligates one to bring a sliding-scale offering only in cases where one partook of consecrated foods or entered the Temple while in a state of impurity of which one was unaware.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a woman whose fetus died in her womb and</b> the <b>midwife extended her hand</b> into the womb <b>and touched</b> the fetus, <b>the midwife is</b> thereby rendered <b>impure with the seven-</b>day <b>impurity</b> imparted by a corpse, <b>and the woman</b> remains <b>ritually pure until the offspring emerges</b> from the womb.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabba says: Just as</b> a ritually <b>impure</b> item that is <b>encapsulated</b> within a body <b>does not impart impurity</b> to an item that comes in contact with it, <b>so too,</b> a ritually <b>pure</b> item that is <b>encapsulated</b> within a body <b>cannot be rendered impure</b> if it comes in contact with an impure item. For example, if one swallowed a ring that was ritually pure and then entered a tent containing a corpse, the ring would not be rendered impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>an encapsulated impure</b> item does not impart impurity? <b>As it is written: “And one who eats of its carcass shall wash his clothes,</b> and be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:40), i.e., he must immerse his body and garments in a ritual bath, and he then becomes pure at sunset. <b>Are we not dealing</b> even with a case <b>where one ate</b> from the carcass <b>close to sunset</b> and then immersed? <b>And</b> yet <b>the Merciful One states</b> that he is <b>pure</b> once the sun sets, despite the fact that his stomach still contains pieces of the carcass that have not yet been digested. If so, it is apparent that an encapsulated impure item does not impart impurity.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But perhaps</b> it <b>is different there,</b> as with regard to the prohibition against eating a carcass the Torah states: “You shall not eat any carcass; you may give it to the gentile resident who is in your cities” (Deuteronomy 14:21). The juxtaposition of the two parts of the verse teaches that the prohibition is limited to a carcass that is fit to be given to a gentile resident, i.e., it is fit for human consumption. Accordingly, perhaps the carcass that the person ate does not impart impurity, <b>as it is no</b> longer <b>fit for a gentile resident,</b> i.e., it is now unsuitable for human consumption.
The Gemara comments that the effectiveness of the proof depends on whether a carcass can impart impurity to a person despite its not being fit for human consumption: <b>This</b> proof <b>works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who says:</b> A carcass imparts impurity to <b>both this,</b> a person, <b>and that,</b> food, even if it is unfit for human consumption, <b>until</b> it is no longer fit <b>for</b> consumption by <b>a dog.</b> According to this opinion the proof is understood <b>well,</b> as the carcass in the person’s stomach still has the ability to impart impurity to him because it is still fit for consumption by a dog. Therefore, it is apparent that the only reason it does not impart impurity is that it is encapsulated within his body.
<b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>bar Padda, who says</b> a carcass has the <b>severe form of ritual impurity,</b> which can impart impurity to people only while it is still fit to be eaten <b>by a gentile resident and</b> it has <b>the light form of ritual impurity</b> even <b>until</b> the point that it is no longer fit for consumption <b>by a dog,</b> this proof is flawed. This is because it is possible the carcass in the person’s stomach does not render him impure simply because it is no longer fit for human consumption. Can one claim that the carcass cannot impart impurity <b>because it is no</b> longer <b>fit for a gentile resident?</b>
<b>Granted that</b> the carcass <b>is not fit</b> to be eaten by someone when it was eaten <b>in his presence,</b> as he is aware that it was swallowed and considers it disgusting to eat a swallowed item, but <b>it is</b> still sometimes <b>fit</b> for a person to eat when it was eaten <b>not in his presence</b> and he is unaware that it had been previously swallowed. This is possible where one consumed a small piece of food and did not chew it prior to swallowing. The Gemara concedes this point and therefore accepts the proof.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>an encapsulated impure</b> item does not impart impurity. <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>a pure</b> item that is <b>encapsulated</b> within another body <b>cannot be rendered impure</b> if it comes in contact with an impure item?
The Gemara explains: It is derived through <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If an earthenware vessel that is closed with a tightly sealed cover, which does not shield,</b> i.e., prevent, the <b>impure</b> piece of a corpse <b>contained within it from imparting impurity</b> to other items in the same tent as it; the Gemara interrupts the explication of the inference and clarifies: <b>As the Master said:</b> The <b>impure</b> piece of a corpse that is <b>in a tight space;</b> e.g., it is buried in the ground and there is not a handbreadth of hollow space above it, beneath the dirt, <b>breaks through</b> the earth above it <b>and ascends up to the heavens,</b> imparting impurity in that path. The Gemara resumes the explication of the inference: Although the tightly sealed earthenware vessel does not shield the impure item, it <b>does shield a pure</b> item <b>contained within it from being rendered impure</b> (see Numbers 19:15).

Daf 71b

Then with regard to <b>a person, who does shield</b> the <b>impurity</b> of a piece of a corpse <b>contained within him from imparting impurity</b> to other items in the same tent, as the Gemara derived above, <b>is it not logical that he shields a pure</b> item <b>contained within him from being rendered impure?</b>
The Gemara challenges the inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about an earthenware vessel?</b> It is notable <b>in that it cannot become impure through</b> a source of impurity coming in contact with <b>its exterior. Can you say,</b> then, that it is comparable <b>to a person, who can become impure through</b> a source of impurity coming in contact with <b>his exterior?</b> Since here the <i>halakhot</i> concerning impurity of a person are more stringent than those concerning an earthenware vessel, one cannot apply to a person a leniency with regard to an earthenware vessel.
The Gemara responds: <b>Is that to say we are speaking of</b> rendering an item impure through a source of impurity coming in contact with <b>its exterior? We are</b> in fact <b>speaking of</b> where the impurity comes in contact with <b>its interior.</b> For such cases, it is reasonable to compare the case of a person with an earthenware vessel.
The Gemara adds: <b>On the contrary,</b> the contraction of impurity by <b>an earthenware vessel is more stringent</b> than that of a person, <b>as</b> it <b>becomes impure through</b> the presence of a source of impurity in <b>its airspace,</b> even if the source does not touch the vessel itself. By contrast, a person is rendered impure from a source of impurity in his airspace, e.g., in his mouth, only if it actually touches him, and the <i>a fortiori</i> inference remains valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that an impure item <b>encapsulated</b> in a body that entered it <b>from above,</b> i.e., through the mouth, does not impart impurity. <b>From where do we</b> derive that an impure item <b>encapsulated</b> in a body that entered it <b>from below,</b> i.e., through the rectum, also does not impart impurity? The Gemara answers: It is derived through <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And if,</b> when the impure item enters <b>from above,</b> through the mouth, <b>which</b> is a place that <b>does not digest</b> the food, the body nevertheless <b>shields</b> the impure item from imparting impurity, then <b>with regard to</b> a case where the impure item enters <b>from below, which</b> is a place that <b>does digest</b> food, <b>is it not logical that</b> the body should <b>shield</b> it from imparting impurity?
The Gemara challenges the basis of the inference: <b>Isn’t digestion performed below only by means of</b> the chewing and digestive functions of the body <b>above?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Even so,</b> the <b>digestion</b> performed <b>below is greater</b> than that performed above.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that an impure item <b>encapsulated</b> in the body <b>of a person</b> does not impart impurity; <b>from where do we</b> derive that an impure item <b>encapsulated</b> in the body <b>of an animal</b> does not impart impurity? The Gemara answers: It is derived through <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If</b> the body of <b>a person, who can impart impurity</b> even <b>while he is</b> still <b>alive,</b> e.g., if he is a leper or a <i>zav</i>, nevertheless <b>shields</b> the impure item <b>encapsulated</b> inside him from imparting impurity, then with regard to <b>an animal, which does not impart impurity while it is alive, is it not logical that it should shield</b> an impure item <b>encapsulated</b> inside it from imparting impurity?
The Gemara challenges the inference: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the impurity of <b>a person?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> if he entered a leprous house, in order for his garment to be rendered impure <b>he needs to remain in</b> the <b>leprous house</b> for a minimal period of time (see Leviticus 14:33–53). <b>Can you say,</b> then, that it is comparable <b>to an animal, which does not need to remain in a leprous house</b> for a minimal period of time? Rather, any utensils placed upon it are rendered impure immediately upon its entry. Since here the <i>halakhot</i> concerning impurity of an animal are more stringent than those concerning a person, one cannot necessarily apply to an animal a leniency with regard to a person.
The Gemara responds: When it is stated about <b>an animal that it does not need to remain in a leprous house</b> for a minimal period of time, <b>with regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> was that said? A living animal itself cannot be impure. Perforce, the statement is referring <b>to utensils that are</b> placed <b>upon its back,</b> and they are rendered impure immediately upon entry. But in this regard there is no difference between animals and people: <b>A person as well does not need</b> to remain in the leprous house for a minimal period of time in order to render impure any utensils placed on his back. Rather, they are rendered impure immediately upon entry.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 13:9): With regard to <b>one who enters a leprous house with his clothes</b> resting <b>on his shoulders</b> but who is not wearing them in the normal manner, <b>and his sandals and his rings</b> are <b>in his hands,</b> both <b>he and they,</b> the clothes, sandals, and rings, are rendered <b>ritually impure immediately.</b> If <b>he was dressed in his clothes, and his sandals</b> were <b>on his feet and his rings</b> were <b>on his fingers, he</b> is rendered <b>impure immediately</b> upon entering the house, <b>but they,</b> the clothes, sandals, and rings, remain <b>pure until he remains</b> in the house <b>for</b> the time it takes <b>to eat a half-loaf</b> of bread. This calculation is made with <b>wheat bread and not</b> with <b>barley bread,</b> which takes more time to eat than wheat bread. In addition, the calculation is made with regard to one who is <b>reclining, and eating</b> the bread together <b>with a relish</b> usually consumed with bread, which hastens the eating.
§ Rabba stated above that an encapsulated impure item cannot impart impurity and that an item that is ritually pure that is encapsulated within another body cannot be rendered impure. <b>Rava said:</b> Why is this statement necessary? <b>We learn both</b> <i>halakhot</i> in a mishna: <b>We learn</b> about <b>an encapsulated impure</b> item, and <b>we learn</b> about <b>an encapsulated pure</b> item.
Rava elaborates: With regard to <b>an encapsulated impure</b> item, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>as we learned</b> (<i>Mikvaot</i> 10:8): If someone <b>swallowed a ring</b> that was <b>impure</b> due to having been in contact with a corpse, he is thereby rendered impure. To render himself pure <b>he immerses and</b> then <b>he may partake of his <i>teruma</i>,</b> despite the fact that the impure ring is still inside him. The reason this is permitted is that since the ring in encapsulated inside the person’s body it cannot impart impurity. If <b>he vomited</b> out this ring it remains <b>impure,</b> as it was not purified by his immersion, <b>and</b> therefore <b>it renders him impure</b> upon its exit from his body.
Likewise, <b>we learn</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>an encapsulated pure</b> item cannot be rendered impure, <b>as we learn</b> in the same mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 10:8): If one <b>swallowed a ritually pure ring and</b> then <b>entered a tent containing a corpse,</b> thereby contracting impurity, <b>and</b> then in order to render him pure someone <b>sprinkled</b> upon him the water that is mixed with the ashes of the red heifer, once on the third day <b>and again</b> on the seventh day as required, <b>and</b> then <b>he immersed,</b> thereby completing the purification process; <b>and</b> then <b>he vomited</b> out the ring, the ring <b>is</b> pure <b>as it</b> always <b>was,</b> i.e., it was not rendered impure from the corpse.
The Gemara answers: The cases in the mishna concern the possibility of imparting impurity from the ring to the body within which it is contained and vice versa. But <b>when Rabba was speaking</b> he was referring to imparting impurity from one item to another where both are contained together inside a body, <b>such as where</b> a person <b>swallowed two rings, one impure and one pure,</b> and they came in direct contact with one another. Rabba taught that even in this case the <b>impure</b> ring <b>does not render the pure</b> ring <b>impure.</b>

Daf 72a

The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> what about the mishna’s case of a dead <b>fetus</b> in its mother’s womb, <b>and a midwife</b> who touched it there, <b>which is similar</b> to the case of <b>two</b> swallowed <b>rings, and</b> yet the mishna rules that the <b>fetus renders</b> the midwife <b>impure.</b>
<b>Rabba said: A fetus is different</b> from a ring in this regard, <b>since it will ultimately leave</b> the womb. <b>Rava said</b> in puzzlement: Is that to say that <b>a fetus will ultimately leave</b> the womb, but <b>a ring</b> that someone swallowed <b>will not ultimately leave</b> his body? A ring will certainly be expelled eventually as well. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The scholars <b>of Pumbedita know the reason for this matter, and who</b> is the Sage referred to as the scholars of Pumbedita? It is <b>Rav Yosef.</b>
<b>As Rav Yosef says</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: This impurity</b> of the midwife in the mishna’s case <b>is not</b> in effect <b>by Torah law; rather,</b> it was decreed <b>by rabbinic law.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> was Shmuel’s intention in emphasizing: <b>It is not</b> in effect <b>by Torah law; rather,</b> it was decreed <b>by rabbinic law?</b> It should have sufficed for him to say simply the impurity is decreed by rabbinic law. The Gemara answers: He said this so <b>that you should not say</b> that the ruling of the mishna is only <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that one who touches a dead <b>fetus in a woman’s womb is impure</b> by Torah law, and that is why the midwife was rendered impure. <b>Rather, even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, who says</b> that one who touches a dead <b>fetus in a woman’s womb is pure</b> by Torah law, nevertheless, the Sages <b>decreed</b> that a midwife who touches it is <b>impure by rabbinic law.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this decree? <b>Rav Hoshaya said:</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> the <b>fetus extend its head out of the concealed opening</b> of its mother’s womb. If it did, it would be regarded as having been born, and it would then be ritually impure by Torah law. The Sages were concerned that the fetus extended its head and then the head returned inside but the midwife did not notice. Consequently, when she touched the fetus she mistakenly assumed she remained ritually pure. To safeguard against this, the Sages decreed that in any case where she touches the dead fetus, she is ritually impure.
The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> the Sages should <b>also</b> decree that the <b>woman</b> herself, who is carrying the fetus, is impure, since she also might not notice that the fetus’s head emerged. The Gemara explains: <b>A woman</b> accurately <b>senses with regard to her own</b> body whether the head of the fetus had emerged. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> then <b>she would have said</b> this <b>to the midwife.</b> Why is there a need for a decree? The Gemara answers: Since the mother is <b>distracted</b> by the pain of childbirth, she does not have the presence of mind to warn the midwife.
The Gemara cited a dispute as to whether one who touches a dead fetus in a woman’s womb is ritually impure. It now elucidates that dispute: <b>What</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, and what</b> is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“And whoever in the open field touches</b> one who is slain by the sword, or one who dies on his own, or a bone of a man, or a grave, shall be impure seven days” (Numbers 19:16). The phrase “in the open field” indicates that one is rendered impure only in a case where he touches an exposed corpse. This serves <b>to exclude</b> one who touches a dead <b>fetus in a woman’s womb</b> from being rendered impure; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> This phrase serves <b>to include the grave cover and the grave walls,</b> upon which the cover rests, as sources of impurity that render impure anyone who touches them.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> from where does <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> derive that <b>the grave cover and the grave walls</b> render one who touches them impure? He <b>learned this <i>halakha</i> through tradition,</b> not from a verse. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Akiva, from where</b> does <b>he</b> derive that a dead <b>fetus in a woman’s womb is impure by Torah law? Rabbi Oshaya said</b> he derives it from <b>the verse</b> that <b>states: “Whoever touches of a corpse, of the life</b> of a person that died, he will be impure” (Numbers 19:13). The term “of the life” can also be interpreted as: Inside the life. <b>What is</b> the case of <b>a corpse that is inside the life of a person? You must say</b> that <b>this is</b> a dead <b>fetus inside a woman’s womb.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And Rabbi Yishmael requires</b> that verse <b>to</b> teach about <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>of blood that comes from a corpse,</b> meaning <b>that</b> even <b>it imparts impurity</b> like a corpse, <b>as it is stated: “Whoever touches of a corpse, of the life of a person</b> that died” (Numbers 19:13). <b>What is</b> the case of <b>a life of a person that imparts impurity? You must say this</b> is referring to <b>a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> <b>of blood,</b> as blood is regarded as the life force of a person, as the verse states: “For the blood is the life” (Deuteronomy 12:23), and a person requires a minimum of a quarter-<i>log</i> of blood to survive.
The Gemara comments: <b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> does not accept this derivation. He conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as he says even a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> <b>of blood that comes from two corpses imparts ritual impurity in a tent</b> to people and other items that are under the same roof. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>of blood that came out of two</b> separate <b>corpses</b> also <b>imparts ritual impurity in a tent?</b>
It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to the prohibition against priests coming in contact with a dead body: <b>“He shall not come upon any people that are a corpse [<i>nafshot met</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 21:11). The use of the plural form “people [<i>nafshot</i>]” indicates that the blood imparts impurity even if it comes from <b>two people,</b> as blood is referred to as “<i>nefesh</i>” (see Deuteronomy 12:23), and the use of the singular form “corpse [<i>met</i>]” indicates that this blood combines to complete <b>one measure,</b> i.e., the minimum amount of a quarter-<i>log</i> required to impart impurity.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>an animal was encountering difficulty giving birth and</b> as a result <b>the fetus extended its foreleg</b> outside the mother’s womb, <b>and</b> someone <b>severed it and afterward slaughtered the mother</b> animal, <b>the flesh</b> of the fetus is <b>ritually pure.</b> If one first <b>slaughtered the mother</b> animal <b>and afterward severed</b> the foreleg, <b>the flesh</b> of both the mother animal and the fetus are ritually impure due to having been in <b>contact with a carcass.</b> Since the foreleg was not permitted to be consumed through the act of slaughtering, it is regarded as a carcass with the associated ritual impurity. The rest of the flesh, which was permitted to be consumed by the slaughter, was in contact with it and so was rendered ritually impure from it; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The flesh has the ritual impurity of having been in <b>contact with a <i>tereifa</i> that was slaughtered,</b> as the limb is regarded as a <i>tereifa</i> that was slaughtered. By Torah law, although it is prohibited to consume it, it does not impart ritual impurity. Nevertheless, the Sages decreed that a <i>tereifa</i> that was slaughtered, as well as anything that comes in contact with it, is regarded as ritually impure to the extent that it disqualifies sacrificial foods that come in contact with it.

Daf 72b

The Rabbis explain the rationale behind their opinion: <b>Just as we found in</b> the case of <b>a <i>tereifa</i> that its slaughter renders it ritually pure</b> according to Torah law, i.e., ritual slaughter prevents it from having the ritual impurity of a carcass despite not rendering the animal permitted for consumption, <b>so too, the slaughter of</b> the mother <b>animal should render the limb</b> of its fetus that left the womb <b>ritually pure,</b> despite the fact that its consumption is prohibited.
<b>Rabbi Meir said to them: No, if the slaughter of a <i>tereifa</i> renders</b> the body of the animal <b>ritually pure,</b> it is because the slaughter is performed on <b>something that is</b> part of <b>its body,</b> i.e., its throat. Does it necessarily follow that <b>you should</b> also <b>render the limb</b> that left the womb <b>pure,</b> given that it is <b>something that is not</b> part of the mother’s <b>body?</b> Certainly not.
The mishna asks: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to a <i>tereifa</i> that its slaughter renders it ritually pure,</b> i.e., prevents it from having the ritual impurity of a carcass? The mishna notes there is a reason to say the slaughter should not render it pure, as one can compare a <i>tereifa</i> with a non-kosher animal: <b>A non-kosher animal is prohibited for consumption; so too, a <i>tereifa</i> is prohibited for consumption.</b> Therefore, conclude: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a non-kosher animal, its slaughter does not render it ritually pure, so too</b> with regard to <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, its slaughter should not render it ritually pure.</b>
The mishna questions the comparison: <b>No, if you said</b> that slaughtering cannot prevent an animal from having the ritual impurity of a carcass <b>in</b> the case of <b>a non-kosher animal, which</b> is distinct in that it <b>did not have a period of</b> potential <b>fitness</b> when slaughtering it could have rendered its consumption permitted, does it necessarily follow that <b>you should</b> also <b>say</b> this <b>in</b> the case of <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, which did have a period of</b> potential <b>fitness?</b> Perhaps, since the animal had a period of potential fitness its slaughter remains effective in preventing it from having the ritual impurity of a carcass.
The mishna rejects this distinction: <b>Take</b> back <b>to yourself</b> this claim <b>that you brought,</b> as it is insufficient. What about a case <b>where</b> an animal <b>was born as a <i>tereifa</i> from the womb,</b> and so it never had a period of potential fitness? For such a case, <b>from where</b> is it derived that its slaughter renders it ritually pure?
The mishna reformulates the distinction: <b>No, if you say</b> that slaughtering cannot prevent a prohibited animal from having the ritual impurity of a carcass <b>with regard to a non-kosher animal, which</b> is distinct in that <b>there are no</b> animals <b>of its kind</b> that are permitted through <b>slaughtering,</b> as the Torah states the concept of slaughtering only with regard to kosher animals, does it necessarily follow that <b>you should</b> also <b>say</b> this <b>with regard to a <i>tereifa</i></b> kosher animal, given <b>that there are</b> other animals <b>of its kind</b> that are permitted through <b>slaughtering,</b> i.e., kosher animals that are not <i>tereifa</i>? Perhaps, since the concept of slaughtering is relevant to that kind of animal it can serve to prevent the animal from having the ritual impurity of a carcass even if the slaughter cannot render it permitted for consumption.
The mishna notes: Based on this reasoning, one must conclude that with regard to <b>an eight-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus that was born <b>alive, slaughter does not render it ritually pure, as there are no</b> animals <b>of its kind</b> that are permitted through <b>slaughtering.</b> The Torah applies the concept of slaughter only with regard to animals that were born full term.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that according to Rabbi Meir, if a foreleg of a fetus emerges from the womb and is severed after the slaughter of the mother, it is regarded as a carcass with the associated ritual impurity. Furthermore, the rest of the fetus from which it was cut is thereby rendered ritually impure through its contact with the foreleg. The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> should the rest of the fetus be impure? <b>This is</b> a case of <b>impurity</b> imparted within <b>a concealed area,</b> as the point of contact between the foreleg and the fetus existed when they were still naturally connected to each other. <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>an impure</b> item within <b>a concealed area does not impart impurity.</b> If the two items were in contact in a concealed area and not on an external surface, impurity cannot be imparted from one item to the other. <b>Shall we say</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning</b> in this regard, as he holds that an impure item within a concealed area does impart impurity?
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 27:10) concerning ritual impurity imparted by treading: If a person who is ritually impure due to having experienced a bodily emission, such as a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>], sits or leans upon an item that was designated for that purpose, the item is rendered ritually impure due to ritual impurity imparted by treading. The item will then impart impurity to people or utensils that come in contact with it. In the case of a garment that is impure with ritual impurity imparted by treading that was <b>three by three</b> handbreadths in size, i.e., the minimum size to impart such impurity, <b>that was split</b> into smaller pieces, each part is <b>ritually pure with regard to</b> ritual impurity <b>imparted by treading</b> and will no longer impart impurity to people and utensils that come in contact with it.
The mishna continues: <b>But</b> each piece will still have the <b>ritual impurity</b> of having been in <b>contact with</b> an item that imparts ritual impurity <b>imparted by treading.</b> Before the garment was split, when it still imparted ritual impurity imparted by treading, each piece of the garment was in contact with another part of it. Through that connection, each piece was rendered ritually impure with the impurity of having been in contact with ritual impurity imparted by treading. When the garment was subsequently split, although the pieces were no longer able to impart ritual impurity imparted by treading, they retained the ritual impurity they acquired through their contact with the other pieces before the garment was split. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> In this case, the contact between the pieces occurred within a concealed area, as the connection between parts of the same item has the status of a connection within a concealed area. Evidently, Rabbi Meir holds that impurity can be imparted within a concealed area.
<b>And it is taught</b> in that mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei says,</b> disagreeing with Rabbi Meir: <b>But what</b> source of impurity <b>imparted by treading did these</b> pieces <b>touch?</b> Rabbi Yosei disregards the contact between the pieces that occurred before the garment was split, as that contact has the status of a connection within a concealed area. <b>Rather,</b> the only way the pieces could still be ritually impure is if <b>a <i>zav</i> had touched</b> the garment directly, e.g., when he sat on the garment he also touched it with his skin. In that case the garment would have also been rendered <b>ritually impure due to contact with a <i>zav</i>,</b> and that impurity would remain even after the garment was split. It would appear, then, that the opinion of Rabbi Meir in the mishna here can be reconciled only with the opinion of Rabbi Meir in the mishna in <i>Kelim</i>, but not with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei.
The Gemara responds: <b>Wasn’t it stated with regard to that</b> mishna in <i>Kelim</i> that <b>Ulla said: They taught</b> that Rabbi Yosei disagrees with Rabbi Meir <b>only</b> in the case of a garment of <b>three by three</b> handbreadths <b>that was split</b> into smaller pieces, as once it is split, there is no piece large enough to impart to the other pieces impurity imparted through treading.
<b>But</b> with regard to pieces of <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths <b>that come,</b> i.e., are cut, <b>from a large garment,</b> everyone agrees that <b>at the time of their separation from their original</b> garment, before they are fully detached from it, <b>they are rendered impure through</b> their contact with the <b>original</b> garment, despite the fact that the contact occurs within a concealed area. In <b>this</b> case of the mishna here <b>also,</b> one can say that <b>at the time of separation</b> of the flesh of the fetus <b>from</b> the <b>limb,</b> i.e., the foreleg, it is <b>rendered impure through</b> its contact with <b>the limb.</b> According to Ulla, then, the mishna can be reconciled also with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei.
<b>Ravina said</b> there is a different explanation of how the mishna can be reconciled with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei: <b>A garment does not stand,</b> i.e., is not intended, <b>to be cut.</b> On the contrary, it is better for it to remain whole. Therefore, the connections between its pieces are regarded as being within a concealed area that cannot impart impurity. By contrast, with regard to <b>a fetus</b> that extends its foreleg, the foreleg <b>does stand to be cut,</b> as it is prohibited for consumption while the rest of the fetus is permitted, <b>and</b> the halakhic principle is that <b>any</b> item <b>that stands to be cut</b>

Daf 73a

<b>is regarded as though it were cut.</b> Therefore, it is regarded as though the foreleg had already been severed from the body of the fetus, and the point of contact between them is not considered to be a concealed area. Rather, it is regarded as if the foreleg and fetus were two separate items that came into contact with each other. Consequently, the former can impart impurity to the latter.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with</b> whose opinion is this halakhic principle that Ravina cites? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Mikvaot</i> 10:5): When a vessel is immersed in a ritual bath, it is purified only if all parts of the vessel are submerged at the same time. But with regard to <b>any handles of vessels that are</b> too <b>long and</b> therefore <b>will ultimately be cut off, one</b> must <b>immerse them</b> only <b>until the point of</b> their eventual <b>size.</b> Even though the part of the handle that will be cut off is not submerged, the vessel is nevertheless purified; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> Evidently, Rabbi Meir holds that even though the handle is still physically attached, since that part of the handle stands to be cut off, it is already regarded as though it were cut off. Consequently, immersing the handle up until that point is regarded as immersing the entire vessel.
<b>And the Rabbis say</b> that the vessel is not purified <b>until he immerses all of it,</b> including the handle. Apparently, the Rabbis do not hold that an item that stands to be cut is regarded as though it was already cut, and Ravina’s explanation is in accordance only with the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
