The Gemara responds: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that Ravina’s explanation is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The disagreement between the Rabbis and Rabbi Meir concerns utensils, but even the Rabbis agree that the <b>connections</b> between two pieces <b>of food are</b> disregarded, and the item is <b>considered as though it is</b> already <b>separated</b> into two pieces <b>that are touching one another,</b> and so ritual impurity can be imparted from one piece to another. Similarly, the fetus and the foreleg are considered like food in this regard. Therefore, it is considered as if they have already been separated and are touching, allowing the foreleg to impart impurity to the fetus.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to</b> the explanation of <b>Ulla</b> that the fetus was rendered impure at the time of separation of the flesh of the fetus from the limb, <b>this</b> explanation is consistent with <b>that which</b> the mishna <b>teaches,</b> that the foreleg <b>was severed</b> from the body of the fetus. <b>But according to</b> the explanation of <b>Ravina,</b> the connection between the foreleg and fetus is like that of food, and even if the foreleg was never severed from the fetus it would still impart impurity to the fetus. <b>What,</b> then, is the reason the mishna states <b>it was severed?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the mishna needed to <b>teach</b> in <b>the first clause</b> that the foreleg <b>was severed, it also taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> that <b>it was severed,</b> for stylistic consistency, even though the <i>halakha</i> would apply even were it not severed.
§ The mishna states: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The flesh of a fetus that extended its foreleg outside the mother’s womb and whose mother was subsequently slaughtered has ritual impurity due to having been in <b>contact with a <i>tereifa</i> that was slaughtered.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Does a slaughtered <i>tereifa</i> impart impurity?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> and this is <b>in accordance</b> with the statement <b>of Shmuel’s father, as Shmuel’s father says:</b> The Sages decreed that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> that one slaughtered imparts impurity to sacrificial</b> animals, i.e., it will disqualify them if it comes in contact with them.
§ The mishna cites the Rabbis’ rationale for their opinion: <b>Just as we found in</b> the case of <b>a <i>tereifa</i> that its slaughter renders it ritually pure</b> according to Torah law, i.e., it prevents it from having the ritual impurity of a carcass, despite not rendering the animal permitted for consumption, <b>so too, the slaughter of</b> the mother <b>animal should render the</b> limb of its <b>fetus</b> that left the womb <b>ritually pure,</b> despite the fact that it is prohibited for consumption.
The mishna itself proceeds to cite Rabbi’s Meir’s response to this claim. The Gemara here cites a different version of his response based on that which <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>But what renders this limb pure from</b> the impurity of <b>a carcass?</b> You might say it is <b>the slaughter of its mother,</b> but <b>if so,</b> the act of slaughter <b>should</b> also <b>permit</b> it even <b>for consumption.</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> The slaughter of an animal has <b>a greater effect in shielding that which is not</b> part of <b>its body</b> from having the ritual impurity of a carcass <b>than that which is</b> part of <b>its body, as</b> is apparent from that <b>which we learned</b> in the mishna (68a): If, prior to slaughtering an animal, one <b>severs</b> pieces <b>from a fetus that is in</b> its <b>womb,</b> leaving those pieces in the womb, their <b>consumption is permitted</b> by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal. By contrast, if one severs pieces <b>of the spleen or of the kidneys</b> of an animal and then slaughtered it, then even if those pieces were left inside the animal, their <b>consumption is prohibited.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the response of the Rabbis: <b>What are</b> the Rabbis <b>saying? Rava said, and some say it unattributed [<i>kedi</i>]</b> to any particular Sage, that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete, and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching: Rabbi Meir said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>But what renders this limb pure from</b> the impurity of <b>a carcass?</b> You might say it is <b>the slaughter of its mother,</b> but <b>if so, it should</b> also <b>permit it</b> even <b>for consumption.</b> In response the Rabbis <b>said to him: Let</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a <i>tereifa</i> prove</b> the point, <b>as its slaughter renders it pure from</b> the impurity of <b>a carcass but it does not permit it for consumption.</b> Similarly, the slaughter of the mother animal should render pure even the foreleg of its fetus, even if it does not permit it for consumption.
Rabbi Meir <b>said to them: No,</b> even <b>if the slaughter of a <i>tereifa</i> renders</b> the animal itself <b>pure</b> from having the impurity of a carcass, that is true with regard to <b>something that is</b> part <b>of its own body.</b> Does it necessarily follow that <b>it should</b> also <b>render pure the limb</b> of its fetus, which is <b>something that is not</b> part of <b>its own body?</b> The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> The slaughter of an animal <b>has a greater effect in shielding that which is not</b> part of <b>its body</b> from having the impurity of a carcass <b>than that which is</b> part of <b>its body, as</b> is apparent from that <b>which we learned</b> in the mishna at the beginning of the chapter: If one <b>severs</b> pieces <b>from a fetus that is in</b> an animal’s <b>womb</b> and then slaughters the mother animal, their <b>consumption is permitted.</b> By contrast, if one severs pieces <b>of the spleen or of the kidneys</b> of an animal and then slaughters it, their <b>consumption is prohibited.</b>
The Gemara notes that <b>this</b> clarification of Rava <b>is also taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>But what renders this limb pure from</b> the impurity of <b>a carcass?</b> The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> It is <b>the slaughter of its mother.</b> Rabbi Meir responded: But <b>if so, it should</b> also <b>permit it</b> even <b>for consumption.</b> In response the Rabbis <b>said to him: Let</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a <i>tereifa</i> prove</b> the point, <b>as its slaughter renders it pure from</b> the impurity of <b>a carcass but it does not permit it for consumption.</b> Similarly, the slaughter of the mother animal should render pure even the foreleg of its fetus, even if it does not permit it for consumption.
Rabbi Meir <b>said to them:</b> Even <b>if the slaughter of a <i>tereifa</i> renders</b> the animal itself <b>pure, and</b> likewise the slaughter of any animal renders <b>the limb that</b> was partially cut from it but still <b>hangs from it</b> pure from imparting the impurity of a carcass despite being prohibited for consumption, that is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>something that is</b> part of <b>its own body.</b> Does it necessarily follow that <b>it should</b> also <b>render pure the limb</b> of its fetus, which is <b>something that is not</b> part of <b>its own body?</b>
The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> The slaughter of an animal <b>has a greater effect in shielding that which is not</b> part of <b>its body</b> from imparting the ritual impurity of a carcass <b>than that which is</b> part of <b>its body, as</b> is apparent from that <b>which we have learned</b> in the mishna above: If one <b>severed</b> pieces <b>from a fetus that was in</b> an animal’s <b>womb</b> and then slaughtered the mother animal, their <b>consumption is permitted.</b> But if one severed pieces <b>of the spleen or of the kidneys</b> of an animal and then slaughtered it, their <b>consumption is prohibited.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Just as</b> there is <b>a dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis <b>with regard to fetuses,</b> concerning whether the slaughter of the mother prevents a limb that emerged from the womb from having the impurity of a carcass, <b>so</b> too, they have a parallel <b>dispute with regard to limbs</b> of an animal that were partially cut from it but still hanging from it, whether the slaughter of the animal prevents such limbs from having the impurity of a carcass.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Their <b>dispute</b> is only <b>with regard to a limb of a fetus</b> that emerged from the womb, <b>but with regard to a limb</b> hanging <b>from an animal, everyone agrees</b> that the <b>slaughter</b> of the animal <b>renders</b> such a limb as though it had already <b>fallen</b> off prior to the slaughter, and the slaughter does not prevent the limb from having the impurity of a carcass.
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: What is the reason</b> for the distinction made <b>by Rabbi Yoḥanan concerning</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis</b> that the slaughter of an animal renders pure the limb of its fetus, but does not render pure a limb hanging from the animal itself? The reason is that <b>this</b> limb of the fetus that emerged from its womb <b>has</b> a means of <b>rectification by returning back</b> inside the womb, in accordance with the opinion that it will then be permitted for consumption by virtue of the slaughter of the mother animal. <b>But this</b> hanging limb <b>does not have</b> a means of <b>rectification by returning,</b> as it cannot be reattached to the animal’s body.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion from the <i>baraita</i> cited above: <b>Rabbi Meir said to them: No,</b> even <b>if the slaughter of a <i>tereifa</i> renders pure</b> the animal itself <b>and</b> similarly the slaughter of any animal renders pure <b>the limb that is hanging from it</b> from having the impurity of a carcass, this is true with regard to <b>something that is</b> part of <b>its own body.</b> Does it necessarily follow that <b>it should</b> also <b>render pure the limb</b> of its fetus, which is <b>something that is not</b> part of <b>its own body?</b>

Daf 73b

Rabbi Meir’s statement appears inconsistent with his opinion, as he holds that a hanging limb is not rendered pure by slaughtering the animal. The Gemara suggests that this difficulty can be resolved only according to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish’s version of the Rabbis’ opinion, but not according to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s version. <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> one can explain that Rabbi Meir <b>was speaking in accordance with the statement of</b> the Rabbis, as follows: <b>According to my</b> own opinion, there <b>is no difference</b> with regard to <b>the limb of a fetus, and</b> there <b>is no difference</b> with regard to <b>a limb</b> hanging <b>from an animal; they are the same</b> in that the slaughter of the animal does not render either of them pure. Accordingly, Rabbi Meir must have been speaking in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis that a limb hanging from an animal is rendered pure by the animal’s slaughter.
<b>But according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who holds that both the Rabbis and Rabbi Meir agree that a limb hanging from an animal is not rendered pure by the animal’s slaughter, Rabbi Meir’s statement is <b>difficult,</b> as it is inconsistent with both his opinion and the Rabbis’ opinion. The Gemara concedes the challenge.
<b>Rather, if</b> such a dispute <b>was stated, it was stated like this: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Just as</b> there is <b>a dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis <b>with regard to fetuses</b> whose limbs emerged from the womb, <b>so</b> too, they have a parallel <b>dispute with regard to limbs</b> hanging from an animal. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Their <b>dispute is</b> only <b>with regard to the limb of a fetus</b> that emerged from the womb; <b>but with regard to a limb</b> hanging <b>from an animal, everyone agrees</b> that the <b>slaughter</b> of the animal <b>does not render</b> such a limb as though it had already <b>fallen off</b> prior to the slaughter, and does not impart the impurity of a carcass. According to this version of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s understanding of the dispute, Rabbi Meir’s statement is consistent even with his own opinion.
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: What is the reason</b> for the distinction made <b>by Rabbi Yoḥanan concerning</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir,</b> that the slaughter of an animal does not render pure the limb of its fetus, but it does render pure a limb hanging from the animal itself? It is that <b>this</b> hanging limb is part of the animal’s <b>body, but that,</b> the limb of the fetus, is <b>not</b> part of <b>its body.</b>
§ The Gemara continues to elucidate the dispute between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis. <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Everyone agrees that</b> the <b>death</b> of an animal by means other than slaughter <b>renders</b> a limb as though it had already <b>fallen off</b> prior to the animal’s death. Therefore, it will not have the impurity of a carcass, but it will have the impurity of a limb taken from a living animal. <b>And</b> likewise, everyone agrees that the <b>slaughter</b> of the animal <b>does not render</b> a limb as though it had already <b>fallen off</b> prior to the slaughter, and therefore it will not have the impurity of a carcass.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are we dealing with</b> here? <b>If we say</b> we are dealing <b>with a limb of</b> its <b>fetus</b> that emerged from its womb, Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis explicitly <b>disagree</b> with regard to this case. <b>Rather,</b> we are dealing <b>with a limb</b> hanging <b>from an animal.</b> But if so, Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement is unnecessary. With regard to a hanging limb, <b>we</b> already <b>learn</b> about the effect of the <b>death</b> of the animal in a mishna elsewhere, and <b>we</b> already <b>learn</b> about the effect of the <b>slaughter</b> of the animal in a mishna elsewhere.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>We</b> already <b>learn</b> about the effect of the <b>death</b> of an animal in the mishna (127b): If <b>the animal died</b> without slaughter, any hanging <b>flesh needs</b> to be rendered <b>susceptible</b> to contracting ritual impurity in order to become impure. This is accomplished by coming in contact with liquid, with the owner’s approval. The reason is that its halakhic status is that of flesh severed from a living animal, which is ritually pure and does not have the status of an unslaughtered carcass. <b>And</b> a hanging <b>limb imparts impurity as a limb</b> severed <b>from a living</b> animal, <b>but does not impart impurity as a limb from a carcass;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> Evidently, Rabbi Meir holds that upon the animal’s death, anything hanging from the animal is considered as though it had already fallen off before the animal’s death. Since the mishna does not record that the Rabbis disagree, it would appear that they agree.
Likewise, <b>we</b> already <b>learn</b> about the effect of the <b>slaughter</b> of an animal in the same mishna: If <b>the animal is slaughtered, they,</b> the limb and the flesh hanging from it, <b>are</b> thereby <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity, by coming in contact <b>with its blood.</b> Blood is one of the seven liquids that render foods susceptible to impurity and its presence is considered to be with the approval of the owner, as it makes the meat look redder and fresher; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Shimon says: They were not rendered susceptible</b> to impurity through the animal’s own blood, but only once they were wet with another liquid, with the owner’s approval. It is apparent that both opinions in that mishna agree that the limb does not have the impurity of a limb severed from a living animal. Evidently, they hold that the slaughter does not render the hanging limb as though it had already fallen off beforehand.
Given that the mishna has already taught both <i>halakhot</i>, what was the necessity of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement? The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> these <i>halakhot</i> were derived only <b>from that</b> mishna, <b>I would say</b> that actually, slaughter does render a hanging limb as though it had already fallen off beforehand, and such a limb would have the impurity of a limb severed from a live animal. If so, <b>what</b> does the mishna mean when it states: <b>They are rendered susceptible</b> to impurity by coming in contact with its blood? Ostensibly, the intention is that both the limb and the flesh must be rendered susceptible to impurity, which indicates that the limb does not have any impurity of its own. The Gemara explains: One would have explained that the need to be rendered susceptible to impurity is referring only <b>to the flesh,</b> as flesh severed from a living animal does not have any impurity of its own.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> the mishna <b>teaches: They are rendered susceptible,</b> in the plural, which is apparently referring to both the flesh and the limb, which were mentioned previously in the mishna. The Gemara explains: <b>You might say</b> that the plural is used because the statement is referring to two types of hanging flesh that upon slaughter are considered to have been separated from a living animal: <b>One</b> is <b>for flesh that separates from</b> the body of <b>the animal, and</b> the other <b>one</b> is <b>for flesh that separates from the</b> hanging <b>limb.</b> Neither type has its own impurity, so they must be rendered susceptible to impurity by coming in contact with liquid.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> it <b>more compelling</b> to apply the <i>halakha</i> <b>to this</b> type of flesh <b>than</b> to <b>that</b> type, making it necessary to state the <i>halakha</i> with regard to both? The Gemara answers: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> flesh that is attached to a limb severed from a living animal <b>imparts</b> the same <b>severe</b> form of <b>ritual impurity</b> as the limb <b>on account of being a part of</b> it, one might <b>say</b> that once the flesh is separated from the limb it does <b>not need to</b> then <b>be rendered susceptible</b> to impurity. To reject this possibility, the mishna uses the plural form to <b>teach us</b> that this type of flesh does need to be rendered susceptible to impurity.
§ <b>Rav Yosef said: Take</b> the statement <b>that Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef</b> says that Rabbi Yoḥanan says, i.e., that the slaughter of an animal does not render a hanging limb as though it had already fallen off prior to the slaughter, <b>in your hand,</b> i.e., accept it as correct, <b>as Rabba bar bar Ḥana</b> also <b>holds in accordance with</b> this opinion. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“And flesh that is torn in the field, you shall not eat”</b> (Exodus 22:30). This serves <b>to include</b> the case of <b>the limb or the flesh that was</b> partially cut off but was still <b>hanging on a domesticated animal or on an undomesticated animal or on a bird, and one slaughtered</b> them; it is derived <b>that they are prohibited</b> as limbs severed from a living animal. <b>And Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> with regard to the ruling of this <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 74a

In fact, such limbs and flesh are not prohibited by Torah law, as the slaughter does not render them as though they had already fallen off prior to the slaughter, and the verse cited in the <i>baraita</i> is not a true derivation but a mere support. Accordingly, <b>with regard to them, there is nothing other than</b> a rabbinic <b>mitzva to separate</b> oneself from consuming them.
§ <b>Rav Yosef sat before Rav Huna, and he sat and said: Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If <b>one ate this</b> hanging limb he is <b>flogged</b> for violating the prohibition against eating a limb from a living animal. <b>One of the Sages said to him: Do not listen to his</b> statement in the name of Rav, as <b>this</b> is what <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta says in the name of Rav:</b> If <b>one ate this</b> hanging limb <b>he is not flogged.</b>
<b>Rav Huna said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Upon whose</b> version of Rav’s ruling <b>shall we rely? Rav Yosef turned his face away</b> in anger <b>and said to him: What is the difficulty? When I said</b> in Rav’s name that one is flogged for eating a limb that had been hanging from an animal when it died, I was <b>referring to</b> a case of <b>death</b> by means other than slaughter, <b>which renders</b> the limb as though it had already <b>fallen</b> off prior to the animal’s death. <b>When</b> Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta <b>said</b> in the name of Rav that one is not flogged, he was <b>referring to</b> the case of <b>a slaughter, which does not render</b> the limb as though it had already <b>fallen off</b> prior to the slaughter and therefore serves to render the limb permitted for consumption.
§ <b>Rava said: From where is this matter that the Sages stated</b> derived: The <b>death</b> of an animal by means other than slaughter <b>renders</b> a hanging limb as though it had already <b>fallen off</b> prior to the slaughter, whereas the <b>slaughter</b> of the animal <b>does not render</b> a limb as though it had already <b>fallen off? As it is written</b> with regard to the eight species of impure creeping animals: <b>“And anything that these fall upon, when they are dead, it shall be impure”</b> (Leviticus 11:32). <b>What</b> does the term “when they are dead” serve <b>to exclude? If we say</b> it serves <b>to exclude</b> the time <b>when they are alive,</b> that principle is <b>derived from:</b> “And everything upon which any part <b>of their carcass</b> falls shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:35), which explicitly states that only their carcasses impart impurity. <b>Rather, learn from</b> the verse that <b>death renders</b> a hanging limb as though it had already <b>fallen off,</b> and <b>slaughter does not render</b> a hanging limb as though it had already <b>fallen off.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said to Rava: But</b> this <b>verse is written with regard to creeping animals,</b> which do not require slaughter. How then can a <i>halakha</i> with regard to slaughter be derived from here? Rava <b>said to him: If,</b> because it is superfluous, this verse <b>is not</b> referring to the <b>matter of creeping animals, which are not subject to the</b> requirement of <b>slaughter, apply it</b> to the <b>matter of an animal,</b> which is subject to slaughter.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> the phrase “when they are dead, it shall be impure” <b>is still necessary</b> to teach a different <i>halakha</i>, i.e., that they impart impurity only when they are still in a state <b>similar to</b> their state at the time of their <b>death,</b> i.e., if they <b>are moist they impart impurity,</b> whereas if they <b>are dry they do not impart impurity.</b> The Gemara explains that <b>“when they are dead” is written twice,</b> once in the verse cited, and once in the previous verse, which states: “Whoever touches them when they are dead shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:31).
§ The Gemara returns to the dispute in the mishna (72a) with regard to a fetus that extended its foreleg and then its mother was slaughtered. Rabbi Meir holds that the foreleg is regarded as a carcass with the associated impurity, while the Rabbis hold that although it is not permitted for consumption, the slaughter prevents it from having the impurity of a carcass. With regard to this dispute, <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The <b>dispute concerns</b> only <b>the limb of a fetus that was alive</b> when the mother was slaughtered; <b>but concerning</b> the case of <b>the limb of a fetus that was dead</b> when the mother was slaughtered, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>slaughter renders</b> the fetus’s limb as though it had already <b>fallen off</b>  prior to the slaughter, and it imparts impurity as a limb from a living animal. <b>But Rabba said:</b> Just <b>as</b> there is <b>a dispute</b> between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis <b>concerning this</b> case, where the fetus was alive, <b>so</b> too, there is <b>a dispute</b> between them <b>concerning that</b> case, where the fetus had died.
§ The mishna states that <b>an eight-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus that was born <b>alive</b> is not rendered ritually pure by slaughtering it. The reason given is that the concept of permitting an animal through slaughter is never stated with regard to that kind of animal. The Gemara challenges: But <b>isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in a discussion about whether slaughter renders a <i>tereifa</i> pure from the impurity of a carcass: <b>An eight-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus that was born <b>alive will prove</b> the point, <b>as even though there are</b> other animals <b>of that kind</b> that are permitted through <b>slaughter, its slaughter does not render it pure</b> from having the impurity of a carcass. This refutes the claim that the issue of slaughter rendering an animal pure from having the impurity of a carcass is a function of whether or not the concept of slaughter applies to that kind of animal.
<b>Rav Kahana said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> holds that even with regard to an eight-month-old fetus it can be said that <b>there are</b> animals <b>of that kind</b> that are permitted through <b>slaughter,</b> i.e., when they are still inside the womb and the mother is slaughtered; such an animal is permitted <b>by virtue of</b> the slaughter of <b>its mother.</b> Therefore, he cites the case of an eight-month-old fetus as a refutation. <b>But the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna holds that the fact that this <b>kind</b> of animal is permitted by virtue of the slaughter <b>of its mother</b> does not define it as a kind of animal concerning which there is a concept of slaughter, and therefore he holds that this case <b>cannot be used as a refutation.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to that <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>who does use</b> it <b>as a refutation, from where does he</b> derive <b>that the slaughter of a <i>tereifa</i> renders it pure</b> from having the impurity of a carcass? The Gemara answers that he <b>derives it from that</b> which <b>Rav Yehuda</b> says that <b>Rav says, as Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says, and some say it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And if some domesticated animal,</b> of which you may eat, <b>dies,</b> one who touches its carcass shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39). The word “some” teaches that only <b>some</b> dead <b>animals impart impurity</b> as a carcass, <b>but some</b> dead <b>animals do not impart impurity</b> as a carcass. <b>And what is</b> it <b>that</b> does not impart impurity? <b>That is a <i>tereifa</i> that one slaughtered.</b>
§ <b>Rav Hoshaya raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>inserted his hand inside the womb of an animal and slaughtered a nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus that was <b>alive, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does the slaughter performed inside the mother render the fetus permitted? The Gemara notes: This dilemma <b>may be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> and it <b>may be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: It <b>may be raised according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b> It is possible that <b>Rabbi Meir states</b> in the mishna below that a nine-month-old <b><i>ben pekua</i> requires slaughter,</b> and slaughter renders the animal permitted <b>only</b> in that case, because <b>that statement</b> may apply only in a case <b>where</b> the animal <b>emerged into the airspace of the world,</b> i.e., once it was born alive. <b>But</b> if it is still <b>inside its mother,</b> its <b>slaughter does not render it permitted.</b>
<b>Or perhaps even the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Meir and maintain that a nine-month-old <i>ben pekua</i> is permitted by virtue of its mother’s slaughter, would concede that the slaughter of the fetus itself also permits it. Perhaps <b>with regard to</b> such an animal <b>the Merciful One considers four <i>simanim</i>,</b> i.e., the windpipe and the gullet of the mother and the windpipe and the gullet of the fetus, <b>to be fit</b> for slaughter, and the fetus is permitted by the cutting of either pair.
<b>Rav Ḥananya said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution of this dilemma from the mishna (72b), as it considers an animal <b>that was born as a <i>tereifa</i> from the womb</b> as one that never had a period of potential fitness. <b>But if it is so,</b> that one can slaughter a fetus in its mother’s womb, <b>you find that</b> actually <b>it did have a period of</b> potential <b>fitness, as if one wants</b> to, <b>he can insert his hand</b> into the womb <b>and slaughter it</b> before it develops into a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Ḥananya: <b>Teach</b> that mishna as referring to a case <b>where</b> the fetus <b>was formed as a <i>tereifa</i></b> from its outset <b>while inside the womb, and you find such</b> a case <b>where</b> a fetus <b>has five legs,</b> which certainly developed from the outset. Consequently, there was never a possibility of slaughtering it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slaughtered an animal and found within it an eight-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus, i.e., one that was not full term, whether it was <b>alive or dead, or a nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus, i.e., one that was full term, that was <b>dead,</b> that fetus is permitted by virtue of the slaughter of its mother, as it is considered part of its mother. Therefore, its blood is considered part of its mother’s blood and is prohibited, so one must <b>tear</b> the fetus <b>and remove its blood</b> before it may be consumed.
If <b>he found</b> within it <b>a live nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus, <b>it requires</b> its own <b>slaughter,</b> as it is considered an independent full-fledged animal, <b>and</b> if one slaughters both the mother and fetus on the same day, <b>one is liable for</b> violating the prohibition against slaughtering an animal <b>itself and its offspring</b> on the same day; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> Even when the fetus is nine months old, it is still considered part of its mother, and <b>the slaughter of its mother renders it permitted</b> for consumption.

Daf 74b

<b>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri says: Even</b> if the fetus emerged alive and <b>is</b> now <b>five years old and plowing in the field,</b> the earlier <b>slaughter of its mother rendered it permitted</b> and it does not require slaughter before it is eaten. But if <b>one tore</b> an animal, i.e., he killed it without slaughtering it, <b>and</b> inside <b>he found a live nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus, everyone agrees that the fetus <b>requires</b> its own <b>slaughter because its mother was not slaughtered.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says:</b> The Sages <b>discussed</b> the permissibility of a live nine-month-old fetus found inside a slaughtered animal <b>only with regard to the matter of</b> whether it requires its own <b>slaughter.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What does</b> Rav Oshaya’s statement serve <b>to exclude?</b> Rav Oshaya’s statement indicates that with regard to other matters all agree that it is considered an independent animal, with the associated prohibitions. The Gemara suggests: It serves <b>to exclude its fat,</b> i.e., the fats that are prohibited in a regular animal, such as the fat of the kidneys and innards, <b>and its</b> sciatic <b>nerve.</b>
The Gemara asks: The <b>fat of which</b> part? <b>If we say</b> that this is referring to the <b>fat of</b> the <b>fetus,</b> that is difficult because the Sages <b>disagree</b> as to whether or not it is permitted, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The prohibition of <b>the sciatic nerve applies to a fetus and its fat is prohibited;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The prohibition of the sciatic nerve <b>does not apply to a fetus, and its fat is permitted. And Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says:</b> This <b>dispute concerns a live nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus, <b>and Rabbi Meir follows his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning,</b> which he expressed in the mishna, that such a fetus is considered an independent full-fledged animal; <b>and Rabbi Yehuda</b> follows <b>his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning,</b> as expressed by the Rabbis in the mishna, that such a fetus is considered a part of the mother.
<b>Rather,</b> say that Rabbi Elazar is referring to the <b>fat of</b> the sciatic <b>nerve</b> of the fetus, which all agree is permitted. The Gemara rejects this as well: But the Sages also <b>disagree</b> with regard to that, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the sciatic nerve, one scrapes around it</b> to remove it entirely <b>in any place that it is</b> found in the thigh, <b>and one cuts out its fat completely,</b> even those fats that are sunk into the flesh; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: One cuts out</b> the nerve and the fat that is <b>level with the flesh</b> of the thigh, but there is no obligation to remove all traces of the fat.
<b>Rather, if</b> Rabbi Oshaya’s statement <b>was stated, it was stated like this: Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says:</b> The Sages <b>discussed</b> the permissibility of the fetus <b>only with regard to matters of consumption,</b> i.e., whether or not it must be slaughtered in order to permit its flesh and whether or not the fat and the sciatic nerve are permitted. This statement serves <b>to exclude</b> only one who <b>copulates with</b> the animal, <b>or</b> one who <b>plows with it</b> together with an animal of a different species, as everyone agrees that these prohibitions apply to such a fetus just as they do to any other animal.
§ A related amoraic dispute is cited concerning a live nine-month-old fetus found inside a slaughtered animal: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: According to the statement of</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>who permits the fat,</b> he also <b>permits its blood; according to the statement of</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>who prohibits its fat,</b> he also <b>prohibits its blood. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even according to</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>who permits its fat,</b> he <b>prohibits its blood.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> from the mishna, which states with regard to an eight-month-old fetus, whether alive or dead, or a dead nine-month-old fetus, found inside a slaughtered animal, that since it is considered part of the mother its blood is prohibited. Therefore, one must <b>tear</b> the fetus <b>and remove its blood</b> before it may be consumed. The mishna prohibits the blood but apparently permits the rest of the fetus, including its fat, which contradicts the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish. In resolution of this difficulty, <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish meant <b>to say</b> only <b>that</b> the consumption of blood lost as the fetus died <b>is not punishable by excision from the World-to-Come</b> [<b><i>karet</i>],</b> whereas Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that it is.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>According to whom did</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>state</b> that one who permits the fat of the fetus also holds that the consumption of its blood is not punishable by <i>karet</i>? Ostensibly, it is <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who permits its fat. But that is difficult, because this blood <b>should be regarded only as blood of exudate,</b> i.e., blood that exudes from the neck of the animal after the initial spurt of its slaughter concludes. This blood did not spurt out during the slaughter of the mother. Rabbi Yehuda holds that consumption of even this blood is punishable by <i>karet</i>, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The consumption of <b>blood of exudate</b> is prohibited <b>by</b> a regular <b>prohibition</b> and is punishable with lashes, unlike the initial spurt of blood, known as blood of the soul, whose consumption is punishable by <i>karet</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Blood of exudate is also punishable <b>by <i>karet</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef, son of Rav Salla the Pious, interpreted</b> this matter <b>before Rav Pappa:</b> One of the verses prohibiting the consumption of blood states: “And whoever…eats any blood, and I will set My face against that soul that eats the blood, and will cut him off from among his people” (Leviticus 17:10). <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that since it would have been sufficient for the verse to state: <b>Blood, but</b> instead it states: <b>“Any blood,”</b> it is interpreted as teaching that <b>wherever one is liable</b> for <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> the consumption of <b>blood of the soul,</b> i.e., the initial spurt from the slaughter, as is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a regular animal, one <b>is</b> also <b>liable</b> for <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> the consumption of <b>blood of exudate,</b> i.e., the rest of the blood. <b>But wherever</b> one <b>is not liable</b> for <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> the consumption of <b>blood of the soul,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the blood of a fetus according to Rabbi Yehuda, who holds that the fetus is not considered an independent life, one <b>is</b> also <b>not liable</b> for <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> the consumption of <b>blood of exudate;</b> rather, its blood is subject to a regular prohibition.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to redeeming</b> a firstborn donkey <b>with a <i>ben pekua</i>?</b> Can one perform the mitzva, as stated in the Torah: “And every firstborn of a donkey you shall redeem with a lamb” (Exodus 13:13), with this animal? The Gemara elaborates: <b>According to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir do not raise the dilemma, as, since he says</b> a <i>ben pekua</i> <b>requires slaughter,</b> evidently <b>it is a full-fledged lamb,</b> and therefore it can certainly be used to redeem a donkey.
<b>When should you raise the dilemma?</b> Raise it <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis, as they say</b> that <b>the slaughter of its mother renders it permitted. What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in this case? Does one say that <b>since</b> the Rabbis <b>say</b> that <b>the slaughter of its mother renders it permitted, it is</b> apparent that despite being physically alive, a <i>ben pekua</i> is halakhically regarded <b>like meat</b> placed <b>in a pot,</b> which cannot be used to redeem a donkey (see <i>Bekhorot</i> 12a)? <b>Or perhaps, since</b> the animal is <b>running back and forth,</b> i.e., it is alive, <b>we call it a lamb</b> and it can be used?
<b>Mar Zutra said: One cannot redeem</b> a donkey with this lamb, <b>and Rav Ashi said: One can redeem</b> it.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Mar Zutra: What</b> is the reason for <b>your opinion?</b> Is it <b>because you derive</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of redeeming a firstborn donkey <b>from Paschal offerings</b> by means of a verbal analogy between the term <b>“lamb”</b> (Exodus 13:13) written concerning a firstborn donkey and <b>“lamb”</b> (Exodus 12:5) written concerning a Paschal offering, and a <i>ben pekua</i> is unfit for sacrifice as a Paschal offering?
<b>If</b> so, <b>just as there,</b> with regard to the Paschal offering, it must be <b>male, unblemished, and in its</b> first <b>year, so too here,</b> the lamb must be <b>male, unblemished, and in its</b> first <b>year.</b> Yet the mishna in <i>Bekhorot</i> (9a) states explicitly that one may redeem with a female lamb, and even if it is blemished, and also with one that is past its first year. Mar Zutra responded: The repetition of the words <b>“You shall redeem,” “You shall</b> not <b>redeem”</b> written in the verse: “And every firstborn of a donkey you shall redeem with a lamb, and if you shall not redeem it then you shall break its neck” (Exodus 13:13), <b>included</b> a lamb that does not fulfill these criteria.
Rav Ashi responds: <b>If</b> the repetition of <b>“You shall redeem,” “You shall</b> not <b>redeem”</b> serves <b>to amplify,</b> then it should <b>even</b> amplify <b>all</b> other types of lambs, including a <i>ben pekua</i>, i.e., they should also be included in the category of those that are fit for redemption. Mar Zutra answers: <b>If</b> that was <b>so, what purpose would</b> the verbal analogy of <b>“lamb,” “lamb” serve?</b> Rather, the repetition of “You shall redeem” serves to include all types of lambs, but the verbal analogy still serves to exclude a <i>ben pekua</i>.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: According to the Rabbis, a <i>ben pekua</i> is permitted for consumption and is therefore susceptible to ritual impurity. If the <i>ben pekua</i> was still inside the slaughtered mother and the body of the mother came in contact with a primary source of ritual impurity, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to counting</b> the mother as having <b>first-</b>degree ritual impurity <b>and</b> the <i>ben pekua</i> as having <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity? If the fetus is considered independent of the mother, it is rendered impure only through its contact with the mother and so would have second-degree impurity. But if it is considered part of the mother it would have the same first-degree impurity as the mother.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One counts</b> the mother as having <b>first-</b>degree impurity <b>and</b> the <i>ben pekua</i> as having <b>second</b>-degree impurity. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: One does not count</b> the mother as having <b>first-</b>degree impurity <b>and</b> the <i>ben pekua</i> as having <b>second</b>-degree impurity. Rather, the fetus has first-degree impurity like its mother, as <b>it is considered like a nut rattling in its shell;</b> this is considered a single entity such that if impurity touches the shell, both the nut and the shell are rendered impure with the same degree of impurity.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raised an objection to Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> from the mishna (72a): If a fetus extended its foreleg outside its mother’s womb and then the mother was slaughtered, and afterward the foreleg was severed, <b>the flesh</b> of both the mother and the fetus are ritually impure due to having been in <b>contact with a carcass.</b> Since the foreleg was not permitted through an act of slaughter it is regarded as a carcass with the associated ritual impurity. The rest of the flesh, which was permitted, was in contact with it and was thereby rendered ritually impure; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The flesh has the ritual impurity of having been in <b>contact with a <i>tereifa</i> that was slaughtered.</b> The limb is regarded as a <i>tereifa</i> that was slaughtered, which by Torah law is prohibited for consumption but does not carry ritual impurity. Nevertheless, the Sages decreed that if a <i>tereifa</i> was slaughtered and then came in contact with another item, the other item should be regarded as ritually impure to the extent that it will disqualify sacrificial foods that come in contact with it.
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish explains his objection: <b>Granted, according to my</b> opinion, <b>as I say</b> that the mother and fetus together <b>are one entity; that is</b> why the flesh of the fetus <b>is rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity <b>through the blood of its mother</b> that spilled onto the body of the mother. When the blood from the mother’s slaughter renders the mother susceptible to impurity, the fetus is also rendered susceptible to impurity, as it is considered part of the mother. <b>But according to your</b> opinion, that the fetus is an independent entity, <b>through what</b> means is <b>it rendered susceptible</b> to contracting impurity from its foreleg?
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: It is rendered susceptible <b>through the slaughter</b> of its mother, which also permits the consumption of the fetus, <b>and</b> this is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who maintains that the flesh of a slaughtered animal is rendered susceptible to ritual impurity by virtue of the fact that it is permitted for consumption, even if it did not come in contact with blood or one of the other six liquids. Accordingly, the fetus will be susceptible to impurity even if it is not considered part of its mother.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If a <i>ben pekua</i> grew up and <b>passed through a river, it was</b> thereby <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity. Therefore, if it <b>went</b> from there <b>to a cemetery, it is rendered impure.</b>
Rabbi Yoḥanan explains his objection: <b>Granted, according to my</b> opinion, <b>as I say</b> that the mother and fetus <b>are two entities;</b> it is <b>due to that</b> reason that only if the <i>ben pekua</i> itself <b>has been rendered susceptible</b> to impurity by coming in contact with the water of the river, <b>yes,</b> it can be rendered impure upon entering a cemetery, whereas if <b>it has not been rendered susceptible</b> to impurity through these waters, <b>no,</b> it does not become impure when it enters a cemetery. <b>But according to your</b> opinion, in <b>which you said</b> that the mother and fetus together <b>are one entity,</b> why is it necessary for it to have passed through a river? <b>It was</b> already <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity <b>through the blood of its mother</b> that spilled onto the mother’s body when it was slaughtered.

Daf 75a

Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish answers: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of the mother was <b>dry,</b> i.e., where no blood was emitted, and therefore, even the mother was not rendered susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>And</b> the <i>baraita</i> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who maintains that the flesh of a slaughtered animal is rendered susceptible to ritual impurity by virtue of the fact that it is permitted for consumption, regardless of whether or not it came into contact with blood or other liquids.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> this <i>baraita</i>: If a <i>ben pekua</i> grew up and <b>passed through a river, it was</b> thereby <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity, and therefore if it <b>went</b> from there <b>to a cemetery, it is rendered impure? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili:</b> The flesh of a <i>ben pekua</i> <b>can become impure with the ritual impurity of food, but it</b> first <b>needs to be rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity by coming in contact with liquid. <b>But the Rabbis say: It cannot become impure with the ritual impurity of food because it is alive, and any live</b> animal <b>cannot become impure with the ritual impurity of food,</b> even if it is permitted for consumption.
The Gemara notes: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Beit Shammai said the same thing,</b> i.e., they both hold that even a live animal can become impure with the ritual impurity of food.
The opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili</b> is <b>that which we stated</b> in the <i>baraita</i>. The opinion of <b>Beit Shammai</b> is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 3:8): With regard to <b>fish, from when are they susceptible to impurity</b> as food? <b>Beit Shammai say: From when they are caught</b> in a trap, as at this point they are considered food, since they do not require slaughter. <b>And Beit Hillel say: From when they die. Rabbi Akiva says: From when they are no</b> longer <b>able to live.</b>
The Gemara analyzes that mishna: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> the opinions of Rabbi Akiva and Beit Hillel? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The difference <b>between them</b> is the case of <b>a convulsing fish.</b> Rabbi Akiva holds that such a fish can already become ritually impure, while Beit Hillel require it to have actually died.
<b>Rav Ḥisda raises a dilemma:</b> According to Rabbi Akiva, if <b>symptoms of a <i>tereifa</i> developed in a fish,</b> e.g., a perforation in the intestines, which will certainly result in the animal’s death (see 42a), <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Can it already be rendered ritually impure as if it were now dead? The Gemara clarifies: One can <b>raise this dilemma according to the one who says</b> that an animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> can <b>live,</b> i.e., it will not necessarily die within a year, <b>and</b> one can <b>raise this dilemma according to the one who says</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> cannot live,</b> but will die within a year.
The Gemara elaborates: One can <b>raise this dilemma according to the one who says</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> can <b>live,</b> as perhaps that opinion is limited to <b>an animal, as</b> an animal has <b>a strong life force,</b> and it could live despite such symptoms. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a fish, whose life force is not strong,</b> all would agree that it will <b>not</b> survive. <b>Or perhaps, even according to the one who says</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> cannot live,</b> it is possible that <b>this matter,</b> that a <i>tereifa</i> is regarded as dead, applies only to <b>an animal, as</b> the requirement to <b>slaughter</b> it in order to permit it for consumption <b>applies to this type</b> of creature, i.e., to animals, and so to invalidate its slaughter, the Torah classifies an animal that is a <i>tereifa</i> as though it is dead. But with regard to <b>fish, where</b> the requirement to <b>slaughter</b> it in order to permit it <b>does not apply to this type</b> of creature, <b>I would say</b> that a fish with symptoms of a <i>tereifa</i> is <b>not</b> considered as though it were dead. The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The Rabbis state in the mishna that a nine-month-old fetus is considered to be part of its mother. Therefore, when the mother is slaughtered, the entire fetus is permitted, including all its fats. The Gemara asks: If an animal <b>expelled a non-viable newborn,</b> what is the status of the fetus’s fat? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Its fat is like the fat</b> of any other <b>domesticated animal,</b> and one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> if he eats it. <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Its fat is like the fat of an undomesticated animal,</b> which is not prohibited.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Its fat is like the fat of</b> any other <b>domesticated animal,</b> as he maintains that the exit of a fetus through <b>the airspace</b> of the opening of the womb <b>causes</b> it to be regarded as an independent animal. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Its fat is like the fat of an undomesticated animal,</b> as he maintains that the completion of the <b>months</b> of gestation <b>causes</b> a fetus to be regarded as an independent animal, and this stillborn did not reach this stage.
<b>Some say</b> that there is another explanation of this dispute: In <b>any case where its months</b> of gestation <b>were not completed,</b> everyone agrees that <b>it is nothing,</b> i.e., it is not an independent animal and its fat is not included in the prohibition of forbidden fats. <b>When they disagree</b> it is with regard to a case <b>where</b> one <b>inserted his hand into the womb of an animal and removed the fat of a live nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus <b>and ate</b> it. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Its fat is like the fat of</b> any other <b>domesticated animal,</b> as the <b>months</b> of gestation alone <b>cause</b> it to be regarded as an independent animal. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Its fat is like the fat of an undomesticated animal,</b> as it is the <b>months</b> of gestation <b>and</b> its exit through the <b>airspace</b> of the opening of the womb that together <b>cause</b> it to be regarded as an independent animal. Since this fetus was not yet born, it is not subject to the prohibition of forbidden fats.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> from a <i>baraita</i> that discusses the sacrifice of the fat surrounding a fetus inside a pregnant animal: <b>Just</b> as with regard to the requirement to sacrifice <b>the fat and two kidneys</b> (see Leviticus 7:3–4), <b>which is stated with regard to a guilt offering,</b> the fat of <b>a fetus is excluded from the category</b> of fats that one is required to sacrifice because a guilt offering is always a male, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>every</b> offering, even in the case of a female offering, the fat of <b>a fetus is excluded from the category</b> of fats that one is required to sacrifice.
Rabbi Yoḥanan explains his objection: <b>Granted, according to my</b> opinion that the fat of a fetus is forbidden for consumption, <b>this is why a verse was necessary to exclude</b> it from being sacrificed on the altar. <b>But according to your</b> opinion that it is not forbidden, <b>why is</b> a verse <b>necessary</b> to exclude it? Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>said to him: My explanation is also</b> derived <b>from</b> the verse <b>here,</b> which serves as the source for the fact that the fat of a fetus is not forbidden.
<b>And some say</b> that there is another version of this objection in which <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raised</b> an <b>objection to Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> from that <i>baraita</i>: <b>Just</b> as with regard to the requirement to sacrifice <b>“the fat and two kidneys” that is stated with regard to a guilt offering,</b> the fat of <b>a fetus is excluded from the category</b> of fats that one is required to sacrifice, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>every</b> offering, the fat of <b>a fetus is excluded from the category</b> of fats that one is required to sacrifice.
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish explains the objection: <b>Granted, according to my</b> opinion that the fat of the fetus is not prohibited like the other fats, it is <b>due to that</b> reason that <b>the Merciful One excludes it</b> from the requirement of being sacrificed. <b>But according to your</b> opinion, that the fat of the fetus is considered one of the forbidden fats, <b>let it</b> also <b>be sacrificed.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> The reason that this fat is not sacrificed is <b>just as it is</b> with regard to an offering <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived, i.e., it is not yet seven days old, which may not be sacrificed (see Leviticus 22:27) despite being of a species of animal that may be sacrificed. Similarly, with regard to the fat of the fetus, despite being included among those fats that are prohibited, it may not be sacrificed.
§ The Gemara returns to the dispute in the mishna with regard to a nine-month-old fetus found alive inside its slaughtered mother. Rabbi Meir holds that the fetus itself must be slaughtered in order to permit it, whereas the Rabbis hold that it is permitted by virtue of the slaughter of its mother. <b>Rabbi Ami said:</b> With regard to <b>one who slaughtered a <i>tereifa</i> and found inside it a live nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus: <b>According to the statement of</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>who prohibits</b> a nine-month-old fetus found inside a kosher animal until it is slaughtered itself, if it is found inside a <i>tereifa</i> <b>he permits</b> the fetus once it is slaughtered itself. But <b>according to the statement</b> of Rabbi Yehuda, referred to as the Rabbis in the mishna, <b>who permits</b> a nine-month-old fetus found inside a kosher animal by virtue of the slaughter of its mother, if it is found inside a <i>tereifa</i> <b>he prohibits</b> it, even if it is slaughtered itself.
<b>Rava said: According to the statement of</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>who permits</b> a nine-month-old fetus found inside a kosher animal by virtue of the slaughter of its mother, he <b>also permits</b> it if it is found inside a <i>tereifa</i>, once the fetus itself is slaughtered. The reason is that <b>the Merciful One considers four <i>simanim</i> to be fit</b> for slaughter, i.e., the windpipe and gullet of the mother and those of the fetus, with the fetus being permitted by the cutting of either pair.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> With regard to <b>one who slaughtered a <i>tereifa</i> and found inside it a live nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus,

Daf 75b

the fetus <b>requires</b> its own <b>slaughter</b> to permit its consumption, <b>and it is subject to the obligation to</b> give <b>the foreleg and the jaw and the maw</b> to a priest, as is required for a non-sacred animal that is slaughtered. <b>But</b> nevertheless, <b>if it dies,</b> the fact that its mother was slaughtered serves to render it <b>pure with regard to imparting impurity</b> to people <b>through</b> their <b>carrying</b> of it, as it does not impart the impurity of a carcass.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: Your ruling is inconsistent. When you say it <b>requires slaughter, in accordance with whose</b> opinion is that? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> that a live nine-month-old fetus is not permitted by virtue of its mother’s slaughter. <b>But</b> when you say that <b>if it dies,</b> it is <b>pure with regard to imparting impurity through carrying, in accordance with whose</b> opinion is that? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
Rav Ḥisda replied: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> the same difficulty arises with <b>that which Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who slaughtered</b> an animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i> and found inside it a live nine-</b>month<b>-old</b> fetus, it <b>requires</b> its own <b>slaughter, and it is subject to the obligation to</b> give <b>the foreleg and the jaw and the maw</b> to a priest. <b>But</b> nevertheless, <b>if it dies,</b> it is <b>pure with regard to imparting impurity through carrying.</b> When he says that it <b>requires slaughter, in accordance with whose</b> opinion is that? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir. But</b> when he says that <b>if it dies,</b> it is <b>pure with regard to imparting impurity through carrying,</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
Rava responded: <b>That</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as it is possible that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya was speaking</b> about <b>if one found</b> that the fetus <b>had already died</b> inside the mother. In such a case, Rabbi Meir concedes that its mother’s slaughter renders it pure, as stated in the mishna. Accordingly, the <i>baraita</i> is entirely in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir. <b>But according to your</b> opinion, that even if it was found alive and died later it is pure from the impurity of a carcass, it is <b>difficult.</b>
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rava: <b>According to my</b> opinion <b>also</b> it is <b>not difficult,</b> as I claim that the entire <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, and although the slaughter of its mother permits the fetus, its own slaughter can also permit it, as <b>the Merciful One considers four <i>simanim</i> to be fit</b> for slaughter, two of the mother and two of the fetus, the fetus being permitted through the cutting of either pair.
The Gemara relates: <b>When Rabbi Zeira ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>Rav Asi found him sitting and saying this <i>halakha</i></b> of Rav Ḥisda, i.e., that the Merciful One considers four <i>simanim</i> to be fit for slaughter. Rav Asi <b>said to him: That is correct, and so says Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> Rabbi Zeira asked him: Can I conclude <b>by inference</b> from your statement <b>that Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s colleague, <b>disagrees with him?</b>
Rav Asi answered: I do not know, as after Rabbi Yoḥanan made his statement, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>was waiting for him</b> to see if he would retract, <b>and</b> he therefore <b>remained silent</b> about whether or not he disagreed. But it is possible that after I left, he disagreed. <b>And some say</b> that Rav Asi said: At that time, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>was drinking, and</b> that is why he <b>remained silent.</b> Therefore, I do not know whether or not he disagreed.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri says: Even</b> if a nine-month-old fetus emerged alive and is now five years old and plowing in the field it does not require slaughter. The Gemara asks: This opinion of Rabbi Shimon Shezuri <b>is</b> identical to that of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., the Rabbis. What difference is there between them? <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> The difference <b>between them</b> is a case where the fetus <b>stood upon the ground.</b> According to the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>, once the fetus walks on the ground there is a rabbinic decree requiring that it be slaughtered before it is consumed, lest people mistakenly permit other animals without slaughter. Rabbi Shimon Shezuri disagrees and holds that it does not require slaughter.
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya said: According to the statement of the one who says</b> that when defining the status of an animal <b>one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity,</b> if <b>a <i>ben pekua</i> copulated with a full-fledged animal, the offspring has no rectification.</b> Although when the mother and father are each a <i>ben pekua</i> the offspring is permitted without ritual slaughter, if the father is a <i>ben pekua</i> but the mother is not, the offspring is simultaneously defined as requiring slaughter, based on the mother, and being excluded from the requirement for slaughter, based on the father. Therefore, no act of slaughter can permit it.
<b>Abaye says: Everyone,</b> i.e., even the first <i>tanna</i>, who requires the slaughter of a <i>ben pekua</i> that stood upon the ground, <b>agrees with regard to a <i>ben pekua</i></b> with <b>non-cloven</b> hooves that was found inside a kosher animal, <b>that it is permitted</b> by virtue of the slaughter of its mother. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is that <b>people remember any bizarre matter,</b> and there is no concern that if it is permitted without slaughter, people will mistakenly permit regular animals without slaughter. <b>Some say</b> that <b>Abaye said: Everyone agrees with regard to a <i>ben pekua</i></b> with <b>non-cloven</b> hooves found inside an animal with <b>non-cloven</b> hooves that was itself born to a kosher animal, <b>that</b> the fetus <b>is permitted</b> without slaughter even if it stood on the ground. <b>What is the reason?</b> It is that <b>people remember two bizarre matters.</b>
<b>Ze’eiri says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Shezuri</b> that a <i>ben pekua</i> is permitted without slaughter even if it stood upon the ground. <b>And similarly, Rabbi Shimon Shezuri would permit</b> without slaughter <b>the offspring</b> of a <i>ben pekua</i> <b>and the offspring of its offspring,</b> and so on <b>to the end of all</b> future <b>generations. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: It,</b> the <i>ben pekua</i> itself, <b>is permitted, but its offspring is prohibited</b> unless it is slaughtered.
The Gemara relates: <b>Adda bar Ḥavu had a <i>ben pekua</i> that was attacked by a bear</b> and was about to die. <b>He came before Rav Ashi</b> to inquire what to do. Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Go</b> and <b>slaughter it</b> before it dies so that you can eat it, in accordance with the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i> that if a <i>ben pekua</i> stood upon the ground it requires slaughter. Adda bar Ḥavu <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>But doesn’t Ze’eiri say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri</b> that a <i>ben pekua</i> is permitted without slaughter even if it stood upon the ground, <b>and similarly, Rabbi Shimon Shezuri would permit</b> without slaughter <b>the offspring</b> of a <i>ben pekua</i> <b>and the offspring of its offspring,</b> and so on <b>to the end of all</b> future <b>generations? And even Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who disagreed, <b>said</b> his dissenting opinion <b>only</b> with regard to <b>its offspring, but</b> with regard to a <i>ben pekua</i> <b>itself,</b> he did <b>not</b> disagree that it is permitted.
Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Adda bar Ḥavu: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan was speaking according to the statement of Rabbi Shimon Shezuri,</b> i.e., he said that even Rabbi Shimon Shezuri permits only a <i>ben pekua</i> itself, but not its offspring. But Rabbi Yoḥanan himself agrees with the first <i>tanna</i> that a <i>ben pekua</i> that stood upon the ground is prohibited without slaughter.
Adda bar Ḥavu persisted: <b>But didn’t Ravin bar Ḥanina say</b> that <b>Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says</b> with regard to a different issue: The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri; and moreover,</b> not only is the <i>halakha</i> in accordance with his opinion with regard to this matter, but in <b>any place where Rabbi Shimon Shezuri taught</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>in our Mishna,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with his</b> opinion?
Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Adda bar Ḥavu: <b>I hold in accordance with this</b> statement of Rabbi Yonatan, <b>as Rabbi Yonatan says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon Shezuri in</b> the case of one who is <b>dangerously ill, and in</b> the case of <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe of doubtfully tithed produce [<i>demai</i>],</b> but not in other cases, e.g., in the case of his disagreement with the first <i>tanna</i> concerning a <i>ben pekua</i>.
The Gemara now elaborates on these two cases. The case of one who is <b>dangerously ill</b> is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>gittin</i> 65b): <b>Initially,</b> the Sages <b>would say</b> that in the case of <b>one who is taken out in a neck chain [<i>bekolar</i>]</b> to be executed <b>and</b> who <b>said: Write a bill of divorce for my wife, these</b> people who hear <b>should write</b> the document <b>and give</b> it to her. Although there was no explicit instruction to give it to her, this is understood to have been his intention, in order to release her from the obligation to perform levirate marriage or the ritual through which she becomes free of her levirate bonds [<i>ḥalitza</i>]. <b>They then said</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> to <b>one who sets sail and one who departs in a caravan</b> to a distant place. A bill of divorce is given to his wife under these circumstances even if her husband said only: Write a bill of divorce for my wife. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Shezuri says: Even</b> in the case of <b>one who is dangerously ill</b> who gives that instruction, they write the bill of divorce and give it to his wife.
The case of <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe of <i>demai</i></b> is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Demai</i> 4:1): With regard to <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe of <i>demai</i>,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i> of the tithe that was separated from the produce of an <i>am ha’aretz</i>, who is suspected of not separating tithes properly, <b>that</b> fell and <b>returned to its</b> original <b>place,</b> becoming mingled with the rest of produce from which it had been separated, <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Shezuri says: Even on a weekday one may ask</b> the <i>am ha’aretz</i> whether or not he separated the necessary tithes <b>and</b> then <b>eat based on his statement.</b>

Daf 76a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>an animal whose hind legs were severed,</b> if they were severed <b>from the leg joint and below,</b> the animal is <b>kosher; from the leg joint and above,</b> the animal is thereby rendered a <i>tereifa</i> and is <b>not kosher. And likewise,</b> an animal <b>whose convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh <b>was removed</b> is a <i>tereifa</i> and is not kosher.
If <b>the bone</b> of a limb <b>was broken</b> but the limb was not completely severed, and the animal was then slaughtered, <b>if the majority of the flesh</b> surrounding the bone <b>is intact, the slaughter of</b> the animal <b>renders it permitted; but if not, its slaughter does not render it permitted.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya says:</b> When the mishna makes reference to the leg being severed from the leg joint and <b>below,</b> it means that the cut was <b>below the leg joint,</b> and when it says that if it was severed from the leg joint and <b>above</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>it means</b> that the cut was <b>above the leg joint.</b> And <b>with regard to which leg joint did they say</b> this? <b>With regard to</b> the <b>leg joint that is sold together with the head</b> of the animal. This is the lower leg joint that connects the lower bone, or metatarsus, and middle bone, or tibia. Accordingly, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> only if the leg was severed in the middle bone or upper bone.
<b>Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya</b> says: The mishna is referring to the leg joint that in most animals cannot be seen from the outside, but <b>the corresponding</b> joint <b>in</b> the leg of <b>a camel</b> is prominent and <b>conspicuous.</b> This is referring to the joint between the upper bone, or femur, and middle bone, or tibia. Accordingly, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i> only if it was severed in the upper bone.
<b>Ulla said to Rav Yehuda: Granted, according to my</b> opinion, <b>as I say</b> it means the joint whose <b>corresponding</b> joint <b>in</b> the leg of a camel is <b>conspicuous,</b> i.e., the upper joint, <b>this</b> explanation is consistent with <b>that which</b> the mishna <b>teaches: And likewise,</b> an animal <b>whose convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh <b>was removed</b> is not kosher. The convergence of sinews lies on the lower part of the middle bone. Since I hold that if the middle bone is severed, this does not render the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, it is necessary for the mishna to teach that nevertheless, if that bone was severed at the point of the convergence of sinews, this would render it a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>But according to your</b> opinion that the mishna is referring to the lower joint, and if the middle bone is severed, this renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>what</b> is the purpose of teaching: <b>And likewise,</b> an animal <b>whose convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh <b>was removed</b> is not kosher?
Rav Yehuda <b>said to</b> Ulla: According to my opinion, the mishna is referring to two cases: The first is where the leg was severed above the lower <b>leg joint,</b> in the middle bone, <b>without</b> the removal of <b>the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh, <b>and</b> the second is where <b>the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh was removed <b>without</b> the leg above the <b>leg joint</b> being severed. Ulla then asked Rav Yehuda: <b>But</b> the mishna <b>teaches: Were severed,</b> indicating that the leg was entirely severed, which perforce includes the convergence of sinews. Rav Yehuda <b>was silent,</b> as he did not have a resolution.
<b>After</b> Ulla <b>left,</b> Rav Yehuda <b>said</b> to himself: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>I did not say to him</b> the following resolution: When the mishna states that if the leg was severed <b>below</b> the leg joint the animal is kosher, it means <b>below the</b> lower <b>leg joint,</b> and when it says that if it was severed <b>above</b> it is a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>it means</b> in the middle bone above <b>the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh. Accordingly, it would still be necessary to teach that if the convergence of sinews in the thigh was removed, this would render it a <i>tereifa</i>.
Rav Yehuda <b>then said</b> to himself: It is good that I did not suggest this resolution, as <b>did I not</b> initially <b>say</b> a resolution <b>to him, and he said to me</b> that it was refuted by the fact that the mishna <b>teaches: Were severed,</b> which clearly indicates that it was severed completely? <b>Here too,</b> he could have said: You cannot explain the mishna as referring only to severing the leg above the convergence of sinews, as the mishna <b>teaches: From the</b> lower <b>leg joint and above,</b> which clearly includes the entire middle bone, including the area of the convergence of sinews.
<b>Rav Pappa teaches</b> the previous discussion <b>like this: Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya says:</b> When the mishna refers to severing the leg <b>below,</b> it means severing <b>below</b> both <b>the leg joint and the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh, i.e., the lower bone was severed, and when it refers to severing the leg <b>above,</b> it means severing <b>above</b> both <b>the leg joint and the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh, i.e., the upper bone was severed. <b>And</b> then the mishna adds that with regard to the middle bone, it is only a <i>tereifa</i> <b>when</b> the <b>convergence of sinews was removed.</b> And this explanation assumes that <b>the leg joint itself</b> is referring to the upper leg joint, <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Ulla said</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya</b> said, i.e., that it means the joint whose corresponding joint in the leg of a camel is conspicuous.
The Gemara questions Rav Pappa’s explanation of the opinions of Ulla and Rav Yehuda: <b>But is there any</b> possibility <b>that if one went higher up</b> the leg and <b>severed</b> the middle bone above the convergence of sinews, <b>it would live,</b> i.e., the animal would not be a <i>tereifa</i>, but if <b>one went down</b> the leg and <b>severed it</b> on the convergence of sinews, it would be a <i>tereifa</i> <b>and would die</b> within twelve months? It is illogical that severing more of the leg is less life-threatening for the animal.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Are you comparing</b> different types of <b><i>tereifot</i> to one another? One cannot say with regard to <i>tereifot</i></b> that <b>this is similar to that, as</b> different areas of an animal’s body react differently: One <b>cuts it from here,</b> at a low point on the animal’s body, <b>and it</b> could <b>die;</b> and one <b>cuts it from there,</b> at a higher point, <b>and it</b> could <b>live.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: <b>And which</b> parts are included in <b>the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh, such that if they are removed it renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>? The sinews at the bottom of the bone cleave to it, as there is no flesh on that part of the bone. A short distance above that they separate from the bone and then they diverge from each other as they enter the flesh. <b>Rabba says</b> that <b>Rav Ashi</b> says: Those <b>which are off the bone,</b> before they diverge. <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav Ashi</b> says: Those <b>which are adjacent to the bone. Rava, son of Rabba bar Rav Huna, says</b> that <b>Rav Asi</b> says: The convergence of sinews begins even lower and includes those <b>which are above the <i>arkum</i></b> bone, a small bone that lies between the lower bone and the middle bone of the leg.
The Gemara relates: <b>One of the Sages sat before Rabbi Abba, and he sat and said:</b> The convergence of sinews includes the sinews <b>of the <i>arkum</i></b> bone <b>itself. Rabbi Abba said to</b> his students: <b>Do not listen to</b> that Sage, as his ruling is too stringent. <b>This</b> is what <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> It is in the place <b>where butchers split open</b> the animal’s leg. The Gemara comments: <b>And this is</b> the same as that which <b>Rava, son of Rabba bar Rav Huna,</b> says that <b>Rav Asi says,</b> i.e., that it includes the sinews above the <i>arkum</i>.
<b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: The convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh <b>that they spoke</b> of in the mishna is the <b>place where the sinews converge</b> and appear as though they are a single entity. The Gemara asks: <b>And until how far</b> does it extend? <b>One of the Sages, and his name is Rav Ya’akov, said to them: When we were</b> studying <b>in the school of Rav Yehuda, he said to us: Hear from me a matter that I heard from a great man, and who is he? Shmuel. The convergence of sinews that they spoke</b> of is the <b>place where the sinews converge, and</b> it extends <b>from</b> the <b>place where they converge until</b> the <b>place where they diverge</b> and are subsumed within the flesh.
The Gemara asks: <b>And how far</b> is this? <b>Abaye said: Four handbreadths in an ox.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the measure <b>in a small domesticated animal? Abaye said:</b> There is no set measure; rather, as long as the sinews are <b>prominent</b> and are not subsumed within the flesh, <b>they are</b> part of <b>the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh, but once they are <b>subsumed they are not</b> considered part of <b>the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh.
Abaye adds: The sinews that are <b>hard are</b> part of <b>the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh; those that are <b>soft are not</b> part of <b>the convergence of sinews.</b> Those that are <b>thick are</b> part of <b>the convergence of sinews;</b> those that are <b>thin are not</b> part of <b>the convergence of sinews.</b> Those that are <b>white are</b> part of <b>the convergence of sinews;</b> those that are <b>not white are not</b> part of <b>the convergence of sinews.</b>

Daf 76b

<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said: Once</b> the sinews begin to be <b>translucent, even if they are not</b> actually <b>white,</b> they are considered part of the convergence of sinews.
§ With regard to the removal of the convergence of sinews in the thigh, which renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>Ameimar says in the name of Rav Zevid: There are three strands,</b> i.e., sinews; <b>one</b> is <b>thick and</b> the other <b>two</b> are <b>thin.</b> If the <b>thick</b> sinew <b>was severed, a majority of the structure</b> of the convergence of sinews <b>is gone,</b> as the thick sinew is thicker than the other two combined. If <b>the thin ones were severed,</b> then <b>a majority of the number</b> of sinews <b>is gone.</b> If either type of majority has been severed, the animal is rendered a <i>tereifa</i>. Conversely, <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi teaches a lenient</b> version of this ruling: If the <b>thick</b> sinew <b>was severed,</b> since <b>there is a majority</b> of the <b>number</b> of sinews that remains, the animal is not a <i>tereifa</i>. Likewise, if <b>the thin ones were severed,</b> since <b>there is a majority of the structure</b> that remains intact, the animal is not a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara comments: All this applies to animals, whereas <b>with regard to birds, there are sixteen strands; if</b> even <b>one of them is severed,</b> it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. Mar bar Rav Ashi said: I was standing before father,</b> i.e., Rav Ashi, <b>and they brought before him a bird, and he examined</b> it to see if it was a <i>tereifa</i> <b>and found fifteen</b> sinews. <b>There was one</b> of them <b>that was different from the others; he broke it apart and it was found</b> to be composed of <b>two</b> sinews.
