The Gemara returns to the issue of the convergence of sinews in an animal. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: The convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh of <b>which</b> the Sages <b>spoke,</b> stating that if it is severed the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, is referring <b>to</b> the severing of <b>the majority of it.</b> Rav Yehuda added: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>the majority of it?</b> This means <b>the majority of one of</b> the sinews. Rav Yehuda further stated: <b>When I stated this</b> <i>halakha</i> in the name of Rav <b>before Shmuel, he said to me: Since they are three</b> sinews, <b>when one of them is severed entirely, there are</b> still <b>two</b> remaining, which means that the majority of the convergence of sinews is intact. Therefore, the animal is still kosher.
The Gemara infers from Shmuel’s statement: The <b>reason</b> the animal is not a <i>tereifa</i> is only that <b>there are two</b> remaining, from which it may be inferred that if <b>there are not two</b> remaining it is <b>not</b> kosher, despite the fact that the other sinew is intact. The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> according to this version of his opinion, Shmuel <b>disagrees with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbenai,</b> who also stated his ruling in Shmuel’s name. <b>As Rabbenai says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh, <b>even if only</b> one sinew <b>remains of it,</b> which is as thick <b>as</b> the <b>string</b> used to close the neckline of <b>a cloak [<i>hasarbal</i>],</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b>
<b>And some say</b> that there is a different version of this discussion. Rav Yehuda said: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>a majority of it?</b> This means <b>a majority of each and every one of</b> the sinews. Rav Yehuda added: <b>When I stated this</b> <i>halakha</i> in the name of Rav <b>before Shmuel, he said to me: Since they are three</b> sinews, <b>there is one-third of each and every one,</b> and that should be sufficient. There is no need for a majority of each sinew to remain. The Gemara notes: Rav Yehuda’s statement in the name of Shmuel <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbenai, as Rabbenai says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>the convergence of sinews</b> in the thigh of <b>which</b> the Sages <b>spoke, even if</b> there <b>remains of</b> each of the three sinews <b>only</b> as much <b>as</b> the thickness of the <b>string</b> used to close the neckline of <b>a cloak,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b> This also indicates that there is no need for a majority of the sinew to remain.
§ The mishna states: If <b>the bone</b> of a limb <b>was broken</b> but the limb was not completely severed, and the animal was then slaughtered, if the majority of the flesh surrounding the bone is intact, the slaughter of the animal renders it permitted; but if not, its slaughter does not render it permitted.
<b>Rav says:</b> If the bone was broken <b>above the leg joint</b> and then the animal was slaughtered, <b>if a majority of the flesh</b> around the break <b>is intact,</b> both <b>this,</b> the animal itself, <b>and that,</b> the limb, are <b>permitted.</b> The break does not render the animal a <i>tereifa</i> and the limb is not regarded as a hanging limb; therefore it is permitted by the slaughter of the animal. <b>But if not,</b> i.e., if a majority of the flesh around the break is not intact, both <b>this and that,</b> the animal and the limb, are <b>prohibited.</b> If the bone was broken <b>below the leg joint,</b> then <b>if a majority of the flesh is intact,</b> both <b>this and that</b> are <b>permitted; if not,</b> then the <b>limb</b> itself is <b>prohibited</b> from the area of the break and below, as it is not permitted by the slaughter of the animal, <b>but</b> the rest of the <b>animal is permitted.</b>
<b>And Shmuel says: Whether</b> the break is <b>above or below</b> the leg joint, the <i>halakha</i> is the same: <b>If a majority of the flesh is intact,</b> both <b>this and that,</b> the limb and the animal, are <b>permitted. If</b> the majority of the flesh is <b>not</b> intact, the <b>limb</b> is <b>prohibited and</b> the <b>animal is permitted.</b> Even if the leg was broken above the leg joint the animal does not become a <i>tereifa</i> unless the leg was entirely severed.
<b>Rav Naḥman objects to this</b> ruling <b>of Shmuel:</b> If one permits the animal despite the fact that its leg is prohibited, people <b>will say: A limb from</b> the animal <b>is placed in the garbage,</b> as it is prohibited, <b>and</b> yet the animal itself <b>is permitted?</b> They may then mistakenly conclude that even if that leg had been completely severed from the animal, the animal would be permitted. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav Huna said to Rav Naḥman:</b> This concern <b>also</b> exists <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> in a case where the bone is broken below the joint and the flesh is not intact. Rav rules in that case that the animal is permitted and the limb is prohibited. But is there not the concern that people <b>will say: A limb from</b> this animal <b>is placed in the garbage, and</b> the animal itself <b>is permitted?</b>
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: This is</b> what I meant to <b>say:</b> People will say: <b>A limb from which</b> this animal <b>lives,</b> i.e., which if removed, renders the animal a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>is placed in the garbage, and</b> the animal itself <b>is permitted?</b> The concern exists only according to the opinion of Shmuel, who permits the animal even when the break is above the joint, as were it severed there, the animal would thereby be rendered a <i>tereifa</i>. People may mistakenly equate the case where the bone was broken and the case where it was severed and permit both. The concern does not exist according to the opinion of Rav, as he permits the animal only in a case where the bone is broken below the joint, and even if it were severed there that would not render it a <i>tereifa</i>.
§ With regard to this dispute, <b>they sent</b> a ruling <b>from there,</b> Eretz Yisrael: <b>The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav</b> that if the bone was broken above the leg joint, if a majority of the flesh around the break is not intact, both the animal and the limb are prohibited. <b>They then sent</b> a ruling: The <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel</b> that only the limb is prohibited. <b>They then</b> a ruling: The <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav</b> that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>and</b> they added that the <b>limb itself</b> is not rendered pure by the slaughter; rather, it <b>imparts</b> the <b>impurity</b> of a limb from a living animal <b>by carrying.</b> The animal itself, though, is rendered pure from the impurity of a carcass and is prohibited only as a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rav Ḥisda raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> cited earlier (73a) concerning whether the slaughter of a mother animal can render pure a limb of its fetus that was extended outside the womb even though the act of slaughter cannot render the fetus permitted for consumption. The Rabbis brought proof for their opinion that this limb is rendered pure from the <i>halakha</i> that a <i>tereifa</i> is rendered pure by slaughter even though it is not thereby permitted for consumption. Rabbi Meir responded: <b>No,</b> even <b>if the slaughter of a <i>tereifa</i> renders</b> the animal itself <b>pure, and</b> likewise, the slaughter of any animal renders pure <b>the limb that</b> was partially cut from it but still <b>hangs from it</b> from imparting the impurity of a carcass, despite the fact that this animal or limb is prohibited for consumption, that is so with regard to <b>something that is</b> part <b>of its own body.</b> Does it necessarily follow that <b>it should</b> also <b>render pure the limb</b> of its fetus, which is <b>something that is not</b> part <b>of its own body?</b> It is explicit in Rabbi Meir’s claim that the hanging limb of a <i>tereifa</i> is rendered pure by the slaughter of the animal.
<b>Rabba said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>Why are you searching after refutations</b> from <i>baraitot</i> that are not known by all? You can <b>raise a conclusive refutation from the mishna</b> (127b): With regard to the limb or flesh of an animal that was partially severed but remains hanging from it, if <b>the animal was slaughtered,</b> the limb and the flesh <b>were</b> thereby <b>rendered susceptible</b> to contracting the impurity of food <b>by the blood</b> of the animal, as blood is one of the seven liquids that render foods susceptible to impurity; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Shimon says: They were not rendered susceptible</b> with the blood of the slaughtered animal. It is evident that according to all opinions in the mishna, the hanging limb and flesh are not regarded as a limb or flesh from a living animal, which would not need to be rendered susceptible to impurity, as they impart their own impurity.
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rabba: The difficulty from <b>the mishna can be refuted, as we refuted</b> it earlier (73a), by claiming that the dispute about the blood rendering the animal susceptible to impurity concerns only the hanging flesh, but that a hanging limb from an animal that was slaughtered does have the status of a limb from a living animal and the associated impurity.
The Gemara relates that <b>when Rabbi Zeira ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael <b>he found Rav Yirmeya sitting and saying this <i>halakha</i></b> of Rav, i.e., that if the bone is broken above the leg joint and the flesh is not intact, the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>. Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him:</b> You have spoken <b>well, and Aryokh interpreted</b> the matter <b>likewise in Babylonia.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who is Aryokh?</b> It is <b>Shmuel. But</b> that is difficult, as Shmuel <b>disagrees</b> with Rav concerning this issue. The Gemara explains: <b>Shmuel retracted his</b> opinion <b>in favor of</b> that of <b>Rav.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>the bone broke and protruded outward, if skin and flesh cover a majority of</b> the bone the animal is <b>permitted; if not,</b> it is <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> is <b>a majority of</b> a bone? <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A majority of its width, and some say</b> that he said: <b>A majority of its circumference. Rav Pappa said: Therefore,</b> as there is no clear ruling on the matter, <b>we require</b> that the bone be covered by <b>a majority of its width, and we</b> also <b>require</b> that it be covered by <b>a majority of its circumference.</b>
<b>Ulla said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Skin is like flesh</b> with regard to this issue, i.e., if the flesh has been removed but the skin covers a majority of the bone, the animal is kosher. <b>Rav Naḥman said to Ulla: And let the Master say</b> that <b>skin combines with flesh,</b> i.e., that if flesh and skin together cover a majority of the bone the animal is kosher, <b>as</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the above <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Skin and flesh,</b> which indicates that skin alone is ineffective. Ulla <b>said to him: We learned</b> that the <i>baraita</i> states: <b>Skin or flesh.</b>
<b>Some say</b> that there is a different version of this discussion: <b>Ulla said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Skin combines with flesh. Rav Naḥman said to Ulla: And let the Master say</b> that <b>skin completes</b> the amount of <b>flesh</b> required, and this <b>is a stringent</b> ruling. This would mean that if the majority of the bone is covered mostly with flesh and the rest of the majority is covered with skin the animal is kosher, but if the majority is covered half with flesh and half with skin, it is not kosher.
Ulla <b>said to him: I know</b> my ruling from the following <b>incident: As there was a certain fledgling that was in the house of Rabbi Yitzḥak,</b> and its leg broke, and <b>it was</b> a situation where the <b>skin combined with flesh</b> to cover the majority of the bone. <b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak came before Rabbi Yoḥanan and he deemed</b> the bird <b>kosher.</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: Do you speak</b> of <b>a fledgling?</b> The <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>a fledgling is different, as</b> its skin <b>is soft</b> and is considered like flesh.
The Gemara further relates: There was a case involving <b>certain soft sinews</b> that combined with flesh to cover the majority of a broken bone, and <b>they came before Rabba</b> for a ruling. <b>Rabba said: What concern</b> is there <b>with</b> the sinews in <b>this</b> case? <b>First,</b> there is no concern, <b>because Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> With regard to <b>sinews that will ultimately harden,</b>

Daf 77a

<b>one may be registered</b> as part of a group that will eat the <b>Paschal offering on their account,</b> i.e., even if those sinews are the only part of the lamb he will eat. Evidently, such sinews are regarded as flesh. <b>And furthermore, the Torah spared the money of the Jewish people,</b> and one must tend toward leniency.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Rabba:</b> But <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> disagrees with Rabbi Yoḥanan and holds that one may not be registered for those sinews, as they will eventually harden and are therefore not considered flesh. <b>And</b> therefore, the broken bone in this case is not covered by flesh and the animal is <b>prohibited by Torah law</b> as a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>and</b> yet <b>you say: What concern</b> is there <b>with</b> the sinews in <b>this</b> case? Rabba <b>was silent.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And why was</b> Rabba <b>silent? But doesn’t Rava say</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> in his disputes with Rabbi Yoḥanan only <b>with regard to these three</b> matters, i.e., three matters that are mentioned in <i>Yevamot</i> 36a, and not in other cases? If so, Rabba could simply have replied that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish with regard to this issue.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here,</b> with regard to sinews that will ultimately harden, <b>it is different, as Rabbi Yoḥanan retracted his</b> ruling <b>in favor of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, as</b> when Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raised a difficulty against Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion, Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: Do not provoke me</b> by asking questions to refute my opinion that the fact that the sinews will ultimately harden is disregarded, <b>as I teach it</b> in explanation of <b>a lone opinion</b> (see <i>Pesaḥim</i> 84a). Even Rabbi Yoḥanan conceded that the opinion he expressed was only according to one Sage, but is not the <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain</b> case in <b>which a bone</b> in an animal’s leg <b>broke and protruded outward.</b> This bone was mostly covered with flesh and skin, but <b>a small piece [<i>kurtita</i>]</b> of the bone <b>had been removed from it.</b> The case <b>came before Abaye,</b> who <b>delayed</b> his response until <b>three</b> pilgrimage <b>Festivals</b> had passed, when the Sages gathered together and he could ask them.
<b>Rav Adda bar Mattana said to</b> the owner of the animal: <b>Go before Rava, son of Rav Yosef bar Ḥama, whose knife is sharp,</b> i.e., he has insight into halakhic matters and decides matters quickly, and ask him to decide your case. The owner <b>came before</b> Rava to seek his opinion. Rava <b>said</b> to him: <b>Since we learned</b> in the <i>baraita</i> (76b): If <b>the bone broke and protruded outward,</b> if skin and flesh cover a majority of the bone the animal is permitted, <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if the bone <b>fell</b> out, and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if <b>it is in</b> its place? In either case, the animal is permitted.
With regard to a case where flesh covers the majority of a broken bone, <b>Ravina said to Rava:</b> If the flesh was torn in pieces and spread over the area, and if <b>gathered</b> it would constitute a majority, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Similarly, if the flesh was <b>pulverized</b> and thin, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If it was <b>decomposed, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case in which the flesh is <b>decomposed? Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> This is referring to <b>any</b> kind of flesh <b>that the doctor cuts away [<i>kodro</i>]</b> and removes to enable the surrounding area to heal.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If the flesh that covers the bone <b>was perforated, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Likewise, if the flesh <b>was peeled</b> off the bone, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If it <b>was cracked, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? If <b>the bottom third</b> of the width of the flesh, i.e., the part that is adjacent to the bone, <b>was removed, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear, as Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Skin is like flesh.</b> This would appear to indicate that any covering is sufficient. The Gemara refutes this proof: <b>Perhaps</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan was referring to a specific case where there was never flesh on the bone, but only skin, e.g., adjacent to the knee, where <b>the skin holds its own</b> place close to the bone. This ruling may not apply in an area where there was flesh. Perhaps in such a place the bone must be covered by flesh that is still healthy.
<b>Rav Ashi said: While we were</b> studying <b>in Rav Pappi’s study hall, we raised a dilemma:</b> If the flesh and skin were <b>cut in the shape of a ring</b> around the break, and yet most of the circumference of the bone is surrounded by flesh, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>And we resolved</b> this dilemma <b>from this</b> statement that <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: I asked</b> about <b>this matter to the Sages and to the doctors,</b> what to do when a bone breaks and the surrounding flesh has been cut away, <b>and they said: One makes an incision in it with</b> a sharp piece of <b>bone</b> to help the blood flow and then congeal, <b>and</b> in this manner the wound <b>will heal.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>But</b> one should not make the incision with <b>an iron</b> implement, <b>as it will cause inflammation. Rav Pappa said: And this</b> advice should be implemented only in a case where one can see that <b>the bone is holding</b> firmly onto <b>its</b> flesh, as only in such a case will the flesh heal.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slaughters an animal and finds a placenta in its</b> womb, one with <b>a hearty soul [<i>nefesh hayafa</i>],</b> i.e., who is not repulsed by it, <b>may eat it,</b> as its consumption was permitted by virtue of the slaughter of the mother. Nevertheless, since generally speaking, people do not consume such placentas, it is not regarded as food <b>and</b> so it <b>cannot become impure</b> with <b>the ritual impurity of food</b> even were it to come into contact with a source of impurity. <b>And</b> furthermore, it does <b>not</b> impart <b>the ritual impurity of animal carcasses</b> as it was permitted by virtue of the slaughter of the mother. But if <b>one intended to</b> eat <b>it,</b> one thereby elevated it to the status of food, and the placenta <b>becomes impure</b> with <b>the ritual impurity of food</b> if it comes into contact with a source of impurity. <b>But</b> even so, it still does <b>not</b> impart the <b>ritual impurity of animal carcasses.</b>
With regard to <b>a placenta, part of which emerged</b> from the womb before the mother was slaughtered, its <b>consumption</b> is <b>prohibited</b> even after the mother animal is slaughtered because the emergence of the placenta is <b>an indication of a fetus in a woman and an indication of a fetus in an animal.</b> Accordingly, there is a concern that the head of the fetus might have emerged in that part of the placenta, thereby rendering the fetus as having been born, a status that precludes it from being permitted by the slaughter of its mother. Since the offspring is prohibited, its placenta is likewise prohibited.
If <b>an animal that was giving birth to its firstborn expelled a placenta, one may cast it to the dogs,</b> and one does not need to be concerned that the placenta came from a male fetus that has the consecrated status of a firstborn. <b>But in</b> the case of <b>sacrificial</b> animals the placenta <b>must be buried,</b> because it came from a fetus that is assumed to have been sacred. The mishna adds: <b>But one may neither bury it at an intersection, nor may one hang it on a tree,</b> superstitious rites intended to prevent the animal from miscarrying again, <b>due to</b> the prohibition against following <b>the ways of the Amorite,</b> which prohibits Jews from practicing the superstitious rites observed by gentiles.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the ruling that a placenta is permitted by virtue of the mother’s slaughter, the Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught:</b> “And <b>every</b> animal that parts the hoof, and has the hooves wholly cloven in two, and chews the cud, <b>of the animals, it you may eat”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:6). The verse is the source of the <i>halakha</i> that a fetus is permitted by virtue of the mother’s slaughter (see 69a). The word “every” at the beginning of the verse serves <b>to include the placenta</b> as well as the fetus. One <b>might</b> have thought that a placenta is permitted <b>even if part of it emerged</b> from the womb before slaughter. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “It</b> you may eat,” i.e., you may eat <b>it,</b> the slaughtered animal, <b>but not its placenta,</b> if it partially emerged.
The Gemara objects: <b>Now</b> the assumption is that there is <b>no placenta without a fetus.</b> Therefore, if part of the placenta emerged, there is a concern that the head of the fetus might have emerged in that part of the placenta, thereby rendering the fetus as having been born. Such a status would preclude it from being permitted by the slaughter of its mother. <b>Why do I</b> need a verse to teach this? The Gemara explains: The <b>verse is a mere support</b> for the <i>halakha</i>, but not the source for it.
§ The mishna states: <b>And</b> a placenta found inside a slaughtered animal <b>cannot become impure</b> with the ritual impurity of food and does not impart the ritual impurity of animal carcasses. In a related discussion, <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Nappaḥa raises a dilemma: A donkey hide that one cooked</b> and it became softened, <b>what is</b> its halakhic status? The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> issue did he raise this dilemma? <b>If</b> it was <b>with regard to the ritual impurity of food, we</b> already <b>learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> in a <i>baraita</i>,

Daf 77b

and <b>if</b> you say it was <b>with regard to the ritual impurity of animal carcasses, we</b> already <b>learn</b> that <i>halakha</i> as well in another <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara elaborates: With regard to the <b>ritual impurity of food,</b> it is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The hide and the placenta</b> of an animal, which people do not typically eat, <b>cannot become impure</b> with the <b>ritual impurity of foods.</b> But <b>a hide that one cooked</b> until it became edible <b>and a placenta that one intended</b> to eat <b>can become impure</b> with the <b>impurity of foods.</b>
With regard to <b>the ritual impurity of animal carcasses also, we</b> already <b>learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And when a domesticated animal dies, of those that you eat, one who touches <b>its carcass</b> shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39). The verse indicates that one is rendered impure if he touches its carcass, <b>but not</b> if he touches its <b>hide, and not its bones, and not</b> its <b>sinews, and not</b> its <b>horns, and not</b> its <b>hooves.</b>
<b>And Rabba bar Rav Ḥana said</b> with regard to this <i>baraita</i>: This derivation <b>is necessary only</b> for a case in <b>which one prepared</b> these parts of the animal as a meat <b>pudding [<i>tzikei kedera</i>],</b> in which they are cooked for an extended period and spices are added. One might have thought they would be considered edible flesh and therefore impart the impurity of a carcass. The <i>baraita</i> therefore teaches that this is not so.
Given these two <i>baraitot</i>, why did Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa inquire about the status of the cooked hide of a donkey? The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa was inquiring about <b>the impurity of foods, and</b> although the <i>halakha</i> was already taught in the first <i>baraita</i>, Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa thought it is possible that <b>the hide of a donkey is different, as it is repulsive</b> and perhaps even when cooked it is not regarded as food.
§ The mishna states: With regard to <b>a placenta,</b> part of <b>which emerged</b> from the womb before the mother was slaughtered, its consumption is prohibited, as there is a concern that the head of the fetus might have emerged in that part of the placenta. Commenting on this mishna, <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where there was no fetus</b> found <b>in</b> the mother’s womb. <b>But if there was a fetus</b> with its head and the majority of its body <b>in</b> the womb, <b>one</b> need <b>not be concerned for</b> the existence of <b>another fetus</b> that might have been in the placenta. Therefore, the consumption of the placenta is permitted. <b>But Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Whether there was no fetus</b> found <b>in</b> the womb, or <b>whether there was a fetus, one</b> needs to <b>be concerned for</b> the existence of <b>another fetus</b> in the placenta, and therefore its consumption is prohibited.
According to the way the Gemara records the dispute, Rabbi Yoḥanan rules stringently and Rabbi Elazar rules leniently. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But doesn’t Rabbi Yirmeya say</b> concerning this dispute: <b>Rabbi Elazar said</b> an explanation of the mishna that presents <b>a stringency?</b>
<b>Rather, if it was stated, it was stated like this: Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The ruling of the mishna is that the placenta is prohibited even if a fetus is found inside the womb. But the Sages <b>taught</b> this <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the placenta <b>is not attached to</b> the <b>fetus</b> found inside. Consequently, one must be concerned with the possibility that the placenta came from another fetus that already left the womb, and it is therefore prohibited. <b>But if it is attached to</b> the <b>fetus</b> found inside, <b>there is no concern for</b> the possibility that the placenta came from <b>another fetus,</b> and therefore it is permitted.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In my understanding of the mishna, <b>we have</b> the ruling that the placenta is prohibited <b>only</b> in a case where there is <b>a placenta without</b> any <b>fetus</b> being found. <b>But if a fetus was</b> found <b>with it,</b> then <b>whether it is attached to the fetus</b> or <b>whether it is not attached to the fetus, there is no concern for</b> the existence of <b>another fetus.</b> The Gemara confirms: <b>And this</b> understanding of the two opinions <b>is</b> in line with that which <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says: Rabbi Elazar said</b> an explanation of the mishna that presents <b>a stringency.</b>
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar:</b> The periods of purity and impurity observed by a woman after giving birth apply only after delivering a fetus with a human form. With regard to a woman <b>who expels</b> a fetus that has the form of <b>a type of domesticated animal, undomesticated animal, or bird, and</b> there is <b>a placenta with them,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: <b>When</b> the placenta is <b>attached to them, there is no concern for</b> the existence of <b>another fetus</b> that may have had a human form. But if the placenta is <b>not attached to them,</b> it is possible there was another fetus that had a human form and so <b>I</b> must <b>impose upon</b> the woman <b>the severity of two</b> types of <b>births,</b> i.e., both the longer period of impurity observed after delivering a female, and the shorter period of purity observed after delivering a male.
The reason is <b>that I</b> can <b>say:</b> Perhaps the placenta that was found did not come from the fetus that was found, but from a fetus with a human form. To say this one must be concerned with the possibility that <b>perhaps</b> the <b>fetus of</b> the <b>placenta</b> that was found had a human form, and that fetus <b>dissolved,</b> and <b>perhaps</b> the <b>placenta of</b> the <b>fetus</b> that was found <b>dissolved.</b>
§ The mishna states: If <b>an animal that was giving birth to its firstborn expelled</b> a placenta, one may cast it to the dogs. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this ruling? <b>Rav Ika, son of Rav Ami, said: The majority of domesticated animals give birth to something that</b> can be <b>consecrated</b> with <b>firstborn status,</b> i.e., an animal with the same form as its mother, <b>but a minority of animals</b> give birth to <b>something that cannot</b> be consecrated with <b>firstborn status, and what is this?</b> It is an animal that <b>resembles</b> a species other than that of its mother.
<b>And</b> furthermore, with regard to <b>all gestating</b> animals, when they <b>give birth, half</b> of their offspring are <b>male and half</b> are <b>female.</b> Therefore, one can <b>combine the minority</b> of animals that <b>resemble</b> another species <b>with the half</b> that are <b>females, and</b> arrive at the conclusion that <b>male</b> offspring that resemble their species, which are the only offspring that can be consecrated with firstborn status, <b>are the minority.</b> Accordingly, one does not need to be concerned that the placenta found was from an animal consecrated with the status of a firstborn.
§ The continuation of the mishna states: <b>But in</b> the case of <b>sacrificial</b> animals the placenta <b>must be buried,</b> because it came from a fetus that is assumed to have been sacred. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> to assume this? The Gemara answers: It is because the <b>majority</b> of the offspring of sacrificial animals <b>are fit to be sacred,</b> as, in contrast to firstborn status, both female and male offspring of sacrificial animals can be sacred. Therefore, one must be concerned that the offspring, and its placenta, were sacred.
§ The mishna adds: <b>But one may neither bury it</b> at an intersection, nor may one hang it on a tree, due to the prohibition against following the ways of the Amorite. The Gemara cites <b>Abaye and Rava, who both said: Anything that has</b> an apparently effective <b>medicinal</b> purpose or any other logical reason behind it <b>is not subject to</b> the prohibition against following <b>the ways of the Amorite.</b> But if <b>it does not have</b> an apparently effective <b>medicinal</b> purpose <b>it is subject to</b> the prohibition against following <b>the ways of the Amorite.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If there is <b>a tree that sheds its fruit</b> prematurely, <b>one may paint it with red paint and load it with stones,</b> even though this is the practice of the Amorites? The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>Granted,</b> it is permitted <b>to load it with stones,</b> as one does so for a logical reason, <b>in order</b>

Daf 78a

<b>that</b> the tree’s <b>strength will lessen.</b> It is possible that the tree shed its fruits prematurely due to excessive blossoming. It taxes the tree to sustain these blossoms, and this may render the tree incapable of sustaining the fruits that subsequently grow from the blossoms. Stones were used to weaken the tree during blossoming, thereby reducing the number of blossoms that it needed to nourish. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>painting it with red paint, for what</b> benefit is it performed that makes it permitted despite the fact that this was the practice of the Amorites? The Gemara explains: One does so <b>in order that people will see</b> the tree <b>and pray for it.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is derived from the verse: <b>“And he will cry: Impure, impure”</b> (Leviticus 13:45), that a leper must publicize the fact that he is ritually impure. <b>He must announce</b> his pain <b>to the masses, and the masses will pray for mercy on his behalf. And likewise, one to whom</b> any unfortunate <b>matter happens must announce</b> it <b>to the masses, and</b> then <b>the masses will pray for mercy on his behalf.</b>
<b>Ravina said: In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>do we hang bunches of</b> unripe <b>dates on a palm tree</b> that casts off its dates, despite the fact that this is the practice of the Amorites? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i> just cited, who states that one must announce such occurrences to the masses so that they will pray for mercy.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The prohibition against slaughtering an animal <b>itself and its offspring applies both in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, both <b>in the presence,</b> i.e., the time, <b>of the Temple and not in the presence of the Temple,</b> and it applies <b>with regard to non-sacred</b> animals <b>and with regard to sacrificial</b> animals.
<b>How so?</b> In the case of <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal <b>itself and its offspring,</b> both of which are <b>non-sacred,</b> and slaughters them <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>both of</b> the animals <b>are fit</b> for consumption, <b>but</b> for slaughtering <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs [<i>sofeg</i>] the forty</b> lashes for violating the prohibition: “You shall not slaughter it and its offspring both in one day” (Leviticus 22:28).
If both animals were <b>sacrificial</b> animals slaughtered <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>then</b> for slaughtering <b>the first</b> animal, <b>one is liable</b> to receive <b>excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>].</b> For slaughtering the second animal one is not liable to receive <i>karet</i>. The second animal was not fit for sacrifice, since one may not slaughter an animal and its offspring on the same day. <b>And both</b> animals <b>are disqualified</b> for use as offerings, <b>and</b> for the slaughter of <b>both of them, one incurs forty</b> lashes apiece: The first being a sacrificial animal slaughtered outside the courtyard and the second being the offspring of an animal slaughtered that day.
If both animals were <b>non-sacred and</b> slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>both of them are unfit</b> to be sacrificed, being non-sacred animals slaughtered in the courtyard. <b>And</b> for slaughter of <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs the forty</b> lashes for slaughtering an animal and its offspring on a single day. If both animals were <b>sacrificial</b> animals slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>the first is fit</b> for sacrifice, <b>and</b> one who slaughters it is <b>exempt</b> from any punishment. <b>But</b> for slaughter of <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs the forty</b> lashes for slaughtering an animal and its offspring on a single day, <b>and</b> it is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice, because one was not allowed to slaughter it on that day.
If the first animal was <b>non-sacred and</b> the second <b>a sacrificial</b> animal, and both were slaughtered <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>the first is fit</b> for consumption <b>and</b> one who slaughters it is <b>exempt</b> from any punishment. <b>But</b> for slaughtering <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs the forty</b> lashes for slaughtering an animal and its offspring on a single day, <b>and</b> the animal is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice.
If the first animal was <b>a sacrificial</b> animal <b>and</b> the second was <b>non-sacred</b> and both were slaughtered <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, for <b>the first</b> animal, <b>one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i></b> for slaughtering a sacrificial animal outside the courtyard, <b>and</b> the animal is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice. <b>And the second is fit</b> for consumption; <b>and</b> for the slaughter of <b>both of them</b> one <b>incurs forty</b> lashes apiece: The first being a sacrificial animal slaughtered outside the courtyard and the second being the offspring of an animal slaughtered that day.
If the first animal was <b>non-sacred and</b> the second was <b>a sacrificial</b> animal and both were slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>both of them are unfit</b> for sacrifice. <b>And</b> for slaughtering <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs the forty</b> lashes. If the first animal was <b>a sacrificial</b> animal <b>and</b> the second was <b>non-sacred</b> and both were slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>the first is fit</b> for sacrifice <b>and</b> one who slaughters it is <b>exempt</b> from any punishment. <b>And</b> for slaughtering <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs the forty</b> lashes, <b>and</b> the animal is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice, as it is non-sacred.
If both animals were <b>non-sacred,</b> and one slaughters them, the first <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and</b> the second <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>the first is fit</b> for consumption <b>and</b> one who slaughters it is <b>exempt</b> from any punishment. <b>And</b> for slaughtering <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs the forty</b> lashes for slaughtering an animal and its offspring on a single day, <b>and</b> the animal is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice as it is non-sacred.
If both animals were <b>sacrificial</b> animals, and one slaughters them, the first <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and</b> the second <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, for slaughtering <b>the first</b> animal <b>one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>, and</b> for slaughtering <b>both of them one incurs forty</b> lashes apiece. One set of lashes is given because the first was a sacrificial animal slaughtered outside the courtyard, and the second set of lashes is given because the second animal is the offspring of an animal slaughtered that day. <b>And both of them are unfit</b> for sacrifice.
If both animals were <b>non-sacred,</b> and one slaughters them, the first <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and</b> the second <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>the first is unfit</b> for sacrifice, as it is non-sacred, <b>and</b> the one who slaughters it is <b>exempt. And</b> for <b>the second, one incurs the forty</b> lashes <b>and</b> the animal is <b>fit</b> for consumption. If both animals were <b>sacrificial</b> animals, and one slaughters them, the first <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and</b> the second <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>the first is fit</b> for sacrifice <b>and</b> one who slaughters it is <b>exempt. And</b> for <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs the forty</b> lashes, <b>and</b> the animal is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice because its requisite time has not yet arrived.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> the prohibition against slaughtering an animal <b>itself and its offspring</b> in a single day <b>applies to sacrificial</b> animals? It is derived from a verse, <b>as the verse states: “When a bull, or a sheep, or a goat, is born</b>…but from the eighth day and forward it may be accepted for an offering…to the Lord” (Leviticus 22:27), <b>and it is written</b> in the <b>following</b> verse: <b>“And whether it be a bull or a sheep, you shall not slaughter it and its offspring both in one day.”</b> The juxtaposition of the verses <b>teaches with regard to</b> the prohibition against slaughtering an animal <b>itself and its offspring that it applies to sacrificial</b> animals as well.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> since this prohibition is taught in the context of other <i>halakhot</i> of consecrated animals, perhaps <b>I will say: Yes,</b> it applies <b>to sacrificial</b> animals, but it does <b>not</b> apply <b>to non-sacred</b> animals. The Gemara explains: The repetitive phrase “and whether it be <b>a bull</b> or a sheep” in the second verse, when those types of animals, i.e., bulls and sheep, were already mentioned in the first verse, <b>interrupted the topic,</b> clarifying that the second verse is not referring to sacrificial animals.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> if so, <b>I will say: Yes,</b> the prohibition applies <b>to non-sacred</b> animals, but it does <b>not</b> apply <b>to sacrificial</b> animals. The Gemara explains: Since in that verse <b>it is written: “And whether it be a bull</b>…you shall not slaughter it and its offspring,” the conjunction <b>“and” adds</b> the prohibition stated in the second verse <b>to the first matter,</b> including sacrificial animals as well.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If</b> this prohibition also applies to sacrificial animals, perhaps <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals, the offspring of <b>diverse kinds</b> is <b>not</b> included, e.g., the offspring of a ewe and a goat is unfit to be an offering, <b>so too</b> with regard to the prohibition of: <b>A mother and its offspring,</b> the offspring of <b>diverse kinds</b> should <b>not</b> be included, so that in the case of the offspring of a ewe and a goat, it would be permitted to slaughter the mother and offspring on the same day. <b>Why,</b> then, <b>is</b> it <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (see <i>Tosefta</i> 5:1): The prohibition of: <b>A mother and its offspring, applies to</b> the offspring of <b>diverse kinds and to a <i>koy</i>,</b> a kosher animal with characteristics of both domesticated and undomesticated animals?
<b>And additionally,</b> why should the prohibition of: A mother and its offspring, apply to the offspring of diverse kinds? <b>“A sheep,” is written</b> in the verse with regard to that prohibition, <b>and Rava said</b>

Daf 78b

concerning the verse: “These are the animals that you may eat: An ox, a <i>seh</i> of sheep, and a <i>seh</i> of goats” (Deuteronomy 14:4), that <b>this</b> verse <b>establishes a paradigm</b> for other cases: <b>Wherever</b> the word <b><i>seh</i> is stated</b> in the Torah, <b>it</b> serves <b>only to exclude</b> an animal of <b>diverse kinds.</b> The Hebrew word <i>seh</i> denotes either a sheep or a goat. The offspring of diverse kinds, which is neither a sheep nor a goat, does not qualify as a <i>seh</i>. The Gemara answers that with regard to a mother and its offspring, <b>the verse states:</b> “Whether it be a bull <b>or</b> a sheep” (Leviticus 22:28), and the “or” is superfluous there and serves <b>to include</b> the offspring of <b>diverse kinds.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>This</b> word <b>“or” is necessary to separate</b> the prohibitions, <b>as</b> it might <b>enter your mind to say: One is not liable unless he slaughters</b> both <b>a bull and its offspring</b> and <b>a sheep and its offspring</b> in a single day. Therefore, the word “or” <b>teaches us</b> that one is liable for slaughtering either type of animal with its offspring. The Gemara responds: <b>Separating</b> the prohibitions <b>is derived from</b> the use of the words <b>“its offspring”</b> instead of their offspring.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> the word “or” <b>is still necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If it were stated: A bull, and a sheep, and its offspring</b> you shall not slaughter in one day, <b>I would say:</b> One is not liable <b>unless he slaughters a bull, and a sheep, and the offspring</b> of one of them in a single day. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “A bull or a sheep…it and its offspring”</b> (Leviticus 22:28), to teach that one is liable even for slaughtering either of them and its offspring. <b>What, is it not from</b> the word <b>“or”</b> that the <i>baraita</i> <b>derives</b> this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is derived <b>from</b> the word <b>“it,”</b> and the offspring of diverse kinds are included in the prohibition due to the word “or.”
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> cited further in the discussion, <b>for whom</b> the word <b>“it” is superfluous</b> and can be used for this derivation, leaving the word “or” available to include the offspring of diverse kinds; <b>but according to</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya, for whom</b> the word <b>“it” is not superfluous, from where does he</b> derive that one is <b>to separate</b> into two prohibitions slaughtering either a bull with its offspring or a sheep with its offspring? The Gemara answers that there is <b>no need</b> for <b>a verse to separate</b> them into two prohibitions, <b>as</b> Ḥananya <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yonatan.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: From the verse: <b>“A man who curses his father and his mother</b> shall die” (Leviticus 20:9), <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that one is liable if he curses both <b>his father and his mother. From where</b> do I derive that if one curses <b>his father but not his mother,</b> or <b>his mother but not his father,</b> he is liable? The continuation of <b>the verse states: “His father and his mother he has cursed,</b> his blood is upon him.” In the first part of the verse, the word “curses” is in proximity to “his father,” and in the last part of the verse, “cursed” is in proximity to “his mother.” This teaches that the verse is referring to both a case where <b>he cursed</b> only <b>his father</b> and a case where <b>he cursed</b> only <b>his mother;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya.</b> Rabbi Yoshiya maintains that conjunctions are interpreted strictly unless the verse indicates otherwise.
<b>Rabbi Yonatan says:</b> There is no need for this derivation, because the phrase “his father and his mother” <b>indicates</b> that one is liable if he curses <b>both of them together, and it</b> also <b>indicates</b> that he is liable if he curses either <b>one</b> of them <b>on their own, unless the verse specifies</b> that one is liable only if he curses both <b>together.</b> An example of a verse where the Torah specifies that the <i>halakha</i> applies only to the two elements in conjunction is: “You shall not plow with an ox and a donkey together” (Deuteronomy 22:10). According to Rabbi Yonatan, had the verse stated with regard to a mother and its offspring: A bull and a sheep, and not: A bull or a sheep, one would still be liable for slaughtering each with its own offspring independently. Therefore, the word “or” is superfluous, and is utilized by Ḥananya, who agrees with the opinion of Rabbi Yonatan, to include the offspring of diverse kinds in this prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the opinion of <b>Ḥananya, and what</b> is the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> that were mentioned earlier? Their opinions are elucidated <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Despite the fact that the verse is written in the masculine form, the prohibition against slaughtering <b>itself and its offspring</b> in a single day <b>applies to females,</b> i.e., to a mother and its offspring, <b>but</b> it <b>does not apply to males,</b> i.e., a male animal and its offspring. <b>Ḥananya says: It applies both to males and to females.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of the Rabbis,</b> i.e., the first <i>tanna</i>? Their reasoning is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that the prohibition against slaughtering <b>a mother and its offspring would apply both to males and to females.</b> But could one not derive <b>this</b> by <b>logical inference,</b> reaching the opposite conclusion: The Torah <b>rendered one obligated here</b> not to slaughter an animal and its offspring in a single day, <b>and</b> the Torah <b>rendered one obligated with regard to a mother bird with its chicks</b> not to seize them together, but to dispatch the mother. <b>Just as when it rendered one obligated with regard to a mother bird with its chicks,</b> the obligation applies <b>to female</b> birds <b>but not to males,</b> as the verse states: “And the mother sitting on the chicks” (Deuteronomy 22:6), <b>so too, when it rendered one obligated here,</b> with regard to an animal and its offspring, the obligation should apply <b>to female</b> animals, <b>but not to males.</b>
One may respond: <b>No, if you say</b> that this is so <b>with regard to a mother bird with its chicks, for which</b> the Torah <b>did not render prepared</b> ones equivalent <b>to unprepared</b> ones, as the obligation to dispatch the mother bird applies only where one happens to encounter a mother bird with its chicks spontaneously, but not to ones that he keeps in his property, <b>shall you</b> also <b>say</b> that this is so <b>with regard to</b> the prohibition of an animal <b>itself and its offspring,</b> for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>rendered prepared</b> ones equivalent <b>to unprepared</b> ones, prohibiting an animal and its offspring even if they are prepared? If so, the prohibition against slaughtering an animal and its offspring should apply to both males and females.
Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “A bull or a sheep, <b>it</b> and its offspring” (Leviticus 22:28). The superfluous word “it” indicates that this applies to only <b>one</b> parent, <b>but not</b> to <b>two.</b> The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>After the verse separated</b> the parents, rendering the prohibition applicable to only one of them, <b>I merited</b> returning <b>to the logical inference</b> mentioned earlier: The Torah <b>rendered one obligated here</b> not to slaughter an animal and its offspring in a single day, <b>and</b> the Torah <b>rendered one obligated</b> to dispatch the mother <b>with regard to a mother bird with its chicks. Just as when it rendered one obligated with regard to a mother bird with its chicks,</b> the obligation applies <b>to females but not to males, so too, when it rendered one obligated here,</b> the obligation applies <b>to females but not to males.</b>
<b>And if it is your wish to say</b> that one can refute this, that refutation can be countered by the following derivation: The verse states: “It and <b>its offspring”</b> (Leviticus 22:28), indicating that this applies to <b>that</b> parent <b>whose offspring clings to it.</b> This serves to <b>exclude</b> the <b>male</b> parent, <b>whose offspring does not cling to it.</b>
The Gemara asks: To <b>what</b> possible refutation is the expression: <b>If it is your wish to say,</b> referring? The Gemara explains that the possible refutation is: <b>And if you would say</b> that the word <b>“it,”</b> in the verse <b>denotes a male,</b> as it is expressed in the masculine gender in the Hebrew, the response is that the verse also <b>states “its offspring”</b> in that verse, indicating that this applies to <b>that</b> parent <b>whose offspring clings to it.</b> This serves to <b>exclude</b> the <b>male</b> parent, <b>whose offspring does not cling to it.</b>

Daf 79a

<b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya,</b> the reason for his ruling is that <b>it is written “it,” which indicates a male, and it is written “its offspring,”</b> teaching that the prohibition applies to <b>that</b> parent <b>whose offspring clings to it, which indicates a female. Therefore,</b> this prohibition <b>applies to both males and females.</b>
<b>Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya. And Shmuel follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kilayim</i> 8:4): <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to two animals <b>that are born from</b> a female <b>horse, even if the father</b> of one is <b>a donkey</b> and the father of the other is a horse, <b>they are permitted</b> to mate <b>with one another.</b> Since the mothers of both are horses, the offspring are all considered of the same species. <b>But</b> to mate animals <b>that are born from</b> a female <b>donkey with</b> animals <b>that are born from</b> a female <b>horse,</b> even if one animal was born from a male horse and a female donkey and the other was born from a male donkey and a female horse, is <b>prohibited,</b> due to the prohibition of diverse kinds.
<b>And,</b> commenting on that mishna, <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: This is the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, who says: One</b> need <b>not be concerned with its paternity</b> in determining the species of an animal, as the species is determined solely by the mother. <b>But the Rabbis say:</b> The species of an animal is determined according to both its mother and its father. Therefore, <b>all types of mules,</b> regardless of which parent is a horse and which is a donkey, <b>are</b> considered <b>a single</b> species and may mate with each other.
Now, <b>whose</b> opinion is referred to as that of <b>the Rabbis</b> here? <b>It is</b> that of <b>Ḥananya, who says: One</b> needs <b>to be concerned with paternity,</b> as, in his opinion, the prohibition against slaughtering an animal and its offspring applies to a male and its offspring as well. <b>And</b> therefore, with regard to the prohibition of diverse kinds as well, <b>this</b> mule that is <b>the offspring of</b> a female <b>horse and</b> a male <b>donkey, and that</b> mule that is the <b>offspring of</b> a female <b>donkey and</b> a male <b>horse are all a single species.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Is Rabbi Yehuda certain that one</b> need <b>not be concerned with its paternity</b> in determining the species of the offspring, <b>or perhaps he is uncertain</b> whether or not one need be concerned with its paternity? The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>difference?</b>
The Gemara answers: The practical difference is <b>with regard to permitting</b> the mating of <b>the offspring with</b> the species of <b>the mother,</b> e.g., the mating of the offspring of a female horse and a male donkey together with a horse. <b>If you say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda is <b>certain</b> that one need not be concerned with its paternity, then the mating of <b>the offspring with</b> the species of <b>the mother is permitted,</b> as, in this case, they are both considered horses. <b>But if you say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda is <b>uncertain,</b> then the mating of <b>the offspring with</b> the species of <b>the mother is prohibited,</b> as one must be concerned about the species of the father.
<b>What,</b> then, is the answer to the question? The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a possible resolution from the mishna cited earlier: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: All that are born from</b> a female <b>horse, even if the father</b> of one <b>of them</b> is <b>a donkey, are permitted</b> to mate <b>with each other. What are the circumstances</b> here? <b>If we say that the father of this</b> male animal is <b>a donkey, and the father of that</b> female animal, with which the male is to be mated, is <b>a donkey,</b> does it <b>need to be said?</b> Since the mothers of both animals are horses, they are both of exactly the same species and may certainly mate with each other. <b>Rather, is it not that the father of this</b> one is <b>a horse, and the father of that</b> other one is <b>a donkey?</b>
<b>And</b> yet <b>it is taught</b> that <b>they are permitted</b> to mate <b>with each other. Evidently,</b> Rabbi Yehuda is <b>certain</b> that one need not be concerned with its paternity in determining the species of the offspring. If he were uncertain, he would deem their mating prohibited, as the father of one is a horse while the father of the other is a donkey.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> one cannot cite proof from this, as it can be said <b>that actually, the father of this</b> male animal is <b>a donkey, and the father of that</b> female animal is also <b>a donkey. And</b> with regard to <b>that which you say:</b> Does it <b>need to be said</b> that these two may mate? It does need to be said, <b>lest you say: The horse component</b> of the male mule <b>comes</b> and <b>copulates with the donkey component</b> of the female mule, <b>and the donkey component</b> of the male mule <b>copulates</b> specifically <b>with the horse component</b> of the female mule, which would violate the prohibition of diverse kinds. Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda <b>teaches us</b> that they are both of the same species and may mate.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a possible resolution from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>a female mule in heat, one may not mate a horse or a donkey with her,</b> due to the prohibition against crossbreeding diverse kinds of livestock. <b>Rather,</b> one mates her with <b>one of her kind,</b> another mule. <b>And if you say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda is <b>certain</b> that one need not be concerned with its paternity in determining the species of the offspring, then why not <b>mate her with the species of her mother?</b> Evidently, Rabbi Yehuda is uncertain and therefore deems it prohibited to mate her with either a horse or a donkey. The Gemara responds: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where we do not know what the mother’s species is.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Rather,</b> one mates her with <b>one of her kind,</b> indicating that her species is known. The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: One may not mate the species of a horse or the species of a donkey with her, because one does not</b> usually <b>know the species of</b> the mother of a mule that one encounters. The Gemara suggests: <b>But let one check</b> her species <b>by</b> her <b>distinguishing characteristics, as Abaye says:</b> If <b>its voice is deep,</b> it is <b>the offspring of a female donkey;</b> if <b>its voice is shrill,</b> it is <b>the offspring of a female horse. And Rav Pappa says:</b> If <b>its ears are large and its tail is small,</b> it is <b>the offspring of a female donkey;</b> if <b>its ears are small and its tail is large,</b> it is <b>the offspring of a female horse.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a mule who is <b>mute, and</b> whose ears and tail are <b>lopped off,</b> and whose species cannot be determined. Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion cannot be proven from this case.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about it? Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution, <b>as Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, says: All,</b> including Rabbi Yehuda, <b>agree with regard to</b> mating <b>the offspring with</b> the species of <b>its mother that it is prohibited. Conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Yehuda is <b>uncertain.</b> If he were certain that one need not be concerned with its paternity, he would deem mating the offspring with the species of its mother permitted, since the father’s species would not matter. The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from it</b> that this is so.
The Gemara relates with regard to this issue that <b>Rabbi Abba said to his servant: If you bring me mules</b> attached <b>to a wagon [<i>rispak</i>], look for those that are similar to each other</b> in their voices and the sizes of their ears and tails, <b>and bring</b> those <b>for me,</b> in order not to violate the prohibition of diverse kinds. <b>Evidently,</b> Rabbi Abba <b>holds</b> that with regard to the offspring of diverse kinds, <b>one</b> need <b>not be concerned with its paternity,</b> since, as explained earlier, these distinguishing characteristics indicate only the species of the mother.

Daf 79b

<b>And</b> in addition, he holds that these <b>distinguishing characteristics</b> apply <b>by Torah law,</b> such that they may be relied upon to allay concerns of violating even a prohibition that is mandated by Torah law.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (see <i>Tosefta</i> 5:1): The prohibition against slaughtering an animal <b>itself and its offspring applies to</b> the offspring of <b>diverse kinds</b> of animals, such as a goat and a ewe, <b>and to the <i>koy</i>,</b> even though the prohibition does not apply to undomesticated animals. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>a hybrid</b> that <b>results from</b> the mating of <b>a goat and a ewe,</b> the prohibition of <b>a mother and its offspring applies;</b> with regard to <b>a <i>koy</i>,</b> the prohibition of <b>a mother and its offspring does not apply. Rav Ḥisda says: What is the <i>koy</i> about which Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis disagree?</b> It is <b>that which results from</b> the mating of <b>a goat and a doe.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> surrounding the birth of this <i>koy</i>? <b>If we say</b> that it is the result <b>of a goat that mates with a doe, and she gives birth, and one slaughters her and her offspring</b> on the same day, that is difficult: <b>But doesn’t Rav Ḥisda say: All concede in</b> the case where <b>she is a doe and her offspring is a goat,</b> because she mated with a goat, <b>that</b> one who slaughters them both on the same day <b>is exempt</b> from lashes for violating the prohibition of a mother and its offspring? He is exempt because <b>the Merciful One states:</b> “And whether it be a bull or <b>a sheep,</b> you shall not slaughter it <b>and its offspring</b> both in one day” (Leviticus 22:28), indicating that the prohibition applies to a domesticated animal and its offspring, <b>but not</b> to an undomesticated animal and its offspring, such as <b>a doe and its offspring.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps this <i>koy</i> is the product <b>of a deer that mates with a female goat, and she gives birth, and one slaughters her and her offspring</b> on the same day. <b>But doesn’t Rav Ḥisda say: All concede</b> that <b>in</b> the case where <b>she is a goat and her offspring is a deer</b> because she mated with a deer, <b>that</b> one who slaughters them both on the same day <b>is liable?</b> He is liable because <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“A sheep</b>…and its offspring” (Leviticus 22:28), indicating that the prohibition applies to a domesticated animal such as a sheep <b>and its offspring</b> of <b>any</b> species, even if it is an undomesticated animal.
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis is in the case <b>of a goat that mates with a doe, and she gives birth to a female offspring,</b> a <i>koy</i>, <b>and</b> this <b>female offspring gives birth to a male offspring, and one slaughters her and her male offspring</b> on the same day.
<b>The Rabbis hold: One</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity,</b> and therefore the <i>koy</i> is partially a goat due to its father, <b>and</b> the word <b>“sheep”</b> in the verse means that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep,</b> i.e., a domesticated animal, it may not be slaughtered with its offspring in a single day. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer holds: One</b> need <b>not be concerned with its paternity,</b> and the status of the <i>koy</i> is unaffected by the fact that its father is a goat, <b>and</b> therefore, in this case <b>we do not say</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> mentioned in the verse means that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep</b> it may not be slaughtered with its offspring in a single day, as the father’s component is ignored.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let them disagree</b> with regard to any animal of mixed breed <b>about</b> whether <b>one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity,</b> i.e., <b>with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute between Ḥananya and the Rabbis,</b> whether the prohibition against slaughtering an animal and its offspring on the same day also applies to a father and its offspring because one needs to be concerned with an animal’s paternity.
The Gemara responds: <b>If they would disagree</b> only <b>about that</b> issue, <b>I would say:</b> With regard to <b>this</b> issue of a doe mother and a goat father, <b>even the Rabbis concede that we do not say</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> mentioned in the verse means that <b>even</b> if an animal is <b>partially a sheep,</b> i.e., a domesticated animal, it may not be slaughtered with its offspring in a single day. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> teaches us that according to the Rabbis, not only does one need to be concerned with paternity, but the word “sheep” indicates that even if it is partially a sheep, i.e., a domesticated animal, it may not be slaughtered with its offspring.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But that which we learned</b> in a mishna (83b) appears to contradict this: <b>One may not slaughter a <i>koy</i> on a Festival,</b> because covering its blood entails the performance of prohibited labor that is permitted only if there is a definite obligation to do so. <b>And if one slaughtered</b> a <i>koy</i> on a Festival after the fact, <b>one does not cover its blood,</b> as the Sages prohibited transporting soil on a Festival where it is uncertain that a mitzva by Torah law exists.
The Gemara explains the question: <b>What are we dealing with? If we say</b> that we are dealing <b>with a goat who mates with a doe, and she gives birth,</b> then <b>whether according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis or according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, let him slaughter</b> the <i>koy</i> on the Festival <i>ab initio</i> <b>and cover</b> the blood, as the mother of the <i>koy</i> is <b>a deer, and</b> the <i>koy</i> therefore may be termed an undomesticated animal, whose blood requires covering. This should be so <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a deer,</b> i.e., it has an undomesticated animal component from only one parent, since all agree that the offspring’s species derives from its mother.
<b>Rather,</b> we must be dealing <b>with</b> a case of <b>a deer that mates with a female goat, and she gives birth.</b> This, too, is difficult: <b>If</b> the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> that one needs to be concerned with paternity, <b>let him slaughter</b> this <i>koy</i> on the Festival <i>ab initio</i> <b>and cover</b> the blood, as it is partially an undomesticated animal due to its father. <b>If</b> the mishna holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> that one need not be concerned with paternity, <b>let him slaughter</b> the <i>koy</i> on the Festival <i>ab initio</i> <b>and not cover</b> the blood, as it should be considered a domesticated animal, whose blood does not require covering due to its mother who is a goat.
The Gemara concludes that <b>actually</b> this mishna is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, and it is referring to a case <b>of a deer who mates with a female goat, and the Rabbis</b> do not say with certainty that in determining the species of an animal one must be concerned with paternity, but rather the Rabbis <b>are</b> simply <b>uncertain whether one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity or one</b> need <b>not be concerned.</b> Therefore, they rule that one should not slaughter it on a Festival, <i>ab initio</i>, in order to avoid a possible prohibition, and if one did slaughter it, he should not cover the blood, to avoid violating a prohibition in order to perform an uncertain mitzva.
The Gemara infers: <b>And from</b> the fact <b>that the Rabbis are uncertain,</b> and therefore they rule that the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, applies to a <i>koy</i>, it can be inferred that <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who rules that the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, does not apply to a <i>koy</i>, it is <b>obvious</b> that, with regard to a <i>koy</i> resulting from a deer mating with a female goat, one need not be concerned with its paternity at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to this, <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (see <i>Tosefta</i> 9:1) presents a difficulty: The mitzva to give <b>the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw</b> of non-sacred animals to a priest <b>applies</b> both <b>to a <i>koy</i> and to</b> the offspring of <b>diverse kinds</b> of animals. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: A hybrid</b> that <b>results from</b> the mating of <b>a goat and a ewe is obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood given from it; a hybrid that results <b>from a <i>koy</i> is exempt from</b> having <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood given from it.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What</b> type of <i>koy</i> <b>are we dealing with? If we say</b> that we are dealing <b>with a goat who mates with a doe, and she gives birth, granted,</b> this is consistent <b>according</b> to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who deems</b> it <b>exempt</b> from having gifts of the priesthood given from it. As <b>he holds</b> that <b>we do not say</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> (see Deuteronomy 18:3) means that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep</b> one must give gifts of the priesthood from it, as paternity is ignored and this <i>koy</i> is considered solely the offspring of a doe, exempting it from having gifts given from it.
<b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> even if it is <b>granted that they hold</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> means that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep,</b> or any other type of domesticated animal, one is obligated to give gifts of the priesthood from it, why should the owner of this <i>koy</i> be required to give the gifts to a priest? <b>Granted, he does not give</b> the priest <b>half</b> of the gifts, since half of the <i>koy</i>, i.e., the mother’s component, is an undomesticated animal; but with regard to <b>the other half,</b> as well, <b>let him say to</b> the priest: <b>Bring proof that one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity and take</b> that half; otherwise receive nothing.
<b>Rather,</b> we are dealing <b>with</b> the case of <b>a deer who mates with a female goat and she gives birth. Granted,</b> this is consistent <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who say that one is obligated to give gifts of the priesthood from it, as <b>what</b> is meant by: <b>Obligated?</b> It means: It is obligated <b>in half of the gifts,</b> since on its mother’s side the goat component is subject to the obligation to give the gifts, but with regard to the other half of the gifts he can tell the priest: Bring proof that one need not be concerned with paternity, and take it. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who says that one need not be concerned with paternity at all, such that this <i>koy</i> would be considered a domesticated animal like its mother, <b>let</b> the owner <b>be obligated in all of the gifts.</b> Why, then, does Rabbi Eliezer deem him exempt?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it is referring <b>to a deer who mates with a female goat, and she gives birth, and Rabbi Eliezer is also uncertain whether,</b> in determining the species of an animal, <b>one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity or not.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But since</b> the conclusion is <b>that the Rabbis are uncertain and Rabbi Eliezer is uncertain, in what</b> case <b>do they disagree</b> where Rabbi Eliezer deems the owner exempt from giving the gifts entirely?

Daf 80a

They disagree <b>concerning</b> whether the word <b>“sheep”</b> mentioned in the verses indicates that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep,</b> it is considered a domesticated animal. <b>The Rabbis hold</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> indicates that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep</b> it is considered a domesticated animal, <b>and Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> indicates that it must be descended entirely from sheep or other domesticated animals, <b>but not partially</b> descended from <b>sheep.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa says: Therefore,</b> the cases relating to a <i>koy</i> must be interpreted in accordance with this understanding of the disagreement between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis. <b>With regard to the matter of covering the blood</b> of a <i>koy</i>, which the mishna indicates is performed due to uncertainty as to whether a <i>koy</i> is an undomesticated animal, <b>and</b> with regard to <b>the gifts</b> of the priesthood, which the Rabbis require to be given from a <i>koy</i> as from a domesticated animal, but Rabbi Eliezer does not, <b>you find</b> a way to interpret the cases <b>only</b> if they are referring <b>to</b> a <i>koy</i> resulting from <b>a deer who mates with a female goat.</b>
This is so <b>because,</b> according to the aforementioned conclusions about their opinions, <b>both according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis and according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer it is uncertain whether one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with paternity,</b> and the <i>koy</i> is considered partially an undomesticated animal, <b>or</b> one need <b>not</b> be concerned, and it is considered entirely domesticated.
<b>And they disagree as to</b> whether the word <b>“sheep”</b> means that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep</b> it is considered a domesticated animal. Therefore, the mishna, which requires one to cover the blood of a <i>koy</i> whose father is a deer due to uncertainty, is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, because they, as opposed to Rabbi Eliezer, hold that if an animal has a domesticated component, it is considered a domesticated animal, and with regard to covering the blood if the animal has an undomesticated component, the animal is considered undomesticated. As for the gifts of the priesthood, the Rabbis require half of them to be given from this <i>koy</i>, as it has a domesticated component from its mother, while Rabbi Eliezer exempts one from giving them, as he holds that an animal’s parents must both be domesticated to qualify the animal as domesticated.
Rav Pappa continues: <b>With regard to the matter of</b> the prohibition against slaughtering an animal <b>itself and its offspring</b> on the same day, which the Rabbis hold applies to a <i>koy</i> but Rabbi Eliezer does not, <b>you find</b> such a case <b>either with regard to</b> a <i>koy</i> who is the daughter of <b>a goat who mates with a doe, or with regard to</b> a <i>koy</i> who is the daughter of <b>a deer who mates with a female goat.</b>
Rav Pappa explains: The case may be referring <b>to</b> a <i>koy</i> who is the daughter of <b>a goat who mates with a doe, and</b> it relates <b>to a prohibition,</b> i.e., whether slaughtering it and its offspring in one day is prohibited <i>ab initio</i>, <b>as the Rabbis hold: Perhaps one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity,</b> and this <i>koy</i> is therefore considered part domesticated, <b>and we say</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> means that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep</b> this prohibition applies, <b>and</b> its slaughter on the same day as its daughter is <b>prohibited</b> <i>ab initio</i>, although one does not receive lashes for it as it is not a definite transgression.
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer holds: Though one indeed</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity,</b> and this <i>koy</i> is considered partially domesticated, <b>we do not say</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> means that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep</b> the prohibition applies. Therefore, its slaughter on the same day as its offspring is permitted.
Additionally, the case under dispute may be referring <b>to</b> a <i>koy</i> who is the daughter of <b>a deer who mates with a female goat, and</b> it relates <b>to</b> whether slaughtering it and its offspring in one day renders one liable to receive <b>lashes. The Rabbis hold: Though one indeed</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity,</b> and this <i>koy</i> is considered partially undomesticated, <b>we say</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> means that the prohibition applies <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep,</b> such as this <i>koy</i>, <b>and</b> one who slaughters it and its offspring on one day <b>is flogged. And Rabbi Eliezer holds: There is a prohibition</b> against slaughtering this <i>koy</i> and its offspring on the same day, but if one slaughtered them <b>there are no lashes.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>There is a prohibition</b> in the case of this <i>koy</i> that is itself a mother, since <b>perhaps one</b> need <b>not be concerned with its paternity, and</b> therefore <b>this</b> <i>koy</i> <b>is a full-fledged sheep,</b> like its mother. Due to uncertainty, <b>there are no lashes</b> for violating the prohibition <b>because perhaps one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity,</b> in which case this <i>koy</i> is only a partial sheep.
<b>And</b> according to Rabbi Eliezer, <b>we do not say</b> that the word <b>“sheep”</b> means that <b>even</b> if it is <b>partially a sheep</b> it is subject to the prohibition. Therefore, one is not flogged for slaughtering this <i>koy</i> on the same day as its offspring, as lashes are administered only when the witnesses give the transgressor a definite forewarning against violating the prohibition. Since the prohibition in this case is uncertain, any forewarning would be uncertain.
§ Until this point, the Gemara considered the <i>koy</i> to be the result of interbreeding a deer and a goat. The Gemara now cites other opinions as to its identity: <b>Rav Yehuda says: A <i>koy</i> is a distinct entity, and the Sages did not determine whether it is a species of domesticated animal or a species of undomesticated animal. Rav Naḥman says: The <i>koy</i> is the wild ram.</b>
The Gemara notes that this dispute is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> cited in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The <i>koy</i> is the wild ram, and there are</b> those <b>who say:</b> It is <b>that which results from</b> the mating of <b>a goat with a doe. Rabbi Yosei says: A <i>koy</i> is a distinct entity, and the Sages did not determine whether</b> it is <b>a species of undomesticated animal or a species of domesticated animal. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: It is a species of domesticated animal, and</b> the members <b>of the house of Dushai would raise flocks</b> and <b>flocks of them,</b> as with other domesticated animals.
§ The Gemara cites a statement with regard to goats: <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rav Safra says</b> that <b>Rav Hamnuna says</b> that <b>these forest goats,</b> i.e., wild goats, <b>are fit</b> to be sacrificed <b>on the altar,</b> as they are considered a type of goat. The Gemara comments that Rav Hamnuna <b>holds in accordance with that which Rabbi Yitzḥak says: The verse lists ten</b> kosher <b>animals, and no more.</b> He is referring to the verses: “These are the animals that you may eat: An ox, a <i>seh</i> of sheep, and a <i>seh</i> of goats, a deer, and a gazelle, and a fallow deer, and a wild goat, and an oryx, and an aurochs, and a wild sheep” (Deuteronomy 14:4–5). The first three are domesticated animals, while the other seven are undomesticated animals.
