<b>And</b> with regard to <b>these</b> forest goats, <b>since they are not reckoned among the undomesticated animals, learn from it that they are</b> a type <b>of goat,</b> as they are also called goats and have a goat-like appearance. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Yaakov objects to this:</b> Perhaps wild goats are a different species of undomesticated animal not explicitly mentioned in the verse, as the next verse provides a more general description, <b>and I will say</b> that the verse: <b>“A deer and a gazelle,</b> etc.,” is a list of undomesticated animals, each of which is a specific <b>detail.</b> The next verse: “And <b>any animal,”</b> is <b>a generalization.</b>
According to the principles for explicating verses, when there is <b>a detail and</b> then <b>a generalization,</b> the <b>generalization was made to expand beyond the detail.</b> Therefore, <b>there are more</b> species of kosher undomesticated animals than the verse lists, one of which may be forest goats.
The Gemara responds: <b>If so, why do I</b> need <b>all of these details?</b> The mention of a single undomesticated animal and then the generalization should suffice for applying the principle of: A detail and a generalization. Rather, these are the only kosher undomesticated animals, and the forest goat must therefore be a type of domesticated goat. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, objects to this: But</b> even if forest goats are not a different type of undomesticated animal from those mentioned in the verse, <b>perhaps they are a type of wild goat,</b> one of the undomesticated animals mentioned in the verse, rather than a type of domesticated goat.
With regard to this topic, <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi, and some say</b> it was <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya,</b> who said <b>to Rav Ashi: Perhaps they are a type of aurochs [<i>te’o</i>], or a type of wild sheep,</b> which are also undomesticated animals. <b>Rav Ḥanan said to Rav Ashi:</b> Differing from Rav Hamnuna’s opinion, <b>Ameimar deems</b> the consumption of <b>their fat permitted,</b> which is prohibited with regard to domesticated animals, indicating that he considers forest goats a species of undomesticated animal.
<b>Abba, son of Rav Minyamin bar Ḥiyya, inquired of Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> offering <b>these forest goats [<i>izei devala</i>] on the altar?</b> Are they domesticated animals that may be sacrificed? Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya <b>said to him: Rabbi Yosei and the Rabbis disagree only with regard to the wild ox.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kilayim</i> 8:6): <b>The wild ox is a species of domesticated animal. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> It is <b>a species of undomesticated animal. As the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> “aurochs” (Deuteronomy 14:5) <b>is translated</b> into Aramaic as: <b>Forest ox [<i>turbala</i>],</b> it can be understood that the wild ox <b>is a species of domesticated animal, and Rabbi Yosei holds: From</b> the fact <b>that it is reckoned among the undomesticated animals,</b> it can be derived that <b>it is a species of undomesticated animal. But</b> with regard to <b>these</b> forest goats, which are not reckoned among the undomesticated animals, <b>all agree</b> that <b>they are a type of goat</b> and are fit to be sacrificed upon the altar.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, objects to this: But perhaps they are a type of wild goat.</b> Similarly, <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: But perhaps they are a type of aurochs, or a type of wild sheep.</b> Additionally, <b>Rav Naḥman said to Rav Ashi: Ameimar deems</b> the consumption of <b>their fat permitted,</b> which is prohibited with regard to domesticated animals, as he considers them undomesticated animals.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>How so? One who slaughters</b> an animal itself and its offspring, etc. <b>Rabbi Oshaya says: The entire mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. From where</b> is this derived? It is derived <b>from that</b> which the mishna <b>teaches:</b> If both animals were <b>sacrificial</b> animals slaughtered <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>then</b> for slaughtering <b>the first</b> animal, <b>one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>. And both</b> animals <b>are disqualified</b> for use as offerings, <b>and</b> for the slaughter of <b>both of them, one incurs forty</b> lashes. <b>Since we have heard that Rabbi Shimon says:</b> An act of <b>slaughter that is unfit</b> to permit consumption of the meat <b>is not considered</b> to have the halakhic status of an act of <b>slaughter.</b>

Daf 80b

Therefore, when one slaughters a mother and its offspring that are both sacrificial animals outside the Temple courtyard, with regard to <b>the first,</b> it is as if <b>he has</b> simply <b>killed it</b> without ritual slaughter, since being slaughtered outside the Temple courtyard renders it unfit. Accordingly, <b>the second</b> would have been fit to be <b>accepted within</b> the Temple, and there would have been no prohibition against slaughtering it on that day. If so, when he slaughtered it outside the courtyard, why is he liable only to receive lashes? <b>Let him also be liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
Likewise, the same question may be asked with regard to what is taught in the mishna: If both animals were <b>non-sacred</b> and they were slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>both of them are unfit</b> for sacrifice. <b>And</b> for the slaughter of <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs the forty</b> lashes. <b>Since we have heard that Rabbi Shimon says:</b> An act of <b>slaughter that is unfit is not considered</b> to have the halakhic status of an act of <b>slaughter,</b> with regard to <b>the first</b> animal, it is as if <b>he has</b> simply <b>killed it</b> without ritual slaughter, since a non-sacred animal slaughtered in the Temple courtyard is rendered unfit, as deriving benefit from it is prohibited. If so, <b>why,</b> for the slaughter of <b>the second</b> animal, <b>does one incur the forty</b> lashes?
Similarly, the mishna teaches: If both animals were <b>sacrificial</b> animals slaughtered <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>the first is fit</b> for sacrifice, <b>and</b> one who slaughters it is <b>exempt</b> from any punishment. <b>But</b> for the slaughter of <b>the second</b> animal, <b>one incurs the forty</b> lashes for the slaughter of an animal and its offspring on a single day, <b>and</b> it is <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice.
<b>Since we have heard that Rabbi Shimon says:</b> An act of <b>slaughter that is unfit</b> to permit consumption of the animal <b>is not considered</b> to have the halakhic status of an act of <b>slaughter.</b> One can then raise the question: An act of <b>slaughter of sacrificial</b> animals <b>is also</b> considered an act of <b>slaughter that is unfit, because as long as one has not sprinkled the blood, the meat is not permitted</b> to be burned on the altar or eaten. Since slaughtering the first animal is not considered slaughtering, <b>why,</b> for slaughtering <b>the second</b> animal, <b>does one incur the forty</b> lashes for slaughtering an animal and its offspring on a single day, <b>and</b> why is it <b>unfit? Rather, conclude from</b> this analysis <b>that</b> the mishna <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious that this is so?</b> There is no need for this long analysis. The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary for</b> Rabbi Oshaya to mention that the mishna is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon due to the case of <b>slaughtering</b> an animal and its offspring that are <b>sacrificial</b> animals inside the Temple courtyard. This is because it may <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>slaughtering sacrificial</b> animals <b>is</b> considered <b>an</b> act of <b>slaughtering</b> that is <b>fit, because if he stabbed</b> the animal to death <b>and sprinkled</b> its <b>blood, the meat is not permitted, but if he slaughtered</b> it, <b>the meat is permitted and it is</b> considered <b>slaughtering</b> that is <b>fit</b> according to Rabbi Shimon. Therefore, he <b>teaches us</b> that it is not fit.
§ With regard to the ruling that one who slaughters an animal and its offspring that are sacrificial animals inside the Temple courtyard receives lashes for violating the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, when slaughtering the second animal, the Gemara suggests: <b>And let him be flogged also for</b> violating <b>the prohibition against</b> sacrificing an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived, since it is forbidden to sacrifice it until the next day. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to all of the disqualifications of the bull,</b> i.e., any feature that disqualifies cattle brought as offerings, <b>and of the lamb,</b> i.e., sheep brought as offerings, <b>that</b> if one consecrates, slaughters, or burns on the altar an animal so disqualified, <b>he</b> violates the prohibition <b>of: It shall not be accepted,</b> and is flogged?
It is derived from the fact that, in the middle of the passage prohibiting blemished animals from being sacrificed upon the altar, <b>the verse states: “Either a bull or a lamb that has anything too long or too short…</b>but for a vow it shall not be accepted” (Leviticus 22:23). Since this passage is already discussing a bull and lamb, it is unnecessary to mention them. Rather, this verse <b>taught about</b> all of <b>the disqualifications of the bull and of the lamb,</b> including that of an animal whose time has not yet arrived, <b>that</b> if one offers an animal with one of those disqualifications, <b>he</b> violates the prohibition <b>of: It shall not be accepted.</b>
The Gemara answers: He receives lashes for violating that prohibition as well, but <b>when</b> the mishna <b>lists</b> the prohibitions violated by the actions described, it lists only <b>prohibitions</b> related to the prohibition <b>of: Itself and its offspring,</b> but <b>it does not list unrelated prohibitions.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does the mishna <b>not</b> list unrelated prohibitions? <b>But</b> there are prohibitions with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals slaughtered <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>which are unrelated prohibitions, and it lists them. As it teaches:</b> If both animals were <b>sacrificial</b> animals slaughtered <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>then</b> for slaughtering <b>the first</b> animal, <b>one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b> And both animals are disqualified for use as offerings, <b>and</b> for the slaughter of <b>both of them one incurs forty</b> lashes apiece.
<b>Granted,</b> with regard to the <b>second</b> animal one is flogged <b>due to the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring. But</b> with regard to the <b>first</b> animal, <b>why does he incur</b> the forty lashes? <b>Isn’t it due to the prohibition of</b> consecrated animals <b>slaughtered outside</b> the Temple courtyard? Therefore, with regard to the case of sacrificial animals slaughtered inside the Temple courtyard, the mishna should also have mentioned the unrelated prohibition of: It shall not be accepted.
The Gemara answers: <b>Wherever there is no</b> violation of <b>the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring,</b> for slaughtering an animal, the mishna <b>lists unrelated prohibitions, but wherever there is</b> a violation of <b>the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring,</b> the mishna <b>does not list unrelated prohibitions,</b> but only the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said: Leave</b> the prohibition against sacrificing an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived, <b>as the verse</b>

Daf 81a

<b>transmuted it</b> from the standard prohibition of: It shall not be accepted, which is violated in the case of the other disqualifications, <b>into</b> a prohibition that stems from <b>a positive mitzva. What is the reasoning</b> by which this is derived? It is derived from that <b>which the verse states: “From the eighth day and forward it may be accepted</b> for an offering” (Leviticus 22:27), which teaches that <b>from the eighth day</b> after its birth, <b>yes,</b> it may be sacrificed as an offering, but <b>initially,</b> before the eighth day, <b>no,</b> it may not be sacrificed. Therefore, this is <b>a prohibition that stems from a positive mitzva,</b> which is not considered a negative prohibition for which one is flogged, but rather <b>a positive mitzva.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But this</b> verse <b>is required for</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Aptoriki, as Rabbi Aptoriki raises a contradiction: It is written: “Then it shall be seven days with its mother”</b> (Leviticus 22:27), indicating that on <b>the night</b> after the seventh day it is already <b>fit</b> to be sacrificed. <b>But it is</b> also <b>written</b> in that verse: <b>“From the eighth day and forward it may be accepted,”</b> indicating that <b>from the eighth day forward, yes,</b> it is fit, but on <b>the night</b> before it is <b>not.</b>
<b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? <b>The night</b> after the seventh day is fit <b>for consecration,</b> which is permitted at that time, while <b>the</b> eighth <b>day</b> is fit <b>for effecting acceptance,</b> and only then may it be sacrificed on the altar. The Gemara answers that <b>another verse is</b> also <b>written</b> that specifies this positive mitzva: <b>“So shall you do with your ox and with your sheep;</b> seven days shall it be with its mother; on the eighth day you shall give it to Me” (Exodus 22:29).
§ The Gemara returns to discussing Rabbi Shimon’s opinion with regard to slaughtering an animal and its offspring on the same day. <b>Rav Hamnuna says</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon would say:</b> The prohibition against slaughtering an animal <b>itself and its offspring does not apply to sacrificial</b> animals. <b>What is the reason?</b> The reason is that <b>since Rabbi Shimon says</b> that an act of <b>slaughter that is unfit</b> to permit consumption <b>is not considered</b> to have the halakhic status of an act of <b>slaughter,</b> the prohibition will not apply here. This case of <b>slaughtering sacrificial</b> animals <b>is also</b> considered <b>slaughter that is unfit,</b> in that the flesh may not be burned upon the altar or eaten until the blood has been presented.
<b>Rava raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If one slaughtered an animal <b>itself and its offspring</b> and both animals were <b>sacrificial</b> animals slaughtered <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> For slaughtering the <b>second</b> animal he transgresses <b>a prohibition</b> in slaughtering it outside the Temple, <b>as Rabbi Shimon would say:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> offering <b>that is fit to come</b> to the altar <b>after</b> a certain amount of <b>time</b> and is offered outside the Temple before that time, <b>he</b> who slaughters it transgresses <b>a prohibition, but there is no</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i>. And the Rabbis say:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> offering slaughtered outside of the Temple <b>for which there is no</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i></b> because it is unfit to be an offering at that time, he who sacrifices it also <b>does not</b> transgress <b>a prohibition.</b>
<b>And</b> this statement in the <i>baraita</i> is <b>difficult for us:</b> If both animals were <b>sacrificial</b> animals slaughtered <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, Rabbi Shimon says: For slaughtering the <b>second</b> animal he transgresses <b>a prohibition</b> for slaughtering outside the Temple. According to Rabbi Shimon, slaughter that is unfit for consumption is not considered slaughter. Therefore, with regard to <b>the first</b> animal, it is as if <b>he has killed</b> it without ritual slaughter, since its slaughter was unfit, and the <b>second</b> animal <b>would be accepted inside</b> the Temple upon the altar. Therefore, <b>let</b> one who slaughters it outside of the Temple <b>be liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> as well.</b>
<b>And Rava said, and some say it unattributed:</b> The <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete and this is what</b> it is <b>teaching:</b> If one slaughters an animal and its offspring that are both <b>sacrificial</b> animals, and <b>both of them</b> are slaughtered <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> the slaughter of <b>the first</b> animal <b>is punishable by <i>karet</i>,</b> while the <b>second</b> animal <b>is disqualified</b> as its time has not yet arrived, <b>and</b> therefore, for its slaughter one is <b>exempt from</b> punishment for violating <b>the prohibition of</b> offerings <b>slaughtered outside</b> the Temple.
<b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> the slaughter of <b>both of them,</b> including the second one alone, is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>.</b> This is because the slaughter of the first is not considered slaughter, and therefore it does not disqualify the second through the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring.
If an animal and its offspring that are sacrificial animals are slaughtered, the first <b>one outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> the second <b>one inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> the slaughter of the <b>first is punishable by <i>karet</i>,</b> while the <b>second</b> animal <b>is disqualified</b> as its time has not yet arrived, <b>and</b> its slaughterer is <b>exempt</b> from punishment for its slaughter outside the Temple, because he slaughtered it inside the Temple. <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> the <b>second</b> animal is <b>fit</b> for the altar, and it is sacrificed, as the slaughter of the first animal is not considered slaughter, and therefore the slaughter of the second does not violate the prohibition of a mother and its offspring.
If an animal and its offspring that are sacrificial animals are slaughtered, the first <b>one inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>and</b> the second <b>one outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> the <b>first</b> animal <b>is fit</b> for the altar, <b>and</b> one who slaughters it <b>is exempt</b> from any punishment, as its slaughter is perfectly legitimate. The <b>second is unfit</b> for the altar, as it was slaughtered outside the Temple, <b>but</b> its slaughterer is <b>exempt</b> from punishment for its slaughter outside the Temple because it is unfit for the altar, as its time has not yet arrived. <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> for slaughtering the <b>second</b> animal outside the Temple one transgresses <b>a prohibition,</b> as he holds that an offering whose time has not yet arrived that was slaughtered outside the Temple violates a prohibition.
Rava now explains his objection: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that the prohibition of: <b>Itself and its offspring,</b> does <b>not apply to sacrificial</b> animals, then with regard to slaughtering the <b>second</b> animal outside the Temple, <b>why</b> does one transgress only <b>a prohibition and nothing more? Let him be liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> as well,</b> as since its slaughter does not violate the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, it would fit to be sacrificed inside the Temple. Therefore, it is clear that the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, does apply to sacrificial animals.
<b>Rather, Rava said: This is what Rav Hamnuna is saying:</b> Though the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, does apply to sacrificial animals, the administering of <b>lashes for</b> violating the prohibition of: <b>Itself and its offspring, does not apply to sacrificial animals.</b>
The reason is that <b>since as long as one has not sprinkled the blood, the flesh is not permitted</b> to be burned on the altar or eaten, <b>at the time that one slaughters</b> the second animal, when he receives a forewarning that his action violates the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, <b>it is an uncertain forewarning,</b> because if the blood will not be sprinkled, the flesh will not be permitted, sparing him from violating the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring. <b>And an uncertain forewarning is not considered</b> a valid <b>forewarning</b> that renders one liable to receive lashes.
<b>And Rava follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as Rava says:</b> According to Rabbi Shimon, who holds that one does not incur punishment for the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, for a slaughtering that is unfit, if <b>she,</b> the mother, <b>is non-sacred, and her offspring is a peace offering,</b> and one <b>slaughtered</b> the <b>non-sacred</b> mother, <b>and afterward</b> one <b>slaughtered</b> her offspring that is <b>a peace offering</b> on the same day, he is <b>exempt</b> for slaughtering the offspring. This is because the forewarning for slaughtering the offspring is uncertain as its blood might not be sprinkled, rendering the slaughter unfit.
But if one slaughtered the offspring that is <b>a peace offering</b> first and sprinkled its blood, <b>and afterward</b> he slaughtered the <b>non-sacred</b> mother, he is <b>liable</b> to receive lashes for slaughtering the mother. Once the non-sacred mother is slaughtered, the meat is fit; therefore, the forewarning is definite. <b>And Rava says:</b> If <b>she,</b> the mother, <b>is non-sacred, and her offspring is</b> sacrificed as <b>a burnt offering,</b> and both are slaughtered on the same day, <b>it is not necessary</b> to state that if one <b>slaughtered</b> the <b>non-sacred</b> mother, <b>and afterward</b> he <b>slaughtered</b> her offspring as <b>a burnt offering, that</b> he is <b>exempt.</b>

Daf 81b

<b>But even</b> if one <b>slaughtered</b> the offspring as <b>a burnt offering</b> and sprinkled its blood, <b>and afterward slaughtered</b> the <b>non-sacred</b> mother, he is <b>exempt.</b> The reason is that <b>the slaughter</b> of the <b>first</b> animal <b>is not</b> an act of <b>slaughter subject to consumption,</b> as a burnt offering is entirely burned upon the altar, and according to Rabbi Shimon, it is an act of slaughter that is improper, in that it does not render the meat fit to be eaten, is not considered slaughter.
<b>And Rabbi Ya’akov says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> says: <b>Consumption by the altar is considered consumption. What is the reason?</b> The reason is <b>that the verse states</b> with regard to an offering that was sacrificed with the intent to consume it after its designated time [<i>piggul</i>]: <b>“And if any of the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings be at all eaten [<i>he’akhol ye’akhel</i>]</b> on the third day, it shall not be accepted” (Leviticus 7:18).
The repetitive expression “<i>he’akhol ye’akhel</i>” teaches that <b>the verse is speaking of two</b> types of <b>consumption: One</b> is <b>human consumption, and</b> the other <b>one</b> is <b>consumption by the altar,</b> and both are considered consumption with regard to <i>piggul</i> and other matters. Therefore, the slaughter of a burnt offering is considered slaughter that is fit for consumption, and the slaughter of a mother animal and its offspring, one of which is sacrificed as a burnt offering on the same day as the slaughter of the other, renders one liable to receive lashes even according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal and its offspring <b>and</b> one of them <b>is discovered to be an animal with a wound that would have caused it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>]</b> and may not be eaten, or <b>one who slaughters</b> one of the animals <b>for</b> the sake of <b>idol worship,</b> from which deriving benefit is prohibited, <b>or one who slaughters the</b> red <b>heifer of purification, or an ox that</b> was <b>to</b> have been <b>stoned, or a heifer whose neck</b> was <b>to</b> have been <b>broken,</b> all of which are animals from which deriving benefit is prohibited, <b>Rabbi Shimon deems</b> one who slaughters them <b>exempt</b> from lashes for the slaughter of a mother and its offspring, as in his opinion, slaughter that does not render the animal fit for consumption is not considered slaughter and does not violate the prohibition. <b>And the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>liable,</b> as the slaughter need not render the animal fit for consumption in order to violate the prohibition.
All agree that <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal <b>and it becomes a carcass by his hand</b> because the slaughter was invalid, <b>or one who stabs</b> an animal, <b>or one who uproots</b> the windpipe and the gullet, is <b>exempt with regard to</b> the prohibition against slaughtering <b>a mother and its offspring,</b> as it is written: “You shall not slaughter it and its offspring both in one day” (Leviticus 22:28), and in these cases, no ritual slaughter was performed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says:</b> The Rabbis in the mishna <b>taught</b> that one is liable when one of the animals is slaughtered for the sake of idol worship <b>only when he slaughtered</b> the <b>first</b> animal <b>for</b> the sake of <b>idol worship and</b> the <b>second</b> animal <b>for his</b> own <b>table. But</b> if he slaughtered the <b>first</b> animal <b>for his</b> own <b>table and</b> the <b>second</b> animal <b>for</b> the sake of <b>idol worship,</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from lashes for the second act of slaughter, <b>as he receives</b> only <b>the greater</b> punishment, that for idol worship, which is death.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him: Even schoolchildren know this</b> <i>halakha</i>, that one who is liable to receive two punishments receives only the greater punishment. <b>Rather, sometimes, even if he slaughtered</b> the <b>first for his</b> own <b>table and</b> the <b>second for</b> the sake of <b>idol worship,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to receive lashes for the second act of slaughter.
This occurs, <b>for example, where</b> the witnesses <b>forewarned him</b> before the second act of slaughter <b>with regard to</b> the prohibition of: <b>Itself and its offspring, but</b> they <b>did not forewarn him with regard to idol worship.</b> Since he is not punished for performing idol worship, he receives lashes for the less severe transgression. <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: Since, had they forewarned him</b> with regard to idol worship he would have been <b>exempt</b> from lashes; therefore, even <b>if they did not forewarn him</b> with regard to idol worship, <b>he is also exempt</b> from lashes.
The Gemara notes: <b>And they</b> each <b>follow their</b> known lines of <b>reasoning</b> in this matter. <b>As when Rav Dimi came</b> to Babylonia from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said:</b> With regard to <b>those</b> who <b>unwittingly</b> performed a transgression for which one is <b>liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty if one performed it intentionally, <b>or those</b> who <b>unwittingly</b> performed a transgression for which one is <b>liable</b> to receive <b>lashes, and</b> that transgression also involved <b>another matter,</b> monetary payment, and they were forewarned with regard to the monetary penalty but not with regard to the lashes or the death penalty, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> He is <b>liable</b> to pay; <b>and Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the rationales for their statements. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that he is <b>liable; since they did not forewarn him</b> with regard to the severe transgression, he sinned unwittingly, and he remains liable only to pay the monetary payment. <b>And Reish Lakish says</b> that he is <b>exempt; since had they forewarned him</b> with regard to the severe transgression, he would have been <b>exempt</b> from the monetary payment, <b>when they did not forewarn him,</b> he is <b>also exempt.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And it is necessary</b> to state their disagreement with regard to both of these cases. <b>As, if it were taught to us</b> only <b>about this</b> case where one slaughters the mother for his private use and afterward slaughters its offspring for idol worship, perhaps only <b>in this</b> case involving the death penalty and lashes <b>does Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish say</b> that even if they did not forewarn the transgressor with regard to idol worship, he is still exempt from lashes for the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, because the death penalty and lashes are similar in that they are both corporal punishments, and so the obligation of lashes does not take effect at all when the death penalty is potentially applicable. <b>But in that</b> case, involving the death penalty or lashes together with a monetary payment, <b>say that he agrees with Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that the transgressor is liable to pay the monetary payment.
<b>And if</b> the disagreement <b>was stated</b> only <b>with regard to that</b> case, where one unwittingly performed a transgression involving the death penalty or lashes together with a transgression bearing a monetary payment, perhaps only <b>in that</b> case <b>does Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that he is liable to pay the monetary payment. <b>But in this</b> case, where one slaughtered an animal and its offspring, and the second animal was slaughtered for the sake of idol worship, which involves the death penalty and lashes, but without a forewarning with regard to the death penalty, <b>say that he agrees with Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> that one is exempt from lashes. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state their disagreement with regard to both cases.
§ The mishna teaches that Rabbi Shimon deems one who slaughters the red heifer of purification exempt from punishment for the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, as that act of slaughter does not render the animal fit for consumption. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is the slaughter of <b>the</b> red <b>heifer of purification</b> considered an act of <b>slaughter that is unfit</b> for consumption? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> A red <b>heifer,</b> even if it has been slaughtered and it is therefore prohibited to derive benefit from it, <b>is susceptible to the ritual impurity of food, since it had a time in which it was fit</b> for consumption?

Daf 82a

<b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says</b> in explanation of Rabbi Shimon’s statement: <b>Rabbi Shimon would say</b> that the red <b>heifer can be redeemed</b> with money even once it has been slaughtered and placed <b>upon its pyre</b> in preparation for being burned. Therefore, Rabbi Shimon states that there could be a time when the heifer was fit for consumption, i.e., if it was redeemed. Why, then, does he deem one who slaughters it exempt from liability for transgressing the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring? <b>Rav Shemen bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The statement with regard to <b>the</b> red <b>heifer of purification is not</b> considered part of the <b>mishna,</b> and Rabbi Shimon agrees that its slaughterer is liable for transgressing the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> the slaughter of the <b>heifer whose neck</b> was <b>to</b> have been <b>broken not</b> considered an act of <b>slaughter</b> that is <b>fit? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Sota</i> 47a): If a heifer was set aside to have its neck broken to atone for the murder of an individual whose murderer was not known, and then <b>the murderer was found before the heifer’s neck was broken,</b> the heifer <b>shall go out and graze among the flock,</b> as it is not consecrated. Evidently, before its neck is broken, deriving benefit from it is not prohibited, and its slaughter would be one that is fit. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said in the name of Rabbi Yannai:</b> The statement with regard to <b>the heifer whose neck</b> was <b>to</b> have been <b>broken is not</b> considered part of the <b>mishna,</b> and Rabbi Shimon agrees that its slaughterer is liable for violating the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Yannai</b> actually <b>say so? But doesn’t Rabbi Yannai say: I heard</b> the <b>boundary,</b> i.e., stage, beyond which the heifer is forbidden, <b>but I have forgotten</b> what it is; <b>but the group</b> of scholars <b>were inclined to say</b> that the heifer’s <b>descent to a hard valley,</b> where its neck is broken, <b>is</b> the action that <b>renders it forbidden?</b>
<b>And if it is so, let him resolve</b> the contradiction by saying: <b>Here,</b> where deriving benefit from the heifer is permitted, and its slaughterer is liable for transgressing the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, it is referring to an act of slaughtering that is fit and is performed <b>before</b> the heifer’s <b>descent,</b> while <b>there,</b> in the mishna, where Rabbi Shimon holds that there is no liability for transgressing: Itself and its offspring, it is referring to slaughtering performed <b>after</b> its <b>descent.</b> At that time, deriving benefit from the heifer is already prohibited, and the slaughter is therefore not considered fit.
<b>Rav Pineḥas, son of Rav Ami, said: We taught</b> the statement <b>in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> himself, not as a quote from Rabbi Yannai: The statement with regard to <b>the heifer whose neck is broken is not</b> considered part of the <b>mishna. Rav Ashi said: When we were</b> studying in <b>the study hall of Rav Pappi,</b> that statement was <b>difficult for us: Did Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> actually <b>say</b> that it is not considered part of the mishna?
<b>But it was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> engaged in a dispute concerning the following issue: <b>From when</b> is one <b>prohibited</b> from deriving benefit from <b>the leper’s birds? Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> One is prohibited <b>from the moment of</b> their <b>slaughter; and Reish Lakish says:</b> One is prohibited <b>from the moment</b> they are <b>taken</b> and designated to be a leper’s birds. <b>And we say: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish?</b>
His reasoning is that he <b>derives</b> it via verbal analogy <b>from</b> the terms: <b>“Taking [<i>kiḥa</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 14:4), with regard to the birds, and: <b>“Taking [<i>kiḥa</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:3), with regard to the <b>heifer whose neck is broken.</b> Consequently, just as deriving benefit from the heifer whose neck is broken is prohibited from the time of its selection, so too must deriving benefit from these birds be prohibited from the time of their selection. Clearly, then, Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish holds that deriving benefit from the heifer whose neck is broken is prohibited while it is still alive. Therefore, its slaughter is one that does not render the animal fit for consumption. Accordingly, Rabbi Shimon would exempt its slaughterer from the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, as is taught in the mishna.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The statement with regard to the <b>heifer whose neck is broken is not</b> considered part of <b>the mishna,</b> and this resolution of the difficulty was articulated by Rabbi Yoḥanan rather than Reish Lakish.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>two</b> people <b>who purchased a cow and its offspring,</b> where each purchased one of the animals, <b>whoever purchased</b> his animal <b>first shall slaughter</b> it <b>first,</b> and the second one must wait until the next day to slaughter his animal, so as not to violate the prohibition of: It and its offspring. <b>But if the second</b> one <b>preceded</b> him and slaughtered his animal first, he <b>benefitted,</b> and the one who purchased the animal first may not slaughter it until the next day.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yosef said: We learn</b> in the mishna that the first purchaser is granted precedence only <b>with regard to the matter of</b> a court <b>judgment,</b> in case the two purchasers go to court each demanding to slaughter his animal first. But there is no prohibition against the second one slaughtering his animal first if no claim is brought to court. Likewise, a Sage <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If the second</b> one <b>preceded</b> him and slaughtered his animal first, <b>he is diligent and rewarded;</b> he is <b>diligent because he did not violate a prohibition, and</b> he is <b>rewarded because he eats meat</b> already that day.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one slaughtered a cow and thereafter</b> slaughtered <b>its two offspring</b> on the same day, <b>he incurs eighty</b> lashes for two separate actions violating the prohibition against slaughtering the mother and the offspring on the same day. If <b>one slaughtered its two offspring and thereafter slaughtered</b> the mother cow, <b>he incurs the forty</b> lashes, as he performed a single prohibited act. If <b>one slaughtered</b> the mother <b>and its daughter, and,</b> later that day, slaughtered <b>its daughter’s daughter, he incurs eighty</b> lashes, as he has performed the act of slaughtering a mother and its offspring twice.
But if <b>one slaughtered</b> the mother <b>and its daughter’s daughter and thereafter slaughtered its daughter, he incurs the forty</b> lashes, as he performed a single prohibited act. <b>Sumakhos says in the name of Rabbi Meir: He incurs eighty</b> lashes for slaughtering the daughter on the same day as its calf and its mother, as that act comprises two separate violations of the prohibition.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the statement in the mishna that if one slaughters two calves and thereafter slaughters their mother he incurs the forty lashes, the Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> does he receive lashes? After all, the phrase: <b>“It and its offspring”</b> (Leviticus 22:28), is what <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah, <b>and not: Its offspring and it.</b> The Gemara answers: That thought should <b>not enter your mind, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: From the phrase <b>“it and its offspring” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the prohibition includes slaughtering the animal <b>itself</b> first <b>and its offspring</b> afterward. <b>From where</b> do I derive that the prohibition also includes the case of slaughtering the offspring <b>itself</b> first <b>and its mother</b> afterward?
It is derived in the following manner: <b>When</b> the verse <b>states: “You shall not slaughter [<i>tishḥatu</i>]</b> both in one day” (Leviticus 22:28), <b>this</b> is referring to <b>two</b> people who are prohibited from slaughtering on the same day, as the word “slaughter” is phrased in the plural. <b>How so?</b> If, during the course of a single day, there is <b>one</b> person <b>who slaughters the cow and</b> then <b>another who slaughters</b> that cow’s <b>mother, and</b> then there is <b>another</b> person <b>who slaughters</b> that cow’s <b>offspring, the two latter</b> people <b>are liable,</b> the first of them for slaughtering the mother after its offspring was slaughtered, and the second person for slaughtering the offspring after its mother was slaughtered.

Daf 82b

The Gemara challenges: <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary for</b> the prohibition <b>itself,</b> and it cannot be used to teach this additional <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara explains: <b>If so,</b> that the verse teaches only the prohibition against slaughtering an animal and its offspring in one day, <b>let</b> the Torah <b>write: You shall not slaughter [<i>tishḥot</i>],</b> in the singular. For <b>what</b> reason did the Torah write: <b>“You shall not slaughter [<i>tishḥatu</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 22:28), in the plural? It is to teach that two different people are prohibited from slaughtering, as explained earlier.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But, nevertheless,</b> the plural <b>is necessary, as had the Merciful One written</b> in the Torah: <b>You shall not slaughter [<i>tishḥot</i>]</b> in the singular, <b>I would say:</b> With regard to <b>one</b> person, <b>yes,</b> it is prohibited to slaughter an animal and its offspring in a single day, but with regard to <b>two,</b> it is <b>not</b> prohibited for one of them to slaughter the mother and the other to then slaughter the offspring on the same day.
Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes</b> in the Torah: <b>“You shall not slaughter [<i>tishḥatu</i>],”</b> in the plural, indicating that <b>even two</b> individuals may not slaughter an animal and its offspring in a single day. The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that only this is derived from the verse, <b>let</b> the Torah <b>write: They shall not be slaughtered,</b> indicating that whether by one individual or two, the slaughter of an animal and its offspring in a single day is prohibited, but only the one who slaughters the offspring has violated the prohibition.
<b>What</b> is meant by: <b>“You shall not slaughter,”</b> which indicates that two different people are prohibited from slaughtering? <b>Conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it:</b> Conclude that the prohibition applies even if two people perform the two acts of slaughter, and that two cases are prohibited: Slaughtering the offspring after the mother, and slaughtering the mother after the offspring.
§ The mishna teaches: If <b>one slaughtered</b> the mother <b>and its daughter’s daughter</b> and thereafter slaughtered its daughter, he incurs the forty lashes. Sumakhos says in the name of Rabbi Meir: He incurs eighty lashes, because by slaughtering the daughter, he transgresses twice the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring. <b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: What is the reasoning</b> for the opinion <b>of Sumakhos</b> that the transgressor incurs eighty lashes?
<b>Does Sumakhos hold,</b> in general, that if <b>one</b> unwittingly <b>ate two olive-bulks of</b> forbidden <b>fat during one lapse of awareness</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>two sin offerings,</b> since he transgressed the prohibition twice? If so, then in a case where one is forewarned that if he transgresses intentionally he will receive lashes and he then violates the same prohibition twice, as is the case in the mishna, he receives two sets of lashes.
<b>And by right</b> the mishna <b>should have informed us</b> of Sumakhos’s opinion <b>in a general</b> case, such as that of eating two olive-bulks of forbidden fat during a single lapse of awareness, <b>but</b> the reason <b>that it teaches us</b> this dispute <b>in this</b> situation, where one slaughters an animal and its daughter’s offspring and, later that day, slaughters its daughter, is <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature of</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, that even though</b> the two animals that caused the daughter to be forbidden are <b>separate entities, the Rabbis</b> still <b>exempt</b> the transgressor from a second set of lashes.
<b>Or perhaps, Sumakhos holds</b> in general that if <b>one ate two olive-bulks of</b> forbidden <b>fat during one lapse of awareness,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin offering. If so, one who transgresses intentionally after being forewarned receives only one set of lashes even if he transgresses the same prohibition twice. <b>But here,</b> in the mishna, <b>this is the reason</b> that the transgressor receives two sets of lashes: It is <b>that</b> the two animals that caused the daughter to be prohibited are <b>separate entities.</b> Rav Yosef <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>Yes,</b> Sumakhos <b>holds</b> in general that if <b>one ate two olive-bulks of</b> forbidden <b>fat during one lapse of awareness</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>two sin offerings.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> does Rav Yosef derive this? He derives it <b>from that which we learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who sows diverse kinds, diverse kinds,</b> i.e., he twice sows grain together with grape seeds, is <b>flogged</b> for violating the prohibition of diverse kinds. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by: Is <b>flogged? If we say</b> it means that he is <b>flogged one</b> set of lashes, this is <b>obvious. And additionally,</b> if he receives only one set of lashes, <b>what</b> is the reason that the case of: Sowing <b>diverse kinds</b> twice, is mentioned, where he transgressed twice? Even if he transgressed only once, he receives lashes. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that he receives <b>two</b> sets of <b>lashes.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are we dealing with? If we say</b> that we are dealing with a case <b>where</b> one violates the prohibition twice, <b>one</b> time <b>after the other and with two</b> separate <b>forewarnings,</b> it is unnecessary for the <i>baraita</i> to teach this, as <b>we</b> already <b>learn</b> it in a mishna (<i>Nazir</i> 42a): <b>A nazirite who was drinking wine all day is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes. If onlookers <b>said to him: Do not drink, do not drink,</b> forewarning him several times, <b>and he drinks</b> after each forewarning, he is <b>liable</b> to receive lashes <b>for each and every</b> drink. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that he violated the prohibition twice <b>at the same time and with a single forewarning,</b> i.e., after he was forewarned he sowed wheat together with a grape seed with one hand, and barley together with a grape seed with the other hand, and he receives two sets of lashes.
The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this <i>baraita</i>? <b>If we say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis who disagree with Sumakhos</b> in the mishna, who hold that one who slaughters an animal and its daughter’s offspring and, later that day, slaughters its daughter receives only one set of lashes, that would not be reasonable: <b>Now, if there,</b> in the mishna, <b>where</b> there are animals that are <b>separate entities, the Rabbis exempt</b> him from a second set of lashes, since he violated a single prohibition with a single forewarning; <b>here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> with regard to diverse kinds, where, unlike animals, seeds are not considered separate entities (see 83a), if one sows diverse kinds twice at the same time, should they <b>not all the more so</b> exempt him from a second set of lashes?
<b>Rather, is it not</b> that the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> with regard to diverse kinds <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Sumakhos</b> and teaches that, even with a single entity, one who violates the same prohibition twice receives two sets of lashes? The Gemara responds: <b>No, actually</b> the <i>baraita</i> with regard to diverse kinds is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and he was forewarned before each act of sowing, which is why he receives two sets of lashes. <b>And</b> although this statement is redundant, by repeating the phrase: Diverse kinds, <b>it teaches us a matter in passing: That there are two categories of</b> the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds:</b> Sowing wheat together with grape seed and sowing barley together with grape seed.
<b>And</b> the <i>baraita</i> serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoshiya, as Rabbi Yoshiya says:</b> One who sows diverse kinds is not liable by Torah law <b>until he sows wheat, and barley, and</b> grape <b>seed with a single hand motion,</b> i.e., by sowing in the vineyard he violates the prohibition of diverse kinds that applies to seeds and to the vineyard simultaneously. Therefore, <b>it teaches us that when one sows</b> only <b>wheat and</b> grape <b>seed, or</b> only <b>barley and</b> grape <b>seed, he is liable as well.</b> Consequently, a source clarifying Sumakhos’s opinion in a case where one violates the same prohibition twice during a single lapse of awareness, or with only a single forewarning when one violated the prohibition intentionally, has not been found.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from a mishna with regard to the prohibition against eating from the sciatic nerve (96a): If <b>one ate an olive-bulk from this</b> sciatic nerve in the right leg of an animal, <b>and an olive-bulk from that</b> sciatic nerve in the left leg of the same animal, he <b>incurs eighty</b> lashes. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> He <b>incurs only forty</b> lashes. The Gemara analyzes the mishna: <b>What are the circumstances? If we say</b> that he ate them <b>one after the other and with two</b> separate <b>forewarnings, what is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda?</b> According to Rabbi Yehuda, <b>it is an uncertain forewarning,</b> as Rabbi Yehuda is uncertain whether the prohibition against eating from the sciatic nerve applies to the sciatic nerve of the right thigh or that of the left thigh (see 90b). <b>And we have heard that Rabbi Yehuda says: An uncertain forewarning is not considered a forewarning.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one is uncertain which of two men is his father, and he <b>struck this</b> man <b>and then struck that</b> man, or <b>cursed this</b> man <b>and then cursed that</b> man, <b>or struck both of them simultaneously,</b> or <b>cursed both of them simultaneously,</b> in all these cases he is <b>liable</b> for violating the prohibition of: “And he that strikes his father, or his mother, shall be put to death” (Exodus 21:15), or that of: “And he that curses his father, or his mother, shall be put to death” (Exodus 21:17), as one of them is certainly his father.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Although if he struck or cursed both of them <b>simultaneously</b> he is <b>liable,</b> if he struck or cursed them <b>one after the other,</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> as each time he strikes or curses one of them he receives an uncertain forewarning, as perhaps this man is not his father, and one is liable only after receiving a definite forewarning. Consequently, if one was forewarned before eating from the sciatic nerve from the right leg, and afterward he was forewarned before eating from the sciatic nerve from the left leg, he would similarly be exempt as each of the forewarnings was uncertain. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the case in the mishna is one where he partook of the two sciatic nerves <b>simultaneously and with a single forewarning,</b> and therefore, he incurs only forty lashes according to Rabbi Yehuda.
<b>And who is the first <i>tanna</i></b> who holds that in such a case one receives eighty lashes? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>the Rabbis who disagree with Sumakhos</b> in the mishna about the prohibition of: Itself and its offspring, that would conflict with their opinion: <b>Now, if there,</b> in the case of the mishna that discusses various animals <b>that</b> are <b>separate entities, the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt</b> from a second set of lashes, <b>here,</b> in the mishna that discusses the sciatic nerve, where there are no separate animals, should they <b>not all the more so</b> exempt him from a second set of lashes? <b>Rather, is</b> the mishna <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Sumakhos?</b> Consequently, in his opinion one who eats the same prohibited item, such as an olive-bulk of forbidden fat, twice after a single forewarning receives two sets of lashes.
The Gemara responds: <b>No, actually</b> the case is one where he ate from the two sciatic nerves <b>one after the other</b> and received separate forewarnings, <b>and</b> the first opinion in that mishna is that of <b>the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Sumakhos with regard to: Itself and its offspring. <b>And</b> as for the difficulty that Rabbi Yehuda does not render one liable if the forewarning is an uncertain one, <b>this <i>tanna</i> holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>another <i>tanna</i></b> with regard to the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>As</b> that other <i>tanna</i> <b>says</b> that Rabbi Yehuda holds: <b>An uncertain forewarning is considered a forewarning, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the Paschal offering: “And <b>you shall not leave any of it until morning; but that which remains of it until morning you shall burn with fire”</b> (Exodus 12:10).

Daf 83a

<b>The verse comes to provide a positive</b> mitzva to burn the leftovers, in the second part of the verse that states: “But that which remains of it until morning you shall burn with fire.” This positive mitzva is stated <b>after the prohibition</b> against leaving it over was stated in the first part of the verse, <b>to say that one is not flogged for</b> transgressing the prohibition. This is because any prohibition that can be rectified by the performance of a positive mitzva does not carry a punishment of lashes. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> If not for this reason, Rabbi Yehuda evidently would hold that he receives lashes. The forewarning given in this case is uncertain, as he must be forewarned before morning, and at that time he might still consume it.
<b>Rabbi Ya’akov says: This is not for</b> that <b>reason [<i>hashem</i>]. Rather,</b> it is <b>because it is a prohibition that does not involve an action.</b> The transgression is simply the failure to consume all the meat during the allotted time rather than the performance of an action. <b>And one is not flogged for</b> the violation of <b>any prohibition that does not involve an action.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution with regard to the opinion of Sumakhos from a <i>baraita</i> discussing the sciatic nerve: If <b>one ate two</b> sciatic <b>nerves from two thighs of two</b> different <b>animals,</b> he <b>incurs</b> the penalty of <b>eighty</b> lashes; <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> He <b>incurs only forty</b> lashes. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> in this case? <b>If we say</b> that he ate them <b>one after the other and with two</b> separate <b>forewarnings, what is the reasoning of</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, who says:</b> The violator receives <b>forty</b> lashes <b>and nothing more?</b> After all, he violates two separate prohibitions with two separate forewarnings. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that he ate them <b>at the same time and</b> with <b>a single forewarning.</b>
<b>Who is the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> who holds that in such a case one receives eighty lashes? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>the Rabbis who disagree with Sumakhos</b> in the mishna about: Itself and its offspring, that would contradict their opinion: Now, <b>if there,</b> in that mishna in a case <b>where</b> there are various animals that are <b>separate entities, the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt</b> from a second set of lashes, <b>here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> about two sciatic nerves, which are not separate entities, should they <b>not all the more so</b> deem him exempt from a second set of lashes? <b>Rather, is it not Sumakhos</b> who is the first <i>tanna</i>? Consequently, in his opinion one who eats the same prohibited item, such as an olive-bulk of forbidden fat, twice after a single forewarning receives two sets of lashes.
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> he ate the two sciatic nerves <b>one after the other</b> with separate forewarnings, incurring two sets of lashes even according to the Rabbis who disagree with Sumakhos in the mishna about: Itself and its offspring. <b>And</b> as for <b>that which you say: What is the reason of Rabbi Yehuda</b> who holds that the transgressor incurs only a single set of lashes? This is a case <b>where</b> the volume of one of the sciatic nerves <b>is not</b> even <b>an olive-bulk,</b> and Rabbi Yehuda follows his line of reasoning, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one ate</b> the entire sciatic nerve, <b>and</b> its volume <b>is not</b> even <b>an olive-bulk,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to incur forty lashes; <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> He is not liable <b>unless it has</b> a volume of at least <b>an olive-bulk.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>On four occasions during the year one who sells an animal to another is required to inform him: I sold the mother of</b> this animal today for the buyer <b>to slaughter</b> it,or: <b>I sold the daughter of</b> this animal today for the buyer <b>to slaughter</b> it. <b>And those</b> four occasions <b>are: The eve of the last day of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>the eve of the first day of the festival of Passover, and the eve of <i>Shavuot</i>, and the eve of Rosh HaShana. And according to the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, the eve of Yom Kippur in the Galilee</b> is included <b>as well.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: When</b> must he inform the buyer on those days? He must do so <b>at a time when</b> the seller <b>has no interval</b> between the sale of the mother and the offspring, as they were both sold on that day. <b>But</b> if the seller <b>has an interval</b> between the sales, <b>he does not need to inform</b> the buyer, as presumably each buyer purchased the animal to slaughter it on the day he purchased it. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda concedes</b> that in a case <b>where one sells the mother</b> animal <b>to the groom and the offspring to the bride, that</b> even if he did not sell them on the same day, <b>he must inform</b> the buyer, as it is <b>obvious that they are both</b> planning to <b>slaughter</b> their animal <b>on one day,</b> for their wedding feast.
<b>On those four occasions, one compels the butcher to slaughter</b> animals even <b>against his will; even if</b> there is <b>a bull worth one thousand dinars and the buyer has only one dinar</b> worth of meat, i.e., he already paid the butcher for one dinar’s worth of meat, <b>one compels him to slaughter</b> the animal and give him a dinar’s worth of meat. <b>Therefore, if</b> the bull <b>dies</b> before slaughter, although no act of acquisition was performed, <b>it dies at</b> the expense <b>of the buyer,</b> and he loses his dinar. <b>But during the rest of the days of the year it is not so.</b> On other days, until the buyer performs the act of pulling to assume ownership of the portion of the bull that he is purchasing, the bull remains in the butcher’s possession. <b>Therefore, if</b> the bull <b>dies</b> before the transaction is complete, <b>it dies at</b> the expense of <b>the seller,</b> who returns the buyer’s money.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that on the four occasions mentioned it is the seller’s responsibility to inform the purchaser that the mother or offspring of the animal he is purchasing was sold that day. With regard to this it is <b>taught:</b> Consequently, the purchaser has no obligation to clarify the situation, and <b>if</b> the seller <b>did not inform him,</b> the purchaser <b>may go and slaughter</b> the animal he has purchased <b>and</b> need <b>not refrain</b> from doing so.
The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: When</b> must he inform the buyer on those days? It then teaches: And Rabbi Yehuda concedes that in a case where one sold the mother animal to the groom and the offspring to the bride, even if he did not sell them on the same day, he must inform the buyer. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>to teach</b> that the butcher sold specifically <b>the mother</b> animal <b>to the groom and the offspring to the bride?</b> It could have taught: He sold one to the groom and the other to the bride. The Gemara answers: <b>It teaches us a</b> related <b>matter in passing, that</b> it is <b>proper conduct for the groom’s household to exert more</b> effort <b>than the bride’s household</b> in the marriage preparations. Therefore, the groom purchases the mother, the larger animal, while the bride purchases the smaller animal, the offspring.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>On those four occasions,</b> one compels the butcher to slaughter animals even against his will, and even if there is a bull worth one thousand dinars and the buyer has paid for only one dinar’s worth of meat, one compels him to slaughter the animal. Therefore, if the bull dies before slaughter, it dies at the expense of the buyer. The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> the buyer <b>did not</b> yet <b>pull</b> the animal to effect acquisition; consequently, although he paid the seller, the animal is not his. <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The case is <b>where he pulled</b> it, and thereby acquired it. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, say the latter clause: But during the rest of the days of the year it is not so. Therefore, if</b> the bull <b>dies, it dies at</b> the expense of <b>the seller,</b> who returns the buyer’s money. <b>But</b> according to Rav, <b>didn’t</b> the buyer <b>pull</b> the animal? If so, why is its death at the expense of the seller?
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said: Actually,</b> the case in the mishna is one <b>where</b> the buyer <b>did not pull</b> the animal, <b>and</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the seller <b>transfers ownership to</b> the customer <b>by means of another</b> person, i.e., by instructing another to acquire a dinar’s worth of the ox’s meat on the customer’s behalf, without having obtained the customer’s consent. Therefore, <b>on those four occasions, where it is for</b> the customer’s <b>benefit,</b> as he wants meat for the Festival, the principle: <b>One can act in a person’s interest in his absence,</b> applies. By contrast, <b>during the rest of the days of the year, where it is to</b> the customer’s <b>disadvantage</b> to acquire the meat before the bull is slaughtered, as he does not want to incur avoidable expenses, <b>one cannot act to the disadvantage</b> of another <b>person in his absence.</b> Therefore, if the bull dies, it is at the expense of the seller.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that there is a different explanation: <b>On those four occasions the Sages based their statement on</b> the <b>Torah law</b> that giving money effects acquisition, and therefore, the payment of the buyer acquires the meat for him with no need for pulling.
<b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan says: By Torah law,</b> giving <b>money effects</b> the <b>acquisition</b> of movable property with no need for pulling. <b>And what is the reason</b> that the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>pulling effects acquisition?</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> the seller, once he receives the money, be unconcerned about the welfare of the movable property that he has sold, and, for example, not protect it from fire, so that he <b>will say to</b> the buyer: <b>Your wheat was burned in the upper story</b> of my house and I have no responsibility for it. For the benefit of rejoicing on the Festival, the Sages ordained that Torah law remains in effect on those four occasions and the buyer’s money effects acquisition, and one compels the butcher to slaughter animals even against his will.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to the phrase <b>“one day” that is stated with regard to</b> the prohibition against slaughtering an animal <b>itself and its offspring, the day follows the night.</b> Therefore, one may slaughter an animal during the day and slaughter its offspring that night, but one may not slaughter an animal at night and slaughter its offspring the following day. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Zoma derived this</b> by means of a verbal analogy. <b>It is stated in the act of Creation: “One day”</b> (Genesis 1:5), <b>and it is stated with regard to</b> the slaughter of an animal <b>itself and its offspring: “One day”</b> (Leviticus 22:28). <b>Just as</b> concerning the phrase <b>“one day” that is stated in the act of Creation, the day follows the night, so too</b> concerning the phrase <b>“one day” that is stated with regard to</b> the slaughter of an animal <b>itself and its offspring, the day follows the night.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Zoma taught this</b> explanation: <b>Because the entire section</b> of the Torah where the prohibition: Itself and its offspring, appears <b>speaks only about sacrificial</b> animals, <b>and with regard to sacrificial</b> animals the <b>night follows the day,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> with regard to <b>this</b> prohibition it <b>is so.</b> Therefore, the following derivation is required: <b>It is stated here,</b> with regard to the slaughter of an animal and its offspring: <b>“One day,” and it is stated in the act of Creation: “One day.” Just as</b> concerning the phrase <b>“one day” that is stated in the act of Creation, the day follows the night, so too</b> concerning the phrase <b>“one day” that is stated with regard to</b> the slaughter of an animal <b>itself and its offspring, the day follows the night.</b>

Daf 83b

§ <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> The verse: “You shall not slaughter it and its offspring both in <b>one day”</b> (Leviticus 22:28), is referring to a special day, and it indicates that <b>a special day requires a proclamation</b> to prevent buyers from slaughtering an animal together with its offspring on that day. <b>From here</b> is derived that which is <b>stated</b> in the mishna: <b>On four occasions during the year,</b> which are special days, <b>one who sells an animal to another must inform him:</b> I sold its mother for slaughter, or: I sold its offspring for slaughter.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mitzva of <b>covering the blood</b> after slaughter <b>is in effect</b> both <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, both <b>in the presence,</b> i.e., the time, <b>of the Temple and not in the presence of the Temple.</b> And it is in effect <b>with regard to non-sacred</b> animals, <b>but</b> it is not in effect <b>with regard to sacrificial</b> ones. <b>And it is in effect with regard to</b> the slaughter of <b>an undomesticated animal and a bird, with regard to</b> animals and birds that are readily <b>available</b> in his home, <b>and with regard to</b> those <b>that are not</b> readily <b>available</b> and are hunted in the wild. <b>And it is in effect with regard to a <i>koy</i>, because it is uncertain</b> whether a <i>koy</i> is a domesticated animal and one is exempt from the covering of its blood or whether it is an undomesticated animal and one is obligated to cover it.
<b>And one may not slaughter</b> a <i>koy</i> <b>on a Festival,</b> because covering its blood entails the performance of prohibited labor that is permitted only if there is a definite obligation to cover the blood. <b>And if one slaughtered</b> a <i>koy</i> on a Festival after the fact, <b>one does not cover its blood</b> until after the Festival.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> one is <b>not</b> obligated to cover the blood of <b>sacrificial</b> birds? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>because of</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Zeira,</b> that is difficult. <b>As Rabbi Zeira says: One who slaughters</b> a bird or an undomesticated animal <b>must place earth beneath</b> the blood <b>and earth above</b> it, <b>as it is stated: “And he shall pour out its blood and cover it with earth”</b> (Leviticus 17:13). It <b>is not stated:</b> Cover it with <b>earth,</b> but <b>rather, “in earth,”</b> indicating that the blood must be concealed inside the earth. The verse <b>teaches that one who slaughters</b> a bird or undomesticated animal <b>must place earth beneath</b> the blood <b>and earth above</b> the blood.
The Gemara continues: <b>And here,</b> with regard to a bird offering, whose blood is presented on the altar, it is <b>not possible</b> for one to cover the blood with earth from beneath it. As <b>how should one perform</b> the covering of the blood? If one suggests that <b>he should place</b> earth on the altar <b>and nullify</b> that earth to the altar such that it will never be removed from there, this is unfeasible, since by nullifying the earth to the altar, <b>he is adding to the structure</b> of the altar. <b>And it is written</b> with regard to the construction of the Temple: <b>“All was in writing, from the hand of the Lord, which He gave me to understand”</b> (I Chronicles 28:19), indicating that the dimensions of the Temple and all the vessels within were given prophetically and are therefore not subject to change.
And if one suggests that <b>he should not nullify</b> the earth to the altar, this too is problematic, as the earth <b>constitutes an interposition</b> between the blood of the bird and the altar.
The Gemara explains why this statement of Rabbi Zeira does not sufficiently explain why one is not required to cover the blood of sacrificial birds. <b>Granted that</b> it is <b>impossible</b> to place earth <b>beneath</b> the blood of the bird, but it is <b>possible</b> to place earth <b>above</b> the blood of the bird. If so, <b>let</b> him <b>perform a covering</b> of the blood from above.
The Gemara explains this suggestion: <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan ben Yosef says:</b> If <b>one slaughtered an undomesticated animal,</b> whose blood requires covering, <b>and thereafter slaughtered a domesticated animal,</b> whose blood does not require covering, in the same location as the undomesticated animal, he is <b>exempt from</b> the obligation <b>to cover</b> the blood of the undomesticated animal, as it is covered with the blood of the domesticated animal. But if one slaughtered <b>a domesticated animal and thereafter</b> slaughtered <b>an undomesticated animal</b> he is <b>obligated to cover</b> the latter’s blood despite the fact that there is no earth, but rather blood of the domesticated animal, beneath it. It is evident from this <i>baraita</i> that the mitzva of covering the blood applies even when earth cannot be placed beneath the blood.
The Gemara responds: The exclusion of sacrificial birds from the mitzva of covering the blood, even from above, is <b>in accordance with</b> another statement <b>of Rabbi Zeira, as Rabbi Zeira says</b> with regard to meal offerings: For <b>any</b> measure of flour <b>that</b> is <b>suitable for mixing</b> with oil in a meal offering, the lack of <b>mixing does not invalidate</b> the meal offering. Even though there is a mitzva to mix the oil with the flour <i>ab initio</i>, the meal offering is fit for sacrifice even if the oil and the flour are not mixed together. <b>And</b> for <b>any</b> measure of flour <b>that</b> is <b>not suitable for mixing</b> with oil in a meal offering, the lack of <b>mixing invalidates</b> the meal offering. Similarly, if one slaughtered a domesticated animal and thereafter an undomesticated animal, since it was possible to cover the blood of the former before slaughtering the latter, which would allow the proper fulfillment of the mitzva of covering the blood, one is still obligated to cover the blood from above. By contrast, it is always impossible to properly perform the mitzva in the case of sacrificial birds.
The Gemara asks: Still, why is the mitzva of covering the blood not applicable to sacrificial birds? <b>Let one scrape</b> the blood off the altar <b>and cover it</b> elsewhere. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (87b): With regard to <b>blood that spurts</b> outside the pit in which the animal was slaughtered, <b>and</b> blood <b>that</b> remained <b>on the</b> slaughtering <b>knife,</b> one is <b>obligated to cover</b> it? <b>Evidently,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that</b> one may <b>scrape</b> off the blood <b>and cover it</b> in a location other than where it spilled out. <b>Here too, let us scrape</b> the blood of a sacrificial bird off the altar <b>and cover it</b> elsewhere.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the ruling of the mishna was dealing <b>with</b> items <b>consecrated for the altar, indeed,</b> the blood must be scraped off and covered elsewhere. But <b>here we are dealing with</b> items <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance,</b> i.e., birds donated to the Temple in order to be sold, the profits of which would be used for repairs. Such birds may not be slaughtered, and if one transgressed and slaughtered them it is prohibited to derive any benefit from them. The <i>tanna</i> of the mishna holds that the mitzva of covering the blood does not apply to a slaughtered animal that is forbidden for consumption.

Daf 84a

The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> even if the mishna is dealing with birds consecrated for Temple maintenance, <b>let one redeem them</b> after they were slaughtered <b>and</b> then <b>cover their</b> blood. The Gemara responds: This is not feasible, because in order to redeem a consecrated animal <b>we require setting and valuating,</b> i.e., the animal must be stood before a priest in order to evaluate it and only then is it redeemed (see Leviticus 27:11–12). A slaughtered bird cannot be stood before the priest; consequently, it cannot be redeemed.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the mishna is dealing with birds consecrated for Temple maintenance, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion is the mishna? <b>If</b> one suggests the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who says: Everything,</b> i.e., animals consecrated both for the altar and for Temple maintenance, <b>was included in</b> the requirement of <b>setting and valuating,</b> and therefore the slaughtered birds may not be redeemed, this cannot be so. <b>Doesn’t he</b> also <b>say</b> that <b>slaughter that is not fit</b> to render the meat permitted <b>is</b> nevertheless <b>considered</b> a halakhic act of <b>slaughter</b> that requires the covering of the blood? If so, one should be obligated to cover the blood of the bird even if it is not redeemed.
The Gemara continues: And <b>if</b> one suggests the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says: Slaughter that is not fit</b> to render the meat permitted <b>is not considered</b> a halakhic act of <b>slaughter</b> and therefore the bird would require redemption in order to cover its blood, this cannot be so. <b>Doesn’t</b> he also <b>say</b> that animals consecrated for Temple maintenance <b>were not included in</b> the requirement of <b>setting and valuating?</b> If so, let one redeem the slaughtered birds and cover their blood.
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> in reconciliation of this dilemma: The mishna’s ruling <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and he formulates</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinions of different <b><i>tanna’im</i>: With regard to</b> the status of an act of <b>slaughter that is not fit</b> to render the meat permitted <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> while <b>with regard to</b> the requirement of <b>setting and valuating he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b> Therefore, since one cannot redeem a bird that was consecrated for Temple maintenance once it has been slaughtered, there is no obligation to cover its blood, as the slaughter was not fit to render the meat permitted.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>the entire</b> mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that birds consecrated for Temple maintenance may be redeemed even after their slaughter. <b>And</b> although it would seem that their slaughter is fit to render the meat permitted and that one should therefore be obligated in the mitzva of covering the blood, it is <b>different here, as the verse states: “And he shall pour out</b> its blood <b>and cover</b> it” (Leviticus 17:13). By juxtaposing “pour out” to “cover,” the verse indicates that the obligation to cover the blood applies only to blood <b>that is lacking only pouring and covering,</b> without any intervening step. <b>Excluded</b> is <b>this</b> blood of birds consecrated for Temple maintenance, <b>which is lacking pouring, redeeming, and covering.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And now that you have arrived at this</b> explanation, <b>you</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna is referring to birds <b>consecrated for the altar.</b> As for the question asked earlier: Why not let one scrape the blood from the altar and then cover it? The verse states: “And he shall pour out its blood and cover it,” indicating that the obligation to cover the blood applies only to blood that is <b>lacking only pouring and covering,</b> without any intervening step. <b>Excluded</b> is <b>this</b> blood of bird offerings, <b>which is lacking pouring, scraping, and covering.</b>
The Gemara cites another source for the exclusion of consecrated animals from the requirement of covering their blood: <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said</b> that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the mitzva of covering the blood: <b>“An undomesticated animal or bird”</b> (Leviticus 17:13). The juxtaposition of these two species intimates an analogy between them: <b>Just as</b> the <b>undomesticated animal</b> referred to in the verse <b>is not consecrated,</b> as undomesticated animals are never fit for sacrifice, <b>so too,</b> the <b>bird</b> referred to in the verse <b>is not consecrated.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> it is so that the <i>halakhot</i> of slaughtering a bird are derived from those of an undomesticated animal, then say: <b>Just as</b> the verse is referring to <b>an undomesticated animal, whose species cannot be consecrated</b> as an offering, <b>so too,</b> the verse is referring only to <b>a bird whose species cannot be consecrated</b> as an offering. Therefore, <b>I will exclude</b> even non-sacred <b>doves and pigeons, whose species can be consecrated.</b>
The Gemara rejects this possibility: <b>No,</b> the juxtaposition indicates that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the slaughter of birds is entirely <b>like</b> that of <b>an undomesticated animal.</b> Therefore, <b>just as</b> in the case of <b>an undomesticated animal, you did not differentiate</b> between its various species and all non-sacred animals are included in the mitzva, <b>so too,</b> with regard to the <b>bird</b> mentioned in the verse, <b>you should not differentiate</b> between its various species.
§ Concerning the <i>halakha</i> that covering the blood does not apply to a domesticated animal, the Gemara says that <b>Ya’akov the heretic said to Rava: We maintain</b> that <b>an undomesticated animal,</b> e.g., a deer, is <b>included</b> in the category of <b>a domesticated animal with regard to</b> the <b>characteristics</b> necessary to determine whether the animal is kosher, i.e., it chews its cud and has split hooves (see Deuteronomy 14:4–6). If so, <b>I will also say</b> that <b>a domesticated animal is included</b> in the category of <b>an undomesticated animal with regard to</b> the mitzva of <b>covering</b> the blood.
Rava <b>said to him: With regard to your</b> claim, <b>the verse states</b> in reference to the blood of a domesticated animal: “You may slaughter of your cattle and of your sheep…but be strong not to eat the blood…<b>you shall pour it out on the ground, like water”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:21–24). Accordingly, <b>just as water does not require covering, so too, this</b> blood of a domesticated animal <b>does not require covering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that the verse equates the blood of a domesticated animal with water, then let one <b>immerse</b> ritually impure items <b>in it</b> to purify them, just as he can immerse them in water. The Gemara responds: <b>The verse states: “But a spring or a cistern, or a gathering of water shall be pure”</b> (Leviticus 11:36). The exclusionary term: “But,” indicates that only concerning <b>these</b> bodies of water, <b>yes,</b> they render pure an impure item, while <b>something else,</b> e.g., blood, does <b>not.</b>
