The Gemara analyzes the mishna: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>minor</b> sources <b>and what</b> is the meaning of <b>major</b> sources? <b>What, is it not</b> that the term: <b>Minor</b> sources, is referring to <b>a creeping animal or a <i>zav</i>, and</b> that the term: <b>Major</b> sources, is referring to <b>a corpse?</b> If so, the mishna teaches that all liquids that issue from a corpse are ritually impure, in contradiction to the <i>baraita</i>. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the term: <b>Minor</b> sources, is referring to <b>a creeping animal,</b> e.g., urine found inside its body, which is not considered ritually impure, <b>and</b> the term: <b>Major</b> sources, is referring to <b>a <i>zav</i>,</b> concerning whom all liquids that issue from him are ritually impure. By contrast, liquids that issue from a corpse are ritually pure with the exception of blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> with regard to <b>a <i>zav</i>, concerning whom the Sages decreed</b> that liquids that issue from him are ritually impure, <b>and what is different</b> with regard to <b>a corpse, concerning which the Sages did not decree</b> that liquids that issue from it are ritually impure? The Gemara responds: In the case of <b>a <i>zav</i>, since people do not</b> naturally <b>separate from him, the Sages decreed</b> additional restrictions <b>with regard to him</b> in order to prevent others from contracting impurity from liquids that issue from a <i>zav</i> that are impure by Torah law. In the case of <b>a corpse, since people</b> naturally <b>separate from it, the Sages did not decree</b> additional restrictions <b>with regard to it.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that one is obligated to cover <b>blood that spurts</b> outside the pit over which the animal was slaughtered, or onto the wall, <b>and</b> blood <b>that</b> remained <b>on the</b> slaughtering <b>knife.</b> With regard to this <i>halakha</i>, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And he shall cover it”</b> (Leviticus 17:13), which <b>teaches that</b> one is <b>obligated to cover blood that spurted and</b> blood <b>that</b> remained <b>on the</b> slaughtering <b>knife. Rabbi Yehuda said: When</b> is this the <i>halakha</i>? <b>When there is no blood except that</b> blood. <b>But</b> if <b>there is</b> other <b>blood that is not that</b> blood, one is <b>exempt from covering</b> it.
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: The term: <b>“And he shall cover it,” teaches that</b> one is <b>obligated to cover all</b> of the <b>blood. From here</b> the Sages <b>stated:</b> With regard to <b>blood that spurts out and</b> blood <b>that</b> remains <b>on the sides</b> of the animal’s throat where it was slaughtered, one is <b>obligated to cover</b> it. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where</b> one <b>did not</b> already <b>cover the blood of the soul,</b> i.e., the blood that flows from the place of slaughter as the animal dies. <b>But if</b> one already <b>covered the blood of the soul,</b> he is <b>exempt from</b> the obligation <b>to cover</b> the blood that spurted out or the blood remaining on the sides of the animal’s neck in the area of slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> matter <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>The Rabbis hold</b> that the expression: <b>“Its blood”</b> (Leviticus 17:13), indicates an obligation to cover <b>all of its blood,</b> even the blood that spurts out. <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>“its blood”</b> indicates that one may fulfill the mitzva with any part of the blood, <b>even</b> with <b>a small amount of its blood. And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel holds</b> that <b>“its blood”</b> refers to the <b>special</b> blood, i.e., the blood of the soul.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>With what</b> substances <b>may one cover</b> the blood <b>and with what</b> substances <b>may one not cover</b> the blood? <b>One</b> may <b>cover</b> the blood <b>with fine</b> granulated <b>manure, with fine sand, with lime, with</b> crushed <b>potsherd, and with a brick or</b> the <b>lid</b> of an earthenware barrel <b>that one crushed. But one may not cover</b> the blood <b>with thick manure, nor with thick,</b> clumped <b>sand, nor with a brick or the lid</b> of an earthenware barrel <b>that one did not crush. Neither may one</b> merely <b>turn a vessel over</b> the blood. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel stated a principle:</b> With regard to <b>a substance in which plants grow, one may cover</b> blood <b>with it; and</b> with regard to a substance in <b>which plants do not grow, one may not cover</b> blood <b>with it.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that one may cover the blood with fine sand. The Gemara asks: <b>What is considered fine sand? Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>any</b> sand <b>that the</b> pottery <b>producer does not need to crush</b> in order to use it. The Gemara notes: <b>And some teach this</b> statement <b>in reference to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, which states: <b>But one may not cover</b> the blood <b>with thick manure, nor with thick sand.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is considered thick sand? Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>any</b> sand <b>that the</b> pottery <b>producer must crush</b> in order to use it.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> these two versions? The Gemara responds: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to sand <b>that requires</b> some crushing <b>and</b> sand that <b>does not require</b> full crushing, i.e., <b>that crumbles</b> in one’s hand and does not require a tool. According to the first version, as long as the sand does not require crushing it may be used to cover the blood. Therefore, sand that requires crumbling may be used since it is not considered sand that requires crushing. According to the second version, any sand that requires some crushing may not be used. Therefore, sand that requires crumbling may not be used to cover the blood.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the mitzva of covering the blood: <b>“And cover it”</b> (Leviticus 17:13). One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>he may cover</b> the blood <b>with stones or</b> merely <b>turn a vessel over it.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “With earth.”</b> Based on this expression <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>earth</b> may be used. <b>From where</b> does one derive <b>to include fine manure, fine sand, crushed stones, crushed potsherd, fine chaff of flax,</b>

Daf 88b

<b>fine sawdust of carpenters, lime,</b> crushed <b>potsherd,</b> and <b>a brick</b> or the <b>lid</b> of an earthenware barrel <b>that one crushed? The verse states: “And cover it,”</b> i.e., with any substance. One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> will <b>include even thick manure, and thick sand, filings of metal vessels, a brick</b> or <b>a lid that one did not crush, flour, bran, and coarse bran.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And cover it <b>with earth,”</b> indicating that not all substances may be used to cover the blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that led you <b>to include these</b> substances <b>and to exclude those?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>After</b> noting <b>that the verse included</b> certain substances with the term: “And cover it,” <b>and excluded</b> others with the term: “With earth,” <b>I include these</b> substances, e.g., fine sand, <b>which are a type of earth</b> in which plants grow, <b>and I exclude those</b> substances, e.g., thick sand, <b>which are not a type of earth,</b> as plants do not grow in them.
The Gemara asks: Why must the verse be interpreted in this manner? <b>Say</b> that the term: <b>“And cover it,”</b> is <b>a generalization,</b> and the term: <b>“With earth,”</b> is <b>a detail.</b> Consequently, the verse constitutes <b>a generalization and a detail,</b> and according to the corresponding hermeneutical principle, <b>the generalization includes only what</b> is mentioned explicitly <b>in the detail.</b> Therefore, only <b>earth may</b> be used to cover the blood, while <b>any other</b> substance, even substances in which plants grow, may <b>not</b> be used.
<b>Rav Mari said</b> in response: One should not suggest such an interpretation <b>because</b> the term “and cover it” <b>is a generalization that requires a detail</b> to clarify its nature, <b>and any generalization that requires a detail</b> to clarify its nature <b>is not interpreted by</b> the hermeneutical principle of <b>a generalization and a detail.</b> It is necessary for the verse to state that the blood must be covered with earth in order to clarify that the mitzva of covering the blood is such that the blood must be covered with a substance that will absorb the blood, and that it does not suffice to place a vessel over it.
§ <b>Rav Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda taught: One may not cover</b> the blood of an undomesticated animal or a bird <b>except with a substance in which</b> seed is <b>sown and sprouts. Rava said: This</b> is <b>an absurdity [<i>burkha</i>],</b> as the mishna and <i>baraita</i> both teach that one may use substances in which seeds do not sprout.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rava: What is the absurdity</b> of <b>his</b> statement? <b>I said this</b> statement to Rav Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda <b>and I said it to him from this <i>baraita</i>:</b> If one <b>is traveling in the desert,</b> where the earth is not arable, and wishes to slaughter an undomesticated animal or a bird, <b>but he does not have dirt</b> with which <b>to cover</b> the blood, <b>he may grind a gold dinar</b> into powder <b>and cover</b> the blood with it. If one <b>is traveling on a ship</b> and wants to slaughter an undomesticated animal or a bird <b>but he does not have earth</b> with which <b>to cover</b> the blood, <b>he may burn his garment and cover</b> the blood with the ashes. It is evident from the first clause of the <i>baraita</i> that desert sand, which does not allow for the sprouting of seeds, may not be used to cover the blood of an undomesticated animal or a bird.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted,</b> it is understood that <b>one may burn his garment and cover</b> the blood with the ashes, since <b>we found</b> a source for the fact that <b>ashes are called earth [<i>afar</i>],</b> as the Gemara will soon prove; accordingly, the use of ashes is in accordance with the verse: “And cover it with earth.” <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a gold dinar, from where do we</b> derive that one may grind it into powder and use it to cover the blood? <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The verse states: <b>“And it has dust of [<i>afrot</i>] gold”</b> (Job 28:6), indicating that gold is referred to as dust.
The Gemara cites a related <i>baraita</i> in which <b>the Sages taught: One may not cover</b> the blood of an undomesticated animal or a bird <b>except with earth;</b> this is <b>the statement of Beit Shammai. And Beit Hillel say: We find that ashes are called dust [<i>afar</i>], as it is stated</b> with regard to the red heifer: <b>“And for the impure they shall take from the ashes [<i>me’afar</i>] of the burning of the purification from sin”</b> (Numbers 19:17). <b>And Beit Shammai</b> respond: Ashes are <b>called dust of the burning [<i>afar sereifa</i>],</b> but <b>they are not called ordinary dust [<i>afar</i>].</b>
The Gemara notes: It is <b>taught</b> that the Sages <b>added</b> the following <b>to the</b> list of substances in the mishna with which one may cover the blood: <b>Coal dust, stibium [<i>keḥol</i>], and shavings from chiseling. And some say</b> they included <b>even arsenic [<i>zarnikh</i>].</b>
§ The Gemara cites aggadic accounts relating to the mitzva of covering the blood: <b>Rava says: As reward</b> for that <b>which our Patriarch Abraham said: “And I am but dust [<i>afar</i>] and ashes”</b> (Genesis 18:27), <b>his children merited two mitzvot: The ashes of the</b> red <b>heifer</b> (see Numbers, chapter 19) <b>and the dust of the <i>sota</i>,</b> i.e., dirt taken from the ground of the Tabernacle that is mixed into the water that examines whether or not a woman committed adultery (see Numbers 5:17).
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let</b> Rava <b>also consider the earth</b> used in the mitzva of <b>covering the blood.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>There,</b> the earth <b>does</b> serve as an <b>accessory to the mitzva</b> of covering the blood, but <b>there is no benefit</b> imparted by it. It occurs after the animal has been slaughtered and does not itself render the meat fit for consumption. By contrast, the ashes of the red heifer and the dust of the <i>sota</i> provide benefit, as the former purifies one who became ritually impure and the latter leads to peace between husband and wife when drinking the water proves that she did not commit adultery.
<b>And Rava says: As reward</b> for that <b>which our Patriarch Abraham said</b> to the king of Sodom:

Daf 89a

<b>“That</b> I will not take <b>a thread nor a shoe strap</b> nor anything that is yours” (Genesis 14:23), distancing himself from anything not rightfully his, <b>his children merited two mitzvot: The thread of sky-blue wool</b> worn on ritual fringes <b>and the strap of phylacteries.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, the strap of</b> the <b>phylacteries</b> imparts benefit, <b>as it is written: “And all the peoples of the earth shall see that the name of the Lord is called upon you;</b> and they shall be afraid of you” (Deuteronomy 28:10). <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer the Great says: This is</b> a reference to <b>the phylacteries of the head,</b> upon which the name of God is written. Phylacteries therefore impart the splendor and grandeur of God and are a fit reward. <b>But what is</b> the benefit imparted by <b>the thread of sky-blue wool?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: What is different about sky-blue from all other colors</b> such that it was specified for the mitzva of ritual fringes? It is <b>because sky-blue</b> dye <b>is similar</b> in its color <b>to the sea, and the sea is similar to the sky, and the sky is similar to the sapphire stone, and the sapphire stone is similar to the Throne of Glory, as it is stated: “And they saw the God of Israel; and there was under His feet</b> the like of a paved work of sapphire stone, and the like of the very heaven for clearness” (Exodus 24:10). This verse shows that the heavens are similar to sapphire, <b>and it is written:</b> “And above the firmament that was over their heads was <b>the likeness of a throne, as the appearance of a sapphire stone”</b> (Ezekiel 1:26). Therefore, the throne is similar to the heavens. The color of sky blue dye acts as an indication of the bond between the Jewish people and the Divine Presence.
The Gemara above mentioned that Abraham refused to accept property that did not belong to him. With regard to this, <b>Rabbi Abba says: Difficult</b> is the return of <b>theft that has been consumed, as even</b> the <b>perfectly righteous are unable to return it, as it is stated:</b> “That I will not take a thread nor a shoe strap nor anything that is yours…<b>except only that which the young men have eaten with me”</b> (Genesis 14:23–24). Even the righteous Abraham was unable to return that which the young men had already consumed.
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon: Any place where you find the statements of Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, in</b> reference to <b>aggada, make your ears like a funnel [<i>ka’afarkeset</i>],</b> i.e., be receptive to his words. As Rabbi Eliezer interpreted the verse: <b>“Not because you are more in number than any people did the Lord desire you</b> and choose you, for you were the fewest of all peoples” (Deuteronomy 7:7), as follows: <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to the Jewish people: I desire you, since even at a time that I bestow greatness</b> upon <b>you, you diminish,</b> i.e., humble, <b>yourselves before Me.</b>
<b>I granted greatness to Abraham,</b> yet <b>he said before Me: “And I am but dust and ashes”</b> (Genesis 18:27). I granted greatness <b>to Moses and Aaron,</b> yet Moses <b>said</b> of the two of them: <b>“And what are we”</b> (Exodus 16:7). I granted greatness <b>to David,</b> yet <b>he said: “But I am a worm, and no man”</b> (Psalms 22:7).
<b>But the</b> gentile <b>nations of the world are not so. I granted greatness to Nimrod,</b> yet <b>he said: “Come, let us build a city</b> and a tower, with its top in heaven, and let us make for ourselves a name” (Genesis 11:4). I granted greatness <b>to Pharaoh,</b> yet <b>he said: “Who is the Lord”</b> (Exodus 5:2). I granted greatness <b>to Sennacherib,</b> yet he said: <b>“Who are they among all the gods of the countries</b> that have delivered their country out of my hand, that the Lord should deliver Jerusalem out of my hand” (II Kings 18:35). I granted greatness <b>to Nebuchadnezzar,</b> yet <b>he said: “I will ascend above the heights of the clouds”</b> (Isaiah 14:14). I granted greatness <b>to Ḥiram, king of Tyre,</b> yet <b>he said: “I sit in the seat of God, in the heart of the seas”</b> (Ezekiel 28:2).
The Gemara relates: <b>Rava says, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> says: <b>Greater</b> is <b>that</b> which <b>is stated with regard to Moses and Aaron than that</b> which <b>is stated with regard to Abraham. As with regard to Abraham it is written: “And I am but dust and ashes,” while with regard to Moses and Aaron it is written: “And what are we,”</b> i.e., we are not even dust and ashes. <b>And Rava says, and some say Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> says: <b>The world endures only in the merit of Moses and Aaron. It is written here: “And what are we,” and it written elsewhere: “He hangs the earth upon nothing”</b> (Job 26:7). That is, the earth endures in the merit of those who said of themselves that they are nothing, i.e., Moses and Aaron.
With regard to that verse, <b>Rabbi Ile’a says: The world endures only in the merit of one who restrains [<i>shebolem</i>] himself during a quarrel, as it is stated: “He hangs the earth upon nothing [<i>belima</i>]. Rabbi Abbahu says:</b> The world endures only in the merit of <b>one who renders himself as if he were non-existent, as it is stated: “And underneath are the everlasting arms”</b> (Deuteronomy 33:27), i.e., one who considers himself to be underneath everything else is the everlasting arm that upholds the world.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “Do you indeed [<i>ha’umnam</i>] speak as a righteous company [<i>elem</i>]? Do you judge with equity [<i>meisharim</i>] the sons of men”</b> (Psalms 58:2)? The verse is interpreted as follows: <b>What</b> should be <b>a person’s occupation [<i>umanut</i>] in this world? He should render himself</b> silent <b>as a mute [<i>ilem</i>].</b> If so, one <b>might</b> have thought that he should render himself as a mute <b>even with regard to words of Torah.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Speak as a righteous</b> company,” indicating that one should speak the righteous words of Torah. If so, he <b>might</b> have thought that one who speaks words of Torah has the right to <b>become arrogant.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Judge with equity [<i>meisharim</i>] the sons of men.”</b> Even a learned judge must take extra care to judge with equity, and not assume that he will immediately arrive at the correct understanding.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the mitzva of covering the blood: <b>Rabbi Zeira says, and some say Rabba bar Yirmeya</b> says: <b>One may cover</b> the blood of an undomesticated animal or a bird <b>with the dust of an idolatrous city.</b> The Torah states that the city and anything contained therein must be burned (see Deuteronomy 13:17). The Gemara, assuming the statement of Rabbi Zeira refers to the ashes of a burned idolatrous city, asks: <b>But why</b> may one use these ashes to cover the blood? <b>These</b> ashes <b>are items from which</b> deriving <b>benefit is prohibited,</b> as the verse states: “And there shall cleave none of the banned property to your hand” (Deuteronomy 13:18).
<b>Ze’eiri said:</b> Rabbi Zeira is not referring to the ashes of the burned city, which may not be used. Rather, his statement is <b>necessary only concerning the dust of its dust,</b> i.e., the dust of the ground of the idolatrous city, from which deriving benefit is not prohibited, <b>as it is written: “And you shall gather all its spoil into the midst of the broad place thereof, and shall burn</b> with fire the city” (Deuteronomy 13:17). Accordingly, items <b>lacking only</b> the acts of <b>gathering and burning</b> must be burned. This serves to exclude <b>this</b> dust of the ground, <b>which lacks</b> the acts of <b>removal</b> from the ground, <b>gathering, and burning.</b> The dust must also be removed from the ground before it can be gathered and burned.
<b>And Rava says:</b> One can even use the ashes from the idolatrous city to cover the blood, despite the fact that it is prohibited to derive any benefit from them. This is because <b>mitzvot were not given for benefit,</b> that is, the fulfillment of a mitzva is not considered deriving benefit, but the fulfillment of a divine decree.
The Gemara relates that <b>Ravina was sitting and saying this <i>halakha</i>,</b> that one may use the ashes of an idolatrous city to cover the blood. <b>Rav Reḥumi raised an objection to Ravina</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a shofar of idol worship,</b> from which it is prohibited to derive benefit, <b>one may not blow with it. What, is it not</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means to say that <b>if one blew</b> with it <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that one should not use such a shofar <i>ab initio</i>, but <b>if one blew</b> with it <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation.
Rav Reḥumi persists: It is taught in another <i>baraita</i> that with regard to <b>a <i>lulav</i> of idol worship, one may not take</b> it to perform the mitzva. <b>What, is it not</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means to say that <b>if one took</b> such a <i>lulav</i> he has <b>not fulfilled</b> his obligation? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that one should not use such a <i>lulav ab initio</i>, but <b>if one took</b> it <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that if <b>one blew</b> a shofar of idolatry <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation? And isn’t it taught in another <i>baraita</i> that if <b>one took</b> a <i>lulav</i> of idolatry to perform the mitzva <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation?
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> in response: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared</b> to the case of covering the blood? <b>There,</b> with regard to a shofar and <i>lulav</i> of idol worship, although the use of such items for a mitzva does not constitute benefit, one cannot fulfill his obligation with them, because

Daf 89b

<b>we require</b> a minimum <b>measure</b> in order to fulfill these mitzvot. A shofar must be large enough that, when grasped, part of it protrudes from both sides of one’s hand, and a <i>lulav</i> must be at least four handbreadths long. <b>And</b> since an object of <b>idol worship</b> and its effects must be burned, <b>its size</b> as required for the mitzva <b>is seen</b> by <i>halakha</i> <b>as crushed</b> into powder. Since a <i>shofar</i> or <i>lulav</i> of idol worship is destined for burning, it is considered as if it is already burned, and it therefore lacks the requisite measurement for fulfilling the mitzva. By contrast, <b>here,</b> with regard to the ashes used to perform the mitzva of covering the blood, no minimum measure is required to fulfill the mitzva; in fact, <b>the more</b> the ash <b>is crushed, the better it is for</b> the mitzva of <b>covering</b> the blood.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The prohibition of eating <b>the sciatic nerve applies</b> both <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>in the presence of,</b> i.e., the time of, <b>the Temple and not in the presence of the Temple,</b> and <b>with regard to non-sacred</b> animals <b>and with regard to sacrificial</b> animals. <b>And it applies to domesticated animals and to undomesticated animals, to</b> the <b>thigh of the right</b> leg <b>and to</b> the <b>thigh of the left</b> leg. <b>But it does not apply to a bird, due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the verse makes reference to the sciatic nerve as being “upon the spoon of the thigh” (Genesis 32:33), and a bird <b>has no spoon</b> of the thigh.
And the prohibition <b>applies to</b> a late-term animal <b>fetus [<i>shalil</i>]</b> in the womb. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: It does not apply to a fetus; and</b> similarly, <b>its fat is permitted.</b>
<b>And butchers are not deemed credible</b> to say that <b>the sciatic nerve</b> was removed; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: They are deemed credible about</b> the sciatic nerve <b>and about the</b> forbidden <b>fat.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve applies to both non-sacred animals and sacrificial animals. The Gemara asks: Is it not <b>obvious</b> that the prohibition applies to <b>sacrificial</b> animals? Would it be reasonable to suggest that <b>because one consecrated it, he has abrogated the prohibition of</b> eating the sciatic <b>nerve from it?</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that sciatic <b>nerves have</b> the ability to <b>impart flavor,</b> i.e., they possess flavor, <b>and</b> the mishna is teaching that <b>the prohibition of</b> eating meat of <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>comes and takes effect upon</b> the sciatic nerve despite the fact that it is already subject to the <b>prohibition of</b> eating the sciatic <b>nerve,</b> the mishna <b>should have</b> stated: The prohibition of eating meat of <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>applies to the</b> sciatic <b>nerve.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Rather,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>holds</b> that the sciatic <b>nerve does not have</b> the ability to <b>impart flavor, and</b> the mishna is teaching that <b>with regard to sacrificial</b> animals <b>there is a prohibition</b> of eating the sciatic <b>nerve</b> but <b>there is no</b> additional <b>prohibition</b> of eating the meat of <b>a sacrificial</b> animal.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>And</b> does <b>the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna <b>hold</b> that the sciatic <b>nerve does not have</b> the ability to <b>impart flavor? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (96b): In the case of <b>a thigh that was cooked</b> with <b>the sciatic nerve in it, if there is</b> enough of the sciatic nerve <b>in</b> the thigh to <b>impart</b> its <b>flavor</b> to the meat, the entire thigh <b>is forbidden?</b> Consequently, it is clear that the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna holds that the sciatic nerve does possess flavor.
<b>Rather,</b> in the mishna <b>here we are dealing with offspring of sacrificial</b> animals. <b>And</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve <b>applies with regard to a fetus, and</b> he also <b>holds</b> that the <b>offspring of sacrificial</b> animals <b>are consecrated</b> even while they are <b>in the womb of their mother.</b> Consequently, the <b>prohibition of</b> eating the sciatic <b>nerve and the prohibition of</b> eating <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>come</b> into effect <b>at the same time,</b> and therefore both prohibitions apply and one does not say that a prohibition does not take effect where another prohibition already exists.
The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>Can you interpret</b> this clause of the mishna as referring <b>to a fetus? From</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause teaches: It applies to</b> a late-term <b>fetus,</b> and Rabbi Yehuda holds that it does not apply to a late-term fetus, <b>it may be inferred that</b> in <b>the first</b> clause <b>we are not dealing with a fetus.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>This</b> is what the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>is saying: This matter</b> that was taught in the first clause <b>is</b> a matter of <b>dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis.</b>
The Gemara again challenges the explanation that the first clause of the mishna is referring to a fetus: <b>And how can you say that both</b> prohibitions <b>come</b> into effect <b>at the same time? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Nazir</i> 49b): <b>A nazirite shaves for</b> having become impure from <b>these</b> sources of <b>ritual impurity: For</b> impurity imparted by <b>a corpse and for</b> impurity imparted by <b>an olive-bulk of a corpse.</b>
<b>And</b> the clause: For impurity imparted by a corpse, is <b>difficult for us,</b> as it seems unnecessary; if a nazirite <b>must shave for</b> impurity imparted by <b>an olive-bulk of a corpse,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> true that he must shave <b>for</b> impurity imparted by <b>an entire</b> corpse? <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>necessary only for a miscarried</b> human <b>fetus whose limbs had not</b> yet <b>become joined to</b> its <b>sinews.</b> Since the spine is complete the fetus is considered a full corpse, but as the limbs have not yet joined to the sinews it does not contain an olive-bulk of flesh.

Daf 90a

<b>Evidently,</b> the limbs of the body are formed before the nerves and sinews, and therefore the <b>prohibition of</b> eating <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>precedes</b> the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve.
The Gemara answers: <b>Even though the prohibition of</b> eating <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>precedes</b> the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve, the <b>prohibition of</b> eating the sciatic <b>nerve comes and takes effect upon</b> the offspring of consecrated animals, <b>because</b> the <b>prohibition</b> of eating the sciatic nerve adds an extra stringency in that it <b>applies</b> also <b>to descendants of Noah.</b> The prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve was in effect from the time Jacob wrestled with the angel (see Genesis 32:25–33), before the Torah was given. At that time, Jacob and his sons had the status of descendants of Noah, i.e., gentiles. Therefore, the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve is broader than the prohibition of eating meat of sacrificial animals, which took effect only when the Torah was given.
The Gemara challenges this answer: <b>Whom did you hear</b> holds in accordance with <b>this reasoning?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> cited in a later mishna (100b). <b>But the mishna</b> here <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as it teaches</b> that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve <b>applies to domesticated animals and to undomesticated animals, to</b> the <b>thigh of the right</b> leg <b>and to</b> the <b>thigh of the left</b> leg. By contrast, Rabbi Yehuda holds that the prohibition applies only with regard to the sciatic nerve in the thigh of one leg (see 90b).
The Gemara explains: The <b><i>tanna</i></b> of <b>this</b> mishna <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda <b>with regard to one</b> <i>halakha</i>, i.e., that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve applies to the descendants of Noah, <b>and disagrees with his</b> opinion <b>with regard to one</b> <i>halakha</i> and holds that the prohibition applies to the sciatic nerves of both legs.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Say that you heard that Rabbi Yehuda</b> rules that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve takes effect in addition to the prohibition <b>with regard to a non-kosher</b> animal, <b>which is a prohibition</b> punishable by lashes. Since the prohibition of the sciatic nerve is broader in that it applies to the descendants of Noah, it takes effect even though the animal is already prohibited as being not kosher. But in the case of <b>sacrificial</b> animals, <b>whose</b> consumption by an impure person is <b>a prohibition</b> punishable by <b><i>karet</i>, did you hear</b> that Rabbi Yehuda considers the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve more stringent, such that it takes effect even though the animal is already prohibited? Therefore, this answer is rejected.
The Gemara offers an alternative answer: <b>Rather, here</b> in the mishna <b>we are dealing with</b> a non-sacred animal <b>giving birth to</b> its <b>firstborn, which</b> becomes <b>sanctified</b> as it leaves the <b>womb.</b> The mishna teaches that although the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve does not apply to the offspring of sacrificial animals, because their sacrificial status renders them prohibited for consumption before the prohibition of the sciatic nerve takes effect, that is not the case with regard to a firstborn. The sanctified status of a firstborn takes effect only as it leaves the womb, which is after the prohibition of the sciatic nerve takes effect.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the mishna is dealing with the <b>offspring of</b> all <b>sacrificial</b> animals, and this <i>tanna</i> holds that such animals <b>are sanctified</b> only <b>when they come into being</b> as independent creatures, i.e., at birth. Consequently, the prohibition of the sciatic nerve takes effect before the animal becomes prohibited at the time of its birth; or, according to the opinion that the sciatic nerve is permitted in a fetus, the two prohibitions take effect simultaneously.
§ Having addressed the need for the mishna to state that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve applies with regard to sacrificial animals, the Gemara discusses which types of sacrificial animals are included in this prohibition. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that the prohibition of the sciatic nerve applies <b>only</b> with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>that are eaten,</b> e.g., sin offerings, guilt offerings and peace offerings; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>that are not eaten,</b> e.g., burnt offerings, <b>the prohibition</b> of the sciatic <b>nerve does not apply. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The prohibition</b> of the sciatic <b>nerve applies both</b> with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>that are eaten and</b> with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>that are not eaten.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef and Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>do not disagree;</b> they are merely referring to different cases. <b>Here,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan says that the prohibition of the sciatic nerve applies <b>with regard to flogging</b> one who eats it. <b>There,</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef says that the prohibition of the sciatic nerve does not apply <b>with regard to bringing</b> the meat of the animal <b>up</b> to the altar, i.e., offerings that are burned on the altar are brought up with the sciatic nerve. Burning the sciatic nerve on the altar is not comparable to eating it and is not prohibited.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rav Pappa said</b> as follows: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef and Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>do not disagree;</b> they are merely referring to different cases. <b>Here,</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef says that the prohibition of the sciatic nerve does not apply to burnt offerings, in that one is not required <b>to remove it</b> before burning the offering on the altar. <b>There,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan says that he prohibition does apply, in that if one did remove the sciatic nerve, it is prohibited <b>to bring it up</b> onto the altar independently.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</b> disagreed with Rav Pappa and <b>said:</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef and Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>disagree</b> with regard to whether it is permitted <b>to bring up</b> the sciatic nerve to the altar even when it remains in the thigh. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the verse: <b>“And the priest shall make it all smoke on the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:9), the term “it all” serves <b>to include the bones, and the sinews, and the horns, and the hooves</b> among those items burned on the altar.
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> if <b>they became detached</b> from the flesh of the burnt offering they are burned upon the altar. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood,</b> upon the altar of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:27), indicating that only the flesh and the blood are offered upon the altar.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If</b> it is only <b>the flesh and the blood</b> that are offered on the altar, one <b>might</b> have thought that a priest must first <b>remove the sinews and bones</b> from an offering <b>and</b> only then may he <b>bring up the flesh</b> to be burned <b>upon the altar.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And the priest shall make it all smoke on the altar,”</b> including the sinews and bones. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? If the sinews and bones are <b>attached</b> to the flesh, <b>they shall ascend.</b> If they <b>became detached</b> from the flesh, then <b>even</b> if they are already <b>at the top of the altar, they shall descend.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And who is the <i>tanna</i> that you heard, who said</b> if <b>they became detached</b> from the flesh, <b>they shall descend? It is Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the verse that states: <b>“And the priest shall make it all smoke</b> on the altar,” the term “it all” serves <b>to include the bones, and the sinews, and the horns, and the hooves</b> among those items burned on the altar, <b>and</b> that is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if <b>they became detached</b> from the flesh of the offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>But</b> if so, <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of the verse: <b>“And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood,</b> upon the altar of the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 12:27), which indicates that only the flesh and blood of an offering are offered on the altar? It is referring <b>to</b> parts of the offering that become <b>dislodged</b> from the fire. <b>How so?</b> If the partially <b>consumed flesh</b> of a burnt offering is dislodged from the altar, <b>you return</b> it to the fire, <b>but you do not return</b> the partially <b>consumed sinews and bones</b> that become dislodged.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that <b>one verse states: “And the priest shall make it all smoke</b> on the altar,” which <b>included</b> sinews and bones. <b>And one verse states: “And you shall offer your burnt offerings, the flesh and the blood,”</b> which <b>excluded</b> any part other than the flesh and the blood. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? If the sinews and bones were <b>attached</b> to the flesh, <b>they shall ascend.</b> If they <b>became detached</b> from the flesh, then <b>even</b> if they are already <b>on top of the altar, they shall descend.</b>
The Gemara explains their dispute: <b>And the Rabbis</b> hold that with regard to sinews and bones that <b>are attached</b> to the flesh it <b>was not necessary</b> for <b>a verse to include</b> the obligation to bring them up to the altar. It is clear that they must be brought up, <b>just as it is</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>the head of a burnt offering,</b> which contains many bones, is brought up, as stated explicitly in the verse: “And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall lay the pieces, and the head, and the fat, in order upon the wood that is on the fire that is upon the altar” (Leviticus 1:8). <b>When a verse was necessary</b> it was <b>for</b> the case where the sinews and bones <b>became detached</b> from the flesh. Consequently, when the verse uses the inclusive phrase “it all,” it is to include sinews and bones that became detached.
<b>But Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi holds that with regard to sinews and bones that are <b>attached</b> to the flesh and <b>that are permitted</b> to be eaten,

Daf 90b

<b>it was not necessary</b> for <b>the verse to include</b> them. <b>When</b> a verse <b>was necessary</b> it was <b>for the sciatic nerve that</b> is still <b>attached</b> to the flesh. The term “it all” teaches that if the sciatic nerve is attached to the flesh it is brought up to the altar.
<b>And the Rabbis</b> would explain their opinion based upon the verse: “And one lamb of the flock, out of two hundred, <b>from the well-watered pastures [<i>mimashke</i>] of Israel;</b> for a meal offering, and for a burnt offering, and for peace offerings, to make atonement for them, says the Lord God” (Ezekiel 45:15). Since the term <i>mashke</i> also means beverage, which is consumed, the verse is interpreted to mean that offerings may be sacrificed only <b>from that which is permitted to the Jewish people</b> for consumption. Since the sciatic nerve is not permitted for consumption, it may not be sacrificed on the altar. Consequently, the term “it all” is understood to include sinews and bones even if they have become detached from the flesh.
<b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi would respond that a sciatic nerve that is attached to the flesh may be brought up to the altar, <b>just as it is</b> permitted to sacrifice forbidden <b>fat and blood</b> upon the altar even though they are forbidden for consumption. <b>And the Rabbis</b> would say that forbidden fat and blood <b>are different,</b> because the Torah explicitly states that <b>their mitzva is</b> to be offered on the altar <b>in this</b> way, whereas the Torah never mandates the sacrifice of the sciatic nerve upon the altar. According to Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef agrees with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi that the sciatic nerve is offered upon the altar together with the rest of the animal, whereas Rabbi Yoḥanan holds in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis that the sciatic nerve is not offered upon the altar.
§ The Gemara cites another discussion with regard to the sciatic nerve of a burnt offering. <b>Rav Huna says: The sciatic nerve of a burnt offering</b> is not placed upon the altar with the rest of the animal. Rather, <b>one removes it</b> and places it <b>on the</b> circular <b>mound</b> of ashes in the center of the altar. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Master of this [<i>mari dikhi</i>]</b> ruling! <b>Is it written</b> in the Torah: <b>Therefore the altar does not consume</b> the sciatic nerve? This would indicate that it is prohibited to sacrifice the sciatic nerve on the altar. Rather, it <b>is written: “Therefore the children of Israel eat not</b> the sciatic nerve” (Genesis 32:33).
<b>And Rav Huna</b> holds that the phrase: <b>“From the well-watered pastures of Israel,”</b> indicates that offerings may be sacrificed only <b>from that which is permitted to the Jewish people.</b> Since the sciatic nerve is not permitted for consumption, it may not be sacrificed upon the altar.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav Huna’s opinion. It is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: What should one do with <b>the sciatic nerve of a peace offering,</b> since the meat of the offering must be eaten but the sciatic nerve is forbidden? <b>One sweeps it to the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain. And</b> in the case of the sciatic nerve <b>of a burnt offering, one brings it up</b> to the altar. The Gemara comments: <b>What, is it not</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means that <b>he brings it up</b> to the altar <b>and burns it</b> with the rest of the animal, which contradicts the statement of Rav Huna?
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that <b>he brings it up</b> to the altar <b>and removes it</b> from the thigh before placing the thigh on the fire. The Gemara asks: <b>But since he removes it</b> from the thigh, <b>why does he bring it up</b> to the altar? The Gemara answers that one cannot bring the thigh up to the altar after the sciatic nerve has been removed <b>because it is stated</b> with regard to one who sacrifices offerings that are damaged or unattractive: <b>“Present it now unto your governor;</b> will he be pleased with you, or will he accept your person? says the Lord of hosts” (Malachi 1:8). Consequently, the leg of the animal must be brought up to the altar while it is whole, and the sciatic nerve must be removed on top of the altar.
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Huna:</b> With regard to the <b>sciatic nerve of a peace offering, one sweeps it into the</b> Temple courtyard <b>drain; and</b> with regard to the sciatic nerve <b>of a burnt offering, one removes it</b> and places it <b>on the</b> circular <b>mound</b> of ashes in the center of the altar.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Tamid</i> 28b): <b>There was</b> a circular <b>mound</b> of ashes <b>in the center of the altar,</b> and <b>sometimes there was</b> as much <b>as three hundred <i>kor</i></b> of ashes <b>upon it. Rava said:</b> This description is <b>an exaggeration [<i>guzma</i>];</b> the <i>tanna</i> means merely that there was a significant quantity of ashes.
Similarly, it is taught in a mishna (<i>Tamid</i> 30a) that before slaughtering the daily offering the priests <b>gave</b> the lamb selected for <b>the daily offering</b> water <b>to drink in a golden cup,</b> in order to render the animal easier to flay after slaughter. With regard to this mishna, <b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>an exaggeration,</b> as the priests did not actually let the animal drink from a golden vessel.
The Gemara provides other examples of statements not meant literally. <b>Rabbi Ami says:</b> In some instances, <b>the Torah spoke</b> employing <b>exaggerated [<i>havai</i>] language, the Prophets spoke</b> employing <b>exaggerated language,</b> and <b>the Sages spoke</b> employing <b>exaggerated language.</b> The fact that <b>the Sages spoke</b> employing <b>exaggerated language</b> is evident from <b>that which we stated above,</b> concerning the mound of ashes and the lamb of the daily offering.
<b>The Torah spoke</b> employing <b>exaggerated language,</b> as it is written: “Hear, Israel: You are passing over the Jordan this day, to go in to dispossess nations greater and mightier than you, <b>cities great and fortified up to heaven”</b> (Deuteronomy 9:1), whereas the fortifications obviously did not actually reach up to heaven. <b>The Prophets spoke</b> employing <b>exaggerated language,</b> as it is written with regard to the coronation of King Solomon: “And all the people came up after him, and the people piped with pipes, and rejoiced with great joy, <b>so that the earth rent with the sound of them”</b> (I Kings 1:40), where the verse means merely that the sound was very loud.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Naḥmani says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: In three places the Sages spoke</b> in <b>exaggerated language, and they are</b> with regard to the circular <b>mound</b> of ashes on the altar; the <b>vine; and</b> the <b>Curtain</b> separating the Sanctuary and Holy of Holies. The case of the circular <b>mound</b> of ashes <b>is that which we said.</b>
The case of the <b>vine</b> is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Middot</i> 36a): <b>A golden</b> ornament in the form of <b>a vine was standing at the entrance to the Sanctuary,</b> and it was <b>hung upon poles. And whoever would donate</b> an ornamental golden leaf, <b>grape, or cluster</b> of grapes to the Temple would <b>bring</b> it to the Temple <b>and hang</b> it <b>upon</b> the vine. <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, said: There was</b> once <b>an incident, and three hundred priests were enlisted to move</b> the vine because of its immense weight. According to Shmuel, this description is also an exaggeration.
The case of the <b>Curtain</b> is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 8:2): <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says in the name of Rabbi Shimon, the deputy</b> High Priest: The <b>Curtain</b> is the <b>thickness of a handbreadth [<i>tefaḥ</i>]. It is woven from seventy-two strands [<i>nirim</i>]</b> of yarn, <b>and each and every strand [<i>nima</i>]</b> of those seventy-two is made from <b>twenty-four threads</b> consisting of six threads each of sky-blue wool, purple wool, scarlet wool, and fine linen. <b>Its length</b> is <b>forty cubits,</b> the height of the Sanctuary, <b>and its width</b> is <b>twenty cubits,</b> the width of the entrance. <b>And</b> it <b>is made from eighty-two ten-thousands,</b> i.e., 820,000 dinars. <b>And</b> the overseers of the Temple <b>make two</b> new Curtains every <b>year. And</b> the Curtain was so heavy that when it was immersed, <b>three hundred priests would immerse it.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that the prohibition of the sciatic nerve applies <b>to</b> the <b>thigh of the right</b> leg <b>and to</b> the <b>thigh of the left</b> leg. The Gemara says: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The prohibition of the sciatic nerve <b>applies only to</b> the sciatic nerve <b>in one</b> of the animal’s thighs, <b>and logic dictates</b> that it is <b>the right</b> thigh.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Is it <b>obvious to Rabbi Yehuda</b> that the prohibition applies only to the sciatic nerve in the right thigh, <b>and</b> accordingly, <b>what</b> does he mean when he says that <b>logic</b> dictates? He means <b>the logic of the Torah. Or perhaps he is uncertain</b> as to whether it applies only to the right thigh or only to the left, <b>and</b> accordingly, <b>what</b> does he mean when he says that <b>logic</b> dictates? He means that <b>logic inclines</b> one to believe that the prohibition applies to the right thigh.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution based upon the following mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 83a): <b>The bones</b> of the Paschal offering that contain edible marrow but cannot be eaten because it is prohibited to break the bones of the Paschal offering; <b>and the sinews; and the leftover</b> meat <b>should</b> all <b>be burned on the sixteenth</b> of Nisan, not on the fifteenth, the first day of Passover. <b>And we discussed it: What are the circumstances</b> in which <b>these sinews</b> must be burned? <b>If we say</b> they are <b>sinews of meat, let one eat them.</b> Why are they burned? <b>And if</b> they are sinews <b>that were left over</b> and not eaten, <b>that is</b> the case of <b>leftover</b> meat; why does the mishna list sinews separately? <b>Rather,</b> the mishna is referring to <b>sinews of the neck,</b> which are different from other sinews and are therefore mentioned separately. But <b>if they are not meat,</b> why do they require burning? <b>Let one</b> simply <b>discard them</b> like other waste.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The mishna’s mention of sinews <b>is necessary only</b> in order to teach the <i>halakha</i> <b>of the sciatic nerve,</b> and <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, who said:</b> The prohibition of the sciatic nerve <b>applies only to</b> the sciatic nerve in <b>one</b> of the animal’s thighs, and not to both.
The Gemara explains how this resolves the dilemma: <b>Granted if you say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda <b>is uncertain</b> as to whether it is the sciatic nerve of the right or the left thigh, it works out <b>well.</b> Since it is uncertain which thigh may be eaten, one may not eat either of them, and one must burn each of them on the sixteenth due to the possibility that it was the permitted one and now has the status of leftover meat. <b>But if you say</b> that it is <b>obvious to</b> Rabbi Yehuda that the sciatic nerve of only the right thigh is forbidden, <b>let him eat</b> the sciatic nerve <b>of the permitted</b> left thigh, and <b>let him throw</b> away only the sciatic nerve <b>of the forbidden</b> right thigh. Neither one should be burned.
The Gemara responds: <b>Rav Ika bar Ḥanina said: Actually I</b> could <b>say to you</b> that it is <b>obvious to</b> Rabbi Yehuda that the sciatic nerve of only the right thigh is forbidden. Nevertheless, <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the sciatic nerves <b>were identified</b> and removed, <b>but ultimately</b> the sciatic nerves <b>became intermingled</b> and one cannot tell which is from the right thigh and which is from the left thigh. Consequently, they must both be left over until the next day and then burned.

Daf 91a

<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The mishna’s ruling that the sinews must be burned <b>is necessary only</b> with regard to the <b>fat</b> around the sciatic nerve, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>fat</b> around the sciatic nerve <b>is permitted</b> by Torah law, <b>but the Jewish people are holy</b> and <b>treated it as forbidden.</b> Since it is permitted by Torah law, it has the status of sacrificial meat and may not be simply discarded. Nevertheless, since the Jewish people treat it as forbidden, they do not eat it even from the Paschal offering, despite the mitzva to eat that offering in its entirety. Therefore, it is left until after the time when the meat may be eaten and it is burned as leftover sacrificial meat.
<b>Ravina said:</b> The mishna’s statement <b>is necessary only</b> with regard to the outer nerve, and it is <b>in accordance with that which Rav Yehuda</b> said that <b>Shmuel said. As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: There are two nerves</b> included in the prohibition of the sciatic nerve. The <b>inner</b> nerve that is <b>next to the bone is forbidden</b> by Torah law, <b>and one is liable</b> to be flogged <b>for</b> eating <b>it.</b> The <b>outer</b> nerve that is <b>next to the flesh is forbidden</b> by rabbinic law, <b>and</b> therefore <b>one is not liable</b> to be flogged <b>for</b> eating <b>it.</b> In the case of a Paschal offering, since the outer nerve is permitted by Torah law, it assumes the status of leftover sacrificial meat when it is not eaten.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another resolution to the dilemma about Rabbi Yehuda’s statement, from a mishna (96a): If <b>one ate an olive-bulk from this</b> sciatic nerve of the right leg <b>and an olive-bulk from that</b> sciatic nerve of the left leg, <b>he incurs eighty</b> lashes. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He incurs only forty</b> lashes.
<b>Granted, if you say</b> it is <b>obvious to</b> Rabbi Yehuda that the sciatic nerve of the right thigh is the one forbidden by Torah law, it is <b>well. But if you say he is uncertain,</b> why would he hold that one incurs any lashes? When the individual is forewarned not to partake of each sciatic nerve, which is necessary in order to be liable for incurring lashes, <b>it is an uncertain forewarning, and we have heard</b> about <b>Rabbi Yehuda that he said: An uncertain forewarning is not characterized as forewarning.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one is uncertain which of two men is his father and he <b>struck this</b> one <b>and then struck that</b> one, or <b>cursed this</b> one <b>and then cursed that</b> one, or <b>struck both of them simultaneously, or cursed both of them simultaneously, he is liable</b> to receive the death penalty, as he certainly struck or cursed his father. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If he struck or cursed both of them <b>simultaneously he is liable,</b> provided he was forewarned that his action will certainly render him liable to receive the death penalty. But if he struck or cursed them <b>one after the other he is exempt.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda is of the opinion that one is not punished after uncertain forewarning; since in this case it is impossible to determine which of them is the father, inevitably each forewarning is uncertain. Similarly, if Rabbi Yehuda is uncertain which sciatic nerve is forbidden by Torah law, he should hold that since the forewarning before eating either sciatic nerve is uncertain, one who consumes both should be exempt.
The Gemara answers: <b>This <i>tanna</i></b> of that mishna, on 96a, <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>another <i>tanna</i></b> with regard to the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, who said</b> that Rabbi Yehuda holds that <b>an uncertain forewarning is characterized as forewarning.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the Paschal offering: <b>“And you shall not leave any of it until morning;</b> but that which remains of it until morning you shall burn with fire” (Exodus 12:10). <b>The verse comes to provide a positive mitzva</b> to burn the leftover meat <b>after</b> it has taught <b>a prohibition</b> against leaving it over, <b>to say that one is not flogged for</b> violation <b>of</b> the prohibition; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> Rabbi Yehuda holds that one is not flogged for any transgression that can be rectified by the performance of a positive mitzva.
<b>Rabbi Ya’akov says: This,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that one is not flogged, <b>is not for</b> that <b>reason. Rather,</b> it is <b>because</b> leaving over sacrificial meat <b>is a prohibition that does not involve an action,</b> as one violates the prohibition through failure to take action, <b>and</b> concerning <b>any prohibition that does not involve an action, one is not flogged for</b> its violation. The forewarning one could receive for this transgression is an uncertain one, because witnesses who forewarn the individual cannot be certain until daybreak that he will leave it over. Nevertheless, this <i>baraita</i> indicates that if not for the fact that leaving over sacrificial meat can be rectified by a positive mitzva, Rabbi Yehuda would hold that one is flogged for leaving over sacrificial meat.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution of the uncertainty with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one ate two</b> sciatic <b>nerves from two thighs of two</b> different <b>animals, he incurs eighty</b> lashes. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He incurs only forty</b> lashes.
The Gemara comments: <b>From</b> the fact that the first <i>tanna</i> <b>said</b> that he was referring to <b>two thighs of two</b> different <b>animals,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that he meant they were both from the right thigh, because if one were from the right thigh and one were from the left thigh it would not matter if they were from two different animals or from the same animal. Consequently, <b>both</b> sciatic nerves are definitely <b>forbidden</b> by Torah law, and according to the first <i>tanna</i> one incurs eighty lashes for eating them. <b>And</b> it <b>was necessary</b> to teach that <b>according to Rabbi Yehuda</b> one incurs only forty lashes, as will be explained. <b>Conclude from</b> this <i>baraita</i> that it is <b>obvious to</b> Rabbi Yehuda that it is the sciatic nerve of the right thigh that is forbidden by Torah law. The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from</b> it that this is Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion.
The Gemara seeks to clarify the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But if it</b> is <b>obvious to</b> Rabbi Yehuda that the sciatic nerve from the right thigh is prohibited by Torah law, <b>why</b> does he <b>incur forty</b> lashes <b>and nothing more? Let him be flogged eighty</b> times. The Gemara answers: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the volume of one of the sciatic nerves <b>is not an olive-bulk,</b> and Rabbi Yehuda holds that in such a case one is not flogged for its consumption. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one ate</b> the entire sciatic nerve <b>and</b> its volume <b>is not an olive-bulk,</b> he is nevertheless <b>liable</b> to be flogged, because he ate a complete, natural unit of forbidden food. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> He is not liable <b>unless it has</b> a volume of at least <b>an olive-bulk.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that Rabbi Yehuda holds that only the sciatic nerve of the right thigh is forbidden by Torah law? <b>Rava said</b> that it is because the <b>verse states:</b> “Therefore the children of Israel eat not the sciatic nerve that is upon the spoon of <b>the thigh”</b> (Genesis 32:33). The definite article indicates that this is referring to <b>the most important thigh.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the sciatic nerves of both the right and left thighs are forbidden by Torah law, explain the definite article as teaching that the prohibition applies to <b>the one whose prohibition spreads through the entire thigh,</b> i.e., the inner nerve. This serves <b>to exclude</b> the <b>outer</b> nerve, <b>which is not</b> prohibited by Torah law.
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said</b> that Rabbi Yehuda holds that the sciatic nerve of the right thigh is forbidden because <b>the verse states:</b> “And when he saw that he could not prevail against him, he touched the spoon of his thigh; and the spoon of Jacob’s thigh was strained, <b>as he wrestled with him”</b> (Genesis 32:26). The angel grappled with Jacob <b>like a man who hugs another</b> in order to throw him to the ground, <b>and his hand reaches to the spoon of the right</b> thigh <b>of the other.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani says:</b> The angel <b>appeared to him as a gentile, as the Master said: A Jew who is joined by a gentile on the road</b> and continues his travels with him should <b>position</b> the gentile <b>to his right,</b> close to one’s dominant hand. This allows the Jew to defend himself against any potential attack. Since Jacob followed this practice, it was therefore Jacob’s right thigh that the angel touched.
<b>Rav Shmuel bar Aḥa said before Rav Pappa in the name of Rava bar Ulla</b> that the angel <b>appeared to</b> Jacob <b>as a Torah scholar,</b> and therefore Jacob positioned the angel on his right side, <b>as the Master said: One who walks to the right of his teacher is an ignoramus,</b> in that he does not know how to act with good manners. Consequently, it was Jacob’s right thigh that the angel touched.
<b>And the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the sciatic nerves of both thighs are forbidden, understand that the angel <b>came from behind</b> Jacob <b>and hit him on both</b> thighs.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis, what do they derive</b> from <b>this</b> phrase: <b>“As he wrestled with him”</b> (Genesis 32:26)? The Gemara answers: They <b>require it for the other</b> interpretation <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> This <b>teaches that the dust [<i>avak</i>] from their feet ascended to the throne of glory. It is written here: “As he wrestled [<i>behe’avko</i>] with him,” and it is written there</b> in a description of how God will punish the wicked: “The Lord, in the whirlwind and in the storm is His way, <b>and the clouds are the dust of His feet”</b> (Nahum 1:3).
§ The Gemara cites another statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi concerning the sciatic nerve: <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: Why is its name called sciatic nerve [<i>gid hanashe</i>]?</b> It is <b>because</b> the sciatic nerve <b>left [<i>nasha</i>] its place and rose. And similarly</b> the verse <b>says:</b> “The mighty men of Babylon have ceased to fight, they remain in their strongholds; <b>their might has left [<i>nashata</i>], they are become as women”</b> (Jeremiah 51:30).
The Gemara continues with other expositions pertaining to the sciatic nerve. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written:</b> “The Lord <b>sent a word to Jacob, and it has fallen upon Israel”</b> (Isaiah 9:7)? <b>“He sent a word to Jacob”; this</b> is a reference to <b>the sciatic nerve. “And it has fallen upon Israel”;</b> this teaches <b>that its prohibition has</b> been <b>extended to the entire Jewish people.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> also <b>said: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written:</b> “And when Joseph saw Benjamin with them, he said to the steward of his house: Bring the men into the house, <b>and slaughter the animals, and prepare</b> the meat; for the men shall dine with me at noon” (Genesis 43:16)? Joseph commanded his steward: <b>Expose the place of the slaughter</b> on the neck of the animal <b>to them</b> so that the brothers will know that it is being slaughtered correctly. <b>“And prepare”</b> teaches that Joseph instructed the steward to <b>remove the sciatic nerve in their presence</b> so that the brothers would know that it had been fully removed. The Gemara comments that this opinion is <b>according to the one who said</b> that <b>the sciatic nerve was forbidden to</b> the children of Jacob even before the Torah was given, when they still had the status of <b>descendants of Noah.</b>
The Gemara returns to the verse of Jacob wrestling with the angel. The verse states: <b>“And Jacob was left alone;</b> and a man wrestled with him until the breaking of the day” (Genesis 32:25). <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The reason Jacob remained alone was <b>that he remained</b> to collect some <b>small pitchers</b> that had been left behind. <b>From here</b> it is derived <b>that the possessions of the righteous are dearer to them than their bodies. And why</b> do they care <b>so much</b> about their possessions? It is <b>because they do not stretch out their hands to</b> partake of <b>stolen property.</b>
The verse states: <b>“And a man wrestled with him until the breaking of the day.” Rabbi Yitzḥak says: From here</b> it is derived <b>that a Torah scholar should not go out</b> of his house <b>alone at night,</b> as Jacob went out alone at night and was injured. <b>Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said</b> that the source for this instruction is <b>from here:</b>

Daf 91b

“And now is there not Boaz our kinsman, whose maidens you were with? <b>Behold, he winnows barley tonight in the threshing floor</b>…and it shall be, when he lies down, that you shall mark the place where he shall lie” (Ruth 3:2–3). This teaches that the reason Boaz did not return home from the threshing floor was that a Torah scholar should not go out alone at night.
<b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that the source is <b>from here: “And Abraham rose early in the morning, and saddled</b> his donkey, and took two of his young men with him and Isaac his son; and he split the wood for the burnt offering, and rose up, and went to the place that God had told him” (Genesis 22:3). The fact that Abraham waited until morning and did not set off at night, even though others were traveling with him, indicates that a Torah scholar should not go out at night at all, and certainly not alone.
<b>And the Rabbis say</b> that the source is <b>from here,</b> the verse that describes when Jacob sent Joseph to his brothers: “And he said to him: <b>Go now, see whether it is well with you brothers and well</b> with the flock; and bring me back word. So he sent him out of the valley of Hebron, and he came to Shechem” (Genesis 37:14). The verse indicates that Jacob sent Joseph at a time when he could see his brothers, i.e., during the day. This shows that a Torah scholar should not go out alone at night.
<b>Rav said</b> that the source is <b>from here: “And the sun rose for him</b> as he passed over Peniel, and he limped upon his thigh” (Genesis 32:32). This indicates that Jacob remained where he was all night and left in the morning, because a Torah scholar should not go out alone at night.
The Gemara cites an incident involving the final verse cited above. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: I asked</b> the following question of <b>Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Yehoshua in the meat market [<i>be’itliz</i>] of</b> the town <b>Emmaus, where they went to purchase an animal for the</b> wedding <b>feast of Rabban Gamliel’s son: It is written</b> in the verse: <b>“And the sun shone for him</b> when he passed Peniel, and he limped upon his thigh” (Genesis 32:32). <b>But did the sun shine only for him? Didn’t it shine for the entire world?</b>
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> The verse means that <b>the sun, which set</b> early exclusively <b>for him,</b> also <b>shone</b> early exclusively <b>for him</b> in order to rectify the disparity created by the premature sunset. The Gemara explains when the sun set early for him: <b>As it is written: “And Jacob went out from Beersheba and went toward Haran”</b> (Genesis 28:10). <b>And it is written</b> thereafter: <b>“And he encountered the place,</b> and he slept there, because the sun had set” (Genesis 28:11). <b>When</b> Jacob <b>arrived at Haran, he said:</b> Is it <b>possible</b> that <b>I passed a place where my fathers prayed and I did not pray</b> there? <b>When he set his mind to return, the land contracted for him. Immediately</b> the verse states: <b>“And he encountered the place,”</b> indicating that he arrived there miraculously.
<b>When he</b> had finished <b>praying</b> and <b>he wanted to return</b> to Haran, <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: This righteous man came to my lodging place and he will depart without remaining overnight? Immediately, the sun set</b> before its proper time so that Jacob would stay overnight in that place.
The Gemara cites another exposition of Rabbi Yitzḥak to explain an apparent contradiction between two verses pertaining to this incident. <b>It is written: “And he took of the stones of the place,</b> and placed them under his head, and lay down in that place to sleep” (Genesis 28:11). <b>And it is written:</b> “And Jacob rose up early in the morning, <b>and he took the stone</b> that he had placed under his head, and set it up for a pillar, and poured oil upon the top of it” (Genesis 28:18). The first verse indicates that Jacob took several stones, whereas the latter verse indicates that he took only one stone. <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> This <b>teaches that all those stones gathered to one place and each one said:</b> Let <b>this righteous man place his head upon me.</b> And it was <b>taught: And all of them were absorbed into one</b> large rock.
The Gemara expounds other verses pertaining to the same incident. The verse states: <b>“And he dreamed, and behold a ladder set up on the earth,</b> and the top of it reached to heaven; and behold the angels of God ascending and descending on it” (Genesis 28:12). It was <b>taught: How wide was the ladder?</b> It was <b>eight thousand parasangs [<i>parsaot</i>], as it is written: “And behold the angels of God ascending and descending on it.”</b> The word <b>“ascending [<i>olim</i>],”</b> written in plural, indicates that there were <b>two</b> angels ascending simultaneously. Likewise, the term <b>“and descending [<i>veyordim</i>],”</b> also in the plural, indicates that <b>two</b> angels were descending simultaneously. <b>And when they met one another they were</b> a total of <b>four</b> in one place, so the ladder must have been wide enough to accommodate four angels.
<b>And it is written</b> in a verse <b>with regard to an angel: “His body was like Tarshish”</b> (Daniel 10:6). <b>And</b> it <b>is learned</b> as a tradition <b>that</b> the city of <b>Tarshish was two thousand parasangs.</b> Consequently, in order to accommodate four angels, the ladder must have been eight thousands parasangs wide.
It was <b>taught</b> that the angels were <b>ascending and gazing at the image of [<i>bidyokeno</i>]</b> Jacob <b>above,</b> engraved on the Throne of Glory, <b>and descending and gazing at his image below.</b> The angels subsequently became jealous of Jacob, and <b>wanted to endanger</b> his life. <b>Immediately</b> Jacob received divine protection, as the verse states: <b>“And behold, the Lord stood over him”</b> (Genesis 28:13). <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: Were it not written</b> in a <b>verse it would be impossible to utter it,</b> in deference to God, since it describes God as standing over Jacob to protect him from the angels <b>like a man who waves</b> a fan <b>over his son</b> to cool him down.
The Gemara explains another verse from Jacob’s dream. “And behold, the Lord stood over him and said: I am the Lord, the God of Abraham your father and the God of Isaac. <b>The land upon which you lie,</b> to you will I give it, and to your seed” (Genesis 28:13). The Gemara asks: <b>What is the greatness</b> of this promise, i.e., why is it expressed in this way despite the fact that in a literal sense Jacob was lying on a very small amount of land? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> This <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, folded</b> up <b>the entirety of Eretz Yisrael and placed it under Jacob, our patriarch, so that it would be easy for his children to conquer.</b>
The Gemara returns to the verses that describe Jacob wrestling with the angel. <b>“And he said: Let me go, for the dawn has risen.</b> And he said: I will not let you go until you bless me” (Genesis 32:27). Jacob <b>said to</b> the angel: <b>Are you a thief, or are you a gambler [<i>kuveyustus</i>], who is afraid of dawn?</b> The angel <b>said to him: I am an angel, and from the day I was created my time to recite a song</b> before God <b>has not arrived, until now.</b> Now I must ascend so that I can sing songs of praise to God.
The Gemara comments: This <b>supports</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥananel</b> when he related what <b>Rav said. As Rav Ḥananel said</b> that <b>Rav said: Three groups of ministering angels recite a song every day</b> from the verse “Holy, holy, holy is the Lord”; <b>one says: “Holy,” and</b> another <b>one says: “Holy,” and</b> another <b>one says: “Holy is the Lord of hosts;</b> the whole earth is full of His glory” (Isaiah 6:3).
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Jewish people are more dear to the Holy One, Blessed be He, than the ministering angels, as the Jewish people</b> may <b>recite a song</b> of praise to God <b>at any time, but ministering angels recite a song</b> of praise <b>only one time per day. And some say</b> that the ministering angels recite a song of praise <b>one time per week. And some say</b> that they recite a song of praise <b>one time per month. And some say</b> that they recite a song of praise <b>one time per year. And some say</b> that they recite a song of praise <b>one time in</b> every <b>seven years. And some say</b> that they recite a song of praise <b>one time per Jubilee. And some say</b> that they recite a song of praise <b>one time in</b> the entire history of <b>the world.</b>
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>the Jewish people mention the name</b> of God <b>after two words, as it is stated: “Hear, Israel: The Lord</b> our God, the Lord is one” (Deuteronomy 6:4). <b>But the ministering angels mention the name</b> of God <b>only after three words, as it is written:</b> “And one called unto another, and said: <b>“Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of hosts;</b> the whole earth is full of His glory” (Isaiah 6:3).
<b>And the ministering angels do not recite</b> their <b>song above until the Jewish people recite</b> their song <b>below,</b> on earth, <b>as it is stated: “When the morning stars sang together”</b> (Job 38:7), referring to the Jewish people, who are compared to stars; <b>and</b> only <b>then</b> does the verse state: <b>“And all the sons of God shouted for joy,”</b> which is a reference to the angels. This <i>baraita</i> teaches that the angels mention the name of God only after three words, i.e., after saying the word “holy” three times, whereas according to what Rav Ḥananel stated that Rav said, the third group of angels says the word “holy” once and then immediately mentions the name of God.
The Gemara emends Rav Ḥananel’s statement citing Rav: <b>Rather,</b> Rav said that <b>one</b> group of ministering angels <b>says: “Holy,” and</b> another <b>one says: “Holy, holy,” and</b> another <b>one says: “Holy, holy, holy is the Lord of hosts.”</b> The Gemara challenges the statement of the <i>baraita</i> that the angels mention the name of God only after three words: <b>But there is</b> the verse: “Then a spirit lifted me up, and I heard behind me the voice of a great rushing: <b>Blessed be</b> the glory of the Lord from His place” (Ezekiel 3:12). In this praise, “Blessed be the glory of the Lord,” the word “Lord” appears as the third Hebrew word, apparently uttered by the ministering angels.

Daf 92a

The Gemara answers that it is the <b><i>ofanim</i> who say</b> the verse: <b>“Blessed be</b> the glory of the Lord from His place,” as the next verse mentions “the noise of the <i>ofanim</i>” (Ezekiel 3:13), and Rav Ḥanina’s statement citing Rav was referring not to <i>ofanim</i> but to ministering angels. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>once permission has been given</b> to them to mention the name of God after three words when they say: “Holy, holy, holy,” permission is also <b>given</b> to them to mention the name of God again while praising Him even after fewer than three words.
The Gemara continues to discuss Jacob wrestling with the angel. The prophet states: <b>“So he strove [<i>vayyasar</i>] with an angel, and prevailed; he wept, and made supplication to him;</b> at Beth El he would find him, and there he would speak with us” (Hosea 12:5). From this verse <b>I do not know who became master [<i>sar</i>],</b> i.e., was victorious, <b>over whom. When</b> another verse <b>states:</b> “And he said: Your name shall no longer be called Jacob, but Israel; <b>for you have striven with angels</b> and with men, and have prevailed” (Genesis 32:29), <b>you must say</b> that <b>Jacob became master over the angel.</b>
The verse in Hosea states: <b>“He wept, and made supplication to him.”</b> From this verse <b>I do not know who cried to whom. When</b> another verse <b>states: “And he said: Let me go,</b> for the dawn has risen” (Genesis 32:27), <b>you must say</b> that <b>the angel cried to Jacob.</b>
The verse states: “And he said: Your name shall no longer be called Jacob, but Israel; <b>for you have striven with angels [<i>elohim</i>] and with men,</b> and have prevailed” (Genesis 32:29). <b>Rabba says:</b> The angel <b>intimated to</b> Jacob <b>that in the future two princes would emerge from him:</b> They are the <b>Exilarch who is in Babylonia and the <i>Nasi</i> who is in Eretz Yisrael.</b> And <b>from here he</b> also <b>intimated to</b> Jacob that there would be <b>an exile.</b>
Similarly, with regard to the dream of Pharaoh’s butler, the verse states: <b>“And in the vine were three branches [<i>sarigim</i>];</b> and as it was budding, its blossoms shot forth, and its clusters brought forth ripe grapes” (Genesis 40:10). <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rav says: These</b> three branches refer to the <b>three proud princes [<i>sarei ge’im</i>] who emerge from the Jewish people in each and every generation.</b> There are <b>times</b> when <b>two are here</b> in Babylonia <b>and one is in Eretz Yisrael,</b> and there are <b>times</b> when <b>two are in Eretz Yisrael and one is here</b> in Babylonia. When this was stated in the study hall, <b>the Sages</b> present <b>turned their eyes toward Rabbana Ukva and Rabbana Neḥemya, the sons of the daughter of Rav,</b> who were from the family of the Exilarch and were two leaders of the generation who resided in Babylonia.
<b>Rava says</b> a different explanation of the verse: <b>These</b> three branches [<i>sarigim</i>] <b>are the three ministering</b> angels appointed to oversee <b>the gentiles [<i>sarei goyim</i>], who plead in favor of the Jewish people in each and every generation.</b>
