<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> an alternate interpretation of the verse. <b>“Vine”; this</b> is a reference to <b>the world. “Three branches”; this</b> is a reference to <b>Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. “And as it was budding, its blossoms shot forth”; these are the matriarchs. “And its clusters brought forth ripe grapes”; these are the</b> twelve <b>tribes,</b> i.e., the twelve sons of Jacob.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua said to him: But is a person shown</b> in a dream <b>what was</b> in the past? <b>Isn’t</b> it true that <b>one is shown only what will be in the future?</b> Since the patriarchs, matriarchs, and sons of Jacob were all born prior to this dream, the dream was not alluding to them. <b>Rather,</b> the verse should be interpreted as follows: <b>“Vine”; this</b> is a reference to <b>the Torah. “Three branches”; these are Moses, Aaron, and Miriam. “And as it was budding, its blossoms shot forth”; these are the</b> members of the <b>Sanhedrin. “And its clusters brought forth ripe grapes”; these are the righteous</b> people <b>who</b> live <b>in each and every generation.</b>
<b>Rabban Gamliel said:</b> In order to understand this verse (Genesis 40:10) <b>we still need</b> the explanation <b>of</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>HaModa’i, who</b> is an expert in matters of <i>aggada</i>, as he <b>interprets all of</b> the phrases in the verse as referring to <b>one location. Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i says: “Vine”; this</b> is a reference to <b>Jerusalem. “Three branches”; this</b> is a reference to the <b>Temple,</b> the <b>king and</b> the <b>High Priest. “And as it was budding [<i>poraḥat</i>], its blossoms shot forth”; these are the young priests [<i>pirḥei khehunna</i>]. “And its clusters brought forth ripe grapes”; these are the</b> wine <b>libations.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi interprets it with</b> reference to the <b>gifts</b> that God gave the Jewish people, <b>as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: “Vine”; this</b> is a reference to the <b>Torah. “Three branches”; this</b> is a reference to the miraculous items that accompanied the Jewish people in the wilderness and sustained and protected them: The <b>well, the pillar of cloud, and the manna. “And as it was budding, its blossoms shot forth”; these are the first fruits</b> that are brought to the Temple. <b>“And its clusters brought forth ripe grapes”; these are</b> the wine <b>libations.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba says: “Vine”; this</b> is a reference to <b>the Jewish people, and similarly</b> another verse <b>states: “You plucked up a vine out of Egypt;</b> You drove out the nations and planted it” (Psalms 80:9). <b>“Three branches”; these are the three</b> pilgrimage <b>Festivals, on which the Jewish people ascend</b> to Jerusalem <b>every year. “And as it was budding, its blossoms shot forth,”</b> means that <b>the time has arrived for the Jewish people to be fruitful and multiply, and similarly</b> another verse <b>states: “And the children of Israel were fruitful, and increased abundantly,</b> and multiplied, and became exceeding mighty; and the land was filled with them” (Exodus 1:7).
<b>“Its blossoms [<i>nitzah</i>] shot forth”</b> means that <b>the time has arrived for the Jewish people to be redeemed. And similarly</b> another verse <b>states: “And their eternity [<i>nitzḥam</i>] is dashed against My garments, and I have redeemed all My raiment”</b> (Isaiah 63:3). <b>“And its clusters brought forth ripe grapes”</b> means that <b>the time has arrived for Egypt to drink the cup of fury,</b> i.e., to receive its punishment.
<b>And this is as Rava said: Why</b> are there <b>three cups stated with regard to Egypt</b> in the dream of Pharaoh’s butler (see Genesis 40:11)? They are an allusion to three cups of misfortune that would later befall Egypt: <b>One that</b> Egypt <b>drank in the days of Moses</b> during the ten plagues and the Exodus; <b>one that</b> Egypt <b>drank in the days of Pharaoh Nekho,</b> the king of Egypt defeated by Nebuchadnezzar; <b>and one that</b> Egypt <b>will drink in the future with all the</b> other <b>nations,</b> when they are punished in the time of the Messiah.
<b>Rabbi Abba said to Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba: When Rav interpreted these verses homiletically he interpreted them according to</b> the way in which <b>you</b> have interpreted them, and not according to any of the other opinions cited above.
Similar to Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba’s interpretation of the word vine as an allusion to the Jewish people, <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: This nation is likened to a vine. The branches of</b> the vine support the clusters of grapes, the leaves, and the tendrils; <b>these are</b> represented among the Jewish people by <b>the homeowners,</b> who provide financial support for the entire nation. <b>The clusters</b> of grapes <b>on</b> the vine, <b>these are the Torah scholars. The leaves on</b> the vine, which protect the grapes, <b>these are the ignoramuses,</b> who protect the Torah scholars. <b>The tendrils of</b> the vine, which do not directly serve the grapes themselves, <b>these are the empty</b> ones <b>of the Jewish people.</b>
<b>And this is</b> the meaning of the instruction <b>that they sent from there,</b> i.e., from Eretz Yisrael: <b>Let the clusters</b> of grapes <b>pray for the leaves, as were it not for the leaves, the clusters</b> of grapes <b>would not survive.</b>
§ The Gemara cites homiletical interpretations of other verses that pertain to the leaders of the Jewish people in Eretz Yisrael and Babylonia. The verse states: <b>“So I bought her [<i>va’ekkereha</i>] to me for fifteen pieces of silver,</b> and a <i>ḥomer</i> of barley, and a half-<i>ḥomer</i> of barley” (Hosea 3:2). <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak:</b> The term <b><i>kira</i>,</b> which forms the basis of the verb <i>va’ekkereha</i>, <b>is nothing other than language</b> referring to <b>a sale [<i>mekhira</i>], as it is stated</b> that Joseph said: “My father made me swear, saying: Lo, I die; <b>in my grave that I have acquired [<i>kariti</i>] for me</b> in the land of Canaan, there shall you bury me” (Genesis 50:5).
Rabbi Yoḥanan continues: <b>“For fifteen</b> pieces of silver”; <b>this</b> is a reference to <b>the fifteenth of Nisan,</b> the date <b>on which the Jewish people were redeemed from Egypt. “Silver”; these are the righteous</b> people. <b>And similarly,</b> another verse <b>states: “He has taken the bag of silver with him”</b> (Proverbs 7:20), a reference to God taking the righteous away prior to the destruction of the First Temple (see <i>Sanhedrin</i> 96b).
The verse states: <b>“A <i>ḥomer</i> of barley, and a half-<i>ḥomer</i> of barley.”</b> A <i>ḥomer</i> equals thirty <i>se’a</i>, and a half-<i>ḥomer</i> equals fifteen <i>se’a</i>, totaling forty-five <i>se’a</i>; <b>these are the forty-five righteous</b> individuals <b>in whose</b> merit <b>the world</b> continues to <b>exist. And</b> although the verse alludes to the fact that thirty of these righteous individuals are in one place and fifteen are elsewhere, <b>I do not know if thirty are here</b> in Babylonia <b>and fifteen are in Eretz Yisrael, or if thirty are in Eretz Yisrael and fifteen are here</b> in Babylonia. <b>When it says</b> in a different verse: <b>“And I took the thirty pieces of silver and cast them into the treasury, in the house of the Lord”</b> (Zechariah 11:13), <b>you must say</b> that <b>thirty</b> of the righteous individuals are <b>in Eretz Yisrael and fifteen are here</b> in Babylonia.
<b>Abaye said: And most of the</b> fifteen righteous individuals in Babylonia <b>are found in the synagogue under the upper room. And this is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “And I said to them: If it is good in your eyes, give me my hire; and if not, refrain. And they weighed for my hire thirty pieces of silver”</b> (Zechariah 11:12).
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: These are the thirty righteous</b> individuals among the <b>nations of the world, in whose</b> merit <b>the nations of the world</b> continue to <b>exist. Ulla says: These are the thirty mitzvot that the descendants of Noah</b> initially <b>accepted upon themselves; but they fulfill only three</b> of them. <b>One</b> of these three mitzvot is

Daf 92b

<b>that they do not write a marriage contract for</b> a wedding between two <b>males;</b> although they violate the prohibition against engaging in homosexuality, they are not so brazen as to write a marriage contract as for a regular marriage. <b>And one</b> of the three mitzvot is <b>that</b> although they are suspected of eating human beings, <b>they do not weigh the flesh of the dead in butcher shops</b> [<b><i>bemakkulin</i></b>] and sell it publicly; <b>and one</b> is <b>that they honor the Torah.</b>
§ The mishna teaches (89b) that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve <b>does not apply to a bird</b> due to the fact that the verse is referring to the sciatic nerve as being “upon the spoon of the thigh” (Genesis 32:33), and a bird has no spoon of the thigh. The Gemara challenges: <b>But we see that it does have</b> a protrusion of flesh on its thigh. The Gemara answers: <b>It has</b> a protrusion, <b>but</b> that protrusion is <b>not rounded.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> If <b>a bird has</b> a protrusion on its thigh bone <b>and it is rounded,</b> or <b>an animal has</b> a protrusion on its thigh bone <b>but it is not rounded, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we follow it,</b> i.e., does the status of the sciatic nerve depend upon the physical properties of each particular animal, <b>or do we follow its species,</b> so that the sciatic nerve of an animal is always forbidden and that of a bird is always permitted? The Gemara responds: The question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna states that the prohibition of the sciatic nerve <b>applies to</b> a late-term animal <b>fetus</b> in the womb. Rabbi Yehuda says: It does not apply to a fetus; and its fat is permitted. <b>Shmuel says:</b> When the mishna states: <b>And its fat is permitted,</b> that is <b>according to everyone.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>The fat of what? If we say</b> that it is referring to the fat <b>of a fetus, don’t</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree about it, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The prohibition of the <b>sciatic nerve applies to</b> a late-term <b>fetus, and its fat is prohibited;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that the prohibition of the <b>sciatic nerve does not apply to</b> a late-term <b>fetus, and its fat is permitted.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says</b> in explanation of the <i>baraita</i>: This <b>dispute</b> applies <b>to a nine-month-old,</b> i.e., a full-term, fetus that remains <b>alive</b> after its mother has been slaughtered. <b>And Rabbi Meir followed his</b> general <b>opinion</b> in this regard (see 74a), that this fetus is considered a live animal independent of its mother. Consequently, it must undergo ritual slaughter in order for its meat to be permitted for consumption, and its fats and sciatic nerve are forbidden like those of any other animal. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> followed <b>his</b> general <b>opinion</b> that such a fetus is not considered a live animal but rather part of its mother. Consequently, it does not require ritual slaughter, and its fats and sciatic nerve are permitted.
<b>But rather,</b> perhaps Shmuel’s statement was said with regard to <b>the fat of the</b> sciatic <b>nerve. But</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree</b> about this case as well, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the sciatic nerve, one scrapes around it</b> to remove it entirely <b>in any place that it is</b> found in the thigh, <b>and one cuts out its fat from its source,</b> i.e., even the fat that is embedded in the flesh; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: One cuts out</b> the nerve and fat so that they are level <b>with the flesh</b> [<b><i>hashufi</i></b>] of the thigh, but there is no need to scrape out the parts embedded in the flesh. Consequently, there is a dispute about the fat surrounding the sciatic nerve as well.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> Shmuel was referring to the <b>fat of the</b> sciatic <b>nerve,</b> and <b>Shmuel concedes that</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> the fat surrounding the sciatic nerve is <b>forbidden by rabbinic law</b> but permitted by Torah law. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Its fat is permitted</b> by Torah law, <b>but the Jewish people are holy</b> and <b>treated it as forbidden.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>What, is it not</b> that this <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that the fat is <b>permitted by Torah law but forbidden by rabbinic law?</b>
The Gemara challenges this: <b>From where</b> can it be proven that this <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir? <b>Perhaps it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, but according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir it is even forbidden by Torah law.</b>
The Gemara rejects this challenge: It would <b>not enter your mind</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the sciatic nerve, one scrapes around it</b> to remove it entirely from <b>any place that it</b> is found in the thigh, <b>and its fat is permitted.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Whom have you heard who holds</b> that <b>scraping</b> is required? It is <b>Rabbi Meir. And</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>states</b> that <b>its fat is permitted.</b> Consequently, Rabbi Meir must hold that the fat surrounding the sciatic nerve is permitted by Torah law and forbidden by rabbinic law.
§ With regard to the sciatic nerve <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta says</b> that <b>Rav says: The Torah prohibited only its</b> thin, <b>tendril</b>-like nerve fibers <b>[<i>kenokanot</i>]</b> that branch off and run alongside the sciatic nerve, under the flesh. By contrast, the sciatic nerve itself, which is inedible and has no flavor, is therefore considered like wood rather than food, and is not forbidden. Conversely, <b>Ulla says:</b> The sciatic nerve <b>is</b> inedible and has no flavor, like <b>wood, but</b> nevertheless <b>the Torah rendered</b> one <b>liable for</b> eating <b>it.</b>
<b>Abaye said: It stands to reason</b> that the <i>halakha</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Ulla, because Rav Sheshet said</b> that <b>Rav Asi said: The strands</b> of veins <b>that are in the</b> forbidden <b>fat are forbidden, but one is not liable for</b> eating <b>them. Apparently,</b> when <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that it is prohibited to eat <b>fat,</b> the prohibition applies only to the fat itself <b>but not</b> to <b>the strands</b> of veins. <b>Here also, the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that it is prohibited to eat the sciatic <b>nerve, but</b> that does <b>not</b> include <b>the tendril</b>-like nerve fibers.
§ The Gemara now returns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> cited in the discussion above: <b>Rav Sheshet said</b> that <b>Rav Asi said: The strands</b> of veins <b>that are in the</b> forbidden <b>fat are forbidden, but one is not liable for</b> eating <b>them.</b> The strands of veins <b>that are in the kidney are forbidden, but one is not liable for</b> eating <b>them.</b> With regard to the <b>white</b> fat of the <b>kidney,</b> there is a dispute between <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabbi Ḥiyya: One</b> of them <b>prohibits</b> its consumption, because it is similar to the fats that are prohibited by the Torah; <b>and one</b> of them <b>permits</b> eating it.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabba</b> would <b>scrape</b> every remnant of white fat away from the kidney. Similarly, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> would <b>scrape it</b> away from the kidney. By contrast, <b>Rabbi Asi</b> would <b>cut it</b> from the surface of the kidney but would not scrape out the rest of it. <b>Abaye said: It stands to reason</b> that the <i>halakha</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Asi, because Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b>

Daf 93a

The <b>fat that is covered by the flesh</b> is <b>permitted. Apparently,</b> when <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that the fat <b>that is upon the loins</b> is prohibited (see Leviticus 3:4), it is referring only to the fat above the loins <b>but not</b> the fat <b>that is inside the loins. Here also, the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that the fat <b>that is upon the kidneys</b> is prohibited (see Leviticus 3:4), <b>but</b> this does <b>not</b> include the fat <b>that is inside the kidneys.</b>
§ The Gemara addresses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> cited in the discussion above: <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The fat that is covered by the flesh</b> is <b>permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But didn’t Rabbi Abba say</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: This fat that is under the loins is forbidden,</b> even though it is covered by flesh?
The Gemara answers that <b>Abaye said: When an animal is alive</b> its limbs <b>separate</b> at the joints as it walks, so that the fat under the loins is not covered by flesh. Therefore, even after it has been slaughtered this fat is forbidden and does not have the status of fat that is covered by flesh. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: I am not a butcher and I am not the son of a butcher,</b> i.e., I am not expert in the anatomy of animals, <b>but I remember that this is what they would say</b> in <b>the study hall: When an animal is alive</b> its limbs <b>separate</b> at the joints as it walks, so that the fat under the loins is exposed.
§ <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The fat that is on the omasum and the reticulum is forbidden, and</b> its consumption is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>. And this is the fat that is</b> referred to in the Torah as being <b>upon the innards</b> (see Leviticus 3:3). <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: This fat of the coccygeal</b> bone <b>is forbidden, and</b> its consumption <b>is punishable by <i>karet</i>. And this is the fat that is</b> referred to in the Torah as being <b>upon the loins</b> (see Leviticus 3:4).
<b>And Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The veins that are in the foreleg</b> of an animal <b>are forbidden. Rav Safra said</b> to Rabbi Abba: <b>Moses! Did the Merciful One say</b> in the Torah: <b>Do not eat meat?</b> The veins of the foreleg are part of the meat and are not forbidden. <b>Rava said: Moses! Did the Merciful One say</b> in the Torah: <b>Eat blood?</b> The reason that these veins are forbidden is that they are filled with blood. Therefore, if one <b>cuts</b> the foreleg open <b>and salts it</b> to remove the blood, it is <b>permitted even</b> to cook it <b>in a pot;</b> and it is certainly permitted to roast it over a fire, which also draws out the blood.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The fat on the <b>top cubit of the</b> small <b>intestine requires scraping,</b> i.e., it is forbidden and must be removed. <b>And this is</b> the fat referred to by the Sages (see 49b) as <b>the fat that is on the small intestine.</b>
<b>And Rav Yehuda says: The sinews that are in the tailbone are forbidden</b> for consumption, because they contain forbidden fat. <b>There are five sinews in the tail: Three on the right and two on the left.</b> The <b>three</b> on the right <b>each split into two,</b> and the <b>two</b> on the left <b>each split into three.</b> The practical <b>difference,</b> i.e., the reason the Gemara describes this in detail, is <b>that if</b> one <b>draws them out</b> while they are <b>still warm</b> soon after slaughter <b>they are drawn out</b> easily, <b>but if not,</b> he <b>is required to scrape around them,</b> i.e., dig into the flesh to remove them. It is important to know how many there are to ensure that one removes them all.
<b>Abaye said, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda</b> said: <b>There are five strands</b> that are forbidden for consumption; <b>three</b> of them are forbidden <b>because</b> they contain <b>forbidden fat, and two</b> are forbidden <b>because</b> they contain <b>blood.</b> The ligaments <b>of the spleen and of the tail and of the kidneys</b> are forbidden <b>because</b> they contain <b>forbidden fat.</b> And the veins <b>of the foreleg and of the pharynx,</b> i.e., the carotid artery, are forbidden <b>because</b> they contain <b>blood.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What difference is</b> there whether they are forbidden due to fat or due to blood? The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>these</b> veins and arteries <b>that</b> are forbidden <b>because</b> they contain <b>blood, if one cuts them</b> open <b>and</b> then <b>salts them</b> to remove the blood they are <b>permitted.</b> But <b>those</b> strands that contain forbidden fat <b>have no rectification</b> and can never be eaten.
<b>Rav Kahana said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Yehuda</b> who said: <b>There are five membranes</b> that are forbidden for consumption; <b>three</b> of them are forbidden <b>because</b> they contain <b>forbidden fat, and two</b> are forbidden <b>because</b> they contain <b>blood.</b> The membranes <b>of the spleen and of the tail and of the kidneys</b> are forbidden <b>because</b> they contain <b>forbidden fat.</b> And the membranes <b>of the testicles and of the brain</b> are forbidden <b>because</b> they contain <b>blood.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Yehuda bar Oshaya was peeling</b> the membranes from <b>a spleen for Levi, son of Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya. He was cutting them</b> only <b>from the upper</b> surface of the spleen. Levi <b>said to</b> Rav Yehuda: <b>Go down further,</b> i.e., remove the fat that is lower down as well. Levi’s <b>father,</b> Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya, <b>came and found him</b> as Levi was saying this to Rav Yehuda. Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya <b>said to him: This is what your mother’s father said in the name of Rav; and who</b> was Levi’s mother’s father? It was <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba.</b> He said: <b>The Torah prohibits only</b> the membranes <b>that are on the thick,</b> upper surface of the spleen.
Levi asked: <b>Is that so? But didn’t Rav Hamnuna say</b> that it was <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the <b>membrane that is on the spleen is forbidden, but one is not liable</b> to receive the punishment of <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> eating <b>it?</b> Levi clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> referred to in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring to the membranes <b>that are on the thick,</b> upper surface of the spleen, <b>why is one not liable</b> to the punishment of <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> eating <b>it? Rather,</b> it must be referring to the membranes <b>on all</b> sides <b>of</b> the spleen, even the underside. Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya <b>said to</b> his son, Levi: <b>If this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught, it is taught,</b> and I cannot take issue with it.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> mentioned above: <b>Rav Hamnuna said</b> that it was <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>membrane that is on the spleen is forbidden, but one is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> eating <b>it.</b> The <b>membrane that is on</b> the <b>kidney is forbidden, but one is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> eating <b>it.</b> The Gemara challenges this statement: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>one is liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for</b> eating the membrane on the spleen or the kidney?
The Gemara answers: The apparent contradiction between the <i>baraita</i> that states that one is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating the membrane on the <b>spleen</b> and the <i>baraita</i> that states that one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating the membrane on the <b>spleen</b> is <b>not difficult: This</b> <i>baraita</i> that states that one is liable is referring to the membrane <b>on the thick,</b> upper part of the spleen, whereas <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> that states that one is not liable is referring to the membrane <b>that is not on the thick</b> part of the spleen.
Likewise, the apparent contradiction between the <i>baraita</i> that states that one is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating the membrane on the <b>kidney</b> and the <i>baraita</i> that states that one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating the membrane on the <b>kidney</b> is <b>not difficult: This</b> <i>baraita</i> that states that one is liable is referring to the membrane <b>on the upper</b> part of the kidney, whereas <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> that states that one is not liable is referring to the membrane <b>on the lower</b> part of the kidney.
§ With regard to <b>testicles</b> that were <b>crushed</b> while the animal was alive but were still attached to their cords in the scrotum, there is a dispute between <b>Rav Ami and Rav Asi. One</b> of them <b>prohibits</b> eating the testicles after the animal is slaughtered <b>and one</b> of them <b>permits</b> eating them. The Gemara clarifies: <b>The one who prohibits</b> them holds that

Daf 93b

<b>since</b> these testicles <b>do not heal, they are</b> considered <b>a limb</b> severed <b>from a living</b> animal even though they are still attached to the animal. Consequently, they are forbidden even after the animal is slaughtered. And <b>the one who permits</b> eating crushed testicles holds that <b>since they do not rot, there is vitality in them,</b> and they are not considered to have been detached from the animal.
<b>And the other</b> opinion, which holds that crushed testicles are forbidden, holds that <b>the</b> reason the testicles <b>do not rot</b> is not because they have vitality but rather <b>because air does not penetrate</b> the scrotum, and it is contact with air that would cause them to rot. <b>And the other</b> opinion, which holds that crushed testicles are permitted, holds <b>that the</b> fact <b>that they do not heal</b> is because <b>they have been struck with weakness,</b> but not because they are entirely devoid of vitality. Consequently, they should not be considered detached from the body.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to Rav Shemen bar Abba: These crushed testicles are permitted</b> for consumption, <b>but you should not eat them due to</b> the dictum: <b>“And do not forsake the Torah of your mother”</b> (Proverbs 1:8). Since Rav Shemen bar Abba was from Babylonia, where it was customary to be stringent, it was prohibited for him to eat crushed testicles even when he was in Eretz Yisrael.
§ The Gemara cites other <i>halakhot</i> related to testicles. <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi said:</b> With regard to <b>these testicles of goats,</b> from the time the goat is born <b>until</b> the goat is <b>thirty days</b> old, its testicles <b>are permitted without peeling</b> off the membrane that encloses them, because they are presumed not to contain blood. <b>From this</b> point <b>forward, if they contain semen they are forbidden, but if they do not contain semen they are permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How can we know</b> whether or not they contain semen? The Gemara answers: <b>If they have red streaks in them they are forbidden.</b> If they <b>do not have red streaks in them they are permitted.</b>
The Gemara quotes a related discussion pertaining to three cases: With regard to <b>raw meat</b> that is eaten without being salted, <b>testicles</b> of an animal, <b>and</b> the large <b>veins</b> of the neck, <b>Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree about</b> the <i>halakha</i>. The Gemara points out: <b>In all</b> of their disputes with regard to other realms of <b>the Torah</b> where it is not clear which of them holds which opinion, the opinion of <b>Ravina is lenient, and</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa is stringent, and the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ravina to be lenient.</b> This applies to all their disputes <b>except for these three,</b> in <b>which Rav Aḥa is lenient and Ravina is stringent, and the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa to be lenient.</b>
The Gemara explains: With regard to <b>raw meat that became red</b> from the blood inside it, if <b>one cut it and salted it,</b> it is <b>permitted even to</b> cook it in <b>a pot,</b> because the salt removes blood from meat. It is <b>also</b> permitted if one <b>hung it on a spit</b> in order to roast it, because <b>the blood is drawn out</b> by the heat of the fire. With regard to a case where one placed it <b>on coals, Rav Aḥa and Ravina disagree about</b> the <i>halakha</i>: <b>One says</b> that the coals <b>draw out</b> the blood from the meat, <b>and one says</b> that the coals cause the meat to <b>shrivel</b> and harden, trapping the blood inside. <b>And similarly</b> Ravina and Rav Aḥa disagree with regard to <b>testicles</b> placed on coals, <b>and similarly</b> with regard to the large <b>veins</b> of the neck that were placed on coals.
§ Apropos raw meat placed on coals, the Gemara discusses a related topic. In a case where one wants to remove the hair from <b>the head</b> of an animal by placing it <b>in hot ashes,</b> if <b>one placed it</b> with the neck down so that <b>the location of the slaughter</b> is in the ashes, <b>the blood is drawn out</b> by the heat <b>and</b> the meat <b>is permitted.</b> But if one placed the head in the ashes <b>on</b> one of its <b>sides,</b> the blood <b>congeals</b> inside the head and cannot flow out, <b>and</b> therefore the head is <b>forbidden</b> for consumption. In a case where one <b>placed</b> the head down <b>on its nostrils,</b> if <b>he inserted something into</b> the nostrils to keep them open and allow the blood to flow out, the meat is <b>permitted, but</b> if he did <b>not</b> do so it is <b>forbidden.</b>
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say:</b> If the head was placed <b>on its nostrils or on the location of the slaughter,</b> the blood is <b>drawn out</b> and the meat is permitted. If he placed it <b>on</b> one of its <b>sides,</b> then <b>if</b> he <b>inserted something into</b> it in order to allow the blood to flow out, it is <b>permitted, and if not it is forbidden.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: There are two nerves</b> included in the prohibition of the sciatic nerve. The <b>inner</b> nerve, which is <b>next to the bone, is forbidden</b> by Torah law, <b>and one is liable</b> to be flogged <b>for</b> eating <b>it.</b> The <b>outer</b> nerve, which is <b>next to the flesh, is forbidden</b> by rabbinic law, <b>and</b> therefore <b>one is not liable</b> to be flogged <b>for</b> eating <b>it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the <b>inner</b> nerve, which is forbidden by Torah law, is <b>next to the flesh?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Aḥa said</b> that <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> The inner nerve is next to the bone, but it <b>bores</b> into the flesh as well.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The outer</b> nerve <b>is next to the bone?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> This is referring to the spot <b>where the butchers</b> cut the leg open and <b>reveal</b> the nerve, and at that point in the leg the outer nerve is closest to the bone.
§ It <b>was stated:</b> With regard to <b>a butcher who</b> removed the forbidden fats of the animal, and yet <b>forbidden fat was found after</b> he completed his work, <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that the butcher is held liable if there is forbidden fat remaining that is the size of <b>a barley grain. Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that the butcher is held liable only if there is forbidden fat remaining that is the size <b>of an olive-bulk.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> Rav Yehuda and Rabbi Yoḥanan are referring to two different levels of liability, <b>and they do not disagree. Here,</b> when Rabbi Yoḥanan said he is liable only if there is an olive-bulk of forbidden fat remaining, he was referring <b>to flogging him. There,</b> when Rav Yehuda said he is liable even he leaves forbidden fat the size of a barley grain, he was referring <b>to removing him</b> from his position as a butcher.
<b>Mar Zutra said</b> an alternative explanation: If the butcher left forbidden fat the size of <b>a barley grain in one place</b> he is liable, and if he left forbidden fat the size of <b>an olive-bulk,</b> he is liable <b>even</b> if it is spread out <b>in two or three places.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that with regard to <b>flogging him,</b> the butcher is liable only if he left forbidden fat the size of <b>an olive-bulk.</b> With regard <b>to removing him,</b> the butcher is liable even if he left forbidden fat the size of <b>a barley grain.</b>
§ The mishna stated (89b): <b>Butchers are not deemed credible</b> to say that the sciatic nerve was removed; this is the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: They are deemed credible about the sciatic nerve. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The Rabbis initially held that butchers are not deemed credible about the sciatic nerve, and subsequently <b>they retracted</b> and <b>said</b> that butchers are <b>deemed credible</b> in this regard.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> to him: Have the later <b>generations improved</b> such that butchers are more reliable than they were in earlier generations? The Gemara answers: <b>Initially, when</b> the Rabbis <b>held in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> that one must scrape around the flesh in order to remove the roots of the sciatic nerve, butchers <b>were not deemed credible,</b> due to the exertion involved in this process. <b>But later</b> the Rabbis <b>held in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> that it is unnecessary to scrape around the flesh. Consequently, removing the sciatic nerve is not especially arduous, and butchers are deemed credible to say that they removed it.
<b>There are those who teach</b> this discussion <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, as follows: <b>And the Rabbis say: They are deemed credible about</b> the sciatic nerve <b>and about the</b> forbidden <b>fat. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: They</b> subsequently <b>retracted</b> this opinion and <b>said</b> that butchers <b>are not deemed credible. Rav Naḥman says: Today</b> the butchers <b>are deemed credible.</b>
The Gemara asks: Have the later <b>generations improved</b> such that butchers are more reliable than they were in earlier generations? The Gemara answers: <b>Initially they held</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> that one is not required to scrape around the flesh to remove the roots of the sciatic nerve, and therefore butchers were deemed credible to say that they removed it. The Rabbis <b>then</b> reversed their opinion and <b>held</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> that one is required to scrape around the flesh.
As <b>long as</b> the butchers <b>remembered</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and did not scrape around the flesh to remove the roots of the sciatic nerve, <b>they were not deemed credible</b> to say that they removed it; <b>but now that they have forgotten</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and have grown accustomed to scraping around the flesh to remove the roots of the sciatic nerve, <b>they are deemed credible.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that the Rabbis maintain that butchers are deemed credible about the sciatic nerve <b>and about the</b> forbidden <b>fat.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who mentioned anything about</b> forbidden <b>fat?</b> The topic of discussion in the mishna until this point is the sciatic nerve, not forbidden fat; why do the Rabbis mention forbidden fat? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> The butchers <b>are not deemed credible about</b> the sciatic nerve <b>or about the</b> forbidden <b>fat;</b> this is the statement of Rabbi Meir. <b>But the Rabbis say:</b> The butchers <b>are deemed credible about</b> the sciatic nerve <b>and about the</b> forbidden <b>fat.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Although it is prohibited for Jews to eat the sciatic nerve, <b>a</b> Jewish <b>person</b> may <b>send</b> the <b>thigh</b> of an animal <b>to a gentile with the sciatic nerve in it,</b> without concern that the gentile will then sell the thigh to a Jew and the Jew will eat the sciatic nerve. This leniency is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that the place</b> of the sciatic nerve <b>is conspicuous</b> in the thigh.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna’s statement that a Jew may send a thigh to a gentile indicates that if it is <b>whole, yes,</b> a Jew may send it to a gentile, but if the thigh has been <b>cut,</b> a Jew may <b>not</b> send it to a gentile. The Gemara asks: <b>What are we dealing with? If we say</b> that the mishna is referring <b>to a place where</b> all the butchers are Jewish but <b>they do not announce</b> publicly when they have sold to a gentile an animal that turns out to have a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>], then it is prohibited for Jews to purchase any meat from gentiles, due to the possibility that it was from an animal that was a <i>tereifa</i>.

Daf 94a

Consequently, it should <b>also</b> be permitted <b>to send</b> to a gentile a thigh that has been <b>cut, because</b> Jews <b>will not come to purchase</b> it <b>from him. Rather,</b> if the mishna is referring <b>to a place where</b> all the butchers are Jewish, and <b>they announce</b> every time they sell a <i>tereifa</i> to a gentile, in which case Jews may purchase meat from the local gentiles when such an announcement is not made, one should <b>not</b> be permitted <b>to send even a whole</b> thigh to a gentile, due to the concern <b>that</b> he might <b>cut it up and sell it to</b> Jews who would not realize that it still contains the sciatic nerve.
The Gemara offers two answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the mishna is referring <b>to a place where they announce</b> every time they sell a <i>tereifa</i>; <b>and if you wish, say</b> that the mishna is referring <b>to a place where they do not announce</b> every time they sell a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara explains: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the mishna is referring <b>to a place where they announce</b> every time they sell a <i>tereifa</i>, and nevertheless it is permitted to send a whole thigh of meat to a gentile. There is no concern that the gentile will sell the thigh to a Jew, because the Jew <b>would know</b> that it is non-kosher by the manner of <b>cutting of the gentile.</b> Jewish butchers would cut the meat in a distinctive manner that would not be replicated by a gentile who cut the meat.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that the mishna is referring <b>to a place where they do not announce</b> every time they sell a <i>tereifa</i>, and nevertheless it is prohibited to give the gentile a thigh that has been cut up. The Sages issued a <b>decree</b> against doing so, <b>lest he give it to</b> the gentile <b>in the presence of another Jew,</b> who will think that it is kosher and purchase it from the gentile.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that there is an entirely different reason why one may not send a gentile a cut-up thigh without removing the sciatic nerve: <b>Because he</b> thereby <b>deceives</b> the gentile. The gentile will think that the Jew has exerted himself to cut up the leg and remove the sciatic nerve and that although the Jew could have eaten the meat himself he decided to send it to the gentile. The gentile will therefore be more appreciative of the gift than he would be if he realized that the sciatic nerve had not been removed. This is <b>as Shmuel said: It is prohibited to deceive people, and even</b> to deceive <b>a gentile.</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara points out that <b>this</b> ruling <b>of Shmuel was not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference,</b> i.e., it was inferred based upon the following incident: <b>Shmuel was</b> once <b>crossing</b> a river <b>in a ferry [<i>mavra</i>]. He said to his attendant: Compensate the ferryman</b> with an appropriate gift. The attendant <b>compensated him, but</b> Shmuel <b>became angry</b> with his attendant.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that Shmuel <b>became angry? Abaye said:</b> The compensation that the attendant gave the ferryman <b>was a chicken</b> that was <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, and he gave it to him as though it were a slaughtered,</b> kosher chicken. <b>Rava said:</b> Shmuel <b>told him to give</b> the ferryman wine <b>for drinking</b> in <b>an <i>anpaka</i>,</b> i.e., a utensil that holds a quarter-<i>log</i> and which was generally used for undiluted wine, <b>but he gave him diluted wine for drinking.</b> According to both Abaye and Rava, Shmuel was upset that his attendant deceived the gentile ferryman.
The Gemara asks: <b>And if</b> Shmuel’s opinion was derived <b>by inference, what</b> of it? The story clearly demonstrates that according to Shmuel it is prohibited to deceive a gentile. The Gemara answers that it cannot be ascertained with certainty that this is the reason Shmuel became angry. <b>According to the one who said it was</b> a chicken that was <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> that was given as compensation, perhaps Shmuel became angry and <b>said to</b> his attendant: <b>Why did you retain</b> in your possession an animal that is <b>forbidden</b> for consumption? This could have led to a Jew accidentally eating it.
Similarly, <b>according to the one who said</b> that Shmuel <b>told him to give</b> the ferryman wine <b>to drink</b> in <b>an <i>anpaka</i>,</b> since <b><i>anpaka</i> indicates undiluted</b> wine and the attendant gave the ferryman diluted wine, perhaps Shmuel became angry simply because his attendant disobeyed his instruction.
§ Apropos the prohibition against acting deceitfully, the Gemara cites other statements on this topic. <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: A person may not importune [<i>yesarhev</i>] another to eat with him,</b> making it seem as though he genuinely wants his company, <b>but</b> in reality he entreats him only because <b>he knows that</b> the other <b>will not eat</b> with him, i.e., will not accept the invitation. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>one may not</b> send another person <b>many gifts</b> merely because <b>he knows that</b> the other <b>will not accept</b> them.
<b>And one may not open barrels</b> of wine for a guest if they have already been <b>sold to a storekeeper, unless he notifies</b> the guest beforehand that the barrel had been sold. <b>And he may not say to</b> another: <b>Anoint</b> yourself with <b>oil,</b> and place <b>an empty</b> jug before him with the knowledge that he will not attempt to anoint himself. <b>But if</b> he does so <b>for</b> the guest’s <b>honor,</b> to show that he holds his guest in high esteem, rather than to deceive the guest so that he will feel indebted to him, <b>it is permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But didn’t Ulla happen</b> to come <b>to the house of Rav Yehuda,</b> and Rav Yehuda <b>opened barrels</b> of wine <b>for</b> Ulla <b>that</b> had already been <b>sold to a storekeeper?</b> The Gemara answers: Rav Yehuda <b>notified</b> Ulla that he was not opening the barrels especially for him. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>Ulla is different</b> from an ordinary guest <b>because he was</b> very <b>dear to Rav Yehuda, so that even without this,</b> i.e., even if he had not already sold the barrels to a storekeeper, Rav Yehuda would have <b>opened</b> the barrels <b>for him.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person may not go to a house of mourning with a</b> wine <b>jug [<i>lagin</i>] in his hand that</b> is mostly empty and where the small amount of wine <b>rattles</b> about, because the mourner will think that his visitor is bringing him a full jug of wine. <b>And he may not fill up</b> that jug of wine with <b>water, because he</b> thereby <b>misleads</b> the mourner into thinking he has brought him a full jug of undiluted wine. <b>But if there is a crowd of people [<i>ḥever ir</i>]</b> and the guest wants to honor the mourner in their presence, <b>it is permitted.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person may not sell to another a sandal</b> made from the hide <b>of</b> an animal that <b>died</b> of natural causes <b>as</b> though it were a sandal made from the hide <b>of a healthy animal that was slaughtered.</b> This is prohibited <b>due to two factors: One, because he misleads</b> the customer into thinking that the leather is of higher quality than it really is; <b>and another, because of the danger</b> involved, as it is possible that the animal died from a snakebite and the poison seeped into the part of the animal’s hide from which the sandal is made.
<b>And</b> furthermore <b>a person may not send a barrel of wine to another with oil floating at its mouth,</b> such that the recipient thinks that it is a barrel of oil. There was <b>an incident involving a certain</b> individual <b>who sent a barrel of wine to another with oil floating at its mouth, and that</b> recipient, thinking it was a barrel of oil, <b>went and invited guests</b> to share <b>it</b> with him, <b>and</b> the guests <b>arrived.</b> When the host went to bring them oil, <b>he found that it was</b> a barrel <b>of wine</b> rather than oil, <b>and</b> in his shame at not having oil for them, <b>he hanged himself</b> and died.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And guests are not permitted to give</b> some <b>of</b> the food <b>that is</b> placed <b>before them to the son or to the daughter of the host unless they</b> first <b>receive permission from the host.</b>
<b>And</b> there was <b>an incident involving a certain</b> individual <b>who invited three guests during years of famine, and he had</b> enough <b>to place only three eggs before them. The son of the host came,</b> and <b>one of</b> the guests <b>took his portion and gave it to</b> the son. <b>And similarly the second</b> guest gave his portion to the son, <b>and similarly the third</b> guest. <b>The father of the child came and found that</b> his son was <b>holding one</b> egg <b>in his mouth and two in his hand.</b> The father became so angry with his son for taking all the food that <b>he hit</b> the son <b>to the ground, and</b> the son <b>died. When his mother saw</b> what had happened, <b>she ascended to the roof and fell</b> down to the ground <b>and died.</b> And when the father saw that both his son and his wife were dead <b>he also ascended to the roof and fell</b> down to the ground <b>and died.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov said: For this matter</b> of giving food to the child of the host, <b>three Jewish souls were killed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What does this</b> statement <b>teach us?</b> It is obvious from the incident that three people were killed. The Gemara answers: It teaches <b>that the entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> taught by <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who sends</b> a whole <b>thigh</b> of an animal <b>to another, he is not required to</b> first <b>remove the sciatic nerve from it.</b> This is because the recipient can see that it has not yet been removed and will not eat it until he removes the sciatic nerve himself. But if one sends a thigh that has been <b>cut</b> up, <b>he is required to</b> first <b>remove the sciatic nerve from it</b> so that the recipient does not eat it unwittingly. <b>And in</b> the case of one who sends a thigh to <b>a gentile,</b> regardless of <b>whether it is cut or whole he is not required to remove the sciatic nerve from it.</b>
<b>And</b> it was <b>due to two factors</b> that the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one may not sell</b> meat from unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses or <i>tereifot</i> to a gentile: One, because it misleads him,</b> as he thinks that it is kosher meat, which is more desirable; <b>and another</b> factor is the concern <b>lest</b> the gentile <b>then sell</b> the meat <b>to another Jew,</b> who will think it is kosher since it originally was sold by a Jew.
<b>And</b> similarly, <b>a person may not say to a gentile: Purchase meat for me</b> from a Jewish butcher <b>with this dinar, due to two factors:</b>

Daf 94b

<b>One</b> factor is <b>because of the oppressors,</b> i.e., the concern that perhaps the gentile will keep the money for himself and force the merchant to give him the meat without payment. <b>And another</b> factor is <b>lest</b> the merchant <b>sell him</b> meat from unslaughtered <b>carcasses or <i>tereifot</i></b> without realizing that the gentile is purchasing the meat on behalf of a Jew.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And in</b> the case of one who sends a thigh to <b>a gentile,</b> regardless of <b>whether it is cut or whole he is not required to remove the sciatic nerve from it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are we dealing with? If we say</b> that it is referring <b>to a place</b> where all the butchers are Jewish and <b>they announce</b> every time they sell non-kosher meat to a gentile, then in the case of a thigh that has been <b>cut, why</b> is one <b>not required to remove the sciatic nerve? Since it was not announced</b> that they sold non-kosher meat, a Jew might <b>come to purchase it from</b> a gentile without realizing that it still contains the sciatic nerve.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that it is referring <b>to a place where they do not announce</b> every time they sell non-kosher meat, and in such a place a Jew would not purchase meat from a gentile. But <b>say the middle clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: And it was <b>due to two factors</b> that the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one may not sell</b> meat from unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses or <i>tereifot</i> to a gentile: One</b> is <b>because it misleads him; and another</b> is the concern <b>lest</b> the gentile <b>then sell</b> the meat <b>to another Jew,</b> who will think it is kosher since it originally was sold by a Jew.
<b>But if</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a place where they do not announce</b> every time they sell non-kosher meat to a gentile, a Jew <b>will not come to purchase</b> the meat <b>from</b> the gentile. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a place where they announce</b> every time they sell non-kosher meat.
But <b>say the latter clause:</b> And similarly, <b>a person may not say to a gentile: Purchase meat for me with this dinar, due to two factors. One</b> factor is <b>because of the oppressors, and another</b> factor is <b>lest</b> the merchant <b>sell him</b> meat from unslaughtered <b>carcasses or <i>tereifot</i></b> without realizing that the gentile is purchasing the meat on behalf of a Jew. <b>But if</b> it is referring <b>to a place where they announce</b> every time non-kosher meat is sold, <b>if</b> it would happen <b>that it was a <i>tereifa</i></b> the butchers <b>would have announced</b> the fact, and the Jew would know not to eat that meat.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a place where they do not announce</b> every time non-kosher meat is sold. But is it possible that <b>the first clause and the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> are referring <b>to a place where they do not announce</b> every time non-kosher meat is sold but <b>the middle clause</b> is referring <b>to a place where they</b> do <b>announce</b> every time non-kosher meat is sold?
<b>Abaye said: Yes, the first clause and the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> are referring <b>to a place where they do not announce</b> every time non-kosher meat is sold, and <b>the middle clause</b> is referring <b>to a place where they</b> do <b>announce</b> every time non-kosher meat is sold.
<b>Rava said:</b> The <b>entire</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a place where they announce</b> every time non-kosher meat is sold. <b>The first clause and the latter clause</b> are referring to days <b>when they announced</b> that non-kosher meat had been sold, and <b>the middle clause</b> is referring to a day <b>when they did not announce</b> that non-kosher meat had been sold.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The <b>entire</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a place where they do not announce</b> every time non-kosher meat is sold. <b>And</b> the reason that <b>the middle clause</b> teaches that it is prohibited to sell meat from unslaughtered carcasses or <i>tereifot</i> to a gentile is due to <b>a</b> rabbinic <b>decree lest</b> the Jew <b>sell it</b> to the gentile <b>in the presence of</b> another <b>Jew,</b> who will think that this particular piece of meat is kosher.
§ The Gemara noted that there were places where they would announce whenever non-kosher meat was sold to a gentile. The Gemara asks: <b>How do we announce</b> that non-kosher meat has been sold? The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef said: Meat has fallen</b> into our possession <b>for the soldiers,</b> i.e., the gentiles.
The Gemara objects: <b>But let</b> them <b>say: A <i>tereifa</i> has fallen</b> into our possession <b>for the soldiers.</b> The Gemara answers that if a butcher would publicize the fact that it is a <i>tereifa</i>, the gentiles would <b>not purchase</b> it from him because they would not want an animal rejected by the Jews.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the announcement is made in a way that obscures from the gentiles the fact that the animal is a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>doesn’t</b> this <b>deceive them?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is they who deceive themselves,</b> because the seller does not specify which kind of meat he is selling.
The Gemara cites proof that it is permitted to allow others to mislead themselves. It is <b>like this</b> incident <b>when Mar Zutra, son of Rav Naḥman, was going from</b> the city of <b>Sikhra to</b> the city of <b>Bei Meḥoza, and</b> at the same time <b>Rava and Rav Safra were going to Sikhra. They met each other,</b> and Mar Zutra <b>thought they were coming</b> out to greet <b>him. He said to them: Why did the Rabbis exert</b> themselves <b>and come all this</b> way to greet me? <b>Rav Safra said to him: We did not know that the Master was coming; if we would have known we would have exerted</b> ourselves <b>more.</b>
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Safra: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>you said this</b> to Mar Zutra? <b>By</b> telling him that we were not coming to greet him you <b>upset him.</b> Rav Safra <b>said to</b> Rava: <b>But</b> if I would not have said so <b>we</b> would have <b>misled him.</b> Rava responded: Mar Zutra <b>misled himself,</b> since we never said we were coming to greet him.
§ The Gemara returns to the topic of selling non-kosher meat to a gentile. There was <b>a certain</b> Jewish <b>butcher who said to another</b> individual:

Daf 95a

<b>If you would have made peace with me</b> yesterday, <b>wouldn’t I have given you</b> a cut <b>from the fattened bull that I prepared yesterday?</b> The other individual <b>said to him:</b> Nevertheless <b>I ate from the finest of the fine</b> of that bull that you prepared. The butcher <b>said to him: From where</b> did <b>you</b> get a piece? The other <b>said to him: So-and-so the gentile bought</b> it <b>and fed</b> it <b>to me.</b> The butcher <b>said to him: I prepared two</b> bulls yesterday. One was kosher, <b>but that one</b> you ate <b>was a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> which is why I sold it to a gentile.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said</b> when he heard of this incident: <b>Because of this imbecile who acted improperly</b> and sold non-kosher meat to the gentile butcher without publicizing that he did so, should <b>we forbid all</b> of <b>the</b> meat from gentile <b>butcher shops</b> in the city?
The Gemara notes that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said:</b> If there are <b>butcher shops</b> in a city <b>and Jewish butchers</b> prepare the meat, any <b>meat found in the possession of a gentile,</b> i.e., in a gentile’s butcher shop, <b>is permitted.</b> There is no concern that the meat is from an animal that was a <i>tereifa</i>, because the Jewish butcher would not have sold it to a gentile to sell in his butcher shop.
The Gemara presents an alternate version of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s reaction to the incident cited above: <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: Because of this imbecile, who intended</b> only <b>to cause distress to his fellow,</b> should <b>we forbid all</b> of <b>the</b> meat from gentile <b>butcher shops?</b> That butcher was presumably lying about the meat having been from a <i>tereifa</i>.
The Gemara notes that <b>the reason</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi considers the meat to be kosher is <b>that</b> the butcher <b>intended</b> only <b>to cause distress to his fellow.</b> This indicates that if <b>that were not so,</b> all the meat in the gentile butcher shops would be <b>forbidden. But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said:</b> If there are <b>butcher shops</b> in a city <b>and Jewish butchers</b> prepare the meat, any <b>meat found in the possession of a gentile is permitted?</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>different here because it has been established</b> that there is <b>forbidden</b> meat being sold in the butcher shops. Since it is known that a Jewish butcher sold non-kosher meat to a gentile proprietor of a butcher shop, one must be concerned that this was not an isolated incident.
§ Apropos meat in the possession of a gentile, the Gemara cites a related discussion. <b>Rav says: Once meat is obscured from sight</b> and unsupervised, it is <b>forbidden,</b> as one must be concerned that it was exchanged for non-kosher meat. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said:</b> If there are <b>butcher shops</b> in a city <b>and Jewish butchers</b> prepare the meat, any <b>meat found in the possession of a gentile is permitted.</b> The Gemara answers: Meat <b>found in the possession of a gentile is different,</b> because the meat was not left unsupervised.
The Gemara raises another objection to the statement of Rav. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the following <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>nine stores</b> in a city, <b>all of which sell</b> kosher <b>meat</b> from <b>a slaughtered</b> animal, <b>and one</b> other store that <b>sells meat</b> from unslaughtered <b>animal carcasses, and</b> an individual <b>purchased</b> meat <b>from one of</b> the stores <b>and he does not know from which</b> store <b>he purchased</b> the meat, in this case of <b>uncertainty,</b> the meat <b>is forbidden. But in</b> the case of meat <b>found</b> outside, <b>follow the majority.</b> Consequently, since most of the stores sell kosher meat, it may be assumed that the meat found outside is kosher, which contradicts Rav’s statement that meat that was left unsupervised is forbidden. The Gemara answers: <b>Here also</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where the meat was not unsupervised but rather was <b>found in the possession of a gentile.</b>
The Gemara cites another challenge to the opinion of Rav: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the following mishna (<i>Makhshirin</i> 2:9): If one <b>found meat in</b> a city inhabited by both Jews and gentiles, <b>if</b> the meat <b>is raw, follow the majority of butchers,</b> so that if the majority of the butchers are Jewish, the meat is presumed to be kosher. <b>And if</b> the meat <b>is cooked, follow the majority of meat eaters,</b> because even if the majority of the butchers are Jewish, if the meat was cooked by a gentile it is forbidden. This mishna indicates that there are circumstances when the meat is permitted even though it was obscured from sight.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>here also</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the meat <b>is found in the possession of a gentile,</b> why does the <i>baraita</i> state that if the meat is cooked, one should <b>follow the majority of meat eaters? Let us see</b> whether <b>a gentile is holding it or a Jew is holding it.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Here we are dealing with</b> a case where the meat was on the ground but someone was <b>standing and watching it</b> from the time it was dropped on the ground, so that it was never left unsupervised. Yet, the person watching does not know whether it was dropped by a Jew or a gentile, and therefore a determination must be made based upon the majority of the people in the city.
The Gemara cites another challenge to the opinion of Rav from a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 19a). <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> With regard to meat <b>found in the outlying areas,</b> outside of Jerusalem, if it is found as whole <b>limbs,</b> the meat presumably comes from <b>carcasses</b> of animals that were not properly slaughtered, as carcasses were generally cut up into full limbs and fed to dogs or sold to gentiles. But if it is in small <b>pieces,</b> it is presumably kosher and <b>permitted</b> to be eaten, as kosher meat was ordinarily cut up into small pieces. This mishna indicates that even though the meat was obscured from sight, it remains permitted. <b>And if you would say</b> that <b>here also</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> someone was <b>standing and watching it, why</b> is it assumed to be from <b>a carcass</b> if it is cut into whole <b>limbs?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> mishna requires <b>explanation only according to Rav,</b> but <b>wasn’t it stated with regard to that</b> mishna: <b>Rav says</b> that the correct version of the mishna is that the small pieces of meat are <b>permitted,</b> in that they are not considered impure and that one who eats them is not liable to be flogged, as would be the case if it were meat from a <b>carcass.</b> But it is not actually permitted to eat the meat, due to the fact that it was obscured from sight. <b>And Levi says:</b> The mishna means to say that the small pieces of meat are even <b>permitted to be eaten.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And this</b> statement <b>of Rav,</b> that meat that was obscured from sight is forbidden, <b>was not stated explicitly</b> by Rav. <b>Rather, it was stated</b> that he held this opinion <b>based on an inference</b> from a different statement of Rav. <b>As, Rav was</b> once <b>sitting on the ford of</b> the <b>Ishtetit River. He saw a certain man who was</b>

Daf 95b

<b>cleaning</b> the <b>head</b> of an animal in the river. The head <b>fell from him. He went and brought a basket, cast</b> the basket into the river, and <b>pulled out two</b> animal heads. <b>Rav said</b> to him: Does it commonly <b>happen this</b> way that one loses one item and finds two? Just as one of the animal heads is not the one you dropped, it is possible that neither of them is the one you dropped. Therefore, Rav rendered both of <b>them forbidden to him.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav:</b> Is <b>forbidden</b> meat <b>common</b> but <b>permitted</b> meat <b>not common?</b> Most of the meat in this general location is kosher, so why did you forbid the two animal heads? <b>He said to them: Forbidden</b> meat <b>is more common.</b> From this incident the Sages derived that according to Rav, meat that has been obscured from sight becomes forbidden due to the possibility that the meat one finds now was actually deposited by ravens, who transported it from a location where the majority of the meat is forbidden.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> does it matter <b>if</b> this opinion of Rav is known <b>by inference</b> based on this incident, rather than by an explicit statement made by Rav? The Gemara answers: There is room to say that this incident cannot serve as a precedent for a general policy, because that location <b>was a port of gentiles,</b> where most of the meat was non-kosher. <b>Know</b> that this is the case, <b>as</b> Rav <b>said to</b> Rav Kahana and Rav Asi: <b>Forbidden</b> meat <b>is more common.</b> Consequently, it is possible that Rav would not have prohibited the meat in a location where the majority of the meat is kosher.
The Gemara asks: <b>But how did Rav</b> ever <b>eat meat</b> if he holds that meat becomes forbidden if it is unsupervised for even a short time? The Gemara answers: Rav ate meat only <b>in its time,</b> i.e., shortly after it was slaughtered, <b>when it had not been obscured from his sight</b> from the time of the slaughter until he ate it. Alternatively, <b>if you wish, say</b> that Rav ate meat that was <b>tied and sealed</b> in a way that proved it had not been swapped for non-kosher meat. <b>Or alternatively,</b> he ate meat that could be recognized <b>by a distinguishing mark, like that</b> practice of <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna,</b> who would <b>cut</b> meat into pieces <b>with three corners,</b> i.e., triangles, before he would send it to his family members.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav was going to the home of Rav Ḥanan, his son-in-law. He saw</b> that <b>the ferry was coming toward him</b> just when he arrived at the riverbank. <b>He said: The ferry is coming toward me</b> even though I did not arrange for it to come now; this is a sign that <b>a good day,</b> i.e., a festive meal, awaits me <b>in</b> the place where I am going.
After crossing the river on the ferry, Rav <b>went and stood at the gate</b> of Rav Ḥanan’s home. <b>He looked</b> through <b>a crack in the door</b> and <b>saw an animal that was hanging</b> and ready to be cooked. <b>He knocked on the gate,</b> and <b>everyone went out to</b> greet <b>him,</b> and <b>the butchers also came</b> out to greet him. <b>Rav did not remove his eyes from</b> the meat that the butchers were preparing. <b>He said to them: If</b> you had eaten the meat based upon the supervision you provided <b>now,</b> you would have <b>fed forbidden</b> meat <b>to the sons of</b> my <b>daughter</b> because no one apart from me was watching the meat when you all came out to greet me. And despite the fact that he had kept the meat in his sight <b>Rav did not eat from that meat.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that Rav did not eat the meat? <b>If</b> one suggests that he was concerned <b>because</b> it had been <b>obscured</b> from sight, that cannot be the reason, as Rav kept watching it so that it <b>was not obscured</b> from sight. <b>Rather,</b> Rav did not eat <b>because he divined,</b> i.e., he saw the arrival of the ferry as a good omen. This is prohibited, and therefore Rav penalized himself and abstained from the meat.
The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t Rav say</b> that <b>any divination that is not like</b> the divination of <b>Eliezer, the servant of Abraham,</b> when he went to seek a bride for Isaac (see Genesis 24:14), <b>or like</b> the divination of <b>Jonathan, son of Saul,</b> who sought an omen as to whether he and his arms bearer would defeat the Philistines (see I Samuel 14:8–12), <b>is not divination?</b> Since Rav did not rely on the omen in his decision making, he did not violate the prohibition against divination, and there was no reason for him to penalize himself. The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> the reason Rav did not eat the meat is that <b>it was an optional feast,</b> rather than a feast associated with a mitzva, <b>and Rav would not derive pleasure from an optional feast.</b>
Having mentioned Rav’s reaction to the ferry in the incident cited above, the Gemara states that <b>Rav would check</b> whether to travel based upon <b>the ferry;</b> if it came quickly he would take the ferry, but otherwise he would not. <b>And Shmuel would check</b> what would happen to him <b>by</b> opening <b>a scroll</b> and reading from wherever it was open to. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan would check</b> what was in store for him <b>by</b> asking <b>a child</b> to recite the verse he was learning.
The Gemara relates an incident when Rabbi Yoḥanan checked his luck based on a child’s verse. During <b>all the years</b> when <b>Rav</b> lived in Babylonia, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who lived in Eretz Yisrael, would <b>write to him</b> and begin with the greeting: <b>To our Master who is in Babylonia. When</b> Rav <b>died,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>would write to Shmuel</b> and begin with the greeting: <b>To our colleague who is in Babylonia.</b> Shmuel <b>said: Does</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>not know</b> any <b>matter in which I am his master?</b> Shmuel <b>wrote</b> and <b>sent to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan the calculation of the <b>leap</b> years <b>for</b> the next <b>sixty years.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan was not impressed by this and <b>said: Now he</b> has <b>merely</b> demonstrated that <b>he knows mathematics,</b> which does not make him my master.
Shmuel then <b>wrote</b> and <b>sent to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan explications of <b>uncertainties</b> pertaining to <b><i>tereifot</i></b> that had to be transported on <b>thirteen camels.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan was impressed by this and <b>said: I have a Master in Babylonia; I will go and see him.</b> Before departing on his journey, Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to a child: Recite to me your verse</b> that you studied today. The child <b>recited</b> the following verse <b>to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>“Now Samuel was dead”</b> (I Samuel 28:3). Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said</b> to himself: <b>Learn from this</b> that <b>Shmuel has died.</b> Therefore, Rabbi Yoḥanan did not go to see Shmuel.
The Gemara comments: <b>But it was not so; Shmuel had not died. Rather,</b> the reason Rabbi Yoḥanan was given this sign was <b>so that Rabbi Yoḥanan would not trouble himself</b> to embark on the long and arduous journey from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> With regard to one who is successful with his first business transaction after he has built <b>a home,</b> after the birth of <b>a child, or</b> after he marries <b>a woman, even though</b> he may <b>not</b> use this as a means of <b>divination</b> to decide upon future courses of action, <b>it is</b> an auspicious <b>sign</b> that he will continue to be successful. Conversely, if his first transaction is not successful he may take that as an inauspicious sign.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said: But this</b> is provided <b>that</b> the sign <b>has been established</b> by repeating itself <b>three times.</b> This is based on a verse, <b>as it is written:</b> “And Jacob their father said to them: Me you have bereaved of my children: <b>Joseph is not, and Simeon is not, and you will take Benjamin away;</b> upon me are all these things come” (Genesis 42:36). If calamity were to befall Benjamin, that would establish a pattern of three tragedies.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss distinguishing marks that prevent meat from being prohibited despite its having been obscured from sight. <b>Rav Huna inquired of Rav:</b> If pieces of meat were <b>strung</b> together and then were obscured from sight, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav <b>said to him: Do not be an imbecile;</b> of course if the meat is <b>strung</b> together <b>it is</b> considered to be <b>a distinguishing mark,</b> and the meat is permitted. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> this <i>halakha</i> as follows: <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> If pieces of meat are <b>strung</b> together <b>it is a distinguishing mark,</b> and the meat remains permitted even if it is obscured from sight.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Naḥman of Neharde’a arrived at</b> the home of <b>Rav Kahana in Pum Nahara on the eve of Yom Kippur,</b> which is a day when people commonly eat meat. <b>Ravens came</b> and <b>dropped livers and kidneys.</b> Rav Kahana <b>said to</b> Rav Naḥman: <b>Take</b> these livers and kidneys <b>and eat</b> them, as they are not forbidden, even though they were obscured from sight. This is because <b>at this time permitted</b> meat is <b>more common</b> than forbidden meat, since Jews slaughter many animals on this day.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin lost</b> a cut of meat from an animal <b>intestine among</b> the <b>barrels</b> of wine in his wine cellar. When he found it, <b>he came before Rav Huna</b> to ask whether the meat was now prohibited because it had been obscured from sight. Rav Huna <b>said to him: Do you have a distinguishing mark on it</b> so that you can identify it? Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin <b>said to him: No.</b> Rav Huna asked him: <b>Do you have visual recognition of it?</b> Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin <b>said to him: Yes.</b> Rav Huna said: <b>If so, go and take</b> it and eat it.
<b>Rav Ḥanina Ḥoza’a lost a side of meat.</b> When he found it, <b>he came before Rav Naḥman</b> and asked him whether the meat was now prohibited because it had been obscured from sight. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: Do you have a distinguishing mark on it</b> so that you can identify it? Rav Ḥanina Ḥoza’a <b>said to him: No.</b> Rav Naḥman asked him: <b>Do you have visual recognition of it?</b> Rav Ḥanina Ḥoza’a <b>said to him: Yes.</b> Rav Naḥman said: <b>If so, go and take</b> it and eat it.
<b>Rav Natan bar Abaye lost a skein of sky-blue</b> wool prepared for use in ritual fringes. He searched for it and found it. <b>He came before Rav Ḥisda</b> to ask whether the wool was now prohibited because it had been obscured from sight and may have become confused with other blue wool that is not valid for ritual fringes. Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: Do you have a distinguishing mark in it</b> so that you can identify it? Rav Natan bar Abaye <b>said to him: No.</b> Rav Ḥisda asked him: <b>Do you have visual recognition of it?</b> Rav Natan bar Abaye <b>said to him: Yes.</b> Rav Ḥisda said: <b>If so, go and take</b> it, and you may use it for ritual fringes.
<b>Rava said: At first I would say</b> that <b>a distinguishing mark is preferable to visual recognition, because we return a lost item</b> to its owner based <b>on a distinguishing mark,</b>

Daf 96a

<b>but we do not return</b> a lost item to one who claims to be its owner based solely <b>on visual recognition.</b> But <b>now that I have heard these statements</b> pertaining to meat or sky-blue wool that were obscured from sight and then permitted based upon visual recognition, <b>I say</b> that <b>visual recognition is preferable</b> to a distinguishing mark.
Furthermore, one must hold that sensory recognition is reliable even without identifying marks, <b>for if you do not say so, how is</b> it that <b>a blind</b> man <b>permitted to</b> engage in sexual intercourse with <b>his wife</b> despite the fact that he cannot identify her by means of her identifying marks? <b>And</b> similarly, <b>how are</b> any <b>men permitted to</b> engage in intercourse with <b>their wives at night,</b> when it is dark and they cannot see their wives’ identifying marks? <b>Rather,</b> one must say that they identify their wives <b>based on voice recognition. Here too,</b> in these cases of lost meat and sky-blue wool, they remain permitted <b>based on visual recognition.</b>
<b>Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Mesharshiyya, said:</b> You can <b>know</b> that visual recognition is preferable to a distinguishing mark, <b>because if two</b> witnesses <b>come</b> to court <b>and say: So-and-so, who has this distinguishing mark and that distinguishing mark, killed a person, we</b> would <b>not kill him</b> based on this testimony. <b>But if</b> the two witnesses <b>say: We have visual recognition of him,</b> and they confirm that the accused individual committed murder, <b>we kill him</b> based on their testimony.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> You can <b>know</b> that visual recognition is preferable to a distinguishing mark, <b>because if a man says to his agent: Call so-and-so, who</b> has <b>this distinguishing mark and that distinguishing mark, it is uncertain</b> whether the agent will recognize him and <b>know</b> whom to call or whether he will <b>not know him. But if he has visual recognition of</b> him, <b>when he sees him he will know</b> it is <b>him.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who removes the sciatic nerve must</b> scrape away the flesh in the area surrounding the nerve to ensure <b>that he will remove all of it. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Scraping is not required; it is sufficient to excise it from the area above the rounded protrusion <b>in order to</b> thereby <b>fulfill the mitzva of removal</b> of the sciatic nerve.
<b>One who eats an olive-bulk of the sciatic nerve incurs forty</b> lashes. If <b>one eats</b> an entire sciatic nerve <b>and it does not</b> constitute <b>an olive-bulk,</b> he is nevertheless <b>liable</b> to receive lashes, because a complete sciatic nerve is a complete entity. If <b>one ate an olive-bulk from this</b> sciatic nerve in the right leg, <b>and an olive-bulk from that</b> sciatic nerve in the left leg, <b>he incurs [<i>sofeg</i>] eighty</b> lashes. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He incurs only forty</b> lashes, for eating the olive-bulk from the right leg, and he is exempt for eating the olive-bulk from the left leg.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> A man known as <b>bar Peyoli was standing before Shmuel and was removing</b> the sciatic nerve from the <b>leg</b> of an animal. <b>He was cutting</b> out the nerve without scraping away the surrounding flesh, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. Shmuel <b>said to him: Go down further</b> and scrape away the flesh in order to remove the entire nerve. <b>Now,</b> if I would <b>not have seen you</b> and instructed you in the process of removing the sciatic nerve, <b>you would have fed me forbidden</b> meat.
Bar Peyoli became <b>afraid</b> due to Shmuel’s rebuke and <b>the knife fell from his hand.</b> Shmuel <b>said to him: Do not be afraid.</b> I do not think that you are an ignoramus or a wicked person. You are removing the sciatic nerve as you were taught; the person <b>who taught you</b> must hold <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> and this is how <b>he taught you</b> to remove the sciatic nerve. But I hold that the entire sciatic nerve must be removed, in accordance with the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>.
<b>Rav Sheshet said</b> in explanation of this incident: <b>That which bar Peyoli removed was</b> the section of the sciatic nerve one is required to remove <b>by Torah law according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The Gemara asks: Based upon this statement, one can derive <b>by inference that he left</b> behind the section of the sciatic nerve one is required to remove <b>by rabbinic law according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. But</b> if so, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion did the person <b>who taught him</b> how to remove the sciatic nerve <b>teach him?</b> Even according to Rabbi Yehuda he would have transgressed a rabbinic prohibition.
<b>Rather, Rav Sheshet said: That which bar Peyoli removed</b> was the section of the sciatic nerve that is forbidden <b>by Torah law. And that which he left</b> over is forbidden <b>by rabbinic law according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> as explained above (92b) in a <i>baraita</i>; <b>as if</b> one were to follow the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> the section that bar Peyoli left over <b>is permitted even by rabbinic law.</b>
