§ The mishna teaches: <b>One who eats</b> an olive-bulk <b>of the sciatic nerve</b> incurs forty lashes. <b>Shmuel says: The Torah prohibits only</b> the part of the sciatic nerve <b>that is on the</b> rounded protrusion of flesh shaped like <b>a spoon</b> that is near the end of the femur. This is <b>as it is stated</b> in the verse: “Therefore the children of Israel eat not the sciatic nerve that is <b>upon the spoon of the thigh”</b> (Genesis 32:33).
<b>Rav Pappa says:</b> This statement of Shmuel is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one ate</b> the entire sciatic nerve and <b>it did not contain an olive-bulk, he is</b> nevertheless <b>liable</b> to be flogged. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> He is not liable <b>unless it has</b> a volume of at least <b>an olive-bulk.</b>
Rav Pappa explains how this relates to Shmuel’s statement. <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda? They hold that the sciatic nerve <b>is a distinct entity.</b> Therefore, even if one eats less than an olive-bulk it is a significant act of eating, and one is liable.

Daf 96b

<b>And</b> what does <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> hold? He holds that since the term: <b>Eating, is written with regard to</b> the sciatic nerve, and a significant act of eating is generally defined as eating an olive-bulk, one is liable only if he eats an olive-bulk. <b>And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> derive from this term? <b>That</b> usage of the term <b>eating</b> indicates <b>that</b> in a case where the sciatic nerve <b>contains four or five olive-bulks and</b> one <b>ate</b> only <b>one olive-bulk, he is liable.</b> Nevertheless, if one eats the entire sciatic nerve, he is liable even if it contains less than an olive-bulk.
<b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> from where is it derived that one is liable for eating one olive-bulk of a larger sciatic nerve? He holds that it <b>is derived from</b> the phrase <b>“that is upon the spoon of the thigh,”</b> which indicates that even if one eats only the part of the sciatic nerve that is upon the spoon of the thigh, rather than the entire sciatic nerve, he is liable.
<b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> interpret that phrase? <b>That</b> phrase <b>is necessary to</b> teach the <i>halakha</i> stated by <b>Shmuel, as Shmuel said: The Torah prohibits only</b> the part of the sciatic nerve <b>that is on the</b> rounded protrusion of flesh shaped like a <b>spoon. And</b> what does <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> hold with regard to the <i>halakha</i> stated by Shmuel? He derives from the fact that it <b>is written:</b> “The spoon of <b>the thigh,”</b> that the sciatic nerve <b>of the entire thigh</b> is forbidden, not just the part that is on the rounded protrusion of flesh shaped like a spoon.
<b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> interpret “the spoon of the thigh”? According to the Rabbis, <b>this</b> expression indicates that <b>the prohibition of</b> the sciatic nerve applies to the nerve <b>that extends</b> throughout <b>the entire thigh,</b> i.e., the inner nerve, which serves <b>to exclude the outer</b> nerve, <b>which is not</b> forbidden by Torah law; <b>but in fact,</b> only the part of the inner nerve <b>that is on the</b> protrusion of flesh shaped like <b>a spoon</b> is forbidden, not the entire inner nerve.
The Gemara objects: <b>But this</b> term <b>“spoon” is required to exclude</b> the sciatic nerve of <b>a bird, which does not have</b> a rounded protrusion on its thigh bone that can be described as the <b>spoon of the thigh,</b> as taught in the mishna (89b). The Gemara explains: There are <b>two</b> usages of the term <b>“spoon”</b> written in the verse, and therefore two separate <i>halakhot</i> can be derived from this term.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a thigh that was cooked</b> with <b>the sciatic nerve in it, if there is</b> enough of the sciatic nerve <b>in it</b> to <b>impart</b> its <b>flavor</b> to the thigh, the entire thigh <b>is forbidden</b> for consumption. <b>How does one measure</b> whether there is enough sciatic nerve to impart flavor to the meat of the entire thigh? One relates to it <b>as though</b> the sciatic nerve were <b>meat</b> imparting flavor <b>to a turnip.</b> If meat the volume of the sciatic nerve would impart flavor to a turnip the volume of the thigh when they were cooked together, then the entire thigh is forbidden.
With regard to <b>a sciatic nerve that was cooked with</b> other <b>sinews, when one identifies</b> the sciatic nerve and removes it, the other sinews are forbidden if the sciatic nerve was large enough to <b>impart flavor. And if</b> he does <b>not</b> identify it, <b>all</b> the sinews are <b>forbidden</b> because each one could be the sciatic nerve; <b>but the broth</b> is forbidden only if the sciatic nerve <b>imparts flavor</b> to the broth.
<b>And similarly,</b> in the case of <b>a piece of an animal carcass or a piece of non-kosher fish that was cooked with</b> similar <b>pieces</b> of kosher meat or fish, <b>when one identifies</b> the forbidden piece and removes it, the rest of the meat or fish is forbidden only if the forbidden piece was large enough to <b>impart flavor</b> to the entire mixture. <b>And if</b> he does <b>not</b> identify and remove the forbidden piece, <b>all</b> the pieces <b>are forbidden,</b> due to the possibility that each piece one selects might be the forbidden piece; <b>but the broth</b> is forbidden only if the forbidden piece <b>imparts flavor</b> to the broth.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that a thigh that was cooked with the sciatic nerve is forbidden if the nerve imparts flavor to the thigh. <b>Shmuel says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that the thigh is entirely forbidden <b>only when it was cooked</b> with the sciatic nerve <b>inside it. But</b> if the sciatic nerve was <b>roasted inside</b> the thigh, one may <b>peel</b> away the meat <b>and eat</b> it <b>until he reaches the</b> sciatic <b>nerve,</b> and then he removes the nerve.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Is that so? But doesn’t Rav Huna say:</b> With regard to <b>a kid that was roasted with its</b> forbidden <b>fat, it is prohibited to eat</b> any part of the animal, <b>even from the top of its ear?</b> This proves that roasting, like cooking, spreads the flavor of the forbidden fat throughout the entire animal.

Daf 97a

The Gemara answers: Forbidden <b>fat is different</b> from the sciatic nerve, <b>because</b> its flavor <b>permeates</b> throughout the animal, unlike that of the sciatic nerve.
The Gemara challenges Rav Huna’s statement: <b>And</b> in the case of a kid roasted <b>with</b> its forbidden <b>fat,</b> is the meat <b>forbidden? But didn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say: There was an incident</b> that came <b>before Rabbi Yoḥanan in the synagogue of</b> the town of <b>Maon, where a young goat was roasted with its fat, and</b> the people <b>came and asked Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> about the status of the meat, <b>and he said: Peel</b> away the meat <b>and eat</b> it <b>until</b> you <b>reach the</b> forbidden <b>fat?</b> This indicates that the flavor of the fat does not permeate the entire animal in which it is roasted. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> kid <b>was lean</b> and had so little fat that its flavor did not permeate throughout the animal.
<b>Rav Huna bar Yehuda said:</b> That <b>was</b> a case of <b>a kidney</b> of a young goat roasted <b>with its</b> forbidden <b>fat, and</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>permitted it</b> to be eaten because there is a membrane that separates the fat from the kidney and prevents the fat from penetrating the kidney. <b>Ravin bar Rav Adda said:</b> That <b>was</b> a case of a small, non-kosher fish known as <b><i>kilkhit</i>,</b> which fell <b>into a stewpot [<i>ilpas</i>], and they came</b> to <b>ask Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> about its status. <b>And he said to them: Let a gentile cook [<i>kapeila</i>] taste it</b> in order to determine whether the flavor of the non-kosher fish has permeated the entire mixture.
<b>Rava said: Initially that which is taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i> posed <b>a difficulty for me:</b> With regard to <b>a pot in which one cooked meat, one may not cook milk in it; and if he did cook</b> milk in it, the meat absorbed by the pot renders the milk forbidden if it <b>imparts flavor</b> to the milk. Similarly, if one cooked <b><i>teruma</i></b> in a pot, one <b>may not cook non-sacred</b> food <b>in it; and if one did cook</b> non-sacred food in it, the absorbed <i>teruma</i> renders the food in the pot sacred if it <b>imparts flavor</b> to it.
Rava explains: <b>Granted,</b> in the case of a pot used for <b><i>teruma</i>, a priest,</b> who is permitted to partake of <i>teruma</i>, <b>can taste</b> the non-sacred food subsequently cooked in the pot in order to determine whether the <i>teruma</i> imparted flavor to the non-sacred food. <b>But</b> in a case where it is not known whether <b>meat</b> imparted flavor <b>into milk, who can taste it?</b> If the meat did impart flavor to the milk, it would be forbidden for any Jew to consume the milk. But <b>now that Rabbi Yoḥanan said: We rely on a gentile cook</b> in the case of the <i>kilkhit</i>, <b>here also we rely on a gentile cook</b> to taste it and say whether the meat has imparted flavor to the milk.
The Gemara summarizes the guidelines that determine when an item cooked with another item affects the status of the mixture. <b>Rava said: The Sages said</b> that there are cases where one relies <b>on</b> a Jew <b>tasting</b> the food, <b>and the Sages said</b> that there are some cases where one relies <b>on</b> a gentile <b>cook</b> to taste the food,

Daf 97b

<b>and the Sages said</b> that there are cases where the mixture is permitted if there is <b>sixty</b> times as much permitted food as forbidden food. <b>Therefore,</b> in a case where the mixture is <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food <b>not</b> of <b>its</b> own <b>type,</b> so that there is a difference in taste between the two components, <b>when</b> there are Jews for whom the mixture is <b>permitted,</b> one relies <b>on</b> a Jew <b>tasting</b> the mixture. This is the <i>halakha</i> when <i>teruma</i> is cooked with non-sacred food. <b>When</b> the mixture is potentially <b>forbidden,</b> e.g., in the case of meat cooked with milk, one relies <b>on</b> a gentile <b>cook</b> to taste it.
<b>And</b> if the mixture is composed of <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type, where one cannot ascertain</b> whether the forbidden component has imparted <b>flavor; or</b> if it is composed of <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food <b>not</b> of <b>its</b> own <b>type when</b> the mixture may be <b>forbidden</b> and it is a case <b>where there is no</b> gentile <b>cook</b> available to taste it, the mixture is permitted if there is <b>sixty</b> times as much permitted food as forbidden food.
§ The Gemara (96b) cited Shmuel’s opinion with regard to the thigh of an animal that was roasted or cooked with the sciatic nerve still inside. The Gemara relates the following incident: There were <b>those</b> animal <b>thighs that were salted in the home of the Exilarch with the sciatic nerve</b> still inside; <b>Ravina</b> ruled that they were <b>forbidden,</b> whereas <b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav Ashi</b> ruled that they were <b>permitted. They came and asked Mar bar Rav Ashi</b> to render a decision. <b>He said to them:</b> My <b>father permitted</b> the meat in such circumstances.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav said to Ravina: What is your reasoning</b> in prohibiting the meat? Is it because of <b>what Shmuel said: A salted</b> food item <b>is</b> considered <b>like a boiling hot</b> food item, and a food item <b>marinated</b> in vinegar, brine, or the like <b>is</b> considered <b>like a cooked</b> food item? Perhaps based on this statement of Shmuel you consider the salted thighs as though they have been cooked with their sciatic nerves, in which case they are forbidden.
<b>But didn’t Shmuel</b> also <b>say</b> (96b): <b>They taught</b> that the thigh is entirely forbidden <b>only when it was cooked</b> with the sciatic nerve <b>inside it. But</b> if the sciatic nerve was <b>roasted inside</b> the thigh, one may <b>peel</b> away the meat <b>and eat</b> it <b>until he reaches the</b> sciatic <b>nerve,</b> and then he removes the nerve.
<b>And if you would say: What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>Like a boiling hot</b> food item, <b>that</b> Shmuel <b>said?</b> It is <b>like boiling hot</b> food <b>that was cooked</b> rather than hot food that was roasted, and therefore if the thigh was salted with its sciatic nerve the entire thigh becomes forbidden. This is not a convincing claim, because <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> Shmuel <b>said:</b> A food item <b>marinated</b> in vinegar, brine, or the like <b>is</b> considered <b>like a cooked</b> food item, it may be understood <b>by inference</b> that <b>when he said</b> that salted food is like <b>boiling hot</b> food he <b>was saying</b> that it is <b>like boiling hot</b> food <b>that is roasted.</b> The Gemara concludes: This poses <b>a difficulty</b> to the opinion of Ravina.
§ The Gemara elaborates on the statement that if permitted and forbidden foods are cooked together and there is sixty times as much permitted food as forbidden food, the mixture is permitted. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: When they assess</b> whether or not there is sixty times as much permitted food, <b>they assess</b> the volume of <b>the broth, the deposits [<i>kifa</i>], the pieces</b> of permitted food cooked in the pot, <b>and the pot</b> itself. The Gemara explains this last point: <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> this means that one includes the volume of the material of <b>the pot itself, and there are</b> those <b>who say</b> it means that one includes the volume of <b>that which the pot has absorbed</b> from the permitted food. When meat cooks its volume decreases, and some of the meat that constitutes that discrepancy is absorbed into the sides of the pot.
The Gemara continues its discussion of nullification. <b>Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> With regard to <b>all forbidden</b> foods <b>that are</b> prohibited <b>in the Torah,</b> if they are cooked with permitted food and one cannot tell whether they have imparted flavor to the permitted food, <b>we assess</b> the mixture <b>as though</b> the forbidden food were <b>onion or leek [<i>kaflot</i>].</b> If that amount of onions or leeks would impart flavor to the permitted food, one must assume that the mixture is forbidden.
<b>Rabbi Abba said to Abaye: But let one assess</b> the mixture as though the forbidden food were <b>pepper or</b> other <b>spices, which</b> are even more pungent, in which case <b>they</b> would <b>not be nullified even</b> if they were mixed <b>with a thousand</b> times as much permitted food. Abaye <b>said to him: The Sages ascertained that with regard to forbidden</b> foods, <b>there is nothing that imparts more flavor</b> to a mixture <b>than onion and leek.</b>
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the nullification of forbidden foods. <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> A sciatic <b>nerve</b> that was cooked with kosher food is nullified if the mixture contains permitted food that is <b>sixty</b> times the nerve’s volume, <b>and the</b> sciatic <b>nerve</b> itself <b>is not counted</b> in that number, because it cannot nullify itself. If <b>an udder,</b> which is meat but also contains milk, is cooked with other meat, the milk is nullified if the meat is <b>sixty</b> times its volume, <b>and</b> the <b>udder</b> itself <b>is counted</b> with the rest of the meat. If the <b>egg</b> of a non-kosher bird is cooked with kosher food, it is nullified if the permitted food is <b>sixty</b> times its volume, <b>and the egg</b> itself <b>is not counted</b> in that number, as it cannot nullify itself.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak, son of Rav Mesharshiyya, says:</b> In the case of an udder cooked with meat, even if the meat is sixty times the volume of the milk, so that the meat is permitted, the <b>udder itself is forbidden,</b> because the meat imparts flavor to the milk contained within the udder, which then renders the udder forbidden. <b>And if</b> the udder subsequently <b>falls into another pot,</b> it also <b>renders</b> the contents of that pot <b>forbidden</b> unless they are sixty times the volume of the udder.
<b>Rav Ashi said: When we were in the study hall of Rav Kahana, a dilemma was raised before us: When we assess</b> whether the contents of the pot are sufficient to nullify the udder, <b>do we assess</b> whether the pot contains sixty times as much permitted food as the entire volume of the meat of the udder <b>itself, or do we assess</b> only <b>that</b> milk <b>which came out from</b> the udder, since the udder itself has been removed from the mixture?
The Gemara responds: It is <b>obvious that we assess</b> the entire volume of the meat of the udder <b>itself, as if</b> we were to attempt to assess only <b>that which came out of it, how would we know</b> how much came out? The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so,</b> then if the udder <b>falls into another pot, it should not render</b> the food in that second pot <b>forbidden,</b> because it has been assumed that all the milk in the udder has been released into the first pot.
The Gemara explains: <b>Since Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Mesharshiyya, says</b> that even if there is sixty times as much meat in the pot as there is milk in the udder, <b>the udder itself is forbidden,</b> clearly <b>the Sages equated</b> the udder <b>with a piece of non-kosher</b> meat. Consequently, the reason the udder renders the contents of the second pot forbidden is that the udder is intrinsically forbidden, not because of the milk that is released into the pot while it is being cooked.
§ The Gemara addresses Rav Naḥman’s statement that if the <b>egg</b> of a non-kosher bird is cooked with kosher food, it is nullified if the permitted food is <b>sixty</b> times its volume, <b>and the egg</b> itself <b>is not counted</b> in that number, as it cannot nullify itself. <b>Rav Idi bar Avin said to Abaye:</b> Is this <b>to say that</b> the forbidden egg <b>imparts flavor</b> to the food with which it is cooked? <b>But isn’t</b> it true that when <b>people</b> want to indicate that food is tasteless, they <b>say:</b> This is <b>like mere egg-water?</b> This indicates that an egg does not impart flavor.
Abaye <b>said to him: Here we are dealing with</b>

Daf 98a

<b>an egg</b> that contains <b>a chick,</b> as the chick imparts flavor to the food in which the egg is cooked. <b>But</b> with regard to an egg that does not contain a chick but is from <b>a non-kosher</b> bird, it does <b>not</b> impart flavor to the food with which it is cooked.
Rav Idi bar Avin <b>raised an objection to</b> this answer based on a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Terumot</i> 9:5): With regard to <b>kosher eggs that one boiled with non-kosher eggs, if they have</b> a ratio that allows the non-kosher eggs to <b>impart flavor</b> to the kosher eggs, <b>they are all forbidden.</b> This indicates that eggs from non-kosher birds do have flavor. Abaye answered: <b>Here, too</b> it is referring <b>to an egg</b> from a kosher bird that contains <b>a chick. And why</b> does the <i>baraita</i> <b>call this a non-kosher</b> egg, indicating that it is an egg from a non-kosher species? <b>Since it has a chick inside,</b> which causes the egg to be forbidden, the <i>baraita</i> <b>calls it non-kosher.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause teaches:</b> With regard to <b>eggs that one boiled and a chick was found in one of them, if they have</b> a ratio that allows the chick to <b>impart flavor to them, they are all forbidden, it may be inferred that</b> in <b>the first clause we are dealing with</b> an egg <b>that does not have a chick inside.</b>
The Gemara explains that this is an incorrect inference, as the latter clause <b>is explaining</b> the first clause, so that the <i>baraita</i> should be read as follows: With regard to <b>kosher eggs that one boiled with non-kosher eggs, if they have</b> a ratio that allows the non-kosher eggs to <b>impart flavor</b> to the kosher eggs, <b>they are all forbidden. How</b> so? It can be referring to a case <b>where one boiled them and a chick was found in one of them.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>So too it is reasonable</b> to explain the <i>baraita</i> in this manner, <b>as if</b> it would <b>enter your mind</b> to say that <b>the first clause</b> is referring to a case <b>where there is no chick in</b> the egg, the latter clause is redundant: <b>Now</b> that the <i>tanna</i> has taught that in a case <b>where there is no chick inside,</b> the non-kosher egg imparts flavor to the kosher eggs and renders them <b>forbidden, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> for the <i>tanna</i> to teach that an egg <b>that has a chick inside</b> imparts flavor to the kosher eggs?
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>If it is due to that</b> reason, <b>there is no</b> conclusive <b>argument,</b> i.e., the proof of the argument is inconclusive. The reason is that one can say that the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught the latter clause to reveal</b> the meaning of <b>the first clause.</b> The latter clause was stated so <b>that you would not</b> mistakenly <b>say</b> that <b>the first clause</b> is referring only to a case <b>where</b> the egg <b>has a chick inside, but</b> if <b>there is no chick inside</b> the kosher eggs would be <b>permitted.</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches the latter clause</b> and specifies <b>that</b> it is referring to an egg <b>that has a chick inside. By inference the first clause</b> is referring to a case of an egg <b>that does not have a chick inside, and even so it</b> renders all of the other eggs <b>forbidden.</b>
§ The Gemara continues discussing the nullification of forbidden foods. There was once <b>a certain olive-bulk</b> of forbidden <b>fat that fell into a pot of</b> kosher <b>meat. Rav Asi thought to measure</b> the volume of the kosher meat together <b>with that which the pot had absorbed. The Rabbis said to Rav Ashi: Is that to say that</b> the pot <b>absorbed</b> the <b>permitted</b> meat but <b>did not absorb</b> the <b>forbidden</b> fat?
The Gemara relates a similar incident: There was once <b>a certain half-olive-bulk of</b> forbidden <b>fat that fell into a pot of</b> kosher <b>meat. Mar bar Rav Ashi thought to measure</b> the amount of kosher meat needed to nullify the forbidden fat as <b>thirty half-olive-bulks,</b> rather than sixty. <b>His father,</b> Rav Ashi, <b>said to him: Have I not told you: Do not</b> treat <b>measures lightly</b> even with regard to <b>rabbinic</b> prohibitions? <b>And furthermore, didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: A half-measure</b> is <b>prohibited by Torah</b> law? Consequently, the half-olive-bulk of forbidden fat is nullified only in sixty times its volume of permitted meat.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of nullifying forbidden foods. <b>Rav Shemen bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rav Idi bar Idi bar Gershom says</b> that <b>Levi bar Perata says</b> that <b>Rabbi Naḥum says</b> that <b>Rabbi Biryam says in the name of a certain elder, and his name was Rabbi Ya’akov,</b> that the Sages <b>in the house of the <i>Nasi</i> said:</b> If a non-kosher <b>egg</b> is mixed <b>with</b> kosher eggs, if there are <b>sixty</b> eggs they are all <b>forbidden,</b> but if there are <b>sixty-one</b> eggs they <b>are</b> all <b>permitted.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rav Shemen bar Abba: See,</b> one can infer from your words <b>that you fix a limit</b> to <b>permit</b> the eggs if there is a total of sixty-one eggs, including the non-kosher egg. This is a revelation, <b>because the two</b> most <b>eminent</b> Sages <b>of the generation did not clarify this matter.</b> These two eminent Sages were <b>Rabbi Ya’akov bar Idi and Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani,</b> and <b>both of them said in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi:</b> In a case where a non-kosher <b>egg</b> is mixed <b>with</b> kosher eggs, if there are <b>sixty</b> eggs they are all <b>forbidden,</b> but if there are <b>sixty-one</b> eggs they <b>are</b> all <b>permitted.</b>
<b>And a dilemma was raised before</b> these Sages: When Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said they are permitted if there are <b>sixty-one</b> eggs, does that mean there are <b>sixty-one</b> eggs altogether, <b>with the</b> non-kosher egg, <b>or</b> does it <b>perhaps</b> mean that there must be sixty-one kosher eggs <b>aside from</b> the non-kosher egg? <b>And</b> they <b>did not resolve</b> this dilemma. <b>And</b> yet, it appears as though <b>the Master,</b> Rav Shemen, has <b>resolved</b> the dilemma, because you implied that the mixture is kosher if there are a total of sixty-one eggs including the non-kosher egg.
The Gemara continues: It <b>was stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥelbo says</b> that <b>Rav Huna says:</b> If a non-kosher <b>egg</b> becomes mixed <b>with</b> kosher eggs, if there are <b>sixty</b> kosher eggs in addition to <b>that</b> non-kosher egg, the entire mixture is <b>forbidden.</b> But if there are <b>sixty-one</b> kosher eggs in addition to <b>that</b> one non-kosher egg, the mixture is <b>permitted.</b>
§ There was <b>a certain</b> person <b>who came before Rabban Gamliel bar Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi with a half-olive-bulk of non-kosher food that had been mixed with a larger amount of kosher food. Rabban Gamliel <b>said to him:</b> A similar case came before my <b>father,</b> and even though he <b>did not measure</b> the kosher food as being sixty times the volume of the non-kosher food, he nevertheless permitted the mixture due to the fact that there was <b>forty-seven</b> times as much kosher food as non-kosher food. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>I will</b> permit the mixture because I <b>measure</b> that the kosher food is <b>forty-five</b> times the volume of the non-kosher food.
Similarly there was <b>a certain</b> person <b>who came before Rabbi Shimon bar Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi with a mixture of kosher and non-kosher food. Rabbi Shimon <b>said to him:</b> A similar case came before my <b>father,</b> and even though he <b>did not measure</b> the kosher food as being sixty times the volume of the non-kosher food, he nevertheless permitted the mixture due to the fact that there was <b>forty-five</b> times as much kosher food as non-kosher food. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>I will</b> permit the mixture because I <b>measure</b> that the kosher food is <b>forty-three</b> times the volume of the non-kosher food.
There was <b>a certain</b> man <b>who came before Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> with a mixture of kosher and non-kosher food. Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>said to him: Is there</b> even <b>thirty</b> times the volume of permitted food as forbidden food? Clearly, the mixture is forbidden.
The Gemara seeks to clarify: This indicates that <b>the reason</b> that he prohibited the mixture is <b>that there was not thirty</b> times as much kosher food as non-kosher food. <b>But</b> it may then be inferred that if <b>there is thirty</b> times as much kosher food as non-kosher food, one may <b>assess,</b> i.e., permit, the mixture. And this contradicts the <i>halakha</i> that non-kosher food is nullified only in a mixture containing sixty times as much kosher food as non-kosher food. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya did not make this statement to set a halakhic principle, but merely as <b>an exaggeration.</b> There was not even thirty times the volume of kosher food, so it was obvious that the mixture was forbidden.
§ <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says in the name of bar Kappara: All</b> the <b>forbidden</b> foods <b>in the Torah</b> are nullified when they are mixed <b>with</b> kosher food that is <b>sixty</b> times their volume. <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said before</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: <b>My teacher, you say this</b> citing Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, who said that bar Kappara said it. But <b>this is what Rav Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says in the name of bar Kappara: All</b> the <b>forbidden</b> foods <b>in the Torah</b> are nullified when they are mixed <b>with</b> kosher food that is <b>one hundred</b> times their volume.
The Gemara adds: <b>And both of them learned</b> their principles of nullification <b>only from</b> the term: <b>“Cooked foreleg,” as it is written</b> with regard to the nazirite’s ram: <b>“And the priest shall take the cooked foreleg</b> of the ram” (Numbers 6:19). <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“Cooked,”</b>

Daf 98b

and the term <b>“cooked”</b> indicates that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to a foreleg that is <b>whole. Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai</b> disagrees and <b>says:</b> The term <b>“cooked”</b> indicates that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to a foreleg <b>that is cooked with the</b> entire <b>ram.</b>
The Gemara clarifies their dispute: <b>Everyone</b> agrees that <b>one cooks</b> the foreleg <b>with the</b> rest of the <b>ram.</b> But one <b>Sage holds</b> that one first <b>cuts</b> the foreleg off the animal <b>and then cooks it</b> along with the rest of the animal. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai, <b>holds</b> that one first <b>cooks</b> the entire ram <b>and then cuts</b> off the foreleg.
<b>And if you wish, say that everyone</b> agrees that one first <b>cuts</b> off the foreleg <b>and then cooks it. But</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai, <b>holds</b> that one <b>cooks</b> the foreleg <b>with</b> the rest of <b>the ram, and</b> one <b>Sage holds</b> that he <b>cooks</b> the foreleg <b>in another pot,</b> separate from the rest of the ram.
The foreleg of the nazirite’s ram is permitted to be eaten only by a priest, whereas the rest of the ram is eaten by the nazirite even if he is not a priest. Consequently, <b>according to the first formulation, all agree</b> that the principle of nullification may be derived from here, since all agree that the foreleg is cooked together with the rest of the ram, and yet it does not cause the rest of the ram to be forbidden to a non-priest. <b>According to the latter formulation,</b> the principle of nullification may be derived from here <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai,</b> who says that the foreleg is cooked together with the rest of the ram. But according to the latter formulation the first <i>tanna</i> holds that the foreleg is not cooked with the rest of the ram, in which case the principle of nullification cannot be derived from here.
The Gemara now returns to the dispute about whether non-kosher food is nullified in sixty or one hundred times its volume of kosher food, and explains how each opinion is derived from the <i>halakha</i> of the foreleg of the nazirite’s ram. <b>The one who said</b> that non-kosher food is nullified <b>in sixty</b> times its volume of kosher food <b>holds</b> that <b>we assess</b> the ratio of <b>meat and bones</b> of the foreleg <b>to</b> the <b>meat and bones</b> of the rest of the ram, <b>and this is</b> a ratio of one to <b>sixty. The one who said</b> that non-kosher food is nullified <b>in one hundred</b> times its volume of kosher food <b>holds</b> that <b>we assess</b> only the volume of the <b>meat</b> of the foreleg <b>to</b> the <b>meat</b> of the rest of the ram, <b>and this is</b> a ratio of one <b>to one hundred.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And do we derive</b> the principles of nullification <b>from</b> the case of the nazirite’s ram? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the nazirite’s ram, which absorbs the flavor of the foreleg with which it was cooked: <b>This is</b> a case of <b>permitted</b> meat <b>that comes from the category</b> of <b>forbidden</b> food, i.e., it is permitted despite the fact that it was cooked with forbidden food. The Gemara infers: <b>What</b> does the expression: <b>This is,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> serve <b>to exclude?</b> Does it <b>not</b> serve <b>to exclude all</b> the other <b>forbidden</b> foods <b>that are in the Torah?</b> This indicates that only the cooked foreleg of the nazirite’s ram is nullified in sixty or one hundred times its volume of permitted food, but other prohibited foods are not subject to the principle of nullification.
The Gemara answers that <b>Abaye said:</b> This emphasis <b>is necessary only according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said</b> that in general, <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type is not nullified.</b> Therefore the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that here,</b> the flavor imparted by the foreleg to the rest of the nazirite’s ram is <b>nullified.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>Let</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>learn from this</b> case that all forbidden food can be nullified when it is mixed with permitted food of its own type. The Gemara explains: <b>The Merciful One revealed</b> in the Torah: <b>“And he shall take of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat</b> and put it upon the corners of the altar round about” (Leviticus 16:18). <b>Both of</b> these two bloods <b>are</b> mixed <b>with each other, and</b> although a bull has more blood than a goat has, the verse makes reference to the blood of the goat, indicating that it maintains its own identity and is <b>not nullified.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to Rabbi Yehuda, <b>what did you see that</b> caused <b>you</b> to <b>derive</b> a principle <b>from that</b> verse with regard to the blood of the bull and the blood of the goat? <b>Derive</b> a principle <b>from this</b> verse about the foreleg of the nazirite’s ram. The Gemara answers: The case of the nazirite’s ram <b>is a novelty,</b> because even when nullification does apply one may not nullify a forbidden food <i>ab initio</i>, whereas here one is supposed to cook the foreleg together with the rest of the ram; <b>and we do not learn</b> principles <b>from a novelty.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> if Rabbi Yehuda does not consider the case of the nazirite’s ram a viable precedent for general halakhic principles, then <b>let him also not learn</b> from that case that when forbidden food is mixed with permitted food of a different type, it is nullified <b>in</b> either <b>one hundred or sixty</b> times its own volume. As discussed above, the two opinions in this regard are each based on the case of the nazirite’s ram.
The Gemara explains: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>we learn</b> that forbidden food is nullified in sixty or one hundred times its volume of permitted food as <b>a leniency? We learn it</b> only as <b>a stringency, as</b> if it were not for this derivation, we would say that <b>by Torah law</b> forbidden food <b>is nullified in</b> a mixture in which there is a simple <b>majority</b> of permitted food.
<b>Rava stated</b> an alternative explanation of the term: This is, which appears in the <i>baraita</i> with regard to the nazirite’s ram: This limitation <b>is necessary only for</b> the principle that the halakhic status of the <b>flavor</b> of forbidden food is <b>like</b> that of its <b>substance.</b> If the flavor of <b>sacrificial</b> food is absorbed into another food, it renders that food <b>forbidden,</b> i.e., it is not nullified. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that here,</b> in the case of the nazirite’s ram, the rest of the ram is <b>permitted</b> even to non-priests.

Daf 99a

The Gemara objects: <b>Let</b> us <b>learn from</b> the case of the nazirite’s ram that the flavor of sacrificial food can be nullified. The Gemara explains: <b>The Merciful One revealed</b> in the Torah <b>with regard to the sin offering: “Whatever shall touch its flesh shall be holy”</b> (Leviticus 6:20). This teaches that the halakhic status of any food that touches and absorbs flavor from a sin offering <b>becomes like it, so</b> that <b>if</b> the sin offering <b>is disqualified,</b> this food <b>shall</b> also <b>be disqualified, and if</b> the sin offering is <b>valid,</b> this food may be <b>eaten in accordance with the stringencies</b> that apply to a sin offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> to indicate <b>that we learn</b> the principle of nullification concerning sacrificial food <b>from that</b> verse of the sin offering? <b>Derive it</b> instead <b>from this</b> verse concerning the foreleg of the nazirite’s ram. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> case of the nazirite’s ram <b>is a novelty, and we do not learn</b> principles <b>from a novelty.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> if the case of the nazirite’s ram is not a viable precedent for general halakhic principles, then <b>one should also not learn</b> from that case that when forbidden food is mixed with permitted food of a different type, it is nullified in either <b>one hundred or sixty</b> times its own volume. As discussed above, the two opinions in this regard are both based on the case of the nazirite’s ram. The Gemara responds: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>we learn</b> that forbidden food is nullified in sixty or one hundred times its volume of permitted food as <b>a leniency? We learn it</b> only as <b>a stringency, as</b> if it were not for this derivation, one would say that <b>by Torah law</b> forbidden food <b>is nullified in</b> a mixture in which there is a simple <b>majority</b> of permitted food.
<b>Ravina said</b> an alternative explanation of the term: This is, that appears in the <i>baraita</i> with regard to the nazirite’s ram. This limitation <b>is necessary only for the place</b> where the foreleg is <b>cut</b> from the body of the ram, <b>as</b> it was <b>said</b> that in a case where permitted and forbidden foods were attached and one cut the forbidden section from the permitted section, <b>the place of the cut</b> on the permitted part <b>is generally forbidden. But here,</b> in the case of the nazirite’s ram, <b>it is permitted.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to discussing the statement of Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak (98a) that forbidden food is nullified in a mixture only if there is one hundred times its volume of permitted food. <b>Rav Dimi sat and said this <i>halakha</i>.</b>
<b>Abaye said to him: And</b> is it true that <b>all the forbidden</b> foods <b>in the Torah</b> that are mixed with permitted foods are nullified only <b>in</b> a mixture containing <b>one hundred</b> times their volume of permitted food? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Orla</i> 2:6): <b>Why did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that with regard to <b>anyone who leavens</b> non-sacred food with a leavening agent that is <i>teruma</i> <b>or flavors</b> it with spices of <i>teruma</i> <b>or mixes</b> <i>teruma</i> into non-sacred food, thereby making the food forbidden for non-priests, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>to be stringent</b> if he mixed one <b>type</b> of food that is <i>teruma</i> with non-sacred food of the same <b>type.</b> But the <i>halakha</i> is <b>to be lenient and to be stringent</b> if he mixed one <b>type</b> of <i>teruma</i> with non-sacred food of <b>a different type.</b>
<b>And it is taught in the latter clause,</b> i.e., in the following mishna (<i>Orla</i> 2:7): When it is stated that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>to be lenient and to be stringent</b> if he mixed one <b>type</b> of <i>teruma</i> with non-sacred food <b>not</b> of <b>its type, how</b> is this accomplished? For example, in a case of <b>split beans</b> of <i>teruma</i> that were cooked <b>with</b> non-sacred <b>lentils, if there are</b> enough split beans relative to the lentils to <b>impart flavor</b> to the lentils, then regardless of <b>whether there are</b> enough lentils <b>to neutralize</b> the split beans <b>in one hundred and one</b> times their volume, i.e., the volume of the lentils is one hundred and one times the volume of the split beans, or <b>whether there are not</b> enough lentils <b>to neutralize</b> the split beans <b>in one hundred and one</b> times their volume, the entire mixture is <b>forbidden</b> to a non-priest.
Conversely, if <b>there are not</b> enough split beans of <i>teruma</i> to <b>impart flavor</b> to the lentils, then regardless of <b>whether there are</b> enough lentils <b>to neutralize</b> the split beans <b>in one hundred and one</b> times their volume, or <b>whether there are not</b> enough lentils <b>to neutralize</b> the split beans <b>in one hundred and one</b> times their volume, the mixture is <b>permitted</b> even to a non-priest.
Abaye commented: When the mishna says that <b>there are not</b> enough lentils <b>to neutralize</b> the split beans <b>in one hundred and one</b> times their volume, and nevertheless if the split beans did not impart flavor to the lentils, the mixture is permitted, <b>in what</b> amount of lentils are the split beans nullified? Is it <b>not</b> that the split beans are permitted because they are mixed <b>with sixty</b> times their volume of non-sacred lentils? This contradicts the opinion of Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak.

Daf 99b

Rav Dimi answered Abaye: <b>No,</b> the mishna means that although there is not one hundred and one times as much non-sacred food as <i>teruma</i>, the <i>teruma</i> is nullified because there is <b>one hundred</b> times its volume of non-sacred food.
Abaye responded: <b>But since the first clause</b> states that it is nullified <b>in one hundred</b> times its volume, it must <b>be</b> that <b>the latter clause</b> is referring to a case where there is <b>sixty</b> times its volume. <b>As</b> the mishna (<i>Orla</i> 2:6) <b>teaches in the first clause:</b> When it is stated that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>to be stringent</b> if one <b>type</b> of <i>teruma</i> is mixed with non-sacred food of <b>its type, how</b> is this accomplished? For example, in a case of <b>leaven of</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>wheat that fell into dough</b> made of non-sacred <b>wheat, and there is enough</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>to cause</b> the non-sacred wheat <b>to become leavened, whether there is</b> enough non-sacred wheat <b>to neutralize</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>in one hundred and one</b> times its volume, or <b>whether there is not</b> enough non-sacred wheat <b>to neutralize</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>in one hundred and one</b> times its volume, the entire dough <b>is forbidden</b> to a non-priest.
But if <b>there is not</b> enough non-sacred wheat <b>to neutralize</b> the <i>teruma</i> <b>in one hundred and one</b> times its volume, then <b>whether there is</b> enough <i>teruma</i> <b>to cause</b> the non-sacred wheat <b>to become leavened</b> or <b>whether there is not</b> enough <i>teruma</i> <b>to cause</b> the non-sacred wheat <b>to become leavened,</b> the entire dough <b>is forbidden</b> to a non-priest. Would you suggest that both <b>the first clause and the latter clause</b> are stating that the <i>teruma</i> is nullified <b>in one hundred</b> times its volume?
Rav Dimi answered: <b>No. The first clause</b> is referring to a case where the <i>teruma</i> is mixed <b>with one hundred and one</b> times its volume of non-sacred food, <b>and the latter clause</b> is referring to a case where the <i>teruma</i> is mixed <b>with one hundred</b> times its volume of non-sacred food.
Abaye asked Rav Dimi: If so, <b>when</b> the mishna states that if <b>there is</b> enough <i>teruma</i> <b>to cause</b> the non-sacred wheat <b>to become leavened</b> the entire mixture is forbidden to non-priests, why is that the case? If leaven is mixed <b>with one hundred and one</b> times its volume of non-sacred wheat it will have no leavening effect, so <b>why is it not nullified?</b> Rav Dimi did not have an answer and <b>was silent.</b>
Abaye <b>said to him: Perhaps leaven is different, because its leavening</b> properties are <b>potent,</b> and there are some forms of leaven that can have an effect on such a large quantity of dough. Rav Dimi <b>said to him: You reminded me</b> of <b>a matter that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: Not all the measures are equal, because the measure</b> required in order to nullify non-kosher fish <b>brine</b> is <b>close to two hundred</b> times its volume. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 10:8): <b>The brine</b> of <b>a non-kosher fish is forbidden. Rabbi Yehuda says: A quarter-</b><i>log</i> of non-kosher fish brine renders kosher food forbidden even if it is mixed <b>with two <i>se’a</i></b> of permitted food, which is one hundred ninety-two times as much as a quarter-<i>log</i>.
The Gemara asks: How can Rabbi Yehuda say that fish brine is nullified at all? <b>Doesn’t Rabbi Yehuda say</b> that <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type is not nullified?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Brine is different because it is merely sweat,</b> i.e., it does not have the halakhic status of the fish itself.
§ The mishna (96b) teaches: <b>How does one measure</b> whether there is enough sciatic nerve to impart flavor to the meat of the entire thigh? One relates to it as though the sciatic nerve were meat and the thigh were a turnip. If the meat would impart flavor to the turnip when they were cooked together, then the entire thigh is forbidden. The Gemara states that <b>Rav Huna says:</b> The mishna means that it is measured <b>like meat</b> cooked in a pot <b>with turnip heads.</b> The Gemara notes that <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says:</b> Sciatic <b>nerves do not impart flavor</b> at all.
There was <b>a certain</b> man <b>who came before Rabbi Ḥanina</b> to ask about the status of a thigh of an animal that was cooked with its sciatic nerve, and <b>Rabbi Yehuda bar Zevina was sitting at the gate. When</b> the man <b>left,</b> Rabbi Yehuda bar Zevina <b>said to him: What did</b> Rabbi Ḥanina <b>say to you?</b> The man <b>said to him: He permitted me</b> to eat the thigh.
Rabbi Yehuda bar Zevina <b>said to him: Bring</b> the animal <b>before him again;</b> perhaps he did not fully understand the question. When the man returned to Rabbi Ḥanina, Rabbi Ḥanina <b>said: Who is this</b> person <b>who is bothering me? Go and say to the</b> individual <b>who is sitting at the gate,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yehuda bar Zevina: Sciatic <b>nerves do not impart flavor.</b> Consequently, he can remove the sciatic nerve and the rest of the meat is permitted.
<b>When</b> people <b>would come before Rabbi Ami</b> to ask about the <i>halakha</i> of a thigh that was cooked with the sciatic nerve inside, he would <b>send them before Rabbi Yitzḥak ben Ḥalov, who</b> would <b>rule</b> leniently <b>about</b> this issue and say that is was <b>permitted, in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi.</b> Rabbi Ami <b>himself did not hold accordingly,</b> but he did not wish to rule stringently for others. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that sciatic <b>nerves do not impart flavor</b> at all.
§ The mishna states (96b): With regard to <b>a sciatic nerve that was cooked</b> with other sinews, when one identifies the sciatic nerve and removes it, the other sinews are forbidden if the sciatic nerve was large enough to impart flavor. And if he does not identify it, all the sinews are forbidden because each one could be the sciatic nerve. The Gemara challenges: <b>Let</b> the sciatic nerve <b>be nullified by</b> a simple <b>majority.</b>

Daf 100a

The Gemara answers that the sciatic nerve is a distinct <b>entity,</b> and therefore it <b>is different</b> in that it is not subject to nullification.
§ The mishna states: <b>And similarly,</b> in the case of <b>a piece of an animal carcass</b> or a piece of non-kosher fish that was cooked with similar pieces of kosher meat or fish, when one identifies the forbidden piece and removes it, the rest of the meat or fish is forbidden only if the forbidden piece was large enough to impart flavor to the entire mixture. And if he does not identify and remove the forbidden piece, all the pieces are forbidden, due to the possibility that each piece one selects might be the forbidden piece. The Gemara challenges: Even if the piece of an animal carcass was not removed, <b>let</b> it <b>be nullified by</b> a simple <b>majority,</b> as the majority of the pieces are kosher.
The Gemara clarifies its challenge. <b>This</b> ruling <b>works out well according to the one who said</b> that <b>we learned: Any</b> item <b>whose manner is to be counted,</b> i.e., that is sometimes sold by unit rather than by weight or volume, is considered significant and therefore is not subject to nullification. <b>But according to the one who said</b> that <b>we learned:</b> It is only an item <b>whose manner is</b> exclusively <b>to be counted,</b> i.e., that is always sold by unit, that is considered significant, and is therefore not subject to nullification, <b>what can be said?</b> Since pieces of meat or fish are not always sold by unit, they should be subject to nullification. The Gemara answers: <b>A piece</b> of meat or fish <b>is different, since it is suitable to give honor with it</b> by placing it <b>before guests.</b> Therefore, due to its significance it is not subject to nullification.
The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> it was <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach both the <i>halakha</i> that the sciatic nerve is not nullified and the <i>halakha</i> that a piece of non-kosher meat or fish is not nullified, <b>as if</b> the mishna had <b>taught us</b> only the case of a sciatic <b>nerve,</b> one might think that it is not nullified <b>because it is</b> a distinct <b>entity, but</b> in the case of <b>a piece</b> of non-kosher meat, <b>say</b> it is <b>not</b> significant, and it is subject to nullification.
<b>And if</b> the mishna had <b>taught us</b> the <i>halakha</i> only in the case of <b>a piece</b> of non-kosher meat or fish, one might think that it is not nullified <b>since it is suitable to give honor with it</b> by placing it <b>before the guests. But</b> in the case of a sciatic <b>nerve, say</b> it is <b>not</b> significant, and it is subject to nullification. Therefore it was <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach both cases.
§ <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana taught: A piece</b> of meat <b>of an unslaughtered carcass or of a non-kosher</b> species of <b>fish</b> that fell into a pot of kosher food <b>does not render</b> the contents of the pot <b>forbidden unless it imparts flavor to the broth and to the deposits</b> of food remaining in the pot <b>and to the</b> other <b>pieces</b> of food in the pot.
<b>Rav</b> disagreed with Rabba bar bar Ḥana and <b>appointed a disseminator</b> to stand <b>before him</b> and teach his statement to a wider audience, <b>and</b> he <b>taught: Once</b> the non-kosher meat or fish <b>has imparted flavor to</b> another <b>piece</b> in the pot, that second <b>piece itself becomes non-kosher. And</b> this second piece <b>renders all the pieces</b> of meat or fish in the pot <b>forbidden, because they are</b> of the same <b>type;</b> therefore, nullification does not apply.
<b>Rav Safra said to Abaye: Now, in accordance with whose</b> opinion did <b>Rav say his statement?</b> It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who says</b> that <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type is not nullified.</b> But if so, <b>why</b> does Rav state <b>specifically that</b> the non-kosher meat renders all the pieces forbidden only <b>when it</b> has <b>imparted flavor</b> to another piece? <b>Even if it did not impart flavor</b> to another piece it should render all the contents of the pot forbidden. Abaye <b>said to him: Here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where he</b> cooked the non-kosher piece with one kosher piece and <b>first removed</b> the non-kosher piece before adding the other pieces. Consequently, the remaining pieces are forbidden only if the non-kosher piece imparted flavor to the piece it was cooked with.
<b>Rava said</b> an alternate answer to Rav Safra’s challenge of Rav’s statement:

Daf 100b

<b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that it is referring to a case where <b>he did not first remove</b> the piece of non-kosher meat or fish. Nevertheless, this <b>is</b> a case of a mixture of one <b>type</b> of food <b>with</b> its <b>own type</b> of food <b>and</b> with <b>something else,</b> i.e., the spices and broth in the pot.
<b>And</b> in <b>any</b> case of <b>a type</b> of forbidden food mixed with <b>its own type</b> of food <b>and</b> with <b>something else, disregard</b> the food that is <b>its own type, as though it is not</b> present in the mixture, <b>and</b> if the amount of permitted food <b>that is not its own type is</b> sixty times <b>greater than</b> the forbidden food, the permitted food <b>nullifies it.</b> Rav’s ruling applies to a case where the forbidden piece of meat or fish imparts flavor to another piece before the spices and broth are added, and there is a total volume sixty times greater than the original non-kosher piece. Consequently, even if the amount of spices and broth is eventually sixty times greater than the original non-kosher piece of meat or fish, the entire mixture is forbidden, as the spices and broth are not sixty times greater than the two pieces of meat or fish which are now non-kosher.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve <b>applies to a kosher</b> animal <b>and does not apply to a non-kosher</b> animal. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It applies <b>even to a non-kosher</b> animal. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> in explanation: <b>Wasn’t the sciatic nerve forbidden for the children of Jacob,</b> as it is written: “Therefore the children of Israel eat not the sciatic nerve” (Genesis 32:33), <b>yet</b> the meat of <b>a non-kosher animal was still permitted to them?</b> Since the sciatic nerve of non-kosher animals became forbidden at that time, it remains forbidden now. The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: The prohibition <b>was stated in Sinai, but</b> it <b>was written in its place,</b> in the battle of Jacob and the angel despite the fact that the prohibition did not take effect then.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Yehuda hold</b> that <b>a prohibition takes effect where</b> another <b>prohibition</b> already exists? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>the carcass of a non-kosher bird renders</b> the <b>garments</b> of one who swallows it <b>ritually impure</b> when it is <b>in the throat,</b> similar to the carcass of a kosher bird.
Therefore <b>the verse states</b> concerning the impurity of carcasses of birds: <b>“A carcass, or that which is torn of animals, he shall not eat to defile himself with it”</b> (Leviticus 22:8). The verse indicates that only <b>those</b> birds <b>that are forbidden</b> specifically <b>due to</b> the prohibition: <b>You shall not eat</b> of <b>a carcass,</b> i.e., kosher birds that died without ritual slaughter, cause impurity in this manner. This serves to <b>exclude</b> any bird <b>that is not forbidden due to</b> the prohibition: <b>You shall not eat</b> of <b>a carcass,</b> but <b>rather due to</b> the prohibition: <b>You shall not eat a non-kosher</b> bird. This indicates that according to Rabbi Yehuda, the prohibition of eating a carcass does not take effect with regard to a non-kosher bird, because it is already subject to a different prohibition.
The Gemara continues with its question: <b>And if you would say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda <b>holds</b> that sciatic <b>nerves do not impart flavor,</b> i.e., they do not have flavor and therefore are not classified as food, <b>and even with regard to a non-kosher</b> animal it is prohibited to eat the sciatic nerve because the general <b>prohibition</b> of eating <b>a sciatic nerve applies,</b> whereas the <b>prohibition</b> of eating <b>non-kosher</b> animals <b>does not</b> apply because the sciatic nerve is not considered food, this is untenable.
The Gemara explains: <b>And does Rabbi Yehuda hold</b> that sciatic <b>nerves do not impart flavor? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who eats the sciatic nerve of a non-kosher animal, Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes, one for eating the sciatic nerve and one for eating the meat of a non-kosher animal, <b>and Rabbi Shimon exempts</b> him entirely from lashes. This indicates that Rabbi Yehuda holds that the sciatic nerve does have flavor.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>holds</b> that sciatic <b>nerves do impart flavor, and he</b> also <b>holds</b> that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve <b>applies to</b> the sciatic nerve of an animal <b>fetus.</b> Consequently, although Rabbi Yehuda holds that a prohibition does not take effect where another already exists, one who eats the sciatic nerve of a non-kosher animal is flogged twice, <b>because the prohibition of</b> eating a sciatic <b>nerve and the prohibition of</b> eating meat from <b>a non-kosher</b> animal <b>come</b> into effect <b>at the same time.</b>
The Gemara challenges this answer: <b>And can you say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda holds that the prohibition of eating a sciatic nerve <b>applies to</b> the sciatic nerve of <b>a fetus? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (89b): The prohibition <b>applies to</b> a late-term <b>fetus</b> in the womb. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: It does not apply to a fetus, and</b> similarly the <b>fat</b> of a fetus <b>is permitted?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>This statement,</b> that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve does not apply to a fetus, is <b>with regard to a kosher</b> species of animal, <b>because the Merciful One stated</b> in the Torah: “And <b>every</b> animal that divides the hoof, and has the hoof wholly cloven in two, and chews the cud, <b>among the animals [<i>babehema</i>],</b> that <b>you may eat”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:6). The term <i>babehema</i> may also be translated as: Inside the animals, indicating that anything inside a kosher animal when it is slaughtered is permitted for consumption, including all parts of a fetus. <b>But with regard to a non-kosher</b> species of animal the prohibition <b>applies.</b>
The Gemara challenges the assertion that the prohibitions of eating the sciatic nerve and of eating non-kosher meat take effect at the same time. <b>And can you say</b> that <b>they both come</b> into effect <b>at the same time? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Nazir</i> 49b): <b>A nazirite shaves for</b> having become impure from <b>these</b> following sources of <b>ritual impurity: For</b> having become impure with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse; and for</b> impurity imparted by <b>an olive-bulk of a corpse.</b>
<b>And</b> this poses <b>a difficulty for us:</b> If a nazirite <b>shaves for</b> becoming impure from <b>an olive-bulk of a corpse,</b> is it <b>not</b> obvious that <b>all the more so</b> he must shave <b>for</b> becoming impure from <b>an entire corpse? And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It <b>is necessary only with regard to a miscarried fetus whose limbs have not</b> yet <b>become joined to</b> its <b>sinews.</b> Although the fetus does not yet contain an olive-bulk of flesh, since it is a complete entity, it transmits impurity to anything under the same roof. <b>Evidently,</b> the limbs of the body are formed before the nerves and sinews, and therefore the <b>prohibition of</b> eating <b>non-kosher</b> meat takes effect <b>prior</b> to the prohibition of the sciatic nerve.
The Gemara answers: <b>Even though the prohibition</b> of eating <b>non-kosher</b> meat takes effect <b>prior</b> to the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve, the <b>prohibition of</b> the sciatic <b>nerve</b> also <b>comes and takes effect upon</b> a non-kosher animal <b>because</b> this <b>prohibition applies to descendants of Noah,</b> i.e., to gentiles. Since the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve adds an additional stringency that did not exist with regard to non-kosher meat, it takes effect even though there was an already existing prohibition.
According to this answer, the language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches: Rabbi Yehuda said: Wasn’t the sciatic nerve forbidden for the children of Jacob,</b> as it is written: “Therefore the children of Israel eat not the sciatic nerve” (Genesis 32:33), <b>yet</b> the meat of <b>a non-kosher animal was still permitted to them?</b> This indicates that the basis of Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion is the fact that the sciatic nerve was forbidden to the children of Jacob, who had the status of descendants of Noah.
§ The Gemara returns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> cited above. With regard to <b>one who eats the sciatic nerve of a non-kosher animal, Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes: One for eating the sciatic nerve and one for eating the meat of a non-kosher animal;

Daf 101a

<b>and Rabbi Shimon exempts</b> him entirely.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> according to <b>Rabbi Shimon, whichever way you</b> look at it, it is difficult. <b>If a prohibition takes effect where</b> another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, <b>let</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>deem</b> one <b>liable</b> for eating non-kosher meat and <b>also due to</b> the prohibition of eating the sciatic <b>nerve.</b> Conversely, <b>if a prohibition does not take effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, <b>let</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>deem</b> one <b>liable due to the</b> prohibition of eating meat from <b>a non-kosher</b> species, <b>which preceded</b> the prohibition of the sciatic nerve. <b>And if</b> Rabbi Shimon holds that sciatic <b>nerves do not impart flavor,</b> and therefore the prohibition of eating non-kosher meat does not apply, <b>let</b> him <b>deem</b> one <b>liable due to</b> the prohibition of eating the sciatic <b>nerve.</b>
<b>Rava said</b> in response: <b>Actually</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>holds</b> that sciatic <b>nerves do not impart flavor,</b> and therefore they are not subject to the prohibition of eating non-kosher meat. <b>And</b> the reason the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerves does not apply to non-kosher animals is that <b>it is different there, because the verse states: “Therefore the children of Israel eat not the sciatic nerve”</b> (Genesis 32:33). This teaches that the prohibition applies only to a species <b>whose</b> sciatic <b>nerve is forbidden but whose meat is permitted,</b> and <b>excludes this</b> case of a non-kosher animal, <b>whose</b> sciatic <b>nerve</b> would be <b>forbidden and whose meat</b> would also be <b>forbidden.</b>
§ Having discussed the status of the sciatic nerve of a non-kosher animal, the Gemara addresses the status of the sciatic nerve of a kosher animal that did not undergo a proper ritual slaughter. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>one who eats the sciatic nerve of an unslaughtered carcass, Rabbi Meir deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes, <b>and the Rabbis say: He is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes.
<b>And the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Meir</b> in a case <b>where one eats the sciatic nerve of a burnt offering or of an ox that is stoned that he is liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes. The prohibitions concerning a burnt offering and an ox that is stoned are more severe than that of the sciatic nerve, in that it is forbidden to derive any benefit from them, whereas the sciatic nerve is merely forbidden for consumption. Consequently, these prohibitions take effect even with regard to the sciatic nerve, despite the fact that the sciatic nerve was already forbidden before the animal was consecrated or before it gored a person and became liable to be stoned.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And who is this <i>tanna</i></b> who <b>does not hold that in</b> the case of a more <b>inclusive prohibition,</b> the <b>prohibition takes effect where</b> another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, and consequently, according to his opinion the prohibition of eating an unslaughtered animal, which applies to the entire animal, does not take effect with regard to the sciatic nerve. Yet, <b>he</b> does <b>hold</b> that where the second prohibition is both a more <b>inclusive prohibition</b> and a more <b>stringent prohibition,</b> it does take effect, and therefore the prohibition of eating a burnt offering or an ox that is stoned does take effect with regard to the sciatic nerve.
<b>Rava said: It is Rabbi Yosei HaGelili</b> who holds that a more inclusive prohibition does not take effect where there is an already existing prohibition. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 106a): One who is <b>ritually impure who ate sacrificial</b> food, <b>whether it was ritually impure sacrificial</b> food <b>or ritually pure sacrificial</b> food, is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> if he did so intentionally and to bring a sliding-scale offering if he did so unwittingly.
<b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: An impure</b> individual <b>who ate pure</b> sacrificial food is <b>liable.</b> But <b>an impure</b> individual <b>who ate impure</b> sacrificial food is <b>exempt, as he merely ate an impure item,</b> and the prohibition of eating sacrificial food while one is impure does not apply to impure sacrificial food.
The Rabbis <b>said to him:</b> According to your logic, this <i>halakha</i> would apply <b>even</b> in a case of <b>an impure</b> individual <b>who ate</b> what had been <b>pure</b> sacrificial food, because <b>once he has touched it, he has</b> thereby <b>rendered it impure.</b> Yet, in such a case, he is certainly liable for eating it. So too, an impure individual who ate impure sacrificial food is liable.
The Gemara asks: <b>The Rabbis are saying well to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili;</b> why does Rabbi Yosei HaGelili disagree? <b>And Rava said</b> in elaboration of the dispute: <b>In</b> a case where the person’s <b>body became impure and</b> then <b>afterward</b> the sacrificial <b>meat became impure, everyone agrees that</b> he is <b>liable</b> if he eats the meat, <b>as the prohibition</b> of eating sacrificial meat while impure, which carries the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>, preceded</b> the prohibition of eating impure sacrificial meat.
<b>They disagree when</b> the <b>meat became impure and</b> then <b>afterward the</b> person’s <b>body became impure. The Rabbis hold</b> that a more <b>inclusive prohibition</b> takes effect even where there is an already existing prohibition. Consequently, <b>since</b> the prohibition for an impure person to eat sacrificial meat is more inclusive than the prohibition for a pure person to eat impure sacrificial meat, <b>as</b> an impure person <b>is liable</b> for eating even <b>pure pieces</b> of sacrificial meat that are permitted to the rest <b>of the world, he is also liable</b> for this prohibition when he eats <b>an impure piece</b> of sacrificial meat.
<b>And Rabbi Yosei HaGelili does not</b> accept the principle that a more <b>inclusive prohibition</b> takes effect even where there is an already existing prohibition, <b>as</b> he holds that <b>we do not say that since</b> it applies to cases that were not yet prohibited it applies to all cases.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> even according to <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> HaGelili, <b>granted that he does not</b> hold that a more <b>inclusive prohibition</b> always takes effect where there is an already existing prohibition. But <b>in</b> the case of an already existing <b>lenient prohibition,</b> a more <b>stringent prohibition should come</b> and <b>take effect on</b> the more <b>lenient prohibition. And what is</b> the more stringent prohibition? The prohibition due to the <b>impurity of</b> a person’s <b>body, as</b> one who eats sacrificial food when he has <b>impurity of the body</b> is liable <b>to <i>karet</i>,</b> whereas a pure person who eats impure sacrificial food is merely liable to be flogged. Consequently, the prohibition of eating sacrificial food while impure should apply even though the meat became impure before the person became impure.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Who</b> can <b>say to us that</b> the prohibition due to the <b>impurity of</b> a person’s <b>body is</b> more <b>stringent? Perhaps</b> the prohibition due to the <b>impurity of the meat is</b> more <b>stringent, as</b> impure meat <b>does not have</b> the possibility of restoring its state of <b>purity</b> via immersion <b>in a ritual bath,</b> whereas a ritually impure person can become pure in this manner.

Daf 101b

The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Yosei HaGelili not</b> hold that a more <b>inclusive prohibition</b> takes effect where there is an already existing prohibition?
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: When <b>Shabbat and Yom Kippur</b> occur on the same day, if one acted <b>unwittingly and performed</b> prohibited <b>labor, from where</b> is it derived <b>that he is liable for this by itself and for that by itself,</b> i.e., he is liable to bring two sin offerings, for having transgressed both Shabbat and Yom Kippur? <b>The verse states:</b> “You shall do no manner of work; <b>it is a Shabbat</b> for the Lord in all your dwellings” (Leviticus 23:3), and another verse states: <b>“It is Yom Kippur”</b> (Leviticus 23:27). The term “it is” in each verse teaches that each of these days is considered independently even when it occurs together with another holy day. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> He <b>is liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin offering because a prohibition does not take effect where another prohibition already exists.
The Gemara answers that on this topic <b>Ravin sent</b> a letter citing a statement <b>in the name of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina: This is the</b> correct <b>presentation of</b> this <b>teaching [<i>hatza’a shel mishna</i>],</b> i.e., the opinions in this <i>baraita</i> are accurate, <b>but</b> one must <b>reverse</b> the attributions of each opinion so that the first opinion is that of Rabbi Akiva and the second opinion is that of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Consequently, Rabbi Yosei HaGelili holds that two prohibitions do not take effect at the same time even if one is more inclusive or stringent than the other.
The Gemara continues to discuss the opinion of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ya’akov bar Giyorei sent</b> a letter citing a statement <b>in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: According to the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, as</b> stated in the <i>baraita</i> once the attributions have been <b>reversed,</b> if one unwittingly performed a forbidden labor on a Yom Kippur that occurred on Shabbat, he is obligated to bring one sin offering. If he acted <b>unwittingly with regard to</b> the fact that it was <b>Shabbat,</b> i.e., he forgot that it was Shabbat, <b>but</b> acted <b>intentionally with regard to Yom Kippur,</b> he is <b>obligated</b> to bring a sin offering. But if he acted <b>intentionally with regard to Shabbat but unwittingly with regard to Yom Kippur,</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from bringing any offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement? <b>Abaye said: Shabbat is established and permanent,</b> i.e., it always occurs on the seventh day of the week, whereas in the case of <b>Yom Kippur,</b> it is <b>the court that establishes it,</b> as the Sages determine the New Moon. Consequently, Shabbat is considered to have preceded Yom Kippur, and the prohibition to perform labor on Yom Kippur does not apply, due to the fact that labor is already prohibited because it is Shabbat. Since one brings a sin offering only due to unwitting transgression, he is obligated to bring a sin offering only if he performed labor without realizing it was Shabbat.
<b>Rava said to</b> Abaye: <b>Ultimately both of them,</b> i.e., Shabbat and Yom Kippur, <b>come</b> into effect <b>at the same time.</b> Since both take effect at the beginning of the calendar day, it cannot be said that Shabbat precedes Yom Kippur. <b>Rather Rava said</b> a different explanation. It <b>was</b> a time of religious <b>persecution, and they sent from there,</b> i.e., from Eretz Yisrael, a directive stating <b>that Yom Kippur of this year</b> will not be observed on its proper day but rather on <b>Shabbat.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan was merely stating that on that particular year one who would unwittingly transgress Yom Kippur would be exempt from bringing a sin offering. <b>And similarly, when Ravin and all those who descended</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>came</b> to Babylonia, <b>they said</b> that the true explanation is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> in explanation: <b>Wasn’t</b> the sciatic nerve forbidden for <b>the children of Jacob,</b> as it is written: “Therefore the children of Israel eat not the sciatic nerve” (Genesis 32:33), yet the meat of a non-kosher animal was still permitted to them? Since the sciatic nerve of non-kosher animals became forbidden at that time, it remains forbidden now.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Yehuda: But is it stated</b> in the verse: <b>Therefore the children of Jacob do not eat</b> the sciatic nerve? <b>Isn’t</b> it true that <b>it is stated only</b> that: “Therefore <b>the children of Israel</b> do not eat the sciatic nerve?” <b>And</b> the Jewish people were <b>not called “the children of Israel” until</b> they received the Torah at Mount <b>Sinai. Rather,</b> this terminology indicates that the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve <b>was stated</b> to the Jewish people at Sinai, <b>but was written in its place,</b> after the incident of Jacob wrestling with the angel, to allow the Jewish people <b>to know the reason</b> the sciatic nerve <b>was forbidden to them.</b> Since the prohibition came into effect only at Sinai, there is no proof that it ever applied with regard to non-kosher animals.
<b>Rava raises an objection</b> to this <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And Jacob rose up from Beersheba; <b>and the children of Israel carried Jacob their father,</b> and their little ones, and their wives in the wagons that Pharaoh had sent to carry him” (Genesis 46:5). This occurred before the Torah was given at Sinai, and therefore proves that the title “the children of Israel” was in use before the Torah was given. The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, this occurred <b>after the incident,</b> i.e., after Jacob wrestled with the angel and after the prophetic vision in which God changed Jacob’s name to Israel (Genesis 35:10).
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> In that case, the sciatic nerve <b>should be</b> understood as having become <b>forbidden</b> to them <b>from that time</b> when they were first called the children of Israel. Since this was before the giving of the Torah, this would be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda and not that of the Rabbis.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: Was the Torah given</b> piecemeal, on numerous different <b>occasions?</b> It was given at Sinai. Rather, <b>that time</b> when the title “children of Israel” was first used <b>was not the time</b> when <b>the incident</b> of Jacob wrestling with the angel occurred <b>and</b> also <b>was not the time of the giving of the Torah</b> at Mount Sinai. Therefore, there is no reason to assume that the prohibition took effect at that time.
§ The mishna taught a dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis with regard to the prohibition of eating the sciatic nerve. The Gemara now cites a similar dispute between them with regard to eating a limb from a living animal. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The prohibition of eating <b>a limb from a living animal applies</b> whether the limb comes from <b>a domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, or a bird,</b> and <b>whether</b> it is from <b>a non-kosher</b> species <b>or</b> from <b>a kosher</b> species; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Elazar. But the Rabbis say:</b> The prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal <b>applies only to</b> a limb from <b>a kosher</b> species.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And both of them,</b> i.e., the Rabbis as well as Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Elazar, <b>derived</b> their opinions <b>from one verse: “Only be steadfast in not eating the blood, for the blood is the life;</b>

Daf 102a

and <b>you shall not eat the life with the flesh”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:23). <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Elazar hold</b> that with regard to <b>any</b> animal <b>whose blood you are commanded</b> not to eat, <b>you are commanded with regard to its limbs,</b> i.e., you are prohibited from eating its limbs that were severed while it was still alive. Consequently, with regard to <b>these non-kosher</b> species <b>also, since you are commanded</b> not to eat <b>their blood, you are commanded with regard to their limbs.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that the verse indicates: <b>“And you shall not eat the life with the flesh”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:23), but <b>rather</b> you shall eat <b>the flesh alone,</b> i.e., when the animal is no longer alive. Consequently, with regard to <b>any</b> animal <b>whose flesh is permitted</b> when it is slaughtered, <b>you are commanded with regard to its limbs,</b> i.e., you are prohibited from eating its limbs that were severed while it was still alive. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>any</b> animal <b>whose flesh is not permitted</b> when it is slaughtered, <b>you are not commanded with regard to its limbs,</b> i.e., the prohibition of eating limbs that were severed while it was still alive does not apply.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that a prohibition takes effect upon an already existing, less stringent prohibition, <b>why does he</b> need to derive this from <b>a verse? Let the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a limb</b> from a living animal <b>come and take effect on the prohibition</b> of eating meat from <b>a non-kosher</b> animal, as it is more stringent <b>since its prohibition applies</b> also <b>to descendants of Noah,</b> i.e., gentiles.
The Gemara responds: <b>Yes,</b> that <b>is indeed so.</b> Rabbi Yehuda does not need to derive this <i>halakha</i> from a verse, <b>and the verse was necessary</b> only <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> who holds that a prohibition does not take effect where there is an already existing prohibition, even if the second prohibition is more stringent.
<b>This</b> fact that it is Rabbi Elazar who derives this <i>halakha</i> from the verse, as opposed to Rabbi Yehuda, <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The prohibition of eating <b>a limb from a living</b> animal <b>applies with regard to</b> a limb from <b>a domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, or a bird,</b> and <b>whether</b> it is from <b>a non-kosher</b> species <b>or a kosher</b> species, <b>as it is stated: “Only be steadfast in not eating the blood,</b> for the blood is the life; and you shall not eat the life with the flesh” (Deuteronomy 12:23).
This verse indicates that with regard to <b>any</b> species <b>whose blood you are commanded</b> not to eat, <b>you are commanded with regard to its limbs,</b> i.e., you are prohibited from eating its limbs that were severed while it was still alive. <b>And any</b> species <b>about whose blood you are not commanded,</b> i.e., with regard to which the prohibition of eating blood does not apply, <b>you are not commanded with regard to their limbs.</b> Since the prohibition of eating blood applies even with regard to non-kosher species, the prohibition of eating limbs severed from a living animal also applies; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar.</b>
