<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal <b>applies only to kosher</b> species, <b>as it is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“And you shall not eat the life with the flesh”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:23), but <b>rather</b> you shall eat <b>the flesh alone,</b> i.e., when the animal is no longer alive. Consequently, with regard to <b>any</b> animal <b>whose flesh is permitted</b> when it is slaughtered, <b>you are commanded with regard to its limbs,</b> i.e., you are prohibited from eating its limbs that were severed while it was still alive. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>any</b> animal <b>whose flesh is not permitted</b> when it is slaughtered, <b>you are not commanded with regard to its limbs,</b> i.e., the prohibition of eating limbs that were severed while it was still alive does not apply.
<b>Rabbi Meir says</b> that the prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal <b>applies only with regard to a kosher</b> species <b>of domesticated animal,</b> but not with regard to undomesticated animals or fowl, even if they are kosher.
The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the different opinions with regard to the name of one of the Sages cited in the upcoming discussion: <b>Shmuel, Sheila, Shimi.</b>
<b>Rabba bar Shmuel said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Yosef</b> who said the following statement. <b>And some say</b> the attributions as follows: <b>Rabba bar Sheila said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Yosef</b> who said; <b>and some say</b> the attributions as follows: <b>Rabba bar Shimi said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Yosef</b> who said: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir</b> that the prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal applies only with regard to a kosher species of domesticated animal?
It is that the <b>verse states:</b> “Then <b>you shall slaughter of your cattle and of your sheep”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:21). This verse is closely followed by the verse that serves as the source of the prohibition to eat a limb severed from a living animal (Deuteronomy 12:23), indicating that the prohibition applies only to kosher domesticated animals.
<b>Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Eliezer about whether the prohibition of eating a limb severed from a living animal applies with regard to non-kosher species is only <b>with regard to Jews. But with regard to descendants of Noah,</b> i.e., gentiles, <b>everyone agrees</b> that they are <b>prohibited from</b> eating a limb from a living <b>non-kosher</b> species of animal just <b>like</b> they are prohibited from eating a limb from a living <b>kosher</b> species.
The Gemara comments that <b>this is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A descendant of Noah is prohibited</b> from eating <b>a limb from a living</b> animal from <b>non-kosher</b> species just <b>as</b> from <b>kosher</b> species. <b>But a Jew is prohibited</b> from eating a limb from a living animal of <b>kosher</b> species <b>only.</b>
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that the correct wording of the <i>baraita</i> is that a Jew is prohibited from eating a limb from a living <b>kosher</b> species, in singular, <b>and</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who holds that the prohibition is limited to kosher domestic animals. And <b>there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that the correct wording of the <i>baraita</i> is that a Jew is prohibited from eating a limb from living <b>kosher</b> species, in plural, <b>and</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the prohibition also applies to a limb from a living bird or a living undomesticated animal of kosher species.
<b>Rav Sheizvi said: We learn</b> in the mishna <b>as well</b> that a gentile is prohibited from eating a limb from a living being even with regard to non-kosher species (<i>Teharot</i> 1:3): If one <b>ate a limb</b> severed <b>from a living</b> non-kosher bird, <b>he does not incur forty</b> lashes, <b>and slaughter does not purify it,</b> i.e., cause it to become permitted for consumption.
Rav Sheizvi clarifies: <b>With regard to what</b> case does the mishna issue this ruling? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring <b>to a Jew</b> who ate the limb, it is <b>obvious that slaughter does not purify it,</b> because it is a non-kosher species and cannot be made kosher. <b>Rather</b> is it <b>not</b> referring <b>to descendants of Noah</b> and teaching that even after the bird is slaughtered the limb severed while it was alive remains forbidden? <b>By inference,</b> it is clear from the mishna <b>that it is prohibited</b> for a gentile to eat a limb severed from a living being even from a non-kosher species.
<b>Rabbi Mani bar Pattish raises a contradiction</b> between <b>the first clause</b> of that mishna, which states that one does not receive lashes for eating a limb severed from a living non-kosher bird, <b>and the latter clause</b> of the mishna, which states that a limb severed from a living non-kosher bird remains forbidden after the bird is slaughtered. The first clause indicates that the prohibition of eating a limb severed from a living creature applies only to kosher species, while the latter clause indicates that it applies also to non-kosher species. <b>And he answers</b> this contradiction by explaining that <b>the first clause</b> is referring <b>to a Jew and the latter clause</b> is referring <b>to a descendant of Noah.</b>
§ The Gemara continues discussing the prohibition of eating a limb severed from a living creature. <b>Rav says: A limb</b> severed <b>from a living</b> animal <b>requires an olive-bulk</b> in order to render one who eats it liable to receive lashes. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is because the term: <b>Eating, is written with regard to</b> the prohibition of a limb severed from a living animal, and the definition of eating is the consumption of at least one olive-bulk.
<b>Rav Amram raises an objection</b> from the mishna cited above (<i>Teharot</i> 1:3): If one <b>ate a limb</b> severed <b>from a living</b> non-kosher bird, <b>he does not incur the forty</b> lashes, <b>and slaughter does not purify it,</b> i.e., cause it to become permitted. <b>But if it enters your mind</b> that <b>we require an olive-bulk</b> in order for one to receive lashes for eating a limb severed from a living creature, that mishna must be referring to such a case; therefore, it should <b>emerge</b> that he is liable to receive lashes <b>because he ate an olive-bulk</b> of a non-kosher bird.
The Gemara answers: This can be explained <b>as Rav Naḥman said</b> with regard to another issue, that it is referring to a case <b>of</b> eating <b>a small amount of meat</b> together with <b>sinews and bones</b> and the total volume is an olive-bulk. <b>Here also,</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>of</b> eating <b>a small amount of meat</b> together with <b>sinews and bones.</b>
The Gemara raises another challenge to Rav’s statement that one receives lashes for eating a limb severed from a living animal only if he eats an olive-bulk: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof in this regard, <b>as Rav said:</b>

Daf 102b

If one <b>ate a kosher bird alive,</b> one is punished with lashes <b>for any amount,</b> i.e., even if he ate less than an olive-bulk. If the bird <b>was dead</b> and was not ritually slaughtered, one is punished with lashes only if he ate <b>an olive-bulk. And</b> if one ate a whole bird of <b>a non-kosher</b> species, <b>whether</b> he ate it <b>when it was alive or dead,</b> he is punished with lashes <b>for any amount,</b> i.e., even if the bird contained less than an olive-bulk of meat. The Gemara answers: <b>Here also</b> explain that Rav’s statement is referring to a case <b>of</b> eating <b>a small amount of meat</b> along with <b>sinews and bones,</b> and the total volume is an olive-bulk.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another challenge based upon a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to one who <b>took</b> a live <b>bird</b> of a kosher species <b>that did not have</b> a volume of <b>an olive-bulk and ate it, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>exempts</b> him from lashes <b>and Rabbi Elazar bar Rabbi Shimon deems</b> him <b>liable</b> for lashes. <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, said:</b> He should be liable based upon <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: If one <b>is liable</b> to receive lashes <b>for</b> eating <b>a limb of</b> a living animal, <b>all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that one is liable to receive lashes <b>for</b> eating <b>all of it?</b> The <i>baraita</i> concludes: With regard to one who <b>strangled</b> the bird <b>and ate it, everyone agrees</b> that he is liable to receive lashes only if it had the volume <b>of an olive-bulk.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, <b>disagree only with regard to</b> one who ate an entire live bird, <b>as</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that even <b>during its life</b> all creatures <b>stand</b> to be divided <b>into limbs,</b> i.e., they will ultimately be cut into pieces. Consequently, each of its limbs is considered a separate entity, and even if one eats a limb without first separating it from the rest of the body, one violates the prohibition of eating a limb from a living being. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that <b>during its life</b> it <b>does not stand</b> to be divided <b>into limbs.</b> Therefore, one does not violate the prohibition of eating a limb from a living being unless he severs a limb from the body.
But <b>in any event, everyone</b> agrees that <b>we do not require</b> one to eat <b>an olive-bulk</b> of meat in order to be liable for lashes for eating a limb from a living being, which is the basis of the <i>a fortiori</i> inference of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon. <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> in response: Explain that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> one ate <b>a small amount of meat</b> together with <b>sinews and bones,</b> making a total of an olive-bulk.
The Gemara challenges this answer: <b>But is there any</b> bird <b>that does not have an olive-bulk of meat in its whole</b> body, <b>but in one limb it has an olive-bulk</b> of the combination of <b>a small amount of meat</b> together with <b>sinews and bones? Rav Sherevya said: Yes,</b> this is the case <b>with regard to</b> the <b><i>kelanita</i>,</b> a bird that is very small and scrawny.
The Gemara challenges this answer that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a <i>kelanita</i>. <b>Say the latter clause:</b> With regard to one who <b>strangled</b> the bird <b>and ate it, everyone agrees</b> that he is liable to receive lashes only if it had the volume of <b>an olive-bulk. But a <i>kelanita</i> is a non-kosher bird, and Rav says:</b> If one eats a whole <b>non-kosher</b> bird, <b>whether</b> he eats it <b>when it is alive or dead,</b> he is punished with lashes <b>for</b> eating <b>any amount.</b> The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> is not referring to an actual <i>kelanita</i>, but <b>rather</b> to a kosher species of bird <b>similar</b> to <b>a <i>kelanita</i></b> in that it is small and scrawny.
§ The Gemara above cited a dispute between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, with regard to one who eats an entire live kosher bird that is less than an olive-bulk. With regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that an entire bird is not considered to be a limb and is therefore not included in the prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal, <b>Rava said: If you say</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>thought</b> with regard to <b>food is considered thought,</b> i.e., one’s thoughts have halakhic significance in determining a food’s status, then in a case where one <b>thought to eat</b> the bird <b>limb</b> by <b>limb, and</b> instead <b>ate it all</b> at once, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi would hold that he is <b>liable</b> for transgressing the prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>But is there anything</b> with regard to which <b>if another</b> person <b>ate it he would not be liable, but</b> if <b>this</b> person <b>ate it he is liable?</b> Rava <b>said to</b> Abaye: There can be different outcomes for different people who perform the same act, as <b>this</b> individual’s action is judged <b>according to his thought and that</b> individual’s action is judged <b>according to his thought.</b>
<b>And Rava</b> also <b>said: If you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar bar Rabbi Shimon holds</b> that <b>thought</b> with regard to <b>food is considered thought,</b> then in a case where one at first <b>intended to eat</b> the entire bird after it had <b>died, but</b> ultimately he <b>ate it alive,</b> Rabbi Elazar bar Rabbi Shimon would hold that he is <b>exempt</b> from lashes, as according to his thought it does not stand to be divided into limbs while alive.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>But is there anything that if another</b> person <b>ate it he would be liable, but if</b> this person <b>ate it he is exempt?</b> Rava <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>This</b> individual’s action is judged <b>according to his thought and that</b> individual’s action is judged <b>according to his thought.</b>
§ The Gemara discusses the source of the prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: “You shall not eat the life with the flesh”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:23); <b>this</b> is the source for the prohibition of eating <b>a limb from a living</b> animal. And the verse: <b>“And you shall not eat any flesh that is torn in the field”</b> (Exodus 22:30); <b>this</b> is the source for the prohibition of eating <b>flesh</b> severed <b>from the living and flesh</b> severed <b>from a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> even if it is not an entire limb.
<b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: “You shall not eat the life with the flesh”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:23); <b>this</b> is the source for the prohibitions of eating <b>a limb from a living</b> animal <b>and</b> of eating <b>flesh</b> severed <b>from the living.</b> And the verse: <b>“And you shall not eat any flesh that is torn in the field”</b> (Exodus 22:30); <b>this</b> is the source for the prohibition of eating <b>flesh</b> severed <b>from a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the difference between these two opinions. If one <b>ate a limb from a living</b> animal <b>and flesh</b> severed <b>from the living,</b> then <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan he is liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes but <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish he is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes. Conversely, if one <b>ate flesh</b> severed <b>from the living and flesh</b> severed <b>from a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> then <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish he is liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes but <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan he is liable to</b> receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes. If one <b>ate a limb from a living</b> animal <b>and flesh</b> severed <b>from a <i>tereifa</i>, everyone agrees</b> that he is <b>liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> to the claim that everyone agrees that one who eats both a limb from a living animal and flesh severed from a <i>tereifa</i> is liable to receive two sets of lashes, based upon the following statement:

Daf 103a

With regard to one who <b>ate a limb from a living</b> animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> He is <b>liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes, <b>and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: He is liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> this <b>works out well</b> because the prohibitions of eating a limb from a living animal and of eating flesh severed from a <i>tereifa</i> are derived from two different verses. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> it is <b>difficult;</b> why does he hold that the individual receives only one set of lashes?
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. Here</b> it is referring <b>to one animal,</b> but <b>there</b> it is referring <b>to two animals.</b> Rav Yosef clarifies: <b>In</b> a case of <b>two animals,</b> e.g., where one ate a limb from a living animal and flesh severed from a different animal that was a <i>tereifa</i>, everyone agrees that <b>he is liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes. But <b>in</b> a case where he ate from <b>one animal,</b> e.g., he ate a limb severed from a live <i>tereifa</i> animal, Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>disagree.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to</b> the case of <b>one animal, in what</b> case <b>do they disagree? Abaye said:</b> They disagree, <b>for example,</b> in a case where the animal <b>became a <i>tereifa</i> as the majority of it emerged</b> from its mother’s womb. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>an animal,</b> even <b>during its life, stands to</b> be divided into <b>limbs,</b> and therefore each of its limbs is considered a separate entity; <b>and</b> here <b>the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i> and the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a limb</b> from a living animal <b>come</b> into effect <b>at the same time.</b> Consequently, both prohibitions apply.
<b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, <b>holds</b> that <b>during its life an animal does not stand</b> to be divided into <b>limbs.</b> Consequently, although the prohibition of eating a <i>tereifa</i> comes into effect when it is born, the prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal does not take effect until the limb is actually severed from the animal, <b>and</b> at that point <b>the prohibition of a limb</b> from a living animal <b>does not come and take effect upon the</b> already existing <b>prohibition of a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone agrees</b> that <b>during its life an animal does not stand</b> to be divided into <b>limbs, and they disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>the prohibition of a limb</b> from a living animal <b>comes and takes effect upon the</b> already existing <b>prohibition of a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a limb</b> from a living animal, which applies to gentiles as well as to Jews, <b>comes and takes effect upon the</b> already existing <b>prohibition of</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i>. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, <b>holds</b> that <b>the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a limb</b> from a living animal <b>does not come and take effect upon the</b> already existing <b>prohibition of</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
And <b>if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone agrees</b> that <b>an animal,</b> even <b>during its life, stands to</b> be divided into <b>limbs, and</b> the dispute is about a case <b>where</b> the animal <b>became a <i>tereifa</i> afterward,</b> i.e., after it was born, <b>and they disagree</b> with regard to whether <b>the prohibition of a <i>tereifa</i> comes and takes effect upon the</b> already existing <b>prohibition of a limb</b> from a living animal.
One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that the prohibition of eating a <i>tereifa</i> <b>comes and takes effect</b> in addition to the already existing prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, <b>holds</b> that the prohibition of eating a <i>tereifa</i> <b>does not come and take effect</b> in addition to the already existing prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal.
<b>Rava says</b> an alternative explanation: This is referring to a case <b>where he severed a limb from</b> the animal <b>and</b> thereby <b>rendered</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>during its life, an animal does not stand to</b> be divided into <b>limbs.</b> Consequently, <b>the prohibition of a limb</b> from a living animal <b>and the prohibition of a <i>tereifa</i> come</b> into effect <b>at the same time.</b>
<b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, <b>holds</b> that even <b>during its life, an animal stands to</b> be divided into <b>limbs,</b> and therefore the prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal takes effect when the animal is born. Consequently, <b>the prohibition of a <i>tereifa</i> does not come and take effect upon the</b> already existing <b>prohibition of a limb</b> from a living animal.
§ <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one <b>ate</b> forbidden <b>fat from a living</b> animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> he is <b>liable</b> to receive <b>two</b> sets of lashes. <b>Rabbi Ami said to him: But let the Master say</b> that he is liable to <b>three</b> sets of lashes, <b>because I say</b> that the correct version of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement is that he is liable to <b>three</b> sets of lashes. It <b>was also stated: Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one <b>ate</b> forbidden <b>fat from a living</b> animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> he is <b>liable</b> to <b>three</b> sets of lashes.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba and Rabbi Ami <b>disagree?</b> They disagree in a case <b>where</b> the animal <b>became a <i>tereifa</i> as the majority of it emerged</b> from its mother’s womb; <b>the one who said</b> that he is liable to <b>three</b> sets of lashes <b>holds</b> that even <b>during its life an animal stands to</b> be divided into <b>limbs,</b> and each of its limbs is considered as a separate entity, <b>so that the prohibition of</b> eating forbidden <b>fat, the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a limb</b> from a living animal, <b>and the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i> come</b> into effect <b>at the same time.</b>
<b>And the one who said</b> that he is liable to <b>two</b> sets of lashes <b>holds</b> that <b>during its life, an animal does not stand to</b> be divided into <b>limbs,</b> i.e., its limbs are not considered separate entities while the animal is alive. Consequently, <b>the prohibition of</b> eating forbidden <b>fat and the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> animal <b>apply,</b> as they came into effect at the same time, when the animal was born. By contrast, <b>the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a limb</b> from a living animal <b>does not come and take effect,</b> due to the fact that other prohibitions already apply.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone agrees</b> that <b>during its life an animal does not stand to</b> be divided into <b>limbs,</b> and each of its limbs is not considered as a separate entity. <b>But they disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a limb</b> from a living animal <b>comes and takes effect upon the</b> already existing <b>prohibition of eating</b> forbidden <b>fat and the</b> already existing <b>prohibition of</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Ami, <b>holds</b> that it does <b>come and take effect, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, <b>holds</b> that <b>it does not come and take effect.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead <b>that everyone agrees</b> that <b>during its life an animal stands to</b> be divided into <b>limbs, and</b> it is a case <b>where</b> the animal <b>became a <i>tereifa</i> afterward,</b> i.e., after it was born; <b>and they disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i> comes and takes effect upon the</b> already existing <b>prohibition of</b> eating <b>a limb</b> from a living animal.
One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Ami, <b>holds</b> that it does <b>come and take effect, just as is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with</b> forbidden <b>fat. As the Master said</b> that in the verse: “And the fat of a carcass, and the fat of a <i>tereifa</i> may be used for any other service; but you shall in no way eat of it” (Leviticus 7:24), <b>the Torah said: Let the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a carcass come and take effect upon the prohibition of</b> eating forbidden <b>fat,</b> despite the fact that the prohibition of forbidden fat came into effect first. <b>And</b> similarly, the word “<i>tereifa</i>” teaches: <b>Let the prohibition of</b> eating <b>a <i>tereifa</i> come and take effect upon the prohibition of</b> eating forbidden <b>fat.</b> Consequently, one who eats forbidden fat from a <i>tereifa</i> is liable to receive two sets of lashes. Rabbi Ami holds that just as the prohibition of eating a <i>tereifa</i> takes effect in addition to the prohibition of eating forbidden fat, it also takes effect in addition to the prohibition of eating a limb from a living animal.
<b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, holds <b>that it is</b> only the prohibition of eating forbidden <b>fat for which he is liable</b> in addition to being liable for the prohibition of eating a <i>tereifa</i>. The prohibition of eating a <i>tereifa</i> takes effect in addition to the prohibition of eating forbidden fat <b>because</b> with regard to the latter, there are <b>permitted</b> circumstances that serve as exceptions

Daf 103b

<b>to its general prohibition,</b> as the fat of an undomesticated animal is permitted. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a limb</b> from a living animal, <b>where</b> there are <b>no permitted</b> circumstances to <b>its general prohibition,</b> the prohibition of consuming a <i>tereifa</i> does <b>not</b> take effect.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the prohibition against eating a limb from a living animal. <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish inquired of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If one took from a living animal a limb that was an olive-bulk and <b>divided it</b> into two pieces <b>when it was outside</b> his mouth and ate each piece separately, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> He is <b>exempt.</b>
Reish Lakish then asked Rabbi Yoḥanan: If he placed an olive-bulk of a limb from a living animal <b>inside</b> his mouth and then divided it and swallowed the two parts separately, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> He is <b>liable</b> to receive lashes.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia he <b>said</b> an alternative version of this discussion. If one took from a living animal a limb that was an olive-bulk and <b>divided it</b> into two pieces <b>when it was outside</b> his mouth, and he then ate each piece separately, he is <b>exempt.</b> If he divided the limb into two parts <b>inside</b> his mouth, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that he is <b>liable, and Reish Lakish says</b> that he is <b>exempt.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> he is <b>liable</b> because his <b>throat derives pleasure from an olive-bulk</b> of a limb from a living animal. <b>And Reish Lakish says</b> that he is <b>exempt</b> because in order to be liable <b>we require</b> an act of <b>eating</b> that contains the requisite amount, i.e., an olive-bulk, when it enters <b>his stomach, and</b> in this case <b>there is not</b> a full olive-bulk that enters his stomach at one time.
The Gemara asks: According to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan it is clear how one can be liable for eating an olive-bulk of a limb from a living animal. <b>But according to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, how can you find</b> a case <b>where</b> one will <b>be liable</b> for eating a limb from a living animal, since the food is generally broken up before he swallows it? <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> One would be liable <b>in</b> a case where he eats <b>a small bone</b> that contains an olive-bulk of meat, bone and sinew all together, and that he can swallow whole.
As quoted above, Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish agree that if one divides a limb from a living animal before placing it in his mouth, he is not liable for eating it. The Gemara adds: <b>But Rabbi Elazar says: Even</b> if one <b>divided</b> the limb <b>outside</b> his mouth he is <b>liable.</b> This is because the fact that the two pieces are <b>lacking</b> in <b>proximity</b> to each other as they are placed in one’s mouth is <b>not comparable to lacking an action,</b> i.e., it is not comparable to a case where he ate only half an olive-bulk. Since he ate an entire olive-bulk, he is liable.
§ The Gemara cites another dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish pertaining to the measure of an olive-bulk with regard to prohibitions involving eating. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says:</b> The <b>olive-bulk</b> of <b>which</b> the Sages <b>spoke</b> with regard to prohibitions involving eating is measured by the food one actually swallows, <b>aside from</b> the food that remains stuck <b>between the teeth. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that it includes <b>even</b> the food that remains stuck <b>between the teeth.</b>
In explanation of this dispute, <b>Rav Pappa says:</b> With regard to food <b>that</b> remains stuck <b>between</b> the <b>teeth, everyone agrees</b> that it is not included in measuring an olive-bulk that would render one liable to receive lashes. <b>When they disagree</b> it is with regard to food that remains <b>on the palate,</b> which one tastes but does not swallow. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that since <b>his throat derives pleasure from an olive-bulk,</b> i.e., he tastes the full olive-bulk, he is liable. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Reish Lakish, <b>holds</b> that in order to be liable, <b>we require</b> an act of <b>eating</b> that contains the requisite amount, i.e., an olive-bulk, when it enters <b>his stomach.</b>
§ The Gemara quotes another related ruling of Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>Rabbi Asi says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one <b>ate half an olive-bulk</b> of a forbidden food <b>and vomited it, and then ate another half an olive-bulk,</b> he is <b>liable. What is the reason?</b> It is <b>because his throat derives pleasure from an olive-bulk</b> of the forbidden food, even though the full olive-bulk did not actually enter his stomach.
<b>Rabbi Elazar raised a dilemma before Rabbi Asi:</b> If one <b>ate half an olive-bulk</b> of forbidden food <b>and vomited it, and then ate it</b> again, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the dilemma he is raising? If</b> it is about whether the half-olive-bulk that he ate and vomited up <b>is</b> considered to have been <b>digested,</b> in which case it is no longer considered food, <b>or whether it is not</b> considered to have been <b>digested, let him raise the dilemma</b> with regard to an entire <b>olive-bulk.</b> If one eats an entire olive-bulk and vomits it and then eats it again, if the food is considered not to have been digested the first time, he is liable to be flogged twice.
<b>Rather,</b> his dilemma must be about <b>whether we follow the throat or whether we follow the stomach</b> in measuring how much forbidden food one has swallowed. That being the case, <b>let him resolve</b> the dilemma <b>from</b> that <b>which Rabbi Asi</b> said that Rabbi Yoḥanan said, which indicates that we follow the throat.
The Gemara explains that Rabbi Elazar knew the answer to his question, but <b>Rabbi Asi forgot the statement</b> that he had learned from Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>and Rabbi Elazar came to remind him</b> of what he had known previously. <b>And this is what</b> Rabbi Elazar was <b>saying to him: Why do I</b> need the case where he swallows <b>another half an olive-bulk? Let the Master</b> teach this ruling <b>in</b> a case where he swallows <b>the same</b> half-olive-bulk he had swallowed previously and vomited, <b>as two</b> principles <b>can be derived from</b> the ruling in <b>that</b> case: <b>We</b> can <b>learn from it that</b> the food <b>was not</b> considered to have been <b>digested</b> the first time he swallowed it, <b>and we</b> can <b>learn from it that</b> since <b>his throat derives pleasure from</b> a full <b>olive-bulk,</b> he is liable.
Rabbi Asi <b>was silent and did not say anything.</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>said to him: Wonder of the generation, did you not say</b> this case <b>many times before Rabbi Yoḥanan, and he said to you:</b> This person is liable <b>because his throat derives pleasure from</b> a full <b>olive-bulk?</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> It is <b>prohibited to cook any meat</b> of domesticated and undomesticated animals and birds <b>in milk, except for the meat of fish and grasshoppers,</b> whose halakhic status is not that of meat. <b>And</b> likewise, the Sages issued a decree that it is <b>prohibited to place</b> any meat together <b>with</b> milk products, e.g., <b>cheese, on</b> one <b>table.</b> The reason for this prohibition is that one might come to eat them after they absorb substances from each other. This prohibition applies to all types of meat, <b>except for the meat of fish and grasshoppers.</b>

Daf 104a

And <b>one who takes a vow</b> that <b>meat</b> is prohibited to him is <b>permitted to</b> eat <b>the meat of fish and grasshoppers.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Since the mishna does not distinguish between the meat of animals and that of birds, it may <b>consequently</b> be inferred that the meat of <b>birds</b> cooked in milk is <b>prohibited by Torah law,</b> just like the meat of animals. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this ruling? It is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, as, if</b> you say it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, didn’t he say</b> that the prohibition of the meat of <b>undomesticated animals and birds</b> cooked in milk <b>is not by Torah law?</b>
The Gemara continues: But <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>One who takes a vow</b> that <b>meat</b> is forbidden to him is <b>permitted to</b> eat <b>the meat of fish and grasshoppers.</b> It may <b>consequently</b> be inferred that it is <b>prohibited</b> for him to eat <b>birds.</b> If so, here <b>we arrive at</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who said: Anything about which an agent</b> sent to purchase a given item <b>would inquire,</b> being unsure whether it qualifies as that type of item, <b>is</b> considered <b>its type.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Nedarim</i> 54a): <b>One who takes a vow</b> that <b>vegetables</b> are forbidden to him <b>is permitted to</b> eat <b>gourds,</b> as people do not typically consider gourds a type of vegetable, <b>but Rabbi Akiva deems</b> it <b>prohibited</b> for him to eat gourds. The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Akiva: But</b> it is a common occurrence that <b>a person says to his agent: Purchase vegetables for us, and</b> the agent, after failing to find vegetables, returns and <b>says: I found only gourds.</b> This indicates that gourds are not considered vegetables.
Rabbi Akiva <b>said to them: The matter is so,</b> and that proves that my opinion is correct. <b>Does</b> the agent return and <b>say: I found only legumes? Rather,</b> it is evident <b>that gourds are included in</b> the category of <b>vegetables,</b> although they differ from other vegetables, and therefore, the agent explains that he found only gourds, and asks whether he should purchase them. <b>But legumes are not included in</b> the category of <b>vegetables,</b> and that is why an agent would not even ask about them. Therefore, Rabbi Akiva should also hold that one who takes a vow that meat is forbidden to him is prohibited from eating birds. And if so, <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Akiva, <b>and the latter clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> That is not difficult. The entire mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and he formulates</b> the mishna <b>according to</b> the opinions of different <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> In the latter clause, <b>with regard to vows, he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> whereas in the first clause, <b>with regard to meat</b> cooked <b>in milk, he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> a different explanation: <b>The entire</b> mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> as indicated by the latter clause, concerning vows. <b>And</b> as for the first part of the mishna, <b>this</b> is what it <b>is saying:</b> It is <b>prohibited to cook any meat</b> cooked <b>in milk, some</b> types <b>of</b> meat <b>by Torah law,</b> i.e., that of domesticated animals, <b>and some</b> types <b>of</b> meat <b>by rabbinic law,</b> i.e., that of undomesticated animals and birds. This prohibition applies to all types of meat <b>except for the meat of fish and grasshoppers, which are</b> not prohibited, <b>neither by Torah law nor by rabbinic law.</b>
§ The mishna teaches further: <b>And</b> it is <b>prohibited to place</b> any meat with cheese on one table. <b>Rav Yosef said: Conclude from</b> this clause that eating the <b>meat of birds</b> cooked <b>in milk</b> is prohibited <b>by Torah law. As, if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> that the prohibition against eating it applies merely <b>by rabbinic law,</b> this would be because the <b>consumption</b> of the meat of birds cooked in milk is <b>itself</b> a rabbinic <b>decree,</b> lest one come to eat the meat of an animal in milk. <b>And</b> would <b>we decree</b> against <b>placing</b> birds together with cheese on one table <b>due to</b> the possibility of <b>consumption,</b> which is itself a decree? The Sages do not enact one decree to prevent the violation of another decree.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do you say that we do not issue</b> one rabbinic <b>decree to</b> prevent violation of another rabbinic <b>decree?</b> The source is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥalla</i> 4:8): <b><i>Ḥalla</i> from outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, which must be eaten by a priest,

Daf 104b

<b>may be eaten with a non-priest</b> present <b>at the</b> same <b>table.</b> The Sages did not issue a decree prohibiting this lest the non-priest partake of the <i>ḥalla</i>, as the separation of <i>ḥalla</i> outside of Eretz Yisrael is itself a rabbinic decree. This proves that the Sages do not issue one decree to prevent violation of another decree. <b>And</b> similarly, <i>ḥalla</i> from outside of Eretz Yisrael <b>may be given to any priest that</b> one <b>wishes,</b> even an uneducated priest who would not guard its state of ritual purity. This is in contrast to <i>ḥalla</i> from Eretz Yisrael, which may be given only to priests who observe the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Granted,</b> your inference would be valid <b>if</b> the mishna in tractate <i>Ḥalla</i> had <b>taught us</b> this with regard to <b><i>ḥalla</i> from outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael that had been brought <b>into Eretz</b> Yisrael. <b>As</b> in that case, <b>there</b> could be reason <b>to decree</b> against eating it while a non-priest is at the same table, despite the fact that the non-priest eating it is prohibited only by rabbinic law, <b>due to</b> the concern that one might come to eat <b><i>ḥalla</i> from Eretz</b> Yisrael, which is prohibited to the non-priest <b>by Torah law,</b> at the same table as a non-priest; <b>and</b> yet <b>we do not decree</b> against this practice. If so, <b>there</b> would be grounds <b>to learn from</b> this mishna that the Sages do not issue one decree to prevent violation of another decree.
<b>But</b> the mishna actually teaches this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <i>ḥalla</i> from <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael that remains there. It therefore proves nothing about compound decrees, as it can be claimed that the practice <b>is</b> permitted only <b>because there is no</b> reason <b>to decree.</b> Since by Torah law the obligation of <i>ḥalla</i> does not apply outside of Eretz Yisrael, there is no chance that such behavior will lead to transgression of Torah law. <b>But here, if you permit one to place</b> the meat of <b>birds and cheese</b> on the same table, some might <b>come to place</b> the <b>meat</b> of domesticated animals <b>and cheese</b> on a single table <b>and</b> to <b>eat</b> this <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk,</b> thereby transgressing a prohibition <b>by Torah law.</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet objects to</b> the premise of Rav Yosef’s inference: Even if one were to posit that the meat of birds in milk is prohibited by Torah law, <b>ultimately</b> this is still a decree issued due to another decree, as <b>it is</b> a case of <b>cold</b> food <b>in</b> another <b>cold</b> food, consumption of which is itself prohibited by rabbinic law. <b>Abaye said:</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree, lest one place</b> the meat with cheese <b>in a boiling stewpot,</b> which is a manner of cooking and therefore prohibited by Torah law.
The Gemara counters: <b>Ultimately,</b> even a stewpot is only <b>a secondary vessel,</b> i.e., not the vessel that was on the fire, <b>and</b> as a rule, <b>a secondary vessel does not cook. Rather,</b> one must say that it is a rabbinic <b>decree, lest one place</b> the meat with cheese <b>in a stewpot</b> that is <b>a primary</b> vessel, i.e., that was on the fire. This is certainly cooking meat in milk, and it is prohibited by Torah law.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The</b> meat of <b>birds may be placed with cheese on</b> one <b>table but</b> may <b>not be eaten</b> together with it; this is <b>the statement of Beit Shammai. And Beit Hillel say:</b> It may <b>neither be placed</b> on one table <b>nor be eaten</b> with cheese. <b>Rabbi Yosei said: This is</b> one <b>of the</b> disputes involving <b>leniencies of Beit Shammai and stringencies of Beit Hillel.</b>
The mishna elaborates: <b>With regard to which table</b> are these <i>halakhot</i> <b>stated?</b> It is <b>with regard to a table upon which one eats. But on a table upon which one prepares the cooked food, one</b> may <b>place this</b> meat <b>alongside that</b> cheese or vice versa, <b>and</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> that perhaps they will be mixed and one will come to eat them together.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara challenges: The opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei is</b> identical to that of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>. And if you would say</b> that there <b>is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to the permissibility of <b>eating itself, as the first <i>tanna</i> says</b> that Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <b>disagree with regard to placing</b> meat of birds with cheese on one table, which indicates that <b>with regard to eating they do not disagree, and Rabbi Yosei said</b> in response <b>to</b> this that they also disagree with regard to the permissibility of <b>eating</b> meat of birds in milk, and this is <b>itself</b> one <b>of the</b> disputes involving <b>leniencies of Beit Shammai and stringencies of Beit Hillel,</b> one can refute this claim.
The refutation is as follows: <b>Isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says</b> that <b>six matters</b> are included <b>as the</b> disputes involving <b>leniencies of Beit Shammai and stringencies of Beit Hillel, and this is one of them:</b> The meat of <b>birds is placed with cheese on</b> one <b>table, but</b> it may <b>not be eaten</b> together with it; this is <b>the statement of Beit Shammai. And Beit Hillel say:</b> It may <b>neither be placed</b> on one table <b>nor be eaten</b> with cheese. Evidently, Rabbi Yosei agrees that even according to Beit Shammai the meat of birds may not be eaten with cheese.
<b>Rather, this</b> is what the mishna <b>teaches us: Who is the first <i>tanna</i>?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> The identification is important, since <b>whoever reports a statement in the name of the one who said it brings redemption to the world. As it is stated</b> with respect to the incident of Bigthan and Teresh: <b>“And Esther reported it to the king in the name of Mordecai”</b> (Esther 2:22), and Mordecai was later rewarded for saving the king’s life, paving the way for the miraculous salvation.
§ The Gemara continues discussing the consumption of poultry cooked in milk. The Sage <b>Agra, the father-in-law of Rabbi Abba, taught:</b> The meat of <b>birds and cheese may be eaten freely</b> [<b><i>apikoren</i></b>], i.e., there is no need to be strict in this matter. The Gemara notes: <b>He,</b> Agra, <b>teaches it and he says it,</b> i.e., explains his statement: The meat of birds and cheese may be eaten <b>without washing</b> one’s <b>hands and without wiping the mouth</b> between the consumption of each.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Mesharshiyya, happened</b> to come <b>to the house of Rav Ashi. They brought him cheese,</b> and <b>he ate</b> it. Next <b>they brought him meat,</b> and <b>he ate</b> it <b>without</b> first <b>washing his hands.</b> The members of Rav Ashi’s household <b>said to him: But didn’t Agra, the father-in-law of Rabbi Abba, teach</b> only that the meat of <b>birds and cheese may be eaten freely?</b> One can infer that with regard to the meat of <b>birds and cheese, yes,</b> one may eat them without washing one’s hands in between, but with regard to the <b>meat</b> of domesticated animals <b>and cheese, no,</b> one may not.
Rav Yitzḥak <b>said to them: This statement</b> of Agra applies only if one eats them <b>at night,</b> as one cannot see whether some of the food of the previous dish still remains on his hands, and he must therefore wash them. <b>But</b> if one eats <b>by day, I</b> can <b>see</b> that no food remains on his hands, and consequently there is no need to wash them.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> Between the consumption of meat and milk one must <b>wipe</b> out his mouth, <b>and Beit Hillel say</b> that he must <b>rinse</b> his mouth. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the word: <b>Wipe [<i>mekane’aḥ</i>], and what</b> is the meaning of the word: <b>Rinse [<i>mediaḥ</i>]?</b>

Daf 105a

<b>If we say</b> that <b>Beit Shammai say</b> that one <b>wipes</b> out his mouth with solid food <b>and does not need</b> to <b>rinse</b> his mouth with water, since they maintain that wiping is more effective than rinsing, <b>and Beit Hillel say</b> that he <b>rinses</b> his mouth in water <b>and does not need</b> to <b>wipe</b> his mouth, as rinsing is more effective, one can respond: <b>But</b> as for <b>that which Rabbi Zeira said: Wiping of</b> the <b>mouth</b> can be performed <b>only with bread, in accordance with whose</b> opinion is it? It is apparently <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai,</b> since Beit Hillel do not require wiping. Yet, it is unlikely that Rabbi Zeira would rule in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai rather than Beit Hillel.
<b>Rather,</b> one must explain the dispute as follows: <b>Beit Shammai say</b> that one <b>wipes</b> his mouth after eating meat <b>and does not need</b> to <b>rinse</b> his mouth as well, <b>and Beit Hillel say</b> that in addition to wiping one must <b>also rinse.</b> This interpretation is difficult as well, since if so, this <b>constitutes</b> one <b>of the</b> disputes between them that involve <b>leniencies of Beit Shammai and stringencies of Beit Hillel, and</b> consequently, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> of tractate <i>Eduyyot</i> <b>teach it alongside</b> the other disputes listed there that involve <b>leniencies of Beit Shammai and stringencies of Beit Hillel.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> one must interpret their statements as follows: <b>Beit Shammai say</b> that one <b>wipes</b> his mouth after eating meat, <b>and the same is true of rinsing,</b> i.e., one must rinse his mouth as well. <b>And Beit Hillel say</b> that one <b>rinses</b> his mouth, <b>and the same is true of wiping.</b> And <b>one Sage said one</b> statement <b>and one Sage said another</b> statement, <b>and they do not disagree.</b>
§ After citing Rabbi Zeira’s statement tangentially, the Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabbi Zeira says: Wiping of the mouth</b> can be performed <b>only with bread.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>And this statement</b> applies only <b>to</b> bread prepared <b>from wheat</b> flour. <b>But with regard to</b> bread prepared <b>from barley</b> flour, one may <b>not</b> use it for wiping, as barley bread crumbles in the mouth and does not wipe thoroughly.
The Gemara adds: <b>And even</b> in the case of bread prepared <b>from wheat</b> flour, <b>we said</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>only with regard to cold</b> bread, <b>but</b> as <b>for warm</b> bread, it is ineffective for wiping even if made of wheat, as it softens and <b>sticks</b> to the palate, and it does not wipe the mouth properly. <b>And</b> furthermore, even if the bread is cold, <b>this statement</b> applies only <b>with regard to soft</b> bread, <b>but</b> one may <b>not</b> wipe <b>with hard</b> bread, as it also does not clean effectively. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is</b> that the use <b>of all items constitutes</b> effective <b>wiping, except for flour, dates, and vegetables.</b>
§ <b>Rav Asi posed a dilemma to Rabbi Yoḥanan: How much</b> time <b>should one wait between</b> eating <b>meat and</b> eating <b>cheese?</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: No</b> time <b>at all.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But doesn’t Rav Ḥisda say:</b> If one <b>ate meat,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for him <b>to eat cheese</b> immediately, but if he ate <b>cheese</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for him <b>to eat meat</b> without delay? <b>Rather,</b> Rav Asi actually asked Rabbi Yoḥanan the following question: <b>How much</b> time <b>should one wait between</b> eating <b>cheese and</b> eating <b>meat?</b> In response to this question, Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: No</b> time <b>at all.</b>
After tangentially citing a statement of Rav Ḥisda, the Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav Ḥisda says:</b> If one <b>ate meat,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for him <b>to eat cheese</b> immediately, as the meat contains fatty substances that stick to one’s mouth and preserve the flavor of meat. But if he ate <b>cheese</b> it is <b>permitted</b> for him <b>to eat meat</b> without delay. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Yosef said to Rav Ḥisda:</b> In the case of <b>meat that is between the teeth, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Are these remnants considered meat to the extent that one may not eat cheese as long as they are in his mouth?
In response, Rav Ḥisda <b>read about him</b> the following verse: <b>“While the meat was yet between their teeth”</b> (Numbers 11:33). This verse indicates that even when the meat is between one’s teeth it is still considered meat, and therefore one may not partake of cheese until that meat has been removed.
<b>Mar Ukva said: I am, with regard to this matter,</b> like <b>vinegar, son of wine, with respect to Father,</b> i.e., my practice is inferior to that of my father. <b>As Father, if he were to eat meat at this time, would not eat cheese until tomorrow at this time. But as for me,</b> only <b>at this meal,</b> during which I ate meat, <b>do I not eat</b> cheese; <b>at a different meal</b> on the same day <b>I</b> will <b>eat</b> cheese.
Similarly, <b>Shmuel said: I am, with regard to this</b> other <b>matter,</b> like <b>vinegar, son of wine, with respect to Father. As Father would patrol his property</b> to examine it <b>twice daily, but I patrol</b> it <b>only once</b> a day. The Gemara notes: In this regard <b>Shmuel</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as Shmuel said: One who patrols his property every day will find an <i>asteira</i></b> coin.
The Gemara relates that <b>Abaye would patrol his property each and every day. One day he encountered his sharecropper carrying a load of wood</b> that the sharecropper intended to take for himself. Abaye <b>said to him: To where</b> are you taking <b>these</b> logs of wood? The sharecropper <b>said to him: To the Master’s house.</b> Abaye, who knew that the sharecropper had intended to take the wood for himself, <b>said to him: The Sages already preempted you</b> when they said that one should patrol his property regularly, and they thereby prevented you from stealing the wood.
The Gemara likewise relates that <b>Rav Asi would patrol his property every day. He said: Where are all these <i>asteira</i></b> coins mentioned <b>by Mar Shmuel?</b> This patrol is not reaping me any benefit. <b>One day he saw</b> a water <b>channel that overflowed,</b> causing water to flood <b>onto his land. He took off his cloak, wrapped it, and placed it inside</b> the pipe to block the flow of water. <b>He</b> then <b>raised</b> his <b>voice,</b> and <b>people came</b> and <b>sealed</b> the hole. He said: <b>I have</b> just <b>found all the <i>asteira</i></b> coins mentioned <b>by Mar Shmuel,</b> as I would have suffered a great loss had I not patrolled my fields.
§ Having mentioned the manner of washing hands during a meal, the Gemara discusses another matter concerning washing hands. <b>Rav Idi bar Avin says</b> that <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashyan says:</b> The <b>first waters,</b> i.e., washing of the hands before eating bread, are <b>a mitzva</b> by rabbinic law, <b>but</b> the <b>final</b> waters, washing of the hands upon conclusion of the meal and before reciting Grace after Meals, are <b>an obligation,</b> a more stringent requirement.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this ruling from a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>first waters and</b> the <b>final</b> waters are <b>an obligation,</b> whereas the <b>middle</b> waters, between courses during the meal, are <b>optional.</b> Apparently, the first waters are also an obligation, not a mitzva. The Gemara responds: Although the first waters are in fact a mitzva, the <i>tanna</i> <b>calls a mitzva an obligation</b> when <b>compared to an optional</b> requirement.
The Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> matter <b>itself.</b> The full text of the <i>baraita</i> is as follows: <b>First waters and final</b> waters are <b>an obligation,</b> whereas <b>middle</b> waters are <b>optional.</b> For <b>first</b> waters, <b>one may wash either</b> by spilling the water <b>into a vessel or onto the ground.</b> But for <b>final</b> waters, <b>one washes only</b> by pouring the water <b>into a vessel. And some say</b> a slightly different version of the <i>baraita</i>: For final waters, <b>one may not wash</b> by pouring the water <b>onto the ground.</b>
The Gemara interjects: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> these two versions? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to pouring the water on thin wood <b>slivers</b> on the ground. According to the first version, which requires that the water be poured into a vessel, one may not use such slivers for this purpose, whereas according to the second version, which merely prohibits pouring the water onto the ground, one may use wood slivers.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: With regard to <b>first waters, one may wash either with hot</b> water <b>or with cold</b> water. But for <b>final</b> waters, <b>one may wash only with cold</b> water, <b>because hot</b> water <b>softens the hands and does not remove the dirt</b> from them. The Gemara analyzes the statement that for <b>first waters one may wash either with hot</b> water <b>or with cold</b> water: <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where the hand does not</b>

Daf 105b

<b>recoil [<i>soledet</i>] from</b> the water’s heat. <b>But</b> if <b>the hand recoils from it, one may not wash with it.</b>
<b>And there are those who teach</b> a version of <b>this</b> statement <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: For <b>final</b> waters, <b>one may wash only with cold</b> water, <b>but</b> one may <b>not</b> wash <b>with hot</b> water. <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai says: They taught</b> that one may not use hot water <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the water is so hot that <b>the hand recoils from it, but if the hand does not recoil from it, one may wash</b> with it. The Gemara comments: One can learn <b>by inference</b> from this version of the statement <b>that</b> in the case of <b>first</b> waters, <b>even if</b> the water is so hot that <b>the hand recoils from it,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> to use it for washing.
§ The <i>baraita</i> states that <b>middle</b> waters are <b>optional. Rav Naḥman says: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> with regard to washing the hands <b>between</b> one <b>cooked dish and</b> another <b>cooked dish</b> served at a meal. <b>But between a cooked dish and cheese</b> there is <b>an obligation</b> to wash one’s hands.
§ The <i>baraita</i> further teaches that final waters are an obligation. <b>Rav Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, says: For what</b> reason did the Sages <b>say that final waters are an obligation?</b> It is <b>because Sodomite salt is</b> sometimes <b>present,</b> a small amount of <b>which blinds the eyes.</b> Since Sodomite salt could remain on one’s hands, one must wash them after eating. <b>Abaye said: And</b> this type of dangerous salt <b>is present</b> in the proportion of <b>a pinch</b> [<b><i>korta</i></b>] <b>in</b> an entire <b><i>kor</i></b>  of regular salt. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> If one <b>measured salt</b> between meals, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Must he wash his hands afterward? <b>He said to him: It is not necessary</b> to say this; he is certainly obligated to do so.
§ <b>Abaye said: At first I would say</b> that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>that one may not wash</b> his hands with <b>final waters over the ground</b> is <b>due to messiness.</b> But the <b>Master,</b> Rabba, <b>said to me</b> that it is <b>because an evil spirit rests upon</b> the water and passersby are liable to be afflicted.
<b>And Abaye</b> also <b>said: At first I would say</b> that the reason for <b>this</b> statement of the Sages <b>that one should not take anything from the table when a person is holding a cup to drink,</b> is <b>lest a mishap occur at the meal,</b> i.e., the one holding the cup might have wanted the item that was taken, and since he is unable to speak he will choke in his anger. But <b>the Master</b> subsequently <b>said to me</b> that it is <b>because it is bad for</b> one’s health, causing <b>a spirit of</b> pain in <b>half</b> his head, i.e., a migraine.
<b>And we said</b> that this practice is prohibited <b>only if one takes</b> an item from the table <b>and does not put</b> it <b>back. But</b> as for <b>taking and putting back, we have no</b> problem <b>with it. And</b> likewise, <b>we said</b> it is prohibited <b>only</b> if one takes the item <b>beyond four cubits</b> of the table. <b>But</b> if one leaves it <b>within four cubits, we have no</b> problem <b>with it. And</b> furthermore, <b>we said</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to <b>an item that is necessary for the meal. But</b> in the case of <b>an item that is not necessary for the meal, we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Mar bar Rav Ashi was particular</b> not to remove any object from the table when someone was holding his cup in hand, <b>even with regard to a mortar [<i>asita</i>] and pestle [<i>bukhna</i>] for spices,</b> like all <b>items that are necessary for the meal.</b>
<b>And Abaye</b> further <b>said: At first I would say</b> that <b>this</b> practice <b>that</b> people <b>collect the crumbs</b> of bread after a meal is <b>due to cleanliness.</b> But <b>the Master</b> subsequently <b>said to me</b> that it is <b>because</b> leaving them <b>is bad for,</b> i.e., it can increase, a person’s vulnerability to <b>poverty.</b>
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain man who was pursued by the ministering angel of poverty, but</b> the angel <b>was unable to</b> impoverish <b>him, as he was exceptionally careful with regard to crumbs. One day</b> that man <b>broke</b> his <b>bread over grass,</b> and some crumbs fell among the blades of grass. The angel <b>said: Now he will certainly fall into my hands,</b> as he cannot collect all the crumbs. <b>After</b> the man <b>ate, he brought a hoe, uprooted the grass,</b> and <b>threw it into the river.</b> He subsequently <b>heard</b> the ministering angel of poverty <b>say: Woe</b> is me, <b>as that man has removed me from my house,</b> i.e., my position of comfort.
<b>And Abaye said: At first I would say</b> that <b>this</b> practice <b>that</b> people <b>do not drink the foam</b> from the top of a beverage is followed <b>because</b> it is <b>repulsive.</b> But <b>the Master said to me</b> that it is followed <b>because it is bad for</b> one’s vulnerability to <b>catarrh.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Drinking it is bad for catarrh,</b> while <b>blowing</b> off the foam from the drink <b>is bad for head</b> pains, and <b>removing it</b> with one’s hand <b>is bad for poverty.</b> If so, <b>what is its remedy?</b> How may one drink? He <b>should sink</b> the foam inside the beverage and then drink it.
The Gemara notes: The treatment <b>for catarrh</b> caused by the foam <b>of wine</b> is <b>beer;</b> the treatment for catarrh caused by the foam <b>of beer</b> is <b>water;</b> and for catarrh caused by the foam <b>of water there is no remedy. And this</b> is in accordance with the adage <b>that people say: Poverty follows the poor.</b> Not only does a pauper have nothing to drink other than water, but there also is no treatment for the disease caused by his beverage.
<b>And Abaye said: At first I would say</b> that the reason for <b>this</b> practice <b>that</b> people <b>do not eat vegetables from a bundle tied by the gardener</b> is <b>because it has the appearance of gluttony,</b> as he does not wait to untie the bundle to eat. But <b>the Master said to me</b> that it is <b>because</b> it <b>is bad for</b> one’s vulnerability to <b>witchcraft.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna were traveling on a boat. A certain matron said to them: Seat me together with you</b> on the boat, but <b>they did not seat her</b> alongside them. <b>She said something,</b> an incantation, and thereby <b>tied the boat</b> to its spot so that it could not move. <b>They</b> too <b>said something and</b> thereby <b>released it.</b> That matron <b>said to them: What can I do to you?</b> Witchcraft has no power over you, <b>as</b> after attending to your bodily functions, <b>you do not wipe yourselves with an earthenware shard, and you do not kill a louse</b> that you find <b>on your garments, and you do not eat vegetables from a bundle tied by the gardener.</b>
<b>And Abaye said: At first I would say</b> as follows: The reason for <b>this</b> practice <b>that</b> people <b>do not eat vegetables that fell on the table</b> is <b>because</b> it is <b>replusive.</b> But <b>the Master said to me</b> that it is <b>because it is bad for halitosis. And Abaye said: At first I would say</b> that the reason for <b>this</b> practice <b>that</b> people <b>do not sit under a gutter</b> is <b>because</b> of the <b>waste water</b> that pours out of it. But <b>the Master said to me</b> that it is <b>because demons are</b> commonly <b>found</b> there.
The Gemara relates: There were <b>certain porters who were carrying a barrel of wine.</b> When <b>they wanted to rest, they placed it under a gutter</b> and the barrel <b>burst. They came before Mar bar Rav Ashi,</b> who <b>brought out horns and</b> had them blown as he <b>excommunicated</b> the demon of that place. The demon <b>came before</b> Mar bar Rav Ashi, and the Sage <b>said to it: Why did you do this?</b> The demon <b>said to him: How</b> else <b>should I act, when</b> these men <b>place</b> a barrel <b>on my ear?</b>
Mar bar Rav Ashi <b>said to it: What are you doing in a place where many</b> people <b>are found? You are the one who deviated</b> from the norm; <b>go</b> and <b>pay</b> them the value of the barrel of wine. The demon <b>said to him: Let the Master now set a time for me,</b> so that I can find the money, <b>and I will pay.</b> Mar bar Rav Ashi <b>set a time for</b> his payment. <b>When</b> that <b>time arrived,</b> the demon <b>delayed</b> in coming to pay. <b>When</b> the demon eventually <b>came,</b> Mar bar Rav Ashi <b>said to it: Why did you not come at</b> the <b>time</b> set for <b>you?</b> The demon <b>said to him:</b> With regard to <b>any item that is tied up, or sealed, or measured, or counted, we have no authority to take it.</b> We are unable to obtain money <b>until we find an ownerless item.</b> For this reason, it took him a long time to find enough money to pay for the barrel.
<b>And Abaye said: At first I would say</b> that <b>this</b> practice <b>that</b> people <b>pour out</b> a little <b>water from the mouth of a pitcher</b> before drinking from it is followed <b>because of twigs</b> it might contain. But <b>the Master said to me</b> that it is followed <b>because there are foul waters</b> in the pitcher.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain son of a demon that was in Rav Pappa’s house</b> as a servant. It <b>went to bring water from the river,</b> and <b>it delayed</b> in returning. <b>When it came,</b> the members of Rav Pappa’s household <b>said to it: Why did you delay? It said to them:</b> I waited <b>until the foul waters passed. In the meantime,</b>

Daf 106a

the demon <b>saw</b> the members of Rav Pappa’s household <b>pouring water from the mouth of the pitcher</b> before drinking from it. The demon <b>said</b> to them: <b>If I had known that you regularly do this, I would not have delayed.</b> I would have brought the water straight from the river, knowing you would pour out the foul waters.
§ <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said:</b> Due to the failure to wash with <b>the first waters,</b> they ultimately <b>fed</b> a Jew <b>pig meat.</b> This case involved a storekeeper who would sell different meat to his Jewish and gentile customers. When a Jew who came to eat with him neglected to wash before eating, the storekeeper assumed he was a gentile and fed him pig meat.
And due to the failure to wash with <b>final</b> waters <b>a woman</b> was ultimately <b>divorced from her husband.</b> In this incident, a host who had stolen his guests’ money had lentils on his mustache from a previous meal because he had not washed his hands and mouth after eating. Realizing he had eaten lentils that day, his victims approached the man’s wife and said that her husband had instructed them to tell her to return their money. They then claimed that the man told them to tell her that he had eaten lentils that day as proof that they were telling the truth. They thereby fooled his wife into thinking he wanted her to give their money back. Out of anger, the host divorced his wife.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said</b> the statement slightly differently: Due to the failure to wash with <b>first</b> waters, they <b>fed</b> a Jew meat from <b>an animal carcass,</b> and the failure to wash with <b>final</b> waters <b>killed a person,</b> as in the second incident the host was so angry with his wife that he killed her. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And your mnemonic</b> to remember which Sage said which version is: <b>Rav Dimi came</b> and <b>divorced her</b> from her husband, i.e., according to his version she was divorced, and <b>Ravin came</b> and <b>killed her,</b> since in his version the husband killed his wife.
<b>Rabbi Abba would teach one of these</b> versions involving first waters <b>and one of them</b> with regard to final waters, and in both cases he taught <b>the more severe</b> version, i.e., he specified the meat of a pig and that the husband killed his wife.
A disagreement <b>was stated</b> with regard to <b>water heated by fire: Ḥizkiyya says</b> that <b>one may not wash</b> his <b>hands with</b> such water, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>one may wash</b> his <b>hands with it. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: I asked Rabban Gamliel, son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, about this <i>halakha</i>, <b>and</b> he was one who would <b>eat</b> only in a state of <b>ritual purity</b> and was therefore careful about washing his hands; <b>and he said to me</b> that <b>all the great men of the Galilee would do so,</b> i.e., wash their hands in heated water.
Likewise, with regard to <b>the hot springs of Tiberias, Ḥizkiyya says</b> that <b>one may not wash</b> his <b>hands with</b> water from them before eating, <b>but</b> if there are forty <i>se’a</i>, the requisite size of a ritual bath, then <b>one may immerse the hands</b> directly <b>in them,</b> and this is effective for the ritual of washing the hands before a meal. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that an impure person <b>may immerse his entire body in</b> such water to become pure, <b>but</b> one may still <b>not</b> use it for the immersion of part of his body, such as <b>his face, hands, and feet,</b> as this immersion is not considered equivalent to washing the hands.
The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> that it has been said that one <b>may immerse his entire body in</b> the hot springs of Tiberias, is it <b>not all the more so</b> permitted for <b>his face, hands, and feet? Rav Pappa said:</b> When the water in the hot springs stands <b>in place, everyone,</b> both Ḥizkiyya and Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>agrees that it is permitted</b> to immerse one’s hands in it. Likewise, <b>everyone agrees that</b> to <b>take from</b> these waters <b>in a vessel</b> and wash one’s hands from it <b>is prohibited. They disagree when one draws</b> the waters <b>through a ditch.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>we decree</b> against the use of <b>ditch</b> water <b>due to</b> the concern that one might come to use water in <b>a vessel, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Ḥizkiyya, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not decree</b> against it.
The Gemara comments: This dispute is <b>like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it was taught: When <b>water that has ceased to be fit for drinking</b> even <b>by an animal</b> is <b>in vessels,</b> it is <b>unfit</b> for washing the hands, but when it is <b>in the ground</b> it is <b>fit</b> for immersion, like a ritual bath. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Even</b> when the water is <b>in the ground,</b> one <b>may immerse his entire body in it, but</b> he may <b>not</b> immerse <b>his face, hands, and feet.</b>
As above, one might ask: <b>Now</b> that one <b>may immerse his entire body in</b> the water, is it <b>not all the more so</b> the case that one may immerse <b>his hands and feet</b> in it? <b>Rather,</b> must it <b>not</b> be referring to a case <b>when one draws</b> the waters <b>through a ditch? And</b> if so, <b>they disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, <b>holds</b> that <b>we decree</b> against the use of <b>ditch</b> water <b>due to</b> concern that one may come to use <b>a vessel, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i> of that <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not decree</b> against it.
§ <b>Rav Idi bar Avin says</b> that <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashiyan says:</b> The obligation of <b>washing hands</b> before eating <b>non-sacred</b> food is <b>due to an ancillary</b> decree on account of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> the portion of produce designated for the priest, which must be consumed in a state of ritual purity. By rabbinic decree, one’s hands are considered impure with second-degree ritual impurity, as they may have touched impure items. Therefore, they render <i>teruma</i> impure. Consequently, priests who partake of <i>teruma</i> are obligated to wash their hands first. The Sages therefore decreed that all must wash their hands even before eating non-sacred food, so that people not become accustomed to eating without washing their hands, which would in turn lead the priests to partake of <i>teruma</i> without washing their hands.
<b>And</b> the obligation is <b>further due to</b> its being <b>a mitzva.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What mitzva</b> does it involve? <b>Abaye says:</b> It is <b>a mitzva to listen to</b> and obey <b>the statements of the Sages,</b> who instituted this washing of the hands. <b>Rava says:</b> It is <b>a mitzva to listen to the statement of Rabbi Elazar ben Arakh, as it is written</b> with regard to a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>]: <b>“And whomever he that has the issue touches, without having rinsed his hands in water,”</b> he contracts ritual impurity (Leviticus 15:11), and <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Arakh says: From here the Sages based washing of the hands</b> upon a verse <b>from the Torah.</b>
<b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: From where</b> is this <b>inferred?</b> How can this verse, which concerns a <i>zav</i>, be interpreted as referring to washing the hands before a meal? Rava explains: <b>As it is written: “Without having rinsed his hands in water.” Consequently,</b> one could infer that if he <b>rinsed</b> his hands the <i>zav</i> becomes <b>ritually pure. But</b> this cannot be correct, as verses elsewhere prove that a <i>zav</i> <b>requires</b> the <b>immersion</b> of his entire body. <b>Rather, this</b> is what the verse <b>is saying: And</b> there is <b>another</b> type of person <b>who,</b> if he <b>has not rinsed</b> his hands in water, is considered like one who is <b>impure.</b> The verse thereby serves as the basis for washing the hands.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> that <b>washing of the hands</b> before eating <b>fruit</b> is mandatory <b>only due to cleanliness.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>They understood from this</b> statement that <b>there is no</b> true <b>obligation</b> to wash the hands before eating fruit, <b>but there is a mitzva</b> to do so. <b>Rava said to them:</b> This practice is <b>not an obligation nor a mitzva, but</b> merely <b>optional. And</b> the Gemara notes that Rava <b>disagrees with Rav Naḥman</b> in this regard, <b>as Rav Naḥman said: One who washes his hands</b> before eating <b>fruit is nothing other than</b> one <b>of the arrogant,</b> i.e., it is actually prohibited to do so.
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: I was standing before Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi</b> when attendants <b>brought a basket of fruit before them, and they ate and did not wash their hands. And they did not give me anything</b> to eat, to enable me to join the <i>zimmun</i>, the quorum required for communal Grace after Meals, <b>and they each recited a blessing</b> after eating, <b>separately.</b> One may <b>learn three</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>from</b> this incident. <b>Learn from it</b> that <b>there is no washing of the hands</b> before <b>fruit. And learn from it</b> that <b>one does not issue a <i>zimmun</i> on fruit,</b> i.e., the <i>halakha</i> that when three people eat together, one leads the Grace after Meals does not apply when they ate fruit. <b>And</b> finally, <b>learn from it</b> that if only <b>two</b> people <b>ate,</b> it is <b>a mitzva</b> for them <b>to separate,</b> i.e., each should recite the blessing after eating for himself.
The Gemara notes: <b>This</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If only <b>two</b> individuals <b>ate,</b> it is <b>a mitzva</b> for them <b>to separate. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said <b>when they were both scribes,</b> i.e., Torah scholars, who know how to recite Grace after Meals properly. <b>But</b> if <b>one</b> of them was <b>a scribe and one</b> was <b>an ignoramus,</b> the <b>scribe recites Grace</b> after Meals <b>and</b> the <b>ignoramus fulfills</b> his obligation by listening to the scribe.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In <b>washing of the hands for</b> consumption of <b>non-sacred</b> food, one must pour the water on the area that extends <b>until the joint</b> of the fingers. In washing hands <b>for</b> consumption of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b>

Daf 106b

he must pour on the area extending <b>until the joint.</b> In <b>sanctifying the hands and feet in the Temple</b> before the service, he must pour the water <b>until</b> another <b>joint,</b> where the palm meets the wrist. <b>And any item that</b> is considered to <b>interpose</b> between one’s skin and the water <b>with regard to immersion of the body</b> in a ritual bath, disqualifying the immersion, likewise <b>interposes with regard to washing the hands for</b> eating <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>and with regard to sanctification of the hands and feet in the Temple.</b>
<b>Rav said</b> this <i>halakha</i> to his students while indicating with his hand the joints to which the <i>baraita</i> is referring: One washes <b>until here,</b> the second joint of the fingers, <b>for non-sacred</b> food, and <b>until there,</b> the third joint, where the fingers join the palm, <b>for <i>teruma</i>. And Shmuel</b> disagreed and <b>said:</b> One washes <b>until here both for</b> eating <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>and for <i>teruma</i>,</b> indicating <b>the more stringent</b> location, the third joint where the fingers join the palm. <b>And Rav Sheshet said: Until here both for</b> the consumption of <b>non-sacred</b> food <b>and for <i>teruma</i>,</b> indicating <b>the more lenient</b> location, the second joint.
<b>Bar Hedya said: I was standing before Rabbi Ami, and he said:</b> One washes <b>until here both for non-sacred</b> food <b>and for <i>teruma</i>,</b> indicating <b>the more stringent</b> location, the third joint. <b>And do not say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami</b> acted this way only <b>because he is a priest</b> and acted stringently to avoid confusing <i>teruma</i> and non-sacred food. This cannot be, <b>as Rabbi Meyasha, son of the son of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, is a Levite, and</b> yet <b>he</b> too <b>said: Until here both for non-sacred</b> food <b>and for <i>teruma</i>,</b> indicating <b>the more stringent</b> location.
§ <b>Rav says: A person may wash both</b> of <b>his hands in the morning and stipulate with regard to them</b> that he may eat on the basis of that washing throughout <b>the entire day,</b> provided he guards his hands from dirt and ritual impurity. It is likewise related that <b>Rabbi Avina said to the inhabitants of</b>

Daf 107a

<b>the valley of Aravot [<i>pakta da’aravot</i>],</b> where there was a shortage of water: People <b>such as you, for whom water is scarce,</b> should <b>wash your hands in the morning and stipulate with regard to them for the entire day. Some say</b> that Rabbi Avina maintains that <b>in exigent circumstances, yes,</b> one should act in this manner, but when one is <b>not in exigent circumstances,</b> he should <b>not</b> do so. <b>And</b> according to this explanation, Rabbi Avina <b>disagrees with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav,</b> who permitted this practice to all. <b>And some say</b> that Rabbi Avina ruled that one may do so <b>even</b> when <b>not in exigent circumstances, and</b> Rabbi Avina’s opinion <b>is</b> identical to that <b>of Rav.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> With regard to <b>this irrigation channel [<i>arita dedalla’ei</i>],</b> into which water is poured from a river using buckets, and which then transports the water to the fields, <b>one may not wash</b> his <b>hands in</b> it.
