The reason is that this water <b>does not come from a person’s force,</b> i.e., it is not poured on the hands by a direct act, as it moves by force of the current in the channel. <b>But if one draws his hands near the bucket</b> itself, in such a manner <b>that</b> the water poured on his hands <b>comes from a person’s force</b> before it begins to flow in the channel, then <b>one may wash</b> his <b>hands with it.</b>
<b>And if the bucket</b> in which the water is drawn from the river <b>is perforated</b> with a hole large enough <b>to enable liquid to enter</b> the vessel when it is placed in the river, the presence of this hole <b>connects</b> the water in the channel to the water in the river, as they touch through that hole. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>one may immerse</b> his <b>hands in</b> that channel as he would in the river itself. Yet the perforated bucket is invalid for the washing of the hands by pouring, since it is no longer considered a vessel. As <b>Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>a vessel that is perforated</b> with a hole large enough <b>to enable liquid to enter, one may not wash</b> his <b>hands with it.</b>
<b>And Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>a vessel that does not have a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> of water <b>in it, one may not wash</b> his <b>hands with it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But doesn’t Rava say:</b> With regard to <b>a vessel that cannot contain a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> of water, <b>one may not wash</b> his <b>hands with it.</b> It may be <b>consequently</b> inferred that as long as the vessel <b>can contain</b> a quarter-<i>log</i>, one may use it <b>even if it does not</b> currently <b>have</b> a quarter-<i>log</i> <b>in it.</b>
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult; this</b> former statement, requiring a quarter-<i>log</i> of actual water, is referring to washing <b>for one</b> person, whereas <b>that</b> latter statement, requiring only that the vessel have a capacity of a quarter-<i>log</i>, is referring to washing <b>for two</b> people. If a vessel originally contained a quarter-<i>log</i> of water, then even if less than that amount remains after one person has washed his hands, a second individual may use the remainder, which is considered fit based on the water’s original volume. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With <b>a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> <b>of water, one may wash the hands of one</b> individual, <b>and even</b> those <b>of two.</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet said to Ameimar: Are you particular about the vessel</b> used for washing hands, that it be wholly intact? Ameimar <b>said to him: Yes.</b> Rav Sheshet further inquired: Are you also particular <b>about the appearance</b> of the water, that it be normal? Ameimar again <b>said to him: Yes.</b> Rav Sheshet further asked: Are you particular <b>about the measure</b> of water, that it be no less than one quarter-<i>log</i>? Ameimar <b>said to him: Yes.</b>
<b>Some say</b> that <b>this</b> is what Ameimar <b>said to him: We are particular about</b> the wholeness of <b>the vessel and about</b> the water’s <b>appearance,</b> but <b>we are not particular about</b> the water’s <b>measure, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With <b>a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> <b>of water one may wash the hands of one</b> individual, <b>and even</b> those <b>of two.</b> The <i>baraita</i> indicates that there is no need for a quarter-<i>log</i> for each individual.
The Gemara notes: <b>And it is not so,</b> i.e., one cannot derive from the <i>baraita</i> that the measure of water is immaterial. <b>It is different there because</b> there the water <b>comes from the remainder of</b> a measure initially sufficient for <b>purity.</b> If there was not initially a quarter-<i>log</i>, the water is unfit for even one person.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Ya’akov from Nehar Pekod prepared a glass vessel that could contain a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> of water for washing his hands. <b>Rav Ashi in Huzal</b> likewise <b>prepared an earthenware vessel that could contain a quarter</b>-<i>log</i>.
<b>And Rava says:</b> If <b>one prepared the stopper of a barrel</b> for use as a vessel by hollowing it out until it contained a quarter-<i>log</i>, <b>one may wash</b> his <b>hands with it,</b> even though it was not originally designated for this function. <b>This</b> ruling <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one prepared the stopper of a barrel</b> for this purpose, <b>one may wash</b> his <b>hands with it.</b> Likewise, with regard to <b>a <i>ḥemet</i> and a <i>kefisha</i>,</b> types of leather wineskins, <b>that one prepared</b> for this purpose, <b>one may wash</b> his <b>hands with them,</b> as they were initially designed to hold liquids. But with regard to <b>a sack and a basket, even if they can contain</b> water, <b>one may not wash</b> his <b>hands with them,</b> as no sack or basket is designed to hold water, and most cannot.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to eating with a cloth [<i>mappa</i>]</b> on one’s hands, rather than washing them to purify them? <b>Are we concerned</b> that <b>perhaps</b> he will <b>touch</b> the food with his hands, <b>or not?</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from a mishna (<i>Sukka</i> 26b): <b>And when they gave Rabbi Tzadok</b> on the festival of <i>Sukkot</i> <b>less than an egg-bulk of food, he took</b> the food <b>in a cloth, and he ate it outside the <i>sukka</i>,</b> as he held one is not obligated to eat food of this amount in a <i>sukka</i>. <b>And he did not recite a blessing after</b> eating <b>it,</b> since less than an egg-bulk does not satisfy the verse: “And you shall eat and be satisfied and bless the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 8:10). <b>What, is it not</b> to be inferred that <b>consequently,</b> if one eats <b>an egg-bulk,</b> it <b>requires washing of the hands,</b> even if one uses a cloth?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps</b> one can conclude from that mishna only that <b>consequently,</b> if one eats <b>an egg-bulk</b> he <b>needs</b> to do so in <b>a <i>sukka</i> and needs</b> to recite <b>a blessing</b> after eating; but he can still use a cloth instead of washing his hands.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from an incident <b>where Shmuel found Rav eating with a cloth</b> rather than washing his hands, and Shmuel <b>said to him:</b>

Daf 107b

<b>Do we act in this manner?</b> Rav <b>said to</b> Shmuel: I did wash my hands, but as <b>I am delicate</b> I do not wish to hold food in my bare hands; therefore I covered them with a cloth.
The Gemara further relates: <b>When Rabbi Zeira left</b> Babylonia for Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi eating</b> bread while covering their hands <b>with worn</b> pieces of <b>wineskins,</b> rather than washing them. Rabbi Zeira <b>said</b> to them: Could <b>two great men such as yourselves err with regard to</b> the incident of <b>Rav and Shmuel</b> related above? After all, Rav <b>said</b> to Shmuel: I am using a cloth because <b>I am delicate;</b> he did wash his hands beforehand.
The Gemara notes: <b>It escaped</b> Rabbi Zeira’s <b>mind that Rav Taḥlifa bar Avimi said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The Sages <b>permitted</b> the consumption of bread while the hands are wrapped with <b>a cloth</b> rather than washed, specifically <b>to</b> priests <b>who partake of <i>teruma</i>,</b> as they are careful not to touch the bread with their hands. <b>But they did not permit</b> the use of <b>a cloth</b> in this manner <b>to</b> non-priests, even those <b>who</b> are particular to <b>eat</b> non-sacred food in a state of <b>ritual purity,</b> as they do not maintain the same level of diligence as priests. <b>And</b> since <b>Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi were priests,</b> it was permitted for them to eat with a cloth.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If one <b>eats by means of</b> another <b>feeding</b> him, without himself touching the food, does he <b>need to wash hands</b> before eating <b>or not?</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from the following incident <b>where Rav Huna bar Seḥora was standing before Rav Hamnuna</b> and serving him. Rav Huna bar Seḥora <b>cut a slice of meat for</b> Rav Hamnuna and placed it in his mouth, <b>and he ate</b> it. Rav Huna bar Seḥora <b>said to</b> Rav Hamnuna: <b>Were you not Rav Hamnuna, I would not feed you</b> in this fashion.
The Gemara infers from this episode: <b>What is the reason</b> that it was permitted for Rav Hamnuna to eat in such a manner? Is it <b>not because he was careful not to touch</b> the food with his hands? This indicates that someone may be fed even without washing his hands. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> one can say <b>that he was vigilant</b> and <b>went ahead and washed his hands at the outset.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from that <b>which Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav said: A person may not place a slice</b> of bread <b>into the mouth of</b> the <b>attendant</b> serving at a meal <b>unless he knows that he has washed his hands. And</b> it was also stated that <b>the attendant recites a blessing over each and every cup</b> of wine presented to him at a meal. This is because he never knows if he will receive another cup, and he cannot intend that his initial blessing apply to a cup he does not know he will receive. <b>But</b> he <b>does not recite a blessing over each and every slice</b> of bread given to him. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that he must <b>recite a blessing over each and every slice</b> he receives.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Granted,</b> the apparent contradiction between the opinions <b>of Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> is <b>not difficult;</b> one can resolve it by saying that <b>this</b> statement of Rav, that the attendant need not recite a blessing for every slice of bread, is referring to a case <b>where there is an important person</b> at the meal. Since the attendant is confident that the important person will ensure the attendant receives enough to eat, his initial blessing applies to each slice he receives. And <b>that</b> statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan is referring to a meal <b>where there is no important person.</b> Since the attendant is not confident that he will receive another slice, he must recite a new blessing whenever he does receive one.
<b>In any case,</b> Rav first <b>says</b> that one should not place a slice into the attendant’s mouth <b>unless he knows that he has washed his hands.</b> This indicates that one who is fed by another must wash his hands. The Gemara responds: The case of <b>an attendant is different, as</b> he <b>is occupied</b> with his duties and may touch the food inadvertently. Therefore, he specifically may not eat without washing his hands.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person</b> who is a guest <b>may not give a slice</b> of bread from the meal in front of him <b>to the attendant</b> serving, <b>whether a cup is in</b> the attendant’s <b>hand or a cup is in the host’s hand, lest a mishap occur at the meal.</b> The host might become angry or distracted by the concern that there will not remain enough food for his guests, and the cup will fall from his hand. If the cup is in the attendant’s hand, he might drop it while accepting food from the guest. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>an attendant who has not washed his hands,</b> it <b>is prohibited to place a slice</b> of bread <b>into his mouth.</b>
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Does one who feeds</b> another <b>need to wash</b> his <b>hands,</b> since his hands are touching the food? <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>he does not need</b> to wash his hands, as he himself is not eating.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to the dilemma from <b>that</b> which <b>the school of Menashe taught</b> that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A woman may rinse one hand in water</b> on Yom Kippur, so that she does not touch food before she has washed her hands in the morning, <b>and give bread to her minor son,</b> without concern about violating the prohibition against bathing on Yom Kippur. <b>They said about Shammai the Elder that he did not want to feed</b> his children <b>with</b> even <b>one hand</b> on Yom Kippur, to avoid having to wash it. <b>But</b> due to concerns about the health and well-being of his children, <b>they decreed that he must feed</b> them <b>with two hands,</b> forcing him to wash both. Apparently one who feeds another must wash his hands, even though he himself is not eating.
<b>Abaye said:</b> The reason for the washing <b>there</b> is not on account of the food specifically. Rather, it is <b>due to</b> an evil spirit named <b>Shivta,</b> who contaminates hands that have not been washed in the morning. As long as one washes his hands in the morning, perhaps he need not wash them again to feed another.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to the dilemma from the following incident, <b>as Shmuel’s father found</b> the young <b>Shmuel crying,</b> and <b>said to him: Why are you crying?</b> Shmuel replied: <b>Because my teacher struck me.</b> His father asked: <b>Why</b> did he strike you? Shmuel responded: My teacher <b>said to me: You are feeding my son, but you did not wash your hands.</b> His father asked: <b>And why did you not wash</b> your hands? Shmuel <b>said to him:</b> Only <b>he,</b> the teacher’s son, <b>is eating, and I</b> must <b>wash my hands?</b>
Shmuel’s father <b>said to him: Is it not enough that</b> your teacher <b>did not learn</b> the <i>halakha</i> properly, <b>that he even strikes you</b> on account of his error? One who feeds another need not wash his hands if he himself is not eating. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that one who <b>eats by means of</b> another <b>feeding</b> him <b>needs to wash</b> his <b>hands,</b> even though he does not touch the food. But <b>one who feeds</b> another <b>does not need to wash</b> his <b>hands.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A person may bind meat and cheese in one cloth, provided that they do not come into contact with each other. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Two</b> unacquainted <b>guests [<i>akhsena’in</i>] may eat</b> together <b>on one table, this</b> one eating <b>meat and that</b> one eating <b>cheese, and they</b> need <b>not be concerned</b> lest they come to violate the prohibition of eating meat and milk by partaking of the food of the other.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that one may bind meat and cheese together in one cloth, provided that they do not come into contact with each other. The Gemara asks: <b>And if they come into contact with each other, what of it? It is</b> a case of one <b>cold</b> food <b>in</b> contact with another <b>cold</b> food, and they would not absorb substances from one another. <b>Abaye said: Granted that</b> cold foods <b>do not require</b> the <b>peeling</b> of the place where they came into contact, as they do not absorb substances from one another. Nevertheless, <b>don’t they require rinsing</b> in water? The Sages therefore decreed against the contact of even cold meat and cheese, lest one come to eat them without rinsing them first.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Two guests may eat</b> together <b>on</b> one <b>table,</b> this one eating meat and that one eating cheese. <b>Rav Ḥanan bar Ami says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> the guests <b>do not know each other,</b> as they will not eat of each other’s food. <b>But</b> in a situation where <b>they know each other,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> for them to eat together at the same table.
<b>That</b> opinion <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> If <b>two guests roomed in one inn, this one coming from the north and that one coming from the south, this one coming with his piece</b> of meat <b>and that one coming with his cheese, they may eat</b> together <b>on one table, this one</b> eating <b>meat and that one cheese, and they</b> need <b>not be concerned.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And</b> the Sages <b>prohibited</b> this practice <b>only</b> if they both eat <b>from one parcel.</b> The Gemara adds: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is actually referring to a case where they eat from <b>one parcel?</b> This is obviously prohibited. <b>Rather,</b> it prohibits eating even in a manner <b>as though</b> they were eating from <b>one parcel,</b> i.e., when the diners are somewhat acquainted with each other, since neither would mind if the other ate from his food.
§ It was stated above that if two diners are acquainted with each other they may not eat meat and cheese on the same table. <b>Rav Yeimar bar Shelemya said to Abaye:</b> If these diners are <b>two brothers, but they are</b> each <b>particular</b> not to let <b>one another</b> eat of his food, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? May they eat separate dishes of meat and cheese at a single table?
Abaye <b>said to him:</b> Your question evokes that of Baitos ben Zunin. The Sages prohibited the baking of elaborately decorated Syrian cakes for Passover, lest people tarry in their preparation and the cakes become leavened. Baitos wished to prepare the cakes in a way that would not lead to a violation of any prohibition, and yet the Sages prohibited it, because people <b>will say: All the</b> decorated <b>Syrian cakes are forbidden, but the Syrian cakes of Baitos are permitted?</b> Here too, to avoid confusion, we will not allow exceptions to the rule.
Rav Yeimar responded: <b>But according to your reasoning,</b> one may refute <b>that which Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Although the Sages prohibited laundering on the intermediate days of a Festival, <b>one who has only one shirt is permitted to launder it on the intermediate days of a Festival.</b> Here too, one can claim: People <b>will say</b> metaphorically:

Daf 108a

<b>All the Syrian cakes are prohibited, but the Syrian cakes of Baitos are permitted?</b> The Gemara responds: With regard to the case <b>there, Mar, son of Rav Ashi, said: His belt is proof for him,</b> as in those days people commonly had one belt, which was worn over the shirt. If a person had more than one shirt, then whenever he laundered one he would remove the belt and wear it over the second. If one saw a shirt being washed with its belt, he would know that the owner had only one shirt.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a drop of milk that fell on a piece</b> of meat, <b>if</b> the drop <b>contains</b> enough milk <b>to impart flavor to that piece</b> of meat, i.e., the meat is less than sixty times the size of the drop, the meat is <b>forbidden.</b> If <b>one stirred</b> the contents of <b>the pot</b> and the piece was submerged in the gravy before it absorbed the milk, <b>if</b> the drop <b>contains</b> enough milk <b>to impart flavor to</b> the contents of <b>that</b> entire <b>pot,</b> the contents of the entire pot are <b>forbidden.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Abaye said:</b> The principle that <b>the flavor</b> of a forbidden food renders prohibited the substance in which it is absorbed, <b>and</b> it is <b>not</b> necessary for there to be <b>actual</b> forbidden substance, applies <b>by Torah law in general,</b> and not just to the prohibition of meat cooked in milk.
<b>As, if it enters your mind</b> that the principle applies to other prohibited foods <b>by rabbinic law,</b> one can claim: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>we do not learn</b> that it applies by Torah law <b>from</b> the analogous case of <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk?</b> It must be <b>because</b> the prohibition of meat cooked in milk <b>is a novelty</b> that is not derived through logical reasoning, as each substance is separately permitted, and they are prohibited only when cooked together. No analogies can be drawn to a novelty. But <b>if</b> the prohibition <b>is a novelty,</b> then <b>even if there is not</b> enough milk to <b>impart flavor,</b> the meat and milk should <b>also</b> be prohibited. Since the measure of the prohibition follows the standard principles of mixtures, the prohibition itself is apparently not a novelty. One may therefore draw an analogy to other mixtures, inferring that this measure applies to them by Torah law as well.
<b>Rava said to</b> Abaye: This is not a valid proof. The prohibition of meat cooked in milk is in fact a novelty and differs from other prohibited mixtures. Nevertheless, its measure is the imparting of flavor only because the action <b>the Torah prohibited</b> is in <b>the manner of cooking,</b> and cooking involves the imparting of flavor.
§ The mishna teaches that if the piece of meat acquires the flavor of milk, it is forbidden. <b>Rav says: Once</b> the milk <b>imparts flavor to the piece</b> of meat, the <b>piece itself becomes non-kosher</b> meat in its own right. <b>And</b> therefore, if one did not immediately remove the piece from the pot, <b>it renders all the pieces</b> of meat in the pot <b>forbidden,</b> even if they are together more than sixty times the size of that forbidden piece. This is <b>because they are</b> the same <b>type</b> as the forbidden piece, and as a rule, a substance in contact with the same type of substance cannot be nullified.
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina: Now</b> consider, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion did <b>Rav say his <i>halakha</i>?</b> It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said</b> that <b>a type</b> of food mixed with food <b>of</b> its <b>own type is not nullified.</b> If so, <b>shall we say</b> that Rav <b>disagrees with Rava’s</b> interpretation of Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion?
<b>As Rava said: Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> with regard to <b>any</b> tripartite mixture <b>consisting of</b> a forbidden <b>type</b> of food, a permitted food of <b>the same type, and another</b> food <b>item</b> that is permitted, one <b>disregards</b> the permitted food that is its <b>own type as though it were not there, and</b> if the permitted food <b>that is not</b> of <b>its own type is more than</b> the forbidden food, the permitted food <b>nullifies</b> the forbidden food. In the case Rav describes, although the other pieces of meat are of the same type as the piece that has become forbidden, the gravy in the pot is not of the same type, and it should nullify the forbidden piece. Since Rav does not mention this principle, he apparently disagrees with it.
Ravina <b>said to him: If</b> the forbidden substance <b>fell into thin gravy,</b> Rav would concede that the gravy would <b>indeed</b> nullify the piece of meat, since the two substances are of different types. <b>But here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where it fell into thick gravy,</b> which is composed of meat residue. Since the gravy is of the same substance as the meat, the forbidden piece is not nullified.
The Gemara returns to Rav’s statement that the piece of meat upon which the milk fell is considered a non-kosher item in its own right. <b>And what does</b> Rav <b>maintain</b> in this regard? <b>If he maintains</b> that an item <b>that can be wrung</b> to remove the forbidden substance it contains becomes <b>permitted</b> again after wringing, then it follows that only the absorbed substance is truly forbidden. If so, <b>why</b> should this <b>piece</b> of meat itself <b>become non-kosher?</b> Once it has been mixed into the stew, the milk it has absorbed should be evenly distributed throughout the pot and be nullified. <b>Rather,</b> Rav must <b>maintain</b> that even an item <b>that can be wrung</b> to remove the forbidden substance is <b>forbidden.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>As it was stated: Rav and Rabbi Ḥanina and Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> that even an item <b>that can be wrung</b> to remove the forbidden substance is <b>forbidden,</b> whereas <b>Shmuel, and Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and Reish Lakish say:</b> An item <b>that can be wrung</b> to remove the forbidden substance is <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rav</b> really <b>maintain</b> that an item <b>that can be wrung</b> to remove the forbidden substance is <b>forbidden? But wasn’t it stated:</b> If <b>an olive-bulk of meat fell into a pot of milk</b> so large that the meat did not impart flavor to it, <b>Rav says:</b> The <b>meat is forbidden,</b> as it absorbed the taste of the milk, <b>but</b> the <b>milk is permitted,</b> since it did not absorb the taste of the meat. <b>But if it enters your mind</b> that according to Rav an item <b>that can be wrung is forbidden,</b>

Daf 108b

<b>why is</b> the <b>milk permitted?</b> All the milk that the meat absorbed <b>is</b> rendered <b>non-kosher milk</b> in and of itself. When it seeps back out of the meat, it cannot be nullified by the rest of the milk, which is the same substance, as Rav holds in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda that a type of food mixed with food of its own type is not nullified. Therefore, the whole pot of milk should be prohibited.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav actually maintains</b> that an item <b>that can be wrung</b> to remove the forbidden substance is <b>prohibited, and there,</b> the pot of milk mentioned above <b>is different, as the verse states: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:21). The verse teaches that <b>the Torah prohibits</b> only the <b>kid,</b> i.e., the meat, that was cooked in milk, <b>but not</b> the <b>milk</b> that was cooked in meat. The milk is not itself rendered non-kosher.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And does Rav</b> really <b>maintain</b> that <b>the Torah prohibits</b> only the <b>kid but not</b> the <b>milk</b> cooked with it? <b>But isn’t it stated:</b> If <b>half an olive-bulk of meat and half an olive-bulk of milk were cooked together, Rav says:</b> One <b>is flogged for consuming</b> the combined olive-bulk, as he has eaten a whole olive-bulk of forbidden food. <b>But he is not flogged for cooking</b> the two half olive-bulks, as he did not cook items of the minimum size. <b>And if</b> it should <b>enter your mind</b> that Rav holds that <b>the Torah prohibits</b> only the <b>kid but not</b> the <b>milk, why is</b> this individual <b>flogged for consuming</b> only half an olive-bulk of meat? <b>It is</b> only <b>half</b> the prohibited <b>measure.</b>
<b>Rather, Rav actually maintains</b> that <b>milk</b> cooked in meat <b>is also prohibited, and</b> the reason Rav permits the pot of milk mentioned above is that <b>here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the olive-bulk of meat <b>fell into a boiling pot</b> of milk. In such a case the meat <b>absorbs</b> milk, but <b>it does not expel</b> it, and therefore the prohibited milk does not mix with the rest.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Ultimately, when</b> the pot <b>cools</b> from boiling, the meat <b>then expels</b> the prohibited milk. The Gemara answers: It is referring to a case <b>where he first removed</b> the meat before the pot cooled.
The Gemara turns to <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> mentioned above: If <b>half an olive-bulk of meat and half an olive-bulk of milk were cooked together, Rav says:</b> One <b>is flogged for consuming</b> the mixture, <b>but he is not flogged for cooking it.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>Whichever way you</b> look at it, this ruling is problematic. <b>If</b> these two halves of olive-bulks <b>combine</b> to form the requisite measure, then <b>let him be flogged for cooking</b> them <b>as well.</b> And <b>if they do not combine,</b> then <b>let him not be flogged for</b> their <b>consumption either.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> half an olive-bulk of meat and half an olive-bulk of milk <b>do not combine</b> to form the requisite measure, <b>and</b> when Rav says that one is flogged for consuming them, he is referring <b>to</b> a case where they <b>come from a large pot,</b> in which a sizable amount of meat and cheese had been cooked. The mixture is now considered a single prohibited entity, such that half an olive-bulk of the cheese and the meat can combine to constitute the requisite measure to be held liable for consumption.
<b>And Levi</b> disagrees with Rav on this matter, and <b>says:</b> Half an olive-bulk of meat and half an olive-bulk of milk can combine to form the requisite measure, and therefore one <b>is also flogged for cooking</b> the mixture. <b>And so Levi teaches in</b> his collection of <b><i>baraitot</i>: Just as one is flogged for consuming it, so too he is flogged for cooking it. And for what</b> degree of <b>cooking did they say</b> that one is liable to be flogged? It is <b>for</b> a degree of <b>cooking</b> that produces food <b>that others,</b> gentiles, would <b>eat due to its cooking,</b> i.e., cooking that renders it fit for consumption.
§ The Gemara returns to the issue previously discussed: <b>And</b> the case of an item <b>that can be wrung</b> to remove an absorbed prohibited substance <b>is itself</b> the subject of a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>a drop of milk fell onto a piece</b> of meat, <b>once it imparts flavor to the piece, the piece itself is rendered non-kosher</b> in its own right. <b>And</b> it therefore <b>renders all the</b> other <b>pieces</b> of meat in the pot <b>prohibited,</b> even if they combine to more than sixty times its size; this is <b>because they are</b> of <b>the same type,</b> and a type of food mixed with food of its own type is not nullified. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say</b> that even the original piece of meat is not prohibited <b>unless</b> there is enough milk to <b>impart flavor</b> even <b>to the gravy and to the spices and to the</b> other <b>pieces</b> of meat in the pot, since the milk is assumed to diffuse from the first piece until it is evenly distributed throughout the pot.
With regard to this dispute, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: The statement of Rabbi Yehuda appears</b> to be correct in a case <b>where one did not stir</b> the contents of the pot <b>and where he did not cover</b> it, both of which would promote the diffusion of the milk throughout the pot. <b>And the statement of the Rabbis</b> appears to be correct in a case <b>where one stirred</b> the contents of the pot <b>and covered</b> it.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the clause: Where <b>one did not stir</b> the pot <b>and did not cover</b> it? <b>If we say</b> that he <b>did not stir</b> the contents of the pot <b>at all and did not cover</b> it <b>at all,</b> in this case the piece of meat onto which the milk fell <b>absorbs</b> the drop of milk but <b>does not expel</b> it. Therefore, even according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda there is no reason to prohibit the other pieces of meat.
<b>And</b> if you say <b>rather</b> that <b>he did not not stir</b> the contents of the pot <b>at the beginning,</b> immediately after the milk fell in, <b>but</b> stirred <b>at the end,</b> afterward, <b>and</b> likewise <b>he did not cover</b> the pot <b>at the beginning but at the end,</b> one must ask: <b>Why</b> are all the pieces in the pot prohibited? The same milk that the piece <b>absorbs</b> it subsequently <b>expels,</b> and once the milk diffuses throughout the pot it should be nullified.
The Gemara responds: Evidently, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>maintains</b> that an item <b>that can be wrung</b> remains <b>prohibited.</b> Once the first piece of meat absorbs the milk, it is considered non-kosher in its own right, and even after the milk itself is nullified, the flavor of the forbidden meat renders the rest of the pieces prohibited. The flavor of the meat cannot be nullified by the other meat in the pot, since a substance in contact with the same type of substance is not nullified, according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.

Daf 109a

The Gemara objects: From Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s acceptance of Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion only when one did not stir or cover the pot, one can conclude <b>by inference that Rabbi Yehuda</b> himself <b>maintains</b> that even <b>when one stirred</b> the contents of the pot continuously <b>from beginning to end,</b> i.e., before and after the drop of milk was absorbed, <b>or covered</b> the pot continuously <b>from beginning to end,</b> all the contents of the pot are <b>prohibited.</b> But <b>why</b> should this be so? The first piece of meat <b>did not absorb any</b> more milk than the others. Since the milk definitely diffused evenly through the pot immediately, it should be nullified, assuming that the pot’s contents amount to more than sixty times the milk.
The Gemara responds: <b>Say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda is stringent because one might <b>not</b> have <b>stirred thoroughly, or</b> he might <b>not</b> have <b>covered</b> the pot <b>thoroughly,</b> and therefore initially the milk might have been absorbed only by the first piece, rendering it prohibited. Afterward, when he does stir thoroughly, that piece of meat renders the other pieces prohibited. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi does not share this concern.
§ The Gemara returns to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement: <b>The Master said</b> above: <b>And the statement of the Rabbis</b> appears correct in a case <b>where one stirred</b> the pot <b>and covered</b> it. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>Stirred, and what</b> is the meaning of the term: <b>Covered? If we say</b> that he <b>stirred at the end,</b> after the first piece absorbed the milk, <b>and did not stir at the beginning,</b> beforehand, <b>and</b> likewise he <b>covered at the end and did not cover at the beginning,</b> one may respond: <b>Didn’t you</b> already <b>say</b> on the previous <i>amud</i> that <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda appears</b> to be correct <b>in this</b> case? <b>Rather,</b> it must be a case where he <b>stirred</b> continuously <b>from beginning to end or covered</b> the pot continuously <b>from beginning to end.</b>
If so, one can conclude <b>by inference</b> from Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s qualified acceptance of the Rabbis’ opinion <b>that the Rabbis</b> themselves <b>maintain</b> that even when one <b>stirred</b> only <b>at the end and did not stir at the beginning,</b> and similarly if he <b>covered</b> the pot only <b>at the end and did not cover at the beginning,</b> all the contents of the pot are <b>permitted.</b> Even the first piece is permitted, as they hold that the milk it absorbed diffused out of it and throughout the pot.
<b>Evidently,</b> the Rabbis <b>maintain</b> that an item <b>that can be wrung</b> to remove the forbidden substance is <b>permitted.</b> This illustrates that <i>tanna’im</i> dispute this issue, as according to Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, an item that can be wrung to remove the forbidden substance is prohibited.
<b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <b>disagree with regard to</b> an item <b>that can be wrung? Perhaps</b> even if an item <b>can be wrung, everyone agrees</b> that it remains <b>prohibited, and here they disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type</b> can be nullified. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as he said</b> that <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type cannot be nullified. And</b> likewise, <b>the Rabbis</b> conform <b>to their</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as they said</b> that <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type can be nullified.</b> This is why they maintain that all the meat in the pot is permitted.
Ravina responded: <b>What is this</b> reasoning? <b>Granted, if you say that the Rabbis here hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to</b> the issue of <b>a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type, and they disagree with regard to</b> an item <b>that can be wrung, that is</b> why <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: The statement of Rabbi Yehuda appears</b> to be correct <b>in this</b> case, when one did not initially stir or cover the pot, <b>and the statement of the Rabbis</b> appears to be correct <b>in that</b> case, when one did initially stir or cover it, since the issue of when one stirred or covered the pot is relevant to the dispute, as explained above.
<b>But if you say: Everyone agrees</b> that an item <b>that can be wrung is prohibited, and here they disagree</b> only <b>with regard to a type</b> of food mixed <b>with</b> food of <b>its</b> own <b>type,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi should not phrase his statement as a qualified acceptance of both opinions, which seems arbitrary. Rather, <b>he should have</b> said <b>this:</b> I accept that a type of food is not nullified by a food of its own type. Therefore, <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda appears</b> correct where one did not stir initially, as the flavor of the prohibited first piece cannot be nullified; <b>but</b> it <b>does not appear</b> correct where one stirred immediately, since in that case, even the first piece is not prohibited, and I do not share Rabbi Yehuda’s concern that perhaps one did not stir thoroughly. <b>And nothing more</b> need be said.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One who wants to eat <b>the udder</b> of a slaughtered animal <b>tears it and removes its milk,</b> and only then is it permitted to cook it. If <b>he did not tear</b> the udder before cooking it, <b>he does not violate</b> the prohibition against cooking and eating meat and milk and does not receive lashes <b>for it,</b> as the halakhic status of the milk in the udder is not that of milk. One who wants to eat <b>the heart</b> of a slaughtered animal <b>tears it and removes its blood,</b> and only then may he cook and eat it. If <b>he did not tear</b> the heart before cooking and eating it, <b>he does not violate</b> the prohibition against consuming blood and is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for it.</b>

Daf 109b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if one did not tear the udder of a slaughtered animal before cooking it he does not violate the biblical prohibition against eating meat and milk. <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rav says: He does not violate</b> the prohibition, <b>and</b> it is altogether <b>permitted</b> to eat the cooked product <i>ab initio</i>. The Gemara objects: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>He does not violate</b> the prohibition, i.e., he is not held liable after the fact. One can infer from here as follows: <b>He does not violate</b> a prohibition by Torah law, <b>but there is</b> nevertheless <b>a prohibition</b> <i>ab initio</i> by rabbinic law.
The Gemara explains: <b>By right</b> the mishna <b>should have</b> taught <b>that there is no prohibition</b> here by rabbinic law <b>either. But</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna uses this language <b>since he wants to teach</b> in <b>the latter clause:</b> One who wants to eat <b>the heart</b> of a slaughtered animal <b>tears it and removes its blood,</b> but if <b>he did not tear</b> the heart before cooking and eating it, <b>he does not violate</b> the prohibition. <b>There</b> it is true that although <b>he does not violate</b> a prohibition by Torah law <b>there is a prohibition</b> by rabbinic law. To preserve linguistic symmetry, <b>he teaches the first clause</b> in this manner <b>as well,</b> stating: <b>He does not violate</b> the prohibition.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> this opinion: One who wants to eat <b>the udder</b> of a slaughtered animal <b>tears it and removes its milk.</b> If <b>he did not tear</b> the udder before cooking it, <b>he does not violate</b> the prohibition against cooking and eating meat and milk and does not receive lashes <b>for it.</b> One who wants to eat <b>the heart</b> of a slaughtered animal <b>tears it and removes its blood.</b> If <b>he did not tear</b> the heart before cooking and eating it, <b>he tears it after its cooking, and it is permitted.</b> One can infer from the <i>baraita</i> that <b>it is</b> only the <b>heart that requires tearing</b> after cooking if it was not torn beforehand. <b>But</b> the <b>udder does not require tearing</b> after being cooked unlawfully. Evidently, it is permitted as is.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps</b> one should infer the opposite, that <b>tearing</b> after cooking <b>is sufficient</b> only <b>to</b> render the <b>heart</b> permitted, as the heart does not absorb blood through cooking. <b>But tearing</b> after cooking <b>is not sufficient to</b> render the <b>udder</b> permitted, as the meat of the udder absorbs the milk through cooking, and tearing will not remove the absorbed milk.
<b>And some say</b> a different version of the above exchange, based on a different version of Rav’s statement: <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If one does not tear the udder of a slaughtered animal before cooking it, <b>he does not violate</b> the Torah prohibition, <b>but</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> to eat the cooked product by rabbinic law. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the mishna <b>supports</b> this opinion, as it states: <b>He does not violate</b> the prohibition, indicating that although <b>he does not violate</b> a Torah prohibition and is not flogged, <b>there is</b> nevertheless <b>a prohibition</b> by rabbinic law.
The Gemara responds: <b>By right</b> the mishna <b>should have</b> taught <b>that there is not even a prohibition</b> by rabbinic law. <b>But</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna uses this language <b>since he wants to teach the latter clause:</b> One who wants to eat <b>the heart</b> of a slaughtered animal <b>tears it and removes its blood,</b> but if <b>he did not tear</b> the heart before cooking and eating it, <b>he does not violate</b> the prohibition <b>for it. There,</b> it is true that although <b>he does not violate</b> a Torah prohibition <b>there is a prohibition</b> by rabbinic law. <b>He</b> therefore <b>teaches</b> in <b>the first clause</b> in this manner <b>as well,</b> stating: <b>He does not violate</b> the prohibition <b>for it.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: One who wants to eat <b>the udder</b> of a slaughtered animal <b>tears it and removes its milk.</b> If <b>he did not tear</b> the udder before cooking it, <b>he does not violate</b> the prohibition <b>for it.</b> One who wants to eat <b>the heart</b> of a slaughtered animal <b>tears it and removes its blood.</b> If <b>he did not tear</b> the heart before cooking and eating it, <b>he tears it after its cooking, and it is permitted.</b> One can infer from the <i>baraita</i> that <b>it is</b> only the <b>heart that requires tearing</b> after cooking if it was not torn beforehand, <b>but</b> the <b>udder does not require tearing</b> after being cooked unlawfully. Evidently, it is permitted as is.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps</b> one should infer the opposite, that <b>tearing</b> after cooking <b>is sufficient</b> only <b>to</b> render the <b>heart</b> permitted, as the heart does not absorb blood through cooking. <b>But tearing</b> it after cooking <b>is not sufficient to</b> render the <b>udder</b> permitted, as the meat of the udder absorbs the milk through cooking, and tearing will not remove the absorbed milk. This concludes the second version of the Gemara’s discussion.
The Gemara comments: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with the first version of Rav’s</b> statement: <b>An udder that one cooked,</b> i.e., roasted, <b>in its milk is permitted.</b> By contrast, the <b>stomach</b> of a suckling lamb or calf <b>that one cooked,</b> i.e., roasted, together <b>with</b> the <b>milk</b> it contains is <b>prohibited</b> for consumption.
The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>And what</b> is the <b>distinction between this</b> stomach <b>and that</b> udder? The milk <b>this</b> calf suckled was considered milk the moment it left the mother’s teat, and it was merely <b>collected in</b> the calf’s <b>innards. But that</b> milk in the udder is not defined as milk, since it was <b>never collected in</b> the animal’s <b>innards</b> from outside but is found in the flesh. Consequently, this meat of the udder is not prohibited if it is roasted with the milk it contains, although one should still tear it by rabbinic law <i>ab initio</i>.
§ The Gemara inquires: <b>How must one tear</b> an udder before cooking it? <b>Rav Yehuda says: One tears it lengthwise and widthwise [<i>sheti va’erev</i>] and smears it against a wall</b> to remove all the milk. The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Elazar said to his attendant: Tear</b> an udder <b>for me</b> before you roast it, <b>and I will eat</b> it. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this episode <b>teaching us? It is</b> explicitly stated in <b>the mishna</b> that one must do this. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> story <b>teaches us that</b> according to Rabbi Elazar <b>we do not require</b> one to tear it <b>lengthwise and widthwise and smear it against a wall.</b> Rather, it is enough simply to tear it once, either lengthwise or widthwise.
§ <b>Yalta said to</b> her husband <b>Rav Naḥman: Now</b> as a rule, for <b>any</b> item <b>that the Merciful One prohibited to us, He permitted to us a similar</b> item. He <b>prohibited to us</b> the consumption of <b>blood,</b> yet <b>He permitted to us</b> the consumption of <b>liver,</b> which is filled with blood and retains the taste of blood. Likewise, God prohibited sexual intercourse with <b>a menstruating woman,</b> but permitted sexual intercourse with one’s wife while she discharges <b>the blood of purity.</b> During a particular period after giving birth, even if she experiences a flow of blood she is not rendered ritually impure and remains permitted to her husband by Torah law.
Furthermore, the Torah prohibits the consumption of the forbidden <b>fat of a domesticated animal,</b> but permitted the <b>fat of an undomesticated animal,</b> which has the same flavor. It is prohibited to eat <b>pork,</b> but one may eat <b>the brain of a <i>shibuta</i></b> fish, which has a similar taste. One may not eat <b><i>giruta</i>,</b> a non-kosher fish, but one may eat the <b>tongue of a fish,</b> which tastes similar.
Likewise, the Torah prohibits sexual intercourse with <b>the wife of</b> another <b>man</b> but permitted one to marry <b>a divorced woman in her</b> previous <b>husband’s lifetime.</b> The Torah prohibits sexual intercourse with one’s <b>brother’s wife,</b> and yet it permits one to marry his <b><i>yevama</i>,</b> i.e., his brother’s widow when the brother dies childless. Finally, the Torah prohibits sexual intercourse with <b>a gentile woman</b> but permitted one to marry <b>a beautiful woman</b> who is a prisoner of war (see Deuteronomy 21:10–14). Yalta concluded: The Torah prohibits the consumption of meat cooked in milk; <b>I wish to eat</b> a dish that tastes like <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk.</b>
Upon hearing this, <b>Rav Naḥman said to</b> his <b>cooks: Roast udders on a spit for her.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that one must <b>tear</b> the udder first? Rav Naḥman did not tell his cooks to tear the udders. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> requirement was stated only <b>with regard to</b> cooking in <b>a pot,</b> not roasting.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i> cited above: An udder <b>that one cooked</b> in its milk is permitted? This indicates that <b>after the fact, yes,</b> it is permitted, but one may <b>not</b> roast it <b><i>ab initio</i></b> without tearing it. The Gemara answers: <b>The same is true even</b> of roasting <b><i>ab initio</i>,</b> i.e., it is permitted, <b>and</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> uses this language <b>since he wants to teach</b> in <b>the latter clause: A stomach</b>

Daf 110a

of a suckling lamb or calf <b>that one cooked</b> together <b>with</b> the <b>milk</b> it contains <b>is prohibited.</b> There, <b>even</b> if one roasted it he may <b>not</b> eat it <b>after the fact.</b> To preserve symmetry, the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>taught</b> in <b>the first clause</b> in this manner <b>as well,</b> stating: An udder <b>that one cooked</b> in its milk is permitted.
§ The Gemara above cited a second version of Rav’s opinion, according to which an udder that was roasted without being torn is prohibited for consumption. The Gemara relates: <b>When Rabbi Elazar ascended</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael <b>he found Ze’eiri</b> and <b>said to him: Is there a <i>tanna</i> who taught Rav</b> that <b>an udder</b> roasted without first being torn is prohibited? Ze’eiri <b>showed him Rav Yitzḥak bar Avudimi.</b> Rav Yitzḥak bar Avudimi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Elazar: <b>I did not teach</b> Rav that <b>an udder</b> is prohibited <b>at all;</b> rather, <b>Rav found</b> an unguarded <b>valley and fenced it in.</b> Rav taught this stringent ruling as an additional safeguard in Babylonia, where Jews were not careful about the prohibition of meat cooked in milk.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>As</b> when <b>Rav arrived in Tatlefush, he heard a certain woman saying to another: How much milk does it require to cook a quarter</b> weight <b>of meat?</b> Rav <b>said:</b> Evidently, these people <b>are not learned</b> enough in <i>halakha</i> to know <b>that meat</b> cooked <b>in milk is prohibited.</b> Rav <b>tarried</b> in that place, <b>and prohibited</b> even <b>udders to them,</b> so that they would not come to violate the prohibition of meat cooked in milk.
<b>Rav Kahana teaches</b> that Rav Yitzḥak bar Avudimi replied to Rabbi Elazar in <b>that</b> manner described above. By contrast, <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Abba teaches</b> that Rav Yitzḥak bar Avudimi said: <b>I taught</b> Rav only that <b>the udder of</b> an animal <b>nursing</b> offspring is prohibited, as its udder contains much milk. <b>And due to the sharp</b> mind <b>of Rav Ḥiyya,</b> Rav’s teacher, he assumed that Rav too would understand this without his saying so explicitly. Therefore, he <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> to Rav with regard to <b>an unspecified udder.</b> Rav mistakenly thought that the ruling applies to all animals.
The Gemara relates that <b>Ravin and Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef arrived at the house of Rav Pappi.</b> The servants <b>brought before them a dish</b> made <b>of udder. Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef ate</b> of it, but <b>Ravin did not eat. Abaye said: Bereaved Ravin, why do you not eat? After all, Rav Pappi’s wife is the daughter of Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa, and Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa was a master of</b> good <b>deeds,</b> who was meticulous in his performance of mitzvot. <b>Had</b> Rav Pappi’s wife <b>not heard in her father’s house</b> that such a dish is permitted, <b>she would not have made</b> it.
The Gemara relates: <b>In Sura they would not eat udders</b> at all, even torn and roasted. But <b>in Pumbedita they would eat udders. Rami bar Tamrei, who is</b> also called <b>Rami bar Dikulei, from Pumbedita, arrived in Sura on the eve of Yom Kippur.</b> Since it is a mitzva to eat and drink then, large quantities of meat were cooked, and <b>everyone brought out their udders</b> from the animals they had slaughtered and <b>threw them</b> away. Rami bar Tamrei <b>went</b> and <b>gathered</b> the udders, roasted them, and <b>ate them,</b> in accordance with his custom.
The residents of Sura <b>brought</b> Rami bar Tamrei <b>before Rav Ḥisda,</b> who <b>said to him: Why did you do this?</b> Rami bar Tamrei <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>I am from the place of Rav Yehuda, who eats</b> udders, and this is the accepted custom in Pumbedita. Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: And do you not hold</b> by the principle that the Sages <b>impose upon</b> a traveler <b>the stringencies of the place that he left and</b> also <b>the stringencies of the place to which he went?</b> You should have accepted the stringency of Sura and not eaten the udders. Rami bar Tamrei <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: That principle applies only to one who remains in the place he is visiting, but <b>I ate</b> the udders <b>outside the boundaries</b> of Sura.
Rav Ḥisda further asked Rami bar Tamrei: <b>And with what did you roast</b> the udders? Rami bar Tamrei <b>said to him:</b> I roasted them <b>with grape seeds</b> [<b><i>purtzenei</i></b>] I found in the vines there. Rav Ḥisda objected: <b>But</b> how could you roast the udders with grape seeds, as <b>perhaps they were from wine</b> used for <b>a libation</b> to idolatry, from which it is prohibited to derive benefit. Rami bar Tamrei <b>said to him:</b> These <b>were</b> old seeds that still lay there <b>after twelve months</b> had passed since the grapes were used, and any prohibition had expired, as by that point they are assumed to have lost any prohibited liquid that previously remained inside (see <i>Avoda Zara</i> 34a).
Rav Ḥisda further objected: <b>But perhaps</b> these seeds <b>were from stolen</b> property, i.e., they belonged to someone and it was prohibited for you to take them. Rami bar Tamrei <b>said to him:</b> Even so, in this case <b>there was</b> certainly <b>despair of the owners</b> of recovering them, <b>as grass was growing among them.</b> Since the owners had allowed them to lie there for so long, they had clearly given up all hope of retrieving them.
Rav Ḥisda <b>saw that</b> Rami bar Tamrei <b>had not donned phylacteries,</b> and <b>said to him: What is the reason that you have not donned phylacteries?</b> Rami bar Tamrei <b>said to him: He,</b> i.e., I, am suffering from <b>intestinal illness, and Rav Yehuda said</b> that one who has <b>intestinal illness is exempt from the</b> mitzva of <b>phylacteries,</b> which require a clean body, because he would have to remove them constantly to defecate.
Rav Ḥisda further <b>saw that</b> Rami bar Tamrei <b>had not placed</b> the <b>threads</b> of ritual fringes on his garment and <b>said to him: What is the reason that you do not have</b> the <b>threads</b> of ritual fringes? Rami bar Tamrei <b>said to him: It is a borrowed robe, and Rav Yehuda said:</b>

Daf 110b

With regard to <b>a borrowed robe,</b> during <b>all</b> of the first <b>thirty days</b> that one borrows it, one is <b>exempt from</b> performing the mitzva of <b>ritual fringes</b> with it.
<b>Meanwhile,</b> as Rav Ḥisda and Rami bar Tamrei were talking, the attendants <b>brought</b> in <b>a certain man</b> to Rav Ḥisda’s court <b>who would not honor his father and mother,</b> and <b>they tied him</b> to a pillar in order to flog him.
Rami bar Tamrei <b>said to them: Leave him</b> alone, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>any positive mitzva whose reward</b> is stated <b>alongside it</b> in the Torah, <b>the</b> earthly <b>court below is not warned to</b> enforce <b>it</b> through punishments such as flogging. And it is stated after the mitzva of honoring one’s father and mother: “That your days may be long, and that it go well with you” (Deuteronomy 5:16). Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rami bar Tamrei: <b>I see that you are very sharp.</b> Rami bar Tamrei <b>said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>If you were in the place where Rav Yehuda</b> resides, <b>I would</b> be able to <b>show you my sharpness</b> of mind far better than here.
§ Pursuant to the discussion of different local customs, <b>Abaye said to Rav Safra: When you ascend there,</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>ask</b> the Sages there: With regard to <b>liver, how do you</b> treat <b>it? When</b> Rav Safra <b>ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael <b>he found Rav Zerika</b> and asked him this question. Rav Zerika <b>said to him: I cooked</b> liver <b>for Rabbi Ami and he ate</b> it.
<b>When</b> Rav Safra returned to Babylonia and <b>came before</b> Abaye and reported what Rav Zerika had said, Abaye <b>said to him: I do not raise the dilemma</b> as <b>to</b> whether liver <b>renders itself prohibited</b> if cooked alone. It is clear to me that the blood that diffuses out of the liver is not absorbed again while it cooks. <b>When I raise the dilemma,</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> whether liver <b>renders prohibited another</b> piece of meat cooked with it. Rav Zerika’s statement therefore has no bearing on my question.
Rav Safra asked Abaye: <b>What is different</b> about the issue of the liver <b>rendering itself prohibited, that you did not raise the dilemma</b> with regard to this case? It is presumably because the answer is obvious to you, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 10:11) that liver <b>is not rendered prohibited</b> by its own cooking. But if so, <b>you should not raise the dilemma with regard to</b> whether it <b>renders the other</b> piece of meat <b>prohibited either, as we learned</b> in that same mishna: <b>Liver renders</b> food cooked with it in the same pot <b>prohibited but is not prohibited</b> itself, <b>because</b> while it does <b>expel</b> blood as it cooks, it <b>does not absorb</b> this blood again, since the blood diffuses only outward. Abaye <b>said to</b> Rav Safra: That mishna does not answer my question, as <b>perhaps there</b> it is referring specifically <b>to forbidden liver,</b> e.g., the liver of a non-kosher animal.

Daf 111a

<b>And</b> the other food is not forbidden due to the liver’s blood, <b>but</b> rather <b>due to the fat</b> of the liver it absorbed. But if permitted liver is cooked with another piece of meat, and the concern is only that the meat might be prohibited <b>due to</b> the meat absorbing excess <b>blood</b> from the liver, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Perhaps blood is absorbed less easily than fat.
<b>When</b> Rav Safra <b>again ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found Rabbi Zerika</b> once more and asked him about liver cooked with another piece of meat. Rabbi Zerika <b>said to him: You</b> need <b>not ask this</b> question <b>either, as I and Yannai, son of Rabbi Ami, arrived at the house of Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, and they brought before us the windpipe</b> of an animal <b>with</b> all the parts <b>attached to it,</b> i.e., the lungs, heart, and liver, all of which had been cooked together, <b>and we ate</b> it. This proves that the blood emitted from the liver does not render prohibited other pieces of meat cooked with it.
<b>Rav Ashi, and some say Rabbi Shmuel from Zerokinya, objects to this</b> conclusion: <b>But perhaps</b> in that incident <b>the mouth of the windpipe was</b> positioned <b>outside of the pot,</b> allowing the liver’s excess blood to run out of the pot rather than being absorbed by the other pieces of meat. <b>Alternatively,</b> perhaps they <b>poured boiling liquid on</b> the liver <b>at the outset,</b> before it was cooked with the lung and heart, <b>like that</b> custom <b>of Rav Huna,</b> for whom <b>they would pour boiling vinegar on</b> liver, <b>and</b> that of <b>Rav Naḥman,</b> for whom <b>they would pour boiling water on</b> liver. This would cook the excess blood into the liver and prevent it from diffusing into the other pieces. Abaye’s question remains unresolved.
<b>And</b> with regard to the pouring of boiling vinegar on the liver, <b>Rav Pappa,</b> when he was a student <b>before Rava, thought to say</b> that the <b>vinegar</b> becomes <b>prohibited</b> for consumption in the process, since it absorbs blood from the liver. Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa: <b>If</b> you claim that the <b>vinegar is prohibited,</b> then the liver <b>itself</b> should <b>also</b> be <b>prohibited,</b> since <b>just as</b> the liver <b>expels</b> blood and prohibits the vinegar, so too <b>it then absorbs</b> the blood back from the forbidden vinegar. Rather, one must say that no blood is expelled from the liver during this process at all, which is why the liver is permitted afterward.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav bar Shabba visited the house of Rav Naḥman. They brought him cooked liver, but</b> Rava bar Shabba <b>did not partake</b> of it. The members of the household <b>said to</b> Rav Naḥman: There is <b>a student</b> of Torah <b>inside</b> who <b>is not eating. And who is he? Rav bar Shabba. Rav Naḥman said to them: Feed Shabba</b> against his will.
The Gemara notes: Abaye’s question above with regard to liver cooked with other meat is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The liver</b> that was cooked with other pieces of meat <b>prohibits</b> them, <b>but</b> it itself <b>is not prohibited, because it expels</b> blood as it cooks <b>but does not absorb</b> it again. <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says:</b> If the liver was <b>spiced</b> when cooking, it <b>prohibits</b> the other meat <b>and</b> it becomes <b>prohibited</b> as well, as the spices cause the liver to reabsorb the blood that was expelled. Likewise, if the liver was <b>stewed,</b> i.e., heavily cooked, it <b>renders</b> the other pieces <b>prohibited and</b> is itself <b>prohibited.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna visited the house of Rabba bar Rav Naḥman</b> and dined with him on Shabbat. <b>They brought before him three <i>se’a</i></b> of fine bread that had been <b>kneaded</b> in oil and honey. Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>said to</b> the members of Rabba bar Rav Naḥman’s household: <b>Did you know that I was coming,</b> that you prepared such superior food? <b>They said to him: Are you more distinguished than</b> Shabbat, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to Shabbat: <b>“If you proclaim Shabbat a delight,</b> the sacred day of God honored” (Isaiah 58:13).
<b>Meanwhile,</b> Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>found</b> among the dishes before him <b>a certain liver that contained an artery suffused with blood. He said to</b> the members of the household: <b>Why do you do this?</b> Although the blood absorbed in the liver is permitted, that which is collected in the blood vessels is prohibited. The members of the household <b>said to him: Rather, what should we do</b> in order to prepare the liver? Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>said to them:</b> First <b>tear</b> the liver <b>lengthwise and widthwise, and</b> position the side with <b>the tear downward,</b> so that the blood will flow out when you place it on the fire.
The Gemara comments: <b>And this statement</b> applies only to <b>liver,</b> due to the blood that collects in its blood vessels; <b>but</b> there is no need to tear the <b>spleen</b> in this manner, as it <b>merely</b> contains <b>fat.</b> And this ruling <b>accords with that</b> which is reported <b>about Shmuel,</b> that his attendants <b>would prepare a dish of spleens for him on the day that he performed the practice</b> of bloodletting.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> If liver and other meat are roasted on spits in an oven such that <b>the liver</b> is positioned <b>on top of the meat,</b> the meat is <b>permitted</b> even though blood from the liver flows onto it. This is because <b>the blood</b> that flows from an item roasting in the oven <b>slides</b> over meat located underneath it and is not absorbed. But if <b>an udder</b> is positioned <b>on top of the meat</b> when roasted in the oven, the meat is <b>prohibited. What is the reason?</b> It is that the <b>milk</b> expelled by the roasting udder <b>adheres to</b> and is absorbed by the meat.
<b>Rav Dimi from Neharde’a</b> would <b>teach the opposite:</b> Whenever <b>an udder</b> is positioned <b>on top of the meat,</b> the meat is <b>permitted. What is the reason?</b> The prohibition of meat cooked in <b>milk of a slaughtered</b> animal applies <b>by rabbinic law,</b> and is treated less stringently. But if <b>liver</b> is positioned <b>on top of the meat,</b> the meat is <b>prohibited,</b> as the prohibition of <b>blood</b> applies <b>by Torah law,</b> and one must be concerned that perhaps the meat will absorb blood from the liver.
<b>Mareimar taught</b> in public: The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is: <b>Whether</b> in the case of <b>liver or</b> in the case of <b>an udder,</b> if it is <b>underneath the meat,</b> the meat is <b>permitted,</b> but if it is <b>on top of the meat,</b> then <b>after the fact, yes,</b> the meat is permitted, but <b><i>ab initio</i>, no,</b> one may not situate them in this manner.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Ashi arrived at the house of his father-in-law Rami bar Abba,</b> and <b>he saw that the son of Rami bar Abba was</b>

Daf 111b

<b>skewering liver on top of meat</b> for roasting. Rav Ashi <b>said: How haughty is this Sage!</b> Even if you <b>say that the Sages stated</b> that one may eat meat roasted under liver <b>after the fact, did they say</b> that one may roast them in this manner <b><i>ab initio</i>?</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>And if there is a receptacle</b> under the spit <b>for the drippings</b> of fat, then even if the <b>meat</b> is <b>on top of</b> the <b>liver</b> it is <b>also prohibited</b> to roast the meat, as the blood from the liver will fall into the fat in the vessel, and one might come to eat the mixture.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> this case <b>different from</b> roasting a piece of meat by itself over such a vessel, which is permitted? Here too the <b>blood of the meat</b> drips into the fat in the vessel. The Gemara answers: <b>Blood of</b> most <b>meat sinks</b> to the bottom of the vessel, while the fat floats on top. Since the fat can be separated from the blood, it is permitted. By contrast, the <b>blood of the liver floats</b> above the fat and cannot be removed from it, and therefore the entire mixture is prohibited.
§ <b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b>knife with which one slaughtered</b> an animal absorbs blood due to its heat, and it is therefore <b>prohibited to cut</b> any <b>boiling</b> food <b>with it,</b> since that food will in turn absorb the blood from the knife. If one cut <b>cold</b> food with this knife, <b>some say</b> that the piece he cut <b>requires rinsing</b> before one may eat it, <b>and some say</b> that it <b>does not require rinsing.</b>
§ The Gemara cites other statements of Shmuel. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>a bowl in which meat was salted</b> to remove its blood before cooking, it is <b>prohibited to eat</b> any <b>boiling</b> food placed <b>in it,</b> as that food absorbs blood of the meat from the bowl. <b>And</b> in this <b>Shmuel</b> conforms <b>to his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning, as Shmuel said: A salted</b> food imparts its flavor <b>like a boiling</b> food, <b>and</b> a food item <b>marinated</b> in vinegar, brine, or the like absorbs flavor from the liquid or vessel <b>as</b> would <b>a cooked</b> food.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A salted</b> food <b>is not</b> considered <b>like a boiling</b> food, <b>and a marinated</b> food <b>is not</b> considered <b>like a cooked</b> food. <b>Abaye said:</b> I can prove that <b>this</b> ruling <b>that Ravin</b> cited <b>is not</b> correct, <b>as there was a certain bowl</b> [<b><i>pinka</i></b>] <b>in Rabbi Ami’s house in which meat was salted, and</b> Rabbi Ami <b>broke it</b> so that it would no longer be used. <b>Now Rabbi Ami was a student of Rabbi Yoḥanan. What is the reason he broke</b> that bowl? Is it <b>not because he heard that Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A salted</b> food <b>is</b> considered <b>like a boiling</b> food? Ravin’s citation was evidently in error.
<b>Rav Kahana, the brother of Rav Yehuda, sat before Rav Huna, and he sat and said:</b> With regard to <b>a bowl in which meat was salted, it is prohibited to eat</b> any <b>boiling</b> food placed <b>in it. And</b> he added: With regard to <b>a radish that one cut with a knife</b> used for cutting meat, it is <b>permitted to eat it with <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> a food that contains milk, even though the sharpness of the radish causes it to absorb the fat of the meat from the knife.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> to distinguish between blood absorbed in a bowl and fat absorbed by the radish? <b>Abaye said: This</b> radish <b>absorbed a permitted</b> substance, as the fat on the knife is permitted for consumption by itself, <b>but that</b> bowl in which meat was salted <b>absorbed a prohibited</b> substance, i.e., blood.
<b>Rava said to</b> Abaye: And <b>if</b> the radish <b>absorbed a permitted</b> substance, <b>what of it? Ultimately,</b> if one desires to eat the radish with <i>kutaḥ</i>, <b>it is a permitted</b> substance <b>that leads to a prohibition, as he</b> will <b>eat a prohibited</b> substance. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The distinction is that with regard to <b>this</b> radish, it is <b>possible</b> for a Jew <b>to taste it</b> before eating it with milk to see if it has acquired the flavor of meat. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>that</b> bowl, it is <b>not possible</b> for a Jew <b>to taste its</b> contents to see whether they have absorbed blood.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Rava: But let a gentile cook taste</b> the contents of the bowl to see whether they have the taste of blood. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Terumot</i> 8:12): With regard to <b>a pot in which one cooked meat, one may not cook milk in it, and if he cooked</b> milk in it, the meat absorbed in the pot renders the milk forbidden if it <b>imparts flavor</b> to the milk. Likewise, if one <b>cooked <i>teruma</i> in</b> the pot, <b>he may not cook non-sacred</b> food <b>in it, and if he cooked</b> non-sacred food in it, the non-sacred food is prohibited if there is sufficient <i>teruma</i> absorbed in the pot <b>to impart flavor</b> to the non-sacred food.
<b>And we said</b> with regard to this <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted,</b> one can know whether the non-sacred food has acquired the flavor of <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> as <b>a priest can taste it. But</b> with regard to the prohibition of <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk, who can taste it? And</b> you, Rava, <b>said to us: Let</b> a gentile <b>cook taste it. So too</b> here, with regard to the food in the bowl, <b>let</b> a gentile <b>cook taste it.</b> Rava responded: <b>Indeed,</b> a gentile cook can discover whether the food in the bowl has absorbed the taste of blood. <b>When I said</b> my statement I was referring to a case <b>where there is no</b> gentile <b>cook</b> available.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> If <b>a fish was removed</b> from the fire and placed, still hot, <b>in a bowl</b> in which meat had been eaten, <b>Rav says: It is prohibited to eat</b> the fish <b>with</b> the milk dish <b><i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> since the fish has absorbed meat from the bowl. <b>And Shmuel says: It is permitted to eat</b> the fish <b>with <i>kutaḥ</i>.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>Rav says</b> that it is <b>prohibited</b> to eat the fish with <i>kutaḥ</i> because this <b>is</b> a case of <b>imparted flavor,</b> i.e., from the meat to the fish. <b>And Shmuel says</b> that it is <b>permitted</b> because the flavor is first imparted to the bowl, and only then from the bowl to the fish. This <b>is</b> therefore a case of <b>imparted flavor derived from imparted flavor.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And this</b> opinion <b>of Rav was not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference. As Rav arrived at the house of Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya, the son of his son. He felt</b> pain <b>in his eyes, and they prepared for him an ointment in an earthenware bowl</b> as a remedy. <b>Later they placed a dish for him in</b> that same bowl. Rav <b>tasted</b> in that dish <b>the flavor of the ointment</b> and <b>said: It imparts so much flavor!</b> Those present inferred that according to Rav, imparted flavor derived from imparted flavor is strong enough itself to impart flavor. The Gemara rejects this: <b>But</b> that <b>is not so,</b> and one cannot reach any general conclusions from this story. <b>It is different there, as</b> the ointment was <b>very bitter.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Elazar was standing before Mar Shmuel,</b> and <b>they brought before</b> Shmuel <b>a fish that had been removed</b> directly from the fire and placed <b>into a bowl</b> used previously for meat, <b>and he ate</b> it together <b>with <i>kutaḥ</i>.</b> Shmuel <b>gave</b> Rabbi Elazar some of this dish, <b>but</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>did not eat</b> it, as he was a student of Rav, who prohibited such mixtures. Shmuel <b>said to him: To your teacher,</b> Rav, <b>I gave</b> this dish <b>and he ate</b> from it, <b>yet you</b> will <b>not eat?</b> Later Rabbi Elazar <b>came before Rav,</b> and <b>said to him: Did</b> the <b>Master retract this <i>halakha</i>?</b> Do you permit this? Rav <b>said to him: God forbid that the progeny of Abba bar Abba,</b> i.e., Shmuel, <b>would feed me something that I do not hold</b> to be permitted. Shmuel never fed me such a dish.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Huna and Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi were sitting</b> down to eat. <b>One</b> of them was sitting <b>on this side of the ford of</b> the <b>Sura</b> River, <b>and</b> the other <b>one</b> was sitting <b>on that side of the ford. They brought</b> one <b>Sage a fish that had been removed</b> from the fire and placed <b>into a bowl</b> previously used for meat, <b>and he ate</b> it together <b>with <i>kutaḥ</i>. They</b> also <b>brought</b> the other <b>Sage figs and grapes during the meal, and he ate</b> them <b>but did not recite</b> a separate <b>blessing</b> over them, even though these foods were usually consumed following the main portion of the meal before reciting Grace after Meals, and a separate blessing was made on them.
One <b>Sage said to his colleague: Orphan!</b> Student without a teacher! <b>Would your teacher do this,</b> i.e., eat such fish with <i>kutaḥ</i>? <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage said to his colleague: Orphan! Would your teacher do this,</b> i.e., eat these fruits during a meal without reciting a blessing over them? One <b>Sage said to his colleague: I hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> who permits eating such fish with <i>kutaḥ</i>. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage said to his colleague: I hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, as Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches:</b> The blessing over the <b>bread exempts all</b> the other <b>types of food</b> eaten during a meal, including those usually eaten separately following bread, <b>and</b> likewise the blessing over <b>wine exempts all types of drinks.</b>
<b>Ḥizkiyya says in the name of Abaye:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is: If <b>a fish was removed</b> from the fire and placed <b>into a bowl</b> used for meat, <b>it is permitted to eat</b> it together <b>with <i>kutaḥ</i>.</b> But with regard to <b>a radish that one cut with a knife with which he had cut meat, it is prohibited to eat</b> that radish <b>with <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> contrary to Rav Kahana’s statement above.
The Gemara notes: <b>And this statement</b> applies only to <b>a radish,</b>

Daf 112a

<b>as due to its sharpness it absorbs</b> the fat on the knife. <b>But</b> if one cut <b>a cucumber</b> with the same knife, it does not absorb the fat to the same extent. One may therefore simply <b>scrape the place of the cut</b> to remove any fat residue, <b>and</b> then one may <b>eat</b> the cucumber with <i>kutaḥ</i>.
Likewise, <b>turnip stalks</b> cut with such a knife are <b>permitted</b> for consumption with <i>kutaḥ</i>. But <b>chard</b> cut with such a knife is <b>prohibited</b> for consumption with <i>kutaḥ</i>, as it absorbs flavor from the knife. <b>And if one alternated between</b> cutting chard <b>and turnip</b> stalks it is <b>permitted,</b> as the turnip stalks nullify the taste of the meat in the knife.
§ <b>Rav Dimi inquired of Rav Naḥman: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to placing a jug of salt,</b> used to salt meat, <b>alongside a jug of <i>kamka</i>,</b> i.e., <i>kutaḥ</i>, a milk dish? Need one be concerned lest some of the <i>kutaḥ</i> fall on the salt without his knowledge and ultimately contaminate his meat? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: It is prohibited</b> to place the two jugs next to each other. Rav Dimi further inquired: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a similar case involving a jug <b>of vinegar</b> used to season meat? Need one be concerned lest the <i>kutaḥ</i> fall into the vinegar? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: It is permitted</b> to place these two jugs next to each other.
Rav Dimi asked: <b>And what is different</b> about the vinegar? Rav Naḥman responded: <b>When you</b> have thought <b>about it</b> long enough to <b>eat a <i>kor</i> of salt,</b> you will know the reason. The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the reason</b> then? In <b>this</b> case of the salt, <b>the prohibited</b> substance <b>is substantive,</b> as the traces of <i>kutaḥ</i> are discernible and not nullified by the salt. <b>But</b> in <b>that</b> case of the vinegar, <b>the prohibited</b> substance <b>is not substantive,</b> since the <i>kutaḥ</i> melts away in the vinegar and will no longer impart flavor.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain young bird that fell into a jug of <i>kamka</i>,</b> i.e., <i>kutaḥ</i>. <b>Rav Ḥinnana, son of Rava of</b> the city of <b>Pashronya, permitted</b> the bird. <b>Rava said</b> about this: <b>Who is wise</b> enough <b>to</b> discern reasons to <b>permit</b> the food in difficult <b>cases like this, if not Rav Ḥinnana, son of Rava of Pashronya? He maintains</b> that <b>when Shmuel said</b> that <b>a salted</b> food imparts flavor <b>like a boiling</b> food, <b>that statement</b> applies only to a food so salty <b>that it is not eaten due to its salt, but this <i>kutaḥ</i></b> can still be <b>eaten due to,</b> i.e., despite, <b>its salt.</b> Therefore, it is as if both foods are cold and unsalted, and they do not impart flavor to one another, provided one rinses the area of contact.
The Gemara adds: <b>And this statement</b> applies only if the bird is <b>raw, but</b> if it is <b>roasted, it requires peeling</b> to remove the outer layer, since roasting softens the meat and causes it to absorb more flavor. <b>And if it has cracks [<i>pilei</i>], it is entirely forbidden,</b> because the milk is absorbed into the cracks. <b>And if it has been flavored with spices it is</b> likewise <b>entirely forbidden,</b> because the spices soften the meat and render it absorbent.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel says: It is prohibited to eat a loaf</b> of bread <b>upon which one cut</b> unsalted roasted <b>meat,</b> since the blood expelled from the roasted meat is absorbed in the loaf. The Gemara adds: <b>And this statement</b> applies only <b>if</b> the meat <b>is ruddy</b> from the blood it contains. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>this statement</b> applies only <b>if</b> so much blood was absorbed in the loaf that <b>it passed through</b> from one side of the loaf to the other and was visible from both sides. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>this statement</b> applies only <b>if</b> the liquid emitted by the roasted meat <b>is viscous. But</b> if it is <b>runny, we have no</b> problem <b>with it,</b> i.e., the loaf is permitted.
The Gemara relates: <b>Shmuel would throw to his dog</b> such a loaf of bread that he held was prohibited. <b>Rav Huna</b> would not eat the loaf himself but <b>would</b> rather <b>give it to his attendant.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>Whichever way you</b> look at it, Rav Huna’s behavior is problematic: <b>If</b> the loaf <b>is permitted, it is permitted for everyone,</b> including Rav Huna himself. And <b>if it is prohibited, then it is prohibited for everyone,</b> and he should not give it to his attendant.
