The Gemara explains: In fact, the loaf is permitted for consumption, and <b>Rav Huna is different, as he is of delicate constitution</b> and did not want to eat the loaf himself. The Gemara further relates: <b>Rava would eat</b> a loaf of this type, <b>and he would call</b> the red liquid <b>meat wine.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: One may not place a vessel under</b> roasting <b>meat</b> to catch the drippings of fat <b>until all the ruddiness of</b> the meat’s <b>appearance has dissipated.</b> Beforehand, though, one must be concerned that blood will fall with the drippings into the vessel, rendering the mixture and the vessel prohibited. The Gemara asks: <b>How do we know</b> when all the meat’s redness has disappeared? <b>Mar Zutra said in the name of Rav Pappa: As soon as its smoke rises,</b> one can be sure that all the blood has been expelled from the meat.
<b>Rav Ashi objects to this: But perhaps the underside</b> of the meat, which is closest to the coals, has been fully <b>roasted,</b> but its <b>upper</b> part is still <b>not roasted</b> and still expels blood at this stage. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said:</b> One who wishes to collect the drippings <b>has no remedy except</b> to <b>place two lumps of salt in it,</b> i.e., one in the receptacle under the meat and one on top, in the meat itself.

Daf 112b

Doing this will allow the blood dripping from the meat to stick to the salt on the sides of the vessel, while the fat will float to the top. <b>And</b> when emptying the receptacle, he should <b>tilt it</b> gently to pour the fat into another vessel without it mixing with the blood.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said to Rav Ashi: And did Shmuel</b> really <b>say this,</b> that once the meat’s ruddiness has dissipated it is permitted to place a receptacle underneath it? <b>But didn’t Shmuel say: It is prohibited to eat a loaf</b> of bread <b>upon which one cut</b> roasted <b>meat?</b> Apparently he holds that meat contains blood even after it has finished roasting. Rav Ashi replied: Shmuel holds that the meat no longer emits blood after its ruddiness has dissipated. And as for his ruling with regard to a loaf of bread, it <b>is different there, as due to the pressure of the knife</b> the meat <b>expels</b> more blood.
§ <b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> If <b>one salted fish and birds together,</b> the fish <b>are prohibited</b> for consumption due to the blood they absorb from the birds. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this ruling? <b>If</b> they were placed <b>in an unperforated vessel,</b> in which the blood emitted by the birds will pool, then <b>even</b> if one salted <b>a bird and</b> another <b>bird</b> together they should be <b>prohibited,</b> as the blood expelled from one bird will be absorbed by the other. And <b>if</b> the case involves <b>a perforated vessel,</b> out of which the blood can flow, then <b>even</b> if <b>fish</b> are salted with <b>birds</b> the fish should be <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the ruling is referring <b>to a perforated vessel. And</b> the <b>fish</b> are prohibited <b>because their skin is soft,</b> and therefore when they are salted <b>they expel</b> their blood <b>first, whereas</b> the skin of <b>birds</b> is <b>hard. After</b> the <b>fish finish</b> expelling their blood, the <b>birds</b> continue to <b>expel</b> their blood, <b>and then</b> the fish <b>absorb</b> blood <b>from them.</b> If one salts two birds together, they expel their blood simultaneously, and neither will absorb blood from outside while expelling its own.
The Gemara relates: <b>Meat of a slaughtered</b> animal <b>was salted for Rav Mari bar Raḥel together with</b> prohibited <b>meat of an animal that had a wound that would have caused it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>],</b> in a perforated vessel, as meat is generally salted. <b>He came before Rava</b> to ask whether the kosher meat was prohibited, as perhaps it would not have absorbed flavor from the non-kosher meat while itself expelling blood.
Rava <b>said to him:</b> When the verse states, with regard to forbidden foods: “These are <b>the unclean</b> to you” (Leviticus 11:31), the added definite article serves <b>to prohibit</b> not only their flesh but also <b>their juice</b> emitted by salting, <b>and their gravy, and their spices</b> with which they are cooked. Even while the kosher meat is emitting its blood, it still absorbs the juices of the non-kosher meat, which are absorbed more easily than blood.

Daf 113a

The Gemara objects: <b>But let</b> Rava <b>say to</b> him the same ruling by instead citing the seemingly more relevant statement <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel said: A salted</b> food imparts its flavor <b>like a boiling</b> food, <b>and a marinated</b> food <b>is</b> as absorbent <b>as a cooked</b> food. Clearly, the kosher meat absorbed flavor from the meat of the <i>tereifa</i> as it would have had they been cooked together.
The Gemara explains: <b>Had</b> Rava based his ruling only <b>on Shmuel’s</b> statement, <b>I would say</b> in response: <b>This statement</b> applies only to the absorption of <b>the blood of</b> the meat, <b>but</b> kosher meat is <b>not</b> prohibited if it absorbs only <b>the juices and gravy of</b> the meat of the <i>tereifa</i>. Since in this case the meat is salted in a perforated vessel, the blood from each piece runs out and is not absorbed by the other, and one might think that the kosher meat remains permitted. Rava’s interpretation of the verse in Leviticus <b>teaches us</b> that the juices and gravy of the meat of the <i>tereifa</i> must also be taken into account.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A kosher fish that one salted</b> together <b>with a non-kosher fish is permitted. What, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where they were both salted</b> and expel juices? This indicates that the kosher fish is not prohibited by the juices of the non-kosher fish, contrary to Rava’s statement. The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> this is referring to a case <b>where</b> the <b>kosher</b> fish was <b>salted and</b> the <b>non-kosher</b> fish was <b>unsalted.</b> Since an unsalted fish does not emit juices, the kosher fish does not absorb the flavor of the non-kosher fish.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause teaches: But if</b> the <b>kosher</b> fish <b>was salted and</b> the <b>non-kosher</b> fish was <b>unsalted</b> the kosher fish remains permitted, <b>it may be inferred that</b> in <b>the first clause we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where they are both salted.</b> The Gemara responds: The latter clause <b>is explaining</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the first clause. The <i>baraita</i> should be read as follows: <b>A kosher</b> fish <b>that one salted</b> together <b>with a non-kosher fish is permitted. How so?</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>if</b> the <b>kosher</b> fish <b>was salted and</b> the <b>non-kosher</b> fish was <b>unsalted.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>So, too, it is reasonable</b> that this is the meaning of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>as if it enters your mind</b> that <b>the first clause</b> is referring to a case where <b>both of them are salted,</b> one can claim: <b>Now</b> that the <i>baraita</i> has stated that even if <b>both of them are salted</b> the kosher fish is <b>permitted, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that the same applies in the less problematic case where the <b>kosher</b> fish was <b>salted and</b> the <b>non-kosher</b> fish was <b>unsalted?</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>If it is due to that</b> reason, <b>there is no</b> conclusive <b>argument.</b> It is possible that the first clause of the <i>baraita</i> is indeed referring to a case where both fish are salted, and the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> nevertheless <b>taught the latter clause to shed light on the first clause,</b> so <b>that you</b> should <b>not say: The first clause</b> is referring only to a case where the <b>kosher</b> fish was <b>salted and</b> the <b>non-kosher</b> fish was <b>unsalted, but</b> if they were <b>both salted,</b> then the kosher fish is <b>prohibited.</b> To rule this out, he <b>taught the latter clause,</b> which explicitly makes reference to a case where the <b>kosher</b> fish was <b>salted and</b> the <b>non-kosher</b> fish <b>unsalted,</b> which <b>by inference</b> indicates <b>that the first clause</b> is referring to a case where they are <b>both salted, and</b> teaches that <b>even so</b> the kosher fish is <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof against Rava’s ruling <b>from the latter clause of the latter clause,</b> i.e., the third clause of that <i>baraita</i>: <b>But if</b> the <b>non-kosher</b> fish <b>was salted and</b> the <b>kosher</b> fish was <b>unsalted,</b> the kosher fish is <b>prohibited.</b> One can infer from here that <b>it is</b> only if the <b>non-kosher</b> fish is <b>salted and</b> the <b>kosher</b> fish is <b>unsalted that</b> the kosher fish is <b>prohibited. But</b> if they were <b>both salted,</b> then the kosher fish is <b>permitted,</b> contrary to Rava’s ruling.
The Gemara rejects this: Perhaps the last section of the <i>baraita</i> uses this language only <b>since</b> it <b>teaches</b> in <b>the former clause,</b> i.e., the second clause: If the <b>kosher</b> fish was <b>salted and</b> the <b>non-kosher</b> fish <b>unsalted,</b> etc. The <i>baraita</i> therefore <b>taught the last clause as well</b> using parallel language: If the <b>non-kosher</b> fish was <b>salted and</b> the <b>kosher</b> fish <b>unsalted,</b> etc. But nothing can be derived from here with regard to a case where both fish were salted.
§ The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for remembering the three <i>halakhot</i> stated by Shmuel below: The manner in which blood is expelled from <b>meat;</b> salted meat <b>that is placed</b> on a vessel; an animal whose neck is broken before its soul <b>departs.</b>
<b>Shmuel says: Meat cannot be rid of its blood unless one salts it thoroughly and rinses it thoroughly</b> in water. <b>It was stated: Rav Huna says:</b> One must <b>salt and rinse</b> the meat in water. And it <b>was taught in a <i>baraita</i>:</b> One must <b>rinse</b> the meat, <b>and salt</b> it, <b>and</b> then <b>rinse</b> it again. The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> these two rulings <b>do not disagree. This</b> ruling of Rav Huna is referring to a case <b>where one</b> already <b>washed</b> the meat <b>in the slaughterhouse</b> before salting, whereas <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where one did not wash</b> the meat <b>in the slaughterhouse.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Dimi of Neharde’a would salt</b> meat <b>with coarse salt and</b> then <b>shake</b> the salt off the meat.
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya says: One does not presume</b> that there is <b>blood in the intestines,</b> and therefore they are not prohibited if they have not been salted. The Gemara comments: The Sages <b>interpreted</b> this statement as referring <b>to the rectum, the intestines, and the spiral colon.</b>
<b>Shmuel says: One may place salted meat only on a perforated vessel,</b> so that the expelled blood can run out. But if the vessel is not perforated then the blood will pool and be reabsorbed by the meat.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Sheshet would salt</b> meat <b>one bone,</b> i.e., one piece, <b>at a time.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that he would <b>not</b> salt <b>two</b> together? Could it be <b>because</b> the blood <b>leaves this</b> piece <b>and that</b> piece <b>absorbs</b> it? If so, with regard to <b>one</b> piece <b>as well,</b> one could claim that the blood <b>leaves this side</b> of the piece <b>and that side absorbs</b> it. <b>Rather,</b> there <b>is no difference</b> between one piece and two pieces, and one may salt even several pieces together.
<b>Shmuel says in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: One who breaks the neck of an animal</b> after it is slaughtered but <b>before its soul departs thereby makes the meat heavy.</b> The meat expels blood at the time of slaughter, but if one breaks the animal’s neck, excess blood is trapped inside and weighs down the meat. <b>And</b> by this action <b>he robs people,</b> as <b>he causes blood to be absorbed in the</b> animal’s <b>limbs,</b> and since he sells the meat by weight, people will pay extra to acquire the same amount of edible meat.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>what</b> case <b>is he speaking?</b> Does Shmuel mean that there is only one problem with this practice, namely, that it <b>renders the meat heavy and robs people since he causes blood to be absorbed in the</b> animal’s <b>limbs?</b> If so, it may be inferred that if one wishes to keep the meat <b>for himself,</b> one may <b>well</b> do so, since he is robbing no one. <b>Or perhaps</b> Shmuel is referring to two prohibitions, first, that the blood trapped in the meat renders it prohibited for consumption, and second, that of robbery. If so, then even if one wants to keep the meat <b>for himself,</b> it is <b>also prohibited.</b> The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who places</b> the meat of <b>birds with cheese on the table</b> upon which he eats <b>does not</b> thereby <b>violate</b> a Torah <b>prohibition.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara suggests: Since the mishna mentions only that placing meat of birds and milk on one table does not violate a Torah prohibition, one may <b>consequently</b> infer that if one <b>eats</b> them together he does <b>violate</b> a Torah <b>prohibition.</b> If so, <b>learn from</b> the mishna that <b>meat of birds in milk</b> is prohibited <b>by Torah law,</b> contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, who maintains that it applies by rabbinic law. The Gemara responds: <b>Say</b> that the mishna should be understood as follows: <b>One who places bird meat with cheese on the table will not</b> thereby <b>come to</b> violate a Torah <b>prohibition,</b> since eating the two together is a rabbinic prohibition, as Rabbi Akiva maintains.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> It is <b>prohibited to cook the meat of a kosher animal in the milk of</b> any <b>kosher animal,</b> not merely the milk of its mother, <b>and</b> deriving <b>benefit</b> from that mixture is <b>prohibited.</b> It is <b>permitted to cook the meat of a kosher animal in the milk of a non-kosher animal,</b> or <b>the meat of a non-kosher animal in the milk of a kosher animal, and</b> deriving <b>benefit</b> from that mixture is <b>permitted. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Cooking the meat of <b>an undomesticated animal or bird</b> in milk is <b>not</b> prohibited <b>by Torah law, as it is stated: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk”</b> (Exodus 23:19, 34:26; Deuteronomy 14:21) <b>three times.</b> The repetition of the word “kid” three times <b>excludes an undomesticated animal, a bird, and a non-kosher animal.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says</b> that <b>it is stated: “You shall not eat of any animal carcass”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:21), <b>and</b> in the same verse <b>it is stated: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk.”</b> This indicates that meat of an animal <b>that</b> is subject to be <b>prohibited due to</b> the prohibition of eating <b>an unslaughtered carcass</b> is <b>prohibited</b> for one <b>to cook in milk.</b> Consequently, with regard to meat of <b>birds, which</b> is subject to be <b>prohibited due to</b> the prohibition of eating <b>an unslaughtered carcass,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that it <b>would be prohibited to cook</b> it <b>in milk.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “In its mother’s milk,” excluding a bird, which has no mother’s milk.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Elazar said: The verse states: “And Judah sent the kid of the goats”</b> (Genesis 38:20).

Daf 113b

One may infer that <b>here,</b> since this verse specifies that it is referring to <b>a kid of the goats, consequently, anywhere</b> the word <b>“kid” is stated without specification, it means even a cow or a ewe.</b> Accordingly, the prohibition of meat cooked in milk applies to all kosher domesticated animals.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>derive from</b> that verse that in general, every instance of the word “kid” is referring to a goat, including the prohibition of meat cooked in milk? The Gemara answers: This cannot be, as <b>another verse is written: “And the skins of the kids of the goats”</b> (Genesis 27:16). This indicates that only <b>here</b> they are <b>kids of the goats, but anywhere</b> the word <b>“kid” is stated without specification, it means even a cow or a ewe.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But let us derive from</b> this verse as well that on the contrary, the word “kid” is always referring to a goat. The Gemara explains: These two examples <b>are two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., to teach the same matter, <b>and</b> as a rule, <b>any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their common element to other cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> this principle that two verses that come as one <b>do not teach</b> their common element to other cases, <b>but according to the one who says</b> that two verses that come as one do <b>teach</b> their common element to other cases, <b>what is there to say?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Two exclusions are written,</b> as both of the verses cited use the term “the goats.” The verses could have stated simply: <b>Goats,</b> but state <b>“the goats,”</b> with the definite article, teaching that it is only in these cases that the reference is specifically to a goat.
§ <b>Shmuel says:</b> Each of the Torah’s three mentions of the prohibition of not cooking a kid in its mother’s milk serves to include a different case. The first mention of the word <b>“kid”</b> serves <b>to include</b> liability for cooking in milk and eating forbidden <b>fats,</b> beyond the liability for eating forbidden fat per se. The second mention of the word <b>“kid”</b> likewise serves <b>to include</b> additional liability for cooking in milk and eating the meat of <b>a dead</b> animal carcass. Finally, the third mention of the word <b>“kid”</b> serves <b>to include</b> liability for cooking in milk and eating an animal <b>fetus.</b>
Each mention excludes a case as well: The first mention of the word <b>“kid”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> liability for cooking in milk and consuming <b>blood.</b> The second mention of the word <b>“kid”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> liability for cooking in milk and eating <b>the placenta</b> of an animal. The third mention of the word <b>“kid”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> liability for cooking in milk and eating the meat of <b>a non-kosher</b> animal.
Furthermore, the first instance of the phrase <b>“in its mother’s milk”</b> indicates that one is <b>not</b> liable for cooking meat <b>in the milk of a male</b> animal, in the rare case that a male might produce milk. The second instance of the phrase <b>“in its mother’s milk”</b> indicates that one is <b>not</b> liable for cooking meat <b>in the milk of</b> an already <b>slaughtered</b> animal, since it is considered milk only if given while the animal is alive. The third instance of the phrase <b>“in its mother’s milk”</b> indicates that one is <b>not</b> liable for cooking meat <b>in the milk of a non-kosher</b> animal.
The Gemara challenges: The word <b>“kid” is written</b> only <b>three</b> times, <b>and</b> yet <b>we expound</b> it to teach <b>six</b> different <i>halakhot</i>. The Gemara responds: <b>Shmuel maintains</b> that <b>a prohibition takes effect</b> even where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, <b>and</b> therefore the <b>prohibition of</b> forbidden <b>fat</b> in milk <b>and</b> the prohibition of <b>a dead</b> animal carcass in milk <b>are both derived from one verse,</b> as both are applications of the prohibition to an already prohibited item. The exclusion of <b>blood</b> from the prohibition <b>also</b> does not require its own verse, as blood <b>is not</b> considered <b>a kid</b> at all, <b>and likewise</b> there is no need for a verse to exclude <b>a placenta</b> from the prohibition, as it <b>is merely a secretion</b> of the animal, rather than a kind of meat. Therefore, <b>two</b> mentions of “kid” <b>are left; one</b> serves <b>to include a fetus, and one</b> serves <b>to exclude a non-kosher animal.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Shmuel</b> really <b>maintain</b> that <b>a prohibition takes effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists? <b>But didn’t Shmuel say in the name of Rabbi Elazar: From where</b> is it derived that <b>an impure priest who partakes of impure <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., the portion of produce designated for the priest, <b>is not</b> punished <b>with death</b> at the hand of Heaven as he would had the <i>teruma</i> been ritually pure? It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated,</b> with regard to the prohibition of an impure priest partaking of <i>teruma</i>: <b>“And die therein if they desecrate it”</b> (Leviticus 22:9), <b>to the exclusion of this</b> case of <i>teruma</i> that is impure, <b>which was already desecrated</b> before the priest ate it. Here, it seems, since impure <i>teruma</i> is already prohibited for consumption, the added prohibition of an impure priest partaking of <i>teruma</i> does not take effect.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that <b>in general</b> Shmuel maintains that <b>a prohibition takes effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, and it <b>is different there,</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i>, <b>as the Merciful One</b> expressly <b>excludes</b> impure <i>teruma</i> by the phrase <b>“and die therein</b> if they desecrate it,” and in this case the <i>teruma</i> is already desecrated. And <b>if you wish, say</b> that <b>in general Shmuel maintains</b> that <b>a prohibition does not take effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, <b>and here,</b> the case of meat cooked in milk, <b>is different, as the Merciful One</b> expressly <b>includes</b> the meat of an animal carcass and forbidden fat by the repetition of the word <b>“kid.”</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>this</b> statement of Shmuel with regard to meat cooked in milk is <b>his</b> own opinion, as he maintains that a prohibition takes effect where another prohibition already exists, and <b>that</b> statement with regard to <i>teruma</i> <b>is his teacher’s,</b> i.e., Rabbi Elazar’s, opinion, as he holds that a prohibition does not take effect where another prohibition already exists.
§ <b>Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami raised a dilemma to Rav:</b> If <b>one cooks</b> meat <b>in milk of a goat that has not</b> yet <b>nursed,</b> but that is about to give birth and already has milk, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rav <b>said to him: From</b> the fact that <b>it was necessary for Shmuel to say</b> that the phrase <b>“in its mother’s milk”</b> teaches: <b>And not in the milk of a male</b> animal, one can infer that <b>it is</b> only the milk of <b>a male</b> that is excluded, as the male <b>cannot attain the status of a mother. But</b> in <b>this</b> case, <b>since</b> the goat <b>will attain the status of a mother,</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> to cook meat in its milk.
It <b>was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who cooks</b> forbidden <b>fat in milk, Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi</b> disagree as to the <i>halakha</i>. <b>One says</b> that he <b>is flogged</b> for violating the prohibition of meat cooked in milk, <b>and one says</b> that he <b>is not flogged.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>they disagree about this: That the one who says</b> he <b>is flogged maintains</b> that <b>a prohibition takes effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, <b>and the one who says</b> he <b>is not flogged maintains</b> that <b>a prohibition does not take effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists.
The Gemara responds: <b>No; everyone</b> agrees that <b>a prohibition does not take effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, and therefore <b>everyone agrees that</b> one <b>is not flogged for eating</b> the mixture. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to cooking. The one who says</b> he <b>is flogged</b> holds that one who cooks violates only <b>one prohibition,</b> that of cooking meat in milk, since it is permitted to cook forbidden fat without eating it. Consequently, this is not a case of a prohibition taking effect where another prohibition already exists. <b>And the one who says</b> he <b>is not flogged</b> holds that it was <b>for this</b> reason that <b>the Merciful One expressed</b> the prohibition of <b>eating</b> meat cooked in milk in the Torah using <b>the language of cooking:</b> “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk.”

Daf 114a

This link between cooking and eating indicates that <b>since one is not flogged for eating</b> forbidden fat cooked in milk, as agreed upon above, one <b>also is not flogged for cooking</b> the two together.
<b>And some say</b> the opposite: <b>With regard to cooking, everyone agrees that</b> one <b>is flogged</b> for this act, since the principle of a prohibition not taking effect where another prohibition already exists is not relevant. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to eating. The one who says he is not flogged</b> applies the principle <b>that a prohibition does not take effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, and the fat was already prohibited for consumption in its own right before being cooked with milk. <b>And the one who says he is flogged</b> holds that it was <b>for this</b> reason that <b>the Merciful One expressed</b> the prohibition of <b>eating</b> meat cooked in milk using <b>the language of cooking,</b> to teach that <b>since one is flogged for cooking</b> forbidden fat in milk, one <b>also is flogged for eating</b> the product.
The Gemara suggests a third explanation of the dispute between Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi: <b>And if you wish, say</b> that <b>one Sage said one</b> statement <b>and one Sage said another</b> statement, <b>and they do not disagree,</b> as they are referring to different cases. The Sage who said that one is flogged is referring to the transgression of cooking forbidden fat with milk, whereas the one who said one is not flogged is referring to the consumption of forbidden fat with milk. Everyone agrees that a prohibition does not take effect where another prohibition already exists, and therefore one is flogged only for cooking forbidden fat in milk, but not for eating the two together.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>Tosefta</i> (8:3): <b>One who cooks</b> meat <b>in whey,</b> the liquid leftover after milk has been curdled, is <b>exempt</b> from lashes, as whey is not defined as milk for purposes of the prohibition. Likewise, for <b>blood that one cooked in milk,</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> as blood is not considered meat. Similarly, with regard to <b>the bones, the tendons, the horns, and the hooves that one cooked in milk,</b> he is <b>exempt.</b>
The <i>Tosefta</i> continues: By contrast, with regard to prohibited <b><i>piggul</i></b> meat, i.e., meat from an offering that was sacrificed with the intent to sprinkle its blood or partake of its meat beyond its designated time, <b>and</b> similarly prohibited <b><i>notar</i>,</b> meat from an offering whose period for consumption has expired, <b>and</b> the prohibited <b>impure</b> meat of an offering, <b>that one cooked in milk,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to be flogged for violating the prohibition of meat cooked in milk. This indicates that the prohibition applies to items already prohibited for consumption, contrary to the above opinion attributed to Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi.
The Gemara answers: <b>This <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>maintains</b> in general that <b>a prohibition takes effect</b> where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, whereas Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi are of the opposite opinion. It is conceivable that these Sages, who are <i>amora’im</i>, disagree with that <i>tanna</i>, as the issue of whether a prohibition takes effect where another prohibition already exists is a well-known dispute among the <i>tanna’im</i> themselves.
§ It was stated in the above <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who cooks</b> meat <b>in whey is exempt</b> from lashes. The Gemara comments: This ruling <b>supports</b> the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish, as we learned</b> in a mishna, with regard to liquids that render food susceptible to ritual impurity (<i>Makhshirin</i> 6:5): The halakhic status of <b>whey is like</b> that of <b>milk,</b> which is one of the liquids that render food susceptible to impurity, <b>and</b> the halakhic status of olive <b>secretion is like</b> that of <b>oil,</b> which also renders food susceptible to impurity. With regard to this mishna, <b>Reish Lakish says: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to <b>rendering seeds,</b> i.e., produce, <b>susceptible</b> to impurity. <b>But with regard to cooking meat in milk,</b> the halakhic status of <b>whey is not like</b> that of <b>milk.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: From the phrase <b>“in its mother’s milk” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the prohibition applies <b>to</b> the <b>mother</b> goat’s <b>milk. From where</b> do I derive that it also applies <b>to the milk of a cow and a ewe?</b>
<b>You</b> can <b>say an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as</b> a kid’s <b>mother, which is not prohibited for mating with</b> the kid, as they are of the same species, <b>is</b> nevertheless <b>prohibited for cooking with it,</b> as stated in the verse, <b>is it not right that a cow or a ewe, which are prohibited for mating with it,</b> as they are of different species, <b>should be prohibited for cooking with it?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> elsewhere: <b>“In its mother’s milk,”</b> a second time, to include a cow and a ewe.
The Gemara challenges the conclusion of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>But why do I</b> need <b>a verse? It was</b> just <b>derived</b> through the <i>a fortiori</i> inference.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> It is needed <b>because one can say that</b> the <b>refutation of the</b> <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference</b> is present <b>from the outset,</b> i.e., there is a difficulty with the comparison: <b>From where do you derive</b> the inference? It is derived <b>from its mother</b> goat, which the <i>baraita</i> presents as being treated more leniently than a cow or ewe since it may be mated with a kid. But there is a stringent aspect of the mother goat not shared by a cow or ewe: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about its mother?</b> It is unique <b>in that it is prohibited for slaughter with it,</b> since one may not slaughter an animal and its mother on the same day (see Leviticus 22:28). <b>Will you say</b> the same <b>about a cow, which is not prohibited for slaughter with it?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “In its mother’s milk,”</b> to include a cow and a ewe.
§ The above <i>baraita</i> accounts for two of the Torah’s three mentions of the phrase “in its mother’s milk.” The Gemara now addresses the third. It <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: From one instance of the phrase <b>“in its mother’s milk” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the prohibition applies <b>to the milk of its mother,</b> if the mother is less than a year old and has not yet entered the pen for the purpose of its owner’s separating the annual animal tithe. <b>From where</b> do I derive that it also applies <b>to the milk of its older sister,</b> i.e., one that is more than a year old that has already entered the pen for the animal tithe in the previous year?
<b>You</b> can <b>say an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as</b> a kid’s <b>mother, which enters the pen to be tithed with it, is</b> nevertheless <b>prohibited for cooking with it, is it not right that its sister, which does not enter the pen to be tithed with it, should be prohibited for cooking with it?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> elsewhere: <b>“In its mother’s milk,”</b> a third time, to include the older sister in the prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>But why do I</b> need <b>a verse? It was</b> just <b>derived</b> from the <i>a fortiori</i> inference. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> It is needed <b>because one can say</b> that the <b>refutation of</b> that <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference</b> is present <b>from the outset. From where do you derive</b> the inference? It is derived <b>from its mother.</b> But one may respond: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about its mother?</b> It is unique <b>in that it is prohibited for slaughter with it</b> on the same day. <b>Will you say</b> the same <i>halakhot</i> apply <b>to its older sister, which is not prohibited for slaughter with it?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “In its mother’s milk,”</b> including the older sister.
The Gemara continues: <b>We have found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that <b>its older sister</b> is included in the prohibition of meat cooked in milk. <b>From where</b> is it derived that the same applies to <b>its younger sister,</b> one that has not yet entered the pen for the tithe? The Gemara responds: <b>It is derived from between them,</b> i.e., from the combination of the mother and the older sister.
The Gemara elaborates on the need for both cases in order to derive the third: <b>From which</b> of the two cases <b>should it be derived?</b> If <b>it should be derived from its mother,</b> one can claim: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about its mother?</b> It is unique <b>in that it is prohibited for slaughter with it</b> on the same day, unlike the younger sister. One may respond: <b>Its older sister can prove</b> the point, since it is not prohibited for slaughter with the kid, but it is still included in the prohibition of meat cooked in milk. But this can be refuted as well: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about its older sister?</b> It is unique <b>in that it does not enter the pen to be tithed with it,</b> unlike the younger sister. One may respond that <b>its mother can</b> then <b>prove</b> the point, as it can enter the pen to be tithed with the kid and is still included in the prohibition.
<b>And</b> consequently, <b>the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point: <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case; <b>their common element</b> is <b>that</b> both the mother and older sister are <b>meat and</b> it is <b>prohibited to cook</b> them <b>in milk.</b> If so, <b>I will also include its younger sister</b> in the prohibition, <b>since it is</b> also <b>meat, and</b> therefore it is <b>prohibited to cook</b> it <b>in milk.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> the inclusion of <b>its older sister</b> in the prohibition can <b>also be derived from between them,</b> i.e., from the combination of the kid’s mother and a cow. Although both a cow and the mother possess unique stringencies not shared by the older sister, i.e., the prohibition of mating and of slaughtering with the kid, respectively, neither possesses both stringencies, and the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the older sister can be derived from their common element, i.e., that they are both meat and prohibited to cook in milk, as stated above. If so, what need is there to derive this <i>halakha</i> from the verse?
The Gemara responds: <b>Yes,</b> it <b>is indeed so;</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the older sister is derived from the common denominator of the mother and a cow. <b>Rather, why do I</b> need the verse’s additional mention of the phrase <b>“in its mother’s milk?” It is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: When the verse states: <b>“In its mother’s milk,” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> the prohibition to cook the kid <b>in its mother’s milk;</b>

Daf 114b

<b>from where</b> is it derived that the meat of a mother animal may not <b>itself</b> be cooked <b>in its</b> own <b>milk? Say an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as</b> with regard to an issue <b>where</b> the <b>fruit is not prohibited with</b> the <b>fruit,</b> i.e., <b>slaughter,</b> as it is permitted to slaughter two offspring of one mother on one day, the <b>fruit is</b> nevertheless <b>prohibited for slaughter with the mother, is it not right that</b> with regard to an issue <b>where</b> the <b>fruit is prohibited with</b> the <b>fruit,</b> i.e., <b>cooking,</b> as it is prohibited to cook a mother’s offspring with its milk, the <b>fruit,</b> i.e., the milk, <b>should be prohibited for cooking with the mother?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “In its mother’s milk,”</b> to prohibit the cooking of the meat of the mother in its own milk.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>a verse? It was</b> just <b>derived</b> <i>a fortiori</i>. <b>Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami said:</b> The verse is necessary <b>because one can say</b> that the case of <b>a horse born of</b> both a stallion and <b>mare</b> but which is <b>the brother of a mule,</b> i.e., its mother also bore a mule after being impregnated by a donkey, <b>proves</b> this <i>a fortiori</i> inference invalid. <b>As</b> here the <b>fruit is prohibited with</b> the <b>fruit, but</b> the <b>fruit is permitted with the mother.</b> One may not mate a horse with a mule, but one may mate a horse with its mother.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>There it is the seed of the father that effects</b> the prohibition of mating the mule with the daughter horse. The two may not be paired for reasons unrelated to their status as offspring of one mother. This ruling therefore proves nothing about the hypothesis that if two fruit cannot be paired, one can learn by <i>a fortiori</i> inference that the fruit cannot be paired with the mother.
And this explanation must be true, <b>as</b> the case of <b>a mule born of</b> a donkey and <b>a mare</b> and which is <b>the brother of a female mule proves. As</b> here one <b>fruit is permitted with</b> the other <b>fruit,</b> i.e., one may mate the male and female mules since they are of the same species, <b>and</b> yet the <b>fruit is prohibited</b> to be mated <b>with the mother,</b> i.e., the mare. This case illustrates that the prohibition of crossbreeding is contingent on paternity, and does not rest solely on the relation between the mother and the fruit.
<b>Rather, Mar, son of Ravina, said:</b> The <i>a fortiori</i> inference is invalid <b>because one can say that</b> the case of a male Canaanite <b>slave born of a female slave</b> and who is <b>the brother of a female freed</b> slave <b>proves</b> it invalid. <b>As</b> here the <b>fruit is prohibited with</b> the <b>fruit,</b> i.e., the slave may not engage in sexual intercourse with his freed sister, <b>and</b> yet the <b>fruit is permitted with</b> his slave <b>mother.</b>
The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>There it is the bill of manumission that effects</b> the prohibition. The slave is prohibited to his sister only because she has been freed, not because they are both fruit of one mother, <b>as</b> the case of a male <b>slave, son of a female freed</b> slave, and <b>the brother of a female slave proves. As</b> here the <b>fruit is permitted with</b> the <b>fruit,</b> i.e., he is permitted to his sister, since they are both slaves, <b>and</b> yet the <b>fruit is prohibited with</b> his released <b>mother,</b> as she is now considered a full-fledged Jew. Clearly the prohibition is entirely contingent on the emancipation of one of the slaves, irrespective of their relationship.
<b>Rather, Rav Idi bar Avin said:</b> The <i>a fortiori</i> inference is invalid <b>because one can say</b> that the case of <b>diverse kinds of seeds proves</b> it invalid. <b>As</b> it <b>is prohibited</b> to sow <b>fruit</b> of one species <b>with fruit</b> of another species, <b>and</b> yet it is <b>permitted</b> to sow all types of <b>fruit with the mother,</b> i.e., the ground, from which all fruit grows. The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>Isn’t fruit</b> of one species <b>with fruit</b> of another species <b>prohibited only by means of the mother,</b> i.e., the ground? The prohibition of sowing diverse seeds applies only when they are both sown in the ground, <b>as wheat and barley</b> can be placed <b>in</b> a single <b>jug and they are not prohibited.</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said:</b> The <i>a fortiori</i> inference is invalid <b>because one can say: What</b> is unique <b>about fruit with fruit,</b> e.g., the kid and its mother’s milk, which are prohibited for cooking together? They are unique <b>in that</b> they are <b>two</b> separate <b>bodies</b> that were never unified. Must <b>you say</b> the same prohibition of pairing applies <b>to</b> the <b>fruit with the mother,</b> i.e., the mother’s meat and its milk, <b>which</b> were once <b>one body? Due to this</b> reason, <b>the</b> extra <b>verse</b> stating: “In its mother’s milk,” <b>was necessary</b> to include the meat and milk of the same animal in the prohibition.
§ <b>Rav Ashi says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that meat</b> cooked <b>in milk is prohibited for consumption,</b> even though the verse explicitly prohibits only cooking? It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated</b> elsewhere: <b>“You shall not eat any abominable thing”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:3). This verse teaches that with regard to <b>any</b> practice <b>that I have made abominable,</b> i.e., forbidden, <b>to you,</b> the product <b>is prohibited for consumption.</b>
<b>And I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that meat cooked in milk is prohibited <b>with regard to consumption; from where</b> do I derive that it is also prohibited <b>with regard to benefit?</b> It is derived <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Wherever it is stated, “He shall not eat,”</b> or <b>“you,”</b> in the singular, <b>“shall not eat,”</b> or <b>“you,”</b> in the plural, <b>“shall not eat,” both a prohibition</b> against <b>eating and a prohibition</b> against deriving <b>benefit</b> are indicated. This is so <b>unless the verse specifies for you</b> that one may derive benefit, <b>in the manner that it specified for you with regard to an animal carcass,</b> from which the verse explicitly permits one to derive benefit, as it states: “You may sell it to a foreigner” (Deuteronomy 14:21). Accordingly, one may provide such meat <b>to</b> a gentile <b>resident alien</b> in Eretz Yisrael <b>by giving</b> it to him as a gift, <b>and to</b> any other <b>gentile by sale.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“You shall not eat of any unslaughtered animal carcass; you may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates, that he may eat it; or you may sell it to a foreigner;</b> for you are a sacred people to the Lord your God.” From this verse <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that it is permitted to provide such meat <b>to a resident alien through giving and to a gentile through selling. From where</b> is it derived that it is permitted to transfer an unslaughtered animal <b>to a resident alien through selling</b> as well? <b>The verse states: “You may give it to the stranger…or you may sell it,”</b> indicating that one has the option to do either of these.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>From where</b> is it derived that it is permitted <b>to a gentile through giving</b> as well? <b>The verse states: “You may give it</b>…<b>or you may sell it to a foreigner.”</b> Consequently, <b>one finds</b> that he may transfer an animal carcass to <b>both a resident alien and a gentile, both through selling or through giving.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> These <b>matters are</b> to be understood <b>as they are written;</b> one may transfer an unslaughtered animal carcass <b>to a resident alien</b> only <b>through giving, and to a gentile</b> only <b>through selling.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda?</b> The Gemara responds: Rabbi Yehuda holds that <b>if it enters your mind</b> to understand the verse <b>in accordance</b> with that which <b>Rabbi Meir says,</b> then <b>let the Merciful One write: You shall not eat of any animal carcass, you may give it to the resident alien who is within your gates that he may eat it and</b> also <b>you may sell it</b> to a foreigner. <b>Why do I</b> need the word <b>“or”</b> between these two options? <b>Learn from it that it comes to</b> teach that the <b>matters are</b> to be understood <b>as they are written: To a resident alien through giving</b> alone, <b>and to</b> any other <b>gentile through selling.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Meir</b> explain the wording of the verse? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Meir could <b>say to you</b> that <b>this</b> word <b>“or”</b> teaches one <b>to prioritize to giving to a resident alien over selling to a gentile. And Rabbi Yehuda</b> holds that the <b>priority of giving to a resident alien over selling to a gentile does not require a verse,</b> as <b>it is</b> based on <b>logical reasoning: You are commanded</b> by the Torah <b>to sustain this</b> resident alien, <b>but you are not commanded to sustain that</b> gentile.
§ The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> device for the topics that will be discussed: <b>Shabbat; plows; and diverse kinds of seeds; a mother and its offspring; and sending</b> away of the mother bird from <b>the nest.</b>
Rav Ashi stated above that the product of any practice described in the Torah as abominable is prohibited for consumption. The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b>

Daf 115a

then <b>let</b> the product of <b>an action</b> that desecrates <b>Shabbat,</b> e.g., food cooked on Shabbat, <b>be prohibited</b> for consumption, <b>as</b> desecration of Shabbat <b>is</b> a practice of which God states: <b>I have made</b> it <b>abominable to you,</b> in that it is prohibited to cook on Shabbat. How can this food be prohibited only to the one who cooked it as a penalty by rabbinic law, but be permitted to others (see 15a)?
The Gemara answers: A product of the desecration of Shabbat is an exception to the rule, as <b>the verse states</b> with regard to Shabbat: <b>“For it is sacred to you”</b> (Exodus 31:14). One may infer: <b>It,</b> Shabbat itself, <b>is sacred, but</b> the products of <b>actions</b> that desecrate <b>it are not sacred,</b> i.e., not prohibited.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: If <b>one plows with an ox and with a donkey</b> together, thereby violating the prohibition in Deuteronomy 22:10, <b>or</b> if <b>one muzzles the mouth of a cow and threshes with it,</b> thereby violating the prohibition in Deuteronomy 25:4, the seeds or threshed grain <b>should be prohibited</b> for consumption according to the above principle, <b>as</b> these are both practices <b>I have made abominable to you.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Now</b> that it has been established that products of desecration of Shabbat are permitted, one can derive the following using an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat, which is</b> treated more <b>stringently,</b> the products of prohibited <b>actions are permitted;</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> with regard to <b>these</b> prohibitions of plowing with an ox and a donkey and threshing with a muzzled animal, which are treated less stringently, that the products of prohibited actions should be permitted?
The Gemara challenges: <b>Diverse kinds of seeds</b> sown together <b>should be prohibited</b> for consumption, <b>as</b> this <b>is</b> a matter whose practice <b>I have made abominable to you.</b> The Gemara explains: One learns otherwise <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One revealed with regard to diverse kinds in a vineyard:</b> “You shall not sow your vineyard with two kinds of seed; <b>lest</b> the growth of the seed that you will sow <b>be forfeited [<i>pen tikdash</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:9). The Sages read the phrase “be forfeited [<i>pen tikdash</i>]” as though it states: <b>Lest it be burned [<i>pen tukad esh</i>],</b> indicating that diverse kinds in a vineyard must be destroyed so that no benefit is derived from them. Since this is stated specifically with regard to a vineyard, one can conclude <b>by inference that</b> other <b>diverse kinds of seeds are permitted.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But say</b> instead that the uniqueness of <b>diverse kinds in a vineyard</b> is that they <b>are prohibited both for consumption and for benefit,</b> whereas <b>diverse kinds of seeds are prohibited for consumption</b> but <b>are permitted for benefit.</b> The Gemara responds: One cannot say that diverse kinds of seeds are prohibited for consumption, as <b>they are juxtaposed</b> in the Torah <b>to diverse kinds of animals,</b> whose offspring are permitted. <b>As it is written: “You shall not let your cattle mate with a diverse kind; you shall not sow your field with two kinds of seed”</b> (Leviticus 19:19). The juxtaposition teaches that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>your cattle,</b> the animal <b>that comes from</b> diverse species <b>is permitted, so too,</b> with regard to <b>your field, that</b> produce <b>that comes from</b> diverse seeds <b>is permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>diverse kinds of animals themselves, from where do we</b> derive that their offspring is permitted? The Gemara answers: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One prohibits</b> the offspring of <b>diverse kinds</b> of animals for sacrifice <b>to the Most High</b> upon the altar (see 38b), learn <b>by inference that they are permitted to ordinary</b> people for consumption.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>A mother and its offspring</b> slaughtered on the same day <b>should be prohibited</b> for consumption, as this too is a practice made abominable. The Gemara answers: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One prohibits</b> an animal <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived, i.e., that is less than eight days old, as an offering <b>to the Most High</b> (Leviticus 22:27), learn <b>by inference that</b> such animals are <b>permitted to ordinary</b> people for consumption. The offspring of a mother slaughtered that day is also considered an animal whose time has not yet arrived, since the prohibition against slaughtering it is limited to that day.
The Gemara raises a final difficulty: If one violated the mitzva that mandates <b>sending</b> away the mother bird from <b>the nest,</b> as it is stated: “You shall not take the mother with the young. You shall in any way let the mother go” (Deuteronomy 22:6–7), and the court instructed him to set the mother bird free, that mother bird <b>should be prohibited</b> to all, as this practice is also abominable. The Gemara responds: <b>The Torah did not say: Send</b> it away, if doing so could lead <b>to a mishap.</b> If the bird were prohibited, the Torah would not have commanded one to send it away, as others might eat it unwittingly.
§ <b>Reish Lakish says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that meat</b> cooked <b>in milk is prohibited</b> for consumption? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to the Paschal offering: <b>“You shall not eat it partially roasted, nor boiled in any way”</b> (Exodus 12:9). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state:</b> “Boiled <b>in any way,”</b> since it could simply have stated: “Boiled.” <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states:</b> “Boiled <b>in any way?”</b> It is included <b>to tell you</b> that <b>there is another</b> manner of <b>cooking,</b> the product of <b>which is</b> prohibited <b>like this one. And which</b> cooking <b>is this? This is meat</b> cooked <b>in milk.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to</b> Reish Lakish:

Daf 115b

<b>Is that</b> derivation <b>that Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught ugly,</b> that you derive a new one? The verse states with regard to an animal’s blood: “You shall not eat it; you shall pour it upon the earth as water” (Deuteronomy 12:24), and the next verse adds: <b>“You shall not eat it;</b> that it may go well with you, and with your children after you.” Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi teaches that the redundant second verse is not referring to the prohibition of blood. Rather, <b>the verse is speaking of</b> the prohibition of <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk,</b> teaching that it is prohibited for consumption.
<b>Do you say</b> that <b>the verse is speaking of</b> the prohibition of <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk? Or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> referring <b>to one of the</b> other <b>prohibitions in the Torah? You say: Go out and learn from the thirteen hermeneutical principles,</b> one of which is: <b>A matter that is derived from its context. To what are the</b> adjacent <b>verses referring?</b> They are referring <b>to</b> consecrated animals that were redeemed, which are a combination of <b>two types:</b> They are non-sacred in that they may be eaten, but they are prohibited for shearing and work, like consecrated animals. <b>Here too,</b> one may conclude that the verse is referring <b>to</b> a prohibition that involves <b>two types</b> of food, i.e., the prohibition of meat cooked in milk.
Reish Lakish replied to Rabbi Yoḥanan: My exposition is still necessary, since <b>if</b> the source for the prohibition of eating meat cooked in milk were <b>from that</b> verse cited by Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi alone, <b>I would say</b> that <b>this statement</b> applies only <b>to</b> the prohibition of <b>eating</b> meat cooked in milk, <b>but not to</b> that of deriving <b>benefit</b> from it. The verse cited with regard to the Paschal offering <b>teaches us</b> that even deriving benefit is prohibited, just as it is prohibited to derive benefit from a disqualified Paschal offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>from where</b> does he derive that meat cooked in milk is prohibited <b>for benefit?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>He derives it from here,</b> as <b>it is stated here: “For you are a sacred [<i>kadosh</i>] people unto the Lord</b> your God. You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk” (Deuteronomy 14:21). <b>And it is stated below: “Neither shall there be a sodomite [<i>kadesh</i>] of the sons of Israel”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:18). The similar expressions teach that <b>just as below,</b> the prohibition of sodomy is a prohibition that involves enjoyment, i.e., deriving <b>benefit,</b> not eating, <b>so too here,</b> meat cooked in milk is prohibited <b>with regard to</b> deriving <b>benefit.</b>
<b>The school of Rabbi Eliezer taught:</b> The verse states: <b>“You shall not eat of any animal carcass;</b> you may give it to the stranger who is within your gates, that he may eat it; or you may sell it to a foreigner; for you are a sacred people to the Lord your God; you shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk” (Deuteronomy 14:21). <b>The Torah stated</b> the prohibition of meat cooked in milk after the <i>halakha</i> of an animal carcass to teach that <b>when you sell</b> a carcass to a gentile, <b>you shall not cook it</b> in milk <b>and</b> then <b>sell it,</b> i.e., meat cooked in milk is prohibited for benefit and may not be sold.
<b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The Torah states <b>three times: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk”</b> (Exodus 23:19, 34:26; Deuteronomy 14:21). <b>One</b> verse serves <b>to</b> teach <b>the prohibition</b> against <b>eating</b> meat cooked in milk, <b>and one</b> serves <b>to</b> teach <b>the prohibition</b> against deriving <b>benefit</b> from it, <b>and one</b> serves <b>to</b> teach <b>the prohibition</b> against <b>cooking</b> meat in milk.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Isi ben Yehuda says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that it is prohibited</b> to eat <b>meat</b> cooked <b>in milk? It is stated here: “For you are a sacred people</b> unto the Lord your God. You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk” (Deuteronomy 14:21). <b>And it is stated below: “And you shall be sacred men unto Me; therefore you shall not eat any flesh that is torn of animals in the field [<i>tereifa</i>];</b> you shall cast it to the dogs” (Exodus 22:30). <b>Just as below it is prohibited</b> to eat a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>so too here it is prohibited</b> to eat meat cooked in milk.
<b>And</b> from this <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that it is prohibited <b>for consumption. From where</b> do I derive that it is prohibited <b>for benefit</b> as well? <b>You</b> can <b>say</b> it can be derived by <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the prohibition against eating <b>the fruit of a tree during the first three years after its planting [<i>orla</i>],</b> which is treated less stringently <b>as no sin has been committed in</b> the planting of the tree and its production of fruit, <b>it is prohibited for benefit, is it not right that meat</b> cooked <b>in milk, with regard to which a sin has been committed, should be prohibited for benefit?</b>
The Gemara rejects this, as <i>orla</i> exhibits a unique stringency: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about <i>orla</i>?</b> It is unique <b>in that it never had a time when it was fit.</b> The same cannot be said about meat and milk, which were each permitted on their own before being cooked together.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let leavened bread on Passover prove</b> the point, <b>as it had a time when it was fit,</b> before Passover, <b>and</b> yet <b>it is prohibited for benefit.</b> The Gemara rejects this inference as well: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about</b> consumption of <b>leavened bread on Passover?</b> It is unique <b>in that it is punishable by <i>karet</i>,</b> unlike the prohibition of meat cooked in milk.
The Gemara comments: <b>Let</b> the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds in a vineyard prove</b> the point, <b>as</b> it <b>is not punishable by <i>karet</i>, and</b> yet <b>it is prohibited to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from the product.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need both Isi ben Yehuda’s <b>verbal analogy</b> to teach the prohibition of consumption and the <i>a fortiori</i> inference to teach the prohibition of benefit? <b>Let all of it,</b> both the prohibition of consumption and the prohibition against deriving benefit, <b>be derived</b> by an <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from <i>orla</i>: Just as <i>orla</i>,</b> which is treated less stringently, <b>as no sin has been committed in</b> the tree’s planting, is nevertheless <b>prohibited both for consumption and for benefit; is it not right that meat</b> cooked <b>in milk, with regard to which a sin has been committed,</b> should be <b>prohibited both for consumption and for benefit?</b>
The Gemara responds: That inference would be invalid <b>because one could say:</b> The cases of one <b>who plows with an ox and with a donkey, and</b> one <b>who muzzles the mouth of a cow and threshes with it prove</b> it invalid. <b>As</b> in those cases, <b>a sin has been committed through them, and</b> yet benefit from the products of these actions is <b>permitted.</b> One cannot refute a verbal analogy with logical reasoning.
The Gemara asks further: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>to say,</b> as was stated above, that the case of <b>diverse kinds in a vineyard proves</b> that benefit from meat and milk is prohibited? At that point, two other cases, <i>orla</i> and leavened bread on Passover, had already been offered as proof. Although they were rejected because they both possess a unique stringency, each lacks the stringency possessed by the other. Therefore, <b>let us say</b> that the case of <b><i>orla</i> proves</b> that the stringency for consumption of leavened bread on Passover, i.e., the penalty of <i>karet</i>, is irrelevant, and vice versa. <b>And let the inference revert</b> to its starting point, <b>and let</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to meat cooked in milk <b>be derived by</b> analogy from <b>the common element</b> of the two sources, i.e., the prohibition against both consumption and benefit.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> Such a derivation cannot be suggested, <b>because one can say</b> that the case of an unslaughtered <b>animal carcass proves</b> it invalid, <b>as</b> an animal carcass <b>is prohibited for consumption and</b> yet <b>it is permitted for benefit.</b>
<b>Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: We say in the name of Reish Lakish as follows:</b> For <b>any</b> analogy derived from <b>the common element</b> of two sources, <b>one can refute</b> the analogy only <b>by</b> invoking conflicting details of the two sources <b>themselves,</b> e.g., here, some stringency shared by <i>orla</i> and leavened bread, but not by meat cooked in milk. <b>One cannot refute</b> the analogy <b>from an external</b> case, as you do.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then the question remains: Why not <b>let</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>be derived by</b> analogy from <b>the common element</b> of <i>orla</i> and leavened bread on Passover? The Gemara responds: <b>Because</b> the analogy <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about the common element of</b> <i>orla</i> and leavened bread? It is unique <b>in that</b> they both involve produce <b>that grows from the ground,</b> whereas meat and milk do not grow from the ground.
The Gemara counters: <b>If so,</b> then <b>even now</b> that the Gemara has invoked diverse kinds in a vineyard to prove the point, the derivation <b>can be refuted</b> in the same manner: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about</b> the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds in a vineyard?</b> It is unique <b>in that</b> it involves produce <b>that grows from the ground.</b>
<b>Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: We say in the name of Reish Lakish as follows:</b> For <b>any</b> analogy derived from <b>the common element</b> of two sources, <b>one can refute</b> the analogy by invoking <b>any</b> factor shared by the two source cases but not by the target case. But this is insufficient to refute an analogy to <b>a single</b> source <b>from a single</b> source using the standard formulation: <b>No, if you say</b> the <i>halakha</i> applies to the source case, which possesses a unique factor X, must you say the same of the target case, which does not? <b>One can refute</b> such analogies using this formulation only by way of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference, i.e., if the unique factor X is a stringency. But <b>one cannot refute</b> it by simply mentioning <b>any</b> unique factor, e.g., that diverse kinds in a vineyard grow from the ground.
The Gemara counters: <b>But</b> one need not invoke the case of diverse kinds in a vineyard by itself, since it is invoked in addition to the cases of <i>orla</i> and leavened bread. Consequently, this is effectively a derivation from the common element of all three sources, not from one single case to another. If so, <b>let us refute</b> the derivation from <b>all of them: What</b> is unique <b>about all of</b> the cases? They are unique <b>in that</b> they involve produce <b>that grows from the ground.</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: We say in the name of Reish Lakish as follows:</b>

Daf 116a

As stated above, for any <i>a fortiori</i> inference of <b>a single</b> source <b>from a single</b> source, <b>one can refute</b> the derivation by invoking a unique <b>leniency</b> in the supposedly stringent case <b>and a stringency</b> in the lenient one, but <b>one cannot refute</b> it by simply mentioning <b>any</b> aspect unique to the first source. And for inferences of <b>one</b> source from <b>two other</b> sources <b>one can even refute</b> the derivation by mentioning <b>any</b> aspect unique to the first source.
For inferences of <b>one</b> source <b>from three</b> other sources, as suggested here, only <b>if the inference reverts</b> to its starting point, as each source possesses its own unique stringency, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> then <b>derived by</b> analogy from <b>the common element</b> of all of them, <b>can one refute</b> the inference by mentioning <b>any</b> factor unique to the source cases. <b>But if</b> the inference does <b>not</b> revert, <b>one can refute</b> the derivation only by invoking <b>a leniency and a stringency,</b> but <b>one cannot refute</b> it by mentioning <b>any</b> unique factor. The suggested inference does not revert, since the prohibition of diverse kinds in a vineyard possesses no stringent element that the other sources lack. Therefore, the fact that all the source cases involve produce is immaterial, and the inference from diverse kinds in a vineyard stands.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But let one refute</b> the inference as follows: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about diverse kinds in a vineyard?</b> They are unique <b>in that they had no time that they were fit.</b> The produce is forbidden as soon as it begins to grow, whereas meat and milk are prohibited only when they are cooked together. <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> If this suggestion was not employed, <b>that is to say that</b> even <b>the roots of diverse kinds in a vineyard are prohibited,</b> including the seeds and saplings from which the hybrid plants grow. <b>And they</b> too <b>had a time when they were fit, before taking root.</b> Consequently, the premise of the question must be false.
<b>Rav Shemaya bar Zeira raises an objection</b> to this conclusion from a mishna (<i>Kilayim</i> 7:8): If <b>one transfers a perforated pot</b> with seeds in it <b>into a vineyard, if</b> the size of the plant growing in the pot <b>increases</b> by one <b>two-hundredth</b> of its previous size, such that the permitted original plant is less than two hundred times the amount of the prohibited growth and insufficient to nullify it, the produce is <b>prohibited,</b> due to the prohibition against planting diverse kinds in a vineyard. One may infer: If it <b>increases, yes,</b> it is prohibited; but if it <b>does not increase, no,</b> it is permitted. Apparently, only the additional growth is prohibited, not the planted seeds or saplings.
<b>Abaye said: Two verses are written,</b> i.e., two separate terms in one verse indicate two separate prohibitions: The verse states: “You shall not sow your vineyard with two kinds of seed, lest the growth of the seed that you will sow be forfeited together with the increase of the vineyard” (Deuteronomy 22:9). <b>It is written: “Lest the growth be forfeited,”</b> indicating that it is prohibited only if it has grown, <b>and it is written: “Of the seed,”</b> from which it can be inferred that it is prohibited immediately when it is planted and takes root.
<b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? Abaye explains: If it was <b>planted initially</b> in the vineyard, it becomes prohibited immediately <b>upon taking root.</b> But in a case where it was <b>planted</b> elsewhere <b>and brought</b> into the vineyard later, e.g., in a perforated pot, then one must distinguish: If its size <b>increases</b> in the vineyard, <b>yes,</b> the growth is prohibited; if its size <b>does not increase, no,</b> it is not prohibited.
The Gemara notes: <b>The mishna,</b> which states that meat cooked in milk is prohibited for benefit, <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b> It is <b>prohibited to eat meat</b> cooked <b>in milk but</b> it is <b>permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it, <b>as it is stated: “For you are a holy people</b> to the Lord your God; you shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk” (Deuteronomy 14:21). And the verse <b>states elsewhere: “And you shall be holy people to Me;</b> therefore you shall not eat any flesh that is torn by animals [<i>tereifa</i>] in the field; you shall throw it to the dogs” (Exodus 22:30).
The use of the word “holy” in both verses indicates that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, it <b>is prohibited to eat</b> it <b>but</b> one <b>is permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it, as one may give it to the dogs, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to meat cooked in milk, it <b>is prohibited to eat</b> it <b>but</b> one is <b>permitted to</b> derive <b>benefit</b> from it.
§ The mishna states: <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Cooking the meat of <b>an undomesticated animal or a bird</b> in milk is not prohibited by Torah law, as it is stated: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk” (Exodus 23:19, 34:26; Deuteronomy 14:21), three times, excluding an undomesticated animal, a bird, and a non-kosher animal. The Gemara raises a difficulty: Other <i>halakhot</i> have already <b>been derived from these</b> mentions of the word “kid,” <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Shmuel</b> (see 113b).
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Akiva maintains</b> in general that <b>a prohibition takes effect</b> even where another <b>prohibition</b> already exists, <b>and</b> therefore forbidden <b>fat and</b> the meat of <b>a dead</b> animal, which are already prohibited, <b>do not require a verse</b> to teach that the prohibition of meat and milk applies to them. Furthermore, there is no need to derive from a verse that <b>a fetus</b> is included, as <b>it is a full-fledged kid.</b> Consequently, <b>all</b> three mentions of the word <b>remain for him</b> to expound that they serve <b>to exclude an undomesticated animal and a bird and a non-kosher animal.</b>
§ The mishna further teaches that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: It is stated: “You shall not eat</b> of any animal carcass” (Deuteronomy 14:21), and in the same verse it is stated: “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk.” This indicates that the meat of an animal that is subject to be prohibited due to the prohibition of eating an unslaughtered carcass is prohibited to cook in milk. Consequently, one might have thought it is prohibited to cook in milk the meat of a bird, which is subject to this prohibition. Therefore, the verse states: “In its mother’s milk,” to exclude a bird, which has no mother’s milk. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili,</b> who excludes a bird from the prohibition of meat and milk due to the phrase “in its mother’s milk,” <b>and</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who comes to the same conclusion as Rabbi Yosei HaGelili based upon the phrase “You shall not cook a kid”?
The Gemara explains: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to <b>an undomesticated animal. Rabbi Yosei HaGelili maintains</b> that the prohibition of cooking the meat of <b>an undomesticated animal</b> in milk applies <b>by Torah law,</b> as an undomesticated animal has mother’s milk, <b>but Rabbi Akiva maintains</b> that the prohibition of cooking the meat of <b>an undomesticated animal</b> in milk applies only <b>by rabbinic law,</b> as it is excluded by the phrase: “You shall not cook a kid.”
<b>If you wish, say</b> instead that there is a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to the meat of <b>a bird</b> itself: <b>Rabbi Akiva maintains</b> that the prohibitions of <b>an undomesticated animal and a bird do not</b> apply <b>by Torah law; but</b> it may be inferred from his statement that <b>they are prohibited by rabbinic law. And Rabbi Yosei HaGelili maintains</b> that <b>a bird is not prohibited even by rabbinic law.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>That</b> distinction <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In the locale of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> where his ruling was followed, <b>they would cut down trees</b> on Shabbat <b>to prepare charcoal</b> from them with which to light a fire <b>to fashion iron</b> tools with which to circumcise a child on Shabbat. In Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion, not only does the mitzva of circumcision override Shabbat, but also any action required for the preparation of the tools necessary for the circumcision likewise overrides Shabbat. The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>In the locale of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili they would eat bird meat</b> cooked <b>in milk.</b> Evidently, Rabbi Yosei HaGelili maintains that the prohibition of meat cooked in milk does not include birds.
The Gemara relates: <b>Levi happened</b> to come <b>to the house of Yosef the bird hunter [<i>rishba</i>]. They served him the head of a peacock [<i>tayvasa</i>] in milk and he did not say anything to them. When</b> Levi <b>came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: Why did you not excommunicate</b> these people who eat bird meat cooked in milk, contrary to the decree of the Sages?
Levi <b>said to him: It was</b> in <b>the locale</b> of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira, and I said:</b> Perhaps <b>he taught them</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said</b> that the phrase “in its mother’s milk” serves to <b>exclude a bird, which does not have mother’s milk.</b> If so, I could not prohibit it to them, and I certainly could not excommunicate them for following their ruling.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The congealed milk in <b>the stomach</b> of the animal <b>of a gentile and of an</b> unslaughtered <b>animal carcass is prohibited.</b> With regard to <b>one who curdled milk by</b> using <b>the skin of the stomach of a kosher</b> animal as a coagulant to make cheese, which may then have the taste of meat cooked in milk,

Daf 116b

<b>if</b> the measure of the skin is enough <b>to impart flavor</b> to the milk, <b>that</b> cheese <b>is prohibited.</b> In the case of <b>a kosher</b> animal <b>that suckled</b> milk <b>from a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> the milk in <b>its stomach is prohibited,</b> as the milk is from the <i>tereifa</i>. If it was <b>a <i>tereifa</i> that suckled</b> milk <b>from a kosher</b> animal, the milk in <b>its stomach is permitted,</b> as the milk is from the kosher animal. In both cases, the milk that an animal suckles has the status of the animal from which it was suckled, and not that of the animal which suckled, <b>because</b> the milk <b>is collected in its innards</b> and is not an integral part of its body.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna makes reference to the stomach of the animal of a gentile and that of an unslaughtered carcass. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>the stomach of</b> an animal slaughtered by <b>a gentile is not</b> itself <b>a carcass?</b> Why does the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna differentiate between them? <b>Rav Huna said:</b> The mishna <b>here</b> is not referring to an animal slaughtered by a gentile. Rather, <b>we are dealing with</b> a Jew who <b>purchases a kid from a gentile</b> and slaughters it himself. Therefore, the kid is not prohibited as a carcass, <b>but we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps it suckled from a <i>tereifa</i></b> animal, and it is therefore prohibited.
The Gemara asks: <b>And are we concerned</b> that <b>perhaps it suckled from</b> an animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>? But didn’t we learn</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 3:8): <b>One may purchase eggs from gentiles, and we are not concerned</b> that perhaps the eggs came <b>from a carcass nor</b> that they came <b>from a <i>tereifa</i>.</b> The Gemara answers: Indeed, there is no concern that the kid might have suckled from a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rather, say</b> that <b>we are concerned</b> that <b>perhaps it suckled from a non-kosher</b> animal, and therefore the milk in its stomach is prohibited.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is different</b> about <b>a <i>tereifa</i> that we are not concerned</b> that perhaps the animal suckled from it, <b>and what is different</b> about <b>a non-kosher</b> animal <b>that we are concerned?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>A <i>tereifa</i></b> animal <b>is not common,</b> whereas <b>a non-kosher</b> animal <b>is common,</b> and it is therefore more likely that the young animal suckled from one.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If</b> suckling from a non-kosher animal is <b>common,</b> then <b>let us be concerned even with regard to our</b> own animals. The Gemara responds: <b>We</b> Jews, <b>who separate ourselves from</b> non-kosher animals, <b>when we see them we</b> immediately <b>distance</b> our suckling animals from them. Therefore, <b>the Sages did not issue a decree with regard to</b> animals purchased from Jews. But as for the gentiles, <b>who do not separate themselves from</b> non-kosher animals, <b>when they see them they do not distance</b> their kosher animals from them. Consequently, <b>the Sages issued a decree with regard to</b> animals purchased from a gentile.
<b>And Shmuel said</b> a different explanation of the mishna’s language: The <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>is teaching</b> only <b>one</b> <i>halakha</i>: The congealed milk in <b>the stomach of</b> an animal <b>slaughtered by a gentile is</b> like <b>a carcass,</b> and it is therefore prohibited.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Shmuel</b> actually <b>say this?</b> Does he hold that the milk in the stomach of an unslaughtered animal is prohibited as if it were part of its body? <b>But didn’t Shmuel say: For what</b> reason did the Sages <b>prohibit the cheese of gentiles?</b> It is <b>because they curdle it with the skin of the stomach of a carcass.</b> One may infer <b>consequently</b> that congealed milk, or rennet, from the <b>stomach</b> of a gentile’s animal <b>is itself permitted</b> and would not render the cheese prohibited if used as a coagulant.
The Gemara answers: That is <b>not difficult.</b> Elsewhere (<i>Avoda Zara</i> 29b), Rabbi Yehoshua teaches two reasons for the prohibition on gentile cheese. Initially, he held it to be prohibited because it is curdled using rennet from the stomach of an animal carcass. He later adopted the opinion that such rennet is permitted, and that the cheese is prohibited because it is curdled using rennet from the stomach of calves used for idol worship, which is prohibited. Therefore, the mishna <b>here,</b> which states that the rennet in a carcass’s stomach is itself prohibited, was taught <b>before</b> Rabbi Yehoshua’s <b>retraction,</b> while Shmuel’s statement <b>there,</b> that the Sages prohibited gentile cheese only because it is curdled with the skin of the stomach of a carcass, was <b>after</b> Rabbi Yehoshua’s <b>retraction.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: In the case of <b>a kosher</b> animal <b>that suckled</b> milk <b>from a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> the milk in its stomach is prohibited, whereas if a <i>tereifa</i> suckled milk from a kosher animal, the milk in its stomach is permitted. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But doesn’t the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>teach:</b> The congealed milk in <b>the stomach</b> of the animal <b>of a gentile and of a carcass is prohibited?</b> What is the difference between the milk found in the stomach of a <i>tereifa</i> in the second clause and the milk found in the stomach of an unslaughtered carcass in the first clause?
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> In fact, milk found in the stomach of a carcass is not itself prohibited. <b>The first clause</b> of the mishna prohibits it only because one who partakes of it <b>looks like one who eats carcasses,</b> which is repulsive. By contrast, <b>here,</b> with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, the consumption of milk found in its stomach is less repulsive, as here <b>there is</b> at least <b>slaughter</b> of the animal.
