<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>But is it not</b> possible to claim <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> that milk found in the stomach of a <i>tereifa</i> should be prohibited? <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a carcass, which is</b> so <b>repulsive that</b> even <b>if you permit</b> the milk in <b>its stomach</b> people <b>will not come to partake of</b> the meat, <b>you</b> nevertheless <b>said</b> the milk is <b>not</b> permitted for consumption, is it <b>not all the more so</b> with regard to <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> that has been <b>slaughtered,</b> which is not as repulsive, <b>such that if you permit</b> the milk in its stomach people might <b>come to partake of it?</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> This question is <b>not difficult.</b> The first clause of the mishna <b>here,</b> which teaches that the milk in the stomach of a carcass is prohibited, was taught <b>before</b> Rabbi Yehoshua’s <b>retraction</b> cited above, whereas the latter clause <b>there,</b> that milk from the stomach of a <i>tereifa</i> is permitted, was taught <b>after</b> Rabbi Yehoshua’s <b>retraction.</b> A mishna can sometimes preserve an older ruling and then immediately teach a contradictory later ruling, because <b>a mishna does not move from its place.</b> Since the first clause of the mishna was already canonized, it was not removed, despite Rabbi Yehoshua’s change of opinion.
§ <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: One may curdle</b> milk <b>with</b> rennet extracted from <b>the stomach of carcasses, but one may not curdle</b> milk <b>with</b> rennet from <b>the stomach of</b> animals <b>slaughtered by a gentile. Rabbi Shimon bar Abba said before</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this ruling? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who said: A gentile’s presumed intention</b> during slaughter <b>is for idol worship.</b> Therefore, the prohibition against deriving benefit from an animal slaughtered in idol worship applies to it, and this prohibition includes the contents of its stomach that are not actually part of its body. By contrast, a carcass is prohibited only for consumption, and the prohibition does not extend to the contents of its stomach.
Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba <b>said to</b> Rabbi Shimon bar Abba: <b>Rather, in accordance with whose</b> opinion could this ruling be? Of course it is the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
The Gemara relates: <b>When Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One may curdle</b> milk <b>both with</b> rennet from <b>the stomach of a carcass and with</b> rennet from <b>the stomach of</b> an animal <b>slaughtered by a gentile, as</b> there is <b>no</b> need <b>to be concerned for the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> According to this account, Rabbi Yoḥanan does not maintain that a gentile’s presumed intention is for idol worship.
The Gemara concludes: <b>And</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is: <b>One may not curdle</b> milk <b>with the skin of the stomach of a carcass, but one may curdle</b> milk <b>with</b> rennet from <b>the stomach of a carcass and with</b> rennet from <b>the stomach of</b> an animal <b>slaughtered by a gentile, and with</b> rennet from <b>the stomach of a kosher</b> animal <b>that suckled from a <i>tereifa</i>, and all the more so with</b> rennet from <b>the stomach of a <i>tereifa</i></b> animal <b>that suckled from a kosher</b> animal. <b>What is the reason</b> for these lenient rulings? <b>The milk collected in</b> a stomach <b>is merely secretion</b> and is not considered food that can be prohibited.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Although animal fats and blood are similar in that they are both prohibited by Torah law and punishable by <i>karet</i>, there are elements more <b>stringent in</b> the prohibition of <b>fat than in</b> that of <b>blood, and</b> likewise there are elements more <b>stringent in</b> the prohibition of <b>blood than in</b> that of <b>fat.</b> The elements more <b>stringent in</b> the prohibition of <b>fat are</b> the following: The first is <b>that</b> with regard to <b>fat</b> of an offering,

Daf 117a

one who derives benefit <b>from it</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. <b>And</b> second, one is <b>liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> if it was from an offering that was slaughtered with the intent to sprinkle its blood or partake of it beyond its designated time, <b>and</b> due to the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>,</b> if it was from an offering whose period for consumption has expired. <b>And</b> third, if one is ritually impure, he is liable due to the prohibition of partaking of it while <b>impure. This is not so with regard to blood,</b> as one is not liable in these cases for violating the prohibitions of <i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, and partaking of offerings while impure, but rather is liable only for violating the prohibition of consuming blood.
<b>And</b> the more <b>stringent</b> element <b>in</b> the prohibition of <b>blood</b> is <b>that</b> the prohibition of <b>blood applies to domesticated animals, undomesticated animals, and birds, both kosher and non-kosher, but</b> the prohibition of forbidden <b>fat applies only to a kosher domesticated animal.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> According to the mishna, one who consumes forbidden fat of an offering is liable for misuse of consecrated property. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yannai said:</b> They are derived from a verse, <b>as the verse states</b> that the sacrificial portions of a bull brought for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest must be burned upon the altar: <b>“As it is taken off from the bull of the peace offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:10). <b>But what, then, do we learn from the bull of the peace offering?</b> Everything that is specified with regard to a peace offering is stated with regard to this bull as well (see Leviticus 4:8–9).
Rather, <b>this</b> phrase initially <b>comes to teach</b> a <i>halakha</i> about the bull brought as an offering for an unwitting sin of the anointed priest, <b>but it turns out</b> that <b>it</b> actually <b>derives</b> a <i>halakha</i> from that case, as the verse <b>juxtaposes the bull of the peace offering to the bull of the anointed priest.</b> It teaches that <b>just as the bull of the anointed priest,</b> as an offering of the most sacred order, <b>is subject to</b> the prohibition on <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, as offerings of the most sacred order are called “the sacred items of the Lord” (see Leviticus 5:15), <b>so too</b> the sacrificial portions of <b>the bull of the peace offering,</b> including its forbidden fat, are <b>subject to misuse</b> of consecrated property, even though it is an offering of lesser sanctity and is considered the property of the owner before slaughter.
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina said to</b> Rabbi Yannai: <b>Is that</b> derivation <b>that Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>taught unattractive,</b> that you derive a new one? He taught that when the Torah states with regard to peace offerings, which are of lesser sanctity: <b>“All the fat is the Lord’s”</b> (Leviticus 3:16), it serves <b>to include the sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity in</b> the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, even though the prohibition is stated explicitly only with regard to offerings of the most sacred order.
<b>Abaye said:</b> Rabbi Yannai’s derivation <b>was necessary, as, if the Merciful One had written</b> only the verse “All <b>the fat</b> is the Lord’s,” <b>I would say</b> that the <b>fat</b> of offerings of lesser sanctity, <b>yes,</b> they are included in the prohibition, but the <b>diaphragm and</b> the <b>two kidneys</b> of such offerings are <b>not,</b> even though they are also burned upon the altar. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “As it is taken off</b> from the bull of the peace offering,” to teach that even these portions are subject to the prohibition of misuse.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if the Merciful One had written</b> only the phrase: <b>“As it is taken off</b> from the bull,” <b>I would say</b> that the prohibition applies only to those portions that are found in a bull, and that <b>the fat of</b> a sheep <b>tail, which is not</b> found <b>in a bull,</b> is <b>not</b> included. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “All the fat</b> is the Lord’s,” to teach that the prohibition of misuse applies to all portions of offerings of lesser sanctity, including a sheep tail, which is referred to as fat in Leviticus 3:9.
<b>Rav Mari said to Rav Zevid: If</b> a sheep <b>tail is called “fat,” it should be prohibited for consumption,</b> like forbidden fat. Rav Zevid <b>said to</b> Rav Mari: <b>With regard to your</b> claim, <b>the verse states:</b> “You shall eat no <b>fat, of ox, or sheep, or goat”</b> (Leviticus 7:23). This teaches that the Torah designates as forbidden fat only <b>an item that is</b> found <b>equally in an ox, and a sheep, and a goat.</b> Since the ox and goat do not have a tail that consists of a large amount of fat, the sheep’s fatty tail is not prohibited.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> a different explanation: <b>It is called “the fat tail,”</b> but <b>it is not called</b> simply: <b>Fat, without specification.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so</b> that the addition of a modifier indicates that the tail is not truly fat, then one who derives benefit <b>from</b> the tail <b>should not be</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property either. <b>Rather, it is clear</b> that the correct answer is <b>as</b> stated <b>by Rav Zevid.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>This is not so with regard to blood,</b> as one who derives benefit from blood is not liable for misuse of consecrated property. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Ulla said: The verse states</b> with regard to blood: “For the life of the flesh is in the blood, and I have given it <b>to you</b> upon the altar to make atonement for your souls” (Leviticus 17:11). The term “to you” indicates that <b>it shall be yours,</b> rather than consecrated property, and is therefore not subject to the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property. <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> a different derivation. By using the term <b>“to make atonement,”</b> the verse teaches that God is saying: <b>I gave it to</b> achieve <b>atonement, but</b> not to be subject <b>to</b> the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is derived from the latter part of <b>the verse,</b> which <b>states:</b> “For <b>it is</b> the blood that makes atonement for the soul” (Leviticus 17:11). The term “it is” teaches that the status of the blood remains as it is, i.e., <b>it is before atonement as</b> it is <b>after atonement.</b> As the Gemara will state, there is a principle that once the mitzva involving a consecrated item has been performed, the item is no longer subject to the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property. Accordingly, the term “it is” teaches that <b>just as after atonement,</b> i.e., after the blood has been sprinkled upon the altar, it is <b>not subject to</b> the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, as the mitzva has already been performed, <b>so too, before atonement,</b> i.e., before the blood has been sprinkled upon the altar, it is <b>not subject to</b> the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> if the term “it is” teaches that the status of the blood remains the same before and after atonement, one can <b>say</b> just the opposite: <b>It is after atonement as</b> it is <b>before atonement. Just as before atonement</b> the blood <b>is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>so too, after atonement it is subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. The Gemara responds: This cannot be the case, since as a rule, <b>there is no item whose mitzva has been performed and</b> is still subject to the prohibition of <b>misusing</b> of consecrated property.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is there <b>no</b> such case? <b>But there is</b> the mitzva of the daily <b>removal of the ashes</b> of offerings burned on the altar, <b>the mitzva of which has been performed, and</b> yet one who derives benefit <b>from it</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>as it is written:</b> “And he shall take up the ashes of what the fire has consumed of the burnt offering on the altar, <b>and he shall put them beside the altar”</b> (Leviticus 6:3). The ashes must be left there, where they are absorbed into the ground, and one who removes and derives benefit from them violates the prohibition against misuse of consecrated property, even though their mitzva has been performed. This contradicts the principle posited above.
The Gemara answers: The principle does not apply in that case, <b>because</b> the mitzva of <b>the removal of the ashes and the</b> matter of the four white <b>priestly vestments</b> worn by the High Priest on Yom Kippur, which may not be used again, are both specified as exceptions to the <i>halakha</i> that the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property does not apply after their mitzva has been performed. Consequently, they <b>are two verses that come as one,</b> i.e., they share a unique <i>halakha</i> not found elsewhere. <b>And</b> as a rule, <b>any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their common element to apply to other cases. The principle therefore remains in place.
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: <b>This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that the verse: “And he shall take off the linen garments, which he wore when he went into the Sanctuary, <b>and shall leave them there”</b> (Leviticus 16:23), <b>teaches that</b> these four white garments worn by the High Priest on Yom Kippur are not fit for further use, and <b>they require interment. But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Dosa, who said</b> that the verse teaches only <b>that</b> the High Priest <b>may not use</b> the vestments <b>on Yom Kippur</b> in <b>a different</b> year, but they are fit for an ordinary priest and do not require interment, <b>what is there to say?</b> If the priestly vestments are not an exception to the <i>halakha</i> that there is no prohibition of misuse of consecrated property after the performance of a mitzva, the removal of the ashes remains as the only exception. Why, then, does it not serve as a paradigm for other instances in the Torah?
The Gemara responds: <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>because</b> the cases of the <b>removal of the ashes and the heifer whose neck is broken</b> to atone for an unsolved murder (Deuteronomy 21:1–9) <b>are two verses that come as one,</b> as it is also prohibited to derive benefit from the heifer after its mitzva is performed. <b>And any two verses that come as one do not teach</b> their common element to apply to other cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that two verses that come as one <b>do not teach</b> their common element to apply to other cases, <b>but according to the one who says</b> that two verses that come as one do <b>teach</b> their common element to apply to other cases, <b>what is there to say?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Two</b>

Daf 117b

<b>exclusions are written</b> in these two cases, which indicate that this <i>halakha</i> applies to them alone. <b>Here,</b> with regard to the removal of ashes, <b>it is written: “And he shall put it”</b> (Leviticus 6:3), indicating that this <i>halakha</i> applies to “it,” and nothing else. <b>There,</b> with regard to the heifer whose neck is broken, <b>it is written: “Whose neck was broken”</b> (Deuteronomy 21:6). This superfluous description teaches that the <i>halakha</i> that the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property is in effect even after the performance of a mitzva applies solely to this case and should not be extended to others.
The Gemara returns to the three phrases from Leviticus 17:11 cited above as teaching that the blood of offerings is not subject to the prohibition of misuse of consecrated property: <b>And why do I</b> need all <b>three verses</b> stated <b>with regard to blood?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>One</b> term serves <b>to exclude</b> blood <b>from</b> the prohibition of <b><i>notar</i>.</b> If one consumed the blood of such an offering, he is not liable for consuming <i>notar</i> as one who consumed the flesh would be. Rather, he is liable for violating only the prohibition against consuming blood. <b>And one</b> term serves <b>to exclude</b> blood <b>from</b> the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>and one</b> other term serves <b>to exclude</b> it <b>from</b> the prohibition of consumption of offerings in a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b> If one consumed this blood in a state of ritual impurity, he is liable only for consuming blood, but not for consuming consecrated food while ritually impure.
<b>But no verse is required</b> to exclude this blood <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> an offering sacrificed with intention to consume it beyond its designated time, consumption of which is punishable by <i>karet</i>, as this exception is already derived from another source. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 43a): Concerning <b>any</b> item <b>that has permitting factors, either with regard to</b> consumption by <b>a person or with regard to</b> burning on <b>the altar, one is liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>. But</b> the permitting factor itself is not subject to <i>piggul</i>, and the <b>blood</b> of an offering <b>is itself a permitting factor,</b> as consumption of the offering by a person or by the altar is only permitted after the blood has been sprinkled on the altar. Therefore, the blood is not subject to the prohibition of <i>piggul</i>.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> All foods that became ritually impure through contact with a source of impurity transmit impurity to other food and liquids only if the impure foods measure an egg-bulk. In that regard, the Sages ruled that even if a piece of meat itself is less than an egg-bulk, <b>the</b> attached <b>hide,</b> even if it is not fit for consumption, joins together with the meat to constitute an egg-bulk. <b>And</b> the same is true of <b>the</b> congealed <b>gravy</b> attached to the meat, although it is not eaten; <b>and</b> likewise <b>the spices</b> added to flavor the meat, although they are not eaten; <b>and the meat residue</b> attached to the hide after flaying; <b>and the bones; and the tendons; and</b> the lower section of <b>the horns,</b> which remains attached to the flesh when the rest of the horn is removed; <b>and</b> the upper section of <b>the hooves,</b> which remains attached to the flesh when the rest of the hoof is removed.
All these items <b>join together</b> with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk <b>to impart the impurity of food.</b> Although if any of them was an egg-bulk they would not impart impurity of food, when attached to the meat they complete the measure. <b>But</b> they do <b>not</b> join together to constitute the measure of an olive-bulk required to impart <b>the impurity of animal carcasses.</b>
<b>Similarly,</b> there is another item that imparts impurity of food but not impurity of animal carcasses: In the case of <b>one who slaughters a non-kosher animal for a gentile and</b> the animal <b>is</b> still <b>twitching</b> and comes into contact with a source of impurity, the animal becomes impure with impurity of food and <b>imparts impurity of food</b> to other food, <b>but</b> does <b>not</b> impart <b>impurity of animal carcasses until</b> it <b>dies, or until one severs its head.</b> The mishna summarizes: The Torah <b>included</b> certain items <b>to impart impurity of food beyond those which it included to impart impurity of animal carcasses.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>the meat residue</b> attached to the hide after flaying <b>that</b> was <b>collected, if there is an olive-bulk of it in one place</b> it imparts impurity of an animal carcass, and one who contracts impurity from it and then eats consecrated foods or enters the Temple is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i>. By collecting it in one place, the person indicates that he considers it as meat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the attached hide joins together with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food even though it is not fit for consumption. This is because the hide acts as a protective cover for the meat. But it does not join to constitute the measure of an olive-bulk required to impart the impurity of animal carcasses. The Gemara notes: <b>We learn</b> in the mishna <b>that which the Sages taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: An appendage that serves as <b>protection</b> joins together with food <b>with regard to a light</b> level of <b>impurity,</b> such as the impurity of food, which can be transmitted only to food but not to people or vessels. <b>But protection</b> attached to food does <b>not</b> join together with food <b>with regard to a severe</b> level of <b>impurity,</b> such as the impurity of an animal carcass, which can be transmitted even to people and vessels.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>protection</b> joins together with food <b>with regard to a light</b> level of <b>impurity?</b> The Gemara answers that it is derived from a verse, <b>as the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> With regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of imparting impurity of food, the verse states: “And if anything falls from their carcass <b>upon any sowing seed</b> that is sown, it is pure. But if water is put upon the seed, and any of the carcass falls on it, it is impure for you” (Leviticus 11:37–38). The phrase “upon any sowing seed” indicates that the entire seed is susceptible to impurity when it is in a state where it is <b>typical for people to take it out</b> to the field <b>for sowing:</b> This applies to <b>wheat in its shell, and barley in its shell, and lentils in their shells.</b> This demonstrates that shells and other components that protect the food are considered part of the food with regard to a light level of impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>protection does not</b> join together with the food <b>with regard to a severe</b> level of <b>impurity?</b> The Gemara answers that it is <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the impurity of a carcass, the verse states: “And if any animal of which you may eat dies, one who touches <b>its carcass</b> shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39). This indicates that only one who touches the flesh of the carcass becomes impure, <b>but</b> one who touches the <b>hide</b> of the carcass <b>upon which there is not an olive-bulk of flesh</b> does <b>not</b> become impure.

Daf 118a

One <b>might</b> have thought that only one who touches the flesh of the carcass becomes impure, but <b>one who touches the external</b> side of the hide of the carcass that is <b>aligned with the flesh,</b> but does not touch the flesh itself, <b>does not become impure.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “One who touches its carcass <b>shall be impure</b> until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39). It is derived from the term “shall be impure” that even one who touches the hide in this manner becomes impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying?</b> The first clause of the <i>baraita</i> teaches that the hide does not impart impurity of a carcass while the latter clause teaches that one who touches the hide does become impure with the impurity of a carcass. <b>Rava said, and some say it unattributed:</b> The <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete and this</b> is what <b>it is teaching:</b> The term <b>“its carcass”</b> teaches that one who touches the flesh of a carcass becomes impure <b>but</b> one who touches the <b>hide</b> of a carcass <b>upon which there is not an olive-bulk of flesh</b> does <b>not</b> become impure. <b>And</b> even if the volume of the <b>hide</b> together with the flesh <b>adds up to an olive-bulk,</b> the hide does not join together with the flesh to constitute the measure of an olive-bulk required to impart impurity of an animal carcass.
One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I remove</b> from the category of impurity of a carcass <b>even a hide upon which there is an olive-bulk of flesh</b> with regard to <b>one who touches the external</b> side of the hide of the carcass that is <b>aligned with the flesh</b> but does not touch the flesh itself. One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>he does not become impure</b> in such a case, <b>and</b> that the hide in this case <b>does not even constitute a handle</b> of the flesh, which would render one who touches it impure as though he touched the flesh itself.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Shall be impure,”</b> from which it is derived that even though an appendage that serves as protection for the flesh does not join together with the flesh to constitute the measure of an olive-bulk required to impart the impurity of animal carcasses, it is considered a handle of the flesh, which does impart impurity. Therefore, if there is an olive-bulk of flesh attached to the hide, one who touches the outside of the hide becomes impure, even if he did not touch the flesh.
§The Gemara discusses the transmission of impurity of food with regard to accessories that serve as a handle and that provide protection. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Okatzin</i> 1:1): With regard to <b>any</b> appendage <b>that</b> serves as <b>a handle,</b> i.e., a part that one holds while eating the food, <b>but</b> does <b>not</b> provide <b>protection,</b> the attached food becomes <b>impure</b> if the handle comes into contact with a source of impurity, <b>and</b> the handle <b>transmits impurity</b> from the attached food to other foods that come into contact with the handle. <b>But</b> the handle <b>does not join together</b> with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
With regard to any appendage that provides <b>protection, even if</b> it does <b>not</b> serve as <b>a handle,</b> the attached food becomes <b>impure</b> if the protection comes into contact with an impure item, <b>and</b> the protection <b>imparts impurity, and it</b> also <b>joins together</b> with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. With regard to an appendage that does <b>not</b> serve as <b>a handle nor</b> as <b>protection,</b> the attached food does <b>not</b> become <b>impure</b> if the appendage comes into contact with a source of impurity, <b>nor</b> does the appendage <b>impart impurity.</b> In addition, it does not join together with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>Where</b> is this <i>halakha</i> that <b>handles</b> are susceptible to and impart impurity <b>written?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written</b> with regard to the impurity of food: <b>“But if water is put on the seed, and any of the carcass falls on it, it is impure for you”</b> (Leviticus 11:38). It is derived from the term <b>“for you”</b> that <b>any</b> part <b>needed for your</b> use of the food is susceptible to impurity and imparts impurity, <b>including the handles</b> that facilitate the consumption of the food.
<b>And</b> furthermore <b>it is written</b> with regard to the impurity of a carcass: <b>“And if any animal which is for you</b> to consume <b>dies,</b> one who touches its carcass shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39). The term <b>“for you”</b> indicates that <b>any</b> part <b>needed for your</b> use of the carcass imparts impurity, <b>including the handles.</b> One who touches the handle of an item that is impure with impurity of a carcass becomes impure as though he touched the carcass itself. These two verses teach that <b>a handle</b> transmits impurity both <b>with regard to importing</b> impurity into the attached food <b>and with regard to exporting</b> impurity from the attached food.
<b>A verse is not needed</b> to derive that <b>protection</b> both <b>imports and exports</b> impurity. This <i>halakha</i> <b>is inferred <i>a fortiori</i> from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a handle: If a handle, which</b> is treated more leniently than protection because it <b>does not protect</b> the food, nevertheless both <b>imports and exports</b> impurity, then with regard to <b>protection,</b> which is treated more stringently than a handle because it protects the food, should it <b>not all the more so</b> import and export impurity?
Since this is so, <b>why do I</b> need the verse <b>that the Merciful One writes</b> from which it is derived that <b>protection</b> is considered part of the food with regard to ritual impurity, i.e., the verses: “Upon any sowing seed that is sown…It is impure for you” (Leviticus 11:37–38)? <b>Conclude from</b> these verses that protection not only imparts impurity, but even <b>joins together</b> with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But say</b> that these verses should be interpreted differently: <b>A handle,</b> which is treated more leniently than protection, is considered part of the food such that it <b>imports but does not export</b> impurity. <b>Protection,</b> which is treated more stringently than a handle, is considered like food <b>to import and export</b> impurity. <b>But</b> it is <b>not</b> derived that <b>a handle exports</b> impurity nor that <b>protection joins together</b> with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
The Gemara explains: <b>You cannot say</b> that <b>a handle</b> is considered part of the food such that it <b>imports but does not export</b> impurity for the following reason: <b>Now</b> that the handle is considered part of the food with regard to <b>importing</b> impurity into the food, <b>is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to state that it <b>exports</b> impurity? If a handle can cause ritually pure food attached to it to become impure, certainly it can transmit the impurity of impure food attached to it to other foods. Consequently, since a handle both imports and exports impurity, it is inferred <i>a fortiori</i> that protection also imports and exports impurity. It is therefore derived from the verse concerning appendages that serve as protection that protection joins together with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But say</b> instead that <b>a handle,</b> which is treated more leniently than protection, is considered part of the food such that it <b>exports but does not import</b> impurity. <b>Protection,</b> which is treated more stringently than a handle, both <b>exports and imports</b> impurity. <b>But</b> it is <b>not</b> derived that <b>a handle imports</b> impurity <b>nor</b> that <b>protection joins together</b> with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
The Gemara explains: There is <b>an additional</b> derivation with regard to <b>a handle,</b> as <b>it is written</b> with regard to the impurity of vessels: “And everything upon which any part of their carcass falls shall be impure; whether <b>an oven, or a range for pots, it shall be broken</b> in pieces; they are impure, and shall be impure for you” (Leviticus 11:35).
It is derived from the term <b>“for you”</b> that <b>any</b> part <b>needed for your</b> use of a vessel has the impurity status of the vessel itself, <b>including the handles.</b> Therefore, if the vessel comes into contact with a source of impurity, the handle is considered part of the vessel and is also rendered impure. Consequently, there are two derivations with regard to a handle: One teaches that a handle imports impurity into the object to which it is attached, and the other teaches that a handle exports impurity from the object. It is derived through <i>a fortiori</i> inference from the <i>halakha</i> of a handle that protection both imports and exports impurity, and therefore the verse that states “Upon any sowing seed” teaches that protection joins together with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
The Gemara asks: With regard to these three verses that are interpreted as referring to handles, one of which discusses the impurity of food, one of which discusses the impurity of vessels, and one of which discusses the impurity of carcasses, <b>which of them is superfluous</b> such that one can derive from it that a handle does not merely export impurity from the food but imports impurity to the food as well? All of these verses are necessary to teach that a handle exports impurity.
The Gemara elaborates on the question: <b>Let the Merciful One write</b> that a handle exports impurity <b>with regard to</b> the impurity of <b>seeds,</b> i.e., food, <b>and let those</b> matters, i.e., that it exports the impurity of vessels and animal carcasses, <b>be derived from it.</b> But one cannot infer from the impurity of food that a handle exports the impurity of vessels, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about seeds?</b> It is notable <b>in that they have a greater</b> susceptibility to <b>impurity.</b> Food is susceptible to even second-degree impurity, whereas vessels are susceptible to only first-degree impurity. Likewise, one cannot derive from the impurity of food that a handle exports the impurity of an animal carcass because the impurity of food applies to more items, as is taught in the mishna that some items are susceptible to the impurity of food but not to the impurity of animal carcasses.
<b>Let the Merciful One write</b> that a handle exports impurity <b>with regard to</b> the impurity of <b>an oven,</b> i.e., vessels, <b>and let those</b> matters, i.e., that it exports the impurity of food and the impurity of an animal carcass, <b>be derived from it.</b> But this inference is also not valid, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about</b> the impurity of <b>an oven?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> a vessel <b>transmits impurity</b> to foods not only through contact but also <b>through its airspace,</b> whereas those other types of impurity do not share this element of stringency.
<b>Let the Merciful One write</b> that a handle exports impurity <b>with regard to</b> the impurity of an animal <b>carcass, and let those</b> matters, i.e., that it exports the impurity of food and of vessels, <b>be derived from it.</b> But this inference is also not valid, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about</b> the impurity of <b>a carcass?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> a carcass <b>transmits impurity to a person, and transmits impurity to</b> one <b>carrying</b> the carcass even if he is not touching it, <b>and</b> its <b>impurity emanates from its body</b> and does not originate from an external source. Those other types of impurity do not share these elements of stringency.
The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> of <b>one</b> of these three types of ritual impurity <b>cannot be derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of any <b>one</b> of the others. Yet, one of the verses is still superfluous because one can <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>one</b> of these three types <b>from</b> the other <b>two.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Which</b> can one <b>derive</b> from the other two? <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> that a handle exports impurity <b>with regard to</b> the impurity of <b>seeds,</b> i.e., food, <b>and derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from those</b> two other cases, the impurity of carcasses and of vessels. But this inference is not valid, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about those</b> cases? They are notable <b>in that they become ritually impure without</b> first being <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity by coming into contact with liquid. <b>Shall you say</b> the same <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to seeds, which</b> do not share this element of stringency, as food <b>can become impure only</b> after first being <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity by coming into contact with liquid?
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> This element of leniency is not unique to the impurity of food. <b>Produce that is not rendered susceptible</b> to impurity by coming into contact with liquid <b>is equivalent to an oven whose construction is not complete.</b> An oven whose construction is incomplete is also not susceptible to impurity.
<b>Rather, refute</b> this derivation <b>in the following manner: What</b> is notable <b>about those</b> cases of impurity of carcasses and vessels? They are notable <b>in that they become impure</b> even <b>without contact.</b> An oven becomes impure if a creeping animal is within its airspace, and the impurity of an animal carcass originates from its own body without contact with an external source. <b>Shall you state</b> the same <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to seeds, which become impure only through contact?</b>
<b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> that a handle exports impurity <b>with regard to</b> the impurity of <b>an oven,</b> i.e., vessels, <b>and derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from those</b> cases, the impurity of food and carcasses. But this derivation is not valid, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about those</b> cases of the impurity of food and carcasses? They are notable <b>in that they are food.</b> Therefore, their <i>halakhot</i> cannot necessarily be applied to an oven and other vessels that are not food.
<b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> that a handle exports impurity <b>with regard to a carcass and derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from those</b> cases of the impurity of food and vessels. The Gemara responds: <b>Yes, it is indeed so. Rather,</b> since one can derive in such a manner that a handle attached to a carcass imparts impurity, <b>why do I</b> need the verse to state the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a handle</b> with regard to the impurity <b>of a carcass? If it is not</b> needed for the <b>matter of a handle</b> with regard to the impurity of <b>a carcass, apply it</b> to the <b>matter of a handle in general</b> with regard to food, and derive from it that a handle imports impurity to the food.
Therefore, in summary, one can derive that <b>a handle imports</b> impurity and that <b>a handle exports</b> impurity, and one can infer that protection imports and exports impurity <i>a fortiori</i> from the <i>halakha</i> of a handle. It is therefore derived from the verse concerning protection that <b>protection joins together</b> with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But it is still necessary</b> for the verse to state the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a handle</b> exports impurity with regard to the impurity <b>of a carcass; as, if the Merciful One had not written</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a handle <b>with regard to</b> impurity of <b>a carcass, I would say: It is sufficient for the</b> conclusion that <b>emerges from</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference to be like</b> its <b>source.</b> In this case, a <i>halakha</i> with regard to the impurity of carcasses which is inferred <i>a fortiori</i> from the cases of impurity of food and impurity of vessels is no more stringent than the source from which it is derived. <b>Just as</b> handles in <b>these</b> cases of impurity of food and vessels <b>do not transmit impurity to a person, so too</b> the handle of <b>a carcass does not transmit impurity to a person.</b> Therefore, the verse from which it is derived that a handle exports the impurity of a carcass <b>is</b> necessary, and cannot be applied to the matter of importing impurity.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, it is necessary</b> for the verse to state the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a handle</b> with regard to the impurity <b>of a carcass, but it is not necessary</b> for the verse to state the <i>halakha</i> of <b>protection</b> with regard to the impurity <b>of a carcass. With regard to what <i>halakha</i> does the Merciful One write</b> that verse? <b>If</b> it is teaching that protection <b>joins together</b> with the carcass to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity, <b>you said</b> that protection <b>does not join together</b> with the carcass to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. <b>And</b> if it is teaching that protection <b>exports</b> the impurity of a carcass, it is not necessary to teach that, because that <i>halakha</i> <b>is inferred <i>a fortiori</i> from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a handle.</b>
<b>Rather, if it is not</b> needed for the <b>matter of protection of a carcass, apply it</b> to the <b>matter of the handle of a carcass. And if it is not</b> needed for the <b>matter of a handle of a carcass, apply it</b> to the <b>matter of a handle in general,</b> and derive from it that a handle imports impurity. Therefore, in summary, one can derive that <b>a handle exports</b> impurity and that <b>a handle imports</b> impurity, <b>and</b> one can derive from the verse concerning protection with regard to the impurity of food that <b>protection joins together</b> with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.

Daf 118b

The Gemara asks: Why is it assumed that if the verse is not needed for the matter of protection of a carcass, it should be applied to the matter of a handle in general? <b>Say</b> that <b>if</b> the verse <b>is not</b> needed for the <b>matter of protection of a carcass, apply it</b> to the <b>matter of protection in general</b> with regard to food. Although it is already written: “Upon any sowing seed” (Leviticus 11:37), two verses are necessary to teach the <i>halakha</i> of protection with regard to food: One verse to teach that <b>protection imports</b> impurity <b>and</b> one to teach that <b>protection joins together</b> with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. <b>But</b> there is <b>no</b> source from which to derive that <b>a handle imports</b> impurity.
The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> that a handle imports impurity is not derived from the superfluous verse written with regard to the impurity of a carcass. <b>Rather,</b> it is necessary to return to the explanation that was initially proposed, i.e., that it is written with regard to the impurity of food: “It is impure for you” (Leviticus 11:38), from which it is derived that any part needed for your use of the food imparts impurity, including handles. It was asked with regard to this derivation: Say that this verse teaches that a handle exports impurity but not that it imports impurity. The Gemara suggests: That question is not difficult. <b>From the outset, when</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a handle is written:</b> “But if water is put upon the seed, and any of their carcass falls on it, it is impure for you” (Leviticus 11:38), <b>it is written</b> in the context <b>of importing</b> impurity. Therefore, it is inferred <i>a fortiori</i> that a handle exports impurity from the <i>halakha</i> that it imports impurity, and it is derived <i>a fortiori</i> from the <i>halakhot</i> of a handle that protection both imports and exports impurity. It is also derived that protection joins together with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity from that which is written: “On any sowing seed.”
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if that is so, <b>why do I</b> need the verse to teach the <i>halakha</i> of <b>protection with regard to a carcass,</b> as it is written: “Shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:39)? The Gemara answers: It is necessary <b>for the matter itself,</b> to teach that the <i>halakha</i> of protection is applicable to the impurity of a carcass.
The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to what</b> <i>halakha</i> is this taught? <b>If</b> it teaches that protection <b>joins together</b> with the carcass to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity, <b>you said</b> in the mishna that protection <b>does not join together</b> with the carcass to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. <b>If</b> it teaches that protection <b>imports and exports</b> the impurity of a carcass, it is not necessary for the verse to teach this <i>halakha</i> because <b>it is inferred <i>a fortiori</i> from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a handle.</b> The Gemara answers: Sometimes there is <b>a matter that</b> could be <b>inferred <i>a fortiori</i>,</b> and <b>the verse</b> nevertheless <b>takes the trouble and writes it</b> explicitly.
The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> one may ask: With regard to <b>protection in general,</b> i.e., with regard to food, it was established that the verse is not necessary to teach that it imports and exports impurity, and therefore the verse teaches that protection joins together with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. <b>I will say to you</b> instead that the verse teaches that protection <b>imports</b> impurity, <b>and</b> the reason that the verse teaches this <i>halakha</i> even though it could be inferred <i>a fortiori</i> is because sometimes there is <b>a matter that</b> could <b>be inferred <i>a fortiori</i></b> and <b>the verse</b> nevertheless <b>takes the trouble and writes it</b> explicitly.
The Gemara answers: <b>Where it is</b> possible <b>to interpret</b> the verse in a manner that a novelty is derived, <b>we interpret</b> it in such a manner and do not maintain that the verse teaches that which could be inferred <i>a fortiori</i>.
The Gemara returns to the previous proposal to derive that a handle imports impurity from the verse concerning protection of a carcass based on the reasoning that if the verse is not needed for the matter of protection of a carcass, it should be applied to the matter of a handle in general. Previously, the Gemara challenged this derivation: If the verse is not needed for the matter of protection for the impurity of a carcass, it should be applied to the matter of protection in general. <b>Rav Ḥaviva said</b> in response: The <i>halakha</i> of <b>protection of a carcass is different</b> because it imports and exports impurity but does not join together with the carcass to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. <b>Since</b> the protection <b>serves as a handle</b> in that it only imports and exports impurity, <b>we apply its</b> novelty <b>to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a handle</b> and not to the <i>halakhot</i> of protection.
§Previously it was derived that protection joins together with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity from that which is written: “On any sowing seed that is sown” (Leviticus 11:37), indicating that the entire seed is susceptible to ritual impurity when it is in a state where it is typical for people to take it out to the field for sowing, e.g., wheat and barley in their shells. <b>Rav Yehuda bar Yishmael objects to this</b> from <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 2:3): <b>The protrusion of a pomegranate joins together</b> with the pomegranate to constitute the measure of an egg-bulk that is required to impart impurity, because it provides protection for the fruit. <b>But its flower does not join together</b> with the pomegranate in that regard because it does not provide protection for the fruit; rather, it provides protection for the protection of the fruit.
Rav Yehuda bar Yishmael asks: <b>And why</b> does the protrusion join together with the pomegranate to constitute an egg-bulk? <b>Read here</b> that the verse states: <b>“On any sowing seed,”</b> indicating that the entire seed is susceptible to ritual impurity when it is in a state where it is typically taken out to the field for sowing. <b>But</b> pomegranates <b>are not</b> typically taken out to the field for sowing with their protrusions, since they are usually planted in the field as seedlings.
<b>And furthermore,</b> one can object to this derivation from <b>that which we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>The hide and the</b> congealed <b>gravy</b> attached to the meat, <b>and the spices,</b> and the meat residue, and the bones, and the tendons, and the lower section of the horns, and the section of the hooves, all <b>join together</b> with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk <b>to impart impurity of food. From where do we</b> derive that these protections, although they are not sown together with the food, join together with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity?
<b>Rather, three terms</b> with the root <i>zayin</i>, <i>reish</i>, <i>ayin</i> <b>are written</b> in the verse with regard to protection: <b>“On any sowing [<i>zerua</i>] seed [<i>zera</i>] that is sown [<i>yizzare’a</i>].” One</b> term is written <b>to</b> teach the <i>halakha</i> of <b>protection with regard to seeds, and one</b> is written <b>to</b> teach the <i>halakha</i> of <b>protection with regard to trees,</b> and <b>the other</b> term is written <b>to</b> teach the <i>halakha</i> of <b>protection with regard to meat, and eggs, and fish.</b> Accordingly, this <i>halakha</i> is not limited to protection that is sown together with the food.
§It is written: “And if anything falls from their carcass upon any sowing seed that is sown, it is pure. But if water is put upon the seed, and any of the carcass falls on it, it is impure for you” (Leviticus 11:37–38). Previously, the Gemara derived from this verse that an appendage that serves as a handle both imports impurity to and exports impurity from the food. In addition, the simple understanding teaches that food can become impure only after first being rendered susceptible to impurity by coming into contact with liquid. With regard to these two <i>halakhot</i>, <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi says</b> that <b>Rav says: There is</b> significance to <b>a handle with regard to</b> importing and exporting <b>impurity,</b> i.e., a handle imports impurity to and exports impurity from to the attached food, <b>but there is no</b> significance to <b>a handle with regard to rendering</b> the attached food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity. Rather, the food itself must come into contact with liquid directly.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: There is</b> significance to <b>a handle with regard to</b> importing impurity to and exporting <b>impurity</b> from the attached food, <b>and with regard to rendering</b> the attached food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity even if only the handle came into contact with liquid.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>With regard to what do</b> Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>disagree? If you wish, say</b> that they disagree with regard to <b>a logical argument. If you wish, say</b> that they disagree with regard to the interpretation of <b>a verse.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>If you wish, say</b> that they disagree with regard to the interpretation of <b>a verse.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> that <b>a verse is interpreted homiletically</b> based on juxtaposition to the term immediately <b>preceding it and not</b> based on juxtaposition to the term <b>before the one preceding it.</b> In this case, the verse states: “For you,” indicating inclusion of a handle with regard to the matter of imparting impurity, which is stated in the preceding phrase: “It is impure,” but not with regard to the matter of rendering the attached food susceptible to impurity through contact with liquid which is stated before the preceding phrase: “If water is put.”
<b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>a verse is interpreted homiletically</b> based on juxtaposition to the term immediately <b>preceding it, as well as</b> to the term <b>before the one preceding it.</b> Therefore, he maintains that a handle can also render the attached food susceptible to impurity.
<b>If you wish, say</b> that they disagree with regard to <b>a logical argument.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>rendering</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity <b>is the initial stage of</b> the process of imparting <b>impurity</b> to it. Therefore, just as a handle imparts impurity, it can also render the food susceptible to impurity. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> that <b>rendering</b> food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity <b>is not the initial stage of</b> the process of imparting <b>impurity.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan: Just as there is</b> significance to <b>a handle with regard to</b> imparting <b>impurity</b> to food, <b>so too there is</b> significance to <b>a handle with regard to rendering</b> the attached food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity. <b>And just as</b> produce is susceptible to <b>contracting impurity only when it is detached</b> from the soil, <b>so too</b> produce <b>cannot be rendered susceptible</b> to impurity through contact with liquid <b>until it is detached</b> from the soil.
§The Gemara cites another disagreement between Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan. <b>Rav says: There is no</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>a handle</b> with regard to imparting impurity <b>for</b> a handle that is attached to <b>less than an olive-bulk</b> of food. <b>And there is no</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>protection</b> with regard to imparting impurity <b>for</b> protection that is attached to <b>less than a bean-bulk</b> of food. In addition, the protection does not join together with the food to constitute the measure of an egg-bulk required to impart the impurity of food.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: There is</b> a <i>halakha</i> of <b>a handle</b> with regard to imparting impurity <b>for</b> a handle that is attached to <b>less than an olive-bulk</b> of food. <b>And there is</b> a <i>halakha</i> of <b>protection</b> with regard to imparting impurity <b>for</b> protection that is attached to <b>less than a bean-bulk</b> of food. In addition, it joins together with the food to constitute the measure of an egg-bulk required to impart the impurity of food.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinions of both Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan from that which is taught in a <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Oholot</i> 4:8): In a case of <b>two bones</b> that have <b>two halves of an olive-</b>bulk of flesh of a dead person <b>upon them,</b> i.e., half an olive-bulk of flesh is attached to one end of each bone, <b>and one placed the ends of both</b> bones that are not directly attached to the flesh <b>inside a house</b> in such a manner that <b>the house overlies those</b> ends of the bones but not the ends of the bones attached to the flesh, it is considered as though the house is overlying the flesh itself, and <b>the house is impure.</b>
<b>Yehuda ben Nekosa says in the name of Rabbi Ya’akov: How can two bones join together to</b> constitute <b>an olive-bulk</b> if the flesh attached to each bone is less than the measure of an olive-bulk?

Daf 119a

The Gemara explains the objection: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rav,</b> who holds that a handle that is attached to less than an olive-bulk of food or protection that is attached to less than a bean-bulk of food is not considered a handle or protection with regard to imparting impurity, <b>in what</b> manner <b>does he interpret this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>If</b> the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of a bone without marrow, and therefore the bone constitutes merely <b>a handle</b> for the flesh, which measures less than an olive-bulk, then <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is difficult,</b> because it indicates that a handle that is attached to less than an olive-bulk of food is considered a handle with regard to imparting impurity.
<b>If</b> the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of a bone containing marrow, and therefore the bone constitutes <b>protection</b> for food measuring less than an olive-bulk, then <b>the last clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is difficult</b> because Yehuda ben Nekosa apparently holds that protection that is attached to less than an olive-bulk of food is not considered protection with regard to imparting impurity, contrary to the opinion of Rav, who holds that it is protection unless it is attached to less than a bean-bulk of food.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that Rav interprets the <i>baraita</i> as discussing the case of a bone that constitutes <b>protection. If you wish, say</b> instead that Rav interprets the <i>baraita</i> as discussing the case of a bone that constitutes <b>a handle.</b>
The Gemara explains its answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of a bone that constitutes <b>a handle, and</b> Rav <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Nekosa,</b> who maintains that the house does not become impure because he holds that a handle that is attached to less than an olive-bulk of flesh does not impart impurity. <b>And If you wish, say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of a bone that constitutes <b>protection, and</b> Rav <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> who maintains that the house is impure because he holds that protection attached to less than an olive-bulk of flesh imparts impurity if the flesh measures at least a bean-bulk.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said</b> that <b>the entire</b> <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of a bone that constitutes <b>a handle, and</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> who maintains that the house becomes impure because he holds that a handle that is attached to less than an olive-bulk of food imparts impurity. But he did not state his opinion in accordance with the opinion of Yehuda ben Nekosa, who maintains that the house does not become impure.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another objection to the opinions of Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan from the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Okatzin</i> 2:5): <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>a femur that has an olive-bulk of flesh upon it,</b> the flesh <b>draws the entire</b> femur <b>into ritual impurity</b> if any part of the femur comes into contact with a dead creeping animal. The Sage referred to as <b>Aḥerim says: Even</b> if <b>there is only a bean-bulk</b> of flesh <b>upon</b> the femur, <b>it draws the entire</b> femur <b>into impurity.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>In what</b> manner <b>does Rav interpret this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>If</b> the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of a femur that constitutes merely <b>a handle</b> for the flesh, then <b>the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is difficult,</b> because Aḥerim apparently maintains that a handle that is attached to less than an olive-bulk of flesh imparts impurity, contrary to the opinion of Rav. <b>If</b> the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of a femur that constitutes <b>protection,</b> then <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is difficult,</b> because Rabbi Yehuda apparently holds that protection that is attached to less than an olive-bulk of flesh does not impart impurity, contrary to the opinion of Rav.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of a femur that constitutes <b>a handle, and</b> Rav <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that a handle attached to less than an olive-bulk of flesh does not impart impurity. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of a femur that constitutes <b>protection, and</b> Rav <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion introduced with the words: <b>Aḥerim</b> says, according to which even protection attached to less than an olive-bulk of flesh imparts impurity.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said</b> that <b>the entire</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to case of a femur that constitutes <b>protection, and</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion referred to as: <b>Aḥerim</b> says, according to which even protection that is attached to a bean-bulk of flesh imparts impurity.
The Gemara asks: How is Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion consistent with the opinion referred to as: <b>Aḥerim</b> says? <b>Don’t</b> they <b>say</b> that protection that is attached to <b>a bean-bulk</b> of flesh imparts impurity, and Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that even protection that is attached to less than a bean-bulk of food imparts impurity?
The Gemara answers: Aḥerim agrees that even protection that is attached to less than a bean-bulk imparts impurity. Nevertheless, <b>since the first <i>tanna</i> states</b> the specific <b>measure</b> of an olive-bulk, Aḥerim <b>also states</b> the specific <b>measure</b> of a bean-bulk even though he maintains his opinion with regard to a measure of less than a bean-bulk as well.
<b>Rava said:</b> The language of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is also precise,</b> indicating <b>that we are dealing with protection</b> and not a handle, <b>as it teaches</b> the case of <b>a femur,</b> which contains marrow, and therefore the bone provides protection for the food inside. If the <i>baraita</i> were discussing a handle, it would have taught this <i>halakha</i> with regard to any other bone that is attached to flesh and not specifically a femur. <b>Conclude from it</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the <i>halakha</i> of protection.
§The <i>baraita</i> cited above teaches that Aḥerim says: Even if there is only a bean-bulk of flesh attached to the femur it causes the entire femur to become impure. A dispute <b>was stated</b> with regard to this opinion. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> When Aḥerim stated the measure of a bean-bulk, <b>this is</b> a specific <b>measure,</b> and Aḥerim holds that the <i>halakha</i> of protection applies to an appendage only if a bean-bulk of food is attached to it. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This is not</b> a specific <b>measure.</b> Aḥerim holds that the <i>halakha</i> of protection applies even if it is attached to less than a bean-bulk of food.
The Gemara asks: How is it possible for Rabbi Yoḥanan to hold that <b>this is not</b> a specific <b>measure? But doesn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> explicitly <b>teach</b> the measure of <b>a bean-bulk?</b> The Gemara answers: Indeed, Aḥerim holds that protection that is attached to even less than a bean-bulk of food imparts impurity. But <b>since the first <i>tanna</i> states</b> the specific <b>measure</b> of an olive-bulk, Aḥerim <b>also states</b> the specific <b>measure</b> of a bean-bulk even though he maintains his opinion with regard to a measure of less than a bean-bulk as well.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof against the opinion of Rav from that which is taught in a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 1:5): <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya deems</b> a pod containing <b>beans</b> that came in contact with a dead creeping animal <b>ritually pure.</b> Since beans are large and do not require the protection of the pod, the pod is not considered protection for the beans and therefore does not impart impurity. <b>But he deems</b> a pod containing smaller <b>legumes</b> that came in contact with a dead creeping animal <b>ritually impure</b> if even only one grain is attached to the pod, <b>because one desires</b> the use of the pod <b>when handling</b> the legumes so that he will not damage them, and it is therefore considered protection, which imparts impurity. Apparently, Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya holds that even protection that is attached to less than a bean-bulk of food imparts impurity, contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina and Rav.
The Gemara rejects this proof: The explanation of that mishna is <b>in accordance with that which Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said</b> in the context of a different discussion: That mishna is discussing a case <b>where</b> a dead creeping animal came into contact with <b>the stalk</b> to which the pod is attached, but not with the pod itself. <b>And</b> therefore the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is not with regard to the matter of protection; rather, it is <b>with regard to</b> the matter of <b>a handle,</b> as the stalk serves as a handle for the pod and its attached grain.
<b>Here, too,</b> with regard to this proof one can respond that the mishna is discussing a case <b>where</b> a dead creeping animal came in contact with <b>the stalk and</b> therefore the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is <b>with regard to</b> the matter of <b>a handle.</b> Since the mishna is referring to a stalk, and the stalk has many pods on it, it serves as a handle to more than an olive-bulk of food, and is consistent with the opinions of Rabbi Ḥanina and Rav. <b>And what</b> does Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya mean when he says that in the case of legumes, the stalk is impure because one desires the use of the stalk <b>when handling [<i>bemashmishan</i>]</b> the legumes? He is referring <b>to using [<i>betashmishan</i>],</b> i.e., carrying, the legumes with the stalk.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from that <b>which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> With regard to the impurity of food the verse states: <b>“On any sowing seed that is sown”</b> (Leviticus 11:37), indicating that the entire seed is susceptible to impurity when it is in a state where it is <b>typical for people to take it out</b> to the field for sowing: This applies to <b>wheat in its shell, and barley in its shell, and lentils in their shells.</b> It is derived from here that shells and other appendages that protect the food are considered part of the food. Since wheat, barley, and lentil grains are smaller than a bean-bulk, this statement indicates that even protection that is attached to less than a bean-bulk of food imparts impurity, contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina and Rav.
The Gemara rejects this proof: A grain is a distinct <b>entity,</b> and therefore its status <b>is different.</b> The <i>halakha</i> of protection is applicable to a distinct entity even if it measures less than a bean-bulk.
§<b>Rav Oshaya raises a dilemma:</b>

Daf 119b

As the Gemara stated, protection joins together with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>two protections joining together</b> with the food to constitute the measure of an egg-bulk required to impart impurity?
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of the dilemma? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring to a case <b>where</b> a food item has two layers of protection, and <b>this</b> outer protection <b>is on top of that</b> inner protection, <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of protection applicable with regard to <b>protection</b> that is <b>on top of</b> another <b>protection?</b>
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 2:4) that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> There are <b>three peels</b> surrounding <b>an onion.</b> The <b>inner</b> peel is considered like the food itself, and therefore, <b>whether whole or punctured, it joins together</b> with the onion to constitute the requisite measure to impart the impurity of food. With regard to the <b>middle</b> peel, when it is <b>whole</b> it provides protection and therefore <b>joins together</b> with the onion, but when it is <b>punctured</b> it does not provide protection and therefore <b>does not join together</b> with the onion. The <b>outer</b> peel does not join together with the onion at all, and <b>both</b> in <b>this</b> case, when it is whole, <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case, when it is punctured, it remains <b>ritually pure.</b> Evidently, the <i>halakha</i> of protection is not applied to a protection that surrounds another protection.
The Gemara explains the dilemma: <b>Rav Oshaya</b> does not raise the dilemma with regard to a food item that has two layers of protection. Rather, he <b>raises the dilemma</b> with regard to <b>protection of food that one divided</b> such that the food is whole but the protection is divided into separate sections.
The dilemma is as follows: <b>Since this</b> section of the protection is protecting this part of the food but <b>does not provide protection for that</b> other part of the food, <b>and that</b> other section of the protection is protecting another part of the food but <b>does not provide protection for this</b> part of the food, must one conclude that the two protections <b>do not join together</b> to constitute the requisite measure for the impurity of food?
<b>Or perhaps,</b> should one reason that <b>since this</b> section of the protection <b>provides protection for its</b> part of the food, <b>and that</b> section of the protection <b>provides protection for its</b> part of the food, and the two parts of the food are joined together, therefore the entire entity is considered unified and the two sections of the protection <b>join together</b> to constitute the requisite measure?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to the dilemma from that which is taught in a mishna cited previously (<i>Okatzin</i> 1:5): <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya deems</b> a pod containing <b>beans</b> that came in contact with a dead creeping animal <b>ritually pure. But he deems</b> a pod containing <b>legumes</b> that came in contact with a dead creeping animal <b>impure because one desires</b> the use of the pod <b>when handling</b> the legumes so that he will not damage them. Since the requisite volume for a food item to be susceptible to impurity is an egg-bulk, and the volume of one pod and its legumes is less than an egg-bulk, this statement must be discussing multiple pods joined together. Evidently, protection of food that is divided into separate sections joins together to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said</b> in rejection of this resolution: That mishna is discussing a case <b>where</b> a creeping animal touched <b>the stalk</b> to which the pods are attached but not the pods themselves. <b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> in that mishna is not referring to the matter of protection; rather, it is <b>with regard to</b> the matter of <b>a handle,</b> as the stalk serves as a handle for the pod and its attached grain. <b>And what</b> does Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya mean when he says that in the case of legumes, the stalk is impure because one desires the use of the stalk <b>when handling [<i>bemashmishan</i>]</b> the legumes? He is referring <b>to using [<i>betashmishan</i>],</b> i.e., carrying, the legumes with the stalk.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from that <b>which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> With regard to the impurity of food the verse states: <b>“On any sowing seed that is sown”</b> (Leviticus 11:37), indicating that the entire seed is susceptible to ritual impurity when it is in a state where it is <b>typical for people to take it out</b> to the field <b>for sowing:</b> This applies to <b>wheat in its shell, and barley in its shell, and lentils in their shells.</b> It is derived from here that shells and other appendages that protect the food join together with the food to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. Since the measure of one grain and its shell is less than an egg-bulk, this statement must be discussing multiple grains and their shells joined together. Evidently, protection of food that is divided into separate sections joins together to impart impurity.
The Gemara rejects this resolution: One can explain this statement <b>in accordance with</b> that <b>which Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said</b> with regard to the statement of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya that was cited previously: The mishna is discussing a case <b>where</b> a creeping animal came in contact with <b>the stalk</b> to which the pods are attached but not the pods themselves. <b>And</b> therefore, the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is not referring to the matter of protection; rather, it is <b>with regard to</b> the matter of <b>a handle.</b>
<b>Here too,</b> the statement of the school of Rabbi Yishmael is not referring to independent grains of wheat and barley, but rather <b>to the stem</b> to which the grains are attached, <b>and</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> the status of all the shells of the grains on one stem as <b>protection.</b> All of the grains surrounding the stem protect each other, since if one shell with its grain falls it causes all of the other shells and their grains to fall as well. Therefore, this case is not similar to Rav Oshaya’s dilemma, where each protection protects only part of the food.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> the grains located <b>higher</b> on the stem <b>need</b> the grains located <b>lower</b> on the stem to remain in place in order to not fall. <b>But</b> for <b>what</b> purpose do the grains located <b>lower</b> on the stem <b>need</b> the grains located <b>higher</b> on the stem? The Gemara answers: The case is one where the grains are all positioned tightly around the stem <b>in one row</b> in such a manner that if even one located higher up on the stem were to fall, the remaining grains would fall too.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is there</b> a volume of <b>an egg-bulk of food in one row</b> of grain? The Gemara answers: Yes, this <i>baraita</i> is stated <b>with regard to</b> large grains of <b>wheat,</b> such as those grown in the time <b>of Shimon ben Shataḥ.</b>
The Gemara points out: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> conclusion, it is not necessary to interpret the <i>baraita</i> as referring to many grains tightly packed around the stem. It is <b>even</b> possible to explain that the <i>baraita</i> is discussing the case of <b>one</b> grain of <b>wheat,</b> such as the large grains of <b>wheat</b> grown in the time <b>of Shimon ben Shataḥ.</b>
§The Gemara proceeds to discuss the <i>Tosefta</i> <b>itself</b> that was cited earlier (118b): In a case of <b>two bones upon which there are two halves of an olive-bulk</b> of flesh of a corpse, i.e., half an olive-bulk of flesh is attached to one end of each bone, <b>and one placed the ends of both</b> bones that are not directly attached to the flesh <b>inside the house</b> in such a manner that <b>the house overlies those</b> ends of the bones but not the ends of the bones attached to the flesh, it is considered as though the house is overlying the flesh itself and <b>the house is impure.</b>
<b>Yehuda ben Nekosa says in the name of Rabbi Ya’akov: How can two bones join together to</b> constitute <b>an olive-bulk</b> if the flesh attached to each bone is less than the measure of an olive-bulk? It may be inferred from here that according to all, if the end of a bone that is attached to an olive-bulk of flesh is outside the house, and the other end that is not directly attached to any flesh is inside the house, the house becomes impure with the ritual impurity of a corpse.
With regard to this matter <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to <b>a bone, as it constitutes a handle</b> vis-à-vis the flesh, <b>but</b> if one <b>hair</b> of a corpse is attached to an olive-bulk of flesh at one end, and the other end of the hair is inside a house, it does not render the house impure, because the hair <b>does not constitute a handle</b> vis-à-vis the flesh. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even a hair constitutes a handle</b> vis-à-vis the flesh, and therefore the house is rendered impure.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish</b> from the mishna taught later (124a): In the case of the <b>hide</b> of an unslaughtered animal carcass <b>upon which there is an olive-bulk of flesh, one who touches a strand</b> of flesh <b>emerging from</b> the flesh, <b>or</b> touches <b>a hair that is</b> on the side of the hide <b>opposite</b> the flesh, <b>is ritually impure</b> with the impurity of an unslaughtered carcass, even though he did not touch an olive-bulk of the flesh. <b>What</b> is the reason that one who touches the strand of flesh or the hair becomes impure? <b>Is it not because</b> they constitute <b>a handle</b> for the flesh, contrary to the opinion of Reish Lakish with regard to a hair?
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the ruling of that mishna is not because the hair serves as a handle for the flesh. Rather, it is <b>because</b> the hair serves as <b>protection</b> for the flesh. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> the hide protects the flesh, and the hair is on top of the hide; <b>is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of protection applicable with regard to <b>protection</b> that is <b>on top of</b> another <b>protection?</b> The Gemara answers: The hair <b>penetrates through</b> the hide and touches the flesh, thereby providing protection directly for the flesh.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov objects to this</b> answer: <b>If that is so,</b> that there are perforations in the hide through which the hairs penetrate, <b>how can we write phylacteries? Don’t we require</b> phylacteries to be written with <b>a perfect writing,</b> with no perforations in the letters? <b>And</b> that <b>is not</b> possible if there are perforations in the hide.
The Gemara answers: Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov <b>overlooked that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>which they say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael: <b>Any perforation over which the ink passes</b> and which it covers <b>is not</b> considered <b>a perforation</b> that invalidates the writing.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead a different answer to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s objection to Reish Lakish: <b>The entire</b> mishna teaches that one who touches either a strand of flesh or a hair becomes impure <b>because</b> these appendages serve the flesh as <b>a handle</b> and not as protection. Nevertheless, that statement does not contradict the opinion of Reish Lakish that a hair does not constitute a handle for the flesh, because one can explain this mishna <b>as Rabbi Ela stated</b> with regard to a different mishna: It is stated <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>an awn among</b> many <b>awns.</b>
<b>So too,</b> the mishna taught later is stated <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>a hair among</b> many <b>hairs</b> and not the case of a single hair. Therefore, the hair constitutes a handle for the flesh because one can hold the hair and lift the flesh without the hair becoming detached.
<b>And where was</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ela stated?</b> It was stated <b>with regard to that</b> which is taught in a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 1:3): <b>An awn [<i>melai</i>] that is on top of a stalk</b> constitutes a handle for the stalk. Therefore, <b>it can become impure and impart impurity, but it does not join together</b> with the grains to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. It was asked: <b>For what</b> function <b>is an awn fit</b> such that it is considered to be a handle for the stalk? <b>Rabbi Ilai,</b> i.e., Rabbi Ela, <b>said:</b> That mishna is stated <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>an awn among</b> many <b>awns</b> and not the case of a single awn. Therefore, the awns constitute a handle for the stalk because one can hold the awns and lift the stalk without the awns becoming detached from it.
<b>Some say another version</b> of this dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish and the ensuing discussion with regard to the status of hairs vis-à-vis the flesh: Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish agree that a single hair does not constitute a handle vis-à-vis the flesh connected to it, but they disagree with regard to several hairs.
