Rabbi Yoḥanan raises an objection to Reish Lakish’s opinion that hair is not considered a handle from the mishna taught later, which states that one who touches a hair emerging from the hide of an animal carcass opposite the flesh is impure, indicating that hair constitutes a handle.
Reish Lakish answers that one who touches the hair is impure not because it is considered a handle, but rather because it is considered protection for the flesh. The Gemara adds: <b>So too it is reasonable</b> to explain that the person is impure <b>because</b> hair is considered <b>protection</b> and not because it is considered a handle, <b>as, if it enters your mind</b> that it is <b>because</b> hair is considered <b>a handle, for what</b> function <b>is one hair fit</b> such that it is considered a handle?
The Gemara responds: One can explain that that mishna considers hair to constitute a handle, <b>as Rabbi Ela stated</b> in explanation of a different mishna: It is stated <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>an awn among</b> many <b>awns. Here too,</b> that mishna is stated <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>a hair among</b> many <b>hairs</b> and not the case of a single hair.
<b>And where was</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ela stated?</b> It was stated <b>with regard to that which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>An awn that is on top of a stalk can become impure and impart impurity, but it does not join together</b> with the grains to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. It was asked: <b>For what</b> function <b>is an awn fit</b> such that it is considered to be a handle for the stalk? <b>Rabbi Ilai said:</b> That mishna is stated <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>an awn among</b> many <b>awns.</b>
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who teach</b> another version of this dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish,

Daf 120a

maintaining that the dispute is <b>with regard to</b> that which is taught in <b>the mishna: The</b> attached <b>hide, and the</b> congealed <b>gravy</b> attached to the meat, <b>and the spices,</b> and the meat residue, and the bones, and the tendons, and the horns, and the hooves all <b>join together</b> with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk <b>to impart the impurity of food.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that <b>only a bone</b> and the other items mentioned in the mishna join together with the meat to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity <b>because</b> they <b>constitute protection</b> for the meat. <b>But a hair</b> does not join together with the meat to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity because it <b>is not protection</b> for the meat. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even a hair is protection</b> for the meat and therefore joins together with the meat to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity.
<b>Reish Lakish said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: But</b> the hide protects the flesh, and the hair is on top of the hide. <b>Is</b> the <i>halakha</i> of protection applicable with regard to <b>protection</b> that is <b>on top of</b> another <b>protection?</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan answered: The hair <b>penetrates through</b> the hide and touches the flesh, thereby providing protection directly for the flesh.
<b>Rav Aḥa objects to this</b> answer: <b>If that is so,</b> that there are perforations in the hide through which the hairs penetrate, <b>how can we write phylacteries? Don’t we require</b> phylacteries to be written with <b>a perfect writing</b> with no perforations in the letters? <b>And</b> that <b>is not</b> possible if there are perforations in the hide.
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>which they say in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>escaped</b> Rav Aḥa: <b>Any perforation over which the ink passes</b> and which it covers <b>is not</b> considered <b>a perforation</b> that invalidates the writing.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish</b> opinion from the mishna taught later (124a): In the case of the <b>hide</b> of an animal carcass <b>upon which there is an olive-bulk of flesh, one who touches a strand</b> of flesh <b>emerging from</b> the flesh <b>or</b> touches <b>a hair that is</b> on the side of the hide <b>opposite</b> the flesh <b>is ritually impure,</b> even though he did not touch an olive-bulk of the flesh. <b>What</b> is the reason that one who touches the strand of flesh or the hair becomes impure? <b>Is it not because</b> they constitute <b>protection</b> for the flesh? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>because</b> the hair constitutes <b>a handle</b> for the flesh.
The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> function <b>is one hair fit</b> such that it constitutes a handle? The Gemara answers: One can explain that mishna <b>as Rabbi Ela said</b> in explanation of a different mishna: It is stated <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>an awn among</b> many <b>awns. Here too,</b> the mishna is stated <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>a hair among</b> many <b>hairs</b> and not the case of a single hair. The hair serves as a handle for the flesh because one can hold the hair and lift the flesh without the hair becoming detached.
<b>And where was</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ela stated?</b> It <b>was stated with regard to that which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>An awn that is on</b> top of <b>a stalk can become impure and impart impurity, but it does not join together</b> with the grains to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. It was asked: <b>For what</b> function <b>is an awn fit</b> such that it is considered to be a handle for the stalk? <b>Rabbi Ela said:</b> The mishna is stated <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>an awn among</b> many <b>awns.</b>
§The mishna teaches: <b>The gravy [<i>rotev</i>]</b> joins together with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food, but an egg-bulk of gravy itself is not susceptible to impurity. The Gemara asks: To <b>what</b> is the term <b><i>rotev</i></b> referring? <b>Rava said:</b> The term <i>rotev</i> is referring to <b>the fat</b> that floats on top of a soup of cooked meat.
<b>Abaye said</b> to Rava: That fat <b>itself</b> is eaten and <b>is</b> therefore susceptible to <b>impurity of food. Rather,</b> the term <i>rotev</i> is referring to <b>fat that</b> oozed out of the meat and <b>congealed.</b> That fat is not eaten, but it does join together with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> is the mishna referring <b>specifically</b> to <b>congealed</b> fat? <b>Even</b> in a case <b>where the fat did not congeal</b> it joins together with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food, <b>as Reish Lakish said: Brine on a vegetable,</b> even though it is a liquid, <b>combines</b> with the vegetable <b>to</b> constitute <b>a large date-bulk [<i>kakotevet</i>]</b> with regard to rendering one liable for violating the prohibition against eating <b>on Yom Kippur.</b> Similarly, liquid fat should combine with the meat to constitute the requisite volume to impart the impurity of food.
The Gemara answers: Liquids and solids do not join together to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food. The reason for the <i>halakha</i> <b>there,</b> with regard to Yom Kippur, <b>is because</b> one is liable even for the consumption of a liquid that is not characterized as food if the <b>mind</b> of the one who consumes it is <b>settled.</b> This is because with regard to the fast of Yom Kippur the Torah is concerned with a person’s affliction, as the verse states: “You shall afflict your souls” (Leviticus 23:27). Therefore, one is liable on Yom Kippur for <b>any</b> eating that <b>settles his mind.</b>
But that is not the case <b>here with regard to</b> impurity. For two substances to join together to impart impurity, <b>a combination</b> between substances that have a common requisite measure for imparting impurity <b>is</b> necessary. Liquid and solid foods do not have the same requisite measure. Therefore, <b>if</b> the fat <b>is congealed, it joins together</b> with the meat. <b>If it is not congealed, it does not join together</b> with the meat.
§The mishna teaches: <b>The spices [<i>kifa</i>]</b> join together with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food, but an egg-bulk of <i>kifa</i> itself is not susceptible to impurity. The Gemara asks: To <b>what</b> is the term <b><i>kifa</i></b> referring? <b>Rabba said:</b> The term <i>kifa</i> is referring to a congealed <b>hash</b> of cooked meat that settled to the bottom of the pot.
<b>Abaye said</b> to Rabba: That hash <b>itself is</b> eaten and is therefore susceptible to <b>the impurity of food. Rather, Rav Pappa said:</b> The term <i>kifa</i> is referring to <b>spices,</b> which are not eaten themselves but do join together with the meat to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food.
§Since the mishna mentions <i>kifa</i>, which, according to Rabba, is referring to a congealed substance, the Gemara discusses the <i>halakha</i> of one who congealed a forbidden substance and consumed it. <b>We learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>there:</b> One who <b>caused blood to coagulate and ate it or melted</b> forbidden <b>fat and swallowed it is liable.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>Granted,</b> one who <b>caused blood to coagulate and ate it</b> is liable. Although blood is not normally eaten in such a manner, <b>since he caused</b> the blood <b>to coagulate, he ascribed</b> the <b>significance</b> of food <b>to it,</b> and the Torah prohibits the eating of blood, as it is written: “You shall eat neither fat nor blood” (Leviticus 3:17). <b>But</b> why is one who <b>melted</b> forbidden <b>fat and swallowed it</b> liable? <b>Eating,</b> and not drinking, <b>is stated</b> in the Torah with regard to the prohibition against the consumption of forbidden fat, as it is written: “You shall eat no fat of ox or sheep or goat” (Leviticus 7:23), <b>and this</b> swallowing of a liquid <b>is not eating.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish said:</b> One is liable even for drinking the melted forbidden fat of an animal. <b>The verse states:</b> “For all who eat the fat of the animal that one could offer from it a fire offering to the Lord, the soul that eats it shall be cut off from his people” (Leviticus 7:25). The term <b>“soul”</b> is interpreted homiletically <b>to include</b> in the prohibition <b>one who drinks</b> the fat.
The Gemara comments: A novelty <b>of this kind is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to</b> the prohibition against eating <b>leavened bread</b> on Passover: If one took bread, <b>dissolved it</b> in water, <b>and swallowed</b> this mixture on Passover, the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: <b>If it is leavened bread, he is punished with <i>karet</i>; if it is <i>matza</i>,</b> then <b>a person does not fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on Passover with</b> this food.
The Gemara objects: <b>Granted, if it is <i>matza</i>, a person does not fulfill his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on Passover with</b> this food, as <b>the Merciful One states</b> with regard to the prohibition against eating leavened bread on Passover: “You shall eat no leavened bread with it; seven days you shall eat unleavened bread with it, even <b>the bread of affliction”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3), indicating that one must eat the bread of affliction, <b>but this</b> bread dissolved in water <b>is not</b> considered <b>the bread of affliction. But if</b> the bread <b>is leavened bread,</b> why <b>is he punished with <i>karet</i>? Eating is written with regard to</b> the prohibition against leavened bread, and in this case he did not eat it but rather drank it.
<b>Reish Lakish said:</b> One is liable even for drinking leavened bread. <b>The verse states:</b> “For all who eat leavened bread from the first day until the seventh day, that soul shall be cut off from Israel” (Exodus 12:15). The term <b>“soul”</b> is interpreted homiletically <b>to include</b> in the prohibition <b>one who drinks</b> leavened bread.
The Gemara comments: A novelty <b>of this kind is also taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Zavim</i> 5:9) <b>with regard to</b> one who eats <b>the</b> unslaughtered <b>carcass of a kosher bird: One who liquefied</b> the carcass of an unslaughtered kosher bird <b>in fire</b> and drank the substance <b>is impure.</b> But one who liquefied it <b>in the sun</b> and drank it <b>is pure. And we discussed it: Eating</b> and not drinking <b>is stated</b> with regard to the impurity of a carcass, as it is written: “And every soul that eats an unslaughtered carcass or that which is mauled by an animal, whether he is native or stranger, he shall wash his garments, bathe in water, and shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 17:15). Why, then, does one who drinks a kosher bird carcass become impure?
<b>Reish Lakish said:</b> He becomes impure because <b>the verse states:</b> “And every <b>soul.”</b> The term “soul” is interpreted homiletically <b>to include one who drinks.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> one who drinks a carcass that is melted <b>in the sun</b> should <b>also</b> become impure. The Gemara explains: A carcass takes a long time to melt <b>in the sun.</b> Therefore, the liquid <b>becomes rotten</b> and unfit for consumption.
The Gemara cited three instances in which Reish Lakish interpreted the term “soul” as including one who drinks. The Gemara explains: All three mentions of the term “soul” <b>are necessary. As, if the Merciful One had written</b> the term “soul” only with regard to forbidden <b>fat,</b> liability for drinking liquefied <b>leavened bread could not have been derived from it, since</b> the prohibition against the consumption of forbidden fat has an element of stringency that does not apply to leavened bread in that the forbidden fat <b>had no period of fitness</b> for consumption. Leavened bread, on the other hand, may be consumed before Passover. Likewise, impurity contracted by drinking a liquefied <b>carcass could not be derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of forbidden fat <b>because</b> the consumption of forbidden fat is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>,</b> which is not the case with regard to the consumption of a carcass.
<b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> the term “soul” only with regard to <b>leavened bread,</b> liability for drinking melted forbidden <b>fat could not be derived from it, as</b> there are <b>no</b> circumstances in which <b>the general prohibition</b> against eating leavened bread <b>was permitted.</b> The consumption of forbidden fat, on the other hand, is permitted with regard to the fat of an undomesticated animal. <b>And</b> similarly, impurity contracted by drinking a liquefied <b>carcass could not be derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of leavened bread, <b>because</b> the <i>halakha</i> of leavened bread has an element of stringency that does not apply to a carcass in that its consumption is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>.</b>
<b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> the term “soul” only <b>with regard to a carcass, those</b> prohibitions against drinking melted fat and liquefied leavened bread <b>could not be derived from it, because</b> a carcass has an element of stringency that does not apply to those prohibitions in that <b>it transmits impurity</b> to one who eats it. Therefore, all three mentions of the term “soul” are necessary.
The Gemara objects: It is true that <b>one</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>cannot be derived from</b> either <b>one</b> of the others, as detailed above. Nevertheless, one can <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>one</b> of them <b>from</b> the other <b>two.</b> The Gemara responds: This is not possible, as <b>which</b> <i>halakha</i> can one <b>derive</b> from the others? <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> a liquefied <b>carcass and derive</b> it <b>from these</b> other prohibitions against eating forbidden fat and leavened bread. One can refute this derivation: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> other prohibitions? They are notable <b>in that</b> one who transgresses them <b>is punished with <i>karet</i>,</b> contrary to one who eats a carcass.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> dissolved <b>leavened bread and derive</b> it <b>from these</b> <i>halakhot</i> of forbidden fat and a carcass. The Gemara refutes the derivation: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> <i>halakhot</i>? They are notable <b>in that they had no period of fitness</b> for consumption, as opposed to leavened bread, which was fit for consumption before Passover.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let the Merciful One not write</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> forbidden <b>fat and derive</b> it <b>from these</b> <i>halakhot</i> of consuming leavened bread and a carcass. The Gemara refutes the derivation: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> <i>halakhot</i>? They are notable <b>in that</b> there are <b>no</b> circumstances in which <b>their general prohibition was permitted. Shall you say</b> the same <b>with regard to</b> forbidden <b>fat, whose general prohibition was permitted</b> in certain circumstances? Therefore, all three mentions of the term “soul” are necessary.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is</b> the case in which forbidden fat is permitted? <b>If we say</b> that it is the <b>fat of a domesticated animal</b> that is permitted to be sacrificed in the Temple <b>to the Most High,</b> a bird <b>carcass is also permitted</b> to be sacrificed in the Temple. Although <b>pinching</b> the nape of the neck of <b>a bird</b> renders it an unslaughtered carcass and forbidden for consumption, bird offerings are sacrificed <b>to the Most High</b> in such a manner.
<b>And</b> if the reference is <b>rather</b> to <b>the</b> forbidden <b>fat of an undomesticated animal,</b> which is permitted <b>to an ordinary</b> person, one may respond that <b>a carcass is also permitted</b> for a person’s consumption in a certain case, as <b>the pinching of</b> the nape of the neck of <b>a bird sin offering</b> renders it fit <b>for</b> consumption of <b>the priests.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the reference is to <b>the</b> forbidden <b>fat of an undomesticated animal,</b> which is permitted <b>to an ordinary</b> person. <b>And that which</b> is <b>difficult for you</b> with regard to the fact that the <b>priests</b> eat the carcass of a bird which is brought as a sin offering is not difficult, as the <b>priests receive</b> their portion <b>from the table of the Most High.</b> Since this carcass is permitted as an offering to God, it is permitted to the priests as well. Therefore, this does not qualify as a case of an unslaughtered carcass permitted to ordinary people.
§The Gemara challenges: <b>But that which is taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i> is difficult. The Torah states with regard to the prohibition against eating creeping animals: “These are they <b>that are impure [<i>hatteme’im</i>]</b> to you among all the creeping animals” (Leviticus 11:31). The Sages interpret the letter <i>heh</i> in the term “<i>hatteme’im</i>” <b>to forbid their juice</b> that oozes from their carcasses, <b>and their gravy</b> that is produced when they are cooked, <b>and sediments</b> of <b>their</b> flesh that congeal at the bottom of the dish when cooked. The Gemara explains the challenge: <b>Why do I</b> need a verse to teach this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Let</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>be learned from these</b> <i>halakhot</i> of melted forbidden fat, a liquefied bird carcass, and dissolved leavened bread.
The Gemara answers: <b>It is necessary</b> for this <i>halakha</i> to be written, <b>as if the Merciful One had not written</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to creeping animals and instead the <i>halakha</i> was derived from the other <i>halakhot</i>, <b>I would say: It is sufficient for the</b> conclusion that <b>emerges from</b> an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference to be like</b> its <b>source.</b> Accordingly, <b>just as there,</b> one who consumes melted forbidden fat, a liquefied carcass, or dissolved leavened bread is not liable <b>until</b> he consumes <b>an olive-bulk, so too here,</b> with regard to consuming the juice, gravy, and sediments of creeping animals, one is not liable <b>until</b> he consumes <b>an olive-bulk.</b> Therefore, a separate verse is necessary to teach that one is liable even for consuming a lentil-bulk of the juice, gravy, or sediments of a creeping animal, just as one is liable for consuming this measure of the creeping animal itself.

Daf 120b

The Gemara objects: <b>Let the Merciful One write</b> the prohibition against consuming the juice, gravy, and sediments of <b>creeping animals and let these</b> <i>halakhot</i> of consuming liquefied forbidden fat, dissolved leavened bread, and a melted carcass of a bird <b>come and be learned from</b> it. The Torah does not need to state those <i>halakhot</i> explicitly.
The Gemara explains: It is not possible to derive those <i>halakhot</i> in such a manner <b>because</b> that derivation <b>can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about creeping animals?</b> They are notable <b>in that their impurity</b> is imparted <b>in any amount.</b> Those other <i>halakhot</i>, on the other hand, do not apply to less than an olive-bulk.
§The Gemara continues to examine the source for the status of liquids with regard to various <i>halakhot</i> based on <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>untithed produce; and the new crop</b> of grain of the year, which is forbidden until after the <i>omer</i> offering is brought on the sixteenth of Nisan (see Leviticus 23:14); <b>and consecrated</b> produce; <b>and</b> the produce of <b>the Sabbatical</b> Year after the designated time when it must be removed from one’s house; <b>and diverse kinds,</b> i.e., the produce of a vineyard in which grains were sown; with regard to <b>all of them,</b> it is prohibited to consume <b>liquid that emerges from them just as</b> it is prohibited to consume them <b>themselves.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>?
<b>And if you would say: Let</b> those prohibitions <b>be learned from these</b> prohibitions of consuming the liquid that seeps from creeping animals, liquefied fat, dissolved leavened bread, and liquefied bird carcasses, one can respond that this derivation can be refuted. <b>What</b> is notable <b>about these</b> prohibitions? They are notable <b>in that</b> each of them is <b>a prohibition that develops on its own</b> without any human intervention, as opposed to the prohibitions in the <i>baraita</i>, which do not necessarily share this element of stringency.
Therefore, <b>it works out well</b> to derive the prohibition against consuming liquids that emerged from a solid <b>where the prohibition</b> is one that <b>develops on its own,</b> such as untithed produce, the new crop, Sabbatical Year produce and diverse kinds. But with regard to consecrated produce, <b>where the prohibition does not develop on its own</b> but rather only after a person consecrates the produce, <b>from where do we</b> derive that it is prohibited to consume the liquid that emerges from the produce just as it is prohibited to consume the produce itself?
The Gemara answers: <b>We learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the case of <b>first fruits.</b> Consumption of first fruits is a prohibition that does not develop on its own, because the owner must set aside the first fruits. And consumption of the liquid that emerges from first fruits is prohibited like consumption of the fruit itself. The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>first fruits themselves?</b>
The Gemara answers that first fruits can be brought as wine, <b>as Rabbi Yosei teaches:</b> The verse states with regard to first fruits: “You shall take of the first of all the <b>fruit</b> of the ground, which you shall bring in from your land” (Deuteronomy 26:2). Since the verse mentions fruit, this indicates that <b>you must bring</b> actual <b>fruit, and you may not bring</b> the first fruits in the form of <b>beverages.</b> But if one <b>brought grapes and</b> he had already <b>pressed them</b> into wine, <b>from where</b> is it derived that he has fulfilled his obligation? <b>The verse states: “You shall bring in</b> from your land.” This superfluous term serves to teach that if one brings wine for the mitzva of first fruits, he has fulfilled his obligation.
But this derivation from the case of first fruits <b>can be refuted: What</b> is notable <b>about first fruits?</b> They are notable <b>in that they require reciting</b> the passage which begins: “My father was a wandering Aramean” (Deuteronomy 26:5), <b>and placing</b> the fruits in the Temple, whereas no such requirements exists with regard to consecrated produce.
<b>Rather,</b> one can <b>derive</b> the prohibition against consuming the liquid that emerges from consecrated produce <b>from</b> the prohibition against consuming liquid that emerges from <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., the portion of produce designated for the priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i> itself?</b> the Gemara answers: It is derived from the fact <b>that</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>is compared to first fruits, as</b> it is written: “You may not eat within your gates the tithe of your grain, or of your wine, or of your oil, or the firstborn of your cattle and of your flocks, or any of your vows that you will vow, or your pledges, nor the offering of your hand” (Deuteronomy 12:17), and <b>the Master said</b> with regard to the phrase <b>“nor the offering [<i>teruma</i>] of your hand”</b> that <b>these are</b> the <b>first fruits.</b> Since the verse uses the term “<i>teruma</i>” with regard to first fruits, the <i>halakha</i> of <i>teruma</i> is compared to the <i>halakha</i> of first fruits: Just as liquid that emerges from first fruits is forbidden like the fruit itself, so too liquid that emerges from <i>teruma</i> is forbidden like the produce itself. Consequently, the prohibition against consuming the liquid that emerges from consecrated produce can be derived from <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara refutes this derivation from <i>teruma</i>: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about <i>teruma</i>?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> a non-priest <b>is liable</b> to receive the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven <b>for</b> consuming <i>teruma</i>, <b>and</b> he must restore the value of the produce he ate, adding <b>one-fifth</b> of its value as a fine. This element of stringency does not exist with regard to one who consumes consecrated produce.
<b>Rather,</b> one can <b>learn</b> the prohibition against consuming the liquid that emerges from consecrated produce <b>from both <i>teruma</i> and first fruits.</b> The Gemara refutes this derivation: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about <i>teruma</i> and first fruits?</b> They are notable <b>in that</b> a non-priest <b>is liable</b> to receive the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven <b>for</b> consuming <i>teruma</i> or first fruits, <b>and</b> he must restore the value of the produce he ate, adding <b>one-fifth</b> of its value as a fine. This is not true with regard to one who consumes consecrated produce.
<b>Rather,</b> the prohibition against consuming the liquid that emerges from consecrated produce <b>is derived from <i>teruma</i> and one of these</b> prohibitions, i.e., a liquefied carcass of a bird or dissolved leavened bread; <b>or</b> it can be derived <b>from first fruits and one of these</b> prohibitions.
§The Gemara elaborates on the comparison between <i>teruma</i> and first fruits with regard to the <i>halakha</i> that the status of liquid that emerges from produce is like that of the produce itself, <b>and</b> it explains <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 11:2): If a non-priest ate <b>date honey, or apple wine, or vinegar</b> made <b>from grapes of autumn</b> that grow stunted at the end of the season and are unfit for wine production, <b>or</b> any of the <b>other types of</b> juice made from <b>fruits of <i>teruma</i>, Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> him <b>obligated</b> to repay <b>the principal and</b> an additional <b>fifth,</b> like the penalty for one who ate the <i>teruma</i> produce itself. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua deems</b> him <b>exempt</b> from payment.
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what</b> principle do Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua <b>disagree? They disagree with regard to</b> the principles governing the process of deriving one <i>halakha</i> from another <i>halakha</i>. One maintains the exegetical principle: <b>Infer from it, and</b> again <b>from it,</b> i.e., when one case is derived from another all the details of the source case are applied to the other case; <b>and</b> one maintains the principle: <b>Infer from it but interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to its</b> own <b>place,</b> i.e., one derives only the basic principle of the source case, whereas all other aspects of the source case are not applied to the case at hand.
<b>As Rabbi Eliezer holds: Infer from it, and</b> again <b>from it. Just as</b> with regard to <b>first fruits,</b> the status of the <b>liquid that emerges from them is like</b> that of the produce itself, <b>so too</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> the status of the <b>liquid that emerges from it is like</b> that of the produce itself. <b>And</b> again infer <b>from it: Just as</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>first fruits</b> includes not only olives and grapes but <b>even other types</b> of produce from the seven species for which Eretz Yisrael is praised, and the status of liquid that emerges from that produce is like that of the produce itself, <b>so too</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> although oil and wine are the only liquids from which one is obligated to separate <i>teruma</i>, <b>even</b> liquid that emerges from <b>other types</b> of produce designated as <i>teruma</i> besides olives and grapes has the same status as the produce itself.
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua holds: Infer from it</b> that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>first fruits</b> the status of the <b>liquid that emerges from them is like</b> that of the produce itself, <b>so too</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> the status of the <b>liquid that emerges from it is like</b> that of the produce itself. <b>But interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to its</b> own <b>place: Just as</b> in the case of <b>liquids that are consecrated as <i>teruma</i>,</b> with regard to <b>wine and oil, yes,</b> they are included, <b>but other</b> types are <b>not</b> included, <b>so too</b> in the case of <b>liquid that emerges from</b> <i>teruma</i>, as with regard to <b>wine and oil, yes,</b> they <b>are like</b> the produce itself, <b>but any other</b> type of liquid that emerges from <i>teruma</i> is <b>not</b> like the produce itself. Therefore, Rabbi Yehoshua deems exempt a non-priest who consumed any of the beverages mentioned in the mishna.
The Gemara cites <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 11:3): <b>One may bring beverages</b> made from <b>first fruits</b> to the Temple <b>only</b> in the case of <b>that which emerges from the olives,</b> i.e., oil, <b>or from the grapes,</b> i.e., wine. The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is that mishna?
The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, who says: Infer from it but interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to its</b> own <b>place.</b> He derives the <i>halakha</i> of liquid that emerges from <i>teruma</i> from first fruits only with regard to wine and oil, <b>and</b> in the opposite direction, <b>he derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of</b> liquid that emerges from <b>first fruits from <i>teruma</i>.</b> Therefore, even with regard to first fruits the status of liquid that emerges from the produce is like that of the produce itself only with regard to wine and oil. But according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, who holds that the <i>halakha</i> of liquid that emerges from <i>teruma</i> is derived from first fruits even with regard to other types of produce besides grapes and olives, contrary to the statement of that mishna, one may bring beverages extracted from other first fruits besides wine and oil to the Temple.
The Gemara cites <b>that which we learned</b> in the same mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 11:3): <b>One incurs the forty</b> lashes <b>due to</b> drinking the juice squeezed from <b><i>orla</i>,</b> i.e., the fruit of a tree during the first three years after its planting, <b>only for that which emerges from the olives or from the grapes.</b> The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is that mishna?
The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, who says: Infer from it but interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to its</b> own <b>place, and he derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of</b> liquid that emerges from <b>first fruits from <i>teruma</i>.</b> Therefore, even with regard to first fruits, the status of liquid that emerges from the produce is like that of the produce itself only with regard to wine and oil.

Daf 121a

<b>And then he derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>of</b> liquid that emerges from <b><i>orla</i> from first fruits</b> via a verbal analogy between one instance of the word <b>fruit</b> and another instance of the word <b>fruit.</b> With regard to <i>orla</i> the verse states: “And you shall count the fruit thereof as forbidden” (Leviticus 19:23), and with regard to first fruits the verse states: “And you shall take of the first of all the fruit of the ground” (Deuteronomy 26:2). Therefore, just as with regard to first fruits the status of liquid that emerges from the produce is like that of the produce only with regard to grapes and olives, so too with regard to <i>orla</i> one receives lashes only for drinking the liquid of grapes and olives, but not for drinking the liquid of other types of produce.
§The mishna teaches that <b>the <i>alal</i></b> joins together with the flesh to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food, despite not being considered food itself. The Gemara asks: To <b>what</b> is the term <b><i>alal</i></b> referring? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is referring to <b>the nuchal ligament [<i>marteka</i>]. And Reish Lakish says:</b> It is referring to the <b>meat</b> residue <b>that</b> is attached to the hide after <b>the knife has flayed</b> the flesh.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the explanation of Reish Lakish from that which is written: <b>“But you are plasterers of lies, you are all physicians of no value [<i>elil</i>]”</b> (Job 13:4). The term “no value [<i>elil</i>]” stems from the same linguistic root as the word <i>alal</i>. <b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that the word <i>alal</i> is referring to <b>the nuchal ligament,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>that is</b> why Job accused his companions of giving advice without merit by making an analogy to a physician who attempts to heal the nuchal ligament, <b>which cannot be healed. But according to the one who says</b> that the word <i>alal</i> is referring to the <b>meat</b> residue <b>that</b> is attached to the hide after <b>the knife has flayed</b> the flesh, i.e., Reish Lakish, flesh that is hanging from the hide <b>is able to be healed.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to</b> the term <b><i>elil</i> in the verse, everyone agrees</b> that it is referring to the nuchal ligament. <b>When</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish <b>disagree,</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> the definition of the term <b><i>alal</i></b> employed by the Sages <b>in the mishna.</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from that which is taught in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>the <i>alal</i> that</b> was <b>collected, if there is an olive-bulk</b> of it <b>in one place</b> it imparts the impurity of animal carcasses. Therefore, one who eats it or touches it and then eats consecrated food or enters the Temple <b>is liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for it. And Rav Huna said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> applicable only <b>when</b> a halakhically competent person <b>collected</b> the <i>alal</i> in one place, but not if the <i>alal</i> was collected by a child or without human intervention. By collecting it in one place, the person indicates that he considers it to be food.
<b>Granted, according to the one who says</b> that the word <i>alal</i> is referring to the <b>meat</b> residue <b>that</b> is attached to the hide after <b>the knife has flayed</b> the flesh, i.e., Reish Lakish, <b>that is</b> why Rabbi Yehuda says <b>that one is rendered liable when there is an olive-bulk</b> of <i>alal</i> collected in one place, because the person who collected it considers it to be food. <b>But according to the one who says</b> that the word <i>alal</i> is referring to <b>the nuchal ligament,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan, even in a case <b>when there is an olive-bulk</b> of <i>alal</i> collected in one place, <b>what of it? It is merely wood,</b> i.e., it is unfit for consumption.
The Gemara answers: <b>According to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish <b>do not disagree;</b> they agree that the term <i>alal</i> is referring to the meat residue attached to the hide after the knife has flayed the flesh. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is with regard to the definition of the word alal according to the opinion of the Rabbis. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The Rabbis maintain that the nuchal ligament also joins together with the meat to constitute the requisite measure of an egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food. And Reish Lakish says: The Rabbis maintain that <b>specifically</b> the <b>meat</b> residue <b>that</b> is attached to the hide after <b>the knife has flayed</b> the meat joins together with the flesh, <b>but the nuchal ligament does not join together.</b>
<b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>that</b> which is taught in the mishna, that the <b>meat</b> residue <b>that</b> is attached to the hide after <b>the knife flayed</b> the flesh joins together with the meat to constitute the measure of an egg-bulk required to impart the impurity of food? <b>If</b> it is a case <b>where one intends</b> to eat this meat residue, then it <b>can become impure</b> not only by joining together with the meat, but <b>even by itself,</b> like any other food. <b>And if</b> it is a case <b>where one does not intend</b> to eat this meat residue, why should it be susceptible to impurity at all? One has completely <b>nullified</b> its status as food.
<b>Rabbi Avin and Rabbi Meyasha</b> answered this dilemma. <b>One said:</b> It is a case where <b>one intends</b> to eat <b>part of</b> the meat residue, but it is uncertain which part. Therefore, the meat residue is not susceptible to impurity by itself because it is not entirely considered to be food, but the part that he intends to eat joins together with the meat to constitute the measure of an egg-bulk.
<b>And one said:</b> It is a case where one does not intend to eat any part of the meat residue. Rather, <b>an animal severed part of</b> the meat residue attached to the hide, and therefore that part of the meat residue retains its status as food. <b>And</b> the <b>knife severed part of</b> the meat residue, and one therefore nullified its status as food with regard to that part. Since it is uncertain which part was severed by a knife and which part by an animal, the meat residue itself is not susceptible to impurity, but the part that was severed by an animal joins together with the meat to constitute the measure of an egg-bulk.
§The mishna stated that the horns join together with the flesh to constitute the requisite egg-bulk to impart the impurity of food. The Gemara comments that <b>we learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Teharot</i> 1:2): <b>The beak and the talons</b> of a bird that come into contact with a creeping animal can <b>become impure, and transmit impurity</b> to food, <b>and join together</b> with the attached flesh to constitute the requisite measure to impart impurity. The Gemara asks: Why does <b>a beak</b> join together with the flesh to impart impurity? <b>It is merely wood,</b> i.e., it is unfit for consumption.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The mishna is stated <b>with regard to the lower</b> half of the <b>beak,</b> i.e., the lower mandible. The Gemara objects: <b>The lower</b> mandible <b>is also merely wood. Rav Pappa says:</b> The mishna is discussing <b>the lower</b> section <b>of the upper</b> mandible and is referring to the membrane inside the mouth that is attached to the beak.
Similarly, with regard to the <b>talons</b> mentioned in that mishna, <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> That mishna is not discussing the talons themselves, but rather <b>the place</b> at the base of the talon <b>that is subsumed within the flesh.</b>
Similarly, with regard to the <b>horns</b> mentioned in the mishna, <b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The mishna is not discussing the hard substance of the horn, but rather is referring <b>to the place</b> at the base of the horns <b>where one severs</b> the horns <b>and blood flows from them.</b>
§The mishna teaches: <b>Similarly,</b> in the case of <b>one who slaughters</b> a non-kosher <b>animal</b> for a gentile and the animal is still twitching and comes into contact with a source of impurity, it imparts impurity of food, but does not impart impurity of an animal carcass.
<b>Rabbi Asi says:</b> Some Sages <b>teach</b> that when <b>a Jew</b> slaughters <b>a non-kosher</b> animal <b>or a gentile</b> slaughters <b>a kosher</b> animal, in order for it to be susceptible to impurity of food, it is <b>necessary</b> that the <b>intention</b> of the one performing the slaughter be that the flesh be designated as food while it is still twitching. <b>And</b> furthermore, in order for the animal to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity, it requires contact with <b>water</b> or another liquid that renders food susceptible to impurity that comes <b>from another place.</b> The blood of this slaughter is not considered a liquid that renders food susceptible to impurity because it flowed from a valid slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the animal to come in contact with liquid in order for it to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity of food? The flesh of the animal <b>will eventually become impure</b> with a more <b>severe</b> level of <b>impurity</b> when it dies, i.e., impurity of an animal carcass. <b>And any</b> food <b>that will eventually become impure</b> with a more <b>severe</b> level of <b>impurity does not require</b> contact with liquid to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity of food.
The Gemara now explains the source of this principle. <b>As the school of Rabbi Yishmael teaches:</b> With regard to rendering food susceptible to impurity through contact with liquid, the verse states: <b>“But if water is put upon the seed,</b> and any of the carcass falls on it, it is impure for you” (Leviticus 11:38). <b>Just as seeds, which will never contract</b> a more <b>severe</b> level of <b>impurity,</b> because no form of severe impurity applies to foods other than meat, <b>require</b> contact with liquid to <b>render</b> them <b>susceptible</b> to their less severe level of impurity, <b>so too any</b> food <b>that will never contract</b> a more <b>severe</b> level of <b>impurity requires</b> contact with liquid to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity of food. By contrast, any food that will become impure with a more severe level of impurity does not require contact with liquid to be rendered susceptible to impurity of food.
<b>And</b> similarly, <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: For what</b> reason <b>did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that in order for <b>the carcass of a kosher bird</b> to become susceptible to impurity it <b>requires</b> that the <b>intention</b> of the one performing the slaughter be to designate the animal as food, <b>but it is not required</b> for the bird to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity through contact with liquid? The reason is <b>because</b>

Daf 121b

<b>eventually</b> the carcass of the bird <b>will impart</b> a more <b>severe impurity</b> when it is in the throat of the person who consumes it. Therefore, it is not necessary for the carcass of a kosher bird to come in contact with liquid in order for it to be susceptible to impurity.
<b>Ḥizkiyya says</b> in response: The reason for the opinion of the Sages stated by Rabbi Asi is <b>since</b> the slaughterer <b>is able to chop</b> the animal into small pieces <b>and</b> thereby <b>establish</b> the volume of every piece of the animal <b>as less than an olive-bulk.</b> In such a scenario, the animal would not be susceptible to impurity. Therefore, it is not certain that the animal will eventually become impure with a more severe impurity.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira: And did Ḥizkiyya</b> actually <b>say such</b> a statement? <b>But wasn’t it stated:</b> If one <b>slaughtered</b> a non-kosher animal in a valid manner by cutting the <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i>, i.e., the windpipe and the gullet, <b>or the majority of</b> the <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i>, <b>and</b> the animal <b>is still twitching, Ḥizkiyya says: There is no</b> prohibition against eating the <b>limbs</b> from such a twitching animal. Therefore, a gentile, who is prohibited from consuming a limb from a living animal, may consume this animal. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: There is</b> a prohibition against eating the <b>limbs</b> of such an animal.
The Gemara explains the opinions: <b>Ḥizkiyya says</b> that <b>there is no</b> prohibition against eating the <b>limbs</b> of such an animal, as since it was slaughtered in a valid manner <b>it is</b> considered <b>dead. Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>there is</b> a prohibition against eating the <b>limbs</b> of such an animal, as since it is twitching <b>it is not</b> yet <b>dead.</b> Therefore, since Ḥizkiyya maintains that a twitching animal is considered dead, it should have the impurity of a carcass, contrary to the opinion of the Sages cited by Rabbi Asi, as well as the mishna.
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya in response: Ḥizkiyya maintains that such an animal has <b>left the category of a living</b> animal, <b>but has not entered the category of a dead</b> animal. Therefore, it is not prohibited for a gentile to consume such an animal, but the animal does not have the impurity of a carcass.
§The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself</b> of the dispute between Ḥizkiyya and Rabbi Yoḥanan: If one <b>slaughtered</b> a non-kosher animal by cutting the <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i>, <b>or the majority of</b> the <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i>, <b>and</b> the animal <b>is still twitching, Ḥizkiyya says: There is no</b> prohibition against eating its <b>limbs. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: There is</b> a prohibition against eating its <b>limbs. Rabbi Elazar said: Take that</b> opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan in your hand</b> and accept it, <b>as Rav Oshaya teaches</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with his</b> opinion.
<b>As Rav Oshaya teaches</b> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Oholot</i> 2:1): In the case of <b>a Jew who slaughtered a non-kosher animal for</b> the consumption of <b>a gentile,</b> if <b>he slaughtered</b> it by cutting <b>two</b> <i>simanim</i> <b>or the majority of two</b> <i>simanim</i>, <b>and</b> the animal is still <b>twitching,</b> the animal <b>imparts impurity of food; but</b> so long as it is twitching it does <b>not</b> impart <b>the impurity of</b> animal <b>carcasses.</b>
<b>A limb that separates from</b> this twitching animal is considered <b>like</b> a limb that <b>separates from a living</b> animal, and as such it imparts the impurity of a carcass. <b>And flesh that separates from</b> this twitching animal is considered <b>like flesh that separates from a living</b> animal, and as such it does not impart impurity. <b>And it is prohibited for the descendants of Noah</b> to consume the flesh that separates from this twitching animal, <b>and</b> this prohibition applies <b>even after its soul departs.</b> This ruling of Rav Oshaya is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara cites the continuation of the <i>Tosefta</i>: In the case where a Jew slaughtered a non-kosher animal for a gentile’s consumption, if <b>he slaughtered</b> it by cutting only <b>one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>or the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i>, and the animal is still twitching, the animal <b>does not impart the impurity of food</b> because the slaughter was invalid. Similarly, if he did not perform a valid slaughter but rather <b>stabbed</b> the animal, the animal <b>has no impurity whatsoever</b> while it is still twitching.
<b>And</b> similarly, in the case of <b>a gentile who slaughtered a kosher animal for</b> the consumption of <b>a Jew, and</b> the animal <b>is</b> still <b>twitching,</b> the animal <b>imparts the impurity of food</b> because it is considered to be food, <b>but</b> so long as it is twitching it does <b>not</b> impart <b>the impurity of an animal carcass.</b>
<b>A limb that separates from</b> this twitching animal is considered <b>like</b> a limb that <b>separates from a living</b> animal, and as such it imparts the impurity of a carcass. <b>And flesh that separates from</b> this twitching animal is considered <b>like</b> flesh that <b>separates from a living</b> animal, and as such it does not impart the impurity of food. <b>And it is prohibited for the descendants of Noah</b> to consume the flesh that separates from this twitching animal, <b>and</b> this prohibition applies <b>even after its soul departs.</b>
If the gentile <b>slaughtered</b> the kosher animal by cutting only <b>one</b> <i>siman</i> <b>or the majority of one</b> <i>siman</i>, and the animal is still twitching, the animal <b>does not impart impurity of food</b> because the slaughter was not valid. Similarly, if he <b>stabbed</b> the animal rather than slaughtering it properly, <b>it has no impurity whatsoever.</b>
If <b>a gentile</b> partially <b>slaughtered</b> a kosher animal <b>in a place that does not render</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> i.e., unfit for consumption due to a mortal wound, e.g., he cut half of the windpipe, <b>and</b> then <b>a Jew came and completed</b> the slaughter, the animal is <b>fit</b> for consumption.
But if <b>a Jew slaughtered</b> the animal, <b>either in a place that renders</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> e.g., he cut the majority of the windpipe, <b>or in a place that does not render</b> the animal <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> e.g., he only partially cut the windpipe, <b>and</b> then <b>a gentile came and completed</b> the slaughter, <b>his slaughter is not valid.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>One who wishes to eat from</b> the meat of a slaughtered <b>animal before its soul departs may cut an olive-bulk of meat from the area of its slaughter,</b> the neck, <b>and salt it very well,</b> i.e., more than is normally required, <b>and rinse it very well</b> in water to remove the salt and blood, <b>and</b> then <b>wait until</b> the animal’s <b>soul departs, and</b> then <b>eat it. Both a gentile and a Jew are permitted to</b> eat <b>it</b> because the prohibition against eating a limb from a living animal is not applicable in such a case.
The Gemara notes: This <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Idi bar Avin, as Rav Idi bar Avin said</b> that <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Ashyan said: One who wants to be healthy should cut an olive-bulk of meat from the area of the slaughter, and salt it very well and rinse it very well, and</b> then <b>wait until</b> the animal’s <b>soul departs,</b> and then <b>both a gentile and a Jew are permitted to</b> eat <b>it.</b>
§It was previously taught in the <i>baraita</i> that if a Jew slaughtered a non-kosher animal for a gentile’s consumption, or a gentile slaughtered a kosher animal for a Jew’s consumption, that animal imparts impurity of food when it is twitching after the slaughter. With regard to that <i>halakha</i>, <b>Rabbi Elazar raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in such a case if <b>one interrupted</b> the slaughter or <b>pressed</b> on the knife during the slaughter? Do these acts, which normally invalidate slaughter, also invalidate this slaughter, or does the slaughter in this case not have to fulfill all of the halakhic requirements of valid slaughter in order to render the slaughtered animal as food with regard to imparting the impurity of food?
<b>A certain elder</b> resolved this dilemma and <b>said to him: Rabbi Yoḥanan said as follows:</b> This case <b>requires a valid slaughter</b> in every detail, <b>just like</b> a Jew slaughtering <b>a kosher animal.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>To what</b> requirement does <b>valid</b> slaughter just like a kosher animal refer? <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yitzḥak said:</b> It is referring to the requirement of <b>examining the knife</b> before the slaughter.
<b>Rabbi Zeira asked Rav Sheshet:</b> If a non-kosher animal slaughtered by a Jew is twitching under the same roof as a corpse, and the animal swallowed items before being slaughtered, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to</b> those swallowed items that are inside the animal? Is the animal considered to be living and therefore <b>it should save</b> these items <b>that are swallowed inside it</b> from the impurity transmitted by the corpse to all items under the same roof? Or is the animal considered to be dead and therefore the items become impure?
<b>Rav Sheshet said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: Since it is established that such an animal is considered to be dead and <b>imparts impurity of food,</b> is it possible that it <b>saves</b> those items inside it from impurity? Certainly it does not. Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him</b> in response: It is also established that such an animal <b>does not impart impurity of carcasses and</b> is considered to be a living animal in that regard. How is it possible that the animal <b>does not save</b> those items inside it from impurity?
<b>Abaye</b> resolved the dilemma and <b>said:</b> It is proper to treat this case stringently. Therefore, such an animal <b>does not save</b> the items <b>that are swallowed inside it because it imparts impurity of food. But one who engages in bestiality with</b> such an animal <b>is liable because</b> the animal <b>does not impart impurity of a carcass</b> and is considered to be living in that regard.
§The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>the meat residue</b> attached to the hide after flaying that was collected, if there is an olive-bulk of it in one place it imparts impurity of an animal carcass, and one who contracts impurity from it and eats consecrated foods or enters the Temple is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for it. <b>Rav Huna says</b> in explanation: This <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> applicable only when a halakhically competent person <b>collected</b> the meat residue in one place, but not if the meat residue was collected by a child or without human intervention. By collecting it in one place, the person indicates that he considers it to be food.
<b>And Rav Huna says:</b> In a case of <b>two</b> pieces of flesh of an animal carcass, each measuring <b>half an olive-</b>bulk, <b>that are</b> attached <b>to the hide, the hide nullifies them,</b> as the hide does not impart the impurity of a carcass. Consequently, these pieces do not impart impurity either.

Daf 122a

The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is the statement of Rav Huna? It is taught in the mishna (124a) that in a case where the hide of an unslaughtered carcass was attached to two half olive-bulks of flesh, Rabbi Yishmael says that the hide imparts the impurity of an unslaughtered carcass by means of carrying but not by means of contact with the flesh, because one touches them separately whereas one carries them together. Rabbi Akiva says: One contracts impurity neither by means of contact with the hide nor by means of carrying it.
<b>If</b> one maintains that Rav Huna’s statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yishmael, didn’t</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>say</b> that the <b>hide does not nullify</b> the attached flesh and therefore the one who carries it becomes impure with the impurity of a carcass? <b>And if</b> one maintains that Rav Huna’s statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva,</b> then it is <b>obvious,</b> as <b>didn’t</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>say</b> that <b>the hide nullifies</b> the flesh and therefore one who carries it does not become impure?
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the statement of Rav Huna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yishmael. And when Rabbi Yishmael said</b> that <b>the hide does not nullify</b> the flesh, <b>that statement</b> applies to a case <b>where an animal severed</b> the hide. <b>But</b> in a case where a person used <b>a knife</b> to <b>flay</b> the hide, the hide <b>nullifies</b> the attached flesh.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a refutation to this explanation of the statement of Rav Huna from that which is taught in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> With regard to <b>the meat residue</b> attached to the hide after flaying <b>that was collected, if there is an olive-bulk</b> of it <b>in one place</b> it imparts impurity of an animal carcass, and one who contracts impurity from it and eats consecrated foods or enters the Temple <b>is liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for it. And Rav Huna says</b> in explanation of this statement of Rabbi Yehuda: This <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> applicable only when a halakhically competent person <b>collected</b> the meat residue in one place, but not if the meat residue was collected by a child or without human intervention.
Since Rav Huna interprets the statement of Rabbi Yehuda as referring to a case where a halakhically competent person collected the pieces of flesh, the mishna must be discussing a case where such a person flayed the hide with a knife in multiple places and then collected the pieces of flesh attached to the hide. Evidently, the hide does not nullify the flesh because if the hide did nullify the flesh, that flesh would not impart the impurity of a carcass even if it were later collected. Therefore, the Gemara challenges: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>according to Rabbi Yishmael, even</b> in a case where a person used <b>a knife</b> to <b>flay</b> the hide, the hide <b>does not nullify</b> the flesh, accordingly, <b>Rav Huna said</b> his statement <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael</b> that a hide flayed by a knife does not nullify the flesh, and therefore the flesh imparts the impurity of a carcass if a person collected the pieces.
<b>But if you say</b> that <b>according to Rabbi Yishmael,</b> in a case where a person used <b>a knife</b> to <b>flay</b> the hide, the hide <b>nullifies</b> the flesh and therefore the flesh does not impart the impurity of a carcass even if a halakhically competent person collected the pieces, then <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>did Rav Huna say</b> that the hide does not nullify the flesh and that the pieces of flesh that one collected impart the impurity of a carcass?
The Gemara responds: <b>Rather,</b> it is necessary to explain the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael differently. <b>Actually, according to Rabbi Yishmael</b> even a hide <b>flayed by a knife does not nullify</b> the attached flesh. <b>And Rav Huna said</b> his statement that the hide nullifies attached pieces of flesh <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that the hide nullifies the flesh according to Rabbi Akiva? Rav Huna’s statement is unnecessary. The Gemara answers: Rav Huna’s statement is necessary <b>lest you say: When Rabbi Akiva said</b> that the hide nullifies the attached pieces of flesh, <b>that statement</b> applies only to a case where a person used <b>a knife</b> to <b>flay</b> the animal. <b>But</b> if <b>an animal severed</b> the hide, the hide <b>does not nullify</b> the flesh.
Therefore, Rav Huna <b>teaches us</b> that <b>the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva</b> is <b>because the hide nullifies</b> the flesh, and there <b>is no difference</b> whether <b>an animal severed</b> the hide, <b>and</b> there <b>is no difference</b> whether a person used <b>a knife</b> to <b>flay</b> the hide. This statement of Rav Huna is therefore <b>in accordance with that which the latter clause</b> of that mishna <b>teaches: For what</b> reason <b>does Rabbi Akiva deem</b> one ritually <b>pure in</b> a case where he moved both half olive-bulks with <b>the hide?</b> It is <b>because the hide</b> separates between them and <b>nullifies them.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>These</b> are the entities <b>whose skin</b> has the same halakhic status <b>as their flesh: The skin of</b> a dead <b>person,</b> which imparts impurity like his flesh; <b>and the skin of a domesticated pig,</b> which is soft and eaten by gentiles, and imparts the impurity of an animal carcass like its flesh. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even the skin of a wild boar</b> has the same status.
<b>And</b> the halakhic status of the skin of all of the following animals is also like that of their flesh: <b>The skin of the hump of a young camel</b> that did not yet toughen; <b>and the skin of the head of a young calf; and the hide of the hooves; and the skin of the womb; and the skin of</b> an animal <b>fetus</b> in the womb of a slaughtered animal; <b>and the skin beneath the tail</b> of a ewe; <b>and the skin of the gecko [<i>anaka</i>], and the desert monitor [<i>ko’aḥ</i>], and the lizard [<i>leta’a</i>], and the skink [<i>ḥomet</i>],</b> four of the eight creeping animals that impart ritual impurity after death. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The halakhic status of the skin of <b>the lizard</b> is <b>like</b> that of the skin of <b>the weasel</b> and is not like that of its flesh.
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of</b> these skins, in a case <b>where one tanned them or</b> spread them on the ground and <b>trod upon them for the period of time required for tanning,</b> they are no longer classified as flesh and are <b>ritually pure, except for the skin of a person,</b> which maintains the status of flesh. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says:</b> All <b>eight creeping animals</b> enumerated in the Torah <b>have skins</b> whose halakhic status is not that of flesh.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The first clause of the mishna teaches that the skin of a dead person imparts impurity like his flesh. With regard to this, <b>Ulla says: The skin of</b> a dead <b>person is pure by Torah law; and what</b> is the <b>reason</b> that the Sages <b>said</b> that it is <b>impure?</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree lest a person fashion mats</b> from <b>the skins of his</b> deceased <b>father and mother.</b>
<b>And there are those who teach</b> this statement of Ulla <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of</b> these skins, in a case <b>where one tanned them or</b> spread them on the ground and <b>trod upon them for the period of time required for tanning,</b> they are no longer classified as flesh and are <b>ritually pure, except for the skin of a person,</b> which maintains the status of flesh. With regard to that clause, <b>Ulla says: The skin of</b> a dead <b>person that one tanned is pure by Torah law; and what</b> is the <b>reason</b> that the Sages <b>said</b> that it is <b>impure?</b> It is a rabbinic <b>decree lest a person fashion mats</b> from <b>the skins of his</b> deceased <b>father and mother.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>The one who teaches</b> the statement of Ulla that the skin of a corpse is pure by Torah law <b>with regard to the first clause</b> of the mishna, which discusses a softer hide that is not tanned, <b>all the more so</b> would teach it <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna. <b>But the one who teaches</b> this statement <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna holds that only the tanned skin of a corpse is pure by Torah law, <b>but</b> does not teach it <b>with regard to the first clause</b> of the mishna because he holds that the <b>impurity</b> of the skin of a corpse that is not tanned is <b>by Torah law.</b>
§The mishna teaches that according to the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>the skin of</b> a domesticated <b>pig</b> imparts impurity of an animal carcass like its flesh, indicates that the skin of a wild boar does not impart impurity of a carcass. Rabbi Yehuda disagrees and holds that even the skin of a wild boar has the same status as its flesh. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do</b> the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Yehuda <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: One <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>this</b> skin of a wild boar <b>is tough</b> and therefore its status is not that of flesh, <b>but that</b> skin of a domesticated pig <b>is soft</b> and therefore its status is that of flesh. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>this</b> skin of a wild boar <b>is also soft</b> and therefore its status is that of flesh.
§The mishna teaches that the <b>skin of the hump of a young camel</b> that did not yet toughen imparts impurity of a carcass like its flesh. The Gemara asks: <b>And for how long is a camel</b> considered <b>young</b> and the status of the skin considered like that of the flesh? <b>Ulla says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: As long as</b> the camel <b>has not carried</b> a burden.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the skin of a camel <b>whose time,</b> i.e., age, <b>to carry</b> a burden <b>has arrived, but it has not</b> yet <b>carried</b> one? <b>Abaye raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the skin of a camel <b>whose time to carry</b> a burden <b>has not arrived, but it has</b> nevertheless <b>carried</b> one? The Gemara answers: These dilemmas <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Reish Lakish sat and raised a dilemma:</b> For <b>how long is a camel</b> considered <b>young? Rabbi Yishmael bar Abba said to him: This is what Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: As long as</b> the camel <b>has not carried</b> a burden. In response to his answer, Reish Lakish honored him and <b>said to him: Sit opposite me.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira sat and raised a dilemma:</b> For <b>how long is a camel</b> considered <b>young? Ravin bar Ḥinnana said to him: This is what Ulla said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: As long as</b> the camel <b>has not carried</b> a burden. Ravin bar Ḥinnana then <b>repeated</b> his answer to Rabbi Zeira. Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: Do you have</b> only <b>one</b> <i>halakha</i> to <b>say,</b> and that is why you are repeating it?
The Gemara points out: <b>Come</b> and <b>see what</b> the difference is <b>between the harsh</b> scholars <b>of Eretz Yisrael,</b> such as Reish Lakish, <b>and the saintly ones of Babylonia,</b> such as Rabbi Zeira. Although Reish Lakish was known for his harsh nature, he was the one who honored the Sage who resolved his dilemma, whereas Rabbi Zeira responded sharply to the one who taught him this <i>halakha</i>.
§The mishna teaches: <b>And the skin of the head</b> of a young calf has the same halakhic status as the flesh with regard to impurity. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> for <b>how long is a calf</b> considered <b>young? Ulla says:</b> It is considered young in <b>its</b> first <b>year of age. Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> For <b>as long as</b> the calf is <b>suckling. A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>what</b> case <b>is Ulla speaking?</b> Is he referring to a calf that is in <b>its</b> first <b>year of age and is</b> still <b>suckling,</b>

Daf 122b

<b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> disagreed with Ulla and <b>said to him:</b> A calf is considered young <b>as long as it is suckling,</b> even after its first year of age? According to this explanation, Ulla considers a calf to be young only when it is both in its first year and suckling, and Rabbi Yoḥanan considers a calf that is suckling to be young even if it is beyond its first year.
<b>Or perhaps, does Ulla say</b> that a calf is considered young if it is in <b>its</b> first <b>year of age, whether it is suckling or whether it is no</b> longer <b>suckling, and Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him:</b> The calf must be in <b>its</b> first <b>year of age and it</b> must also be <b>suckling</b> in order to be considered young?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The calf is considered young <b>the entire time that it is suckling. And if it is so</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan requires a calf to be both in its first year and suckling to be considered young, Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>should have</b> said: <b>And</b> provided the calf <b>is suckling,</b> indicating an additional condition. <b>Conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan considers a calf that is suckling to be young even if it is beyond its first year, and that Ulla considers only a calf that is both in its first year and suckling to be young.
§The Gemara continues to discuss the skin of the head of a young calf. <b>Reish Lakish asked Rabbi Yoḥanan: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to whether <b>the skin of the head of a young calf</b> that is still fit to be eaten <b>imparts impurity?</b> Is the status of the skin like that of flesh or not? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: It does not impart impurity.</b>
Reish Lakish <b>said to him:</b> But didn’t <b>you teach us, our teacher,</b> that it says in the mishna: <b>These</b> are the entities <b>whose skin</b> has the same halakhic status <b>as their flesh, and the skin of the head of a young calf</b> is included among them? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Reish Lakish: <b>Do not provoke me</b> by asking such a question. <b>I teach that</b> mishna <b>in the singular,</b> i.e., that mishna is in accordance with an individual opinion and is contrary to the majority opinion. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with it.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who slaughters a burnt offering</b> with the intention <b>to burn an olive-bulk of the skin beneath the tail outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> i.e., outside the Temple courtyard, renders the offering <b>unfit, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i></b> for one who partakes of the offering. If he intended to burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> i.e., not on that day, then it is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> partaking of <b>it.</b> Since this particular area of the skin is soft, its status is therefore like that of flesh. This is the opinion of the Rabbis.
<b>Elazar ben Yehuda of Aveilum says in the name of Rabbi Ya’akov, and so Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda of Kefar Ikom says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b> This <i>halakha</i> applies <b>both</b> to <b>the hide of the hooves, and the skin of the head of a young calf, and the skin beneath the tail, and all</b> of the entities <b>that the Sages listed with regard to ritual impurity</b> that the halakhic status of <b>their skin is like that of their flesh, including the skin of the womb.</b>
Therefore, one who sacrifices a burnt offering with the intention to burn an olive-bulk of any of these skins <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area</b> renders the offering <b>unfit, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i></b> for one who partakes of the offering. If he intended to burn it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> then it is rendered <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> eating <b>it.</b> Therefore, the mishna is in accordance with the individual opinion of Elazar ben Yehuda, who holds that all of the skins listed in the mishna have the status of flesh, and not in accordance with the Rabbis’ opinion that only the skin beneath the tail has the status of flesh.
§The mishna teaches: <b>And the hide of the hooves</b> has the status of flesh with regard to imparting impurity. The Gemara asks: To <b>what</b> is <b>the</b> term <b>hooves</b> referring? <b>Rav says:</b> It is <b>literally</b> referring to <b>the hooves. Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> It is referring to the skin of the section of <b>the knee</b> at the top of the lower bone, <b>which is sold with the head.</b> This skin of the knee, and of the lower bone attached to it, has the status of flesh.
§The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> the halakhic status of <b>the skin of the gecko,</b> and the desert monitor, and the lizard, and the skink, four of the eight creeping animals that impart ritual impurity after death, is like that of their flesh with regard to imparting impurity. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is written: “And these are they which are impure for you among the creeping animals that creep upon the earth: The weasel, and the mouse, and the great lizard after its kinds. And the gecko, and the desert monitor, and the lizard, and the skink, and the chameleon. These are <b>they which are impure</b> for you among all that swarm; whosoever touches them, when they are dead, shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:29–32). The term “they which are” in the expression “they which are impure” seems superfluous, and serves <b>to include the skins of</b> these animals as having the same halakhic status <b>as their flesh.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>even</b> to <b>all</b> of the creeping animals listed in the verses. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “These,”</b> indicating that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to these animals mentioned in the mishna, i.e., the gecko, the desert monitor, the lizard, and the skink.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t</b> the term <b>“these” written with regard to all</b> eight of the creeping animals listed in the verse? <b>Rav says:</b> After mentioning the weasel, the mouse, and the great lizard the verse states: <b>“After its kinds.”</b> Therefore, the verse <b>interrupted the</b> previous <b>matter</b> and taught that the status of the skin is like that of the flesh only with regard to the creeping animals mentioned in the latter part of the verse.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> since the chameleon is listed in the latter part of the verse, <b>let</b> the <b>chameleon also be counted</b> among the animals whose skin has the status of flesh. <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yitzḥak said: Rav,</b> who interprets the verse in this manner, has the status of <b>a <i>tanna</i>, and</b> unlike the mishna, <b>he teaches</b> that the skin of the <b>chameleon</b> has the status of flesh.
The Gemara asks: <b>But the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna <b>does not teach</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>chameleon.</b> According to his opinion, why doesn’t the skin of the chameleon have the status of flesh?
<b>Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, said: The <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda that</b> the halakhic status of the skin of the lizard, even though it is mentioned in the latter part of the verse, is like that of the skin of the weasel and is not like that of its flesh. Rabbi Yehuda does not derive that the status of the skin is like that of flesh from the verse that states: “They which are impure.” Rather, he <b>follows the texture</b> of the skin of each creeping animal when deciding whether the status of its skin is like that of its flesh.
The first <i>tanna</i> of the mishna and Rabbi Yehuda agree that the texture of the skin of the gecko, the desert monitor, and the skink is soft and therefore the status of their skin is like that of their flesh; <b>and they disagree with regard to the texture</b> of the skin <b>of the lizard.</b> Rabbi Yehuda classifies its skin as tough, and the first <i>tanna</i> of the mishna classifies its skin as soft.
§The mishna teaches: <b>And all of these</b> skins, in a case <b>where one tanned them</b> or spread them on the ground and trod upon them, are no longer classified as flesh and are ritually pure. The Gemara objects: The mishna indicates that if one <b>trod</b> upon them they <b>are</b> no longer classified as flesh, but if one <b>did not tread</b> upon them they do <b>not</b> cease being classified as flesh. <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya teach: The ear of a donkey that one sewed into his basket is pure</b> and is no longer classified as flesh. Just as the ear is no longer classified as flesh once it is <b>sewed</b> into a basket, so too skin that is spread on the ground, <b>even if</b> one <b>did not tread</b> upon it, should no longer be classified as flesh.
The Gemara explains: <b>No,</b> this is not difficult. <b>Sewing</b> the ear is an action that nullifies the ear’s classification as flesh. But spreading skin on the ground is not an action that nullifies the skin’s classification as flesh unless one trod upon the skin. Therefore, if one <b>trod</b> upon the skin it <b>is</b> no longer classified as flesh, but if one <b>did not tread</b> upon it, it does <b>not</b> cease being classified as flesh.
The mishna states that the skin must be trodden upon for the period required for tanning. The Gemara clarifies: <b>How long is the period</b> required <b>for tanning? Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai says:</b> The time which it takes one to walk <b>four <i>mil</i>.</b>
§Since the period of time it takes to walk four <i>mil</i> was mentioned, the Gemara lists <i>halakhot</i> that employ this period of time. <b>Rabbi Abbahu says in the name of Reish Lakish: With regard to</b> a professional <b>kneader</b> who is careful to maintain the ritual purity of the dough that he kneads for others, he must walk up to four <i>mil</i> in order to purify the vessel he is using by immersing it in a ritual bath. He is not required to walk farther than this unless the person hiring him pays for him to do so.
<b>And</b> similarly, <b>with regard to prayer,</b> one who is traveling may not pray where he is if there is a synagogue within four <i>mil</i> ahead of him, but rather must continue traveling in order to pray in the synagogue. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>with regard to washing</b> one’s <b>hands</b> before eating, one who is traveling may not eat without washing his hands if there is water within <b>four <i>mil</i></b> ahead of him.
With regard to this statement of Reish Lakish, <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b>

Daf 123a

It was <b>Aivu</b> who <b>said</b> this statement in the name of Reish Lakish and not Rabbi Abbahu, <b>and he said four</b> <i>halakhot</i>, not three, with regard to the measure of four <i>mil</i>, <b>and</b> the fourth <b>one of them</b> is the <i>halakha</i> mentioned in the mishna: Skins that one spread on the ground and trod upon for the period required for <b>tanning,</b> i.e., the amount of time it takes to walk four <i>mil</i>, are no longer classified as flesh and are ritually pure.
