<b>A full ladle of dust imparts impurity via carrying and in a tent, but it does not impart impurity via contact,</b> as it is impossible for one to touch all of the particles of dust simultaneously. <b>And where</b> among these sources of impurity is the imparting of impurity via <b>contact</b> applicable? It is applicable <b>with one of those</b> other two sources of impurity, i.e., a bone the size of a barley grain and the cover or wall of a grave.
<b>A bone</b> the size of <b>a barley grain imparts impurity via carrying and contact, but it does not impart impurity in a tent.</b> This <i>halakha</i> was transmitted to Moses from Sinai. <b>And where</b> among these sources of impurity is impurity imparted in <b>a tent?</b> It is <b>with one of those</b> other two sources of impurity.
<b>A grave cover and a grave wall impart impurity via contact and in a tent, but they do not impart impurity via carrying.</b> This <i>halakha</i> too was transmitted to Moses from Sinai. <b>And where</b> among these sources of impurity is impurity transmitted via <b>carrying?</b> It is <b>with one of those</b> other two sources of impurity. It may be inferred from Rabbi Shimon’s statement that a full ladle of dust imparts impurity in a tent but not via contact that he disagrees with Rabbi Yosei and holds that overlying is not the same category as touching.
§The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>the thigh bone of an unslaughtered carcass and the thigh bone of a creeping animal,</b> one who touches them when they are sealed remains ritually pure, because the bone itself does not impart impurity. With regard to this topic, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “One who touches the carcass thereof shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:39). The word <b>“carcass”</b> indicates that one who touches the carcass is impure, <b>but</b> one who touches <b>a sealed thigh bone is not.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> one who touches <b>a perforated</b> thigh bone remains pure. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “One who touches</b> the carcass thereof [<i>benivlatah</i>] <b>shall be impure,”</b> indicating that one who touches a part of the animal through <b>which it is possible to touch</b> the flesh, which has the halakhic status of an unslaughtered carcass [<i>neveila</i>], is <b>impure, but</b> one who touches a part of the animal through <b>which it is impossible to touch</b> the flesh remains <b>pure.</b> Therefore, one who touches a protective layer such as the outside of a sealed thigh bone does not become impure, as it is impossible to touch the marrow.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to Abaye: If that is so,</b> that one who touches the protective layer of a carcass via which it is impossible to touch the flesh of the carcass itself does not become impure, <b>an animal</b> still <b>in its hide should not impart impurity,</b> as one can touch the hide, which constitutes a protective layer, but not the flesh. Abaye answered: <b>Go out</b> and <b>see how many orifices there are in</b> the body of an animal via which one can touch the flesh, e.g., the eyes, the nostrils, and the mouth.
Similarly, <b>Rav Pappa said to Rava: If that is so,</b> that one who touches the protective layer of a carcass via which it is impossible to touch the flesh of the carcass itself does not become impure, <b>the kidney</b> of a carcass that is completely covered <b>in its fat should not impart impurity</b> via contact. Rava answered: <b>Come</b> and <b>see how many sinews emerge from</b> the kidney that one is able to touch.
§The mishna taught that the <i>halakha</i> distinguishes between a sealed and a perforated thigh bone of a carcass or a creeping animal. With regard to this topic, <b>Rav Oshaya raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if <b>one intended to perforate</b> the thigh bone <b>but did not</b> yet <b>perforate it?</b> This is the dilemma: Is a thigh bone <b>lacking perforation considered to be lacking</b> the necessary <b>action</b> for it to impart impurity, and it therefore retains its status as a sealed thigh bone, <b>or not?</b>
Rabbi Oshaya <b>then resolves</b> the dilemma: A thigh bone <b>lacking perforation is not considered to be lacking</b> the necessary <b>action</b> for it to impart impurity. If one intends to perforate it, it imparts impurity immediately.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The egg of a creeping animal in which tissue</b> of an embryo <b>developed</b> and one who comes into contact with the egg are <b>ritually pure,</b> as the impure creeping animal is hermetically sealed. But if <b>one perforated</b> the egg with a hole of <b>any size,</b> one who comes in contact with the egg is <b>ritually impure.</b> In the case of <b>a mouse that</b> grows from the ground and <b>is half-flesh half-earth, one who touches the</b> half that is <b>flesh is impure;</b> one who touches <b>the</b> half that is <b>earth is pure. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even one who touches the</b> half that is <b>earth where it is adjacent to the flesh is ritually impure.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that in the case of an egg of a creeping animal in which tissue of an embryo developed, if it is perforated then one who touches it is ritually impure. With regard to this matter <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “These are the impure ones to you among all that creep; whoever touches them when they are dead shall be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 11:31). The term <b>“the impure ones”</b> is interpreted as <b>including the egg of a creeping animal and the thigh bone of a creeping animal</b> in the category of sources of impurity.
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>even</b> an egg <b>in which tissue</b> of an embryo <b>has not developed</b> imparts impurity. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “That creep,”</b> indicating that <b>just as a creeping animal has developed tissue, so too</b> only <b>the egg of a creeping animal in which tissue</b> of an embryo <b>has developed</b> imparts impurity.
One <b>might</b> have thought that in the case of an egg in which tissue of an embryo has developed, it imparts impurity <b>even</b> if it <b>was not perforated.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Whoever touches</b> them when they are dead <b>shall be impure,”</b> indicating that <b>when it is possible to touch</b> the flesh, contact renders one <b>impure; but when it is impossible to touch</b> the flesh, one remains <b>pure.</b>
<b>And how</b> large must <b>its perforation</b> be to render one touching the egg or thigh bone impure? Its width must be the size of <b>a strand of hair, as it is possible</b> for one <b>to touch</b> the inside of an egg or thigh bone <b>with a strand of</b> his <b>hair.</b>
§The mishna teaches: In the case of <b>a mouse that</b> grows from the ground and <b>is half-</b>flesh half-earth, one who touches the half that is flesh is impure. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says</b> in this regard: One becomes impure in such a case <b>only</b> if the flesh of the mouse has <b>developed along the entire</b> length of the mouse, from head to foot. <b>Some teach</b> the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even one who touches</b> the half that is <b>earth where it is adjacent to the flesh is ritually impure. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> One becomes impure in such a case <b>only</b> if the flesh of the mouse has <b>developed along the entire</b> length of the mouse.
<b>The one who teaches</b> the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>with regard to the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>all the more so</b> he teaches this same <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna. <b>But the one who teaches</b> the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna holds that it applies only to that clause, with regard to one who touches the half that is earth where it is adjacent to the flesh according to Rabbi Yehuda. <b>But</b> according to the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>, stated in <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>even if</b> the flesh of the mouse <b>has not developed</b> along the entire length of the mouse, one who touches the half of the mouse that is flesh is impure.
§<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning the following verse: “And these are they which are impure to you among the creeping animals that creep upon the earth: The weasel, and the mouse, and the great lizard after its kinds” (Leviticus 11:29). <b>Since “mouse” is stated</b> among the creeping animals that impart impurity, <b>I</b> would <b>derive</b> that <b>even a sea mouse,</b> i.e., a sea creature that has an appearance similar to a mouse, imparts impurity <b>because its name is</b> also <b>mouse. But</b> ostensibly, the opposite conclusion could be derived through <b>logical inference:</b> The verse <b>deems a weasel impure and deems a mouse impure.</b> Therefore, <b>just as a weasel is a species that grows on land, so too</b> the <b>mouse</b> to which the verse is referring is <b>a species that grows on land;</b> a sea mouse does not impart impurity.
<b>Or,</b> perhaps <b>go this way:</b> The verse <b>deems a weasel impure and deems a mouse impure;</b> accordingly, <b>just as “weasel”</b> is referring to <b>any</b> animal <b>whose name is weasel, so too, “mouse”</b> is referring to <b>any</b> animal <b>whose name is mouse, even a sea mouse, as its name is</b> also <b>mouse.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Upon the earth,”</b> indicating that a land mouse imparts impurity, but a sea mouse does not.
<b>If</b> this <i>halakha</i> is derived only from the phrase <b>“upon the earth,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the verse means that any mouse, whether a land mouse or a sea mouse, <b>imparts impurity</b> when it is <b>upon the earth,</b> but if <b>it descended to the sea it does not impart impurity.</b>

Daf 127a

Therefore, <b>the verse states: “That creep,”</b> indicating that creeping animals impart impurity <b>anywhere that</b> they <b>creep,</b> including the sea, as these animals can float in the sea. Consequently, the phrase “upon the earth” is understood as indicating that a sea mouse does not impart impurity.
The <i>baraita</i> raises an alternative interpretation: <b>Or</b> perhaps the term <b>“that creep [<i>hashoretz</i>]”</b> should <b>not</b> be interpreted in this manner, as it <b>could rather</b> be interpreted to mean that <b>any</b> creeping animal <b>that breeds [<i>hammashritz</i>] imparts impurity,</b> but a creeping animal <b>that does not breed does not impart impurity. I shall</b> therefore <b>exclude a mouse that is half</b>-<b>flesh half-earth,</b> i.e., that generates spontaneously from the earth, <b>as it does not breed</b> and therefore does not impart impurity.
<b>But</b> ostensibly, the <i>halakha</i> of a mouse that is half-flesh half-earth is subject to <b>logical inference:</b> Since the verse <b>deems a weasel impure and deems a mouse impure,</b> then <b>just as “weasel”</b> is referring to <b>any</b> animal <b>whose name is weasel, so too, “mouse”</b> is referring to <b>any</b> animal <b>whose name is mouse, even a mouse that is half-flesh half-earth.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps <b>go this way:</b> One might think that <b>just as a weasel breeds, so too, “mouse”</b> is referring to a mouse that <b>breeds,</b> excluding one that generates from the earth, which does not impart impurity. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And these are they which are impure to you <b>among the creeping animals</b> that creep upon the earth.” The term “among the creeping animals” is interpreted as including a spontaneously generated mouse. Therefore, the term “that creep” is interpreted as indicating that creeping animals impart impurity on land and in the sea, and the phrase “upon the earth” teaches that a sea mouse is not included in the category of mouse and does not impart impurity.
<b>One of the Sages said to Rava: Say</b> the interpretation of the verse differently. The term <b>“among the creeping animals”</b> serves <b>to include a mouse that is half-flesh half-earth</b> among those that impart impurity. The term <b>“that creep”</b> teaches that <b>any</b> animal <b>that creeps</b> imparts impurity, <b>and even a sea mouse. And if</b> one should reject this interpretation <b>due to</b> the phrase <b>“upon the earth,”</b> which seems to indicate that a sea mouse does not impart impurity, that phrase teaches that a creeping animal <b>imparts impurity</b> only when it is <b>on land,</b> but if it <b>descended to the sea</b> it <b>does not impart impurity.</b>
Rava <b>said to him:</b> Your suggestion is not logical. According to your opinion, a sea mouse, which is in the sea, imparts impurity. <b>And since you consider the sea a location of impurity,</b> it is impossible to suggest that a mouse does not impart impurity when it is located in the sea. Since both land and sea are places of impurity, <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>for me</b> if the mouse is located <b>here</b> on land, and <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>for me</b> if it is located <b>there</b> in the sea?
The Gemara asks: How can the <i>baraita</i> interpret the phrase “upon the earth” as teaching that a sea mouse does not impart impurity? Isn’t <b>this</b> phrase: <b>“Upon the earth,” necessary to exclude</b> a case of <b>uncertainty</b> involving <b>a floating</b> source of <b>impurity?</b> If a person is uncertain whether he touched a source of impurity that is floating in the water, he remains pure even if the incident took place in a private domain, where a case of uncertain impurity is generally deemed impure. <b>As Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi said:</b> The phrase <b>“upon the earth”</b> is written <b>to exclude</b> a case of <b>uncertainty</b> involving <b>a floating</b> source of <b>impurity.</b>
The Gemara answers: The phrase <b>“upon the earth” is written two</b> times in the passage. One instance is written to exclude a case of uncertainty involving a source of impurity that is floating, and the other instance teaches that a sea mouse does not impart impurity.
§With regard to the topic of the eight creeping animals mentioned in the Torah, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse: <b>“The great lizard after its kinds”</b> (Leviticus 11:29) <b>includes</b> in the category of creeping animals <b>the <i>arvad</i>,</b> a type of snake, <b>and also</b> the creeping animals called <b><i>nefilim</i> and salamander [<i>salamandera</i>].</b>
Apropos the salamander, which was thought to generate from fire, the <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>When Rabbi Akiva would reach this verse</b> in Leviticus, he would <b>say</b> in exclamation: <b>“How great are Your works, O Lord”</b> (Psalms 104:24). <b>You have creatures</b> that <b>grow in the sea and you have creatures</b> that <b>grow on land. If those in the sea would ascend to the land they would immediately die. If those that are on land would descend to the sea they would immediately die.</b>
Similarly, <b>you have creatures</b> that <b>grow in the fire and you have creatures</b> that <b>grow in the air. If those in the fire would ascend to the air they would immediately die. If those in the air would descend to the fire they would immediately die.</b> Therefore, <b>“how great are Your works, O Lord.”</b>
§The Gemara continues to discuss creatures living in a particular environment. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Kilayim</i> 5:10): For <b>every</b> animal <b>that exists on land there is</b> an equivalent animal <b>in the sea, except for the weasel,</b> which exists only on land. <b>Rabbi Zeira said: What is the verse</b> from which it is derived? It is written: <b>“Listen all you inhabitants of the world [<i>ḥeled</i>]”</b> (Psalms 49:2). Dry land is called <i>ḥeled</i> because it is the sole habitat for the weasel [<i>ḥulda</i>].
In continuation of the discussion of creatures living in a particular environment, <b>Rav Huna the son of Rav Yehoshua said: The beavers</b> of the region <b>of Neresh are not from the settled area,</b> because they live only in the water and not on dry land. Consequently, one who eats their meat is not liable to receive lashes for violating the prohibition: “And every creeping animal that creeps upon the earth is a detestable thing; it shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 11:41).
§Apropos the region surrounding Neresh, <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The people of the city of <b>Neresh</b> shall be placed <b>under excommunication,</b> as they are all wicked, including <b>its fat, its hide, and its tail,</b> i.e., all types of people, both old and young. The Gemara continues to discuss Neresh. The verse states: <b>“Oh land, land, land hear the word of the Lord”</b> (Jeremiah 22:29). <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> This verse is appropriate with regard to the inhabitants of Neresh, as <b>Neresh does not want to listen to the word of the Lord.</b>
Furthermore, <b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> If <b>a resident of Neresh kisses you, count your teeth</b> to make sure he did not steal one. And if <b>a resident of</b> the city of <b>Nehar Pekod accompanies you</b> on a journey, it is <b>because of the beautiful jacket that he sees on you</b> and wants to steal from you. If <b>a resident of Pumbedita accompanies you</b> on a journey, <b>change your lodging place</b> because there is a concern that he will rob you.
§The Gemara returns to discussing different types of creatures. <b>Rav Huna bar Torta said: Once I went to</b> the city of <b>Va’ad and I saw</b> that the locals were in the practice of placing <b>a snake wrapped around a great lizard</b> in order to breed the two. <b>After a period of time, an <i>arvad</i>,</b> a snake that bites and kills people, <b>emerged from between them.</b>
<b>And when I came before Rabbi Shimon the Righteous, he</b> explained why this crossbreeding created an <i>arvad</i> and <b>said to me: The Holy One, Blessed be He, said:</b> These residents of Va’ad <b>caused the emergence of a creature that I did not create in My world</b> by crossbreeding a snake and a great lizard; <b>so too, I will bring upon them</b> a punishment, the hazard of this uniquely dangerous <b>creature that I did not create in My world,</b> i.e., an <i>arvad</i>.
The Gemara objects: <b>But didn’t the Master say: All</b> different animals <b>whose</b> method of <b>procreation and</b> period of <b>gestation are the same</b> are able to <b>reproduce and raise offspring together. But all</b> animals <b>whose</b> method of <b>procreation and</b> period of <b>gestation are not the same cannot reproduce and raise offspring together.</b> And the gestation period for a great lizard and a snake are not equal.
<b>Rav says:</b> It was <b>a miracle within a miracle</b> that they were able to reproduce and a new creature was born. The Gemara asks: Why is <b>this</b> considered a miracle? <b>It was a calamity</b> because an <i>arvad</i> was born. The Gemara answers: <b>What</b> is meant by <b>a miracle within a miracle?</b> It was a miraculous <b>calamity</b> for the wicked people, to punish them for their actions.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The limb</b> of an animal, with flesh, sinews, and bones, <b>and the flesh</b> of an animal, <b>that were</b> partially severed and remain <b>hanging from the animal</b> do not have the halakhic status of a limb severed from a living animal, which imparts impurity like an unslaughtered carcass, or of flesh severed from a living animal, which is ritually pure, respectively. If one had intent to eat the limb or the flesh, the limb or flesh becomes impure if it comes in contact with a source of impurity, and they <b>impart impurity as food</b> to other foods and liquids, although they remain <b>in their place</b> attached to the animal. <b>But</b> in order for them to become impure, <b>they need</b> to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity through contact with one of the seven liquids that facilitate susceptibility.

Daf 127b

If <b>the animal was slaughtered,</b> although this act of slaughter does not render it permitted for consumption by a Jew (see 73b), the limb and the flesh <b>were</b> thereby <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity by coming in contact <b>with the blood of</b> the slaughtered animal, as blood is one of the seven liquids; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Shimon says: They were not rendered susceptible</b> to impurity through the animal’s own blood; they are rendered susceptible only once they have been wet with another liquid.
If <b>the animal died</b> without slaughter, <b>the</b> hanging <b>flesh needs</b> to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity in order to become impure, as its halakhic status is that of flesh severed from a living animal, which is ritually pure and does not have the status of an unslaughtered carcass. <b>The</b> hanging <b>limb imparts impurity as a limb</b> severed <b>from a living</b> animal <b>but does not impart impurity as the limb of</b> an unslaughtered <b>carcass;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> the limb <b>ritually pure.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that the limb of an animal that was partially severed and remains hanging from the animal imparts impurity as food if one had intent to eat it. The Gemara infers: It imparts <b>impurity as food, yes,</b> but it does <b>not</b> impart <b>the impurity of a carcass,</b> which can be transmitted to people and utensils in addition to food.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> the limb <b>can heal</b> and reattach to the animal’s body then <b>it should not be susceptible even to impurity as food. And if it cannot heal, it should impart the impurity of a carcass as well.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the mishna is discussing a case <b>where</b> the limb <b>will not heal, and</b> the reason that the limb does not impart impurity of a carcass is that <b>the impurity of a carcass is different</b> and unique, <b>as the Merciful One states</b> with regard to the impurity of a carcass: “And <b>if</b> any of their carcass <b>fall</b> upon any sowing seed” (Leviticus 11:37), indicating that the severed limb of an animal is not considered a carcass <b>until it</b> completely <b>falls</b> from the animal.
<b>This</b> explanation <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the limb and the flesh</b> of an animal <b>that</b> were partially severed and remain <b>hanging from the animal and are connected</b> to the animal <b>by</b> a connector the size of <b>a strand of hair,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they impart the impurity of a carcass.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And if any of the carcass <b>fall,”</b> indicating that a severed limb does not impart the impurity of a carcass <b>until it</b> completely <b>falls</b> from the animal. <b>And nevertheless,</b> despite the fact that it is not considered severed with regard to the impurity of a carcass, such a limb is considered severed with regard to <b>being susceptible to impurity as food.</b>
This explanation <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi, as Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>figs that dried</b> while still attached to <b>their tree,</b> despite the fact that they are still attached, they are considered as if they have been picked and <b>are susceptible to impurity as food. But</b> with regard to <b>one who picks them on Shabbat</b> they are considered attached, and <b>he is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin offering.</b> Just as a partially severed limb of an animal is considered both attached and severed with regard to different <i>halakhot</i>, so too this dried fruit is considered both attached and detached with regard to different <i>halakhot</i>.
<b>Let us say</b> that a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Okatzin</i> 2:11) <b>supports</b> the opinion of Shmuel, who holds that dried figs still attached to the tree are considered as if they are detached with regard to susceptibility to impurity as food: <b>Vegetables that dried</b> while they are attached to <b>their plant, such as cabbage and gourd,</b> which become hard as wood and inedible when dried, <b>are not susceptible to impurity as food.</b> But if <b>one cut them</b> when they were still moist <b>and</b> then <b>dried them</b> in order to use them for fuel, or, in the case of gourds, to make utensils out of them, <b>they are susceptible to impurity as food.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> that if <b>one cut them and dried them</b> they are susceptible to impurity as food? Such a vegetable <b>is merely wood,</b> and it is inedible. <b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is discussing a case <b>where</b> one cut the vegetables when they were still moist <b>in order to dry them.</b> The novelty of the <i>baraita</i> is that even though one intends to dry the vegetables and render them inedible, as long as they are still moist they are susceptible to impurity as food.
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i> in the <i>baraita</i> is <b>that it is</b> discussing <b>cabbage and gourd: Since one dried them, they are inedible</b> and consequently are not susceptible to impurity as food. <b>But other</b> types of <b>produce,</b> which are edible when dried, <b>are susceptible to impurity.</b>
The Gemara explains the suggested support to Shmuel: <b>What are the circumstances? If one dried</b> both the produce <b>itself and its stems,</b> isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that the produce is no longer considered attached to the plant and is susceptible to impurity? If so, it would be unnecessary for the <i>baraita</i> to teach this. <b>Rather, isn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> discussing a case where one dried the produce <b>without</b> drying <b>its stems?</b> Accordingly, in such a case the produce is considered detached with regard to impurity even though it is considered attached with regard to Shabbat, in accordance with the statement of Shmuel.
The Gemara rejects this interpretation: The <i>baraita</i> is not necessarily discussing that case. <b>Actually,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is discussing a case where both the produce <b>itself and its stems</b> were dried. <b>And</b> although it appears that the <i>halakha</i> is obvious in such a case, <b>it was necessary for</b> the <i>baraita</i> to mention it in order to teach the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i>: In a case where one <b>cut</b> the cabbage and gourd when they were still moist <b>in order to dry them,</b> they are susceptible to impurity as long as they are still moist.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a challenge to the opinion of Shmuel from a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a tree from which a branch broke off, and</b> the branch <b>has fruit</b> attached to it, even if the fruit is still moist <b>it is considered detached</b> from the tree. But if the branch did not break off, and the fruit <b>dried</b> on the tree, <b>it is considered attached. What, isn’t</b> the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> that <b>just as</b> in the first clause the fruit on the detached branch is considered <b>detached with regard to all matters,</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of both Shabbat and impurity, <b>so too</b> in the latter clause the fruit that dried on the tree is considered <b>attached</b> to the tree <b>with regard to all matters,</b> even the transmission of impurity, contrary to the opinion of Shmuel?
The Gemara rejects this challenge: <b>Are the cases comparable? This</b> case is <b>as it is, and that</b> case is <b>as it is.</b> In the first clause of the <i>baraita</i>, the fruit on the detached branch is considered detached with regard to all matters. In the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i>, the dried fruit on the tree is considered attached with regard to Shabbat but detached with regard to impurity.
§The mishna teaches: If <b>the animal was slaughtered,</b> Rabbi Meir holds that with the blood of the slaughtered animal the limb and the flesh were rendered susceptible to impurity. Rabbi Shimon says that they were not rendered susceptible with the animal’s own blood. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon <b>disagree?</b>
<b>Rabba said:</b> The mishna is discussing a case where the blood of the slaughtered animal came into contact with the body of the animal but not with the partially severed limb. The <i>tanna’im</i> agree that if an appendage that constitutes a handle is rendered susceptible to impurity, the food to which it is attached is also rendered susceptible. But <b>they disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>an animal constitutes a handle for</b> its <b>limb.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>an animal does not constitute a handle for</b> its <b>limb,</b> and therefore the limb is not rendered susceptible to contract impurity along with the body of the animal. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that <b>an animal constitutes a handle for</b> its <b>limb,</b> and therefore the limb is rendered susceptible along with the body of the animal.
<b>Abaye said</b> a different explanation of the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon: The mishna is discussing a case where the blood of the slaughtered animal came into contact with the body of the animal but not with the partially severed limb, and both <i>tanna’im</i> agree that an animal does not constitute a handle for its limb. But they also agree that if the liquid comes into contact with only part of the food it renders the entire item susceptible to impurity. Therefore, if the partially severed limb is considered part of the animal it is rendered susceptible to impurity along with the animal. Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon <b>disagree with regard to</b> whether the limb is considered part of the animal, and generally speaking, with regard to any case where a small part of an item is hanging off the larger part such that if one <b>grasps</b> and lifts the <b>small</b> part the <b>large</b> part <b>does not ascend with it.</b>
One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that although if one <b>grasps</b> and lifts the <b>small</b> part the <b>large</b> part <b>does not ascend with it,</b> the small part <b>is</b> still considered one and <b>the same</b> with the large part. Therefore, a partially severed limb is rendered susceptible to impurity along with the body of the animal. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that the small part <b>is not</b> considered one and <b>the same</b> with the large part in such a case, and therefore the partially severed limb is not rendered susceptible to impurity along with the body of the animal.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan also holds</b> in accordance with the explanation of Abaye that the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to</b> the status of a small part of an item that is hanging off the larger part such that one <b>grasps</b> the <b>small</b> part <b>and</b> the <b>large</b> part <b>does not ascend with it.</b>
<b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan raises a contradiction</b> between one statement <b>of Rabbi Meir and</b> another statement <b>of Rabbi Meir: Did Rabbi Meir</b> actually <b>say</b> that even in a case where one <b>grasps</b> the <b>small</b> part of an item <b>and</b> the <b>large part does not ascend with it,</b> the small part <b>is</b> still considered one and <b>the same</b> with the large part?
One can <b>raise a contradiction</b> to this statement from a mishna (<i>Tevul Yom</i> 3:1): With regard to a piece of <b>food that was sliced</b> from a larger piece of food <b>and</b> remains <b>partially connected</b> to the larger piece, the entire item is considered one and the same with regard to impurity. If one who was previously ritually impure and immersed that day and is waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed touched either piece of the item, the entire item becomes impure.

Daf 128a

<b>Rabbi Meir says: If</b> when one <b>grasps the small</b> piece, the <b>large</b> piece <b>ascends with it,</b> it <b>is</b> considered one and <b>the same; but if</b> it does <b>not</b> ascend with it, it <b>is not</b> considered one and <b>the same.</b> This statement of Rabbi Meir is not in accordance with his statement in the mishna that a partially severed limb is part of the body of the animal and is rendered susceptible to impurity along with the body even if one lifts the partially severed limb and the body of the animal does not ascend with it.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> resolves the contradiction and <b>says: The</b> attribution of the <b>opinions</b> in tractate <i>Tevul Yom</i> <b>is reversed.</b> Indeed, Rabbi Meir holds that even if when one lifts the smaller piece, the larger piece does not ascend with it, it is still the same item. Therefore, it is apparent that Rabbi Yoḥanan explains the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon in the mishna in accordance with the explanation of Abaye.
With regard to the contradiction between the two statements of Rabbi Meir, the Gemara asks: <b>What is the difficulty? Perhaps Rabbi Meir distinguishes between</b> the impurity of <b>one who immersed that day and other types of impurity.</b> The impurity of one who immersed that day is a more lenient type of impurity, because he has already immersed and need only wait until the end of the day in order to consume sacrificial offerings. Therefore, there is reason to be more lenient when he touches a partially severed piece of food and to rule that the entire food item does not become impure.
The Gemara answers: One cannot make such a distinction between different types of impurity because it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> With regard to <b>both</b> the impurity of <b>one who immersed that day and other types of impurity,</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of contact are the same; whatever is considered contact that transmits impurity with regard to one type of impurity transmits impurity for all types of impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>does not distinguish</b> between the impurity of one who immersed that day and other types of impurity <b>and Rabbi Meir does distinguish</b> in such a manner. Therefore, there is no contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Meir.
<b>Rabbi Yoshiya said: This is what Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> meant to <b>say: According to the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who does not distinguish between the impurity of one who immersed that day and other types of impurity, there is a contradiction between the two statements of Rabbi Meir, and <b>the</b> attribution of the <b>opinions</b> in the mishna in tractate <i>Tevul Yom</i> <b>is reversed.</b>
<b>Rava said</b> a different explanation of the dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon: The mishna is discussing a case where the blood from the slaughter came into contact with the body of the animal but not with the partially severed limb, and both <i>tanna’im</i> agree that an animal constitutes a handle for its limb. <b>They disagree with regard to</b> the principle that <b>there is</b> a status of <b>a handle,</b> i.e., a handle is considered part of the item itself, <b>with regard to</b> transmitting <b>impurity</b> to the attached food, <b>but there is no</b> status of <b>a handle with regard to rendering</b> the attached food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity, as in that regard the handle is considered a separate item.
One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>there is</b> a status of <b>a handle with regard to</b> transmitting <b>impurity, but there is no</b> status of <b>a handle with regard to rendering</b> the attached food <b>susceptible</b> to impurity. Therefore, although the body of the animal constitutes a handle vis-à-vis the limb, it does not render the limb susceptible to impurity. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that <b>there is</b> a status of <b>a handle</b> both <b>with regard to</b> transmitting <b>impurity and with regard to rendering</b> the attached food susceptible to impurity. Therefore, the body of the animal renders the limb susceptible to impurity.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> a different explanation of the dispute: Both <i>tanna’im</i> hold that a handle renders the attached food susceptible to impurity. Yet, the mishna is discussing a case where the slaughter took place before the owner of the animal designated its meat for the consumption of a gentile. Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon <b>disagree with regard to</b> whether an item can be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity <b>before intention,</b> i.e., before one intends to use it as food. Rabbi Shimon holds that since the animal came in contact with the blood of the slaughter before the owner intended to use it as food, it is not rendered susceptible to impurity. Rabbi Meir holds that the susceptibility to impurity takes effect such that when the owner considers it as food it will be susceptible to impurity.
This dispute is also found in that <b>which we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Okatzin</i> 3:2): <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rabbi Akiva would teach this</b> <i>halakha</i>: <b>Fat</b> forbidden in consumption for a Jew from an animal <b>slaughtered in the villages requires intention,</b> i.e., designation, for consumption, for it to become susceptible to impurity. This is because the population in such places is small and there is an abundance of meat, so people do not generally consume the fat. Consequently, unless the Jewish owner intends for a gentile to consume it, it is not considered food. <b>But</b> the fat <b>does not require</b> contact with a liquid in order to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity, <b>as it was already rendered susceptible by the</b> blood of <b>slaughter</b> even though it came into contact with the blood before the Jew designated it for consumption.
Rabbi Yehuda continues: <b>I said before him: You taught us, our teacher,</b> that in a case of <b>endives that one picked and rinsed</b> in water <b>for</b> the consumption of <b>an animal, and</b> one later <b>reconsidered</b> and decided to designate <b>them for human</b> consumption, the endives <b>need</b> to come into contact with liquid <b>a second</b> time in order to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity, as food designated for animal consumption does not contract impurity. Evidently, for a food item to become susceptible to impurity, its contact with liquid must occur after one designated it as food. <b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> then <b>retracted</b> his previous statement and <b>taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
Rav Pappa concludes: Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon disagree in the same manner. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds in accordance with</b> that which Rabbi Akiva taught <b>originally, and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds in accordance with</b> that which Rabbi Akiva taught after his <b>retraction</b> of his original statement.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said</b> another explanation of the dispute: The mishna is discussing a case where the blood of slaughter came into contact with a partially severed limb, and the blood of slaughter is one of the liquids that render food susceptible to impurity. But slaughter is valid only if one cuts the two <i>simanim</i>, the windpipe and the gullet, or the majority of the two <i>simanim</i>, and the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to</b> a case where <b>the blood</b> in question <b>was wiped off between</b> the cutting of the first <b><i>siman</i> and</b> the second <b><i>siman</i>.</b>
One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that <b>slaughter is</b> defined <b>from</b> the <b>beginning to</b> the <b>end</b> of its performance, <b>and this</b> blood that splashed on the limb <b>is</b> considered <b>blood of slaughter. And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>slaughter is</b> defined <b>only</b> as <b>the conclusion</b> of its performance, <b>and this</b> blood from the first <i>siman</i> <b>is</b> considered the <b>blood of a wound</b> and does not render the limb susceptible to impurity.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> another explanation of the dispute: The case is where the blood of slaughter came in contact with the partially severed limb, but Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon <b>disagree with regard to</b> the principle that the <b>slaughter</b> itself <b>renders</b> the limb <b>susceptible</b> to impurity, <b>and not</b> the <b>blood</b> of slaughter. Rabbi Shimon holds that the blood of slaughter is not one of the liquids that render food susceptible to impurity. But the slaughter itself renders the meat of the animal susceptible to impurity, because it prepares the meat for consumption. Therefore, since a partially severed limb is not prepared for consumption by the slaughter, as it remains forbidden, the slaughter does not render it susceptible to impurity. Rabbi Meir maintains that the blood of slaughter is one of the liquids that render food susceptible to impurity, and therefore, the limb is rendered susceptible.
§Earlier (127b), Rabba explained that Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon disagree with regard to whether the body of an animal constitutes a handle for its limb. With regard to the opinion of Rabbi Meir, who holds that it does constitute a handle, <b>Rabba raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if <b>an animal</b> with a partially severed limb came into contact with a source of impurity <b>during its lifetime?</b> In such a case, where the animal is not susceptible to contract impurity because it is alive but the partially severed limb is susceptible to contract impurity as food, does the animal <b>constitute a handle for</b> its <b>limb</b> and transmit the impurity to the limb? The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara introduces a similar dilemma. <b>Abaye says:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> in the mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 2:9): In the case of an impure <b>cucumber that one planted in</b> an unperforated <b>flowerpot,</b> such that the cucumber is considered detached from the ground and susceptible to impurity as food, <b>and</b> the cucumber <b>grew and went out beyond</b> the edge of <b>the flowerpot</b> such that part of the cucumber is overlying the ground, the entire cucumber is considered attached to the ground and therefore becomes <b>pure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon says: What is the nature of</b> the impurity of the cucumber that it <b>is rendered pure</b> in such a case? <b>Rather, the</b> part of the cucumber that is inside the flowerpot and <b>impure</b> remains <b>in its</b> state of <b>impurity, and</b> the part of the cucumber that is outside the flowerpot and <b>pure</b> remains <b>in its</b> state of <b>purity.</b>
Based on this mishna, <b>Abaye raises a dilemma</b> according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if the part of the cucumber outside of the flowerpot comes into contact with a source of impurity? Does the part of the cucumber outside the flowerpot <b>constitute a handle for its counterpart</b> inside the flowerpot and transmit impurity to it to it? The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara relates another dilemma based on the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one who bows down to a half of a gourd,</b> worshipping it as a divinity, <b>renders</b> that half of the gourd <b>forbidden,</b> i.e., it is prohibited to derive benefit from it, because it was worshipped as an idol. The other half, though, is not forbidden. Based on this ruling, <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b>

Daf 128b

According to Rabbi Shimon, an item that is forbidden due to idol worship is not susceptible to impurity as food (see 129a). <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if the forbidden part of the gourd comes into contact with a source of impurity? Does the forbidden part <b>constitute a handle for its</b> permitted <b>counterpart</b> and transmit impurity to it? The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara discusses a similar dilemma. <b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> in a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 3:8): In the case of <b>a branch of a fig</b> tree <b>that was</b> mainly <b>detached</b> from the tree <b>and</b> which remains <b>attached</b> only <b>to the bark of</b> the tree, <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> holds that the figs on the branch are considered as if they are still attached to the tree. Therefore, he <b>deems</b> them <b>not susceptible to impurity. And the Rabbis say: If</b> one is <b>able</b> to reattach the branch to the tree such that the branch can continue <b>to live</b> and produce fruit, then it is considered as if it is attached to the tree and the fruit on it is <b>not susceptible to impurity. But if not,</b> then the fruit is <b>susceptible to impurity.</b>
With regard to this mishna, <b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma:</b> According to the Rabbis, who distinguish between a branch that can be reattached and one that cannot, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the case of a branch that is mainly detached from a tree but can be reattached, and a second branch grows out from that branch, and is mainly detached from it and cannot be reattached? In such a case, the branch that can be reattached to the tree is not susceptible to contracting impurity, but the branch attached to it is. If the branch that is not susceptible to contract impurity comes into contact with a source of impurity, does it <b>constitute a handle for the other</b> branch and transmit impurity to it? The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara discusses another similar dilemma. <b>Rabbi Zeira says:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> in a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 13:2): In the case of a large <b>stone that</b> is situated <b>in the corner</b> of a wall shared by two houses, where the stone is visible from inside both houses, if a leprous mark appears in one of the houses on the stone, <b>when one extracts</b> the stone <b>he must extract the entire</b> stone, even the part of the stone that is part of the neighbor’s wall. <b>But when one destroys</b> his house, after a reappearance of the leprous mark, <b>he must destroy</b> only the part of a stone that is in <b>his</b> house, <b>and leaves</b> the part of a stone <b>that belongs to his neighbor.</b>
With regard to this mishna <b>Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in such a case with regard to the transmission of impurity from the leprous house to the adjacent house? Does half of the stone in the adjacent house <b>constitute a handle for the other</b> half and impart impurity such that one who enters the neighbor’s house becomes impure just as one who enters the leprous house? Or perhaps there is no <i>halakha</i> of a handle with regard to the impurity of a leprous house. The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§The mishna teaches: If <b>the animal died,</b> the hanging flesh needs to be rendered susceptible to impurity via contact with a liquid in order to become impure, as its halakhic status is that of flesh severed from a living animal, which is ritually pure and does not have the status of an unslaughtered carcass. The hanging limb imparts impurity as a limb severed from a living animal but does not impart impurity as the limb of an unslaughtered carcass. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the impurity of <b>a limb from a living</b> animal <b>and</b> the impurity of <b>a limb from a carcass?</b>
The Gemara answers: The difference <b>between them</b> is with regard to <b>flesh that separates from the limb of an animal, as flesh that separates from a limb</b> severed <b>from the living does not impart impurity,</b> just like flesh that separates directly from a living animal. By contrast, an olive-bulk of flesh that separates <b>from the limb of a carcass imparts impurity</b> like the flesh of a carcass.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the verse</b> from which it is derived <b>that a limb</b> severed <b>from the living imparts impurity? Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to the impurity of a carcass it is written: <b>“And if some animal [<i>min habehema</i>]</b> of which you may eat <b>dies,</b> he who touches its carcass shall be impure until evening” (Leviticus 11:39). The phrase “some animal [<i>min habehema</i>],” which also means: From an animal, is interpreted as indicating that a limb torn from an animal is included in the impurity discussed in the verse.
The Gemara asks: How can Rav interpret this verse in such a manner? <b>This</b> verse <b>is necessary for</b> another <i>halakha</i> <b>that Rav Yehuda</b> said that <b>Rav said,</b> as <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said, and some say it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>:</b> In the verse: <b>“And if some animal [<i>min habehema</i>]</b> of which you may eat <b>dies,</b> he who touches its carcass shall be impure until evening,” the phrase “some animal [<i>min habehema</i>]” indicates that <b>some</b> dead <b>animals impart impurity</b> as a carcass, <b>and some</b> dead <b>animals do not impart impurity</b> as a carcass. <b>And which is that</b> animal that does not impart impurity as a carcass? <b>That is an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>] that one slaughtered.</b> Even though slaughter does not render the animal permitted to be eaten, it removes the animal from the category of a carcass with regard to impurity.
The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> if the verse teaches only one of the two <i>halakhot</i>, <b>let the Merciful One write <i>mibehema</i>,</b> in one Hebrew word. <b>What</b> is the verse teaching when it states: <b>“<i>Min habehema</i>,”</b> with two Hebrew words? It is teaching that one should <b>conclude two</b> conclusions <b>from it.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> if this verse teaches that a limb from a living animal imparts impurity, one can <b>also</b> derive from it that <b>even flesh</b> from a living animal imparts impurity. The Gemara responds: <b>It should not enter your mind</b> to derive this, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>flesh that separates from a living</b> animal <b>is impure</b> like a carcass. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And if some animal</b> of which you may eat <b>dies.” Just as death does not generate a replacement,</b> i.e., life is not regenerated from the dead, <b>so too any</b> element of an animal <b>that</b> dies and <b>does not generate a replacement</b> assumes the impurity of a carcass. An animal does not replace a severed limb but it does replace severed flesh; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> One can derive this <i>halakha</i> from the word <b>“animal”</b> in the verse. <b>Just as an animal</b> contains <b>sinews and bones, so too, any</b> element of an animal that contains <b>sinews and bones</b> imparts impurity. Therefore, a limb, which contains sinews and bones, imparts impurity, but flesh, which does not contain sinews and bones, does not impart impurity. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> One can derive this <i>halakha</i> from the word <b>“animal”</b> in the verse. <b>Just as an animal</b> contains <b>flesh, sinews, and bones, so too, any</b> element of an animal that contains <b>flesh, sinews, and bones</b> imparts impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabbi Akiva?</b> The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to the <b>leg joint,</b> which contains sinews and bones but no flesh. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi it does not impart impurity when it separates from a living animal, but according to Rabbi Akiva it does.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> practical difference <b>is there between</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yosei HaGelili? Rav Pappa said:</b> The practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to the <b>kidney and</b> the <b>upper lip</b> that separate from a living animal. According to Rabbi Yosei these parts of the animal impart impurity because the animal does not generate a replacement for them; according to Rabbi Akiva they do not impart impurity, because they do not contain bones.
The Gemara states a different <i>halakha</i> where these three <i>tanna’im</i> express the same opinions. <b>So too, it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to creeping animals like this case:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>flesh that separates from a creeping animal</b> during its lifetime <b>should be impure</b> like a creeping animal carcass. Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to creeping animal carcasses: “And upon whatever any of them falls <b>when they are dead</b> shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:32). The word “dead” teaches that <b>just as death does not generate a replacement, so too any</b> element of a creeping animal <b>that</b> dies and <b>does not generate a replacement</b> imparts the impurity of a creeping animal carcass, excluding flesh; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> One can derive this <i>halakha</i> from the term <b>“creeping animal.” Just as a creeping animal</b> contains <b>sinews and bones, so too any</b> element of a creeping animal that contains <b>sinews and bones</b> imparts impurity. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> One can derive this <i>halakha</i> from the term <b>“creeping animal.” Just as a creeping animal</b> contains <b>flesh, sinews, and bones, so too, any</b> element of a creeping animal that contains <b>flesh, sinews, and bones</b> imparts impurity.
The Gemara comments: The practical difference <b>between</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and Rabbi Akiva is</b> with regard to <b>the leg joint,</b> which contains sinews and bones but no flesh. <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Yosei HaGelili? Rav Pappa said:</b> The practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to <b>the kidney and the upper lip,</b> which contain no bones and which are not regenerated by the creeping animal.
<b>And it is necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> both with regard to flesh that separates from a living animal and with regard to flesh that separates from a creeping animal. <b>As if</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>had taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>an animal,</b> one might have said that <b>this is the reason that</b> flesh that separates <b>from a living</b> animal <b>does not impart impurity:</b> It is <b>because</b> an animal carcass <b>does not impart impurity in</b> the measure of <b>a lentil-bulk,</b> but rather only in the measure of an olive-bulk. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a creeping animal, which imparts impurity</b> even <b>in</b> the measure of <b>a lentil-bulk, say</b> that flesh that separates <b>from</b> it while it is <b>living should impart impurity.</b>
<b>And if</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>had taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only with regard to <b>a creeping animal,</b> one might have said that flesh that separates from a creeping animal does not impart impurity <b>because</b> a creeping animal <b>does not impart impurity via carrying,</b> and therefore flesh that separates from it <b>while it is living does not impart impurity. But</b> with regard to <b>an animal, which imparts impurity via carrying, say</b> that flesh that separates from it <b>while it is living should impart impurity.</b> Therefore, <b>it is necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in both cases.
§The Gemara continues to discuss flesh that separates from a living animal. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who severs an olive-bulk of flesh from a limb</b> severed <b>from the living,</b> the flesh does not impart the impurity of a carcass but it does impart impurity as food if one designated it as food before it came into contact with a source of impurity. Therefore, if <b>one severed</b> the flesh from the limb <b>and afterward intended it</b> to be used for the consumption of a gentile, the flesh remains <b>pure</b> because at the time he designated the flesh as food it was not in contact with a source of impurity.
But if <b>he intended it</b> to be used for the consumption of a gentile <b>and afterward severed</b> the flesh, the flesh is <b>impure,</b> because it came into contact with a source of impurity, i.e., the limb, after it was designated as food.
One day <b>Rabbi Asi did not go to the study hall. He found Rabbi Zeira,</b> and <b>said to him: What was said</b> today <b>in the study hall?</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: What</b> matter is <b>difficult for you</b> that you think may have been discussed in the study hall? Rabbi Asi <b>said to him:</b> I find difficult that <b>which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one intended</b> flesh from a limb that was severed from a living animal to be used for the consumption of a gentile, <b>and afterward he severed</b> the flesh from the limb, the flesh is <b>impure.</b>

Daf 129a

Why should the flesh be impure? Since the source of its impurity is the limb, and the location of the contact between the limb and the flesh is hidden and not visible, <b>it</b> constitutes contact with a source of <b>impurity</b> in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body, <b>and</b> the principle is that contact with a source of <b>impurity</b> in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body <b>does not render</b> an item <b>impure.</b>
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Rabbi Asi: This matter is <b>difficult for me as well, and I asked Rabbi Abba bar Memel, and he said to me:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that contact with a source of <b>impurity</b> in <b>a concealed part</b> of the body <b>renders</b> an item <b>impure.</b>
Rabbi Asi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: <b>But hasn’t</b> Rabbi Abba bar Memel <b>said</b> this answer <b>in my presence many times? And I said to him</b> that this answer does not explain the ruling of the <i>baraita</i>. The reason is that with regard to a concealed part of the body imparting impurity, <b>Rabbi Meir differentiates between</b> a type of <b>impurity that requires</b> an item to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> in order to take effect <b>and</b> a type of <b>impurity that does not require</b> an item to be <b>rendered susceptible.</b> The case in the <i>baraita</i> is one where the flesh was not yet rendered susceptible to impurity when it was severed from the limb, and Rabbi Meir concedes that in such a case impurity should not apply to a concealed part of the body.
<b>Rava</b> was surprised by Rabbi Asi’s statement and <b>said: But what is the difficulty? Perhaps</b> the <i>baraita</i> is discussing a case <b>where</b> the flesh <b>was rendered</b> susceptible to impurity before it was severed from the limb.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan said to Rava: Why do I</b> need the flesh severed from the limb to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity? Flesh that is upon a limb from a living animal <b>imparts a severe</b> form of <b>impurity due to its original</b> limb, as it is considered part of the limb that was severed from a living animal, which imparts the impurity of a carcass, a severe form of impurity that is transmitted even to people and vessels. Therefore, it is not necessary to render this flesh susceptible to impurity after its separation from the limb, because the <i>halakha</i> is that any food item that will eventually impart a severe form of impurity does not require contact with liquid in order to be rendered susceptible to imparting a lesser form of impurity.
Rava <b>said to</b> Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan: This principle applies only when the more severe and more lenient forms of impurity are both impurities of food. But in the case of the <i>baraita</i>, the flesh needs to be rendered susceptible to impurity after it is severed from the limb, because <b>when it</b> initially <b>served</b> as part of the limb, <b>it performed the role of wood,</b> i.e., it had the status of flesh of the limb, which is necessary to give the limb the status of a limb severed from the living (see 128b), but it was not impure due to its status as food.
§Rava said that if a food item serves a function other than food, the principle that if it will eventually contract a severe form of impurity it does not require contact with liquid in order to be rendered susceptible to a lesser form of impurity does not apply. The Gemara now relates a number of matters that are explained with the same reasoning. <b>Abaye said:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A mass of</b> hardened <b>leaven that one designated for</b> the purpose of <b>sitting</b> upon it, not for consumption, <b>is nullified.</b> The item is no longer considered food and one may possess it in his house during Passover. But the item is now considered a chair, and it is subject to ritual impurity imparted by treading. It therefore is rendered impure if a <i>zav</i> sits on it.
Abaye explained: <b>Its impurity</b> in such a case is clearly <b>not by Torah law</b> but by rabbinic law; <b>as if it enters your mind</b> that it is impure <b>by Torah law,</b> then <b>we have found</b> that <b>food can become susceptible to a severe</b> type of <b>impurity.</b> This cannot be true, because the category of food that requires contact with liquid to be susceptible to impurity is food that will not eventually impart a more severe type of impurity. Based on Rava’s reasoning, the Gemara responds: The seat imparts impurity by Torah law. <b>When</b> the leaven <b>served</b> as a chair it was not considered food, as <b>it performed the role of wood.</b>
Similarly, <b>Abaye said:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An idolatrous offering of food imparts impurity in a tent.</b> Abaye explained: <b>Its impurity is not by Torah law</b> but by rabbinic law; <b>as if it enters your mind</b> that it is impure <b>by Torah law,</b> then <b>we have found</b> that <b>food can become susceptible to a severe</b> type of <b>impurity.</b> The Gemara responds: The idolatrous offering imparts impurity by Torah law. <b>When</b> the food <b>served</b> as an idolatrous offering it was not considered food, as <b>it performed the role of wood.</b>
Similarly, <b>Abaye said:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Foods that are connected</b> to vessels are considered <b>like the vessels.</b> For example, if dough is attached to a kneading bowl and the owner wishes for the dough to remain there, the dough is considered part of the bowl. Therefore, if an olive-bulk of a corpse touches that dough, it becomes impure with the more severe impurity of a vessel, which imparts impurity to people and other vessels. Abaye explained: <b>Their impurity is not by Torah law</b> but by rabbinic law; <b>as if it enters your mind</b> that it is impure <b>by Torah law,</b> then <b>we have found</b> that <b>food can become susceptible to a severe</b> type of <b>impurity.</b> The Gemara responds: Food connected to vessels imparts impurity by Torah law. <b>When</b> the food <b>served</b> as a connection to the vessel it was not considered food, as <b>it performed the role of wood.</b>
Similarly, <b>Rav Pappa said to Rava</b> in explanation of <b>that which is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 3:3): <b>Fat</b> forbidden in consumption for a Jew from <b>an animal carcass in the villages, requires designation</b> as food in order for it to become susceptible to contract impurity as food, <b>and</b> it must be <b>rendered susceptible</b> via contact with liquid. Rav Pappa explained: Although the forbidden fat that covers the kidney of a carcass imparts the impurity of a carcass, <b>its impurity due to</b> the impurity of the <b>kidney is not by Torah law</b> but by rabbinic law. <b>As if it enters your mind</b> that it is impure <b>by Torah law,</b> then <b>we have found</b> that <b>food can impart a severe</b> type of <b>impurity</b> and subsequently become susceptible to impurity as food.
The Gemara responds: The fat of a carcass imparts impurity by Torah law. <b>When</b> the fat <b>served</b> the kidney as protection and imparted the impurity of a carcass it did not serve as food, as <b>it performed the role of wood.</b>
Similarly, <b>Rav Mattana said:</b> The Sages <b>said</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a house that one roofed with seeds,</b> i.e., vegetation, if those seeds were impure, they are rendered <b>pure</b> when they are used as the roof of the house. The seeds are no longer considered food but rather part of the house. Therefore, if the house becomes leprous, the entire house becomes impure. Rav Mattana explained: <b>Its impurity is not by Torah law</b> but by rabbinic law; <b>as if it enters your mind</b> that it is impure <b>by Torah law,</b> then <b>we have found</b> that <b>seeds can become susceptible to a severe</b> type of <b>impurity.</b> The Gemara responds: The seeds used for the roof of the house impart impurity by Torah law. <b>When</b> the seeds <b>served</b> as the roof of the house they were not considered food, but rather <b>performed the role of wood.</b>
§The mishna teaches with regard to a hanging limb or flesh of a living animal that if the animal died, the hanging flesh needs to be rendered susceptible to impurity, as its halakhic status is that of flesh severed from a living animal, which is ritually pure. Rabbi Meir then states that the hanging limb imparts impurity as a limb severed from a living animal, but not as an unslaughtered carcass. And <b>Rabbi Shimon deems</b> the limb <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, the ruling of Rabbi Shimon is difficult. <b>If death renders</b> a hanging limb one that has <b>fallen off,</b> i.e., if when the animal died of its own accord the hanging limb is considered to have fallen off its body beforehand, the limb <b>should become impure as a limb from a living</b> animal. <b>If death does not render</b> a hanging limb one that has <b>fallen off,</b> the limb <b>should become impure as a limb from a carcass.</b> How is it possible for Rabbi Shimon to deem the limb pure?
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Shimon is not responding to Rabbi Meir’s statement in the final clause of the mishna. Rather, <b>Rabbi Shimon is referring to the first clause</b> of the mishna, which teaches: <b>The limb and the flesh</b> of an animal that were partially severed and remain <b>hanging from the animal impart impurity as food</b> although they remain <b>in their place</b> attached to the animal. <b>But</b> in order for them to become impure, <b>they need</b> to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> through contact with a liquid. <b>And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> them <b>not susceptible to impurity</b> at all.
<b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon? The verse states</b> with regard to impurity as food: <b>“From all food which may be eaten,</b> that on which water comes shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:34). The repetitive phrase “food which may be eaten” indicates that only <b>food that you are able to feed to others,</b> including gentiles, <b>is called food</b> with regard to being susceptible to impurity as food, but <b>food that you are not able to feed</b>

Daf 129b

<b>to others,</b> such as the limb and flesh from a living animal, which are forbidden even to gentiles, <b>is not called food.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira</b> questioned the explanation of Rabbi Yoḥanan and <b>said to Rabbi Asi:</b> If Rabbi Shimon is discussing the first clause in the mishna, claiming that a hanging limb or flesh is pure during the lifetime of the animal, the reason for his statement is not necessarily that food that is forbidden to all people is not considered food. <b>Perhaps the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon there</b> is that <b>since</b> the flesh or limb is still <b>attached</b> to the animal, it is considered <b>attached.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Okatzin</i> 3:8): With regard to <b>a branch of a fig</b> tree <b>that was detached</b> from the tree <b>and</b> remains <b>attached</b> only <b>to the bark</b> of the tree, <b>Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> the figs on the branch <b>not susceptible to impurity,</b> as they are considered attached to the tree. <b>And the Rabbis say: If</b> it is possible to reattach the branch to the tree and the branch <b>can</b> continue to <b>live</b> and produce fruit, then it is considered attached to the tree, and the fruit <b>is not susceptible to impurity. But if not,</b> the fruit is <b>susceptible to impurity. And we said to you,</b> Rabbi Asi: <b>What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda? And you said to us: Since</b> the branch is still <b>attached</b> to the bark of the tree, it is considered <b>attached.</b> Therefore, the same logic applies to the statement of Rabbi Shimon.
Rabbi Asi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Zeira: Rabbi Yoḥanan is explaining the reasoning for Rabbi Shimon’s opinion in <b>the middle clause</b> of the mishna, which teaches: If <b>the animal was slaughtered,</b> the limb and the flesh <b>were rendered</b> susceptible to impurity <b>with the blood of</b> the slaughtered animal; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Shimon says: They were not rendered</b> susceptible with the blood of the slaughtered animal.
<b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon?</b> The reason is that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to impurity as food: <b>“From all food which may be eaten,</b> that on which water comes shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:34). The phrase “food which may be eaten” indicates that only <b>food that you can feed to others,</b> including gentiles, <b>is called food</b> in this regard, but <b>food that you cannot feed to others,</b> such as the limb and flesh from a living animal, <b>is not called food.</b>
Rabbi Zeira questioned this explanation of Rabbi Yoḥanan as well, and said to Rabbi Asi: If it is with regard to Rabbi Shimon’s opinion in the middle clause of the mishna, <b>perhaps the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon in that</b> clause is not that food that is forbidden to all is not called food.
Rather, it is <b>either in accordance with</b> the explanation <b>of Rava or in accordance with</b> the explanation <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> cited earlier (127b–128a). According to both explanations of Rabbi Shimon’s opinion, the mishna is discussing a case where only the body of the animal, but not the partially severed limb, came into contact with the blood of slaughter. According to Rava, the reason for Rabbi Shimon’s opinion is that the body of the animal serves the partially severed limb as a handle, and he holds that a handle of a food item transmits impurity to the attached food, but a handle that comes into contact with liquid does not render the attached food susceptible to impurity. And according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, Rabbi Shimon holds that if one grasps a small part of a large item such that the large part does not ascend with the small part, the small part is not considered part of the item with regard to impurity (see 127b).
<b>Rather, actually,</b> one must explain the statement of Rabbi Shimon as it was explained originally, that he is referring <b>to the latter clause</b> of the mishna. <b>And</b> he is <b>not</b> referring <b>to</b> the case of a partially severed <b>limb, but rather to</b> the case of partially severed <b>flesh.</b> Therefore, the latter clause of the mishna teaches: If <b>the animal died</b> without slaughter, Rabbi Meir holds that <b>the</b> hanging <b>flesh needs</b> to be <b>rendered susceptible</b> to impurity in order to impart impurity as food, <b>and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> the limb <b>not susceptible to impurity</b> even if it came into contact with liquid.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon?</b> The reason is that <b>the verse states</b> with regard to impurity as food: <b>“From all food which may be eaten,</b> that on which water comes shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:34). The phrase “food which may be eaten” indicates that only <b>food that you can feed to others,</b> including gentiles, <b>is called food</b> with regard to being susceptible to impurity as food, but <b>food that you cannot feed to others,</b> such as flesh from a living animal, which is forbidden even to gentiles, <b>is not called food.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The limb and the flesh</b> of a person that were partially severed and remain <b>hanging from a person are ritually pure,</b> although there is no potential for healing. If <b>the person died, the</b> hanging <b>flesh is ritually pure,</b> as its halakhic status is that of flesh severed from a living person. <b>The</b> hanging <b>limb imparts impurity as a limb</b> severed <b>from the living and does not impart impurity as a limb from a corpse;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> the flesh and the limb <b>ritually pure.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara challenges the opinion of Rabbi Shimon in the latter clause of the mishna: <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, the ruling of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> is difficult. <b>If death renders</b> a hanging limb <b>fallen off,</b> i.e., if after the person dies the hanging limb is considered to have fallen off his body beforehand, the limb <b>should impart impurity as a limb</b> severed <b>from the living. And if death does not render</b> a hanging limb <b>fallen off,</b> and the limb is considered attached to the body at the time of death, then the limb <b>should impart impurity as a limb from a corpse.</b>
The Gemara explains: This statement of Rabbi Shimon is not referring directly to the case in the mishna. Rather, the statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon is referring</b> to the matter of a limb that separates from a corpse <b>in general.</b> Rabbi Shimon inferred from <b>that which the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>said: The</b> hanging <b>limb imparts impurity as a limb</b> severed <b>from the living and does not impart impurity as a limb from a corpse,</b> that <b>evidently, in general the limb of a corpse imparts impurity. And</b> in reference to this <b>Rabbi Shimon said to him: In general, the limb of a corpse does not impart impurity,</b> if it does not contain an olive-bulk of flesh.
Another pair of <i>tanna’im</i> had the same dispute as Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Shimon, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: I heard that a limb</b> severed <b>from the living imparts impurity. Rabbi Yehoshua said to him:</b> May one infer from this statement that a limb <b>from a living</b> person imparts impurity <b>but</b> a limb <b>from a corpse does not?</b> But it can be inferred <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> that a limb from a corpse imparts impurity: <b>If</b> with regard to <b>a living</b> person, <b>who is pure</b> and does not impart impurity, nevertheless <b>a limb that separates from him is impure,</b> then with regard to <b>a corpse, which is impure, all the more so</b> is it <b>not</b> clear that the limb that separates from it is impure?
Furthermore, Rabbi Yehoshua adds that <b>it is written in <i>Megillat Ta’anit</i>:</b> On <b>Minor Passover,</b> i.e., the fourteenth of Iyyar, <b>one does not eulogize.</b> Should one infer from here <b>that</b> on <b>Major</b> Passover, i.e., the fourteenth of Nisan, it is permitted <b>to eulogize?</b> Clearly that is not the case. <b>Rather,</b> if one may not eulogize on the fourteenth of Iyyar, <b>all the more so</b> one may not eulogize on the fourteenth of Nisan. <b>Here too,</b> if a limb from a living person is impure, <b>all the more so</b> a limb from a corpse is impure. Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to him:</b> Despite this reasoning, <b>such</b> is the ruling <b>I heard</b> from my teachers.
§The mishna teaches that Rabbi Meir holds that with regard to a partially severed limb of a person, after the person dies the limb imparts impurity as a limb from a living person but not as a limb from a corpse. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the impurity of <b>a limb from a living</b> person <b>and</b> the impurity of <b>a limb from a corpse?</b> The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them</b> is with regard to the case of <b>an olive-bulk of flesh, or a bone</b> the volume of <b>a barley grain, that separates from</b> the severed <b>limb of a living</b> person.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Eduyyot</i> 6:3): In the case of <b>an olive-bulk of flesh that separates from a limb</b> severed <b>from a living</b> person, <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> it <b>impure, and Rabbi Neḥunya ben HaKana and Rabbi Yehoshua deem</b> it <b>pure.</b> In the case of <b>a bone</b> the volume of <b>a barley-grain that separates from a limb</b> severed <b>from a living</b> person, <b>Rabbi Neḥunya deems</b> it <b>impure, and Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua deem</b> it <b>pure.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> dispute between <i>tanna’im</i>, it is possible to say that the difference <b>between the first <i>tanna</i></b> in the mishna, i.e., Rabbi Meir, <b>and Rabbi Shimon</b> is <b>also</b> with regard to the cases of <b>an olive-bulk of flesh and a bone</b> the size of <b>a barley grain.</b> Rabbi Meir states that the partially severed limb of a person imparts the impurity of a limb from a living person but not the impurity of a limb from a corpse. The difference between these two types of impurity is with regard to a case where either an olive-bulk of flesh or a bone the size of a barley grain was separated from the severed limb; Rabbi Neḥunya holds that flesh that separated from a limb of a living person is pure, but a bone that separated from a limb of a living person is impure, and Rabbi Eliezer holds vice versa. Rabbi Meir consequently holds in accordance with one of these two opinions. Rabbi Shimon holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua that both a bone and flesh that separated from a limb of a living person are pure.

Daf 130a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mitzva to give <b>the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw</b> of slaughtered animals to the priests, known as the gifts of the priesthood, <b>applies</b> both <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>in the presence of the Temple and not in the presence of the Temple,</b> and it applies <b>to non-sacred</b> animals, <b>but not to sacrificial</b> animals.
It is necessary to emphasize that it does not apply to sacrificial animals, <b>as by right it should be</b> inferred <i>a fortiori</i>: <b>If non-sacred</b> animals, <b>which are not obligated to</b> have the <b>breast and thigh</b> taken from them and given to the priest, <b>are obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood given from them, then with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals, <b>which are obligated to</b> have the <b>breast and thigh</b> given from them, <b>is it not right that</b> they should be <b>obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood given from them?
