Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “For the breast of waving and the thigh of giving I have taken of the children of Israel from the sacrifice of the peace offerings, <b>and have given them to Aaron the priest and to his sons as a due forever</b> from the children of Israel” (Leviticus 7:34), from which it is derived that the priest <b>has only that which is stated with regard to</b> that <b>matter,</b> i.e., the breast and the thigh, and not the foreleg, the jaw and the maw.
<b>All sacrificial</b> animals in <b>which a permanent blemish preceded their consecration</b> do not assume inherent sanctity, and only their value is consecrated. <b>And</b> once <b>they were redeemed,</b> they <b>are obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>a firstborn,</b> i.e., their offspring are subject to being counted a firstborn, <b>and in the gifts</b> of the priesthood, <b>and they can emerge</b> from their sacred status and assume <b>non-sacred</b> status <b>with regard to being shorn and with regard to being utilized for labor,</b> as it is prohibited to shear animals with sacred status or utilize them for labor. <b>And their offspring and their milk are permitted after their redemption.</b>
<b>And one who slaughters</b> these animals <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard is <b>exempt</b> from <i>karet</i>, <b>and</b> those animals <b>do not render</b> an animal that was <b>a substitute</b> for them consecrated. <b>And if</b> these animals <b>died</b> before they were redeemed, <b>they may be redeemed</b> and fed to dogs. Although typically sacrificial animals that were redeemed may not be fed to the dogs, in this case it is permitted. This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all animals <b>except for the firstborn</b> animal <b>and the</b> animal <b>tithe,</b> whose sanctity is inherent, even when a permanent blemish preceded their consecration.
With regard to <b>all</b> sacrificial animals <b>whose consecration preceded their blemish, or</b> who had <b>a temporary blemish prior to their consecration and afterward developed a permanent blemish and they were redeemed, they are exempt from</b> the mitzva of <b>a firstborn, and from the gifts</b> of the priestood, <b>and they do not emerge</b> from their sacred status and assume <b>non-sacred</b> status <b>with regard to being shorn and with regard to being utilized for labor.</b>
<b>And their offspring,</b> which were conceived prior to redemption, <b>and their milk, are prohibited after their redemption. And one who slaughters them outside</b> the Temple courtyard is <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i>, <b>and</b> those animals <b>render</b> an animal that was <b>a substitute</b> for them consecrated. <b>And if</b> these animals <b>died</b> before they were redeemed, they may not be redeemed and fed to dogs; rather, <b>they must be buried.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the verse: “And have given them to Aaron the priest and to his sons” (Leviticus 7:34), indicates that only the breast and thigh, which are the subject of that verse, are given from sacrificial animals to the priest, but gifts of the priesthood are not given from sacrificial animals. The Gemara infers: The <b>reason</b> sacrificial animals are not included in the mitzva of gifts of the priesthood is due to the fact <b>that the Merciful One writes: “Them,”</b> in reference to the breast and the thigh of sacrificial animals. <b>But</b> were it <b>not</b> for <b>this, I would say</b> by <i>a fortiori</i> inference that <b>sacrificial</b> animals are <b>obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood given from them.
The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to derive this <i>halakha</i> from a verse? The <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>can be refuted</b> as follows: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about non-sacred</b> animals? They are unique <b>in that</b> they <b>are obligated</b> in the mitzva of <b>a firstborn,</b> whereas sacrificial animals are exempt. Therefore, the <i>a fortiori</i> inference stated in the mishna should not apply.
The Gemara responds: One could <b>derive</b> that the mitzva to give the gifts of the priesthood applies to sacrificial animals through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>from</b> non-sacred <b>male</b> animals, which do not give birth to offspring and whose owners are therefore exempt from counting their offspring a firstborn, and nevertheless are subject to the giving of the gifts of the priesthood. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about</b> non-sacred <b>male</b> animals? They are unique <b>in that</b> they are <b>obligated to</b> have <b>the first sheared wool</b> given to the priest from them.
The Gemara persists: One can derive that the obligation applies to sacrificial animals by an <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>from male goats,</b> whose owners are exempt from counting their offspring a firstborn as well as from the first sheared wool, and yet are subject to the obligation of gifts of the priesthood. The Gemara rejects this claim as well: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about male goats?</b> They are unique <b>in that they enter the pen to be tithed</b> for the animal tithe, whereas sacrificial animals are not subject to the animal tithe.
The Gemara further suggests that one can derive the obligation of sacrificial animals having the breast and thigh given from them by <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>from old</b> male goats, which have already entered the pen in order to be tithed. Consequently, the obligation of the animal tithe, the obligation of counting the offspring a firstborn, and the first sheared wool do not apply. The Gemara rejects this suggestion as well: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about old</b> male goats? They are unique <b>in that they</b> have <b>entered the pen to be tithed,</b> which is not the case with regard to sacrificial animals.
The Gemara again suggests that perhaps one can derive the obligation of giving gifts of the priesthood with regard to sacrificial animals by an <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>from a purchased</b> animal, to which the obligation of the animal tithe never applies. <b>Or</b> perhaps it can be derived from <b>an orphaned</b> animal, born after the death of its mother, which is also not subject to the obligation of animal tithe. The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>What</b> is unique <b>about a purchased</b> animal <b>or an orphaned</b> animal? They are unique <b>in that</b> although they themselves do not enter the pen, animals <b>of their type enter the pen to be tithed.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>You say</b> that it is significant that animals <b>of their type</b> enter the pen? With regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals <b>as well,</b> non-sacred animals <b>of their type enter the pen to be tithed.</b> Accordingly, one can claim <i>a fortiori</i> that the mitzva to give the gifts applies to sacrificial animals, and it is only due to the verse that they are exempt.
§ The Gemara challenges: <b>And</b> now that it has been established that the obligation of the gifts of the priesthood does not apply to sacrificial animals, <b>non-sacred</b> animals <b>should be obligated to</b> have the <b>breast and thigh</b> given from them <b>by an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>If sacrificial</b> animals, <b>which are not obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood given from them, are nevertheless <b>obligated to</b> have the <b>breast and thigh</b> given from them, then with regard to <b>non-sacred</b> animals, <b>which are obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood given from them, <b>is it not right that</b> they should be <b>obligated to</b> have the <b>breast and thigh</b> given from them?
The Gemara responds that the <b>verse states: “And this shall be the priests’ due</b> from the people, from them that perform a slaughter, whether it be an ox or sheep, that they shall give to the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3). The verse indicates that <b>“this,”</b> the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw, <b>yes,</b> is given to the priests, but <b>another item,</b> i.e., the breast and thigh, is <b>not</b> given to the priests from non-sacred slaughtered animals.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But</b> this derivation indicates that the <b>reason</b> the giving of the breast and thigh does not apply to non-sacred animals is that <b>the Merciful One writes “this,”</b> from which it may be inferred if <b>not</b> for <b>this, I would say</b> that one is <b>obligated to</b> give the <b>breast and thigh</b> from <b>non-sacred</b> animals. <b>But</b> the procedure for giving the breast and thigh <b>requires waving,</b> and <b>where would one wave</b> the breast and thigh of a non-sacred animal? <b>If</b> it is suggested that one wave them <b>outside</b> the Temple, that cannot be done, as <b>it is written:</b> “That the breast may be waved for a wave offering <b>before the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 7:30), indicating that they must be waved inside the Temple.

Daf 130b

<b>If</b> it is suggested that they should be waved <b>inside</b> the Temple, that too cannot be correct, because one who waves them inside the Temple thereby <b>brings a non-sacred</b> animal <b>into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard. Therefore,</b> since it is <b>not possible</b> to perform the procedure of giving the breast and thigh with non-sacred animals, it is not necessary for a verse to teach that the giving of the breast and thigh does not apply to such animals.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if that is so, <b>why do I</b> need the verse to state: <b>“This</b> shall be the priests’ due” (Deuteronomy 18:3)? The Gemara answers: The verse is necessary <b>for that which Rav Ḥisda</b> taught, <b>as Rav Ḥisda said: One who causes damage</b> to <b>gifts of the priesthood, or who consumed them</b> before they were given to the priests, is <b>exempt from</b> having <b>to pay</b> to the priest, as the verse states: “This shall be the priests’ due,” which indicates that only the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw themselves, not their replacements, are given to the priests.
§ The Gemara analyzes <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>one who causes damage</b> to <b>gifts of the priesthood or who consumed them</b> is <b>exempt from</b> having <b>to pay</b> a substitute to the priest. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason? If you wish, say that</b> it is because <b>“this” is written</b> in the verse, indicating that only the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw themselves are given to the priests, as explained above. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that it is <b>because it is money that has no claimants.</b> Since one may give the gifts to any priest, no single priest can issue a claim on them.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>. The verse states: <b>“And this shall be the priests’ due [<i>mishpat</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:3), which <b>teaches that the gifts</b> given to the priests are considered <b>a judgment,</b> as <i>mishpat</i> can mean judgment. The Gemara continues: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> are the gifts a judgment? Is it <b>not with regard to extracting</b> them <b>through judges,</b> i.e., a priest may claim them in court and the court will order the individual to give the gifts to that priest? If so, the gifts are considered to be money that has claimants. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> they are a judgment <b>with regard to distributing them through judges,</b> i.e., the court dictates to the owner to which type of priests he should give the gifts.
<b>And</b> this is <b>in accordance with that which Rav Shmuel bar Naḥmani</b> taught, <b>as Rav Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that one does not give a gift</b> of the priesthood <b>to a priest</b> who is <b>an <i>am ha’aretz</i>?</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated: “And he commanded the people who dwelled in Jerusalem to give the portion of the priests and of the Levites, so that they may firmly adhere to the Torah of the Lord”</b> (II Chronicles 31:4). This indicates that <b>anyone who firmly adheres to the Torah of the Lord has a portion, and one who does not firmly adhere to the Torah of the Lord does not have a portion.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof with regard to the statement of Rav Ḥisda from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says</b> that the phrase “And this shall be the priests’ <b>due” teaches that the gifts</b> of the priesthood are <b>a judgment.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that the gifts of the <b>breast and thigh</b> are <b>also a judgment.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “This,”</b> to teach that only the gifts of the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw are called a judgment.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>With regard to what</b> matter is this <i>halakha</i> stated? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>with regard to distributing</b> them <b>through judges, is that to say</b> that the <b>breast and thigh are not distributed through judges?</b> These are also called a “portion” (II Chronicles 31:4), and therefore the court determines to which priests they should be given, as stated above. <b>Rather, is it not</b> stated <b>with regard to extracting</b> them <b>through judges?</b> If so, one can infer from the <i>baraita</i> that gifts of the priesthood can be extracted in court by a priest, which contradicts the statement of Rav Ḥisda.
The Gemara responds: <b>Here, we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the gifts already <b>came into</b> the priest’s <b>possession,</b> and the owner stole them from him. The <i>baraita</i> teaches that the priest may claim them in court and the court will order that they be returned to him. The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> this is a case <b>where they came into his possession, what</b> is the purpose <b>of stating</b> that the priest may claim them in court? That is obvious, as they already belong to him. The Gemara responds: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where they came into his possession while they</b> were still <b>untithed,</b> i.e., the priest received the entire animal before the gifts were separated, <b>and this <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>gifts that have not been separated are considered as though they have been separated.</b> Accordingly, the gifts belong to the priest, and if the owner takes them from him against his will it is considered theft.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof with regard to the statement of Rav Ḥisda from a mishna (<i>Pe’a</i> 5:4): In the case of <b>a homeowner who was passing from place to place,</b> and he ran out of money while traveling <b>and needs to take gleanings, forgotten</b> sheaves, <b><i>pe’a</i>, or the poor man’s tithe</b> in order to sustain himself, he may <b>take</b> them, <b>and when he returns</b> to his house <b>he will pay</b> a poor person for whatever he took; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> The mishna teaches that a poor person may extract payment for that which the homeowner took, despite the fact that he never had possession of the gifts. This ruling apparently contradicts the statement of Rav Ḥisda.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The mishna <b>taught an attribute of piety here,</b> i.e., strictly speaking a poor person has no right to claim any amount from the homeowner for what he took. <b>Rava said</b> in bewilderment: <b>The <i>tanna</i> taught</b> explicitly that <b>he will pay, and you say</b> that he <b>taught an attribute of piety here? And furthermore, should</b> one <b>arise and raise an objection from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Eliezer?</b> The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his opinion.
<b>Rather,</b> the objection is <b>from the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that the homeowner is not required to pay for what he took during his travels, as <b>he was</b> considered <b>poor at that time.</b> It may be inferred that the <b>reason</b> he is exempt from payment is only <b>that</b> he was considered <b>poor</b> at the time, <b>but</b> if he were considered <b>wealthy,</b> he would have to <b>pay</b> the poor people who issue a claim against him in court, as he was not entitled to those gifts.
The Gemara explains the objection: But <b>why</b> must he pay? <b>Let it be</b> considered <b>like</b> a case where one <b>causes damage to gifts of the priesthood or consumes them,</b> with regard to which Rav Ḥisda states that he is not required to pay the priest. The opinion of the Rabbis apparently contradicts the statement of Rav Ḥisda. <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> Even if the homeowner was considered wealthy at the time he is not required to pay, and the Rabbis who obligated him to pay <b>taught an attribute of piety here.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to a homeowner who consumed his produce</b> while it was <b>untithed,</b> i.e., neither <i>teruma</i> nor the first tithe had been separated, <b>and similarly,</b> with regard to <b>a Levite who consumed his tithes</b> while they were <b>untithed,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i> of the tithe had not been separated, <b>from where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> he is <b>exempt from payment? The verse states: “And they shall not profane the sacred things of the children of Israel, which they set apart</b> to the Lord” (Leviticus 22:15). This teaches that <b>you,</b> the priest, <b>have</b> rights <b>to them only from the time of separation onward.</b> Since the produce was eaten before <i>teruma</i> was separated from it, the priest cannot claim payment for it in court.
The Gemara infers from this ruling: This indicates that if it was consumed <b>from the time of separation onward,</b> the priest may <b>in any event</b> claim payment for the <i>teruma</i> in court, and the one who consumed it must <b>pay.</b> But <b>why</b> must one pay? <b>Let it be like</b> a case where one <b>causes damage to gifts of the priesthood or consumes them,</b> with regard to which Rav Ḥisda states that he is exempt from payment. The Gemara responds: <b>Here too,</b>

Daf 131a

the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where they came into</b> the priest’s <b>possession while they</b> were still <b>untithed, and this <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that <b>gifts that have not been separated are considered as though they have been separated.</b> In such a case, the priest obtained rights to the ownerless gifts by seizing them first. Although when he seized the produce it was still untithed, the portion of the produce that is to be separated has the status of <i>teruma</i>. Accordingly, one who consumes such produce is required to pay the priest.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof with regard to the statement of Rav Ḥisda from a <i>baraita</i>: In a case <b>where the household of the king seized one’s threshing floor</b> by force, <b>if</b> they took it <b>as</b> payment of <b>his debt</b> owed to the king, then <b>he is obligated to tithe</b> other grain in accordance with the amount he would have tithed before the grain was seized. Since he was already obligated to tithe the grain before it was seized, it is considered as though the grain was sold in an untithed state. <b>If they took it without reason [<i>anparot</i>],</b> then <b>he is exempt from tithing.</b> The fact that one is required to tithe grain seized as payment of a debt indicates that the tithe is considered money that has claimants, from which it follows that a priest may extract payment of the tithe from him. Again, this apparently contradicts the statement of Rav Ḥisda.
The Gemara rejects this proof: It <b>is different there,</b> since if one is not required to tithe grain seized as payment of a debt, this would mean <b>that</b> the seizure <b>causes benefit for him,</b> as he will be exempt from tithing grain that he was previously obligated to tithe. It is for this reason that the <i>baraita</i> rules that one must tithe other grain instead of the seized grain, not because a priest could have issued a claim against him in court.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a mishna (132a): If an Israelite <b>says</b> to a butcher: <b>Sell me the innards of</b> a particular <b>cow, and there were gifts of the priesthood</b> included <b>with it,</b> i.e., the maw, that were not yet given to the priest, the purchaser <b>must give them to the priest, and</b> the butcher <b>may not deduct</b> the value of the gifts <b>from the money</b> that the purchaser pays <b>him,</b> as it is assumed that the gifts were not included in the sale. If <b>he purchased</b> the innards <b>from</b> the butcher <b>by weight,</b> the purchaser <b>must give</b> the gifts <b>to the priest, and</b> the butcher <b>deducts</b> the value of the gifts <b>from the money</b> that the Israelite pays <b>him.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> must the buyer give the maw to the priest? <b>Let</b> the butcher’s sale of the maw <b>be</b> considered <b>like</b> a case where one <b>causes damage to gifts of the priesthood or consumes them,</b> with regard to which Rav Ḥisda states that one is exempt from payment. This mishna apparently contradicts Rav Ḥisda’s statement. The Gemara rejects this: It <b>is different there, as</b> the gifts <b>are intact,</b> i.e., they are distinct items in their own right. In such a case, the gifts must be given to the priest. By contrast, Rav Ḥisda is discussing cases in which the gifts are not distinguishable objects at the time.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof: <b>Nine</b> items are the <b>property of a priest: <i>Teruma</i>, <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> the portion of dough given to the priest, <b>the first sheared</b> wool, <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood, <b>doubtfully tithed produce [<i>demai</i>], first fruits, the principal</b> value of the property of a convert, <b>and the</b> additional <b>one-fifth.</b> The two are paid to the priest in a case where the property of a convert was stolen and the thief took an oath that he did not steal it, and after the convert died the thief admitted to taking a false oath.
The Gemara explains the proof: <b>With regard to what</b> matter are these items considered the property of a priest? <b>Is it not with regard to extracting them with judges,</b> which would contradict the opinion of Rav Ḥisda? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is <b>with regard to that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bikkurim</i> 3:12): <b>To what</b> end did <b>they say</b> that these items are the <b>property of a priest?</b> It means <b>that</b> a priest may <b>purchase with them slaves and lands and a non-kosher animal; and a lender takes them</b> as payment <b>of his debt; and</b> if the <b>wife</b> of a priest is divorced from him, she takes them as payment <b>of her marriage contract; and</b> a priest may purchase <b>a Torah scroll</b> with them.
§ The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain Levite who would snatch gifts</b> of the priesthood from children who were delivering them to the priests on their fathers’ behalf. <b>They came</b> and <b>told Rav</b> about this Levite. Rav <b>said to them: Is it not enough that</b> when he slaughters his own animals <b>we do not take</b> the gifts of the priesthood <b>from him, but he also snatches</b> gifts that are being delivered to priests?
Rav’s comment indicates that in his opinion there are grounds to take the gifts from Levites, but nevertheless they are not taken. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what does <b>Rav</b> maintain in this regard? <b>If</b> he maintains that Levites <b>are called</b> part of the <b>“people,”</b> then <b>let one take</b> the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw <b>from them as well,</b> as the verse states: “From the people, from them that perform a slaughter, whether it be ox or sheep, they shall give to the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3).
<b>And if they are not called</b> part of the <b>people,</b> then <b>the Merciful One</b> has <b>exempted them</b> from giving those gifts, and there would be no grounds to take the gifts from them. The Gemara responds: Rav <b>is uncertain whether or not they are called</b> part of the <b>people.</b> Therefore, he exempts the Levites from giving their own gifts, in accordance with the principle that the burden of proof rests upon the claimant.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Pappa was sitting and saying this <i>halakha</i></b> in the name of Rav. <b>Rav Idi bar Avin raised an objection to Rav Pappa</b> from a <i>baraita</i>, with regard to the uncertainty of Rav: <b>Four gifts</b> are left <b>to the poor</b> from the produce <b>of a vineyard: The individual fallen</b> grapes <b>[<i>peret</i>], and the incompletely formed clusters</b> of grapes <b>[<i>olelot</i>], and the forgotten</b> clusters, <b>and <i>pe’a</i>. And three</b> gifts are left to the poor <b>from grain: The gleanings,</b> i.e., sheaves that fell during the harvest, <b>and the forgotten</b> sheaves, <b>and the <i>pe’a</i>. Two</b> gifts are left to the poor from the fruit <b>of a tree: The forgotten</b> fruits <b>and the <i>pe’a</i>.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: With regard to <b>all of</b> these gifts, <b>the owner</b> of the produce <b>does not have the benefit of discretion.</b> This is the benefit accrued from giving a gift to an individual of one’s choice, e.g., giving <i>teruma</i> or tithes to whichever priest or Levite that one chooses. Instead, poor person who takes possession of these gifts becomes their rightful owner. <b>And even a poor person of Israel</b> who owns a vineyard, field, or tree must leave these gifts for all other poor people; and if he does not do so, <b>the court removes</b> them <b>from his possession.</b>
By contrast, with regard to the <b>poor man’s tithe, which is distributed</b> from <b>within one’s house,</b> unlike other gifts to the poor that are left in the field for them to take, <b>the owner has the benefit of discretion. And even</b> in the case of <b>a poor person in Israel,</b> if he fails to separate the poor man’s tithe from his produce, <b>the court removes it from his possession. And</b> with regard to <b>other gifts of the priesthood, such as the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw,</b> the court <b>does not remove them, neither from a priest</b> to give <b>to</b> another <b>priest, nor from a Levite</b> to give <b>to</b> another <b>Levite.</b>
Before Rav Idi bar Avin explains his objection, the Gemara cites the sources for the <i>halakhot</i> of the <i>baraita</i>: The <i>baraita</i> teaches that <b>four gifts</b> are left to the poor from the produce <b>of a vineyard: The <i>peret</i>, and the <i>olelot</i>, and the forgotten</b> clusters, <b>and the <i>pe’a</i>, as it is written: “And you shall not glean [<i>te’olel</i>] your vineyard, neither shall you gather the fallen fruit [<i>peret</i>] of your vineyard;</b> you shall leave them for the poor and for the stranger” (Leviticus 19:10).
<b>And</b> it <b>is</b> also <b>written: “When you gather the grapes of your vineyard, you shall not glean it [<i>te’olel</i>] after you;</b> it shall be for the stranger, for the fatherless, and for the widow” (Deuteronomy 24:21). And <b>Rabbi Levi says</b> that with regard to the term <b>“after you,” this</b> is a reference to <b>forgotten</b> clusters, as the <i>halakha</i> is that clusters that were passed over by the harvester have the status of forgotten clusters, whereas those that remain in front of him do not have that status.
The <i>halakha</i> that the mitzva of <b><i>pe’a</i></b> applies to one’s vineyard is <b>derived</b> by a verbal analogy between the term <b>“after you”</b> in that verse and the term <b>“after you” from</b> another verse concerning <b>an olive</b> tree. <b>As it is written: “When you beat your olive tree, you shall not go over the boughs [<i>tefa’er</i>] after you;</b> it shall be for the stranger, for the fatherless, and for the widow” (Deuteronomy 24:20); <b>and the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> that the term “You shall not go over the boughs” means <b>that you should not take</b> all of <b>its splendor [<i>tiferet</i>] from it;</b> rather, you should leave a portion of the olives for the poor. So too, one must leave a portion of one’s vineyard as <i>pe’a</i> for the poor.
The Gemara continues: The <i>baraita</i> teaches that <b>three</b> gifts are left to the poor <b>from grain: The gleanings,</b>

Daf 131b

<b>and the forgotten</b> sheaves, <b>and the <i>pe’a</i>. As it is written: “And when you reap the harvest of your land, you shall not wholly reap the corner of [<i>pe’at</i>] your field,</b> neither shall you gather <b>the gleaning of your harvest;</b> you shall leave them for the poor, and for the stranger” (Leviticus 23:22). And it is also written: <b>“When you reap your harvest in your field and have forgotten a sheaf in the field,</b> you shall not go back to fetch it; it shall be for the stranger, for the fatherless, and for the widow” (Deuteronomy 24:19).
The <i>baraita</i> taught that <b>two</b> gifts are left to the poor <b>from</b> the produce <b>of a tree: The forgotten</b> fruits <b>and the <i>pe’a</i>, as it is written: “When you beat your olive tree, you shall not go over the boughs [<i>tefa’er</i>] after you;</b> it shall be for the stranger, for the fatherless, and for the widow” (Deuteronomy 24:20), <b>and the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> that the phrase: “You shall not go over the boughs,” means <b>that you should not take</b> all of <b>its splendor [<i>tiferet</i>] from it;</b> rather, you should leave a portion of the olives for the poor as <i>pe’a</i>. Additionally, when the verse states: <b>“After you,” this</b> is a reference to <b>forgotten</b> fruits.
The Gemara continues its analysis of the <i>baraita</i>. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of</b> the gifts left to the poor, <b>the owner</b> of the produce <b>does not have the benefit of discretion,</b> i.e., the right to distribute the gifts to poor people of his choosing. Instead, any poor person who takes possession of these gifts becomes their rightful owner. <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? It is because the requirement of <b>leaving is written with regard to them,</b> e.g., in the verse that states: “You shall leave them” (Leviticus 23:22).
The <i>baraita</i> also stated: <b>And even a poor person of Israel</b> who owns a vineyard, field, or tree must leave these gifts for all poor people, and if he does not, <b>the court removes</b> them <b>from his possession.</b> This is derived from a verse, <b>as it is written: “Neither the gleaning of your harvest shall you gather; for the poor you shall leave them, and for the stranger”</b> (Leviticus 23:22). Since the verse juxtaposes the words “the poor” to the mitzva in the previous clause, this serves <b>to warn a poor person</b> that he must also separate these gifts from <b>his own</b> produce.
<b>And</b> the <i>baraita</i> teaches with regard to the <b>poor man’s tithe that is distributed</b> from <b>within his house</b> that <b>the owner has the benefit of discretion.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? It is because the requirement of <b>giving is written with regard to it,</b> as the verse states: “When you have made an end of tithing all the tithe of your increase in the third year, which is the year of tithing, and you shall give it to the Levite, to the stranger, to the fatherless, and to the widow, that they may eat within your gates, and be satisfied” (Deuteronomy 26:12). Consequently, in this case it is not left for the poor but is actively given to them.
The <i>baraita</i> states: <b>And even</b> in the case of <b>a poor person in Israel,</b> if he fails to separate the poor man’s tithe from his produce, <b>the court removes it from his possession.</b> The Gemara explains that this is <b>as Rabbi Ile’a said:</b> This is <b>derived</b> from a verbal analogy between the term <b>“to the stranger”</b> stated with regard to the poor man’s tithe in the verse cited previously, and the term <b>“to the stranger” from there,</b> the mitzva to leave gleanings for the poor. <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the mitzva to leave gleanings, <b>a poor person is warned that</b> he must leave gleanings from the produce of <b>his own</b> fields, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the mitzva to separate the poor man’s tithe, <b>a poor person is warned to</b> separate it from <b>his own</b> fields.
The <i>baraita</i> taught: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>other gifts of the priesthood, such as the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw,</b> the court <b>does not remove them, neither from a priest</b> to give <b>to</b> another <b>priest nor from a Levite</b> to give <b>to</b> another <b>Levite.</b> Rav Idi bar Avin now explains his objection: It may be inferred that the court does <b>remove</b> the gifts <b>from a Levite</b> to give <b>to a priest. Evidently,</b> Levites <b>are called</b> part of the <b>“people.”</b> Accordingly, since the verse states: “And this shall be the priests’ due from the people” (Deuteronomy 18:3), the gifts of the priesthood may be removed from the possession of Levites. Why, then, was Rav uncertain with regard to their status?
The Gemara responds: The <i>baraita</i> is not referring to the actual gifts of the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw themselves. Rather, it is referring to a gift that is <b>like the foreleg,</b> the jaw, and the maw, <b>but not</b> the <b>foreleg,</b> the jaw, and the maw themselves. <b>And what is this?</b> It is the <b>first tithe.</b>
The Gemara asks: But the <b>first tithe is</b> given <b>to</b> the <b>Levite.</b> Why would it be removed from his possession? The Gemara responds: The <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, as it is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Teruma</i></b> is given <b>to the priest,</b> whereas the <b>first tithe</b> is given <b>to the Levite;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says:</b> The first tithe is given <b>to the priest as well,</b> despite the fact that the Torah states that it is given to the Levite, as priests are often called Levites in the Torah.
The Gemara asks: <b>Say that Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya said</b> that the first tithe is given <b>to the priest as well;</b> but <b>did he say</b> that it is given exclusively <b>to the priest and not to the Levite?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Yes;</b> although generally the first tithe is not removed from the possession of a Levite and given to a priest, the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> first tithe in the period <b>after Ezra penalized</b> the Levites for their unwillingness to return to Eretz Yisrael from Babylonia, as he decreed that they should no longer be given the first tithe.
The Gemara persists: One can <b>say that Ezra penalized them</b> and decreed <b>that we should not give them</b> first tithe, but <b>did he say</b> that first tithe should even be <b>taken from them</b> and given to the priests? <b>Rather,</b> explain instead that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a gift that is <b>like</b> the <b>foreleg,</b> the jaw, and the maw, <b>but</b> is <b>not</b> actually the <b>foreleg,</b> the jaw, or the maw. <b>And what is this?</b> It is <b>the first sheared</b> wool, with regard to which the verse states: “And the first of the fleece of your sheep, you shall give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4). Since the verse does not state that the first fleece is taken from the “people,” even Levites are obligated to give their first shearing to the priest, and it may be removed from their possession to that end.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof with regard to the uncertainty of Rav from a <i>baraita</i>. <b>This is the principle:</b> With regard to <b>any item that is of sanctity,</b> i.e., that may not be consumed by a non-priest, <b>such as <i>teruma</i>, and <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, and <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> the court <b>removes it from the possession</b> of a Levite in order to give it to the priests. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>any item that is not of sanctity, such as the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw,</b> which are given from a non-sacred animal, the court <b>does not remove it from the possession</b> of the Levites to give to the priests. Evidently, Levites are not called part of the “people,” and therefore they are exempt from giving the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw.
The Gemara rejects this proof: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a gift that is <b>like</b> the <b>foreleg,</b> the jaw, and the maw, <b>but</b> is <b>not</b> actually the <b>foreleg,</b> the jaw, and the maw themselves. <b>And what is this?</b> It is <b>first tithe, and</b> the <i>baraita</i> is dealing with first tithe in the period <b>after Ezra penalized</b> the Levites and decreed that the first tithe should be given to the priests rather than the Levites. Nevertheless, if a Levite received the first tithe it may not be removed from his possession, since this penalty was not included in Ezra’s decree.
The Gemara further suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: An Israelite <b>who slaughters</b> an animal <b>for a priest or for a gentile</b> is <b>exempt from</b> giving <b>the gifts,</b> as priests and gentiles are exempt from this obligation. The Gemara infers: This indicates that if an Israelite slaughtered an animal <b>for a Levite or for an Israelite,</b> he is <b>obligated</b> to give the gifts, and they may be removed from his possession to that end. Evidently, Levites are called part of the “people,” and Rav should not have been uncertain with regard to their status. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Do not say</b> that one should infer that if an Israelite slaughtered an animal <b>for a Levite or for an Israelite</b> he is <b>obligated</b> to give the gifts. <b>Rather, say</b> merely that if an Israelite slaughtered an animal <b>for</b> another <b>Israelite,</b> he is <b>obligated</b> to give the gifts.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, when one slaughters an animal <b>for a Levite, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is one <b>exempt? If so, let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach: One who slaughters</b> an animal <b>for a Levite or for a gentile</b> is <b>exempt from</b> giving <b>the gifts,</b> and it would be obvious that this is also the <i>halakha</i> when one slaughters for a priest. <b>And furthermore, isn’t it taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>one who slaughters for a priest or for a gentile</b> is <b>exempt from</b> giving <b>the gifts,</b> whereas one who slaughters <b>for a Levite or for an Israelite</b> is <b>obligated</b> to give the gifts? This <i>baraita</i> apparently constitutes <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the uncertainty <b>of Rav.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Rav</b> could <b>say to you</b> that although this <i>baraita</i> is in fact contrary to his opinion, the question of whether or not Levites are called part of the “people” <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse states with regard to the Yom Kippur Temple service: “And he shall make atonement for the most holy place, and he shall make atonement for the Tent of Meeting and for the altar; and he shall make atonement for the priests and for all the people of the assembly” (Leviticus 16:33). The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>“And he shall make atonement for the most holy place”; this</b> is referring to <b>the innermost sanctum,</b> i.e., the bull and goat offerings brought on Yom Kippur atone for ritual impurity occurring inside the Holy of Holies.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>“Tent of Meeting”; this</b> is referring to the <b>Sanctuary,</b> i.e., the offerings atone for impurity occurring inside the Sanctuary. <b>“Altar”;</b> this is understood <b>in accordance with its plain meaning,</b> i.e., the offerings atone for one who performs sacrificial rites on the altar in a state of ritual impurity. <b>“He shall make atonement”; this</b> is referring to the Temple <b>courtyards,</b> i.e., the offerings atone for impurity occurring there. “For <b>the priests”;</b> this is understood <b>in accordance with its plain meaning,</b> indicating that the offerings atone for a priest who unwittingly enters the courtyard while impure. “And for all the <b>people of the assembly”; these are the Israelites. “He shall make atonement”; this</b> is referring to <b>the Levites.</b>
<b>And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>“He shall make atonement”; this</b> is referring to Canaanite <b>slaves</b> in the possession of Jews. These slaves are obligated in certain mitzvot and are therefore in need of atonement. The Gemara analyzes these sources: Why doesn’t the <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i> interpret the term “He shall make atonement” as a reference to Levites? <b>What, is it not</b> that <b>they disagree about this, as</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the second <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that Levites are <b>called</b> part of the <b>“people”</b> and are therefore included in the clause “the people of the assembly,” and consequently, the term “he shall make atonement” is not required to include the Levites but instead serves to include Canaanite slaves. <b>And</b> by contrast, one <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the first <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>they are not called</b> part of the <b>“people,”</b> which means that the term “He shall make atonement” is required to include Levites.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if this is a dispute between <i>tanna’im</i>, why is <b>Rav</b> uncertain with regard to the status of Levites? <b>If he holds in accordance with this <i>tanna</i>, let him say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with him, <b>and if he holds in accordance with that <i>tanna</i>, let him say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with him. The Gemara responds: Rav <b>is uncertain whether</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with this <i>tanna</i> or in accordance with that <i>tanna</i>.</b>
<b>Mareimar taught: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> that it is uncertain whether or not Levites are called part of the “people.” Consequently, the court may not compel Levites to give the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw to the priests. <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda,</b> who said that one who damages or consumes gifts of the priesthood is exempt from payment.
§ With regard to the gifts of the priesthood, the Gemara relates that <b>Ulla would give gifts</b> of the priesthood <b>to a female priest,</b> i.e., the daughter of a priest, even if she was married to an Israelite. <b>Rava raised an objection to</b> the practice of <b>Ulla</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The remainder of <b>a meal offering of a female priest is consumed,</b> just like the remainder of the meal offering of an Israelite. But the remainder of <b>a meal offering of a priest is not consumed,</b> as the verse states: “And every meal offering of the priest shall be wholly made to smoke; it shall not be eaten” (Leviticus 6:16).
Rava explains his objection: <b>And if you say</b> that one may give gifts of <b>a priest even</b> to <b>a female priest,</b> because when the verse mentions a priest it is referring even to the daughter of a priest, <b>but isn’t it written: “And every meal offering of the priest shall be wholly made to smoke; it shall not be eaten”?</b> Why, then, is the remainder of a meal offering of the daughter of a priest consumed? Ulla <b>said to him</b> in response: <b>My teacher,</b>

Daf 132a

<b>from your burden [<i>mitunakh</i>],</b> i.e., from that which you raise your objection, I can cite a proof for my practice: With regard to the meal offering of a priest, both <b>Aaron and his sons are written in the passage</b> discussing this offering: “And this is the law of the meal offering: The sons of Aaron shall offer it before the Lord, in front of the altar” (Leviticus 6:7). The verse emphasizes that these <i>halakhot</i> apply only to male priests and not to their daughters. This indicates that when the verse refers merely to priests, even their daughters are included. Accordingly, one may give gifts of the priesthood to the daughter of a priest.
The Gemara cites the opinions of various <i>tanna’im</i> with regard to the practice of Ulla: <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> Anywhere that the Torah mentions a priest with regard to gifts of the priesthood, it is referring specifically to <b>a priest and not a female priest, and</b> let one <b>derive</b> the meaning of <b>an unspecified</b> reference to a priest <b>from the explicit</b> verse that states with regard to meal offerings: “Aaron and his sons.” This verse indicates that any reference to a priest excludes a priest’s daughter.
<b>The school of Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov taught:</b> In general, the reference to a priest in a verse serves to exclude a priest’s daughter. But when the verse mentions <b>a priest</b> with regard to gifts of the priesthood, it means to include <b>even a female priest.</b> This is because the verse mentions priests twice: “And this shall be the priests’ due from the people, from them that perform a slaughter, whether it be ox or sheep, that they shall give to the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3). Since each reference to a priest excludes the daughter of a priest, this verse <b>is</b> a case of <b>a restrictive expression following a restrictive expression, and</b> there is a hermeneutical principle that <b>a restrictive expression following a restrictive expression</b> serves <b>only to amplify</b> the <i>halakha</i> and include additional cases, in this instance, the daughter of a priest.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Kahana,</b> who was an Israelite, <b>partook</b> of gifts of the priesthood <b>on account of his wife,</b> who was the daughter of a priest. Similarly, <b>Rav Pappa partook</b> of gifts of the priesthood <b>on account of his wife, Rav Yeimar partook</b> of gifts <b>on account of his wife,</b> and <b>Rav Idi bar Avin partook</b> of them <b>on account of his wife.</b>
<b>Ravina said: Mareimar said to me</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav</b> that it is uncertain whether or not Levites are obligated to give the gifts of the priesthood, and consequently, gifts are not removed from their possession to be given to the priests. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda</b> that one who damages or consumes gifts of the priesthood is exempt from payment. <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Ulla</b> that gifts of the priesthood may be given to the daughter of a priest.
<b>And</b> in a case not previously discussed but related to the opinion of Ulla, <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> with regard to <b>a female Levite,</b> i.e., the daughter of a Levite, <b>who gave birth</b> to a firstborn boy, even if she is married to an Israelite, that <b>her son is exempt from</b> the obligation to give <b>five <i>sela</i></b> to the priest for his redemption, as the child is considered the son of a Levite, and Levites are exempt from this obligation.
§ The Gemara cites a dispute with regard to the gifts of the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The obligation to give <b>the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw applies</b> even <b>to a hybrid</b> animal <b>and to</b> the animal known as <b>a <i>koy</i>. Rabbi Eliezer says: A hybrid</b> that <b>results from</b> the mating of <b>a goat and a ewe is obligated to</b> have <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood given from it, while a hybrid that results <b>from</b> the mating of <b>a goat and a doe is exempt from</b> having <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood given from it. This is because the verse states with regard to gifts of the priesthood: “Whether it be an ox or sheep” (Deuteronomy 18:3), i.e., a domesticated animal, and a doe is not a domesticated animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>Now, we maintain</b> (see 79b–80a) <b>with regard to</b> the mitzvot of <b>covering the blood and</b> giving the <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood that <b>you do not find</b> that Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis disagree <b>except in</b> the case of an animal born from <b>a deer that mates with a female goat. And both Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis are uncertain whether one</b> needs <b>to be concerned with its paternity</b> when determining the species of a hybrid animal, which would mean that this animal is part domesticated and part undomesticated, or <b>whether one does not</b> need to be <b>concerned</b> with paternity and the species of an animal is determined entirely by the species of its mother, in which case it is a domesticated animal.
<b>And</b> they <b>disagree with regard to</b> whether the obligation of the gifts applies to <b>a sheep and even</b> an animal that is <b>partially a sheep,</b> i.e., partially domesticated. One <b>Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that the obligation applies to <b>a sheep and even</b> an animal that is <b>partially a sheep; and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not say</b> that the obligation applies to <b>a sheep and even</b> an animal that is <b>partially a sheep.</b>
The Gemara concludes its question: <b>Granted,</b> it is understandable that <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> the owner of a hybrid <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva to give the priestly gifts, as <b>he holds</b> that only in the case of <b>a sheep</b> is one obligated to give gifts of the priesthood, <b>but not</b> with regard to animals that are only <b>partially sheep. But according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, though indeed they hold</b> that <b>sheep and even</b> animals that are <b>partially sheep</b> are subject to the obligation of giving gifts of the priesthood, <b>let</b> the priest <b>take</b> only <b>half</b> of the gifts. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the other half, let</b> the owner of the animal <b>say to him: Bring proof that one</b> need <b>not be concerned with its paternity and</b> then you may <b>take</b> the other half. <b>Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya said</b> in response: <b>What</b> do the Rabbis mean <b>when they say</b> that the owner of this animal is <b>obligated?</b> They mean that he is <b>obligated in half of the gifts.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira raises an objection</b> to this response from a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a <i>koy</i>,</b> with regard to which it is uncertain whether it is a domesticated animal or an undomesticated one, <b>there are ways</b> in which its <i>halakhot</i> <b>correspond to</b> those of <b>a domesticated animal, and there are ways</b> in which its <i>halakhot</i> <b>correspond to</b> those of <b>an undomesticated animal. And there are ways in</b> which its <i>halakhot</i> <b>correspond to</b> those of both <b>an undomesticated animal and a domesticated animal.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>How so? Its fat is forbidden like</b> the forbidden <b>fat</b> of <b>a domesticated animal,</b> unlike that of an undomesticated one. <b>And</b> one is <b>obligated to cover its blood</b> from slaughter with dirt, <b>like the blood</b> of <b>an undomesticated animal.</b> And there are <b>ways</b> in which its <i>halakhot</i> <b>correspond to</b> both those of <b>a domesticated animal and an undomesticated animal, as its blood and its sciatic nerve are forbidden like</b> those of <b>a domesticated animal and an undomesticated animal. And</b> its owner is <b>obligated</b> to give the <b>foreleg, the jaw, and the maw</b> from it to the priest, as in the case of domesticated animals. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> the owner of a <i>koy</i> <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva to give the gifts.
Rabbi Zeira asks: <b>And if it is so</b> that the Rabbis mean that the owner of a <i>koy</i> is obligated to give half of the gifts, then the <i>baraita</i> <b>should have</b> said that he is <b>obligated to</b> give <b>half of the gifts</b> from it. The Gemara responds: <b>Since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> that <b>its fat and its blood</b> are forbidden, with regard to <b>which it</b> could <b>not teach</b> that <b>half</b> of its blood or <b>half</b> of its fat are forbidden, as it is impossible that half of it is forbidden while the other half is permitted, <b>due to that</b> reason the <i>tanna</i> <b>did not teach</b> that the owner of a <i>koy</i> is obligated in <b>half</b> of the gifts.
The Gemara relates that <b>when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: According to the Rabbis, a <i>koy</i> is obligated to</b> have <b>all of the gifts</b> of the priesthood given from it. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the gifts of the priesthood: “Whether it be an ox or sheep” (Deuteronomy 18:3). Since the verse needed to state only <b>“ox,” why</b> must <b>the verse state: “Whether it be an ox”?</b> This phrase serves <b>to include a hybrid</b> in the obligation to give the gifts of the priesthood. And since the verse needed to state only <b>“sheep,” why</b> must <b>the verse state: “Or sheep”?</b> This phrase serves <b>to include the <i>koy</i></b> in the obligation to give the gifts.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who deems the owners of a <i>koy</i> and the offspring of a hybrid exempt from giving gifts of the priesthood from these animals, <b>why do I</b> need <b>this</b> phrase: <b>“Whether</b> it be an ox or sheep”? The Gemara responds: <b>He requires it to divide</b> between an ox and a sheep, indicating that one is obligated with regard to either animal alone. Were it not for this phrase, one might have concluded that he is obligated to give the gifts only after slaughtering both an ox and a sheep. The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> who derive other <i>halakhot</i> from this phrase, <b>from where do they</b> derive <b>to divide</b> between an ox and a sheep? The Gemara responds: <b>They derive it</b> from the phrase: <b>“From them that perform a slaughter”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:3), which indicates that the obligation to give the gifts applies even to one animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Eliezer, what does he do with this</b> phrase: <b>“From them that perform a slaughter,”</b> i.e., what does he derive from it? The Gemara responds: <b>He requires it for</b> a statement <b>of Rava, as Rava said:</b> If a priest seeks to claim gifts of the priesthood in court, the priest issues his <b>demand with the butcher,</b> even if the animal itself belongs to another individual.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to a blemished <b>firstborn</b> animal, which one may slaughter and eat without being required to give the foreleg, jaw, and maw to the priest, <b>that was intermingled with one hundred</b> non-sacred animals, from which one is required to give those gifts, in a case <b>when one hundred</b> different people <b>slaughter all of them,</b> each slaughtering one animal, one <b>exempts them all</b> from giving the gifts, as each could claim that the animal that he slaughtered was the firstborn. If <b>one</b> person <b>slaughtered them all,</b> one <b>exempts one</b> of the animals <b>for him.</b>
<b>One who slaughters</b> the animal of a priest <b>for the priest or</b> the animal of a gentile <b>for the gentile is exempt from</b> the obligation to give <b>the gifts</b> of the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw. <b>And</b> an Israelite <b>who enters into partnership with</b> a priest or a gentile <b>must mark</b> the animal to indicate that it is jointly owned and exempt from the obligation to give the gifts. <b>And if</b> a priest sold his animal to an Israelite and <b>said:</b> The animal is sold <b>except for the gifts</b> with it, the Israelite is <b>exempt from</b> the obligation to give <b>the gifts,</b> as they are not his.
If the Israelite <b>said</b> to the one slaughtering the animal: <b>Sell me the innards of a cow, and there were gifts</b> included <b>with it,</b> i.e., the maw, the purchaser <b>gives them to the priest and he does not deduct</b> the value of the gifts <b>from the money</b> that he pays <b>him.</b> If <b>he bought</b> the innards <b>from</b> the slaughterer <b>by weight,</b> the purchaser <b>gives</b> the gifts, i.e., the maw, <b>to the priest and deducts</b> the value of the gifts <b>from the money</b> that he pays <b>him.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if a firstborn animal was intermingled with one hundred non-sacred animals, each belonging to a different person, all of the animals are excluded from the obligation to give the gifts, due to the uncertainty of which animal is the firstborn. The Gemara asks: <b>But why</b> is this the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Let the priest come upon</b> each slaughterer with a claim <b>from two sides,</b> i.e., <b>let</b> the priest <b>say to him: If</b> this animal <b>is a firstborn, it is completely mine; and if it is not a firstborn</b> but is instead a non-sacred animal, then <b>give me my gifts.</b>

Daf 132b

<b>Rav Oshaya says</b> in response: In general, a priest may issue such a claim. But the mishna is dealing with a case <b>where</b> the firstborn <b>came into the possession of</b> the <b>priest</b> when it was unblemished and thereafter it developed a permanent blemish, <b>and</b> the priest <b>sold it to an Israelite in its blemished</b> state. In such a case, the priest may not demand that the owner give him the entire animal with the claim that it is a firstborn, as he already received it once as a firstborn.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>one who slaughters</b> the animal of a priest <b>for the priest or</b> the animal of a gentile <b>for the gentile is exempt from</b> the obligation to give <b>the gifts</b> of the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw. The Gemara suggests: <b>And let</b> the <i>tanna</i> simply <b>teach</b> that <b>a priest and a gentile are exempt from</b> the obligation to give <b>the gifts. Rava says</b> in explanation: <b>That is to say,</b> i.e., the wording of the mishna indicates, that <b>the demand</b> of a priest who seeks to claim gifts of the priesthood is <b>with the butcher,</b> not with the owner of the animal. Even if the butcher is himself a priest, if he slaughters an animal on behalf of an Israelite he is obligated to give the gifts.
The Gemara adds: <b>Rava</b> also <b>interpreted</b> the verse in such a manner. The verse states: “This shall be the priests’ due from the people, from them that perform a slaughter, whether it be ox or sheep, that they shall give to the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3). The verse specifies that the gifts are taken <b>“from the people,” and not from the priests. When</b> the verse <b>states: “From them that perform a slaughter,”</b> indicating that the gifts are given by anyone who slaughters an animal, <b>you must say</b> that this teaches that <b>even a butcher</b> who is <b>a priest is included</b> in the obligation to give the gifts.
§ The mishna teaches that the obligation to give the gifts of the priesthood does not apply to an animal jointly owned by an Israelite and a priest. The Gemara relates that the <b>host [<i>ushpizikhnei</i>] of Rabbi Tavla was a priest and he was hard-pressed</b> for money. <b>He came before Rabbi Tavla</b> to ask for advice. Rabbi Tavla <b>said to him: Go</b> and <b>enter into a partnership with those Israelite butchers,</b> to obtain part ownership of their animals, <b>as since they</b> will be <b>exempt from</b> the obligation to give the <b>gifts</b> on account of this partnership, they will agree to <b>enter into</b> a business <b>partnership with you</b> free of charge.
The priest heeded the advice of Rabbi Tavla and entered into a partnership with an Israelite butcher. Nevertheless, <b>Rav Naḥman obligated</b> the butcher to give the gifts of the priesthood from the animals he slaughtered. The priest <b>said to</b> Rav Naḥman: <b>But Rabbi Tavla exempted us</b> from this obligation. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: Go remove</b> the gifts of the priesthood that are in your possession and give them to a priest, <b>and if</b> you will <b>not</b> do so, <b>I will remove Rabbi Tavla from your ear [<i>me’unakh</i>],</b> i.e., I will refute his basis for deeming you exempt.
<b>Rabbi Tavla came before Rav Naḥman</b> and <b>said to him: What is the reason</b> that the <b>Master has done this</b> and ruled in contradiction to the mishna? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him:</b> I ruled in this manner, <b>as when Rabbi Aḥa bar Ḥanina of the south came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he <b>said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> and all <b>the elders of the south said:</b> With regard to <b>a priest</b> who becomes <b>a butcher,</b> for the first <b>two or three weeks</b> he is <b>exempt from</b> the obligation to give <b>the gifts,</b> as he has not yet established himself in the community as a butcher. But <b>from this</b> point <b>forward</b> he is <b>obligated to</b> give the <b>gifts,</b> as he is now known as a butcher.
Rabbi Tavla <b>said to</b> Rav Naḥman: <b>And let the Master at least do for</b> the priest <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Aḥa bar Ḥanina</b> and exempt him from giving the gifts for the first three weeks of his partnership. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: This statement</b> of Rabbi Aḥa bar Ḥanina applies only when the priest <b>did not</b> immediately <b>establish a butcher shop.</b> In such a case, the priest is exempt until he becomes known as a recognized butcher. <b>But here, he has</b> already <b>established a butcher shop</b> and is therefore obligated to give the gifts without delay.
§ <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> With regard to <b>a priest who</b> slaughters an animal and <b>does not separate gifts</b> of the priesthood from them for another priest, <b>let him be</b> under the <b>excommunication of the God of Israel. Rabba bar Rav Sheila said: These butchers of</b> the city of <b>Huzal</b> have <b>remained</b> under the <b>excommunication of Rav Ḥisda these</b> last <b>twenty-two years,</b> as they have continuously refused to separate gifts of the priesthood for this period.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> did Rabba bar Rav Sheila state that the butchers of Huzal have been under excommunication for twenty-two years? <b>If we say that we do not excommunicate them</b> for a period <b>any longer</b> than twenty-two years, <b>but isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that one is not excommunicated for committing a transgression, <b>said?</b> It is said <b>with regard to a prohibition,</b> for which one is liable to receive a relatively severe punishment, e.g., death or <i>karet</i>. <b>But with regard to</b> one who refuses to perform <b>a positive mitzva, e.g.,</b> the court <b>says to him: Perform</b> the mitzva of <b><i>sukka</i>, and he does not do</b> so, or: Perform the mitzva of taking the <b><i>lulav</i>, and he does not do</b> so, or: <b>Prepare ritual fringes</b> for your garments, <b>and he does not do</b> so, the court <b>strikes him</b> an unlimited number of times, even <b>until his soul departs.</b> Accordingly, the butchers of Huzal should remain under excommunication indefinitely until they separate the gifts.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabba bar Rav Sheila means <b>that</b> because the butchers of Huzal have refused to give the gifts for so many years, <b>we fine them</b> even <b>without forewarning.</b> There was a case <b>like this</b> of a person who refused to give the gifts of the priesthood to a priest, <b>where Rava fined</b> him by taking the entire <b>thigh</b> of his animal and giving it to a priest. Similarly, <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak fined</b> an individual who refused to give the gifts of the priesthood to a priest by taking his <b>cloak</b> and giving it to a priest.
§ <b>And Rav Ḥisda</b> also <b>says</b> with regard to gifts of the priesthood: The <b>foreleg</b> is given <b>to one</b> priest <b>and</b> the <b>maw</b> is given <b>to one</b> priest, while the <b>jaw</b> is given <b>to two</b> priests. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But when Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef came</b> to Babylonia from Eretz Yisrael <b>he said: In the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>we divide</b> the gifts <b>bone by bone,</b> each of which is given to two priests.
The Gemara explains: <b>There,</b> in the case dealt with in Eretz Yisrael, the gifts were <b>of a</b> large <b>bull.</b> The Torah states: “That they shall give to the priest” (Deuteronomy 18:3). The use of the term “give” indicates that the gift given should be a substantial one. Even when one limb of the large bull was divided between two priests, each received a substantial portion. This is not the case with regard to the gifts of smaller animals, where each limb is not large enough to provide two substantial portions.
§ <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>prohibited to partake of</b> a slaughtered <b>animal whose gifts have not</b> yet <b>been separated.</b> Furthermore, <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Anyone who partakes of an animal whose gifts have not</b> yet <b>been separated</b> is considered <b>as though he consumes untithed produce. But</b> the Gemara states: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
<b>Rav Ḥisda says: Gifts of the priesthood may be consumed only</b> when they are <b>roasted, and they may be consumed only with mustard</b> seasoning. <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? The <b>verse states:</b> “And the Lord spoke to Aaron: And I, behold, I have given you the charge of My gifts; of all the consecrated items of the children of Israel to you have I given them for prominence, and to your sons, as an eternal portion” (Numbers 18:8). The term <b>“for prominence”</b> means that the portions were given to the priests as a mark <b>of greatness.</b> Accordingly, they should be eaten <b>in a manner that kings eat,</b> i.e., roasted and with mustard.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda says: One may not give a gift to any priest who is not an expert in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to all <b>twenty-four gifts of the priesthood.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>But</b> this <b>is not correct, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Any priest who does not believe in</b> the validity of the Temple <b>service has no portion in</b> any of the gifts given to the <b>priesthood, as it is stated: “He among the sons of Aaron, who offers [<i>hamakriv</i>] the blood of the peace offerings, and the fat, shall have the right thigh for a portion”</b> (Leviticus 7:33). The word “<i>hamakriv</i>,” which literally means: Who brings it close, indicates that only one who believes in the validity of conveying the blood to the altar is entitled to receive the right thigh of the offering, as only one who believes in the rite would perform it.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a priest does not have a share in the priestly gifts if he does not believe in <b>this</b> rite of conveying of the blood <b>alone. From where</b> do I derive <b>to include fifteen</b> additional sacrificial <b>rites, such as</b> the rites of a meal offering, i.e., <b>the pouring</b> of the oil <b>and the mixing</b> of the oil and the subsequent pouring of the oil; <b>and the crumbling</b> of meal offerings prepared in a shallow or deep pan or in an oven, whose handfuls are removed after they are baked and subsequently crumbled; <b>and the salting</b> of meal offerings (see Leviticus 2:13); and the <b>waving</b> of certain meal offerings; <b>and the bringing</b> of certain meal offerings to the southwestern corner of the altar before a handful is removed; <b>and the removal of the handful;</b> and <b>the burning</b> of offerings on the altar; <b>and the squeezing</b> of a bird offering to extract its blood; <b>and the pinching</b> of the nape of the neck of a bird offering;

Daf 133a

<b>and</b> the <b>receiving</b> of the blood in a vessel; and its <b>sprinkling</b> upon the altar, each offering according to its <i>halakha</i>; <b>and</b> the <b>giving of water to a woman suspected by her husband of having been unfaithful [<i>sota</i>]; and</b> the ritual of <b>breaking a heifer’s neck</b> in an untilled valley when a corpse is discovered and the murderer is unknown; <b>and</b> the <b>purification of a leper; and</b> the <b>lifting of the hands</b> for the Priestly Benediction, <b>whether inside or outside</b> the Temple; from where are these derived? <b>The verse states: “Among the sons of Aaron,”</b> indicating that this is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to any sacrificial <b>rite that is stated to the sons of Aaron.</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara explains the proof: The <i>baraita</i> teaches that <b>any priest who does not believe in</b> the validity of these rites <b>has no portion in the</b> gifts of the <b>priesthood.</b> It may be inferred that the <b>reason</b> the priest has no portion is <b>that he does not believe in it,</b> whereas if <b>he does believe in it, even though he is not an expert in its</b> <i>halakhot</i>, he receives a portion. This contradicts the opinion of Rav Ḥisda.
With regard to priests who should not be given gifts of the priesthood, <b>Rabbi Abba says</b> that <b>Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The <b>veins that</b> are contained <b>in the jaw</b> of an animal are <b>prohibited</b> for consumption, due to the blood they contain. <b>And one does not give</b> the <b>gift</b> of the jaw <b>to any priest who does not know</b> how <b>to remove</b> the veins, as the priest might eat them.
The Gemara notes: <b>But</b> that <b>is not so,</b> i.e., one need not be concerned that the priest might consume the blood within the veins, as any method of preparing the jaw will remove the blood: <b>If</b> the priest prepares the jaw <b>by roasting</b> it, the blood <b>will drain</b> from the jaw due to the fire. <b>And if</b> he intends <b>to</b> place the jaws in <b>a pot</b> to cook them, <b>if he cuts them and salts them,</b> as one is required to do before cooking any meat, the blood <b>will drain</b> from them, and they will be permitted for consumption.
§ With regard to the manner in which a priest takes gifts of the priesthood from their owners, <b>Rava said: Rav Yosef examined us,</b> his students, with the following question: <b>A priest who seizes gifts</b> of the priesthood from their owners, is <b>he demonstrating fondness</b> for the <b>mitzva or is he demonstrating contempt for the mitzva? And I resolved</b> this question <b>for him</b> from the verse: “That they shall give to the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3). The term <b>“that they shall give”</b> indicates that the owner should give the gifts, <b>and not that</b> a priest <b>should take them by himself.</b> Accordingly, a priest who seizes the gifts from their owners is demonstrating contempt for the mitzva.
<b>Abaye,</b> who was a priest, <b>said: At first, I would seize gifts</b> of the priesthood, as <b>I said</b> to myself that <b>I am demonstrating fondness</b> for the <b>mitzva</b> in this manner. <b>Once I heard this</b> interpretation: <b>“That they shall give,” and not that he should take by himself, I did not seize</b> them anymore. Instead, <b>I would say</b> to the owners of the gifts: <b>Give me. And once I heard that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the sons of Samuel, who were Levites: <b>“But turned aside after wealth”</b> (I Samuel 8:3), and <b>Rabbi Meir says: The sons of Samuel</b> sinned when they <b>asked for their portion,</b> the first tithe given to the Levite, <b>with their mouths,</b> i.e., they demanded that the owners give them the first tithe. Abaye continued: After I heard that, <b>I also did not say</b> anything to the owners, <b>but if they would give me</b> gifts <b>I would take</b> them.
Abaye said further: <b>Once I heard that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the distribution of the shewbread among the priests: <b>The modest ones [<i>hatzenu’im</i>] withdraw their hands</b> and do not take, <b>and the gluttons divide</b> all the bread; <b>I also did not take</b> gifts even when they were offered to me, <b>except for</b> when they were given on <b>the eve of Yom Kippur,</b> when there was an abundance of gifts due to the many animals that were slaughtered, as it is a mitzva to eat that day. In that instance, I took the gifts in order <b>to affirm myself among the priests,</b> i.e., if I would never take gifts then my status as a priest might be called into question.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But let him spread his hands</b> for the Priestly Benediction throughout the year, as this will make it clear to all that he is in fact a priest. The Gemara responds: <b>His schedule constrained him,</b> as he was constantly involved in teaching Torah to his students, so much so that he would miss the time during which the community gathered in the synagogue for the Priestly Benediction.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> In a case where <b>a priest who has a Torah scholar [<i>tzurva merabbanan</i>]</b> living <b>in his neighborhood and</b> that Torah scholar <b>is hard-pressed</b> for money, <b>let</b> the priest <b>grant</b> his <b>gifts to him,</b> i.e., the priest may declare that those gifts he is destined to receive should be given to the poor Torah scholar. <b>And even though</b> the gifts <b>have not</b> yet <b>come into his possession,</b> he may grant them to the Torah scholar <b>in</b> a case where there are <b>associates of the priesthood and the Levites,</b> i.e., if that specific priest or Levite was well known in his neighborhood and has a standard arrangement with many people that they give him their gifts, as he is certain that he will be given them.
With regard to the statement of Rav Yosef, the Gemara relates that <b>Rava and Rav Safra visited the house of Mar Yoḥana, son of Rav Ḥana bar Adda, and some say</b> they visited <b>the house of Mar Yoḥana, son of Rav Ḥana bar Bizna.</b> Mar Yoḥana <b>prepared for them a third-born calf. Rava said to</b> the <b>attendant</b> of Mar Yoḥana, who was a priest and would normally receive gifts of the priesthood from Mar Yoḥana: <b>Grant us the gifts, as I wish to eat tongue with mustard,</b> and the tongue along with the jaw is one of the gifts.
The attendant <b>granted</b> the gifts <b>to him; Rava ate</b> from them <b>but Rav Safra did not eat.</b> Following this incident, <b>they read</b> the following verse <b>to Rav Safra in a dream: “As one that takes off a garment in cold weather, and as vinegar upon niter, so is he that sings songs to a heavy heart”</b> (Proverbs 25:20). The verse can be interpreted allegorically as a chastisement of one who studies Torah but fails to understand it.
Rav Safra <b>came before Rav Yosef</b> and <b>said to him: Perhaps because I transgressed the <i>halakha</i> of the Master they read this</b> verse to me in chastisement. Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> No, you acted appropriately by refraining from consuming the gifts. <b>When I said</b> that a priest may grant the gifts to a Torah scholar, that was only <b>with regard to</b> a priest who grants them to <b>another</b> person of his own choosing. I did not permit this in the case of <b>an attendant</b> who grants the gifts to a dignified guest of the homeowner. The reason is that <b>he grants</b> the gifts <b>against his will,</b> as he feels pressured by the homeowner to acquiesce. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>when I said</b> this <i>halakha</i>, it was only <b>for one who cannot</b> eat under another circumstance, as he is hard-pressed for money. In <b>this</b> incident, it was <b>possible for</b> Rava to consume his own meat with mustard, since Rava was not poor.
Rav Safra asked Rav Yosef: <b>But</b> if so, <b>what is the reason</b> that <b>they read this</b> verse to me? Rav Yosef responded: The reading was directed not toward you but <b>toward Rava,</b> who ate from the gifts against my ruling. The Gemara objects: <b>But let them read</b> this verse <b>to Rava</b> himself in a dream. The Gemara responds: <b>Rava was rebuked</b> as a result of this incident and therefore was not granted heavenly communication. The verse was therefore proclaimed to Rav Safra instead.
In the preceding incident, the Gemara related that the verse: “As one that takes off a garment in cold weather, and as vinegar upon niter, so is he that sings songs to a heavy heart” (Proverbs 25:20), was proclaimed to Rav Safra in a dream. <b>Abaye said to Rav Dimi: And with regard to what</b> matter <b>is the plain meaning of the verse written?</b> Rav Dimi <b>said to him:</b> It is referring <b>to</b> one who <b>teaches an unworthy student.</b> In other words, just as one should remove a worn garment that has no use in cold weather, or just as vinegar upon niter ruins the niter, rendering it unusable, so too, there is no use in singing songs, i.e., teaching Torah, to an unworthy student who has a heavy heart, i.e., who does not intend to adhere to the <i>halakhot</i> he is taught.
<b>As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Anyone who teaches</b> Torah <b>to an unworthy student falls into Gehenna, as it is stated: “All darkness is laid up for his treasures; a fire not blown by man shall consume him; it shall go ill with him that remains [<i>yera sarid</i>] in his tent”</b> (Job 20:26), <b>and <i>sarid</i></b> means <b>nothing other than a Torah scholar, as it is stated: “And among the remnant [<i>sarid</i>] those whom the Lord shall call”</b> (Joel 3:5). The word <i>yera</i> shares a root with the word <i>ra</i>, evil, and “<i>yera sarid</i>” is therefore understood to be referring to an unworthy student.
On a similar note, <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rav says: Anyone who teaches</b> Torah <b>to an unworthy student</b> is considered <b>like one who throws a stone to Markulis, as it is stated: “As a small stone in a heap of stones, so is he that gives honor to a fool”</b> (Proverbs 26:8), <b>and it is written: “Luxury is not seemly for a fool”</b> (Proverbs 19:10).
§ The mishna teaches that <b>one who enters into partnership with</b> a priest or a gentile <b>must mark</b> the animal. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is one obligated to mark the animal <b>even</b> if he enters into partnership <b>with a gentile? And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who enters into partnership with a priest must mark</b> the animal, <b>but one who enters into partnership with a gentile and</b> one who slaughters <b>disqualified consecrated</b> animals <b>does not need to mark</b> the animal.

Daf 133b

The Gemara responds: <b>Here, we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the <b>gentile is sitting in the butcher shop</b> of the Israelite. In such a situation, it is evident that the gentile is in partnership with the Israelite and the animal need not be marked. By contrast, the mishna is referring to a case where the gentile does not sit in the shop.
The Gemara asks: If so, then <b>in the corresponding</b> situation <b>involving a priest,</b> where the <i>baraita</i> teaches that one who enters into partnership with a priest must mark the animal, this must also be referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>sits in the butcher shop. Why,</b> then, <b>must one mark</b> the animal?
