The Gemara responds: The fact that the priest sits in the shop does not indicate that he is in partnership with the Israelite, <b>as</b> people will <b>say:</b> He is in the shop because <b>he is purchasing meat.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>If so,</b> then in the case of the <b>gentile as well, they</b> will <b>say</b> that he is in the shop because <b>he is purchasing meat.</b>
<b>Rather, here we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where the gentile sits by the safe</b> into which the butcher places money received from his customers. In such a situation, it is evident that the gentile is in partnership with the Israelite, and therefore the animal need not be marked. The Gemara asks: If so, then <b>the corresponding</b> situation in the <i>baraita</i> <b>involving a priest</b> must also be a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>sits by the safe. Why,</b> then, <b>must one mark</b> the animal? The Gemara responds: The fact that the priest sits by the safe does not indicate that he is in partnership with the Israelite, <b>as</b> people will <b>say:</b> The butcher <b>trusts him</b> to protect the safe from theft. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then in the case of the <b>gentile as well, they</b> will <b>say</b> that he sits by the safe because the butcher <b>trusts him.</b>
The Gemara responds: It is <b>not</b> common for a Jew to place his <b>trust in a gentile. If you wish, say</b> instead that in both cases of the <i>baraita</i> the priest and the gentile sit in the butcher shop, not by the safe. It is evident that the gentile is in partnership with the Israelite, as <b>an ordinary gentile</b> partner <b>yells</b> at the seller, saying, for example: Do not sell an item for this price but for a different price. By contrast, a priest, even if he sits in the shop, would not question the practices of the salesman, due to his modesty, but would defer to the seller’s expertise. Accordingly, it is not evident that the priest is a partner, and the animal must therefore be marked.
§ <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> the owner of <b>disqualified consecrated</b> animals, which were slaughtered after they were redeemed and became non-sacred, is exempt from the obligation to give the gifts, and one <b>does not need to mark</b> the animal. The Gemara objects: <b>Apparently, it is an evident matter</b> that this is a disqualified consecrated animal, and therefore one need not mark it. <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Bekhorot</i> 31a): All <b>disqualified consecrated</b> animals <b>are sold in the meat market [<i>be’itliz</i>], and are slaughtered in the meat market, and are weighed</b> and sold <b>by the <i>litra</i>,</b> in the manner of non-sacred meat? Since disqualified consecrated animals are treated in the same manner as ordinary non-sacred animals, how is it evident that this is a disqualified consecrated animal?
The Gemara responds: <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava interpreted</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Pappa</b> as referring <b>to those</b> disqualified consecrated animals <b>that are sold</b> from <b>inside the house,</b> i.e., a firstborn animal and an animal tithe, whose redemption payments belong to their owners, as their value has no sanctity. Since no gain would accrue to the Temple, the Sages prohibited one from selling these animals in the market, despite the fact one could have obtained a higher sale price there due to the high concentration of customers.
§ With regard to gifts of the priesthood from animals owned in partnership, <b>Rav Huna says:</b> If an Israelite is <b>a partner</b> with a priest or gentile <b>in</b> only <b>the head</b> of the animal, he is <b>exempt</b> merely <b>from</b> the obligation to give the <b>jaw,</b> which is part of the head. He remains obligated to give the foreleg and the maw. If he is <b>a partner</b> with a priest or gentile <b>in the leg and hoof</b> of the animal, he is <b>exempt</b> only <b>from</b> the obligation to give <b>the foreleg.</b> If he is <b>a partner</b> with a priest or gentile <b>in the innards,</b> he is <b>exempt</b> merely <b>from</b> the obligation to give <b>the maw. And Ḥiyya bar Rav says</b> that <b>even</b> if the priest or gentile is <b>a partner in</b> only <b>one of them,</b> the Israelite is <b>exempt from all of</b> the gifts.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Ḥiyya bar Rav from a <i>baraita</i>: If a priest says to an Israelite butcher: Let us enter into a partnership in which <b>the head</b> of the animal <b>is mine and the entire</b> remainder <b>is yours, even</b> if the priest proposes that only <b>one-hundredth of the head</b> should be his, the Israelite is <b>exempt.</b> Similarly, if the priest offers: Let us enter into a partnership in which <b>the leg and hoof</b> of the animal <b>are mine and the entire</b> remainder <b>is yours, even</b> if the priest suggests that only <b>one-hundredth of the leg and hoof</b> will be his, the Israelite is <b>exempt.</b> And likewise, if the priest says: Let us enter into a partnership in which <b>the innards</b> of the animal <b>are mine and the entire</b> remainder <b>is yours, even</b> if the priest offers to take only <b>one-hundredth of the innards,</b> the Israelite is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara explains the objection: <b>What, is it not</b> correct that the <i>baraita</i> is teaching that when the priest owns the head the butcher is <b>exempt from</b> giving <b>the jaw, but obligated in</b> giving <b>all</b> the rest, and likewise when the priest owns the leg and hoof, he is <b>exempt from</b> giving <b>the foreleg but obligated in all</b> the rest, and when the priest owns the innards, he is <b>exempt from the maw and obligated in all</b> the rest? This would contradict the opinion of Ḥiyya bar Rav. The Gemara responds: <b>No;</b> in each case the <i>baraita</i> means that he is <b>exempt from all</b> the gifts.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach</b> explicitly that he is <b>exempt from all the</b> gifts, rather than simply stating that he is exempt. <b>And furthermore,</b> it <b>is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> that if a priest says to an Israelite butcher: Let us enter into a partnership in which <b>the head</b> of the animal <b>is mine and the entire</b> remainder <b>is yours, even</b> if the priest suggests that only <b>one-hundredth of the head</b> will be his, the butcher is <b>exempt from</b> the obligation to give <b>the jaw but is obligated in</b> giving <b>all the</b> rest. This <i>baraita</i> explicitly contradicts the opinion of Ḥiyya bar Rav. The Gemara concludes: <b>The refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav</b> is indeed <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> in explanation of the opinion of Ḥiyya bar Rav: <b>This <i>baraita</i> misled Ḥiyya bar Rav, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There are twenty-four gifts of the priesthood, and all of them were given</b> in the Torah <b>to Aaron and his sons by a generalization and a detail, and</b> with <b>a covenant of salt.</b> The verse states: “And the Lord spoke to Aaron: And I, behold, I have given you the charge of My gifts; of all the consecrated items of the children of Israel to you have I given them for prominence, and to your sons, as an eternal portion” (Numbers 18:8). After this generalization, the Torah proceeds to list the gifts in detail. Finally, after delineating all the gifts of the priesthood, the verse states: “It is an everlasting covenant of salt” (Numbers 18:19), assuring Aaron that just as a covenant of salt is unbreakable, so too, the gifts of the priesthood are eternal.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Therefore, <b>anyone who fulfills</b> the mitzva of giving the gifts of the priesthood is considered <b>as though he fulfills</b> all these mitzvot that are derived using the principle of <b>a generalization and a detail, and</b> as though he has upheld the <b>covenant of salt. And anyone who violates</b> the mitzva of giving the gifts of the priesthood is considered <b>as though he violates</b> all of the mitzvot derived by the principle of <b>a generalization and a detail, and</b> as though he has not upheld the <b>covenant of salt.</b>
<b>And these are</b> the twenty-four gifts: <b>Ten</b> are consumed <b>in the Temple, and four in Jerusalem, and ten in the boundaries</b> of Eretz Yisrael. The <b>ten</b> gifts consumed only <b>in the Temple</b> are an animal <b>sin offering; and a bird sin offering;</b> and <b>a definite guilt offering; and a provisional guilt offering; and communal peace offerings,</b> i.e., the lambs that accompany the two loaves brought on <i>Shavuot</i> and which are considered offerings of the most sacred order; <b>and</b> the remainder of <b>the <i>log</i> of oil</b> that accompanies the guilt offering of a recovered <b>leper; and the two loaves</b> offering from the new wheat brought on <i>Shavuot</i>; <b>and the shewbread; and the leftovers of meal offerings; and the <i>omer</i> meal offering,</b> i.e., the measure of barley brought as a communal offering on the sixteenth of Nisan.
<b>And</b> these are the <b>four</b> gifts that the priests consume anywhere <b>in Jerusalem: The</b> unblemished <b>firstborn</b> of kosher animals; <b>and the first fruits; and the</b> portions <b>separated</b> for the priests <b>from the thanks offering,</b> i.e., the breast and thigh and one loaf from each of the four types of loaves brought with a thanks offerings: Cakes, wafers, cakes of fine flour, and leavened bread, <b>and</b> the portions separated <b>from the nazirite’s ram,</b> i.e., the boiled shoulder, a cake, and a wafer, in addition to the breast and thigh of any peace offering; <b>and</b> the <b>hides of sacrificial</b> animals brought as burnt offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings.
<b>And</b> these are the <b>ten</b> gifts that the priests consume anywhere <b>in the boundaries</b> of Eretz Yisrael: <b><i>Teruma</i>,</b> i.e., the portion of the produce designated for the priest; <b>and <i>teruma</i> of the tithe; and <i>ḥalla</i>; and the first sheared</b> wool; <b>and the gifts</b> of the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw; <b>and</b> the five <i>sela</i> given as <b>redemption of</b> the firstborn <b>son; and</b> a sheep or goat given as <b>redemption of the firstborn donkey.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues the list: <b>And a</b> consecrated <b>ancestral field</b> that one did not redeem, which was sold to another by the Temple treasurer and is therefore given to the members of the priestly watch serving during the Jubilee Year; <b>and a dedicated field; and</b> payment for the <b>robbery of a convert</b> who died without heirs. If one takes an oath that he did not rob from a convert, and after the death of the convert he admits to having taken a false oath, he must pay the principal value of the stolen item and an additional one-fifth of the value, all of which is given to the priests.
Rav Ḥisda explains how the <i>baraita</i> misled Ḥiyya bar Rav: <b>He thought</b> that <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>counts the gifts</b> of the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw <b>as one</b> gift, <b>they are</b> treated as <b>one</b> gift, which means that if one is exempt from one of them he is exempt from all of them. <b>But it is not so,</b> as <b>is that to say</b> that <b>the</b> portions <b>separated</b> for the priests <b>from the thanks offering and</b> from <b>the nazirite’s ram, which</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>counts as one,</b> are counted this way <b>because they are one?</b> Obviously, these are independent gifts. <b>Rather, since they are similar to one another</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>counts them as one. So too,</b> with regard to the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw, <b>since they are similar to one another he counts them as one.</b>
§ With regard to animals owned in partnership with a priest, the Gemara relates that <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If a priest says to an Israelite butcher: Let us enter into partnership in ownership of a live animal, in which <b>the head is yours and the entire</b> remainder <b>is mine, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is the Israelite obligated to give the jaw to a priest when it is slaughtered? The Gemara explains the sides of the dilemma: Do <b>we follow the obligation,</b> i.e., the limbs of the animal which contain the gifts, <b>and</b> since <b>the obligation is</b> owned <b>by the Israelite</b> he is obligated? <b>Or perhaps, we follow the principal</b> part of the <b>animal, and</b> since <b>the principal</b> of the <b>animal is</b> in the possession <b>of the priest,</b> the Israelite is exempt?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a gentile or a priest who transferred his sheep to an Israelite</b> to act as his agent <b>to shear</b> it, the Israelite is <b>exempt</b> from giving the first sheared wool to a priest. Similarly, <b>one who purchases</b> the <b>shearing</b> of the <b>sheep of a gentile,</b> even before the sheep was actually sheared, is <b>exempt from</b> giving <b>the first sheared</b> wool.
The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And this,</b> the <i>halakha</i> in a case where one purchases an item before the obligation of a certain gift of the priesthood takes effect, <b>is a stringency</b> that applies <b>in</b> the case of <b>the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw more so than</b> in the case of the <b>first sheared</b> wool. In other words, one who purchases wool from a priest before it is shorn is exempt from giving first sheared wool, whereas one who purchases part of an animal from a priest before its slaughter is obligated to give any gifts contained within the purchased portion. Since this is the <i>halakha</i> even if the portion he purchased is not the principal part, similar to the stated case of one who purchases only the shearing of the sheep of a gentile, one can <b>conclude from</b> this <i>baraita</i> that <b>we follow the obligation,</b> i.e., the limbs of the animal that contain the gifts. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is correct.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And if</b> a priest sold his animal to an Israelite and <b>said</b> that he is selling everything <b>except for the gifts</b> with it, the Israelite is <b>exempt from</b> the obligation to give <b>the gifts,</b> because they are not his.

Daf 134a

The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> one can <b>raise a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If a priest sells his animal to an Israelite and stipulates: I am selling it <b>on the condition that the gifts are mine,</b> the Israelite is not obligated to give the gifts to that priest. Rather, he <b>gives</b> the gifts <b>to any priest that he wants.</b> Since the priest sold his animal, the priest cannot issue a condition involving the gifts, as they no longer belong to him but to the entire tribe of priests. The <i>baraita</i> indicates that the Israelite is nevertheless obligated to give the gifts, which apparently contradicts the ruling of the mishna.
The Gemara responds: Do <b>you raise a contradiction</b> from a <i>baraita</i> that discusses a case where the priest states: <b>On the condition</b> that the gifts are mine, <b>with regard to</b> the case of the mishna, where the priest states: <b>Except</b> for the gifts? That is not a contradiction, as the word <b>except</b> is a term of <b>retention,</b> i.e., the priest retains the gifts and does not sell them to the Israelite. By contrast, the term: <b>On the condition,</b> is <b>not</b> one of <b>retention,</b> as the priest does not keep the gifts for himself but instead stipulates that the buyer must give the gifts to him. The priest is not authorized to issue such a stipulation and it is therefore disregarded entirely, and because the Israelite owns the gifts he must give them to a priest.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> one may <b>raise a contradiction</b> against the previous <i>baraita</i> from another <i>baraita</i>: If a priest sells his animal to an Israelite and stipulates: I am selling it <b>on the condition that the gifts are mine, the gifts are his</b> and the Israelite must give the gifts to that priest. The Gemara responds: There is a dispute between the <i>tanna’im</i> of these <i>baraitot</i>, and <b>they disagree with regard to this</b> matter: One <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the second <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that the term: <b>On the condition, is</b> one of <b>retention,</b> and the priest therefore retains possession of the gifts. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the first <i>baraita</i>, <b>holds</b> that: <b>On the condition, is not</b> a term of <b>retention,</b> and the priest is not authorized to stipulate that the buyer must give the gifts to him.
§ The mishna teaches that if one <b>said to</b> a butcher: <b>Sell me the innards</b> of a cow that you slaughtered, and there were gifts, i.e., the maw, included with it, the buyer gives the gifts to the priest and does not deduct its value from the money that he pays to the butcher. If he bought the innards by weight, the buyer gives the maw to the priest and deducts its value from the money he pays to the butcher. With regard to innards purchased by weight, <b>Rav says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that the buyer gives the maw to the priest <b>only when</b> the buyer <b>weighed</b> the innards <b>for himself</b> when purchasing them. In such a case, the priest claims the maw from the buyer. <b>But</b> if the <b>butcher weighed</b> the innards <b>for</b> the buyer, <b>the judgment is</b> also <b>with the butcher,</b> i.e., the priest may claim the maw from either the butcher or the buyer. <b>And Rav Asi says: Even</b> if the <b>butcher weighed</b> the innards <b>for</b> the buyer, <b>the judgment is with</b> the buyer alone.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>they disagree with regard to</b> a statement <b>of Rav Ḥisda, as Rav Ḥisda said:</b> In a case where one <b>robbed</b> another of an item, <b>and the owners had not despaired of retrieving</b> it, <b>and another</b> person <b>came and consumed</b> the stolen item, if the owner <b>wants, he</b> may <b>collect</b> the value of the stolen item <b>from this one,</b> the robber, and if he <b>wants, he</b> may <b>collect from that one</b> who consumed it. The suggestion is <b>that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda,</b> and he therefore holds that the priest may claim the maw from either the buyer or the butcher; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav Asi, <b>does not hold</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda,</b> and the priest may therefore claim the maw from the buyer alone.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No; everyone holds</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rav Ḥisda, and here they disagree with regard to</b> whether or not <b>gifts of the priesthood can be stolen. As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> that they <b>can be stolen,</b> and accordingly the robber remains responsible for them even if they are consumed by another. Consequently, if the butcher weighed the innards, the priest may claim the gifts from either the butcher or the buyer. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav Asi, <b>holds</b> that gifts of the priesthood <b>cannot be stolen.</b> Since technically one cannot steal the gifts, the obligation to return them to the priest rests solely on the one in physical possession of them. Accordingly, the priest may claim the gifts from the buyer alone, as the gifts are in his custody.
The Gemara notes that <b>some teach this <i>halakha</i>,</b> that there is a dispute between Rav and Rav Asi as to whether or not gifts of the priesthood can be stolen, <b>by itself,</b> i.e., as an independent dispute between them rather than in explanation of another dispute: <b>Rav says</b> that <b>gifts of the priesthood can be stolen, and Rav Asi says</b> that <b>gifts of the priesthood cannot be stolen.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>a convert who converted and he had a cow,</b> if the cow <b>was slaughtered before</b> he <b>converted,</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from giving the gifts to the priest. If the animal was slaughtered <b>after he converted,</b> the convert is <b>obligated</b> to give the gifts. If there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether it was slaughtered before or after the conversion, the convert is <b>exempt, as the burden of proof rests upon the claimant.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if there is an uncertainty whether an individual is obligated to give gifts of the priesthood, he is exempt from giving them. In this regard, the Gemara relates that <b>when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raised a contradiction to Rabbi Yoḥanan: We learned</b> in the mishna that when there is <b>an uncertainty</b> one is <b>exempt</b> from giving the gifts. <b>Evidently,</b> in cases of <b>uncertainty</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>to</b> be <b>lenient.</b>
But one can <b>raise a contradiction</b> from that which is taught in another mishna (<i>Pe’a</i> 4:11) with regard to gleanings left for the poor: In a case of grain found in <b>ant holes that are inside the standing</b> crop in an area of the field that was not harvested, <b>these are</b> the property <b>of the owner</b> of the field, as this grain does not have the status of gleanings. <b>And</b> in the case of grain found in ant holes <b>that are behind the harvesters</b> in an already harvested area, <b>the upper</b> wheat stalks, i.e., those stalks found at the mouth of the holes, belong <b>to the poor,</b> as they are assumed to be gleanings that fell from the bundles when that area was harvested, <b>and the lower</b> wheat inside the holes are the property <b>of the owner,</b> since it is possible that they were collected by the ants before the harvest and are not gleanings.
<b>Rabbi Meir says: Everything</b> goes <b>to the poor, as</b> grain whose status as <b>gleanings</b> is <b>uncertain</b> is considered <b>gleanings.</b> According to Rabbi Meir, the <i>halakha</i> is stringent in the case of an uncertainty with regard to gifts left for the poor. This apparently contradicts the mishna’s statement that one is lenient in the case of an uncertainty with regard to gifts of the priesthood, as these gifts are similar in this regard to gifts left for the poor. Since any unattributed mishna is considered to be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, this is apparently a contradiction with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish: <b>Do not trouble me</b> with this contradiction, <b>as I teach</b> that <i>baraita</i> <b>in the singular,</b> i.e., it is not certain that this is the opinion of Rabbi Meir; rather, it is merely the claim of one Sage that this is Rabbi Meir’s opinion. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra says in the name of Rabbi Meir:</b> Grain whose status as <b>gleanings</b> is <b>uncertain</b> is considered <b>gleanings;</b> grain whose status as <b>forgotten</b> sheaves is <b>uncertain</b> is considered <b>forgotten</b> sheaves; and grain whose status as <b><i>pe’a</i></b> is <b>uncertain</b> is considered <b><i>pe’a</i>.</b> Therefore, one should not raise a contradiction to the mishna from the statement of a single Sage claiming to represent the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: Even if <b>you teach that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>only in a language</b> whereby a certain imbecile named <b>ben Tedal</b> states that this is the opinion of Rabbi Meir, a question remains, as <b>isn’t</b> there <b>a stated reason</b> for stringency in cases of uncertainties with regard to gifts left for the poor? <b>As Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “Do justice to the afflicted and destitute”</b> (Psalms 82:3)? Specifically, <b>what is</b> the meaning of <b>“do justice”?</b>
<b>If we say</b> that it means that one should do justice <b>in judgments,</b> i.e., a judge should sway judgments in favor of the afflicted and destitute, <b>but isn’t it written: “Neither shall you favor a poor man in his cause”</b> (Exodus 23:3)? <b>Rather,</b> the verse is teaching that in cases of uncertainty with regard to gifts left for the poor, <b>be righteous with that which is yours and give it to</b> the poor. Why, then, is the <i>halakha</i> stringent in the case of gifts left for the poor but lenient with regard to gifts to priests?
<b>Rava said</b> in response: <b>Here,</b> in the case of gifts of the priesthood, the <i>halakha</i> is lenient because the <b>cow</b> of a convert <b>maintains</b> the <b>presumptive status of exemption,</b> as the obligation of the gifts did not apply to the cow before the convert converted. By contrast, the <i>halakha</i> is stringent in the case of the gifts left for the poor, as the <b>standing</b> crop <b>maintains</b> the <b>presumptive status of obligation.</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>But</b> with regard to the <b>dough</b> of a convert, the <i>halakha</i> is that if <b>it was prepared before he converted</b> he is <b>exempt from</b> separating <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> from this dough, and if it was prepared <b>after he converted,</b> he is <b>obligated</b> to separate <i>ḥalla</i> from it. And if there is an <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether the dough was prepared before or after his conversion, he is <b>obligated,</b> despite the fact that dough prepared by a gentile is exempt from <i>ḥalla</i>. Why isn’t the convert exempt from separating <i>ḥalla</i> just as he is exempt from giving gifts of the priesthood in the case of an uncertainty, as both the dough and the cow maintain a presumptive status of exemption?
Rava <b>said to</b> Abaye: There is a difference between <i>ḥalla</i> and gifts of the priesthood. Although the dough maintains the presumptive status of exemption, here there is also uncertainty with regard to a prohibition, as a non-priest who consumes <i>ḥalla</i> is liable to receive the punishment of death at the hand of Heaven. And whenever there is <b>an uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>a prohibition,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>to</b> be <b>stringent.</b> Conversely, uncertainties with regard to gifts of the priesthood involve no prohibition and are strictly monetary, and whenever there is <b>an uncertainty</b> with regard to <b>monetary matters,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>to</b> be <b>lenient.</b> Consequently, one relies on the presumptive status of exemption in the case of a cow, and the convert is exempt from giving the gifts to the priest.
<b>As Rav Ḥisda said, and Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches likewise: Eight</b> instances of <b>uncertainties were stated with regard to the convert;</b> in <b>four</b> instances the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that</b> there is <b>an obligation, and</b> in the other <b>four</b> instances the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that</b> there is <b>an exemption.</b> These are the four instances where the <i>halakha</i> is stringent: The first is an uncertainty with regard to the <b>offering of</b> one’s <b>wife</b> who gave birth, where it is uncertain whether she gave birth before her conversion and she is exempt from bringing an offering, or after her conversion and she is obligated. This case involves a prohibition, as a woman who does not bring her atonement offering is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for consuming sanctified items.
<b>And</b> the second case is an uncertainty with regard to the obligation to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i></b> from his dough, which also involves a prohibition, as explained above. <b>And</b> the third case is an uncertainty with regard to a male <b>firstborn non-kosher animal,</b> i.e., a firstborn donkey, where it is uncertain if it was born before or after the owner’s conversion, which involves the prohibition against deriving benefit from it before its redemption. <b>And</b> the fourth case of an uncertainty is with regard to a male <b>firstborn of a kosher animal,</b> where it is uncertain if it was born before or after the owner’s conversion, where one can be liable to receive <i>karet</i> for slaughtering it outside the Temple courtyard. In these four cases, the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that</b> there is <b>an obligation.</b>

Daf 134b

And these are the four uncertainties with regard to a convert where the <i>halakha</i> is lenient: The first is an uncertainty with regard to <b>the first sheared</b> wool of one’s sheep, where it is uncertain whether they were shorn before or after his conversion. <b>And</b> the second is whether or not the obligation of giving <b>the gifts</b> of the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw applies to his animal. <b>And</b> the third is an uncertainty with regard to the obligation to give five <i>sela</i> for the mitzva of the <b>redemption of</b> the firstborn <b>son,</b> where it is uncertain if he was born before or after the owner’s conversion. <b>And</b> the last is an uncertainty with regard to the <b>redemption of a firstborn donkey</b> by means of a sheep or a goat, where it is uncertain if it was born before or after the owner’s conversion. In each of these instances, the uncertainty is only with regard to monetary matters, and therefore the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that</b> one is <b>exempt.</b>
In connection to the previous discussion between Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish and Rabbi Yoḥanan, the Gemara relates that <b>when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> a slightly different version of the above discussion: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish <b>raised</b> the <b>contradiction</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Meir from a <i>baraita</i> that states that Rabbi Meir exempts the <b>standing</b> crop of a convert from the obligation to leave gleanings for the poor when it is uncertain whether the crop was harvested before or after his conversion. This <i>baraita</i> is in contradiction <b>to</b> the <i>baraita</i> that likewise discusses the <b>standing</b> crop: Grain whose status as gleanings is uncertain is considered gleanings. Rabbi Yoḥanan resolved this contradiction by explaining that the second <i>baraita</i> is the opinion of Rabbi Meir only according to Rabbi Yehuda ben Agra.
§ With regard to gifts left for the poor, the Gemara relates that <b>Levi sowed</b> crops in his field <b>in Kishar, but there were no poor</b> people in Kishar <b>to take gleanings</b> from his field. Levi <b>came before Rav Sheshet</b> to ask what should be done with the gleanings. Rav Sheshet <b>said to him:</b> The verse states with regard to the mitzvot of <i>pe’a</i> and gleanings: <b>“You shall leave them for the poor and for the stranger”</b> (Leviticus 23:22), <b>and not for the ravens nor for the bats.</b> Since there are no poor people to take the gleanings, you should take them for yourself.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The owner of a field <b>does not</b> need to expend the effort to <b>bring <i>teruma</i>, neither from the threshing floor to the city nor from the wilderness to a settled area,</b> in order to give it to a priest. Rather, the priest must travel to the field to receive the <i>teruma</i>. <b>And if there is no priest there,</b> at the threshing floor or in the wilderness, to receive the <i>teruma</i>, the owner must <b>hire a cow and bring</b> the <i>teruma</i> to the city, <b>due to</b> the <b>loss of <i>teruma</i></b> that would occur if it were left in the field. According to this <i>baraita</i>, the owner of the field should likewise be obligated to do the same with gleanings.
The Gemara explains: <b><i>Teruma</i> is different,</b> in <b>that</b> if it is not separated <b>it</b> causes the entire crop to be considered <b>untithed, and</b> it is therefore <b>not possible for</b> one <b>not</b> to <b>separate</b> <i>teruma</i> from the crop. By contrast, gleanings do not render the remaining crop prohibited for consumption, and therefore it is not necessary to set them aside and remove them.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> what about the case of the <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood, <b>which do not render</b> the rest of the animal <b>untithed,</b> i.e., they do not prohibit the entire animal in consumption before they are separated. <b>And</b> nevertheless <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a <b>place where they were accustomed to put the</b> meat of slaughtered <b>calves in boiling water</b> in order to remove the hairs from the skin, and then eat the meat with the skin still attached to the flesh, one <b>may not skin the foreleg</b> before giving it to the priest. Rather, he gives it with its skin intact.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Similarly, in a place where people are accustomed <b>to skin the head</b> of an animal, one <b>may not skin the</b> cheek of the <b>jaw</b> of an animal before giving it to the priest, but must give it with its skin intact so that the priest may use the skin as he wishes. <b>And if there is no priest</b> available to receive the gifts, the gifts are <b>appraised</b> by their <b>monetary</b> value, <b>and</b> the owner may <b>eat them</b> and gives their monetary value to a priest at the next available time, <b>due to</b> the <b>loss</b> that would otherwise be incurred by the <b>priest.</b> Evidently, one must expend effort to ensure that a priest receives the gifts despite the fact that they do not render the entire animal untithed. Why is the <i>halakha</i> different with regard to gleanings?
The Gemara responds: The <i>halakha</i> <b>is different</b> in the case of <b>gifts of the priesthood, as</b> a term of <b>giving is written with regard to it:</b> “That they shall give to the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3). This teaches that one must actively give the gifts to a priest, whereas no equivalent term is written with regard to gleanings. The Gemara adds: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> explanation with regard to gifts of the priesthood, one can likewise explain that the reason <b><i>teruma</i></b> must be brought to a locale where there is a priest is <b>likewise</b> due to the fact that a term of <b>giving is written with regard to it:</b> “The first fruits of your grain, of your wine, and of your oil, and the first sheared wool of your sheep you shall give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4), not because <i>teruma</i> renders the crop untithed.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the verse to state <b>an extra</b> term of <b>leaving</b> with regard to gleanings? One verse states: “Neither shall you gather the gleaning of your harvest, and your vineyard you shall not harvest completely, and the fallen fruit of your vineyard you shall not gather; you shall leave them for the poor and for the stranger” (Leviticus 19:9–10), and another verse states: “Neither shall you gather the gleaning of your harvest; you shall leave them for the poor and for the stranger” (Leviticus 23:22). Doesn’t this additional mention of leaving indicate that even if there are no poor people to take the gleanings, the owner must collect them and ensure that a poor person can claim them?
The Gemara responds: No, the extra term of leaving is required <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who declares his vineyard ownerless, and in the morning awoke</b> and reclaimed the ownerless vineyard <b>and harvested</b> the grapes, he <b>is obligated in</b> the mitzva of leaving <b>individual fallen</b> grapes for the poor [<i>peret</i>], <b>and in</b> the mitzva of leaving <b>incompletely formed clusters</b> of grapes for the poor [<i>olelot</i>], <b>and in</b> the mitzva of leaving <b>forgotten</b> clusters, <b>and in</b> the mitzva of <b><i>pe’a</i>. And he is exempt from</b> the obligation to separate <b>the tithes</b> from the grapes, as the vineyard had been ownerless. The <i>baraita</i> rules that he is obligated in the gifts for the poor despite the <i>halakha</i> that the obligation to leave these gifts does not apply to an ownerless vineyard. It is derived from the additional mention of leaving that the obligation of gifts to the poor applies even to an ownerless field of this type.
§ In relation to the discussion of a case where the owner of a field takes gifts left for the poor for himself, the Gemara relates that there was <b>a certain sack of dinars that was brought to the study hall</b> to provide financial assistance for the students. <b>Rabbi Ami rushed and acquired them.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And how can he act in this</b> manner? <b>But isn’t it written</b> with regard to gifts of the priesthood: <b>“That they shall give</b> to the priest” (Deuteronomy 18:3), and the Sages derived from the verse that a priest should receive the gifts <b>and he should not take</b> them <b>by himself.</b> The same applies to gifts for the poor as well. The Gemara responds: <b>Rabbi Ami too</b> did not take the gifts for himself. Rather, <b>he acquired them for the poor.</b>
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a distinguished person</b> such as Rabbi Ami, who was the head of the yeshiva, <b>is different,</b> and he may acquire the gifts for himself. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse: <b>“And the priest who is greater than his brethren”</b> (Leviticus 21:10), indicates <b>that</b> the High Priest <b>should be greater than his</b> priestly <b>brethren in beauty, in wisdom, and in wealth.</b>
<b>Others say: From where</b> is it derived <b>that if</b> the High Priest <b>does not have</b> property of his own, <b>his brethren the priests elevate him</b> and render him wealthy from their own property? <b>The verse states: “And the priest who is greater than his brethren,”</b> i.e., they must <b>elevate him from</b> the property <b>of his brethren.</b> Since the members of the study hall are required to enrich Rabbi Ami from their own property, it is certainly permitted for him to take these gifts for himself.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>What is the</b> definition of the <b>foreleg</b> that is given to the priests as one of the gifts? It is the part of the leg <b>from the joint of the</b> lower <b>knee until the rounded protrusion</b> surrounding the thigh bone <b>of the foreleg; and that is</b> the foreleg mentioned in the Torah <b>with regard to the nazirite:</b> “And the priest shall take the foreleg of the ram when it is cooked” (Numbers 6:19). <b>And the parallel in the hind leg is the thigh</b> that is given to the priest from the peace offering, which is also from the joint of the lower knee until the rounded protrusion surrounding the thigh bone. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The <b>thigh is from the joint of the</b> lower <b>knee until the upper knee</b> joint, which connects the middle and upper parts of the leg. <b>What is the</b> definition of the <b>jaw?</b> It is <b>from the joint of the</b> lower <b>jaw</b> beneath the temples and downward <b>until the upper ring of the windpipe.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the gifts of the priesthood: “That they shall give to the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3). <b>“The foreleg”; this is</b> the <b>right foreleg</b> of the animal. The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Do you say</b> that <b>this is</b> the <b>right foreleg, or is it only the left foreleg? The verse states: “The foreleg.”</b> The definite article indicates that the verse is referring to the right foreleg.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation</b> for this, i.e., how is it understood from the definite article that the verse is referring to the right foreleg? The Gemara responds: It is derived <b>like that</b> which <b>Rava said</b> with regard to the verse: “Therefore the children of Israel do not eat the sciatic nerve which is upon the hollow of <b>the thigh”</b> (Genesis 32:33). The definite article indicates that this is referring to <b>the most important thigh. Here too,</b> the definite article in the term <b>“the foreleg”</b> indicates that the verse is referring to <b>the most important foreleg,</b> i.e., the right foreleg.
The Gemara continues: And in the term <b>“and the jaw,” for what</b> purpose <b>does</b> the definite article <b>come,</b> i.e., what <i>halakha</i> does it teach? It serves <b>to include wool that is on the head of lambs and hair that is in the beard of goats</b> in the obligation to give the jaw to the priest. And in the term <b>“and the maw,” for what</b> purpose <b>does</b> the definite article <b>come?</b> It serves <b>to include fat that is on the maw and fat that is inside the maw</b> in the obligation to give the maw to the priest. <b>As Rabbi Yehoshua said: Priests behaved generously with</b> fat that is on the maw <b>and they gave it to</b> its <b>owner,</b> i.e., they relinquished their right to receive it. The Gemara infers: The <b>reason</b> this fat was not given to the priests is <b>that they behaved</b> generously, <b>but</b> had they <b>not behaved</b> generously, the fat would be <b>his,</b> the priest’s.
The Gemara cites a homiletical idea with regard to the gifts of the priesthood: <b>The interpreters</b> of Torah <b>symbolism [<i>dorshei ḥamurot</i>] would say</b> with regard to the reason why the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw are given to the priests: <b>The foreleg corresponds to the hand</b> of Pinehas, son of Elazar the priest, who killed Zimri, son of Salu, thereby bringing an end to the plague that was ravaging the children of Israel. <b>And it likewise states</b> in the verse: <b>“And he took a spear in his hand”</b> (Numbers 25:7).
<b>And</b> the <b>jaw</b> corresponds to the <b>prayer [<i>tefilla</i>]</b> offered by Pinehas during the aforementioned incident. <b>And so it states</b> in the verse: <b>“Then stood up Pinehas, and wrought judgment [<i>vayefallel</i>],</b> and so the plague was stayed. And that was counted to him for righteousness, to all generations forever” (Psalms 106:30). The <b>maw</b> is <b>as its plain meaning</b> in the verses describing the incident, <b>and it likewise states:</b> “And he thrust both of them through, the man of Israel, <b>and the woman through her belly.</b> So the plague was stayed from the children of Israel” (Numbers 25:8).
The Gemara above cited a source for the <i>halakha</i> that the right foreleg is given to the priest. The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> of the following <i>baraita</i> <b>cites</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from here:</b> The verse states with regard to the gift to the priest from a peace offering: “And <b>the right thigh</b> you shall give to the priest as a gift from your sacrifices of peace offerings” (Leviticus 7:32). <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>the right thigh</b> of a peace offering is given to the priest. <b>From where</b> do I derive that the right <b>foreleg</b> of the <b>sacrificial</b> ram of the nazirite is given to the priest? <b>The verse states:</b> “You shall give to the priest as <b>a gift.”</b> And <b>from where</b> is it derived that the right <b>foreleg</b> of <b>a non-sacred</b> animal is also given as a gift to the priest? <b>The verse states: “You shall give.”</b>
§ The mishna taught: <b>What is</b> definition of <b>the jaw?</b> It is <b>from the joint of the jaw</b> beneath the temples and below <b>until the upper ring of the windpipe.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that when one removes the jaw from the animal to give to the priest, <b>he removes it and the area of slaughter</b> on the throat <b>with it?</b> The area of slaughter is beyond the upper ring of the windpipe.
The Gemara responds: This is <b>not difficult.</b> Everyone agrees that the priest receives only the part until the upper ring of the windpipe, and the difference between the two rulings is that <b>this</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and that</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus.</b>
The Gemara explains that this is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The slaughter of an animal in such a manner that the knife is <b>diverted</b> to an area above the place of slaughter on its throat is <b>not valid. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus testified with regard to</b> the slaughter of an animal when the knife is <b>diverted that it is valid</b> (see 18b). The <i>baraita</i> calls the area of the jaw until the upper ring of the windpipe the area of slaughter, in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Antigonus, who maintains that it is also a valid area for slaughter.
And <b>if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>this</b> mishna <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are both in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and what</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean when it says: <b>With it?</b> It means that the area of slaughter remains <b>with the animal,</b> i.e., it remains with the owner and is not given to the priest.

Daf 135a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mitzva of <b>the first sheared wool</b> that every Jew must give to the priest, as stated in the verse: “And the first sheared wool of your flock [<i>tzonekha</i>] shall you give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4), <b>applies</b> both <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>in the presence of the Temple and not in the presence of the Temple,</b> and <b>with regard to non-sacred</b> animals. <b>But</b> it does <b>not</b> apply <b>to sacrificial</b> animals.
There are more <b>stringent</b> elements <b>in</b> the mitzva of <b>the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw</b> (see 130a) <b>than</b> in the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the first sheared wool</b> in <b>that</b> the mitzva of <b>the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw applies to cattle and to sheep,</b> as it is written: “Whether it be ox or sheep, that he shall give unto the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3); and it applies <b>to numerous</b> animals <b>and to few</b> animals. <b>But</b> by contrast, the mitzva of <b>the first sheared wool applies only to sheep</b> and not to goats and cattle, <b>and applies only to numerous</b> animals.
<b>And how many are numerous? Beit Shammai say:</b> It is at least <b>two sheep, as it is stated: “That a man shall rear a young cow, and two sheep [<i>tzon</i>]”</b> (Isaiah 7:21), indicating that two sheep are characterized as <i>tzon</i>; and the mitzva of the first sheared wool is written using the term “your flock [<i>tzonekha</i>].” <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> It is at least <b>five</b> sheep, <b>as it is stated: “And five sheep [<i>tzon</i>] made”</b> (I Samuel 25:18).
<b>Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas says:</b> When shearing <b>five sheep,</b> the <b>sheared</b> wool of each sheep weighing <b>one hundred dinars</b> each <b>and half [<i>peras</i>]</b> of one hundred dinars each, i.e., one hundred and fifty dinars each, <b>are</b> subject to the <b>obligation of the first sheared wool,</b> i.e., they render the owner obligated to give the first sheared wool to the priests. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> Any <b>five sheep,</b> each of whose <b>sheared</b> wool weighs <b>any amount,</b> render the owner obligated in the mitzva.
<b>And how much</b> of the sheared wool <b>does one give to</b> the priest? One gives him sheared wool of the <b>weight</b> of <b>five <i>sela</i> in Judea, which are</b> the equivalent of <b>ten <i>sela</i> in the Galilee,</b> as the weight of the Galilean <i>sela</i> is half that of the Judean <i>sela</i>. Furthermore, although one may give the wool to the priest without laundering it, this must be the weight of the wool once <b>laundered and not</b> when <b>sullied,</b> as is characteristic of wool when sheared. The measure that must be given to the priest is <b>enough to fashion a small garment from it, as it is stated: “Shall you give him”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:4), indicating <b>that</b> the sheared wool <b>must contain enough for</b> a proper <b>gift.</b>
If the owner of the shearing <b>did not manage to give it to</b> the priest <b>until he dyed it,</b> the owner is <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of the first sheared wool, as this constitutes a change in the wool by which means he acquires ownership of it. If he <b>laundered it but did not dye it,</b> he is <b>obligated</b> to give the first sheared wool, as laundering does not constitute a change in the wool.
<b>One who purchases the fleece of the sheep of a gentile</b> is <b>exempt from</b> the obligation of giving <b>the first sheared wool</b> to the priest. With regard to <b>one who purchases the fleece of the sheep of another</b> Jew, <b>if</b> the seller <b>kept</b> some of the wool, then <b>the seller is obligated</b> to give the first sheared wool to the priest. If the seller <b>did not keep</b> any of the wool, <b>the buyer is obligated</b> to give it. If the seller <b>had two types</b> of sheep, <b>gray and white,</b> and he <b>sold</b> the buyer the <b>gray</b> fleece <b>but not</b> the <b>white</b> fleece, or if he sold the fleece of the <b>male</b> sheep <b>but not</b> of the <b>female</b> sheep, then <b>this</b> one, the seller, <b>gives</b> the first sheared wool <b>for himself</b> to the priest from the wool that he kept, <b>and that</b> one, the buyer, <b>gives</b> the first sheared wool <b>for himself</b> to the priest from the wool that he bought.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that the mitzva of the first sheared wool does not apply <b>to sacrificial</b> animals. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that it does <b>not</b> apply? The Gemara answers that the <b>verse states: “Your flock”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:4), indicating that the mitzva applies to non-sacred animals, which belong to a private individual, <b>and not</b> to <b>a flock</b> that is <b>consecrated</b> property.
The Gemara challenges: <b>The reason</b> for the exemption of sacrificial animals <b>is that the Merciful One writes “your flock,”</b> from which it may be inferred that <b>were that not</b> the case <b>I would say</b> that even with regard to <b>sacrificial</b> animals one is <b>obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>the first sheared wool. But</b> this suggestion is impossible, since <b>they are not fit for shearing, as it is written</b> with regard to firstborn animals, which are consecrated: <b>“And you shall not shear the firstborn of your flock”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:19).
The Gemara explains: <b>If</b> the mishna was referring to sheep <b>consecrated</b> for the <b>altar, indeed</b> there would be no need to derive their exemption from the verse. But <b>here we are dealing with</b> sheep <b>consecrated</b> to the treasury for <b>Temple maintenance,</b> which it is permitted to shear, and the verse teaches that even with regard to these one is exempt from the mitzva of the first sheared wool.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Elazar say</b> with regard to animals <b>consecrated</b> for <b>Temple maintenance</b> that it is <b>prohibited to shear</b> them <b>or</b> to <b>work</b> them? The Gemara answers: The prohibition with regard to animals consecrated for Temple maintenance applies <b>by rabbinic</b> law, not by Torah law. Therefore, it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since by Torah</b> law <b>they</b> are <b>fit for shearing,</b> in a case <b>where</b> one transgressed the rabbinical prohibition and <b>sheared</b> the consecrated sheep, he <b>should give</b> the first sheared wool <b>to</b> the priest. Consequently, the verse teaches that he is exempt from the mitzva of the first sheared wool.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> since he <b>consecrated</b> the wool it is consecrated property, and therefore in practice it cannot be given to a priest. Consequently, there is no need to derive their exemption from the verse. The Gemara explains: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that the owner is required <b>to redeem</b> the wool by giving its value to the Temple treasury <b>and</b> then <b>give</b> it <b>to</b> the priest.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> when an animal is redeemed it <b>requires standing and valuation,</b> as it is written: “And he shall stand the animal before the priest, and the priest shall value it, whether it be good or bad; as the priest evaluates it, so shall it be” (Leviticus 27:11–12). Once the wool has been sheared this process cannot be performed, which means that the wool cannot be redeemed. The Gemara comments: <b>This works out well according to the one who said</b> that animals <b>consecrated</b> for <b>Temple maintenance were not included in</b> the requirement <b>of standing and valuation. But according to the one who said</b> that they <b>were</b> included in this requirement, <b>what can be said?</b>
<b>Rabbi Mani bar Pattish said in the name of Rabbi Yannai:</b> The statement <b>here</b> in the mishna is referring <b>to</b> a case where one <b>consecrated</b> the rest of <b>his animal for Temple maintenance except for its fleece,</b> which he reserved for himself. Because the owner did not consecrate the wool, it might <b>enter your mind to say: Let him shear</b> the sheep <b>and</b> be obligated to <b>give</b> the wool to the priest. Therefore, the <b>verse states: “Your flock,”</b> indicating that the mitzva applies to non-sacred animals, which belong to an individual, <b>and not</b> to <b>sheep that are consecrated</b> property.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> that the mishna is discussing a case where one consecrated an animal except for its fleece, one could say that it is <b>also</b> referring to animals <b>consecrated</b> for the <b>altar.</b> The Gemara answers: The mishna cannot be discussing animals consecrated for the altar, as it is prohibited to shear them even if their fleece was not consecrated. The reason is that this causes the animal to <b>become weakened,</b> which entails a loss of consecrated property.
The Gemara objects: But animals <b>consecrated</b> for <b>Temple maintenance</b> are <b>also weakened</b> by shearing, and therefore it should be prohibited to shear them as well. The Gemara explains: The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> one <b>said</b> that he consecrates his animal for Temple maintenance <b>except for</b> both its <b>fleece and</b> its <b>weakening,</b> i.e., the loss of strength caused by shearing.
The Gemara further objects: The mishna could <b>also</b> be referring to animals <b>consecrated</b> for the <b>altar</b> in a case <b>where</b> one <b>said</b> that he consecrates the animal <b>except for</b> both its <b>fleece and</b> the <b>weakening,</b> i.e., the loss in strength caused by shearing. The Gemara explains: With regard to animals consecrated for the altar this stipulation is ineffective, as <b>even so,</b> i.e., despite his declaration, the <b>sanctity extends to the entire</b> animal, and therefore it is prohibited to shear it.
The Gemara explains: <b>And from where do you say</b> that if one consecrates an animal for the altar the sanctity extends to the entire animal? This is <b>as Rabbi Yosei said: Isn’t it</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to sacrificial</b> animals that if <b>one says: The leg of this</b> animal is consecrated as <b>a burnt offering,</b> then the <b>entire</b> animal is <b>a burnt offering,</b> as the sanctity of the leg spreads throughout the animal’s body? <b>And even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> that <b>it is not entirely a burnt offering, that statement</b> of Rabbi Meir applies only <b>where he consecrated</b> its leg, which is <b>not a matter,</b> i.e., a limb, <b>upon which</b> the animal’s <b>life depends.</b> It is possible for an animal to survive the removal of a leg. <b>But</b> if <b>one consecrated a matter upon which</b> the animal’s <b>life depends,</b> everyone agrees that all of it <b>is consecrated.</b>
§ <b>Rava said</b> that there is no need to interpret the mishna as discussing a case where one consecrated a whole animal apart from its fleece and the loss caused by shearing. Rather, the mishna is referring <b>to</b> one who <b>consecrates the fleece itself</b> to the treasury for Temple maintenance, but not the sheep. It might <b>enter your mind to say: Let him shear</b> the sheep <b>and redeem</b> the wool by giving its value to the Temple treasury, <b>and</b> then be required to <b>give</b> the wool <b>to</b> the priest.
Therefore, the <b>verse states:</b> “The first sheared wool <b>of your flock, shall you give him”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:4), which indicates that there should be no additional action between shearing and giving the first sheared wool to the priest. In other words, the mitzva of first sheared wool applies to a sheep <b>that is lacking only shearing and giving,</b> which <b>excludes this</b> sheep <b>that is lacking shearing, redeeming, and giving.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if this verse is the source of the exemption of consecrated animals, then <b>for what</b> purpose does the term <b>“your flock” come?</b> That term also indicates that certain sheep are excluded from the mitzva. The Gemara answers that it is necessary <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An animal</b> owned by two <b>partners is obligated,</b> i.e., renders its owners obligated, <b>in the</b> mitzva of the <b>first sheared</b> wool, <b>but Rabbi Ilai exempts</b> them. <b>What is the reason for</b> the ruling <b>of Rabbi Ilai?</b> The reason is that the <b>verse states “your flock,”</b> using the singular pronoun, indicating that the mitzva applies to animals belonging to an individual, <b>but not</b> to sheep that are owned <b>in partnership.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that joint owners of sheep are obligated in the mitzva of the first sheared wool, what is excluded by the term “your flock”? The Gemara answers that this serves <b>to exclude</b> an animal owned in <b>partnership</b> with <b>a gentile.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And from where does Rabbi Ilai</b> derive that an animal owned in <b>partnership</b> with <b>a gentile</b> renders its Jewish owner exempt from the mitzva?
The Gemara answers: He <b>derives it from the beginning of</b> this <b>verse,</b> which states with regard to <i>teruma</i>: <b>“The first fruits of your grain,</b> of your wine, and of your oil” (Deuteronomy 18:4), using the singular pronoun. This indicates that only in the case of produce owned by a Jew is one obligated to separate <i>teruma</i>, <b>but not</b> with regard to that which is owned <b>in partnership</b> with <b>a gentile.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> why do the <b>Rabbis,</b> who derive the exemption of sheep owned in partnership with a gentile from the term “your flock,” not derive this from the term “your grain”? The Gemara answers that the repetition of the term “the first” with regard to the first sheared wool: “The first fruits of your grain, of your wine, and of your oil, and <b>the first sheared wool</b> of your flock, shall you give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4), is an indication that the verse <b>concluded</b> discussion of <b>the</b> previous <b>matter.</b> The superfluous mention of “first” signals that the two issues discussed in this verse, which are the first fruits, i.e., <i>teruma</i>, and the first sheared wool, are two separate matters. Therefore, one cannot derive the <i>halakhot</i> of one from the other.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Ilai</b> respond to the Rabbis’ claim? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Ilai holds that when the verse states: “And the first sheared wool,” the conjunction <b>“and” goes back and combines</b> the two matters together.

Daf 135b

The Gemara asks further: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to Rabbi Ilai’s claim? The Gemara answers: The Rabbis do not accept that the conjunction “and” goes back and combines the two matters together, as, if that were so, <b>let the Merciful One write neither “and” nor “the first.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Ilai</b> respond to this contention? The Gemara answers that Rabbi Ilai would say that the first sheared wool and <i>teruma</i> are essentially different obligations, as the first sheared wool is merely a monetary obligation with no inherent sanctity. By contrast, it is prohibited for non-priests to partake of <i>teruma</i>. <b>Since this</b> case of the first sheared wool involves only <b>sanctity</b> that inheres in its <b>value, and that</b> case of <i>teruma</i> referred to in the beginning of the verse involves <b>inherent sanctity,</b> the verse <b>separated them</b> through the repetition of the term “the first,” <b>and</b> then the verse <b>went back and combined them</b> through the term “and,” so that their <i>halakhot</i> could be derived from one another.
The Gemara provides an alternative explanation as to why the Rabbis do not derive the exemption of sheep owned in partnership with a gentile from the case of <i>teruma</i>. <b>If you wish, say</b> instead that <b>with regard to <i>teruma</i>, the Rabbis</b> hold that one who owns produce in <b>partnership</b> with <b>a gentile</b> is in fact <b>obligated, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If there were <b>a Jew and a gentile who purchased a field in partnership,</b> the produce grown in that field is considered to be <b>untithed produce,</b> which is subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>terumot</i> and tithes, <b>and non-sacred</b> produce, which is exempt from the requirements of <i>terumot</i> and tithes, <b>mixed together;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> The portion <b>of the Jew is obligated</b> in <i>teruma</i> and tithes, <b>but</b> the portion <b>of the gentile is exempt.</b>
The Gemara explains the inference. <b>They disagree only with regard to</b> the following issue: <b>That</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <b>holds</b> that <b>there is</b> retroactive <b>clarification,</b> which means that when they divide the produce it will be clarified who owned which produce from the outset; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>holds</b> that <b>there is no</b> retroactive <b>clarification,</b> and because it grew in a mixed state, it retains that status even after they divide the produce. <b>But</b> with regard to produce that a Jew owns in <b>partnership</b> with <b>a gentile, everyone agrees</b> that it is <b>obligated</b> in <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara presents an alternative explanation of Rabbi Ilai’s opinion: <b>If you wish, say</b> instead that Rabbi Ilai does not derive only the exemption of sheep owned in partnership with a Jew from the term “your flock” while he derives the exemption of sheep owned in partnership with a gentile from the term “your grain.” Rather, <b>according to Rabbi Ilai both</b> exemptions are <b>derived from</b> the term <b>“your flock.”</b>
The Gemara explains why both exemptions can be derived from a single phrase: With regard to <b>partnership</b> with <b>a gentile, what is the reason</b> that one is exempted from the obligation of the first sheared wool? It is due to the fact <b>that</b> the sheep is <b>not exclusively his.</b> In the case of a partnership <b>with a Jew too,</b> the sheep is <b>not exclusively his.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> reply to this claim of Rabbi Ilai? The Gemara answers: The Rabbis hold that partnership with a Jew cannot be compared to partnership with a gentile, as <b>a gentile is not obligated</b> in the mitzva of the first sheared wool, whereas <b>a Jew is obligated.</b>
§ <b>Rava said</b> with regard to the dispute between the Rabbis and Rabbi Ilai: Although <b>Rabbi Ilai</b> holds that two partners who own a sheep are exempt from the first sheared wool, he <b>concedes</b> that jointly owned produce is obligated <b>in <i>teruma</i>.</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though it is written</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i>: <b>“Your grain”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:4), using the singular pronoun, from which one may infer that with regard to <b>yours, yes,</b> one is obligated, whereas with regard to that <b>which is</b> owned <b>in partnership,</b> the partners are <b>not</b> obligated.
The Gemara explains that the joint owners of produce are nevertheless obligated in <i>teruma</i>, as <b>the Merciful One writes:</b> “There will I require <b>your <i>terumot</i>”</b> (Ezekiel 20:40). The use of the plural pronoun in this verse indicates that even partners who own produce are obligated in <i>teruma</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the term: <b>“Your grain,”</b> using the singular pronoun? The Gemara answers: This serves <b>to exclude</b> produce owned in <b>partnership</b> with <b>a gentile.</b>
Similarly, with regard to <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> the portion of dough that one is required to separate and give to a priest, Rabbi Ilai concedes that joint owners are obligated in this mitzva, <b>even though</b> one could claim otherwise, <b>as it is written:</b> “Of <b>the first</b> of your dough you shall set apart a cake for a gift” (Numbers 15:20), <b>and it is possible to say</b> that one <b>should derive</b> a verbal analogy between the term <b>“the first”</b> in this context and the term <b>“the first” from the first sheared wool: Just as there,</b> with regard to the first sheared wool, if the sheep are owned <b>in partnership</b> the owners are <b>not</b> obligated, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to <i>ḥalla</i>, if the dough is owned <b>in partnership</b> they are <b>not</b> obligated. Nevertheless, <b>the Merciful One writes: “Your dough,”</b> using a plural pronoun, indicating that even joint owners of dough are obligated to separate <i>ḥalla</i>.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> according to this claim, <b>the reason</b> joint owners of dough are obligated to separate <i>ḥalla</i> is <b>that it is written “your dough,”</b> using a plural pronoun. It can be inferred from here that <b>were that not</b> the case <b>I would say</b> that they are exempt, as <b>derived</b> by a verbal analogy between the term <b>“the first”</b> mentioned with regard to <i>ḥalla</i> and the term <b>“the first” from the first sheared wool. On the contrary,</b> one <b>should derive</b> a verbal analogy between the term “the first” with regard to <i>ḥalla</i> and the term “the first” <b>from <i>teruma</i>:</b> Just as the obligation to separate <i>teruma</i> applies to produce owned in partnership, so too, the obligation to separate <i>ḥalla</i> applies to dough owned in partnership. It is preferable to compare <i>ḥalla</i> to <i>teruma</i>, because their halakhic status is similar in that they are both prohibited to non-priests. If so, the inference from the term “your dough” is unnecessary.
The Gemara explains: It <b>is indeed so;</b> the obligation of produce owned in partnership in the case of <i>ḥalla</i> is derived from the case of <i>teruma</i>. <b>But</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the term <b>“your dough”?</b> This teaches that the quantity of dough to which the obligation of <i>ḥalla</i> applies <b>is equivalent to</b> the quantity of <b>your dough,</b> i.e., the quantity of dough kneaded daily by the Jewish people when they were in the Sinai Desert, when the mitzva was given. This is one <i>omer</i> for each person (see Exodus 16:16), which is a tenth of an ephah (see Exodus 16:36).
Likewise, with regard to <b><i>pe’a</i>,</b> produce in the corner of the field that is left for the poor, Rabbi Ilai concedes that the joint owners of produce are obligated, <b>even though it is written</b> in the verse cited below: <b>“Your field [<i>sadekha</i>],”</b> using a singular pronoun, from which it can be inferred that with regard to <b>your</b> field, <b>yes,</b> one is obligated, whereas with regard to that <b>which is</b> owned <b>in partnership,</b> one is <b>not</b> obligated. The reason is that <b>the Merciful One writes: “And when you reap [<i>uvekutzrekhem</i>] the harvest of your land,</b> you shall not entirely reap the corner of your field” (Leviticus 19:9). The term “when you reap” uses the plural pronoun, which indicates that even partners of land are obligated in <i>pe’a</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the term <b>“your field”</b> in the singular? The Gemara answers: This serves <b>to exclude</b> land owned in <b>partnership</b> with <b>a gentile</b> from the obligation of <i>pe’a</i>.
Similarly, with regard to the <b>firstborn</b> status of a male firstborn kosher animal, Rabbi Ilai concedes that jointly owned animals are sanctified, <b>even though it is written: “All the firstborn that are born of your herd [<i>bivkarekha</i>] and of your flock [<i>tzonekha</i>]</b> that are male you shall sanctify to the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 15:19). Once again it might have been inferred from the singular pronoun in the terms “your herd” and “your flock” that <b>your</b> firstborn, <b>yes,</b> are sanctified, but the firstborn <b>that is</b> owned <b>in partnership</b> is <b>not</b> sanctified.
Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes:</b> “And there you shall bring there your burnt offerings, and your peace offerings, and your tithes, and the gift of your hand, and your vows, and your gift offerings, <b>and the firstborn of your herd [<i>bekarkhem</i>] and of your flock [<i>tzonekhem</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:6). The pronouns in the terms “your herd” and “your flock” in this verse are in the plural, which indicates that firstborn animals owned in partnership are sanctified. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the terms <b>“your herd” and “your flock”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:19), where the pronouns are in the singular? The Gemara again answers: This serves <b>to exclude</b> animals owned in <b>partnership</b> with <b>a gentile,</b> which are not sanctified.
Likewise, with regard to <b>a <i>mezuza</i>,</b> Rabbi Ilai concedes that the house of two partners is obligated, <b>even though it is written:</b> “And you shall write them upon the doorposts of <b>your house [<i>beitekha</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 6:9), with a singular pronoun, from which one might have inferred that with regard to <b>your</b> house, <b>yes,</b> it is obligated, whereas a house owned by two people <b>in partnership</b> is <b>not</b> obligated. Consequently, <b>the Merciful One writes</b> with regard to the mitzva of <i>mezuza</i>: <b>“So that your days may be multiplied, and the days of your children”</b> (Deuteronomy 11:21). The use of the plural pronoun in the terms “your days” and “your children” in this verse indicates that partners are obligated in the mitzva of <i>mezuza</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>for what</b> purpose does the term <b>“your house [<i>beitekha</i>]” come?</b> The Gemara answers: It is necessary <b>for that which Rabba</b> derived, <b>as Rabba said:</b>

Daf 136a

The term “your house [<i>beitekha</i>]” is similar to the term: You enter [<i>bi’atkha</i>], indicating that one places the <i>mezuza</i> in the <b>way</b> that <b>you enter</b> the house. When a person lifts his foot to begin walking, he lifts his right foot first. Therefore, the <i>mezuza</i> is affixed <b>to the right</b> side of the doorway, as one enters.
Similarly, with regard to <b>tithe,</b> Rabbi Ilai concedes that joint owners of produce are obligated, <b>even though it is written: “The tithe of your grain [<i>deganekha</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:17), using the singular pronoun, from which one might have inferred that with regard to <b>your</b> grain, <b>yes,</b> one is obligated, whereas with regard to that <b>which is</b> owned <b>in partnership,</b> one is <b>not</b> obligated. The reason is that <b>the Merciful One writes:</b> “All <b>your tithes [<i>ma’asroteikhem</i>]”</b> (Numbers 18:28), using the plural pronoun, indicating that even partners are obligated in this mitzva. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>for what</b> purpose does the term: <b>“The tithe of your grain [<i>deganekha</i>],”</b> using the singular pronoun, <b>come?</b> The Gemara answers: It serves <b>to exclude</b> produce owned in <b>partnership with a gentile</b> from the obligation of tithes.
Likewise, with regard to the <b>gifts</b> to which members of the priesthood are entitled, i.e., the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw, Rabbi Ilai concedes that the joint owners of an animal are obligated, <b>even though the Merciful One writes:</b> “And this shall be the priests’ due from the people, from those who slaughter an animal, whether it be ox or sheep; <b>and he shall give</b> to the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3).
The Gemara elaborates: <b>It is possible to say</b> that one should <b>derive</b> a verbal analogy between <b>giving</b> mentioned in the context of gifts to the priesthood and <b>giving from the first sheared wool.</b> The Torah states: “He shall give,” with regard to the gifts of the priesthood, and it states: “Shall you give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4), with regard to the first sheared wool; <b>just as there,</b> with regard to the first sheared wool, sheep owned <b>in partnership</b> do <b>not</b> render their owners obligated, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the gifts of the priesthood, an animal owned <b>in partnership</b> does <b>not</b> render the owners obligated. But <b>the Merciful One writes: “From those who slaughter an animal,”</b> in the plural, indicating that even the owners of an animal owned in partnership are obligated to give the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> according to this inference, <b>the reason</b> the joint owners of an animal are obligated in the gifts of the priesthood is <b>that the Merciful One writes: “From those who slaughter an animal,”</b> in the plural. <b>But</b> were it <b>not so, I would say</b> that they are exempt, as <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy <b>from the first sheared wool. On the contrary,</b> since the term “shall you give him” is also referring to <i>teruma</i>, one should <b>derive</b> by means of a verbal analogy <b>from <i>teruma</i>:</b> Just as the obligation of <i>teruma</i> applies to those who own produce in partnership, so too, the requirement of the gifts of the priesthood applies to partners that own an animal together.
The Gemara explains: <b>Yes,</b> it <b>is indeed so;</b> the obligation of partners with regard to gifts of the priesthood is derived from <i>teruma</i>. But if so, <b>why do I</b> need the phrase <b>“from those who slaughter an animal”?</b> It is necessary <b>for that which Rava</b> taught, <b>as Rava said:</b> The priest issues his <b>demand</b> to receive the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw <b>from the butcher</b> who slaughtered the animal, not from the buyer.
Similarly, with regard to the <b>first fruits,</b> Rabbi Ilai concedes that the joint owners of produce are obligated, <b>even though it is written:</b> “And you shall take of the first of all the fruit of the ground, which you shall bring in from <b>your land [<i>be’artzekha</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 26:2), using the singular pronoun. One might have inferred from the singular pronoun that with regard to <b>your</b> land, <b>yes,</b> one is obligated, whereas with regard to <b>that which is</b> owned <b>in partnership</b> one is <b>not</b> obligated.
Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “The first fruits of all that is in their land,</b> which they bring to the Lord, shall be yours” (Numbers 18:13). The use of the plural pronoun indicates that even from land owned in partnership one is obligated to bring first fruits. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the term <b>“your land [<i>be’artzekha</i>],”</b> using the singular pronoun? The Gemara answers: This serves <b>to exclude</b> produce grown <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael from the mitzva of the first fruits.
Likewise, with regard to the mitzva to attach <b>ritual fringes</b> to one’s garment, Rabbi Ilai concedes that a jointly owned garment is obligated, <b>even though the Merciful One writes:</b> “You shall make yourself twisted cords upon the four corners of <b>your covering [<i>kesutekha</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:12), using the singular pronoun. It might have been inferred from the singular form that with regard to <b>your</b> covering, <b>yes,</b> it is obligated, whereas with regard to <b>that which is</b> owned <b>in partnership</b> it is <b>not</b> obligated.
Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes:</b> “And they shall make for themselves fringes <b>in the corners of their garments, throughout their generations,</b> and they shall put with the fringe of each corner a thread of blue” (Numbers 15:38). The use of the plural pronoun indicates that even jointly owned garments are obligated. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the term <b>“your covering [<i>kesutekha</i>],”</b> using the singular pronoun? The Gemara answers: This is necessary <b>for that which Rav Yehuda</b> taught, <b>as Rav Yehuda said: A borrowed cloak is exempt from the</b> mitzva of <b>ritual fringes throughout</b> the first <b>thirty days.</b>
Similarly, with regard to the obligation of establishing <b>a parapet</b> around a roof, Rabbi Ilai concedes that the joint owners of a roof are obligated, <b>even though the Merciful One writes:</b> “When you build a new house, then you shall make a parapet <b>for your roof [<i>legaggekha</i>],”</b> using the singular pronoun, “and you shall not bring blood upon your house, if any man falls from there” (Deuteronomy 22:8). One might have inferred from the singular form that with regard to <b>your</b> roof, <b>yes,</b> one is obligated, whereas with regard to <b>that which is</b> owned <b>in partnership</b> one is <b>not</b> obligated.
Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “If any man falls from there,”</b> indicating that wherever the danger of falling from the roof exists, there is an obligation to erect a parapet. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>for what</b> purpose does the term <b>“your roof [<i>gaggekha</i>],”</b> using the singular pronoun, <b>come?</b> The Gemara answers: It serves <b>to exclude synagogues and houses of study.</b>
§ Rava maintains that although Rabbi Ilai holds that if a sheep is owned in partnership its owners are exempt from giving the first sheared wool to a priest, he concedes that partners are obligated with regard to all the other issues discussed above, including the mitzva of the firstborn animal and the gifts of the priesthood. <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: These principles</b> stated by Rava <b>are not</b> accepted, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An animal</b> owned by <b>partners is obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>a firstborn,</b> i.e., its offspring is subject to firstborn status. <b>And Rabbi Ilai exempts</b> the animal from having its offspring subject to firstborn status.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ilai? As it is written:</b> “And the firstborn of <b>your herd and of your flock [<i>bekarekha vetzonekha</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:17), using the singular pronoun, indicating that only privately owned animals are consecrated. The Gemara comments: <b>But it is</b> also <b>written:</b> “And the firstborn of <b>your herd and of your flock [<i>bekarkhem vetzonekhem</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:6), using the plural pronoun. The Gemara explains: This verse is referring to the obligation <b>of all Jews</b> to bring their firstborn animals to the Temple, but this applies only to animals with a single owner.
