<b>Rav Ḥanina of Sura</b> also <b>said: These principles</b> stated by Rava <b>are not</b> accepted, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An animal</b> owned by <b>partners is obligated,</b> i.e., renders its owners obligated, <b>to</b> take <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood from it, <b>and Rabbi Ilai exempts</b> the partners from the obligation. <b>What is the reason</b> for Rabbi Ilai’s statement? He <b>derives</b> a verbal analogy between <b>giving</b> mentioned in this context <b>and giving from the first sheared wool.</b> The Torah states: “He shall give” (Deuteronomy 18:3), with regard to the gifts of the priesthood, and: “Shall you give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4), with regard to the first sheared wool. <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the first sheared wool, in the case of sheep owned <b>in partnership</b> the owners are <b>not</b> obligated according to Rabbi Ilai, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the gifts of the priesthood, if the animal is owned <b>in partnership</b> the owners are <b>not</b> obligated.
Rabbi Ḥanina of Sura adds: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> to accept Rava’s statement that in the case <b>of <i>teruma</i></b> Rabbi Ilai <b>deems</b> partners <b>obligated,</b> this is not possible. The reason is that the term “shall you give him” is also used with regard to <i>teruma</i>. Accordingly, instead of deriving the <i>halakha</i> of an animal owned by partners with regard to gifts of the priesthood by verbal analogy from the first sheared wool, one should <b>derive</b> by verbal analogy between <b>giving</b> mentioned with regard to gifts of the priesthood and <b>giving from <i>teruma</i>,</b> as follows: Just as joint owners of produce are obligated to separate <i>teruma</i> from that produce, so too with regard to an animal owned in partnership, the owners are obligated to take the gifts of the priesthood from it. <b>Rather, conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that <b>with regard to <i>teruma</i> too,</b> Rabbi Ilai <b>deems</b> partners <b>exempt,</b> and therefore their exemption from the gifts of the priesthood can be derived either from the first sheared wool or from <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If</b> it is possible to derive <i>halakhot</i> of the gifts of the priesthood from <i>teruma</i> by verbal analogy, one could also say: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>yes,</b> it applies, whereas <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael it does <b>not</b> apply, <b>so too,</b> with regard to the <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood, <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>yes,</b> they apply, whereas <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael they do <b>not</b> apply. <b>Rabbi Yosei of Neharbil said: Yes,</b> it is indeed so, <b>and it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ilai says:</b> The <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood <b>apply only in Eretz</b> Yisrael. <b>And likewise, Rabbi Ilai would say:</b> The mitzva of <b>the first sheared wool applies only in Eretz</b> Yisrael.
<b>What is the reason for</b> the ruling of <b>Rabbi Ilai? Rava said:</b> He <b>derives</b> by means of a verbal analogy between <b>giving</b> mentioned in the context of the first sheared wool and <b>giving from <i>teruma</i></b> that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>yes,</b> it applies, whereas <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, it does <b>not</b> apply; <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>the first sheared wool, in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>yes,</b> it applies, whereas <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael it does <b>not</b> apply.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>If</b> one compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i> by means of a verbal analogy, one can say that <b>just as</b> with regard to the requirement to separate <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> it <b>produces</b> the halakhic status of forbidden <b>untithed produce, so too</b> the requirement to separate <b>the first sheared wool produces</b> the halakhic status of <b>untithed produce,</b> i.e., wool from which the first sheared wool has not been separated should be forbidden. Yet this is not the <i>halakha</i>. Rava <b>said to him</b> that the <b>verse states: “And the first sheared wool of your flock, shall you give him,”</b> i.e., the priest, which indicates that <b>you,</b> i.e., the priest, have a right <b>to</b> the first sheared wool <b>only from its</b> designation as <b>the first sheared wool and onward.</b> Since the first sheared wool does not belong to the priest prior to its designation, it does not render the rest of the wool forbidden.
Abaye continues to question Rava: <b>If</b> one compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i> by means of a verbal analogy, one can say that <b>just as</b> non-priests who partake of <b><i>teruma</i></b> intentionally are <b>liable</b> to receive the punishment of <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven, <b>and</b> those who do so unwittingly are obligated to pay an additional <b>one-fifth</b> of its value, <b>so too,</b> non-priests who derive benefit from <b>the first sheared wool</b> intentionally should be <b>liable</b> to <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven, <b>and</b> those who do so unwittingly should be obligated to pay an additional <b>one-fifth</b> of its value.
Rava replies: The <b>verse states</b> with regard to a non-priest who partakes of <i>teruma</i>: “Lest they bear sin for it, <b>and die because of it,</b> if they profane it…and if a man eat of the holy thing through error, <b>and he shall add</b> its fifth part <b>to it,</b> and shall give to the priest the holy thing” (Leviticus 22:9–14). Rava infers: “He shall add its fifth part <b>to it,” and not to the first sheared wool. “And die because of it,” and not because of the first sheared wool.</b> Consequently, a non-priest is liable to death at the hand of Heaven or to pay an additional one-fifth for partaking of <i>teruma</i>, but not for deriving benefit from the first sheared wool.
Abaye further questions Rava: <b>If</b> one compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i> by verbal analogy, one can say that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> the <b>first and second</b> tithes are separated from the produce <b>after</b> <i>teruma</i> is separated, <b>so too</b> with regard to the <b>first sheared wool, first and second</b> tithes should be separated from the fleece <b>after it.</b> Rava replies: The <b>verse states</b> that the first sheared wool is <b>“the first.”</b> Since the verse already stated “first” with regard to <i>teruma</i>, its repetition indicates that in this case there is no second separation. One <b>does not have</b> any separation <b>in this</b> case <b>other than the first</b> one.
Abaye continues to question Rava: <b>If</b> one compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i> by means of a verbal analogy, one can say that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> one may <b>not</b> separate <b>from</b> the <b>new</b> produce of this year <b>on</b> behalf of <b>the old</b> produce from last year, <b>so too,</b> one may <b>not</b> separate <b>the first sheared wool from</b> the <b>new</b> shearing of this year <b>on</b> behalf of <b>the old</b> shearing from last year. On this occasion Rava replied: <b>Yes,</b> that is the <i>halakha</i>.
Rava proves his point: <b>And it is</b> likewise <b>taught</b> that this is Rabbi Ilai’s opinion, through a contradiction between two <i>baraitot</i>. One <i>baraita</i> teaches: A person <b>had two sheep;</b> he <b>sheared</b> them <b>and left</b> the shearing in his possession, and the following year he again <b>sheared</b> them <b>and left</b> the shearing in his possession, and continued in this manner for <b>two or three years.</b> Although the accumulated wool is equivalent to the wool of five sheep, to which the obligation of the first sheared wool applies, the wool <b>does not accumulate</b> to constitute the minimum amount, as only two sheep were shorn. This indicates that if the wool is from <b>five</b> sheep, then it <b>accumulates,</b> and one is obligated to give the priest the first sheared wool, despite the fact that the wool was shorn in different years.
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that even wool from five sheep shorn in different years <b>does not accumulate</b> to create an obligation? <b>Rather, conclude from</b> this contradiction that <b>this</b> second <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ilai,</b> who compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, he holds that wool from separate years does not accumulate. <b>And that</b> first <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who do not compare the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, they maintain that wool from separate years does accumulate.
Abaye asks Rava: <b>If</b> one compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i>, one can say that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> if a Jew purchased a field from a gentile then produce that <b>grew under</b> the ownership of a Jew, who is <b>obligated</b> to separate <i>teruma</i> from his produce, is <b>obligated,</b> whereas produce that <b>grew under</b> the ownership of a gentile, whose produce is <b>exempt,</b> is <b>exempt</b> even after purchase by a Jew; <b>so too,</b> with regard to the <b>first sheared wool,</b> the fleece that <b>grew under</b> the ownership of a Jew, who is <b>obligated</b> in the first sheared wool, is <b>obligated,</b> whereas the fleece that grew <b>under</b> the ownership of a gentile, who is <b>exempt,</b> is <b>exempt</b> even after purchase by a Jew.
Abaye adds: <b>And with regard to <i>teruma</i>, from where do we</b> derive that produce that grew when owned by a gentile is exempt? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a Jew who purchased a field in Syria from a gentile,</b> if he bought the field <b>before</b> the produce <b>reached one-third</b> of its growth, he is <b>obligated</b> to separate <i>teruma</i>. If he bought the field <b>after</b> the produce <b>reached one-third</b> of its growth, <b>Rabbi Akiva deems him obligated</b> to separate <i>teruma</i> <b>from the</b> growth <b>added</b> after he bought the field, <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt.</b> All agree, though, that he is exempt with regard to the part of the produce that grew under the gentile’s ownership.
<b>And if you would say: Indeed,</b> Rabbi Ilai holds that wool that grew under the ownership of a gentile is exempt from the mitzva of the first sheared wool, that is difficult, as <b>didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna (135a): <b>One who purchases the fleece of</b> the <b>sheep of a gentile</b> is <b>exempt from</b> the obligation of the <b>first sheared wool?</b> It can be inferred from the mishna that if one purchased the gentile’s <b>sheep</b> when they were ready <b>for shearing,</b> he is <b>obligated</b> in the mitzva of the first sheared wool. Rava replied: <b>The mishna</b>

Daf 136b

<b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ilai,</b> who holds that if the wool grew under the ownership of a gentile one is exempt from separating the first sheared wool.
Abaye further asks Rava: <b>If</b> one compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i>, can one say that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> one may <b>not</b> separate <i>teruma</i> <b>from</b> one <b>type</b> of produce <b>on</b> behalf of that <b>which is not</b> of the same <b>type, so too,</b> one may <b>not</b> separate <b>the first sheared wool from</b> one <b>type</b> of sheep <b>on</b> behalf of sheep <b>which are not</b> of the same <b>type?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And with regard to <i>teruma</i>, from where do we</b> derive that one may not do so? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one had two types of figs, black</b> figs <b>and white</b> figs; <b>or similarly,</b> if one had <b>two types of wheat,</b> one may <b>not separate <i>teruma</i> and tithes from this</b> type <b>on</b> behalf of <b>that</b> type. <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says in the name of Rabbi Ilai: Beit Shammai say</b> that one may <b>not separate <i>teruma</i></b> from one of these on behalf of the other, <b>and Beit Hillel say</b> that one may <b>separate <i>teruma</i></b> from one on behalf of the other, as they consider all forms of figs or wheat to be a single type. But all agree that with regard to two distinct types of food one may not separate <i>teruma</i> from one type on behalf of another type. <b>So too,</b> with regard to <b>the first sheared wool,</b> perhaps one may <b>not</b> separate <b>from</b> one <b>type</b> of sheep <b>on</b> behalf of sheep <b>which are not</b> of the same <b>type.</b>
Rava replied: <b>Yes,</b> this is the <i>halakha</i>. <b>And we learned</b> in the mishna (135a) that one may not separate the first sheared wool from one type of sheep on behalf of another: If the seller <b>had two types</b> of sheep, <b>gray and white,</b> and he <b>sold him</b> the <b>gray</b> fleece <b>but not</b> the <b>white</b> fleece, then <b>this</b> seller <b>gives</b> the first sheared wool <b>for himself</b> from the wool that he kept, <b>and that</b> buyer <b>gives</b> the first sheared wool <b>for himself</b> from the wool that he bought.
The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so,</b> then consider <b>the latter clause, which teaches:</b> If he sold the fleece of the <b>male</b> sheep <b>but not</b> of the <b>female</b> sheep, then <b>this</b> seller <b>gives</b> the first sheared wool <b>for himself</b> from the wool that he kept, <b>and that</b> buyer <b>gives</b> the first sheared wool <b>for himself</b> from the wool that he bought. Is this <b>also due to</b> the fact that <b>they are two</b> different <b>types?</b> Clearly, it is not.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rather,</b> the mishna <b>teaches us good advice.</b> The seller is obligated to give the first sheared wool even on behalf of the wool he sold. Since the fleece of the female sheep is softer and more valuable, it is profitable for the seller to buy back part of the fleece of the male sheep and separate it as the first sheared wool on behalf of the sheep he sold, so <b>that he gives</b> the priest both <b>from this</b> wool <b>that is soft and from that</b> wool <b>that is hard,</b> rather than giving him from the fleece of his female sheep on behalf of the male sheep. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to the gray and white sheep, the mishna <b>teaches us good advice,</b> that it is profitable for the seller to buy back part of the fleece of the gray sheep, so <b>that he gives</b> the priests <b>from both</b> types of wool, rather than giving the first sheared wool entirely from the more valuable white fleece.
According to the above explanation, the mishna rules that it is permitted to separate the first sheared wool from one type of sheep on behalf of another type. This is difficult according to the opinion of Rabbi Ilai, who compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i>, where this practice is prohibited. The Gemara answers: <b>We</b> already <b>established that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ilai.</b>
The Gemara challenges further: <b>If</b> one compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i> by means of a verbal analogy, one can say that <b>just as</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i> we require</b> it to be <b>a first</b> gift <b>whose remainders are evident,</b> i.e., a part of the produce must remain after one has separated <i>teruma</i>, <b>so too, the first sheared wool</b> must be a gift <b>whose remainders are evident.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Yes,</b> it is indeed so.
The Gemara cites a proof for this claim. <b>And we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥalla</i> 1:9): With regard to <b>one who says: All my granary</b> shall be <b><i>teruma</i>, or: All my dough</b> shall be <b><i>ḥalla</i>,</b> he <b>has not said anything. But</b> one can infer from the mishna that if he said: <b>All my shearing</b> shall be designated as <b>first</b> sheared wool, <b>his declaration is valid. And</b> yet it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> tannaitic source, a <i>baraita</i>, that if he said: All my shearing shall be designated as first sheared wool, he <b>did not say anything.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> must one <b>not conclude from</b> the conflicting rulings that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ilai,</b> who compares the first sheared wool to <i>teruma</i>, <b>and that</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who do not compare the two cases? The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from</b> here that this is correct.
§ <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Nowadays the universally</b> accepted <b>practice is in accordance with</b> the lenient rulings of <b>these three elders:</b> It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ilai with regard to the first sheared wool, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ilai says:</b> The mitzva of <b>the first sheared wool applies only in Eretz</b> Yisrael.
<b>And</b> the accepted practice is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira with regard to matters of Torah, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: Matters of Torah are not susceptible to ritual impurity.</b> Therefore, it is permitted for one who experienced a seminal emission to engage in Torah study even without first immersing in a ritual bath.
<b>And</b> lastly, the accepted practice is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoshiya with regard to diverse kinds, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yoshiya says: One</b> who sows diverse kinds <b>is never liable</b> by Torah law <b>until he sows wheat and barley and</b> a grape <b>pit with a single hand motion,</b> i.e., by sowing in the vineyard he violates the prohibitions of diverse kinds that apply to seeds and to the vineyard simultaneously.
§ The mishna states: There are more <b>stringent</b> elements <b>in</b> the mitzva of <b>the foreleg,</b> the jaw, and the maw than in the mitzva of the first sheared wool. The mishna then proceeds to list a number of these stringent elements. The Gemara objects: <b>But let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> that there is a more <b>stringent</b> element <b>in</b> the mitzva of <b>the first sheared wool, as</b> it <b>is in effect with regard to animals with a wound that will cause them to die within twelve months [<i>tereifot</i>],</b> but that <b>is not so with regard to the gifts</b> of the priesthood, i.e., the foreleg, the jaw, and the maw, which are not given to the priest from a <i>tereifa</i>. This is because the Torah states: “He shall give to the priest the foreleg, and the jaw, and the maw” (Deuteronomy 18:3), whereas in the case of a <i>tereifa</i> the gifts are effectively not given to the priest himself but to his dog, as it is prohibited for the priest to eat them.
<b>Ravina said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon deems <i>tereifot</i> exempt from</b> the mitzva of <b>the first sheared wool. What is the reason for</b> the ruling of <b>Rabbi Shimon?</b> The reason is that he <b>derives</b> a verbal analogy between the term <b>giving</b> mentioned with regard to the first sheared wool and <b>giving from the gifts</b> of the priesthood. The Torah states: “Shall you give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4), with regard to the first sheared wool, and it states: “He shall give,” with regard to the gifts of the priesthood. <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood, one is <b>not</b> obligated to give them from <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> animal, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>the first sheared wool,</b> one is <b>not</b> obligated to give them from <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>derives</b> a verbal analogy between <b>giving</b> mentioned with regard to the first sheared wool and <b>giving from the gifts</b> of the priesthood, let him also <b>derive</b> a verbal analogy between <b>giving</b> mentioned with regard to the first sheared wool and <b>giving from <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Torah states: “The first fruits of your grain, of your wine, and of your oil, and the first sheared wool of your flock shall you give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4). <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> produce grown <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>yes,</b> it is obligated, whereas produce grown <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael is <b>not</b> obligated, <b>so too</b> with regard to the mitzva of <b>the first sheared wool: In Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>yes,</b> it applies, whereas <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael it does <b>not</b> apply. <b>Why,</b> then, <b>did we learn</b> in the mishna that the mitzva of <b>the first sheared wool applies</b> both <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Rather, this is</b> the <b>reason for</b> the ruling of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as he derives</b> a verbal analogy between the term <b>“flock [<i>tzon</i>]”</b> mentioned with regard to the first sheared wool and the term <b>“flock [<i>tzon</i>]” from</b> the animal <b>tithe.</b> With regard to the first sheared wool, the verse states: “And the first sheared wool of your flock [<i>tzonekha</i>], shall you give him” (Deuteronomy 18:4), and with regard to the animal tithe it states: “And all the tithe of the herd or the flock [<i>tzon</i>], whichever passes under the rod, the tenth shall be holy unto the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32). <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>tithe,</b> one is <b>not</b> obligated in the case of an animal that is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, so too,</b> with regard to <b>the first sheared wool,</b> one is <b>not</b> obligated in the case of <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And there,</b> with regard to the animal tithe, <b>from where do we</b> derive that it does not apply to a <i>tereifa</i>? The Gemara answers <b>that it is written: “Whichever passes under the rod,”</b> which <b>excludes a <i>tereifa</i>, which is not</b> able to <b>pass</b> under the rod due to its physical state. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But let</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>derive</b> a verbal analogy between the term <b>“flock [<i>tzon</i>]”</b> mentioned in this context and the term <b>“flock [<i>tzon</i>]” from</b> the mitzva to consecrate the male <b>firstborn</b> animal. In that context, the Torah states: “All the firstborn males that are born of your herd and of your flock [<i>tzonekha</i>] you shall sanctify to the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 15:19). <b>Just as</b> with regard to the consecration of the <b>firstborn even a <i>tereifa</i></b> is consecrated, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>the first sheared wool</b> the obligation applies <b>even</b> in the case of <b>a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara answers: It <b>is reasonable</b> that Rabbi Shimon <b>should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the first sheared wool <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of animal <b>tithe</b> rather than from the mitzva of the firstborn, <b>as</b> there are many <i>halakhot</i> that are common to both the first sheared wool and the animal tithe. The Gemara enumerates these <i>halakhot</i>: First, the first sheared wool and the animal tithe apply to both <b>male</b> and female animals, while the mitzva of the firstborn applies only to males. Furthermore, the first sheared wool and the animal tithe do not apply to <b>non-kosher</b> animals, whereas the sanctity of the firstborn also applies to donkeys, which are not kosher.
In addition, these two mitzvot both apply only in a case <b>of numerous</b> animals: The first sheared wool applies only if one shears no fewer than five sheep, and one must own at least ten animals to set aside the animal tithe, whereas the sanctity of the firstborn applies to a single animal. Another common feature is that unlike the firstborn, the first sheared wool and the animal tithe are not sanctified <b>from the womb,</b> but only once they are designated.
Moreover, both the first sheared wool and the animal tithe apply only to animals, whereas the sanctity of the firstborn also applies to a firstborn son in the case of <b>a man.</b> Likewise, these two mitzvot apply not only to firstborn animals but also to <b>ordinary</b> non-firstborn animals, unlike the sanctity of the firstborn. Finally, the first sheared wool and the animal tithe did not apply <b>before the</b> divine <b>word</b> was issued at the giving of the Torah at Mount Sinai, whereas the sanctity of the firstborn already applied while the Jews were still in Egypt.
The Gemara responds: <b>On the contrary,</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the first sheared wool <b>from</b> the sanctity of the <b>firstborn</b> rather than from the animal tithe, <b>as</b> there are many <i>halakhot</i> common to the first sheared wool and the firstborn animal. The Gemara again enumerates the <i>halakhot</i> in common: Both apply to <b>an orphan</b> animal, i.e., one whose mother died before its birth, whereas the animal tithe does not apply to an animal of this kind. Furthermore, both mitzvot are in effect in the case of an animal <b>that one purchased,</b> whereas the animal tithe does not apply to a purchased animal.
In addition, both the mitzva of the first sheared wool and the mitzva of the firstborn animal apply to an animal owned <b>in partnership,</b> unlike the animal tithe. Both apply as well to an animal that one <b>gave</b> another as a gift, whereas the animal tithe does not apply in the case of a gift. Likewise, both apply even when not <b>in the presence of</b> the Temple, whereas the animal tithe is in effect only when the Temple is standing. Moreover, both the first sheared wool and the firstborn are given to <b>a priest,</b> whereas the animal tithe is eaten by the owner.

Daf 137a

The Gemara further states that the matter <b>of consecration</b> applies neither to the mitzva of the first sheared wool nor to the firstborn animal. The firstborn is consecrated from the womb, while the first sheared wool is non-sacred. By contrast, the animal tithe is consecrated by the owner when passed under the rod. <b>And</b> finally, the option of <b>sale</b> by the priest applies to the first sheared wool and the firstborn animal after the priest receives them, whereas the animal tithe may not be sold. The Gemara adds: <b>And these</b> <i>halakhot</i> common to the first sheared wool and the firstborn are <b>more numerous</b> than the <i>halakhot</i> shared by the first sheared wool and the animal tithe. Therefore, Rabbi Shimon should derive the verbal analogy between the first sheared wool and the firstborn.
The Gemara answers: Even so, Rabbi Shimon <b>prefers</b> to derive the <i>halakhot</i> of the first sheared wool, which apply to <b>an ordinary</b> non-firstborn animal, <b>from</b> those of animal tithe, which also apply to <b>an ordinary</b> animal. Rabbi Shimon maintains that the shared factor that the first sheared wool and the animal tithe apply to all animals, not only the first to emerge from the womb, is decisive and overrides the other shared <i>halakhot</i>.
§ The mishna states: <b>The first sheared wool is in effect only with regard to sheep.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> It is <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between <b>shearing</b> mentioned in this context and <b>shearing</b> mentioned elsewhere. It is <b>written here: “The first sheared wool of your flock [<i>tzonekha</i>], shall you give him”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:4), <b>and</b> it is <b>written there</b> that Job says concerning the needy: <b>“And he was warmed with the shearing of my sheep [<i>kevasai</i>]”</b> (Job 31:20). <b>Just as there,</b> the verse is referring specifically to the shearing of <b>sheep,</b> as the term <i>keves</i> is used only with regard to a sheep, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the first sheared wool, the verse is referring to <b>sheep,</b> despite the fact that the term <i>tzon</i> can be interpreted as referring also to goats.
The Gemara objects: <b>But derive</b> instead a verbal analogy concerning <b>shearing</b> mentioned in this context <b>from shearing</b> mentioned in the case of the <b>firstborn</b> animal: Just as the prohibition against shearing the firstborn also applies to a firstborn ox, so too, the <i>halakhot</i> of the first sheared wool should also apply to oxen. It is prohibited to shear a firstborn ox, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“You shall do no work with the firstborn of your ox, and you shall not shear the firstborn of your flock”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:19). From a straightforward reading of the verse, <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that a firstborn <b>ox</b> may not be used <b>for labor and</b> that a firstborn of an animal from the <b>flock</b> may not be used <b>for shearing.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to apply</b> the prohibition <b>that was stated about that</b> animal <b>to this</b> one, <b>and</b> the prohibition <b>that was stated about this</b> animal <b>to that</b> one? <b>The verse states: “You shall do no work…and you shall not shear.”</b> The conjunction “and” indicates that the two parts of the verse apply to both animals.
The Gemara explains: One cannot say that oxen are subject to the mitzva of first sheared wool, as the <b>verse states</b> with regard to this mitzva: <b>“Shall you give him,”</b> which indicates that the shearing is given to the priest himself, i.e., for him to wear, <b>and not for</b> use as <b>his sack.</b> The shearing of oxen is fit for use only as sackcloth, not as clothing.
The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so, let</b> one be obligated in the mitzva of the first sheared wool in the case of <b>goats’ hair,</b> as it too can be used for clothing. The Gemara explains: To be obligated in the first sheared wool <b>we require</b> an act of <b>shearing, and</b> goats’ hair is plucked, <b>not</b> sheared.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who did you hear</b> who accepts <b>this reasoning</b> that only an act of shearing renders one obligated in the mitzva of the first sheared wool? This is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> which the Gemara will soon cite. But <b>Rabbi Yosei concedes</b> that the obligation does exist without the act of shearing <b>in a case where the</b> usual <b>manner of</b> removing the wool is not by shearing. Since goats’ hair is not commonly shorn, the obligation of the first sheared wool should apply.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara provides a different source for the mishna’s statement. The reason that the mitzva of first sheared wool applies only to sheep is <b>as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> It is stated in the verse following the source for the mitzva of first sheared wool: “For the Lord your God has chosen him out of all your tribes, <b>to stand to serve</b> in the name of the Lord, he and his sons forever” (Deuteronomy 18:5). The term “to serve” indicates that the first sheared wool that is given to the priest must consist of <b>a matter fit for</b> the Temple <b>service,</b> i.e., its size must be large enough for use for the priestly garments. <b>Here too,</b> the first sheared wool must be of <b>a matter fit for</b> Temple <b>service,</b> i.e., sheep’s wool, from which the priestly garments are woven.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>for what</b> purpose does the verbal analogy between <b>shearing</b> mentioned with regard to the first sheared wool and <b>shearing</b> mentioned with regard to the flock <b>come?</b> The Gemara answers: It is necessary <b>for that which was taught</b> in <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael. As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> In the case of <b>sheep whose wool is hard,</b> the owner is <b>exempt from the first sheared wool, as it is stated: “And he was warmed with the shearing of my sheep”</b> (Job 31:20). Since hard wool does not provide warmth, the mitzva of the first sheared wool does not apply to this wool.
§ It <b>is taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>shears goats, or washes sheep,</b> which causes some of their wool to be detached, he is <b>exempt</b> from the obligation of first sheared wool with regard to this wool. <b>And</b> it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who shears goats is exempt but</b> one who <b>washes the sheep</b> is <b>obligated</b> to separate the first sheared wool from the wool that was washed off. The Gemara resolves this apparent contradiction: It is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which requires one to separate the first sheared wool from the washed-off wool, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which exempts the washed off wool, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b>
The Gemara cites the source of this dispute. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And when you reap the harvest of your land, you shall not completely remove the corner of your field when you reap, and you shall not gather the gleaning of your harvest; you shall leave them for the poor” (Leviticus 23:22). The phrase <b>“the gleaning of your harvest”</b> indicates that only such a gleaning is included, <b>and not gleaning from picking.</b> If one picks the crop by hand rather than harvesting it using agricultural tools, he is exempt from the mitzva to leave the gleanings for the poor. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Gleanings</b> are <b>only</b> those <b>that come due to harvesting</b> using agricultural tools.
The Gemara expresses puzzlement at this <i>baraita</i>: The opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei is</b> identical to the opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: The <b>entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, and this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching:</b> The phrase “the gleaning of your harvest” teaches that crops picked by hand are exempt from the mitzva, <b>as Rabbi Yosei says: Gleanings</b> are <b>only</b> those <b>that come due to harvesting.</b> The Gemara infers that just as Rabbi Yosei interprets the term “harvest” as exempting crops that were picked by hand, so too he derives from the term “shearing” that the mitzva of the first sheared wool does not apply to fleece that was washed off. The Rabbis, who disagree with Rabbi Yosei with regard to the gleanings, likewise disagree with regard to the first sheared wool.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: Rabbi Yosei concedes</b> that the mitzva of gleanings applies <b>to a case where the</b> usual <b>manner</b> of harvesting is by picking, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse cited above that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> From the term <b>“harvest” I have</b> derived <b>only</b> the obligation of gleanings with regard to <b>harvest. From where</b> do I derive the obligation of gleanings with regard to one who <b>uproots</b> the crop?
<b>The verse states:</b> “And when you reap the harvest of your land, you shall not completely remove the corner of your field by reaping, and you shall not gather the gleaning of your harvest” (Leviticus 19:9). The superfluous term <b>“by reaping”</b> includes uprooting the crop. <b>From where</b> is it derived that the obligation extends to one who <b>picked</b> the crop by hand? <b>The verse states: “When you reap”</b> (Leviticus 23:22), which is also superfluous. It is derived from here that the mitzva applies to all ways of gathering the crop, provided they are the usual manner of harvesting that particular crop.
<b>Ravina said to Ravi Ashi: We learn as well</b> in a mishna (<i>Pe’a</i> 3:4) that discusses the mitzva to leave produce in the corner of the field for the poor [<i>pe’a</i>]: If one has <b>garden beds of onions that are among the vegetables, Rabbi Yosei says</b> that one leaves separate <b><i>pe’a</i> from each and every one</b> of the beds. <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that one leaves <i>pe’a</i> <b>from one</b> garden bed <b>for all</b> of them. This indicates that Rabbi Yosei concedes that one is obligated to leave <i>pe’a</i> and gleanings from onions, despite the fact that they are picked by hand rather than harvested with tools. The reason is that this is the usual manner of gathering onions.
§ The mishna states: <b>And how many is numerous?</b> Beit Shammai say: It is at least two sheep, and Beit Hillel say: It is at least five sheep. The Gemara objects: <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, two</b> sheep are <b>also called <i>tzon</i>,</b> as in the verse cited by Beit Shammai: “That a man shall rear a young cow and two sheep [<i>tzon</i>]” (Isaiah 7:21). Since the mitzva of the first sheared wool is written with regard to <i>tzon</i>, it is logical that it applies to two sheep. <b>But what is the reasoning of Beit Hillel,</b> who hold that the mitzva applies only to five sheep, due to the verse: “And five sheep [<i>tzon</i>] made” (I Samuel 25:18)? Why do they not apply the obligation using the broader criterion of two sheep, as the verse quoted by Beit Shammai clearly indicates that two sheep are also called <i>tzon</i>?
<b>Rav Kahana said:</b> The <b>verse states:</b> “Five sheep <b>made [<i>asuyot</i>],”</b> in plural. The plural form indicates <b>that two mitzvot</b> have been <b>made,</b> i.e., performed, with them. The two mitzvot are <b>the first sheared wool and</b> the <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood, a mitzva that applies to a single animal. If the two mitzvot have been performed only when there are five sheep, evidently the mitzva of the first sheared wool applies only to five sheep. The Gemara asks: Why can’t one <b>say</b> that the two mitzvot are the <b>firstborn</b> animal <b>and</b> the <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood?
The Gemara answers: The other mitzva cannot be the firstborn animal, as with regard to the <b>firstborn, isn’t one</b> animal <b>obligated,</b> i.e., doesn’t one animal render its owner obligated? Yet the verse states that one performs the two mitzvot only with five sheep. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> with regard to the <b>gifts</b> of the priesthood, <b>isn’t one</b> animal <b>obligated,</b> i.e., doesn’t one animal render its owner obligated?<b>Rather, Rav Ashi says:</b> The term <b>“made”</b> should be understood as meaning <b>that</b> five sheep <b>make their owner</b> perform the first sheared wool <b>and</b> figuratively <b>say to him: Stand</b> and <b>fulfill a mitzva,</b> whereas less than five sheep do not obligate their owner in the mitzva of first sheared wool.
It <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei,</b> that he <b>says in the name of his father:</b> The obligation of the first sheared wool applies to one who owns <b>four</b> sheep, since a verse calls four sheep <i>tzon</i>, <b>as it is stated:</b> “If a man steals an ox or a sheep, and kills it or sells it, he shall pay five oxen for the ox, <b>and four sheep [<i>tzon</i>] for a sheep”</b> (Exodus 21:37).
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: Had their statements,</b> i.e., the opinions of Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, been based on <b>statements of the Torah, and the statement of the Distinguished One [<i>Beribbi</i>],</b> Rabbi Yosei, based on the texts of the <b>tradition [<i>kabbala</i>],</b> the Prophets and Writings, even so <b>we</b> would <b>listen</b> to <b>the statement of the Distinguished One,</b> Rabbi Yosei. <b>All the more so</b> now <b>that their statements</b> are based on <b>texts of the tradition,</b> as both Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel derived their rulings from verses from the Prophets, while <b>the statement of the Distinguished One,</b> Rabbi Yosei, is based on <b>the statements of the Torah.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But didn’t the Master say: The decision</b> of <b>a third</b> opinion that compromises between the first two opinions is <b>not</b> considered <b>decisive</b> if it is based on considerations that were not mentioned by the other two opinions. Although Rabbi Yosei’s opinion is a compromise between the opinions of Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, it is based on a different source.

Daf 137b

<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> in response: Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi accepted Rabbi Yosei’s opinion not because it was a compromise, but rather because <b>he said it according to a tradition</b> he had <b>from</b> the prophets <b>Haggai, Zechariah, and Malachi.</b>
§ The mishna states: <b>Rabbi Dosa ben Harkinas says</b> that the mitzva of the first sheared wool applies to five sheep, each of whose shearing weighs one hundred and fifty dinars, whereas the Rabbis say: Five sheep, each of whose shearing is any amount. The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> is signified by the phrase: <b>Any amount? Rav says:</b> It is a total weight of <b>one hundred dinars</b> [<b><i>maneh</i></b>] <b>and half</b> of one hundred dinars [<b><i>peras</i></b>], <b>provided that they are divided</b> equally <b>between the five</b> sheep. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> It is a total weight of <b>sixty</b> <i>sela</i>, of which he <b>gives</b> the weight of <b>one <i>sela</i> to the priest.</b>
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana</b> says that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is a total weight of <b>six</b> <i>sela</i>, of which he gives <b>to the priest</b> the weight of <b>five</b> <i>sela</i>, <b>and</b> he leaves <b>one</b> <i>sela</i> <b>for himself. Ulla</b> says that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: We learned</b> in the mishna that according to the Rabbis the obligation of the first sheared wool applies to <b>any amount,</b> even if the total weight is only one <i>sela</i>.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna (135a): <b>And how much does one give to</b> the priest? One gives him sheared wool of the <b>weight</b> of <b>five <i>sela</i> in Judea, which are</b> the equivalent of <b>ten <i>sela</i> in the Galilee. Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinions of <b>Rav and Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> the mishna <b>works out well,</b> as their statements do not contradict the mishna. Rav does not discuss the amount one is required to give the priest, and Rabbi Yoḥanan states that one gives the priest five <i>sela</i>. <b>But</b> according <b>to Shmuel and Rabbi Elazar,</b> the mishna is <b>difficult,</b> as Shmuel states that one is required to give one <i>sela</i>, while Rabbi Elazar states that the obligation of the first sheared wool applies even for a weight of less than five <i>sela</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>And according to your reasoning, does it work out well</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav? But Rav and Shmuel both say</b> that <b>the first sheared wool</b> given to the priest is one part <b>in sixty.</b> Rav holds that the weight of one hundred and fifty dinars renders one obligated in the first sheared wool, and one-sixtieth of this weight is less than one <i>sela</i>. Therefore, Rav’s opinion is also not in accordance with the mishna.
The Gemara answers: <b>It was stated with regard to that</b> mishna that <b>Rav and Shmuel both say:</b> The five <i>sela</i> stated in the mishna is not referring to the total amount given from the sheared wool. Rather, in the mishna <b>we are dealing with a Jew who has a large</b> amount of <b>shearing, and he wishes to give them to the priest,</b> i.e., to several priests. <b>And we say to him:</b> With regard to <b>each and every one</b> of the priests, do <b>not</b> give <b>him less than five <i>sela</i>.</b> But if one has only a small amount of shearing, he gives the priest one-sixtieth of the shearing, even if it is less than five <i>sela</i>.
§ The Gemara mentioned a ruling of Rav and Shmuel with regard to the amount that one is required to give as the first sheared wool. The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rav and Shmuel both say: The first sheared wool</b> given to the priest is one part <b>of sixty.</b> Likewise, the amount one is required to separate as <b><i>teruma</i></b> is one part <b>of sixty,</b> and the amount one must leave in his field as <b><i>pe’a</i></b> is one part <b>of sixty.</b>
The Gemara asks: Is the amount one is required to separate as <b><i>teruma</i></b> one part <b>of sixty? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 4:3): With regard to the measure one should separate as <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> if one is of <b>generous disposition</b> he gives <b>one-fortieth.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>By Torah law,</b> it is sufficient to give one part <b>of sixty; by rabbinic law</b> the requisite amount is one part <b>of forty.</b>
The Gemara asks: Is the measure of <i>teruma</i> <b>by Torah law</b> one part <b>of sixty? But doesn’t Shmuel say:</b> By Torah law, even <b>one</b> grain of <b>wheat</b> given as <i>teruma</i> <b>exempts the</b> entire <b>pile [<i>keri</i>]</b> of grain? The Gemara answers: <b>By Torah law</b> the measure is <b>as</b> stated <b>by Shmuel,</b> that even one grain of wheat is sufficient. <b>By rabbinic law</b>, <b>with regard to</b> produce that is obligated in <i>teruma</i> <b>by Torah law</b> the measure is <b>one-fortieth,</b> whereas <b>by rabbinic law</b>, <b>with regard to</b> produce obligated in <i>teruma</i> <b>by rabbinic law</b> the measure is one part <b>of sixty.</b>
Rav and Shmuel said above that the amount one is required to leave in his field as <b><i>pe’a</i></b> is one part out <b>of sixty.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Pe’a</i> 1:1): <b>These are</b> the <b>matters,</b> i.e., mitzvot, <b>that have no measure: <i>Pe’a</i>, and the first fruits, and the</b> burnt offering of <b>appearance</b> sacrificed on the pilgrimage Festivals. The Gemara answers: <b>By Torah law,</b> <i>pe’a</i> <b>has no</b> fixed <b>measure; by rabbinic law</b> the measure is one part <b>of sixty.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the statement of Rav and Shmuel <b>teaching us? We</b> already <b>learn</b> in the subsequent mishna (<i>Pe’a</i> 1:2): One should <b>not give for <i>pe’a</i> less than</b> one part <b>of sixty, even though they said</b> that <b>the</b> mitzva of <b><i>pe’a</i> has no measure.</b> The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>there</b> is referring to the obligation to leave <i>pe’a</i> <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael, whereas <b>here,</b> the statement of Rav and Shmuel is referring to the obligation of <i>pe’a</i> <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael.
§ <b>When Isi bar Hini ascended</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan found him teaching</b> the mishna <b>to his son.</b> Isi taught that the obligation of the first sheared wool applies only in the case of <b>sheep [<i>reḥelim</i>],</b> the masculine plural form of <i>raḥel</i>, meaning a sheep. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Isi: You should <b>teach him</b> using the term <b><i>reḥelot</i>,</b> the feminine plural form. Isi <b>said to him</b> in reply: I teach the mishna in accordance with <b>that which is written: “Two hundred <i>reḥelim</i>”</b> (Genesis 32:15). Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Isi: The <b>language</b> of the <b>Torah is distinct</b> and the <b>language</b> of the <b>Sages is distinct,</b> i.e., these are like two separate languages, and the Sages do not always use the same forms that appear in the Bible. In this case, they use <i>reḥelot</i> rather than <i>reḥelim</i>.
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Isi: <b>Who is the head of the yeshiva [<i>reish sidra</i>] in Babylonia?</b> Isi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: It is <b>Abba the tall,</b> i.e., the <i>amora</i> Rav. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Isi: <b>You call him Abba the tall,</b> in such a familiar manner? <b>I remember when I sat seventeen rows behind Rav,</b> who sat <b>before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and fiery sparks emerged from the mouth of Rav to the mouth of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and from the mouth of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>to the mouth of Rav, and I did not know what they said,</b> due to the profundity of their discussion. <b>And</b> yet <b>you call him Abba the tall?</b>
Isi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: With regard to <b>the first sheared wool, to how much</b> fleece does the mitzva apply? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him:</b> The first sheared wool applies <b>to</b> fleece weighing <b>sixty</b> <i>sela</i>. Isi asked: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna (135a) that the first sheared wool applies <b>to any amount</b> of fleece? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him</b> in reply: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if the <i>halakha</i> could be understood by a simple reading of the mishna, <b>what</b> is the difference <b>between my</b> knowledge <b>and yours?</b> In fact, you know only the mishna’s statement, whereas I know the halakhic conclusion in this matter.
§ <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he <b>said:</b> With regard to <b>the first sheared wool, Rav says</b> that the mitzva applies <b>to sixty</b> <i>sela</i>, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan in the name of Rabbi Yannai says</b> that the mitzva applies <b>to six</b> <i>sela</i>. <b>Abaye said to Rav Dimi: You have made one</b> statement <b>work out well for us, but you have made another</b> statement <b>difficult for us.</b>
Abaye elaborates: <b>Granted,</b> you have resolved a contradiction between two statements of Rabbi Yoḥanan. Rabbi Yoḥanan said above that the amount of fleece to which the obligation of the first sheared wool applies is six <i>sela</i>, whereas in his answer to Isi he stated that the amount is sixty <i>sela</i>. According to Rav Dimi, the apparent contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan and</b> the other statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> statement <b>is his</b> and <b>that</b> statement <b>is his teacher’s.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that the obligation applies to sixty <i>sela</i>, whereas his teacher Rabbi Yannai maintains that it applies to six <i>sela</i>.
<b>But</b> the contradiction between one statement <b>of Rav and</b> another statement <b>of Rav</b> poses <b>a difficulty, as Rav said</b> that fleece weighing <b>one hundred dinars [<i>maneh</i>] and half</b> of one hundred dinars [<i>maneh</i>] is obligated in the first sheared wool, whereas Rav Dimi stated that according to Rav the obligation applies to sixty <i>sela</i>, which are 240 dinars. The Gemara answers: The apparent contradiction between the one statement <b>of Rav and</b> the other statement <b>of Rav</b> is <b>also not difficult,</b> as <b>what</b> is the <b><i>maneh</i></b> of <b>which</b> Rav <b>said</b> that a <i>maneh</i> and a half are obligated? Rav was referring not to a <i>maneh</i> of one hundred dinars but to a <i>maneh</i> <b>of forty <i>sela</i>,</b> i.e., 160 dinars, a <i>maneh</i> and a half of <b>which is</b>

Daf 138a

equivalent to the weight <b>of sixty</b> <i>sela</i>, as stated by Rav Dimi. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> does <b>a <i>tanna</i> teach</b> that <b>a <i>maneh</i> is of forty <i>sela</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes; and we learned</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> (<i>Kelim</i>, <i>Bava Metzia</i> 6:2): With regard to <b>a new</b> leather <b>flask</b> that is not yet completely sewn together, <b>even though it can contain pomegranates,</b> nevertheless, because it cannot contain liquids it is considered unfinished and is <b>not susceptible to ritual impurity.</b>
If one <b>sewed</b> the flask together <b>and it tore,</b> the <b>measure</b> of the tear that renders the flask no longer susceptible to impurity is a hole large enough <b>to enable pomegranates to go out,</b> as then it ceases to serve as a vessel. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> The tear must be <b>like</b> the measure of <b>balls of a warp,</b> the weight of each of which is <b>one-quarter of a <i>maneh</i> of forty <i>sela</i>.</b> This <i>tanna</i> explicitly mentions a <i>maneh</i> of forty <i>sela</i>.
§ The mishna states: <b>And how much</b> of the sheared wool <b>does one give to</b> the priest? One gives him the weight of five <i>sela</i> in Judea, which are ten <i>sela</i> in the Galilee, once laundered and not when sullied. The Sages <b>taught:</b> The mishna does <b>not</b> mean <b>that one</b> must <b>launder</b> the wool <b>and</b> then <b>give it to</b> the priest; <b>rather,</b> the meaning is <b>that</b> one must give him enough wool for the <b>priest to launder it and it will amount to five <i>sela</i>.</b>
The mishna states: The measure that must be given to the priest is <b>enough to fashion a small garment</b> from it. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> The <b>verse</b> that follows the mention of the first sheared wool <b>states:</b> “For the Lord your God has chosen him out of all your tribes, <b>to stand to serve</b> in the name of the Lord, he and his sons forever” (Deuteronomy 18:5). The term “to serve” indicates that the first sheared wool given to the priest must be <b>a matter that is fitting for service</b> in the Temple, i.e., an amount of wool sufficient to fashion one of the priestly garments. <b>What is</b> the garment in question? It is the <b>belt,</b> which is made from wool weighing five <i>sela</i>.
The Gemara asks: Is the garment in question necessarily the belt? <b>Say</b> that it is the <b>robe,</b> which is fashioned from a far greater amount of wool. The Gemara answers: This inference is based on the principle that if <b>you grasped a lot you did not grasp</b> anything; if <b>you grasped a little, you grasped</b> something. Since a belt meets the condition of “to serve,” as it is one of the priestly vestments, one cannot say that the obligation is any greater than the amount of wool needed to fashion a belt.
<b>But say</b> that the garment in question is the <b>cap of wool</b> that the High Priest wears, which is smaller than the belt. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A cap of wool was placed on the High Priest’s head, and</b> the <b>frontplate was placed upon it, to fulfill that which is stated</b> with regard to the frontplate: <b>“And you shall put it on a thread of sky blue,</b> and it shall be upon the mitre; upon the forefront of the mitre it shall be” (Exodus 28:37). The term “thread of sky blue” is referring to the cap of sky-blue wool.
The Gemara answers that the <b>verse states:</b> “To stand to serve in the name of the Lord, <b>he and his sons”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:5), which indicates that the verse is referring to <b>a matter,</b> i.e., a garment, <b>that is equal for Aaron and for his sons.</b> The wool given to the priest must be of sufficient size for fashioning a garment worn both by the High Priest and by common priests, whereas the woolen cap is worn only by the High Priest.
The Gemara objects: But the <b>belt is also not equal</b> for all priests. The Gemara elaborates: <b>This works out well according to the one who said</b> that the linen <b>belt of</b> the <b>High Priest</b> worn on Yom Kippur <b>is not</b> the same as <b>the belt of an ordinary priest.</b> According to this opinion, both the belt of common priests and the belt worn by the High Priest during the rest of the year were fashioned from a mixture of wool and linen. This belt is therefore equal for all priests, and it works out <b>well.</b>
<b>But according to the one who said</b> that the linen belt worn by the High Priest on Yom Kippur <b>is</b> the same as the <b>belt of an ordinary priest, what can be said?</b> According to this opinion, the belt fashioned from wool and linen is worn only by the High Priest during the rest of the year. The Gemara answers: Although the belts are different, the <b>term belt in general</b> applies to all priests, whereas no type of cap is worn by common priests.
§ The mishna states: If the owner of the shearing <b>did not manage to give it</b> to the priest until he dyed it, he is exempt from the obligation of giving the first sheared wool. The mishna further teaches that one who purchases the fleece of the sheep of a gentile is exempt from the obligation of the first sheared wool. It <b>was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to one who owned five sheep and he <b>sheared and sold the first</b> sheep before shearing the second, and in this manner sold each sheep after shearing it. When he finished shearing he owned the requisite five fleeces, to which the obligation of the first sheared wool applies, but he no longer owned the sheep. <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> He is <b>obligated</b> in the mitzva of the first sheared wool; and <b>Rabbi Natan bar Hoshaya says:</b> He is <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of the first sheared wool.
The Gemara clarifies the two opinions. <b>Rav Ḥisda says</b> that he is <b>obligated, as</b> he <b>sheared</b> five sheep that he owned at the time of shearing, and therefore the term: “Your flock” (Deuteronomy 18:4), applies to this case. <b>Rabbi Natan bar Hoshaya says</b> that he is <b>exempt,</b> as <b>at the time that the measure</b> of five fleeces <b>is completed, we require</b> the term <b>“your flock”</b> to apply, since the obligation takes effect at that stage, <b>and</b> in this case it does <b>not</b> apply.
The Gemara raises a challenge: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna (135a): <b>One who purchases the fleece of the sheep of a gentile is exempt from</b> the obligation of <b>the first sheared wool,</b> as he purchased only the fleece but not the sheep. One can infer from here that if he purchased the gentile’s <b>sheep</b> themselves in order <b>to shear</b> them and then return them to the gentile, he is <b>obligated,</b> because the sheep belonged to him at the time of shearing. But <b>why</b> is he obligated, according to the opinion of Rabbi Natan bar Hoshaya? <b>Each and every one</b> of the sheep, <b>after</b> the <b>shearing</b> is completed, <b>leaves his possession,</b> and when he has sheared five sheep, the term “your flock” no longer applies to them.
<b>Rav Ḥisda interpreted</b> the mishna <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Natan bar Hoshaya:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the gentile <b>transferred ownership to him</b> for the <b>entire</b> period of <b>thirty days</b> during which the Jew sheared the sheep. Therefore, he retained ownership after he completed shearing, and the term “your flock” does apply to the sheep at the time when the obligation of the first sheared wool took effect.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>one who purchases the fleece of the sheep of another</b> Jew, if the seller kept some of the wool, then he is obligated to give the first sheared wool to the priest. If the seller did not keep any of the wool, the buyer is obligated to give it. The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught that</b> in a case <b>where there is residual</b> wool <b>in</b> the possession of the <b>seller, we follow the seller</b> in determining who is obligated in the mitzva of first sheared wool?
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> who taught the mishna <b>is Rabbi Yehuda, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Pe’a</i> 3:5): With regard to <b>one who sells</b> a few fruit-bearing <b>tree stalks within his field,</b> without selling the field itself, for the buyer to uproot them and plant them in his own field, the buyer <b>gives</b> separate <b><i>pe’a</i> for each and every one</b> of the trees. The field does not combine the trees into a single unit for <i>pe’a</i>, as the land is not owned by the buyer.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: When</b> is it the buyer’s obligation to give <i>pe’a</i>? It is <b>when the owner of the field did not leave</b> any of the trees in his possession. <b>But</b> if <b>the owner of the field left</b> some of the trees in his possession, the owner <b>gives <i>pe’a</i> for all</b> the trees. Just as in the case of <i>pe’a</i>, if the seller left trees for himself then the obligation applies to him, so too, with regard to the first sheared wool, if the seller left some of the wool for himself, the obligation applies to him.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: <b>But wasn’t it</b> you, <b>Master, who said</b> with regard to Rabbi Yehuda’s ruling that the owner gives <i>pe’a</i> for all the trees: <b>This is</b> the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when the owner of the field began to harvest</b> the fruit before he sold the trees, as the obligation to give <i>pe’a</i> had already applied to him. By contrast, with regard to the first sheared wool, the obligation came into effect only after he sold his sheep.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>so too,</b> with regard to the first sheared wool, <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> that the seller gives the first sheared wool applies only <b>if</b> the seller <b>began to shear</b> the sheep before he sold them, that explanation is difficult. The Gemara elaborates: <b>Granted, there,</b> with regard to <i>pe’a</i>, it <b>is written: “And when you reap the harvest of your land”</b> (Leviticus 19:9), which indicates that <b>from the time that he began to harvest he is obligated</b> in the mitzva of <i>pe’a</i> <b>with regard to the entire field. But here,</b> in the case of the first sheared wool, <b>he is not obligated with regard to the entire flock from the time that he began to shear</b> his sheep. Therefore, even if he began shearing before he sold the sheep, the obligation to give the first sheared wool should not apply to the seller.
<b>Rather, Rava said: It is this <i>tanna</i></b> who taught the mishna, <b>as we learned</b> in a different mishna (132a): If one <b>said to</b> a butcher: <b>Sell me the innards of this cow, and there were gifts</b> of the priesthood included <b>in them,</b> i.e., the maw, the purchaser <b>must give them to the priest, and</b> he <b>may not deduct</b> the value of the gifts <b>from the money</b> that he pays the butcher, as it is assumed that the gifts were not included in the sale. If <b>he purchased</b> the innards <b>from</b> the butcher <b>by weight,</b> the buyer <b>must give</b> the gifts <b>to a priest and</b> he <b>may deduct</b> the value of the gifts <b>from the money</b> that he pays the butcher. If the priestly gifts have not yet been separated from the animal, the price by weight includes the price of these gifts. But since the priests had the right to their gifts from the time of the slaughter, the buyer does not need to pay for them and may therefore deduct their value from his payment.

Daf 138b

<b>Evidently, a person does not sell the gifts</b> belonging <b>to</b> the <b>priest,</b> and therefore they are not included in the sale of the innards unless they were sold by weight. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to the first sheared wool, <b>a person does not sell the gifts</b> belonging <b>to</b> the <b>priest. Therefore,</b> if <b>the seller left</b> wool in his possession, the <b>seller is obligated</b> to give the first sheared wool from the remaining wool for that which he sold, <b>as</b> the <b>buyer</b> can <b>say to</b> the seller: The <b>gift of</b> the <b>priest is in your</b> possession, since you did not sell me everything. If the seller did <b>not leave</b> any wool in his possession, <b>the buyer is obligated</b> to give the first sheared wool and he does not deduct its value from the price, <b>as the seller</b> can <b>say to him: I did not sell the gift of</b> the <b>priest to you,</b> i.e., there was no obligation to give the gifts to a priest when I sold the wool to you, and therefore the buyer is required to give the gifts to the priest.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mitzva of <b>sending</b> away the mother bird from <b>the nest applies</b> both <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, and <b>in the presence of the Temple and not in the presence of the Temple.</b> It applies <b>to non-sacred</b> birds, <b>but</b> it does <b>not</b> apply <b>to sacrificial</b> birds. There are more <b>stringent</b> elements <b>in the covering of the blood than in the sending</b> away of the mother bird from <b>the nest, as the covering of the blood applies to undomesticated animals and birds, to</b> animals and birds that are readily <b>available</b> in one’s home, <b>and to</b> animals and birds <b>that are not</b> readily <b>available</b> and are hunted in the wild; <b>and the sending</b> of the mother bird from <b>the nest applies only to birds, and applies only to</b> birds <b>that are not</b> readily <b>available.</b>
<b>What are</b> considered birds <b>that are not</b> readily <b>available?</b> They are any birds, even domesticated, that may fly away at any time, <b>such as geese or chickens that nested in the orchard [<i>pardes</i>]. But if</b> geese or chickens <b>nested in the house, and likewise,</b> with regard to <b>domesticated pigeons [<i>yonei hardisei’ot</i>],</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother bird. With regard to the nest of <b>a non-kosher bird,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother bird. In a case where <b>a non-kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a kosher bird, or a kosher</b> bird <b>is resting upon the eggs of a non-kosher bird,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the bird. With regard to <b>a male pheasant [<i>korei</i>],</b> which is known to sit upon the eggs like the female of its species, <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> one <b>obligated</b> to send it away, <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> one <b>exempt</b> from sending it away.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna contains several phrases related to the mitzva of sending away the mother bird from the nest that also appear in the first mishna of several other chapters of this tractate. With regard to this, <b>Rabbi Avin and Rabbi Meyasha</b> made the following statements. <b>One</b> of them <b>said: Anywhere</b> in this tractate <b>that we learned</b> in a mishna that a particular mitzva applies both <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, it is stated <b>needlessly,</b> as those mitzvot are not related to land, such that there is no need to teach that they apply outside of Eretz Yisrael as well. This is true <b>except for</b> the mitzva of <b>the first shearing</b> of wool, which one must give to a priest. It was necessary to teach that that mitzva applies even outside of Eretz Yisrael, <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ilai, who said: The first shearing is in effect only in Eretz</b> Yisrael.
<b>And</b> the other <b>one said: Anywhere</b> in this tractate <b>that we learned</b> in a mishna that a particular mitzva applies both <b>in the presence of the Temple and not in the presence of the Temple,</b> it is stated <b>needlessly,</b> as these mitzvot are requirements of the object itself, and there is no need to teach that they apply even after the destruction of the Temple. This is true <b>except for</b> the prohibition against slaughtering an animal <b>itself and its offspring</b> on the same day. It was necessary to teach that this mitzva applies even after the destruction of the Temple, because it might <b>enter your mind to say: Since</b> this prohibition <b>is written in</b> a passage in the Torah discussing <b>the matter of sacrificial</b> animals (see Leviticus, chapter 22), <b>at a time when there are sacrificial</b> animals, i.e., when the Temple is standing, <b>we will abide</b> by it, but <b>at a time when there are no sacrificial</b> animals, after the destruction of the Temple, <b>we will not abide</b> by it. Therefore, that mishna <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so.
<b>And both of them said: Anywhere</b> in this tractate <b>that we learned</b> in a mishna that a particular mitzva applies both <b>to non-sacred</b> animals <b>and to sacrificial</b> animals, it is stated <b>necessarily.</b> This is the case <b>except for</b> the mishna discussing the <b>sciatic nerve,</b> as it is <b>obvious</b> that the prohibition applies to sacrificial animals as well. Can it enter one’s mind to say that <b>because it was consecrated, the prohibition of</b> eating <b>the sciatic nerve is abrogated from</b> the animal?
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we establish</b> that the mishna there (89b) is referring <b>to offspring of sacrificial</b> animals? Without the mishna, one might have thought that since the offspring was already prohibited as a sacrificial animal before its sciatic nerve was even formed, the prohibition with regard to the latter does not take effect where the former prohibition already exists. If so, it was in fact necessary to teach this <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>But what is the reason we interpreted</b> that mishna as referring to offspring of sacrificial animals? Is it <b>not due to</b> the fact that the question: <b>Let</b> the mishna <b>not teach</b> that the prohibition applies to both non-sacred and sacrificial animals, is <b>difficult for us?</b> It is in response to this question that Rabbi Avin and Rabbi Meyasha stated that <b>even from the outset,</b> this <b>should not</b> pose a <b>difficulty for you.</b> Rather, <b>since</b> the phrase: Applies to both non-sacred and sacrificial animals, <b>is taught necessarily</b> with regard to the prohibition against slaughtering an animal itself and its offspring, it <b>is also taught needlessly</b> with regard to the prohibition against eating the sciatic nerve, to parallel the formula of the other mishna.
§ The mishna states that the mitzva of sending away the mother bird from the nest applies <b>to non-sacred</b> birds, <b>but not to sacrificial</b> birds. The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> does this mitzva <b>not</b> apply to sacrificial birds? The Gemara responds: <b>As the verse states: “You shall send the mother”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:7). The verse refers only <b>to</b> a bird <b>that you are commanded to send</b> away, i.e., a non-sacred bird; that <b>excludes this</b> sacrificial bird, <b>which you are not commanded to send</b> away, but <b>rather to bring it to the custody of</b> the Temple <b>treasurer.</b>
<b>Ravina says: Therefore,</b> with regard to <b>a kosher bird that killed a person</b> and must now be executed, one <b>is exempt from sending</b> it away. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>as the verse states: “You shall send the mother.”</b> The verse is referring only <b>to</b> a bird <b>that you are commanded to send</b> away, which <b>excludes this</b> bird <b>that you are not commanded to send</b> away, but <b>rather to bring it to court.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case, i.e., how is this bird that killed a person now resting on its eggs? <b>If</b> this is a case <b>where its verdict</b> of execution <b>was issued,</b>

Daf 139a

how could it be free to rest on its eggs? <b>It is subject</b> to being <b>killed</b> and should have been executed. <b>Rather,</b> it must be a case <b>where its verdict was not</b> yet <b>issued, and</b> one is <b>required to bring it to the court to fulfill through it</b> the verse: <b>“And you shall eradicate the evil from your midst”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:6).
§ With regard to the statement of the mishna that sacrificial birds are not included in the mitzva of sending away the mother bird from the nest, the Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances of these sacrificial</b> birds discussed in the mishna? <b>If we say that</b> the mishna is referring to a case where one <b>had a nest in his house and consecrated it, is one obligated</b> to send away even a non-sacred bird in such a case? The verse states: <b>“If a bird’s nest happens</b> before you on the way” (Deuteronomy 22:6), which <b>excludes</b> a nest readily <b>available</b> in one’s home.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> one <b>merely saw a nest</b> that did not belong to him, <b>and he consecrated it. But</b> this, too, is problematic: <b>Is</b> the nest <b>consecrated</b> in such a case? But <b>the Merciful One states: “When a man shall sanctify his house to be holy”</b> (Leviticus 27:14), indicating that <b>just as his house</b> is <b>in his possession</b> when he consecrates it, <b>so too, any</b> item that one wishes to consecrate must be <b>in his possession</b> when consecrating it. If so, one cannot consecrate a nest that does not belong to him.
<b>Rather,</b> say that the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> one <b>lifted</b> the <b>chicks,</b> taking possession of them, <b>and</b> then <b>consecrated them, and then returned them</b> to the nest. But <b>this</b> too cannot be, as <b>even with regard to non-sacred</b> birds one <b>is not obligated</b> to send the mother away in such a case, <b>as is taught</b> in a mishna (141a): If one sent the mother away and <b>took the offspring and</b> then <b>returned them to the nest, and thereafter, the mother returned</b> and rested <b>upon them,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> the mother bird away, because he has acquired the offspring and they are now considered readily available.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Rather,</b> say that the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> one <b>lifted the mother,</b> taking possession of her, <b>and</b> then <b>consecrated her, and</b> thereafter <b>returned her</b> to the nest. The Gemara responds that this too cannot be, because <b>he was initially obligated in</b> the <b>sending</b> away of the mother bird <b>before he consecrated her.</b> Consequently, the consecration of the bird afterward cannot abrogate the requirement to send it away, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Yosef says:</b> If one <b>consecrated an undomesticated animal and then slaughtered it,</b> he is <b>exempt from covering</b> its blood, because a consecrated animal is not subject to the obligation of covering the blood. But if he <b>slaughtered it and then consecrated it,</b> he is <b>obligated to cover</b> its blood, <b>as he was already obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>covering</b> of the blood <b>before it came into the possession of the Temple</b> treasury.
Rather, <b>Rav says:</b> The mishna is referring <b>to</b> a case of one who <b>consecrates the fruit,</b> i.e., the chicks, <b>of his dovecote</b> for sacrifice on the altar, <b>and they</b> later <b>rebelled</b> and fled from the dovecote and nested elsewhere. The mishna teaches that although such birds are not considered readily available, one is exempt from sending away the mother because they are sacrificial birds. If they were non-sacred, one who finds them would be obligated to do so. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> The mishna is referring <b>to</b> a case of one who <b>consecrates his chicken for Temple maintenance,</b> and the chicken later rebelled and fled its owner’s home and established a nest elsewhere.
The Gemara objects: <b>Granted, Shmuel did not state</b> his explanation of the mishna <b>in accordance with</b> that of <b>Rav, since he interprets it</b> as referring even <b>to</b> birds <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance,</b> which do not have inherent sanctity. Accordingly, the mishna teaches that all consecrated birds are not included in the mitzva of sending away the mother bird. <b>But what is the reason</b> that <b>Rav did not state</b> his explanation <b>in accordance with</b> that of <b>Shmuel?</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Rav</b> could have <b>said to you: I specifically exempted</b> one <b>from sending</b> the mother bird away in a case <b>where</b> the birds are the <b>fruit of his dovecote, as they are consecrated for</b> the <b>altar. Since they are consecrated</b> with <b>inherent sanctity, their sanctity is not abrogated from them</b> even when they flee from the dovecote. <b>But in</b> a case where one <b>consecrates his chicken for Temple maintenance, where</b> the chicken is <b>not consecrated for</b> the <b>altar but merely</b> has <b>sanctity</b> that inheres in its <b>value, once it rebels its sanctity is abrogated, and it is obligated in,</b> i.e., subject to, the mitzva of <b>sending</b> away the mother bird.
<b>And Shmuel</b> could have <b>said:</b> Though it has rebelled, the chicken retains its sanctity, since <b>wherever it is, it is in the treasury [<i>bei gazza</i>] of the Merciful One, as it is written: “The earth is the Lord’s, and its fullness thereof”</b> (Psalms 24:1). <b>And so Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that the mishna is referring <b>to</b> a case where one <b>consecrated his chicken for Temple maintenance, and</b> the chicken then <b>rebelled. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said to him: But once it rebels, its sanctity is abrogated.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him:</b> Wherever it is, <b>it is in the treasury of the Merciful One, as it is written: “The earth is the Lord’s, and its fullness thereof.”</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> between the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> here <b>and that of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> elsewhere, <b>and</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> between the statement <b>of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> here <b>and that of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> elsewhere.
<b>As</b> it <b>was stated:</b> If one declares that <b>these one hundred dinars</b> are consecrated <b>for Temple maintenance, and they were stolen or lost, Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He bears responsibility for them until they come into the</b> physical <b>possession of the</b> Temple <b>treasurer [<i>gizbar</i>].</b> Consequently, he must pay one hundred dinars to the treasury. <b>And Reish Lakish says:</b> One is not required to replace the lost money, since <b>wherever it is, it is in the treasury of the Merciful One, as it is written: “The earth is the Lord’s, and its fullness.”</b> Accordingly, the money is considered to have entered the possession of the treasury. If so, this statement <b>of Reish Lakish</b> poses <b>a difficulty for</b> the other statement <b>of Reish Lakish,</b> and this statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> poses <b>a difficulty for</b> the other statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b>
The Gemara responds: The apparent contradiction between this statement <b>of Reish Lakish</b> and that statement <b>of Reish Lakish</b> is <b>not difficult. This</b> statement, that the sanctity of a consecrated chicken that rebelled is abrogated, was made <b>before he heard</b> the statement <b>from Rabbi Yoḥanan, his teacher,</b> that wherever it is, it is in God’s treasury. <b>That</b> statement, that one is not liable to replace the missing consecrated funds, was made <b>after he heard</b> that statement <b>from Rabbi Yoḥanan his teacher.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> still, this statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> poses <b>a difficulty</b> for that statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> The Gemara responds: The apparent contradiction between this statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> and that statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> is <b>also not difficult. This</b> statement, that one bears responsibility for the missing consecrated funds, is referring to a case <b>where</b> the consecrator <b>said:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring one hundred dinars to the Temple treasury. In such a case, one bears responsibility for the money until it reaches the Temple treasurer. <b>That</b> statement, that a consecrated chicken that rebelled remains consecrated, is referring to a case <b>where</b> the consecrator <b>said: This</b> chicken <b>is</b> consecrated for Temple maintenance. In such a case, the sanctity is not abrogated even after the chicken flees, because wherever it is, it is in God’s treasury.
