The Gemara objects: If it is so that when Rabbi Yoḥanan says that one bears financial responsibility for the missing consecrated funds, he is referring to a case where one said: It is incumbent upon me, <b>by inference</b> one may conclude <b>that</b> according to <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> who says that one does not bear responsibility for the money, one <b>does not bear</b> financial responsibility <b>even though</b> one <b>said:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me.</b>
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a mishna (<i>Kinnim</i> 1:1): <b>Which is</b> the case of <b>a vow</b> offering, <b>and which is</b> the case of <b>a gift</b> offering? <b>A vow</b> offering is where <b>one says: It is</b> incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering. A gift</b> offering is where <b>one says: This</b> animal is <b>a burnt offering. And what is</b> the difference <b>between a vow</b> offering <b>and a gift</b> offering? With regard to <b>a vow</b> offering, if <b>it died or was stolen or lost,</b> one <b>bears</b> financial <b>responsibility for it.</b> With regard to <b>a gift</b> offering, if <b>it died or was stolen or lost,</b> one <b>does not bear</b> financial <b>responsibility for it.</b>
The Gemara responds that <b>Reish Lakish</b> could have <b>said to you: This statement,</b> that one who says: It is incumbent upon me, bears financial responsibility, applies only to an item <b>consecrated for the altar, since</b> one vowed to sacrifice it as an offering and <b>it has not yet been sacrificed. But</b> with regard to an item <b>consecrated for Temple maintenance, which is not lacking sacrifice</b> on the altar, <b>even though</b> one <b>said:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me,</b> one <b>does not bear</b> financial responsibility for it.
The Gemara objects: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Arakhin</i> 20b) that in the case of <b>one who says: This bull</b> is consecrated as <b>a burnt offering, or: This house</b> is consecrated as <b>an offering,</b> and <b>the bull died</b> or <b>the house collapsed, he does not bear</b> financial <b>responsibility for them;</b> but in the case of one who says: It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to give <b>this bull</b> as <b>a burnt offering, or:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to give <b>this house</b> as <b>an offering,</b> if <b>the bull died</b> or <b>the house collapsed,</b> he is <b>obligated to pay</b> its value? Evidently, even with regard to items consecrated for Temple maintenance, if one says: It is incumbent upon me, one bears financial responsibility for them.
The Gemara responds: With regard to <b>this statement,</b> that if one says: It is incumbent upon me to give an item for Temple maintenance, he bears financial responsibility, that applies only <b>where the bull died or the house collapsed.</b> In such a case <b>he is obligated to pay, since they no</b> longer <b>exist. But where they</b> still <b>exist,</b> e.g., in the case of an item or sum of money that was lost or stolen, one applies the principle: <b>Wherever it is, it is in the treasury of the Merciful One, as it is written: “The earth is the Lord’s, and its fullness thereof.”</b>
§ The Gemara above cited a dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish as to the <i>halakha</i> about one who says: It is incumbent upon me to bring an item for Temple maintenance. With regard to this dispute, <b>Rav Hamnuna says: Everyone concedes with regard to valuations</b> that <b>even if one said:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to donate my own valuation, and one set aside money that was then lost or stolen, one <b>does not bear</b> financial responsibility for it. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because it cannot be stated by him without</b> stating: <b>Upon me.</b> In other words, one cannot say: This is my valuation, since he has yet to accept upon himself any such obligation.
Therefore, although one says: It is incumbent upon me to donate my valuation, this is not considered an acceptance of financial responsibility. After all, <b>how shall he say</b> it without stating: It is incumbent upon me? <b>Shall he say</b> only: <b>My own valuation,</b> without: Is incumbent upon me? If so, <b>upon whom</b> is the obligation placed to pay the money? Or <b>shall he say</b> only: <b>The valuation of so-and-so?</b> Still, <b>upon whom</b> is the obligation placed to pay the money?
<b>Rava objects to this: Let him say: I am</b> encumbered <b>with my own valuation,</b> or: <b>I am</b> encumbered <b>with the valuation of so-and-so.</b> One need not say: Is incumbent upon me. <b>Additionally, it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the redemption of a purchased field that was consecrated that <b>Rabbi Natan says</b> about the verse: “Then the priest shall reckon for him the worth of your valuation until the Jubilee Year, <b>and he shall give your valuation on that day, as a consecrated thing to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 27:23): <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state:</b> “And he shall give your valuation”? It could have stated simply: And he shall give it. It is necessary <b>because we have found with regard to consecrated</b> property <b>and tithes that they can be desacralized</b> by transferring their sanctity <b>onto non-sacred money,</b> and that if that money <b>was stolen or lost,</b> the owners <b>do not bear</b> financial <b>responsibility for it.</b>

Daf 139b

One <b>might</b> have thought that with regard to <b>this</b> valuation <b>too,</b> the <i>halakha</i> should be <b>so,</b> i.e., if money from a valuation is stolen or lost, the owner does not bear financial responsibility for it. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And he shall give your valuation</b> on that day,” indicating that the valuation money is <b>non-sacred until it enters the possession of</b> the Temple <b>treasurer,</b> and that the owner bears responsibility for it until that time. Evidently, even with regard to valuations, the consecrator bears financial responsibility, in contradiction to the statement of Rav Hamnuna.
<b>Rather, if</b> a statement <b>was stated, this</b> is what <b>was stated: Rav Hamnuna says</b> that <b>everyone concedes with regard to valuations that even if</b> one <b>did not say:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me,</b> one <b>bears</b> financial responsibility for it, <b>as it is written: “And he shall give your valuation,”</b> indicating that the valuation money is <b>non-sacred until it enters the possession of</b> the Temple <b>treasurer.</b>
§ The mishna states: There are more <b>stringent</b> elements <b>in the covering</b> of the blood than in the sending away of the mother from the nest, as the covering of the blood applies to undomesticated animals and birds, to animals and birds that are readily available in one’s home, and to animals and birds that are not readily available; and the sending of the mother from the nest applies only to birds that are not readily available. With regard to the mitzva of sending away the mother, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“If a bird’s nest happens before you</b> on the way, in any tree or on the ground, with fledglings or eggs, and the mother is resting upon the fledglings, or upon the eggs, you shall not take the mother with the young; you shall send the mother, but the young you may take for yourself” (Deuteronomy 22:6–7). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> all the various details contained in it?
<b>Since it is stated: “You shall send [<i>shalle’aḥ teshallaḥ</i>] the mother, but the young you may take for yourself,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the doubled verb “<i>shalle’aḥ teshallaḥ</i>” indicates that one must <b>search</b> even <b>in the mountains and hills in order to find a nest</b> with which to perform this mitzva. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “If</b> a bird’s nest <b>happens,”</b> indicating that one is obligated to send away the mother only <b>when it confronts you;</b> one is not required to seek out a nest.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The word <b>“nest”</b> indicates that this mitzva applies <b>in any case,</b> even to a nest with only a single chick or egg. The word <b>“bird’s”</b> indicates that the mitzva applies only to <b>kosher</b> birds, <b>and not</b> to <b>non-kosher</b> birds. The term <b>“before you”</b> indicates that the mitzva applies to a nest that is <b>on private property,</b> e.g., an unguarded orchard or field, such that the owner’s property does not acquire the nest for him. The term <b>“on the way”</b> indicates that the mitzva also applies to a nest found <b>in a public thoroughfare. From where</b> is it derived that the mitzva also applies to nests found <b>in trees? The verse states: “In any tree.”</b> And with regard to nests found <b>in pits, ditches, and caves, from where</b> is it derived that the mitzva also applies to them? <b>The verse states: “Or on the ground,”</b> indicating that the mitzva applies to a nest on any type of ground.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And since, in the end, we will include everything,</b> i.e., every location of the nest, from the verse: “In any tree or on the ground,” <b>why do I</b> need the earlier statement: <b>“Before you on the way”?</b> It is <b>to say to you: Just as</b> a nest on the <b>way</b> is a case in <b>which</b> the bird’s <b>nest is not in your possession</b> and is not readily available for you, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>all</b> other cases, one is obligated only <b>when its nest is not in your possession. From here</b> the Sages <b>stated:</b> With regard to <b>pigeons of a dovecote or pigeons of an attic that nested in</b> small <b>wall niches or in buildings, and geese or chickens that nested in an orchard, one is obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>sending</b> the mother bird away, because such birds are not in one’s possession. <b>But</b> with regard to birds that <b>nested inside the house, and likewise</b> with regard to <b>domesticated pigeons, one is exempt from</b> the mitzva of <b>sending</b> the mother bird away.
§ The Gemara analyzes the above <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said: Just as</b> a nest on the <b>way</b> is a case in <b>which</b> the bird’s <b>nest is not in your possession, so too,</b> with regard to <b>all</b> other cases, one is obligated only <b>when its nest is not in your possession.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>this</b> derivation? <b>It</b> may be <b>derived from: “If</b> a bird’s nest <b>happens,”</b> as it is taught: <b>“If</b> a bird’s nest <b>happens” excludes</b> a nest that is readily <b>available. And furthermore, why do I</b> need the term <b>“before you”</b> to include even a nest found on private property? It is already derived from the verse: “In any tree or on the ground.”
<b>Rather,</b> the term <b>“before you”</b> is necessary <b>to include</b> a case <b>where</b> the birds <b>were before you,</b> i.e., they had an owner and were readily available to him, <b>and</b> they then <b>rebelled</b> and fled and nested elsewhere. <b>“On the way”</b> is necessary for <b>that which Rav Yehuda</b> said that <b>Rav said, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> If one <b>found a nest in the sea,</b> e.g., in a case where a tree was washed out to sea with a nest in its branches, one <b>is obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>sending</b> the mother bird away, <b>as it is stated: “So said the Lord, who makes a way in the sea,</b> and a path in the mighty waters” (Isaiah 43:16). The term “way” applies even to the sea.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If that is so,</b> then if <b>one found a nest in the sky,</b> e.g., in a case where a bird carries the nest as it flies, about <b>which it is written: “The way of an eagle in the sky”</b> (Proverbs 30:19), one should <b>also be obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>sending</b> away the mother bird from <b>the nest.</b> The Gemara responds: The sky <b>is called “the way of an eagle,”</b> but <b>it is not called: A way,</b> in <b>an unspecified</b> manner. The sea, by contrast, is referred to simply as: A way.
§ <b>The</b> residents <b>of Pappunya said to Rav Mattana:</b> If one <b>found a nest on the head of a person, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the mitzva of sending away the mother? Is the nest considered to be on the ground, such that one is obligated in the mitzva? Rav Mattana <b>said</b> to them that one is obligated in the mitzva in such a case because the verse states: <b>“And earth upon his head”</b> (II Samuel 15:32), rather than: Dirt upon his head, indicating that one’s head is considered like the ground. They also asked Rav Mattana: <b>From where in the Torah</b> is the existence of <b>Moses [<i>Moshe</i>]</b> alluded to before his birth? He replied that the verse states: <b>“For that he also [<i>beshaggam</i>] is flesh;</b> therefore shall his days be one hundred and twenty years” (Genesis 6:3). The numerical value of <i>beshaggam</i> is the same as that of the Hebrew name <i>Moshe</i>, and it is known that Moses lived a total of 120 years (see Deuteronomy 34:7).
They also asked Rav Mattana: <b>From where in the Torah</b> can one find an allusion to the hanging of <b>Haman?</b> He replied: The verse states after Adam ate from the tree of knowledge: <b>“Have you eaten of [<i>hamin</i>] the tree,</b> about which I commanded you that you should not eat?” (Genesis 3:11). <i>Hamin</i> is spelled in the same manner as Haman: <i>Heh</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>nun</i>.
They also asked Rav Mattana: <b>From where in the Torah</b> can one find an allusion to the events involving <b>Esther?</b> He replied to them that the verse states: “Then My anger shall be kindled against them on that day, and I will forsake them, and I will hide My face from them, and they shall be devoured, and many evils and troubles shall come upon them; so that they will say in that day: Have not these evils come upon us because our God is not among us? <b>And I will hide [<i>haster astir</i>]</b> My face on that day for all the evil which they shall have wrought, in that they are turned to other gods” (Deuteronomy 31:17–18). They also asked him: <b>From where in the Torah</b> can one find an allusion to the greatness bestowed upon <b>Mordecai?</b> He replied: <b>As it is written</b> with regard to the anointing oil in the Tabernacle: “And you shall also take the chief spices, of <b>flowing myrrh [<i>mor deror</i>]”</b> (Exodus 30:23); <b>and we translate</b> <i>mor deror</i> into Aramaic as: <b><i>Mira dakhya</i>,</b> which resembles the name Mordecai.
§ The mishna states: <b>And which</b> are considered birds <b>that are not</b> readily <b>available?</b> They are any birds such as geese or chickens that nested in the orchard. But if the geese or chickens nested in the house, one is exempt from sending them away, and likewise with regard to domesticated pigeons. The Gemara relates: With regard to the correct name of the domesticated pigeons referred to in the mishna, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rabbi Shimon</b> disagree. <b>One teaches</b> that the correct name is <i>yonei <b>hadrisei’ot</b></i><b>, and</b> the other <b>one teaches</b> that the correct name is <i>yonei <b>hardisei’ot</b></i><b>.</b> According to the <b>one who teaches</b> that the correct name is <i>yonei <b>hardisei’ot</b></i><b>,</b> they are called so <b>on account of</b> King <b>Herod,</b> who was involved in breeding these pigeons; <b>and</b> according to the <b>one who teaches</b> that the correct name is <i>yonei <b>hadrisei’ot</b></i><b>,</b> they are called so <b>on account of their location.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana said: I myself saw</b> these pigeons, <b>and they</b> were <b>standing</b> in <b>sixteen rows,</b> each <b>a <i>mil</i> wide, and they were calling</b> out: <b>My master, my master. There was one of them who was not calling</b> out: <b>My master, my master. Another</b> one <b>said to it: Blind</b> one, i.e., fool, <b>say: My master, my master,</b> so that you will not be punished for refusing to acknowledge the authority of the king. The pigeon <b>said</b> in response: <b>Blind</b> one, you should <b>say: My master, my slave,</b> as Herod is not a king but a slave. <b>They brought</b> that pigeon to a slaughterhouse <b>and slaughtered it</b> for speaking against the king.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Rabbi Ḥanina said to me:</b> This story is no more than mere <b>words,</b> as no such incident took place. The Gemara asks: Can it <b>enter your mind</b> that Rabbi Ḥanina dismisses as mere <b>words</b> an incident reported by Rav Kahana? <b>Rather, say</b> that Rabbi Ḥanina said that those pigeons acted as described above <b>through words</b> of witchcraft.
§ The mishna states: If one encounters a nest of <b>a non-kosher bird,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother bird. The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: As the verse states: “If a bird’s [<i>tzippor</i>] nest happens before you”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:6), and not: If a bird’s [<i>of</i> ] nest happens before you. The word <b><i>of</i> indicates to us</b> that all birds are included, <b>whether kosher or non-kosher.</b> But with regard to the word <b><i>tzippor</i>, we have found</b> that <b>a kosher</b> bird <b>is called a <i>tzippor</i>,</b> but <b>we have not found</b> that <b>a non-kosher</b> bird <b>is called a <i>tzippor</i>.</b>
The Gemara attempts to reject the above assertion: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is stated in the verse with regard to the prohibition against fashioning idols: <b>“The likeness of any winged bird [<i>tzippor</i>]”</b> (Deuteronomy 4:17). <b>What, is it not</b> that the word <b>“<i>tzippor</i>”</b> is referring to any bird, <b>whether kosher or non-kosher,</b> and the word <b>“winged”</b> adds the likeness of <b>grasshoppers</b> to the prohibition? If so, we have found that a non-kosher bird is called a <i>tzippor</i>. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> the word <b>“<i>tzippor</i>”</b> means <b>a kosher</b> bird, while the word <b>“winged”</b> is referring to <b>non-kosher</b> birds <b>and</b> to <b>grasshoppers.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is stated in the passage describing how all of creation praises God: <b>“The undomesticated animal and all domesticated animals, creeping things and winged birds [<i>tzippor</i>]”</b> (Psalms 148:10). <b>What, is it not</b> that the word <b>“<i>tzippor</i>”</b> is referring to all birds, <b>whether kosher or non-kosher, and</b> the word <b>“winged”</b> is referring to <b>grasshoppers?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> the word <b>“<i>tzippor</i>”</b> means <b>a kosher</b> bird, while the word <b>“winged”</b> is referring to <b>non-kosher</b> birds <b>and</b> to <b>grasshoppers.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is stated in the verse about the animals that entered Noah’s ark: <b>“Every bird [<i>tzippor</i>] of every type of wing”</b> (Genesis 7:14). <b>What, is it not</b> the same <b>difficulty that we posed</b> previously, that the word “<i>tzippor</i>” is referring to all birds, kosher and non-kosher, and the word “wing” is referring to grasshoppers? The Gemara rejects this as well: <b>No,</b> it is actually <b>as we resolved</b> it, that the word “<i>tzippor</i>” is referring only to kosher birds, and the word “wing” is referring to non-kosher birds and to grasshoppers.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is stated in the passage describing the war of Gog and Magog: <b>“And you, son of man,</b> so said the Lord God: <b>Speak to the birds [<i>tzippor</i>] of every type of wing,</b> and to every animal of the field: Assemble yourselves, and come” (Ezekiel 39:17). <b>What, is it not</b> the same <b>difficulty that we posed</b> previously? The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> it is actually <b>as we resolved</b> it.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is

Daf 140a

stated in the verse describing a tree: <b>“And in its branches will dwell the birds [<i>tzipparei</i>] of the heaven”</b> (Daniel 4:9). The verse states only: “The birds [<i>tzipparei</i>],” and not: The birds of any type of wing. Accordingly, the term “the birds [<i>tzipparei</i>]” must be referring to all birds, whether kosher or non-kosher, since all birds dwell in tree branches. The Gemara rejects this: Non-kosher birds <b>are called: Birds [<i>tzipparei</i>] of the heaven,</b> but <b>they are not called: <i>Tzipparei</i>,</b> in <b>an unspecified</b> manner.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is stated in the passage discussing kosher and non-kosher animals: <b>“Every kosher bird [<i>tzippor</i>]</b> you may eat” (Deuteronomy 14:11). Since it was necessary for the verse to specify that it is referring to a kosher bird [<i>tzippor</i>], <b>by inference,</b> one may conclude <b>that there is a non-kosher</b> bird [<i>tzippor</i>], in contradiction to the statement of Rabbi Yitzḥak. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> this is not the correct inference. Rather, <b>by inference</b> one may conclude <b>that there is</b> a <i>tzippor</i> that is <b>prohibited</b> for consumption, despite its being a kosher bird.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> this kosher bird whose prohibition must be derived from this verse? <b>If</b> it is a bird <b>with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>],</b> that would be superfluous, as that <b>is written explicitly</b> in the verse: “An unslaughtered animal carcass, or a <i>tereifa</i>, he shall not eat” (Leviticus 22:8). <b>And if</b> it is referring <b>to the slaughtered</b> bird from the purification ritual <b>of a leper,</b> which is prohibited for consumption despite being kosher, that would also be superfluous, since it <b>is derived from the latter clause of the verse</b> in Deuteronomy, as the verse states: <b>“But these are they of which you shall not eat”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:12), which serves <b>to include the slaughtered</b> bird <b>of the leper.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> the verse: “Every kosher bird you may eat,” is referring <b>to the slaughtered</b> bird <b>of a leper, and</b> the verse indicates that one <b>transgresses</b> the <b>positive mitzva</b> of: “You may eat,” in addition to the <b>prohibition</b> of: “But these are they of which you shall not eat,” <b>on account of it.</b> The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> why not <b>interpret</b> the verse as referring <b>to a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> and explain that the verse teaches that one <b>transgresses a positive mitzva and a prohibition on account of it?</b> The Gemara responds: The verse should be interpreted as referring to the slaughtered bird of a leper, since it is <b>a matter derived from its context,</b> as that verse <b>is written in the context of a slaughtered</b> bird. By contrast, a <i>tereifa</i> is not properly slaughtered, and interpreting the verse in that manner does not fit the context.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is stated in the passage discussing the purification ritual of a leper: “Then shall the priest command to take for him that is to be cleansed <b>two living birds [<i>tzipporim</i>]</b> that are kosher” (Leviticus 14:4). Since the birds are obviously alive before the purification ritual begins, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the word <b>“living”?</b> Is it <b>not that they are living in your mouth,</b> i.e., permitted for consumption? If so, <b>by inference,</b> one may conclude <b>that there are</b> birds [<i>tzipporim</i>] <b>that are not living in your mouth,</b> i.e., that are not kosher. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> that is not its meaning. Rather, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the word <b>“living”?</b> It means <b>that their extremities are living,</b> i.e., attached to their bodies. The verse indicates that the kosher birds must have all their limbs attached to their bodies in order to be used in the purification ritual.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof <b>from the latter clause</b> of that verse: “Two living birds [<i>tzipporim</i>] that are <b>kosher.”</b> Since it was necessary for the verse to specify that it is referring to kosher birds, <b>by inference</b> one may conclude <b>that there are non-kosher</b> birds, in contradiction to the statement of Rabbi Yitzḥak. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> that is not the correct inference. Rather, <b>by inference</b> one may conclude <b>that there are</b> other birds of kosher species that may not be used for this ritual, i.e., <b><i>tereifot</i>.</b>
The Gemara objects: But the disqualification of <b><i>tereifot</i> is</b> already <b>derived from</b> the word <b>“living”</b> in that verse. The Gemara elaborates: Granted, <b>this works out well according to the one who says</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> can live</b> (see 42a); it is therefore necessary for the verse to state “kosher” to exclude <i>tereifot</i>, because one could not have derived it from the word “living.” <b>But according to the one who says</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> animal <b>cannot live, what is there to say?</b> Let it be derived from the word “living.” <b>And furthermore, whether according to the one who says</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> can live or according to the one who says</b> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i> cannot live,</b> it is not necessary to derive the exclusion of <i>tereifot</i> from the word “kosher,” since it <b>is derived from that which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught.</b>
<b>As the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> It is <b>stated</b> in the Torah that there are offerings that <b>enable</b> one to partake of sacrificial foods, e.g., the sin offering of a woman who has given birth or the guilt offering of a leper, <b>and</b> there are offerings that <b>atone,</b> e.g., a sin offering or guilt offering, all of which are brought <b>inside</b> the Temple. <b>And</b> it is also <b>stated</b> in the Torah that there are offerings that <b>enable</b> one to partake of sacrificial foods, e.g., the birds of a leper’s purification ritual, <b>and</b> offerings that <b>atone,</b> e.g., the scapegoat of the Yom Kippur service, that are brought <b>outside</b> the Temple.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Therefore, the offerings brought outside the Temple are compared to those offered inside: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the offerings that <b>enable or atone stated</b> in the Torah that are offered <b>inside</b> the Temple, the Torah <b>made</b> the offering that <b>enables like</b> the offering that <b>atones,</b> as even the former has portions of it that are burned on the altar, <b>so too,</b> with regard to offerings that <b>enable or atone stated</b> in the Torah that are offered <b>outside</b> the Temple, the Torah <b>made</b> the offering that <b>enables like</b> the offering that <b>atones.</b> Accordingly, just as the scapegoat must not be a <i>tereifa</i>, so too, the birds of a leper’s purification ritual must not be <i>tereifot</i>. If so, there is no need to derive the exclusion of <i>tereifa</i> birds from the word “kosher.”
<b>Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The word “kosher” serves <b>to exclude birds from an idolatrous city.</b> Such a city must be burned to the ground, and it is prohibited for one to derive benefit from any of its contents. The verse indicates that such a bird is unfit for use in the leper’s purification ritual. The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> function are such birds rendered unfit by the word “kosher”? <b>If</b> the verse means <b>to</b> render them unfit for <b>sending</b> away as part of the ritual, this is unnecessary, since the <b>Torah did not say</b> to <b>send</b> a bird only <b>to</b> create <b>a stumbling block.</b> It is obvious that any bird prohibited for consumption is unfit for sending, since the Torah would not allow for the possibility that the bird sent away will be trapped and consumed by unwitting individuals. <b>Rather,</b> the verse means <b>to</b> render them unfit for use as the bird intended for <b>slaughter.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> The word “kosher” serves <b>to exclude</b> the repeated use of a bird, i.e., a leper may <b>not pair</b> a bird <b>with another</b> bird from a previous leper, <b>before its</b> being <b>sent</b> away. The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> function does the word “kosher” indicate that a bird may not be reused? <b>If</b> it means <b>to</b> indicate that the bird intended for being sent away by the first leper may not be used for <b>slaughter</b> by the second leper, the verse is unnecessary, as this bird <b>requires</b> being <b>sent</b> away as part of the first leper’s purification ritual. <b>Rather,</b> the verse means <b>to</b> indicate that the bird intended for being sent away by the first leper may not be used for <b>sending</b> simultaneously by the second leper.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The word “kosher” serves <b>to</b> exclude the use of <b>birds that were exchanged for birds of idol worship,</b> i.e., a gentile paid a Jew for his idol by giving the Jew birds. Such birds are prohibited from use in the leper’s ritual, <b>as it is written</b> about objects of idol worship: “And you shall not bring an abomination into your house, <b>and become [<i>vahayita</i>] accursed like it”</b> (Deuteronomy 7:26), indicating that <b>anything that you generate [<i>mehayye</i>] from it,</b> e.g., through exchange, is prohibited <b>like it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> function does the word “kosher” indicate that such birds are prohibited? <b>If</b> it serves <b>to</b> exclude such birds from being <b>sent</b> away, this is unnecessary, because <b>the Torah did not say: Send</b> it away, if doing so could lead <b>to a mishap.</b> If the bird were prohibited, the Torah would not have commanded one to send it away, as others might eat it unwittingly. <b>Rather,</b> the word “kosher” serves <b>to</b> disqualify such birds for <b>slaughter.</b>
<b>Ravina said: Here we are dealing with a bird that killed a person</b> and is therefore subject to being killed. The verse indicates that such a bird is unfit for use in the leper’s ritual. The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If</b> this is a case <b>where its verdict</b> of execution <b>was issued,</b> then <b>it is subject</b> to being <b>killed,</b> and there is no need for the verse to teach that it cannot be used in the ritual. <b>Rather,</b> it must be referring to a bird <b>before its verdict</b> of execution <b>was issued. And for what</b> function does the verse exclude such a bird? <b>If</b> it serves <b>to</b> exclude the bird from <b>sending</b> away, this is unnecessary, since one is <b>required to bring it to the court to fulfill</b> the verse: <b>“And you shall eradicate the evil from your midst”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:6). Obviously, one may not send it away. <b>Rather,</b> the verse serves <b>to</b> disqualify such a bird for <b>slaughter.</b>
§ The mishna states: If <b>a non-kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a kosher bird,</b> or a kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a non-kosher bird, one is exempt from sending away the bird. The Gemara objects: <b>Granted,</b> it is understandable that one is exempt in a case where <b>a non-kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a kosher</b> bird, since <b>we require</b> a kosher bird, as the verse uses the word <b>“<i>tzippor</i>”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:6) in this context, which the Gemara earlier (139b) interpreted as a reference to a kosher bird, <b>and</b> this bird <b>is not</b> kosher. <b>But</b> in a case where <b>a kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a non-kosher bird, it is a <i>tzippor</i>,</b> a kosher bird, and one should be required to send it away.
The Gemara responds that this is in accordance with <b>that which Rav Kahana said</b> in a different context: The verse states: “But the young <b>you may take for yourself”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:7), indicating that one is required to send away the mother only if the eggs are fit for consumption, <b>but not</b> if they are fit only <b>for your dog. Here too,</b> with regard to non-kosher eggs, the mitzva applies only if <b>you may take for yourself, but not</b> if they are fit only <b>for your dog</b> because they are not kosher.
The Gemara asks: <b>And where was</b> this statement <b>of Rav Kahana stated?</b> The Gemara answers that it was stated <b>with regard to that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Even if the <b>mother</b> bird is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> away the mother from the nest. But if the <b>fledglings</b> are <b><i>tereifot</i>,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother. <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>Rav Kahana said: As the verse states: “You may take for yourself,”</b> indicating that you are required to send away the mother only if the fledglings are fit for consumption, <b>but not</b> if they are fit only <b>for your dog</b> because they are <i>tereifot</i>.
The Gemara objects: <b>But</b> why not <b>compare a <i>tereifa</i> mother</b> bird <b>to</b> <i>tereifa</i> <b>fledglings</b> and say: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b><i>tereifa</i> fledglings</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>a <i>tereifa</i> mother</b> one should <b>also</b> be <b>exempt from sending</b> her away.

Daf 140b

The Gemara responds: <b>If so,</b> that the mother should be compared to the fledglings, then <b>why do I</b> need the word <b>“<i>tzippor</i>” to exclude a non-kosher bird?</b> One could simply derive it from the fact that one is exempt from the mitzva in the case of non-kosher fledglings, since they are not fit for consumption. Rather, since it was necessary for the verse to teach that non-kosher birds are not included in the mitzva of sending away the mother, it must be that no such comparison is to be drawn.
The Gemara questions the statement of Rav Kahana that the mitzva of sending away the mother bird from the nest does not apply in the case of fledglings unfit for consumption: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a mother of fledglings,</b> in the case of a <b><i>tereifa</i>,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> away the mother bird from the nest? The <i>baraita</i> appears to teach that even if the fledglings themselves are <i>tereifot</i>, one is obligated in the mitzva. <b>Abaye said</b> in response: The word <i>tereifa</i> is not referring to the fledglings. Rather, <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> In the case of <b>a fledgling whose mother is a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> away the mother bird. This <i>baraita</i>, then, is in accordance with the statement of Rav Kahana.
§ With regard to the statement of Rav Kahana above, <b>Rav Hoshaya raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>stretched his hand into a nest</b> containing a mother bird and its fledglings <b>and slaughtered,</b> i.e., severed, <b>a minority of</b> the <b>two organs that must be severed in ritual slaughter [<i>simanim</i>],</b> i.e., the windpipe and the gullet, of the fledglings,<b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to sending away the mother bird?
The two sides of the dilemma are explained: <b>Do we say: Since if those</b> fledglings <b>are left</b> as they are, with only partially severed <i>simanim</i>, <b>they will</b> eventually be rendered <b><i>tereifot</i>,</b> one is therefore exempt from sending away the mother because <b>we require</b> that the fledglings be taken <b>“for yourself,” and not for your dog? Or perhaps, since it is in his power to complete the</b> act of <b>slaughter,</b> thereby permitting the fledglings for consumption, <b>we</b> may <b>call</b> this case: <b>“Take for yourself,” and one is obligated to send</b> away the mother bird. Since no answer is given, the Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> In a case where <b>a rag</b> is lying in the nest between the mother bird and the eggs, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does <b>it interpose</b>between them,such that the mother is not considered to be resting upon the eggs? If so, one would be exempt from sending away the mother. Similarly, if feathers are detached from a bird’s <b>wings</b> and are lying between the mother bird and the eggs, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do <b>they interpose</b> between the eggs and the mother?
Rabbi Yirmeya continues: If <b>unfertilized [<i>muzarot</i>] eggs</b> separate between the mother bird and fertilized eggs, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Additionally, in a case where <b>two sets of</b> fertilized <b>eggs</b> are lying <b>one on top of the other, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does the upper set of eggs interpose between the mother and the lower set? Furthermore, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in a case where <b>a male</b> bird is resting <b>on top of</b> the <b>eggs and a female</b> bird is resting <b>on top of</b> the <b>male?</b> Does the male bird interpose between the female and the eggs? No answers are given, so the Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved in all of these cases.
§ <b>Rabbi Zeira raises a dilemma:</b> If <b>a pigeon</b> is resting <b>upon the eggs of a <i>tasil</i>,</b> a kosher bird resembling a pigeon, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to sending away the mother bird from the nest? Likewise, if <b>a <i>tasil</i></b> is resting <b>upon the eggs of a pigeon, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Abaye said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is taught in the mishna: In a case where <b>a non-kosher bird is resting upon the eggs of a kosher bird, or a kosher</b> bird <b>is resting upon the eggs of a non-kosher bird,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the bird. One may infer from the mishna <b>that</b> in a case involving <b>a kosher</b> bird <b>and kosher</b> eggs, e.g., a <i>tasil</i> resting on the eggs of a pigeon, one is <b>obligated</b> to send away the mother bird. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps</b> this inference applies only <b>to</b> the case of a female <b>pheasant,</b> which normally rests upon the eggs of other birds. Since this is its normal behavior, one is obligated to send it away even if it rests upon the eggs of another kosher bird. This may not be the case with regard to a <i>tasil</i> or pigeon.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to the case of <b>a male pheasant</b> that rests upon the eggs of its species, <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> one <b>obligated</b> to send away the pheasant, <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> one <b>exempt</b> from sending it away. With regard to this dispute, <b>Rabbi Abbahu said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Eliezer?</b> According to Rabbi Eliezer, a verbal analogy between <b>brooding</b> stated with regard to a male pheasant and <b>brooding</b> with regard to a female bird <b>comes</b> to indicate that the resting of a male pheasant upon its eggs is considered an effective resting. <b>It is written here: “As the pheasant that broods over young that he has not brought forth”</b> (Jeremiah 17:11), <b>and it is written elsewhere</b> about a female bird: “There shall the great owl make her nest, and lay, <b>and hatch, and brood under her shadow”</b> (Isaiah 34:15). Just as a female bird broods over its nest, so too, a male pheasant broods over a nest. Therefore, one is required to send away the male bird from the nest as well.
With regard to this dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis, <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> Their <b>dispute</b> is only <b>with regard to a male pheasant, but</b> with regard <b>to a female pheasant all agree</b> that one is <b>obligated</b> to send away the bird. The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious,</b> given that <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>A male pheasant?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>the Rabbis deem</b> one <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of sending away the mother bird <b>even</b> in the case of <b>a female pheasant, and</b> as for <b>that which</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> the dispute in the case of <b>a male</b> pheasant, the reason is <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> in that he requires one to send away even a male pheasant, therefore, Rabbi Elazar <b>teaches us</b> that the Rabbis agree that one must send away a female pheasant.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar</b> also <b>says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis is only <b>with regard to a male pheasant, but</b> with regard <b>to male</b> birds <b>in general, all agree</b> that one is <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of sending away the bird from the nest. The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious,</b> given that <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>A male pheasant?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> one <b>obligated</b> to send away <b>even male</b> birds <b>in general, and that which</b> the mishna <b>teaches: A male</b> pheasant, is <b>to convey to you the far-reaching nature of</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> in that they also deem one exempt from sending a male pheasant, therefore, Rabbi Elazar <b>teaches us</b> that even according to Rabbi Eliezer, one is exempt from sending away male birds in general.
The Gemara notes: <b>This</b> explanation of Rabbi Elazar <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a male</b> bird <b>in general,</b> one is <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of sending it away, but with regard to <b>a male pheasant, Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> one <b>obligated</b> to send it away from the nest, <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> one <b>exempt</b> from sending it away.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If the mother bird <b>was hovering</b> over the eggs or fledglings in the nest, <b>when its wings are touching</b> the eggs or fledglings <b>in the nest,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> away the mother. When its wings <b>are not touching</b> the eggs or fledglings <b>in the nest,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother. Even if <b>there is only one fledgling or one egg,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> away the mother, <b>as it is stated:</b> “If a bird’s <b>nest</b> happens before you” (Deuteronomy 22:6), indicating that one is obligated to send away the mother bird from the <b>nest in any case.</b>
If <b>there were fledglings</b> capable of <b>flying, or unfertilized eggs</b> from which a fledgling will not hatch, one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother bird from the nest, <b>as it is stated</b> in the same verse: <b>“And the mother is resting upon the fledglings or upon the eggs.”</b> From the juxtaposition of the fledglings and the eggs one derives: <b>Just as the fledglings are living, so too, the eggs</b> must <b>be</b> capable of producing <b>living</b> fledglings. This <b>excludes unfertilized</b> eggs, which cannot produce a living fledgling. <b>And</b> furthermore, <b>just as the eggs need their mothers</b> to hatch them, <b>so too, the fledglings</b> must be those that <b>need their mothers.</b> This <b>excludes</b> fledglings that are capable of <b>flying.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna discusses the case of a mother bird that hovers over the nest. With regard to this, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse teaches that one is obligated to send away the mother bird only when it is at rest, as it states: “And the mother is <b>resting</b> upon the fledglings” (Deuteronomy 22:6), <b>and not</b> when it is <b>hovering.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that one is exempt <b>even</b> if the mother is hovering and <b>its wings are touching the nest.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Resting,”</b> indicating that in fact one is obligated in the mitzva in such a case. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation,</b> i.e., how is this derived from the word “resting”? The Gemara responds: It is derived <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the word <b>sitting is not written</b> in the verse. Although a bird whose wings are touching the nest is not sitting upon it, such a bird is considered to be resting upon it.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If the mother bird <b>was sitting</b> above the eggs or fledglings <b>between two tree branches,</b> one <b>looks</b> at the following factor in order to determine whether the obligation to send away the mother applies: In <b>any</b> case <b>where if</b> the branches were to separate, the bird <b>would slip</b> between them and <b>fall upon</b> the eggs or fledglings, one is <b>obligated to send</b> away the mother bird. <b>And if</b> the bird would <b>not</b> fall upon them, but to the sides, one is <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of sending away the mother bird.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rav from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If the mother bird <b>was sitting among</b> the eggs or the fledglings, one is <b>exempt from sending</b> it away, as the verse states: “And the mother is resting upon the fledglings, or upon the eggs” (Deuteronomy 22:6), i.e., upon and not among. If it was sitting <b>above them,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> it away. If it <b>was hovering, even</b> if <b>its wings are touching the nest,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> it away.
<b>What, is it not</b> that the case of sitting <b>above them</b> is <b>similar to</b> the case of sitting <b>between them?</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Just as</b> in the case of sitting <b>between them</b> one is exempt <b>where she is touching them, so too,</b> in the case of sitting <b>above them</b> one is obligated <b>where she is touching them.</b> If so, conclude from this <i>baraita</i> that one is obligated only if the bird is touching the fledglings or eggs, <b>but</b> if it is sitting between two <b>tree branches</b> above the eggs or fledglings without touching them, one is <b>exempt</b> from sending her away.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No;</b> actually, the case of sitting <b>above them</b> is <b>similar to</b> that of sitting <b>between them</b> in the following manner: <b>Just as</b> the case of sitting <b>between them</b> is one <b>where she is not touching them</b> from <b>above,</b> but from the side, <b>so too,</b> the case of sitting <b>above them</b> is one <b>where she is not touching them</b> from <b>above.</b> Accordingly, the <i>baraita</i> teaches that one is obligated to send away the bird if it is resting on branches above the nest, even though it is not touching the eggs or fledglings. <b>And that is</b> the case where the mother is sitting between two <b>tree branches.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>This, too, stands to reason,</b> that one is obligated to send away a mother bird that is sitting between two tree branches above the nest. <b>As, if</b> it should <b>enter your mind</b> that one is <b>exempt</b> when the mother bird is sitting between two <b>tree branches,</b> then one may ask: <b>Rather than teaching</b> that if it <b>was hovering, even</b> if <b>its wings are touching the nest,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> it away, <b>let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach</b> that one is exempt in the case of a mother bird that is sitting between two <b>tree branches, and all the more so</b> if the mother <b>is hovering.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: Perhaps one is exempt from sending the mother bird if it is resting between two tree branches. Nevertheless, it <b>was necessary</b> for the <i>tanna</i> to teach the case of <b>a hovering</b> bird, in order to teach <b>that even</b> if <b>its wings are touching the nest,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother bird. Had the <i>tanna</i> taught the exemption in a case of a bird resting between two tree branches, one might have thought that this is because the bird’s wings are not touching the nest.
The Gemara now questions the <i>baraita</i> itself: How can the <i>baraita</i> state that even if the hovering bird’s wings are touching the nest, one is exempt from sending the bird away? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>When its wings are touching the nest,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> away the mother? <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said: When</b> the case of the hovering mother bird <b>is taught</b> in <b>the <i>baraita</i>,</b> it is referring <b>to</b> a bird <b>touching</b> the nest <b>from the side.</b> In such a case, one is exempt because its wings are not touching the nest from above. By contrast, the mishna is referring to a case where the bird is hovering directly above the nest and touching the nest with its wings from above.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that the discussion proceeded as follows: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the opinion of Rav: If the mother bird <b>was sitting among</b> the eggs or the fledglings, one is <b>exempt from sending</b> it away. If it was sitting <b>above them,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> it away. If <b>it was hovering, even</b> if <b>its wings are touching the nest,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> it away.
<b>What, is it not</b> that the case of sitting <b>above them</b> is <b>similar to</b> that of sitting <b>between them</b> in the following manner: <b>Just as</b> the case of sitting <b>between them</b> is one <b>where she is not touching them</b> from <b>above</b> but from the side, <b>so too,</b> the case of sitting <b>above them</b> is one <b>where she is not touching them</b> from <b>above?</b> If so, the <i>baraita</i> teaches that if the bird rests on branches over the eggs or fledglings without touching them, one is obligated in the mitzva. <b>And that is</b> the case where the mother is sitting between two <b>tree branches.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> the case of sitting <b>above them</b> is <b>similar to</b> that of sitting <b>between them</b> in the following manner: <b>Just as</b> the case of sitting <b>between them</b> is one <b>where she is touching them, so too,</b> the case of sitting <b>above them</b> is one <b>where she is touching them.</b> Accordingly, one is obligated only if the bird is touching the nest from above; <b>but</b> if it is sitting between two <b>tree branches</b> without touching the eggs or the fledglings, one is <b>exempt</b> from sending it away. The Gemara objects: <b>If that is so, rather than teaching</b> in <b>the last clause:</b> If it <b>was hovering, even</b> if <b>its wings are touching the nest,</b> one is <b>exempt</b> from sending it away,

Daf 141a

<b>let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach</b> that one is exempt in a case where the bird is sitting between two <b>tree branches,</b> which resembles a case where the bird is resting upon the nest itself in that the bird is sitting in both cases, <b>and</b> it would be clear <b>all the more so</b> that one is exempt if the mother <b>is hovering.</b> The Gemara responds: It <b>was necessary</b> for the <i>baraita</i> to teach the case of <b>a hovering</b> bird in order to teach <b>that even</b> if <b>its wings are touching the nest,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother bird. Had the <i>baraita</i> taught the exemption in a case of a bird resting between two tree branches, one might have thought that this is because the bird’s wings are not touching the nest.
The Gemara now questions the <i>baraita</i> itself: How can the <i>baraita</i> state that even if the hovering bird’s wings are touching the nest, one is exempt from sending the bird? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>When its wings are touching the nest,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> away the mother? <b>Rav Yehuda said: When</b> the case of the hovering mother bird <b>is taught</b> in <b>the <i>baraita</i>,</b> it is referring <b>to</b> a bird <b>touching</b> the nest <b>from the side.</b> In such a case, one is exempt because its wings are not touching the nest from above. By contrast, the mishna is referring to a case where the bird is hovering directly above the nest and touching the nest with its wings from above.
§ The mishna teaches: Even if <b>there is</b> only one <b>fledgling</b> or one egg, one is obligated to send away the mother, as it is stated: “If a bird’s nest happens before you” (Deuteronomy 22:6), indicating that one is obligated to send the mother bird away from the nest in any case. Additionally, if there were fledglings capable of flying or unfertilized eggs, one is exempt from sending away the mother bird, as it is stated in the same verse: “And the mother is resting upon the fledglings or upon the eggs.” From the juxtaposition of the fledglings and the eggs, one derives that the eggs or fledglings must be capable of living and they must require their mothers. With regard to this, <b>one of the Sages said to Rava: Say the opposite,</b> that if <b>there is only one fledgling or one egg,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother, <b>since we require</b> that the mother be “resting upon the <b>fledglings or</b> upon the <b>eggs,” and</b> this condition is <b>not</b> fulfilled with fewer than two.
Additionally, if <b>there were fledglings</b> capable of <b>flying or unfertilized eggs</b> in the nest, say that one is <b>obligated to send</b> the mother bird away, <b>as it is stated</b> in that verse: <b>“Nest,”</b> indicating that one is obligated to send the mother bird away from the <b>nest in any case.</b> Rava responds: <b>If so, let the verse write: And the mother is resting upon them.</b> For <b>what</b> reason does the verse state: <b>“And the mother is resting upon the fledglings or upon the eggs”?</b> It is <b>to compare the fledglings to the eggs and the eggs to the fledglings,</b> i.e., to indicate that the eggs or fledglings must be capable of living and must require their mothers. Fledglings that can fly and unfertilized eggs are therefore not included in the mitzva. Consequently, the word “nest” serves to indicate that one is obligated to send away the mother bird even if there is only one egg or fledgling in the nest.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one sent</b> away the mother bird <b>and it returned</b> to rest on the eggs, <b>even</b> if it returned <b>four or five times,</b> one is <b>obligated</b> to send it away again, <b>as it is stated: “You shall send [<i>shalle’aḥ teshallaḥ</i>] the mother”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:7). The doubled verb indicates that one must send away the mother bird multiple times if needed. If one <b>said: I am hereby taking the mother and sending</b> away <b>the offspring,</b> he is still <b>obligated</b> to send away the mother even if he sent away the offspring, <b>as it is stated: “You shall send the mother.”</b> If one sent away the mother and <b>took the offspring and</b> then <b>returned them</b> to the mother’s nest, <b>and thereafter the mother returned</b> and rested <b>upon them,</b> one is <b>exempt from sending</b> away the mother bird.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if the mother bird returned to rest on the eggs, even if it returned four or five times, one is obligated to send it away again, as it is stated: “You shall send [<i>shalle’aḥ teshallaḥ</i>].” With regard to this, <b>one of the Sages said to Rava: But say</b> instead that the word <b>“<i>shalle’aḥ</i>”</b> indicates that one must send away the mother <b>once,</b> and the word <b>“<i>teshallaḥ</i>”</b> indicates that one must do so <b>twice,</b> and beyond that there is no obligation.
Rava <b>said to him:</b> Actually, the <i>halakha</i> that one must send away the mother multiple times is not derived from the phrase “<i>shalle’aḥ teshallaḥ</i>.” Rather, the word <b>“<i>shalle’aḥ</i>”</b> indicates that one must send away the mother bird <b>even one hundred times,</b> and the word <b>“<i>teshallaḥ</i>”</b> teaches another matter: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> the obligation to send away the mother bird in a case where one takes the eggs or the fledglings and wants to take the mother bird <b>for a discretionary purpose,</b> e.g., to eat it. In a case where one takes the eggs or the fledglings and needs the mother bird <b>for a matter</b> involving <b>a mitzva,</b> e.g., the purification of a leper, <b>from where</b> is the <i>halakha</i> that he must send away the mother derived? <b>The verse states: “<i>Teshallaḥ</i>,”</b> to teach that <b>in any case</b> one must send away the mother bird.
<b>Rabbi Abba, son of Rav Yosef bar Rava, said to Rav Kahana: But</b> according to this explanation, the only <b>reason</b> that one must send away the mother bird even when needed for a matter involving a mitzva is <b>that the Merciful One wrote: “<i>Teshallaḥ</i>”; but</b> if <b>not</b> for <b>this, I would say</b> that when the mother is needed <b>for a matter</b> involving <b>a mitzva,</b> one is <b>not</b> obligated to send her away. But this is difficult, as the sending of the mother bird <b>is</b> both <b>a positive mitzva and a prohibition,</b> as the verse states: “You shall not take the mother with the young; you shall send the mother” (Deuteronomy 22:6–7), <b>and</b> there is a principle that <b>a positive mitzva cannot override</b> both <b>a prohibition and a positive mitzva.</b>
Rav Kahana replied: <b>No,</b> the word “<i>teshallaḥ</i>” is <b>necessary</b> for a case <b>where one transgressed and took the mother</b> with the fledglings. In such a case, <b>he has</b> already <b>transgressed the prohibition,</b> and <b>there is</b> now only <b>a positive mitzva</b> to send away the mother. Perhaps one might say: <b>Let the positive mitzva</b> performed with the mother, e.g., the purification of the leper, <b>come and override the positive mitzva</b> of sending away the mother. Therefore, the word “<i>teshallaḥ</i>” <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so, and one is obligated to send away the mother.
The Gemara notes: <b>This works out well according to the one who teaches</b> that the criterion for determining whether one is flogged for violating a prohibition that entails fulfillment of a positive mitzva is whether he <b>fulfilled</b> the mitzva immediately afterward <b>or did not fulfill it.</b> If he does not fulfill the mitzva immediately, he is flogged when he fails to do so. Consequently, if one does not send away the mother bird immediately after taking her with the fledglings, he has immediately violated the prohibition, and only the requirement to fulfill the positive mitzva remains.
The Gemara continues: <b>But according to the one who teaches</b> that the criterion for determining whether one is flogged in that case is whether he <b>negated</b> the possibility of fulfilling the positive mitzva <b>or did not negate it,</b> and one is flogged only if he performed an action that renders it impossible to fulfill the mitzva, this explanation does not work out well. After all, <b>as long as one has not slaughtered</b> the mother bird, he <b>has not transgressed the prohibition,</b> since he may still send her away. Consequently, even if one takes the mother, as long as he has not slaughtered her, the prohibition remains in addition to the positive mitzva. If so, there is no need for the Torah to teach that the obligation to send away the mother bird applies in the case of a mitzva.
<b>And furthermore,</b> one may ask: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said</b> that the word <b>“<i>shalle’aḥ</i>” indicates</b> that the mitzva to send away the mother bird applies only <b>at the outset,</b> i.e., before taking the fledglings, one who takes the mother together with the fledglings violates both the prohibition and the positive mitzva associated with it, such that <b>even a positive mitzva does not</b> remain.
<b>Rather, Mar bar Rav Ashi said:</b> The word “<i>teshallaḥ</i>” is necessary to indicate that the mitzva to send away the mother bird applies in a case <b>where one took her in order to send</b> her away immediately. In such a case, <b>there is no prohibition,</b> as one intends to send her away, but <b>there is</b> still <b>a positive</b> mitzva to send her away. <b>And</b> therefore, one might have said: <b>Let</b> another <b>positive mitzva,</b> e.g., taking the mother for the purification of a leper, <b>come and override the positive mitzva</b> of sending the mother. Therefore, the word “<i>teshallaḥ</i>” indicates that the mitzva of sending the mother bird applies even in such a case.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the strength of that</b> other <b>positive mitzva over this positive mitzva</b> of sending away the mother bird? Why might the former override the latter? The Gemara responds: It might <b>enter your mind</b> to say that <b>since the Master said: Great</b> is <b>peace between a man and his wife, as the Torah said</b> that <b>the name of the Holy One, Blessed be He, which is written in sanctity, shall be erased on the waters</b> as part of the ritual of a woman suspected by her husband of adultery (see Numbers 5:23) in order to clear her from suspicion and restore peace between her and her husband, therefore, perhaps the <i>halakha</i> should be more lenient with regard to the leper.
The Gemara explains: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>this leper, since as long as he is not purified he is prohibited from</b> engaging in <b>marital relations, as it is written: “But he shall dwell outside his tent seven days”</b> (Leviticus 14:8), and when the verse states: <b>“His tent,” this</b> is referring to <b>his wife,</b> such that one may derive <b>from here that</b> a leper <b>is prohibited from</b> engaging in <b>marital relations,</b> perhaps his purification ceremony should take precedence. This is because <b>perhaps you</b> will <b>say: Since he is prohibited from</b> engaging in <b>marital relations, let his positive mitzva</b> of purification <b>come and override the positive mitzva of the sending</b> away <b>of</b> the mother bird from <b>the nest.</b> Therefore, the word “<i>teshallaḥ</i>” <b>teaches us</b> that even so, one may not take the mother bird.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who takes the mother</b> bird <b>with</b> its <b>fledglings, Rabbi Yehuda says: He is flogged</b> for taking the mother bird, <b>and</b> he <b>does not send</b> away the mother. <b>And the Rabbis say: He sends</b> away the mother <b>and is not flogged,</b> as <b>this is the principle:</b> With regard to <b>any prohibition that entails</b> a command to <b>arise</b> and <b>perform</b> a mitzva, <b>one is not flogged for its</b> violation.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that according to Rabbi Yehuda, one who takes the mother with the offspring is flogged. With regard to this, <b>Rabbi Abba bar Memel raises a dilemma:</b> Is <b>the reasoning</b> for the ruling <b>of Rabbi Yehuda that he holds</b> that <b>one is flogged for</b> violation of <b>a prohibition that entails</b> fulfillment <b>of a positive mitzva?</b> Accordingly, one is flogged for transgressing the prohibition: “You shall not take the mother with the young,” which entails the fulfillment of: “You shall send the mother.”
The second possibility is now presented: <b>Or perhaps in general</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>holds</b> that <b>one is not flogged for</b> violation of <b>a prohibition that entails</b> fulfillment <b>of a positive mitzva; and here, this is the reason</b> one is flogged for taking the mother: It is <b>because he holds</b> that when the verse states: “You shall send the mother [<i>shalle’aḥ teshallaḥ</i>]” (Deuteronomy 22:7), the word <b>“<i>shalle’aḥ</i>” indicates</b> that the mitzva to sending the mother bird applies only <b>at the outset,</b> i.e., when encountering the nest. Accordingly, this is not a case of a prohibition that entails the performance of a positive mitzva, but an independent prohibition, for which one is liable to receive lashes.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to the dilemma from that which is taught: <b>A thief and a robber are included among</b> those who are liable to receive <b>lashes</b> by Torah law. A thief violates the prohibition of: “You shall not steal” (Leviticus 19:11), and a robber violates the prohibition of: “You shall not rob” (Leviticus 19:13); this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The Gemara continues: <b>But here,</b> the prohibition against robbing <b>is a prohibition that entails</b> fulfillment <b>of a positive mitzva, as the Merciful One states: “You shall not rob”</b> (Leviticus 19:13), and: <b>“And he shall restore the robbed item”</b> (Leviticus 5:23). And nevertheless, Rabbi Yehuda deems one liable to receive lashes for transgressing the prohibition against robbing. Therefore, <b>conclude from it</b> that <b>the reasoning</b> of the ruling <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> in the mishna is <b>that he holds</b> that <b>one is flogged for</b> violation of <b>a prohibition that entails</b> fulfillment <b>of a positive mitzva.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to him: Didn’t I</b> already <b>tell you</b> that <b>any <i>baraita</i> that is not taught</b> in the study <b>hall</b>

Daf 141b

of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya or</b> the study <b>hall</b> of <b>Rabbi Oshaya,</b> who were precise in the formulation of their <i>baraitot</i>, <b>is corrupted, and you may not raise objections</b> based <b>upon it</b> in <b>the study hall?</b> Since this <i>baraita</i> was not taught in either of the aforementioned study halls, you may not cite it as proof. After all, <b>perhaps</b> the phrase: <b>Are not included among</b> those who are liable to receive <b>forty lashes</b> by Torah law, <b>was taught</b> by Rabbi Yehuda in the <i>baraita</i>, but the text was corrupted. It is therefore possible that according to Rabbi Yehuda, one is not flogged for violation of a prohibition that entails fulfillment of a positive mitzva, and his reasoning of his ruling in the mishna is that the word “<i>shalle’aḥ</i>” indicates that the mitzva to send away the mother bird applies only at the outset.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from that <b>which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> by <b>Rabbi Oshaya and Rabbi Ḥiyya:</b> It is written with regard to forgotten sheaves left for the poor: “When you reap your harvest in your field and forget a sheaf in the field, <b>you shall not return</b> to fetch it” (Deuteronomy 24:19). If one transgressed this prohibition <b>and</b> one <b>returned</b> to fetch it, he is liable to receive lashes. Likewise, it is written with regard to produce in the corner of the field [<i>pe’a</i>], which is given to the poor: “And when you reap the harvest of your land, <b>you shall not wholly reap</b> the corner of your field” (Leviticus 19:9). If one transgressed this prohibition <b>and reaped</b> the corner of his field, such individuals <b>are included among</b> those who are liable to receive <b>lashes</b> by Torah law. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
The Gemara concludes the resolution: Since the mitzvot of leaving <i>pe’a</i> and forgotten sheaves are prohibitions that entail fulfillment of a positive mitzva, as the verse states with regard to both of them: “For the poor and for the stranger you shall leave them” (Leviticus 19:10), <b>conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that <b>the reasoning</b> of the ruling <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> in the mishna is <b>that he holds</b> that <b>one is flogged for</b> violation of <b>a prohibition that entails</b> fulfillment <b>of a positive mitzva.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps there,</b> with regard to <i>pe’a</i> and forgotten sheaves, <b>this is</b> the <b>reason</b> that Rabbi Yehuda deems one liable to receive lashes: <b>Because he holds</b> that the positive mitzva: “For the poor and for the stranger <b>you shall leave</b> them,” <b>indicates</b> that these mitzvot apply only <b>at the outset.</b> Accordingly, these are not cases of prohibitions that entail fulfillment of a positive mitzva, but of independent prohibitions. Similarly, it is possible that the reasoning of the ruling of Rabbi Yehuda in the mishna is that the mitzva of the sending away of the mother bird applies only at the outset.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from that which is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the Paschal offering: <b>“You shall let nothing of it remain until the morning;</b> but that which remains of it until the morning <b>you shall burn in fire”</b> (Exodus 12:10). <b>The verse comes to position the positive mitzva</b> of burning the leftover meat <b>after</b> the <b>prohibition</b> against leaving over the meat, in order <b>to say that one is not flogged for its</b> violation; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
Ravina continued: <b>Conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that according to Rabbi Yehuda, one is not flogged for violation of a prohibition that entails fulfillment of a positive mitzva, and that <b>the reasoning</b> of the ruling <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> in the mishna is <b>that he holds</b> that the word <b>“<i>shalle’aḥ</i>” indicates</b> that the mitzva to send away the mother applies only <b>at the outset.</b> Consequently, the prohibition against taking the mother with the offspring is not one that entails fulfillment of a positive mitzva, but an independent prohibition that is punishable by lashes. The Gemara concedes: <b>Conclude from</b> it that this is the reasoning of Rabbi Yehuda.
<b>Rav Idi said to Rav Ashi:</b> The language of <b>the mishna is also precise, as it teaches:</b> With regard to <b>one who takes the mother with the offspring, Rabbi Yehuda says: He is flogged and there is no</b> longer a mitzva to <b>send</b> away the mother. <b>But if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> to say that <b>the reasoning</b> of the ruling <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> in the mishna is that <b>one is flogged for</b> violation of <b>a prohibition that entails</b> fulfillment <b>of a positive mitzva,</b> then Rabbi Yehuda <b>should have</b> said: <b>He is flogged and sends</b> away the mother. Rather, conclude that according to Rabbi Yehuda, this is not a prohibition that entails fulfillment of a positive mitzva.
The Gemara rejects this: One cannot infer anything from the language of the mishna, since <b>perhaps this</b> is what Rabbi Yehuda <b>is saying in the mishna:</b> There is still a mitzva to send away the mother, but <b>one is not absolved</b> of guilt for transgressing the prohibition against taking the mother <b>until</b> the court <b>flogs him.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that according to the Rabbis, if one transgressed the mitzva and took the mother bird with the young, one must send away the mother. The Gemara asks: <b>How far</b> from the nest must he <b>send her? Rav Yehuda says:</b> Far <b>enough that she leaves his grasp</b> and can no longer be caught immediately. The Gemara asks: <b>In what</b> manner <b>does</b> he <b>send her</b> away?<b>Rav Huna says:</b> He holds the mother <b>by her feet</b> and sends her away. <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> He holds her <b>by her wings [<i>baagappeha</i>]</b> and sends her away. The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rav Huna says</b> that one holds the mother <b>by her feet, as it is written: “That send forth freely the feet of the ox and the donkey”</b> (Isaiah 32:20), indicating that the sending of an animal is associated with its feet. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that one holds her <b>by her wings, because</b> the feet of the mother bird <b>are her wings,</b> as it is by means of her wings that she moves about.
§ The Gemara relates: <b>A certain</b> person <b>clipped</b> a mother bird’s <b>wing and sent it</b> away <b>and thereafter caught it. Rav Yehuda flogged him</b> for transgressing the prohibition: “You shall not take the mother with the young” (Deuteronomy 22:6). Rav Yehuda also <b>said to him: Go</b> and let <b>its wings grow</b> back <b>and</b> then <b>send it</b> away.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Rav Yehuda act in this case? <b>If</b> he acted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> then there was no need to send away the mother, because according to Rabbi Yehuda, <b>he is flogged</b> for taking the mother bird, <b>and</b> he <b>does not send</b> away the mother. <b>If</b> he acted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> then he should not have flogged this individual, since according to the Rabbis, <b>he sends</b> away the mother <b>and is not flogged.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> he acted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and</b> the lashes administered by Rav Yehuda were not for transgressing a Torah prohibition; rather, they were <b>rabbinic lashes for rebelliousness [<i>makkat mardut</i>],</b> as this individual acted inappropriately.
The Gemara relates that <b>a certain</b> man <b>came before Rava</b> and <b>said to him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a certain kosher bird known as the <b><i>teima</i>?</b> Is it included in the mitzva of sending away the mother bird from the nest? Rava <b>said: Doesn’t this man know that</b> with regard to any <b>kosher bird one is obligated to send</b> away the mother? The man responded: Nevertheless, I am uncertain with regard to the <i>halakha</i>. Rava <b>said to him: Perhaps</b> you are uncertain about a case where <b>a single egg is placed</b> in the nest, since the Torah states: “Upon the fledglings or upon the eggs” (Deuteronomy 22:6). The man replied in the affirmative. Rava <b>said to him: That</b> too should be <b>known to you,</b> as <b>it is</b> stated in <b>the mishna</b> (140b): Even if <b>there is only one fledgling or one egg,</b> one is <b>obligated to send</b> away the mother.
The man <b>sent</b> away the bird, <b>and Rava</b> then <b>surrounded her with nets [<i>perastekei</i>] and caught her.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But shouldn’t</b> Rava <b>be concerned about</b> arousing <b>suspicion</b> that he required the sending away of the bird only so that he might catch it for himself? The Gemara responds: The nets were positioned far from the nest <b>in an unusual manner</b> that did not arouse suspicion.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Pigeons of a dovecote and pigeons of an attic are subject to the obligation of sending</b> away the motherbird,because they are ownerless and therefore not considered readily available. <b>But</b> nevertheless, <b>they are subject to the prohibition of robbery due</b> to a rabbinic ordinance to maintain <b>the ways of peace.</b>
The Gemara objects: <b>But if it is so that this</b> ruling is correct <b>that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, says,</b> i.e., that <b>a person’s courtyard effects acquisition for him</b> of an item placed in it even <b>without his knowledge,</b> then a dovecote or attic will effect acquisition for its owner of any eggs inside them. Accordingly, one should <b>apply here</b> the principle that the mitzva to send away the mother bird from the nest applies only in the case described in the verse: <b>“If</b> a bird’s nest <b>happens</b> before you” (Deuteronomy 22:6), which <b>excludes</b> from the mitzva a bird or egg readily <b>available</b> in one’s home. Yet the <i>baraita</i> rules that the mitzva does apply in this case.
<b>Rav says:</b> It is <b>from</b> the time of the <b>emergence of the majority of an egg</b> from a mother bird’s body <b>that</b> one <b>becomes obligated to send</b> away the mother from the nest. On the other hand, the owner of a courtyard <b>does not acquire</b> the egg <b>until it</b> fully emerges and <b>falls into his courtyard. And</b> therefore, <b>when</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that in the case of the pigeons in a dovecote or an attic, they are <b>subject to the obligation of sending</b> away the mother bird, it is referring to a time <b>before</b> the egg <b>falls into his courtyard.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where the egg has not fully emerged, <b>why</b> does the <i>baraita</i> rule that the eggs <b>are forbidden</b> by rabbinic law for others to take <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b>robbery?</b> The eggs have not yet been acquired by the owner of the courtyard. The Gemara answers: That ruling of the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to their mother,</b> i.e., the mother bird. <b>Or, if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Actually,</b> that ruling is referring <b>to the egg. And</b> the reason the Sages rendered it prohibited to take the eggs due to the prohibition of robbery is that <b>once the majority of an egg emerges</b> from the body of the mother bird, the owner’s <b>mind is upon</b> the eggs to acquire them, although technically he will not acquire them until they fully emerge.
The Gemara adds: <b>And now that Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: It is prohibited to acquire eggs whose mother is resting upon them, as it is stated:</b> “You shall <b>send the mother,” and</b> only <b>then: “The young you may take for yourself”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:7), <b>you</b> may <b>even say: Even though</b> the eggs fully emerged and <b>fell into his courtyard,</b> he must still send away the mother bird. This is because in <b>any case in which</b> a courtyard owner <b>is capable of acquiring</b> an item by himself, <b>his courtyard can also effect acquisition</b> of it for him. <b>But</b> in <b>any case</b> in which <b>he is incapable of acquiring</b> an item by himself, <b>his courtyard cannot effect acquisition</b> of it <b>for him either.</b> Since one is incapable of acquiring the eggs so long as the mother bird is resting upon them, one’s property does not acquire the eggs for him even if they have already fallen into it.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where the courtyard cannot effect acquisition of the eggs for him, <b>why</b> does the <i>baraita</i> rule: <b>They are subject to the prohibition</b> only <b>due to</b> the rabbinic ordinance to maintain <b>the ways of peace? If</b> one <b>sent</b> away the mother bird before taking the eggs, then <b>it is full-fledged robbery</b> by Torah law, since the courtyard has effected acquisition of the eggs on behalf of its owner, and <b>if</b> one <b>did not send</b> away the mother bird, <b>he needs to send</b> her away before it is permitted to take the eggs. Either way, one will have transgressed Torah law and not a rabbinic prohibition.
The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a case where <b>a minor</b> took the eggs without sending away the mother. A minor is not obligated in the mitzva of sending away the mother bird. The Gemara asks: <b>Is a minor subject to</b> a rabbinic ordinance concerning robbery enacted to maintain <b>the ways of peace?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>This</b> is what the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: The father of a minor</b> who took such eggs <b>is obligated to return</b> them <b>to</b> the owner of the dovecote or attic, <b>due to</b> the rabbinic prohibition concerning robbery instituted to maintain <b>the ways of peace.</b>
§ The Gemara relates an additional incident with regard to pigeons of a dovecote that were discussed above: <b>Levi bar Simon transferred ownership of the produce of his dovecote,</b> i.e., the fledglings and the eggs contained in it, <b>to Rav Yehuda.</b> Rav Yehuda <b>came before Shmuel</b> and told him of his acquisition. Shmuel <b>said to him: Go, bang on the nest,</b> i.e., the dovecote, so <b>that</b> the fledglings <b>will rise up and you will acquire them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> purpose did Shmuel tell Rav Yehuda to do this? <b>If</b> he meant for Rav Yehuda <b>to</b> finalize the <b>acquisition</b> so that Levi bar Simon could not retract, <b>let</b> him do so <b>through</b> acquisition by means of <b>a cloth.</b> There is no need for him to bang on the dovecote. <b>If</b> this incident occurred on the eve of a Festival, and Rav Yehuda came to ask what action to take in order to render the birds permitted for slaughter on the <b>Festival,</b> then banging on the dovecote should not be necessary,

Daf 142a
